Author: Macintyre, Ben
Title: War awakes the eloquent anger of the ignored
Full_text:
War awakes the eloquent anger of the ignored
Ben Macintyre
v 7-"'" yy.T9'''u'jyj - T: T'n. J-}'7'*>;'/ ' J v> 7',7 7" ,'* ''-i7>V
THE NOT DEAD by Simon Armitage THE FIRST WORLD WAR marked the bloody heyday of war poetry. The combination of a highly literate fighting force and long periods of enforced inactivity and conditions of extreme horror produced poetry of a quality and quantity that will never (perhaps mercifully) be equalled. Will another Wilfred,Owen or Siegfried Sassoon emerge from the wars in Afghanistan or Iraq? I doubt it. The blog, and not the poem, is the preferred word-weapon of today's soldier. Yet contemporary war poetry is being written, albeit seldom by those at the front. The wars in which we are mired have each lasted longer than the First World War, and war has been woven grimly into the national consciousness. "It could be argued," writes Simon Armitage, that "the permanent backdrop of our current military situation makes almost every poem a war poem". The Not Dead is Armitage's brilliant and painful evocation of the pity of modern warfare, less concerned with the blood and bullets ofthe bat-
tlefield than the carnage left behind in soldiers' minds. The "Not Dead" are the surviving soldiers, broken in mind and body, uncelebrated, invisible and ignored. Armitage's anger is reminiscent of Tommy, Rudyard Kipling's poem condemning the casual civilian disdain for the humble squaddie: We are morbidly ill. Soldiers with nothing but time to kill, we idle now in everyday clothes and ordinary towns, blowing up, breaking down. The poems in this collection were written for the film ofthe same name, a collaboration with the director Brian Hill exploring the lives of returning soldiers, that was broadcast last year on Remembrance Sunday. Each poem in this collection is a vivid little biography: the UN "blue lid" in Bosnia, haunted by the killers he waved through his checkpoint on their way to murder; the veteran of the Malayan Emergency taken from an oily Manchester canal to a burning river in the jungle; the Iraq war infantryman who must patrol, every day, over the "blood-shadow" left by the corpse of the looter he shot. These are poems about what happens when the heat of battle gives way to the brutal chill of a Home Front, where the home fires do not burn. Pomona, £6.99; 80pp m £6.64 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Lupton, Hugh
Title: Darkness and light in poems of madness
Full_text:
Darkness and ht in poems of madness
Poetry Hugh Lupton
*&/,.,£$& Dear Alice
DEAR ALICE Narratives of Madness by Tom Pow THERE WAS A SHIFT in the understanding of lunacy in the early 1800s. The Enlightenment had turned its back on old superstitious notions that madness was somehow connected to ignorance and sin; the madness of George III made the admission of insanity more socially acceptable and popularised the idea that it was an illness that could be treated. And the Dissenters, particularly Quakers, had begun to promote a new, humane system of dealing with insanity. What they called "Moral Treatment" encouraged good diet, exercise, and work in ordered farms and gardens. Samuel Tuke (a pioneer of this style of treatment) wrote that in cases of madness the "intellectual, active and moral powers are usually rather perverted than obliterated". In the first half of the 19th century there was a huge growth in private and public hospitals for the insane. The old regime of barred cells and "strait-waistcoats" began to give way to more kindly systems. Madhouses became asylums, madmen became patients. We can glimpse this new regime in
accounts of John Clare during his 23-year stay in the Northamptonshire General Lunatic Asylum. The newspaper editor Spencer Hall visited him as he worked in the asylum gardens, "rather burly, florid, with light hair and somewhat shaggy eyebrows, and dressed as a plain but respectable farmer, in drab or stone-coloured coat and smalls, with gaiters,... and altogether as clean and brushed up as for market or fair". Clare was convinced that he was being kept there to be "fed up for a fight" (he had delusions that he was a famous prize fighter). When Hall suggested that his reputation as a poet outshone his reputation as a fighter, Clare replied: "Oh poetry, ah, I know, I once had something to do with poetry, a long time ago: but it was no good. I wish, though, they could get a man with courage enough to fight me." These tensions between asylum containment and open fields, between delusion and reason, run through Tom Pow's extraordinary new book of poems, Dear Alice: Narratives of Madness. The collection circles around the Crichton Asylum in Dumfries — now part of Glasgow University. Founded in the 1830s, the asylum was initially part of the same humane impulse as Samuel Tuke's "Moral Treatment". Its 150-year existence charted a shifting and evolving understanding of mental illness and the permeability of identity. This social history is at the root of the book. But madness remains a mystery. And the profound pain and distress of the afflicted makes a harrowing counterpoint to the therapeutic systems that have attempted to cure (or at least constrain) them. In Nightwatch, 1842 the poet treads the asylum corridors as a nurse and notes down the "frac-
\X
Mental patient in straitjacket circa 1818 tured plots" of the lunatic narratives that are cried out in the darkness: ... I give due ballast to the most frivolous claims — become master of reason when I've need to flatter the restless and noisy: "What spikes your night are pictures", I tell them. One's convinced That shadows cut her like knives ... In Questions of Judgement we see the inmates working the fields of the Crichton Home Farm Steading: ... They are judged by simple needs: a plenitude of food, fresh air and exercise. Each evening heading home, the huge clock-face confronts them like a new moon binding them to the slow seasons of growth ... Two poems in the collection feature Charcot and Freud, and there is a sequence that addresses the collective madness of the First World War (when Crichton was a place of convalescence). But it is when Tom Pow speaks of the patients themselves,
their case histories, their torments and consolations, that the book finds its heart. We read of M, who, during her menstruation tried to rescue a hen from a pond, and was mad for the rest of her life. We meet Angus McKay, piper to Queen Victoria, who lost his mind "over study of music". And in Grass we meet Angus McPhee, who in the 1970s and 1980s was weaving grass into clothes at Crichton "for the weaver's own joy and to praise/ The industry of hands". In Resistances Pow ends with a coda that speaks for all the inmates as they address the note-takers who have recorded them: the things I could tell you but again you would sift them through the grid of your understanding and then you would not be speaking for me which is all I ask this clouded evening that somewhere in the silence there is someone who speaks with indifference in a small voice for me The final poem of the cycle is addressed to "The Great Asylums of Scotland". In it Pow sets the noble impulses that built them against the suffering the buildings have contained, and their present dereliction: In attic rooms the sky's light pours over a tide-wrack of maps, plans, records — a grid to lay over a waste of rage, grief, anger and pain. None of that will make a cairn ... The grid, Tom Pow implies, is ofour making: the grid of reason and rationality. The old asylums are empty now. That grandiose 19th-century impulse has been left behind. And what of their inmates? ... though of the mad, little could be salvaged — not one knitted pullover, not one apron — ... The melancholy we mourn they transformed into bread, milk, sunlight. John Clare, bent over his spade in the Northampton asylum, would nod his amen to that. Hugh Lupton and Chris Wood perform On Common Ground (stories and songs about John Clare and the Enclosures) at the Canterbury Festival on October 20 (01227 378188; canterburyfestival.co.uk). Salt, £12.99; 96pp Q £11.69 (freep&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Feinstein, Elaine
Title: Stories with the force of myth
Full_text:
Poetry Elaine Peinstein
Stories with the force of myth
.iWtV *
SELECTED POEMS by Eilean Ni Chuilleanain SEA LEVEL by Angela Leighton AMONG THE MOST distinguished Irish poes other generation, Eilean Ni Chuilleanain's clean, uncluttered lines sing out from the page. Their simplicity is altogether deceptive, however; her propositions are enigmatic, and from her earliest poems we are invited into a fairytale world of ransoms and mysterious tasks: Ants have helped me To sort the millet and barley grains. I have washed bloodstains from the enchanted shirt. There is an unease beneath every moonlit silence. In one bf the sections taken from The Rose Geranium, the central figure opens an egg given to her by a wise woman and finds inside "some of her own hair, a tooth still bloody from her own mouth"; an inexplicable, chilling discovery. Sometimes there is a story behind a poem that the reader is able to piece together, In MacMoransbridge, for instance, sisters of a dead man remain so in awe of him that they dare not touch his desk, simply going on with their own tasks, "boiling up mutton shanks for broth" and so fail to discover his will. The strangest of these stories have the force of myth; for instance, the poem about a girl who falls in love with a reindeer. Her family are appalled by her departure into his frozen world. On a visit home, "They slipped a powder in her drink/ So she forgot her child, her friend." When the reindeer dies, he is seen to have the naked body of a man, and his curse destroys the old Queen. The poem resolves as the child
from the North — "His hair was bleached, his skin blistered" — comes to release his mother from the spell. Angela Leighton's Sea Level is the second book of a much younger poet who uses many different voices. Often her poems are language-led, and she relies on a glittering surface of unusual words; her play with sounds "a water-slipper, whippersnapper" suggesting an invention so rapid that she has to check it: "What is the quick of this quick sand?" She experiments with typography rather as Black Mountain poets once did, using 2 em spaces as a means of insisting on pauses. Consider the images from the natural world she finds for Kings College Chapel: It is strip-willow, pillars like wicks of rushes scored upright from the lodes and dug channels. It is flood plains in flower, trimming heaven, carex, calamus, windlestraw on the common. She writes impressive elegies for Miklos Radnoti and Michael Donaghy, but her most individual voice is as sinister as Plath conflating the murderous with the sexual. In her remarkable Cousin Butchers, Leighton observes the limbs that "... lie with such abandoned purpose here/ Landscaped in trays, like sudden/ Rare colourists of what lies hidden in us". She is clearly an original poet and may come to be an important one. Selected Poems Faber, £12.99; 128pp EJ £11.69 (free p&p) Sea Level Shoestring £8.95 ® £8.50 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst Eilean Ni Chuilleanain appears at Edinburgh International Book Festival on Saturday, August 9. (0845 3735888; www.edbookfest.co.uk)

Author: Verrico, Lisa
Title: Who cares what the lyrics say?
Full_text:
first night
Who cares what the lyrics say?
*•• timesonline.co.uk/arts
Latitude Festival Henham Park, Southwold ••••-fr Lisa Verrico
They didn't have a hope of starting a singalong, but Sigur Ros still pulled the largest crowd at Latitude. The Icelandic band, who sing either in lll§llil§ their native tongue or in an even stranger-sounding, made-up language, may have breached the British Top Ten for the first time in their 14-year career with their current album Med Sud i Eyrum Vid Spilum Endalaust, but as festival headliners they arrived on stage with scant experience. They did bring along a splendid collection of gigantic globe lanterns, which were suspended above them, and enough dry ice to turn a picturesque hillside in Suffolk into what looked like an eerie scene from an old movie. If that was the intention, the frontman Jonsi Birgisson played the flamboyant villain to perfection. Sporting silver, glittery stripes on his cheeks, with feathers protruding from the high collar of a black, buckled jacket with fringed sleeves, he sawed manically at his guitar with a bow and sang in a searing, spooky falsetto. Did it matter that no one knew the words? Not a jot. Backed by a sumptuous band that, from old number Glosoli onwards, included a female string section in Victorian dress and,
later, a brass band in white suits and matching bowler hats, Sigur Ros delivered a majestic set that was spellbinding from start to finish. Their elegant, pounding surge of othe-worldly sounds reached its peak on Hoppipolla, best known as the theme from the TV series Planet Earth, when fans could no longer resist the urge to join in and chanted ludicrous, fabricated lyrics. As
He sawed manically at his guitar with a bow and sang in a spooky falsetto
confetti rained down during the aptly titled, but still utterly incomprehensible Festival, Sigur Ros had achieved what few thought them capable of — enchanting an enormous crowd outdoors in the dark. Earlier, Elbow had been almost as bewitching, though only sporadically so in a set that was distinctly down-tempo. Each member arrived armed with a brass instrument, adding stabs to the opener Starlings, but too often the mournful majesty of songs from their current album, The Seldom Seen Kid, teetered towards morose. One exception was Grounds for Divorce, which sounded like Crosstown Traffic mixed with Sledgehammer-era Peter Gabriel, in
which the frontman Guy Garvey banged what looked like a piece of lead piping with a stick. Garvey lacked a little in the charisma department — he seemed like a lovely bloke, but wasn't convincing as a star. At least not until the closing number, One Day Like This, a string-drenched, orchestral epic that may well have been the weekend's highlight. If Garvey ever needs an ego, boost, he should
listen back to that track and the army of admirers who howled along. Less lucky were the acts who played in Latitude's tents. Or rather, their fans. The weather held out for most of the weekend, but there was one continual criticism: the tents were too small. Anyone wishing to see an act had to save a space early, and plenty were left disappointed. #

Author: May, Derwent
Title: Quest for a kind of paradise
Full_text:
Poetry Derwent May
Quest for a kind of paradise
.
filUtxt<dl'n4OTi
THE ANNOTATED COLLECTED POEMS OF EDWARD THOMAS edited by Edna Longley EDWARD THOMAS was a man who turned from a hack writer into a remarkable poet practically overnight. Born in 1878, he made a meagre living until 1914 by writing topographical and nature books, and endless book reviews. Then two things happened. He met the American poet Robert Frost, who urged him to write poetry, and the First World War broke out. Through these disparate events, something was liberated in him. He wrote his first poem in December 1914, and over the next two years, before he was killed by shrapnel at Arras, he wrote another 141. In them he
revealed himself as one of the most subtle and fascinating poets of the 20th century. Suddenly his relationship with nature appeared as something quite different from what one finds in his prose books. Those were mainly a straightforward celebration of the English countryside, both its wildlife and its ancient human traditions. In the poetry, another side of the man emerged. The love of nature was unmistakeably there. But the poems spoke of a longing, inspired by nature, for something beyond it. In Old Man, which was probably only his third poem, he beautifully describes a feathery herb growing at his cottage door called Old Man or Lad's Love. But he values only its bitter scent — and that only because it leaves him lying in wait for something he "should, yet never can remember..." In Sedge-Warblers he draws a brilliant portrait of these little birds "clinging so light to willow twigs" — but what he finds significant is that in their song they "reiterate endlessly"
'Poems of a longing inspired by nature' something that "no man learnt yet, in or out of school". His most famous poem, Adlestrop, is about a country railway station where his train stopped "unwontedly". He heard a blackbird singing, and then, around him, sang "mist-
ier/ Farther and farther, all the birds/ Of Oxfordshire and Gloucestershire". This is not just a celebration of singing blackbirds. It is a poem about a vision in his mind of some kind of fading, "mistier" paradise. He married when he was still at Oxford and only 21, while his wife Helen was just 20. One poem, in beautiful halting lines, begins "No one so much as you/ Loves this my clay... None ever was so fair/ As I thought you". But it goes on to say, very painfully, that he "could not ever burn/With the love you have". Even in love he knew a sad, strange detachment in himself. He enlisted in the Army in 1915, but was never really a war poet, though the war looms up in the background in many of his poems. How much he. cared for his family shows in a set of four exquisite poems he wrote in April 1316, imagining what he would like to give to his three daughters and to Helen. But the old note is struck for almost the last time in the poem to Helen. He
would, he says, like to "give you back yourself — and, he adds: "myself, too, if I could find/Where it lay hidden and it proved kind." Edna Longley has produced an excellent edition of Thomas's poetry, though it is rather a startling volume with its 108 pages for poems, and its 177 pages for notes. It is as though she has poured a lifetime's study into the notes, accumulating an immense quantity of fact and analysing the poems from every kind of critical angle: formal, biographical, historical, psycho-analytical and sociological. Nevertheless the notes are well worth wading into. She makes fascinating comparisons between Thomas's prose and poetic versions of similar subjects, and in all her spheres comes up with rewarding apercus. What she has not learnt from Thomas is his economy with words. Bloodaxe, £12; 352pp ® £10.80 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Batchelor, Paul
Title: Verse from three perspectives
Full_text:
Poetry Paul Batchelor
Verse from three perspectives
i Mick imlah
BLOODSHOT MONOCHROME by Patience Agbabi THE LOST LEADER by Mick Imlah SEA CHANGE by Jorie Graham READING THESE THREE collections, I was struck by how differently these poets define their responsibility to their readers. Patience Agbabi has the clearest idea of who her audience is. A renowned performer of her work, in Bloodshot Monochrome Agbabi uses poetic form to continue her performance on the page. Foreign Exchange is the best of the collection's many sonnets. It describes a racist encounter in Hamburg: ... reminding me of school, that French exchange, a simple sentence, Parce qu'elle est noire, delivered at such speed and with such hatred it stung me: to encounter so much rage; more, for being judged solely by colour; but most, the fact it had to be translated. Unfortunately, Agbabi does not always craft her cadences
and choose her rhymes so carefully. The sonnet sequence Vicious Circle tells the story of a film-noir love triangle. The story has plenty of intrigue and betrayal, but the sequence is marred by a relentless staccato rhythm, short sentences and repetitive syntax: the poems cry out for a performer to animate them. Problem Pages is more assured. In this sequence, Agbabi plays agony aunt to 14 dead poets, who are having problems with their sonnets. We hear from canonical names (Milton, Keats), all-butforgotten female poets (Lady Mary Wroth, Charlotte Smith) and key black poets (Claude* McKay, June Jordan). It's a risky way of both invoking influences and putting them in their place, and testament to Agbabi's verve and confidence that she pulls it off. To move from Agbabi to Mick Imlah's The Lost Leader is to feel the poetic line slowing and the texture thickening. You're going to have to work harder, but these subtle poems will repay return visits. The Lost Leader is a book of enormous ambition: 20 years in the making and twice as long as most slim volumes, it offers a poetic history of Scotland starting at the year dot ("before/ Colum and Camelot"). Along the way, we hear from some familiar and not-so-familiar Scottish heroes: Robert fhe Bruce and Michael Scot, Bonnie Prince Charlie and Gordon Brown (the rugby player, not the politician). The collection ends with a stunning, full-throated lyric that draws parallels between
LYNDON DOUGLAS
rejected art and the stars. The poet wonders if they dream away their loss of face in a sky like that; if there, though day's glare or the northern night obscure them, though nature has done with them, still through the void they hurtle their wattage, powered with the purpose of having been — being, after all, stars, whose measure we may not take, nor know the wealth of their rays. Douglas Dunn offers one precedent for the consummate formal achievement of these poems, but otherwise Imlah situates himself among much earlier literary models: Edwin Muir, Robert Browning and James Thomson. Indeed Im-
lah remains hard to place on a map of contemporary Scottish poetry. His playful-yet-elegiac formalism seems untouched by Don Paterson's satirical bite, or W. N. Herbert's surreal, knockabout humour. As a history of Scotland, The Lost Leader might be a late tackle; but as a display of poetic forms and resources, the collection is invaluable. Jorie Graham is the most private of these three poets. While she has a considerable following in the US, and a growing number of admirers on these islands, her poetry does not seek out connections with the reader. Instead, Graham explores connections between her perceptions and experiences. Sea Change is a series of meditations on political and environmental fears. Many poems
Patience Agbabi takes on the role of agony aunt to 14 dead poets
begin in anxious observation: "Deep autumn & the mistake occurs, the plum tree blossoms." Graham is adept at capturing such moments. She is a poet of transitions and transformations, rather than closely painted images. No Long Way Round begins: Evening. Not quite. High winds again. I have time, my time, as you also do, there, feel it. And a heart, my heart, as you do, remember it. Also am sure of some things, there are errands, this was a voyage ... To a greater extent than most poets would dare, Graham demands that poetry should answer to its moment. Fler work can be difficult, and does not always avoid portentousness: "there is a form of slavery in everything". Nevertheless, Graham's poetry is exhilarating because of its ability to open a space of cleareyed hope. This hope is usually located in artistic creation or, as here, the silence that precedes the creative moment: this will be a time again in which to make — a time of uselessness — the imagined human paradise. Bloodshot Monochrome Canongate, £8.99; 66pp m £8.54 (free p&p) The Lost Leader Faber, £9.99; 144pp m £9.49 (free p&p) Sea Change Carcanet, £9.95; 80pp E £9.45 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Vickers, Salley
Title: An eerie poetry
Full_text:
Novel
An eerie poetry
GLISTER by John Bumside A RESPECTED NOVELIST confided to me recently that: she had a "reservation about novels written by poets". Why? I wondered. Two of our greatest poets, Thomas Hardy and D. II. Lawrence, were also fine novelists and John Burnside's 12 collections of poetry and six novels put him in the Hardy and Lawrence class. Burnside deploys language with a poet's acuity, deftly registering shifts of consciousness and shades of description but never imposing "poetical" visions. Glister is set in Innertown, a bleak No Man's Place whose isolated community once serviced a chemical plant. The plant has spawned human fatalities and engendered the strange fauna and flora found on the eerie headland where the derelict buildings remain. Only Leonard, the novel's 15-year-old protagonist, with a father in the last stages of cancer, visits them now. His mother has scarpered, leaving her son to carry the can, which he does literally, dealing with his father's blood and vomit. Leonard is, understandably, discontented, but intellectually savvy and an avid reader. He devours Henry James and Proust; and he also consorts with Elspeth, who attracts his attention at the local library by offering him oral sex. There is a slight sense that this and subsequent sexual excursions are there to lend respectability to Henry James. This was a moment when I felt a rare touch of authorial pressure. However, this is a small cavil. The unfolding ofthe sinister story of the "lost boys" who have gone "missing" is done with skill. Perhaps a mite too predictably, the disappearances are accredited to a supposed paedophile, by a gang of youthful misfits to which Leonard, with qualms, attaches himself. The qualms are tempered by the allure of Eddie, whose passivity and violence strike a resonant violence from Leonard. Eddie rings utterly true; as does the itinerant, mild-mannered "moth man", the key to the novel's startling denouement where Burnside's twin talents fuse and darkly shine. SALLEY VICKERS Jonathan Cape, £15.99; 272pp m £14.39 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Monro, Alexander
Title: Two trees sprouting from a single root
Full_text:
Two trees sproutin from a single root
Alexander Monro on the Chinese-British Yellow Mountain poetry festival
FOR A FEW MOMENTS on a Cardiff afternoon this week the "tree" that forms the lynchpin of the Welsh Senned provided shelter for a polyglot parliament of the poets, formally launching the 2008 Yellow Mountain Festival. The object was for poets of the English and Chinese languages to conduct joint translations, all funded by the Arts Council and the businessman and poet Luo Ying, dubbed "China's richest poet". Founded two years ago by the Chinese poet Yang Lian, whose collections have appeared in several languages (and whose poetry appears in the Bloodaxe anthology In Person: see overleaf) and the English poet Fiona Sampson, the Editor of Poetry Review, this year's festival began at St Donat's Castle on the Glamorgan coast with four days of translation work in pairs. Translation of poetry is a knotty business, with the results tending more towards recreation than replication. But when the languages are Chinese and English, the challenge is greater still. Imagine translating from a language whose written words are fixed without letters, which has no agreements, only rarely indicates plurality or tense, disdains all but a few conjunctions and achieves much of its musicality through its four tones. "Poetry in translation means that you have two different trees that grow from the same root," Yang Lian explained. "At first we thought Chinese was more visual, whereas English, and especially Welsh, were more musical, but we found that the good poems provide all these layers." Yang emerged as a poet in 1980s China and was eventually criticised for "spiritual pollution". After 1989, he became an exile and has since lived in Auckland and London. "For Yang, everything is driven by the pictorial implications of the characters, as though he's uncovering hieroglyphs in ancient languages," his principal translator Brian Holton explains. Such culturally or linguistically defined images, metaphors and allusions risk spawning translations that are prolix, flat or plagued by footnotes. Instead, invention tends to win out. "It's not only meaning, or we could write novels," said Robert Minhinnick, the award-winning poet and editor of Poetry Wales. "You might change the structure or feeling. The key is images and sound — sensory things." The Chinese script has bequeathed its poets an extraordinary capacity for ambiguity, thanks to its pareddown grammar and lack of agree ments. Visual impact: Yang Lian, founder of the Yellow Mountain Festival publishing his poetry since the 1980s, alludes frequently to the history of Chinese literature. "Until 2002 he taught Western literature exclusively. Now he only teaches classical Chinese literature," Arthur Sze, an American poet and lecturer at the festival says. "It's almost as though he only learnt to use Western techniques for his own purposes." For China, modernity was a Western import, and with it came new literary influences, among them Ezra Pound, who imitated the bald but graceful expressiveness of classical Chinese poetry. "Translation has this ability to bring in different angles, whether on values, human life, even on a chair," says Yan Li, whose poetry has been translated into several languages. It is this engagement abroad that

marks the new paths that Chinese poets have struck out on over the past decade or two — it is also the concern of the festival, and of the anthology it will publish next year. As I leave St Donat's Castle, Yang is explaining to Sampson that the hanging clouds in his poem are like curtains on a stage but that, as they roll open, they also allow you to reveal your inner self. This is Yang at his conceptual best, always seeking out greater symbolisms, what he calls "that self sufficient universe of poetry" that Pound had striven fbr. Author: Macintyre, Ben
Title: Ben MacIntyre ' Bush's language might be mangled, but it has an accidental poetry'
Full_text:
Ben Macintyre fBushfs language might be mangled, but it has an accidental poetry1

WHEN GEORGE W. BUSH leaves office, the war will finally come to an end. For years the President has struggled, locked in mortal combat, determined to crush and destroy an enemy that his father confronted before him. At times, Bush seemed weighed down by the conflict, but he never gave up the fight. This war was personal. I refer, of course, to George W. Bush's single-handed and brutal battle with the English language. No leader of modern times (with the possible exception of John Prescott) has attacked the language with such sustained violence. No other politician can match Bush's ability to mangle syntax and sense into surreal shapes. quite simple sentences found themselves remoulded into Byzantine complexity in the from Bush's brain to his mouth. Malapropisms, neologisms, spoonerisms, mispronunciations and other verbal exotica out ofthe President in torrents. Rogue would suddenly wander into his senand refuse to leave. Verbs, prepositions, were locked in permanent conflict. Weisberg, editor of Slate magazine, becollecting these "Bushisms" at the start of Bush Administration, and has since pubno less than six volumes of the Presiverbal gaffes, selling more than half a copies and almost as many calendars. Covering Bush's campaign in 2000 was an exercise in approximate translation. I privileged to be present in Iowa when told an audience: "It's a world of madand uncertainty and potential mential losses." I still have no idea what he meant, the word has entered my family's lexicon: a "mential loss" is what happens whenever anyone says something particularly idiotic, or mislays the car keys. Bush's refashioning of the language might be incomprehensible, but it also had a sort of accidental, internal poetry. An enterprising schoolteacher, Dirk Schulze, welded together some of Bush's more famously peculiar phrases to create an entire poem:
Rarely is the question asked: "Is our children learning?" Will the Highways of the Internet become more few? How many hands have I shaked? Occasionally, Bush can get stuck in his own
circular grammar, producing a mellifluous if
meaningless rap: "When I was coming up, it was a dangerous world, and you knew exactly who they were. It was us versus them, and it was clear who them was. Today, we are not so sure who the they are, but we know they're there." This is reminiscent of Donald Rumsfeld, the acknowledged master of inadvertent existential poetry: As we know, There are known knowns. There are things we know we know. We also know There are known unknowns. Opinion has long been divided over whether Bush's inarticulacy is natural or partly feigned,
the mark of an honest Texan with no time for fancy talk, or evidence of mental (and possibly mential) confusion. Sometimes Bush's linguistic slips brought out a hidden truth. He once declared that racial quotas tended to "vulcanise society". He meant to say "Balkanise", of course, but the malapropism probably more nearly captured what he meant: vulcanisation (after Vulcan, the Roman God of fire) is the process whereby rubber is cured with sulphur or other chemicals to create an artificial substance that is harder, denser and insoluble. A society divided by race is truly vulcanised. Weisberg himself admits that "Bushisms give a misimpression of Bush; and the misimpression is they make him sound like he's dumb." Bush is careless of the way he speaks, he reaches for long words and then falls over them, but this is very far from a sign of stupidity. In Weisberg's words: "He has some particular kinds of intelligence that serve him very well. He has a strong interpersonal intelligence in that he reads people very quickly and very well." Many Americans came to relish his unique way with words. Bush became adept at mocking his own inarticulacy. One never knew where the language might take him, and nor did he. 1 rememberafter one particularly baffling extemporised speech, when Bush passed the press corps he simply grinned and asked: "Bumble though OK?" In part, Bush's language is inherited, for his father was prone to the same linguistic chaos. The former President startled a group of foreign tourists in 1992 by attempting to begin a conversation with the words "I ley, hey, nihaoma. Hey, yeah, yeah. Heil, heil-a kind of Hitler salute." Nihaoma is Mandarin for "How are you?" The rest is untranslatable. In the end, Bush's numerous assaults on the English language did no harm, which cannot be said of his other battles. At a rally in Oregon recently, President Bush declared: "1 hope you leave here and walk out and say: 'What did he say?'". Ofthe epitaphs on the Bush era, "What did he say?" will be among the kindest.

Author: Riley, Chris
Title: Don't Forget the Lyrics
Full_text:
DlgltalChoice Chris Riley
Dont Forget the Lyrics Sky One, 7pm
y,p Game show, hosted by Shane Richie and part of Sky One's shiny St/per Sunday package, putting pop knowledge to the test: fill in the missing lyrics to ten songs and contestants can win £250,000. Think karaoke meets Who Wants to Be a Millionaire? — despite all the warbling (game Paula, first up to the mic, isn't what you'd call an undiscovered talent), this shares most of its basic grammar with the Tarrant juggernaut. (There are even lifelines, known as "back-ups".) All of which may well explain why it's actually rather good fun, Richie's drunk-dad-at-a-wedding dancing aside. Best moment? Paula, pondering one of her guesses, earnestly asking: "Does it make sense?" It's Bananarama, Paula.

Christmas Service Radio 4, 9am The service, conducted by the Rev Dr Leslie Griffiths is broadcast from Wesley's Chapel in East London. The youthful singing group All Angels will be in attendance, and among the carols sung by the chamber choir Canticum will be one of John Wesley's greatest hits, Hark! The Herald Angels Sing. And not only that, but by staying at home worshippers will avoid the passing of the collection plate. With Great Pleasure at Christmas Radio 4, 10am All of which segues nicely into Alan Titchmarsh's "personal anthology" of Christmas-friendly poetry and prose, including runnning the chronological gamut of literature from Jane Austen to Alan Bennett. Apparently, when asked which readers would best bring his selection to life, Titchmarsh answered: "The best — Dame Judi Dench and Geoffrey Palmer!" And lo, his wish was granted.
David Beckham's Line of Enquiry Radio 2, 3pm And then the People's Goldenballs (Slightly Tarnished) gives us his considered thoughts on Life, the Universe and Everything, or at any rate as much of it as listeners to Radio 2 have chosen to ask him questions about. For two hours — yes! The affable if hitherto opaque superstar will lay open his soul as never before. Or, depending on the screening of the questions beforehand and the editing process afterwards, we might leam little more about him than we knew before. The "referee" in this interface between Beckham (above) and his public is Kate Thornton, who says: "David signing up to do this is a real coup," before adding, confusingly, "And yes, I do know the offside rule!" Author: Hill, Tobias
Title: A master of domestic disquiet
Full_text:
A master of domestic disquiet
Poetry Tobias Hill
ANTHONY TBWTE
COLLECTED POEMS by Anthony Thwaite BY MOST ACCOUNTS, the poetry of Anthony Thwaite is all well and good: well travelled and good humoured, well read and good natured. "Modest", according to one critic, "unflashy", according to another. Born in 1930, and inextricably associated with the poetic movements of the 1950s, Thwaite is seen as a poet unfond of peacockery and extremes. It is a surprise, then, to
come away from his Collected Poems with a sense of having read something spectacular. Certainly, the early poems are modest — or so wary as to seem so. In the earliest there is a sense of lockjawed formality, the flow of the poetry stilted by enjambement and attenuated grammar. By 1963, however, he has moved into new territory — the influence of Larkin tempered by a meditative domestic stillness in Night Thoughts and A Sense of Property (Frost at Midnight is the polestar here). By the late 1960s Thwaite not only has escaped Larkin's shadow but has broken out of his own restraints, his voice more expansive and wholly his own. Collected Poems allows the reader both hindsight and a bird's eye view: patterns are more easily discerned from
these vantage points. In Thwaite, in the remarkable work ofthe 1960s and 1970s as elsewhere, there always runs an undercurrent of disquiet. Often it surfaces in domestic scenes, as in the many poems devoted to vermin — rats, woodworm, flies and cockroaches. Thwaite's parasites infest his dwellings, eating away at the fabric of things. Often they are killed, with a frantic, clumsy violence. It is a motif that occurs in the earliest poems in this book and which is consciously returned to in the last, The Space Between: here, Thwaite hears a rat in his roof and lets it live, not because the poet has come to terms with his cohabitant, but because the rat is beyond his grasp, so deeply embedded in the structure of his property
that he can no longer reach it. The precision of these poetic disturbances is memorable; there is always the property, the infestation, and the destructive urge; the elements nag like those of a recurrent dream. These are poems ener-
'Parasites infest his dwellings, eating away'
gised by disturbance, by an apprehension of impermanenee, and it is this same apprehension that powers some of the most striking pieces in this book, Thwaite's archaeological poems. Archaeology is present in
his early poems, but it is in the late 1960s and early 1970s that the potential of the theme is realised. In the poems of The Stones of Emptiness and Inscriptions, Thwaite's language becomes richer, his references more fertile: the archaeological poems are the main current rather than the first wellspring of his talent. The 12~poem sequence The Letters of Synesius remains electrifying, as does Monologue in the Valley of the Kings: 1 have hidden something in the inner chamber And sealed the lid of the sarcophagus And levered a granite boulder across the door And the debris has covered it so perfectly That though you walk over it daily you never suspect.
This is spectacular poetry. It deserves to be read: good readers deserve to read it. The Collected ends with 16 new poems. In these, Thwaite returns to the formality that characterises much of his work, but he does so with assurance. And here, too, there is a return of the old nagging unease, the anxious domesticity, as in Spring: I have heard a note strike that doesn't sound right. As the logs smoulder away in the steep ash The hot bricks speak against the iron grate. This is beyond the pull and the drift and the wish. Enitharmon, £25; 445pp 0 £22.50 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Nightingale, Benedict
Title: Plenty to get your teeth into but lyrics lack bite
Full_text:
First night
Plenty tp get your teeth into but lyrics lack bite
Little Shop of Horrors Duke of York's, WC2 •••##________ Benedict Nightingale The nerd who has discovered and nurtured the plant names it Audrey II, which isn't exactly a compliment to the girl he forlornly loves. After all, it's one thing to have a rose (Audrea pulchrissima?) called after you. It's quite another to be immortalised in, and eventually eaten by, a gigantic triffid with parts that variously evoke an octopus, a pterodactyl, asparagus, a penis, a crab and dentures as they might have been custom-built for a piranha family. As constructed by David Farley and accoutred with Mike McShane's big, booming voice, this dietetically ambitious Venus flytrap provides Howard Ashman and Alan Menken's musical with a thoroughly satisfactory villain. But, speaking of teeth, there's a second, subsidiary baddie. That's Alistair McGowan's sadistic Orin Scrivello, who flings aside his biker's leathers to reveal a dentist's uni-
form beneath — and is subsequently seen gleefully taking pliers to our wimpish hero's mouth while dosing himself with laughing gas. Maybe that's a parody of Marathon Man, in which, you may recall, a Naziloving Laurence Olivier had a go at Dustin Hoffman's molars. But then Little Shop of Horrors is a parody of just about every sci-fi movie and play, starting with The Rocky Horror Show, which was a parody itself. Everyone who saw Matthew White's Horrors revival at the Menier Chocolate Factory last November seems to have enjoyed it, and, though transfer has clearly deprived it of intimacy, everyone should enjoy it now that it is following the same theatre's Sunday in the Park with George into the West End. The setting, also by Farley, is the last flower shop in an American Skid Row that consists of dustbins, lurking bums and shadowy fire-escapes. How to improve the place's unsurprisingly poor finances? Why, by putting Audrey II in the window and attracting fascinated customers as the plant grows and grows. The trouble is that the plant is not content with the blood provided from his finger-tips by its discoverer,
Paul Keating's namby-pamby Seymour. It wants and gets more: McGowan's evil dentist, Barry James as the shop-owner and, in the stage if not the film version, the adroitly hilarious Sheridan Smith as the cute, coquettish Audrey. An underclass trio calling themselves Chiffon, Crystal and Ronette belt out some big, strong tunes with plenty of brio but, sadly, with less effect than would have been the case if their words could be heard. The general view since the show's inception off-Broadway in 1982 is that the lyrics are far smarter than average, but my poll of audience members couldn't confirm the claim, because the balance between Ashman's rhymes and the orchestra favoured the latter by an acoustic walkover. This is a complaint I hear increasingly often these days. And who cares if, as is often the case, the lyrics improve with inaudibility? But this time it would be nice if we could relish more than the odd soft number. That way, a jolly spoof might become sophisticated fun. Box office: 0870 0606623 More reviews, times?.
Another victim for Audrey II in a spirited revival starring Alistair McGowan

Author: Feinstein, Elaine
Title: Lost pasts and grateful presents
Full_text:
Lost pasts and grateful presents
Poetry Elaine Feinstein
BRIAN PATTEN HAS always been a gifted poet. Forty years ago his charm made him instantly popular, though his imagination sometimes seemed dangerously close to whimsy. Looking back at those early, precocious lyrics in his Selected Poems we can see that their surreal landscape is entirely genuine. So is the wistful tone of later poems. "These boys never grow into men," he acknowledges. He has never lost touch with the sevenyear-old runaway, afraid he will be sniffed out by tracker dogs who have his lollipops. There are American debts. His fantasy of Maud, no longer in Tennyson's garden, but wearing a Mary Quant dress and eating fish and chips, has affinities with Allen Ginsberg's Walt Whitman in the Supermarket. His truest model, though, is English — Stevie Smith, whom he calls "Blake's purest daughter". He is less obsessed with death than she was, but he lets the darkness in. What he regrets most is what he has failed to record from a lost past: "The loose change history spent without caring." Michael Schmidt has always been a fine poet, but his life as editor, anthologist and professor has meant a gap of 20 years since his previous book of new poems and The Resurrection ofthe Body. The new work is stunning. The cat of a 9th-century Irish monk chases a quill over parchment. Suicide bombers wreck the exquisite geometries ofthe Golden Dome in Samarra. Sexual love remains a pervasive theme. The title poem tells the story of one of Christ's
miracles, but is also about the resurgence of desire. Jesus is holding a sick girl in his arms and, as she revives, she feels her nakedness has roused him. Schmidt writes particularly well about unease and ambiguity; of finding the scent of an earlier lover between his sheets: That autumn, when I lay with you, you started pretending These hands of mine were his hands in the dark, these lips And the tufts in my armpits, his... He writes with the most sadness of Don Juan, who once "made love as other men make shoes or music" and now can no longer swim where the mermaids do. Perhaps he has T. S. Eliot's voice in his ears, as Don Juan bids farewell to: 'The suck of their lips, the shimmer of their blue tails, And their hair that was green and silver, their cool breasts Which they said he could touch, which they held up for his kiss. Helen Dunmore reveals herself in Glad of These Times to be that rare creature, a poet who can write about happiness. Like D.H. Lawrence she feels gratitude for "the great privilege of being alive". She loves the world: "the sour earth between wall and wheelie bin", city lilacs, and blue gardens seen from a train. Her exuberant celebration of the 21st century — which gives the book its title — reminds us of many good fortunes forgotten in our fashionable gloom: Because I did not die in childbirth
HULTON ARCHIVE/ GETTY IMAGES
Tennyson's Kama K a:ry in Quant, eating chips' because my children will survive me I am glad of these times.. glad of central heating and cable TV glad of email and keyhole surgeiy glad of power showers and washing machines Dunmore is far from complacent. One of the most haunting poems deals with a nightmare that is all the more alarming because it is no imaginary monster that terrifies the child, but an apprehension of future reality: You'll die and then I'll be alone Daljit Nagra is a voice with fresh new rhythms. Born in London, and working as a teacher, in Look We Have Coming; to Dover! he writes in the idioms of his Sikh community. Hei knows the dangers: Did you inthe Did 7 m; the market? make me for the gap market ? ike me for the gap in
His relationship with his own culture is ambiguous. As a boy, he confesses, he was embarrassed by his mother: That's why I'd bin the letters about parents evenings. Food from home is treated as sacred by the older generation and he doesn't always like it: Ladoo, for instance, a saffron-coloured sweetmeat the size of a golf ball, that his father thrusts into his unwilling mouth. He is equally critical of the English world. With some irony, he observes sexual confidence dwindling into suburban greed: Why now not be naked, you naughty western woman? Not four month since I Delhi -Heathrow to you, already you lying in living room with catalogues. Brian Patten: Selected Poems Penguin, £8.99; 176pp _0 £8.54 (free p&p) The Resurrection of the Body Smith/Doorstop, £8.95; 76pp m £8.50 (free p&p) Glad of These Times Bloodaxe, £7.95; 64pp m £7.55 (free p&p) Look We Have Coming to Dover Faber, £8.99; 64pp m £8.54 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Cohen, Louise
Title: Music and Lyrics
Full_text:
MUS4eANDLYS_.CS Director: Marc Lawrence, PG, 104min Stars: Hugh Grant, Drew Barrymore, Brad Garrett On general release • • • i? Hr
Three years since Love Actually brought us that inimitable hip-wiggle, we finally get a chance to see Grant shamelessly shaking it on a grander scale. He stars as Alex Fletcher, a has-been 1980s pop star who is offered the chance to write a song for a chart-topping teen sensation. In need of a lyricist, he stumbles upon a talent in the form of the ditzy plant-waterer Sophie Fisher (Barrymore) — sparks, of course, soon fly. A formulaic rom-com with two A-list leads who possess decent chemistry results in a sweet and fun easy watch. And though the plot is obvious and the script a little lazy, Barrymore looks fabulous and watching Grant leaping around as an 1980s pop star is not to be missed. LOUISE COHEN

Author: Fordham, Alice
Title: Bleak worlds streaked with light
Full_text:
books
Bleak worlds streaked with light
Classics, Poetry and Essays Alice. Fordham
GRIEF LESSONS: Four Plays by Euripides DECREATION by Anne Carson
ANNE CARSON IS A POET, classicist and thoughtful delineator of the human heart. Her previous books, given awards including the T. S. Eliot Prize for Poetry, have focused on love and heartbreak and have included gorgeous translations of Sappho's love poems and meditations on Eros. At first glance, her most recent two books are a bleak departure. She has gone from Sappho to the wild misery of Euripides' tragedies in Grief Lessons, her new translations of four plays. And in her poetry she has produced Decreation, which begins with a series of poems on the illness of a fading mother. However, these books are full of life. The deconstruction and tragic annihilation are dramatised by Carson's graceful writing and deft trans-
lation. But in both works she moves on, back to life and the way it is and can be lived. In Grief Lessons she has chosen to translate some of the most chaotic tragedies of Ancient Greek literature. The title is significant — these are grief lessons, not gorefests. She writes in her introduction that Euripides "breaks experiences open"; but his love of life shines through Carson's lucid poetry. In Hippolytus, a character mired in doom, as they all are, reflects: "We humans seem disastrously in love with this thing / (whatever it is) that glitters on the earth —/We call it life." Decreation was written first, published last year and is available in the UK now. The opening poems are full of the sorrow of a mother's old age, yet even the old lady's life is worthwhile. Carson writes: "Weak suns yet alive/are as virtue to suns of that other day." The next offering is an essay on sleep, a lively meditation on the liberating possibilities of sleep for the mind, drawing on authors as diverse as Woolf and Homer. The keystone of the book however, is a series of essays that allow the reader to understand why decreation is a positive activity rather than a process of decay. She examines the work of three female writers and their
STEPHEN CHERNIN/AP
!These are grief lessons not gorefests'
thoughts on abandonment of the self. First is Sappho with her breathless description of lust overtaking her, then Marguerite Porete, who wrote a treatise on closeness to God by abandoning self-will (and was burned for it in 1310) and Simone Weil, a philosopher of the last century, who also sought to abandon herself to God.
Her thoughts on this are complex; yet recognising that destruction is the beginning of something exciting is a good way to approach both these books. In both of them a very human poet shows us a life that is worthwhile and which should be embraced with abandon and joy. Author: Freeman, John
Title: The political is personal
Full_text:
books
The political is personal
Just don't mention the White House when the poet Adrienne Rich is around. John Freeman gets the message
THE PAST FOUR YEARS HAVE been good ones for poetry in America. A poet, Dana Gioia, was appointed head of the National Endowment of the Arts. Spoken-word events are packed. Even corporate largesse has come calling. In 2002 the pharmaceutical heiress Ruth Lily announced that she would be giving nearly $150 million (£75 million) to the magazine Poetry. Overnight, a tiny journal became one of the richest publications in the US. Good as this sounds, Adrienne Rich hasn't been rushing to celebrate. "Poetry, the art, doesn't need billions infused into one institution," the 77-year-old poet said, her face souring. "I think artists would do better in a society that was more economically just." Looking a gifthorse in the mouth is one of her specialities. She has won nearly every prize available to an American poet and has turned down several. In 1978, she rejected the National Book Award as an individual to accept it on behalf of silenced voices everywhere. Bill Clinton wanted to give her the National Medal of Arts, but she refused."I could not accept such an award from President Clinton or this White House because the very meaning of art is incompatible with the cynical politics of this Administration." Sitting at an Italian restaurant in Manhattan, Rich doesn't look like a troublemaker. She is small and tidy,
her eyes beatific in moments of pleasure — for example when she talks about jazz or film or young people. But shift the conversation to governments and her voice grows hard and clear. "I, for many, many years have felt not just that the personal becomes political," she says, "but that the political becomes personal." It is a remarkable statement from a poet who worked so hard to get the message across the other way around — that women's bodies were battlegrounds, that their voices had been silenced. But a lot has changed since the driving, declarative poems in
fShe has won so many prizes — and turned them down*
Snapshots of a Daughter-in-Law (1963) and Diving into the Wreck (1973) made Rich a feminist icon. Personal narrative — once a vehicle for feminism — has ushered in the Glamour magazine confessional. Women have obtained higher pay — but at what cost, Rich wonders. "Women in political power can give us a Margaret Thatcher," she says. "It's given us Condoleezza Rice. The question is: what does
one do with the power one gets?" Rich has similar concerns about poetry now that it has millions and is emblazoned on subway cards. Accepting a lifetime achievement award from the National Book Foundation, recently, she defended it from commercialisation. "Poetry is not a billboard," she said. "It is not linguistic aromatherapy. It is not a massage." Rich is particularly concerned with the state of political poetry, because in the US "there are always arguments against poetry in the public discourse, arguments particularly against an engaged poetry". Rich, born in Baltimore in 1929, came of age in the heyday of new criticism, when writers such as F. R. Leavis and William Empson all but crushed the notion that a poem could have a reference point outside itself. In a sense, she has had to fight this twice — first diving into the wreck of her identity as a woman, then backing out into the wider world. "My [past five books] are interrogating the mood and what it's like to be in the US at this time, from a variety of perspectives," she says. "Whether powerless or powerful, whether privileged or not, and how the conditions ofthe public world impinged on our own private lives, as I believe they do." One does not have to look far to find examples of what Rich is talking about. "Questions of who can you
DAVID CORIO \>? i'f i,': i l I IP* ja_K_- I i Tt% »». £' ^!?$65& ltf;;f frif mmm 4_L IS ' W** _B ^HE____f _»^*t wm: Rich tones: the poet in New York
love, what do we as individuals see and what do we not see, to paraphrase Muriel Rukeyser," she says, rattling off the latest flashpoints in American life. "Also — what do we think of as the world? Americans have been prone to think of ourselves as the world." One collection at a time, Rich is trying to smash that parochialism. Lately, her most receptive audience has been students. This is a change. Ten years ago, when she travelled the country, she would hear questions such as: "How do I get published?" and "Do I need an agent as a poet?" "That doesn't come up now," Rich says, a smile breaking. "The last place I had been was Northwestern University, and there were students there from all walks and many different
fields. And they all really wanted to talk about art and politics." As Rich points out, this mixture of intellectual rigour and passion cannot be bought or created. It rises up out of the verse itself. "Poetry can break open locked chambers of possibility,/ restore numbed tones of feeling, recharge desire," she once wrote about passion. It applies to politics, too, she has discovered, and is reminding us all over again.

Author: Wilson, Jean Moorcroft
Title: Memoirs of a poetry-writing boy
Full_text:
Memoirs of a poetry-writing boy
Even at the age of 12, Siegfried Sassoon took his vocation seriously. Jean Moorcroft Wilson is enthralled by some newly discovered verses by the great war poet
SIEGFRIED SASSOON'S mother decided early in his life that he was to be a poet, presenting him on his third birthday with a copy of Coleridge's Lectures on Shakespeare. Partly to avoid disappointing her, he started his first book of poems at 9 — an age when his two brothers were forging mock cannonballs in their makeshift workshop — dedicating it "For Mamsy". His second followed a few months later for her birthday in March 1897. Altogether there were — or so I thought when I wrote my 1999 biography of Sassoon — nine childhood notebooks written between 1896 and 1899. Described by Sassoon as "scribblings" and "automatic poetising", these little notebooks do anticipate some of his characteristic interests and concerns as a poet, in particular nature and a slight fixation with death. They also represent an invaluable apprenticeship, helping to prepare him for the memorable war poems to come. A tenth juvenile collection has
P»||M The poem the Sassoon notebook
now resurfaced in Australia. A tiny exercise book measuring approximately 6in by Min and just 18 pages long, its charmingly illustrated title page announces itself grandly as Verses on Various Occasions, a sign of how seriously Sassoon took his vocation at the age of 12. None of the poems is published, although some are repeat performances. To a Nightingale, for example, had appeared in earlier notebooks, indicating that even at 12 Sassoon was able to recognise a genuine poetic impulse when it escaped to give fresh life to well-worn themes and was already truly inspired by natural beauty: Suddenly from the trees a song so fair Through the still night like purest water flowing Each moment, lovelier and more perfect growing Borne on a breeze came floating on the air... This find is of particular interest for several reasons. It is almost cer-
tainly Sassoon's last childhood effort at composition before a new tutor, the hearty athletic Cambridge graduate Clarence Hamilton, made him feel that writing poetry was rather "priggish". (It would be another three years before his inspiration was reawakened by reading Thomas Hood at Marlborough College.) Its history also provides new insights into Sassoon's character and upbringing. The inheritor ofthis treasure, Gay McAuley, a professor of French and performance art at the University of Sydney, emigrated to Australia in 1968. It was a legacy from her aunt, the daughter ofthe original recipient, Sassoon's nursemaid, Emily Eyles. Painstakingly transcribed in February 1899, Verses on Various Occasions was the aspiring poet's wedding present to Emily. Born in 1878, Emily was the daughter of a blacksmith, and grew up with two or three younger brothers in Brightling, East Sussex, a village Sassoon never tired of nearing her describe. An intelligent child, she stayed on at school as a pupil-teacher before coming to work for Sassoon's mother at her home, Weirleigh, near Matfield, Kent. She was nominally a parlour maid, but Siegfried remembered that she quickly became his mother's "only effective ally", in preventing him and his two equally mischievous brothers "from turning the whole house into a bear garden". (The upwardly mobile Emily always described her job as "nursery maid", apparently a more prestigious position in the servant hierarchy.) The abrupt departure of her nanny and a reluctance to follow the middle-class practice of sending them to school had left Theresa Sassoon to deal single-handedly with three rowdy boys, aged 9 to 12. This made her particularly grateful to Emily who, according to Sassoon, had inherited her blacksmith father's "fortitude". Despite the air of innocence and fragility given by her blue eyes and fair hair, she had no difficulty in handling the Sassoon boys with the necessary firmness. Although "very ladylike in every way", she greatly enjoyed listening in later life to broadcasts of prize-fights, Gay McAuley recalls, a side of her that helps to explain how she could "deal so cheerfully with three wild boys, growing up without discipline of school" — or of father. Alfred Sassoon had abandoned his wife and sons before Siegfried was 5, leaving Theresa, in her loneliness, closer to her servants than most. She was also more enlightened than many of her Victorian contemporaries in her dealing with them. When
s •
Emily married, not only did Theresa attend the wedding but also acted as one of the witnesses. Her present to the bride — an invitation to choose her favourite painting at Weirleigh — shows how close they had become. The family's recollections of the picture, which hung in a place of honour in Emily's dining room, suggest that she chose a work by Theresa herself, a professional painter before her marriage. It showed a boy standing in a doorway, and may well have represented Siegfried, who often served as his mother's model. Siegfried was equally attached to Emily. She was only eight years his senior, and much closer to him than any other woman, apart from his mother, in a predominantly female household. She would often join in his games with his brothers, helping them to find their cricket ball when it was lost in the sweet-briar hedge, or taking them for bicycle rides. The Sassoon boys had taught her to ride a bicycle in the first place.
THis gratitude contrasts with his distrust of other women1
Having discovered them driving their grandmother's brake-less bathchair down a steep hill near Weirleigh, their mother, initially reluctant, had decided that bicycles might be less dangerous. Emily was also taken for swimming lessons with them in the muddy Medway near by although, like Siegfried, she hated the activity. Siegfried particularly appreciated her practice of reading the boys' favourite books to them when they finally felt like sitting still in the evening: The Coral Island, The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, Around the World in Eighty Days, Treasure Island, Black Beauty and, less predictably, The Diary ofa Nobody. A "gently, loving and generous person", according to her granddaughter, Emily was very lively and gaily performed these and many more tedious tasks. Sassoon's gratitude emerges in his autobiography and contrasts strongly with his often resentful or distrustful attitude towards other women. Apart from his mother's eccentric friend Helen Wirgman, who won him over with her passionate piano-playing and understanding of his childish moods, Emily was the only person outside his immediate family to whom he presented his poems. His deep affection for her is a much earlier proof of his ability to relate to a woman nearer his own age
<NEWPAGE>
notebook, written out so lovingly for her all those years before.
TO A NIGHTINGALE AND SLEEP © SIEGFRIED SASSOON, REPRINTED BY KIND PERMISSION OF THE ESTATE OF GEORGE SASSOON
Sasson, the military man in 1915, and below, from left, with his brother Hamo (on left) in the garden at Weirleigh, centre, and Emily Eyles around the time of her marriage
than was previously known. And his admiration for the daughter of a blacksmith shows that he was not such a snob as he sometimes seems. Siegfried's brothers' wedding present to her was a pair of copper bowls made in their workshop from the purloined catches from Weirleigh's drawing-room windows. The wedding, originally scheduled for late 1898 or early 1899, had to be postponed until January 1902. Theresa, clearly apprehensive about being left in charge of her sons without Emily, had made arrangements for the eldest, Michael, to start at boarding school in 1899. Siegfried and the youngest, Hamo, were to follow a year later. Emily's planned wedding explains what I had previously found a puzzlingly uncharacteristic decision on
the part of the over-protective Theresa — to let her sons go. By the time that Emily and her new husband Clarence Dawson, the son of a coal merchant from nearby Headcorn, left to live in Ulcombe, Kent, all three were safely off their mother's hands. Weirleigh remained precious to Emily. Her passion for gardening was inspired by its wonderful garden and the second witness at her wedding was Weirleigh's head gardener, Ned Farris. (For Sassoon, who loved the garden as much as Emily, it became a symbol of lost innocence in later life.) Theresa herself represented an ideal for Emily, not only of how to run a well-ordered household but also how to be a mother. Throughout her life she treasured Theresa's painting, Michael and Hamo's copper bowls, but especially Siegfried's little

Author: Ackroyd, Peter
Title: Friends disunited
Full_text:
Books
Biography Peter Ackroyd Friends disunited
THE FRIENDSHIP: Wordsworth and Coleridge by Adam Sisman THEY HAVE BECOME A famous couple, like Hero and Leander or Pyramus and Thisbe. Their relationship was of the mind rather than of the body, but it had its comic as well as its romantic moments. For a while they needed each other; they were, in the Platonic sense, split halves of a soul that had to be reunited before it could properly manifest itself. That soul became the source of English Romantic poetry. Such a miraculous union — that of Wordsworth and Coleridge — could not last for ever. "William has a great attachment to poetry," his sister Dorothy Wordsworth wrote at the very beginning of his career, "which is not the most likely to produce his advancement in the world." And so it proved. He merely "passed" at university, then set off on a series of desultory wanderings. All paths seemed to lead to France, in the middle of its bloody revolution. He cut short his hair. He fell in love with, and impregnated, his French mistress. He became a convinced democrat and radical. In this he was not
unlike a thousand of his contemporaries. One of those, two years younger, was Samuel Taylor Coleridge. He was similarly convinced of the efficacy and significance of the French Revolution. He signed one of his letters "with the ardour of fraternal friendship". He described himself as a "dreamer" and as "fretful and inordinately passionate". By the time he reached Cambridge he was addicted to laudanum, the drug that became the magic theatre of his life. In 1794, at the age of 24, Wordsworth told a friend that "I have been doing nothing and still continue to be doing nothing, what is to become of me I know not". Although he had published two poems he had, as yet, no sense of his genius. Coleridge was in a similarly disgruntled state. He had joined the Army under the pseudonym of Silas Tomkyn Comberbache to escape his university debts; he was discharged as insane before returning to Cambridge. Here he was involved in extravagant notions such as the idealised community known as Pantisocracy. Both young poets were still passionately committed to the ideas and ideals of the revolution; the "Terror" and the fall of Robespierre did not materially affect their enthusiasm. It had, in fact, become their faith. But otherwise they were lost in the world. They had no income, no future, no prospects to speak of. Coleridge married, and subsisted by public lecturing. Wordsworth received hand-outs
fColeridge had become a drunkard, a nuisance1
from friends and relatives. They first encountered one another in Bristol, in the late summer or early autumn of 1795. It is not perhaps surprising that there are three different and irreconcilable accounts of their meeting; so myths are made. The effect, however, was clear. They impressed each other terrifically. Wordsworth described Coleridge's conversation as "a majestic river, the sound or sight of whose course you caught at intervals". Wordsworth recited his poetry to his new acquaintance, which Coleridge deemed to manifest "the union of deep feeling with profound thought". Soon they were discussing everything — poetry, politics, plans for the future. They settled near each other in the West Country. They read each
other's works, making criticisms and suggestions. They collaborated. They declaimed aloud as they walked down country roads. They were inseparable, Coleridge spending many days away from his wife and family to be close to Wordsworth. As he put it in one of his notebooks, "the flames of two candles joined give a much stronger light than both of them separate". Together they created a new form of English poetry. The fruit oftheir labours in the West Country, Lyrical Ballads, was a new volume for a new age of revolution. But theirs was not a political gesture. It was a deeply creative response to the doctrines of equality and liberty promulgated by the French revolutionaries. Wordsworth and Coleridge
fWordsworth couldnft bear even mild criticism1
were relocating dignity in the commonplace, restoring grace and significance to ordinary lives where saints and heroes walked unannounced and unknown. They were proclaiming a democratic world in which outcasts had as much right to be heard as anyone, and in which women and children had a voice. The Friendship is an elegant tour d'horizon, a scholarly and charming summary of an often explored partnership. On a critical or analytical level, it is perhaps familiar; but Adam Sisman is good at recording the complicated human relationships between all concerned. There is the problem of Coleridge's wife, for example, who resented the amount of time that her husband spent with the Wordsworths. And there is Dorothy Wordsworth, caught in the difficult position of a worshipping sister. Sisman has done his research thoroughly, and is good at disentangling a confusing chronology: in this narrative the two poets march side by side on their journey towards fame and literary glory. But eventually they drew apart. There were growing differences. Wordsworth was egotistical and oversensitive; he could never bear even the mildest criticism. Coleridge, on the other hand, suffered from inanition and self-disgust. He willingly prostrated himself before his companion, comparing himself to John the Baptist before Christ. But he did not see matters clearly from that semi-recumbent
TOPFOTO
position. He let Wordsworth excise many of his poems from the second edition of Lyrical Ballads. His confidence in his poetry was wholly gone. He became ill, and took increasingly to opium. The great slide of his life had begun. When Coleridge returned to England, after a period of dithering in Malta and in Italy, the Wordsworths had never seen a man so changed. Drink and opium had glazed him; he was bloated and pale. He no longer had a commanding eye, but had become introverted and remote. Then came the final break. A mutual friend, in a fit of rashness, blurted out certain truths that Wordsworth had confided to him — in particular that Coleridge had become a drunkard and a "nuisance". Coleridge felt betrayed, and bitterly resented Wordsworth's ingratitude. They met intermittently over the remaining years but their intimacy — their joy in one another's company — had vanished. It is a sad story without a moral except, perhaps, for the obvious one that youthful enthusiasm and youthful friendship are bound to fade — that advancing years do not necessarily bring happiness or contentment — that the greatest careers are accompanied by a sense of disappointment. Only the work of art, as Wordsworth and Coleridge knew, is satisfyingly complete. HarperCollins, £20; 416pp m £18 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Null
Title: Perfect pitch in troubled times
Full_text:
Books
Perfect pitch in troubled times
Poetry Elaine Feinstein
MICHAEI. LONGLEY Collected Poems
COLLECTED POEMS by Michael Longley MICHAEL LONGLEY IS A lyric poet with perfect pitch. His formal elegance seems effortless. In a memorable poem he suggests that a reading of his whole life's work should be by a pebbly waterfall, so that the syllables on the page might be lit in the mind's eye as if they were fireflies. Here are those words: 40 years of his poetry. Yet he is not only a songsmith; he also has a profoundly serious range of subject matten John Clare escaping from his madhouse, his father's experience of the Great War, ghettos during the Holocaust and the Troubles of his own Northern Ireland. And he can write love poetry with a tender sense of the body's richness. He filches images from the literature of classical Greece and Rome and sets them in a new landscape; they are never marmoreal. Romulus and Remus are given life as Longley imagines them licked by their she-wolf mother. In Ceasefire, Achilles is moved to tears as old King Priam weeps for his dead son Hector. He arranges for Hector's corpse to be washed and laid out in uniform. Courteous behaviour costs both Priam and Achilles
a great deal. Peace between enemies is never easy, and as Longley describes King Priam's offer of forgiveness, he must have in mind the difficulties of a recent truce .in Northern Ireland. I get down on my knees and do what must be done • And kiss Achilles' hand, the killer of my son. When he writes about the First World War I am reminded of Ted Hughes's obsession with his father's experience — except that Longley's father is more ready to tell stories than the taciturn Yorkshireman, who can hardly be brought to describe the horrors he has witnessed. Longley's Irishness is a potent inheritance. Some strands of his family tree, however, came as a surprise to me. In the first verse of his poem No Man's Land, in memory of Isaac Rosenberg, Longley writes: Who will give skin and bones to my Jewish granny? She has come down to me in the copperplate writing Of three certificates, a dog-eared daguerreotype And the one stoiy my grandfather told about her. Longley speaks of "tilting her head" towards Rosenberg, as if he were using this relationship to deepen his own involvement with the young poet under bombardment, which might otherwise resemble that of the bird he describes: A shell-shocked carrier pigeon flaps behind the lines. Perhaps his familial connection, however slight, gives him
EAMONN McCABE/ CAMERA PRESS V WW*! Tte . ***** Michael Longley: effortless elegance
a certain purchase on the Jewish experience of the Second World War. In Ghetto, for instance, one ofthe most remarkable poems in this book, he lists the ordinary and precious belongings: "toothbrush and flannel... medicines... a candlestick, a loaf, sardines, needle and thread" which are taken on the doomed journey for Poland. The children, forbidden lessons, record what they see in crayon: ... until in pen and ink They turned into guards at executions and funerals Torturing and hanging even these stick figures. There were drawings of barracks and latrines as well And the only windows were the windows they drew. Some of this knowledge plays out into Couchette, where his much-loved family sleep in layers, on a train, almost as if in a mausoleum. Their dreams stop and start
with the movement of the train, and suddenly he has a surreal vision of the train shunted down a siding and his whole family sleeping on for centuries, waiting to get on their way again. Longley is not exactly a modernist. He has never abandoned capital letters at the beginning of lines, though he comes to use rhyme and metre with elasticity. He knows how to break his lines wittily, as in Jelly Roll Morton, where the tip over invalidates what seemed to be words of praise: To be nearly as great as you Think you are But he is happiest with a long Ime. His work is not finished, but he is a master in an old, great tradition, and that is how he will be remembered. Cape, £25; 368pp H £23 (free p&p) 08701608080 timesonline.co.uly'booksfirst

Author: Ford, Richard
Title: The poetry invested in property

Novel Russell Celyn Jones The poetry invested in property
