THE LAY OF THE LAND by Richard Ford RICHARD FORD resurrects for the third time in The Lay of the Land one of the world's most eloquently idiosyncratic and anguished real estate agents. Frank Bascombe, 39 in The Sportswriter, and 44 in Independence Day, is now 55 — an age at which he hopes life has to be more predictable and thus easier to shape day by day. It's a stage he calls "the Permanent Period". But that was before his second wife, Sally, elopes with her first husband when he turns up after a 30-year absence. And before a siowgrowing tumour is detected in Frank's prostate gland. Suddenly the days ahead look as if they will end in mayhem. Frank lives in Sea Clift on the New Jersey shore, a few hours' drive south from Haddam, where he was in The Sportswriter. His 25-year-old former lesbian daughter Clarissa comes home to be on hand and this forms the central relationship of the novel — as the central relationship in Independence Day was between Frank and Clarissa's brother, Paul, who is still troubled after all these years. That the children of divorced parents grow up too quickly is one of Frank's many observations and features significantly in
the novel. As with the first two novels, the action takes place over a public holiday (Thanksgiving) as Frank returns to Haddam to attend a funeral, oversee a property deal with his business partner, Mike Mahoney (a Tibetan Buddhist and all-American Republican) and meet his former wife Ann, mother of their three children (one died, 21 years ago) to hear her big announcement. That is more or less all the action there is, but the great delight of this novel is not plot but Frank's richly textured, rolling and poetic voice. Not many realtors could be so vividly alive, immersed in the poetry of their trade ("high-end, a buck-twenty, per") or so polemical. Every comment on property and land becomes a comment upon America itself. That Frank's job works so well as metaphor has everything to do with his belief that American values have all morphed into property values. Frank makes a good living selling property along the New Jersey shore, while maintaining a deep
Children of the divorced grow up too quickly1
cynicism about "our present and very odd state of human development". He was an alienated outsider in Ronald Reagan's US in the 1980s, but things have become far worse for Frank by 2000. Death hovers in the thermals over this presidential
BARRY MARSDEN / IDOLS mmn tiutlr, Ford use^aA; property te V qwnmentjyji US v&juiss A
election year. With George W. Bush about to get elected with a little gerrymandering help from his brother in Florida (Ford personifies all Republicans as low-life morons, who have colluded in the corruption of the American way of life), Frank begins to sound like an American contemplating leaving America, rather than just the suburbs, for good, as he itemises the dystopia along what was once a scenic rural pike: drive-throughs, factory outlets, cinema complexes, big-box stores. Families drive from one to another in gridlocked cars. The occasional evangelical church represents what passes for the American spirit. One well orchestrated bar room brawl, a fox on the loose in an empty property, a littie
terrorist outrage prefiguring 9/11, and a shooting do not constitute a dramatic structure and almost 500 pages of Frank's thoughts can be a little taxing. But this authorial indulgence of a favoured character is compensated by sublime characterisation, extended even to the absent. Ford populates this cathartic suburban novel in the way of Richard Yates or John Updike (the Rabbit books in particular) — with whom he shares a mechanism for amplifying daily domestic detail. The souls of his characters blossom and ultimately survive political nihilism. Bloomsbury, £17.99; 496pp m £16.19 (free p&p) 08701608080 timesonline.co.uK/booksfirst

Title: Scourge of the vulgar faction

COLLECTED POEMS by Alan Brownjohn ALAN BROWNJOHN HAS been a shrewd, amused observer of English life since the 1950s, when he worked alongside Peter Porter and Phillip Hobsbaum in "The Group"; they were poets as distmstful of rhetoric as the New Movement and equally willing to accept the muting of emotion that was often a consequence of their passion for wit and precision. Brownjohn's is a dry, quiet voice. In an early poem, he confesses unromantically and without much distress: If we are still together it is because Of the need to weed the garden. This is neatly turned and not particularly sad, though another poem examines the nature of such a relationship with some grandiloquence. Our minor beings are not wide enough To let great love rear hills on their estate. Their scope includes the gesture and the sigh, But not the fire to leave them desolate. Throughout this volume, Brownjohn has an oldfashioned, quintessentially English decency, which de-
plores human spite, and all the cold unloving Acts done in the name of tribe, or god, or bank. He is at his most entertaining when he makes gentle fun of the dubious delights of a village life whose high points are the North Lancashire Ballet Group, and the acquaintance of a man who sometimes has his compositions broadcast on Radio Chesterfield. He is at his most soberly wise as he notes how changing mores took the sting, but also the significance, out of sexual infidelity: Jt was the world. No one seemed later hurt, or Finally betrayed. It was not of consequence For all the knowingness of this, something in it looks back to the resignation of those "minor beings" of his early poem. There are other men inside him: poor Ludlow, for instance, in A Sunday Breakdown, who walks out along a jutting wall to the sea and sits there reading The Times, waiting for the police. And there is something of Larkin's wistfulness too, as he reflects on the bushes into which he failed to drag girls, or looks across at "real boys/ with huge muscles and girls to praise them" in an amusement arcade and adds: And don't think they Couldn't see you trying quietly to tilt the machine. Brownjohn has been increasingly pessimistic about the uneducated vulgarity of the society around him as he has grown older: "The polytechnics that shall inherit the earth", the movements of popu-
MARK GERSON / CAMERA PRESS Brownjohn: 'old-fashioned vT«„_ decencv'
lar dancing, which he finds absurd, his amazement at those who can "sit straight-faced through a Bob Dylan lyric". This is not, I think, snobbery. He reserves his sharpest sympathy for the long, sour ache of being poor; a woman, for instance, who longed to buy a pair of gloves, but goes home On the underground, her fingers keeping Apples and a small loaf covered in polythene. Writing in Transylvania, he reflects on what he most dislikes in the current poetry scene, to many of whose practitioners he once awarded prizes: The reason why much in-your-face poetry Doesn't appeal to veteran lags like me Is not its vein of brutal emphasis But that its custard pies too often miss. Some time in the Eighties Alan Brownjohn imagined an operatic escape on a grand
ship, followed by a return as someone else. To be enjoyable, the stuff of this daydream had to include the moment of pulling off the mask and announcing: "It was me! It was me! This is what I had to do!" There was never such a mask or such a departure, at least in the life of his poetry. Brownjohn has not been much influenced by the Americans, or figures from Eastern Europe, though his novels have drawn on his experience there. His tone of voice has remained* measured. His values have remained constant. Looking across to France, it is Camus — that most humane and rational of novelists — he chooses to quote, speaking through him splendidly of what he loathes most: "The rotten spite, the tireless hates,/ The bloodlust of all men." Enitharmon, £25; 480pp m £22.50 (free p&p) 08701608080 timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: Erica Wagner
Full_text:
Erica Vagner TItTs been that rare thing - a good week for poets1
A GOOD WEEK FOR POETS, THEN — and how often can you say that? If this seems unfair, don't forget Don Paterson's words of advice in these pages at the end of last month: "Everything you've heard about poets is true: the poverty, the insanity, the early death." But poets, as he also remarked, persist nonetheless; perhaps because they must. I've heard the writer Alan Garner say that writing is a pathology, and perhaps this is more true of poetry than any other form. The venerable Writers' & Artists' Yearbook says that poetry "is one of the easiest writing art forms to begin with, though the hardest to excel at or make any money from". Robert Minhinnick, the fine Welsh poet, has made some money this week, however — although, it must be admitted, for a form other than poetry. His book To Babel and Back, his latest, perceptive collection of essays, has just been made Welsh Book of the Year
— the second time that Minhinnick has taken this prize, worth £10,000; he last took it (for another set of essays) in 1993. To Babel and Back is published by Wales's own Seren, but his poetry is published by Carcanet. Carcanet is the doughty poetry publisher who took the poor Oxford poets into the fold when Oxford University Press axed its poetry list late last century, and its fine magazine, PN Review, has just celebrated its 30th anniversary with a garden party in Highgate. (It was our birthday last week, as you know, but we like to remember other people's, too.) "Little magazines" are the places where aspiring poets tend to send their verse — but often, as Carcanet's publisher, Michael Schmidt, has remarked, without, apparently, having read them. This is a shame, for PN Review is one of many excellent publications that still manage to exist despite a tough climate for what is often viewed as an arcane art. The London Magazine, Stand, Ambit, Modern Poetry in Translation, Poetry Review... they're out there, and worth seeking out — you don't have to be a poet to do so. A while back, I asked you all whether we should cover more poetry in Books; I was very glad that so many of you said yes. We'll try to keep that promise, so that there are more good weeks for poets and poetry readers alike. pnreview.co.uk; poetrysociety.org.uk www.mptmagazine.com

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Epic journeys to redemption
Full_text:
Poetry Rachel Campbell-Johnston
Epic journeys to redemption .
THIS YEAR MARKS THE tenth anniversary of the death of George Mackay Brown, the shy Orkney poet whose solitary life Maggie Fergusson celebrates with an affectionate but clear-sighted biography (George Mackay Brown: The Life, John Murray, £25, offer £22.50). Read it alongside his Collected Poems and step into the "small green world" of the remote islands where he spent almost his entire life. "He transforms everything by passing it through the eye of the needle of Orkney," according to Seamus Heaney who, 40 years after a poetic debut deeply rooted in his own rural Irish memories, comes full circle with District and Circle (Faber, £12.99, offer, £11.69). Leave the sunlit city behind you, the parks where lunchtime sunners lie "on body-heated mown grass" and take a Dante-esque journey down as the Tube becomes a metaphor for the underworld. This rich and ruminative collection roams through the
'Take a Dante-esque trip down the Tube'
decades, tracing the conflicts and troubles of our contemporary world on the patterns and maps of our older mythologies. It is deeply reflective and moves slowly to some vision of redemption. Simon Armitage takes the reader on another epic journey, recasting Homer's Odyssey (Faber, £14.99, offer £13.49) in a version originally commissioned for BBC Radio. It is less translation than light-
ning tour — a jaunty voyage into the land of rattling good yarns, moving at a bone-shaking pace. Scene follows swift scene. Deft metaphor replaces long description. Armitage's economic take on this classic has a forceful simplicity, a clarity and a freshness and energy that stings like the sea's salt. Billy Collins, America's former poet laureate, would understand. The Trouble with Poetry, he says in the title poem of his latest collection (Picador, £.8.99, offer £8.54), is "that it encourages the writing of more poetry, 7 more guppies crowding the fish tank". This popular and accessible writer takes the everyday as his subject in a series of deceptively easy poems. He engages you immediately with his colloquial simplicity when suddenly he darts around behind you, taps you on the shoulder to point out something more complex. Collins has a delightfully witty zest for life. But he has followed the same tactks for some years now, and perhaps his poems have lost some freshness. Any new volume by Geoffrey Hill merits the most mindful attention. Oblivious to the demands of popularity, he stands like some poetic legislator of our civilisation. Demanding, formidable (sometimes to the point of impenetrability), his poetry remains a touchstone in an age of mass culture. Questioning even his right to speak in his latest collection, Without Title (Penguin, £9.99, offer £9.49), he proves himself again a severe but playful master of his form. 13 To buy books at offer price (free p&p), call 0870 1608080 or visit timesonline.co.uk/ booksfirst

Author: Abse, Dannie
Title: Better than beautiful
Full_text:
ooks
Better than beautiful
Poetry Elaine Peinstein
"THE NEXT STATION IS God," Peter Redgrove writes in a last, handwritten, draft-of-a-poem published posthumously. And the sense of some grand, encroaching darkness is at the edge of all these very different poets. Dannie Abse, in his collection Running Late, is the least mystical, as he looks steadily at one of those grey pensioner days when the apple lies wormeaten in the wooden bowl. Yet Abse's poems are filled with wonder. Even as he resists the bells of formal religion, he remembers an idiot boy looking down at a Welsh valley, who is moved to cry "Oh, well-done, God". A true humanist, he writes marvellously about the lives of "blaspheming Old Masters" for whom "work becomes worship": All, all sycophants of magic, all flea bitten, mosquito bitten, lice infested Abse's gentle lyricism depends on a natural, spoken voice, and subtle thoughts always expressed with clarity. He remains one of our few great poets of married love. Ruth Fainlight's imagination is pagan: the Moon is a disturbing muse that has often visited her poetry. Here, in these rich new poems collected under the title Moon Wheels, her insomniac mind and the disk in the sky "grind the coarse stuff of the world into poetry". A physical object evokes a helpless sense of childhood itself. A blue Witney blanket holds the memories of many illnesses as well as her knowledge of the measles pathogens that once proved a fatal gift to the American Indians. She puzzles over plants, painting, birds' nests. Her reflections on her own ageing are set alongside rueful memories of a time when she could still "wrap my legs behind your waist". There are quiet poems in which a half-glimpsed other reassures and soothes. Yet the characteristic tone is a metaphysical unease, stoically borne through ordinary misadventures. One of my favourite poems here, Anxiety of Airports, is experienced both by someone waiting to welcome a friend who does not turn up, and some literary traveller left insecure and unmet in a foreign land. Her elegant new work is set alongside a section of excellent translations from Vallejo, Sophia Mello Brenner and Sophocles. The next two books demand to be read together Peter Redgrove, who died in 2003,
BRIDGEMAN ART LIBRARY © ADAGP, PARIS AND DACS, LONDON 2006 t m
With Compliments By Dannie Abse
Dear, if I had a small legacy from Croesus I would purchase — please do not argue — that painting of gladioli by Soutine you so admired. But in a waking fit of realism I've bought this bunch of robust-red, radiantly alive upstanding gladioli from The Corner Flower Stall instead.
From Running Late by Dannie Abse, published by Hutchinson. Reprinted by permission of The Random House Group Ltd.
was one of the most astonishing figures of 20th century poetry, and the poems in this last book, The Harper, show him still dazzled by the world and equally dazzling. Penelope Shuttle was his wife, and her poems of mourning for him are among the best she has written Redgrove's imagery has the true lyric frisson of a man who finds a visionary reality in the world around him. Windows shine like gongs. Water in a well resembles "a tree spinning silk"; he calls up "the smell of apple mortality". Even when he writes of magic and myth he does not lose touch with the everyday world. The seventh tree in the wood, for instance, has fruit that leaves
"a shuddering taste in the mouth". His Duessa is a glorious figure, whose masks disguise a crone looking for a kiss, and whose odours resemble "a hot poker plunged into a spicy drink". He says of her, as one might say of his poetry: "She was better than beautiful. She was magic." The second poem in Shuttle's book Redgrove's Wife is a playful nursery game written for a wedding anniversary two years before Redgrove's death. It is a playfulness that goes to the heart of her imagery. She wishes to nuildyou a house out of Mondays and Thursdays, a boat from Fridays and Wednesdays.
Inspiration: 'Blue Gladioli', c.1929, by Chaim Soutine In her wonderful sequence Missing you — the most memorable — she begins wryly: No-one will bring you your New Scientist try to sell you double glazing or tell you their secrets. But her pain is naked. She weeps in Boots, Tesco and empty churches, finding even good luck is no longer meaningful without Redgrove. When she remembers their happiness together, she speaks of herself as a river that "he travelled to her source". Gradually, as she lives with his death, she begins to release parts of him but his presence continues to resonate, nevertheless, through the rest of these lovely poems. Author: Kirkpatrick, Robin
Title: One hell of a good job
Full_text:
Reviews
One hell of a good job
Poetry Jamie KcKendrick
DANTE: INFERNO
translated by Robin Kirkpatrick
THE PAST TEN YEARS have brought a spate of Inferno translations. We have had Steve Ellis's Yorshire-inflected Hell, Ciaron Carson's tour de force in terza rima, still to come is Sean O'Brien's version; and that is just this side of the Atlantic. Now Robin Kirkpatrick, a distinguished Dante scholar, has published his first instalment of the entire Commedia. What is behind all this industry — apart, that is, from Dante's work being the pre-eminent long poem of the last millennium? Its entirety, compassing Hell, Purgatory and Heaven in 100 cantos, records the poet's journey through the three realms of the afterlife. Osip Mandelstam refers to the poem as a vast crystal made of 30,000 facets — a tall order, then, for any translator. What makes it harder still is that the translator must find a way not only to embody Dante's own narrative voice, but also the hundreds of utterly distinct and unforgettable voices that he records — most famously, from Hell, Francesca, Pier della Vigna, Brunette Latini, Cavalcanti (pere), Farinata, Ulysses and Ugolino. Some of the characters are mythical, others historic, others still Dante's contemporaries. In fact the afterworld, especially Hell, has much in common with the
faction-ridden world of Dante's Tuscany and, as this uninterrupted flow of translations may strongly suggest, with our own world too. The difficulties do not stop there. Stylistically, Dante is one ofthe most omnivorous of poets. Here Mandelstam's beautiful image does scant justice to the fluvial, all-inclusive, perpetually self-transforming nature of the poem. Linguistically it ranges from the most colloquial to the most courtly, from the sepulchral to the burlesque. It is unfair to expect this span from any single contemporary poet: but, doomed to failure, the translator must at least offer one strand that holds. Despite its history, the last century gave us few poems that attempt to understand
'Dante's span is beyond one single translator1
evil. Hell in Pound's Cantos merely draws on the obscene, ordure-laden elements of Dante without a convincing moral context. The Waste Land, deeply indebted to Dante, emphasises the sterile and mechanical life of the living damned without Dante's sense of their towering potential and magnetism — no Francesca, no Brunette, no Ulysses. This lack of a modern equivalent may account for the continuing challenge that Dante throws out to translators and readers. In T. S. Eliot's critical prose, Dante was fashioned into a forbidding, infallible classic. The figure we meet in the poem is
far more engaging. We may find some of Hell's punishments vindictive and repellent — those for homosexuals or heretics or even adulterers, for example — but the journey that Dante takes us on allows us to hear, though not necessarily to believe, the sinners' own versions, brought to a point of absolute selfdefinition. Kirkpatrick's introduction and canto-by-canto notes are remarkably level and lucid, as attentive to structure as to syntax, language and motif, and deftly cross-reference the whole poem. On their own, they would justify the price. He also brings a more nuanced sense ofthe Italian and a more meditated appreciation of the poem's construction than nearly all of his competitors.
Go to hell: Delacroix's vision of Dante and Virgil's journey to the Underworld
At times, however, this advantage can work against him, especially when he is tempted to gloss the original. In the opening, for example, Dante's one word smarrita becomes "blurred and lost", the three adjectives describing the wood become the Hobbesian combo of "savage, brute, harsh and wild", where the last adds little to the first. For my taste, the iambic beat is too insistent, and can lead him to fillers such as "firmly" in these otherwise powerful lines describing the prodigals and misers: Their frenzied sprees or febrile hoardings-up have wrung from them the beauty of the world and brought them firmly to this ugly brawl.
Earlier in the same canto, he has Virgil address Pluto as "you execrable wolf and continues: "May fury gnaw you inwardly away". Dante's 700-year-old Italian sounds decidedly more contemporary. In the long run, any translation of this poem will fall short, but there is much to recommend here — certainly the intelligence, the energy, the linguistic range — and Kirkpatrick's ability to enliven even doctrinal discourse bodes well for his final two instalments. Penguin, £10.99; 576pp 0 £9.89 (free p&p) 0870 1608080

"London Calling by the Clash was a totemic song for those of us who were in our teens when it came out at the end of 1979. Its apocalyptic imagery and anti-Establishment rant struck a thrashing chord with young people who had grown up in that most depressing decade, the 1970s. The nuclear power station in Three Mile Island had just melted down and, before the Thames Barrier had been built, we were being warned that the capital would flood. So the chorus ran: A nuclear error but I have no fear/ London is drowning — and I live by the river."
"My favourite song lyric is always the last one that has banged its way into my brain. So now it's Arctic Monkeys — not the problems of the dance floor, but of pretending to be an American in Rotherham: Fake Tales of San Francisco/ Echo through the room/ More point to a wedding disco/ Without a bride or groom."

Just before our love got lost you said: 'I am as constant as a northern star'/ And I said, 'Constant in the darkness/ Where's that at?/ If you want me I'll be in the bar'."

Author: Feinstein, Elaine
Title: From minarets to Bleecker Street
Full_text:
Books Poetry
Poetry Elaine 1'einstein From minarets to Bleecker Street
ICE MEMORY: Selected Poems by Joachim Sartorius, various translators THE RANGE OF Joachim Sartorius's poetry arises naturally from an unusual life. Born in Franconia, Bavaria, in 1946, the son of diplomat, he grew up in Tunis and was educated at the Lycee de Carthage there, thus acquiring at a stroke the culture of a civilised Arab decadence and a sharp European clarity. He draws images from minarets, street cafes or the flapping sails of Mediterranean boats with equal fluency, making use both of the Bosphorus and of the Seine, where Paul Celan drowned himself in 1970. Bleecker Street and Manhattan appear in his poetry too; but this is not poetic tourism. Sartorius is trying to make sense of the newly-understood Earth we all inhabit. In the title poem Ice Memory the frozen waters hold the residues of all the disasters from the long history of the planet: volcanic ash from Krakatoa,
lead pollution from Ancient Roman blast furnaces, and so on. Rather than meditating on the immensity of such an inheritance, however, men seem to have only one passion: the desire to discover some "imprint of our tiny naked feet" on the Earth's surface. The poem crackles with an ironic knowledge of human vanity. As he explores Alexandria we sense his love of Cavafy. He imagines the city in 1903, when Ramleh was a main street in the foreigners' district, before leading us into a dark alley Cavafy might have entered when he was 40. In homage, Sartorius invents three new poems that purport to be from the Cavafy estate. His own poems have a colloquial lyricism that recalls that old master of the elegaic. His imagination is often triggered by photographs, for instance one of Lilia Brik and Mayakovsky in Samarkand, and most notably in a poem for the Hungarian poet Janos Pilinszky where he evokes luminous skin stretched tightly over sharp cheekbones, as if he knew him personally, or had
'The ice holds all the residue of disaster1

shared the black truths of the lager. This is the first collection of Sartorius's poems in English, though individual poems have been appearing in magazines for some years. As a notable translator himself of American poets such as John Ashbery and Wallace Stevens, he might well have hoped this would happen earlier. He is fortunate in his translators now, however. Author: Spender, Stephen
Title: How poetry can be found in translation
Full_text:
How poetry can be found in translation
Impossible? Or just hugely rewarding? A. S. Byatt hails the Times Stephen Spender prize
TO KNOW ANOTHER language is the best, and most exciting, way of discovering the strengths — and limitations — of the one with which one has grown up. Writing within constraints — of length, rhythm, rhyme perhaps, stress and repetition — is another. Translating poetry is famously both impossible and wildly rewarding and interesting. It is an exercise both in exact reading and in skilful writing. I have come to value my own translators as my wisest readers — they ask searching questions about precise meanings;
they hear the rhythms of long stretches of interwoven writing, they send lists of alternative translations of particular words, all of which add a little meaning in the other language here, and take it away there, all of which are possible, none of which are perfect equivalents. Sometimes they reveal things that I had not understood or reflected on, strengths and weaknesses of my English, meanings I had thought were self-evident, which become truly problematic in Norwegian, or Spanish, or Japanese. I think of translating poetry as a series of difficult decisions, one after the other. If you love a poem, you love the sound of it in the inner ear, you love the shape of it inside your head, the way each word changes all the words round it, singing or muttering or shouting. Putting it into English entails a whole series of difficult decisions — do you try to keep a strictly rhymed form,, or dq ypu go for faithful worcls
in free verse? Have you any right to add an image of your own as an equivalent image in English of some ancient Greek war cry or modern German street argot? Another delightful aspect of translating into English is the doubleness of our inheritance — we so often have the choice between Germanic or Anglo-Saxon bluntness and Latin elegance. (Both qualities can be found in the other vocabulary also of course, Latin bluntness and Germanic elegance.) Our language is flexible, craggy, sinuous, abstract, airy, rapid, ponderous — and can be discovered in all these aspects in finding equivalents for strange and unEnglish words and thought forms. The Times Stephen Spender prize for poetry in translation was created partly because its founders felt that languages were less and less taught in schools and universities, and that translated literature was less and less read and talked about! At first, for
these reasons, it was confined to translators under the age of 30.1 am glad to see that this has been changed, with splendid results. The age-range ofthe entrants in 2005 was ten to 94. Twenty-seven languages were offered, from Anglo-Saxon to Urdu, from Japanese to Tagalog, from Greek and Latin to Persian, Welsh and Esperanto. There are prizes for the young — one for 14 and under, one for 18 and under, that encourage those at school to use the skills they are learning. But there is no age limit on learning about language. A splendidly intelligent part of the prize is that translators are asked for a commentary on their poem and form of translation. These are really illuminating. The whole idea is to make us think about language, poetry, and the English language in particular. A good translator must make everything problematic and strange, and then hear the poem singing again, Witfr a djife'rence.. ^,' ,,'.,,,

SELECTED POEMS by Carol Ann Duffy It's 21 years since the publication of Carol Ann Duffy's first collection. In that time Duffy — who last month won the T. S. Eliot Prize for her new collection, Rapture — has got under the nation's skin. Her books are taught on the school syllabus. She was a favourite for Poet Laureate. Prayer, which ends with the ordinary liturgy of the shipping forecast, is often requested on Poetry Please on BBC Radio 4. Selected Poems is drawn from her first four collections, Standing Female Nude (1985), Selling Manhattan (1987), The Other Country (1990) and Mean Time (1993) as well as The World's Wife (1999). Duffy is good at voices. She does comedy — the unimpressed teacher faced with a live poet in Head of EngUsh — and tragedy, in the agonised cry of the Middle Eastern woman in Shooting Stars. It's that capacity for the jokey crossed with serious observation that has made The World's Wife into a best seller (for poetry). But this survey also shows how she has made a voice of her own. She is excellent on desire, memory and loss. Miles Away begins simply — "I want you and you are not here" — attempts to conjure the imagination of the beloved, and ends with an image of self-reflection: "The stars are filming us for no one." Valentine is cynical — "Not a red rose or a satin heart./ I give you an onion" — but at its core is a truth: "Its fierce kiss will stay on your lips,/ possessive and faithful/ as we are,/ for as long as we are." But Carol Ann Duffy's real love is words. She likes their slippery possibilities. I had forgotten two poems collected here, both reflecting on her mother. Litany, like Prayer, makes a broken mantra out of the everyday to end with the childish error of a rude word and a mother's embarrassment. The Way My Mother Speaks distils nostalgia and pain into the chanting of two familiar phrases. In Duffy's hands poetry is both caustic and healing. MARGARET REYNOLDS Penguin, £8.99, offer £8.54 inc p&p, call 08701608080

Author: Joseph, Jenny
Title: Forget that old biddy in a red hat
Full_text:
Reviews Books
Poetry Bel Kooney Forget that old biddy in a red hat
jknny ;©sei»f! vfXWEMf* :;0iV:THJ*f*!|feS:;
EXTREME OF THINGS by Jenny Joseph SOONER JUDGE A BOOK by its cover than a poet by his or her most famous poem: the truth is conveyed more convincingly by one chosen picture than by a chorus of excited quotation. So the image on Jenny Joseph's new volume is the bleakly beautiful Winter Sea, by Paul Nash: an ocean of great white shards, jagged slices of cold, receding endlessly towards a dark horizon which lowers with the last vestiges of sullen light. No purple garments or red headgear would keep out this cold. Nor could they ever. What would all those who twice voted Warning as "the nation's favourite poem" make ofthe lonely little Giacometti people on the front of Selected Poems, or the buried terracotta soldiers of Xian on the front of Ghosts, each locked in perpetual readiness to engage with death? Such jacket pictures encapsulate a poetic voice as crisp, dry and elegiac as October leaves, drifting deep in corners. "I'm reading Jenny Joseph," you say. "Who?" they ask. "You know — 'When I am an old woman ...'" you prompt. "Oh yes... T will wear purple/ And a red hat that doesn't go ...'" they finish in triumph, relieved to be on familiar ground. This poem, about the persona she once described as "that annoying old woman", has been both a blessing and a curse for Joseph. As a stand-alone publication it has made her world famous,
yet it sits atop her work as might a wisp of scarlet feathers on the tormented head of beautiful, complex, black-clad Lady Dedlock. How could Joseph have predicted that this single poem, first published in 1974 when she was a young woman, would become a global phenomenon, inspiring more than 4,000 women in the United States and eight other countries to quaff wine and giggle in suitable titfers for regular meetings of the Red Hat Society? How could this most serious, oblique and accomplished poet have known that her little monologue would adorn teatowels, aprons, greeting cards, tote bags and T-shirts? Occasionally, Joseph has been prevailed on to attend a gathering of her fans; one wonders what those rollicking ladies bent on growing old disgracefully must make of the quintessentially English poet — so private and fiercely particular.* Still, Joseph's work does "run stick along the public railings" of the mind — challenging and often difficult. Carol Ann Duffy has said that she regrets the fact that Warning may not lead readers into the body of Joseph's work. Certainly they might admire the joyful love poetry (The sun has burst the sky and Bride to Groom) yet be daunted by the difficulty of much ofthe work. Like Duffy, Joseph often uses the device of the persona — the mask — to reveal and conceal; the influence of Browning's Dramatis Personae is clear, especially in poems such as Old Man Going (1974). Joseph's range may not be as broad as Duffy's, yet her ear for patterns of speech and thought transports her into the soul of a child as easily as that of an old man or woman. The new volume is a curious hybrid of old and new,
EX ^flSv: s Wt m k f >4
'Perennial themes of loss haunt her workf
Alive and kicking: Joseph's bestknown poem is far behind her
brought together with reason. She has selected specific poems from earlier volumes to illuminate the new work, and the two "halves" are bridged by lyrics from the long-out-ofprint Persephone, which is a profound meditation on loss. The selections, concentrating as many do on perennial themes of loss and haunting, serve as a shop window for Joseph's talent, from the technical rhyming brilliance of Birth copulation death to the elemental vision of By Lake Huron in Winter, which makes
you flip back to the Nash on the cover. She begins with A chair in my house, after Gwen John, which contains two lines that perfectly encapsulate the spirit ofthis poet: "Here I pare this little stick of words/ To keep away the crowds." An early poem, In a dark stone, directly links to the last poem in the volume (for me the finest) Such is the sea, returning us to Joseph's preoccupations with memory, with transience and with layers of history — the detritus of existence compressed into value by
time, as insignificant shards are uncovered by an archeologist with joy. In Exody the inevitability of change, decay and grief is buffered by the Keatsian insight that knowledge, that joy and beauty are permanent, it is we who change. These poems are hauntings — revenants which console even as they force you to face the extreme. Bloodaxe, £8.95; 128pp 0 £8.50 (free p&p) 0870 1608080 www.timesonline.co.u-k/booksfirst

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Let me count the ways
Full_text:
Books Ghristmas books
Let me count the ways
1965 TIME INC 5$ * ^ ^siii
Poetry Rachel Campbell-Johnston
WHAT IS POETRY FOR IF not writing about love? But that does not mean that sensibilities have to turn soppy. Carol Ann Duffy's latest collection Rapture (Picador £12.99; offer £11.69) takes the reader on an ecstatic rollercoaster: soaring and swooping and holding one's breath; hurtling, heart thumping through the complexities of human feeling before eventually slowing and finally getting off. This is a book that demands to be read from cover to cover. Individually, each poem sparkles. But together — as they run the course from first longing to final loss — they form what must be one of the most intimately intense sequences since Pablo Neruda's
100 Love Sonnets. This work is quintessentially contemporary yet tackles unflinchingly poetry's most fundamental theme. A similarly challenging vision of love lies at the core of a quirky new collection. The Tenth Muse (Carcanet £12.95; offer £11.66) is an anthology of poems by modern writers selected by the "muse" figures that inspired and criticised, interpreted and supported them. Elspeth Barker picks out a dozen or so pieces from the career of her late husband George; Mfanwy Thomas leafs through the repertoire of her father Edward. This collection is far more than some gimmicky poetic take on Desert Island Discs. Sometimes the sense of intimacy is so intense
that it burns. Snippets of classical wisdom are served up as conveniently as quotations in Sherod Santos's new translation Greek Lyric Poetry (Norton £15.99; offer £14.39). This rekindles the embers of verse forms that are sometimes seen as so difficult that they are left for dead. The beginner might be inspired by the simplicity and the sense of refreshed relevance, but the classical scholar will undoubtedly be enraged. If you want to tackle the poetic canon I strongly recommend Camille Paglia's Break, Blow, Burn (Pantheon Books £20; offer £18) instead. The provocative academic broaches 43 of what she considers "the world's best poems" with com-
bative passion, intellectual concision and a deep reverence for craft. You would definitely want her in your book club. The Collected Poems of George Mackay Brown (John Murray £35; offer £31.50), the Orkney bard, is a must-have. Living amid the "'small green world" of his native islands all his life, he found inspiration in the wonder of the everyday. He transforms the mundane with a luminous lyricism. He picks out his words like polished stones from the beach. The reader examines them amid the silences that his poems treasure as much as speech. In a sense, Alice Oswald could be seen as a successor to Mackay Brown. Her work is
Balm for the soul: Louis Armstrong looks after his lips in an image from As / See It: The Photographs of John Leongard (Thames & Hudson £18.95; offer £17.05)
deeply rooted in the wilds of Dartmoor where she lives. In Woods etc (Faber £12.99; offer £11.69) she throws the windows of imagination open. A fresh breeze billows in. Oswald doesn't so much capture the andscape in her poetry as set t loose. Another distinctly individual but far from traditional voice emerges as Mark Haddon follows up his Whitbread prize-winning novel The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time with a collection of poems: The Talking Horse and the Sad Girl and the Vilage Under the Sea (Picador £12.99; offer £11.69). This sly, exuberant, lugubrious, exotic collection is a mishmash of anything from lyrics through ullabies to spoofs. It in turn amuses and irritates. But it is seldom dull. For catching up with the contemporary, The Forward Book of Poetry (Forward Pubishing £8.99; offer £8.54) provides a useful annual reference. Representing anyone from the established writer to the newcomers, it points the reader in myriad directions. This year the prize for the best debut collection was awarded to Helen Farish for the tensely charged lyrics of Intimates (Cape £9; offer £8.55) while David Harsent's Legion (Faber £8.99; offer £8.54) took the prize for best collection with poems as dark and disturbing as his crime fiction. Meanwhile Michael Symmons Roberts with Corpus (Cape £8; offer £7.60) took the Whitbread Prize with a collection described as "a poetic autopsy" and George Szirtes the T. S. Eliot for his virtuoso performance in Reel (Bloodaxe £8.95; offer £8.54). But if you prefer simply to have fun with poetry you could dip into David Bader's One Hundred Great Books in Haiku (Penguin £9.99; offer £9.49). Let one person read out the ridiculous Zen-style summary the rest guess which

Author: Baddiel, David
Title: 'Why is Philip Larkin most novelists' favourite poet?'
Full_text:
Up front Looks
David Baddiel 'Why is Philip Larkin most novelists' favourite poet?1
LAST WEEK, MY COLLEAGUE ON THIS page wrote a piece about poetry and how it functions for her as a tonic for the soul. I feel this too, but recently had my own affection for poetry challenged by the poet Nick Laird, after a panel that I was on at the Toronto International Festival of Authors, when I talked about how much I loved Philip Larkin. Nick, himself also a novelist, said to me afterwards: "Novelists, they always love Larkin." By which I think he was not being negative about Larkin, but was making a point about how many types of poetry there are. Novelists love Larkin because he is a narrative poet: not narrative in the Victorian, Longfellow, telling-a-story-in-185-stanzas sense, but in that he tends to describe concrete experience, things that he has seen — a tourist poster for Prestatyn, some weddings from a train, the trees coming into leaf — and then alchemises that into something larger, into poetry. He is, in a sense, prosaic, partly in his subject matter, but also in that the points he makes could be conveyed in prose; they just happen to be conveyed much more majestically in his poetry. There is, however, another type of poetry — a poetry whose greats, interestingly, are all American: William Carlos Williams, Ezra Pound, Wallace Stevens — where no one experience is described, or conceit outlined: rather the words brushstroke a mood, traverse ambiguities of meaning, and generally create an effect near to the condition of music, or maybe, following the American thought, the condition of abstract Expressionist art. From a poet's point of view, this kind of poetry is perhaps purer, in that its "message", for want of a better word, is not distillable into prose: it can exist only as poetry. This type of poetry can be troubling for novelists, or people — such as Tom Cox, who also wrote a piece in last week's Books about poetry, but about how he has never got it — who prefer to read novels, because, fundamentally, they don't know what it means; which of course, they shouldn't, as what the poet is trying to do is move beyond the convention of meaning. However, I also think that for me liking Larkin, and poets of his school, may be something of a reaction against the type of poetry that I wrote bucketloads of during adolescence. Here's one that made it to fhe school magazine, called Lipstick And Eye-Liner: Melancholic, Looked out of a window,
*■■'- -* '*V'*^*f'v».v/
Thought "I hate mankind" Realised "Misanthrope" And laughed. I almost broke all the windows in my house. Bollocks, of course, but that's what poetry as an adolescent is for: expressing all the bollocks in your soul. I have written poems as an adult, but I am slightly embarrassed about this — that's one of the weird things about poetry, unless you're a professional poet, even as a writer one is somewhat ashamed about it, forever tarnished by the shadow of sixth-form efforts. The way one gets round this embarrassment, I've noticed, is through versification. If I write poetry now, I try to write sonnets, as if formal technique cancels out immaturity, which it sort of does, as I'd never have bothered with all the pfaff of pentameters and "abba"s when I was 16. Incidentally, Stephen Fry's new book, The Ode Less Travelled, puts the case brilliantly for the employment of formal techniques in the writing of verse, demonstrating how forcing your poetic message into the discipline of rhythm and rhyme will create effects in and of themselves, whatever you are trying to say. My friend Peter Bradshaw, the film critic, once did this most effectively by writing a series of "serious"
limericks, such as this one: An Hiroshima victim called Raoul Went stumbling around in a cowl In this grim garb encased He viewed carnage and waste And felt misery and pain in his soul. What's brilliantly funny about this is that it uses only the brain's established reaction to the particular tum-te-tum of limericks to create the classically comic juxtaposition of bleak and absurd — a juxtaposition which, in this case, is simply that between meaning and rhythm. Anyway, my point is, that as you get older, perhaps one's poetic tastes move away from "pure" poetry and towards prose poetry, or prosaic poetry: good solid stuff, basically, where you kind of know more or less what it's about. This has certainly been the case for me, or it was, until a friend happened to show me this poem, on the website of a poet named Len Webster: Late night TV is not generally for me. The sight of Baddiel and Skinner on a set Never rouses me to ecstasy Or, at least, it hasn't yet. Yes. Now I think I might come back to believing that poetry should be diffuse, ambiguous and impossible for the average reader to understand.

Author: Gatti, Tom
Title: Don't miss this Pop Idol for poets
Full_text:
Dont miss this Pop Idol for poets
THESE DAYS, EVERY pursuit has its competition — and its prize. Wannabe pop stars clamour at the gates of Pop Idol and The X-Factor, undiscovered beauties sashay down the catwalk of Britain's Next Top Model, aspiring novelists rush their manuscripts off to Richard and Judy. Next week, performance poetry joins the fray in a tournament boldly dubbed The Contenders, in which five poets will unleash their best lines at the South Bank Centre in London. The winner will walk away with £10,000 of Arts Foundation cash. When the word poetry is coupled with "performance", even many poetry lovers would cross the road to avoid it, fearing an unholy combination of adolescent angst, NewAge nonsense and down-withthe-kids pretension. Some
have gone further in their dislike. Discussing poetry slams — competitive events where performers have three minutes to impress the audience — the American critic Harold Bloom concluded: "This isn't even silly; it is the death of art." But performance poetry is exactly the opposite. The first great works of literature — the Iliad and the Odyssey — are products of an oral tradition in which poems were sung rather than written down; a tradition which also gave us Beowulf. Rhythm, alliteration, repetition (and later rhyme) grabbed the audience's attention and helped the speaker to remember their words just as they do today. The Anglo-Saxon great hall of Beowulf might seem a long way from the Get Me High Lounge of 1980s Chicago (where slam poetry originated), but those
mead-fuelled bards were just as competitive as their 20th-century descendants. Now, performance poetry is all around us: from the rapidfire urban vignettes of Dizzee Rascal, to the vaudeville revival led by clubs such as Duckie in South London, to the spudsand-specs comedy ofthe veteran poet John Hegley, (presenter of next week's competition). And that's before you get into the real "scene", where there are slams, gigs and workshops every day of the week. Part of its appeal, as Geraldine Collinge, director of Apples & Snakes (the organisation behind The Contenders) explains, lies in its directness: "At the best spoken-word nights there's a unique feeling that performers and audience are all in it together." Its roots are so diverse, she
says, that not only are the negative stereotypes wrong, but the term "performance poetry" is inadequate: "When you've got Jamaican dub poets, standup comedians, Nigerian praise singers and solo storytellers rubbing shoulders, it makes for an exciting mix." True to promise, the shortlisted poets are an intriguingly motley bunch: at The Contenders you might encounter sardonic Yorkshire wit, shocking racist violence, melodies from a thumb piano and beauty from a tea-bag. If only the same could be said for The X-Factor. TOM GATTI The Contenders, Thursday December 1, Purcell Room, South Bank Centre, London SEI (0870 3828000; www.rfh.orguk)

Author: Haddon, Mark
Title: The Curious incident of the bestseller and the poet
Full_text:
Cheltenham Looks
Poetry Meel Mukherjee The curious incident of the bestseller and the poet
^jullAfi vWzii Hiepaii
THE TALKING HORSE AND THE SAD GIRL AND THE VILLAGE UNDER THE SEA by Mark Haddon WHO WOULD HAVE thought that the stupendously original and imaginative achievement that was The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time would return to haunt its creator, Mark Haddon? It was inevitable that his next work was going to be measured against that extraordinary book, so the sidestepping involved in writing a slim volume of verse with another long streamer of a title doesn't afford as much insulation as one could have hoped for. The Talking Horse and the Sad Girl and the Village under the Sea, like most volumes of
poetry, is an uneven production: there are lyrics, sonnets, lullabies, reworkings of seven of Horace's odes from the first book; even a poetic precis of a John Buchan novel in 13 "chapters", a prologue and an envoi. Haddon certainly takes this new direction in his published career seriously. Poetry, he seems to be telling us, is his new vocation. The send-off that opens the book, deliberately echoing Chaucer, is both a programmatic statement of intent and purpose and a general figuring of the world of poetry and its makers. Haddon is quite taken with these occasionally metapoetical exercises: Horace's sixth ode (Average Fool; a pre-emptive, irritating piece of self-congratulatory clever-clever piece of prose called This Poem is Certificate 18; a special pleading, Poets, arguing for the privileged, precious apartness of poets, all stand evidence to a selfconscious, reflexive meditation on not just poetry but also on what constitutes a poet. It is a shame, then, that the first poem, Go, Litel Bok,
should contain the first sounding of a staccato rhythmical clunkiness that mars so many of the subsequent poems: "The fire I have felt beneath your shirts. These cloistersJ Red mullet with honey. This surprisingly large/ slab of Perspex. Your hands are on me. But this man/ is another man." Such short phrases and sentences, ending with a full stop, spread like an infection through the volume... That sleepless nightJ This sleepless night." "I walked. You walked/ ... This steak is very good. Sit down." This. Calamitous. Linemongering. This mangling. Of end-stopped lines. Is not poetry. My other big reservation is the arch air of knowingness that hangs over the book. The allusiveness remains undigested, as a forum for showing off, never an organic, assimilated thought process driving the motor of poetry. In the transcreation of Horace's odes, the suave irony of the Augustan master has been flattened out, the pleats
of sly, slippery wit shaken out and hung out on a pedestrian clothesline, the fugitive and constantly shifting distances between voice and persona commuted to a foreclosed exercise. Various poets stalk Haddon's poems — Paterson, Doty, Kleinzahler, Farley, to name a few — but instead of singing in the unmistakably characteristic voices that they do, Haddon seems to be feeling his way still towards a tonal stability that he can make all his own. But there is much to celebrate, too. There are lyrics such as Trees, New Year's Day, Midas, where mood, tone, diction all fuse into an extraordinary bud of meaning, tight with precision and thought, waiting to unfurl into whatever shape your mind will choose to give it at any time. Great White and The River-Car manage the impossibly difficult feat of making their radiant simplicity articulate both an immediate reality and a more amorphous and indeterminate beyond or beneath. If
JONNY HANNAH V J-^ ,1 — -
only his muse didn't fall into the jerky stop-start motion of a nightmarish traffic jam on the M23, and he loosened his lines to let them breathe more., Picador, £12.99; 96pp m £11.69 (free p&p) 08701608080 www.timesonline.co.uk/booksfirst

Author: May, Derwent
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
review books
POETRY DERWENT MAY
Here is a remarkable phenomenon: the stiff upper lip has migrated from British army officers to women poets writing in English. Helen Farish, in her collection Intimates (Cape £9; offer £7.65), is an outstanding example. Many of her poems are about love difficulties, and she feels the pain — but she writes about it with a laconic, jesting air: preferable the flat half of the bed to your hand on my breast
one night, the next on someone else's. Her seemingly throwaway lines let the pain come through because of the subtle expressiveness of her pauses. There are also some happy love poems, with the sex in them breezy but delicate, and some unusual poems about the quiet abundance of mid-life, which she sees as being like an ocean, "uncrashing, slowed/ by the thick coat of day on its back". How imaginatively that embodies a comfortable human
slowness. She is a good poet. In Llfemask (Bloodaxe, £7.95; offer £6.75) Jackie Kay adopts the same tough stance towards love and its loss: The last bit of civilisation happened in the kitchen, where, however much you were bitching at me or me you, I still asked you if you wanted a cup of tea or coffee and you occasionally, not so often, asked me. She wants to live "an eye for an eye; a kiss for a kiss". But she often cracks and lets her emotions burst out. She is a black woman who was
adopted by Scottish parents, and the view of life which that has given her is handled here plainly and powerfully — both the strangeness of her fate and the joy and grief she has found in it. Open the anthology Tower Poets, edited by Peter McDonald (Tower Poetry, £5 from towerpoetry.org.uk), and there again, in Olivia Cole's poems, the resolutely strong note rings straight out: / stood in your shower, how many times? Well, so many times... Olivia Cole is one of seven poets here, all associated with
Tower Poetry, which emanates from Christ Church, Oxford, with the help of a legacy to the college. Everyday spoken rhythms, deftly used, are characteristic of most of these poets. Caroline Bird is witty about love: one poem begins "I'm sorry for waking you up 12 times in one night/ to polish my flipflops". All the other five contributors — Frances Leviston, Anna Lewis, Helen Mort, Tim Smith-Laing and Matthew Sperling — also show distinct talent. The anthology The Thunder Mutters: 101 Poems for the Planet, edited by Alice Oswald
(Faber, £12.99; offer £10.39), could not be more different. Alice Oswald is interested in poetry that "connects the earth to our hands". She wants the strong feel of "nature pulling us back" and will admit to her book none of the pastorals or nostalgic poems about the countryside that the English have so often loved. There are some excellent poems here, but certainly nothing remotely laconic. It is all creaking, pushing, shouting and singing. To buy at offer price, call Books First on 08701608080

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELLJOHNSTON
O^^'^^o-^i ■:■,-. ";A''.
"Wordsworth had a picturesque view of landscape which I hate," Alice Oswald once said in an interview. "He writes about it in huge imprisoning sentences. You can only create meaning if you have physically put yourself through something." It is this physical engagement that the reader senses in her past two volumes (the last won the T. S. Eliot Prize in 2002) and now again, in her latest work Woods etc, which will be published by Faber this month (£12.99; offer £10.39). To open the pages is an almost magical experience. Oswald throws the windows of the imagination open. A fresh breeze billows in, shaking dust from the curtains, scattering light and freshness and stirring up raptures. She doesn't so much capture the landscape in her poetry as set it loose. The reader can almost smell the "last glow of rain dead in the ground", taste "the outline of ice", hear the river's "cloning loops its/ frays and flumes/ and vacillations and/ clings and rips/ and cloops and/ splashy cleats". This is a poetry that seeps through the capillaries of the senses, irrigating our responses. It stirs, as T. S. Eliot — a strong influence on Oswald, would have put it — our "dull roots with spring rain". Guided by instinct Oswald
moves through an elemental world that is miles from the hype of postmodern urban hip. This is the realm of sea and woods and stone and stars. It is a place of aural traditions, of nursery rhyme repetitions and balladeer's rhythms, of the playful shifting patterns of quatrains and couplets. She places a fingertip on the pulse of tradition; the reader feels the quickening that proves it is still very much alive. "This is a story of life in the age of Mandelson" declares the dust jacket of David Herd's Mandelson! Mandelson! A Memoir (Carcanet, £7.95; offer £6.75). And, the question is, declares the writer in an opening disclaimer: "Are you happy?" What follows is a rambling, irreverent outpouring. This collection of poems — from a sonnet to a villanelle, from a Poundian haiku (impishly stolen) to a Japanese Noh play, from solid prose to the poetic equivalent of a scribbled Post-It note — is jumbled and energetic. They can be discursive or elliptical, formally punctilious or free as the flow of thought, chatty or terse. They are confiding but undercutting, provocative but playful, haphazard but probing. The poems offer what could either be faux homage to Mandelson or an exasperated ticking off. This "memoir", as its author David Herd describes it, has all the half-innocent, half-sinister air of the new Labour icon himself. As a whole it is as long and fragmented and erratically contiguous as a stream of consciousness. It is certainly self-indulgent. If you are prepared to indulge the author, you might find that you have a bit of fun. But don't expect straight answers. This rant is as lucid as a spindoctor's speech. The work In Which the Poet and his Wife Address the State of the Nation makes the point. "And I remember thinking that you might have been right,/ But it was late,/ And your meaning escaped me." A quiet debut is made by Hamish Robinson, currently the poet in residence at the Wordsworth Trust. In The Gift Returned (Wordsworth Trust, £5; mail order 015394 35544) Robinson displays a formal accomplishment, a mastery of rhyme and metre, a delicate susceptibility particularly to the understated domestic detail. He is not a poet who feels that he has to shout to make his voice heard. Instead, quietly confident, he speaks with a level-headed eloquence. He knows how to create the pauses which fill up with thought. But, above all, there is a feeling of directness in his form of address. It persuades the reader to listen carefully. And it is this careful listening that is Robinson's gift. El To buy Woods etc or Mandelson! Mandelson! A Memoir at offer price, call Books First (08701608080)

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
review books
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON
Philip Larkin is hardly remembered as a benignly avuncular figure. His vision was sceptical and tough. And when he focused it on himself it could be pretty unforgiving. His first three collections of typewritten poems were contemptuously destroyed. The few works that survived were scored with abusive comments. And yet, as Faber publishes his Early Poems and Juvenilia (£25; offer £20), the Larkin fan will still find that he has a pretty fat book — indeed, positively massive by the anorexic standards of his later slim volumes. Larkin in his youth was prolific; one of our leanest postwar talents was honed by near fanatical practice. Before he went up to Oxford, Larkin penned more than 200 poems in the space of three years. The shaping influences of Auden, of Yeats and Blake can be detected. And yet all the signs of an idiosyncratic development can be seen: the lack of illusion, the unconsoled outlook, the tenderness lying latent in intense observation, the loves and affections, our need for which lies implicit in so much later verse. The juvenilia of Larkin is of a calibre to make the reader question the overstuffed, second-class profusion of poetry published today. Here are works of a moving delicacy, impressionable sensibility and subtle understanding. Here are early love poems of a passion and tenderness that make you wonder if Larkin kept them in much the same spirit as the old woman keeps her love songs in his mature poem Love Songs in Age. I love the way John Burnside looks at the world. He doesn't just look: he watches. He sees into secret spaces that lie somewhere between the hidden and the revealed. In his
latest collection The Good Neighbour (Cape, £9; offer £7.65) he dwells on the question of man's place within his world and society. He traces our intricate connections with others that can somehow connect us back to our own selves again. Burnside moves like some "shapeshifting" shaman, "half-flesh, half-dream", towards an almost — but not quite — visionary apprehension. He perceives that "wider rootedness that, as a kind/ of shorthand, we will sometimes call the soul". But language cannot dissect sense, or paraphrase feeling. "I know the names of almost/ nothing" he writes in a poem written after the anatomist Vesalius. Burnside crafts a poetry as precise in its detail, as subtle in its perceptions, as respectful in its attentions as the blade of a brain surgeon's scalpel. And yet, that which it touches turns out not to be mere physical matter. He stirs strange spirits. You breathe in these poems like you breathe in an atmosphere — and then slowly ponder them before you exhale. A "proper poet" was apparently how G. S. Fraser praised Robert Nye. You sense what he means as you drift about in Nye's collection The Rain and the Glass (Greenwich Exchange, www.greenex.co.uk; £9.95, offer £8.96). This is a poet you know you can trust. You can hear the whisper — or sometimes the whoop — of his inspiration. You can feel his poems rising slowly up through your senses. You sense the slow fall of thoughts dropping lightly as petals. Nye can take anything from dancing hares to copulating frogs as his subject matter. He captures their spirit inside patterns and rhythms and sound. Read Words on the Wind, the opening and presumably the most recent poem in a collection that ends with his first work (and the one that informed him of his lifelong vocation). It is a delightful meditation on the threaded simplicity of the poet's life.

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
books
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON
Send a book instead of a bouquet. That seems to be the message as Everyman publishes a new poetry collection, Motherhood. The launch of this latest addition to its library of "pocket poets" has been carefully tied in with tomorrow's Mothering Sunday. The palm-sized package certainly looks likely to appeal to the gift market with its hardback binding, gold place-marker and pretty dust-jacket picture of a Mary Cassatt pastel. Inside is a mixed bunch of poems. Like the florist's selection in which the exotic and home-grown are combined through some shared colour scheme, this collection brings together under the broad thematic embrace of motherhood works as disparate as a 10th-century Japanese lament for the loss of a daughter to an impish Stevie Smith ditty. A core selection of well-known pieces — the haunting incantation of Louis Macneice's Prayer Before Birth, for instance, or Sylvia Plath's vivid Morning Song, or William Blake's dark Infant Sorrow — are the showy blooms around which a number of lesser-known works cluster. Here, for instance, are the sort of poems which tend not to make it into period collections. Lady Elizabeth Egerton's On My Boy Henry, is a heart-rending 17th-century commemoration of a lost baby which, though it borrows heavily from a more famous work by Ben Jonson, somehow seems all the more tender precisely for that. Or here is Augusta Webster struggling in the elaborate language of her Victorian era to evoke complex maternal feelings. The principal emphasis, however, is on the modern and contemporary — with a strong American slant. Here is a range of richly perceptive, sharply observant and often almost painfully sensitive poems that include Anne Sexton's jubilant evocation of
the security of the mother's lap, "your legs that bounce me up and down,/ your dear nylon-covered legs" to Eric Ormsby's slightly perturbing description of the clipping of his grandmother's toenails, "scissoring the wrinkled horn of nail/ with snipping shears until the pale/ translucencies of toenail ribboned off" to Chinua Achebe's lacerating portrait of a Mother in a Refugee Camp. But this book has the same problem as that bunch of flowers in the corner shop tomorrow. It needs weeding. It has been padded out with the literary equivalent of gypsophila. In the attempt to represent a few more famous male writers a terrible Thomas Hardy has been included, for instance. Ted Hughes is at his worst. If editors wanted to represent him why didn't they choose his bewitching Full Moon and Little Frieda? Focus on the strongest pieces — on works such as George Barker's To My Mother, a poem as vivid and bold and direct as a bunch of bright daffodils plucked squeakyfresh from the garden and plonked down in a jam jar on the kitchen table. El Motherhood: Poems About Mothers, edited by Carmela Ciuraru (Everyman's Library, £9.99, offer £8.49)

Author: Winterson, Jeanette
Title: My Choice
Full_text:
JEANETTE WINTERSON MY CHOICE

His new book, The Book of Shadows (Picador, £12.99; offer £10.39), is an intriguing mixture of prose, poetry, aphorism, commentary, joined together by Paterson's particular use of language and his personal sensibility. A real writer is recognisable — they sound like themselves, but they say what we struggle to say. Don Paterson's voice is his own and ours. His collection of art reviews, Hang-ups (BBC Books, £30; offer £24), combines all the weight of his historical authority with an immediate sense of why a particular art work is worth attention (or not). David Mitchell's Cloud Atlas (Sceptre, £16.99 offer £13.59) is beautiful, brilliant, brave, and what a relief to find a serious book that relishes experiment. Fiction at its best redefines its own territory. We need writers who will take risks with their work. Risk is the

Author: Goodwin, Daisy
Title: Birth of a notion
Full_text:
Christmas
POETRY DAISY GOODWIN Birth of a notion
i "• 7 7 If*--- A «::;'<f%;|
the number of volumes of poetry published rises annually. Perhaps these facts are not unconnected — readers may well be daunted by such an abundance of new collections. One place to start is Newborn by Kate Clanchy (Picador, £12.99; offer £10.39). These vivid, tender poems form a lyrical alternative to all those bossy childcare manuals. The collection flows like a novel through conception, pregnancy and birth — capturing the gradual but ineluctable changes that come with motherhood. Snow Leopard by Ruth Padel (Chatto and Windus, £7.99; offer £6.79) is, for me, her best collection to date. The Amer Leopard of the eponymous poem pads through a failed relationship along Wardour Street by way of Aztec temples and Beauty and the Beast. A classicist, Padel is breathtakingly confident in the way she samples Greek myths in the most mundane modern settings, as in the poem Orpheus' Imagination as a Sub-
It is a striking paradox that while sales of poetry decline year on year,
terranean Car Park. Shortlisted for the T. S. Eliot prize (the poetry equivalent ofthe Booker), this collection, which among many treasures has a fabulously tangy sequence called "Sex, Scars and Alligators", must be a strong contender. It will have to beat The Tree House by the Scottish poet Kathleen Jamie (Picador, £8.99; offer £7.64), which has already collected the Forward Prize. Jamie's book deals with our edgy, vital, fragile relationship with the environment symbolised by the Tree House ofthe title — a place where human culture perches on the edge of the natural world. At once lyrical and disturbing, this is one book that deserves to break through the "poetry barrier" and reach the widest possible audience. The 40th anniversary of Rachel Carson's book about the effects of DDT, Silent Spring, has provoked an anthology called Wild Reckoning edited by John Burnside and Maurice Riordan (Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, £7.50; offer £6.38). This disconcerting collection pulls together poems about the essential fragility of the natural world, from Wordsworth's nimbyish rant
On the Projected Kendal and Windermere Railway to Primavera, a specially commissioned poem by Robin Robertson on the accelerating effects of global warming on the seasons. Our place in the world and the sense of perspective that comes from observing nature is a perennial theme of the American poet Mary Oliver whose selected poems, Wild Geese, are published by Bloodaxe (£7.95; offer £6.76). Her sardonic poem Farm Country is the best description of the reality, as opposed to the Country Living ideal, of rural life that I know. Equally dark are the New and Selected Poems of Dennis O'Driscoll (Anvil, £11.95) whose work in the Irish Customs and Excise has resulted in some mordantly funny poems about the ecology of the office. Finally, for anyone daunted by the torrent of new poetry titles, I recommend membership of the Poetry Book Society (www.poetrybooks.co.uk), which for the price of a few airport thrillers will send you the four best collections ofthe year.
Daisy Goodwin is the editor of Poems to Last a Lifetime (HarperCollins, £18.99; offer £15.19)
