Author: Wheatley, Jane
Title: Booming voices
Full_text:
POETRY JANE WHEATLEY Booming voices
The spirit of Ted Hughes resonates in Arvon's prize anthology
The man who won the Arvon International Poetry Prize (and £5,000) on Tuesday night was Joe Kane, a softly spoken, bearded ceramicist from Donegal. He said he had Ted Hughes to thank for his success. Kane had been in his bathroom reading a book by Hughes, aimed at teenagers, in which the poet advised tiie use
as bang, crash and click. "It was like a gift," says Kane now. "I ran at speed down two flights of stairs to my writing bench and started on a poem. It came as a whole, and very quickly." The spirit of Ted Hughes was everywhere that night; inevitably because he was a champion of Arvon, a charity dedicated to the encouragement of writing, but also because in the room was his old friend Nick Short, a former chairman of the Duncan Lawrie Bank, which sponsors the competition. Short and Hughes often fished together and Short, now in his seventies, recalled a bitterly cold winter's day when the two of them were joined on the river bank IfJbyiMichael Hprdern.' -_• \
"Ted got something on his line," recalls Short, "and then handed it to Michael to land who said, 'My God, it's frozen solid.' In fact, Ted had nipped home and got the fish out of the freezer for a joke. He wrote a poem about it later which I still have." There were more than 5,000 entries for the Arvon prize and the judges, Tom Paulin, Jean Sprackland and Jamie McKendrick, read them all, arriving at a final line-up of six prize winners and 13 highly commended entries. These 19 make up this year's anthology. Popular themes emerged among the entries, said Sprackland — notably 9/11, the Iraq war and the quality of lighten Eurppean cjties --i
» WStMl
but were avoided by the winners in favour of less monumental subjects. In her poem, Hold-all (Aircrew), Anne Berkeley addresses her father's much-used hold-all bag, veteran of countless international flights: "ynpack for,rae again,the*
<NEWPAGE>
doll from Malta,/ Panpipes from Nicosia and tangerines from Tripoli,/Still with their leaves, still cold from 50,000 feet/Even empty, I doubt I can carry you." Gregory Leadbetter recalls the micro moments of war: "A Lmir_£ lifted two men/
into the air and put them back/ all wrong." Such simplicity doesn't come easily; Joe Kane says he "revises and revises and revises" and didn't think of submitting any work until he had been practising for several years. Other prize-winners'-
were equally dedicated; as the Arvon director, Stephanie Anderson, observed: "To aspire to write a great poem is as hard and as good as it gets." The 2004 Arvon Anthology is £7.99. (www.arvonfoundation. org; 020-7931 '7611) •-<•>'■''

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Writing in tongues
Full_text:
www.timesonline.co.uk/weekend books review
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON Writing in tongues The Times Stephen Spender prize for a poem in translation has produced startling results
Today The Times celebrates new poetic talent by announcing the winners of the Times Stephen Spender prize. This annual award for poetry in translation was launched this year to encourage a new generation of writers to pursue the path that Spender took when he made the imaginative worlds of Schiller and Rilke accessible to non-German speakers through his skilled and sensitive translations. "Judging a poetry competition is a tricky task," said Susan Bassnett, Professor of Comparative Literature at the University of Warwick and one of the four judges. "But judging a poetry-in-translation competition is even trickier." The new works have to be weighed against the originals so that the translators' strategies can be assessed, the authenticity of their final product appraised. The breadth and the calibre of the submissions were impressive — sending a message of hope, Bassnett suggests, to beleaguered language teachers. The winning entries, from Latin, Anglo-Saxon, French, Russian, Italian and Romanian, were decided on by a remarkable consensus that bears testimony to their quality. Mark Leech, the winner in the over-18 category, chose that finest of Old English religious poems, The Dream ofthe Rood. Preserving a sense ofthe original's ancient mystery and a feeling for its alliterative muscle, he captures the terse intensity of the Rood's address to the dreamer while loosening
the original's rigid metrical patterns to make the poem clearer, more accessible. "My only regret," he said, "is that the strict rules I set myself prevented me from experimenting more with the verse in order to explore different aspects of its meanings." In the 18-and-under category J. C. H. Potts won for his translation from the Latin of the impassionedly decadent, frenziedly psychological Poem 63 by Catallus. This tells ofthe demise of Attis, so handsome that his grandmother Cybele desired him, warning him never to marry because she wanted him for herself. When Attis fell in love with a king's daughter, Cybele was possessed by If IS THE Alii OF such insane jealousy that she made him mad, sending him running, deranged, through wild mountains where, eventually, he castrated himself. "The impact of the original — and the hardest aspect totranslate — is the way it recreates through sound and imagery the Bacchic dance, with its interlinked motifs and connotations of frenzied, orgiastic, drugged-up, esoteric rites," Potts said. Influenced by Seamus Heaney's Beowulf, he said, he chose to render Catallus's verbal effects "in an alliter-
ative, almost Anglo-Saxon style, trying to capture some of the frenzy and dislocation of the Original with tortured polysyllables, harsh alliteration and compression from 16 syllables to the five-stress sprung line to vary pace and metre". The runners-up were: Adrian Pascu for a piece that introduces us to tiie poetic craft and ironic sophistication of the Romanian writer Ion Minulescu; Holly Hughes for her flowing rendition of Victor Hugo's Tomorrow, at Down; Paul Howard for his dialectical version of the work of a practically unknown Italian, G. G. Belli; and Sasha Dugdale for the intricate clarity of her translation of Elena Schvarts's Memory's Sideways Glance from the Russian. To translate amounts to far more than a mere understanding of vocabularies and grammatical constructions. The most inspired should be hailed as poets in their own rights. "With Poesie to open Poesie" was Chapman's declared aim as he first approached Homer. The best translations demand not only attention to grammar and syntax, to rhythms and forms; they involve ah intricate and subtle interweaving of identities a sense of complicity and almost mystical connection. A translation is a resurrection, notjust ofthe body, but ofthe spirit of the work. The winners can be read at www.stephen-spender.org

Author: Manson, Shirley
Title: Life lines
Full_text:
\ icu' books
Life lines
The Staying Alive anthology became one of Britain's most popular poetry books, selling more than 76,000 copies. Now a sequel, Being Alive, is about to hit the shelves. We asked some admirers to pick their favourites
ANDREW MOTION
The best thing we can say about the index to a poetry anthology is that it's reliable. But the index to Being Alive does more than that it quietly advertises one of the mysteries of late 20th-century poetry — by putting, after the name of the contributor Rosemary Tonks, "b. London, 1932: disappeared 1970s". Disappeared! What happened? Because I admire her poems, I've been tying to find out for years. She published some fiction and two collections of poems during the late-middle of the century, lived in Hampstead for a while, then... Well, according to some people she became a Sufi. Others say she entered a closed order. Others imagine her footloose and anonymous, travelling the wide world. In any event, no trace of her seems to survive — apart from the writing she left behind. It's a bewitching story, and seems all the more fascinating for the challenge it makes to our cult of celebrity. Not only that the poems are seriously interesting, too — often Frenchified and/or fruity, hectic, and with a strangely irritable eroticism. Story of a Hotel Room is a good example. If enough editors put her in their anthologies a publisher might re-issue her collected works. It would be worth it she's a distinctive and authentic voice They might even track her down — if she's still alive, and willing to be found again. Andrew Motion is the Poet Laureate. His novel The Invention of Dr Cake is published by Faber Story of a Hotel Room By Rosemary Tonks Thinking we were safe — insanity! We went in to make love. Ail the same Idiots to trust the little hotel bedroom. Then hi the gloom... ... And who does not know that pair of shutters With the awkward hook on them All screeching whispers? Very well then, in the gloom We set about acquiring one another Urgently! But on a temporary basis Only as guests — just guests of one another's senses. But idiots to feel so safe you hold back nothing Because the bed of cold, electric linen Happens to be illicit... To make love as well as that is ruinous. Londoner, Parisian, someone should have warned us That without permanent intentions You have absolutely no protection — If the act is dean, authentic, sumptuous, The concurring deep love of the heart FoBows the naked work, profoundly moved by it. It has not been possible to confirm copyright clearance for this poem
A. S. BYATT
Dorothy Nimmo's poems are wicked and precise, funny with a kind of terror that comes as an aftertaste. She worked often with the rhythms of our childhood reading — hymns, fairytales, nursery rhymes — and those rhythms give her work a tautness and edge sometimes missing from female anger. Behind this poem Bluebeard and the ogre lurk, and the ambiguous gifts of witches and fairies. But it is also very modern, with its C-cup and bodypiercing. The listed things, black lace, strawberries, bloodstone, little house, gold rings, are both solid and symbolic in an entirely satisfactory way. The voice of the poem is interesting — an impersonal, ironic teller of tales. The poem is exciting, not depressing, because the poet has got the better of both the anonymous "he" and the situation in general. A. S. Byatt's The Little Black Book of Stories is published by Vintage Good Gifts By Dorothy Nimmo He gives her a black lace bra: her heart swells. She fills the C-cup. He gives her a bottle of champagne costing £24.50. He has got a bargain. He gives her a basket of strawberries. Open wide! he says, gently. She opens. He gives her a smooth round bloodstone to wear round her neck. So cold. He gives her a little house. All day long she cleans his fingerprints from the paintwork. He gives her five gold rings, one in her ear, one in her nose, one in her nipple, one in her navel, one in her finger. He takes a fine gold wire and threads it between ear, nose, nipple, navel and finger. He twitches the end. She dances. © Dorothy Nimmo Estate. Originally taken from The Wigbox: New and Selected Poems (Smith/Doorstop Books)
SHIRLEY MANSON
It's a chilly Sunday in late October and I'm living and working in the United States of America, a country I have grown to love as if it were my own yet never have I been more aware that I do not belong here. In nine days' time the US is to hold a general election in which as a resident alien I shall have no vote. I am completely disenfranchised and yet my future and indeed that of the rest of the world will be severely affected by the result. I am left feeling fearful and fretful and wonder at times if the US is already set upon a course that cannot be reversed. Lately my disgust with US foreign policy has left me feeling impotent and indignant and I am driven to seek solace in music, in paintings and in words. This particular poem eloquently articulates the contradictions in humankind and brings into focus the predicament of the bewildering chaos I am struggling to understand. Shirley Manson is the lead singer of the pop band Garbage. They are working on a new album to be released next year What Happens By Erich Fried It has happened and it goes on happening and will happen again if nothing happens to stop it The innocent know nothing because they are too innocent and the guilty know nothing because they are too guilty The poor do not notice because they are too poor and the rich do not notice because they are too rich The stupid shrug their shoulders because they are too stupid and the clever shrug their shoulders because they are too clever The young do not care because they are too young and the old do not care because they are too old That is why nothing happens to stop it and that is why it has happened and goes on happening and will happen again Translated from the German by Stuart Hood. © Erich Fried Estate, 2004. Originally taken from 100 Poems Without a Country (Calder Publications)

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Poems by the plateful
Full_text:
books review
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON Poems by the plateful
Of soup and love, the first is the best, an 18th-century pragmatist confidently declared. Certainly, if the stomach is not satisfied, the feelings tend to flag. There is definitely a reason why it should so often be suggested that the way to the heart is through the digestive tract. "She knew that the best feelings must have victual," as Byron said of Don Juan's dark-eyed lover, "and so she cook'd their breakfast to a tittle." But browse through the poetry section of your local bookshop and for all the dozens of volumes devoted to amorous musings, there may well not even be one given over to the pleasures of culinary pursuits. Metaphorical links between corporal consumption and cultural inspiration, between physical and spiritual sustenance are longstanding. Plato writes in Republic that poetry "nourishes our worst parts" because it "feeds and waters the passions that should be allowed to wither away", while Sir Philip Sidney in The Defence of Poesy counter-argues, calling poetry "food for the tenderest stomach", describing it as the "first nurse, whose milk by little and little enabled", comparing it to a "cluster of grapes" or "a medicine of cherries". Poets across all generations and cultures have celebrated the satisfactions of food. Ben Jonson coaxes a friend to supper with -poetic promises of capers and mutton and shortegged hens to tickle the palate. Sidney Smith suggests a mouthwatering recipe for salad, begging "The pounded yellow of two hard boiled
ABPL I
eggs;/ Two boiled potatoes, passed through the kitchensieve", "onion atoms", "mordant mustard" and a "magic soup-spoon of anchovy sauce" to confect the sort of "herbaceous treat" that "would tempt the dying anchorite to eat". Anything from bamboo shoots ("the purple skins broken — like an old brocade" as the ancient Chinese Po Chu-I describes them) to blackberries ("as big as the end of your thumb/ Real sky-blue and heavy, and ready to drum/ In the cavernous pail of the first one to come" as Robert Frost puts it) can provide the food for poetic meditation. This year, National Poetry Day, which takes place on October 7, whets the appetite for poetry by taking food as
its theme. As events are organised all over the country, there will be ballads for breakfast and lyrics for lunch, couplets for tea and stanzas for supper. There will be rhymes in restaurants and pentameters in pubs. If you are lucky you might even hear a bit of ottava rima down at the market or a few lines of blank verse coming from the cow byre as John Hegley takes up residency on a farm. All over England poetry will be served up on a plate. So prepare, as Robert Browning put it, to "munch on, crunch on, take your nuncheon,/ Breakfast, supper, dinner, luncheon".
To find our more, visit the Poetry Society's website: www.poetrysociety.org. uk/npd

Author: Dalrymple, William
Title: Land of the free
Full_text:
review books
Baghdad enjoyed an enlightened, tolerant rule as the glittering capital of the ancient Muslim world. William Dalrymple examines a paradox
Land of the free
Baghdad is not a place one automatically links with philosophy, learning, poetry, literary criticism or cutting-edge science. Nightly news bulletins showing bombed and shrapnelmarked buildings, shabby backstreets and unshaven youth firing mortars at each other have given the city a quite different set of associations. Yet just as Gaza was once a Byzantine port of fabulous richness, so Baghdad was once the sophisticated capital of the Muslim world at a time when the Caliph ruled from Tunisia to the Indus and presided over a court culture more brilliant even than that of Constantinople. The Abbasid rulers, who founded Baghdad in AD762, have a good claim to be regarded as one of Islam's greatest dynasties: certainly this seems to be the view of Osama bin Laden, whose ultimate aim is the re-establishment of the caliphate. The publication this month of a remarkable narrative history of the Abbasids is thus a major event and should be required reading for the Washington neocons and their Islamist theocon adversaries. Professor Hugh Kennedy's lively and compelling study, The Court of the Caliphs, shatters many of the preconceptions held by both sides and gives some indication of the roots of our current impasse. On one hand, the book presents a picture of a tolerant, cultured and pluralistic Islam that effortlessly salvages and absorbs the learning that survived the wreckage of both Classical and Persian antiquity. On the other, amid this busy scholarship, Kennedy sketches a looming conflict with the clerical establishment that eventually succeeds in closing down whole avenues of speculative theological and philosophical thought, so setting the stage for the current clerical veto on what is and is not permissible in the intellectual life of Islam. The consequences of that defeat are still with us. Sir Steven Runciman, arguably the greatest medievalist of recent times, believed that the real heirs of Roman civilisation were not the chain-mailed knights of the rural West, but the
sophisticated Byzantines of Constantinople and the cultivated Arab caliphate, both of whom had preserved the Hellenised urban civilisation of the ancient world long after it was destroyed in Europe. It followed, said Runciman, that the Crusades should be under¬
stood less as an attempt to reconquer the Christian heartlands lost to Islam so much as the last of the Barbarian invasions. Certainly, as Kennedy's narrative unfolds, it is easy to see the degree to which Abbasid science and thought grew directly from Classical Greek and Roman roots. Although the Abbasids moved the heart of the Islamic world east, away from the old Ummayad capital .of Damascus, where the bureaucracy still operated in Byzantine Greek, they had no doubts about the importance of studying the works of Classical antiquity, in striking contrast to Byzantium, where pagan philosophers were often regarded as rather dangerous, heretical figures.
THE GREAT IS THE CAL nrlUTAWWA NARROW-M CRUEL SAD
According to the Hadith, or Traditions, the Prophet had commanded his followers to "seek knowledge, even unto China"; and it was an instruction that the inquisitive Abbasids took literally. They sent secret agents to Byzantium to buy up Greek manuscripts on astronomy, science, botany and medicine and then smuggle them across the border. Once in Baghdad, the works of Hippocrates, Aristotle, Plato, Euclid and Galen were eagerly translated into Arabic often via Syriac, with the Christian communities of Mesopotamia acting as the conduit. The position of Baghdad at the crossroads of trade routes leading to Persia, India and China meant that the learning of the Arab capital was also cross-fertilised by the ancient learning of the East Yet, as Kennedy makes clear, the Abbasid court was a lively place. Poetry was highly valued, and Abbasid poets appear to have been as drunken and disreputable as literary figures in any age — falling inebriated off rooftops, composing scurrilous ditties and expiring under collapsed piles of their books. Abbasid poetry was often set to music, in direct contravention of the strictures of the more puritanical schools of Islamic thought and was accompanied by the lute, an instrument of Arabic invention: the English word derives from the Arabic al-ud. Those modern Islamists who imagine the Caliph's court as a place of puritanical propriety would be shocked by the outpourings of poets such as Umar ibn Abi Rabia, who is chiefly remembered for his descriptions of picking up girls during the Hajj, even as they walked around the Kaaba itself. There was also a great deal of versification on the delights of attractive young boys and impassioned debate as to whether such pleasures exceeded those of the harem. Another important writer at the court was Ibn al-Shah al-Tahiri whose oeuvre included works on Trie War of Bread and Olives, Adultery and its Enjoyments, Stories about Slave-boys, Stories about Women and a work simply called VILLAIN IPH IOL, A MINDED, D! G * B n M Masturbation. As Kennedy succinctly summarises his output: "Basically, he was concerned with food and sex." Such developments were made possible by the prevailing liberalism of the dominant Mutazalite theology. The Mutazalites believed that the Koran had been created at a certain point in time by God. This was opposed to the rival view which taught that the Koran was eternal. Though this may seem a small distinction to us, this obscure theological controversy has had huge repercussions. As Kennedy explains: "If the Koran was created, then it could be interpreted and even, conceivably, modified by new revelation or human investigation to suit changed circumstances. However, if it had existed throughout all eternity, it clearly had an absolute and universal status that could not be challenged in any way." The great villain in this story is the mid-9thcentury Caliph Mutawwakil: a cruel, narrow-minded sadist who not only did away with much of his court and army in a series of Stalinesque purges, but who also imposed restrictions on the caliphate's Christians and Jews, who had flourished under Islamic rule. More damagingly still, he abandoned the freethinking spirit of the Mutazilites, so discouraging philosophy and in particular the study of the secular sciences. The historian Masudi, writing a century later, was clear about the change: "When Mutawwakil succeeded the caliphate, he ordered the abandonment of investigation and discussion and debate and everything which people had enjoyed in the days of [the previous caliphs]. He ordered submission and the acceptance of tradition." Today, many modern Islamic reformers look back to this change in 9th-century Baghdad as a crucial wrong turning in Islamic intellectual history. Indeed some, such as the leading Indonesian scholar Harun Nasution, have tried to reintroduce Mutazilite ideas in an attempt to free modern Islam from the theological dogmatism that they believe has stunted its development and allow it to embrace the full modem range of philosophical mquiry. So far, such attempts have met a mixed response: when the Egyptian linguistic scholar Nasr Abu Zied recently suggested that some parts of the Koran might be better understood as allegories rather than as literal fact he was quickly accused of blasphemy. After a bizarre court case when an Islamist sheikh tried to get Dr Abu Zied forcibly divorced from his wife on the grounds that he was no longer a proper Muslim, the couple eventually fled to the Netherlands where Dr Abu Zied now teaches. When I went to see him in Cairo just before he left, he was deeply depressed. The Islamists, he said, "want to suppress rational thought they won't let anyone oppose them". But he had no intention of backing down: "This," he said, "is a battle which had to be fought" Seen from this perspective, the defeat of the Mutazalites is the great failure of the Abbasid period; but it is not a failure that is irreversible. Moreover, it should be recognised that even Mutawwakil, the most
<NEWPAGE>
monstrous Abbasid Caliph, had a more liberal attitude to other religions than most of the monarchs of the medieval West. He forced clothing restrictions on the caliphate's Christians and Jews, yet even he still had a Christian as his secretary. Other Abbasid rulers had a better record, and Kennedy's book is full of prominent Christian and Jewish scholars, translators, courtiers and generals. Though by modern standards Muslims and Jews — the dhimmi — were often treated as second-class citizens, there was at least a kind of pluralist equilibrium (what Spanish historians have called convivencia or living together) which had no parallel in medieval Christendom. Such pluralism arguably reached its climax in Islamic Spain, where Muslim, Christian and Jew lived and worked together in an atmosphere of creative tolerance: indeed it was probably through Islamic Spain that such basic facets of Western civilisation as paper, the pointed arch, ideas of courtly love and the abacus passed into Europe — the same route as taken by many of the Greek and Roman classics, lost in the West but carefully translated in Abbasid Baghdad and passed on to the libraries of alAndalus. After the conquest of Granada, however, this creativity was lost: the Catholic kings promptly expelled most of the Moors and Jews, and let loose the Inquisition on those — the new Christians — who were converted. There was a similar pattern in Sicily. After a fruitful period of tolerant coexistence under the Norman kings, the Muslims were later given a blunt choice of transportation or conversion. This forgotten Islamic pluralism is the theme of another important book to be published this month: Mark Mazower's wonderful Salonica, City of Ghosts. Mazower follows the fate of the expelled Spanish Jews as they flourished in their new Ottoman home, a city where "as late as the First World War Salonican bootblacks commanded a working knowledge of six or seven languages". As Mazower shows, Salonica's hybrid "multi-confessional, extraordinarily polyglot Ottoman" multiculturalism survived until imported European ideas of the nation state irreparably shattered the mosaic. Pluralism slowly gave way to polarisation as Muslims came to be seen as Turks and Christians as Greeks. The final chapter came in 1943 with the arrival of Western Christian troops in the form of the Nazis. If the Catholic kings expelled the Spanish Jews from Europe, the Nazis deported them back westwards again — to Auschwitz. Forty-five thousand Salonica Jews — a fifth of the city's population — died in the gas chambers. Today, as we watch the anarchy unleashed in Baghdad by the American invasion, the works of Kennedy and Mazower should give us pause for reflection on the deeper roots of the current mess. As these books show, there are many Islams, just as there are many forms of Christianity. If there is a clash of civilisations taking place, it is happening as much within the Islamic world as between East and West. Islam has long and proud traditions of pluralism, moderation and religious toleration. The disaster is that by
our current heavy-handed and illegal actions in the Middle East, we seem to be liberating the extremists, radicalising the unaffiliated and making life more difficult than ever for our natural allies: ordinary, decent, moderate Muslims. The Court of the Caliphs: The Rise and Fall of Islam's Greatest Dynasty by Hugh Kennedy (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £20; offer, £16) Salonica, City of Ghosts: Christians, Muslims and Jews by Mark Mazower (HarperCollins, £25; offer, £20) William Dalrymple's most recent book, White Mughals (Harper Perennial), won the Wolfson Prize for History
Right: a manuscript from 1219 celebrating the Abbasid culture. Above: an upside-down 10th-century map of northern Iraq shows Baghdad at the top of the Tigris. Below left: a 9th-century bronze astrolabe

Author: Paulin, Tom
Title: Anxiety in a jawful of marl
Full_text:
review books
POETRY TOM PAULIN Anxiety in a jawful of marl
Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Lowell were close friends, never lovers. Then one day, quite unexpectedly, he proposed marriage to her. Wisely, she refused him and their friendship survived. Lowell admired her work enormously and wrote perceptively and sensitively about her poems. In his admiration for her work, there is a current of all-toonuman anxiety: he is the most famous poet of their generation; indeed he is the dominant poei in the English-speaking world, but perhap.-: she i:; better than him? It is invidious to set up hierarchies oi' talent. •.■"a: reputations mc ciianse ■•v.::- am;, a:- reader:- an.- rniies. perhaos. grow wisrv in the 1960> ana the ear.-. 70s, i read Lowell — we ail di-;'. — and it was only the aisa-.- nointment of his ias: three volumes thai made me turn awav from him. " turned to Elizabeth Bishop at tfte same time as I discovered three other poets — Emily Dickir.- son. John Clare and Christina Rossetli — with whom Bishopshares a central theme that 1 would call dwelling-in-theworid or ontological anxiety. Her images for this subject are oil-stained gas station forecourts and workshop floors, or the smell of gasoline left behind when the moose and a coach full of passengers meet in one of her most famous poems, Trie Moose. That poem is partly a gentle and ironic tribute to Robert Frost (it begins north of Boston), and like all her poems it has a distinctive "sentence sound" — the term is Frost's description of the vernacular speaking voice in poetry, a voice that is intimate, direct, touching, and which refuses heroic rhetoric. Bishop has now the reputation of being one of the finest, most formally perfect poets of the second half of the 20th century. Poets such as Seamus Heaney, Anne Stevenson, Paul Muldoon and Craig Raine have testified to the subtlety and complex beauty of her work. She has been called a poet's poet, but she is also preeminently a reader's poet, and a poet whom it is always a serious joy to teach — students come alive when asked to discuss her work, partly because she communicates with an eager, unforced directness, partly because of the wit pizazz and styie with which she writes. in the 1980s there was li certain resistance to he- work: she never came out as r iesnian. '"efuseci to apnea" in ali-womer. antnoio.ihL-.;. guarc■e,i ner privacy ana e'L not take uirect political stances iike Lowell. She wai- seen as insufficient!;.- political, a misreading o' her work which identifies with biack Americans and with the struggle of tne poor and oppressed in South America. But she. wisely, does nor draw attention to those themes. She designs i iHVI ;<\.«&r beautiful cadences, perfect shapes, and then she runs a counter-theme against them: ugliness, bad taste, rough or broken surfaces and sounds infiltrate her paradise of pure form and make it both more ideal and more real. In Cape Breton, she draws our attention to the weaving "silken water" and then offsets it with "hackmatack", the name of a hard American spruce much admired by Walt Whitman. She also introduces an "irregular, nervous sawtooth edge", and a "roughedged pole". A gifted amateur
?&--
painter, she designs a composition which plays the rough against the smooth, and allows a coded unhappiness and anxiety to disturb the surface of her art. Bishop's personal life was often unhappy — two lovers committed suicide — and she became an alcoholic as a young woman. Behind the formal facade of her poems there is a homeless, orphaned imagination whose loneliness was expressed in her insatiable letter-writing and in late-night telephone calls to friends. She was born in Worcester, Massachusetts, on February 11, 1911. Her mother was from Nova Scotia; her father, who was half Canadian, half American, died eight months after she was born. Her mother became disorientated over the next five years, was diagnosed as insane in 1916 and died in a public sanatorium in 1934. Bishop lived alternately with her grandparents in Nova Scotia and New England, and later with an aunt. She had poor health and hadn't much formal education until she was 15. In 1930 she went to Vassar College and joined a brilliant generation there. Bishop impressed everyone she met — she was musical, well read, and was also a painter with a great knowledge of the visual arts. She was a compulsive traveller who manages to avoid all the pitfalls of tourist verse. Unusually, it is to a single academic essay that we must turn to to understand Bishop's idea of form and beauty. As an undergraduate she read Trie Baroque Style in Prose by M. W. Chroll — one of the classic essays on prose style (it can be found in a collection called The English Language, edited by George Watson). Croll's concept of baroque style — "not a thought, but a mind thinking" — spoke to Bishop like a vocation. She quoted Croll's essay in letters to friends because what she admired in the baroque was the "ardour" and dramatic energy and the immediacy of an idea as it was formulated and experienced. The result is a poetry of intense visual and vocal power, where the rhythm, rhyme, spoken inflection and carefully composed images have both spontaneity and deft authority. Their perfect cadences create that "unique feeling of timeliness" which she sought and admired in poetry.If we look at The Bight we can see how finely her imagination works. Bishop was also a gifted short-story writer (her collected prose has been published), and a marvellous translator. Many of her translations came out of the 15 years she spent in Brazil, where she moved in 1952 to live with Lota de Macedo Soares. She moved back to New York in 1967 and Lota killed herself later that year. Though Bishop continued to travel, she based herself in Boston and died there on October 6,1979. She is one of the greatest American poets of the last century and is the subject of many books. Twenty-five years after her death her work continues to be deeply influential. Complete Poems by Elizabeth Bishop, with an introduction by Tom Paulin, is published by Chatto & Windus (£12.99; offer £9.60 plus 99p p&p)

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Found in translation
Full_text:
books review
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON Found in translation
An important new literary prize is launched this month. The Stephen Spender Memorial Trust, in collaboration with The Times, inaugurates the Times Stephen Spender Prize for poetry in translation — by poets aged 30 or under. Spender was himself a subtle translator, praised for, among other things, his reworkings of Leishman's translations from Rilke and his free adaptation of Schiller's Mary Stuart. This new award aims to encourage a new generation to pursue the same skilled and sensitive path. The prize will be judged by Daniel Weissbort, founder (with Ted Hughes) of Modern Poetry in Translation; Alan Jenkins, the deputy editor of the TIS; Susan Bassnett, Professor of Comparative literature at the University of Warwick; and Ewald Osers, the poet and translator. "WTiy?" some might wonda. Aren't our literary traditions already rich enough? Do we need more outsiders? Why not promote originality instead? Quibbles trip from the tongue as glibly as Robert Fro&'s all too famous dictum: "Poetry is what is lost in translation." And Nabokov's wellknown put-down is nothing if not disheartening: What is translation? On a platter A poet's pale and glaring head, A parrot's screech, a monkey's chatter, And profanation of the dead. But there are strong counter-arguments. Our literary traditions are indebted to outsiders. Many classics, The Riad, The Odyssey, the Bible, for instance, all entered our culture through translation. Our greatest poets were often responsible. And the art of translation (to use Dr Johnson's phrase) helped to "tune their tongue". A golden era of poetic translation began almost half a millennium ago when Surrey's Aeneid introduced blank verse into English, when Golding's Metamorphoses became one of Shakespeare's favourite books, when Horace and Martial were disdplining the style of Ben Johnson who in turn laid the foundations on which Dryden stood. And it was Dryden who, through engagement with the andents (Horace, JuvenaL Persius and Virgil), forged a poetic language tiiat remained fundamental to a modem view of literature. "What was said of Rome, adorned by Augustus," dedared Dr Johnson, "may be applied by easy metaphor to English poetry embellished by Dryden, fateritiam invenit marmoreamretiquit, he found it in brick, and he left it in marble." The art of translation waned somewhat during the Romantic period (witii a
PtOTO t£SNIAK/ARDEA t-Cs. X
notable exception in Shelley, whose stylistic intricades are indebted to his versions of Dante, Calderon and Goethe). But with the contemporary it has entered a new golden age. Worics that, with the decline of a dassical education, had fallen silent are redaimed in a freshly relevant idiom Christopher Logue catches "a light that screams across three thou.sand years" in his fragments of The Iliad. Ted Hughes captures Aeschylean cruelties in his harrowing Oresteia. And without Seamus Heaney's Beowulf, the Old English that for centuries has provided a linguistic bedrock would be in danger of disappearing. English has become a world language. Hundreds of voices would lose their audiences if it wasn't for translation. From Ezra Pound's Cathay to Roy Campbell's Lorca, from Geoffrey Mil's Ibsen to Michael Hamburger's Holderlin, the translator's range is expanding.. %£„there, is always room for more.'" Make it new?

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Uproar in New York
Full_text:
books review
POETRY RACHEL CAMPBELL-JOHNSTON Uproar in New York
English poetry was languishing in the Fifties. The Movement poets, united by nothing more bracing than "a negative determination to avoid bad principles", seemed beset by a genteel sobriety. Their verse, in the words of Al Alvarez, was "academic, administrative ... polite, knowledgeable, efficient, polished and, in its quiet way, even intelligent". But it was hardly likely to inspire a new generation, or to open poetry up to insight and experience and innovation. Modernist experiment had lost its impetus. It was slowing to a sludgy stop. But across the Atlantic, creativity was on a roll. The New York art scene, a unique foment of ideas and people, was flourishing. This was the era of Abstract Expressionism, of Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning, of iconoclasm and conflict and wild improvisation. Visual art was about action and energy. It broke with convention. And the whole of culture — including poetry — was swept up by its tide. "New York poets, except I suppose the colour blind, are affected most by the floods of paint in whose crashing surf we all scramble," wrote James Schuyler in 1959. He was one of a group of four — the others being John Ashbery, Frank O'Hara and Kenneth Koch — all of whom were, in one way or another, directly involved with the visual arts, working as critics and curators or collaborating with painters. These four poets were not actually a group in that they never set out their aims in any definitive way. How could they have? They were resolutely unacademic, unprogrammatic,
unprescriptive. But were certainly stimulated by each other. "We envied each other, we emulated each other, we were very critical of each other, we admired each other, we were almost entirely dependent on each other for support," Koch later recalled. Like the Abstract Expressionists who inspired them, they shared a common stance, though not a common style. Now, for the first time, Carcanet gathers their work together into an anthology: The New York Poets, edited by Mark Ford. If the English reader wants to find out what happened to Modernism, to discover what became ofthe innovations of Pound or Eliot or, perhaps even more directly, where the ceaseless formal experiments and conversational expansiveness of Auden went, he need only flick through a few pages of this volume. They
crossed the Atlantic. Here is O'Hara, a modernday Baudelaire and probably the most New York, in the sense of the most-specifically urban of the four poets. The brisk simplicity of his earlier pieces — "And here I am, the/ center of all beauty!/ writing these poems! Imagine!" — gives way to eloquent experiments with prose poems, to his almost adolescent passions for film stars. Impromptu, impulsive, passionate, exclamatory,
his impact depends on his response to the physical matter of language. O'Hara thinks, as he puts it, with his bare hands. Ashbery is perhaps even harder to pin down. His poems, he said were just snapshots "of whatever is going on in my head at the time". Moving from the spare beauty of his prize-winning Some Trees to the disjunctive experimentalism of his extraordinary, long poem The Skaters, this anthology offers a sample of the quixotic range of a writer who can move from lightness to solemnity in a few lines, mix personal memories with poetic philosophies, echo multiple voices. Trains of ideas twist and proliferate. "The poem is the chronicle of the creative act that produces it," he says. Just as Pollock liked to feel that he was "in" his painting, Ashbery seems to inhabit his work. To read it seems less to acquire an understanding of something complete than to assist in the process of its growth. Koch too is an innovator. A maverick among mavericks, as the editor of this anthology describes him, his exuberant powers of invention provoke. "Summer in the trees! 'It's time to strangle several bad poets'," he exclaims. His dynamic pieces expand an art form, fill its lungs with the Fresh Air ofthe work's title. They release daring forces and Koch controls them like a driver who just controls the fast car that goes skidding down mountain bends. Schuyler, who composed his first poem while recovering from the first ofthe many mental breakdowns he was to
HULTON ARCHIVE fflm&m Gferwyvt ^~>>t,i lmWm**St*~ ?//Mm m ?&& HlKPSft
suffer, is in fact the most literal, the most descriptive of the group, though he was quite literally psychotic. His poems are haunted by an almost pastoral mood. Experience and innocence play across their lucid surfaces. But these poets belong together. Their works echo each other; they have attitude. They evoke a fresh way of thinking, a new freedom from rules as they embrace all the energy, the distraction of their era. "You can't plan on the heart," writes O'Hara, "but the better part of it, my poetry, is open." The New York poets create on a vast empty canvas. They let the forces of poetry buffet them about. This anthology can serve only as an
introduction. Just a fraction of the 500 odd poems from the collected edition of O'Hara's works can be reproduced, for example. But with a few omissions (where is Ashbery's benchmark poem The Tennis Court Oath?) the editor has sought to represent them in all their diversity and daring. The reader feels the electricity that fizzles through their lines, frazzling academic conventions, exploding grammatical rules, spitting the bright sparks that smouldered and ignited a new postmodern mindset. The New York Poets: An Anthology edited by Mark Ford (Carcanet, £9.95, offer £8.46)

Title: Riddle and rhyme: win six anthologies
Full_text:
NATIONAL POETRY DAY COMPETITION
Riddle and rhyme: win six anthologies
Founded 25 years ago, the poetry publisher Bloodaxe was named after the Viking king Erik Bloodaxe, last ruler of the old Kingdom of Northumbria, who was perhaps our first patron of poetry: he captured the saga hero Egil and made him write him a praise-poem overnight on pain of death by beheading. This silver anniversary poetry quiz, by Neil Astley, the Bloodaxe editor, takes a leaf out of King Erik's book.
1 Which poet's best-known poem addresse "Bloodaxe , king of York ,/king of Dublin , king of Orkney" and describes his death on Stainmore in AD954? 2 Whose coins were "of good substance ant weight resonant in silver" in Geoffrey Hill's hymns for a Mercian king? 3 Who came to a tavern with "Six hands at an open door dicing for pieces of silver?" 4 Which 16th-century "silver poet" and sonneteer was executed for treason in 1547? 5 Which twice-imprisoned poet wrote in praise of a snail with silver horns? 6 Who used the word "silver" ten times in a 14-line poem featuring a mouse with silver claws? 7 Whose "Golden lockes, Time hath to silver turn'd" when "His Helmet now, shall make a hive for bees' ? S Which poefs wandering hero caught a s ilver trout and plucked the silver apples of the moon? 9 Who swears by a blessed moon "that tips with silver all these fruit-tree tops" before telling his lady. "How silver-sweet sound lovers' tongues by night,/ like softest music to attending ears!" 10 Which poet — who died aged 25 — imagined a beguiling snake woman "full of silver moons, that, as she breathed/ Dissolv'd , or brighter shone' ? 11 Who wrote of her mirror "I am silver and exact I have no preconceptions./ Whatever I see I swallow immediately/ Just as it is, unmisted by love or dislike" ? 12 Which Shakespearean character called England "this precious stone set in the ,. silver sea' ?
s. The five winners will each receive six Bloodaxe anthologies — Neil Astley's Staying Alive: Real Poems for Unreal Times (£10.95), Do Not 1 Go Gentle: Poems for Funerals (£6.99) and Pleased to See Me: 69 Very Sexy Poems (£6.99), as well as Maura Dooley's The Honey Gatherers : A Book of Love Poems (£9.95) and Peter Forbes's We Have Come Through: 100 Poems Celebrating Courage in Overcoming Depression and Trauma (£8.95), plus the 25th birthday anthology, Bloodaxe Poems of the Year (£3.99). These are also available from Books Direct (0870160 8080) at £2 off the cover price (plus 99p p&p). Erica Wagner, literary editor of The Times, writes: "Love , sex, death, depression — poetry engages with the real stuff of life. These are fine anthologies ; have them on your bedside table and surely you'd be ready for anything."
