Author: McMillan, Ian
Title: From history to poetry
Full_text:
RHYME REVIEW IAN McMILLAN '
From history to poetry
M The anonymous Old English fragment and perennial schoolmasters' favourite, The Battle of Maldonr immortalised the bloody events of AD991: "Rang the shield rims, and sang the corselets of mail a certain terrible dirge ... " Si Alfred Lord Tennyson's The Charge of the Light Brigade, inspired by a newspaper report, recounts the disastrous exploits of a cavalry unit during the Crimean War of 1854-1856 : "Into the mouth of Hell/ Rode the six hundred ... " M In 1863 Henry Wadsworth Longfellow composed Paul Revere's Ride (the Landlord's Tale ), based on the most famous incident in the life of the late 18th-century American patriot Paul Revere — a night-time journey to warn Lexington and Concord: "Listen , my children, and you shall hear/ Of the midnight ride of Paul Revere,/ On the eighteenth of April, in Seventy-five ;/ Hardly a man is now alive/ Who remembers that famous day and year... " M Published in 1890, William McGonagall's The Tay Bridge Disaster tells of the 90 deaths caused by a \ train crash in 1879: "Then the central girders with a , crash gave way,/ And down went the train and passengers into the Tay!" — . which, thanks to him "will be remember'd for a very longtime ". IJ Written by one of the decade's prominent activists, Edward Sanders's epic poem 1968: A History in Verse charts the social unrest of that yean "Also on January 5/Benjamin Spock and four others/Were indicted for counselling young men /To avoid the draft/ And on the 9th/ ' Sweden granted asylum to four US Navy guys/Who had deser ted in Japan ... "

Author: williamson, nigel
Title: Cleavage, Poetry and Protest
Full_text:
CLEAVAGE , POETRY AND PROTEST
9NYERVIEW5 FOLK PIN-UP JEWEL WANTS TO BE A POP DIVA. IT'S QUITE LOGICAL SHE TELLS NIGEL WILLIAMSON ..
JEWEL HAS a phrase to describe her transfor - mation from wholesome folk troubadour with the earnest lyrics to sexed-up pop diva with beats. "Here 's cleavage and poetry," she says as she sits in a hotel room overlooking Hyde Park. "People say if I'm being sexy, is that a sell-out ?" she asks rhetorically. "I enjoy the challenge of that. There are so many stigmas about women that are ingrained in society. It's easy for a guy to be intellectual and good-looking . I want to challenge the image that a woman can't also be intelligent and sexy at the same time." Now 29, it's as if the woman who was once hailed as the successor to Joni Mitchell has de - cided to become the new Christina Aguilera. Or rather, she greedily wants both roles. Her new album 0304 (a reference to this year and next) finds Jewel forsaking her acoustic guitar and wistful, earnest songs. In their place are dance beats courtesy of Lester A. Mendez (the man be - hind the "Latin Madonna", Shakira) and catchy pop songs co-written with the likes of Guy Chambers, Robbie Williams's former songwrit - er , and Rick Nowels, whose credits include work for Ronan Keating and Kylie Minogue. The contrast is equally stark between the in - trospective , demurely chaste folkie who stared out of the cover of her first album, Pieces of You (1994), at the age of 19, her book of poetry, A Night Without Armour (1998), and the brash, multi-hued confident pop queen with the come - on look depicted on the front of 0304. "I don't really see a difference," she insists. "Women who want to be taken seriously dress down and in darker colours. I did that for a long time. If you're selling being sexual, you dress a different way and now I'm into really bright colours. But nobody is totally one thing or the other. I've gone nowhere. It's still me." But why change her sound so dramatically, then? "It 's such a dark time for the world, I felt I needed to make a very upbeat record. It's so obvious what's wrong with the world. It's blar - ing . I wanted to feel good. And I wanted to
make kids feel good, too." She makes the analo - gy with big-band music in the Second World Wan "That gave people a place to escape , and that's so important. It's music that goes some place and makes you feel there is a future." Despite her folkie past, she insists that she always wanted to make a danceable pop record: "This album may sound different to everybody else, but to me it's closer to what has been in my head for years. I haven't used electronic music before. That's like being a painter never using red or yellow, but in music it's as if you're not allowed to use beats and intelligent lyrics." Some critics have suggested declining sales as a more cynical reason for the change. Pieces of You shifted 11 million copies in America in 1994. Bright-eyed , serious and oozing sincerity,
"I WANT TO CHALLENGE THE IMAGE THAT A WOMAN CAN 'T BE INTELLIGENT AND SEXY "
it outsold Nirvana's Nevermind. She toured with her acoustic guitar supporting Bob Dylan and lagged behind only Madonna as the biggest female star in America. She had a great story to tell, too. Born and raised on a ranch in Alaska to hippie parents who lived on food stamps and welfare, she was singing in bars before her teens. By the time she was 17, she was living in a Volkswagen with lit - tle more than the clothes on her back and a gui - tar , writing songs and playing in coffee houses. Yet the phenomenal success of her debut al - bum proved hard to follow. Spirit (1998) and This Way (2001) became multi-platinum mil - lion - sellers but came nowhere near the sales figures of Pieces of You. Jewel laughs off the sug - gestion that the change of image is part of some marketing strategy: "If people are saying that I did it to sell records, that's pretty silly because I sold a lot of records without using beats. It's not
a contrived strategy. My record label was wor - ried about me making a record like this. They didn't think it was an easy sell. They thought there was more to lose than to gain." And what does she think? "I always saw my - self doing this kind of record but I waited until I thought I could do it properly." 0304 is her "dance-hip-hop-folk" album, she says. "I wanted it to be a smart record that didn't shy away from topics." And it is true that despite the glossy dance-pop beats, not all of her old seriousness has been obliterated. One song talks about Washington "selling lies". An - other , called America, talks about "shedding blood in the name of liberty"." People can just lis - ten to the melody and the beats if they want," she explains. "They don't have to get the lyric. I'm not forcing anything down people's throats. But it's there if you want it."
She claims that she thought about the poet Pablo Neruda "a lot" while making the record. And it is still the likes of Neil Young and Bob Dylan rather than Avril Lavigne and Christina Aguilera that she measures herself against. "Those are the kinds of careers that I admire. Sustaining talent as they have done over so many years is hard work," she says. "I 've never felt particularly tortured. But I always feel on the edge of failure. It's a bit morbid but I've always imagined myself on my deathbed look - ing back at my life. And 1 don't want to be embarrassed by myself." Before I leave, I ask her to sign my copy of her book of poems. On the title page she draws a picture of herself naked and signs it with a flourish. Cleavage and poetry indeed. 0304 will be released on Atlantic Records on September 1
New album, new image for Jewel: "If I'm being sexy, is that a sell-out ?"

Author: Garner, Alan
Title: Poetry that Lies beneath our Feet
Full_text:
GLOBAL WARMING and cooling are natural rhythms caused by small but complex changes in the Earth's orbit. At the moment, helped only in part by the Industrial Revolution, things are hotting up. Current predictions for the next hun - dred years are a rise of less than 3C, resulting in an increase in sea level of about 3 ft. In the delta of Bangladesh alone, the lives of some 36 mil - lion people will be at risk. Indirect results will be more severe weather patterns and the penetra - tion of salt into fresh water supplies. Drought in Sub-Saharan Africa will be commonplace. The need for water in the Middle East may eclipse land, politics and religion. Extremes of wealth and poverty will increase. World terrorism may become endemic. There are, simply, too many of us. Twelve and a half thousand years ago, the temperature rose by 7C, and the sea level by 400 feet, in 50 years. Yet it is unlikely that many human beings drowned as a direct result. People adapted and moved. The massive global warming led to agriculture, farming, the devel - opment of writing, the building of cities (that is, civilization), and ironically the freeing for occu - pation of a huge land mass that is now the main polluter and threat to our fragile and overload - ed human ecology: America. In 1957, aged 22,1 climbed up a steep field in Cheshire. A roofline appeared, and as more and more of the building was revealed. I believed less and less of what 1 saw. It was a timber framed mediaeval hall of the purest form: solar and parlour, great hall, cross passage and serv - ice bay. By 1957 it had slid down the social scale to be two agricultural tied cottages, one with a clos - ing order on it. Together with an acre of garden it was for sale at £510. I had 8 shillings and 3
AFTER THE ICE REMINDS WRITER ALAN GARNER OF LANDSCAPES FAMILIAR AND DISTANT
pence to my name and no source of income. I am writing this now in the buttery. Over 46 years, scarcely a week has gone by without the house and the land revealing some - thing obvious but unnoticed. Simply by garden - ing and documentary research, we can appor - tion every fragment of pottery that the spade has revealed to the possibility of its being used by a named individual in an uninterrupted line back to 1335. Beyond that, the names are patchy and less secure, and end with Orme the Harper and Wulfric. Yet still the pottery goes on, through Saxon, Romano-British and the Iron Age. Then come the prehistoric periods, where a single moment can change a day. And that mo - ment never lessens its intensity. Flint. Flint is the most sensuous and evoca - tive of things. It is not a part of the geology of ~ Cheshire . When flint appears in the garden , someone must have brought it, used it. left it: here. That is the first visceral kick: to be the first hand and eye to know what the flint is since it was last held, however many thousands of years ago .
The second kick is more subjective but, be - cause of the longevity of my family's living in this area, not entirely to be dismissed. I may be turning in my hand something made by a hand the genes of which I share. The interconnections become more dense. Recently, geophysics has shown that the mediaeval hall occupies half of a Bronze Age round barrow. And next to it is an anomaly that respects the barrow and abuts onto it. From gar - dening , we may interpret that as masonry: prob - ably a collapsed structure. For perhaps two mil - lennia its existence was known and it was used ' as n quarry for building on the- site. The timber
hall, the latest incarnation of dwelling here, used its stone as sills to support and preserve the oak cruck framing. And one of these sill stones is decorated with carving that suggests that the stone building from which it was robbed was an Iron Age temenos or sacred shrine. The flints move backwards. Bronze Age ; Ne - olithic (the setting up of a farm); Mesolithic (hunter-gatherers ); and the evidence from the flints is that here was a winter camp, devoted to survival, repair, preparation.
Back and back. The Mesolithic flints are the link. I look now from the buttery over an Eng - lish idyll of pasture, meadow, oak, alder, brook and undulating green. Once it was different. At the edge of the garden, cobbles have been dumped to clear the field. Others made a yard and paths. They are multicoloured and beauti - ful . They have been brought from the Lake Dis - trict , from Ireland; they have been scooped from the bottom of the sea. The rolling fields are the slurry, the detritus of the ice : ice 1.200 feet thick. Some of the cobbles are quite different from the others. They have the shape of flatirons: smooth underneath, with one end pointed , the other blunt. Their tops are domed, and their up - per surfaces pocked as if by sandblasting. Yet not "as if". It was sand that blasted them. These cobbles are "ventefacts". For hun - dreds of years they sat on the ground here in
"FLINT IS THE MOST SENSUOUS AND EVOCATIVE OF THINGS"
permafrost in a polar desert, where neither snow nor rain fell, but an endless wind blew. The ice had gone, and into this land people returned after an absence of 12,000 years . And so the end of the Ice Age and the start of the latest global warming began, marked in the garden by flint and pocked stone. This sketch of one experience of the steward - ship of a multifaceted yet coherent acre in Cheshire has been provoked by a remarkable book.
Steven Mithen, in After the Ice: A Global Hu - man Histoiy, 20,000-5 ,000 BC, has done for the world what is hinted at in the poetry of one gar - den . He has set out to communicate to the gen - eral reader the total effect of the end of the most recent Ice Age, and, without compromis - ing his scholarship, he has succeeded. He uses the literary conceit of a non - partici - pating time traveller, who observes key events in key places at key times, which are described in de - tail and then analysed and interpreted for us by Mithen. The scene setting and the descriptions are vivid; but these are no televisual trivialities. For ever)' graphic incident there is, in the end notes, the academic citation of Mithen's sources on which his scrupulous imagination has drawn and from which he develops his arguments. Un - derpinning all is a rigorous bibliography. The result is a model for such writing, partic - ularl y when the subject is so remote from us in time, yet so pertinent to our present and our fu - ture . The lucidity of Mithen's thought and prose will inform the professional and illuminate the general reader. After the Ice is that rare event: the right book at the right time. Alan Garner's new novel, Thursbitch, will be pub - lished in October by Har\> ill
Natufian necklace from Mithen's After the Ice (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, £25; offer, £20)

Author: Dalton, Stephen
Title: Poetry in Stop-Motion
Full_text:
f^tf^ TW^Wy^rf P 1 AH tr ^yES u lau H Utft ]
BEFORE Steven Spielberg walked with dinosaurs, before George Lucas blew up the Death Star, and before James Cameron went in search of ghosts on the ocean floor, Ray Harryhausen was king of the creature feature. Over a 40-year career the Oscar - win - ning movie legend created the template for blending stop - mo - tion animation with live action that remains hugely influen - tial , even in this age of compu - terised monsters. Still spry and avuncular at 82, the California-born Harry - hausen sits in his West Lon - don office surrounded by sou - venirs of his illustrious career. A statuette of King Kong, from the movie that changed his life, encouraging him to take film-making classes at the University of Southern Califor - nia , stands shoulder to shoul - der with his Oscar. Mythical beasts from Jason and the Argo - nauts , The Golden Voyage of Sinbad and One Million. Years BC huddle beneath giant can - vases of ancient Greece.
mmmmtt! the veteran animator ray harryhausen STILL KNOWS A TRICK OR TWO. STEPHEN DALTON MET HIM
Harryhausen and his long - time producing partner Charles Schneer moved to Brit - ain in the early Sixties to take advantage of technical advanc - es here, as well as more exotic location options . "You cant keep using the Grand Canyon and Malibu Beach for lost is - lands ," he says. "We could get to Spain quickly, or Jordan or Italy, without sending a big crew over from Hollywood." It is a testament to Harry - hausen 's stylistic signature that he is much better known than the directors of his films. Was he never tempted to go the next step and direct hu - mans as well as models? "Very much so," he says. "In fact, some critics used to say of my early films that it was a pity Mr Harryhausen didn't animate the actors, heh heh! But my actors always do exactly what I want them to, and I don't have to deal with agents. I felt I would water my - self down if I worked with real
Even casual movie fans will know his best-loved produc - tion , Jason and the Argonauts from 1963, with its celebrated skeleton fight sequence that took four months to animate for five minutes on screen. "I think Jason is the most complete of our films," Harry - hausen says. "I prefer Greek mythology over monsters on the loose. I destroyed Washing - ton and San Francisco, I knocked over the Washington
Monument long before Mars Attacks! It got kind of tire - some , especially when God - zilla got in on the act." The veteran animator is un - im pressed by the copycat screen monsters he has in - spired over the decades. He is not a fan of the Japanese Godzilla series, a straight copy of Harryhausen's 1953 crea - tion The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms. More recently, the wobbly spaceships in Tim Bur - ton 's Mars Attacks! paid overt homage to Harryhausen's work on the 1956 film Earth vs the Flying Saucers. "A hom - age ?" he grins. "You could put it that way. That was an inter - esting picture , but when they get too violent it's not really my cup of tea." Harryhausen warms up when conversation turns to
the superstar directors who cite him as an influence. And what a list it is: Steven S piel - berg , James Cameron, George Lucas, John Landis and more. Landis keeps a signed letter on his wall that Harryhausen wrote back to him in his youth, and repaid the animation leg - end with cameo roles in two of his films, Spies Like Us and Bev - erly Hills Cop Ul And Tom Hanks, on presenting Harry - hausen with his valedictory Os - car in 1992, even rated Jason and the Argonauts above Citi - zen Kane and Casablanca as his personal greatest film of all time. "I was delighted," Harry - hausen beams. "Of course, he was joking , I'm
Harryhausen officially re - tired from film-making after Clash of the Titans in 1981, co - incidental !/ at the dawn of the era of computerised animation (CGI). "The type of films that seemed to attract audiences were not my cup of tea," he says. "You can't have an explo - sion every five minutes in Greek mythology." But more recent develo p -
ments in animation have not bypassed Harryhausen. He is a fan and friend of Wallace and Gromit creator Nick Park, and expresses admiration for the computer-generated creatures in Walking with Dinosaurs. "CGI has made some wonder - ful strides ," he says, "but I would find it terribly restrict - ing to the creativity^ the char - acters . I've always thought that stop-motion gives a ni ght - mare quality to a fantasy film." Harryhausen remains un - usually active for a man who retired two decades ago. Last year he was persuaded to com - plete The Tortoise and the Hare, an 11-minute short he be - gan 50 years ago. Later this month his name will be immor - talised with a star on Holly - woo d Boulevard. In July a giant bronze cast of a statue Harryhausen made of a lion wrestling with Dr David Liv - ingstone , his wife Diana's great-grandfather , will be un - ve iled on the Livingstone fami - ly estate in Scotland. And later this year he will spill all his ani - mation secrets in a detailed "technical autobiography ".
But before all of this, Harry - hausen appears as a guest of honour at the Animated En - counters festival in Bristol to - morrow . "I like to keep up with what interests people to - day in motion pictures," he ex - plains . "I find it fascinating to talk to young people and see their tastes. It's nice to know that Charles and I made pic - tures that added something to people's lives rather than sub - tracted . With some of today's films you think they are going to breed a bunch of delin - quents . They all look down in the dirt rather than up at the stars." ® Animated Encounters fe at Watershed Media Centre, 1 Canon's Road, Harbourside, Bristol (0117-927 5102), tomorrow and Saturday
Bone idol: Ray Harryhausen with skeleton warriors from Jason and the Argonauts

Author: bone, james
Title: The Art of Provocation
Full_text:
CONSPIRACY THEORIST AND OCCASIONALLY SUBLIME POET AMIRI BARAKA SPITS HIS VITRIOL AT JAMES BONE
NO ONE SHOULD have any doubt that Amiri Baraka is capable of creating sublime moments of poetry. A unique historical figure, he stands at the confluence of three great vital currents of American life — Beat poetry, jazz and Black Power. The first reading I ever saw him give, in which he was accompanied by Archie Shepp on trumpet and Philly Joe Jones on drums, still ranks as probably the best performance of any - thing I have ever attended. Nearly 20 years af - ter hearing them, I can still chant — the way he does — his poignant lines from Wise 1 about the black experience of being robbed of tribal cul - ture and sold into slavery. If you ever find yourself some where lost and surrounded by enemies who wont let you speak in your own language who destroy your statues & instruments, who ban your omm bomm ba boom then you are in trouble deep trouble they ban your oom boom ba boom you in deep deep trouble humph ! probably take you several hundred years to get out! Several hundred years after his ancestors lost their "oom boom ba boom", and 68 years af - ter his own birth, Amiri Baraka ("Blessed Prince" ), who was once called LeRoi Jones, is again in deep trouble. A Jewish group has de - nounced a polemical poem he wrote in re - sponse to September 11 as anti-Semitic , and com - pared him to collaborationist poet Ezra Pound. The governor and law-makers in Baraka's na - tive New Jersey want to pass a bill to strip him of his title as the state's official poet laureate, a two-year post that carries an annual stipend of $10,000. The row threatens plans by the State University of New York to establish a chair in Afro-American studies for him. "This is the kind of double-think that goes on in bourgeois America," the still energetic Bar - aka complained in an interview at his home, just blocks from where he was born, in the sprawling ghetto that is Newark, New Jersey. "Poetry is supposed to be completely non - politi - cal , and obviously the poetry that gets most of the awards is — though that's the politics of non-politics . This is not the first poem I've been jumped on for its political content A1967 poem called Black People was used as some sort of evi - dence to sentence me to three years in prison for participating in the Newark rebellion. "They are saying that to be a great poet in America, one must have the politics of non - poli - tics . Otherwise, one is some poor poetry - terror - . ist," he said. "But all poetry is political. If you are trying to do that with all your might in a way that is difficult to dismiss it, then one is liable to run into trouble." Baraka, who has won a string of prestigious literary awards and was inducted last year into the American Academy of Arts and Letters, be - gan crafting his response to the terror attacks within days of September II. By the end of Octo - ber , he had finished a six-page poem - cum - con - spiracy theory. The trouble began only a year lat - er when — after being named New Jersey poet laureate — he read Somebody Blew Up America at a local poetry festival. In his fiery black nationalist days, Baraka once wrote that "We want poems that kill". When he reads, he breathes heavily, stomps his foot and becomes intoxicated with the rhythm — as much a musician as a poet Somebody Blew
Up America is long a series of questions begin - ning "Who ?" One stanza asks: Who knew the World Trade Center was gon - na get bombed Who told 4000 Israeli workers at the Twin Towers To stay home that day Why did Sharon stay away? The Anti-Defamation League and the local Jewish newspaper denounced the poem for propagating the "Big Lie" that Jews had been warned to stay away from the World Trade Cen - tre on the day of the attack. This preposterous conspiracy theory had quickly taken hold in much of the Muslim world. My own mother - in - law in Istanbul inquired about it after seeing it reported on Turkish TV. The theory seems to be based on the fact that the Israeli government said soon after the attack that it had received 4,000 calls from worried relatives, but was not immediately able to confirm any. Israeli deaths in the twin towers. "The claim that Jewish peo - ple have special knowledge of things they do not have special knowledge of is anti-Semitism ," said the ADL's Shai Goldstein. Baraka was once married to a Jewish wom - an , the poet Hettie Cohen. But he divorced her after renouncing white bohemianism and em - bracing black nationalism in the wake of the 1965 murder of Malcolm X. During a decade as a proponent of black cultural nationalism and self-confessed "whitey-hater ", he often criti - cised Jews in the rough language of the black ghetto. In the notorious Black People, for exam - ple , he enumerated the merchandise available in "Sears , Bambergers, Klein's, Hahnes', Chase and the smaller joosh enterprises" and advised blacks they could get it by saying the magic words: "Up against the wall mother f**** r this is a stick up!" Another of his lines declared: "I got the extermination blues, jew-boys ". Disappointed in the performance of black politicians he had helped win power, Baraka lat - er renounced black nationalism in favour of
Marxism, writing an essay titled "Confessions of a former Anti-Semite" — a headline he now in - sists he did not pick. But even after his conver - sion to class struggle, he continued to attract controversy with his attacks on Zionism. Baraka lives in a rambling wooden house in Newark that is stylishly adorned with African tribal objects and Modernist art. The family watched the World Trade Centre burning from a bathroom window on the second floor. When I sat down with the poet, he cut straight to the point: "In terms of there being some kind of an - ti - Semitic plot on my behalf to besmirch Jews, that is bizarre," he insisted. It is true, as Baraka pointed out, that Some - body Blew Up America contains passages that ap - pear to defend Jews. One section (misspelling Luxemburg and Liebknecht) reads, for instance: Who put the Jews in ovens, and who JieJped them do it Who said "America First" and ok'd the yellow stars Who killed Rosa Luxembourg, Liebneckt Who murdered the Rosenbergs But when Baraka tried to defend the passage about the. 4,000 Israeli workers who were told to "stay home", his reasoning became decidely bizarre. "The whole point I'm making is: we know Americans died. We know 81 nationalities WE ESSifiUlAL BARAKA The Fiction of LeRoi Jones by Amiri Bara - ka (A Capella, 01524 68765; £17,50) ©The LeRoi Jones/Amiri Baraka Reader Ed . William J Harris (Thunder's Mouth Press, USA, $16.95) © The Autobiography of Amiri Baraka (Freundlich Books, USA; $16.95) © Amiri Baraka: The Politics and Art of a Black Intellectual by Jerry Gafio Watts . (NYUP, 01752 202300; £25)
died. But tell me why the conspicuous absence of Israeli workers," he explained. "And the point I'm making then is not that I'm saying that Isra - el planned it, but that Israel knew, just like Bush knew, and that will obviously come out." In fact, Baraka believes both England and France also knew of the attack in advance. "They all sent warnings to the United States. And then they came out with that cockamamie excuse that they couldn't connect the dots," he said. The problem with Baraka's elaborate con - spiracy theory is that it lacks the most basic fact-checking . It hinges on the claim that no Is - raelis were among the 3,000 people killed — and that claim is just plain wrong. Unlike Bara - ka , I took the rudimentary precaution of calling the Israeli consulate in New York to ask about Israeli casualties. I quickly learnt that seven Is - raelis died that day, two of them on a hijacked plane and the rest in the twin towers. For the historical record, their names are: Daniel Lewin; Leon Leibo; Razu Vaev Alexey; Gui Bar Tzvi (all dual US-Israeli nationals); Hagai-Shefi ; Shai Levenhar; Alon Avraham. Richard Codey, Democratic state senator who introduced the legislation to strip Baraka of his official post, perhaps summed up Baraka's position best when he said tartly: "I think Mr Baraka would be better off writing movies for Oliver Stone than being the poet laureate of New Jersey." Baraka embraces political ideologies as poet - ic tropes , often very successfully. He could sim - ply defend his use of the myth about Israeli workers as a provocative poetic device. But he refuses to do so and instead insists on the literal truth of what he says. "I make no apologies for the work being po - litical , because 1 intend it to be political," he said. Then he added, with a final rhyming flour - ish that reveals much about his thought - pat - terns : "And it's not a bad thing to be attacked by your enemies. It shows, obviously, that you don't need an enema yet"
Amiri Baraka, now 68, cuts straight to the point in his rambling New Jersey home, his anger undiluted

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: On poetry's pilgrims
Full_text:
Rachel Campbell-Johnston
On poetry's pilgrims
rhythms, like a hammer tapping at the end of a bright nail, drive her points pre - cisely home. They pierce the subliminal layers of the mind They point at a deep - er truth. Henry Shukman makes an assured de - but with In Doctor No's Garden (Cape, £8; offer, £6.80). His poems are clear and un - laboured . Untempted to cram images, to try and impress with sputtering verbal py - rotechnics , he turns a slow, calm gaze on the world, captures what he sees with a skill that conceals his artistry. Beneath the understatement the emotion glints all the brighter. Shukman has a sharp eye for the de - scriptive detail, for the telephone wires that "belly between their poles" or the sky that "warps and sings like a saw". But he can move effortlessly from the con - crete to the abstract, from his wife in bed beside him breast feeding the baby to "things more important than my own sleepy head". In "Piano Solo", a haunting evocation of his mother sitting alone at
eoffrey Hill approaches the end of a journey. The Or - chards of Syon (Penguin, £9.99; offer, £8.49), the ^Swfei fourtn ^ ^"^ voi™ofa "^JjfpQ hard-fought sequence, has been compared with Dante's Paradiso. A tough, uncompromising literary intelli - gence arrives, if not triumphant then at least undefeated, at some consolation to sustain the pilgrim mind. He reaches a "hard-won knowledge of what wears us down". . This meandering, meditative poem is dense, complex, perplexing. But Hill is a legislator of the English language. No oth - er uving poet has attended more strin - gently to the materials of his trade. No other has monitored meaning more scep - tically , watched more vigilantly over mor - al implications. Truth may be intransi - gent It may not deliver itself neatly into epigrammatic packages. But readers may trust in Hill completely as he leads them out into open-mindedness . "Watch my hands/ confabulate their shadowed rhetoric," Hill writes. A critical eye oversees each line as it moves for - ward as a sketch might, sometimes confi - dent , sure of its sentiment, sometimes ten - tatively , worked and reworked as it spreads its slow map of the histories and philosophies , the memories and myths which give this world meaning. Hill's lines are the contours of an ances - tral landscape. They sculpt the culture in which his work is so deeply embedded .
This is what makes him England s most important Uving poet Andrew Motion, the poet officially nominated to speak for his country, pub - lishes his first collection since being ap - pointed Poet Laureate. Public Property (Faber, £12.99; offer, £10.39) includes works composed to commemorate the fu - neral of Diana, Princess of Wales, the 100th birthday and, later, the death of Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother. Bat Motion's imaginative resonance lies in a private world. It rises in a rural childhood, stemming from moments swallowed whole by memory, from the unexpected fragments of seeing that set the boy askance to his own experience and made of him a poet with an evoca - tive touch who could recall the "gust of wet air" that "made the lawn enormous", the weather that "twirled round and round/ whacking the wheat heads flat", the collie dog "licking her lips and swal - lowing with a half-whine ", the fish "asssembling itself from broken pieces of the world — gravel, wind, water, sun". His most successful pieces are those that let stories unspool at their own pace, patterns of rhyme and rhythm playing over the surface until some sudden mo -
ment of understanding snaps up the imag - ination . Public feeling finds its sharpest focus when reinterpreted in some mo - ment of intimacy. In Feminine Gospels (Picador, £12.99; of - fer , £10.39) Carol Ann Duffy uses familiar literary structures to present a teasing, quick-witted take on the contemporary woman's experience. She looks for the modern in the mythical, picks the fact from the fantastical, finds the truth inside the fairytale. Marilyn Monroe, like some classical goddess who has inflamed the appetite of Jupiter, is raped by the cam - era , by the omnipotent celebrity which her beauty attracts. Ovid's Metamor - p hoses finds modern parallel in Duffy's poem. "They filmed her harder, harder, till her hair/ was platinum,/ her teeth gems, her eyes/ sapphires pressed by a banker's thumb." Duffy never fumbles. She captures her meanings with one sharp snatch. Her freshness is as startling as a bang on the funny-bone . She scours out cliches and makes them shine. But even as her imag - es skip playfully along, the reader is aware of their darker insinuations, of the more sinister aspects of a story which might otherwise have seemed fun. Her
night battering out Bartok, "a weather/ of notes I wished would pass", Shukman is at his most accomplished. He evokes all that is unspoken, unsaid, and yet most im - portant at the same time. A raw, unpolished, impudent debut is made by Paul Fryer in Don't Be So (Phaid - on / A Trolley Publication, £24.95; offer, £19.96). Illustrated by Damien Hirst, it is the first of a series of volumes intended to mark the collaboration between artists and poets. Often the poems are awkward, the words recalcitrant, refusing to line up obediently and do what he wants. But there is a freshness in his energetic, street-smart approach. Fryer treats lan - guage quite literally as a physical materi - al . It is something to be fought against and twisted, to be wrested round to his will. This is sometimes a strength — when words become blunt instruments, when they smash home a point with col - loquial force and then laugh at the trick. More usually it is a sign that Fryer has some way to go.
Carol Ann Duffy's Feminine Gospels rewrites women 's lives with a quick wit

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Rachel Campbell-Johnston savours seasonal poetry
Full_text:
summer reading
Rachel Campbell-Johnston
_[" " ; o journey is to travel ' i into the imagination i ; as much as to discov - ; er new places and people . That is why _i . ', the poetry book makes the perfect companion. The slim volume that slips into the pocket lightly leads the traveller onwards into a deeper voyage of self-discovery . Dart (Faber £8.99; offer £7.64), a second collection by Alice Oswald, is published late this month. Make a note to buy it. This twiningly complex, gracefully lyrical volume traces the songlines of the river, tracks the course of the Dart from its source in Cranmere Pool on the "rain-coloured wilderness" of Dartmoor to the sea with its "musky fishy genital smell/of things not yet actual". For three years Oswald — whose first book, The Thing in the Gap-stone Stile, was ra ptur - ously received — has recorded her conversations with the peo - ple who live and work on this river — from the bailiff to the forester, from the tin extractor to the water abstractor , from the mythical water nymph to the historical figure who was swept to his death from a ford in the Victorian age: "all day my voice is being washed away/out of a lapse in my throat", he sings, "o I wish I was slammick - in g home /in wet clothes, shrammed with cold and biwer - ing but/this is my voice/under the spickety leaves/under the knee-nappered trees/rustling in its cubby holes".
Oswald has used these records, she explains in a fore - word , "as life-models from which to sketch out a ser ies of characters — linking their voic - es into a sound map of the river". Tones and dialects, prose cadences and verse rhythms flow together, plaiting rivulets of language and cadences of speech into a poem which spar - kles and shifts on the surface, but cuts a course that is embed - ded so deeply into the bones of the landscape that Oswald emerges as an inheritor of some of Br itain's greatest poetic voic - es , an heir to Ted Hughes, Sea - mus Heaney and Geoffrey Hill. Simon Armitage has also been on a journey. The Univer - sal Home Doctor (Faber £12.99; offer £10.39) sees him straying away from his native Yorkshire, exploring South American jun - gles and Australia's deserts. But, as always, Armitage's skill is to reach beyond the prosaic for deeper mysteries. A ticket
bought for a pound and pasted to a car windscreen in the park by the dunes is "stamped with the time" and so can tell us "how taken you are, how car - ried away by now, how deep and how far"; the dead gannet "beached between open water and blue sky/eating into the beach, feeding the sea", speaks with an utter lack of sent imen - tality or pomposity of the transcendent mysteries that lie beyond the ordinary moment. Similarly, in Source (Cape, £8; offer, £6.80) Mark Doty distils the philosophies that are opened up by feeling. He finds
not answers, but the questions that lead the way towards new questions which lead the reader further on the journey towards some sort of truth. This is what he describes as "the So? of poetry". It is the "littlest ques - tion ", but "Shiva built the world, / the story goes, /on a single syl - lable /heavenly irritant,/and the pearl /of reality grew ". Travelling, said Descartes, "is almost like talking with those of other centuries". Paul Farley in The Ice Age (Picador £7.99; of - fer £6.79) retraces lost routes. "This is how I get back_^in piec - es , the tang of a dream you can't
forget", he writes. His poems scoop up melted memories, re - c all their once crystalline struc - tures , recapture their lost gleam. "You can start with a washer, a throat-lozenge , a mouse-mat / and watch them move in like the weather", like a returning ice age that holds the mind in its still and sparkling grip. Roger McGough might make an entertaining drinking part - ner when you take a break in your travels and stop in the pub for a pint In his latest collection Everyday Eclipses (Viking £9.99; offer £8.49), Liverpool 's best-loved poetic son takes to
the bar stool with tales of en - counters with an assortment of rock legends, whether Bob Dy - lan , Paul McCartney or Jimi Hendrix. There are two sides to all his stories — arid it's always the flip side that he exposes, the insights that eclipse the prosaic and make life suddenly strange. His poems work like philosophi - cal puns. And at night, when you are sipping whisky round your campfire , or lying in the slippery nylon of your B&B sheets, you could always slip a CD into a portable player and put on your headphones to listen to the sto - ryteller Hugh Lupton recounting the tales of The Horses (£9 incl. p&p, from Hugh Lupton : 8 Church Terrace, Ayl - sham , Norfolk NR11 6EU). At the funeral of Jenny Wing , who used to babysit him as a child, Lupton listened to the vicar struggling to find something to say of the 104-year-old woman who had been brought up on a farm in South Cambridgeshire and had outlived her genera -
tion . As the vicar stumbled, the stories she had once told him came swimming into his head. In this "funeral oration that never happened ", folksong frames the two stories that weave a whole life around you, bringing the hard world of the late 19th-century farm back to life. You hear the voice of the farmer, "husky early in the morning", on the day that the horses were stolen: Violet, D ia - mon d , Beauty, Captain and Punch. You hear the horseman "speaking more in song than in words" as he calls them, "the sweet high whistle" that turned the working team on the plough, "the secret trill that urged the geldings on behind the wagon". You feel the warm rubbly breath, the hard curve of the nosebone, smell the must of the stables, the sweet harness soap and, as you journey back deeper into the world of imagi - nation , the tears that no one was there to shed at her funeral start slowly to well up inside you and spill.
Like the best poetry, you need to take a closer look to get the most out of Yann Arthus-Bertrand 's The Earth from the Air For Children (Thames & Hudson, £9.95)

Author: Katsoulis, Melissa
Title: Well versed
Full_text:
Well versed
WHEN THE poet Ruth Padel proposed a newspaper column consisting of a contemporary poem and her analysis of it, she thought it unlikely that readers would want anything as "unsexy". But the column was a success, prompting numerous readers to write in asking for more. Sadly, this fairytale relationship between public and poet cannot be extrapolated to the world at large. Even now that modern poetry is enjoying a so-called renaissance, few would claim that they can really "understand" a poem even if they do get pleasure from reading it. So Padel has produced a
special kind of compendium to take the fear out of modern verse. Fifty-two poems, from writers as diverse as Thorn Gunn and Rita Ann Higgins, are accompanied by companion pieces of textbook criticism. The critical essays dissect the poets' technique, revealing how and why they have written what they have. They read like A-level English essays mixed with the Idiot's Guide to Poetry. That said, Padel chooses her poems with impeccable taste, and this book will allow you to appreciate internal rhymes and Alexandrines where previously you saw only prose broken arbitrarily into lines. Her main achievement, though, is as an anthologist of the best of today's English poetry. The commentary is a bonus, but once you have got the hang of listening out for the phrasing of a line you probably won't need Padel to hold your hand. Melissa Katsoulis

Author: Bennett, Vanora
Title: Radio a weekend of poetry is music to Vanora Bennett's ears
Full_text:
RADIO A weekend of poetry is music to Vanora Bennett's ears
ONCE upon a time poets were drab, shy souls who fled-publicity and wrote their inaccessible lines alone in their garrets. Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother was _^famously bored stiff by hearing one of these awkward creatures droning - . through a long andjncomprehensible poem that she thought might have been - called TheDesert He was T.S. Eliot He reminded her of a bank manager. The Queen Mother would have been delighted by last weekend's poetry :; festival on Radio 4/lt was the station's . -' first attempt tp showcase all its current poetry slotsin one great jamboree,'; "" introduced by Andrew.Motion; the Poet Laureate, and cramrned with the nation's : _yqung talentBibf /antiI Ezra Pound might \ nottiaye been_^_interestedih- ; v:_^ ._' _cornmlinicatiriglwith a general audience, S_^utlast ' weekendshowed (thatpoets . _* _; ;:tod_3y;_knpwthattpgetthejrw 6rkread _^ - later_^_eyhave to_: enchant fistenersnow.; _^Performance poets are almost; ; : -; vf " . • • _:"/ _;' f ? ? _f >> :»:_» _f M > _i?' f> ! _»t »
comedians, almost musicians, or almost wild ventriloquists. Even the poets who basically think of their work as words on a page have become performing animals : — and that made for some excellent, entertaining radio. The weekend at the Lowry Centre in Manchester wasn't all perfect. Some of - the more scripted-sounding offerings — Motion's introduction on Saturday of five young poets shortlisted for an Arts Council prize, and the edition of Poetry Please featuring Sophie Hannah and Simon Armitage as well as the young prizewinner — had the timid, stilted feel of Classic FM. Poetry Please didn't quite . _- . have the nerve to stick to the festival's . doings and threw in a Shakespeare sonnet and a piece about Byron when you wanted it to be just that bit braver. _, But Go41t invited Jackie Kay, the. fabulously entertaining poet-in-residence , to talk to a child audience. You could hear them being drawn happily into her
world and losing any suspicion of verse as she performed poems and chatted vivaciously, with charm and at high speed, about anything from writing to Glaswegian slang. I enjoyed Rosie Boycott's laid-back late-night chat with Kay and Frank Delaney, the presenter of Poetry Please, about favourite books. And the Saturday night knees-up , presented by Lemn Sissay, with Manchester's liveliest performance poets as well as Roger McGough and one more burst of Kay, was a mind-stretching , euphoric , joyous entertainment, featuring Rommi Smith and her band with an effective fusion of spoken word and music. There was a lot more that I didn't manage to take in, but the message coming across loud and clear was that the old British suspicion of versifiers might at last be on the wane. There are differences in the kind of poetry that gets on to Radio 4 and Radio.3 —
broadly. Radio 3 may go for more difficult and experimental work, such as . Joby Talbott's haunting Between the Ears piece, The Watchers, on Sunday, which set CCTV and the surveillance. culture in a musical landscape evoking paranoia — but the sheer quantity of poetry on air is growing fast on both stations. Radio 3 is about to bring in unexpected snippets of poetry from its archives to fill in gaps if a concert underruns. Radio 4's Poetry Please has expanded from ten to 30 minutes; poetry has even been heard on the Today programme. Not that the subtle emotions of poetry are taking over completely. Those who prefer to consider words more analytically will have enjoyed the satirist Joe Queenan's pacy and entertaining consideration of irony, and the exaggerated reports of its death, on Radio 3's Sunday Feature. Guests, including Kathy Lette and Ian Hislop,
pondered such gems as Spike Milligan's epitaph, "I said I was ill"; and a briefly serious Hislop defended irony by suggesting it was what "helps you not to take too seriously the version of events foisted on you from outside". Word of Mouth , back for a new series, on Sunday offered insights into darts-commentator-speak , the cultural connotations of foxes and the __ compressed speech of new-style teenagers and old-style foreign correspondents . Those who want their words cut down .to their most basic components — shapes on a grid, anagrams, numbers of
letters and cryptic clues — can always struggle along with Colin Dexter's very dry Crosstalk. I won't be joining them. I were going to opt for a long, solitary, anxious battle with pencil and paper, I'd rather the end result was not a crossword puzzle with all the squares filled in, but a poem.

Author: Nightingale, Benedict
Title: Little poetry in stilted tale of an exile's return
Full_text:
little poetry in stilted tale of an exile's return
ATHOL FUGARD was often in trouble with the South Afri - can authorities, losing his pass - port in the 1960s, but his fear and outrage didn't put him to flight Instead, he worked with the likes of John Kani and Win - ston Ntshona on plays attack - ing the pass laws and the im - prisonment of black dissidents. But other writers left the country, arguing that they could fight apartheid more ef - fectively in places where they could freely publish what they felt. So what effect did exile have on them and their work? That's the question that the 69-year-old Fugard addresses in his his new Sorrows and Re - joicings , through the character of Dawid Olivier, an Afr ikaan - er poet who has returned from 17 years in London to die and be buried in his native Karoo. I'd like to say that the piece packs the emotional punch of some of his early protest plays; hut it doesn't . There's some -
thing stilted about the writing. At times it seems more a for - mal elegy than a living play. There 's good reason for Fu - gard 's elegiac tone, because he sets Sorrows and Rejoicings in Dawid's Karoo house just after his funeral, and the poet him - self appears only in intermit - tent flashback. But there's no reason why the piece 's pulse shouldn't race, given the three women on stage. One is his Anglo widow, Jennifer Steyn's
Allison. Another is Denise Newman's Marta, the maid he loved, made pregnant and left. And the third is the fruit of their union, the daughter he woefully neglected, Amrain Ismail-Essop 's Rebecca. Only Ismail-Essop , whose Rebecca spends most-of the evening standing silently and resentfully at the door of the living room in which she was conceived 18 years ago, adds much power to the produc - tion , which is Fugard's own (a mistake ?). The two older wom - en talk of their mutual resent - ment and pain, but you never feel their feelings are very strong , let alone visceral. That may be because their primary task is to describe and debate the dead man's tri bula - tions . The real drama is in the past , not the present: which
isnt , as it turns out, the most exciting place to be. In any case, the tale of Mar - ius Weyers's Dawid is a none - too - ori ginal one of disenchant - ment and disintegration. He re - nounces the "eager, hungry lit - tle faces" of black children in South Africa for a job in a posh London school. Though he tells himself that "exile is go - ing to give me back my voice" and poetry "is the only weap - on I've got", his poetry dries up and he becomes a soak. "If my writing ever had a heart, it's stopped beating ,"-he tells his now-estranged wife. Only when terminal leukae - mia is diagnosed does he find the pluck to return home.
Theatre Sorrows and Rejoicings Tricycle, NW6 _• _#_&_& -
Im sure that the guilt and demoralisation of exiles was part of the collateral damage wreaked by apartheid; but even the charismatic, emotion - ally resourceful Weyers has trouble making Fugard's oddly literary, sometimes even clunky, dialogue demonstrate this sad truth. And that means that the con - clusion , which is that the new South Africa should embrace whatever was "clean and clear and good" in people like Daw - id , comes across more as an eminent dramatist's rhetoric than as an impassioned citi - zen 's plea. The force is in the sentiments, not the action, not the characters, not the play. \3 Tricycle 020-73281000
Benedict Nightingale
Jennifer Steyn as Allison and Manus Weyers as Dawid in Athol Fugard s stilted, sometimes clunky Sorrows and Rejoicings

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Edge of experience
Full_text:
Edge of experience
—a——— i —.1 i THIS NEW collection of poems by Robin Robertson opens with: "We are drawn to edges, to our own/parapets and sea-walls ". His poetry balances along the mind's boundaries, looking forwards and backwards, outwards and inwards and finding its voice in the echoes that flicker between the two. But always beyond resonance or resolution lies an emptiness to which Robertson is most acutely alert It is this absence that his poems make present, the nothingness that they try to make felt
Yet these poems are rooted in the literal, in noticing and observing and describing. They never lose their anchor in the physical world. Robertson is a master of evocative depiction. He captures "that net of birds/ that moves/unloosened/ under bridges at dusk"; "the sea/wrecking itself against
the rocks", the flamingos that "rise through green beds on their high pink stems,/ swaying gently in full bloom: mesmeric,/self-mesmerised ". Robertson walks through the world like a beachcomber along the shore, picking up each object that catches his eye, turning it over, examining it, holding it up to the light He admires the reflections that glance from prismatic surfaces, he pauses to prod a dead animal with the toe of his boot
Particularly striking is the intensity of the attention that the poet offers each subject There is nothing unpremeditated, no sudden caprice The world is seen filtered through the slow delay of language. And Robertson calibrates this language as carefully as a locksmith his key, so that "the slow-grained slide to embed the blade/of the key is a sheathing,/a gliding on graphite" but when "the true key slots", when there is "a clinch of words", "the sung note snibs on meaning". It is this exactitude that gives Slow At its distinctive edge.
Rachel Campbell-Johnston

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Rhyme and reason
Full_text:
poetry

Amid the frantic efforts to track down presents for everyone , don't forget to treat yourself. And there is no better way to relax than escaping with a self-indulgent book ^M
By Rachel Campbell-Johnston
Do it with flowers. In Flora Poetlca (Chatto & Windus, E17.99/E14.39) Sarah Maguire pays floral tribute to poetic talent with a bouquet of botanical verse. Some 250 entries, spanning eight centuries, home in on horticultural enthusiams. It wasnt just Wordsworth who had an epiphany among the

From the roadside nettle ("I like the dust on nettles, never lost/Except to prove the sweetness of a shower" writes Edward Thomas) to the ancient and exotic ginkgo ("the oldest living captive race" whose "fallen yellow fruit mimics the
£/ scent/Of human Me vomit" writes aa Howard Nemerov) {W a Marvellian world H? overspills on to the WF pages. Everything HT in the garden is fiffi ^ lovely — or is it? £20/£16). "Nonsense is the breath of my nostrils" Lear wrote. He saw it as the only feasible response to "this ludicrously whirligig life which one suffers from first & laughs at afterwards". Collected for the first time into one definitive volume, readers will find Lear's four published books of nonsense along with letters, stories, a number of his illustrated alphabets and a few colour plates of his wildlife illustrations (including the VTtoe Monkey— Gleanings From The Menagerie And Aviary at Knowsley Had , 1846, left]. Some of the material has never been published before. All is extensively footnoted. So while children delight in such alliterative creatures as "The Zigzag Zealous Zebra", adults can also explore the life of the man who hid his wounds behind the whimsy, and of the maverick who made the ludicrous his muse.

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: The view centre
Full_text:
The view centre
poetry Rachel Campbell - Johnston " ~ / ~ " emember when you ." '" ,;. ; were a kid, a pint - ; .-;' . si/cd soiipsist at the " " ," ';' - centre of the uni - . - -„ . wr.se? The Poet Lau - - -' - ." n_'ate does. His new anthology, Here to Eternity (Faber £16-99 ; Books Direct, £13.59), harks back to that habit children have of writing their addresses — name first, then house, village, town, expanding outwards into ever-wider circles, coming to an end with "the world, the universe, space". Adapting this idea, Andrew Motion explores man's position in the world through a collection of poems themed by ten concen - tric subjects. Starting with the idea of "self and Louis Mac - Neice 's Prayer Before Birth, the inquiry widens, ideas overlap ping and interrelating, until, some 400 poems later, the vol - ume finishes with Henry
Books are the best presents . And the best books are present here — in part two of our continuing survey of the pick of this year's literary gifts
Vaughan: "I saw Eternity the other night,/ Like a great ring of pure and endless light". This anthology, its entries dat - ing back to Chaucer, includes plenty of old favourites. But the 20th-century slant is very strong. Giving all his more notable con - temporaries a look-in , Motion provides a serviceable representa - tion of today's poetic establish - ment — and sticks up for women and foreigners at the same time. Though personal preferences do sneak in—Bob Dylan is rep re - sented , and Edward Thomas (on whom Motion wrote a critical study) is allocated as many entries as Shakespeare — read - ers should not expect to draw the - n 1 Vfi i I- 1 J t '
same sort of lucky-dip prizes as they did from his predecessor's eccentric (and now classic) Battle - bag . The wheels run a little too smoothly. You may hear the mu - sic of the spheres , but Faber — which devotes so much of its poet - ic energy to repackaging — was probably more concerned about producing a moneyspinner. Any new volume by Geoffrey Hill is welcomed by admirers of his tenacious intelligence, his dark prophetic vision, his resolve to wrest truths from language. But his latest collection, Speech! Speech! (Penguin, £9.99; Books Direct, £8.49), finds him at break - ing point. An all-consuming urge to communicate struggles with the words which refuse to deliver
their meanings straight. "Erudition . Pain. Light" a poem begins . It's an indication of what's to come. Here are 120 stanzas (one for each of the days of Sodom) to get your teeth into instead of the jumbo crossword. Hill engages in every kind of word game, wrestles with every Protean trick of speech. The poetry is so impenetrable, so widely allusive, so fragmented, it becomes frustrating/ But when you think you will have to give up, a needle 's eye of insight suddenly opens and your mind is drawn through it, an un - spoling thread. Spend a day con - sidering the surreal as a "loss of peripheral vision" for instance, and nnrice how fantastical the
whole world suddenly seems. Derrek Hines simplifies rather than complicates. He takes the ancient fable of Gilgamesh, first told when the Bible was still a twinkle in God the Father's eye , and does to it what West Side Story did for Romeo and Juliet. His Gilgamesh (Chatto, £8.99; Books Direct, £7.64) is less a "pass notes" style introduction to an epic (which can be read in a
literal — and hence much length - ier — version in Andrew George's excellent Penguin Clas - sic s translation) than a variation on a theme. Better not to bear the original too much in mind. Hines's energetic metaphors, nimble wit and laddish tone re - vivify the thrill of a very old tale. Christopher Logue's version of the Iliad, its first three volumes now collected under the title War Music (Faber, £12.99; Books Di - rect , £10.39), is similar. He brings a cinematic perspective and a modern sensibility to Hom - er 's epic narrative. "Just tumbled on Christopher Logue's extraordi - nary rendition," wrote Henry Miller some 40 years ago when he chanced on the opening sec - tions of a work whose piecemeal publication over the intervening years has come to be heralded as a literary event. "If only Homer were anywhere near as good." Logue goes straight for the dra - ma . Forceful language, powerful images and the strong, rolling rhythms of the iambic pentame - ter draw the reader onwards.
The frequent transitions between direct speech and commentary, and the sharp, almost filmic, scene cuts keep the imagination fresh. Logue's skill is to condense and clarify. He distils the essence of an ancient text. John Updike is probably best known for his Pulitzer Prize - win - ning "Rabbit" novels. And read - ers will find echoes of their light - hearted sophistication in his Americana and Other Poems
(Penguin, £10.99; BooksDirect, £8.79). Updike is almost 70, but his eye remains as sharp as his pen. A TV remote "waits by the bed like a suicide pistol", a coas t - line is as flat "as a brain-dead's beep". But it's his subject matter which will strike readers forci - bly . The first section of this volume is about planes, the no - man 's land of the domestic flight . In one poem he explores our fears of the "sweaty , swarthy/
gentleman of Middle Eastern origin/ whose carry-on luggage consists of a bulky black briefcase/... Who wants to have all their careful packing — the trav/eller's checks, the folded un - derwear — / end as floating sea - wrack five miles below,/ drifting in a rainbow scum of jet fuel?" He adds: "The possibility of impossibility will keep drawing us back / to this scrape against the numbed sky."

Title: Poetry? Don't mind if he does

However, m |pf f§§ j Shane MacGow - l £if m3 ZS&l an, once of the Pogues and now with the Popes, seems to have pulled it off in life. I meet him and his longtime amour, journalist and biogra - pher , Victoria Clarke, in their fa - vourite Dublin restaurant, the Trocadero, just around the cor - ner from Blooms, the hotel that MacGowan seems to have adopt - ed as his spiritual home. Having met MacGowan a cou - ple of times before, I know what to expect: the crumpled, mysteri -
ously stained suit, the ghostly pal - lor , the dreadful dental abattoir of a mouth, the cheerful abuse ("You 're a complete moron, what kind of stupid question is that?"), the occasional mouth-breathing naps at the table and, strangely enough, the elegance, wasted though' it might be. The quick wit, the intelligence , the melan - cholic sweetness, the raffish charm and outlaw defiance. "I seriously don't care if I never make another record again," he says . "I could get all the gigs I want, anytime I like. I'd say. 'Just give me a free drink and a bed to sleep in, and I'll sing.' I'd never be short of work, and I'd proba - . bly be a lot happier."
Certainly, whatever else MacGowan might be (and he can be terribly rude: "I don't give a s**t that your daughter is called Erin" ), there is no denying that he has the X factor which makes admirers from all over the world forgive his misdemeanours, re - joice in his achievements, and al - ways keep an eye and an ear open for what he might be get - ting up to. Maybe this is why, even sitting quietly at the restaurant table, MacGowan has a steady stream of wellwishers — friends and strangers — coming up to shake his hand, clutch his arm in a fond , brotherly fashion, or pat him on the back. The number of times this happens, anyone would think that MacGowan was some kind of unusual sight in Dublin, a religious vision in himself, and that this was his
POP Everything you ever heard about Shane MacGowan is true.— and then there's the good bits, says Barbara Ellen
fans' only chance to talk to him. "How you doing, Shane?' they say fondly, or, just as frequently, "Well done, Shane!" What are they congratulating MacGowan for, you wonder. Cynics might say that it's his legendary drink - ing habits, much documented in his increasingly fractious deal - ings with the media. All of which came to a sticky head when Sinead O'Connor shopped him to the authorities a little while back. O'Connor insisted that she'd done it for his own good, and that she'd found MacGowan lying in a heroin-induced stupor on the floor. MacGowan claims he was sitting on the sofa, watc h - ing a. Sam Peckinpah video, when O'Connor burst in. "I don't know what she was try - ing to do," he groans, "and I dont give a damn what she thought . She's dead as far as I'm concerned."
I'm not well-read . It's only next to moronic rock stars that I look well-read
But she was obviously trying to help , I say, she clearly loved you, well, tough-loved you any - way . "That 's her problem," he
growls, annoyed. "I don't want to know about her or talk about her any more." Another growl. "No comment" It's fair to say that public affec - tion for MacGowan and his work seems to run a lot deeper than mere vicarious pride inhis alcoholic machismo or druggy past. "I don't do Class A drugs any more," he sighs. "I want to make that clear. I get very p****d off when people try to make out that I'm out of it all the time. I just like a drink. Who doesn't ?" He laughs. "Who doesn't that's at all interesting, anyway?" Clarke agrees. "That 's one of the reasons why I wrote the book \A Drink with Shane MacGow - an ] really. Shane is always being portrayed as some kind of drunk - en moron, when really he is this very intelligent man who knows lots about Irish history, politics, literature and poetry. And, I think, one of the greatest ever storytellers. A genius, really." Clarke herself is best known for her astonishing spat with Courtney Love over a never - to - be - published Nirvana biogra - phy , which led, she alleges, to her being threatened by grunge's First Lady and the late Kurt Cobain in a series of answer -
phone messages. They were aw - ful ," confirms MacGowan. "They sent a chill down my spine." Clarke decided to present A Drink with Shane MadGowan in a question-and-answer format when writing it more formally had the effect of stifling MacGow - an 's singular narrative style . She took her material from a series of rants (sometimes in hotels, some - times in airports, never entirely sober). What emerges is a hugely funny; interesting and moving memoir, which tells the story of MacGowan's happy, albeit frac - tured , childhood in Ireland, then England, his musical genesis
and career, and even manages to incorporate his encyclopaedic knowledge of Irish culture and history. "I am not well-read ," he insists, adding mischievously, "It 's only next to moronic English rock stars that I look well read." As A Drink with Shane MacGowan proves, Shane is very well-read , underlining his status as a definitive Irish song - writer . Indeed, with global hits such as Fairytale of New York, Pair of Brown Eyes and Rainy Night in Soho, it's apparent that, as much as Van Morrison, he
Shane is always portrayed as some drunken moron, when really he is very intelligent
clearly qualified for the job of writing his memoir. MacGowan, for his part, loves it ("I 'm very proud of what Victoria's done" ) even though he has his beefs, about alleged misprints and inac - curacies and, it seems, the very idea of a memoir. "I admit I wanted the autobiog - raphy written," he says. "It was supreme arrogance , a terrible mistake on my part. I was so drunk I didn't even know what I was saying ." "That's absolute b*****^" says Clarke. "You were as sober as you are now. You had lots of op -
portunities to take out bits you didnt like, and you never did." "I 'm a busy man," yells MacGowan, affronted. "You were watching televi - sion !" counters Clarke, adding, "if you're afraid of looking arro - gant , then forget it, because you are arrogant." Any more of this and they will become my favour - ite couple. Indeed, it's like this a lot with MacGowan and Clarke — one moment smiling, gooey-eyed at each other, the next sparring vi - ciously , if good-humouredly . Will they get married? "Oh yes." What about children? "None of your business," MacGowan snorts. Later he says to Clarke: "It wouldn't work. I wouldn't change nappies and nor would you . You'd be the worst. You'd go to Thailand and never come back. I'd be stuck with them." And MacGowan glares point - edly at me, then emits one of his death-rattle laughs. As ever, it's very hard not to laugh with him.
• A Drink with Shane MacGowan is published on March 23 by Sidg - wick B Jackson. The Very Best of the Pogues is released by Warner ESP
has become a kind of creative touchstone for Ireland. A some - what dishevelled, surly touch - stone maybe f'Stop bloody nag - g ing ," he tells Clarke when she tries to get him to leave with her. "I'll go when I've finished my drink" ), but a touchstone none - theless . Certainly, when those Dubliners came up to MacGow - an it was almost as if they were thanking him for sticking at it, telling his story and theirs, keep - ing the blood, guts and poetry of the real Ireland alive. Whatever. After 20 years of knowing MacGowan, Clarke is
Shane MacGowan doing what he does best — adding to the gaiety of nations with his wit and storytelling

Author: Dickson, E. Jane
Title: Transfixed by the bloody battlefield
Full_text:
Word of mouth E. Jane Dickson
Transfixed by the bloody battlefield
The novelist Pat Barker shares a connection to the Great War with her favourite poet, Ted Hughes
NEW SELECTED POEMS 1957-1994
Ted Hughes Faber & Faber £9.99
lp| AT Barker was shocked by 1—^ her first reading of Ted JL Hughes's poetry. It was the shock of recognition. "It was the English countryside depicted as it actually is," says the Booker Prize-winning novelist. "I would have been in my mid-teens when Hughes's first collection. The Hawk in the Rain (1957), was pub - lished . I had recently moved to Tee - side from rural West Yorkshire where I spent most of my childhood. "I didn't want to move to the town and what struck me particu - larly when I picked up Hughes in die town library was that I could hear the Yorkshire dialect in his poeiry and also see the West York - shire landscape thai I loved." Hughes's bloody-taloned hawk is the nightmare antithesis of Keats's warbling nightingale, and this was something which Barker fiercely identified with. . "The realism of the descriptions of the animals in Hughes's poetry -- the hawk, the pike, the bull — was something 1 could relate to. One of the many English hypocri - sies is thai people don't want to think of what happens between the cow in the field and the beefburger on their plate, it's certainly not an aspect of the countryside that you find represented in English litera - ture , bui you do find it in Hughes. He has been criticised for being ex - cessively brutal, excessively violent, but nature is excessive. "I grew up on a farm; my grand - father was a slaughterman. I relat - ed to that violence." Barker was brought up from birth by her grandparents. Her grandfather, a veteran of the First World War, was the dominant fig - ure in her early life and the inspira - tion for her highly acclaimed trilo - gy of novels about the Great War, Regeneration (which has been made into a feature Sim), The Eye in The Door and The Ghost Road (winner of the 199$ Booker Prize).
As a child, she watched her grandfather washing at the sink and was fascinated by the scarring on his body from a bayonet wound. 'The unspoken thing in our house was my grandfather's bayo - net wound and my grandfather not talking about how he got his bayo - net wound," Barker says. "In later life, when he was dying of cancer, his interpretation of the symptoms of his cancer was that the bayonet wound had opened up ." It is easy to imagine the impact Hughes's poem Bayonet Charge had on a teenager who had grown up with this livid symbolism. Barker quotes the lines: "In what cold clockwork of the stars and the nations/Was he the hand pointing, that second?" She says it with quiet intensity, more mantra than recita - tion . "It 's probably one of the weak - er poems in the collection but even if it doesn't quite come off, it's a hugely powerful image." Still more impressive, for Barker, is the poem Six Young Men. in which Hughes contemplates a photo of long-dead soldiers. 'The poem gives very powerfully the impression that the Great War is something that is still around. Hughes calls it 'the national ghost'. His father fought in the First World War and it must have been the ghost in the house where he was growing up. It was certainly the ghost in ours." The incalculable losses of that war will never be reconciled, says Barker, who presents the Armistice Day programmes on BBC Knowl - edge . "We were filming at the war' graves," she recalls, "and I walked around a graveyard behind a young man, who was about 19 years old. He turned to me and said: 'But they were my age', and he was very shocked." ^ . .„..,. >,.,. „.;, Yet in Hughes's " poetry.-it :VKas,the, living argument, not the commemo - ration of the dead, which so deeply impressed her. "Hughes talks
about this ghost which is still 'every - where , molesting everybody' and the reason he gives for it is that be - cause of the hostility that grew up between the fighting men at the front and the people at home who were totally uncomprehending of what was going on in France, you have got some of the resonance of a civil war. It is an argument I hadn't heard advanced by anyone else. That is why it is so difficult for us to put this particular war to sleep." As veterans grow fewer with each Armistice Day, Barker recognises that the "direct inheritance" — that personal connection with the First World War — is disappearing. Jingoism is not appropriate in a modern Europe. And the point, she insists, is not that we should not for - get , but that we cannot forget. "I think Hughes was right: mat chasm, that huge crater left in socie - ty by the First World War, was psychologically like a civil war. And no nation can afford to forget its civil war." . Pat .Barker introduces Armistice, . Day , a day of programmes commemorating the First World War, on BBC Knowledge today
THE BEDROOM OF THE MISTER'S WIFE
Philip Hensher Vintage £6.99
P HILIP Hensher's short story collection, The Bedroom of the Mister's Wife, is an oddly random affair. There is seemingly no link between these stories of qui - et dismay: rather a series of distinct images, like lives glimpsed for an instant in lighted windows. The characters Hensher chooses to impersonate — a barefoot boy at a missionary school, a clubber pumped up on Ecstasy, a frustrated secretary, a gay civil servant, an in - ternational terrorist — might be plucked from a hat for all the rela - tion they bear each other, yet all im - plant themselves in the reader's con - sciousness with peculiar tenacity. Hensher turns a flat but forgiv - ing light on a world where people are, on the whole, disappointed. One of the stories is set in Czecho - slovakia in the aftermath of the Prague Spring. Another concerns a 'Hensher turns a forgiving light on a world where people are disappointed'
Russian emigre locked in a person - al vendetta against Stalin's daugh - ter . Even when he's writing about the anonymity of London life or the stifled screams of suburbia, there is a faintly Middle European cast to Hensher's stories. Chekhov would approve of these profoundly ordinary lives, illumi - nated , if rarely ennobled, by pas - sion . In one tale, an aimless man, the much-stigmatised archetypal loner, finds new purpose in his deci - sion to kill his noisy neighbours. In another, an office worker con - demne d to the living hell of writing ads for porcelain figurines, sets out to dismantle a colleague's marriage with a callousness that is almost exhilarating. The rich black seam of humour running through the stories keeps the reader digging away through layers of careful urbanity and ennui. At times Hensher's humour takes an absurdist turn, as in the cautionary tale in which a young professional dies in an attempt to reach the top of the London pro - perty ladder. There is a broad, almost cinema t - ic , humour in the description of German prison guards trying to
impersonate the shrieking, unhing - ed terrorist Ulrike Meinhof, for a rigged identity parade. The short story is a kind of distil - lation process; lives are shrunk to the space of an afternoon, grand ob - sessions reduced to a gesture. In The Bedroom of the Mister's Wife, the writing is filtered and refined until the prose runs clear as gin. Hensher hits the ground run - ning with each new narrative, but somehow the reader believes in the existence of these characters out - side the confines of their particular story : a good trick to pull off in a full-blown novel. In a short story, it is spectacular . EJD

recalls Szirtes . "For those first few years in the Seventies, I think I would have been lost without him." Szirtes 's first published poem appeared in the TLS in 1973. For the next five years , his work appeared intermittently in liter - ar y magazines, before he finally published his first book, The Slant Door , in 1979. Yet the real turning point in his poetry came in 1975, when his mother committed suicide. She had had a weak heart since con - tracting rheumatic fever as a girl. "It was a miracle she survived Ravensbruck ," says Szirtes. "She suffered badly and was in con - s t ant pain . That was certainly a factor when she ended her life. But also, there was a sense — ex - ile is maybe too grand a word — that being away from everything that meant most to her got to her in the end." Her death changed the way Szirtes wrote. "Up until then my chief influences would have been Blake and Rimbaud. I was a
Romantic. After she died I want - ed to write one poem that would hold everything together. The poem that did that was called At the Dressing-table Mirror. It was the first poem that The Listener published. I had become a more formal poet." At the Dressing-table Mirror seems a simple poem. It contains two people, an interior and a brief exchange of glances, based on a memory from his childhood in Budapest. Yet to capture that moment took six months, and more graft than any of his previous efforts. Although the poem is included in The Budapest File, it was writ - ten at a time when the city meant little to him. His visits to Hunga - ry during the Eighties, and his de - veloping skills as a poet, howev - er , led to longer, more explorato - ry poems that pieced together his family's past.
