Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Uncurling a fistful of memories
Full_text:
Uncurling a fistful of memories
Sense of tradition is the perfect excuse for succumbing to poetry as we ring in a new millennium, says Rachel Campbell-Johnston
Can you imagine intro - ducing yourself as an "unacknowledged legislator of the world" ? Things have clearly changed since the days of young Shelley. I mean, poetry? .. .isn't that a bit like talking to yourself? Like dropping a rose petal into the Grand Canyon and waiting for the echo? Well, no, not at the moment. The sound has been turned up on the slim volume of late. This probably had quite a lot to do with debate over the new laureate. But, as far as public poetry is concerned, being on the brink of a new epoch has certainly helped. Britain has succumbed to
the millennial cult of commem - oration . In search of fit ceremo - nies to mark the great moment we turn to tradition — much as a mother , with the birth of a new baby, might rummage for the family christening robe. Poetry may have had to struggle for attention this cen - tury . It may have gone to ground with the Georgians and got mired up with the Movement. But with the arriv - al of a new millennium it has been pulled out of the old chest, freshly laundered and newly pressed. Hardly surprising then that a poet should have been ap - pointed to the Dome. So much money has been invested in
this Teflon folly that it had to be dignified in some way, had to be made to seem important to a public who paid for it with their lottery flutters. So earlier this year Simon Armitage, one of Britain's foremost young po - ets , was approached by the New Millennium Experience Company to write "some - thing " to mark the occasion, "something" to be declaimed in the Dome. "I suggested I would write 1,000 lines," says Armitage. "Rather stupid since I don't usually get past the bottom of the page. But then writing is what I do and this commission was like taking my job on the chin."
His finished work, Killing Time, to be published on New Year's Eve, takes inspiration from the news events of the past 12 months — from "an y - thing that tweaked my con - science ". Armitage "uncurls the stubborn fist of what is gone" with a bold, energetic, sceptical account of the age which alights on anything from Bjork to breaches in the ozone layer, from the Soho bombing to Bill Gates, from mobile phones to the Balkans. "I saw this poem as a sort of time capsule," he explains, "grabbing things out of time, however intense or banal." But does Killing Time serve its purpose as a public poem? Armitage, who was writing it during the months when the laureateship was under discus - sion , was constantly aware of debate as to the purpose and nature of public poetry in a contemporary age.
The rhythms of declam - atory verse sound lu - dicrously gallumph - ing to the modern ear. The grandiloquent Victorian verse structure vanished with its greatest architects, Kipling and Tennyson. "In the Victori - an age," says Armitage, "there was a prevalent idea that things should last forever. But I don't think that global, wordy language works any more. I was brought up in a pop culture of'enjoy things for what they are at the time' and I'm not sure that poetry hasn't changed to reflect that." Poet and novelist Helen Dunmore suggests that the only distinction between the public and the private poem now is that the former deals with national or political is - sues . "I 'm not sure that you can have public poetry with - out politics," she says, citing the intense political commit - ment of Louis MacNeice's Au - tumn Journal. (It was, inciden - tally , on the leapfrogging rhythms of this poem that Ar - mitage modelled his Killing Time.) Still the problem remains: which voice should a public poet adopt in order to stay true to his thoughts and emotions and, at the same time, convey them to a wider audience? "It is ridiculous in this day and age to imagine that we have a national voice," says ^
the Poet Laureate, Andrew Mo - tion . 'There is no one voice which speaks for everyone. What a public poet probably needs is a private voice which resonates in public spaces." Armitage agrees. 'The amaz - ing thing about art," he says, "is that you think a feeling is individual and then you find that hundreds of people feel the same. The ideas that are peddled on a day-to-day basis are the ones that people recog - nise the most." "I don't think that there is any necessary distinction be - tween the commissioned pub - lic poem and the private one," says James Fenton, formerly Professor of Poetry at Oxford. He uses the work of Seamus Heaney as an example. "Heaney wrote many poems to do with the deaths of friends, with events in Ulster . They have become the public poetry of Ireland although in
no sense were they commis - sioned . Ted Hughes, on the other hand, as Laureate, made the somewhat eccentric choice of putting his deeply personal mythology at the service of the Royal occasion. When they were published everyone main - tained a respectful silence." Of course, a principal prob - lem for anyone commissioned to write a public piece is the deadline. Where anyone else might scrumple up failed at - tempts into the bin and await further inspiration , the com - missioned poet must produce. There is bound to be a high failure rate. Killing Time highlights this — although probably without intending to — for Armitage serves as a sort of retrospective laureate for those vacant months between the death of Hughes and the appointment of Motion . It is hard not to feel that he has dodged many of
the charges of melodrama, op - portunism , inaptness and in - eptness to which any public poem is inevitably open, by vir - tue of the fact that he has had time for reflection. "Perhaps fu - ture laureates should not feel impelled to react instantane - ously to events," suggests Helen Dunmore. Certainly a central theme of Armitage's poem is a sense of the manipulation of an infor - mation age, a sense of a media that imprints ready-processed sentiments upon people. He is sceptical of news "that starts as business, ends as enter tain - ment ", of the cold-blooded pur - suit of "the story". In the end, for the public as much as the private writer, there is only one touchstone: the self. "Every poet has to be true to his own artistic na - ture ," says Fenton. This at - tempted fidelity is what comes across most strongly in Kill -
ing Time. The poem draws to its close in a quietly personal space : "And finally, last week in a West Yorkshire village/ nothing happened at all./ An incident room is being set up at the scene,/ and security cam - eras installed." We may call it the millenni - um . We may call it history. We may make a record of our times — but all that makes it up in the final assessment is lots of small moments in the lives of thousands of people. All the public poet can really acknowledge is himself as a part of this. "After all," says A r - mita ge , "you can't be an unac - knowledged legislator of the world if you are sitting at a writing desk acknowledging it to yourself all the time". Killing Time will be broad - cast on Radio 3 on December 18 and on Channel 4 televi - sion on New Year's Day.
Meanwhile, somewhere in the state of Colorado, armed to the teeth with thousands of flowers, two boys entered the front door of their own high school and for almost four hours gave floral tributes to fellow students and members of staff, beginning with red roses strewn amongst unsuspecting pupils during their lunch hour, followed by posies of peace lilies and wild orchids. Most thought the whole show was one elaborate hoax using silk replicas of the real thing, plastic imitations, exquisite practical jokes, but the flowers were no more fake than you or I, and were handed out as compliments returned, favours repaid, in good faith, straight from the heart. No would not be taken for an answer. Therefore a daffodil was tucked behind the ear of a boy in a baseball hat, and marigolds and peonies threaded through the hair
of those caught on the stairs or spotted along corridors, until every pupil who looked up from behind a desk could expect to be met with at least a petal or a dusting of pollen, if not an entire daisy-chain , or the colour-burst of a dozen foxgloves, flowering for all their worth, or a buttonhole to the breast. Upstairs in the school library, individuals were singled out for special attention: some were showered with blossom, others wore their blooms like brooches or medallions; even those who turned their backs or refused point-blank to accept such honours were decorated with buds, unseasonable fruits and rosettes the same as the others. By which time a crowd had gathered outside the school, drawn through suburbia by the rumour of flowers in full bloom, drawn through the air like butterflies to buddleia, like honey bees to honeysuckle, like hummingbirds dipping their tongues in, some to soak up such over-exuberance of thought, others to savour the goings-on . Finally, overcome by their own munificence or hay fever, the flower-boys pinned the last blooms on themselves, somewhat selfishly perhaps, but had also planned further surprises for those who swept through the aftermath of broom and buttercup:
garlands and bouquets were planted in lockers and cupboards, timed to erupt like the first day of spring into the arms of those who, during the first bout, either by fate or chance had somehow been overlooked and missed out. Experts are now trying to say how two apparently quiet kids from an apple-pie town could get their hands on a veritable rain-forest of plants and bring down a whole botanical digest of one species or another onto the heads of classmates and teachers, and where such fascination began, and why it should lead to an outpouring of this nature. And even though many believe that flowers should be kept in expert hands only, or left to specialists in the field such as florists, the law of the land dictates that God, guts and gardening made the country what it is today and for as long as the flower industry can see to it things are staying that way. What they reckon is this: deny a person the right to carry flowers of his own and he's liable to wind up on the business end of a flower somebody else has grown. As for the two boys, it's back to the same old debate: is it something in the mind that grows from birth, like a seed, or is it society makes a person that kind?
from KILLING TIME by Simon Armitage

The Poet Laureate, Andrew Motion, will join Simon Armitage, the poet for the Millennium Dome; Jo Shapcott, one of the most distinctive and original voices in contemporary poetry,
whose most recent collection has been shortlisted for the Forward Prize, and Christopher Reid, former Poetry Editor at Faber & Faber, with five prize-winning collections to his name. The reading will be held at Brunei Gallery Theatre, Thornhaugh Street, London WC1. Tickets are £10 and £7.50 for concessions (students, over-60 s and unemployed on production of a valid ID) and include £2 off any of the poets' books.

Author: Barnard, Matt
Title: 'Splurge of emotion' or a combination of inspiration and craft? Poetry's great debate and the lessons of rhyme and reason
Full_text:
A A A ' ^** ' ' . £ind tli6 lessons of Thvm p and rp£t ^nn
While poetry 's torchbearers continue to argue the role of its formal armoury , Matt Barnard finds a school where metre still matters The publication of Birthday Letters, by Ted Hughes, and the subsequent death of the Poet Laureate, were two unusual events in the world of poetry. Neither, in itself , is par ticular - ly out of the ordinary — poets die like everyone else and pain - ful , personal relationships are the staple subject matter for most of them while they are alive. What was unusual was that both events saw poetry break free of the essentially parochial world to which it is usually confined. While poetry traditionally takes on the great themes of life, poets are largely talking to each other. The newly appointed Poet Laureate, Andrew Motion, has been telling anyone who will listen that his mission is to
make poetry "part of the conversation of Britain" . The fact that people are more inter - es t e d in reading about the vitriol that Motion's appoint - ment inspired than the signifi - cance of the role he should play, or his own poetry, perhaps illustrates the difficult job that lies ahead. The brutal truth is that although poetry is periodically hailed as the new rock'n'roll, it just doesn't sell. Considering that none but the most famous poets such as Seamus Heaney cannot hope to sell more than a few thousand copies, the fact
that Birthday Letters sold 200,000 in hardback and so far has got to 130,000 sales in paperback is extraordinary. In large part it can be explained by the fact that Plath and Hughes are the Posh and Beckham of the chat - tering classes. But credit must also go to the writing, and the fact that the language is so accessible. As all the polls to find the nation's favourite poem indicate, most people agree with the Literary Review Editor Auberon Waugh's view that poetry should "rhyme, scan and make sense".
B irthday Letters un - doubtedly makes sense. However, it fails to obey Waugh's other pre - cepts for "proper poetry" . It is written in free verse, which most poets find hard to define in any concrete way except by what it is not, ie, poetry which follows formal, metrical rules. It occupies the same position in poetry that modern art does in the art world. Just as it is hard for most people to accept that a cow, sliced and pre - served in formaldehyde, can be "proper art" , many people find it hard to understand how free verse can be "proper poetry". Most people also believe, like Waugh, that free verse has come to dominate modern poetry: "Of course, a lot of these modern so-called poets do occasionally doff their caps towards scansion and rhyme, but they dont use it in a signifi - cant way. Heaney has written one or two things which make
you sit up, but I think he is someone who could try a bit harder and produce some good stuff," he says. However, most poets would disagree with Waugh's assess - ment , not only in the case of Heaney, but that most modern poetry is written in free verse. Peter Forbes, Editor of the Poetry Review, believes that many people havea mistaken impression of modern poetry: "It annoys me that people have this impression that formal poetry has disap - peare d . If you look at the ma - jor poets of the century, they all have great formal skill. Auberon's attitude is very counter-productive ." Though Motion emphasises the importance of emotion and feeling in poetry, he is in no doubt of the importance of the role the formal side of the art has: "I feel that one of the great
benefits of being a Post - Mod - ernist poet (as opposed to Post-Modernist ) is that we dont feel we have to make hard and fast decisions about whether to write in strict form or free verse — we are free to choose the form that fits the poem." In fact, though free verse was dominant in the middle part of the century, the pendu - lum has swung back towards metrical poetry in the past two decades. However, given that most poets will argue that even if you write free verse it is vital that you have an under - standing of the formal side of poetry, it is perhaps surpris - in g that aspiring poets find it so hard to get any guidance on metre, rhyme and the rest of
poetry's formal armoury. Most of the myriad poetry groups around the country will hardly touch upon the formal side of poetry, pre - ferring instead a group feedback approach, and even some of the now numerous MA courses in creative wri t - ing do not include it in their syllabus. Motion is also head of the MA in creative writing at the University of East Anglia. As the oldest and most famous creative writing MA in Brit - ain , it is able to select the best applicants, most of whom arrive at the course already accomplished writers. How - ever , Motion finds that even they often have to begin from scratch: "I have to say that,
brilliant as a lot of them are, they do tend to arrive without any knowledge of the formal aspects of poetry." One of the prob - lems is that while it is accept - e d that other art forms can and should be taught formally, many people do not accept that writing can be taught in a similar way, and even now the term "creative writing course" conjures up images of people sitting around in a field with flowers in their hair. Writing is seen as a splurge of emotion rather than a combination of inspiration and craft. This is perhaps why art schools and drama schools are
common, while writing schools are almost unheard of. It is one of the things that inspired the poet Mimi Khal - vati , herself a graduate of a drama school, to set up the London-based Poetry School, along with two fellow poets. Versification courses, which teach the formal aspects of po - etry , are common in America, but the one taught by Khalvati at the Poetry School is one of a small number in Britain. Khalvati believes that it is vital to learn different poetry techniques because a poet who tends to stick to one form of poetry will tend to write only one sort of poem. She is keen

SEAMUS HEANEY'S translation of the Anglo-Saxon poem Beowulf and Ted Hughes's version of Aeschylus's The Oresteia, (both Faber) are among the most eager - l y - awaited books of the autumn. The visceral, language of the poets is expected to capture the violence of the originals. On a lighter note, Carol Ann Duffy takes a sidelong look at his - tory through the eyes of the wives of famous men, The World's Wife (Picador), and the expansive Aus - tralian poet, Les Murray, follows up his modern odyssey, Fredy Neptune , with a new collection, Conscious & Verbal (Carcanet). work well with metre you need the detail." The main principle of Khal - vati 's course, as- with most versification courses, is that it has to be learning by doing. Many people use the analogy
"Initially I dare people to write terrible cliche or gibber - ish ," Khalvati says, "because if you try to do everything at once — try to learn metre but at the same time try to produce great lines of poetry — you wont be able to." Most people don't under - stand the language of poetry and find it intimidating and dull. As the poet Michael Donaghy asks: "Can you imag - ine how you'd feel about music if the only way you encountered it was if you had to analyse a piece in the classroom?" Until people are given a way to connect with poetry, the notion of a poetry bestseller will remain an oxymoron. 19 To contact The Poetry School , write to: Stuart Mayes, la Jewel Road, Walthamstow, London, E174QU. It helps to give him one of his most important tools, the element of surprise. The versification course came about because of the number of requests Khalvati was getting for guidance: "I remember trying to write metrical stuff for ages and I had all sorts of questions and difficulties. Author: Maunsell, Jerome Boyd
Title: Fancy More Poetry? Then Try These
Full_text:
FANCY mm FOEIW? THEN TRY THESE
1. DEREK WALCOTT Caribbean-born Nobel Prize-winner Derek Walcott produces work with a universal richness and range! In his most recent long poem . The Bounty (Faber & Faber, £7.99), a broad, searching world view is tied up in delicately powerful language and rhythms which curl snake-like around the reader. A true master of the written word. 2. PAUL MULDOON Muldoon (above) used to be a BBC radio producer, and his poetry abounds with a fascination for the sounds of words. His last collection, Hay (Faber, £7.99), is filled with puns, word-games , and aural delights, which are simultaneously playful and serious. His new book Bandanna (Faber, £7.99) is an opera libretto set in a Mexican border town.
3. JOHN ASHBERY Widely regarded as one of the most accomplished contemporary American poets, Ashbery is perhaps most renowned for his 1975 classic Self-Portrait in a Convex Mirror (Carcanet, £6.95). Equally head-spinning perspectives can be found in his latest collection, Wakefulness (Carcanet, £7.95).
4. JORIE GRAHAM Science, philosophy and history are all brought into the balance of Graham's work, creating a poetic world brimming with narrative possibilities. In The Errancy (Carcanet, £9.95), she crafts a pensive, erotic sequence of poems celebrating the power of dreaming in a world too often dominated by reason. « 5. BENJAMIN ZEPHANIAH - Rasta poet Benjamin Zephaniah (right) is as well known for his voice as for his written work. Spreading the word from Palestine to Argentina, he has also released several records, one with the Wailers. Author: Cliff, Nigel
Title: Take That?and poetry
Full_text:
Take That — and poetry
YOU can see why the King's Head, newly deprived of its London Arts Board grant, liked this play. A new work by Jim Kenworth, Gob lobs an iconoclastic missile at the com - paratively cushy and conven - tional mainstream arts estab - lishment . Or rather at the Fes - tival Hall, which is the villain of the piece. The play's two main charac - ters —one , the Liberator, a cul - tural hooligan, the other, Hard Man Les, just a hooli - gan — set out to storm the South Bank. While Les is all psyched up for a good rumble, the Liberator is a self-styled "Gob Warrior" with higher things on his mind. Poetry, he says, is the last weapon of the weaponless, and anybody should have the right to ex - press themselves in the so - called People's Palace. Onstage they find two per - formance poets in full flow: a foul-mouthed American named Mike Nietzsche whose poem consists of the single word "Arsehole ", and the Dar - ling Boy, a dreadful drama queen who cranks out much romantic mush about mur -
; King 's Head, Nl " 1 dered petals. A battle of the bards ensues. You can guess . who wins: Kenworth hardly gives his upstarts much compe - tition . As it happens, the Liberator is not a very good poet either,
but that (I hope) misses the point. Gob is about freedom, not quality, of expression. Too much of a good thing, you might be excused for thinking, when it results in great globs of cod-poetic hyperbole, but then I suppose that is being elitist too. There is plenty of irony to lighten the load. But the play passionately insists that poet - ry , if not quite revolutionary,
is indeed the means to individ - ual liberty. This is a refreshing - ly uncynical thesis. Given the emphasis on honest and direct expression, though, it comes couched in mightily preten - tious terms. And in its own way — when, for instance, it dismisses clubbers as moronic herd-followers incapable of po - etic thought— the play is just as elitist as those who would exclude the unsophisticated from the temples of high art. But for all its cringe-making excess, this is a fresh and some - times very funny piece, marvel - lously directed by James Mar - tin Charlton with an acute eye for physical comedy. Two actors play all the parts with well-honed versatility. Ja - son Orange (formerly of Take That) is exuberantly impas - sioned , if never completely plausible, as the Liberator. Tom Hayes is spot-on as Les and the Darling Boy. The show is enlivened by the presence on stage of DJ Spike, who mixes in his own witty musical asides through - out .
Nigel Cliff
One-time teen idol Jason Orange (left) grows up in the company of Tom Hayes and the exuberant Gob

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Poetry 's losses- and its gains
Full_text:
Poetry's losses — and its gains
If one pursued regular ac - countancy methods, this year wouldn't get out of red figures. Ted Hughes leaves a painful gap as the only English poet of recent times whom the art had, in the words of D. H. Lawrence, " tak - en by the throat". Earlier in the year, the Czech Miroslav Holub and the Pole Zbigniew Herbert died — poets as politi - cally effective in their societies as they were stylistically ad - mired in ours. To add insult to injury, the OUP poetry listwas summarily wound up: the ceil - ing falling in on our harmless games of musical chairs. The book of the year was Hughes'S Birthday Letters (Faber, £14.99), a book one had been waiting for without ever expecting to see it, for decades. The poems are of somewhat variable quality, but the hum - bler , more literal transcrip - tions of scenes and memories burn with irresistible clarity and power. It seems like Hugh - es 's bridge back to the rest of us: it's odd to have him writing "I-you" poems, finally. Anthologies come like buses — none for ages, then several at once. November saw two:
Poetry From Britain and Ireland since 1945 edited by Robert Crawford and Simon Armit -
B ».M age (Penguin, £10.99); and The Firebox: Poetry from Britain and Ireland after 1945 edited by Sean O'Brien (Picador, £10.95). The O'Brien is widely reckoned to be the better book. Both offer standing room only: 150 and 120 poets respectively. What's really needed isht an - other doorstep, but "Ocean 's Choice of Contemporary Brit - ish Poetry". Two other volumes stand out: Paul Muldoon's Hay (Fab - er , £14.99) his most approacha - ble book for some time, though without any diminu - tion of his characteristic guile and inventiveness; and Les Murray's abundant novel - in - verse , Fredy Neptune (Carcan - et , £18.95). There are also two outstanding imports: Jonath - an Galassi's English versions of Montale, Collected Poems 1920-1954 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $40), and the prose - po - ems of the Frenchman Francis Ponge, Selected Pomes (Faber, £9.99), a kind of home-made poetic lexicographer ("less than a peach skin, a mist, a hint of muffled downiness" ). A terrible year, but not, for all that, a bad year.
The last year of Ted Huehes's life was one of his most successful. Birthday Letters has now sold nearly 100,000 copies

If you dont already own this — the book was a best - seller when it appeared — now is the time to snap it up.

Author: Davison, Peter
Title: Orwell, the honest master of the poetry of fact
Full_text:
Orwell , the honest master of the poetry of fact
The diaries which George Orwell kept during the Second World War contained many intriguing references: "The Germans are definite - ly in Paris... This evening I saw a her - on flying over Baker Street ... X de - clares that Jews greatly predominate among the people sheltering in the Tubes. Must try and verify this ... " That last abbreviated sentence might stand as one of Orwell's most distinc - tive ; he had a curiously open, and open - ly curious, mind. The range and variety of his work are not in question. Here are 20 vol - umes springing from a professional writing life of some 19 years which sug - gest that, as has been reported of anoth - er author, he could write faster than God could read. Orwell himself said that he always felt some external "com - pulsion " to write, but the nature of his achievement is another matter. Is he an English essayist in the tradition of Defoe and Hazlitt? Or is he that more quixotic and wilful figure who, as a child, announced that: "You are no - ticed more if you stand on your head than if you are right way up" ? He stood upon his head on many occasions. He was a pupil at Eton, and then he was a tramp; he was a member of the military police in India, and then joined a Trotskyist organisation in Spain; he was a committed Socialist who wrote about seaside postcards and
The complete artist or myth? Peter Ackroyd relishes a genius
the proper way to make tea. Yet his cen - tral preoccupations remained the same, from the time he depicted a lonely tramp earning his living as a street-artist on the Embankment, in Down And Out in Paris and London, to the moment in 1984 when the demor - alised and demolished Winston Smith sits alone in an empty bar. Orwell's early novels were filled with homelessness compounded by heart - lessness and helplessness. His figures feel themselves to be "dead" in the real world, but come momentarily to life when they drift down into the under - world of poverty and degradation. They experience some fundamental rev - elation — perhaps it is that of being fully human — but of its nature such a moment cannot last. Then they return to their ordinary lives with a sense of de - jection and depression, just as Orwell returned to middle-class life after his brief forays with the vagrants of Lon - don . It is often said that he felt shame and guilt, variously attributed to his privileged days at Eton or his imperial - ist days in Burma, but it is more likely that he suffered from ennui. His true genius was formed when he began his researches into the unem - ployed of northern England. All his an - ger and frustration found their first
k%£ eplfor^E,WORK$ OF, j r ^eOR^E^RWEli</ . . ,\ Liv ?** "* %15^L*£?C_ * Seeker & Warburg, £750 Twenty volumes
proper means of expression in The Road To Wigan Pier, and from that time forward he was concerned with what he called "political writing". It allowed him, like Defoe, to com - bine imaginative insight with docu - mented record; he was able, in other words, to provide the poetry of fact. It has often been suggested that he dissi - pated his talent by employing so many different forms in pursuit of that enter - prise — novel, satire and essay among them. It is an odd indictment: no com - poser , after all, is ever asked to confine his production to string quartets or symphonies. His own style has become well known, partly from his own apothegm that "good prose is like a window pane" . This is a half-truth at best and cannot even be used to describe those writers, such as Dickens and Gissing, whom Orwell himself most admired. In fact "plain" prose can be an affecta -
tion . It is no more plain than the fact that plain George Orwell was in reality Eric Blair. He once said of Dickens that " strong - ly individual" writing displays the face of the author behind it, but in truth it is hard to see that of Orwell. He remains too complicated. In many respects he was the product of public school and of the imperial police force — he wrote dis - paragingly of "fashionable pansies" and "pinks", while even keeping a list of those whom he deemed to be "fellow travellers" with the Communists. There is something hard, almost ruth - less , about his inward temperament. We do not see a face behind his writ - ing but rather a figure who was vari - ously described by contemporaries as shy, detached, solitary and aloof. It was also noticed that he had a "thin, flat voice" . He had a great capacity for an - ger as well but, paradoxically, that is what gives his language its living force. His journalism and even his occa - sional reviewing can still be read with pleasure, not least because they revive the extraordinary level of partisanship and commitment in the Thirties and Forties. The years of the war, with all their seediness, fatigue and foreboding, may be said to live again in these vol - umes . Their publication is in that sense
an event of some significance, since they can be read as the history of a soci - ety as well as the chronicle of one man. This edition is in almost all respects definitive and its editor, Dr Peter Davi - son , has repaired mutilated texts and restored Orwell's original intentions. Everything is here — articles, diaries, telegrams, letters, talks and notebooks as well as those volumes which have kept his name at the forefront of 20th - century English literature. Whether he realised his achieve - ment , or not, is another matter. He be - came deeply pessimistic towards the end of his life and evoked that mood ad - mirably in his last book, 1984. He had contracted tuberculosis, and described the world itself as "suffering from a dis - ease which is simultaneously acute, chronic and fearful". Public opinions can sometimes spring from private tor - ments . His was in many respects a hectic and feverish life, but not without a certain nobility of purpose. He was haunted by the spectre of failure and by the fear of poverty, oppressed by fore - bodings of the future — yet somehow common sense and decency kept on breaking though . He said that he had once believed he lived in a world "where it was not poss - ible for me to be good". Yet he went a stage further, and became honest instead.
Timeless: Orwell's journalism is still incisive

Author: milnes, Rodney
Title: Small-town poetry in slow motion
Full_text:
S mall-town poetry in slow motion
When Gavin Bryars started composing his First stage work, Medea (1981-84 ), he had not, he tells us, seen any mainstream opera. Medea was written in collaboration with Robert Wilson, the idiosyncratic American director whose concept of "expanded time" — a polite term for slow motion — Bryars also alludes to in his helpful programme notes, though not of course in that sense. All of which makes Jules Verne's novel about Dr Ox's experimental speeding up of time in a sleepy little Belgian town a suitable case for the Bryars treatment, but it also raises certain problems for traditional opera-goers . Blake Morrison has supplied r. smart, sassy libretto that could well have done for Offenbach, who also had a go at Dr Ox (in 1877), and failed. But Bryars's slow-moving , maxi - minimal - ist musical language and his penchant for writing at the extreme upper range of the singing voice conspire to make it extremely difficult to articulate words, let alone point them in the way that Morrison's text presupposes. Potential customers should definitely get to the Coliseum in time to read the libretto oaramin^ Ul UUl;;. .-
. .-. ^ooiii u, i-town life without being — um — boring. Bryars proceeds at his own "expanded time" pace, his basically tonal patterns burbling on perfectly pleasantly over slowly shifting chords. Occasionally there is a momentary stringendo, a suggestion of doubling the speed, but the music still moves at basically the same pulse. After about 60 minutes, someone sang "You have condemned me to everlasting torment", which got a nervous laugh even from this markedly well-disposed audience. Atom Egoyan's production is little
Dr Ox 's Experiment r};?' ' V Coliseum % ;.V'-. ' . help. How far its style was dictated by financial stringency it is hard to say — Michael Levine's set consists of a few milk churns, a couple of ladders and countless balls of string — but the 19th - century bourgeois milieu suggested by novel and libretto is replaced by abstract medievalism. The combina - tion of slow-motion direction and verbal cloudiness does not make the action clear, to put it mildly. Younger audiences might think this irrelevant, "culinary" even. Instead they will revel, as I did in an abstracted, dopey kind of way, in the fastidious beauty of Bryars's instru - mental textures, and his gift — uncom - mon today — for writing for the voice. The music for the four young lovers, two pairs of high sopranos and counter-tenors , is absolutely lovely, as are the final aria for one of them — the sweet-toned if wordless Valdine Ander - son — and the moment of stasis before the explosive colln- ^ r '^ o^ -« experiment, with it* .. ucculun , .. iued string sound and mysterious offstage cries. There is plenty to listen to in Dr Ox, whether it is in any sense operatic is quite another matter.
In the pit, James Holmes does full justice to Bryars's textures and loyally, energetically seeks to make the pulse work. Bonaventura Bottone in the somewhat shadowy title role, Riccardo Simonetti as his assistant, Delia Jones, David James and Nicholas Folwell make heroic contributions. Go with an open (empty?) mind, and lie back.
Rodney Milnes
Time travellers: Bonaventura Bottone makes an heroic contribution as the mad scientist in Gavin Bryars's maxi-minimalist new opera, Dr Ox's Experiment

Author: Finch, Hilary
Title: New Classical CDs: Poetry in emotion; Ax's gentle touch; Teutonic tones
Full_text:
NEW CLASSICAL CDs: Poetry in emotion; Ax's gentle touch; Teutonic tones
CHAMBER Hilary Finch CHAUSSON Poeme, Piano Trio, etc Chilingirian/Graffin/ Devoyon Hyperion CDA 67028 £14.99 THE LUSH green light of Monet's The Boat on the cover indicates a disc of music for a sultry summer's night. Chaus - son ' s heady Poeme for violin and orchestra is well enough known; but his version for violin, string quartet and piano was discovered only two years ago. The warm, close ensemble of the Chilingirian Quartet takes us deep into the private heart of the work, as Philippe Graffin's solo violin and Pascal Devoyon's piano recreate music which, in De - bussy 's words , "becomes the very feeling which inspires its emotion". This Poeme was recorded in the company of Chausson's CDs reviewed in The Times can be ordered from the Times Music Shop on 0345 023498.
youthfully buoyant Piano Trio; and Gary Hoffman also joins Devoyon for a properly contemplative reading of the much later Piece for cello and piano. Charles Neidich, mean - while , gives a spritely and sophisticated performance of the Andante and Allegro for clarinet and piano, an ardent nine minutes of championship for an instrument still lurking in the shadows at the time this engaging piece was written. ^jjgBJBliALv-Barry Millington CHOPIN Piano Concerto No 2; Grand Fantasia: Grande Polonaise Brillante Ax/OAE/Mackerras Sony SK 63371 £15.49 THE PIANOS with which Chopin would have been most familiar were instruments by Erard and Pleyel, of which the former were judged to be most suitable for the present project of Emanuel Ax: three works for piano and orchestra in - cluding the F Minor Concerto. The choice was well made, and piano restorer David Winston has provided Ax with a beautiful London Erard of
1851 , which he has mastered with admirable skill. The brilliant upper register is clearly differentiated from the mellow, full-toned bass, allowing the pianist to realise the bel canto singing line with unprecedented clarity and subtlety. Ax takes full advan - tage , dispatching the gossa - mer quasi-cadenza figuration (often given a marking such as "leggierissimfl" or "very light) with a delicacy simply not possible on the modern grand. The Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and Charles Mackerras give first-rate sup - p ort , both in the concerto and in the Grand Fantasia on Polish Airs and the Grande Polonaise Brillante.
OPERA John Higgins TIANA LEMNITZ Opera Arias EMI CDH 5667742 £10.49 THE GERMAN soprano Tiana Lemnitz died only four years ago, aged 97. She was the epitome of the gracious Teutonic style of singing, gent - ly crystalline notes supported by superb breath control float -
ing over the orchestra. She specialised in unsullied hero - ines such as Weber's Agathe and Wagner's Elisabeth (Tannha'user), both well repre - sented here. These recordings come from her peak years, which, alas, coincided with the Second World War. Earlier she had been Strauss's first choice for Arabella, but musical machi - nations prevented that. Prob - ably she would have been a cool customer who lets her defences slip a little when Mandryka comes along. Such is the impression from two 1940 extracts with the great baritone Gerhard Husch. Elisabeth 's Act III aria from Tannhduser shows Lemnitz at her gleaming best, as do two lengthy extracts from Lohen - grin , in one of which she is joined by the underrated Swedish tenor, Torsten Ralf. They are together again in Verdi's Otello, in German of course, to excellent effect. Lemnitz follows up the love duet with the Willow Song (variable) and the Ave Maria (outstanding). She was a mis - tress of piety. * Worth hearing k-k Worth considering k-k-k Worth buying

Author: Meisner, Nadine
Title: Poetry in the ring
Full_text:
Poetry in the ring
Federico Garcia Lorca was killed by Spanish Fascists in 1936. Rambert Dance Company's Cruel Garden lingers over the event, the dying poet tossed like a slab of meat from tormentor to tormentor, then struggling defiantly to stand before his final collapse. The scene is unashamed pathos — but it produces its intended heart-troubling effect. Lindsay Kemp and Christo - pher Bruce teamed up in 1977 to make Cruel Garden for Rambert, a dance-theatre spectacle now revived for the centenary of Lorca's birth. As well as Ralph Koltai's superb - ly simple set — a bullring that sometimes opens up on vistas of countryside, — Cruel Garden displays, for better and worse, all the lineaments of the Kemp style. It also contains Bruce's adept chore - ography which rephrases tra - ditional folkloric forms into a modem idiom, as does Carlos
I Cruel Garden ; /Apollo , Oxford V
Miranda's wonderfully ele - mental score, played by London Musici. Most of the musical and dance references are Spanish, except for an "America" section where Bruce includes an extraordi - nary Solo for A Negro, built from motifs of agony, labour and black jazz dance, and performed with a coiled power by Paul Liburd . Rambert has castthis reviv - al from strength, but also brought in the required sing - ers — Judy Slater, and Francois Testory — together with John Chesworth, who returns to his created role of Franco-like inquisitor. Christopher Bruce was the original central Lorca figure who appears succes - sively as a matador, a bride,
Buster Keaton (apropos Lor - ca 's screenplay about the film star) and a dinner-jacketed poet. Conor O'Brien , who now dances the role, has a vivid presence and bears a resem - blance to Bruce, although that may be partly due to the white make-up Kemp likes perform - ers to wear. Firmly in place are the other Kemp trademarks: the fantas - tical parade of archetypes; the sense of fugitive beauty; the sexual ambiguities; the drag - bride with her oblique, scut - tling walk and jerky stiffness of a puppet. In Cruel Garden these come together in a satisfyingly cohesive whole, marred only by the surrealist "America" passage which ar - rives with the incongruity of
an ostrich striding into a flock of pigeons . Otherwise the per - sonages form a dense, clever web of associations: the char - acter called the bull, for exam - p le , starts as the matador's combatant, but then becomes the inquisitor's brutal hench - man and, as such, the repre - sentative of masculinity and physical oppression. The programme notes make much of the solitary poet as Christ-like prophet and ; ma r - tyr , but equally implicit is the theme of'the homosexual as outcast. And what is the Cruel Garden? It is Cocteau's bull - ring splattered with blood, and it is the Garden of Gethsemane; it is Lorca's imaginary world.and the real world around him. Nadine Meisner ^SR
Conor O'Brien as the central Lorca character, here in bridal guise (with Simon Cooper)

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: No rhythm but plenty of blues
Full_text:
Michael Hofmann sees a glimmer of promise in a poet's pensees
No rhythm but plenty of blues
A uden put it pretty con - clus ively , though he named no names, when he said: "I have known three great poets, each one a prize son of a bitch." And yet one clings to a stubborn hope — more a superstition, really — that because someone has written great poetry, they will tend to be worth something in human terms as well. The German poet Rainer Maria Rilke (1875-1926 ) is at least as unedifying as the trio — whoever they were — that Auden had in mind. The word "bounder" might have been coined for him. (John Berryman called him a jerk.) He was a snob, a wastrel and a parasite , who led the most skimmingly uncommitted life. And yet he wrote lines, poems and passages of prose that are unassailably great, deep and hard. So what to do? The only way to deal with him is to read his greatest work and nothing else. To read his life — still more, I imagine, to write it, as Ralph Freedman most recently did, last year — is to have one's admiration
DIARIES OF A YOUNG POET By Rainer Maria Rilke Translated by Edward Snow and Michael Winkler Norton, £19.95 ISBN039 3045536 1912, hung in abeyance a long time, and was dramatically completed ten years later, along with its aftershocks, the Sonnets to Orpheus . But scholarship, like na - tu re , abhors a vacuum. Things have to come from somewhere. The New Poems have to come from some - where . {They cant just be new — though obviously Rilke, calling them that, thought they were.} The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge wants antecedents as well as ances - tors . And so Edward Snow and Michael Winkler, an art his - torian and a Germanist — it's a useful combination for this book, and for all of Rilke's work have brought out this rather splendid looking, fully annotated and painstakingly translated volume.
The Diaries of a Young Poet — a title given them by the editors to chime with Rilke's seemingly ever-popular Letters to a Young Poet — date from 1898 to 1900. They are generally ad - dressed to, and were more or less written at the behest of, Lou Andreas-Salome , an in - tellectual and (sometimes) erotic free spirit and, to borrow Musil's title, "the girl friend of famous men". She and Rilke started off as lov - ers , before she transformed herself into a sort of mentor and mother-figure to him instead; had she not done so, he might not have evolved his philosophy of unconsummat - ed love and his general nega -
tive metaphysics. Mutatis mutandis, they might have been like Lawrence and Frieda. The Diaries, then, are part punishment, part courtship , part escape. By the end of them, Rilke has broken with Lou, and moved into a rather intense artists' colony — its narcissistic, submarine and underachieving atmosphere is well-captured — and is about to marry a large sculp - tress . ("Clara arrived with her little Rilke under her arm ," it was once unkindly noted.) Rilke didnt have the quali - ties of the good diarist: curios - ity , informal recollection, human accuracy. Intimacy,
clouded by an intimate con - tempt . To make matters worse, Rilke was a prodigy, but more particularly he was a late developer, which is perhaps the secret truth of all prodi - gies . He published and self - published books in his teens. Thousands of pages flowed from his pen, in his unformed hand: novels, novellas, books of poems, art criticism, short stories. He had the 19th - century faible for theatre — like Balzac and Henry James — and wrote weedy plays. But the only thing going for him is industry and indomitable - ness . All his life, he had a phenomenal ease as a writer
— and as a writer of verse. And once his ease found itself something to say, the combi - nation made him great. What made Rilke were the years in the 1900s when he lived in Paris, first as the secretary of the sculptor Auguste Rodin, and then on his own. He had a stark and solitary life with humiliations that he couldn't , for once, duck out of. In his thirties in Paris, he wrote and published the two volumes of New Poems (of 1907 and 1908) and his novel The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge (1910), one of the great books of the century and still far too little read. Then his long poem, the Duino Elegies, was begun in
with him, is always oddly anonymous, just as his poems are like addresses to an Other — an Angel — across infinite space . Things that would be gifts to the diarist — a chance, slighting encounter with the poet Stefan George in Flor - ence ; the ins and outs of his relationships — don|t even appear. Whatever interest this book may promise, it is not as a diary but as Rilke. And Rilke, at this stage, was only on his way. There are some magnificent apho - ristic passages — about God,
for example, or about art, "a reconciled St Sebastian, who allows the arrows to rest in his wounds" — foreshadow - ings of future sayings and poems , but probably no more than ten or 20 pages' worth. The translators have done him no favours either in using an English that is actually even stiffer than the German original: "how requi - site I was to them", "fun , fun, fun ... sickening climax of German sociality". That android quality of diction is a misrepresentation of Rilke's language — though possibly not of his thought.
Not in his fellow-poets' good books: Rilke in 1897, aged 22

Author: Dunmore, Helen
Title: Too swift to be sure
Full_text:
* Too swift to be sure
IN A recent interview with Tim Kendall in the poetry magazine Thumbscrew , Lavinia Greenlaw responded with plea - sure to the suggestion that her new poems were more engaged, more openly emo - tional than those inher first collection. "I 'm glad you sensed this as it is what I have hoped for." Poets tend to acquire labels which have more to do with the convenience of those who are trying to sell the books than with the poet's own ' intentions. Greenlaw's first collection, Night Photograph, was published in 1993: the pitch for its contents became that she was a poet who wrote about science; ' This was not untrue. In several poems, ideas drawn from astronomy, medicine or physics gave birth to metaphor. Paired stars which cannot "touch or part" reminded the poet of a past lover whose magnetism can never increase or de - crease . The cool delicacy of the reminder was part of the poem's appeal. Night Photograph was a precise and entertain - ing book, especially when Greenlaw went rapidly into reverse at the very moment when she seemed about to meet her reader's expectations. Suddenly you saw that she was gently mocking the set-up : ; . "You thought the poem was about this: But really, it is about that!" -
A WORLD WHERE NEWS TRAVELLED SLOWLY By Lavinia Greenlaw Faber, £6.99 1SBN.O571191606 .
A first collection of poems may have many weaknesses, but its strength is that it. brings together the best poems of five years or a decade. No one has hurried these poems into print, or pressured the writer with the idea that she is this kind of poet, or that. The second collection is usually more problematic. Lavinia Greenlaw's A World Where News Trav - elled Slowly is',>a book about being changed and remade by love. From one poem to another there runs a story which is. half-hidden , half-transparent . This
could work wonderfully well, as it does in Emily Bronte's love-poems , or in Tess Gallagher's poems written for Raymond Carver. Yet here, there is a strange sriltedness. The poems don't come close. Certainly, it isn't easy to make the sealed world of two lovers interesting to those outside the charm. The sense of "we" — so palpitatingly vital to the couple concerned — does not necessarily hold any meaning for others. At worst, the reader may feel like a a voyeur. If the poem does not offer an imaginative space which can be entered by others, and can kindle the imaginations of others, then it remains a notebook piece, however accomplished it maybe .
There are two and a half lines in a poem called No Particular Horse, which sum up Greenlaw's strengths and show, perhaps, that she is thwarting herself in much of A World Where News Travelled Slowly. The poem wants to be about the quality of horseness, so it sets itself to escape from writing about a particular horse. But it cannot escape. Here is the real horse, and the real poet: "Running my hand/along the hooked spine of a broken-backed /roan crippled by a bite from his father." ;.-.....
Helen Dunmore

Author: Wagner, Erica
Title: Until it trips off the tongue
Full_text:
Erica Wagner remembers her favourites on National Poetry Day
Until it trips off the tongue
BE CAREFUL: people might think you've gone mad. I've decided I don't mind the stares asj I walk down the street. Don't you stare at people who taik to themselves? You won - der , don't you, if they're not, well... a little cracked. But I will confidently assert that I am quite sane. I am not debating with my inner de - mons , or questioning an angel at my ear. If you walk quite close behind me, you might hear what I say: "God rest that wicked woman,/ Queen Jeze - bel , the bitch/ Who peeled the clothes from her shoulder - bones / Down to her spent teats ... " (It's a sunny day; I feel fine and I swing my arms); or — "Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,/ And sorry I could not travel both and be one traveller/ Long I stood and looked down one as far as I could/ To where it bent in the
BY HEART 101 Poems to Remember Edited and with an Introduction by Ted Hughes Faber, £7.99 ISBN057109263 7
undergrowth." (The sky is grey; I feel a little pensive.) I have been memorising poems. Memory has been called an art, but it is also a tool. It is useful to remember things: where you left the car, your mother's birthday, the num - ber on your passport. Like all tools , it will grow rusty from lack of use, and the 20th - century memory may be in danger of seizing up. When feats of memory — all of Virgil recited backwards, line by line —I were practised by ancient orators, their prodigious work was spurred by the knowledge that the poet's works were not available in paperback. Now there is no need to know him byj heart. Or is there? Ted Hughes clearly thinks there is, although he merely informs us briskly that "there are many reasons for learning pcjems", before launching into the Hughes Method of
Memorisation. This discards the punishment of learning by rote in favour of the more ancient system of learning by image espoused by Cicero and Thomas Aquinas. For each line of poetry, work out a picture in your head; link the pictures : let the rhythm do the rest. So: a cat and a hedgehog yowling at a harper, who escapes their cries by dancing round a cauldron. There is the witches' curse from Macbeth: "Thrice the brinded cat hath mew'd ./ Thrice and once the hedge-pig whin'd ./ Harper cries: Tis time, 'tis time./ Round about
the cauldron go ... " You're off. All right , at first it seems a bit of a pain. You have to add your own creativity to that of the poet. But that, as Hughes points out, is just it: the memoriser's input fixes the image far more firmly than numbing repetition. Add to that the "physical momentum of inevitability", the rhythm of the verse , and you have an unbeatable combination. It is noticable that where rhythm is subtler — Eliot's La Figlia Che Piange vs. F. R. Higgins's Song for the Clatterbones (which takes on Jezebel) — the task takes longer. But to return: why under - take the task in the first place ? Hughes's choice, if not his introduction, gives a hint. The same names appear again and again: Blake, Frost, Shake - speare , Eliot, Dickinson (is it worth mentioning that, but for Emily D. and one each from Elizabeth Barratt Browning and Stevie Smith — unless we
hold out hope for Anonymous — it is an almost entirely masculine collection? What the heck... ). Here , yes, is Jabberwocky; but here for the most part is poetry that has become part of what is called the canon: and if you have ever wondered why this is so, try Hughes's method and you will learn. There is a reason, I discov - ered , when I took to reciting Robert Frost through Shore - ditch , that such things are not learnt simply "by mind": Hughes's selection will work its way into your blood. And then you may find yourself
branching out (or compiling your own selection, as p ub - lisher John Murray has in his Old Chestnuts Warmed Up, John Murray, £9.95 ), return - ing to dusty volumes on your shelves, picking up new ones: try something from Paul Muldoon's anthology, The Faber Book of Beasts, £14.99 (plenty of images there) or the latest issue of Index on Cen - sorship , Banned Poetry (£7.99) — spread the word by mouth. Hughes's little volume is a reminder and a gift. Take his words to heart. And if I see you on the street , muttering under your breath, I promise not to think you mad.

Author: Null
Title: The Forward Poetry Prize
Full_text:
THE FORWARD POETRY PRIZE
On October 8, the eve of National Poetry day, the winners of the sixth Forward Prize for poetry will be announced, writes Michael Hofmann. There are three categories: the main one of £10,000 for the best collection of poetry this year; then a £5,000 prize for the best newcomer; and a prize of £1,000 for the best single poem. The panel of judges is chaired by John Fuller, last year's winner. Shortlisted are Selima Hill, Ted Hughes, Jamie McKendrick, Andrew Motion, Susan Wicks and C.K. Williams. Their poems , and some 20 or 30 more , are all published in an anthology called The Forward Book of Poetry 1998. It is a subtle, varied and well - balanced list. All the poets are worth reading, and any one of them would be a deserving winner. Hill and McKendrick most resemble the popular conception of the poet, pure and unworldly , writing poems on park benches, living on fresh air and roll-ups . Motion and Wicks are both more in the world, with teaching jobs and admired prose books to their names. Charlie Williams, an American in Paris, has the toughness one used to associate with Americans before they became institutionalised in the nurseries of their universities. And Ted Hughes, living down the Laureateship and enjoying an extraordinary late efflorescence of brilliance, is as compelling as ever. His book is my favourite. It is the only one you would unhesitatingly back to last out not just the century, but the one after and beyond. His re-telling of 24 of the myths from Ovid 's Metamorphoses is clone with tremendous gusto and conviction. Whether he's writing a fight scene, a natural catastrophe or a god's sly lust for a mortal, he seems to mean it. Ovid's world is his world. When Midas's brain moves strangely, '"like a muscle", or Thisbe's "seemed to turn over", you can't tell the antique curse from the modern psychological moment. After Hughes , there are the books that are their authors' best work to date: The Marble Fly and The Clever Daughter . Jamie McKendrick makes a comedy of decrepitude. His book is full of industrial antiques: a bicycle, a canal , his car, his home town of Liverpool. Its lovingly polished engineering terms and its endearing self-deprecation put it, I suppose , in the line of Larkin, but he has a lovely wry warmth that no one ever accused Larkin of having. There isn't a weak poem in the book. Susan Wicks writes about being a mother and a daughter. The poems about the loss of both her parents, all the tidying and sorting
and remembering and grieving, have an extraordinary poise. The kind of derangement that smears mustard on the roof and has moss covering the floors is unforgettable. Maybe a dozen of the poems are superb. Elsewhere, I think she has taken too much from the in - your - face American poet Sharon Olds. Then there are the poets who, while I think they may have written better elsewhere, are still worth anyone's consideration. Selima Hills's Violet is a cute diptych : My Sister's Sister about sibling rivalry
and My Husband's Wife about sexual jealousy. What looks batty and free-form actually pursues a strict emotional logic. The sister, with her sexuality (those "swelling hymns" are actually swelling hims), and the betrayed wife are both ingenious designs. Anyone with an older sister, anyone who has ever been abandoned, will understand. Over the years, Andrew Motion has gone from lyric to narrative to an energetic plainness, sometimes fury, that is harder to do than it looks. Salt Water follows the theme
of water: the Thames, the North Sea, the Marchioness. Its second section, in prose, is a shipboard diary, interspersed with small, sinewy poems. C.K. Williams can, it seems, do anything in his double-length lines: description, meditation, snapshot or droll psychologising. The Vigil, with poems for the death of his mother and of friends, is his most sombre work to date. Its subject is keeping one's humanity even at the moment of death: a strange meeting of prayer and analysis.

Author: williamson, nigel
Title: Frothy Sixties poetry
Full_text:
Frothy Sixties poetry
ONE of the oddest cult figures of our age is Serge Gainsbourg. Such hip acts as Black Grape and Stereolab have recorded the songs of the late French roue, and Suede's Brett Anderson duets on the new album by Gainsbourg's partner of many years, Jane Birkin. Gallic pop has long been derided by rock'n' rollers and there is a strong suspicion that Gainsbourg's posthumous attraction lies more in his bad-boy reput - ation than in his songs. This one-off London date at the Festival Hall was Birkin's
. ' : "' ftQP » ', tribute and presented an op - portunity to reassess Gains - bourg 's oeuvre. The verdict was mixed. Di Do Dah, for example, is pure pop from in any language and made risi - ble Birkin's claim that her partner was "as great a poet as Apollinaire" . On the other hand, Quoi and Baby Alone in Babylon expressed a matur - er emotionality. Backed by an unimagina - tive rock band and a rather better string quartet, Birkin made her mission, harder by gushing incontinently about the man for whom she still carries a torch. We had all made Serge "very happy by being there"; every time he
wrote her a song he was "giving me himself to sing". Part of Birkin's appeal lies in her vulnerability but this was mawkishness run amok. Birkin's thin, fragile voice appeared close to cracking on occasion, but that is also part of the charm. Ultimately for someone with a reputation as a former wild child, she came across as far too polite and bourgeois. The audience loved her. As most seemed to be in their late twenties it was impossible to avoid the thought that many of them were probably conceived with Je VAime... Moi Non Plus, the notorious 1969 duet with Gainsbourg which was Birkin's sole British hit, playing seduc - tively in the background-
Nigel Williamson

Author: Null
Title: Bags of wobble and flop
Full_text:
Bags of wobble and flop
Ted Hughes and Seamus Heaney are together again. That is the news from the literary world. A few years ago they co-operated to bring out a very successful anthology of poetry called The Rattle Bag. Now they have produced another poetry an - thology , The School Bag, and they will both be on the stage reading from it at a forum in London on April 14. What prompted them to do the new book? Heaney says that while The Rattle Bag was meant to be a "carnival of poetry" , The School Bag is more like a checklist. They wanted to do something which would cover ground that they more or less took for granted when they did the first book — "something going from the age of Caedmon to the age of Auden, taking in the canonical names , roaming to America and Australia" . The other motivation for him, he says, was "the sense of restoration and confirmation you get from going through the word-hoard at this stage of life. I really enjoyed revisiting the first sites of my own reading , that whole memory bank of stuff that sustains your taste and your convic - tion . It was great to reopen that ground, and especially to do so with Ted."
Hughes agrees: "We always thought of The Rattle Bag as an anthology for young readers — or at least for those young in heart. As if we'd imagined ourselves back to 13 or 14, then picked our secret favourites from all we now know. Thinking of a school of poetry, The Rattle Bag is the playground — and that made us wonder about a complementary an - thology , one for the classroom in that same school of poetry ." One feature of the new book is that each poet is represented by Only one poem, or passage of poetry. Why did they decide on that?. Hughes says it was a levelling device. "The emperors have, to some extent, been stripped of the grand robes of their richly supportive other works. Each stands just as naked as the many other poets who have produced only one masterpiece. We found this made us look at them all with fresh eyes. We want readers to do the same." "We wanted people to see the gleam of the hoard rather than wanting to give them an inventory of the entire holdings," Heaney adds.
Ted Hughes and Seamus Heaney reveal what prompted them to compile a new poetry anthology, The School Bag
Also, he says, "Christopher Reid, who was on the ball as our editor at Faber, came up with an idea of the book as a kind of flow-chart , each poem being somehow in dialogue with those around it. "Wordsworth 's Resolution and In - depen d ence , for example, which is really a poem about the leech - gatherer as Doppelgdnger , is now situated between an extraordinary Dafyd ap Gwylm poem called The Shadow and Wilfred Owen's Strange Meeting, and this gives an extra dimension to your reading of all three of them." Although the book does not say so anywhere, The School Bag only goes up to poets who were, as Hughes puts it, "of combat age or came of age during the Second World War". Why did they choose that cut-off point? "To my ear," Heaney says, "the title The School Bag suggests a book con - c erned with cultural memory rather than the contemporary scene." "Some of the most interesting poems in the book were written by that last generation about that war," Hughes says. "One can see now, I
think , that they felt themselves to be full inheritors of the First World War, and of their national history before that. For the generation that fol - lowed , the world seemed to fall open in a new way." It was "a distinct and convenient watershed between the generations ". One poet who appears in the anthology has for long been considered a joke by poetry lovers — the rollick - ing Victorian , William McGonagall . But his poem The Tay Bridge Disaster is there, and both of the editors defend the decision to include it. Hughes is eloquent about it: "Marianne Moore is the most fastidi - ous , most excruciatingly careful, exacting and sophisticated wild poet of this century. Ogden Nash is unfailingly one of the funniest. Stevie Smith plays her naive part with demonic intelligence and a perfect ear. "Behind all these, at some oblique angle or other, is McGonagall. How is it that his every flung-away line gives you such a lift? But it does. Such
a draught of liberation. Don't dismiss McGonagall." "The wobble and flop of McGonagall is the signature of his genius," Heaney observes. There are many translations from Irish, Welsh and Scots Gaelic in the book, and both editors regard this as essential to the whole idea of the anthology. They wanted to present the entire family tree of our poetry, and, Heaney says, "there was never any doubt in our minds that the roots of this tree are largely made up of the early poetic literatures of Ireland, Scotland and Wales, along with the Anglo-Saxon" . Both editors also firmly believe in the value and pleasure of memorising poetry. In the book itself, Hughes gives a suggestion for re - membering a poem — invent a vivid image to associate with each line, and if those are conjured up, the lines will come back too. Heaney says that "memorised poetry stays with you all your days as a kind of mental fossil fuel. You tap into a cable that hums with all the energies and veteran knowledge of human language at its surest and richest."

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Making the sound of sense
Full_text:
Making the sound of sense
For a time in the mid - 1980 s, when his poem A Letter won the Arvon Competition, when he and Blake Morrison edited the Penguin Book of Contempo - rary British Poetry together, and when Penguin published Dangerous Play, his early selected poems, Andrew Mo - tion looked to be in the absolute mainstream of Brit - ish poetry of the time: writing poems that were talky and oblique, working on a fusion of image, narrative and voice, stealing the clothes of prose fiction. Since then, having tried — and then thrown in — his hand at fiction himself, then rapidly becoming an experi -
enced biographer (a triple header of.the Lambert family, his Larkin, a shiny new Keats out in a few months), poetry has changed for him, and his own poetry has changed too. One couldn't any longer call him typical. He has left the mainstream and is hacking his way into his own undergrowth. His books now tend to be longer, and to contain fewer, longer poems (his last volume, The Price of Everything, just two). They like to accommo - date prose—the second part of Salt Water, entitled Sailing to Italy , is his prose journal of taking a sailing boat to Rome,
Michael Hofmann
SALTWATER
Faber, £7.99 ISBN057119019 7
following in the watery foot - steps of the dying Keats in 1820. And the verse in them is pured into stout and service - able forms: rhymed couplets and quatrains, blank verse. Writing about Keats has had an effect too — as writing on Philip Larkin did previously. There are soul-landscapes like The Clearing, a poem about
the Thames like Shelley's Alastor. What you get in these new poems is a peculiar collision — again, not unlike the Roman - tics — between matter and manner. It's as though writing so much prose in the past ten years has made Motion bigger and bolder and bluffer. He is unfussy and plain-spoken , even impatient, no longer will - ing or able to wait for the poetic formulation or image. The poems begin loudly and confidently: "This is a long time ago," "I would like to make it clear," "I won't say much about it now." But at the same time, these robust poems
are about ghosts: those of Keats, of the poet's mother, of friends who died in the sink - ing of the Marchioness and of cancer. They become that strange thing: an almost impersonal pursuit of Motion's innermost feelings of sadness and depres - sion ; an unapologetic venting of his own temperament, both in the poems and in the journal, when, for instance, in a flat calm off Trafalgar, he is gripped by a fury: "I want to stick a marlin spike up his arse and throw him to the shark which has just idled past, its fin slick and alert." As those brilliant adjectives show, Motion has not lost or
given up all his finesse by any means; a rainy day has inter - mittent "squirts" of hot sun - shine , an aeroplane " dren - ches " the boat with its noise, a pigeon "stamps" in its bowls of water. But Salt Water is characterised less by such subleties of tone and observa - tion then by insistence and volume. "I love it," Motion writes of the river, or, in a poem about a dress: "I hate — I really hate—to think of some other bum/ swinging those heavy flower-heads left to right." It is meant, I think, to be Frost's "the sound of sense", but I hear too much the grinding of gears and spin - ning of tyres.
By Andrew Motion
Andrew Motion: poems that reveal his temperament

Author: williamson, nigel
Title: I will arise and rock now
Full_text:
I will arise and rock now
Nigel Williamson on how Van Morrison and others came to put Yeats 's poetry to music
B ack in those preten - t ious days of the 1970s, full of rock operas and concept albums, it was often said that if Dylan Thomas were still alive he would have been writing lyrics for a rock band. The conceit was not entirely empty; it could at least be argued that the Welsh poet was living a rock'n'roll life - style before Elvis Presley was even out of short trousers. But W.B. Yeats goes pop? It takes a fair stretch of poetic licence to see the old Nobel laureate as an early template for Jarvis Cocker. Yet over the years many of Ireland's top artists have been unable to resist the challenge of setting Yeats's words to music. Now comes a fully realised musical celebration of the poet, featuring, among others , Van Morrison, the Cranberries , Shane Mac - Gowan and Christy Moore. The result is an album surpris - ingl y free of pretension and as refreshing as the air at Yeats's hplnvpH fnnlp
Astonishingly the entire project was put together by two enthusiastic amateurs who, with no experience of the cynical, exploitative music in - d ustry , sweet-talked a major record label, the Yeats family and some of the biggest artists in the world into helping them to turn a pipe dream into reality. During the summer of 1993 Frank Dunne and Michael Tuft, two journalists on Holi - day Which?, were driving around Sligo, where Yeats lived and worked, researching a routine travel feature. On the car stereo they were playing two cassettes. One was by Van Morrison, the other by Mike
Scott and the Waterboys, and both included settings of Yeats poems. The seeds of the project were sown. The two writers shared an enthusiasm for Yeats but from different perspectives. Dunne has a degree in Anglo-Irish literature. "I have an emotion - a l attachment as opposed to Frank's intellectual one," says Tuft, whose young son died of meningitis in 1992. "We chose Yeats's The Stolen Child for the funeral service , and I became obsessed." The album developed from "just an idea we had in the pub", he says. "We started writing to various artists say - ing we are nothing to do with the record biz but we want to make this Yeats celebration and we would like you to be on it. It was an astonishing piece of cheek." Many of the letters were initially ignored. "But Mike Scott wrote back to say that he had always wanted to do something similar and Christy Moore said he would like to be involved if we found a backer ." A rmed with nothing more than the idea and a couple of en - couraging letters, the two approached the Grape - vine label. "We put in some research browsing in the record shop and saw they did a lot of Irish artists and so picked them," says Frank Dunne. "We met with the label and in ten minutes they said, we'll do it." Grapevine laid down one condition. "They told us that people weren't going to pay £13 for a good idea. It had to be a good record." So the two set about drawing up a list of their dream team — the sort nf
compilation every music fan has constructed in their head at some time, with the differ - ence that this was for real. All of the artists chose their own favourite poems. The Cranberries were persuaded to offer Yeats's Grave, which features words from No Sec - ond Troy. Christy Moore de - livered a spell-binding version of The Song Of Wandering Aengus. Shane MacGowan of Pogues fame said that he was not a Yeats fan but he did like An Irish Airman Foresees His Death. His contribution is a highlight of the album. "The poem seems to be about being a tiny pawn in the great cosmos, but MacGowan makes it belligerent," says Dunne. "He turns it into a poem saying I make my own choices , I live or die by what I've done." Van Morrison's lawyer said that the man never did such things. But when Morrison himself heard
of the project he too came on board with his sublime setting of Before The World Was Made. There were a few disap -
vibrato and dramatic pauses, and Richard Harris opening and closing the album with extracts from Under Ben Bul - ben . "We ended up recording
pointments. bivis Costello was keen but his record company appar - ently was not. Joni Mitchell, who has recorded Yeats's Slouching To - wards Bethlehem, declined to partici - pate . But Michael and Anne Yeats, the poet's surviv - ing children, gave their support and Ijciuiiucu
6 We wrote to various artists. It was an amazing bit of cheek 9
him in a hotel room. There we were with this crackpot idea and Harris in his pyja - mas ," says Dunne . Despite the unusu - al setting, Harris was the true pro - fessional . "I asked him to go through it once and he said he would do it a thousand times until it was
a pann - ing by Jack Yeats, the poet's brother, to be used on the cover . There are just three spoken contributions — an extraordi - nary recording of Yeats him - self reading The Lake Isle of Innisfree in a voice full of
peneci. Harris sweated over the text , extracting every ounce of meaning until he was satisfied he had got it right. When the tape was turned off he then treated them to some of his own verse. Would Yeats be writing pop
songs if he were around today? Perhaps not, but the two men are convinced that the poet would regard the best of contemporary Irish music as part of the great bardic tradi - tion . They deliberately asked Harris to open the album with the lines: "Irish poets learn your trade/ Sing whatever is well made" as an historical exhortation to the artists who follow. "Yeats drew on the ballad tradition and he talked about the music of poetry. He was one link in the long chain of Irish expression and he wrote a lot about love and loss , classic rock themes. He was also very aware of poetry as a populist form," says Dunne. "Poetry as the new rock'n'roll is a cliche, but the link is obvious ." Now And In Time To Be — a musical celebration of the works of W.B. Yeats is released by Grape - vine nn Fph.?
William Strang's portrait of W.B. Yeats, housed in the National Gallery of Ireland: "Love and loss are classic rock themes"

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Poems to keep the barbarians at bay
Full_text:
Poems to keep the barbarians at bay
J ohn Fuller and Christo - pher Reid are both on the ten-strong shortlist for the T. S. Eliot Prize, to be an - nounced this Monday . Both purvey the sort of wit and tidiness that — whatever the final result — are so highly prized in English poetry today. Fuller, the son of the poet Roy Fuller, is a don at Oxford A novelist and short story writer as well as a fluent and prolific poet, sometime collab - orator with James Fenton (on the delicious skit Partingtime Hall), and mentor and friend to a clutch of younger writers — Bernard O'Donoghue , Mick Imlah and Alan Hollinghurst among them — he is a significant presence in British letters who, single - handedly , has made Oxford into a vibrant and nurturing
place. His Collected Poems are published in his 60th year. Fuller has been a skilful and organised poet since his teens. This substantial volume shows the presiding influence of Auden, as well as reflecting a number of passing styles: the Movement in the Fifties, the imagistic vignettes of the Re - view school, the Martianism of the Seventies . Formally, he offers huge variety, a whole department store of poetry: from haiku elegies and a sonnet in disyllables, to terza rima, quartets and quintets, to satirical epistles and Browningesque tales, to C las - sical hexameters and a verse novel, The Illusionists, in the Pushkin stanza (chucking in three acrostics as it goes) to other things I wouldn't even knnw _thf> name nf\
He is the author of a much - loved Valentine ("I like it when you tilt your cheek up./I like the way you nod and hold a teacup./ I like your legs
Michael Hotmann COLLECTED POEMS By John Fuller Chatto & Windus, £20 (S6_M<3 7O((66(Z6 EXPANDED UNIVERSES By Christopher Reid Faber, £6.99 ISBN057117924 X
when you unwind them./ Even in trousers I don't mind them."), a suite on the shires of England, poems on chess and music, and long meditations on landscape and astronomy. Like Auden, he has his lon - gueurs . The Illusionists shows him not quite able to pull off a narrative, more a series of wittily embellished tangents. Still, you never have to go for very many lines without some wit or felicity or spark of enchantment , whether in rhyme (he is probably the best polysyllabic rhymer since By - ron ), or diction (someone do -
ing martial arts in Gerrards Cross becomes "a Black belt in the green belt" ) or idea (say, "the curable romantic" ). His facility and versatility resist easy description: You expect — perhaps — a poem like Amaz - ing , on pornography ("Such drooping and dragging ,/ Such feinting and flagging,/ Such sighing and sagging/ Saw I never."), but not Metropoli - tan , with its cunningly prover - bial alien idiom: "The centre of cities move westwards; the centre of the mother of cities has disappeared./ North the great cat, East the great water, South the great fire, West the great arrow." Christopher Reid, whose fifth bookExpanded Universes is, seems more specialised and
intriguing, less of a challenge to the reviewer with taxonomy on his mind. One of the earl y "Martians ", he has been grad - ually disarming himself and his readers, ever since his 1985 book of Eastern European "translations ," the wonderful Katerina Brae. The ground-note of Expand - ed Universes is a kind of bemused acquiescence. The characteristically clever and mocking pretense is that Reid's speakers are not hurt into articulacy (as Auden describes), but are surprised into it, having it dragged out of them by a wickedly eccentric world. His voice in these short
