Here is literary cunning and ac - complishment of a high order. With the exception of Sorley MacLean (who of course writes in Gaelic), Iain Crichton Smith must be the finest Scottish poet since Hugh MacDiarmid. Patiently, far away from the distractions of fame, he has worked over the past four decades to refine a style that was always original to the point where he seems able now to make poetry out of anything that occurs to him. Born on Lewis in the Outer Hebrides, Smith understands the
Calvinist conscience from the in - side . He has written unforgettably about its effects on rural Scottish life, yet he is not in the last analysis a "regional" writer. His landscapes are countries of the mind. All this is evident in Ends and Beginnings, a collection as various as any Smith has written, ranging from a long meditation on the Israeli-Palestinian War occasioned by a visit to the Golan Heights to small but telling observations on the nature of poetry itself: "Poetry is a swart planet/ with which we are in touch, from which/ we receive at certain times messages." One of Smith's best poems is about two girls he heard singing on a bus — "the unpredicted voices of our kind". It is spontaneities such as this which his work celebrates, setting them against all dogma. MICHAEL Schmidt's PN Review has reached its 100th issue — a rare feat for a little magazine, but then PN Review has always been excep - tional . Edgell Rickword and Laura Riding head the list of 88 poets represented in this centennial number. The whole is called "A Calendar of Modern Poetry", and stands as testament to the maga - zine ' s seriousness and dedication over the past two decades.
Robert Nye

Author: Mcintyre, Ian
Title: The man who kept writing
Full_text:
Chesterton 's rolling English prose and poetry were once on every schoolboy 's lips. Ian Mclntyre assesses the great, saintly polemicist
The man who kept writing
There is, it seems, a move afoot to have G.K. Chesterton beati - fied . The author of the most celebrated telegram in the Eng - lish language C'Am at Market Har - borough . Where ought I to be?") is greatly admired in Argentina, and a number of establishment figures there have appealed to Cardinal Hume to set the ball rolling, drawing attention to GKC's efforts "to rebuild the Catholic imagination and sensitivity of England". I suspect the fat man in the cloak and brigand's hat would have found this hugely entertaining — almost as enter - taining as the knowledge that the Ignatius Press in San Francisco is intent on collecting and publishing every fleeting word he ever wrote. This awesome enterprise has already result - ed in 14 volumes, and there are many
more to come. , "You seem to know everything," gushed an admiring lady at one of his lectures. "I know nothing, Madam," Chesterton replied. "I am a journalist." And some. From 1905 until his death in 1936 he wrote a weekly article for the Illustrated London News; for 11 years he also wrote a column in the teetotal George Cadbury'sDai /yNews , but this association was abruptly terminated when GKC rashly but innocently published "A Song of Strange Drinks", which contained the line "Cocoa is a cad and a coward". He wrote in cabs, on trains and in the pubs of Fleet Street — not just journalism, but thousands of poems; not just the Father Brown stories, but essays on theology and politics; not just plays and novels, but fairy tales, biographies and literary
criticism. "Taking trouble has never been a weakness of mine," he announced cheerfully (in describing the battle of Ethandune in "The Ballad of the White Horse", he has the left wings of the opposing armies facing each other). He quoted from memory and didn't believe in looking things up. Early in his career he dashed off a study of Robert Browning: "There were very few bio - graphical facts in the book," he wrote, "and those were nearly all wrong." None of which prevented Auden from
THE COLLECTED WORKS OF G.K. CHESTERTON Volume X: Poetry, Part 1 Edited by Aidan Mackey Volume XIV: Short Stories, Fairy Tales, Mystery Stories Edited by Denis Conlon Ignatius Press, £34.951 £25.95 pbk each declaring he had written some of the best nonsense verse in the language, Evelyn Waugh from rating The Ever - lasting Man as one of the few really great popular books of the century, and Andre Maurois from saluting Charles Dickens as one of the best biographies ever written. His friend Hilaire Belloc called him an architect of certitude — "he taught
men to see what they had not seen before". His publisher asserts sweep - ingly that he was the most quotable writer of the century. We must perhaps aim off a point or two for co-religionist zeal, but someone who defined bigotry as "the anger of men who have no opinion" and wrote of Tennyson that "he could not think up to the height of his own towering style" certainly de - serves a place on a long shortlist. "Our Lord turned water into wine, not into ginger beer," Chesterton informed an American journalist during Prohibi - tion . On another occasion he had advice for conviction politicians of any nation - ality : "The men who really believe in themselves are all in lunatic asylums."
In their day, his poems were hugely popular. One collection went into 15 editions in his lifetime. I don't know how they fare nowadays under the national curriculum, but an inventory of the mental furniture of an older generation would undoubtedly contain many Chestertonian pieces — "The Donkey", "Lepanto ", "The Rolling English Road" and, from the dark wartime days of 1915, "The Secret People": "Smile at us, pay us, pass us; but ido not quite forget. / For we are the people of England, that never have, spoken yet."
The Head Master of Douaionce said of him that he did not go to.eonfessidh very often, but that when he did, "you could hear him all over the church". At the turn of the century, Chesterton's distinctive voice could be heard all over the country; it was largely his anti - imperialist writing about the Boer War which made his reputation. From 1926 until his death he was much involved with the pistributist League, which drew its inspiration from Pope Leo XIH's Rerum Novarum and aimed to make as many people as possible the owners of property. That should not prove an obstacle to canonisation, although his acknowledged anti - Semi - tism might — even if, rather unusually, it went hand-in-hand with an enthusi - asm for Zionism. . He was a polemicist of rare quality, but he wrote and spoke always with such good humour that he seldom made enemies. To the more acerbic Belloc, his gentleness was almost a matter for reproach: "He wounded none, but thus also he failed to provide weapons wherewith one may wound
and kill folly." Chesterton regarded his Father Brown stories as potboilers. When, a first collection of them appeared in 1911, a reviewer in Country Life felt they should have been left in the pages of a magazine, "where their effect, not being cumulative, would have been greater". A similar thought may strike those who plunge into the potpourri of fiction presented here — 800 pages of short stories and fairy tales, assembled from published sources or transcribed from Chesterton's notebooks. Admirers of the "little Suffolk dump - ling from East Anglia", with his brown paper parcels and his battered umbrel - la , will no doubt be pleased to have "Father Brown and the Donnington Affair" and "The Mask of Midas", the two lost stories included here, but the quality of much of what has been collected, a good deal of it juvenilia, is distinctly uneven. Could it be that Chesterton's propensity for sending cartloads of paper to the municipal dump indicated a more rigorous edito - rial sense than that of the Ignatius Press?
G.K. Chesterton and friend: quotable, prolific often inaccurate but always good-humoured , he furnished the minds of a generation

Author: Logan, Stephen
Title: Poetry in its place
Full_text:
Poetry m its place
IT IS widely rumoured that a renaissance in English poetry is under way. But it does not take the form widely attribut - ed to it by the organisers of last October's "National Poetry Day". Poetry ministers, to what might be called our spiritual needs. Yet our cul - ture at large no longer takes such needs very seriously. Poets have a choice. Either they can dilute the principles of their art so as to make it palatable to a largely indiffer - ent public. Or they can main - tain a steadfast concern for the intricacies of technique, rather than try to curry favour by making concessions. In short poetry can adapt itself to an increasingly unliterary cul - ture , or else that culture can adapt itself to poetry. It is an old story, now more than ever in need of retelling: "Poetry must create the taste by which
it is to be enjoyed". The National Poetry Day jamboree took the popular option, casting poems in the image of contemporary cul - ture : informal, undemanding, free of tradition, and ultimate - ly expendable. Clive Wilmer, himself a poet of distinction, along with the 21 diverse poets he has interviewed here, has taken a sterner course. These interviews constitute a credo on behalf of a tradition that unites Donald Davie, Thorn Gunn, Tony Harrison, Ted Hughes and Seamus Heaney with Spenser, Shake - speare , Milton; Pope, Words - worth , and Elicit. It is a tradition that regards poetry as a learned, art, a profession which; in spite of a culturally sanctioned, indifference, bears witness to the best that has been thought arid felt. Seamus Heaney is about as popular as a poet can current -
Stephen Logan POETS TALKING Edited by Clive Wilmer Carcanet, £12.95 ly get. But to appreciate the soft plagency of his voice (in speech as in verse) or the pro - democratic value of his con - cern for the "hearth language" of a community, requires fa - miliarity with the history of English verse, as well as an interviewer as learned, tactful and incisive as Wilmer to elicit the evidence. Tony Harrison, too, has the kind of popular appeal that
proceeds more directly from classical and prosodic learn - ing than seems to be acknowl - edged by those who acclaim him as a sort of poetic dema - gogue . The ability of poets to speak for the people depends on the acquisition of linguistic skills that the people often slight. Poets (and their read - ers ) need to be informed before they can be inspired. Wilmer's interviews are per - haps the best introduction to the personalities and the prin - ciples that inform the poems. They provide an invigorating exhibition of creative talent in
its easy-chair . The lessons they afford are chiefly these. First, that the task of recording the history of sensibility is impor - tant enough to have com - manded the dedication of such diversely gifted individuals as Czeslaw Milosz, Michael Longley, C.H. Sisson and John Peck. Second, that these, the inheritors of a poetic tradition which they (and Wil - mer with them) lovingly con - serve , are especially to be heeded as critics of their own art.

Author: Campbell-Johnston, Rachel
Title: Now, what rhymes with Euterpe?
Full_text:
Thursday is Britain's first National Poetry Day, when you will get a poem with your pint and a stanza with your shopping
Now, what rhymes with Euterpe ?
Not since Wordsworth's "spontaneous over - flow of powerful feel - ings " have passions about poetry run so high . Thursday has been declared Britain's first ever National Poetry Day, and for all those who thought that poems were just things in books which did not quite reach the margins, this Diony - sian festival of dithyrambs sets out to prove otherwise. All over the British Isles, poetry will tune her sacred voice. London's National The -
atre has a day-long pro - gramme of readings. In Bir - mingham 's NEC there will be a "Readathon live". Cardiff's Royal Hotel hosts "Poems from the Audience" with a live link-up to BBC2's coverage of the Forward Poetry Prizes. "The whole point of Nat - ional Poetry Day" , says Wil - liam Sieghart, chairman of
Forward Publishing and the enthusiast who initiated the event, "is for people to cele - brate poetry in any way they like." The response has been enormous — from Brownie packs competing to write the longest poem to the Cat's Protection League launching its new anthology. Shops will offer service with a spondee
and barmaids will pull poems with your pint. Even that mutest of breeds, the home - counties commuter, will be lured into lyricism when pu - pils of Ashlyns School hand out poems on the Euston line. "A poetry renaissance has been quietly gathering strength in Britain over the past few years", says Peter
Forbes, editor of Poetry Re - view . Though in the 1970s and 1980s the parameters of poetry were largly defined by a small group of Oxford graduates, all sympathetic to an anti - experi - meritai Movement poetic, harking back to Augustan ideals, now in the 1990s poetry seems to be revelling in a renewed vitality. "Because its
context is no longer largely academic," James Fenton, Pro - fessor of Poetry at Oxford, explains , "poetry is enjoying a new popularity." "It has become more in touch with people's needs", says Neil Astley of Bloodaxe. Poets such as Carol Ann Duffy and Simon Armitage tackle the problems of modern urban
life head on. Others such as Heaney and Muldoon have become increasingly political. "The most important thing is that people are beginning to recognise that poetry is direct - ly relevant to.their lives", says Sieghart. "If nothing else I would like to think that people will turn over in bed when the alarm clock rings on Thurs - day and compare their be - loved to a summer's day."
Rachel Campbell-Johnston

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry special: the things of this world sing out in a great oratorio
Full_text:
Poetry special : the things of this world sing out in a great oratorio
When Norman Nicholson died seven years ago , his Times obituary called him "the most gifted English Christian provincial poet,of his century". This encomium is picked up, and quarrelled with, by the editor of his Collected Poems, Neil Curry, in the course of an introduc - tion discussing the nature of Nich - olson 's "parochialism" and its paradoxical universality. Yet this volume — which includes many previously uncoUected poems, as well as his five major volumes — proves the obituarist right Nicholson was born and lived all his, life in the small town of Millom on the west coast of Cumbria, a place he once described as "a curiously isolated spot blocked off from the rest of England on three sides by the sea and on the fourth by mountains". His poems are about a world of rock and stone, becks, walls, dunes, Scafell Pike, shadows and clouds over combes. Nicholson picks over his patch with the assurance and assiduity of a modern Wordsworth. That com - parison is inevitable. But it is where the two men part company that Nicholson begins to be arresting.
COLLECTED POEMS ' - \ By Norman Nicholson ;' . ' . Faber,£25: . COLLECTED POEMS' By Francis Beny ' : ' :-. ; Redcliffe Press, £25 "On the Dismantling of Millom Ironworks", begins asa quarrel with his predecessor for averting his gaze from the charcoal-burning furnace/ Sited like a badger's set deep in Duddon woods — in other words, for rejecting in the name of Nature the poetic possibilities of the Industrial Revolution. The poem moves oh to-celebrate the .ugly but rich reality of this ironworks before finally coming to the conclusion that now the iron - works have been dismantled may - be the ghost of Wordsworth, seeing further than I can,/ Will stare from Duddon Bridge, along miles of sand and mud-flats / To a peninsula bare as it used to be , and, beyond , to a river/ Flowing, untainted now, to a bleak, depopu - lated shore.
The language is flat and unam - b iguous , but the poem seems inspired by a - nice uncertainty .truthfully expressed. Is that "bleak , depopulated shore" really to be preferred to the human reality and peculiar beauty which Nicholson found in the ironworks? Is he being ironic when he says that Words - worth ' s ghost might see further than he can? Or acknowledging that there could be a false romanti - cism in his own nostalgia ? The poem troubles its reader with such questions, and is the stronger for not offering answers. Early Nicholson was not as good as this, either in form or content, the strict iambics tending to come with metronomic regularity and his details sometimes having the effect of a rhymed guidebook. But he got more interesting the longer he went on, and there are not many poets (modern or otherwise) of whom one can say that. If Nicholson has been neglected because his life's work concerned itself with unfashionable matter seriously treated, then what are we to say of Francis Berry? This poet, 80 next year, has been described by Philip Hobsbaum as "a master of
the long poem", and long poems have been out of favour at least since Edgar Allen Poe declared them to be a contradiction in terms. Berry does not even write fractured epics, but for long narrative poems, usually with a historical setting. His Collected Poems (available from 49 Park Street, Bristol ) has work from nine volumes published since the early 1930s. Poe's objection to the long poem was basically that vision involves excitement, and that it is false to pretend that excitement can be sustained for pages on end. Both Chaucer and Browning might be cited against him, and though Francis Berry is certainly not a poet of their stature, he has in common with those predecessors a rich vein of humanity which makes him interested in voices and in stories, and in verse as a means of storytelling through the use of different voices. Introducing this volume, Hobs - baum calls it "an oeuvre unsur - passed in the later 20th century". Those who suppose that the art of dramatic and narrative verse has no living exponents cannot have taken Berry into account.
Robert Nye
Muldoon: allusive, not elitist

Author: Wilmer, Clive
Title: Setting poetry's agenda
Full_text:
Setting poetry's agenda
In 1956, the 16-year-old William Cookson received a letter from the man he still regards as the greatest poet of modern times. Ezra Pound, then incarcerated in an asylum for the criminally in - sane , was responding to an enthusiastic review of The Cantos which Cookson had written for his school maga - zine . Two years later, shortly after-his release, Pound invited the young man to visit his Italian home. There—ever the pedagogue and impresario — he encouraged- Cookson to start a quarterly of his own. Thirty-five years and several crises later, the product of their conspiracy is still alive and kicking. It is called Agen - da and the latest issue (Vol. 31, No. 4-Vol . 32, No. 1) is mainly devoted to the poetry and thought of Kathleen Raine, 86 this month (available at £8 from good bookshops and 5 Cranbourne Court, Albert Bridge Road, London SWU 4PE). About a third of this issue is given over to other poems and articles, including a group of essays on W.H. Auden. I am
CliveWilmer AGENDA : AN ANTHOLOGY The First Four Decades 1958-1993 Edited by William Cookson Carcanet , £25
not myself an admirer of Raine's poetry, which seems to me too formulaic for work that is meant to be visionary. But what other publication would dedicate so much attention to so utterly serious a writer, especially one with no call on a popular following? It needs courage and stub - born independence of mind to maintain a magazine that is so rigorously indifferent to fash - ion . Those virtues are plainly exemplified in Agenda: An Anthology, which Cookson has now assembled from his nearly four decades as an editor. After a foreword by Grey Gowrie, it begins with the "Founders" he has cham - pioned — Pound, David Jones, Basil Bunting, Hugh Mac - Diarmid , William Carlos Wil - liams and Louis Zukofsky. The list also suggests some of Cookson's limitations: these are heroic figures, but not all have worn equally well.
His biggest failure has been his inability to find genuine heirs to the Pound tradition. The sec - ondary figures in the book include several of the best poets currently writing — Geoffrey Hill, Donald Davie, Thorn Gunn, Seamus Heaney and C.H. Sisson. But Cookson is also a pushover for the genteel versifying that marks out the English amateur of poetry . If there is a triumph to compare with the best of the Founders, it must be the brilliant clutch of verse trans - lations — which, of course, is deeply Poundian territory. Compelled to select a star from this constellation, I would
probably go for the ballades of Francois Villon in the craggily musical Lullans of Tom Scott. These, like most of Scott's lyrical work—I have less time for his didactic pieces — send electric shocks through my system. Anyone similarly af - fected should lay hands on another Agenda publication, The Collected Shorter Poems of Tom Scott (Agenda, £11.95). Sadly, in the anthology a page of this poem seems to have gone astray — but then the smoother side of publish - i n g has never been Agenda's strongest suit. The roughness, though, is part of what one values.

Author: Rathbone, Lois
Title: Poetry, love and the meaning of death
Full_text:
Poetry, love and the meaning of death
Writers comment on modern Japan at their peril, so com - plex is that society. For the setting of her latest novel Alison Fell takes the imperial court of 11th-century Japan and a group of verse-writing courtesans. The early classical period of Japanese poetry is in decline — only men being considered clever enough to write in the ever more elabo - rate forms the Chinese charac - ters have become — and women are thus forced to devise their own delicately erotic tankas in the vernacu - lar , which they send as notes to their lovers: When you visit me in winter . Don't be deterred by the curtain Of icicles over the door: just bring your sharpest sword. Lady Onogoro is a provin - cial innocent at court who has for her protector the powerful General Motosuke. Whereas bashful young Japanese brides were traditionally given "pillow books" containing in - structive drawings to guide them through the ordeals of the wedding night, Onogoro has had the foresight to find her own "pillow boy", a blind stablehand gifted with a fe - brile imagination, whom she resourcefully positions behind the tsuitate screen at the head of her bed. While the general is employed on a lower part of her anatomy (we must pre - sume he is slightly deaf for this to work), the silver-tongued stableboy practises his own form of "aural sex" into Onogoro's ear. His lewd sto - ries take up a good part of the book and typically involve congress with whole troops of monks, holy men and all manner of animal life — horses, foxes and even carp. In a mischievously "a ca - demic " introduction, Fell as - sures us that this is no fiction,
but in fact translation by a professor, Arye Blower, of some arcane manuscripts which she has merely edited. She has done a good job of recreating the more measured, ornamental speech of the per - iod , and at finding some local imagery: Onogoro's face, for instance, crumples "like a paper lantern in an autumn cloudburst". She also unearths some interesting titbits on the customs of the age. We discov - er that while men may have several concubines, women must be seen to act with
THE PILLOW BOY OFTHE LADY ONOGORO By Alison Fell Serpents Tail, £7.99pbk original N.P. By Banana Yoshimoto Faber, £5.99 pbk original
forbearance, for if a man has two lovers and one dies, the other may be held to have caused her death through ill - will . But despite the men's seemingly complete control of the dusty corridors of state, it is the scheming women and their uninhibited girls-only gatherings in the Almond Blossom chamber who hold together this delicately - bal - anced society and this very entertaining book. Where Fell's book is a good imitation, N.P. is the real Japanese article. Banana Yoshimoto's first novel, Kitch - en , was up-beat and relentless - ly happy. It did not take itself seriously and was all the better for it. It made Yoshimoto a cult figure in Japan and a million - airess by the age of 25. Now, perhaps stung by criticisms of Kitchen's levity
and its slightly-drawn charac - ters , she has turned to some bigger issues. We are offered incest, telepathy , lesbianism, suicide — but it does not quite come off. Events take place one long, hot summer when Kazami is researching in the English Department of a Japa - nese university and becomes embroiled in the claustropho - bic world of three siblings. Their father has written a collection of short stories in English before committing suicide. Now anyone foolhar - dy enough to attempt to trans - late them into Japanese succumbs to their melancholy nature and kills himself in sympathy with the author. To complicate matters, two of the siblings are in love and consid - ering a joint suicide pact. In the midst of this emotion - al mayhem, Ann Sherif's Eng - lish translation has a poppy, American feel to it: "Wow , that's good" and "It's kinda fun" exclaim her characters brightly. But there are some good descriptions of summer: friends sitting on a pavement, drinking cold cans of barley tea, or warm bottles of wine from soggy paper cups. And the similes have a Japanese flavour: "She looked like a slender willow branch, wav^ ing in the summer breeze, except that she was wearing sunglasses". She has, too, a nice instinct for showing how those banal details of life — the colour of a woman's sandals, for instance — do more to convey her state of mind than any number of explicit statements but her style is just too 'slight, too saccharin to support her sub - ject matter. Yoshimoto's 20th - century Japanese resemble twitching bags of nerves; by comparison, in Fell's pastiche their 11th-century ancestors seem to have had a very much better time of it.
Lois Rathbone
The flying tea ceremony kettle by Ippitsusai Buncho, c.1770. The title alludes to Osen a beautiful waitress at the Kasamori Shrine, who ran away. From The Actor's Image Printmakers of the Katsukawa School by Timothy Clark et al (Princeton, £99.50)

Author: Horovitz, Michael
Title: Poetic power to move
Full_text:
Poetic power to move
THE 15 essays which form the bulk of this book are con - cerned with American poets and poetry, apart from a sensitive appraisal of 16th - century English poetry and another of Basil Bunting, both particular lodestars for Gunn. Lovers of Whitman, Pound, Marianne Moore and Eliza - beth Bishop will find their enthusiasms extended here. I was delighted by Gunn's quotatious expositions of Lorine Niedecker, Robert Duncan, Robert Creeley and other pathfinders still unfa - miliar or neglected in Britain. He appends exuberant ac -
counts of how he took 15 years to write a poem; of his fellow ex-English homosexual in Cal - ifornia , Christopher Isher - wood ; and of his sternly provocative poetry mentor at Stanford University, Yvor Winters. In a revealing interview Gunn recalls that when he first published his verse in the early 1950s, "I found myself identified with some people who eventually became classed as the Movement. However, my contention is that the Movement didnt really exist." What the establishmentar - ian Movement apologists such
SHELF LIFE By Thorn Gunn Faber, £14.99 as Amis and Larkin flaunted were so-called anti-wet , anti - phoney , anti-abroad , com - monsensical , formalistic, and more or less homophobic pre - dilections . Gunn is unim - peachably tough-minded arid has turned out reams of immaculately crafted lines — yet he has also always repre - sented depth of feeling, techni - cal experiment and sexual freedom. After Cambridge he moved to San Francisco to be with his lover, and it has remained his home to this day. While several of his little - Englandist contemporaries traded on the Movement tag, Gunn is the only one I can think of who did move on any meaningful levels, and of his own accord. Gunn points out that Larkin
"right now exercises a terrible influence on English poetry, because if you admire some - body like that so much it means you're not going to be aiming very high. His distrust of rhetoric was also a distrust of feeling, a distrust of dar - ing ." Risk-taking , openness, generosity, imagination, cour - age , tenderness and commit - ment are among the qualities most frequently celebrated on these 235 pages, and also throughout the 500 more of Gunn's Collected Poems, which Faber is about to issue in paperback at only £9.99:
from his youthfully challeng - ing and sensuous explorations in Fighting Terms and The Sense of Movement to his redefinition of elegy in The Man with Night Sweats (1992), they are qualities Britain hath as much need of today as ever. Gunn commends Allen Ginsberg's "humanity of spir - it , humour, ecstasy and vi - sion ... claims and preroga - tives of poetry forgotten in the age of Larkin" — which his own work exemplifies equally. The immortality of Gunn's shelf life is clinched by the real life his books reflect with such integrity, finesse, and passion.
Michael Horovitz

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: At the well of rhythm
Full_text:
Atthe well of rhythm
At the age of 20, C.H. Sisson gave up the writing of poetry, for the very good reason that he was dissatisfied with his own performance. He started again some nine years later on a troopship on the way to India, during the Second World War, when by his own account he found himself im - pelled by certain words and rhythms in his head. Many books later, and 80 years old last April, I suspect that Sisson is still dissatisfied. The rest of us need not be. He is as good a poet as any now writing in English. "My verse," he said once, "is about things I am, at the moment of writing, just begin - ning to understand. When I have understood them, or have that impression, the sub - ject has gone, and I have to find another." The work in
What and Who (Carcanet, £7.95 pbk original) bears out this self-appraisal . Here are poems about old age and mortality which look unflinch - ingly at those conditions, but which read like beginnings. Sisson's finest verse has always been about sex and God, about (in Eliot's phrase) birth, and copulation, and death. He would probably subscribe to Eliot's insistence: That's all the facts when you come to brass tacks. In other words, Sisson is a poet con - cerned with the eternal verities of the human condition, say - ing something new by virtue of the personal passion which he brings to their expression, which newness is marked by the slight shifts in rhythm which make him not quite like anyone else. "The man that was the same in Neolithic and in Roman times, as now, is of more interest than the freak of
circumstances," he has writ - ten . "This truth lies at the bottom of a well of rhythm." . Trying to convey Sisson's flavour , I always find myself quoting his lines to Catullus, where the Latin poet is seen sympathetically as my friend
POETRY across twenty centuries/ Anx ious to complete your lechery before Christ came. This vale - diction is crucial, since much of Sisson's work has been an attempt to return to souce and reknit Christianity to the pa - gan world, or perhaps rather to explore the relationship of the flesh of paganism and the religion of the Incarnation.
That work continues unabated in What and Who, a most remarkable volume by any standards. Five years younger than Sisson, John Heath-Stubbs has some of the same concerns and a touch of the same liveliness. He is a master of traditional verse forms, and his new book Sweetapple Earth (Carcanet, £7.95 pbk) even contains a series, of limericks on the plots of op - eras , the most memorable being "Don Giovanni": That night, when the trap - door stuck fast . In Dublin, we all were aghast,
Till a voice from the 'gods' Started shouting the odds: 'Thank heaven, hell's full up at last!' This .is amusing, and so is Heath-Stubbs 's versified list of the Poets Laureate, not to speak of a number of reflec - tions on flowers and classical history and the birthdays of his friends. If you are looking for well-made light and occa - sional verse, then this is the volume for you. Vernon Scannell is no doubt the only English poet ever to have made a living as a boxer in fairground booths. If that leads you to expect a certain pugnaciousness of his verse, then his Collected Poems 1950-1993 (Robson, £14.95 pbk original) should not prove disappointing. I like the embattled tender - ness of the handful of love poems included here which succeed in the difficult busi - ness of being personal without being coy or messy. He also
writes well about guilt and remorse, most notably in "A Case of Murder". His verse has its feet on the ground, almost to a fault in that the rhythms are too often predict - able . All the same, the decency of Scanner's concern to find meaning in the occasions of everyday life is self-evident , and his work stands out from the ruck by reason of its careful craftsmanship. Dennis O'Driscoll works in Dublin Castle, where he man - ages the Stamp Duty Adjudi - cation office. His verse has an unusual acerbity when it comes to engaging with every - day life and his Long Story Short (Anvil, £7.95 pbk origi - nal ) deserves attention for that reason. Discursive in feeling yet imagist in technique, poems such as those in the two sequences "Breviary" and "Rose Windows" manage to express compassion without the least taint of sentimental - ity . James Joyce had a word for it: jocoserious.
Robert Nye
Sisson: eternal verities

Author: Dannatt, Andrian
Title: Poetry of New York's airwaves
Full_text:
CONCERT : Radio celebrations
Poetry of New York 's airwaves
M anhattan's cultur - al landmarks are always under siege by the forces of profit and space, but the potential demise of WNYC, the city's oldest classical music sta - tion — it's been going 50 years — caused ructions unmatched since Mia left Woody. The threat to the station's frequencies came, ironical - ly , when plans for a celebra - tion concert were already fixed. So the fiftieth anniver - sary began with a message from the mayor declaring not only that the station was saved, but that he had named this Official WNYC Day. If further proof were needed of the central role of 93.9FM on the dial of every civilised radio, the three hours of new music that followed contained it. John Schaefer, the young, ponytailed music program - mer , is responsible for much of the station's hip status and high listening figures, and this birthday concert showed the range of his imagination and con - nections . Schaefer managed to commission 12 of Ameri -
ca s most .celebrated com - posers to write pieces especially for this event, none exceeding ten minutes, and all based on the same poem — No Longer Very Clear by John Ashbery. The equivalent would be Classic FM (which dreams of being WNYC if it grows up and gets lucky) persuad - ing Seamus Heaney to write an ode, and then getting everyone from Sir Michael Tippett to Brian Eno to set it to music. First Ashbery read his 18 - line , four-stanza poem, cryptic, romantic and highly moody at the same time. He also admitted he had listened to nothing but WNYC since he moved to the city in 1949. This hint of nostalgia was confirmed by a sound collage of archival material, an interview with Bob Dylan juxtaposed with Ma Bart6k and, even more improbably, Elvis Presley sharing a studio with Mrs Franklin Roosevelt. The actual compositions demonstrated in textbook
50 th Anniversary Concert WNYC Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center , New York fashion the full range of musical styles in operation, everything from Laurie An - derson to John Corigliano's all-female bassoon quartet. The notion of a hardcore Modernist like Milton Bab - bitt sharing the billing with Philip Glass is more shock - ing than Dylan and Bart6k. As it was, Glass delivered a sentimental, typically riff - driven piano solo, and Bab - bitt used soprano Cheryl Marshall and his usual
dissonant twinkle. The concert proved that outstanding work is being done in every zone, whether a snappy rag by longtime establishment figure Mor - ton Gould, or Robin Hol - comb 's balladeering, reminiscent of Ricky Lee Jones, accompanied by drums and Bill Frisell's electric guitar. Anthony Da - vis , best known as the composer of the Malcolm X opera, created a charming study for piano, clarinet and soprano far from his avant - iazz roots.
It was fascinating to see each composer dealing with the poem, writing solely instrumental work, or just setting one vowel, as with Raphael MostePs True No performed on Tibetan singing bowls and shofar. Peter Schickele, inventor of PDQ Bach, delivered a Steinway-smasher for six hands, and the ivories were equally under attack with Ursula Oppen's breathtak - ing race through "like a... an engine" by Joan Tower. It is only to be hoped that in another 50 years New York will still be able to sustain a station of this quality, and that just as many, if not more, types of music will be there to cele - brate it.
Adrian Dannatt

Author: Williams, Hugo
Title: Sting lays
Full_text:
Sting lays
H ugo Williams's latest collection, Dock Lea ves, is dedicated to his mother, who died last year. Margaret Vyner, a beautiful Australian model, married the actor Hugh Williams and they wrote a string of successful plays together in the late Fifties. Most of the new poems are about their family life. The dock leaves of the title are the remedy for the child - hood pain of a nettle sting. One of the main traits of Williams's poetry is his ability to slip back to the past as effortlessly as a dreamer. In "Old Boy" he finds himself back at school, complete with grey hair,. a wife and motor - bike . Using time in this way fulfils two functions. On the surface there is nostalgia for the past, where things were better than the present, like the Beatles's "Oh I believe in yesterday!" On another level.
writing about old hurts be - comes a sort of therapy. In the opening poem, "On Your Marks", Williams writes "I start furthest back." The logical reason for the delayed start is the fact that he is older than his brother and sister, yet the phrase conveys a sense of inadequacy. Though his fam - ily life seems -privileged , his unhappiness lay chiefly in his inability to become an actor and fit into the bright-ami brittle world of the stage. Williams's father comes across as a charming man in some of the poems and in vintage filmsr~HTs~life is covered in greater dv.rfh in an earlier collection, Writing Home. More detail? are sup - plied in these later poems, like those in "Truce ", where father and son meet up in the kitchen
Fiona Pitt-Kethley DOCK LEAVES By Hugo Williams Faber. £6.99pbk original taking a midnight snack: My father was standing under a light bulb, eating a sausage dipped in horseradish sauce. I helped myself to Shredded Wheat and a banana. We stood on the verandah together and peed on the daffodils. But there was also a less jolly side to the martinet who dismissed his eldest son's the - atrical ambitions. He was: imperious, categorical , al - ways in the wrong and rightly so, the only man in the world who could talk about opera and French mustard
as if they were the same sort of thing. Williams admires this sophis - tication intensely. He has in - herited his father's elegance and put it to use in his poetry, something most of us would believe to be a better and more lasting art forifi.;,..,. _,..,, ' Where the poems don't draw '' directly on his own experience , they are less suc - cessful . "Sex ", a pastiche of the pompous language of man - uals , tells us far less about the writer than the amusing, epi - grammatic "Poetry ": Ten, no,five seconds after coming all over the place too soon. I was lying there wondering where to put the line-breaks in.

Author: Morrison, Richard
Title: Bonfire of the vanity press
Full_text:
Bonfire of the vanity press
Anew definition of "vanity publishing" was offered by some - body the other day: ugly journalists who write col - umns with little pictures of themselves at the top. Well, um, quite. The real thing, however — vanity publish - ing , I mean, not my double - c hin — is even more grotesque. That is revealed in an intriguing new book by Johnathon Clifford, who runs the National Poetry Foundation. Vanity Press and The Proper Poetry Publishers starts from two premises: that there will always be people who will write awful poetry and yet be blind to its total lack of merit and that there will always be "pub - l ishers " (if we can dignify them thus) who will take advantage of the poets' gull -
ibility , and sting them for thousands of pounds. Serve the awful poets right, you say. Well, per - haps . It is true that Clifford lists plenty of genuine poet - r y publishers who will give an honest (if ego - detonat - ing ) appraisal of a literary effort before publishing it — or , more likely , refusing to publish it. But then he demonstrates just how dodgy the recruiting meth - ods of some vanity publish - ers are — by playing a jolly jape on them. To every vanity publisher advertising in the national press he sent a collection of 40 poems (he charitably does not name the "poet", who is clearly a good sport). Their style and quality you may judge from the follow - ing haunting lines:
Watch the warm springtime rain, Streaking across the windowpane. Falling gentle to the ground Replenishing plants that abound . As F.R. Leavis probably would not have said, Keats it aint. Just to add a little more spice to the exercise, where a publisher asked for 64 poems to be submitted, Clifford sent 40, and 25 duplicates . Few publishers appeared to notice this. You will have guessed what sort of replies he
received . "Explosively apoc - alyptic language... a great source of inspiration," one publisher gushed. Other typical effusions were "rhyme and cadence are employed to great effect", "the work is strongly imag - ist ", "these poems will sure - ly cause the reader to think and feel deeply about the current state of society" — and so on. Clifford then compared the vanity publishers' prices with those an average print - er would charge if you published your poetry your - self . One vanity publisher, for instance, asked the au - thor for £4,000 for a print - run of 1,000 copies. ' A printer quoted £1,250 for the same work. So who on earth would fall for all this? Unfor - tunately , hundreds of people — judging by the number of prosperous vani -
ty publishers whom Clifford contacted . In fact, aren't the very people who write naive poetry (and naive novels too, for that matter) also likely to enter into naive business transactions? I fear that there may be a correlation. Clifford wants newspa - pers to verify the credentials of publishers before allow - ing their advertisements to be published. This won't happen, of course. Most editors have enough trouble keeping tabs on their jour - nalists ' methods without being held responsible for the ethics of the advertisers too. But Clifford's book (details 0329 822218) should be read by all those thinking of leaping into print at their ownexpenss . Incidentally , he is pub - lishing and distributing it himself . Doni even whisper the word vanity.
RICHARD MORRISON

Author: Gray, Louise
Title: Pulp thriller with poetry
Full_text:
POP: Moody glamour, acute observations about love, sex and angst; and a front man to fall in love with
Pulp thriller with poetry
FOR a band once labelled as the "escape party from One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest", Pulp are doing very nicely, thank you. His'n'Hers , their debut al - bum for a major label, is sirring comfortably in the charts, and moody romantics have elevated Pulp's lead singer, Jarvis Cocker, to the pantheon of rock's sex gods. He has, of course, all the requirements. Cocker is tall and willowy, a dandy who wears an expression of per - manent angst . Acute observa - tions about love, sex, dreamy days and dreary days fill His 'n' Hers. The band play a glammed-up pop, halfway between Morrissey and
Suede. Candida Doyle's sea - side organ accompaniments and Russell Senior's violin provide Pulp's languid, fluid lines while drummer Nick Banks and bassist Steve Mackey give the band a solid, earthy feel.. Unlike most front men, however, Cocker has an un - usual idea of the kind of rapport he wants with Pulp's audience . "One question be - fore we start", he asks before launching into the opening number, "Joyriders ". "Why are you here? To participate or spectate?" There is little
Pulp The Forum, NW5 room in the hall for the audience to express their full participatory intentions, so they jump up and down. Cocker finishes the song with a deep bow. "You see", he begins saying, "we want this to be an event, something that's unique." A thousand begin to jump approvingly. A lone voice shrills out: "Jarvis ! I love you!" With pauses only for Cock -
er 's between-song reflections about sex education and the symptomatology of Ikea shoppers, Pulp's focus is, not unnaturally , on material from His'n'Hers . Cocker's jerky mobility evens out as the set progresses. Songs like "Do You Remember The First Time?" and "Lipgloss " have a finely tuned dramatic impetus, and Senior and Doyle together add a swoony texture . This is the final concert on a short spring tour, and Pulp's gang from Sheffield are all present. The sight of a
journalist's notebook elicits some strange confessions. Gary wants to tell me that it is his Stylophone that Doyle is poking on "She's A Lady". His Stylophone is bigger and better than, say, the one Rolf Harr is once used. The song accentuates what is best about Pulp. Cocker's lyrics are those of a home - grown Jacques Brel and his delivery develops the requi - site passion well. Encores pass by gracefully and Cock - er promises that Pulp will be back , "when the leaves are falling". It is a poetic goodbye that is entirely in keeping with the Pulp spirit.
Louise Gray

Author: Moman, Praveen
Title: Rajas, Raj and poetry
Full_text:
Rajas , Raj and poetry
THESE five books offer per - s o nal views, reflected through different jalis (screens) on different episodes of India's disjointed past. Grandmother's Footsteps (Macmillan, £20) retraces a journey that Penelope Betje - man , wife of the Poet Laure - ate , made through India with her granddaughter, Imogen Lycett-Green . Penelope first went to India in 1928 aged 18 when her father, Field Mar - shal Lord Chetwode, was ap - pointed Commander-in-Chief of the Indian Army. Despite herself, she fell in love with the country, and her association
continued throughout her life. She regularly led tours and expeditions until her death in the lower Himalayas in 1986. The book weaves together snippets about Lady Betje - man 's travels in India, her friends, her involvement in the magical Kulu valley and her disillusionment with "pro - gress " in the rural areas. This produces an affectionate mem - oir by a devoted and loyal granddaughter and does the grand old lady proud. The unceasing eulogy , however , makes the reader yearn for a more rounded study of Lady Betjeman and her involve - men t with India. .
Lord Curzon, the former Viceroy, claimed that the Indi - an subcontinent had "the greatest galaxy of monuments in the world". Today, sadly much of this heritage is in - creasingly threatened as the burgeoning population puts survival and industrialisation above care of old sites. In Great Monuments of India, Bhutan, Nepal, Pakistan and Shri Lanka (Odyssey, £19.95) Shobita Punja presents his - torical , religious and architec - tural information on her favourite sites, from the obvi - ous to the more obscure. The book is written with clarity and enthusiasm, with good photographs and illustrations, but can only be used to visit a fraction of the monuments in the five countries and is not a comprehensive travel-aid . Some of the greatest patrons of art and architecture were the Mughal emperors who ruled for several hundred years. Dara Shukoh (Banyan, £14.95, available from Books from India, 45 Museum Street , London Wl) is a play in English rhyming verse by
Gopal Gandhi, the grandson of Mahatma Gandhi. It encap - sulates the grandeur and the violence of the Mughal dynas - ty in an original , moving and elegant way. Dara Shukoh, eldest son of the 17th-century Moghul emperor Shah Jahan, aesthete, poet and passionate believer in Hindu-Muslim unity, was the heir apparent. Despite these qualities, his brother, Aurengzeb, the un - scrupulous intriguer, cool pol - itician and katthar (diehard) Muslim, outmanoeuvred and killed him. He reasserted Muslim superiority over the majority Hindu population, sharpening religious division which has left its mark today. The richness and depth of the play makes it readable in its own right, bringing to life the struggle between the two brothers, both political and symbolic . Its structure paral - lels John Dryden's play Aurengzeb and the dramatic tension echoes Shakespearean tragedies. On stage it should
take on an even larger life. Aurengzeb's death in 1707 opened the doors to greater British involvement which is the subject of the other three books. After the 1857 Mutiny, effective administration of the country and its 300 million inhabitants was put in the hands of the 1000 officers (or Civilians) of the Indian Civil Service (ICS). They remained in control until Independence in 1947, making them the most powerful body of bureaucrats in the English-speaking world. With Whitehall far removed and individual offi - cers left largely to their own resources by the Viceregal establishment, they became effective arbiters of British administration and justice. "Perhaps they would have been happier if they had never gone out to India, but the Raj also brought out the best in them.:. It turned clerks into pro-consuls , traders into mer - chant princes and daydream - ers into philosopher kings."
Clive Dewey's Anglo - Indi - an Attitudes: the Mind of the Indian Civil Service (Ham - bledon Press, £25) explores the approaches of two middle ranking Civilians who reflect - ed the two faces of British imperialism: "the Gospel of Uplift and the cult of friend - ship ". F.I. Brayne despised In - dian culture and thought individual Indians were sunk in sin. Sir Malcolm Darling was a cultivated humanist, despised his compatriots and thought Indians were sensi - tive and imaginative. He had a life-long friendship with the Maharaja of Dewas Senior, for whom E.M. Forster wor - ked . Despite its dedication, Dewey believes the ICS was not effective because it applied intellectual frameworks learnt in England and absorbed little from lifetimes in the east. This is one of the few serious assessments of the ICS. Al - though weakened by tackling too many disparate themes, it is nevertheless a thought - pro - voking and original work, controversial with former Imperial servants or modern
Indian historians. After Inde - pendence the ICS gave way to the IAS; although more Indian it faces the same fundamental question: should India take on the mores of the Western world, or should it look within to solve its problems? The IAS has still not resolved this dilemma. In Viceregal India, 1916 - 1921 : The Letters of Ralph Verney, Volume 2 (Tabb House , £20) is a fine example of that rather unique but now sadly dying English art form: letter writing. It contains a collection of letters between
Ralph Verney and his family while he was military secre - tary to the then Viceroy, Lord Chelmsford, edited by his son David. Verney records some of the events, major and trivial, that made up his personal life while responsible for running the Viceregal establishment at the . peak of its power. They range from the purchase of a new uniform for £600 to the organisation of Viceregal tours. Surprisingly, the letters provide little analysis of the changing political scene, even of the historically important Montagu-Chelmsford consti - tutional reforms.
Praveen Moman

Author: Null
Title: Poetry of a death
Full_text:
Poetry of a death
\ homosexual brought a burden of troubles, Jeremy Kingston writes. None, though, was heavier than the carefully worded concern of family, priests and the girls who wished to be girlfriends. . As Barnaby, subject of this dramatic memoir, sourly points out, these would-be healers never used " homosex - ual " as a noun, only as an adjective followed by "leanings ", "tendencies" or "proclivities". But anyway, dear, rest assured, it's only a passing phase. This is not how the 21 - year - old Barnaby sees his position. Pippa takes him to Fortnums, Rosamund offers scones in North Oxford, Father X and Father Y bleat their platitudes, but he is whirling between the maelstrom of desires and the rocks of self-disgust . Eventual - ly the rocks claim their victim. The setting is Barnaby's rooms in an Oxford college, persuasively re-created by Jane Wildgoose, and Quentin walks up to the table where books, LPs and folded clothes are spread, and tells us: "These are my memories of Barnaby Downing." Evidently the young man has just died, and exactly who it is who is now remembering him never becomes clear. He is privy to Barnaby's indeci - sions , recalls his passing
IN THE late 1950s, if we can go along with John Quentin's recollection of that time, being
Barnaby Downing New End, NW3
doubts in the moments of their passing because, after that brief intro - duction Quen -
tin becomes his doomed, self - denouncing hero. Barnaby is a poet, as Quen - tin himself was, in Oxford in the late 1950s, and the poems Barnaby speaks are Quentin's own. In fact, this entire 75 - minute work can be seen as a narrative poem, in poetry and prose, allusive, discursive, at times obscure, where the voice of memory, perhaps also the voice of someone in the last microseconds of life, endeav - ours to trace the course and pattern of that life from scat - tered episodes and phrases. Tall, elegant, absent - mindedly tidying the room, Quentin shows his hero's an - guish in physical terms chiefly by ending sentences with a self-despising smile. The cor - ners of his stretched mouth turn down; the smile is ironic; the feelings just expressed are not to be believed. The reliance upon Barn - aby 's point of view leaves significant gaps in his biogra - phy , and he does seem to have been oddly short of male confidants. Was Oxford so unhelpful in 195 S? Quentin himself managed to survive. How much of him exists in this portrait is impossible to say, but he draws a sombre portrait of a talent that failed to resist the call to snuff itself out. The under-played last moment is excellent.

Author: Roberts, Alison
Title: Poets take to the road
Full_text:
Poets take to the road
This year's literary band - wagon belongs to the poets. The Poetry Soci - ety 's New Generation of 20 scribblers hit the road today on a reading tour which takes in many festival venues, constitut - ing a kind of roving festival itself. Poetry, unlike prose fiction, is perfect literary festival material. Literature is, essentially, a soli - tary art form; neither reading nor writing requires an audi - ence . In fact, the activities can be positively hindered by the presence of a crowd. By and large, novelists, no matter how famous, do not pack a hall by reading aloud from their works. Too often those events turn into glorified sign - in g sessions. It is different with poetry. Poetry sounds better when it is read out loud and a lot of it is designed for performance, which means the poet, unlike the novelist, is part showman and can hold the attention of festival-goers . Poems are self - contained things, usually short.
And if the author is there to read his work, he can explain it too. The New Generation tour takes in more than 20 towns and cities in May alone. Simon Armitage, David Dabydeen and Lavinia Greenlaw are at the Brighton Festival on May 10, for example. Michael Donaghy, Michael Hofmann and Kathleen Jamie visit the Hay Festival on May 22 and the Birmingham Readers and Writ - ers Festival is a stop-off for John Burnside, Glyn Maxwell and Sarah Maguire. The other 11 venues range from Aberdeen to Firle, near Lewes. Other poets who will pop up all over the country this sum - mer include Sir Stephen Spend - er . He will be reading from his new volume Dolphins at sev - eral festivals and takes part in an interesting-sounding 1930s evening at the Brighton Festi - val . A troika of talking heads
A reading tour will crisscross the country. Alison Roberts reports
will dissect the great 1930s poets; Jon Stallworthy will talk on Louis MacNeice, Peter Por - ter on W.H. Auden and Sir Stephen, the last living member of that club, will read his own work. Poetry brings a sense of theatre to the literary festival. How else to enliven an event which can seem too worthy for its own good? The Hay Festival of Litera - ture and the Arts will have an undoubted sense of theatre, though, for its celebration of the written and spoken word will number Barry Humphries among a cast which also in - cludes Vikram Seth, Doris Les - sing and Benjamin Zephaniah.
Humprey Carpenter, biogra - pher and presenter of Radio 3's Nightwaves, takes over as direc - tor of this year's Cheltenham Literary Festival. "I was con - fronted with a festival that was running extremely well," he says. "But I decided to take a slightly different approach by giving each day a theme." This structure is designed to encourage creativity by focus - sing thought on a particular subject, not necessarily literary. It also headlines events with more than a reader's name — which is good marketing. So the opening Sunday is designated Booker Prize Day, with prize-winners on hand to talk and read. This is followed.
in chronological order, by Sci - ence Writing Day, Writers and the Mind (timely, with Peter Brooks' adaptation of Oliver Sachs' neurological novel, The Man who Mistook His Wife for a Hat , wowing theatre audi - ences up and down the country). Then Whodunnit Day, "Old Codgers' Day" (that's a working title and in no way reflects the status of writers such as Sir Kingsley Amis, who will appear), History Writing Day and State of the Church Day. The curtain will come down on the final Sunday with a "big drama event — a world pre - miere which is rather unusual" . Mr Carpenter is keeping its exact nature a secret. "I have found that writers are excited at the prospect of talking about something other than them - selves and their work. So this themed day idea is a sort of challenge for them."
Barry Humphries: reading

Author: Spender, Stephen
Title: An art born of humiliation
Full_text:
An art born of humiliation
from Laura Riding's , as though to prove witch - god - desses and their worshippers still exist. Out of this brew there come some remarkable writings by her: poems which are forbidding yet sometimes hypnotic. They are emana - tions of her character and have something of its power. For a time they influenced, in their moonlike way, Auden's early poetry, as in his beautiful poem beginning "This lunar beauty/Has no History/Is complete and early... " Riding seems determined to limit poetry to the expression of ideas wrung out of literal truths of observation of her own thinking. Her poems are never allowed to stray beyond
M ore than any other writer, Laura Rid - ing comes to us packaged with an almost ines - capable personal legend: how in 1929 she leapt out of the fourth floor window of a house in Hammersmith, breaking her spine and nearly killing herself, followed by Robert Graves who, sensibly, ran down two flights of stairs before jumping out of a second floor window to rescue her. How, leaving his then family and her admirers, they went to Majorca to set up house there, she in command and submit - ting Graves and various visit - ing poets to severe criticism of their works and to her domes - tic rule of witch-like terror; and how, in 1939, she went to Florida where she married Schuyler Jackson, a farmer. The legend seems to have acquired a life inseparable
these into any effect that is for the sake of "the poetry", in order to be "poetic". Each poem seems to be both poem and renunciation of poetry. In the end poetry is rejected for the sake of philosophising'in a prose which sometimes be - comes a kind of abstract poetry. Central to all this is a very consciously controlling sensibility, as though Riding were . an emanation of Graves's White goddess. The collection of her prose writings, edited by Elizabeth Friedman and Alan J. Clark, is a serious and considered dis - cussion of what it signifies to be a woman. It relates how self-admiring , posturing man has always tried to rob woman
THE WORD "WOMAN " and other writings By Laura Riding Carcanet, £14.95 A SELECTION OF THE POEMS OF LAURA RIDING Edited by Robert Nye Carcanet, £9.95pbk of her true identity. Instead of seeing her as the reality she is, he sees her as a problem in his own life. Riding draws a thick black line between the sexes. Although she mentions some - where that she is married
reading her book one wonders how she could ever have crossed this line. Although pushed to the point of caricature, her argu - ment is powerful and, I found, often persuasive. It is that Man, the player of roles, invents a role for women — or, rather, for Woman — and refuses to recognise her real nature: "In relating woman to himself man can only consider the uses of woman: and the standing which he assigns to her derives from the impor - tance that he attaches to her uses. He can only consider the uses of woman because he is motivated only by self-interest : his activities have to do only with himself. Woman is moti -
vated by necessity — the necessity to maintain unity. She has no design to use man; he is something that happens." A weakness of the book is that it is all generalisation. True, there is one chapter in which Riding discusses an - swers to a questionnaire she has sent out: but all the questions are addressed to women, there are none to men, and she deals with the an - swers rather briskly. Her ar - gument is weakened by the impression she gives of either patronising or detesting other women. Most of all, she de - tests Virginia Woolf. The male reader feels him - self gradually battered into
assent at all these" assaults. This is largely because, while discussing qualities which are indeed perhaps common to all, or most men, and while quot - ing statements made by indi - viduals , she does not examine in any depth examples of individual men, the qualities shown in their works and achievements: Shakespeare or Jesus Christ, for example. Nevertheless this book does cover very wide areas of history, literature, work and behaviour. It examines the situation of women under what in all fields, including language, man predominates over women — an injustice which is embedded even with - in grammar, our use of words, indeed in words themselves. What is lacking is the slightest trace of any sense of humour. It leaves one longing for a female Voltaire.
Stephen Spender

Author: May, Derwent
Title: Battle of the slim volumes
Full_text:
Battle of the slim volumes
P oetry is selling again, so the publishers say — and this spring two ma - jor publishers are each putting their money where their mouth is by launching a new poetry series in good-looking paperback format. The books on the new Sinclair-Stevenson list cost £6.99 each, and are headed by James Michie's Collected Poems. Michie, now in his mid-sixties , has been publish - ing poems sparingly all his life. He is an epigrammatic rather than a mellifluous poet, but almost every one of these slowly-gathered pieces has a firm kernel of wit or complex feeling. In one typical poem,
he sits on the river-bank fishing, using satire as his fishing-rod — but what he hauls in is "an ancient horrify - ing conger", which is "the long lie of his education". Satire cannot deal with this monster — the fishing-line breaks and the ugly brute goes back into the river, once more free. He also includes some wry, tender love poems, never expecting too much from the girl (or from himself), but always grateful. Anthony Thwaite's The Dust of the World and Alan Brownjohn's In The Cruel Arcade are both collections by poets long practised at writing a shapely verse. Thwaite now -
adays looks mostly for public occasions, like the death of other poets, or for incidents abroad. He often builds up unemphatic details till feeling breaks out in a plangent final line: like the last words of the poet George MacBeth, "How long will I sleep?" Brownjohn is more introspective. " Mov - ing from hope to hope like stepping stones" one of his poems begins, and many of these poems are about uneasy hopes. He, too, commemo - rates MacBeth's recent death — by desperately visiting a young prostitute to assuage his grief. Afterwards, he is sure (or is it too sure?) that MacBeth's photograph smiles understanding^ at him. The youngest of Sinclair - S tevenson 's poets is Marryn Crucefix, whose collection is called On Whistler Moun - tain . As with films nowadays, you do not know what his poems are about till you are some way into them, but that is clearly what he intends. He likes to create an energetic criss-crossing of moods and
words belonging to different people at different times, until a picture gradually emerges, as in the long poem "At The Mountjoy Hotel", about a restless barfly watching a wedding reception on a Satur - day afternoon. There is real if disorderly vitality here, and some sharp, often comic obser - vation in the shorter poems. Also in the Sinclair-Stevenson list: Selected Poems by Jon Silkin and This Time of Year by Ruth Fainlight. The poets in the new Jonathan Cape list are wilder and cost a penny more (the books are £7 each). Peter Redgrove has been com - posing gleeful fantasies for years and his new collection My Father's Trapdoors is in the same unmistakable vein. He imagines a man serving his woman all-black meals (coffee , molasses) in the day - time and all-white meals ("boiled fish and spumanti" ) at night — until she turns the tables by making scarlet curry and "lung-pink cakes". All
quite teasingly sexy and funny — but such fantasy tires rather quickly. Eleanor Cooke's fantasies in Secret Files are about the Virgin Mary. She offers a half - bawdy , half-mystical rewrit - ing of the story of Christ and his mother, which brings in two Marys that have hitherto been mixed up. The bizarre incidents and paradoxical metaphors occasionally stab one into response but more often they seem to leave the sphere of intelligibility. John Burnside in The Myth of the Twin records numerous intuitions of a spiritual world lurking within the everyday —
like "the whisper of the wind on frosted glass" or "the crown of thorns in a woodpigeon's nest". In other poems, the absence of that world becomes even more haunting. The main weakness in the work of all these last three poets is their lack of any compelling rhythm — or in - deed of any attempt to create one . Too many of their poems move like a dog with a paralysed leg — heave, col - lapse , heave, collapse, from one line to the next. Other books in the Cape series: Turner by David Dabydeen and The Handless Maiden by Vicki Feaver.
Derwent May

Author: Truss, Lynne
Title: Poetic licence
Full_text:
Poetic licence
THE scene is a first-night party, in a recent Simon Gray television play. A famous left - wing dramatic genius and master of the significant pause (can't think who this is) conde - scends to chat with a nervous admirer. "I enjoyed your Big - ots Against Poetry," gushes the fan. There is a significant pause, while the playwright draws a warning breath and his eyes go yellow like a dog's. Unhappily for the victim — whose sudden, flailing, verbal laceration recalls Janet Leigh's unpleasant surprise in Psycho — the book was entitled Poets Against Bigotry. This mix-up comes to mind because, while Ted Wallace, the coruscating minor-poet narrator of Stephen Fry's sec - ond comic novel The Hi ppo - p otamus , slides comfortably into that revolting World of Leather of sexist old snobs and whisky-drenched cantanker - ous bullies who constitute the older generation of our Eng - lish belle-lettrists , it is some - times hard to work out where he stands on this important bigotry-poetry thing, mainly because he is a vain nasty poet
THE HIPPOPOTAMUS By Stephen Fry Hutchinson, £14.99 bigot who is proud to oppose virtually anything. Gloriously rude, Wallace is devoted to shit-and-bum ex - pletives (" stuff my arse with figs" ), and holds decanter - rattling opinions on every - thing from the refurbishments at Liverpool Street station to the abomination of the mod - ern strawberry. On the sexual front, he ogles women whose "breasts stand up like begging dogs"; on the stylistic, he is committed to the resuscitation and vigorous exercise of underused English words such as "gibbous", "beazel " and "footling" . Memorably, he describes his body in motion as resembling "a bin - liner full of yoghurt". Proceeding by means of first and third-person narration,
Lynne Truss encounters the vicious, opinionated, poet-bigot narrator of Stephen Fry's new novel
letters and diaries, the plot is pretty slim, but the tireless inventiveness of the writing more than compensates. Wal - lace meets his god-daughter at a Soho club called Harpo's (cant think what this is). She asks him to cadge an invita - tion to Swafford, the Suffolk country home of her rich uncle, where something mys - terious is going on, concerning miraculous recoveries, resur - rections and a teenage boy. Wallace is enticed by the large sum of money she offers, and agrees. "A quarter of a mil - lion ?" he repeats. "This isn't lire, is it?" At Swafford, we notably meet David, the precocious testosterone-crazed teenager (fotherington-tomas crossed with the boy in Equus), Da - vid 's prosaic older brother Simon (for whom poetry was "a closed book in a locked cupboard in a high attic in a
lonely house in a remote hamlet in a distant land" ), and a few other grown-ups , whose main narrative function is to react to Wallace and be foils for his excellent jokes. In the end, Wallace solves the mys - tery by revealing that it is not a mystery at all. How his bigot - ry or poetry helps him to this opinion is unfortunately unclear. As a crafter of aphorisms, Fry improves on The Liar's Wildean fireworks, finding slightly deeper, more cynical truths. Wallace observes that his god-daughter is not so pretty in the taxi — "but then no one ever is, which is why it's always worth having shares in whisky and cosmet - ics ". Aside from a tiresome gay house-guest at Swafford, who refers laboriously to Tessa Tedium, Hetty the Hosepipe Ban and Clara Cloud, the jokes are all bang on. "David thought my poem 'Lines on the Face of W. H. Auden' was contrived," re - ports Wallace wearily. "Which I told him was like complain - ing that 101 Dalmatians had a lot of dogs in it."
The inventiveness of Stephen Fry's writing in The Hippopotamus compensates for the rather thin plotting

Author: Roberts, Alison
Title: Poetry back in motion
Full_text:
Poetry back in motion
Britain's poets are swarming out of their ghetto, loud and proud
The eruption of poetry — on the radio , in the newspapers, in local pubs — points to an important cultural shift: poetry is coming out of its ghetto. Publishers have begun to take poetry seriously again. For the first time in 20 years, for example, a major publish - i n g house is launching a new poetry list. Cape has signed David Dabydeen , Viki Feaver and John Burnside — all of whom will bring out new, very different , collections in April. Just as significant is the news from Penguin, which publishes volumes by Frank O'Hara and John Ashbury at the end of the month. Its Modern Poets list is being resurrected after a 20-year lapse. The 150-page books, containing selected work'by three poets, brought us the Beat and Liverpool poets, but the list stopped when those scenes petered out. We can expect the first three new volumes , two of them headed by James Fenton and Carol
Ann Duffy, next spring. The phenomenon is not merely London-based : a com - prehensive anthology of Scot - tish poetry comes out in April from Edinburgh University Press , coinciding with a new collection of young Scots work, Dream State (Polygbn). The sixth edition of Francis Turner Palgrave 's Golden Treasury (Oxford University Press) is out in July, and includes verse by established contemporary names — Seamus Heaney and Tony Harrison , for example. Then there are 20 young poets, the Poetry Society 's "New Genera - tion ", touring the country like rock stars. "The work is various, origi - nal , energetic and not homoge - neous . There is much greater freedom and excitement," says Robin Robertson, senior editor at Cape. "This is the point where we should take a snap - shot of poetry ." Robert Crawford, one of the New Generation poets and poetry editor at Polygon in Edinburgh , thinks that poetry
has been energised by a differ - e n t kind of readership and writership, whose roots lie in a "postwar extension of the edu - cational franchise". "The 1930s scene existed around Oxbridge and London, and that set a pattern for various groupings around the country later. Now there are so many different kinds of poetry — much of it very good. "We are living in a time when ideas of plurality are fashionable — that allows poets, who deal in different languages, to be more com - fortable and experimental." Feminist poetry, black poet - r y and Liverpool poetry once existed in separate boxes. Mix - and - match is now the word. P oetry is also speaking more directly about peo - ple 's lives, according to the new director of the Poetry Society, Chris Mead. Again, this reflects poetry's broader base.
"People are hungry for something which articulates their feelings about the world around them and their place in it. I think the New Genera - tion of poets are satisfying that need," he says. Ultimately , Mead wants po - etry to be part of the national popular literary scene. He wants poetry to be just as important to our perception of culture as the novel. Many readers buy the Booker novel because they feel they ought to, but how many go out of their way to find , say, the Forward Poetry Prize winner? At present, statistics from Book Marketing show that poetry 'constituency is still very small. Although James Fenton has sold more than 6,000 copies of his most recent volume, published in Septem - ber , many of the top 20 poets are lucky to sell a couple of thousand. The poets reckon that per - ception of a cultural shift takes some time to filter through. When it does, they are pre - pa red for the deluge. .
Alison Roberts

Author: Finch, Hilary
Title: Too little pity in the poetry
Full_text:
LONDON CONCERTS
Too little pity in the poetry
Kiri and Carreras may fill the Albert Hall, but the audi - ence for a War Requiem tends to be small and som - bre — an assembly of the devoted, eager to accept a Peace Pledge Union hand - bill or two on the way in. Any performance of Britten's masterwork, writ - ten for the restored Coven - try Cathedral 20 years after the war which had devastat - ed it, is always aware of the abiding sense of occasion and the expectations the work still sets up. Stephen Cleobury's , on Sunday, marking the 150th anniver - sary of the Cambridge University Musical Society (whose orchestra and chorus were joined by the
Bach Choir and the choris - ters of Ely Cathedral), was no exception . Every second was meticu - lously planned: the placing of the boys, invisibly, in a high, side gallery; the posi - tioning of the soprano solo - ist in the organ loft; the calculation of the precise length of every resonating choral consonant; the bal - ance of every shifting or - chestral texture. With the soloists, too, nothing was left to chance. Deborah Riedel sang true and clear, Michael George's baritone was as dark and steady as the "long black arm" of the great gun cursed by Wilfred Owen's words and Britten's setting of them. Martyn Hill's
CUMS/Cleobury
Albert Hall faultless control and minute shaping of "One ever hangs where shelled roads part" epitomised the beauty of vocal placing and enuncia - tion in his performance. All this care and intelli - gence , though, rarely led the listener beyond the remark - ing of it. The score is prefaced by Owen's own words on "War , and pity of War". They have, perhaps, been quoted once too often; but "The poetry is in the pity" and any performance which fails to re-create in the listener more than a cerebral acknowledgement of this pity and this terror
has fallen short. This performance was strongest on the cold anger and irony which patters and stutters out of the mock militarism of so much of Britten's writing. But when it came to the subtle modu - lation of tone of voice at "each slow dusk" , when it came to the engagement of the very core of the singer with the despair within Owen's repeated questions, and when suppliance and a sense of time and silence were also needed, this per - formance lost its nerve. Nothing less than "titanic tears" are required from this music, these words.
Hilary Finch

Author: Spender, Stephen
Title: Exploding like poets
Full_text:
Stephen Spender praises a survey of modern poetry but sees its attempt to debunk T.S. Eliot as a symptom of political correctness
Exploding like poets
Christopher Benfey re - marks : "His imagina - tive life seems, in retrospect, a ventrilo - quist 's search for an appropriate dummy"; and Martin Seymour - Smith , writing about Gregory Corso, c om - ments drily: "Corso , less noticed in recent years, still writes, and has managed to hang on to his hard-won immatu - rity (or, in original Beat terms, innocence)" . A volume of this kind has (and should have, if
THE OXFORD COMPANION TO TWENTIETH CENTURY POETRY IN ENGLISH Edited by Ian Hamilton OUP, £25 rial about each poet while describing the nature and character of the poetry; and that they perhaps indicate the degree of the poet's importance within some con - cept of modern poetry. Criticism may be damning, but only in cases where some reputation is completely bogus (as with Ella Wheeler Wilcox). This book is not an arena for carrying on feuds between poets, and there are limits here to the outspoken: though fun is provided by some critics slipping in some snide remarks about their colleagues, especially the Americans. Thus in a thoughtful appraisal of John Berryman,
In this collection of assessments of 20th-century poets writing in Eng - lish Ian Hamilton, the editor, suc - ceeds , on the whole triumphantly, in his declared aim of providing a map of modern poetry in English. He qualifies this by adding: "I want it to be seen as serious and useful, but I will not mind if it is read for fun, as a kind of documentary entertainment." The book is produced in the style of earlier Oxford Companions to various literatures. The great difference is that the style and manner of previous volumes — despite acknowledgement to various "con - tributors " — is anonymous, whereas the contributions by various authors to the present volume are initialled, and the names corresponding to the initials easily discoverable from an introductory "key ". Inevitably most of the contributions are short paragraphs rather than essays. But there are many longer ones, some of them running to three or four double-column pages. The sum of these essays adds up to an anthology of informed current critical opinion about modern poetry. This is as revealing of 20th-century poetics as much of the poetry discussed. Hamilton keeps his contributors on a loose rein, but all respond to certain editorial obligations laid on them: that they provide essential biographical mate -
