it is to be alive) certain characteristics of a manifesto: something of which Hamilton is aware when in his introduction he relates "English" to "American" poetry, referring to arguments of A. Alvarez in his anthology The New Poetry and Helen Vendler's introduction to her anthology Modern American Verse. Considered as a
manifesto, this Oxford Companion makes Au - den the most important poet of the 20th century, an eminence established by his five pages, as against three and a half each to Eliot and to Yeats, three each to Rob - ert Frost, Elizabeth Bishop and Robert Low - ell , two and a half to PhiKp Larkin, two each to Ezra Pound and Wil - liam Carlos Williams. The essay on Auden by Nicholas Jenkins is perhaps the most bril -
liantly informative in a collection which contains many excellent essays: among others, Seamus Heaney on Robert Lowell, Carel Rumens on Wallace Stevens, Wil - liam Pritchard on Robert Frost, Blake Morrison on Philip Larkin, John Haffenden on William Empson, Amit Chaudhuri on D.H. Lawrence — to
mention only a few which particularly struck me. This volume serves a very good purpose in bringing poets like Dom Moraes from India, Chinua Achebe, Wole Soyinka from Nigeria, and other writers in English scattered through the world into the community of modern English poetry. I suppose a book of this kind is bound to have a few let-downs . But the essay here on T.S. Eliot by Hugh Haughton seems worse than a let-down , a gigantic blot. It is written throughout in the kind of encyclo - pedese packaged gobbledegook which other writers here so successfully avoid. Haughton awards The Waste Land the following summation: "With its hallu - cinatory iconography of post-war London and stammering vision of psychic disinte - gration , it is one of the inescapable landmarks of 20th-century poetry. Much of Eliot's later career can be understood as an attempt to escape its consequences." Eliot is treated throughout as a cunning manipulator of his own reputation. "His Collected Poems" we are told, "embodies
one of the most complete and cunningly contrived oeuvres in 20th-century litera - ture ." And in conclusion: "Eliot 's reaction - ary politics, religious orthodoxy, cultural elitism, and mandarin temperament have done much to render his work suspect to later readers on both sides of the Atlantic." The phrase "cultural elitist" here seems to give the game away. At this point Political Correctness seems to have sneaked into this volume. The Liverpool poets are put down here, by Martin Seymour-Smith . Given the vociferous "poetry revival" which provides back - ground music as I write these lines, an anthology of 20th-century poetry edited in the year 2000 will look very different from the present one. But probably it is in the Nineties that a century looks back on its own ripeness. This volume traces the modernism of Pound and Eliot, rooted in what they regarded as the tradition, the re-creation in old age of his individualistic Irish self by Yeats, and the exploitation of these by Auden who, with his irrepress - ible spontaneity, refused to be restrained by the pedantries of modernism.
Sir Stephen Spender's collection of new poems, Dolphins, will be published later this month by Faber.
Auden : a sovereign touch

Author: Welch, Colin
Title: A better man than us
Full_text:
A better man than us
M ost of us old fogies have loved Kipling's poetry (or verse, as he modestly preferred to call it) all our lives. We are comfort - able with it, finding in it few problems, little to question and explain. We are thus baffled by what each new generation appar - ently has to do to rediscover and justify him, to render him acceptable and find him good or great. With some apprehen - sion we see young intellectuals and critics, dons and poets rushing forward to defend him against attacks we never launched or perhaps even noticed; to acquit him of holding obnoxious views which we dont find obnoxious at all; to exonerate him from crimes which we thought no crimes or of which we deemed him innocent anyway; to make Kipling's military moustache and stiff collar (see book jacket ) dear to all those with torn jeans and wild beards. Some of Kipling's new de - fenders seem indeed upon acquaintance most congenial.
Kipling needs no apology or plea of mitigation from later generations, says Colin Welch
Peter Keating for instance (no beard) is, with slight reserva - tions , most welcome. Few indeed can be those Kipling buffs who derive no profit, no new insights from his careful and balanced study of the poetry, enthusiastic, imaginative and sensible as it is. For instance, Kipling is of - ten damned for writing too much public poetry instead of the introspective murmurings now widely favoured. Keating deals crisply with this. He points out that much of Kip - ling 's innermost thought and feeling was about public af - fairs , that his prophetic public warnings (many uncannily ac - curate ) and sombre admoni - tions come right from the heart. Orwell, I think it was, described him as the most "responsible" of our poets. His heavy sense of public responsi - bility was not just a check, a brake on his genius, but its vital inspiration.
E minent indeed have been some of Kipling 's unexpected champions. T.S. Eliot felt impelled on ev - ery opportunity to testify for Kipling. Nobly he did so in his 1941 introduction to his Choice of Kipling's Verse. This sensa - tional publishing event in itself cast doubt on Kipling's neglect by and estrangement from the literary establish - ment , though he hated some of its members and many of them hated him. No compara - ble writers came in 1936, alas, to see him interred in Poet's Corner. Auden too, denounced by Orwell as a sort of gutless The review of Gemma Hussey's Ireland Today (Jan - uary 13) stated wrongly that contraception is available only on prescription there.
Kipling, nonetheless turned out in safe New York in 1943 to praise Kipling's verse and Eliot's Choice. Earlier Auden, quoted by Keating, had said "You were silly like us: Your gift survived it all." Auden was actually addressing Yeats at that point but, according to Keating, addressing himself and Kipling too. Time, Auden continued, has "pardoned Kip - ling and his views". This unctuous absolution Kipling could perhaps have done with - out . His views were to him important and right. He can - not have thought them as silly as some of Auden's, nor in need of any pardon from time, Auden or anyone else. Incidentally, such critical praise as Kipling has got does concentrate disproportionate - ly on his late, "difficult" and "modern" stories. Critics un - derstandably favour work which is complex , ambiguous and in need of an explanatory gloss. Like roughage, It gives them something to chew on, a role and purpose; hence to - day 's much admired obscurity.
K eating is generally and admirably elucidatory about Kipling. Just occasionally he slips, like Au - den , into officious pardons, otiose apologies and pleas of mitigation for what are not obviously crimes, lapses or "sillinesses". For instance, Keating picks out "The White Man's Bur - den " as "what would come to be regarded as Kipling's most infamous poem". Does Keat - ing himself regard it as " infa - mous " ? He does not say so, but does, not explicitly disagree either,Admittedly, if he did, he might be .challenged to name at'leasf one poem even more "infamous ", which might ex - pose him to other charges of squeamish over - censorious - ness . But he does not. "There can be no doubt", Keating goes on, "that the poem is profoundly racist in sentiment". No doubt? The poem is imperialist no doubt, but racist? We should always remember about Kipling, what Keating elsewhere honourably emphasises, that "The White Man" he
addressed and honoured is not just a man who is white. Boers and Germans might be white in colour, but were not white within the moral meaning of Kip - ling 's Act. They did not in his view stand for that freedom and equal justice that he regarded as essential, were not thus in consequence fit to carry the White Man's Burden. They were "lesser breeds without the Law". This "Law " they had rejected, thus putting themselves below the coloured "lesser breeds" who had never known it. The Boer in particu - lar treated the "kaffir" too badly to be a White Man in Kipling's moral sense. If the The White Man's
Burden were in fact " pro - foundly racist", it could not but bring racism into good repute. The White Man is adjured selflessly to serve his captives' needs, to be patient, to suppress his own pride, to "fill full the mouth of Famine and bid the sickness cease". KIPLING The Poet By Peter Keating Seeker & Warburg, £25 What is wrong or "infamous " about this? The White Man brought some peace and pros - perity to Africa. He is gone, or going. Charity workers try nobly, if in vain, to replace him, to alleviate the ensuing chaos. Are they too all "pro - found ly racist" ? About other allegedly racist outbursts of Kipling's Keating is admirably calm and just. He reminds us that the ballad which begins "Oh , East is East and West is West" continues with a resounding assertion that "when two strong men
stand face to face", matters of race, religion, birth and social status are irrelevant. Keating is uneasy about "the two strong men" — a concept open to further objections, "but racism is not one of them". Might not Keating have been wiser to admit at once that Kipling was indeed a racist, as now defined, if of a benign sort? So were most of his contemporaries who had shared his experi - ence and insights, as are perhaps all now who can tell the difference between 1 one race and another. Hit - ler 's racism fathered gas chambers. Kipling's by con - trast fathered a lofty and dutiful paternalism. Certainly Kipling's racism could justify to him no crime or "necessary killing" — Auden's chilling and irresponsible phrase. Wis - er not to deny Kipling's racism but rather to study it impar - tially , sine ira. Two questions arise at once: was Kipling foolish or evil to be a racist? In Kipling's racism what is wise and good? Other potential infamies arise from Kipling's supposed
misogyny and his slipping easily in correspondence "into the casual language of anti - Semitism ". With these Keating deals fairly and briefly. Kipling's misogyny was common enough in the British India of his day, where the arrival of the memsahib had disastrous social consequen - ces . Her racism was perhaps not as benign as his own. The Jews he suspected of being in league first with the Kaiser, then with the Bolshe - viks : too many were, for reasons which non-Jews famil - iar with imperial Russian history ruefully understand. Rightly or wrongly, Jews of Kipling's day regarded both the Kaiser and the Bolsheviks as preferable to the Tsars — none of them perhaps White Men to Kipling. Kipling's "racist" hatred of Germany together with Hit - ler 's persecution of the Jews (if Kipling knew much of it, he died in January 1936) should have cleared his mind. Inci - dentally , he quickly de - nounced the Protocols of the Elders of Zion as "clearly fakes". A good start?
Kipling: it is wiser not to deny his racial prejudices but to study them impartially

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: In a minor key
Full_text:
In a minor key
ELAINE Feinstein's translations of Marina Tsvetaeva are justly famous. First published 22 years ago, they have established Tsvetaeva (1892-1941 ) in the minds of English-speaking readers as one of the great Russian poets of the 20th century. Robert Frost once said that poetry is what gets lost in translation, but here is the exception which proves the rule. Tsvetaeva's Selected Poems, in the Feinstein versions, have now made it to the ranks of the Oxford Poets, and the result is a book which can be read with pleasure as English verse (OUP, £9.99 pbk). Over the years the transla - tor has added to her original selection, and there are ten new lyrics in the present volume, as well as an updated introduction and notes. Tsvetaeva emerges from these pages as a nail-biting poet whose spirit dressed itself in images of curious sensuality — curious because it seems to be a sensuality that wants to deny the body, extolling the handclasp without hands and the kiss without lips. At all points I was reminded of a marvellous sen - tence which I came across in a letter she wrote to Ril -
ke : "I do not live in my lips, and he who kisses me misses me." That is the heart of Marina Tsvetaeva, and Fein - stein (who has also written her biography ) comes close to it. Tsvetaeva killed her - self . Federico Garcia Lorca , Spain's greatest
modern poet, was mur - dered by Nationalist partisans in 1936, shortly after the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War. But all should know that I have not died... Lorca's own words have proved splendidly true, and his fame has spread like wildfire from that day. Yet in the confu - sion of the Civil War the manu - script of his last poems, his tormented "Sonnets of Dark Love", disappeared from sight, and for 50 years the poems lived only in the memory of those who had heard him read them aloud. Recently rediscovered, these son - nets have now been published in Spain, and Merryn Williams is the first to translate them into English in her Federico Garda Lorca: Selected Poems (Blood - axe Books, £7.95). Brooding and
magnificent, they show that Lor - ca was struck down in his prime. This book draws on the com - plete range of Lorca's verse, from the early gypsy ballads to the alienated "Poet in New York" sequence. These are poems of blood and moon and knives and snow, the heart-breaking songs of a wounded nightingale. Lorca was never quite the artless singer he pretended to be, but the best of his work has the drive and the dance of folk-poetry . The duende, he called it, that mysterious power in flamenco which sweeps performers and then audiences off their feet. Williams throws in a transla - tion of the full text of Lorca's lecture on the duende, for good measure. It is an important addition, and indicative of the understanding which she brings
r-stmmWk to him. "I have stuck fairly closely to Lorca's meaning," she de - clares , "while trying to produce poems which are acceptable in their own right." At her finest, as in the version of the "Lament for Ignacio Sanchez Mejias", Lorca's elegy for his bullfighter friend, Williams seems to me as musical a translator of this material as Roy Campbell, and without doubt more accurate. Tsvetaeva and Lorca lived in backward times before poets were punished for their poems by the award of giant cash prizes. The contributors to The Forward Book of Poetry 1994 (Sinclair - Stevenson , £5.95 pbk) have not been so lucky. Here are the winning entries to the Forward Poetry Prizes, 90-odd poems judged to be "the best of new contemporary poetry" by Cres - sida Connolly, Douglas Dunn, Liz Lochhead, Blake Morrison and Margaret Drabble. Top prizes go to Carol Ann Duffy (best collection); Don Patersqn (best first collection); and Vicki Feaver
(smgle poem). I could not be so cruel as to say that these poets de - serve it. Carol Ann Duffy, in particular, seems an authentic poet, writing out of concerns that have nothing to do with the winning of prizes, and Don Paterson's Nil ND (Faber, £5.99 pbk) is at the least an interesting
first book, full of things which suggest its author could be any - thing . The trouble, of course, is that the limelight is not the best place for anyone's anything to develop into their own special something. It will be said that poets have to survive somehow in a world where poetry does not pay. This is true, but the point is that a new peril enters the picture precisely when poetry does pay. Besides, some poets have solved the sur - vival problem by writing prose as it were with their other hand, something that can be done without any undue loss of poetic virtue . Alan Sillitoe is well-known as a novelist and story-writer ; his Collected Poems (HarperCollins,
£14.99) is a decent assemblage of more man 30 years' work. Sillitoe says in his preface that "a poet who presents his collected poems displays the emotional history of <. his heart and soul", contrasting this with the activity of a novelist i "who may hide behind his fiction for the whole of his writing life". It is an interesting distinction, and a revealing one in theory, but I think in practice that Sillitoe has put more of his heart and soul into his stories than into his verse, simply because those stories have come to him more naturally, or read that way. The best of his poems, though, puzzle out per^ sonal meaning from passionate feelings which he seeks to make intelligible to others, and that is always welcome.
Robert Nye
Tsvetaeva

Author: Johnson, Daniel
Title: Poems by the glass
Full_text:
Harry Fainlight, Rilke, women poets and a verse review of the new Fenton
iythe glass
Rilke has a superb image somewhere of the poet being "a ringing glass that shat - ters as it rings". I always think of that when I think of Harry Fairilight. Found dead of bronchial pneumonia outside the remote Welsh cottage where he had made a home for himself alone . The 47 years of Fainlight's life must have looked like total failure to most who met him during the course of it. Frail, fervent, dedicated to poetry in a way that put most of his contemporaries to shame, I must say that he struck me differently. I did not know him well but I admired his work and once tried to get a volume of it into print. This venture ended in disaster with Fainlight threatening to shoot the publisher if he went ahead. Being unpublished was of some impor - tance to him. One of his lyrics
begins "Sing on, unpublished one, O unpolluted throat." He died 11 years ago, and despite subsequent praise from Ted Hughes and Allen Ginsberg is still not as well known as he deserves. Perhaps Journeys (Turret Books, £12) will do the trick. This is a tall, elegant , slim volume , 17 fine poems beautifully printed, with a frontis - p iece by Mary Moore and an introduction by Sir Stephen Spend - er which ends with the words, "Harry Fainlight and his poetry should be famous". Of course, what is really needed to achieve that is a fat collected edition, from one of the big publishing houses. But then nothing about Fainlight was ever fat. His work seems fragmentary almost by definition, since percep - tions of this intensity cannot be long drawn out:
O pavement comfortable to sink down onto as God, why could not I sink? Some - thing stupider even than the weight of my own body still holding me up, impossible to be broken. He is talking about his own poetic vocation, which the world did fail to break. Ringing glasses, as Rilke knew, are shattered by a purer music altogether. You can catch unmistakable sounds of that music in the work of Harry Fairilight, and while it is still ringing in a book published in an edition, limited to 500 copies you can at least regard it as your own discovery. The ringing glass that was Rilke himself can be heard in M.D. Herter Norton's new paperback Translations From The Poetry Of Rainer Maria Rilke and the same author's version of Letters to a Young Poet (Norton, £6.95 each). Norton's translations of the poems are admirably literal, and they manage to suggest the feel of Rilke's thought, the winding verse - sentences , the way his poems move in a logic that is quite other than the
logic of prose. The German is printed on the opposite page to each translation, and the selection is fully representative of Rilke's work up to the long period of silence that fell after publication of the Marienleben in 1913. As for the Letters , they still read with remarkable freshness, and I cannot think of a better book to put into the hands of any young would - be poet, as an inspirational guide to poetry and to surviving as a poet in a hostile world. The English poet Edward Lowbury will have survived for 80 years next month, and it is good to see his life's work honoured with both a Collected Poems (Hippo - potamus Press, £14.95) and a festschrift in celebration of his achievement called Physic Meet and Metaphysic, edited by Yann Lovelock (Hippopotamus Press, £12.95). Lowbury has had a long and distinguished career as a microbi - ologist as well as a poet. His verse is invariably well-made , lucid, and modest in scope, but at his best, as in "The Collector", he manages to turn these Georgian virtues into
. Have you met the great James Fentor f? You certainly must do soon: His latest volume of verse is out , And it's rarer than snow in June. A Fenton poem may console Or it may be raucous and gay; Whatever it is, you know it's his, And tie doesn't care what men say. He knows his rhyme and metre, And his middle name's prosody; But you won't find one emotion faked For the sake of his melody. True, Fentb:n'saai Oxford poet;- = .. : And he knowsjJVIeEwaivand Raine, And Fuile;&todn $t they all know He walks his own dark lane. Maybe it's because he's a journalist That I like Fenton's verse: His songs are sung in words that most Sun headline subs would think too terse.
Are his ballads better than Brecht's? You bet: No favours for Statins from his pen: "And you cant tell/When they'll come again/ They'll come again/to Tiananmen." Though politics is his guiding star, Love is his destination, And the lines that linger in the night Lead us into his temptation. His poems fit the bitter facts !, ; Of love's requital hand in glove: "Learn as leaves must learn to fall/ Out of danger, out of love.Greater poets may be now at work?-: In Mandarin or Greek; .... .. ^ But Fenton is the best I know % :.. * -, -. . In the language that we speak.

something more interesting than anything the actual Georgians wrote. That poem finds a metaphor for his view of life inflowers , telling how as a boy he wanted to pick every bluebell in the wood, learning later the advantage of only picking one flower of every kind, and thence to confining himself purely to the names of flowers. The last stanza is irreproachable: A lifetime brought this new . collector 's itch: In a world of flowers, names, necessities — To see how many I could do without:
And at last the distant shout "Come home" finds me exult - ing in a wealth Of unpossessions — all of it, perhaps, A practice-run for doing with - out myself Lowbury's is a quiet voice, but it might still be heard when many noisier ones have been forgotten. It is the quiet voices that sound clearest in Sixty Woman Poets, Linda France's fascinating anthology of the work of 20th - century British and Irish female poets since 1971 (Bloodaxe, £8.95 pbk original). The older generation, re present - ed by Ruth Pitter and E.J. Scovell, makes its presence felt tellingly, as
do some of the younger ones such as. Carol Ann Duffy and Medbh McGuckian. The book's star, though, is Jenny Joseph, born in 1932. Her lyrical-satirical medita - tions , not well-served by short quotation, best encapsulate that wild quality, "the sense of a creature constrained too long", which France suggests as charac - teristic of the book as a whole. There are more (and more interest - ing ) women poets now active than at any previous period in literary history, and this book testifies eloquently to that fact. - In Book of Matches (Faber, £5.99 pbk original), Simon Armitage is the poet as the Boy Next Door, writing plain sturdy stuff about his own life, as com - pared with the lives of others: At twenty-eight I'm not doing great , but considering I came from the River Colne and its long, lifeless mud, I'm doing good.
Elsewhere, in the sequence about his marriage called "Reading the Banns," there is a better sense of real blood flowing through the veins of memory, but this lad has a long. way to go before anyone mistakes him for a ringing glass. Robert Nye

Author: Millington, Barry
Title: No chance of the poetry prize
Full_text:
No chance of the poetry prize
THE Brazilian Ricardo Castro may have been the jury's choice as winner of the 1993 > Harvey's Leeds International j Piano Competition, but his j victory was not universally approved . His appearance; with the BBC Symphony Or - chestra at the Barbican on Saturday night was therefore a chance for Castro to vindi - ca te himself — and the Leeds jury — with a performance that would erase the memory of his anonymous Beethoven in the competition. A cynic might claim that the choice of Rachmaninov's Piano Concerto No 2 in C minor was more an attempt to curry favour with a broad j constituency than an attempt j to win over the cognoscenti. It i might have done both, of; course, for the need to make a i
BBCSO/Olmi Barbican personal statement with a warhorse like this is greater than ever. Sadly, it was not a reading to set the imagination alight : though thoroughly competent, and far from un - feeling ; there were few hints of the poetic fantasy of a master. Castro did not, at least, crash about the keyboard in the manner favoured by many young players. He is often at his best in light scherzando passagework, where his p lay - ing has a crystalline clarity and attractively sweet tone quality. Not only does he get his fingers impressively round the notes at such moments, but he manages to shape them
into the kind of phrases that reveal them to be more than mere bravura. One or two phrases in the Adagio were also turned in a way that promised something special, but it never material - ised . Neither Castro nor. his young accompanist, the up - and - coming Italian conductor Paolo Olmi, was inclined to wallow in the concerto's ex - travagant sentiments, and it was not until the Big Tune in the finale that Castro really drew on expressive rubato to stamp some individuality on the performance. There may be a poet strug - g ling to get out of this prize - winner . But the discerning jury is still out on that one.
Barry MlLLINGTON

Author: kingston, Jeremy
Title: Passable poetry, dubious drama
Full_text:
THEATRE: Jeremy Kingston finds good reason why a play by Shelley is rarely revived
Passable poetry, dubious drama JL•/ DONALDCOOI
TheCenci Lyric Studio, Hammersmith SHELLEY'S tragedy declares i :s anti - authoritarian stance from the opening line, in which a cardinal tells the wicked Count Cend, "That matter of the murder is hushed up." This will not be a play where the poor and dispossessed will find their I cause espoused by the great. Quite the reverse.. | Pope Clement is content that Cenci should go on sinning so that ihe can demand chunks of the sinner's land as marks of contrition. Later, he opposes Cenci's enemies because they are members of a younger generation — in fact, the Count's children — and the primacy of the father must be maintained. The play received no public perfor - mance in England until Sybil Thorn - dike played Beatrice, the Count's valiant daughter, in a production to mark the centenary of Shelley's death.
Now, to mark the bicentenary of his birth, Louise Bangay and Sydnee Blake have formed Damned Poets Theatre Company in order to mount this production. There have been others in between these two, but not many . "Pure poetry but poor drama," is what the Oxford Companion to the Theatre thinks of the work, and whatever "pure poetry" means, it certainly does not sound the right material for creating living flesh. The language is blank verse, might - ily influenced by Shakespearean trage - dy , and Shelley manages to make it move the story along, though he loses his way whenever the characters debate with themselves the ethics of killing a bad father. Just because the Count is laying hands upon his daughter, does this permit parricide? Presumably the Count is doing murki - er deeds to her, though she cannot bring herself to name them. "There are deeds that have no form," she hints darkly, and incorrectly. Pure or not, the poetry is undistin -
guished , though if the play happened to be better known, I dare say lines would be quoted for the pregnancy of their simple phrasing. "I have met with much injustice in the world," is one such , though Bangay, playing Bea - trice , makes nothing of it. The best lines in the entire evening come right at the end, "Here , Mother, tie / My girdle for me, and bind up this hair / In any simple knot; Ay, that does well." The language is exquisitely ordinary, and the "any" is perfection. This cannot be said of Blake's production. Shelley leaves characters
hanging around with nothing to say but Blake gives them nothing interest - ing to do. Setting the play in the 1930s brings no advantage, though it allows Craig Pinder's Count to look like two of the great egotists of the period, Musso - lini and Charles Foster Kane. His lips curl, he all but licks them with his flickering tongue. Relishing his villainy, Pinder grins and snarls, where a more interesting reading might have come from playing against obvious relish; but he is not dull. Sadly, Bangay often is. Drooping shoulders do not make heroines, nor
do arms that are kept dangling . Recordings of Dame Sybil playing Saint Joan make one thankful not to have seen her performance, but that tremulous voice as Beatrice would have suggested that she felt, however quaintly, what she was saying. I did not find that Bangay did suggest this, and the s'elf-righteous hauteur in court and prison requires every fibre of an actress's vocal chords to keep us on her side. I began wishing the Count would come back as a malicious ghost , and this is not the reaction Shelley intended.
Craig Pinder (centre) as the Count, who relishes his villainy almost to the point of parody, but is never dull

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: A sprig of British bays in a prosaic age
Full_text:
A sprig of British bays in a prosaic age
V erse is for healthy arty farties. The dying and surgeons use prose. Never mind surgeons, but some - one should tell Peter Reading about Rilke's own epitaph for himself, fine lines written right at the end of a long wasting illness, endured without pain-kilters . Read - ing 's street-wise anti-poetics can be taken as typical of the spirit and tone and taste of much of the work collected in The New Poetry. Ambitiously appropriating a de - finitive title made famous by Alva rez some 30 years ago, here is an anthology which sets out to repre - sent that bright generation of poets which came to maturity in the Eighties , and which still flourishes, more or less. Fifty-five writers are included, English, Scottish, Welsh and Irish, along with others who are British citizens though born elsewhere. The result is a volume which its editors announce in their introduction to be "fresh" in its attitudes, risk-taking in ite address, and plural in its forms and voices. The editors claim too much. Ranging from the 52-year-old Pauline Stainer to the 30-year-old Simon Armitage, this is in fact the usual hotch-potch of poetry and fashion, the real and the fake, the felt and the worked-up . The fash - ionable , trie ephemeral 'and the fake are outweighed by the good — in which latter category I would certainly place the poems by Eavan Boland, Peter Didsbury, George Szirtes, Glyn Maxwell, and a promising newcomer Maggie Hannan who has not yet published a book of her own. The book's star poet, though, is for my money the 3 8-year-old Carol Ann Duffy, who contributes six pieces in a variety of modes. Duffy is excellent at the sort of small dramatic monologue which has its speaker reveal himself unwittingly while finding unexpected poetry in turns of modern speech, as when in "Psychopath" she has the man
declare: / thought I was on, no error. But her outstanding achieve ment is her love poetry, and the one specimen of this included here, "Warming Here Pearls", rises to an intensity which reminds me of Sappho: And I lie here awake/ knowing the pearls are cooling even now/ in the room where my mistress sleeps . All night /I feel their absence and I burn. The editors also claim too little. They do Duffy scant justice, for instance, by remarking that she has been "exemplary in re-energising a
THE NEW POETRY Edited by Michael Hulse , David Kennedy and David Morley Bloodaxe, £7.95 pbk original THE MAY ANTHOLOGY of Oxford and Cambridge Poetry , 1993 Edited by Seamus Heaney Varsity/Cherwell, £2.99 pbk original feminist, public voice in poetry" . Beginning with the. proclamation that "every age gets the literature it deserves", they seem bent on pur - suit of a political point that would make poetry the mere mirror of the times. Presumably it is this which permits them to omit several inter - estin g poets who cannot be made to fit in with their theories: Sean Haldane, Robert Wells, Anthony Howell, Hugo Williams, Medbh McGuckian. Still, I would not quarrel with anyone who said that 55 poets in one generation was already far too many. Swift de - clared that Britain was never able to boast more than three poets at a time: Our chilling climate hardly bears/A sprig of bays in fifty years That is not the kind of opinion that can be favoured by anthologists
promoting contemporary writing, of course. The editors have done their best to be fair, and they are not the first to have rounded up a lot of geese and called them swans. The New Poetry is more a record of changes in the verse trade than anything else, yet others than the tradesmen will find value in it. The May Anthology comes w i n g - ing in on quite a different level of ambition. Here are 30 poems by undergraduates, post-graduates and recent graduates from Oxford and Cambridge, all of them much younger than most of the contribu - tors to The New. Poetry , each of them possessing to some degree that hopefulness peculiar to poets in their beginnings. This is an attractive little book:, inexpensive , well-produced , as full of promise as a newlaid egg, and if I single out one or two names it is not because I think the others have no talent. Damian ShaWs "In the Beg in - ning " seems to me a clever and well-made poem; Michael Theune's "To Begin an Even Knowing" is wise in the way that only a 22-year-old can be; while Vesna McMaster ("obsessed by words and writing" as she writes of herself ) has precisely that sort of perceptive confusion allied to a feeling for rhythm which, refined, might one day make for good verse. All are worth encouragement. So is the magazine Agenda (available at £8 an issue from 5 Cranbourne Court, Albert Bridge Road, London SW11 4PE), which has been going strong since before some of these new young poets were born , but whose continued existence is now threatened by an Arts Council decision to withdraw its grant at the end of this year. The current issue, devoted to the poet Tom Scott celebrates one whose translations of Villon into the Scots tongue can still be read with pleasure. Always dedicated to poet - ry in the highest sense, Agenda deserves to survive.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Youth to fortune and to fame6
Full_text:
Youth to fortune and to fame
H ere is an anthology of poems chosen by famous people, with a foreword by Seamus Heaney, himself a famous poet. The project began when some pupils from a Dublin school had the bright idea of trying to raise money for Third World charities in a novel way. . They wrote to celebrities from all walks of life, a preponderance of them Irish, asking them to choose a favourite piece of poetry and to write a brief paragraph ex - plaining their choice. Four of the resulting collections have already been published in pamphlet form, and the present Penguin paperback is a selection of the best of this material. Royalties from the book go to Ethiopian famine relief and similar worthy causes. The volume stands as some sort of testament perhaps, to the persisting importance of poetry in many people's lives. Apart from that, and the fact that it is inevitably something of a glorious rag-bag because the contributors are so various, it seems to me more interest - ing than most anthologies for three reasons.
First, you can see at a glance from it which poets are cur rently most popular, at least with famous (mostly Irish) people: Yeats scores 10, Anon 6, Housman 4, Patrick Kavanagh 4, with Shake - speare and Blake and Hop - kins in next place with three apiece. Second, there is plea - sure and instruction to be had from the short letters in which the choosers seek to justify their choices. Third, and per - haps most intriguing of all, there is the opportunity which the exercise affords of allowing the reader to wonder how much each choice tells us about the contributor. One the last count, when we
LIFELINES An Anthology of Poems Chosen by Famous People Edited by Niall MacMonagle Penguin, £5.99 pbk ARAGE FOR ORDER Poetry of the Northern Ireland Troubles Edited by Frank Ormsby BlackstaffPress, £12.95 pbk see Michael Holroyd going for D. J. Enright's "Biography " {Much easier than your works/To sell your quirks), or Mother Teresa selecting a prayer for peace from St Francis of Assisi, the connec - tion between ' celebrity and choice seems quite straightfor - ward . But what are we to make of Conor Cruise O'Brien choosing Milton's ode "On the Morning of Christ's Nativ ity" with the news that he usually reads it aloud to his family on Christmas Day, or Chaim Herzog picking "The
Lake Isle of Innisfree" ? It is where there is some little interesting distance between the public figure and the private favourite poem that this anthology fascinates. I find it startling and then illuminating, for instance, that Margaret Drabble chooses Blake's three stanzas begin - ning "Never seek to tell thy love", precisely because their intense mystery is at odds with the level-headed realism of her own prose. And surely it counts as surprising that David Owen's favourite poem turns out to be "Candles" by Cavafy, even though he man - ages to find reasons vaguely to do with his political life for liking it. The book is great fun, and the declared reasons for the choices are in some cases as interesting as the choices. Thus, John Gielgud chooses "Bredon Hill" because it was his audition piece for his first drama school; Judi Dench chooses "Adelstrop" by Edward Thomas because it reminds her of steam engines and her childhood; and Ben Elton selects the lyrics of Cliff Richard's song "The Young
Ones", as they recall for him a poignant moment when Rik Mayall, asked to sign an autograph for a boy who was dying, wrote Young Ones shouldn't be afraid. One minor point: of all the contributors, only Kingsley Amis, David Lodge, and Jef - frey Archer address their young female correspondents correctly as Miss in writing back. For the rest we are in a mess of instant first names, Dear Friends, Dear Lifelines, and the like. Something is being lost from the language by such usages. Famous people ought to know how to start their letters respectfully to less famous strangers. A Rage for Order, edited by Frank Ormsby, also has its origin in Ireland. This anthol - ogy consists of 250-odd poems which directly or indirectly address the conflict in North - ern Ireland, for the most part by writers with roots in the
region but with some contribu - tions by outsiders. There are fine poems here by Louis MacNeice, John Hewitt, W.R. Rodgers, and Seamus Heaney, as well as good work by less famous poets such as Norman Dugdale and Robert Greacen. Poets who take the Troubles for their theme have some - times been overvalued in Eng - land , as though that tragic business conferred instant pro - fundity on the slightest talent. The work to come out of Northern Ireland in the past 20 years, however, withstands comparison with anything being done elsewhere in the English language. For that reason, the book can be read as an excellent collection of some of the finest contemporary verse, but it might also be considered es - sential reading for anyone with a serious interest in modern Ireland.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Charm of the light brigade
Full_text:
Charm of the light brigade
France where he is a member of that Oulipo group which revels in literary games and puzzles of all kinds,, Mathews may be best known for his novels. This volume — which I would call verse fiction rather than poetry — does add an interesting dimension to the work in prose. In two elegiac poems addressed to his mother, Mathews speaks out sincerely, showing that his passion for artifice is a means of keeping strong feelings in check and not just gamesmanship. The writing of light verse, let alone deliberately comic verse, is of course a tricky business. There is one contemporary who seems to me a master of it, and who gets better with each book. He is Gavin Ewart, now 77, and his 85 Poems shows him at the height of his admirably unsolemn powers. Ewart is a skilled technician with a good rude sense of humour, consid - era ble command of rhetorical ef - fects , and a nice quirky interest in off-beat subjects. Here (because
TAXING THE RAIN By Penelope Shuttle OUP, £6.99 pbk A MID-SEASON SKY Poems, 1954-1991 By Harry Mathews Carcanet , £8.95 pbk 85 POEMS By Gavin Ewart Hutchinson, £7.99 pbk
Deare, if you change, I'll never think of earth And its animals dwelling in ignorance of heaven, Warm and wise without the comforts of fire, Nested in the ground , or in water, or air, Certain of their ways by the day and night stars. With no use for knowledge, or need for faith. An American, long resident in
P enelope Shuttle is a woman of vision. The trouble is: . vision of what? Her poems make bonfires of their own imag - ery , but it is hard to see what is illuminated by the blaze. Yet her writing, even where clumsy and repetitive , perhaps most where clumsy and repetitive, has that unfakeable urgency which comes from a complete confidence in the authority of one's own imagina - tion . When I think of her I think of someone scribbling away, filling notebook after notebook with verses that possess her mind utterly, someone who probably has to tie a knot in her handkerchief to remind herself to knock off once in a while for a bite to eat. Taxing the Rain, her new slim book of poems, is packed with storm and water stuff, mud and splashings, showers and flooded gardens, and there isn't an umbrel - la or a pair of welly boots anywhere in sight. Shuttle favours naked dalliance with the elements. A typical effusion begins Holding the rain in your arms/you grow wiser, wetter! before going on to recom - mend playing the rain like a musical instrument and answering the question Is it horn or string or percussion? with a blunt It is all. Admitting that much of this strikes me as wet rather than wise, I have still to say that some of it is
quite charming, in a dreamy surrealistic way . There is not a lot of craft to the lines, but the best ones have been to school with Sylvia Plath and Mother Goose and have a sort of simple singability. I wish I was more sure of the nature and meaning of Shuttle's vision, that's all. Sometimes she gives the im - pression of being at the mercy of her own imagination, which is perhaps the price she has to pay for such a fertile and distinctive talent. Harry Mathews operates at the other extreme, at least on the surface of his collection A Mid - Season Sky, which is full of poems very artfully made, even manufac - tured . The central piece "Trial Impressions" might be taken as typical : it consists of 30 variations on John Dowland's Deare , if you change from that Elizabethan luta - nist 's Second Book ofAyres. Since the Dowland is near - perfect , Mathews runs the risk of seeming a mere parodist, with his modern games turning it this way and that, without discernible pur - pose , save of demonstrating inge - nuity . Yet the final variation, in a sestina of his own making, achieves an eloquence which almost justifies the whole eccentric enterprise:
both wholly characteristic and short enough to quote in full) is "A Little Loyal Ode to the Queen Mother on her 90th Birthday": Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon ! It is fit that we should drink to you in a very large G and 77 Mainly because you've been around so long but also because you thought The Waste Land by T. S. Eliot was called The Desert Song! This book, with its epigrams and threnodies, its limericks and potted lives, its jokes and romps and doggerel and crosswords , continues that celebration of all things bright
and frivolous which Ewart has made his own. Yet under the cloak of wit there is a mordant mind at work, directing our attention to the facts of birth and copulation and death with the rudest of two - fingered salutes. Shuttle and Mathews will reward readers pre - pared to work on their opacities, but Gavin Ewart you can read for fun: A big boy kneels at the edge of the sea, A big balloon brandy there by his knee... Whisper who dares! Credibility fails. Kingsley Amis is singing to whales!
Robert Nye

Author: Paulin, Tom
Title: The perils of paulin
Full_text:
^HBh Bssiifl ' SSSu ^^ HfSnljJBHflB ^. BwB ffll l HSmS
Tom Paulin is the bull in lit crit's bone - china shop, and a poet who must be heard Sean O'Hagan listened to him. Photograph by Graham Wood
SEAMUS HEANEY , Ireland's best-known living literary figure, has a poem entitled Whatever You Say Say Nothing, which deals with what he succinctly termed "the famous Northern [Irish] reticence, the tight gag of place... " Yet Heane/s success, and the ongoing clamour of various rich Northern Irish poetic voices, would seem to suggest that, where poetry is concerned at least, reticence is nowhere in evidence . Alongside the man now dubbed Famous Seamus by his Irish readership, there stands the likes of John Montague , Derek Mahon, Seamus Deane, Paul Muldoon, Michael Longley , John Hewitt and Tom Paulin — acclaimed Ulster poets all. Indeed, poetry has flourished to such an extent that if there exists a contemporary Northern Irish literary voice, it is poetic rather than novelistic. If the province were to adapt a Heaneyesque literary motto, it might well be, "Whatever you write , write poetry." Given that it is a form suited to contempla - tion of the enigmatic poetry is perhaps the
perfect medium for considering the vexed question of cultural identity in a place where a person's tribal affiliations, be they Unionist or Nationalist , can be simultaneously un - shaka ble and constantly under siege. In Paulin's newly published Selected Poems 1972-1990 (Faber& Faber), he often touches on the ironies of belonging that are particu - lar to the Six Counties. One poem , entitled An Ulster Unionist Walks The Streets Of London, explores the often painfully felt paradoxes of contem - porary Ulster loyalism. It was inspired by a speech made by Harold McCusker, the Unionist MP, on the day the Anglo-Irish agreement was signed. The speech con - cerne d betrayal , an evergreen — or should that be ever-orange ? — Loyalist theme. In his poem, Paulin pictures the MP as leader of some latterday lost tribe of Israel, travelling to London on the " breakfast - shu ttle " flight from Belfast, adrift in a political and cultural limbo. In the capital , he visits Kentish Town, and walks around "like
a half-foreigner among the London-Irish ", a community he has no wish to belong to but whose place in British life seems as assured as his is fragile. The poem's climax imagines the MP fleeing the House of Commons, the epicentre of his betrayal and the symbol of all he formerly held dear. It is, Paulin says, "a poem about what happens when certainties fall apart, about being British and suddenly feeling homeless even when you are an elected MP." It is the kind of tortuous, almost absurdist striving for identity that Paulin revisits in his poems and essays, looking back at his native Northern Ireland with an ironic detachment and self - ques tioning honesty that sets him apart from almost anyone else writing about the place. Unlike many of his contemporaries, he doesn't dwell in the ritual tradition. His landscapes are seldom romantic often ominous, the "brick canyons" and " black - ene d gasworks" of urban Belfast, "the bungalow on the unapproved road" that snakes through the no man's land at the border of some desolate "sweep of broken road between two guarded towns". He is fond of vernacular language and treasures the rich resonances of Ulster dialect where a
stagnant stream is a sheugh , a whore is a "hoor" and vomit becomes the clipped onomatopoeic "boke ". If much of his poetry is as thorny and spare as, to borrow one of his own descriptions, a "screggy hawthorn", there is a tenderness there too. Often, it is camouflaged, on the one hand, by a fierce formal dexterity and, on the other, by an unerring ability to capture the casual cruelty and black humour that is part of everyday banter in Northern Ireland. According to Christopher Reid, his editor at Faber & Faber, Paulin's poetry possesses "an oral calculation and ingenuity that harks back to Auden". Paulin describes it, in his inimitably blunt way, as "fucked up and
abstract". He was bom in Leeds in 1949, to a Northern Irish mother and an English father , but grew up on Belfast's Ormeau Road. Derek Mahon has memorably described the pre-Troubles Belfast as a city where, "If a coathanger knocked in a wardrobe / That was a great event", but Paulin remembers having a fine time "with a bunch of streetwise adolescents hanging around bookies reading Joyce". His parents belonged to the Northern Ireland Labour party, held "vaguely socialist liberal ideas" and campaigned vigorously against capital punishment. They were also members of the linen Hall Library and furnished the house with books. Paulin seems
to have absorbed not only their love of literature but also their political outlook. Since 1972, he has held a day job as lecturer in English at Nottingham Univer - sity , having himself attended Hull and then Oxford, where he now lives. Although Paulin socialises with fellow Oxford-based writers such as Ian McEwan and James Fenton and professes "a great admiration for scholarship and what the academy represents ideally ", he is different . His undiminished Northern Irish blunt - ness and his effortless ability to ruffle his fellow academics' feathers lend him a vaguely threatening sense of intellectual otherness that he is bemused by but nevertheless revels in. Given that he has published four volumes of poetry and edited two acclaimed antholo - gies for Faber of vernacular and political verse, it is ironic that Paulin is best known as a lit-crit troublemaker. Indeed, his irregular appearances on television have assumed an almost mythical status in academic circles, turning him into English literature 's reigning, and occasionally rag - ing , polemicist. A few years back he wrote and presented a
half-hour demolition job on Virginia Woolf for the Channel 4 series Taccuse, his octave-leaping and effortlessly indignant Ulster twang adding insult to injury in a sustained assault on the elitist values of the Bloomsbury set. Then there was the now-notorious appear - ance on BBC2's The Late Show last October , when a "tired and emotional" Paulin harangued a rather snooty Anthony Thwaite, editor of the Selected Letters of Philip Larkin and executor of the late poet's estate, for supposedly censoring Larkin's more extreme racist comments. What was riveting about Paulin's Late Show performance was the spectacle of someone utterly disregarding the usual rules of the literary debate, opting instead to rail against his fellow academic with a righteousness that recalled the Reverend Ian Paisley in full flow in the House of Commons. The analogy cheers Paulin somewhat, and the sheepish grin that appeared on his face at the mere mention of Thwaite is replaced by a mischievous
<NEWPAGE>
chuckle. "There are times in criticism when you just want confrontation and blood on the walls in order to break through all that civility and facetious protocol. But I should have done it better. I wasn't grown up enough and I made a bit of a fool of myself. What irks me more is that I wasn't
'Going against the grain gives Paulin great energy' tKammuuumm ama
Book Of Political Verse. The private row became public when Raine wrote a letter to the LRB attack - ing Paulin's review of Geoffrey Hill's book on Milton. A mutual acquaintance told me the two poets have not spoken since. "Tom and I have a rather precarious friend - ship ", Raine says, "and I
nave the teeling that anything I say could be misinterpreted. So I'd rather not say anything." "Tom is one of the great disagree-ers ," Reid says. "The whole idea of going against the grain seems to give him a great energy." The Larkin debate was also fuelled by Paulin's distaste for that particular strain of English literary culture characterised by an entrenched reactionary nationalism. "I know that there is a constant barrage of abuse that persons of colour have to endure in this
adept enough to tease out of Thwaite why he had chosen to excise the letters." Paulin is no stranger to this kind of intense intellectual swordplay, having fallen out with his erstwhile editor, the poet Craig Raine, after a long-running feud in the letters page of the London Review of Books. The issue then was Milton, whom Paulin regards as "one of the greatest political poets in the English language", a view not shared by Raine, who objected to the inclusion of great chunks of Milton in the Paulin-edited Faber
country, he says, "and not just because I happen to have two mixed-race children growing up here. It's there every day, but in English literary circles there is very little aware - ness of that. What you do have, though, is the smugness of old farts like Kingsley Amis and co — wretched far-right wankers who indulge themselves in their self - disgust by saying revolt - ing things about members of minorities. I
think it's necessary to confront that." Perhaps, I venture, Thwaite was a soft target for Paulin's ire. This cuts no ice with Paulin, who is now on the offensive with a vengeance. "Anthony Thwaite", he says, his eyes widening as he warms to the subject, "is a little balsawood minor man of letters who is of no consequence at all other than he wants to create this national shrine around Larkin.
"Now , I admire Larkin as a poet immensely, but there is also Larkin the racist. There is this nat - ional monument that the Letters try and construct of our favourite right - wing uncle. You can't siniply have a warm bath in your favourite nationalist author — it's just not on." There is a slight pause for breath here, then a final flourish. "There has to be a distinction be - tween the rancid, farting human being and the art. Instead, the two get put together and the effect is to license and palliate vulgar racist views." In the world of literary scholarship, this kind of emotional outspokenness and fondness for the un - abridged vernacular of the street has made Paulin controversial. He is currently researching a whom he describes as "a whom he describes as "a
paper on Hazlitt, brilliantly civil polemicist, tough and gra - cious at the same time". As his clash with Thwaite shows, when an intellectual issue touches his emotional core, his undoubted toughness is at the expense of such gracious - ness . There is an element here of cultural isolation, and Paulin admits to feeling "estranged in certain ways, in that this is a more emotionally subdued culture. Anyone who is expatriated misses the communalism of social life in Ireland and all the fun that goes with it." Yet. when he isn't carried away with his role as literary agent provocateur, he exudes a rather old-fashioned , slightly eccentric charm, and is as soft-spoken as his alter ego is loud. In political, as well as literary, terms, however, Paulin is an effortless dissenter belonging to a progressive ultra-minority that could be crudely labelled protestant republican. "I suppose I am a republican, but I am as influenced by Milton, Hazlitt and Shelley as I am by Wolfe Tone.
There s a great risk, if you come from Northern Ireland, of being identified trib - ally . The problem with calling yourself a republican is that the likes of Conor Cruise O'Brien have effectively smeared anyone who does that by saying that they, in effect, support violence. I categorically do not." It is this willingness to transcend the tribal and political ideologies that strait-jacket the Northern Ireland question that make his best writing about the subject so refreshing. In the introduction to his provocative volume of essays, Ireland And The English Crisis (Bloodaxe Books), he mourns the passing of the "dissenting tradition" of Ulster Prot - estantism that "created a distinctive and notable culture in the dosing decades of the 18th century" . Aligning himself with this long-neglected radical tradition, he then creates a political space for himself that, given his Ulster Protestant background, is both progressive and courageous:"... For the most part I see no contradiction in revering the idea of England, and at the same time hoping Ireland will eventually be a united and separate country with strong cultural institu - tions of its own."
THE BREADTH OF Paulin's cultural iconoclasm is apparent throughout Ireland And The English Crisis, which includes a devastating critique of the "static and unfruitful contradictions" that make up O'Brien 's "19th century Unionism", an analysis of Paisley's sermonising that looks seriously at the use of biblical language and allusion by the great loyalist demagogue, and a piece on how scholars have continually overlooked the influence of the Fenian movement on Oscar Wilde. All this alongside a selection of provocative literary criticism that is informed by his antipathy to all things deconstructionist. All Paulin's work is informed by a sense of
reclamation, whether he is historicising writers like M ilton or even Joyce, who he feels "have too often been detached from their social moment and their cultures", or aligning himself with the fractured, and endangered, tradition of vernacular verse. In the introduction to his recently published second collection of criticism, Minotaur Poetry And The Nation State (Faber & Faber), he unconsciously pinpoints one of the great strengths of his writing when he says that "these essays are obsessively entangled with social and ideological questions ... because they are intended to bring to the critical act at least the possibility of a historical method" .
And, in writing about Yeats or Milton, he homes in on uncomfortable and unresolved "social and ideological questions" that con - tinue to resound in Ireland and Britain today. "Really ", he says. "I 'm just a failed historian." When I ask him about one of his favourite topics, Protestantism and the private con - science , his answer ranges through history, art and politics, touching on Milton's republicanism, Shakespeare's medieval Catholicism and the shared sense of "vernacular primitivism" that informs the work of Emily Dickinson, Jackson Pollock, Ian Paisley and Van Morrison. It also, however, left me wondering if Paulin's reputation as "the great disagree-er " has diverted attention away from his poetry and the important cultural questions raised by his essays. If he is worried by this, he's not letting on. The last word, as ever, is his. "The great master, Swift, said he wanted to vex people and I'd go along with that. A lot of critics want to have a big party where everyone agrees about everything. I prefer the sort of party where everyone is arguing and shouting."

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Silver vein in an age of iron
Full_text:
S ilver vein in an age of iron
R ussian poetry is dif - ferent , as Fitzgerald once said of the rich. It has another di - mension of intensity, of public speech, of moral hygiene, of tragedy. The English poet speaks for himself and culti - vates his oddity in a corner of the language; the Russian is ordinary and speaks for every - one . This function of poetry, its familiarity and importance, its conspicuous place at the head of an alternative hierarchy, resists translation into English more than the words them - selves — they arrive with an echo, and perhaps sound hol - low to our ears. In England, poetry is a mews off Grub Street; in Russia, it is celestial, half-Parnassus and half - Hollywood . Perhaps only American po - etry can begin to compare with
it. John Berryman summons "the worst possible ordeal that will not actually kill him"; Akhmatova asserts that "Shakespeare's plays — the sensational atrocities, passions, duels — are child's play compared to the life of each one of us" . Robert Lowell makes his "manic statement/ telling off the state and presi - dent " and Pasternak tells Sta - lin on the telephone that he wanted to talk to him about life and death. All are on the Richter Scale, with their exor - bitance and risk. The difference is that the Americans were brinkmen: calculating, perhaps bored; their success or failure mattered only to themselves. It is impossible to imagine them saying (as Akhmatova said): "The Nobel is not enough."
THE COMPLETE POEMS OF ANNA AKHMATOVA Translated by Judith Hemschemeyer Zephyr/Canongate, £17 .95 And if they had said it, it would have been a demand for a rise. For the Russians, poetry was not a career, and they toughed it out, none more than Akhmatova: the only game in town. There was a golden age of Russian poetry, but that was in the early 19th century, and, like most golden ages (in fact, it seems axiomatic) it travels badly: Pushkin in translation seems like a lesser Byron rather than a later Shake - speare . Akhmatova became an
expert on Pushkin, and uses his words, sparingly as saffron, as epigraphs for some of her own work. She was, believe it ornot, part of the silver age of Russian poetry: herself, Paster - nak , Mandelstam and Tsvet - ayeva were born in consecutive years, from 1889 to 1892. They are beyond question the most gifted group of poets of the century. Akhmatova, the first of them, was also the last; she died in 1966. Isaiah Berlin writes: "The wide - spread worship of her memory in the Soviet Union today, both as an artist and as an unsurrendering human being, has, so far as I know, no parallel." The pupil and protege of her
last years, Joseph Brodsky, offers the best description of Akhmatova's poetry (in an essay, "The Keening Muse", included in his Less Than One). She is "the kind of poet that simply 'happens '", with - out apprenticeship or discern - ible development, unlike anyone else and impossible to imitate . He calls her "blatantly non-avant-garde ", "a poet of strict metres, exact rhymes and short sentences" . Of these three qualities, only the third can be relied upon to survive in translation; metre and rhyme (the great majority of Akhmatova's poems consist of three or four rhyumed quatrains) have to be imag - ined . Even so, it is enough. Judith Hemschemeyer's ver - sions are the best I have seen; they have dignity and pace,
and are part way rhymed. Above all, her mission to translate all of Akhmatova — for which she taught herself Russian, though working from literal versions, like many translators — proves to have been inspired. This great lilac brick of a book, with 800 poems (some mere scraps of only two or three wonderful lines), a hundred photo - graphs , Berlin's memoir of his amazing nocturnal meeting with Akhmatova in 1945, all annotated and introduced, is a stupendous bargain. Akhmatova at 20 wrote poems in which she was flawless, interesting and her - self . Brodsky comments on the "terrific novelist quality" of her love poems, and I was capti - vated especially by her second book Rosaty (1914); those poems were recited in order by
her admirers, round a room. Each one is a moment of great physical and psychological clarity: a room or street, an encounter an exchange of words or gestures, and often some bitter twist at the end. Love can be "calculating and malicious", a nightingale sings "poisonously", in a Vic - torian image of sexual taint, there is the smell of tobacco in dishevelled braids. A romantic and feted and beautiful youth was mislead - ing and left Akhmatova un - prepared , one would have
thought, for the future: her first husband, the poet Gumilyov, shot in 1921, two unsatisfactory remarriages, the imprisonment of her son under Stalin, deaths and be - trayals and chicaneries. But no, the proportions of bitter - ness and passion in her work were reversed, her poetic re - sources dealt magnificently with what was thrown at her. At 30 she described herself as old and wrote about her losses. She compared her life to a train rushing off the tracks or — that other miracle of Soviet
engineering — a re-routed river. Poetry, she said superb - ly , grows from "rubbish". The appalling drama of her life — Shakespearean, as she said — is traced and sur - mounted by the poems. Seam - lessly , a girl's love-poems become the tough lamenta - tions of a survivor. At times I thought I was reading some - thing thousands of years old; the Romans or the ancient Chinese would have under - stood Akhmatova. We are lucky to have this account of her in English.
Michael Hofmann
The worship of her memory has no parallel: Anna Akhmatova as a young woman

Author: Ackroyd, Peter
Title: Ring the fuller minstrel in
Full_text:
Tennyson was the Victorian ideal of a poet, yet his poetry had nothing to do with the life of a celebrity. Peter Ackroyd relishes an amiable and breezy new life of the author of In Memoriam
W ell, Arthur, I mean to be famous." So Alfred Tennyson told his younger brother, when they were both still children, and it is an early indication of the strength of will which propelled this apparently dreamy and abstracted creature through his long career. He started to compose poetry at the age of eight, and three years later had amassed his lifetime's writing under these headings: "Vol . 1. The Poetry of Tennyson. Vol 2. The Lyrical Poetry of Tennyson. Vol 3. The Prose Writings of Tennyson." Here in embryo is the author of Idylls of the King and, almost from the beginning, he was able to command that euphonious sound which is as much a matter of cadence as of mellow open vowels. It was not his invention — you can hear it throughout English poetry — and it was helped by his early acquaintance with classical litera - ture . Virgil is an obvious influence but Peter Levi, himself a classicist, mentions Ovid and Sappho as well as Theocritus. Tennyson found his home in language. The young poet needed all the
ambition and confidence he could muster. He came from a troubled and gloomy family ; his father suffered from fitful insanity, exacer - bated by drink and laudanum, and the melancholic nature of the household is best exemplified by the remark of one of his younger brothers on meeting Dante Gabriel Rossetti — "I am Septimus, the most morbid of the Tennysons." By the time he reached Cam - bridge , this "great poetical boa - constrictor " , as Thackeray called him, was already a striking figure . "That man must be a poet," one of his contemporaries noted at first glance, and over the years he became an icon of the poetic temperament. With his hat, his voluminous cloak, and his blue - tinted spectacles, he often caused a sensation on the streets. His ap - pearance was half patriarch, half gypsy, with his distracted expres - sion , his tempestuous hair, and what one female acquaintance called "a very decided nose". The
Victorians believed that they were in the presence of some divining fire. He really came upon the world with the Poems of 1832, but not quite in the manner he expected. It was an age characterised by review - ers almost as foolish as our own, and Tennyson was one of those unfortunate writers who are un - doubtedly affected by criticism in the public prints. He was, Levi writes, "crushed" by the invective against a volume which included "The Lotus-Eaters" and "The Lady of Shalott"; but no great writer can remain in a semi-recumbent pos - ture for long, and the sudden death of Arthur Hallam in the following year brought him back to his feet (and his metres). It took him 17 years to write In Memoriam and he was still tinker -
TENNYSON By Peter Levi Macmillan, £20
» ——^ -^^^^^^ H^a MBH^^^^^^^^M^^H ing with it 50 years later — never can a threnody have taken so long to complete but, on the other hand, few have found so large a public. It became the keepsake of the 19th century. It did not always elicit quite the right response, and one reviewer apparently believed that this work "was by the affectionate widow of a military man" . Levi's biography is full of such asides and diversions: it is an amiable and almost breezy study which proves that it is not necessary to be solemn about greatness. It is disappointing only when it be - comes enmeshed in detail. The difference between a novel and a biography, after all, is this: in a novel one is bound to tell the truth, whereas in a biography one can make things up, by which I mean that the biographer is obliged to impose a pattern upon the narra - tive of a life in order to establish its meaning. Perhaps, in Tennyson, there are too many facts and not quite enough pattern. But Levi has read widely and deeply in the literature of Tennyson's age, and it
is refreshing to come across a biographer who knows more than the collected works of his subject That is how he is able to locate him within the full movement of his time, revealing in the process how much Tennyson was part of his period: he was, like Dickens, a great inclusive genius. It is easy to regard him as a poet of the mournful lyric or the Arthurian epic, but his poetry is filled with intimations of theology, natural science and evolutionary theory; while within the cadence of his verse he is able to depict the real life of industrial England. By the time he published his Poems of 1842, which includes some of the finest verse of the 19th century , he had proved himself to be, in Levi' s words, "a great and a popular poet, inimitably various ... " Certainly, he makes most modern English poetry seem very thin gruel indeed. Within a short time, he had become a grand if not necessarily old man of English letters. Yet throughout his life he was most notable for his innocence and
simplicity; there was an infantile streak not very far beneath the surface of his genius. He sucked on his pipe continually, he drank a bottle of port every night, and always ate a portion of apple pie. He remained what many of his friends described as a "great child". But if so, he was one of those strange infants who keep a distance between themselves and the world. What is most striking about this biography is the extent to which poet and man .led separate lives. Levi remarks that "he relied deeply on himself and there was within his character an inner momentum that rarely connected with his ostensible existence in the world. He does not seem to occupy his life at all, but inhabits some other place where all that matters are words and the sounds of words. And this is a region through which even the most assiduous biographer cannot follow him. "He would have wished," Benjamin Jowett wrote, "that , like Shakespeare, his life might be unknown to posterity" . In a sense, as always, he got his wish.
Tennyson in 18 71, by "Ape" of Vanity Fair, his hat, cloak and blue-tinted spectacles caused a stir

Author: Dugdale, John
Title: Just how do we remember them?
Full_text:
Just how do we remember them ?
As their anniversaries approach , John Dugdale assesses the war poetry of Laurence Binyon and Wilfred Owen
Laurence Binyon, the 50th anniversary of whose death falls tomorrow, secured his niche in history through the poem "For The Fallen", first published in The Times on Septem - ber 21, 1914, in response to early British losses in Flanders: They shall not grow old, as we that are left grow old: Ageshall not weary them, northe years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning We will remember them. Despite the incongruous echo of Shakespeare's Cleopatra (" age can - not wither her" ), the lines have a ponderous, mock-antique elo - quence which allows them to pass for an addendum to The Book of Common Prayer. They have be - come the official expression of mourning for the Great War dead, engraved on countless memorial
stones and incanted at countless memorial services. Elgar set them to music. In this sense Binyon is the best known of the first world war poets, remembered for a promise to remember. Others are more cele - brated , but their work is not publicly recited throughout the country each year on Armistice day. Aged 45 when war broke out, Binyon spent it working at the British Museum, where he was a keeper in the department of prints and drawings; he published semi - nal studies of Oriental painting and the followers of William Blake. By September 1914 he was also of sufficient standing as a poet and verse dramatist to be invited (in the distinguished company of Thomas Hardy, Arthur Conan Doyle, John Masefield and G.K. Chesterton) to attend a secret conference for men of letters organised by a new
government propaganda section. "For The Fallen" was his dutiful contribution to the war effort. When it was reprinted as part of a War Poems from The Times supple - ment in August 1915, Wilfred Owen, 22, was returning from southern France to England in order to enlist. His reaction was lukewarm approval ("Binyon — all right!"), but at that stage he still largely shared the same conven -
Great War writing continues to shape the way the British imagination responds to war tional view of the war, with its linked myths of heroism and Christ-like self-sacrifice . After his first experience of the Western Front in early 1917, however, he could no longer treat death as an abstraction, erasing the appalling reality. The opening of "Anthem For Doomed Youth", his own tribute to the fallen ("What passing-bells for these who die as cattle?"), is manifestly unsuitable for memorial services. And "Dulce Et Decorum Est" directly chal - lenges "the old Lie", the non - combatant 's notion of battle as the perfect arena for a dignified patriot - ic demise; by depicting in detail a soldier being poisoned by gas. Other frequently anthologised works; such as "Spring Offensive" and "The Sentry", are similarly
centred on first-hand reportage — usually combined with an explicit or implicit appeal to the compas - sion of the reader, or with angry protest directed against desk - bound hawks in Whitehall and greedy profiteers. In the climax of "Insensibility ", regarded by many as his greatest poem, this anger is powerfully fused with late-Roman tic lyricism. By choice they made themselves immune To pity and whatever moans in man Before the last sea and the hapless stars; Whatever mourns in man when many leave these shores; Whatever shares The reciprocity of tears. March 18 sees the centenary of Owen's birth. His reputation re - mains healthy, and his work is still widely read, particularly in schools
— although it must be said that academic criticism, preoccupied with the Modernist motorways Eliot and Pound were already building in 1918, tends to view war poetry as a rather dull B-road . The Chatto edition of the Collected Poems , edited by Jon Stallworthy, Owen's biographer, regularly sells 6,000 to 7,000 copies a year, assisted by its presence on A-level syllabuses. Jon Silkin's Penguin Book of First World War Poetry has been in print ever since its first appearance in 1979. The contemporary relevance of Great War writing is obvious and — despite the competing influence of post-194 5 American fiction — it continues to shape the way the British imagination responds to war. Tumbledown, Charles Wood's television play based on the story of ah officer wounded in the'Falk - lands conflict, picked up the argu -
ment against the cult of the hero where Owen left off. Blackadder Goes Forth, the BBC sitcom set in the trenches of Flanders, began as black comedy, blending Oh What A Lovely War! with Catch-22 . But the final episode, in which the characters went over the top, took its tone from Owen and his mentor, Siegfried Sassoon. Owen died in action on Novem - ber 4, 1918, a week before the Armistice was signed. His own vision of his subsequent career, had he survived, can be inferred from "Strange Meeting", a Dante-esque dream poem in which a soldier meets the enemy he killed: death, the ghost says, has prevented him from revealing "the truth ' untold/ The pity of war, the' pity war distilled". On this basis, Owen would have joined Vera Brittain
and her colleagues in the inter-war peace movement. The late George MacBeth envis - aged the railway clerk's son writing "more directly involved poetry about the problems of the working classes" than the socially privileged Auden gang of the Thirties. David Bradshaw's Dictionary of Nat - ional Biography essay surmises that Owen "would have grown in stature to span the native tradition between Thomas Hardy and Philip Larkin".
He would have been bound to his domineering mother — and half enjoyed it. He would have gone on writing, but the great gifts stirred in him by the war would have died down as his memory healed. "Eventually , he would have found his way back to Catholicism, like Sassoon. He would have died in the early 1960s, honoured but slightly diminished by his later works, which would have suffered greatly from his hostility to Modernism." A Tony Harrison of the 1920s, a left-wing social realist, a flag-bearer for old-fashioned verse that rhymes, or a bumt-out case: all are equally plausible,. The career of Robert Graves, the longest survivor among the leading first world war writers, is an effective deterrent to facile extrapolation: had he too died
H owever, Andrew Mo - tion , Larkin's biogra - pher , recently sketched a less glorious possible after-life :' "He would have become a homosexual prep school master in Shropshire, with a pipe! patches on his elbows, and terrible memories.
in 1918, as a promising young member of the gentlemanly Geor - gian school, only a clairvoyant could have foreseen Laura Riding, The White Goddess, the Claudius novels and Majorca. Owen's squalid, senseless death froze him in glamorous potentiali - ty , like Rupert Brooke: Binyon's weary words ("They shall not grow old, as we that are left grow old" ) unwittingly anticipate this process, and hint at something close to envy of those released from time and disillusionment. Binyon himself was successful in all three of his careers, as poet, art historian and museum curator. But "For The Fallen" proved to be his only brush with popularity, and when he died in 1943, his intended magnum opus, the verse drama Merlin, was left unfinished.
Lest we forget: Laurence Binyon (left) was too old to fight in the first world war, Wilfred Owen died a week before the end of it

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Sickness unto death in verse
Full_text:
Sickness unto death in verse
T hey say that John Berryman turned to wave a casual farewell to some passer-by before throwing himself to his death from a bridge in Minneapolis 20 years ago. His poetry is like that too. Offering crazy intimacies to its readers, it goes plunging suicidally down the page in desperate pursuit of meaning. The results can be criticised as obscure in their remorseless self - reference , but the best of his work has a passion and a lucidity rare in modern American verse and un - usual anywhere at any time. I remember him once attacking aca - demic criticism with the remark
that when Shakespeare said he had two loves of comfort and despair he wasn't kidding. It is that quality of Not Kidding which may enable Berryman to live on as a poet where most of his contemporaries seem already dead on the page. The Dream Songs is his longest and most ambitious work, as well as his richest and most difficult, and Faber serves his memory well by issuing it now in a single paperback volume.
