First published as two separate books — 77 Dream Songs (1964) and His Toy, His Dream, His Rest (1968) — this is a sequence of 385 poems, each poem arranged in three six-line stanzas, the lines
varying greatly in length and stress, the stanzas in rhyme pattern. The subject is, broadly speaking, the phantasmagorical doings of a white man in black-face called Henry, or Pussy-cat . Henry's drunken adventures are chronicled, employing the lingo of a minstrel show; at other times he is heard in meditation or in colloquy with a friend who calls him Mr Bones. Behind all these masks, inform - ing these various procedures, the real subject is Berryman himself, the poet in the modern world, a dreamer at odds with society. The process seems truly phenom - enological in that the verse takes in anything and everything that comes to hand. It also gives off a sense that it might not have taken the poet much longer to write the stuff than it takes us now to read it. The probable model here is Whitman's Song for Myself. Like Whitman, the overall sound is loud, but the lines that speak most clearly
POETRY
THE DREAM SONGS By John Berryman Faber. £9.99 pbk THE PATIENT George MacBeth Hutchinson, £7.99 pbk MASS FOR HARD TIMES R. S. Thomas Bloodaxe, £12 ^ 95/£5.95 pbk shock with their quietness: Life, friends, is boring. We must not say so... The Scottish writer George Mac - Beth died early this year from motor neurone disease, and The Patient collects his last verses. It is in many ways a brave and touching volume, with a delightful line drawing of MacBeth on the cover (a drawing which must have been made by his widow in the last months of his life). As a poet, MacBeth seemed to me to
improve a great deal in the latter part of his career, the palpable change of direction in his work seeming to have something to do with his removal about ten years ago from London to Norfolk and his starting to write a smaller and more particular kind of poem about what he found in country living. This is not to say that he settled for being a "nature" poet or anything like that, just that he began to work at limiting the somewhat restless ambition of his earlier work, discovering a home for his imagina - tion in things nearer to hand, and his verse became the stronger for it. The Patient contains poems in which matters of life and death are presented with the unmistakable authority of experience. Once upon a time MacBeth's work was dressed to kill but had nowhere to go. By the end, it had achieved every appear - ance of plain urgency, whether the poet is writing about relationships with others, writing light-hearted
tributes to his friends, or facing up to his own increasing disability and approaching death. The short se - quence of sonnets included here on the last subject is the outstanding thing in a moving little book. Back in the Fifties, when most of the verse being written in English looked and sounded as though it had been compiled by a committee for a committee, the work of the Welsh clergyman-poet R.S. Thomas seemed to stand out by reason of a clean personal imprint, its stamp as of a man with a keen sense of his own identity and his place in a living community, as well as a man possessed of things which
were his alone to say. I think now this must have been an illusion. Either that, or Thomas has deteriorated. Whichever view is correct, the poems in his latest volume Mass for Hard Times strike me as thin and banal. Bleak Liturgies, as one of them is called, would serve to define nearly all of them. While respecting the integrity everywhere apparent in Thomas, not least in his devotion to his flock (/ was vicar of large things/in a small parish, as he wrote once), I have to say that in my opinion this volume records the death of a poet under a weight of ecclesiastical self-discipline .
Robert Nye

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Anthology of old geography
Full_text:
Anthology of old geography
THE FABER BOOK OF MODERN EUROPEAN POETRY Edited by A. Alvarez Faber, £17.50 * T his is not a bad anthology — no book with selections from Montale, Ritsos, Enzensberger and Herbert can be altogether bad — but it has to give best to Daniel Weissbort's The Poetry of Survival, which appeared at the beginning of the year. Weissbort identified the terrain, and had first use of it: broadly, the central European experience of the second world war and the division of Europe. His book is the outcome of a life's work down the mines of poetry translation (for which he has absurdly been called a careerist), and is still loose and negotiable; Alvarez's seems more like an ] afterthought. j It is hard to make good anthologies without a j background, and , as Alvarez says in his j introduction, "until quite recently, foreign ; ; literature, particularly foreign poetry, has not j fared well in Britain" . In one way, Alvarez's j effort is not part of that "recently ", although he { obviously hopes to prosper from it: rather, he is j anthologising from memory, from his own memory of editing the classic Penguin Modern European Poets list in the Sixties. Twenty-five years ago he was a wonderful reader and critic of poetry (if you ask me, there is still an Alvarez - shaped hole), but since then he has been on holiday from it, writing books on divorce, rock - climbing , gambling and such like. The con - sequence is that the introduction is recycled hat, the choice of poets uninspired, the selections out of date . Getting there after Weissbort, Alvarez has extended his field to take in western Europe and the Mediterranean countries (although he won't have anything from Iberia), but his heart remains north and east of the Danube. Of 34 poets, he has six Poles, three Czechs and four Hungarians. The result of the geographical spread is a certain diffuseness and a feeling of "if he liked that how can he like this?" Some literary tastes date a man like fossils date a rock. I wonder if Pasternak, for instance, has made any converts since his poetry arrived on the back of the Nobel prize and DrZhivago in the Sixties: he has never seemed to me much good in English, but there he is in Alvarez. The same with Celan — but he has to be there. Some of the poets are makeweights: Voznesensky, Petri the Hungarian, the French Jaccottet. There are peculiar selections from Brodsky and Montale. There is really no such thing as European poetry. The poetry of the eastern bloc, written with clarity, coolness, ideas and as few words as possible, sits oddly with more traditional verbal and rhetorical poetry from Italy and France. It seems to have been written in order to be understood, and not, as Wallace Stevens once said poetry should do, "almost successfully resist the understanding". There is a premium on difference. We are enlarged by a poem that is straightforward to read, tells an historical anecdote in nondescript diction and ends with a twist: something like Adam by the Romanian Sorescu, in which our founder-father goes on making women from his "intercostal harem" until God finally expels him from Eden "for surrealism". In eastern Europe, meanwhile, there is an appetite for prosy, humdrum, self-deprecating British poetry, and they are translating Philip Larkin with loads of mistakes. We all need the other.
Michael Hofmann

Author: Padel, Ruth
Title: Made of the Wright stuff
Full_text:
MIMHiftiiH —H
Made of the Wright stuff
Wha t have Australia, Bulgaria and ancient Greece in common? Some - thing wonderful: senior women as leading poets. Judith Wright, one of the most distinguished poets of her generation, country (Australia ), and our time, 1992 winner of the Queen's Award for Poetry, frontline conserva - tionist and human rights activist , is a poet of true fire and craft, with the serious sparkle of vintage champagne. This marvellous A Human Pattern: Selected Poems from her 12 books, (Carcanet, £14.95), closes her poetry career. It is more important now, she says, to "get things done". To reverse Australia 's "legal fiction of terra nullius": the pose that when settlers came there was "no onethere , nullus, to whom terra could belong. This terra's supreme poet, of its "delicate gatherings of dancing trees", never ducks its violence: Here, twisted in steel, and spoiled with red your sunlight hide, smelling of death and fear , they crushed out of your throat the terrible song you sang in the dark ranges. The torn mrrigal "voice from the hills" is lover, mythic heroine, elegy-maker Hurling your woes at the moon, that old cleaned bone, till the white shorn mobs of stars on the hill of the sky huddled and trembled. Every word precise. None lazy. This is poetry of search, "for wholeness", for "understanding what was happening to me and around me". Its guilt does not flop about like English guilt. Describing an early massacre, settlers forcing aborigines over a diff, shooting those who wouldn't jump, she brings the tragedy home: Did we not know their blood channelled our rivers and the black dust our crops ate was their dust? O all men are one man at last. We should have known the night that tided up the cliffs and hid them had the same question on its tongue for us. And there they lie that were ourselves writ small... In her first book (1946), Wright emerged as a war poet : We meet and part now all over the world.
we, the lost company, take hands together in the night, forget the night in our brief happiness, silently . She was a trail blazing love-poet too. A penis, "eyeless labourer in the night", opened the title - p oem (on womens sex-experierice ) of her second collection , Woman to Man. In the Sixties , Eve to her Daughters was a flag-poem for the Australian womens movement. We should all be so lucky, at 70, to have produced such a body of work: with a compelling political edge and a wonderfully cadenced personal voice. Bulgaria mirrors this with another septuage - narian leading poet , Blaga Dimitrova, whose The Last Rock Eagle has been translated by Brenda Walker with Vladimir Levchev and Belin Tonchev (Forest Books, £6.95 pbk). Dimitrova (born 1922), Bulgaria's new vice - president fuses geo-political anger with the poetry of attachment — domestic, mythicised — earmarked since Sappho as women's poetic territory. Lines to Vaclav Havel, as Sisyphus, bite like Cassandra: And still the boulder doesn't crash ' ' down in the ravine... Do you want something more impossible, like balancing that boulder on the ridge that took such toil to get it to the top?
WOMEN POETS *
Dimitrova is badly served by the translation. Words like "toil" won't do. According to Julia Kristeva, Dimitrova turns thought into poetry" in Bulgarian. Phrases like "unquaffed sunsets " do not do this in English. However, sometimes you see what Kristeva means: In late autumn — a chestnut in bloom. A yellow leaf-fall and cranes leaving. And on branches — the wig of spring. "Wig" hints at the real poem's life. And occasionally her thought hits through with heartbreaking directness: When hope comes true it's only thenyou realise you never really hoped. For Elizabeth Jennings (bom 1926), "life is mostly inner war", but, she says in this lovely new collection , Times and Seasons (Carcanet , £6.95 pbk), poems work suffering into "good dark shape" . Much-loved poet of mental anguish, love, religion, nature , and childhood, Jennings gives us moving poems of loss. In a terrifying poem on adult abuse, a priest forbids Communion for the sin of doubt: The priest was twisted, sick. I felt no hate For children think they cannot change such things or run from them... Even this is turned to dark good shape: God, you meant terror once. But maybe this Brought me close to your mysteries... And gratitude from which Fve power to build Music the poem, and all they are witnesses of. Judith Kazantsis's new collection, The Rabbit Magician Plate (Sinclair-Stevenson , £7.99 pbk), is a two-edged lament for dvilisedness. Joseph - Columbus , on a "fog-filled , milky" hill "of many colours", plunders South America, prods the rotting crust of the dump and finds a glass bottle no one else found and sticks it in his plastic sack for resale. Indian children, "fluff before Custer "s hoofs, arechopped back" like weeds. Josephine Balmer, introducing her lovely translations of Sappho: Poems and Fragments (Bloodaxe, £6.95 pbk), suggests why it took so long for womens poetry to take fire in such themes. Sappho, "the tenth muse", was quoted most for relationship-poems : Love shook my heart like the wind on the mountain rushing over the oak trees. A specialisation crystallised in the famous fragment: Some say an army on horseback, some an army on foot, some say a fleet of ships is the loveliest sight... but I say, it is what you love. The direction and the weight of this specialisation were both transformed first by Wright's generation, which began, at least, to explode prejudices (exemplified by Sappho's male readers, and beautifully analysed by Balmer) in response to women's poetry through the ages. Women — acknowledged as leading poets , in countries where poets voice political issues compellingly — now use love and myth in the service of the personal and the political . In Wrighf s poetry above all, "what you love" is land and all it signifies. Land's rights ; rights of its people. Terra not nullius, but firma. Image of Wrighfs own, bone-clean poetry .
Rath Padel

Author: Turner, Martin
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
"... and we are what was His... " He was bom as usual, a narrow escape, and forced through the canal of childhood. Strip mining and rocky winters had worried at the moon-charred foothills. The journey was always going to be stations, the destination spectacular, a house with nocturnal fires in every window. Then the fight was on for lives not his own. Quite willing to be unjust himself. he hated judges, not injustice. His own loneliness rose everywhere unforgivingly like palisades. The motorbike made sense when it stopped. A jot of movement then was enough. Even marriage was okay till the solder broke. the usual asiatic alloy. It was plain truth at last, the kind he'd always fought for and agreed to find. With no news pending, no stories to declare. but only a tenderness that would remain untimely, even precipitous . so that they asked themselves. "Just where did it come from, this inexplicable passion, how did it arise?" . he was discarded by the myth-blown tribe. Still his passage was too swift for them. a lyre-toting centaur, drumming the trails. bearing immense anthems for the trial by light.
BOB DYLAN by Martin Turner

Author: Sweeney, Matthew
Title: New poetry
Full_text: New poetry SURPLUS LIGHT by Matthew Sweeney Could be the making of your marriage, or of your divorce. Try it at dusk, when it comes into its own. Sit there at my window with the curtains open, as daylight shrinks behind silhouettes of buildings like my own. See how its headstart leaves the others standing (which, of course, they are), even though one hour later the/re a staggered line of lit streetlights on a night street. Hard for you, I expect, to imagine the effect on the nerves of witnessing such relentless light, of seeing it take on the sun and wear it down. That's apart from its unlikely beauty — my iron star-tree I could call it but I won't. And to think that I rang the Council to complain! What are rates compared to this gift of surplus light, this permanent reminder of wastage?

Author: Biffen, John
Title: Sarky tyke with a taste for the sublime
Full_text:
Sarky tyke with a taste for the sublime
T his is an anthology of the prose and poetry that has provided pleasure and inspi - ration to Denis Healey throughout his life . The bulk of the book is provided by the author's chosen literature. His connecting text is modest but helps illuminate a singularly successful political career that stopped only just short of becoming leader of the Labour Party. It also makes dear that his rumbustious and occasionally vul - gar public reputation was just a veneer containing an intellect that clearly overshadowed his Balliol contemporaries , Roy Jenkins and Edward Heath. The anthology is pleasurable on account of the literature selected and also for the insight it pro - vides of Denis Healey outside the world of politics. The author's choice includes a number of lesser known poets. In particular he underlines the virtues of the work of Emily Dickinson who "can pack more meaning into forty words than some writers get into forty
pages". . Another favoured author is Thomas Traherne, a mid - nth - century shoemaker's son , whom Healey discovered whilst an Oxford undergraduate. He writes: "since then I have returned to him again
! MY SECRET PLANET By Denis Healey MichaelJoseph, £16.99 and again for inspiration." The passage chosen! for My Secret Planet comes j from one of Traheme's "Meditations" and con - cerns the "wonder of childhood". It is powerfully written but without cloying sentimentality. In addition to the relatively unknown poets Healey also acknowledges the in - fluence of the familiar names including Gerard Manley Hopkins and Dylan Thomas.
One of the attractions of the book is that the prose and poetry come from a balance of contributions, ranging from the very familiar to the relatively unknown. Inevitably the book will be examined to find some explanation of Healey's polit - ical career. His outstanding scho - lastic successes at Oxford had prepared him for an academic future. It was not to be. He served in the second world war, seeing action in Italy, but "when I was demobilized I decided not to write my great work on aesthetics as a don at Oxford, but to
go into politics — since there seemed no other way of helping directly to prevent a Third World War". Healey makes clear that his socialism was of a general kind, related to the concept of the brotherhood of man. It is also evident that his flirtation with communism at Oxford was very much the effervescence of a lively intellect The book, both in the author's commentary and the anthology, confirms that Healey, as defence secretary and Chancellor of the Exchequer, was a pragmatic right-of-centre politician. That fortunately, does not pre -
vent the occasional sarcastic broad - side that discomfited his oppo - nents . In the section on boyhood he discusses the William books of Ricmal Crompton. "Violet Eliza - beth , with her constant threat to 'thcream and thcream' till she's sick, seemed all too credible, though it was late in my life when I first came across the type in reality — and then in Downing Street." The main fascination of the book lies outside Healey's political career . The sections of the antholo - gy devoted to the Arts and Nature are particularly rewarding. The author writes "Oxford , the war, and politics all taught me the limita -
tions of scientific reason as a guide to human beings. Fortunately I have always found the arts an inexhaustible source, not only of pleasure , but also of knowledge and understanding ." These sentiments inspire some readable and risible excerpts. Notable is Berlioz's de - scription of Liszt giving an after - dinner speech at a banquet in Prague. Its inclusion is as unexpec ted as it is amusing. Denis Healey acknowledges the importance of the countryside and nature . His Yorkshire upbringing was urban but closely linked to the stark grandeur of the nearby moors. Inevitably this has resulted in an appreciation of such well
known rural chroniclers as Kilvert and Housman, but Healey also acknowledges the work of Tony Harrison, a contemporary Leeds poet and John Clare. The latter was a Northamptonshire peasant writing in the early 19th century. His poem , beginning "I love at early mom from new mown swath to see the startled frog its route pursue", simply sparkles. It is a further example of how the lesser known authors add lustre to an anthology that ranges from classi - cal to contemporary times and from the great names to the obscure. Of course the question abides whether or not the anthology
reveals the author. There is pro - foun d sensitivity, when Healey describes the death of his mother and again in the anguish of Virginia Woolfs letter on her impending madness; there is a profound love of the arts and countryside, and there is great intellectual confidence in a mastery of philosophy . All this seems some - what at odds with the bruising politician that Westminster came to know, respect and half fear over his 40 years in the Commons. I am prepared to believe that My Secret Planet does reveal an authentic Denis Healey, and if it does not then the anthology is a thoroughly good read in its own right
JohnBiffen I
Denis Healey: man of parts

Author: Crawford, Robert
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
ILLNESS
Illness drives a new road through your life. You lie beside its cars and trucks. It has its own quiet spells, rush-hours , Buzzing where there were fields, Everyone in the cars looks fit and well As they speed towards the reshaped horizon, But exhaust leaks from village-sized lorries, Making you cough, shortening your sentences To a few words. Tail-lights wink in the dark. One moment you see them, then the next. From Talkies, Chatto & Windus, £5.99 paperback
by Robert Crawford

Author: Null
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
I'M CONTEMPLATED BY A PORTRAIT OF A DIVINE by Jo Shapcolt
I cannot speak to you. My lips are fused where an archangel kissed them. I have never made much of myself although I know, sometimes, that space is touching me because I have seen the crack in the universe through which the galaxies stream. O God. I will always know how to walk, no rest, until it just ends in blackness when I fall down flat. I have one arching eyebrow: my whole life is in that eyebrow where an angel nestles at the root of every hair, raising it up. Dear Christ. I can hear vice rushing through
the grass. There is someone here. If I could lick the glass clean from this side, I might sec her, though I already know she would look the way I want my soul to look. This pose which I strain to keep, in which I lean on the desk for dear life, is not a pose. It's so important for keeping the drawer shut in case my heart should slip out. fly up. From Phrase Book, published next week by Oxford University Press. £5.99

Author: Kavanagh, P. J.
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
NO MORE SONGS by PJ. Kavanagh The only thing in the world, apart from God. that matters Is money. Not the accumulation or the gaining but The possession of it. Only then can we enjoy the world. There remains the problem of those who have none. Or not enough , who surround us (should we have some). These it is difficult not to resent, and then there is God On his only recorded appearance who was hot Against having or thinking about it; also against resentment. This is a puzzle: for when we study the blackbird And muse on its life and our own, such leisure Costs money, which it is dangerous to have and not To have is measurably worse, so that envy Of everywhere-blackbirds , heads cocked, watching us, turns To a mixed sort of sorrow when innocent unmoneyed life Ends in the jaws of the cat and no more songs for that one. From .An Enchantment , Carcanet

Author: Read, Herbert
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
This high-caught hooded Reason broods upon my wrist, Fetter'd by a so tenuous leash of steel. We are bound for the myrtle marshes, many leagues away. And have a fair expectation of quarry. Over the laggard dove, inclining to green boscage Hovers this intentional doom — till the unsullied sky receives A precipitation of shed feathers And the swifter fall of wounded wings. Will the plain aye echo with that loud hullallo! Or retain an impress of our passage? We have caught Beauty in a wild foray And now the falcon is hooded and comforted away.
THE FALCON AND THE DOVE By Herbert Read

Author: Null
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
LIVING IN THE HILLS: IMPROMPTU VERSES By Wang Wei I close my brushwood door in solitude And face the vast sky as late sunlight falls. The pine trees: cranes are nesting all around. My wicker gate: a visitor seldom calls. The tender bamboo's dusted with fresh powder. Red lotuses strip off their former bloom. Lamps shine out at the ford, and everywhere The water-chestnut pickers wander home. PARTING AT A WINESHOP IN NANJING By U Bai Breeze bearing willow-cotton fills the shop with scent. A Wu girl , pouring wine, exhorts us to drink up. We Nanjing friends are here to see each other off. Those who must go, and those who don't, each drains his cup. Go ask the Yangtze, which of these two sooner ends: Its waters flowing east — the love of parting friends. MOONLIT NIGHT By Du Fu In Fuzhou, far away, my wife is watching The moon alone tonight, and my thoughts fill With sadness for my children, who can't think Of me here in Changan; they re too young still. Her cloud-soft hair is moist with fragrant mist. In the clear light her white arms sense the chill. When will we feel the moonlight dry our tears. Leaning together on our window-sill ? Translated by Vikram Seth

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Exiled by militant rhyme
Full_text:
Exiled by militant rhyme
C hinese poetry is usually pre - sented in the most disas - trously heavy and off-putting way in English. A scholarly introduc - tion fills most of the book: a few tiny ribbons of text, each of them trailing notes, resemble so many jellyfish; and at least one hefty appendix at the end. It looks like an attempt to extinguish these tiny poems with prose; to imitate on paper the vast and inhospitable spaces of the Middle Kingdom: to enforce on the poems conditions of bureaucratisation, exile and separa - tion like those endured by the poets in their lifetimes. Even though Vikram Seth is more a poet than a Sinologist, he follows a similar pattern in his Three Chinese Poets. A slender selection of 36 translations from the three 8th - century masters, Wang Wei, Li Bai and Du Fu (more familiar as Li Po and Tu Fu) is bulked up by his own naivdy informative prose. If this is I disappointing, it is nothing compared to the disappointment with the style of the translations, which might be des - cribed as Californian Georgian. Seth, best known for his bestselling novel in verse, The Golden Gate, is an apologist for what Americans call Forma] Poetry. The Formals proclaim the old virtues of metre and rhyme and, er, storytelling. One should not JJ expect coherence from a warcry.
THREE CHINESE POETS By Vikram Seth Faber ,£l2.99/£6.99pbk a
.^ Three Chinese Poets was under - taken by Seth partly in homage to three great translators. Richard Wil - bur (Moliere). Charles Johnston (Pushkin) and Robert Fitzgerald (Homer). Their fields were comic dramatic and epic verse. However in I tackling lyric Seth overreaches him - self and reaches for the wrong tools. I have nothing against rhyme as such, only against Fundamentalism, Militant Rhyme, and the supposition that if something rhymes it must be good. You get bad poems that rhyme and bad poems that do not. Rhyme is not what sorts them out, and neither is it an infallible way of producing good writing. Rhyme is a robust effect, and lends itself to comic effects. Byron and Shelley were contem -
| poraries and in-laws of sorts, but it is the Byronic line that has prevailed, and Shelley's ghostly fluency has never been matched since. Of all poetry I know. Chinese is the i weakest — it has least strength and I most beauty. It seems to me that rhyme, even when ideal Shelleyan rhyme, is inimical to it, and Seth's is far from ideal. His quatrains are as I coarse and knocked-together as i wooden crates. These sparest, most I perfect of poems, where every line, j every pen-stroke must be just-so , are | horribly over-punctuated , they arc padded to make the syllable-count come out right, their diction is barren, crude and compromised and they are without atmosphere and aroma. Chinese poetry in English can never be "real "; it is an invention of the translator and so tends to chinoiserie. Some of the best "Chinese" writing is deeply inauthentic it is by Pound, or in German it is by Brechu it is Joseph Brodsky's marvellous Letters from the Ming Dynasty , Derek Mahon's Japa - i ncsc The Snow Party, or John Berryman's Note to Wang Wei. "Chinese" is a style, a metaphor , a content, a resource of English. What Seth has done, in presenting what he I thinks arc echt and conservative j tr anslations, is incomparably worse: I he has written merely some dire and I dapped-out anglaiserie.
Michael Hofmann

Author: Raine, Kathleen
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
STAR-BORN
What music of what star Did Schubert hear? What celestial power Touched Shelley's lyre? What heavenly order Raised spires of stone, Moulded sculptured gesture Of Gothic saint and king? Dear human voices, Faces loved and known, From what unseen realm Is that beauty bom? From Living with Mystery
By Kathleen Raine

Author: Horovitz, Michael
Title: Mapping the Gaelic landscape
Full_text:
Mapping the Gaelic landscape
THE FABER BOOK OF TWENTIETH-CENTURY SCOTTISH POETRY Edited by Douglas Dunn Faber, £17 .50 ?- iar ... MacDiarmid made a lan - guage as he wrote". But unlike Joyce, the aesthetic exile, MacDiarmid lived in Scotland all his life, and restored a native lyric conscience that had lain dormant. MacDiarmid tried to amalgamate an extraordinary compound of nationalism, communism and avant - gardism , and remains the most influential figure in Scottish poetry since Burns. But his ideas and achievements were fraught with so many contradictions that his omni - presence is expressed through the ways in which others diverged from his example. In addition to the Scots of MacDiarmid, Robert Garioch, Syd -
T his selection accommodates 400 pages of poems by 72 poets, from Scotland's proto - modernist John Davidson (born in 1857) to a clutch of robust experi - mentalists in their early thirties. Douglas Dunn's erudite introduction outlines the diverse metamorphoses poetry has undergone north of the border since T.S. Eliot wrote that "there is no longer any tenable distinction to be drawn" between Scottish and English literature. That was in 1919, when Andrew Young, William Soutar and Edwin Muir, the other pioneers impressively repre - sented here — and, most substan - tially , with 35 pages, Hugh
MacDiarmid — were only beginning to sharpen their deliberately sepa - ratist pens. In 1923 MacDiarmid scented a "strong moral resemblance" between Jamieson's 1808 Etymological Die tionary of the Scottish Language and Joyce's Ulysses. For the following decade, he forged most of his verse in the long disused smithy of Synthetic Scots and the vernacular Lallans (so - called because it deployed words and expression from the dialects of low - land Scotland). Dunn explains that this is "a language in which old words are used in poetry with the force of neologisms, the shock of the unfamil -
ney Goodsir Smith, Tom Scott and others, and the Scottishly inflected English of most of Dunn's assembly , the third resonantly poetic language of Scotland this century is Gaelic. It can be heard here in manifold forms, with translations, from Derick Thom - son , Iain Crichton Smith and the wondrously bardic Sorley MacLean. V irtually every poem in the collection exemplifies — pace Eliot — a highly distinctive orality, precision and passion of word music. These are qualities shared by the continuing literatures of most tribal or folk cultures: East and West Indian poets and Jewish ones come to mind as articulating communities at once cosmopolitan, separatist and deeply imbued with race memory, and similarly enlivened with several idioms to draw from and extend. As Dunn says, and his anthology indicates, "most Scottish poetry, when compared to its English counterpart, stands in a closer
relationship to its potential audience" . Two of the more maverick writers featured are the Orcadian storyteller George Mackay Brown, and the incantatoryW.S. Graham. Two of the most eclectic mid-century makars are Norman MacCaig and the inter - nationalist Glaswegian Edwin Morgan. I was equally delighted by the variousness of resource, energy, style, wit and inventiveness on display in the latter sections of the book from Ivor Cutler, Alastair Reid, George MacBeth, Kenneth White, Alan Bold, Alison Fell, Brian McCabe and Carol
Ann Duffy. Liz Lochhead and Tom Leonard are among the contributors who deftly versify the uniquely abra - sive panache of Glasgow street life and speech rhythms. Despite what strikes me as a number of glaring omissions — the innovators Ian Hamilton Finlay and Thomas Clark, "inner space" explor - ers such as R.D. Laing, playwright - poets John and Tom McGrath, and songwriter-singer Robin Williamson — this is a richly instructive and enjoyable cornucopia. It demon - strates that, in the face of at least as much hardship and discontent as the rest of Britain, the muse is alive, well and kicking in Scotland.
Michael Horovitz

Author: Okri, Ben
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
NEWTON ENIGMAS by Ben Okri For Sir Michael Aliyah
It is not the nature of Light You teach us the relationship You taught us how with inward eyes That it grows. Beween the apple We can set T.me free But yours does. And gravity And d.scover the secret Between pebbles Mathematics of destiny. Your life is your gospel. And motion You made Time feed the earth Between Light We must always flow-right As we all should And infinity. With the eternity wuh.n. But you did it long You teach us that life And kept your parables silent. Light is your riddle Should always create Light Motion your song Forever and ever You walked with the giants of vision Humanity your earth Amen. And revealed to us God made visible your quest I The greater kingdom Infinity your dream. I Inmty/Los Angeles. May 1992 Of Natural Laws. This poem was written by Ben Okri to mark the 350th anniversary of the birth of Sir Isaac Newton. The poem was heard for the first time last night. when it was performed by the Trinity College choir at a Newton commemoration feast in Cambridge. The work was set to music by Richard Marlow . director of music at Trinity. Okri is fellow commoner in creative arts at Trinity, where Newton was a student and fellow. The poem was commissioned by Sir Michael Atiyah. the master of Trinity.

Author: Lewis, Cecil Day
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Now the peak of summer's past, the sky is overcast And the love we swore would last for an age seems deceit: Paler is the guelder since the day we first beheld her In blush beside the elder drifting sweet, drifting sweet. Oh quickly they fade — the sunny esplanade, Speed-boats , wooden spades, and the dunes where we've lain: Others will be lying amid the sea-pinks sighing For love to be undying, and they'll sigh in vain. It's hurrah for each night we have spent our love so lightly And never dreamed there might be no more to spend at all. It's goodbye to every lover who thinks he'll live in clover All his life, for noon is over soon and night-dews fall. If I could keep you there with the berries in your hair And your lacy fingers fair as the may, sweet may, I'd have no heart to do it, for to stay love is to rue it And the harder we pursue it, the faster it's away.
HORNPIPE by Cecil Day Lewis

Author: Wright, David
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
AN APPEARANCE OF SUCCESS
Some verses, written when he was alive, A poster broadcast on the Underground; My life (an actor plays him) televised: Fame of a kind, if not recognition; Pleasing enough but not enough to please An unambitiousness at seventy-one . Or pierce the unawareness of the dead: This present Fd have loved to give him To make amends, — My father — an appearance of success In his deaf difficult son; Something to recompense As may have seemed to him Rewardless and too long a sacrifice.
by David Wright

Author: Porter, Peter
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
When Hardy looked into his glass he saw A younger self of real not ghostly pain And knew the travelling law that youthful loss is framed as adult gain The reader reads and thinks he understands: He's still inside the huge machine which time Put in his parents' hands And staved on paper with confirming rhyme. They are themselves and so they can't be him, And somewhere as his ancestors retreat Intrusive Cherubim Make singular the general defeat. Always the present lingers in the glass. The lawn is mown and soon the daisies rise Above the new-mown grass And looking in the mirror blanks the eyes. from The Chair of Babel Porter here pays tribute to Thomas Hardy's I Look Into My Glass, a poem about youthful passion's incongruous survival in old age.
GO SOME OF YOU, AND FETCH A LOOKING-GLASS By Peter Porter

Author: Lewis, Peter
Title: This poetry is not for spurning
Full_text:
THEATRE: INTERVIEW
This poetry is not for spu rn i ng
Playwright Christopher Fiy talks to Peter Lewis about his success, years of British neglect and a revival at Chichester
W hen Christopher Fry's verse play, Venus Ob - serve d , opens at Chich - ester Festival Theatre tomorrow, it will be its first perfor - mance in a major theatre for more than 40 years. It will also be an opportunity to reconsider the fervent esteem in which Fry's work was held then, and its neglect since. Venus Observed was commis - sioned by Sir Laurence Olivier to begin his tenure as actor-manager of the now long-defunct St James's Theatre in January, 1950. In the same month, Fry's name was on the boards outside two more London theatres. At the Globe, Ring Round the Moon, his translation from Anouilh with Margaret Rutherford; Paul Scofield and Claire Bloom, followed straight upon The Lady's Not for Burning, in which Pamela Brown and John Gielgud had been the toast of the town. Gielgud had moved to the Lyric Hammersmith, to direct Fry's ear li - er play. The Boy With A Cart, in which the boy, the future St Cuthman, was played by the young Richard Burton. Fry was the writer in demand by actors and directors. "I was rather jealous that he had given his new play to Larry instead of me," recalled Gielgud of Venus Observed.
The play had to be written to the deadline of Olivier's opening night, as Fry remembers: "I had promised to send him a draft of the second act and when it failed to arrive, I received a parcel containing a typewriter ribbon, a brush for the keys and a note from Olivier 'If there is anything else you need, let me know. I'm not making you nervous, am I?' The trouble was that Peter Brook had simultaneously talked me into translating Ring Round the Moon for him to direct." Fry managed to finish the play but was never quite happy with Venus Observed. "I always prom - ised myself that if I lived long enough I would revise it nearer my liking. When I heard of plans for this revival I said, only if I can make some changes. I didn't find it difficult to get back into it after 40
years. In some ways I feel I know how to do some things a bit better now, at 84, than I did before." You believe him , for he looks unmarked by time, exactly resem - bling his photographs of at least 20 years ago. He has a nut-brown , co in - sharp profile, that of an alert but peaceable Roman emperor. Fry's revisions for Chichester have reshaped the play in two acts instead of three, cutting passages and remodelling one character. The play begins with an ageing duke, in his private observatory, deciding to marry at last and settle down with one of his former mistresses — until a new young beauty swims into his ken and awakens his old yearnings for pastures new. The ducal castle
Try's lines are not strictly verse (being without regular metre), but rhythmic prose, cut up into lines of four or five beats' setting and socially superior charac - ters are worlds away from most modem English drama, even if the theme — love in youth and- age — is timeless. But what utterly differentiates a Fry play from anything that fol - lowed the Royal Court revolution is his extravagantly non-naturalistic use of language. With Fry, dialogue is employed to make music, to pursue conceits of imagery and also to make sport in verbal games of high-spirited metaphor, puns and sudden drops into comic bathos. It is not the way people communi - cate on buses or television, but it was the way language was employed on the stage from Marlowe to Dryden. Fry's lines are not strictly verse, being without regular metre. They
are rhythmic prose, cut up into lines of four or five beats, lines which are undetectable when spoken, except for the spring they impart to his long and complex sentences. Poetry, Fry once wrote, "has the virtue of being able to say twice as much as prose in half the time" . But, he added, if you don't pay attention carefully, it may seem to say half as much in twice the time. "I 've never liked the term 'verse drama'," he says. "It sounds terribly stuffy, doesn't it? Really you are trying to find the language that says what you want to say. When I began writing, it was hardly a new departure. Yeats and Masefield, Auden and Isher - wood , MacNeice and Eliot had been writing poetic plays from the early years of the century." Like T.S. Eliot Fry began writing
drama for performance in church. The Boy With a Cart was originally given in his local parish church in Sussex in 1938. He was influenced by Eliot's Murder in the Cathedral. Later he wrote Thor With Angels for Canterbury cathedral. The encouragement of his friend Robert Gittings and of Eliot himself helped Fry develop, at the age of 40, from being a part-time theatre director and odd-job man into perhaps the leading playwright of the postwar deeade. And then suddenly, after a dozen years, it was over. His plays, like Eliot's, Rattigan 's and Coward's, were swept into limbo by the critical and popular enthusiasm for plays of social indignation from Osborne, Wesker, Arden, and absurdist dra - ma from Beckett, Ionesco and Pinter.
For Fry, the limbo lasted for decades and the hostility shown to verse drama dried up the wells of his inspiration. Even in 1954 Kenneth Tynan was writing: "If Mr Eliot and Mr Fry can be persuaded away from their martyrdom in a lost cause, the theatre would benefit." Fry's subsequent plays, The Dark Is Light Enough and Curtmantle, took him longer and longer to write and raised comparatively little en - thusiasm , even some derision. All that poetic stuff, it was implied, was
very as an escape post - war austerity but that time had passed . "I lost confidence," he says now. "I didn't know what theatre I was writing for. I sat at the typewriter wondering who wanted what I could provide. I felt more or less unwelcome." So neglect set in. When Mrs Thatcher announced of herself that "the lady's not for turning," how many people recognised that her speechwriter was borrowing the phrase from the title of a Christo - pher Fry play? He looks back on what must have been a shattering reversal of fortune with the philosophic detachment of a Quaker , untinged by bitterness. The gap was filled partly by film - writing — Ben Hur, Barabbas and
The Bible—a television series on the Brontes, and a new play about Caedmon, One Thing More, on radio. But apart from radio and amateur productions, the plays have lan - guished except abroad. Eastern Europe, when communist, pro - duced them and in America they are campus favourites. Fry has recently returned from lecturing American students; a full-scale study of his plays by Brenda Leeming has been published by Twayne of Boston. Was it a lost cause or is the tide turning? Are audiences ready to re - discover the taste for poetic drama they had 30-40 years ago? James Roose-Evans , who directs Venus Observed at Chichester with Donald Sinden in the Olivier part of the
Duke, is convinced that the time for a Fry revival has arrived. Why should stage poetry only be appreciated in reaction to wartime deprivation? Fry , with characteristic modesty and mildness, is reluctant to talk in terms of changes of taste. "Why does there have to be only one ruling taste? Literature has room not only for fiction but for biography and poetry as well. Why can't we have theatre which contains the poetic as well as other approaches to life? Surely the important thing is that there should be every kind of theatre." Venus Observed begins previews from tomorrow at Chichester Festival Theatre (0243 781312) and opens there on May 27, continuing in repertory untilJuly 30
all well from Fry: leading playwright of the postwar decade, now seeing his Venus Observed revived after 40 years

Author: Grayes, Ida Affleck
Title: New Poetry
Full_text:
New Poetry
This so-and-so of a man has the tidy eye on My Poppies. Terrifies them, threatens to throw in, Along with cabbage rot and mish-mash of old skins And fly buzzing decay of our old sorrows All all their scarlet flounces and swollen black suns This so-and-so swears they now need the chop, These poppies, weed rubbish and trample for the tip, Why oh why when the scarlet stuns you for love of it. When buds know it, droop and hang meek to the blow. Leave them alone, you, or I go too. THE SWALLOW Late, so foolishly too late, but dizzy with faith She cements her nest with an old myth She unravels rags from a power-cable . Danger in the porch and so vulnerable. Mud and spit and energy of her throat The fanatic's flight of a desert route. Obstinate, high-diving among cars, lorries And motor-bikes , the fool knows no worries. Though the sun expires, hers the lunatic truth Of a blind, a soon gaping yellow mouth. Ida Affleck Graves is a poet and a novelist. Her first poems were published by Leonard and Virginia Woolfs Hogarth Press in the Twenties and she is still writing today, after a long and distinguished career. These recent verses have never been published before.
POPPIES by Ida Affleck Graves

Author: Smith, Iain Crichton
Title: New Poetry
Full_text:
New Poetry
TWO GIRLS SINGING by Iain Crichton Smith It neither was the words nor yet the tune Any tune would have done and any words. Any listener or no listener at all. As nightingales in rocks or a child crooning in its own world of strange awakening or larks for no reason but themselves. So on the bus through late November running by yellow lights tormented, darkness falling, the two girls sang, for miles and miles together. And it wasn't the words or the tune. It was the singing. It was the human sweetness in that yellow, the unpredicted voices of our kind.

Author: Thom, Gunn
Title: New Poetry
Full_text:
New Poetry
Now as I watch the progress of the plague, The friends surrounding me fall sick, grow tiiin. And drop away. Bared, is my shape less vague Sharply exposed and with a sculpted skin? I do not like the statue's chill contour Not nowadays. The warmth investing me Led outward through mind, limb, feeling, and more In an involved increasing family. Contact of friend led to another friend, Supple entwinement through the living mass Which for all that I knew might have no end. Image of an unlimited embrace. I did not just feel ease, though comfortable: Aggressive as in some ideal of sport With ceaseless movement thrilling through the whole, Their push kept me as firm as their support. But death — their deaths have left me less defined: It was their pulsing presence made me clear. I borrowed from it, I was unconfined, Who tonight balance unsupported here. Eyes glaring from raw marble, in a pose Languorously part-buried in the block, Shins perfect and no calves, as if I froze Between potential and a finished work. Abandoned incomplete, shape of a shape, In which exact detail shows the more strange, Trapped in unwholeness, I find no escape Back to the play of constant give and change. Taken from The Man with Night Sweats
THE MISSING by Thorn Gunn

Author: Johnson, Daniel
Title: old devils must care for poetry and truth
Full_text:
Old devils must care for poetry and truth
Sir Kingsley Amis's most ambitious novel revolves round a bad Russian poet and an old-fashioned don, says Daniel Johnson
His publisher will hate me for saying so, but at its deepest level The Russian Girl is about neither Russia nor girls. Poetry and truth, Dichtung und Wahrheit, Goethe called his autobiography Kingsley Amis might have recycled that title for this* his most ambitious novel. Whether the book succeeds or not whether this is Amis at his best (and that, for my money, is better than anybody else's best), depends on whether poetry and truth matter any
supposed to be the guardians. This retreat from the lofty bastions of scholarship has nothing to do with "funding" but everything to do with cowardice in the face of militant intellectual egalitarianism. For those who do give a damn, Amis has in store intelligent in - si g hts into the decay of intelligence: a dialogue so dazzling, indeed , that those who find themselves among his targets may even enjoy their own discomfiture. But there is emphatically no conclusion, no statement .
more: to us and to one another. Amis, of course, thinks that they do.
THE RUSSIAN GIRL By Kingsley Amis Hutchinson, £14.99
Though its sat - ire is even more sulphuric than usual, The Russian Girl works on a plane normally reserved for a genre Amis probably despises: the "novel of ideas." He makes the plot of a conventional story about adultery (English academic married, falls for sexy Russian poet who has enlisted his help on behalf of her imprisoned brother) turn on the evanescence of truth in an age in which there are people who do not know "what meaning what you say means. Everything's just saying what you say." He cares, too, about a state of affairs in which the novel has submitted to an unfriendly take - over bid by politics — "No fiction, no art, just statements" — and in which England is a last refuge "where admittedly a lot of fellows would like the novelist to be writing autobiography or social history or gossip rather than fiction, but what's left will last a little while yet" Not many, perhaps, give a damn about that. Amis has some fun with the debasement of the cognitive coinage of which universities are
demic conform - ists , champagne socialists, phonies of all kinds — will find plenty of ammunition here. But Amis deals just as harshly with his representa tives of poetry and truth, all of whom are flawed , especially the chief characters: the Russian girl , Anna Danilova , writes bad poetry and her suitor , Richard Vaisey, sacrifices his integrity by pretend - ing that it is not. Poetry and truth share a tend - ency to be incompatible with most kinds of modern life, and in the remaining few they seem incom - patible with each other. Richard is a scholar — in Amis's estimation, a man who has either consecrated his life to the truth, or is a parasitical fraud . Vaise/s intellectual life rests on fidelity to Russian literature, his emotional life rests on fidelity to his wife Cordelia, and his material existence rests on her inherited wealth. He later discovers that his sanity actually depends on his friends: Cordelia's previous hus - band Godfrey and his brother Crispin in particular. Once Anna has forced herself,
alive and insistent into the inner sanctum hitherto occupied by a literature that is merely immortal, Richard's fragile equilibrium col - lapses . He cannot reconcile the mediocrity of her poetry with her radiant truthfulness except by abandoning the premise without which his critical faculties are neutralised. "Yes , but is she any good, is he any good." No longer to be "a stickler for merit" means that his life in pursuit of truth in poetry is over. Cordelia's physical assault on the trappings of that now invalid-vocation propels Richard into the — for him no less exiguous — adventure of life with - out scholarship, but with Anna.
Cordelia, the chief villain, is a vintage Amis character. Her. fright - fulness is capable of enveloping such innocent operations as pour - in g tea or making a telephone call. The emptiness of her life is a familiar theme. She scores over earlier Amis she-devils in her knowingness, her bullying conde scension, her refusal to exact re venge until she is good and ready. Cordelia is a monster not on account of her irritating voice and habits but because she banishes even the possibility of poetry and truth from her presence. The action is precisely dated in June 1990, and Amis is withering about the reactions evoked here by
the death throes of Soviet commu - nism . One of his best comic figures is Sir Stephen, a fashionable archi - tect whom Richard and Anna try to enlist for their petition. This novel owes much to Robert Conquest, whose poetry inspired Amis in the 1950s and whose prescient books on the Soviet genocides did so much to ensure that some people in the West never lost sight of the evils of the Soviet empire. Mention of the early Amis brings me to the two reprints which coincide with The Russian Girl. A Kingsley Amis Omnibus (Hutchin - son , £15.99) brings together three of his later novels —Jake 's Thing, Stanley and the Women and The
Old Devils — while Penguin have reissued his first, Lucky Jim (£5.99), with an introduction by David Lodge . The new book stands comparison with the funniest of these, Lucky Jim and The Old Devils,- and colonises new regions of experience untouched by either. Amis is now peerless among ser ious British novelists, rivalled only (and quite distantly) by his son Martin in breadth and by nobody in depth. Recognized at last by Mrs Thatcher's knighthood, decent to the young and more convivial than some might think, Amis is yet still an angry and isolated figure. An arresting passage in The Russian Woman has Richard stuck in a
traffic jam outside "a large building of Victorian date" near Trafalgar Square — surely the Garrick. The porters escort an old man, "weep - ing copiously" down the steps to find him a taxi. Amis does not look forward to his dotage. But there is no sign of any diminution in his powers — rather the reverse. Next week he is seventy. The Russian Girl, in which he hits the top of his form, suggests that old Kingsley will continue to sur - prise us all. TOMORROW Valerie Grove talks to Sir Kingsley Amis
Whoever objects to Amis's ani - mus — against self-pitying women, aca-

Author: Null
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
ROBERT NYE: Going to the Dogs Come Friday night my father's public vice Was a greyhound track. He took me there twice. Most of his life his own sad way he went, So going to the dogs with me was different. The electric hare, the eager racing hounds, Tic tacs in their white gloves, fistfuls of pounds — The magic of that place and its event! Oh, to me going to the dogs was different. To choose a trap my poor Dad bruised his wits Perusing form, and when that failed had fits Of asking me my fancies. What this meant For us made going to the dogs quite different. Once the choice dog in the pre-race parade Excreted what looked like bad marmalade. "A sign," my father said, "from heaven sent! You do know going to the dogs is different?" He'd urge his favourite home with passionate cries. The keenest still brings tears into my eyes: "Come on, my son!" It was an accident Which our dear going to the dogs made different. I can't remember what my old man won; God knows he lost much more in the long run. His coat was shabby and his hat was bent, But going to the dogs I found him different. I do recall my father shook my hand When our dog came in first. Now understand: Some of us gamble when our hearts are spent. My going to the dogs is not so different. From A Collection of Poems 1955-1988 , Abacus, £4.99 paperback

Author: Griffiths, Eric
Title: Poetry on a precipice
Full_text:
Poetry on a precipice ^& . VIS1ONBANK
Eric Griffiths praises a biography £of the tormented'Gerard Manley Hopkins for its tact and insight
F ather Hopkins had a remarkable head for heights. A fellow Jesuit kept a pet monkey which es - caped one day and ran along the guttering on the . West Front of Siojiyhurst College. Hopkins climbed out and walked along the narrow ledge to where the monkey was.He coaxed it to within reach aijcLthen led it back through the wj. ndow. Those who know the West Er&r/f.at Stonyhurst will realise the steadiness of nerve which that in - vjai ye 'd. As a child, he was/often up a tree? He sketched the abysmal chines Qf ,, the Isle of Wight, shinned a goalpost to cheer a miserable pupil, andMiked to climb Jeffrey Hill in L' a 'ncashire. ''His' poetry too is undizzied but
precipitous: ^ jCjX the mind mind has moun tqj,ris; cliffs of fall ^Frightful, sheer nb-mdn-fathomed Hold; them cheap "May who ne'e ,
HOPKINS A Literary Biography By Norman White OUP.E3S
hung,there. •^ specially in his later life, Hop - kins frequently "hung there", over bjackp depression and a sense of his 6\vn" vacancy; the "desolate" or "tenable" sonnets, in which he cepor ,ded such experiences, are now (nuch admired. They commend tjienjselves to fans of Sylvia Plath. VT^e truly admirable thing about tfiesie'- poems is less noticed — their "steadiness of nerve", the fact that nip;nqt only "hung there" but hung on'm ' there. This steadiness is ethical ds'Jwell as rhythmic as when, feeling a't ;-his witsV.end — "cry I can no mjjre- ' — he found the wit rather to say:: ', *' l can;/Can isomething, hope, wish "day come, not choose not to bi' /V ' That "I can' at the end of the lif/e ^steels itself (to go on living, answers Hamletjs question about suicide ("To be, or not to be" ) with a respuhding double negative: "I can .'.. ' ,. 'hot choose not to be." " :in ' his tormerit, he thought not oirify&f Hamlet but also of Cardinal faey/man, for "I can no more" came to him from Newman's portrait of a good Catholic death in The Dream of G' erontius , when the dying hero thinks he is finally exhausted: "I can no more; fori now it comes again,/That sense of ruin, which is worse than pain." That both Hamlet and Newman occurred to Hopkins is one reason why he presents difficulties for many readers: he lived in two worlds which have not Had much to do with' each Other for a long time: the _ worlds of Efiglish Roman Catholicism and of literary genius. Depending on
which sphere the commentator comes from, writing about Hopkins tends either to the pious or the impious, and neither version com - prehends what it is to have, as he had, a devout imagination. Norman White's new biography is, then^ all the more welcome. It is deeply researched arid deftly writ - ten , brims overwith tact and insight ; nobody has written better about Hopkins's care for the minutiae of natural history. He marshals so many details so well, from the menu of Balliol College in the 1860s .("rissoles , 9d, half a goose, 1 s 3d" ) to the state of the drains from which Hopkins probably caught the ty - phoid he died of. This is a work of studied love for its subject; there is unlikely to be a more scrupulous
biography of the poet in my lifetime. And yet the book is speckled with misplaced self - con - fidences . It tells us what Victorian Englishmen thought about the
Irish, though Carlyle, a Scot, is not a convincing source to quote for English views, just as Tennyson's poems of the 1840s are poor evidence for the claim that "many poets in the 1870s and early 1880s were obsessed by the mystical significance of twilight". These are venial errors, but they hint at something wrong in the air of the book, like the musty smell which may betray dry rot. The actual rot nestles in this author's unexamined assurance that he knows what's what about his own period and so can pronounce about the past. ' Hopkins wrote several poems in praise of soldiers, including "Yes . Why do we all, seeing of a soldier, bless him?" White flatly declares this poem "embarrassing to modern minds" . I don't like it much myself, -but the first duty of literary people is to exercise imagination. Identifying one's own mind with the modern mind is a habit of the intelligentsia, a bad habit, and a bad place to start on the more subtle task of imagining the past. We most long for security about the ultimate and the intimate — I mean religion and sex — and consequently are least imaginative about these matters. To be imagi - native takes "steadiness of nerve". White's nerve understandably fails him, facing Hopkins in whom these two tricky factors are multiplied by each other. Though White strives a bit to be fair-minded , he will not manage to be even that until he learns to have, at least for a while, a
mind other than his own, and gives up, for instance, saying that Hop - kins was mistaken about how to deal with his own depression. If White really knew how to deal with de - pression , rather than just ticking Hopkins off, he would be a richer man than, I imagine, he is. When Hopkins taught classics to Irish Catholics, he did not skip the descriptions of rapes and suchlike; he would let the class read them and
afterwards hold up his hands and say "O those poor girls" . That took some nerve in the Dublin of those days. On the other hand, he wrote the great poem "To what serves mortal beauty —dangerous ... ?" in which White detects a "cer tain deviousness" because it argues that carnal beauty is perilous but is created by God as the mark of selfhood, and of God's love for the human soul, and therefore a fit
subject for the attention even ot a priest. On this matter, the poet had a more modern mind than his biog - rapher has, because one of the few goods blown to us on the ill wind of Aids is that we rediscover, in our world where it matters for sex to be "safe", the point to Hopkins's " dan - gerous " . Ars longa, vita brevis : this could now be translated as: "Art lasts, biographies pass away."
The chapel at Stonyhurst College , where Hopkins as a boy gave early evidence of a head for heights

Author: Cope, Wendy
Title: New poetry
Full_text:
New poetry
Kindness to Animals If I went vegetarian And didn't eat lambs for dinner, I think I'd be a better person And also thinner. But the lamb is not endangered And at least I can truthfully say I have never, ever eaten a barn owl, So perhaps I am OK. This poem was commissioned by the editor of The Orange Dove of Fiji, an anthology for the benefit of the World Wide Fund for Nature. It was rejected as unsuitable. An Unusual Cat-Poem My cat is dead But I have decided not to make a big tragedy out of it.
A Christmas Poem At Christmas little children sing and merry bells jingle, The cold winter air makes our hands and faces tingle And happy families go to church and cheerily they mingle And the whole business is unbelievably dreadful, if you're single. Poem Composed in Santa Barbara The poets talk. They talk a lot. They talk of T.S.Eliot. One is anti. One is pro. How hard they think! How much they know! They're happy. A cicada sings. We women talk of other things.
From Serious Concerns
FOUR SHORT POEMS by Wendy Cope

Author: Ackroyd, Peter
Title: Sweet journey to a land of floures and sunne
Full_text:
Sweet journey to a land of floures and sunne
E lias Ashmole, the 17th - cen - tury antiquary and scholar, chose to employ the ancient spelling of the documents he pub - lished because "Old words have strong Emphasis". It was a wise course then, and it is an even wiser one now, when the language has been tarnished by promiscuous use. It has become larger but more nebulous, so standardised and flattened that the decision of the editors to retain the original spelling and punctuation within this anthology of Renaissance poetry is a wholly necessary accomp - animent to what is in any case an enterprising selection. To "modernise" a poem is to corrupt and destroy it: boude has a
different circulation from blood, byrds and floures belong in older gardens than birds or flowers, and the sonn, sune, sunne or soonn is part of a different constellation from that of our own modern sun. The original words put the poems back in their vital context: this is also the aim of the anthology itself, which aspires not to some timeless heaven of poetical treasures but to the living culture in which the verse was fashioned. Of course the Renaissance, in an English setting, can mean anything or nothing; it covers a period that includes Doctor Dee and Thomas Hobbes , and runs the gamut (as this volume illustrates) from John Skelton to John Milton.
It was the period of the individual and the period of the modern state, the era of science and the era of alchemy, an age of inductive reason - ing and an age of vigorous super - stition ; like any age, therefore, it is indefinable except in terms of our
own contemporary preoccupations. Certainly such pre - occupations play a part in the making of this volume; there is more attention paid here to the work of
Peter Ackroyd THE PENGUIN BOOK OF RENAISSANCE VERSE Edited by David Norbrook and H.R. Woudhuysen Allen Lane. £25
female poets, for example, than in any previous anthology. But preoccupa - tions change. When the modernist writers and their academic disciples were advancing the concepts of "ambiguity" and "complexity ", it was the intellectual fashion to promote Donne and demote Milton; but that rage for difficulty has burnt itself out, and now the critical judgment is all but reversed. N evertheless, the contem - porary thematic structures which the editors have cho - sen do seem appropriate to their task. Some of the sections , "Topographies " and "The Public World" among them, make perfect sense of. the material, although there is something perhaps a little too post-modern about that one which deals with "the production of poetry itself. It is also instructive to have one part entirely devoted to the vexed question of poetic translation, even though more of Chapman's Homer would have been welcome.
Translation of course raises the even more vexed question of " English - ness " itself:, is there any recognisable or valuable continuity represented by these hundred or more poets? Is there some chronological resonance be - tween generations, to be observed in the continuation of a certain cadence or form? Is there, in other words,
some poetic equivalent to that "undulating double curve" which Nikolaus Pevsner lo - cated in The English - ness of English Art> . But the editors seem wary of any such
nationalistic approach: they have included Irish and Welsh poetry in the original and, in his preface, David Norbrook comments rather too ju - diciously on the dangers of "cultural imperialism". It has to be said that most of the poets included are cultural imperialists of one kind or another, because they were concerned to memorialise and celebrate their cul - ture ; Spenser and Milton, the two greatest poets represented here, considered the English to be the chosen race. Various other questions arise from this collection, not least the role of the poet and the status of his work. The
editors are reluctant to raise questions of value and instead provide some - thing close to a representative social range, as an alternative to that persistent over-emphasis upon aris - tocratic individuals and "private" lyrics which characterises earlier anthologies. In this they are remark - ably successful. Not only have they brought attention to poets who are generally disregarded — John Hey - wood , George Gascoigne, Richard Barnfield and Rachel Speght among them — but they have also provided space for some of the rarer long poems of the period: Ralegh's The One and Twentieth: and last hooke of
the Ocean to Scinthia is one example. So this is an intelligent and com - prehensive anthology, and not the
least of its virtues is the social and historical introduction provided by Norbrook. Here in condensed form is an account of why poetry matters in human society, as well as an explana - tion of the political dimension of all serious literature.
In a recent volume of essays Tom Paulin exposed the nervous pol - itical collusions at the centre of much modern English verse, and here the editors have been able to perform the same service for the poetry of the 16th and 17th centuries: there is hardly a ballad, and certainly not an epic or an ode, which is not part of the general dispensation of the time. They are able to trace the path of religious controversy both in Den - ham 's landscape and in Surrey's translations of Virgil; even in the world of sexual love, with its strident chorus of lyrics and sonnets, the "political issues" are still maintained. Yet such an emphasis can some - times lead to a certain heaviness of interpretation or analysis, and the
most significant omission here lies in the failure of the editors to examine the relationship between poetry and music in a period when, arguably they reached the finest point of complementarity. There is not a word here about Byrd, and only one song is taken from Dowland's Second booke of songs or ayres, without any explanation of Dowland's impor - tance . This complaint aside (and where would Renaissance poetry be without its complaints?) ThePenguin Book of Renaissance Verse can be commended for the subtlety and care with which an extraordinary literary period has been restored.

Author: Shapcott, Jo
Title: Anti-oldies find a voice
Full_text:
Anti-oldies find a voice
In 1969 Michael Horo - witz edited the anthology Children of Albion: Poet - ry ] of the Underground in Britain for Penguin. The sequel and showcase for the next generation, Grandchil - dren of Albion: An Illustrat - ed Anthology of Voices and Visions of Younger Poets in Britain, is, Horovitz claims, only one of several sequels he has in mind. Large dreams, great visions fuel this enterprise. Horovitz has fought his battles through the Albion anthologies, his New Departures editions and the Poetry Olympics readings which he started in 1980 "to restore adventure, enjoyment, answerability and interna - tionalism to a climate of poetry readings which was then by and large in the little - Englandist doldrums" . When Children of Albion came out in 1969, Ted Hughes wrote that "for me it is full of surprises, real new beginnings". In 1992, Albi - on 's grandchildren provide fewer surprises simply because many of the voices here already have large and enthusiastic audiences for their work: John Agard, Sujata Bhatt, Merle Collins, Carol Ann Duffy, Linton Kwesi Johnson, Grace Nich - ols , Fiona Pitt-Kethley , B en - jamin Zephaniah. No-one could make the claim for these grandchildren that they are underground poets like those featured in the 1969 anthology, even though, for the new book, Horovitz has tended to choose work where the poet takes the role of outsider or critic. Adventure, enjoyment, an - swerability and international - ism can be found in abundance in Grandchil - dren of Albion and it may be a measure of some of the changes that Horovitz has been working for that these ideas have now . burrowed risht to the heart of contem - porary poetry in all its forms. The plurality, vibrancy and health of contemporary poet - ry in.Britain are in the hands of many of those included in Grandchildren of Albion, po - ets who are read and heard
GRANDCHILDREN OF ALBION An Illustrated Anthology of Voices and Visions of Younger Poets in Britain Edited by Michael Horovitz New Departures, £9.99
widely, respected and en - joyed . It is a pleasure to see them in this new context. A major drawback of the an - thology is that there are too few surprises and new begin - nings among the many less well-known poets included, although the Slovene Ifigen - ija Zagoricnik was one who reached out and grabbed. But Grandchildren of Al - b ion still has plenty of shocks in store . For a start, the book looks unusual , designed to ambush us at every turn. It begins on page 17. Pages one to 16, the introduction and rationale, are published else - where . The poems and lyrics are interspersed with illustra - tions , some by the poets themselves. Drawings and sketches crawl all over the pages and it is a pity that too often they are not intrinsically interesting enough to avoid making a clutter of an already substantial book. Horovitz has deliberately chosen to include work which blurs the boundaries of poet - ry : poems which move to - wards graphic art in their presentation, song lyrics — sometimes a song complete with musical notation. It is certainly not all poetry for the page, and even excellent lyri - c ists and performance poets sometimes look weak in this context, alongside writers like Sujata Bhatt who are fa - voured by the page. Perhaps it is impossible to play but the intention of this anthology between book cov - ers at all. Poetry, as Horovitz has Beckett remind us in the dedication, "is not only to be read. It is to be looked at, and listened to".
M&?
Jo Shapcott

Author: Hofmann, Michael
Title: Surviving under Big Brother
Full_text:
Surviving under Big Brother
T his is the best anthology of modern poetry for 30 years. Not since I came upon Alvarez's The New Poetry (first published in 1962), have I had this sense of the collective statement of an excep - tional generation, of a mass of powerful new material, gradually finding shape.and identity, of so many outstanding poems and so many new names to follow. In The New Poetry, Alvarez put together four. American poets and 24 British; it looked like an admonition to the British to learn from the Americans, and it worked. That anthology — with Lowell, Plath, Gunn, Hughes — heralded the excitement of the 1960s, when the dominant poetry was American and American - insp ired . Since then, the fulcrum of poetry in the world has shifted back east, and Alvarez shifted with it. In the late 1960s he became the advisory editor of a series called Penguin Modern European Poets, where Amichai, Celan, Holan and Her - bert first appeared. Daniel Weissbort and Ted Hughes got together to found the magazine Modern Poetry in Translation. There were festivals, readings,
publications, exchanges of letters. They were cosmopolitan times (" the good old days" Amichai calls them in an interview, also printed here), and Weissbort has drawn heavily on them in this anthology. About a third of his poets were in that Penguin series; others have been published in small or special - ist presses here or in America; two are presented for the first time in English. To have selected 28 poets from eastern Europe, written essays introducing their work, with a bibliography and interviews with some of the poets, and all in a durable form — Penguin will be publishing the paperback in due course — is a great responsibility, and Weissbort has performed it magnificently. He has identified the essential subject or determination of this poetry, survival, and accepted geographical limits and chrono - logical ones. All his poets lived through the second world war and its aftermath; roughly speaking, they are the generation of the 1920s. This gives the book a coherence,
A new collection of iron curtain poets causes Michael Hofmann to recall a lost generation an intensity and a shared experi - ence , which otherwise Weissbort is hard put to describe, talking as he does about "an aura that em - braces their work. It is a kind of fellowship... "' This occasional incoherence isn't detrimental, though. It comes out of his continuing engagement with the work. It helps to makf The Poetry of Survival what it is: not a closed, cut-and-dried , canon - ical type of anthology, but more an instinctual one, and Weissbort's instincts are true. For instance, his decision to
THE POETRY OF SURVIVAL Post-War Poets of Central and Eastern Europe Edited by Daniel Weissbort Anvil £19.95 begin with Brecht. Brecht is gener - ally vilified in this country, and to set him at the head of this anthology may seem strange, a communist wolf before dissident sheep, only the other poets are not sheep and I am sure they recognise Brecht as one of themselves, with his clarity, brevity, intelligence and concreteness. His unrhymed poems with irregular rhythms — devised so as to be "reasonably
invulnerable to interruptions" (by jamming) — are an apt and evocative way in. As I read through the anthology I asked myself repeatedly, where do these Myrmidon poets come from, what is their Gogol's "Overcoat ", who is their father — and of course the answer is Brecht. In time, the uniqueness of the 28 poets represented here will be seen; they will make some sort of group like the War Poets or the Romantics. Their part of the world bore the brunt of the war and housed the death-camps . They went straight from the Brown terror to the Red, without passing
go. While the west looked on, complaisant or anguished, their countries were hostages to peace. There, poetry was the last thing on anyone's' minds, but still it ap - peared in the reduced, stubbly, oblique form they found for. it - - Actually , it was anti-poetry , anti - language . It was their leaders who fancied themselves as belletrists. Stalin got on the phone to poets, Ulbricht addressed meetings of the writers' union, they all had their lives and their speeches published in many volumes. The poets are the opp - osite , describing themselves vari - ously as "an outside member who would never presume to label himself a poet" (Holub), someone who "never felt myself to be a poet" (Pilinszky), who imagines "a p oet - ry without qualities, a poetry which would be anonymous again" (Rozewicz). Never in history have there been poets who had such a deep quarrel with language: as Celan, who wrote in German, the language of the murderers of his parents, but broken into pieces and re - fash - ioned ; as Dan Pagis, who taught himself Hebrew in order to write;
as Pilinszky with his "ascetic renunciation of words". Bachmann, Holan, Herbert, Rozewicz; they all inveigh against language. I am talking about this antholo - gy as an event in English, even though it is the opposite of most English poetry, which is picky, cluttered, unmomentous, anecdot - al , individualising. In the poems here, you see the wood, not the trees. They mean to be useful (Brecht's favourite word!) even when they only dramatise their usefulness: "/ want to be on time/ even if I am too late" (Jerzy Ficowski). It is not because I feel sentimental about the countries and the poets and what they have suffered. Their achievement — and that of their translators, most of whom, fascinatingly, are not native Eng - lish speakers, and whose versions, Weissbort says "need not be in - stantly recognisable as a poem in English" — makes me wonder whether the possession of one language, and an innocent unbro - ken relationship to it, will ever again be able to make great poetry. This anthology sets new bearings.
Demanding democracy now: a young East German intellectual , 1989-90

Author: Dannatt, Adrian
Title: Feminist verse and its pitfalls
Full_text:
Feminist verse and its pitfalls
If the very nature of poetry is to vanquish the cliche, it is perhaps forgivable to be suspicious of poetry with an agenda. All three of these poets are politically engaged feminists, working in a terrain rich in cliches. Adrienne Rich, the only full-time poet of the three, with a 40-year career behind her, has achieved in An Atlas of the Difficult World a summation of her themes and talents. The long title poem is a triumphant vindication of the potential of her form. Margaret Atwood and Alice Walker, both better known as novelists, cannot compete in their poetry with Rich's subtlety and sophistication. Curiously, the quality of the poetry is inversely proportional to the span of the work. The weakest volume, Walker's, represents her complete poems, from 1965-90 , while Atwood's is a selection from ten years. Rich's slim but superior book covers
AN ATLAS OF THE DIFFICULT WORLD Poems 1988-1991 By Adrienne Rich W. W. Norton, £12.95 POEMS 1976-1986 By Margaret Atwood Virago, £6.99 paperback HER BLUE BODY EVERYTHING WE KNOW Earthling Poems 1965-1990 By Alice Walker The Women's Press, £15.95 a
only 1988-91 .
