These qualitative dif - ferences are not a matter of content: both Rich and Walker write about the political prisoner, and all three poets are concerned with questions of race, ecology, gender and human rights. Atwood and Rich each has a poem entitled She, and Walker has one called She Said. They all largely employ loose, rarely punctuated free verse; a lyrical, fluid style that requires special care. Rich's lines are of a kind that everyone feels they could write, but very few can; her lines are as long and elegant as Walker's are short and bumpy. Their meanings are smuggled past with grace. Rich's title poem takes on nothing less than the state of America, and is a Whitmanesque ode to that stalled dream , as realistic and pessimistic as Whitman was euphoric and
optimistic. Rich transforms events that may have briefly registered as news into human experience. The notes give the source of one section as an account of an attack on two lesbians, taken from Gay Community News. The final part of the title poem is an elegiac haunting address to the reader — every and any possible reader, business executive or parent, of either sex. In the second part of her book, Rich deals more directly with her Jewish childhood and the Holocaust, a theme which, like the slavery Walker addresses, may be all too familiar but is nevertheless important. How to deal with such monstrous historic
material without adding to its banalisation is a problem faced by all three poets. Atwood's boundless verbal facility, her punning gymnastics and essential wit, do not always redeem the obviousness of the material — that exploitation, torture and masculinity are not, on the whole, nice. Certain words recur in each poem with an obsessive touch: 34 counts for the word "blood" and 34 also for "red" out of 73 works in total, not including A Red Shirt, in which the colour appears 11 more times. Atwood's poems bubble, drift and gurgle with that Seventies idea of sisterhood as largely made up of bodily fluids, which seems, in retro - spect , biologically reductive. But if Atwood's women seem dated that is nothing compared to Walker's songs of praise for Winnie Mandela or the Sandinista government. Their eulogistic enthusiasm now has a sinister ring. Walker is above all honest, which makes one doubt whether honesty is
necessarily the best policy when it comes to the lyric arts. There are good poems here, for example Light Baggage, a wise, delicate treatment of ambition and the renunciation of success: fishing in the waters of experience a slouched back against the shoulders of the world.
The disappointment is that there are only a handful of decent poems in 25 years of work. The beginning "snapshots" of Africa , neo-haiku dog - gerel written at too young an age, make one long for those poets who used to buy up and destroy their embarrassing juvenilia. In the preface, Walker explains that she has not deleted or changed anything she has written, whereas she quite obviously should have done. Walker terms Reagan a "bad actor" and praises Malcolm X in equally obvious ways. Too many lines border on agitprop parody. These three books present women as the political and social radar of a deadly world. If Walker or Atwood can shame us for being male, Rich both shames and empowers us all for being human.
Adrian Dannatt
Margaret Atwood: writes poems which bubble, drift and gurgle

Author: McCue, Jim
Title: Verses return from oblivion
Full_text:
Verses return from oblivion
R evision : seeing again. For the revised series of Oxford Books of Verse , which will influence the taste of a generation, OUP commissioned a fresh reading of the huge corpus of our poetry. The most recent results are Alistair Fowler's New Oxford Book of 17 th - C entur y Verse (published today) and Emrys Jones's 16 th<entury volume (published last year). Nearly five centuries and more than 800 poets are now represented , yet even at 3,500 pages, these volumes are scraping the surface, not the barrel. As well as adjusting reputations up and down — Philip Larkin's 20th-century Verse notoriously found no place for Ezra Pound — these anthologies have brought to light many scarcely known poems and poets. Emrys Jones includes one poem apparently never before printed, and some neglected tender lines by Thomas Bastard about a child learning to speak: "the soft air the softer roof doth kiss / With a sweet dying and a pretty miss". Christopher Ricks's Victorian Verse revives Shirley Brooks's "Poem by a Perfectly Furious Academician" :
I takes and paints, Hears no complaints, And sells before I'm dry, Till savage Ruskin He sticks his tusk in. Then nobody will buy. The earliest tradition was courtly and semi-official . Henry VIII, Eliz - abe t h and James I all have poems in these volumes. In 1599, Samuel Daniel hoped this national litera - ture would rival that of the ancients. O blessed letters, that combine in one All ages past, and make one live with all By you we do confer with who are gone And the dead living unto council call By you th" unborn shall have communion Of what we feel and what doth us befall He thought the genius of the lang - ua g e ordained for the production of great works, and in general the old Oxford anthologies agreed. But alongside that canonical history the modern editors value diversity and introduce unrequired writing, voices from the anonymous mass There are versified prayers and wills,
doggerel notes on husbandry, dialect poems, epitaphs and the exuberant dementia of Christopher Smart. Without looking below the first rank, Fowler might have filled all his 800 pages with the 17 th century's unmatched lyrical exploration of love in all its forms, running from Fulke Greville and Drayton (overlapping here with Jones) to Traheme and Rochester. But he also admits "some 'sub - literary verse, and some very minor poets", for ; "If literature ,is the nation's memory, forgotten verse may contain things we need to know". One thing we especially need to know is what women's verse was like , and Fowler has practised "positive discrimination". As well as including women in his New Oxford Book of 18th-century Verse , Roger Lonsdale went further, producing a full-scale anthology of 18th-century Women Poets. Though not included there, the anonymous anguish of "Epitaph on a Child Killed by Procured Abor - tion " is surely a mother's: Soften the pangs that still revenge thy doom:
NEW OXFORD BOOK OF 17th-CENTURY VERSE edited by Alistair Fowler OUP, £25 mSmmmS^Smm^SmSSmS^SS^SS Nor, from the dark abyss of nature's womb. Where back I cast thee, let revolting time Call up past scenes to aggravate my crime. With hundreds of ephemeral poems called back from oblivion to set beside the Augustan classics, Lonsdale's 18 th century is radically political, particularly as it draws to its troubled close. Cowper, James Grainger and others denounce slavery; William Shepherd lam - basts imperialism; Mary Acock and James Bisset decry child labour. Not that all the verse Lonsdale prints is good. Who can have patience with stuff like this: "In yon deep bed of whisp'ring reeds / His airy harp shall now be laid" ? There is too much mock-heroic Miltonic grandeur. Thus sports are routinely aggrandised. Bowls: "A large smooth plain extends its verdant brow" ; golf: "th' exulting orb as - cends "; cricket: "And see where busy counties strive for fame".
A fter a century too much lulled by rhyming couplets, Victorian poets weighed up their words as well as their syllables. Feelings were understated and compressed into sonnets and tight stanzas (Housman, Hardy) to make the reader attend to every nuance. Ralph Hodgson could imply years of misunderstanding in the appar - ently neutral tide "Silver Wedding". Lord de Tabley could write 40 delicate and precise lines about a spider. Out of such restraints burst Hopkins. Even in the best tilled ground, these editors have found neglected furrows, such as the impotence poems of the late 17th century . Out of Horace , perhaps, but very Eng - lish is a long series of poems of leisured contentment: Lord Vaux"s praise of thinking (1576), Edward Dyer's "In Praise of a Contented Mind" ("My mind to me a king - dom is... ". 1588k Henrv Wotton's dom is... ", 1588)Henry Wotton's
, 'The Character of a Happy Life" (1651) and Robert Southwell's "Content and Rich" (1595): "My wishes are but few, / AH easy to fulfil; / I make the limits of my power / The bonds unto my will." Mildmay Fane, in 1648, p redi - cates his serenity upon being at one with nature: - •.;. ... observe by reason .why every plantobeys its season; How the sap rises, and the fall. Wherein they shake of f leaves and all... Which whilst my contemplation sees I am taught thankfulness from trees. Unmistakably, this green wisdom is a pre-echo of Marvell's "Upon Appleton House" — the most perfect of all long poems, though sadly not printed entire by Fowler. Similarly, Lonsdale prints two poems addressed to Coleridge and two on Tintem Abbey. But because the Romantics fall between the 18 th century and the Victorians, they are to have a volume to themselves. And after that? Well, despite a new jacket recently, Helen Gardner's 1972 New Oxford Book of English Verse is beginning to look rather staid.
Jim McCue

Author: Null
Title: Of poetry, politics, spooks and God
Full_text:
Of poetry, politics, spooks and God
I POLITICS I I Joku OmtbeB ] The book of the year? No competition. Roy Jenkins's A life at the Centre (Macmillan, £20) is in a class of its own. Unlike the normal run of self-serving political memoirs, this is a genuine autobiography : a professional biog - rapher turning his polished skills on his own career, able to draw on his contemporary notes to recreate events with almost novelistic detail, but at the same time review his own part in them with the perspective of a historian. Although sometimes verging on self - parody , the book is a treat for con - noisseurs of the high Jenkins style , at once orotund and precise. Runner-up ? Nicholas Ridley's My Style of Govern - men t {Hutchinson, £16.99) - once again, less a conventional memoir than a robust vindication of Margaret Thatcher and all her works, written from within by an independent-minded courtier , and aimed particularly point - edly at the troika of disgruntled ex - collea gues who brought her down.
I SPOOKS AND SPIES I I Chris Petit | Whoever pressed the fast-forward but - ton on European history has left thriller writers double-guessing , and often wrong, now that huge political shifts occur more rapidly than publishers' deadlines can accommodate them: the noise heard most often is that of the author running for cover . The best—all American — went their own way. Richard Condon blew the whistle on the US, yet again, in The Final Addiction (Michael Joseph, £13.99): criminal syndicates , politicians, intelligence agencies and the media are all shown to He easy in the same bed. Charles McCany's Second Sight {Hutchinson, £13.99) completed a panoramic seven - part survey of a lifetime in espionage (and of America's clandestine history), the literary equivalent to a wide-screen epic. Benchley's Chip {Robert Hale, £14.95) by Carl A. Posey proved, in spite of low-grade packaging and drab printing, one of the most readable, and ambitious, thrillers of the year — Dostoevsky in the Balkans.
FASHION I I Liz Smith One privilege of writing about fashion is seeing In close-up the cut and craftsmanship that goes into clothes. Modern Fashion in Detail (Victoria & Albert, £19.95) focuses on the tucks, pleats, buttons and bows of 20th - century style and is even better than a front-row seat at a couture show. Valerie Mendes (the V&A's curator of costume) and Claire Wilcox have assembled a feast of detail from the museum's collections as varied as the shadow - work flowers on a Vionnet scalloped lawn dress (circa 1920) and a metal - springed pocket flap on a Schiaparelli jacket (1936-38 ) to a Katharine Hamnett studded leather jacket (1990).
Richard Davis's close-up photographs are put in perspective with Leonie Davis's line-drawings of the garments. In Vogue : 75 Years of Style (Conde Nast, £25), Georgina Howell's panoramic view of fashion through the decades, proves that politicians, pop stars and the racketings of high society mirror what's in — or out — as much as clothes.
I POETRY I [__ Rober t Nye | The best book of new verse I read in the past year was C.H. Sisson's Antidotes (Carcanet, £6.95). Sisson's poems present you with the movement of a mind that takes nothing for granted, finding plain language and memorable rhythm for its expression: Words fly like birds across the sky, And how they go is also why... It is poetry because it is better than prose. Here is work which will be speaking quietly to new readers when noisier and flashier contemporaries have been forgotten. I also enjoyed Ted Hughes's A Choice of Shakespeare's Verse (Faber, £4.99), approving his selections, and finding him illuminat - ing on the subject of Shakespeare's diction in the thoughtful little essay at the back. One of the best things the Poet Laureate has done.
I GUNS AND GENERALS I I William Jackson | John Strawson's Beggars in Red: The British Army 1789-1889 (Hutchinson , £18.99) is hard to beat in the military field , and is a worthy sequel of his Gentlemen in Khaki, covering 1 890 - 1990 . A great advocate of the regi - mental system, Strawson rubs salt in the wounds being inflicted on it by today's ill-thought through Options for Change. For those who enjoy military biographies, Bernard Freyberg VC: Soldier of Two Nations by his son Paul (Hodder & Stoughton, £30) is an equally good choice, and worth every penny of its price. And perhaps the most important book of all from the political and military historian's viewpoint is From Churchill's Secret Cirde to the BBC (Brassey's, £29.95), Charles Richardson's book on Sir Ian Jacob. It fills substantial gaps in the story of the great wartime inter-Allied conferences, which Jacob attended as Churchill's military secretary.
1 SCIENCE FICTION 1 | Tom Hutchinson Michael Crichton's Jurassic Park (Cen - tury ,£13.99): let me indulge in an ego - binge of satisfaction at successful prophecy. Its story of a dinosaur Disneyworld gone mad was, I forecast, just right for Steven Spielberg . Sure enough, he has completed production. "They 're breeding!" may well be the horror catch-phrase for 1992. Multiply - in g , too, over the year were fascinating what-if universes, the most startling
being The Difference Engine by Wil - liam Gibson and Bruce Sterling (Gol - lancz , £13.95), about the industrial revolution come before its time: a fog- j heavy Victorian mix of Frank Harris and Babbage computers. A more Contemporary identity crisis was Dream Science by Thomas Palmer {Harvill, £13.99), in which an in- j surance executive finds himself in a I doorless office, an existence that admits 1 only violence and the fear of being someone else's imaginings: Lewis Carroll crossed with The Night Of The j Living Dead .
\ TRAVEL I I Shona Crawford Poole i Was Patrick Leigh Fermor so pressed j by his publisher for something 1 immediately printable that he dug I Three Letters from the Andes (John I Murray, £10.95) from some forgotten 1 drawer? The suspicion is ungallant, but 1 understandable. He wrote this account 1 of a journey to Peru with six friends 20 J years ago in letters to his wife. The new. I book, so unlike his uncompleted trilogy I that began with A Time of Gifts, is not J about youth recalled in maturity, but a 1 contemporary account unaccountably I postponed. It is also vintage Leigh * Fermor. The journey was a prototype for the style of trekking holiday that is now graded severe. Would that the travelling companions one encounters on such trips today had the charm, swank, erudition, gusto and good humour of Leigh Fermor and his friends . There is no better or more insouciant observer of the bad travel experience; Puno on the shores of Lake Titicaca is a high-altitude lowpointThe 109 pages are indexed; a nice conceit. Gavin Young's good reputation as a travel writer and my liking for Joseph Conrad's novels ensured that I picked up his In Search of Conrad (Hutch in - son , £17.99) with delicious feelings of pleasurable anticipation. I followed Young's modern far eastern journey in archives , libraries and cemeteries, in search of the real people who became Conrad's fictional characters. I paid close attention to the tightly woven tale in order not to get lost somewhere between now and then, fact and fiction. It is seamlessly done but curiously bloodless, not quite here and now or then and there.
I ' ART I I Richard Cork | John Richardson's magisterial biog - raph y of Picasso (Jonathan Cape, £25) dominates the art books this year. Although only the first of a projected four-volume work, taking the story up to 1906, this engrossing achievement already bears the marks of a definitive account . Richardson knew Picasso well in the artist's later years, but there is no trace of sycophancy. On the contrary: the myth of Picasso's boyhood-precocity is firmly demolished, and his un - cer tainty as a young man clearly defined. Richardson has little time for
the Blue period's sentimentality , and is possibly too severe on the chilling symbolism of La Vie. But his frank discussion of Picasso's youthful short - comings makes the eventual arrival at greatness all the more astonishing. By the time this first, hugely readable volume closes, the 25-year-old artist has exorcised the past and begun the Cubist work that would turn modern art inside-out . I await the second instal - ment with impatience.
i CRIME | I Marcel Berlins | The book that lingered longest in the mind was Barbara Vine's King Sol - omon 's Carpet (Viking, £14.99), a haunting, disturbing, exquisitely writ - ten tale of obsession, music and the London Underground. In Birth Marks (Michael Joseph, £13.99) Sarah Du - nant introduced an entirely convincing heroine, Hannah Wolfe, feminine and feminist, intelligent, wickedly witty and totally captivating; and delivered a strong, clever plot as well. Devil in a Blue Dress by Walter Mosley (Ser - p ent 's Tail, £6.99) was the most impressive debut. It is a tough, atmospheric story of Los Angeles in 194 8, with a black private eye operating in neighbourhoods that Philip Marlowe would not have dared to enter.
I GOD i Eric James The C of E Newspaper called Love Unknown: Meditations on the Death and Resurrect ion of Jesus by John Barton, vice-master of St Cross College, Oxford, (SPCK. £4.99) "exciting and disturbing". The Methodist Recorder said it was "a treasure... something of
a masterpiece". The Tablet called it a "splendid book". For me, it is the best book on God in 1991. The Oxford University Press's Past Masters is a superb series of concise, lucid and authoritative introductions to the great thinkers. There could be no better scholar than E.P. Sanders to write the volume on Paul (£4.99). He brings Paul alive as missionary, theologian and religious genius. Bishop Jim Thomp - son 's Stepney Calling (Mowbray, £5.99) concerns his own calling (God recently called him to Bath and Wells), the search for God, the credibility and justice of God, and how we understand His presence. Most chapters were BBC Thoughts for the Day.
COOKING AND EATING I like cookery books that fire me with their words. Recipes set in the aspic of glossy photographs do not have that effect, but act as a barrier between the writer-cook and the reader-cook . Mary Taylor Simeti married and settled in Sicily. Much more than a cook book, Sicilian Food (Century, £16.99) is history, anthropology, literature and travelogue. Chitrita Banerji's life and Food in Bengal (Weidenfeld & Nicol - son , £15.99) is a loving tribute to her homeland and more particularly to its kitchen. She describes the seasons and festivals and the special dishes that are required of each, interwoven, with a delicately told tale of daily life in a Bengali household. Goose Fat and Garlic {Kyle Cathie, £17 .99) is Jeanne Strang's account of her adoptive home in le grand sud-ouest , in which she describes, with an engaging and appro - priately robust vigour, the solid, rustic food of the region and how to cook it.
<NEWPAGE>
MUSIC Pad Griffiths Most of the bicentenary publications vere ephemeral, but not Ivan Nagel's tatonomy and Mercy: .Reflections on Mozart 's Operas {Harvard University » ress, £19.95), whose search for the shape of the operas' characters is arried out with clarity and seriousness [hrough several avenues of historical, literary, dramatic and psychological approach. This is a humane and beautiful little book. Richly stimulating and enquiring, too, are three lectures by Edward W. Said published as Musical Elaborations (Chatto & Windus, £20), a book where music's specialness is intensified by the testing of bridges to other areas of thought: Said is oneof the few wr iters to make it seem important that Beethoven and Jane Austen were contemporaries . Pierre Boulez's Stocktakings from an Apprenticeship {Oxford University Press, £40) is not new. These jibes, japes and brilliant theoretical flourishes date from his twenties and early thirties. But Stephen Walsh's translation at last makes one of the century's key musical books avail - able in strong, supple English.
CLASSICS Peter Jones The most acclaimed academic books are usually large-screen affairs bursting with unexpected stars, locations, and extras rearranged into novel and seduc - tive scenarios. Enormously beguiling at first glance, they tend to wither under close inspection: does this evidence really support that generalisation? More than ever we need our com - mentaries , and Simon Hornblower* s A Commentary on Thucydides, vol 1,
books 1-3 {Clarendon Press, £60) strikes me as a model for anyone who wants to get to grips with that great historian: detailed scholarship com - bined with breadth and lucidity, and the Greek translated into English, too. It is the model on which all future commentaries should be based. Rich - ard Jenkyns's superb Dignity and Decadence {HarperCollins, £20), shows how to orchestrate a wide - ranging argument — the Classical influence upon the art of the apparently Gothic Victorians. Confident general - isations and aesthetic judgments spring persuasively from intensive analysis of evidence (especially the 235 black and white illustrations), and the whole is sustained by enviably elegant and witty writing: scholarly exposition at its very best. Effective persuasion depends on effective psychology, and for the election year ahead, Penguin has cunningly brought out Aristotle's Art of Rhetoric a brilliant exposition of the two (trans - lated by H. Lawson-Tancred , £6.99).
FILM Geoff Brown Who said silent cinema was idle escapism? In Behind the Mask of Innocence Jonathan Cape, £35), Kevin Brownlow lovingly uncovers a mass of American films about poverty, drink, labour strife, prison conditions, Chinks and Wops. It is beautifully illus - trated in the style Brownlow patented 25 years ago in The Parade's Gone By, although you long to see the photos move. More history in The Dilys Powell Film Reader {Carcanet, £25) — 50 years of cinema seen through the wise, witty eyes of the first lady of British film criticism. "I emerged from Myra Breck - inri dge ", she writes, "pining for a long
evening with Norma Shearer." Plus the perfect stocking-filler : Allen Eyles and Keith Skone's London 's West End Cinemas (Keytone, £9.95), a magical, melancholy pictorial guide to the cap - ital 's pleasure domes over 80 years of Renaissance palaces, art deco dreams, and the current multiplex shoeboxes.
I HISTORICAL | PhilippaToomey Two of the best historical novels have the sea as the background: The Nutmeg of Consolation {HarperCollins, £13.99) is Patrick O'Brian 's most recent book on the adventures of that irresistible pair, Captain Jack Aubrey and Dr Stephen Maturin ; and Middle Passage by Charles Johnson {Picador, £14.99), the tale of Rutherford Cal - houn , a freed slave and by nature a con - man , who finds himself aboard a slave ship, sailing from New Orleans to Africa with a crew of misfits and dangerous men. Marvellous...
I CHILDREN I Brian Aldenon Michael Foreman's Mother Goose {Walker Books, £12.99) is a superlative piece of work—a great skein of nursery rhymes strung through a painted landscape that is full of wonderfully executed pictorial jokes. I haven't met with any other new children's book that is so satisfying, although among a hefty crop of anthologies I would like to single out Brian Patten's Puffin Book of Twentieth Century Children's Verse {Puffin, £5.99) — also illustrated by Foreman. Children's fiction -has been pretty drab, but Anne Fine's Book of the Banshee {Hamish \ Hamilton, £8.99) displayed some neat comic ideas.

p ^ li r r ~~l The torrent of verbiage about wine keeps pace with the ever increasing quantities of it made in ever more I unlikely places: and the quality of both I is rather similar. Modern oenological I techniques ensure that very little really I nasty drink escapes from the wineries, I and much of the writing could be I described in like terms: although all one I can ask of cheap wine is that it does not I taste actively disgusting. I I gather from Webstcrs Wine Guide, I by Oz Clarke {Mitchell Beazley, £8.99), I that one supermarket chain sells 15 per I cent of all wine, and that the most popular red is Bulgarian cabernet, f which presumably fulfils the criteria I above. Hugh Johnson's Pocket Wine I Book (Mitchell Beazley, £6.99) and I Websters are annuals — the former I comes across as sensible and bereft of I flannel, and his comments on attempts I to describe wine in words are worth I reading. Clarke's style can fairly be I called histrionic (he is an actor by I origin), and he must eat some pretty I cur ious things, whose flavours are I called in to tell us what is in the bottle. bibber taste on in pursuit of wines whose flavour is similar but whose provenance disparate: she is a master of wine, one of a band of experts whose interests seem often to be more con - cerned with the many nuances of the taste of wine rather than its main role as a complement to food. It would be nice to be able to identify wine with the near cer tainty of the professionals, although even they will admit, when pressed, that one look at the label is worth 20 years in the trade. Clarke's New Classic Wines (Mitch - ell Beaztey, £19.99) canters breathlessly round the world with plenty of pretty pictures of people, labels, barrets, maps and vines, which go to make up a large part of any modern book about wine. Clarke states in his introduction that he conceived the book while lying with a man on a Sydney nudist beach. The Winemakers Year, by Michael Buller {Thames & Hudson, £19.95) is a whimsical picture book with a some - what stagey icvd, designed for an American market. The handsome photographs illustrate how much money has been made in Bordeaux in the past 20 years. Author: Rogers, Byron
Title: Baldly, roundly dirty
Full_text:
Baldly , roundly dirty
is that they were always there, but the only scholars who knew delib - erately suppressed them. When Dr Thomas Parry published his defin - itive edition of Dafydd ap Gwilym, the greatest Welsh poet, he did not include "The Penis" or "The Poet Sends His Genitals as a Love Messenger" . So these remained in manuscript (poetry being such a national preoccupation, Welsh medieval poems can exist in as many as 75 versions), and for them printing might have come and gone were it not for one man. The circumstances are as bizarre as everything else in this story. The man who found and translated them translated his own Christian name as well, and the publishing
The most startling thing about this book is that it is not a hoax. The poems exist and have existed for 500 years, far filthier than anything by English contemporaries like Chaucer, filth - ier than Rochester even, and with - ou t his snigger. They were written by the roaring boys and one roaring girl in the Welsh Middle Ages, and written in the most elaborate metre of which the oldest vernacular literature in Europe was capable. So these are doubly worrying, being not only filthy but little works of art, and by now the possibility of quotation could be inducing an attack of the vapours in the literary editor of this newspaper. But where, in a country where the first description of sexual inter - course in a novel in the Sixties caused a national outcry, have the poems been until now? The answer
MEDIEVAL WELSH EROTIC POETRY Edited and translated by Dafydd Jonston Tafol , £8.95 house was formed by him and his wife for the sole purpose of printing the poems. Dafydd Jonston, lecturer in Welsh in Cardiff, began life as an Englishman called David Johnston. Yet why should so many Welsh poets have written erotic verse? They have always been seen as an intensely conservative force, serv - ing long apprenticeships which would allow them to write in the old forms and, by praising their patrons,
upholding the social order. The answer is that erotica was a release from this. It allowed them to play. It allowed Dafydd ap Gwilym to mock the poetic convention of sending a messenger, usually a bird, to one's love. Dafydd sends his complete genitalia ("Be you fierce/my bald round love mes - sengers " ). Some poems are satires on such European conventions as courtly love, with its pale ladies. The women here are far randier than the men ("The playful beauty gets cross/And calls out 'Hey , to bed you ape'."), and even long before any secular work by a woman in English there is poetry by a 15 th century Welsh woman, Gwerful Mechain, who addresses an affec -
tionate poem to the female pu - denda . She is quite extraordinary, far more extreme than any modern feminist, and there is not a line of her poetry that can be quoted here. Almost every poem is a counter - part to the norm, which suggests that the erotic was an accepted medieval genre in Wales. Poets appear to have enjoyed themselves before the shadow of the chapels fell, but the irony is that not only were these poems forgotten but so was the detailed physical language used, so that Jonston could only guess at the meaning of some words. There has never been a book quite like this. If you were writing a satire on a race this would be a perfect opening chapter, for it involves the complete reappraisal of a national character. At his wife's request, Jonston did not dedicate the book to her.
Byron Rogers

Author: Smith, Liz
Title: Dabbing on the sweet smell of success
Full_text:
Liz Smith meets the woman who transformed an ailing perfumery business into an international empire
Dabbing on the sweet smell of success
S heila Pickles is a perfumier whose nose is more often buried in a book of poetry than a scent bottle. Ms Pickles is the head of Penhali - gon 's, the gentlemen 's perfumiers she salvaged from extinction in 1975 and has developed into an international empire. She is pas - sionate about poetry, and loves the whiff of the leather-bound books she inherited from her grandmother — believed to be the first woman to read classics at London university — almost as much as their contents.
The same romanticism has driven Ms Pickles to preserve and develop the legacy of design she acquired in 1975, when she bought what remained of the barber shop established by William Henry Penhaligon in London in 1870. By the time Ms Pickles stepped in, the Penhaligon 's shop in Bury Street, St James's, had gone. All that was left was a collection of old labels, eight formula books, eight products (four of which were hair - d ressing lotions) and the goodwill of a dwindling list of loyal custom - ers which had once included Noel Coward, Gertrude Lawrence and the Duke of Edinburgh. The film director Franco Zeffirelli, for whom Ms Pickles had worked in Rome for five years, and with whom she had shopped at Pen - haligon 's original St James's shop on visits to London , prompted her to try to resuscitate the business. She started up with just three colognes — Hammam Bouquet, Blenheim Bouquet and Penhali -
gon s eau-de-Cologne . By then, English Fern was made only as a bath essence , and she abandoned the hair products. "I knew nothing about the perfumery business ," she says. "I went into it with this odd mix of ignorance and ar - rogance . But I never had any doubt I would succeed. I am a Scorpio. Failure just does not come into it." The formulae she inherited clearly had a cult following, es - pecially Hammam , the spicy mix of sandalwood, jasmine and attar of rose created in 1872 and named after the St James's Turkish baths. Hammam Bouquet, the most ex - pe n sive of Penhaligon's men's f ra - gra nces , costs £32 for 100ml of aftershave, £26 for 50ml eau de toilette spray , and £70 for 30ml
extract . But Ms Pickles takes the greatest pleasure in the vintage Victorian labels, with their clean - cut script, and the more flowery Edwardian designs whose orig - inals are framed on her office walls and which are recreated to incor - po rate all the blurb required on perfumery products these days. "Dermaline contains no perfume whatsoever" she reads with relish from one of William Henry's obsolete labels. Penhaligon's, for Ms Pickles, is a select international club of cognoscenti, mostly men, who come to buy traditional colognes and balms in vintage packaging. She moved into Covent Garden in 1975 , as the apple carts in the market pulled out, opening her first Penhaligon's shop in Welling -
ton Street. The Dickensian an- is carefully cultivated, with mahog - a ny display cabinets and an old brass bell to punch for attention. Today it is the showcase shop in a chain of four in London, with branches in Bath, Chester and York and a corner in Bergdorf Goodman in New York. The bottle design is authentic. When Ms Pickles took on the company, flat rectangular stoppers were in use, sealed with a loop of velvet ribbon. In 1977 William Henry 's great-granddaughter , Re - nee Gold, materialised with an original bottle, and the ball stop - per was reinstated.
The success of Penhali - gon 's, Ms Pickles be - lieves , is based on a triangular relationship between her "nose" (the perfumier with whom she develops the formula of a scent), the designer of the packaging , and herself. All three, have been in action recently to create Cornubia, the latest Pen - haligon ' s fragrance and the first specifically created for women. "I wanted an evening scent that was exotic and mysterious but not vulgar or too punchy," she says. The result is a combination of clove and coriander , with Egyp - tian violet leaves and Moroccan and Turkish roses , on a base of vanilla, sandalwood and vetyver. Madeleine Bennett, when she was at Michael Peters, the design company , worked with Ms Pickles on the distinctive Penhaligon's design formula we recognise to -
day . The design of Cornubia, however, is the work of Flo Bayley, her current consultant, who has turned the name on its side and embossed it on gold. The familiar Penhaligon's bottle is dressed in a star-studded purple box and has a fat gold bow at its neck. Cornubia goes on sale in September, the eau de toilette priced from £25 for 30ml, and the full-strength extract £60 for 30ml. The scents may be packaged to look as though they have been brewed at the back of the shop but they are produced in Penhaligon's high-technology headquarters in north London. Ms Pickles takes no notice of trends in the trade. "I listen to my customers," she says. She is surprised to be asked how Penhaligon's products are tested. "What do you mean, tested? I wear it. My sister wears it. My husband always says proudly that his is the head on which Bluebell shampoo was tested." In 1987 she decided she needed a partner to support her plans for
international expansion. Laura Ashley , another company built on the nostalgic vision of one woman, stepped in and bought Penhali - gon ' s , leaving Ms Pickles to do what she enjoys best, thinking up new products. A year ago, when Laura Ashley's own business be - gan to falter, it had to shed Pen - haligon 's. The Limited, the Amer - ican mail order and stores chain, took over the company for $12.8 million. Leslie Wexner , the head
of The Limited , is a Penhaligon's customer of many years. "He is my knight in shining armour ," Ms Pickles says. Penhaligon's range has expanded to include scented candles, room sprays and pot-pourri , as well as bristle brushes, shaving soap bowls and scent bottles in gilded silver and enamel. A range of grooming "requisites", packaged in navy or burgundy leather and in a choice of mock ivory , nickel , slate, chrome, and silver plate, has been launched . A grooming-kit roll costs £95; the smaller 48-hour kit pictured is £65. There are . also Penhaligon's books, anthologies of poetry, - prose and diary snippets on the Grand Tour, summer, Christmas, flowers and love. Each costs £12.95 and there are a million in print. She has been asked to do a book on scent, but turned it down: "I find all those engravings of 17 th century Frenchmen in gauntlets and endless pictures of lavender fields in Norfolk deeply boring."
Sheila Pickles of Penhaligon's : she "never had any doubt" that her business venture would succeed
A corner of Penhaligon's Covent Garden shop: a Dickensian atmosphere is carefully cultivated
In the bag: the 48-hour kit

Author: Howard, Philip
Title: How poetry works
Full_text:
How poetry works
Dante's Inferno, xv, 121-4 Poi si rivolse, e parve di coloro che corrono a Verona il drappo verde per la campagna; e parve di costoro quegli che vince e non colui che perde "Then he turned back, and seemed like one of those who run the cross - co untry race at Verona for the prize of green cloth; and he seemed like the winner, not a loser." Down in the seventh circle of Hell, second zone, Dante meets the sodomites, eternally crossing burning sands beneath a rain of fire. One of them is Brunetto Taring his old tutor, for whom he feels gratitude and love. The passage is inspired by Aeneas's meeting with Deiphobus in hell: Brunetto's burnt face corresponds to the mutilation of Deiphobus. European poetry is a great federation down the centuries, continually echoing and bouncing off its predecessors. As usual , Dante elaborates the scene , and heightens the pathos. The two friends reminisce, and Brunetto warns Dante about his coming exile from beloved Florence. It is a hellish bleak background, as they contemplate their separate eternities, but their meeting has brightness and beauty. Then time is up, and Brunetto sprints back to bis fires, as though he can't wait to be back. I think there is a note of hope and victory there. Poetry is the bit that gets lost in translation. But here is Geoffrey Bickersteth's version in terza rima of one of the memorable scenes of European literature: "Then he turned round and seemed of those who at/Verona run cross-country for the green/cloth-mantle ; and, of those who aim thereat,/seemed not a loser, but the one who'll win ." And here is C.H. Sisson: "Then he turned back, and seemed to be one of those /Who, at Verona, run for the green cloth./Through the open country; and he seemed to be the one/Who wins the race, and not the one loses
wno . «
PHILIP HOWARD

Her ladies and gentlewomen also, the fairest Her gentlewomen , like the Nereids, of them were apparelled like the nymphs Nereids so many mermaids , tended her i' the eyes , (which are the mermaids of the waters) and like and made their bends adornings : at the helm the Graces; some steering the helm, others a seeming mermaid steers: the silken tackle swell tending the tackle and ropes of the barge, out with touches of those flower-soft hands of the which there came a wonderful sweet passing that yarely frame the office. From the barge savour of perfumes, that perfumed the wharfs a strange invisible perfume hits the sense side, pestered with innumerable multitudes of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast her people out of people. u P° n her... How to write poetry? Choose a good prose source, cut it into lines, and do to it what Shakespeare does to North. DAVID WEST

Author: Howard, Philip
Title: How poetry works
Full_text:
How poetry works
ALFRED, LORD TENNYSON from The Princess: A Medley, 1847 Now sleeps the crimson petal, now the white; Nor waves the cypress in the palace walk; Nor winks the gold fin in the porphyry font; The fire-fly wakens: waken thou with me. Now droops the milk-white peacock like a ghost. And like a ghost she glimmers on to me. Now lies the Earth all Danae to the stars. And all thy heart lies open unto me. Now slides the silent meteor on, and leaves A shining furrow, as thy thoughts in me. Now folds the lily all her sweetness up, And slips into the bosom of the lake; So fold thyself, my dearest, thou, and slip Into my bosom and be lost in me.
IN THE way that many paintings tell a story, if you look with a questioning eye, some poems paint a picture. Turner and his contemporaries considered poetry and painting to be joint arts. Poetry did the movement , painting the colours. It is the colours, from crimson to that milk-white peacock, most poetic of birds since Byzantine iconography made it the immortal bird, that paint the picture in one of the finest lyrics in English. The Danae couplet is one of the incantatory spells of love poetry, high romance without slipping into sentimental - ity . The Princess is an extraordinary mixture of haunting lyrics, and rum but compelling narrative, set partly at a high Victorian garden party, and partly in the days when knights were bold, expressing the growing Victorian concerns with geology, astronomy, mathematics, evolutionary theory, feminism, domesticity , and paternalism. It envisages a future in which, "The man [may] be more of woman, she of man" . It is , in part, a brave, early feminist trumpet blast. Tennyson wrote of it to his friend Edward Rubaiyat Fitzgerald, "I hate it and so will you ", and subjected it to considerable revision. It formed the basis of Gilbert and Sullivan's send-up , Princess Ida. But the whole thing is worth a revisit, and not just for those magical lyrical spells.
Philip Howard

Author: West, David
Title: How poetry works
Full_text:
How poetry works
A MIDSUMMER-NIGHT'S DREAM, V.i.1-3 . . . 23-27 Hip: '77s strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of. The : More strange than true: I never may believe These antique fables, nor these fairy toys. Lovers and madmen have such seething brains.. .
Hip: But all the story of the night told over, And all their minds transfigured so together, More witnesseth than fancy's images, And grows to something of great constancy; But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
F our lovers have spent mid - summer - night in a wood near Athens, and been bewitched by Puck. He has now undone his mischief and the lovers are satisfactorily paired, but do not know whether their experi - ences of the night were dream or reality. Hippolyta finds all this strange , but her bridegroom, The - seus , Duke of Athens , mocks the imagination of the lunatic, the lover and the poet in a gloriously eloquent and confident speech, which Times readers should rush to read aloud — "How easy is a bush supposed a bear!" Hippolyta then quietly pro - duces an argument which, l ogi - cally , demands an answer. "If
these were just four dreams, why do they all cohere?" She receives no answer. Enter the lovers. "Come now", cries Theseus, "what dances shall we have?" It is easy to enjoy the great speech and Shakespeare's d emo - liti on (or is it vindication?) of his own work, but we should surely notice also the matrimonial politics. Theseus is the Duke and the br idegroom. Hippolyta is right But she has the sense not to press the point in company on the evening before her wedding. "There is nothing much in the character of Theseus: there 's nothing at all in Hippolyta," writes Bradley in his preface. Not so. These are people in action. David West

Author: Null
Title: Poetry by nature
Full_text: In the 19th century this might have been called an album, since it is, in part, a collection of verse and prose aligned to one very individual taste. But what do we call it now? Miriam Rothschild describes it as "a reflection of daydreams", and indeed it is a kind of oneiric diary in which auto - biographical reflection, scientific enquiry and lyrical divagation find a natural home. It is an account of wings, a history of winged beings, both in fact and in symbol. In its form it exists somewhere between an anthology and a meditation, with a number of short chapters bearing titles such as "The Garden and Your Room", "Candles ", "Hunting Butter - flies " and "Sorrow ". In its spirit, it is natural history as poetry or, perhaps, poetry as natural history. It begins with a discourse on souls, which themselves might be said to take wing, and then proceeds with an account of the artistic representation of doves through the centuries . One theme seems to lead effor tlessly to another so that, for example, Rothschild can go from the symbolism of butterflies to the topography of butterflies to a dream of butterflies. But the book is also an anthology of those writings on winged creatures which she most admires and there are extracts here from Frost , Kipling , Milton, Ne - ruda and many others. These texts are surrounded by a number of

Author: Null
Title: Poetry by nature
Full_text:
Poetry by nature
appropriate paintings or drawings, which range from El Greco to Audubon, Giotto to Balthus. They may all sound very self-indulgent , or even whimsical, but Rothschild is, in fact, a scientist; there is a clarity and objectivity here which precludes the vagaries of literary sentimentality. Yet there is also a larger theme, and in many respects this is a consideration of the way in which all natural things are conceived in harmony with one another. That is why these winged creatures can be seen to represent the state of man; in Rothschild 's account the moth evokes solitude and disaffection, its attraction for the flame like some unendurable human longing , while the butterfly in many myths embod - ies the escape of the soul from the cage or chrysalis of the body. Through the pages of this book, as a result, butterflies are seen to be curiously and almost literally spell - binding creatures, their strange "transmigrations" of form, as Sir Thomas Browne put it, touching within us some deep fascination for the possibilities of change and rebirth. Indeed, that is the secret meaning of this text: to dream
BUTTERFLY COOING LIKE A DOVE By Miriam Rothschild Doubleday, £25 of flight, to venture, to escape. Rothschild 's account of the silk - moth caterpillar conveys that same sense of mystery, as the technical analysis of its manufacturing pro - cess is followed by a quotation from William Blake. Perhaps this is fanciful but, then again, perhaps not : scientists who read and under - stand Blake might well be better scientists. Nobody has claimed that Lucretius or Thomson were inferior poets simply because they assimi - lated contemporary scientific theory, or that Vladimir Nabokov was a worse novelist just because he was also an entomologist So why should scientists not also be poets? V arious disciplines are brought together, and that is the point of the book. Of course, there are very few writers who combine grace of style with carefulness of natural observation — Nabokov is one and so, too, is Marcel Proust, described here as "the first and greatest urban natu -
ralis t the world has ever known". Rothschild has something of the same strength, but the success of her graceful book suggests the larger question. Is there any way now that science and literature can be rec - onciled , as they were, for example, in the previous century? Darwin and Faraday wrote to be understood by an audience larger than their immediate colleagues, and Darwin is closer to Dickens than to Lin - naeus . But how can such a reconcili - ation be achieved now? Can it only be done in the lyrical and mellif - luous way that Rothschild chooses here — science as poetry — or is there some stronger, formal bond to be discovered? No doubt, cultural historians of the next century will recognise such connections, and it will then be shown how contem - porary scientific theory emerges from the same principles that animate contemporary fiction or contemporary painting. Perhaps all of this, in the context of Butterfly Cooing Like A Dove, is to break the very same butterfly upon an iron wheel — the creature which, as the scientist knows, secretes "an aromatic substance, a pyrazine ", which may be defensive

Author: Null
Title: Poetry by nature
Full_text:
in nature, but which Rothschild interprets in a larger and more elusive sense. "Perhaps we will be able to harness this elusive per - fume ", she writes, "to evoke clear memories of the past and provide a retrieval mechanism which will unlock the store of long-forgotten events and emotions." So this book about science is also a disquisition on memory — the memory of a butterfly hunt, the memory of a perfumed garden. The author's own memories are then placed beside what might be called the memories of an entire
culture ; one illustration is from a 14th century psalter, showing boys with tethered butterflies. This is a book which celebrates the continuity of Rothschild's life no less than the continuity of the natural world itself. She describes the first song of the pigeon: "There is something profoundly moving and delightful when, for the first time, a young pigeon spontaneously says its piece, word and tone perfect, a link in an unbroken chain of gently bubbling sound which has emerged from beneath a canopy of green leaves, in early morning sunshine for thou - sands of years." Rothschild 's own absorption in the natural world is so intense that she can see everything at once, and can without strain bring together vitamin A, Jeremiah and "the retina of hens' eyes" in this celebration of the world's mysteries.

Author: Null
Title: Enjoying a piece of poetry
Full_text:
DAS TAGEBUCH - THE DIARY Und weil zuletzt beijeder Dichtungsweise Moralien uns erstlichfordern sollen, So will auch ich in so beliebtem Gleise Euch gem bekennen, was die Verse wollen: Wir stolpern wohl aufunsrer Lebensreise, Und doch vermogen in der Welt, der tollen, Zwei Hebel viel aufs irdische Getriebe: SehrvieldiePflicht , unendlich mehr die Liebe But since the end of all poetic art Is the improvement of the reader's mind (Or so we're told), my verses for their part Shall point the usual moral of their kind And say: Our life>s a road on which the heart May stumble, yet two mighty powers we find
In this mad world to help us as we go: To Duty much, to Love far more we owe. The English may admit to having heard of Goethe as a romantic giant of literature, but not many of them bother to read him. That is our loss. His Roman Elegies are one of the greatest poetic attempts to convey the happiness and fulfilment of physical love. This is the final stanza of Goethe's other great erotic poem, The Diary, which he did not publish in his life time, but consigned it, with other "impossible" texts such as the Satanic Mass intended for the "Walpurgis Night" section in Faust, to what he called his "Walpurgis sack". However, he enjoyed reading it aloud and showing it to friends. It deals with the psychology of sexual failure and psychic impotence, and takes the very unEnglish line that sex is beautiful, and good-humoured , and something to be gloried in rather than sniggered at or ashamed of. This new verse translation of Goethe's Roman Elegies and The Diary by David Luke is published by Libris. Philip Howard

Author: Null
Title: A song is not just a song, as time goes by
Full_text:
A song is not just a song, as time goes by
The popular song, according to one authority cited in this history, "is American culture". Of course, this depends on what is meant by culture. In European soci - e t ies , popular music tends to become more respectable as it recedes into the past. If it is very old indeed, it is treated as poetry, as practically all Elizabethan songs now are: many people might pretend to admire a medieval ballad while at the same time managing to despise a contemporary pop song with practically the same words and senti - ments . It is a simple matter of literary snobbery. And those who find titles such as From This Moment On or Day In—Day Out trite might care to ponder such tunes from the 16th century as Dissembling Love, New New Nothing or Saturday Night and Sunday Morn. The situation is different in America, and for good reasons. A society that prides itself upon being democratic will take much more interest in popular art forms as such, and there is in any case no doubt that Tin Pan Alley (by which term Philip Furia here associates the work of lyricists as different as Irving Berlin and Oscar Hammerstein ) pro - duced in the Twenties and Thirties writing as skilful and as effective as anything then emerging from what is often called "high culture". Not that American lyricists them - selves seem to have realised that fact and, as Furia suggests here, they tend to be variously embarrassed or dis parag - ing about their particular art. Many seem to have come to the Eliotic conclusion that the words do not matter, and are merely the adjunct to an interesting melody. As Ira Gershwin expressed it in the preface to a collection of his own lyrics: "Any resemblance to actual poetry, living or dead, is highly improbable ." Highly improbable , but certainly not impos - sible ; he may not be Wyatt, or even
The popular lyrics of Tin Pan Alley's best songwriters will outlive the works of many serious poets, Peter Ackroyd writes
Surrey, but he is " certainly no worse than many "serious" Ameri - can poets of the ~
THE POETS OF TIN PAN ALLEY By Philip Furia Oxford University Press, £14.95 '
were an influence upon the work of such "serious" poets as Auden or - Eliot The ca -
20 th century . And that is the oblique point Furia makes throughout this volume: he is sensible enough to treat the lyrics for what they are, expert and graceful attempts to find the expressive face of a melody, and learned enough to make cultural comparisons on a grand scale. In fact, his frequent allusions to the work of e.e. cummings, William Carlos Williams and Mari - anne Moore only serve forcibly to suggest that the poetry of Cole Porter or Johnny Mercer will be sung long after that of Moore, for example , has been forgotten . N evertheless , on the evidence collected here, most Ameri - can lyricists are altogether insecure about their art and their position; many of them emphasise the fact that the best songs took only IS or 20 minutes to write, while others are at pains to suggest the improvisatory nature of their activity. This surely does not disqualify them from being artists , however, many famous poems and paintings have been produced with even less effort , and only the latent Puritanism of the American character could disqualify the work of men (and a few women) who spent a lifetime shaping the right words to the right melody. As a result many of the lyrics seem as witty and as poignant now as they did when they were first written, and it should not be forgotten that they
dences and phrases of these lyricists have found an enduring place in the literary culture of America: not just in the way that the "pop art" of the Sixties wilfully embraced commercial im - agery , but because the popular song addresses a deep need in the American spirit for colloquial force and vernacu - lar rhythm . Furia explains this better than any abstract disquisition when he lists such popular titles as / Guess I'll Have To Change My Plan, How Long Has This Been Going On?, Just One Of Those Things, I Should Care and From This Moment On. Cheap music is potent, not because it is cheap at all, but because it can create an immediate mood and, as a result of that immediacy, can conjure up the very conditions of the world (both private and public) in which it was composed . It relates to a specific time, and even a specific place ; as a result , it preserves them for ever. However, it is also important to see these lyrics on their own terms, as expressive and frequently ingenious attempts to shape words around music, so that the strict demands of what is generally an eight-bar unit are aligned with the melodic imperatives of the lyrics themselves. It is an artificial art, in other words, and that in the best possible sense — a sense which the Elizabethans , as the last great genera - tion of popular lyricists, would have understood very well. So let us now
praise some famous New York poets — Irving Berlin, one of the great geniuses of American music, who worked his way to the top. He began as "plugger" of sheet music and singing waiter to become an absolute master of the popular song — whether it be in his earliest success, Alexander's Ragtime Band, or in later and more nostalgic lyrics such as What'HIDo ?ot As Time Goes By. F uria also charts the history of those who followed — among them Lorenz Hart , who first combined "society verse and popular song ", and Ira Gershwin, who helped bring the song lyric into adulthood after a prolonged period of romantic adolescence. But it is Cole Porter who more than anyone seems to embody the sophistication songwriters are thought to represent (and which mod - ern songwriters, justly or unjustly , seem to have inherited): this may be a confusion between the writer and the singer, however, with the popular conception of the lyricist as a sort of literary Fred Astaire. Nevertheless Por ter's decline after a riding ^ accident heralded the return of a more primitive chromaticism, a lyric dark age in which Oscar Hammerstein was the only fitful light Yet there had been between the wars what Furia calls here a "golden age ". In that period American songs achieved a greatness which can properly be com - pared to that of the Elizabethan era — or, if that sounds too grandiose , at least to the tradition of the 18th-century street ballad. Such works achieve a kind of immortality because they manage effor tlessly to convey the atmosphere of a lost period, while at the same time expressing sentiments that are readily identifiable across the centuries . That was the real achieve- - ment of Tin Pan Alley.

Author: Howard, Philip
Title: Gaining in the translation
Full_text:
Gaining in the translation
You may well think that no great poetry is being written today. I could not possibly comment, except to observe that great poets come as single spies, not in battalions, unless you are lucky enough to be born a contemporary of Ovid, or Marlowe, or Tennyson, or maybe, pushing it a bit, Eliot And the single spies come in
unexpected disguises, and are not immediately recognised. His contem - poraries tended to think of the young Shakespeare as a ranting show-off and candidate for Pseud's Corner. Poets are not very useful, because they are not consumeful or very produceful. In one little-noticed field great poetry is still being turned out today; and that is in the field of translation. All great classics need to be continually retranslated, to keep up with the shifting tides of language and scholar - ship , and the new concerns of a new generation. A great work of literature interacts with its translations, which are its footnotes and children down the centuries . Homer sets Virgil off on to his Italian Odyssey and Iliad, and their epics ripple through the work of subsequent poets from Milton to Tennyson to Joyce. Our modern translations are the forgotten army of the great poetry being written today. They are the best translations (even, to an extent, for understanding such maligned works as The New English Bible), because they are written for us
now, and crown the works that have gone before. It is a field in which our generation excels. Today we get David West's new translation of the Aeneid, for which we have waited as long as Odysseus dallied on Calypso's island , and with as much agreeable impatience. He has trans - lated it into prose, partly because he says he is no poet (not strictly true), and partly because nobody reads things that are set out as long narrative poems any more. But set it out how you like, this deploys the power and music and range of contemporary English prose in an unobtrusively poetic way. The single spy has slipped past you unnoticed . West is an ace at the rhetorical device called polyptoton, repeating the same word in a different case or inflexion — a kind of grammatical rhyme. Virgil was also fond of the trick,
but West uses it on occasions where Virgil did not, to convey an effect in heavily inflected Latin that cannot be turned into almost uninflected English. It is the most truthful translation ever, conveying as many nuances and whispers as are possible from the original. This is a highly rhetorical version of an intensely rhetorical poem. Recent commentary has seen the Aeneid as a subversive samizdat protest against the brutalities of Augus - tan imperialism. This suits the anti - imperialist interests of our generation. Westxestores the Aeneid to its original purpose as a panegyric in praise of Virgil's patron, the ruler of Rome, although I think he skates over some of the darker undertones beneath the praise rather lightly. He turns the spotlight on bit players, whose characters Virgil caught for all eternity in a snatch of dialogue , or a description of movement. The Sibyl is
