Author: West, David
Title: Latin lover and performing flea
Full_text:
Latin lover and performing flea
O vid is the performing flea of Latin poetry and no translator could hope to jump so high or draw such gilded coaches; but Melville has worked a miracle. It is difficult to imagine that there will ever be an English version so faithful to the Latin , and written in such sound and engaging verse. Melville insists on rhyme , believing that the brilliance of Ovid's verse cannot be re - produced without it; but he avoids the tedium of an unmixed diet of rhyming couplets by using a variety of metres, notably a Melvillian quatrain : Your husband will be there at the same dinner I wish your husband his last meal tonight. I'm just a guest then , gazing at my darling While at your touch another takes delight. And you to warm another's breast will snuggle While round your neck his arm at will he throws . No wonder that for fair Hippodamia , When wine went round, the Centaurs came to blows .
But the translator can't win. There is a gain in suppleness and variety, but it does not compensate for the loss of the Ovidian glitter. Another difficulty for the trans - lator is the level of Ovid's lan - guage . It is so plain, natural , and easy . When he was young he found it difficult to write prose but the poetry flowed — et quod temptabam scribere, versus erat. There are moments when this translation sounds a little dated . This would never have done for Ovid , who was above all a creatur e of his age: The good old days indeed ! I am, thanks be, This age s child: it 's just the age forme . Perhaps , after all, the answer is to drop rhyme and find a scholar poet Guy Lee in 1968 was further from the Latin but closer to the Ovidian esprit. Your husband? Going to the same dinner as us? I hope it chokes him ... You' ll lie there snuggling up to him ? He' ll put his arm round your neck whenever he wants?
OVID The Love Poems Translated by A. D. Melville Oxford, £15 You would not know it from the title page, but the introduction explains that when we leave the Amores and come to the Ars Amatoria , we are reading not Melville's translation , but bis modernization of the dazzling 1935 version by B. P. Moore. For example , when ladies go to the theatre "They come to look and to be lookedat too. . . " (spectatum veniunt, veniunt spectentur utipsae ) "Secure the mistress first: post - pone the maid. .. " "Gods have their uses: let's believe they 're there... " "I hate a wench who gives because she's bound, While coldly thinking of the wool she's wound . I like not joy bestowed in duty's fee, I'll have no woman dutiful to me."
D elicious . And yet And yet Although it has all the "snap and tang" of the Ovidian elegiac , the fixed rhyme and the fixed number of syllables make it just that little bit less genial. It cloys quicker. Rhyme is tremendous fun in Byron and Gilbert It can't be much fun for a faithful translator. These are astonishing poems, and Melville (and Moore) have worked wonders with them, all the more so since Melville finds Ovid's attitude to women offen - sive , and the poems heartless. But surely Ovid is at play, and the elegiac lover and the elegiac mistress are pawns in his game. The man himself is generous , joyous, warm-hearted / right - minded , sunny-natured . The world he creates is a fantasy world, like Mr Wodehouse's, and like Mr Wodehouse's "it will never stale... but will continue to release future generations from captivity that may be more irk - some than our own ". To condemn Ovid's attitude to women is like condemning Wodehouse's atti - tude to aunts. ;.
David West

Author: MacCarthy, Fiona
Title: An original guru and pseud
Full_text:
Fiona MacCarthy reviews the life and times of the poetic Hindu sage and swami of Forties London
An original guru and pseud A
T ambimuttu arrived in London from Ceylon in 1938 with nimble fingers , a seraphic smile, and (unusual in those days ) a long loose silky mane of hair. He claimed to be a prince at home, and he intended to become the prince of poetry in London. He was only 23. Geoffrey Grigson christened him quickly Tutti - Fru tti . There was something about bis cast of mind and ways with women that a certain sort of Englishman at once and instinc - tively disliked. We hear more from the admir - ers than detractors in this volume, which is what is called a Festschrift and so by definition favourable to the subject, though it is always possible to read between the lines. The 60 contributors of memories of Tambi provide a vivid picture of the chaotic character who founded and edited Poetry London , one of the few small magazines to survive in wartime, and who virtually invented Fitzrovia , an Indianate country of vagabonds and sadhakhas or seek - ers , in which he occupied the man of wisdom role. Who was Tambi? Fact or fic - t ion ? Genius or charlatan ? The best thing in the book is "Swami Rock, Riga Rock" , Tambi's own evocative story of his upbringing. In it he explains the Indian propensity for changing clothes and reversing personalities. Tambi himself had their inherited techniques. He would mesmerize people, with the stillness of the snake charmer. And then he would vanish in a little puff of smoke. He loved ecstasy , a quality that seems to have endeared him to T. S. Eliot , if not the Hampstead rationalists . Eliot welcomed him to England. With his childlike perceptiveness Tambi made the comment : "Mr Eliot is really a
TAMBIMUTTU Bridge Between Two Worlds Edited by Jane Williams Peter Owen, £25
wild man, like me." England , on the edge of war, was ready for the riot of the emotions Tambi offered. The covers of Poetry > London were de- J signed with A regulation lyre ?| birds, symbols of % pure ecstasy, in versions by Suther- ' land and Moore and
Ceri Richards. ^SJ Tambi, looking back, ^ attributed the upsurgings « of ecstasy to his childhood visits to the Hindu temples.
These liberated and exhilarated all his senses "like a plate of very hot rice and curry ".
As it happened, Tambi was himself a poet. On the basis of the poems included in this collection it is tempting to conclude he was not a very good one. Gita Sarasvati, A Theology for Modern Science is a psychedelic version of The Waste Land , with far too much about those Cosmic Geese and Ganders. Tambi's talent was for bringing but the poetry in others . He believed that every man had poetry within him, a mystical principle he took to its logical conclusion by handing out his grant for editorial expenses to the man who came to clean the windows at his flat Tambimuttu was the ultimate consulter of the navel. As described by a girl-groupie — a number of whom contribute fondly to this Festschrift — he
would quite literally gaze down at his diaphragm, seeking inspira - t ion , before answering a question. At moments we are certainly in Peter Sellarsland. Tambi's cult of anti-ego was a help when trouble threatened . He was always in debt, and he was frequently pursued by the anxious owners of the manu - scri pts he kept under his bed in an overflowing chamber-pot The famous Trance of Tambi was defence inviolable and im preg - nable : "I am not a person : I am a mood, a weather , an accent of the
mind." But in fact for a man who claimed to be so incorporeal, Tambi was remarkably prone to fleshly pleasures. Back in Ceylon, a little voyeur in the making , his glimpses of white women through an open door or window had excited and delighted him. He lost no time in England. In the Poetry London office his advances on the secretaries were so frequent and insistent a protective male assis - tant had to put up his umbrella. Balmy, barmy Tambimuttu. He
took baths extremely rarely, but an office girl recruited to provide a wash-and-whipping reported that surprisingly, his smell was baby - swee t In London in the wartime Tambi was successful because he was so different: the brown face in the white city; the pacifist in wartime. (He would playfully flick over the medals of the warriors returning to the Wheatsheaf .) In the Fifties in America the magic seemed to leave him. The explana - t ion offered by Robin Waterfield , most acid and enlightening of writers about Tambi, the spectre at the Festschrift, is probably the true one: that New York had become blase about gurus. It had had too many holy men of wisdom of its own.
If I were choosing examples for a study of the derelict interior I should certainly go for Tambimuttu. He specialized in the literary bed-sit : unmade bed, strewn books and beer cans, and the lopsided (signed) portrait of T. S. Eliot hung up on a nail. In New York , as he drank and drugged himself into oblivion, his succession of apartments, stop - overs , and hovels got starker and more desperate , suffused with ancient curries. Yes, there is an awful lot of assorted curry in this book. Tambi was a flower-power per - son long before that movement was defined. In the 1960s he came into his own again, consorting with the Beatles (in the Maharishi period) and producing a few numbers of Poetry London/Apple Magazine. Tambi was a crashing snob, and he adored the Royal Family . One of his last projects was a grandiose edition of Indian Love Poems, illustrated by John Piper. He sent a personal copy to the Queen of England, choosing as his unlikely emissary , David Frost You take what you get in a Festschrift. What is missing is a serious account of Tambi's rela - t ions with his uncle, Ananda Coomaraswamy , who, a genera - t ion earlier, made the same un - set tling journey from east to west He too became a feted figure around London, the acceptable shaman of his age. His was the famous dictum "Every man is a special sort of artist", and he persuaded avid audiences (Eric Gill among them) of the essential sacredness of Hindu erotic art A biographer of Tambi would need to take account of the role of both the uncle and the nephew in infiltrating Hinduism into English culture. It is a potentially fascinat - in g subject , which sheds in terest - in g light on British attitudes to sex.

Author: Rouse, Rose
Title: MacGowan: poetry in raw emotion
Full_text:
MacGowan: poetry in raw emotion
S hane MacGowan is the lead singer of the Pogues, a band which has cut a jagged course through the meek Eighties with their mix of punk attitude, Irish folk song-writing and im - passioned delivery. Poguetry, a book of MacGowan's fierce lyrics, illus - trated by expressionistic ink drawings by John Hewitt and the documentary-style black - and - white photos by Steve Pyke, has upset some sections of the media. It is published by Faber and Faber, and the general reaction to it has been: how can such a distinguished publishing house add a rock-and-roll item to an august poetry catalogue? "It was commissioned as a popular culture book and not as a poetry book," says Tracey Scho - field , the editor responsible for commissioning it. Does this mean that Faber and Faber does not consider MacGowan's lyrics to be poetry? "No , they are something quite different," Schofield says. "There is a narrative and they make great stories, but they have choruses and are quite formal." According to the illustrator, John Hewitt, "it has brought a lot of snobbery crawling out of the woodwork. The original idea was for a Pogues tour book; there are so many members of the band that
they are like a travelling troupe and they are very democratic All the crew has equal status." Grad - ually the project turned into an illustrated book of MacGowan's lyrics. "After all, without him there wouldn't be the Pogues," says Hewitt "He is the focus." Initially Hewitt, who conceived the idea of the book with photog - rapher Pyke, wanted to do detailed illustrations to accompany the songs, but "they became immedi -
ate , captured-moment sketches," he says. "Some of them do refer to the lyrics but it's more my observations." Hewitt's usual subject matter — London streetlife, the low-life rather than the street credible — made him an appropriate match for MacGowan, whose preoccupa tion with the steamier side of life is well-known . And Pyke's method of photography was equally suited to the Pogues' style. He practises the
"propped up against the wall with a drink and a camera" type of reportage . "It's a nightmare if yon try to set up a band picture," he says. "You have to catch them like Pennebaker [director of 1965 Bob Dylan documentary Don't Look Back] does with his films." MacGowan's lyrics are compel - ling observations of the world around him: pubs, poverty or contemporary pretension. Angry feelings pour out of him but, in the final reckoning, he is an incurable romantic as well. "One summer evening drunk to hell I sat there nearly lifeless An old man in the comer sang Where the water lilies grow And on the juke box Johnny sang About a thing called love And ifs how are you kid and Whafs your name And how would you bloody know" (Tide: A Pair of Brown Eyes) Faber and Faber have printed 10,000 copies of Pogaetry. "There is a young audience who are not being catered for, who enjoy lyrics and visual stimulation," says Schofield. There is, more than likely, an older one as well. Poguetry, published by Faber and Faber (£8.99).
Rose Rouse
Shane MacGowan: his angry feelings on life recorded and illustrated

Author: Null
Title: God bless books, every one
Full_text:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS
God bless books, every one
The essential reading for Christmas: The Times critics pick the best books ?of the year in their fields, from novels i to science, from classics to cookery, and politics to poetry, in a foiir-page Christmas book supplement
B ooks! said Scrooge. "Humbug ! I wonder what we have pub - lished in 1989 that is worth cutting down trees to make paper for the stuff? The only book published this year that I like the sound of, aptly titled Vain Conceit, was by a young nephew of mine, Ddomladen Jeremiah Taylor. He argued that the English novel had become a joke, and that British publishing was a sea of com - placent mediocrity." And with a snort of distaste Scrooge turned back to the bank - er 's book, which was the only reading with which he beguiled his solitary evenings. He was secretly gratified at being haunted yet again, as the only exemplar of literary Christmas known to the great British reading public. Dick - ens ' was emotionally involved with Scrooge. He wrote about himself in the third person at the time he was working on A Christmas Carol: "Charles Dick - ens ' wept and laughed and wept again, and excited himself in a most extraordinary manner in the composition : and thinking
whereof he walked about the black streets of London, fifteen and twenty miles many a night when all the sober folks had gone to bed." Dickens always exaggerated his 'performance. He was a journalist. The Ghost of Christmas Books heaved his annual sigh. He was supernaturally tall, and spec - tacled , and bent over his walking - s t ick , and, in spite of an eternity of authors' lunches in the best res - tauran ts and publication parties of cheap plonk in plastic cups in the worst restaurants, preternaturally thin. His body was transparent : so that Scrooge, observing him, and looking through his waistcoat, could see the unpaid VAT bills in his back pocket . His name was Christopher Simply-Saintly , and henyas in the process of setting up hisbwn publishing house in order to try to please the vain and grumpy nephew of Scrooge .
"Come on, old thing ," said the Ghost of Christmas Books. "You know you don't really mean it Some of our best novelists have
books out in time for Christmas. Our only living Nobel literary laureate, Bill Golding, has finally brought his historical nautical trilogy home from the sea—phew , and splice the mainbrace, chaps, it has been a long journey, but worth the sea-sickness . Graham Greene, who should have won the Nobel years ago but for the malice of a Scroo whoops! — a mean - minded judge, has two books out for Christmas: admittedly cold cabbage recycled, viz. letters to editors and the collected epigraphs to his works, the latter working out at £1 per word written for him by somebody else. Then there are novels from Ackroyd, Anita Brookner, Drabble, Barnes, Fran - cis King, Atwood, Iris Murdoch, Martin Amis. This is a vintage year for fiction."
"Poppycock !" snarled Scrooge. "As Scrooge Taylor says, a novel is less important than a roof over your head, and a good deal less important than a square meal. Is there no Arts Council? Are there no literary prizes? Why should I have to support mendicious and mendacious authors? Who is this Murdoch you rave about ? The same one that you made me read a year or two ago? I'll warrant that her book is full of people with strange names like Gildas and Marzillian, Womans Own melo - drama dressed up in north Oxford chatter, a madman who thinks he has discovered the secret of the universe, and a closed community much like those found in James Bond junk, but less enjoyable. She has been writing the same book for years, and I didn't even like it first time round."
T hat is your loss, Ebenezer," said the Ghost of Christmas Past, gently. "There are many in the Iris Murdoch fan club for whom Christmas is incomplete without a new Murdoch. Her idiosyncratic mixture of emo - tional intensity and high intelli - gence is part of the attraction. I do not see how somebody with your Christian name can grumble about strange names. And, since you refer authors to literary prizes
for their bread, it is interesting that none of these first-rate novelists was even listed for a prize. It demonstrates better than most years the perverse and wicked lottery of literary awards.A smile of Schadenfreude flickered across Scrooge's thin mouth , like winter sunshine glin t - ing on a coffin Jid. "I did enjoy the wailing and gnashing of teeth," he said. "The Booker prize was won, I gather from the fellows at the 'Change who take an interest in literature ," (Scrooge pronounced it literachooer, with a sneer), "by a book written by a Japanese about an English butler , who did not even know that you should decant vintage port, and then thought
that it was handed round. Pah!" "Well , as a matter of fact, The Remains of the Day is a sad and funny story of failed love and failed ideals," said the Ghost of Christmas Books, who was an old - fashioned , kindly reviewer. "And wry, and sensitive, and all the other OK critics' epithets, and a perfectly honourable winner of the Booker, though some of the butlering may be a touch eccen - tric . But I dare say that the winner of the Whitbread Novel of the Year, The Chymical Wedding by Lindsay Clarke, would be more to your peculiar taste . It is haunted, and concerns superstition , and astrology, and Tarot, and bonking across the centuries, and the hero
committing the self-mutilating sin of Attis with a cut-throat razor. The reluctant judge, dear Jane Gardam, doesn't understand the mechanics of castration, bless her. Just up your street, you old brute. And if it wins the Whitbread Book of the Year, I will put my ghostly critic's quill back in the goose." The Ghost of Christmas Books spoke the last sotto wee. "You do not persuade me that it would be more rewarding than the computer print-out of my gold accounts ," grumped Scrooge. The Christmas Books Ghost pretended not to hear him. "Of course, if you want something more modern, about the state of Britain today and where it's all
at," (Scrooge shuddered), "you might consider Disaffection by James Kellman, which is about life at the edge of breakdown among the Glasgow working class today, in their own argot Just as well it didn't win the Booker, or they would have had difficulty serializing all those coarse Glaswe - g ian words in The Times. And London Fields by Martin Amis you really must read. It is about a part of town you know well, and its central character, who plays the fine old English game of darts , is a man after your own heart ." "I detest fiction ," growled Scrooge. "I prefer the Victorian values of real life." "How about some poetry,
then?" asked the ghost with a sigh. "It is a lorn, sorry life that has no poetry in it Why don't you try Michael Donaghy, who has just won the Whitbread for poetry? He is short , sharp , political , eleven., I am the book you ' II never read But carry Forever, One blunt page , garlanded " By daughter Or lover. You already know two-thirds by heart. And I'm passing weighty for a work so short. "Poetry 's for wimps ," snarled Scrooge . "Why not get a biography?" said the ghost, pityingly. "It is a memorable year for memorable lives: Eric Gill, the Young Cole - rid ge , chosen by more of our critics than any other book as the most enjoyable book of the year, or Hugo Young 's Not One of Us."
I ncest and bestiality, a bad husband and a confirmed plagiarist, and That S plen - did Woman," growled Scrooge. "Come on, dear boy," said the ghost "Remember . We go through this routine every year." And he touched him on the arm, and pointed at the sentimental shadow from the past of the lonely boy, the young Ebenezer, reading near a feeble fire. Suddenly a man in exotic garments, wonderfully real and distinct to look at, stood outside the window, with an axe stuck in his belt and leading an ass laden with cut-price not - quite - proper books by the bridle. "Why, it's dear old Terry Maher of Pentos !" Scrooge exclaimed in ecstasy . "He 's announcing, for the umpteenth time, that he is going to end the net book agreement — but not quite yet Like St Augus - tine and chastity. But what he likes is free publicity, not chastity. Yes,
yes, spirit I remember about reading , even if it 's only once a year. Let us go to a proper old - fashioned bookshop , where the staff know their books, like Heffers, or Blackwells, or Hatchards , and do our annual shopping . Composite Delia Smith for Mrs Cratchit I think. And Why Weeps the Brogan? to cheer up Tiny Tim. And the second edition of the Oxford Engl ish Dictionary for Bob. There's a book for you. It would never stand on his flimsy bookshelf, that book. You are right , Ghost of Christmas Books. Reading is one of the great pleasures of life. If only I could remember that all year, every day would be Christmas Day, and shouldn't be such a grumpy old sod."

Author: Wardle, Irving
Title: The poetry of power
Full_text:
The poetry of power
;^ f y- i THEATRE,' ^ .*
... , Irving Wardle
In this first departure from the classical repertory , the Cheek by Jowl troupe presents a piece based on the life of Ireland's only woman executioner. All the programme claims for Lady Betty is that she "probably" held this job at Roscommon Gaol in the late 1700 s. Declan Donnellan takes the legend of Lady Betty (recorded by Oscar Wilde's father) as a springboard into folklore and the fatalistic grip
of Irish history, creating a text that draws upon the dream structures of fairytale and Irish stage routines. She channels the compa - ny 's performance skills into dance and traditional Irish music. One tastes the flavour of the show with the opening sight of the death's-head heroine (Sally Dex - ter ) storming through the chorus, ragged petticoats whirling, and then imperiously commanding them to dance until they drop. The action then unfolds in the manner of a ballad, drawing a savage contrast between the Prot - estant ascendency and the des ti -
tute Catholic population. Betty reappears as a docile young ser - vant , being coaxed into a pre - seduction minuet by her employer . She then sinks into outcast starvation, and unwi t - tingly kills her unknown son when he takes shelter in her hovel. The reels and unearthly back - s tep dances are spellbinding, but they sometimes swamp the nar - rative . What is always clear is Betty's transformation' from an obscure, wretchedly abused girl into an figure of reputed power: from degraded outcast to witch and then to licensed killer.
Donnelan is in full command of the Celtic folk-tale idiom, but he is not locked inside it: he can switch to patriotic rhetoric, authoritarian British speech , and even bring on a turnkey comedian (Ray McBride) with gags about word-r processors. But poetry is the central and most sinister element . It takes over whenever death invades the stage : Betty kills her son as if in a controlled dream, and when she hangs the "whiteboy" rebel (Gerard O'Hare ), ropes and shackles van - ish , and she gently cradles his head for a long sleep. Politically she is an ambiguous figure, but in Dex - ter 's demonaic performance she fearsomely projects the control - ling shadow of the Irish past.

Author: Hobsbaum, Philip
Title: Social poetry that misses the point
Full_text:
Social poetry that misses the point
Philip Hobsbaum THE POETRY BOOK SOCIETY ANTHOLOGY 1989-90
dawn I was still/going round in circles/in a five-mile stack over Edinburgh airspace." There is in the volume a predict - able amount of childhood reminis - cence . Grevel Iindop informs us that his grandfather was in the habit of spying on workmen playing cards when they should have been labouring on a building lot Notice the mild pun , sustained through - out : "Grandfather thought he'd take/ a hand and wrote a letter to the foreman./ The games stopped." There is also a good deal of history, neatly retold. Douglas Dunn narrates an incident from pre-Reformation Scotland. It is mostly pleasant, competent and readily forgettable . The only people who really make the verse work for them are four Irish poets: Eavan Boland, Medbh McGuckian, Paul Muldoon and Seamus Heaney. Heaney, in particular, triumphs over tra - ditional forms:
Deserted harbour stillness. Every stone Clarified and dormant under water. The harbour wall a masonry of silence. This is from a sequence called "Lightenings" but it could have come from anywhere in Heaney's resplendent output It is yet another variation, glittering though it is, upon an old theme. Most of these poets seem to be living in a pastoral landscape that no longer exists, rather than in a vulnerable and threatened environ - men t Young people, on whom poetry depends , are far more alert to the change around them than these poets are. The young, in fact will not be reading this volume. You will find them taking part in workshop drama, playing politically con - scious pop-songs , reciting rap po - etry , and also speaking in the vernacular.
-;'~ :jya he editor has put one of his \rT7- '- own poems into the JL : anthology under review is ' -\ri\ and has called it an in - troduction . He writes, "it was the animals came to Adam/and told him their names/different voices." This may be all right as a poem, but as an introduction it is misleading. The poets did not come to Chris - topher Reid. He wrote to them, asking for contributions to an anthology intended to represent the best in British poetry for the year 1989-90 . Those poets who replied seem to have done so in voices that are distinctly similar. The collection would not sur - prise a reader familiar with Chris - topher Reid's Oxford contem po - raries , such as Craig Raine who originated the "Martian" school of verse (named after his book, A Martian sends a Postcard Home). Its main characteristic is looking at familiar objects as if they had never been seen before, often in the form of versified anecdote . Vicky Feaver, for instance, re - lates the mildly exotic tale of a painter and his Javanese mistress . Helen Dunsinore, in one of the better poems, describes a sojourn in Finland. Simon Armitage tells of an NHS clerk operating in a con - ventionally - imagined future: "At
There is nothing m The Poetry Book Society Anthology to suggest that Christopher Reid and his contributors would welcome an art where poetry and performance are at one. We may not like to think that literature has turned into a mixed genre. But that is ,where the action is, and it is certainly here to stay .
Edited by Christopher Reid Hutchinson , £6.95

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Great in Gaelic-and English
Full_text:
Great in Gaelic — and English
Sorley MacLean is widely acknowl - edged as an important poet in his native Gaelic — perhaps the most original and inventive poet to use Gaelic at all. Those who cannot read him in that language should lose no time in acquiring his From Wood to Ridge, a collected poems where Gaelic and English versions are printed on facing pages, the English in the poet's own transla - tion . Here at last is a key to some of the most fiercely impassioned po - etry of this century, poetry con - cerned with what Alun Lewis once called "the single poetic theme of Life and Death". MacLean's first book, Dain do Eimhir, published in 1943, still
remains his best — a sequence of love poems crossed or cursed by a self-torturing awareness of history. MacLean at the point of writing these poems was a committed Communist, ashamed that he had not fought in Spain, torn between personal and political passion. Perhaps the pressures were greater in that his Highland world was so narrow? Perhaps that world was not narrow at all, but the force of MacLean's feelings would have gone to the making of powerful poetry at any time and in any place? Whatever the reason, here it seems are the poems which none of the English language poets of the 1930s managed to write.
But for you the Cuillin would be an exact and serrated blue rampart girdling with its march-wall all that is in my fierce heart. This, the beginning of "The Blue Rampart" , is typical of MacLean in that while it does not employ the word "love ", it is suffused by that emotion to such a degree that its intensity restores tarnished images to a state of grace. The other big achievement here is without doubt the strange poem "Hallaig" , in which the deer on the high hills are celebrated as creatures of myth. This has an extraordinary tone — raw, peremptory, preoccu pied with absolutes, indifferent to cleverness, the real thing. MacLean reveals himself to the reader with - out Gaelic as a poet of the first rank within the Gaelic tradition. Rilke has a phrase somewhere
Robert Nye FROM WOOD TO RIDGE (O Choille gu Bearradh) Collected poems in Gaelic and English By Sorley MacLean Carcanet , £18.95 RILKE: DUINO ELEGIES Translated by Stephen Cohn Illustrated by Elisabeth Frink
^^w^^Hji y ^wii
Carcanet , £15 hardback, £6.95 paperback about the poet being a "ringing glass that shatters as it rings" . What a superb image. But then there is really only one thing to do with a poet as good as Rilke, and that is to quote him to give the flavour of his mind and its expression, even in translation. Here is the beginning of Stephen Conn's version of the first Duino Elegy: Who, ifl cried out, might hear me —among the ranked Angels? Even if One suddenly clasped me to his heart I would die of the force of his being. For Beauty is only the infant of scarcely endurable Terror , and we are amazed when it casually
spares us I don't think this is as telling in English as the famous Leishman and Spender item which used to comprise the Penguin Rilke. What it does manage, though, is to suggest the feel of Rilke's thought, the winding verse-sentences , the way his poems move in a logic that is.quite other than the logic of prose. All that one ought to say briefly of Rilke, as of MacLean, is perhaps this: in his poems we are in the presence of inspiration. Inspira - t ion , the action of what Words - worth called "the feeling intellect", is not, of course, taken very seriously in poetry just now. No doubt that is why we have so few poets of any consequence.

Author: Patrick, Tony
Title: In their own words

In tlieif d#iiwords
Eight Commonwealth poets, nov - elists and short story writers are reading their work at the South Bank Centre in London this week, beginning this evening with Jamaicans Olive Senior (right) and Lorna Goodison, who will be appearing , in The: Voice Box at 7.30pm. Olive Senior has been acclaimed for her short stories and her recently-published anthology of poems, Talking of Trees (Cala - bash Press); Lorna Goodison won the Commonwealth Poetry Prize for the Americas region in 1986 and her new collection, Heartease (New Beacon Books), has just been published. The series of readings, called Putting, the Lin Word , is an exploration of the different ways in which writers in countries from the Caribbean, Australia and Africa have devel - oped in the post-colonial world, building on their absorption of English, American, European and other influences but finding their own voices and becoming increas -
ingly popular in this country. Novelist Ama Ata Aidob, from Ghana, joins the Jamaican poets this evening; Gabriel Okara, a Nigerian poet, is at The Voice Box tomorrow, 7.30pm, with Austra - lian writers Antigone Kefala, Fay Zwicky and Archie Weiier; Derek Walcott, from St Lucia, probably the most popular of the writers featured in the series, appears at the Chelsfield Room on Saturday at 7.30pm. Tickets for all events are £2.50 (£1.50 concessions), and bookings can be made on 01-928 8800. Tony Patrick

Author: Ackroyd, Peter
Title: The theatre of Poetry
Full_text:
Peter Ackroyd on the collaborations of Isherwood and Auden
V erse drama might have been invented for Au - den , it so suited his natural gifts: the sudden shafts of sententious - ness , the wonderful gnomic ab - s t rac ti ons , the technical dexterity, the fluid cadence which consorted both with the most theoretical argument and with the most pellu - cid detail. In fact it might be said that he began with drama—his first published writing (published, that is, beyond the ambit of school and university magazines) was a short theatrical piece entitled Paid on Both Sides ; it appeared in the Criterion in 1930 and there is no doubt that its editor * T. S. Eliot, was happy to find that his own incipient taste for modern poetic drama was shared by the most enterprising representative of the younger generation of writers. They might be said to have created between them, in England, the kind of theatre that was already a powerful force in Europe. But if there was some similarity of direction between Auden and Eliot, there were equally important differences. In these early years
Eliot saw the drama as a rare hybrid of the Mass, of avant-garde ballet, and of the music hall — remote and hierarchic, but filled with- the rhythms and diction of pantomime speech, as if Massine has suddenly begun to talk like Marie Lloyd. For Auden the drama was vaguely connected with a more than usually vague political awareness of what were then known as "ifte masses" — but if from the beginning he had said that drama was essentially a "social art", his own practice would soon disprove it. He and Isherwood (the joint authors in a volume where, without Edward Mendelson's exact scholar - ship , it would be impossible to know where one ends and the other begins) had seen the future of the theatre in Germany, and it seemed to work. And what could be more heady for this generation of new writers than the spectacle of a truly avant-garde aesthetic being effort lessly combined with political sat -
PLAYS 1928-1938 By W.H. Auden and Christopher Isherwood Edited by Edward Mendelson Faber,£25 ire and a kind of giggling camp? Certainly it seems to have been one of the initial inspirations behind the formation of the Group The - atre , the home for most of Auden's dramatic work, and the exemplar of what he called "a co-operative" and a "community" . Auden was no doubt trying to inveigle the "masses" in this enterprise, too, but the audience at the Group Theatre productions were rather more rar efied young men in dark blue shirts and horn-rimmed glasses (the shirts in particular were de rigueur) who soon settled down to enjoy what were essentially extensions of undergraduate revue. And that is largely what has been repr inted here — 10 years of verse drama, published and unpublished, but with the major items being Paid On Both Sides, The Dance of Death, The Dog Beneath the Skin, The Ascent qfF6 and On the Frontier These last three were written by Auden in collaboration with Isher - wood , although Auden was nec - essarily the dominant partner.
The first of these pieces, Paid On Both Sides, is called a "charade ", which, despite its un - pleasant association with country house parties, is really a kind of early 20th-century masque: from the beginning Auden was trying to place his poetry in some context other than the proclama - tions of the individual self. But a reading of these plays is enough to suggest that the obsessions which informed his verse, and the context which helped to create it, are here merely on an away-day ticket which will bring them safely back to home. Even in this first short drama are to be found the stage cockney (always rendered in Auden's work with something sus -
piciously like a sexual thrill), the head of a reformatory for boys (ditto), the manager of a lead mine. But this was an exercise, and Auden first really came to prom - inence in the theatre with the staging of The Dance of Death in 1934, a play which still retains all the exuberance of its youthful inventiveness, and all the humour of a writer who prefers to play with, rather than elaborate upon, his ideas. The Dog Beneath the Skin and The Ascent ofF6 are perhaps the best known of these collabora - tions ; and, with their combination of comedy, myth, ritual, and Jaco - bean rant, it is impossible not to admire their dexterity even as it becomes increasingly difficult to penetrate beneath the private jokes, the recondite vocabulary of ob - sessions , and what can only be described as a form of political camp — the aspiration towards meaning combined with the gig - gling rejection of it, the use of potent symbols and beliefs in a context that really places them
within a repertoire of comic effects. And yet out of such things great beauty can emerge, and (although Isherwood himself of course wrote fiction) the dramas in this volume make it easy to understand why poets have a better track record than novelists in writing for the theatre — this is partly because drama itself has its deepest roots in poetry, but also because poetry was, in this period between the two world wars, a highly theatrical art. It might be said, in fact, that the greatest dramatic writing of the early 20th century is to be found in its poetry — The Waste Land being perhaps the most obvious can - didate for such a position. Of course that impetus has passed — fiction is now the dominant literary form, and, if novelists are drawn to any art other than their own, it is to film rather than to theatre. And yet until a novelist writes a film-script as powerful as The Ascent ofF6, the advantage will remain with the poets of the recent past, and with the plays so carefully and amply repr inted here.

Author: Goodwin, Noel
Title: Clear, fluent poetry
Full_text:
I CONCERT I
InmMunnKanranl Clear, fluent poetry
RPO /Herbig Festival Hall
With Gunther Herbig from the Detroit Symphony still standing in for the ailing Andre Previn at the Royal Philarmonic Or - ches t ra 's continuing Beethoven series, a kind of climax was reached when Krystian Zimerman appeared as the soloist in the "Emperor" Concerto . Since he first came to youthful prom - inence , over a decade ago, he has been among the most poetic and imaginative pianists around, even if occasionally controversial. ; To hear his views on one of the favourite works in the Concerto repertory was never less than stimulating, often with delight in the clarity of his articulation at the keyboard and in the fluency of his passage work. Any doubts in the opening movement were confined to his overall grasp of his struc - t ure , being inclined to press forward a shade too much to sense the power and searching character that bears the weight of Beetho - ven 's argument For the slow movement of the
pianist and conductor were in agreement on a sensible medium tempo, which allowed the oppor - tunity to appreciate Zimerman's shading of colour and rhythm , and his instinct for subtly pointed detail. This made it the more strange that he should favour such a tearaway course in the Rondo finale, darting this way and that and not really pulling it together until the closing pages. The orchestra gave him soundly paced , sometimes stolid support , following a first part of the programme in which they vig - orously dispatched both the Over - ture to Egmont and the First Symphony. The latter had the virtue of being given its fullest extent, with practically all the repeats taken in each movement , which meant that its proportions acquired a more imposing effect There was , however , little attempt by the conductor to go beyond the outline of a phrase, or to coach much felicitous feeling from the strings in particular.
Noel Goodwin

Author: Wood, James
Title: In love with breaking free
Full_text:
BM$&m&W £
James Wood celebrates the work of a purist late romantic who has written 'some of the finest modern lyric poetry in English'
} riters , said W. H. Auden, XXT are usually in the unfortu - V V nate predicament of hav - " - ''i ing to speak the truth without having the authority to speak it Auden, who never lived under a dictatorship , was giving authority a personal, authorial gloss — writers don't always have greater access to large truths than anyone else, though it is their business to dispense them. What Seamus Heaney is con - cerned with in this fine book is a harsher lack: that dark moment , experienced by writers throughout the unfree world, when authority is no longer simply how you will choose the next word, but a question of who will choose it for you. Heaney writes beautifully of the Russian poet Osip Mandel - s t am , for instance , arrested in 1934 for his grim poem about Stalin : He rolls the executions on his tongue like berries
He wishes he could hug them like big friends from home. Mandelstam 's is "a modern martyrology, a record of courage and sacrifice which elicits our unstinted admiration ," writes Heaney ; and he is rightly sceptical of the pallid pleasures of much poetry in English , when compared with the flushed vigour, the huge temerity of today's Mandelstams — writers like the Polish poets Zbig - niew Herbert and Czeslaw Milosz. But there are other Czechs of poetic authority , closer to Auden 's lucky individualism. What authority, for instance , does the lyric poet have in the face of tempestuous tragedies, material eruptions? What good are
words that can - no t hurt against sticks and stones that can? The Poet Lau - rea t e is expected to turn out a
THE GOVERNMENT OF THETONGUE By Seamus Heaney Faber,£3.95
jeers which the lyric poet en - counters . Lyric poetry, he writes , is often an em - barrassin g intru - sion , "a free gift
freshly-baked lyric at every nat - ional festivity , but the idea of his doing so at every national tragedy is hideously laughable. "Elegy in a Hillsborough stadium" ... ? Heaney writes about the tangled ethics of these eternal worries with all his customary intelligence , all his habitual passion. Conceptually tighter than his last selection of prose (Preoccupations) this book returns to its governing theme in nearly every chapter the joys and
in the presence of the unfree and the hurt". And yet Heaney cele - bra tes the miracle of this freedom as well as any poet has ever done in prose (even Mandelstam , I think). The lyric poem is, writes Heaney, "a paradigm of free action" (this recalls Auden's comment which he does not mention , that "every good poem is very nearly Utopia" ); it "always has an element of the untrammeled about it... in this way, the order of art becomes an
achievement intimating a possible order beyond itself ." Heaney distinguishes between two states of tongued governance : 1, when poetry is its own govern - men t , when it has "its own vindicating force... the tongue granted the right to govern"; and when poetry is itself governed, not only by authoritarian diktat but by subtler pressures — by the social and semantic meanings which ev - ery word inherits, and by the needs and desires of the public. (Pope would be an obvious example ; Heaney's is the American poet Elizabeth Bishop with reticent , mannerly tones, and her " inclina - t i o n to conciliate the social audience".)
This binary division confirms (if we did not already know it) Heaney as the purist late romantic, in love with explosions of the heart , with the joyous liberties of breaking free of verbal government , to reach that moment when , as he writes , "the tongue is suddenly ungoverned". And why should Heaney sink this lovely buoyancy? His romanti - cism has produced some of the finest modern lyric poetry in English (along with Derek Walcott and Richard Wilbur). Furthermore, his poems criti - cally meditate on the very checks and liberties about which he writes so well in prose. In "Exposure" for instance , Heaney ponders on for whom he writes, for the inner lyric ear or the outer social ear "For what? For the ear? For the people?/ For what is said behind-backs ?" One can only pray that the Muse will grant him many more years of ungoverned joy.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Doctor on the table
Full_text:
Doctor on mm
Carlossness: the craft of careful carelessness , allegedly American to the core and once believed (by chaps called Black Mountaineers) to represent the only true voice of feeling ; not to be confused with real spontaneity. The book that can contain a definition like this has' not yet been written, but it will be, one way or another — which is to express the opinion, no more, that William Carlos Williams will even - tually be seen as a necessary part of the history of modern poetry, rather than much of a poet in his own right Thegentle doctor, busy , breath - l e ss , easy, and: domestic, became the GP who would set things right — away with these self-loving eclectics , "no ideas but in things" ! As a programme for the early 20th century literary scene, it had ap - peal . Williams was a healthy re - actor against the cultural artfulness of Pound and Eliot , a breath of fresh New Jersey air in the cosmo - politan wasteland. His energy and purpose still seem admirable. One's reservations are rooted in aware - ness of just how much he owed to the masters he disowned.
L§ \ * ^ssi^^^^^B
THE COLLECTED POEMS OF WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS Volume II, 1939-1962 Edited by Christopher MacGowan Carcanet,£25 . * '-
Take away the Disease — the esoteric solipsism that afflicted so many of his contemporaries — and what is left, in actual person, on the page, to this Dr Williams whom it is so comforting to praise for being "natural" ? A handful of pleasant
lyric observations, a would-be epic {Paterson) where ambition is fever^l ishly at odds with a modest meanse of expression ; a good solid novels called White Mule, one or two low< keyed short stories; and a boring! Autobiography that betrays -an ? essentially second-rate sensibility: on every other page. WilliamsV very vocal admirers do well to plug' his few successes while they 'riiay .i So much depends upon what you can read into that red wheelbarrow, those white chickens !.*• :; .1 '* This second volume of The? Collected Poems of William Carlos Williams , meticulously edited; !' means that we now have a defin*; itive edition of just about every u ' ne^ of verse he ever wrote, apart from Paterson. It isn't a bad book; if sV just that I'm sure that Williams.has< been overrated, in America'and ; elsewhere, and for reasons that'
RobertNye ;:: ;::
<NEWPAGE>
stable
have nothing to do with the health of poetry itself. Praise of him is frequently softened or blurred , for instance, by a near-mystical appreciation of the conversational qualities of such lines, as these: The tree lay down on the garage roof and stretched. You have your own heaven, it said, go to it. That is a whole poem, entitled "The Hurricane" . Does it really amount to what Robert Lowell once: called "a singularly perfect thrust" ? Isn't it somewhere to the point that Williams, in setting his face against traditional forms, dodged the issue that it could be
that for centuries notions of metre have been putting necessities of rhythm to the test? He attacked the sonnet form, for instance, as arti - ficial and inimical to his concept of the- "line" and the "breath" . But might it not be that subscription to sonnet form acts as a means of giving identifiable sense to the - poetic impulse? So that my breath rand your breath have common meas - ure ? Tennis, as I think Robert Frost once ported out > isn't much of a game when played without a net. Here then , are the poems of Dr Williams. There is no net. But there will be those who claim that he has won his matches , and who am I to deny, such umpires ?

Author: Griffiths, Paul
Title: Skirting the perils of prison poetry
Full_text:
Skirting the perils of prison poetry
BBC SO/ Zagrosek Festival Hall/ Radio 3 Brian Eiias is not a composer to play for safety. His latest work, introduced at last night's BBC Symphony Or - chestra concert, takes just about every possible risk, facing technical hazards in setting Russian words and putting them into the most rarely successful of musioal forms , the orchestral song cycle, and also going for moral danger in taking its texts from prison poetry. No doubt this was the
greatest. peril, that the music would seem merely to be profiting, in the at least comparative comfort of the Festival Hall, from the sufferings of its chosen poet, Irina Ratushinskaya. But there was no question of that, partly because Eiias handles her verse with tact and care even when his amplification of it is most vociferous, and partly because there is such abundant inventiveness in this half-hour score. Amply gifted as an orchestral com - poser , but finding himself only very seldom given the chance to exercise his imagination. i
CONCERT Eiias seems to have been able to identify with the condition of creativity exploding out of constraint. The result is a set of five songs in which the music responds directly to mood and image, but finds a great deal else to do as well. They are songs of innocence and experi - ence , the contraries repre - sented by childhood and imprisonment or, in the music, by the clamour of the first and fourth numbers and the quietness (nostalgic or expectant?) of the second and
last. Particularly impressive is the final pairing: the tearing, brutal sounds of "Pencil Let - ter " which never get in the way of the singer, so that the latter can remain fresh and personal (these are settings of Ratushinskaya's voice as much as of her words), and then the high, dry atmosphere of the finale, introduced by a cadenza for celeste with other tuned percussion. Elizabeth Laurence gave the work its full due of purified intensity, immediacy and un - restrained lyricism; Lothar Zagrosek conducted.
Paul Griffiths

Author: Null
Title: Wit and wisdom all wrapped up
Full_text:
CHRISTMAS BOOKS I
Wit and wisdom all wrapped up
PETER ACKROYD My choice of the most enjoy - able reading this year is en - tirely connected with poetry: John Ashbery's latest volume, April Galleons (Carcanet, £8.95), is astonishing in its range and power. Crossing The Frozen River (Paladin, £5.95), Lee Harwood's col - lected poems, is the work of a poet who deserves much greater recognition. Collected Poems and Selected Prose of A. E. Housman, edited by Christopher Ricks (Allen Lane £18.95), must stand high on any list for sheer enjoyment. VICTORIA GLENDINNING Penelope Fitzgerald's The Beginning of Spring (Collins, £10.95) is an unforgettably sad and funny novel set in Mos - cow in the winter of 1913. So much about the texture of life in the nervous, ice-bound city is conveyed that you feel, afterwards, as if you had read a much denser book.
WOODRO W WYATT Horsesweat and Tears by Simon Barnes (Heinemann, £12.95) is the most civilized book I have read on racing. It describes a year's life in the stable of John Dunlop, a leading trainer, with its trag - edies , disappointments, excitements, hopes and suc - cesses . Goodbye Fleet Street by Robert Edwards (Cape, £12.95) is the rattling auto - biography of a brilliant editor . New anecdotes about Lord Beaverbrook, Robert Maxwell and others abound. Tolstoy by A.N. Wilson (Hamish Hamil - ton , £16.95) is an original approach to the towering but tiresome subject. It is enth - ralling and beautifully written. RICHARD HOLMES
In a blazing good year for modern English biograpy, I have particularly relished a little Celtic twilight and scep - ticism in the shape of Richard Ellmann's a long the riverrun (Hamish Hamilton; £13.95), selected essays, paradoxical and alas posthumous, from the old biographical master of Joyce, Yeats and Wilde. In the same spirit, a heretical and wonderfully provocative ac - count of the earlier slorm - and - stress generation, Romantic Affinities: Portraits from an Age 1780-1830 (The Bodley Head, £16), by the young historian Rupert Christiansen, has greatly pleased. Finally, enormous, melancholy satis - faction from Philip Larkin's Collected Poems (The Marvell Press/Faber, £16.95).
FIONA MacCARTHY Peter Gay's Freud: A Life for our Time (Dent, £16.95); Michael Holroyd's Bernard Shaw, Volume 1 (Chatto & Windus, £16); and Dame Alix Meynell's Public Servant, Pri - vate Woman (Gollancz, £16.95), the most captivating autobiography for years, by the widow of the publisher and poet, Francis Meynell, who was herself, as Alix Kilroy, a woman of power at the Board of Trade. It is a candid and intelligent por - trayal of an unconventional marriage and devoted female friendship with Evelyn Sharp.
JAMES WOOD One book arrived this year with the finality of a tomb - stone , and a sad inscription for a title: Larkin's Collected Poems (The Marvell Press/Faber, £16.95) means what it mourns — there can be no more poems. Inside that book, however, are the best poems written in England since Eliot. Larkin the public property is a nostalgic whose famous philis - tinism seems like the quaint quintessence of Englishness. But the Larkin of the poems is not a nostalgic but an elegist. A nostalgic remembers the presence of the past; an elegist
dismembers its absence. For him every moment is elegiac because every moment has disappeared as soon as you live it, and certainly as soon as you record it in a poem. JONATHAN MEADES Peter Conrad's Down Home, (Chatto & Windus, £12.95) is not in the least "down home". There is nothing quaint, noth - ing folklorically cracker-barrel about this autobiography, which poses as a travel book, which in turn mutates into an hallucination of Tasmania and thence into a gaudy run-in with mnemosyne, a medita - tion on belonging, an in - vestigation of place-time . Alain Robbe-Grillet 's Ghosts In The Mirror, translated by Jo Levy (John Calder, £10.95), is another tour de force of reminiscence contaminated by invention, another record of luminous self-creation
From Larkin to Lodge, Macmillan to Mozart, Ireland to Hong Kong — a selection of Times writers and critics suggest some of their favourite books of 1988 to give as presents
BRYAN APPLEYARD Michael Moorcock, one of our best novelists, was studiously ignored by the Booker judges. Mother London (Seeker & Warburg, £9.95) was his masterpiece and should be read and re-read in years to come. John Ashbery's April Galleons (Carcanet, £8.95) was as beautiful a collection of poetry as one could wish for. As if that weren't enough, Don DeLillo's Libra (Viking, £11.95) gave one the uneasy, but definitely exhilarating, feeling that the Americans are doing something newer and better in prose as well.
CHRIS PEACHMENT Most pleasure of the year was afforded by Alan Ross's Coastwise Lights (Collins, £12.50). The autobiographical element of his book is decently modest, it is written in ex - cellently clear prose, which reads like the raw material for his poetry, and it contains acute, friendly portraits of postwar literary figures from the likes of Julian McLaren - Ross and Henry Green to Agatha Christie. I also enjoyed Barry Unsworth's Sugar and Rum (Hamish Hamilton, £11.95), and David Lodge's Nice Work (Seeker & War - burg , £10.95).
FICTION JOHN NICHOLSON In a disappointing year, I'll go for two newcomers. The Eden Man (Andre Deutsch, £10.95) is wildly funny and better controlled than anything writ - ten by Tom Sharpe since the early Seventies. Neil Fer - guson 's Putting Out (Hamish Hamilton, £10.95) was another very accomplished first novel. It's a spoof thriller set in the upper reaches of New York's rag trade. George MacDonald Fraser's The Sheikh and the Dustbin (Col - lins Harvill, £10.95) brought the Private McAuslan saga to a suitably rousing conclusion.
ELAINE FEINSTEIN Love in Time of Cholera by Gabriel Garcia Marques (Cape, £11.95) is a delight; a pungent, quirky tale of long marriage, patient courtship and sex in old age, very much his best book since 700 Years of Solitude. Nice Work by David Lodge (Seeker & War - burg , £10.95) is an ingenious and extremely funny look at contemporary. England di - vided into two nations every bit as- much as in Disraeli's time. And Tom Wolfe's amaz - ing Bonfire of the Vanities (Cape, £12.95) is satire on a grand scale - {he fastest and most compulsively readable book of the year.
PHILIP HOWARD Oscar and Lucinda by Peter Carey (Faber, £10.95) is a Booker winner that one can enjoy as well as admire.
Starting with a religious war between the generations (which borrows a lot from Gosse's Father and Son), it travels to Sydney of a century ago. Here, it describes a rich world of Dickensian charac - te rs , with fascinating detail on private pursuits from glass - making to gambling, drama and jokes. Nice Work by David Lodge (Seeker & War - burg , £10.95) mixes Lodge's Never-Never Academe of Rummidge University with the harsh world of industrial decline outside. STUART EVANS Baby Todd and the Rattle - snake Stradivarius by Teresa Kennedy (The Bodley Head, £11.95) for its hilarity, its
fantasy and its elegiac mo - ments involving two families in a web of love, laughter, envy, lust and attrition woven around the magic fiddle. Rich in Love by Josephine Hum - phreys (Collins Harvill, £10.95), for its richness in that very attribute as well as in character and incident, as a delightful young woman sorts out the gentle turbulence of her unpredictable family and in so doing discovers herself. City of Marvels by Eduardo Mendoza (Collins Harvill, £10.95), for its picaresque account of a villainous ad - venturer against the backcloth of Barcelona bustling and groaning with growing pains at the turn of the century.
ISABEL RAPHAEL After the hurly burly guess - work of the breakfast table, how pleasant to sit down with Philip Howard's paperback of Word-Watching (Elm Tree Books, £4.95), relish the wit of the false etymologies, and enjoy the erudition of the true definitions. The best news oh the novel front is that Anita Brookner is back on form with her new book, Latecomers (Cape, £10.95); and Alison Lurie is tart and sparkling in The Truth about Lorin Jones (Michael Joseph, £11.95). ANDREW SINCLAIR Ted Hughes and William Blake take the Bible to heart. Only as little children may we aproach the divine. Tales of the Early World (Faber, £5.95) may seem to be a children's book, but it is for all who can wonder with the young. I cannot remove Gert
Hofmann's The Parable of the Blind (Seeker & Warburg, £10.95) from my insight. He tells the story of Brueghel's painting of the six blind men stumbling and screaming. The door of the underworld is opened by The Lyre of Or - pheus (Viking, £11.95) by Robertson Davies. This last and best of his trilogy of novels about the influence of a mysterious Canadian painter is a book for Boxing Day to release the belly-laugh .
THRILLERS TIM HEALD In the new Deighton, Spy Hook (Hutchinson, £11.95), successor to Game, Set and Match and precursor of Line and Sinker, all the old favourites lurch about the international stage shooting themselves and each other in the feet. They're finally begin - ning to grow on me, and this time the prose seems to have lost some of the middle-aged spread I thought I'd detected.
lected Letters 1926-1950 (Max Reinhardt, £30), the last of four volumes edited by Dan H. Laurence, has given me a lot of pleasure.
SCIENCE FICTION TOM HUTCHINSON I realize I was only lukewarm in my original review of Isaac Asimov's Prelude To Founda - tion (Grafton, £11.95), the sixth in his remarkable future - and psycho-history . This, coming last, is the curtain - raiser to the others, Dr A. having obviously had sixth thoughts about how it was all going to originate. It was a book that took me back to the others and the realization that here is one of the most staggering achievements in modern SF.
POLITICS JOHN GRIGG Having just finished R.F. Foster's Modern Ireland 1600 - 1972 (Allen Lane, the Penguin Press, £18.95), I think it is the book I have most enjoyed this year. Foster is a young Irish historian without illusions. His book is large, but light and comfortable to hold; ex - tremel y informative, but never dull. A shorter book with much the same quality is Robert Kee's Munich, The Eleventh Hour (Hamish Ham - ilton , £ 14.95). As a book to dip into, Bernard Shaw's Col -
JOHN CAMPBELL The biography of the year must be Alastair Home's Har - old Macmillan 1894-1956 (Macmillan, £16.95). This vol - ume only takes him to the door of No 10, but his diary throws new light on one of the unlikeliest careers ever to have been crowned by the premiership. Norman Teb - bit 's Upwardly Mobile (Weid - enfeld & Nicolson, £14.95) narrowly beats Lord Carr - ington 's more gentlemanly reflections for sheer direct - ness . Tony Benn's diary really takes off with volume two, Office Without Power, 1968 - 72 (Hutchinson, £16.95).
POETRY ROBERT NYE Harry Kemp is the real thing — a poet who has gone his own way, indifferent to fame or fashion. The privately printed edition of his Collected Poems has all but sold out, but a copy may still be available from the author at 6 Western Villas, Western Road,i Crediton, Devon EX 17 3NA. I also very much admired Robert Wells's version of The Idylls of Theocritus (Carcanet, £9.95) and was glad to see Philip Larkin's Collected Poems (The Marvell Press/Faber, £16.95).
CLASSICS PETER JONES Adrian Spooner's Lingo (Bris - tol Classical Press, £4.95), a beguiling farrago of Greek myths, cartoons and language games, is the book for any parent or teacher who wants their 11-13 year old to revel in it. G.E.R. Lloyd's The Rev - olution of Wisdom (California, $45) is one of the great contemporary syntheses in the history of ideas: a true classic. It is brilliantly readable.
THEATRE JOHN HIGGINS Kathleen Tynan's biography of her husband was perhaps the most valuable guide to the theatre published last year. Tynan, now out in paperback
(Methuen, £5.95), was not only a portrait of a man far more revealing than one could reasonably expect from a wife, but also a sharp-eyed view of the inside track of London stage and literary life in the Fifties and Sixties. Gerald Clarke's biography Capote (Hamish Hamilton, £16.95) also portrays a man and his time. Capote's end was ugly but his beginning was as bizarre as that of the Holly - wood star he might have been. IRVING WARDLE Volume Four of Shaw's Se - lected Letters (Max Rein - hardt , £30), which completes Dan Laurence's 23-year lab - our , is a bedside book to last a lifetime, and the greatest piece of theatrical editing since Heminges' and Copdell's First Folio. Chekhov Plays, trans - lated and introduced by Mich - ael Frayn (Methuen, £3.95), is another long-term labour of love by Chekhov's best Eng - lish friend, Constance Gar - nett . Vladimir's Carrot, by John Peter (Methuen, £6.95), opens up the theatrical ho - rizon like nothing since the young Eric Bentley.
ART
JOHN RUSSELL TAYLOR The Art of Paul Gauguin, by authors too numerous to men - tion (Little, Brown, £40), would be the perfect desert island book, supposing one could drag such a hefty vol - ume ashore. It began life as the catalogue of a major show, but just as.a picture book it is splendid, and the texts throw floods of light on the art as well as the life. Nearer home, I have much enjoyed Michael Felmingham's The Illustrated Gift Book 1880-1930 (Scolar, £35), which is all about Rack - ham , Dulac, Heath Robinson and, yes, even Mabel Lucie Attwell.
MUSIC PAUL GRIFFITHS Two music books this year stand out for their engaging humanity and inquisitiveness. H.C. Robbins Landon's 1791:
Mozart's Last Year (Thames & Hudson, £12.95) con - fidently disposes of myth and substitutes truth that is, quite properly, stranger. And many of the truths arc prclty slrange that turn up in John TyrrelPs appealingly organized and al - together fascinating Czech Opera (Cambridge, £25).
FOOD/WINE FRANCES BISSELL Stephanie's Feasts and Stories by Stephanie Alexander (Unwin Hyman, £16.95) is a warmly inviting and generous book, from its sunny cover through its richly detailed recipes to the unstinting praise Alexander gives to her peers. Like all good cookery books, it is more than just a celebration of good food; it is a celebration of a place. Alexander lives and cooks in Melbourne, and she joyfully shares with us Austra - lian cooking today. JANE MacQUITTY
Rambling, infuriatingly illogi - cal and from time to time erroneous, Andrew Barr's Wine Snobbery (Faber, £12.95) is nonetheless one of the more enjoyable wine books I have read this year. Dubbed "an insider's guide to the booze business", it does its best to expose the seamier side of the wine trade and mostly succeeds. Drilling for Wine by Robin Yapp (Faber Paper - back , £6.95) is just the opp - osite : a highly entertaining, anecdotal dentist - turns - wine - merchant yarn that will appeal to all.
FASHION LIZ SMITH Voguedng into its archives for the History of 20th Century Fashion (Viking, £30), in which Jane Mulvagh skips from stately Edwardian S - bends to the body-skimming Lycra leggings of the Eighties. Sadly, the book lacks colour in both illustration and com - ment . Far more fun and stylish is Nicholas Drake's romp through The Sixties, A Decade in Vogue (Pyramid, £16.95), and Nicholas Cole - ridge 's expose of the intrigues and eccentricities of the busi - ness in The Fashion Conspir - acy (Heinemann, £12.95). For pace, plot and style all are outclassed by Fashion in the French Revolution (Batsford, £14.95), Aileen Ribeiro's co - piously illustrated account of a decade in which the niceties of dress, for either sex, dem - onstrate their shades of pol - itical opinion.
CHILDREN BRIAN ALDERSON Fleeing from a deluge of non - sexist , non-classist , non-racist angst for teenagers, I look refuge in Gabriel Garcia Marquez's ageist Love in the Time of Cholera (Cape, £11.95), and would like to think that that splendid work might give adolescents more to enjoy than the jobs run up for them in the sweatshops of Bloomsbury. For the young who are not yet up to such things, I would like to single out as books of the year the picture book by Sarah Hayes, This is the Bear and the Picnic Lunch, illustrated by Helen Craig (Walker Books, £1.99), and the highly original slory - scquence by Peter Dickinson Merlin Dreams, illustrated by Allen Lee (Gollancz, £9.95).
SCIENCE DAVID JONES Modern logic is a devious and
intricate structure, far re - moved from trite deductions about Socratcs's morality. In Forever Undecided: A Puzzle Guide to Gbdei (Oxford, £5.95), Raymond Smullyan expounds it as a scries of nightmarish fables like Alice's adventures in wonderland. GodcFs crucial Incomplete - ness and Consistency Theo - rems and their corollaries emerge almost naturally, and some recent advances in the subject are lightly sketched. Enthralling, demanding, mind-blowing ; a good way into the subject for students and non-specialists , but should have an index.
ROYALTY HUGO VICKERS Recent episodes of Heir of Sorrows by Silvic Krin (Pri - vate Eye, £2.99) are much subtler' than earlier ones. I relished Love in the Saddle and Born to be Queen, and have been known to amuse/bore my friends with readings. The highlight of every episode of Krirfs latest endeavour is when the hapless Prince recalls the words of his mentor and guru. Sir Laurens van dcr Posl: "When a man builds a bridge, he must first decide on which side he intends to begin."
SIIONA CRAWFORD POOLE There arc travel books that explain places brilliantly, such as Jan Morris's Hong Kong (Viking, £14.95). And there are books that do a very good job of describing them. Simon Winchester's Korea, a Walk in the Land of Miracles (Grafton. £12.95) was the pick of this year's bunch. I had no particular interest in going with Eric Hansen on foot across Borneo in Stranger in the Forest (Century Hutchin - son . £12.95). But it turned out to be touchingly more than a young American's tale of sweat and leeches. With him I, too, have been there, done that .
RUSSIA ANDRH NAVROZOV Scenes f om Russian Life, by Vladimir Soloukhin (Peter Owen , £13.95). "A cigarette after bathing, raspberries with milk, a cucumber with a tiny thread of dill (it should not be removed), here is my political credo," wrote Vasily Roz - anov , one of Russia's subtlest thinkers, a few years before his death of hunger in 1919. In the West, with rare exceptions like Emerson, introspection is a cerebral affair ; Russia's contribution to world culture is the use of the heart as a precision instrument.
WILLIAM JACKSON The most important and intellectually satisfying, if not enjoyable, military book of the year was Professor Hinsley's latest volume of the British Intelligence: History of the Second World War (HMSO, £29.95). Through no fault of his team of official historians, it was published when public attention was focused on Spycatclier, and so received far less attention than it deserves. Ii throws new light on the planning thai did so much to win the battles in Normandy, and on the mis - takes made by the Allies that led to the disasters at Arnhcim and in the Ardennes.
MILITARY
TRAVEL

Author: Morrison, Richard
Title: Uneasy poetry
Full_text:
CONCERTS
Uneasy poetry
It is the obvious music to conclude an "Armistice Festival", and in - deed Britten's War Requiem has astonishing moments: the inter - twining of plaintive "Lacrimosa " melody with Wilfred Owen's tenderest poem. "Move him into the sun"; the great gathering of multitudes in the "Sanctus "; the lone baritone articulating the shock ending of "Strange Meet - ing ". Having decided to link Owen with Catholic liturgy, Brit - ten was too canny a dramatist not to exploit the uneasy mutual resonances. But any pacifist who sets out to honour the war dead is going to be in a curious intellectual position. There is a feeling of woolly ambiguity, if not actual duplicity, about a work which asks "what passing-bells for those who die as cattle?" , and then supplies the bells, the trumpets, the mourning choirs, indeed the full panoply of a pompous state funeral , with its inbuilt implication that there is some point in dying for your country after all. Britten here seems to be diluting the uncom - promising message of this great poetry of anger.
War Requiem Festival Hall
Perhaps that explains the un - even musical inspiration. There is a contrived aspect to the heavily pictorial chamber-orchestra writ - ing ; and large chunks of the "Dies irac" simply fail to depict vividly either the Catholic conception of Judgement Day or Owen's vision of Armageddon in Flanders. The work also needs an at - mospheric venue. With the cham - ber orchestra squashed against the main forces, and the boys' choir in an unresonant doorway, this performance, directed by Sir David Willcocks. lacked that ambience. Yet there were many fine things: immaculately tuneful singing by the St Paul's Cathedral choristers, some excellent brass playing from the Philharmonia and strongly characterized solo singing from Sheila Armstrong, Philip Langridge and Stephen Roberts. The well-drilled Bach Choir of - fered a stunning pianissimo in the "Kyrie" and "Pie Jesu"; the orchestra overpowered them at the "Libera me" climax, but perhaps it should.
Richard Morrison

Author: kingston, Jeremy
Title: Life, death and poetry
Full_text:
Life, death and poetry
The Jungle Latchmere, Battersea
quietly spoken, thoroughly under - stood poem about death. "Black March" puts the grey visitor in sombre guise , whereas "Angel Boly" is ghoulish murder, in which the balance between a lip - smackin g relish for batty exag - geration and a stony taste in the mouth is brilliantly sustained by poet and performers to the end. Jane Downs and Sarah Cahn play the older, more reflective voices; Jacquetta May and Cath - erine Thornborrow the lolloping young ones. Sarah Harper's fluent direction develops each scene from some minor item of its prede - cessor , and only near the end stirs the incidents into a muddle. Menacing mood music is played on the cello by Ben Davis, the only male, who also makes wordless appearances as hopeless Freddy and all the other men Stevie Smith passed her life evading .
Devised by the performers and director for a company with the user-friendly name of Buster The - atre , the show is performed against a setting that is partly suburban (presumably Palmers Green), partly Douanier Rousseau. Brightest feature on stage is the doorway under the stairs, painted to represent a colossal tiger's snarling jaws —though , curiously, the acted version of the poetry featuring jungle terrors is the least successful. The imagery here calls on traditional fears, masked by traditional silly-assery . The company's training in swift changes of mood, lithe movement and bold expressions brings best results when a sense of vague alarm builds to something defi - nitely scary (locked in a cellar, punitive games) and climaxes in a
THEATRE
"I was much further out than you thought," explains the dead man in Stevie Smith's best known poem, "and not waving but drown - ing ." As a quick , sharp self - portrait of desperation, the last four words are hard to beat. The temptation to include them in a show created from her poetry must have been difficult to resist, but the decision to leave them out is correct, since the just - discern - ible storyline on which the poems are threaded is quasi - autobio - graphical . Four actresses play Stevie Smith's heroines, weaving her unmistakable verbal pattern of quirky , cocky, narcotic images , and the irruption of a male narrative voice would make a nasty hole in the web.
Jeremy Kingston

Author: Davalle, Peter
Title: Poetry before wicket
Full_text:
Poetry before wicket
( RADIO ^ V CHOICE J I have no patience with cricket and even less with anyone who is obsessed by it — bottom of my list of favourite friends is one who cannot carry on a conversation with - out sporadically giving an impression of someone at the wicket, knocking an invisible ball for six — so I approached John Latham's play Heavy Roller (Radio 4,3.00pm) with deep misgivings. Skip (Clive Swift), ageing captain of the village cricket team, is so far gone about the game that he once powdered over the dis - figuring measles of one of his team so that he could fulfil a fixture . He bought his home because it commanded a view of the cricket pitch, fills his house with catch-practising equipment, and wakes up the family at 6am by perfecting his off-drives m the hall. Small wonder his daughter has little
time for him and his wife is packing her bags. You would infer from all this that Heavy Roller is a comedy. It isn't . It is, in fact, a drama shot ' through with poetry. Skip knows when to bring on his spinners because of the "swoop of brown seeds in the
wind" that tells him how the turf is drying out, and on humid days, the sawdust he sprinkles across the crease clings to his fingers "like lost children". Perhaps cricket writers use images like this, too. If they do, then I could be tempted to scan the sports pages of The Times. After Simon (Radio 4, 11.00am), Marjorie Loft - house 's report on MPS disease in children, is not one of your medical miracle stories. Youngsters continue to die from MPS, families continue to be shattered by it, and doctors have to be satisfied with improving palliative treatment because there is still no cure. Yet , After Simon is not a despairing document Victims' families have set up a fund-raising and mutual help society, and the stricken child - ren benefit from an enlight - ened attitude that sees them as individuals first and medical cases second.
Peter Davalle
Clive Swift as the obsessive cricket captain (R4,3.00pm)

Author: Navrozov, Andrei
Title: Poetry with pimples
Full_text:
Poetry with pimples
First Lines, edited and introduced by Jon Stallworthy (Oxford, £4.95) "Whoever in middle age attempts to realize the hopes and wishes of ;his early youth , invariably deceives himself," wrote Goethe . "Every decade of a mans life has its own for tunes, its own hopes, its own desires." And, if the man is a poet ,— he might have added — its own poetry . * In First Lines Jon Stallworthy has given us a remarkable, valuable anthology of those early imagi - , native efforts which posterity, un - : mindful of Goethe 's words, brands with the term "juvenilia ". This criterion , used to select the 53 poems collected here, affords as
HBHBSBEIB
. fine a glimpse of the landscape of English prosody over the last three centuries as would any other ; organizing principle. Yet in addi - tion it allows the anthologist to uncover the fortunes, hopes and .desires of those forgotten decades 'in the lives of poets, the "early years" often glossed over in their biographies or edited out of their collected works. This is what 'makes this book original and , enduring, qualities that its original ' publisher, Michael Schmidt of Carcanet Press, was discerning enough , as ever, to recognize. "Nor else the primrose, wet with early dew,/Closes her bosom from . approaching night": Walter Savage
Landor, aged 14. "Helen , thy beauty is to me/Like those Nicean barks of yore": Edgar Allan Poe, aged 15. "Why lift the veil, dividing/The brilliant courts of spring —/ Where gilded shapes are gliding/In fairy colouring —" : Al - fred Tennyson, aged 17. "The worm doth woo the mortal, death claims a living bride./Night unto day is married, morn unto even - tide ": Emily Dickinson, aged 19. No, these are not the lucky entries in the First International Mount Olympus Children's Verse Com - petition . Precise and confident, they are the work of hands which, to quote Novalis's definition of poetry, can heal the wounds in - flic ted by reason. Or as George Herbert , addressing God, saw it at 16: Open the bones, and you shall nothingfind In the best face but filth; when. Lord, in Thee The beauty lies in the discovery
In his introduction the editor recalls young Mozart ; the parallel could be developed further. It often seems that , in its baroque and classical youthful phases , the Euro - pean musical tradition was quite incapable of producing anything bad; it was not until the romantic composers began their assault on the human soul that the bad took its place beside the sublime. Within the scope of this analogy it may be held that no poem in this book is
bad, for none of the poets is as yet old enough to attempt anything that could bring about such an outcome . In other words, these are poets in the baroque and classical periods of their lives. Where they went from there is another story. The Victorians seem to have had an easy time under - standing themselves. Charlotte Bronte, we learn, wrote more than half of her poems between the ages of 13 and 20, noting at 24: "At this age it is time that... a few at least of the countless illusions of youth should be cleared away." Tennyson
would have approved: he com - posed "an epic of 6,000" when he was 12. Not so in our century.
