Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry: ivory, stone, gold
Full_text:
Poetry: ivory, stone, gold
This haystack is my ivory tower... Reading through the delightful Stevie Smith: A Selection, cdited by Hprmione Lce (Faber, £3.50 paperback), I kept remembering that sentence from thc poet's early Novel on Yellow Paper (1963). I'm not quiIc sure what it means. Something perhaps to do with art-as-haystack (making a heap of all you can find) and insistence on thc.artist's right to inhabit somc sort of ivory tower if thc artist happens to be, as Stevie Smith undoubtedly was, some sort of ivory person. Anyway, here in one volume is evidence of a' life well-spent looking for a needle in, this haystack that was also an ivory tower, and more than:a fevL good sharp poems written: .with the particular needle it was Smith's vocation to find:
The nearly right Andyet not rufte
In lore i5 wholly evil Anderery heart
Thal loves in part
Is monraged to the-devil.
Miss Lees antholoSy draws on the whole of Smith's output - poetry, prose, and drawings. I could havec done without the last, since they seem to me to misrepresent this writeres es.sential seriousness, but then it is admittedly a most peculiar seriousness, dancing on the edge of doggerel and whimsy, deriving its grace from a habit of never quite falling over. I thinl; it was John Berryman who once remarked that when Shakespeare said he had two loves of comfort and. despair he wasn't kidding. It is that'element of not kidding, even when she is kidding that I like in Stevie Smith: This book, with its.-helpf,ul biographical and textual, notes, should serve to introduce her to a new generation of students. I.trust they learn from it that the saddest poetry can be fmun to read.
Like Stevie Smith, the Scottish poet George Mackay Browvn is a writer who has established, an immediately recognizable 'manner. He %sritcs a kind of hard. clemental
verse, always conccntratcd in his native island of Orkney, celebrating its sights and sounds, its legends, its history and mysttry, thc smack of the sea and the shout of the wind. Unfortunriely, Brown's mastery of this matter seenis nowadays to allow him to manipulate it. His ncw collection Voyages (Hogarlt Press, £3.95) strikes me as pretty thin porridge. I have never much cared for the "mystical" strain in his work, the way hc constructs litanies of namnes and places, because it seems to me that he distances himself from rality by such ritual observances. A poem like "Widowver" shows him in a better light, perhaps because there are no candles, stars,. Magi, or Stations of the Cross decorating its simple statement:
Old Steplhcni thlir,e inters nowv Has spoken to none But his cat
.,nd the.spiderat the back of his bed Anld hinmself
And to a stone in the k-irkyard WVith thirteen names
*(The last cut sharp and deep).
Patric Diclinson's A Rift in Time (Chtatto d: WS'induts, £3.95) is that .-re thing: a book: of poems which seems all of a piece, a series of small private meditations on themes of sleep and death, oblivion and mnemory. Its mood is autumnal, its tone disciplined yet intense. Dickinson has never been a poetic showoff, and the gentle trance-like movement of his. verse here is wholly at one with a certain modest tenderness which I find deeply affecting. Nor is the book, despite its slimness, devoid of intellectual point Over against Plato's view of the J created world as an- imperfect imitation of a divine archetype, with 'its implication that. art is.trivial because it leads us awaY from the True, being.only mimetic, Dickinson sets a beautiful plea for the iniportance of human love as all we caxi 'now of the divine, and for the nedfulness' of poetry as giving a *memorable voice to such knovledge:
Is defined by shadowvsflickcring
n0 1hw xwall. 0 quick, comie in, Beassolidas youcan.
That is surely the vcrse of an old man wise enough. not to rage against the dying of the light, yet sufficiently sensitive and spirited to persist in secking to make poems of those flickring shadows which still define him. The achievement is solid gold, A small handful, but the real stuff.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Disfigured doodles
Full_text:
Poetry
Disfigured doodles
I notice that these days thc Scottish poet Norman MacCaig is much praised for his honesty, modesty, and wit. Reading his latest slim volume A World of Difference (Chatto & Windus/lTe Hogartlh Press, £3.95) it is not hard to see why. Here, for example, is the beginning of a poem called Run ning bull:
All his veighlt 'sforvard.
He looks like a big black hutnchback
withI a small black boy running behJind him.
Put an invisible sixpence on the ground...
he'll turn on it.
So don 't, if he's facing away from you.
People scatter. I scatter too.
Pleasant, amusing, with just enough originality in the actual description of the creature for us to feel that the poet is doing something more than show off his good humour. The tone and the manner are .typical. For the most part, these poems consist of empathetic descriptions of the natural world - sometimes a bit Disneyish, but no matter - matched to expressions of the writer's sense of being sonlehow an intruder in that world because he has the gift of translating it into images. It seems churlish to complain, but I do detect a disfiguring note of self-satisfaction in MacCaig's refusal to write about anything which might possibly disturb him at a deeper level. For a brief time, about 25 years ago, he seemed on the verge of becoming a major poet, a sort of twentieth-century John Donne, and we do his talents a disscrvice if we let him forget it. Elegance is no substitute for urgency, and too great a proportion of his recent work looks like doodling with his left hand while his heart has forty winks. To be fair, in a poem
called Enough included here, he appears to address himself to this specific criticism when he writes:
I don't want to shuffle in a Greek Theatre
chianting powverful platitudes
wlhile Nemzesis, off-stage, gouges and stabs.
But that is to load the dice. Nobody wants to shuffle, chant, or strut - only to engage again with the kind of truth-telling he cxpressed in his line hard feeling is true exercise for wit. Wit without hard feeling makes for whimsey, and I'm afraid that's what we have in the present book.
A similar charge could be brought against much of the work in Charles Causley's Collected Poems 1951-1975 (Macmillan, £4.95), but then Causley has always been a difficult case. At first sight, he seems naive and derivative, a writer whose frequent recourse to traditional ballad forms cheapens his own vision, achieving vigour at the cost of sensitivity. His best things, though, tell if not a different story then at least a more troubling and memorable one:
As ! walked dowvn by the river Down by tle frozen fen I saw the grey cathedral
With the eyev of a child of ten. 0 the railway arch is smoky As the Flying Scot goes by
And but for the Education Act Go Junmper Cross and .
That, I submit, is unmistakably the real thing, and even if the last two lines make you wince it might be worth considering that the poet intenids you to wince, to come down to earth with a bang. Here, in short, is a genuinely popular poet, who can sing both high and low, and whose finest effects spring from a calculated interlacing of the
romantic and the realistic. I should add that there is. also a note of sheer celebration in Causley's work which makes him unusual among other twentieth century poets who have called themselves Christians.
Donald Davie, for instance, seems in the period covered by his Collected Poems 1971-1983 Carcanet Press, f5.95) to have refound his roots in the Protestant tradition, but unfortunately this experience has not warmed or renewed his verse-making. Rather, his religion figures in poem after poem as yet another opportunity for inhibition. One piece cscapes, and has sufficient life to allow me to think that the poet in Davie has not quite been extinguished by his didactic critical intelligence - a strange poem called In the Stopping Train. This man in the stopping train tries to pass the time and comfort himself by staring out of the window at flowers, but even as he does so he accuses himself of knowing only their names and not their identities:
Jonquil is a sweet wvord. Is it ajflowerinig bush?
Let him helplessly wonder
for hours ifperhaps he's seen it. Has it a white and yellow flower, thejonquil?PHas it
a perf ume? O h his art could always pretend it had.
He never needed to see,
not with his art to help him. He never needed to use his nose, exceptfor language.
I find that alm6st too moving to quote in public. I only wish that this man in the stopping. train had written some of the other poems in the book.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry Sources of inspiration
Full_text:
Poetry
Sources of inspiration
It is easy to miss the merits of Jenny Joseph. Her poems are quiet. They do not show off a personality. They make no fuss about tradition or modernity. They just are. And, like all real poetry, this means that what they are is neither old nor new, but seemingly remembered even the first time we read it: Lit the fire last night.
W'ished you were here,
Stared into the glowing coals; /Thiouglht of you, dear.
*,ood stretched alole by thefire Thinking, dear
A'icer things. very likely 7h/wan if,you'd been here
Joseph is not always as straightforward as that. But her Beyond Descartes (Secker & Warburg, £5.50) contains enough to convince me all over again that she is one of the most undervalued poets now writitig in English. Her material is honestly domestic, her manner slyly chatty; the originality of her vision seems the more disturbing because it comes in the guise of a few home truths.
Peter Porter first made his name as a "social poet" with a gift for satire. His Collected Poems (Oxford, £12.50) show that his talents in that line are authentic enough, but owe perhaps too much to fashion - the first two-thirds of this book read rather like an anthology of styles and attitudes common to the Sixties and early Seventies, preserved by Porter's wit and given an extra edge by his position as an expatriate Australian, an outsider, a dog among the fairies. His work seems to me to have changed direction in the last ten years or so, dating from about the time he wrote a fine poem called "An Exequy" in memory of his dead wife;
.4 map of loss, some posted cards,
The living house reduced to shards, The abstract hell of memory. The pointlessness ofpoeiry -
Theseare.the instances which tell
Of something which I know. full well, I owe a death to you.. .
It is significant that the title, metre, and rhyme scheme of this poem copy an earlier exercise in the same vein by Donne's friend Henry King. Porter is a highly formal and self-conscious writer. His latest work seems far more willing to put his skills to use in some attempt to come to terms with deep feelings, and he is to be applauded for that.
In his Later Poems 19721982 (Macmillan, £7.95) the Welsh poet and priest R. S. Thomas offers a comprehensive selection of work done since his Se[ected Poemns 1946-68, together with 43 new poems. While I respect Thomas as plainly an honest man and a good craftsman, I have to say that his case seems to me about the opposite of Porter's in that somewhere along the way his heart has settled for some comfortably stony point of rest where he can go on writing the same poem over and over refining it all the while of course, but never startling himself or his readers with the sort of truth that undoubtedly possessed him in the days of "Song at the Year's Turning" (1955). I make an exception of one beautiful poem, "The River":
A.nd the cobbled waler
Of the stream with the trout's indelible
Shadowvs that winter
Has not erased - I walk it 4gain under a clean
Sky with the fish, speckled like thrushes,
Silently singing among the weed's Brancdtes,
, I bring the heart
Not the mind to the inlerpretation Of their music, letting the stream C'omb me, feeling itfresh
In n.v veins, revisiting the sources That are as near nIow
As on the morning I set out from them.
There, for one moment, Thomas does indeed revisit the sources of his inspiration, and succeeds in sounding near enough to be inspired by them.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: The flash of style
Full_text:
Poetry
The flash of style
Charles Williams has a curious reputation. He died in 1945, leaving a handful of novels usually described as "supernatural thrillers", some unactable plays, a superb study of Dante entitled Th7e Figure of Beatrice. and several other books marrying literary criticism and theology. Auden apparently considered him a saint, and went on record somewhere as saying that a single meeting 'with Williams had been instrumental in his own return to the Christian faith. C. S. Lewis and Christopher Fry seem to have held similarly high opinions. But others have suggested that there was really something devilish about Williams, both in his life and his work.
Saint or devil, I imagine that Williams would best like to have been remembered as a poet. The Arthurian Poems of Charles Williams (Boydell & Brewer Lid: PO Box 9, Woodbridge. Suffolk IP12 3DF, fS.95) collects and reprints his two major efforts in that direction - the contents of the two volumes Taliessin through Logres and' The Region of the Summer Stars, first published in 1938 and 1944 respectively. What these poems amount to is an (obviously unfinished) sequence on the theme of the legends associated with King Arthur and the achievement of the Holy Grail. The poems are not presented as a continuous narra;tive, and instead of taking. Arthur or Lancelot or Galahad as his protagonist' Williams concentrates attention on a more obscure figure: the King's 'poet Taliessin.
I have found these poems fascinating for many years, but I still find it hard to say 'why. Often clumsy in rhythm and tebarbative in diction, 'they nevertheless manage to 'haunt the imagination both by reason of individual lines that seem to hold wisdom (Flesh knows what spirit knows, but spirit knowvs it knows) and by, whole passages -where imagery is brilliantly pressed into . service of an ldriginal vision. As evidence of
the last, take the poem where Williams imagines Taliessin
commanding Arthur's troops in wars. In a moment of vision, "a passion of patience", snatched, from the. centre of the battle, Taliessin is suddenly inspired with thought of Virgil finding the exact words for a line in a poem, sees in his head the Roman poet dash at the wax with his pen, and points his own spear in identical inspiration at the one point in the enemy lines which will yield:
Civilized centuries away, the Romnan
moved. .
Taliessin saw theflash of his styie dash at the Ivax; he saw the
hexameter spring
and the king' sword sswing; he
saw, in-the longfield,
the point wvhere the pirate chaos
might suddenly yield,
the place for the law of grace to
strike.
That seems to me radiant and. tremendous. There is so little radiance and tremendousness in twentieth century English verse that I do not care to let it pass without commendation.
Down at the Low Church end, so to speak, Gavin Ewart goes his mischievous merry way. More Little.Ones (Anvil Press, £3.50) is a further collection of the 'marvellously. witty and invariably filthy poems which he seems able to turn out these days without -any perceptible effort.
There was an oldfellowv called Ewvart whose verse some despised as a blue
art 7
but those with more learning, more clearly discerning.
all recognized it as a true art.
I think it is a true art, no kidding, and that Ewart is a past master of the craft of being light-hearied without- failing into silliness. His subjects are Sex- and Writers. Most of the stuff in the first category is too hot to- quote, but here is, one firom the second which made me laugh out loud; a -complete poem called "Seamus Heaney". He's very popular among his mates.
I think I'm Auden. He thinks he's x Yeats. --
On. reflection, it's\ not a bad world that gives us Charles .Williams and Gavin Ewart in oneweek.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Naughty but nice
Full_text:
Poetry
Naughty
but nice
The' French poet Paul. Ve1laine spent a good part of the last ien years of his life in hospital. Nothing surprising in that, when you consider the multiplicity of diseases he was suffering from: syphilis, diabetes, cirrhosis of the liver, cardiac hypertrophy, and infectious erysipelas. What is surprising is the amount of work he managed to get done in this period, writing 12 separate books of verse and prose. It seems that hospital life suited him, and that the nursing staff were kind, allowing him to scribble away at night wben the rest of the ward was 'asleep. Without doubt the most remarkable things he did in these conditions are the two sets of poems Fenimes/Hommes, now translated - into English by Alistair Elliot (Anvil Press, £3.95 paperback;).
These poems are obscene by any standards, not least Verlaine's own. The first set, celebrating the female body. were published clandestinely and over a pseudonym. The second. doing a similar service for the male, only appeared after the poet's death. There is still no good modern edition of them in print in France, and only six of the poem's are in the Pl]iade Verlaine. So it is especially to be welcomed.that Mr Elliot's book provides the full French text on its left-hand pages. As for his English versions, they: seem tfo me admirable - reproducing the technical zest and virtousity of the originals, as well as their vigour, their good humour, and their often manic high-spiritedness. The result is something like the best of Rochester - to seek for an Anglo-Saxon equivalent - though of course it has more in common with (say) the pornographic fiction of Apollinaire. 'Unfortunately, if inevitably. most of Verlaine/Mr Elliot's best effects are quite unquotable in a newspaper, so i have to cite the beginning of the shyer "Triolets for a 'virtue in excuse for mine being small"-as an example of the translator's
skill:
G*reat length and breadth in wi'lhat Vou feel
Is different fromn how deep it goes.
I wouldn 't claim for iny appeal Great lengthl and breadth in what you feel.
That for Verlaine's:
.4 la grosseutr du sentinent
A'e la pas mnesurer ma force. Je nepret,ends acutnement
.4 Ia grosseur du sentiment.
appears to me quite a noble atlempt to do the impossible. Elsewhere, Mr Elliot shows verbal resourcefulness equal to -his sensitivity in the matter of metre and rhyme, finding home-grown slang equivalents for Verlaine's richly gross erotic argot. Altogether, I must say that I found this little book a work of subversive brilliance, -giving great pleasure, right down to the slyly erudite and riddling notes in the back - e.g. page 131:"Why would the French call the arse a schelingophone?"
I wish that I could be similarly enthusiastic about another recent translation from the French, especially as it is ten times as ambitious. This is a new version of the complete text of Baudelaire's Les Fleurs du Mal, done by the American poet and critic Richard 'Howard, and Published in a handsome volume with illustrations by Michael Mazur (Harvester Press, £I8.95). The trouble with this effort is precisely that Mr Howard for the most part eschews rhyme, whereas Baudelaire always rhymed 'vhen he wrote in verse., Now it is of-course possible for a translation not lo follow the rhyme schemes of its original and still succeed - -1 would instance C.. H.. Sissons's. Englishing of The Dii'ine Comedy a couple of years ago, whicl even read the better for not attemptInggto pretend that Dante's terza rima can . ever be echoed at length . in English without the translator looking like a clown limping along. behind,a ballet dancer. hVbat goes wrong with Mr, Howard's, Baudelaire is that hisU- strong metrical paterns .mak-e one expect and anticipate rllyines, and. then no, rhyme
*tICC4Ic
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Grigson the Poet
Sebastian Barker is a hard poet to pin down with critical tacks. It would not be difficult to suggest that he is just plain awful - all of his books to date have contained a high quota of unsuccesful lines. bathetic images, stuff which a more careful writer would have consigned to the wastepapcr basket. Barker is not careful, he is passionate. He takes risks, he makes a fool of himself by trying to tell the whole truth. In his best work, as in his worst, he always gives a sense of thinking at the nib of his pen, working things out on the page writing like Forster's old woman in order to see what it is that he wants to say. His latest book A Fire in the Rain (Martin Brian & O'Kee/te, f3.9S paperback) is very much in character, a kind of outpouring checked bv craftiness. It confirms my feeling that Barker is the real thing, a genuine poet not just someone writing verses on the side.
That feeling, however, can scarcely be justified by quotations, and it falls to a reviewer to try and explain why this is the case. The book looks like a collection of individual poems, but it is really a single poem with a single theme. That theme, in Barker's own words, is "about adaptation to alien environment". The alien environment is Bracknell New Town in Berkshire, and the adaptation is that of the poet himself since he went to live and work there as Writer-inResidence at its Arts Centre. Unpromising stuff, but Barker plugs away at it, refusing either to despise or sentimentalize his new-found landscape of shopping centres and multi-storey car parks, celebrating the people in the place, finding meaning in their being there, making himself their voice.
It is a modest and in my
opinion honourable thing for a poet to try to do; the energy which Barker brings to the task has to be seen to be believed; there's a totally involving sense of storil to the whole: and the sequenice goes from strength to strength, culminating in two long poems which attain an almost visionary intensity. In the first of these Barker comes up with a line which I take to be central to his undertaking: Hell i.s a sutbutrb under a clawv of a foot ot( God. In the second he declares of language, personified as The Muse: She is the /Brackn/ell of Inv itmagination, even as Brackliell is the Bracktie11 of Her iomagitiation. Those two quotations must stand as indicative of the high seriousnless of this extremeiv talented young poet. The book should be bought and read by anyone who can recognize the genuine article.
So should Geoffrey Grigson's Collected Poems 1963-1980 (Allison and Busby, £9.95). This is Grigson's own culling of all he has written since his earlier collected volume of twenty years ago, and those who have missed the powerful upsurge of his gift since then are in tor a most pleasant shock. Grigson has perfected a quirky yet satisfying poetic idiom immediately recongnizable as his own. Flis strength is in how close that idiom comes to living speech, and the speech of an honest man with something true and uncomfortable to say:
Love. for which there werefew useful rhymes,
A,nd which came only at times,
IWe wrote of like priests writing of God.
Moonlight silvered a sea alley, Rain sparkled into a valle y,
Love shiould be there, we said was there.
.-And it was absent almost everywhere.
Robert Nye

Author: Dickinson, Patrick
Title: Grigson the critic of pems
Full_text:
Grigson the critic of pems
Geoffrey Grigson:
Blessings, Kicks and Curses;
The Private Art
A Poetry Note-Book
(Allison & Busby, f9.95 each)
Geoffrey Grigson was at Oxford in the Twenties, among the budding poets, you-know-who. In 1931 was published Leavis's New Bearings in English Poirv and one might have supposed young Grigson would have approved. Of course not, for he had to "do his own thing" and he soon started his little mag, Neitw V1erse, excellent in its narrow way. But Leavis and Grigson have in common that they are not "critics" in a way that Gosse would have understood the word. They arc propagandists: extravagant in appreciation, and depreciation. Leavis settled for genuflection at the shrines of Hopkins. Pound. and Eliot. Grigson isn't so sure about Pound but adds the young Auden. Incense hangs hcavy in the air. But, do vou see. Grigson "discovered" Auden. In both these writers there seems this necessity to be in first. to be the possessor. almost the captor, of their chosen poets - I might say "'pets" for there is a lovelv misprint of "pem" for "poem"
in Grigson. The tolne of"only-lknow and if you think otherwise you're a fool" pervades their works. Thev know the poems from the pems. Most of us now, and in the past. write pems.
Rcprints of reviews, radio talks, lecturcs, etc. (which are cphcmeral) do not make a book, nor should they - unless the quality of their writer's mind is outstanding. The reprinting of' old and new vonornous animosities offers disturbing questions best left to thc psychiatrist's couch. "An intellectual hatred is the 'worst". wrote Yeats for his daughter (a late poem and thereforc GCrigson-approved). "'So let her thinik opinions arc accursed." Grigson's work is top-heavy witli hatieds and opiniioins and like Ihc Mary Rose or the. Royal Georgc all that happens is that too many cannons are brought to bear and down he and his crew must go; but he is the onc saved. He has so many good things to say. His championship of Crabbe or Clare or Campion is admirablc: vet he cannot sec that his judgments arc vitiated by the silly poisons he pours inlto one's ear about his pathological hatreds. Whv should one believe opinions onl Clare. coming from a critic who has no use for Emily Dickinson. Isaac Rosenberg, or Keith Douglas?
His poetic note-6bok is full of not very sage jottings, "For a poet brains of a high order are only an advantage. They arc not cssential.'Think, of Walter de la Marc;" Wasn't this really the moment to think of himscif? Grigson is a wriicr of fantastic almost grotesquely wide reading. Chincaes is no! Greek. to hiiri, nor Russian, French, nor probably Albanianf
His obsessions with the hitherto-unknown are remarkable and often, vcry endcaring.
He *vould have made a testy,. eccenitric don, and have Icctured well on. thousands of pems; he might eyen have been a Professor of Petry - save that he has an atrabilious detestation of dons. Perhaps he sees himself as a onc-man Universitv - both Vice-Chancellor and perpetual student.
But no. this is not it. Tolerance and love and humour and humility have somehow evaded him. In these books one hcars too loudly "the thin high rarc continuous worship of the self-absorbed." He is jesuitical at heart. Who cares how many "bad" poets burn? And on the jackets of these two books he is made to look like a sort of Graham Greene.
Patrick Dickinson

Author: Ackroyd, Peter
Title: Soothing familiarity under a subversive guise
Full_text:
REVIEW Paperbacks of the month
Soothing familiarity under
a subversive guise
The Penguin Book of
Contemporary British Poetry, edited by Blake Morrison and Andrew Motion (Penguin, £1.95)
This is an anthology, not of the best contemporary British verse, but of the best publicized; although its editors would like it to be placed in the subversive tradition of Ezra Pound's Catholic Anthology and Al Alvarez's Thte Neiv Poetry, this is in fact a rather soothing collection. It is much more itl the tradition of vcrse albums for light hours, such as Poems fbr Travellers or Poets on Chiristmnas.
The introduction is heady with talk about a "new spirit" to bc found in contemporary poetry. I am not sure about that, but certainly it would have to be a free one to cover work as diverse as that which has been assembled here - from cxamples of Northern Irish poetry to the productions of the young Oxford poets. Catchphrases which include the word "new" should be treated with caution, and here they are only
a form of whistling in the dark. The editors havc simply included the poets they admire (and I admire, along with them, Fenton, Reid and Adcock) but seem hard pressed in finding reasons for doing so.
And so when they talk of this "new spirit" as being also the "spirit of post-modernism" I do not think they know what they mean. Post-modernism, as a descriptive term, has been indiscriminately applied to English poetry for at least 40 years - Eliot, the archmodernist, was also the first post-modernist, although he was rather clearer about his reasons. If the term were to mean anything in the context of
this book, it would register only a newv" lack of ambition.
The Oxford poets, * for cxample, take a familiar theme or vista and then attempt to transform it by strangeness of description: the poem becomes a special, because slightly jokey and slightly whimsical, way of looking at the world. It confirms, in other words, its own marginal status. This happens, characteristically, at times when poetry itself is surrounded by other and more dominant forms of expression - and it is revealing that the best work included here is close to journalism, or to the short story.
Most of this Penguin selection, however, is conventional in form and familiar in cadence - agreeable certainly, light and decorative. Any of it could have been published in the last 40 years without arousing the slightest objection.
Peter Ackrovd

Author: Griffiths, Paul
Title: Poetry falling on deaf ears
Full_text:
Concerts
Poetry falling on deaf ears

Author: Applevard, Bryan
Title: Interview: Geoffrey Grigson
Full_text:
THE ARTS
Interview: Geoffrey Grigson
The survivor of English modernism
In his notebook. published today, Geoffrey Grigson writes of the hunt for a cicada in the foliage of his rosemary patch. It is an image of the search for the elusive persona of the poet. His rosemary patch is Broad Town, a village in a fold of some of the few hills in Wiltshire, the idyllic dualities of which are somewhat qualified by thc militar-y air bases dotted around the vicinity. His foliage is poetry, a plant in which he has been thoroughly cntangled for thc past 77 years. With the exception of painting he speaks of anything other than poets and their work with uncertainty or amusement.
He is the most typical survivor of that peculiarly English version of modernism whicih flourished in the Thirties under the aegis of Auden. They were a less apocalyptic band thian the more cosmopolitan originators of modernism, visualizing themselves as part of a continuous English tradition rather than as presiding over the collapse of western culture. For them Joyce and Pound were gigantic figures certainly, but slightly dubious, somehow not entirely to be trusted behind the hard carapace of their leaming. There was even something ambiguous about the enticing gravity of T. S. Eliot.
But thc homc team was magnificent: "If vou think of'tlhe people you could sharpen your claws on at the time - Herbert Read, Henry Moore. Bcn Nicholson, Barbara Hepworth - and you never knew who you'd meet if you went to a party with Read, there was liable to be somebody like Gropius there . . . or Ben Nicholson coming round in an Austin 7 with Braque. He always swore it wasn't an Austin 7.. .
"And then a kind of rot began to set in, the Sitwells, Dylan Thomas; the intellectual edgc went." He searchcs round for a moment for a contemporary artist worth his praise. "Hockney is a verv remarkable painter - yes?"
Surprisingly, Grigson's spoken opinions emerge uncertainly. Thc "yes?" which ends most of his critical assessmnents is a request for agreement, a flattcring hope that his listener will approve. It is surprising if you have read his essays, in which he belabours his enemies - ccrtain academics, Pound, Thomas and all book reviewers - with something close to pitiless contempt. He quotes Coleridgc to justifv his written rage: "Praise of the unworthy is robbery of the deserving - it's a very good flag to hy under."
And, of course, thc quality of his derision makes his adulation for the small band of those he regards as deserving all the more profound, morc sweeping. "Nicholson and Moorc - they werc superior people, you kinew they were in earnest, vou knew that they were doing what thcy should be doing and doing it as well as they could. You knew they weren't cheats and you could sce their relationship with thc past, this sensc of communitv going back to God knows when, to
(rigson: a quality of derision
paleolithic times. And you really felt they weren't playing at it. That was life."
These days he has to struggle to find their like. Hockney apart. He suspects .James Fenton may be a worthiy poet, but hle is unsure. Generally thotigh he dislikes miaking contemporary judgmnctis, feelinlg it is not the role of an cider statesmani like himself. Yet he clearly bemoans the contemporary loss of seClioulsllCss.
"I was at this party at Fabers - in theirniew boardroom - it was to confirm Matthew Evans as manalging director. It was all there with the ghost of Eliot in thc eorner. Two slightly shabbv. I'aded-looking bunny girls came in to deliver a Kissogram for Evans. I mean, after all it was the hoardroom of the author of Thie llasic l aiad(. I remennber the start of'the 'gram. It went: 'Thank Evanis tor little books.' Oh deIar."
Kissogranis apart. (irigson is not one to let his anger or his derisioni turn inito gloom. In his poetry and in his prose he is an incurable celebrator of all that lie finds worth celebrating. It is enough for him that Auden lived or that his belovedt gallerv of' mine minor poets - Clare, Barnes. Campion anld 1'raherne - are there to be outind. Or even that there might be many moie lying
undiscovered in the Bodleian or the Britishl Musetim.
"I don't think anybody believes the atoimi bomb is going to go off. But even if it (toes there will be some embrvonic poets in Platagonia or Australia."
With tihe publication of three books this week Grigson is keeping up his usual rate 01 outptit. The poems between 1963 and 1980 are collected, and his second collection of' essays appears. And for the lirst time hie has brought out his notes in a volume entitled Thle Priatwe .lrt. He was inspired by the notebooks of Valery.
It contains an odd mixture of lyricism, common sense and happy abuse; buit. most important of all, it containis a lot of (irigson, the cicada peeping out of the loliage:
"He is a symbolist. a purist, an imagist, a modernist. He is not a synmbolist, a purist, an imagist, a modernist.
"W\hat does it matter if he is not a fool?"
Bryan ADDlevard
