Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: The return of the Metaphysical Kid
Full_text:
The return of the Metaphysical Kid
The Occasions of Poetry
Essays in Criticism and Autobiography
By Thom Gunn
Edited by Clive Wilmer (Faber, £6.95)
The Passages of Joy By Thom Gunn
(Faber, £4 paperback £3)
"Man, you gotta Go. " At Cambridge in the mid-Sixties I remember we backed Thom Gunn or Ted Hughes, just as we backed either The Stones or The Beatles. Gunn was definitely the Heavy Metal side in those days - the Metaphysical Kid, with all those motorcycle poems, the leather heroes, Elvis and Marlon and Dean (already coolly retro), the Existential Lover growling "Even in bed I pose", the "toughs of history", Corialanus and Von Stauffenberg, Byron and not Shelley, and the unforgettable "Sad Captains" who withdrew to an orbit and turned "with disinterested/ hard energy, like the stars". (The electric half-rhyme, "failures"). Well, I still think that's how you should start to learn poetry: intellectual excitement plus rhythm.
In fact Gunn was already way ahead, living in San Francisco, discovering communes and body contact and LSD, and wrnting the much freer syllabic verse of Touch (1967), and then Moly (1971) - moly being the magic herb (sure) that Hermes gave to Ulysses before entering the dangerous, beautiful zone of Circe, where tough explorers became sloppy, sun-worshipping swine. Some critics felt that California had indeed changed Gunn into something of a poetic pig, the old Yvor Winters' precepts of Energy and Rule, swamped by the hot, laid-back, far out West.
Now Thom Gunn is 53. He has published eight major books over nearly thirty years, and his career makes a distinct and significant shape in the development of modern British poetry. He describes this shape with modesty and great charm in the autobiographical sections of The Occasions of Poetry, his first collection of prose pieces and critical esssays dating between 1965 and 1979.
The shape is indeed Circean, because it consists of a series of transformations. He moves from Cambridge to San Francisco, from a cold culture to a hot one; from strict metrical forms to lesser syllabic structures that concentrate on "spontaneous perceptions"; from guarded heterosexual poetry, to the openly homosexual; from a kind of pop existentialism, concerned with "identity" and "pose", to a deeply felt exploration of tenderness, physical sharing and emotional trust. He tells us a great deal about his parents (especially his mother, who died when he was fifteen), about his intellectual influences, about his friends.
The collection also contains essays on Ben Jonson, Fulke Greville, William Carlos Williams, and Gary Snyder (a typically Gunn-like piece of flexible rostering), together with one of the best studies of Thomas Hardy's ballads I have ever read.
As for the new book of poetry, it marks a fascinating if diffuse growth of Gunn's muse: another layer, a new skin, but patchy and raw in places. The title comes from Dr Johnson: "Time hovers o'er, impatient to destroy, / And shuts up all the Passages of Joy" (The Vanity of Human Wishes). The prevailing mode is elegiac, a turning back and remembering, which is perhaps one of the dominant modes of the late Seventies.
Thom Gunn: back home
Some of the shorter poems will I think stand among the best he has written: "The Cat and the Wind", about the processes of perception and inspiration; "The Conversation" which might bear comparison with Edward Thomas's poem to English Words; and "June", a deceptively, simple lyric about the sustaining nature of love.
There is also a near-perfect sonnet based on young Keats's meeting with the aged Coleridge at Highgate. It is a dialogue between Youth and Age, but also to some extent between Gunn and his critics. In the first part, Coleridge notes that Keats is "Loose, slack, and not well-dressed". Here is the second part, the sestet, with Keats walking home:
He made his way toward Hampstead so alert
He hardly passed the small grey ponds below
Or watched a sparrow pecking in the dirt
Without some insight swelling the mind's flow
That banks made swift. Everything put to use.
Perhaps not well-dressed but oh no not loose.
It adds a peculiar resonance to know that Thom Gunn too, grew up on that Heath. Man, he had to Go, had to get out. But he has found himself, I think, back home in the only tradition that matters.
Richard Holmes

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
"His images have an admirable violence", wrote Edwin Muir, in a review which. helped to establish . Ted Hughes' reputation, as it were overnight, when his first volume The Hawk in the Rain appeared some 25 years ago. The violence has. since struck other critics as less than admirable. If Shelley was guilty of sentimentality in hailing the skylark as a blithe spirit, then there may be a mere inversion of this attitude in Hughes crying:
I suppose you just gape and let your gaspings
Rip in and out through your voicebox
0 lark
But this is to criticize Hughes, as his work demands, from the highest level. He is a serious and authentic poet, restless in everything save his commitment to poetry. This fact comes out loud and clear from his Selected Poems 1957-1981 (Faber Â£4.95, Â£2.50 paper).
Made by Hughes bimself, this selection draws' on all published wotk to date, and*
in particular it supersedes the similar volume of 1967 by giving generous representation to the seven volumes from Crow *to Under the North Star. It thus provides an authoritative introduction to a possibly major poet. If I sound. less than certain irk admitting him to that status, it is because for. my money Hughes has never really surpassed the excellence of the early poem which begins this book, "Thought-Fox", a poem which is as much about the act of writing a poem as it is about the animal which provides the poet with his focus. The- fox enters the poem with a fine physicality: Brilliantly, concentratedly,
Coming about its own business
Till, withl a sudden sharp hot stink of fox
It enters the dark hole of the head.
Yet Hughes is on record as telling how he wrote this poem in a room in London, after a time when he had written little or nothing, and it is clear from the context that the fox's physical presence as it enters the poet's imagination is being identified with the influx and. effect of inspiration itself:
The window is starless still; the clock ticks,
The page is printed.
The "violence" in such a poem is well-contained in a cage of words. I find it preferable in every way to the strutting, ranting, and spilling which characterizes Crow and its derivatives, but I may be wrong.
Karol Wojtyla is also unignorable, but hardly for poetic reasons. If he had not been translated into being Pope. John Paul II then I am sure that his-Collected Poems would not now be appearing in an English version by Jerzy Peterkiewicz (Hutchinson, Â£4.95 paperback). These shy, rambling, worried; and - it must be said - interminably prosy verses are probably no real index to the Pope's mind. But I suppose it is something to have a failed poet occupying St Peter's chair, and not so very surprising that the poor chap sounds like Stephen Spender, returning again and again to images ot eyes and light and frontiers and electricity. He
is best at his most Spenderish. Thus:
Electricity here is fact and symbol.
I look through eyelashes into the eyes:
light through a transparent grove.
The only thing that is not Spender is the title of the poem which gives rise to this - "A bishop's thoughts on giving the sacrament of confirmation in a mountain village."
Ronald Duncan's Collected Poems (Heinemann/Quixote Press, Â£10) is hugely ambitious - wilfully so, in the manner of his mentor Ezra Pound. Duncan has always
taken risks. They are the risks which a poet of vision ought to take. Unfortunately Duncan is not a poet of vision, but a minor poet writing about vision. I like him best at his most honest, modest, loving, and hopeless: when he sounds like a little Elizabethan born too late, as in this complete poem entitled "Epitaph":
Here lics my Mother
My loss, her profit.
My wuhole life's buried here
Chuck earth upon it.
Robert Nye

Author: Howard, Philip
Title: The Chinese in love
Full_text:
The Chinese in love
New Songs from a Jade Terrace
By Anne Birrell
(Allen & Unwin, Â£15.95)
Golden orioles pass through green boughs. I whisper my passion to the lipstick on her mouth. Spring passes, he has not returned; she watches blossom all turned to leaf. Clearly the old, old malarkey of love poetry; but exotic and mandarin, wouldn't you say? Not quite your Ted Hughes. The 656 poems in this famous anthology were written between 14 and 18 centuries ago, in the era of Chinese history known as the Southern Dynasties. They were collected by a court poet, Hsu Ling, around the year 545, and became for China what Palgrave's Golden Treasury was for Victorian England. This is the first unabridged and unexpurgated translation into a Western language.
And it is a strange door into the boudoir that they open for us, my masters. This is a melancholy, claustrophobic world. Lovers seldom meet in the poems. A woman is always waiting in obsessive longing for a man who is off down the road of life, often eager for his next amorous encounter. It is a polite world. Breasts, buttocks, hips, and genitalia are conspicuously absent: contrast their prevalence in Sanskrit and-Occidental love poetry. Instead lipstick, slee-
ves,and belts become erogenous zones.
The imagery is complex and alien. For us a dragon signals a virgin-eater that' needs to be slain by a hero on a white horse. On the jade terrace your dragon is a fertility symbol; or and also the emperor; or and also the celestial courser of a divinity. The jade terrace of the title can be a platform for dancing, or the haunt of a sexy mountain goddess, or a mirror-stand. The poems are dense. with puns and allusions that would fly over our heads without the notes.
So what is there in them for us, a world away in time and space? Critics of mainland China call them a poetic disgrace, and worthless, as the product of an aristocratic society. "The sound of a state in collapse"; "not for gentlemen"; they have been criticized for mannerism shallow conventionality, tedious cleverness, excessive allusion, pretentiousness, and ornateness. In fact, as well as opening a bamboo curtain on the romantic conventions of traditional China, they show that the Chinese heart in love beats much like hearts in that condition the world over. Dr Birrell's scholarly and tender translation of these love poems of erotic decor, decorously erotic, fulfils the purpose of the original compiler, old Hsu Ling: "For long hours be diverted." -
Philip Howard

Author: Ayer, A. J.
Title: Poet as terrapin
Full_text:
..........>r
Poet as terrapina
Roy CamDbeli
A Critical Biography
By Peter Alexander
(Oxford, £12.50)
Although he was a prolific writer, publishing fifteen volumes of verse between the years 1924 and 1954, Roy Campbell is not now generally thought to have made an outstanding contribution to English poetry. While specimens of his work appear in some anthologies, notably 'The Faber Book of Twentiethi Century Verse, he is probably best remembered for the youthful epigram which he was prompted to write by the popularity in his native South Africa of the novelist Sarah 'Gertrude Millin:
You praise the firn restmint with which they write -
I'm with you there of course:
They use the snaffle and the curb all right,
But where's the bloody horse?
Royston Dunnachie Campbell, to give him his full name, was born in Durban, Natal, in 1901 to parents who were both of Scottish descent. His father was a prosperous doctor. In spite of his being badly treated by the 'headmaster of Durban High School and of being less keenly addicted than his four brothers to hunting, shooting or fishing he appears in the main to have had a happy childhood, displaying an apttude for drawing and painting as well as for writing verse.
After an unsuccessful attempt to run away and enlist when he was only 15, Roy Campbell left for England as soon as the war was over. He failed to obtain the academic qualifications for admission to Oxford but made friends then with William Walton and T. W. Earp and through them with such people as the Sitwells, Aldous Huxley and Augustus John.
He had one or two homosexual affairs but was more attracted to women and in 1922 he married Mary Gorman, a beautiful girl, also the daughter of doctor and three years older than' himself. They were very poor and lived in a small cottage in Wates where their eldest daughter was born and Roy completed his first book The Flaming Terrapin. The terrapin was supposed to be a symbol of male energy and the poem was favourably received by the critics for its romantic verve.
The Campbells returned to Durban for the years 1924-6, a period which saw the birth of their second daughter and Roy's father's death. On their return to England they rented a cottage in Kent in
the' :nelgbourlaod, Qf. '; Nicolsons- who t'olk .them'.U and=iniroducpd them te thei
friends.~ Onhe r'esult of `(-is, was, thit ;Mary ha-d..'a love, affair, with VitT a.ckvileWest. ' nlike Vit;q:- bMary. took the' affair-ver seriously and' so: did Ro ' who.was, shocked. and-'humil;ted. HeG revenged him'seIf. by publishing The
eorgiad, inwhich. ae *t-
tackfedtile 'Nicolso'ns and all' their. crsl*. The following onslaugiht on Vita is 'typical:
Each, -titled .bawd, born ?nier. 'Kcnus' htn, -:f
Too0gaU4t aid long- to atct X man
But. pruid: 'in love to - wen whqt shesan c- . ,.
Amon' her- peers wUIl st some cultt iafshion: : '. Where^ pedanitl con macuJwd
Spasison-..e--,' -
But Xor ili its venom and the' range of its targets the poem seems not to have drawnX much blood.
By 1929 the Campbells were back' together in Provence. Four'-years later they moved to Spain where they were both converted to Roman Catholicism. L-iving in Toledo, the became ardent partisans of Franco in the Spanish Civil War, in which Rsoy falsely claimed to have *fought. He did write propa-
anda mainly in the form of a ;lastily written poem entitled "Flowering Rifle". What was probably harder for him was a year's abstinence in fulfil-' ment of a vow not to drink alcohol until Franco's victory.
His espousal of Franco's cause brought Roy Campbell into conflict with the group of young English poets whom he collectively satirized as Macspaundey. His 'main charge against them was later to be that they were non-combatants in the Second World War. This was true of him also, though he often pretended otherwise. He joined the army and rose to the rank of sergeant but was prevented from fighting by ill-health.
After the war Roy worked for a time at the BBC finding a congenial drinking companion in Dylan Thomas. Then in 1952 the Campbells emigrated to Portugal where Roy spent most of his time working hard at making translations from Spanish and Portuguese. In 1959 they suffered a car accident on their return home from spending Holy Week in Seville and Roy was killed. Mary lived on until 1979 holding his memory in affection.
Mr Alexander tells this rather sad story competently mostly letting the facts and numerous auntations sneak
tor themselves.
A. J. Ayer

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
"The poem," saiys the poet, "is concerned with language on a very plain level". An unremarkable statement. But the poet saying it. is John Ashbery, master of that New York school which flirts with nonsense, delights all fans of the difficult and the obscure, eschewing any kind of clear subject matter. Ashbery's friends and disciples throw words at the page much in the manner of Jackson Pollock hurling paint at a canvas, with results about as interesting as the average Rorschach test. I think it worth insisting that Ashbery himself has another dimension. The content of his work may be elusive, but the structures have grown increasingly formal, even beautiful. The fifty poems collected in Shadow Train (Carcanet, £3.25) are each of them sixteen-lines long, governed by immediately distinctive and memorable rhythms, and above all possessed by a sense of humour which makes even their most hermetic moments agreeably modest. Ashbery has been compared with Wallace Stevens, hailed even as a
'philosophical" thinker. I regard this as a serious misrepresentation of his gifts. An English reader is more likely to be reminded of Edward Lear: there is a similar manic despair informing his jokes apd inventions, and the tension between that concern with language on a very plain level and the hectic refusal to come clean about whatever it is that pricks him into verse in the first place makes for some extraordinary effects, the finest of which do not preclude tenderness.
George MacBeth's Poems from Oby (Secker & Warburg, £4) shows a writer who was once as cosmopolitan as Ashbery trying to break new ground. Only one poem in the book, 'Thoughts on a Box of Razors", -harks back to the familiar MacBeth in its preoccupation with violence, menace, the poet as a sort of Jack the Ripper stroking his own wit as it it were a knife with which he might do unmentionably nasty things to his Muse. For the rest, the tone is domestic, the setting pastoral, and the mood rather wilfully contented. MacBeth has apparently settled down in a Norfolk rectory, calmed his imagination by concentrating on country matters, and decided that it is time to take risks by rhyming flowers with showers, and stavihg off melancholy with: verses like this:
The blend of ecstasy and filth
In smell of drazns, an robin-song, Offers the kin of fruitful tilth
In which a poem might grow strong.
In my opinion, the tilth is not yet fruitful enough to make these poems strong, but there are sufficient successes (e.g. the excellent "To Preserve Figs") to make me hope that MacBeth will continue to cultivate his rural garden.
P. J. Kavanagh has always been a poet who seems equally at home (yet intelligently uneasy) whether in city streets or muddy ploughlands. His Selected Poems (Chatto & Windus £4.95) isC a very fine book indeed, and leaves. me in no doubt that. the time has come for, a reassessment of the reputation of this unambitious btut most accomplished writer. Kavanagh (who is the son of Ted Kavanagh who wrote the scripts for "Itma") has sometimes spoiled or fudged poems of undoubted inspiration by turning aside into gags at his own expense, but his critical mind has performed a first-rate. job: in choosing for this volume the best things from the five books he published between 1959 and 1979. He writes well about happiness (which is rare); his love poems are never sentimental; most remarkable of all, he has the knack of turning the simplest nature note into something which goes beyond observation of the outer weather - and to do this without being portentous. Here is a complete poem, "Sun Overcast", which illustrates that last gift:
W'ien brightness leaves the trees they seem to fall
Backwards, deprived of shadows, then rise again in a coot
Diminishment of waiting, solider still. Which it is possible
Is what they mean whom death makes audible
Beyond our ears and, I feel, as simple.
I remember the late James Reeves, praising Edmnund Blunden for having a Muse with an "unpresuming Saxon grace". Kavanagh's has the same grace. She may never be fashionable, but I'd wager she has a Persistence which will survive this fashion and that.
Robert Nye
In Harry Keating's crime briefs last week the notice of Flashpoint by Madelaine Duke was attached by accident to Dealer's Wheels by Steve Wilson.

Author: Spanier, David
Title: The Poetry of Chess
Full_text:
The Poetry of Chess.
edited
by Andrew Waterman (Anvil Press, £4.95)
Poets, like other men, enjoy playing chess. Many of them have taken the game, which is so rich in metaphors, not just for war, but all obsessive states of mind, as an emblem of their feelings about life, in general.
From Lydgate,
Forthough manstudiedallhis Iyve
He shall ayefynde dyversefantasyses There is therein so great diversytie...
down to our own day, Poets have thus celebrated chess. This anthology of chess in goetry, arranged ur der the headings of the game, players, philosophies, moralitiesL p-ublic worlds and personal r-elations, makes a light.hearted and thoughtful collection.
Whether poets can play any better than other men is doubtful. The fact that they can write! better has to be their consolation.
:Dand Spanieri

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Tony Harrison is a poet. He is also, so it appears, something of a one-man industry. Now 44 years old, and engaged on a sonnetsequence in roughly Meredithian form, he is at thei height of his powers, pouring out poems and translations and finding publishers for ali this idiosyncratic and (occasionally) magnificent work. We have grown so used to the Larkin Syndrome - whereby a poet publishes a slim volume perhaps once in a decade, as if to prove the worth and difficulty of opening his mouth at all - that Mr Harrison's energy makes him look alarming. Yet the flux of his production is at one with the fury of its content. I take off my sceptical reviewer's hat to him, convinced that I am in the presence of the real right thing.
First, his version of The Oresteia of Aeschylus, first performed at the National Theatre last November, and now offered in book form by Rex Collings Ltd (E3.50). This is vivid, gutsy, and agglutinative. I take the last adjective from Ezra Pound, who used it to define the special qualities of the original (Literary Essays of Ezra Pound, page 273), while bewailing the fact that a search for Aeschylus in English is "deadly, accursed, mind-rending". Mr Harrison does not mess about. He goes straight for the original glue and renders it in a sort of sticky, eccentric, slanginspired English. Orestes instructs Pylades to "keep out of eye shot"; the Chorus turns to Cassandra and mocks her "painpangs and griefsongs" with the nasty retort, "Don't understand". To which1 Cassandra, only doing her job after all:
Off with the brideveil then. Look into truth's pupils
The truthgust. It's rising. Blowing .4fresh headwinds
sweeping sea-ripples into dawn's molten caul.$ron,
then building a woe-wave as big as a mountain.
I don't much. care for "woe-wave" (sounds like Gilbert Murray glued to W. H. Auden), but this is to pick holes in a translation which undoubtedly makes Aeschylus alive again. As the Chorus grudgingly admits to Cassandra: . "It's as if you'd witnessed all You're describing." Mr Harrison has grasped' -and rendered the very essence of Greek drama: that; it. takes p lace without ceasing- in a theitre of the humian soul. More, :he has found contemporary English words and idiomatic rhythms to match it. A remarkable achievement. I reckon Pound might have approved.
His U.S. Martial (Bloodaxe Books, PO Box 1SN, Newcastle upon Tyne, NE99 1SN £1) is slighter, but stilf extremely ilvely and impressive. Here are 18 translations from poems by Marcus Valerius Martialis, made in March last year while Mr Harrison was staying in New York. The best are obscene and truthful enough to be unquotable. All of them find a happy medium between Martial's epigrammatic disgust with the social and sexual life of Rome round about the time of Christ, and Mr Harrison's feelings about his predicament on Broadway last year. Witnesses number XVI, entitled "The Joys of Separation", which can be quoted in full:
She wants more and more and
more new men in her.
He finally finishes Anna
Karenina.
And lest this suggests that Tony Harrison is only a kind of Woody Allen of modern English poetry, have a look at his exquisite A Kumquat for John Keats (Bloodaxe Books, 75p). A kumquat is a Chinese orange, gold in colour, with sweet pulp and sour skin, or perhaps the reverse, sweet outside and sour within.... Mr Harrison plays deliciously on the doubt:
For however many kumquats that
Ieat
I'm not sure if it's flesh or rind
that's sweet,
and being a man of doubt at life's
mid-way
I'd offer Keats some kumquats
and I'd say:
You'll find that one part's sweet
and one part's tart:
say where the sweetness or the
soumness start.
This single poem should be sufficient to convince any fair-minded reader that Tony Harrison's is a most considerable talent. It has much to say about Keats, about poetry, about life's brevity, about its co ensations (which may well include brevity and Keats), and about the fruit which can also be spelt cumquats. It deserves to be preserved in many anthologies. And at the same time it has to be observed that Mr Harrison is such a restless and original poet that if he goes on at this rate he will prove to be an anthologist's nightmare. Good.
Selected Poems of Alun Lewis (Unwin Pa'perbacks, £2.50), selected by Jeremy Hooker and Gweno Lewis presents in the chronological order of their writing the best poems of one of the best poets killed in the Second world War. Lewis has always -had his admirers, but he has tended to be regarded as somewhat School of Grgves (for no substantial stylistic reason, but because Grgves -> who never met him - helped to select and then introduced a posthumous volume of his work). He may now be seen as a decent, unpretentious, persistently serious writer, aeeply concerned with what he perceived to be "the single poetic theme of Life and Death". Less literary than Sidney Keyes, more accomplished than Keith Douglas, his death (which seems to have been accidental) deprived English poetry of a potentially important voice. Not Just a War Poet. A poet.
Robert Nye

Author: Hunt, David
Title: A continuity of genius
Full_text:
A continuityof genius
Greek Poetry
From Homer to Seferik
By C. A. Trypanis
(Faber, £25)
"Greek poetry constitutes the longest uninterrupted tradition of the Western world" Professor Trypanis declares at the outset of his monumental history. For the first time it is possible to follow the whole course of this triumphant progress from the Geometric Age to the end of the Second World War. He has himself described it as a book more of love than scholarship; the affection is plain to see but the erudition and the assiduity of research are equally staggering.
Another way in which Greek poetry is unique is that it starts off with its greatest poet, Homer; one wvho is also arguably - I should argue it vigorously - the greatest European poet. Instead of the forceful but naive fragments which stand at the fountain heads of other literatures, here are two works of art, the Iliad and the UdysseV, which combine integrity of structure and elaboration of design with a heart-piercing directness and vigour of elocution. The language too is in no way primitive but aristocratically sophisticated. As used by Homer it is a perfect instrument which, as Goethe said, does your thinking and your poetizing for you.
Professor Trypanis, a patriotic Chian who has both geld a chair at Oxford and been a Minister of Culture in the Greek Government, is specially qualified to expound the continuity of Greek culture. He can both trace the dominating influence of Homer on education through two and a half millennia and exemplify 1
sympathetic understanding for the generation of poets vhich has given the world Cavafy, Seferis and Elytis. His book is, in fact, not unlike a dumb-bell, with a serviceable but rather thin handle joining the two important elements, antiquity and modernity. He is very good on good poets - hut no doubt more amusing on the mediocre ones. When he dismisses Hermesianax as "easily the worst of the early Alexandrian poets", a hairraising categorization, no-one will risk checking his judgment.
It is in the Byzantinechapters that he is most at homne and, for the -British reader, most valuable. He deals effectively with the great pronunciation change, complete by the fifth century, and the change from quantitative to accentual verse in the tenth. He argues convincingly that Romanus the Melodist was the greatest Byzantine poet. The Cretan school of the seventeenth century, the Klephtic ballads of the eighteenth and the poets of the lonian islands of the nineteenth (who fell heavily for Ossian, like so many of their Western European contemporaries) are discussed and assessed with easy skill. One other element of continuity comes through. The feeling of despair which lies, in C. S. Lewis's words, only an inch beneath the bright surface of Homer is as close to the surface in the poems of Cavafy, even of Seferis. The best Greek poetry is inspired by the sense of transitoriness of all human endeavour an inspiration sublimated by Pericles when he said in his last speech that all things are subject to decline but the memory of greatness lasts for ever.
David Hunt

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
I tnderstatd you well enough, John Donne ....
Thus, C. H. Sisson, now 67 years old and in my opinion the finest living English poet, addressing a letter across the centuries to one of his peers. The occasion for this poem was that Donne was once rector of the parish church at Sevenoaks, from which town Sisson (in his days as what they call a higher Civil Servant) regularly commuted to London. Comic coincidence? Of course, and the human comedy is never far from the surface of what inspires Sisson, as it inspired his predecessor. Another reluctant Christian - "eaten by lust and by the love of God" - it leads him to the emphatic, passionate, shocking orthodoxy of this poem's conclusion:
Come down and speak to the. men of ability
On the Sevenoaks platform and tell them
That at your Saint Nicholas the faith
Is not exclusive in the fools it chooses
That the vain, the ambitious and the highly sexed
Are the natural prep of the incamate Christ.
If, as I do, you detect in those lines the voice of an authentic poet impelled to find a personal way of uttering some more-thanpersonal truth then you will want as many copies as you have friends requiring Christmas presents of Sisson's Selected Poems (Carcanet New Press, f3.95). The book draws its 53 poems from the three major collections In the Trojan Ditch (1974), Anchises (1976), and Exactions (1980). The selecting has been sensitively done - the only serious omission being the crucial "The Discarnation".
It is worth noting that Sisson was a late starter (he hardly wrote a line of decent verse before the age of 40), and that when he did start lhe first began to reach such a public as there is for new poetry through the pages of a magazine called X: A Quarterly Review, edited by David Wright and Patrick Swift. That was round about 1960; "X" is long since defunct; and I cannot recall if the younger poet Tony Harrison (born 1937) ever appeared in its pages. Whether he did or not, I see that David Wright went on record at some point, hailing Harrison as "the white hope of English poetry'} - a perceptive tip, now proved soundl by the
appearance of Mr Harrison's Continuous (Rex Collings, f3.953, a selection of 50 sonncts from a still proliferating sequence collectively entitled "The School of Eloquence". Harrison employs a 16-line form, like Meredith's but with a different rhyme pattern. He is technically a master of his craft. and the content of the sonnets - broadly speaking, a self-critical analysis of his relationship with his working-class ancestors extended into an examination of the difficulty of all communication - has the necessary drama, the story-line, to make the book very readable as a whole, and not just as a series of isolated witty linguistic exercises. Three cheers for mute ingloriousness! he proclaims, only halfironically, in a sonnet called "On Not Being Milton"; and elswhere, in an epigraph on the subject of heredity, he shows himself to be wellaware of both the power and the impotence of his own predicament:
How you became a poe's a
lWhel-ever did you get your talent from?
I sap: I had two uncles, Joe and Harry.-
one was a stammerer, the other dum!,.
It is heartening to find a poet prepared to take risks,
to indulge himself in the frank expression of his private thoughts and feelings, somewhat in the manner of George Barker in his heyday, staking all on the quest for whatever might emerge from the struggle.
Andrew Waterman's Out for the Elements (Carcanet, £3.95) is chiefly remarkable for its lengthy title poem, written in the intricate stanza fornm which Pushkin used for "Eugene Onegin", and like Harrison's sonnet sequence in that it moves through much personal matter to unsentimental and highly unfashionable general reflections on human nature. Waterman, though, is less eloquent, more intellectually calculating, even solemn, and I found myself wishing that he could have made room for the kind of good-humoured gaiety which surfaces in the book's lighter pieces, such as this punning verse from "Meeting the Poets":
"Dyer?"-- "Well, rather awful, yes."
"A keside?" - "Gut's heaving." "Dunbar?"- "Foch, bar's lang closit doon. "
"Sassoon?"- "Ys, must be Icavr.g. "
Robert Nye
Paperbacks on page 15

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry paperbacks
Full_text:
Poetry paperbacks
Devilish
epic
Robert Browning: The Ring and the Book, edited by Richard D. Altick (Penguin English Poets, £10);
Robert Browning: The Poems, edited by John Pettigrew, supplemented and completed by Thomas J. Collins, two volumes (Penguin English Poets, £10 each).
Anyone who has finally lost patience with BBC 2's Borgias might profitably turn to Browning's The Ring and the Book. This is what a real master can make of devilish Italian costume melodrama. Browning's source was an "old yellow book", part printed pamphlet and part printed manuscript, which he found in the junk stalls of Florence one June morning in 1860.
The crumpled vellum covers - pure crude fact
Secreted from man's life when hearts beat hard,
And brains, high-blooded, ticked two centuries since.
The Book told of a Roman murder trial of 1689 - a genuine cause celebre - involving a jealous husband, a whitewashed wife, a prancing priest, a pack of lies and loveletters, an elopement and adultery (the Grand Perhaps), and three singularly bloody killings with Genoese stilettos (the blades hooked back with teeth for tearing, flesh). The excitement and Nthe alliteration is instantly contagious.
From these peculiarly raw materials Browning fashioned - in the terrible black years following Elizabeth's death in 1861 - a truly remarkable blank-verse poem in 12 books. It has been called the last full-scale poetic epic in English, a real challenge to the prose of Dickens. It remains remarkable and astonishingly readable for several reasons. Browning used his mature technique of dramatic monologue, of writing from within the persona of his characters ("Porphyria's Lover" 1836; "Bishop Blougram's Apology" 1855), to tell the same story from nine different viewpoints, thus presenting nine different and conflicting varsions of the "truth" - with the reader alone left to judge and justify. (Gadzooks! alliterating still, the prosy punk!)
The sinister husband Count Guido, the dying wife Pompilia, the priest, the legal councils, the onlookers, the scandal-mongers, and even the wise old Pope, thus speak to us directly with their passionate pleas. It was a: techniqfie taken up by Wilkie Collins in The Moonstone, and explored by many modern writers since, such as Pound,
Eliot, Lawrence Durrell and John Fowles.
Through this daring method, Browning transformed a blowzy domestic melodrama into a real investigation into the nature of fact, fiction, and human bias and prejudice. The subtle distinctions between motive, act, and intention (more than ever questioned in our present lawcourts), are brilliantly displayed as each witness appeals to us in turn. The complex sexual relationship between the 50-year-old Guido and the 17-year-old Pompilia is moved gradually and deftly to the centre of the poem (Guido is allowed to speak twice, the second time his death-cell "confession" - of a sort).
In the end we are given a view of the relativity of human and historical truth that is rarely associated with Victorian psychology, or poetry. It seems contemporary, for all the tapestry and daggers. Most interesting of all ("tremendously interesting" said Henry James) is the fact revealed by Professor Altick's extensive notes, that Browning himself falsified the documentary truth - in pale Pompilia's favour, of course, identifying her perhaps with Elizabeth:
Womanliness and wifehood opal'ine,
Its milk-white pallor, chastity, suffused
With here and there a tint and hint of flame,
Desire, the lapidary loves to find. Read on, read on.
Penguin have also issued, in two massively splendid volumes 6f over- 1,100 pages each, an entirely new scholarly edition of all Browning's other poems. Four volumes might have been more elegant, but the editorial machinery is excellent, and the copy-texts are taken from impeccable sources, including, I see, a gravestone in Saint Mary's churchyard, Barnsley, Yorkshire.
Richard Holmes

Author: Liddiard, Jean
Title: Homing in
Full_text:
Horning in
Scars Upon My Heart: Women's Poetry and Verse of the First World War, selected by Catherine Reilly (Virago, £3.75)
This story of women's poetry is not so immediately dramatic as the familiar one of the soldier -poets, the patriotic fervour soured by bitternessthat produced the acrid poetry of the trenches. Indeed the male poets' indignation at the women at home is weU;lknown because oDf Wilfred 0wen's savage answer to Jessie Pope's jingoistic. "The Call", included - here. Yet' the emotional climate in the early years of the war confused both sexes; as Iris Tree
records, "we dare not weep who must be brave in battle". The stress of anxiety and loss created a longing for simple certainties which it is easy for later generations to misunderstand. Both men and women sought to invest their experiences with a significance that would make it bearable, and it is interesting and moving to see the women grappling with the received notions of honour, duty and sacrifice that were increasingly opposed by feelings of loss and grief.
High heart! High courage! The poor girls they kissed
Run with them: they shall kiss no more, alas!
As Judith Kazantzis points out in her introduction it is crucial to comprehend the "half altruistic, half romantic" emotions charged with patriotism and a longing to be of service underpinned with religious beliefs that affected both sexes. Women did not have the possibility of direct participation in battle which always offered an acceptable path to the men even when they had lost faith in the war itself, and it. is not surprising that many of them embraced the traditional role of bearing pain on their menfolk's behalf, as in' Vera Brittain's poem to her brother beginning "Your battle-wounds are scars upon my heaFt-. I Many of them- identify the soldiers' sufferings-with tihose of Christ (as indeed did Wilfred Owen) and Mary H. Henderson !invokes "Mary Mother of God/AIl women tread where thy feet have trod".
The physical propinquity that fuelled the homoerotic impulse in much of the poetry! from the trenches also crystallized for Sassoon and Owen their anger at the barbarity of war which transformed their attitude and their poetry: that anger was often directed at the conventions of love and sacrifice, "the stained stones kissed by the English dead". That physical contact was denied to the women and becomes available to them again as they, are increasingly called upon to care for the wounded:
The covers on.the screen are red
The counterpanes are white and clean
He might have lived and loved and wed
But now he's done for at nineteen.
As do their male counterparts the women also begin to question the ultimate ends of war. Edith Sitwell, Marie Stopes and Margaret Postgate Cole:
So our memories are only hopes that came to not
.we are-left atone like old men; weshould be dead ...
-Most of these writers have moments of insight peculiarly their own,.- transcending any deficiencies inevitable in such anthologies:
His son comes in like a ghost through the door.
He'll be ready, maybe, for the next big war.
Jean Liddiard

Author: Hunt, David
Title: Odysseus: Nobel poet of the hungry heart
Full_text:
Odysseus:
Nobel poet of the hungry heart
The Nobel Prize-winner for Literature in 1979, Odysseus Elytis, arrives in London next week to take part in what can only be called an Elytis Festival. On Tuesday he is the guest of honour at a luncheon given by the Greek Ambassador to a chosen company of British philhellenes and lovers of poetry. On Thursday he receives the honorary degree of Doctor of Literature from the University of London, at the hands of Her Royal Highness Princess Anne. On Friday there is an evening reception at the Greek Embassy, and on Saturday he is with the Arts Council of Great Britain. At their shop in Long Acre beween 2:00pm and 3:30 he will sign copies of his Selected IPoems, a collection from his work over the past 50 years in English translation, chosen and introduced by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard. The book is due to be published in Britain on the 26th by Anvil Press Poetry Ltd, who have already published last year the poem generally regarded as his masterpiece: To Axion Esti.
It must be rather an ordeal for a man always modest and averse, since his youth, from
publicity. I say since his youth because in 1935 when he was a student in Athens he took part in the first international surrealist exhibition which was arranged there that year under the inspiration of Andreas Embirikos and other surrealists connected with the paper Nea Grammata. I remember the, stir it made in Athens at the time although I can't claim to remember any of the exhibits. Since then he has pursued his art with faithfulness and assiduity, taking from surrealism the love for fantasy and the freeflowing stream of ideas which was what exhilarated him in his youthful reading of Paul Eluard, and adding to them a gravity which has its base in a deeply felt Hellenism.
His family origins are from the island of Lesbos, but he was born in Heraklion, the capital of the then independent state of Crete, in 1911, one year before Enosis. The family name was Alepoudeli. The first element in it means "fox"; *as Archilochus said, the fox knows many tricks. His pen-name Elytis is close to the ancient word for "scabbard" or "case for a spear" (or a crab's shell) but his admirers connect it with
the first syllables of the words for Hellas, or hope or freedom. All three are concepts which could serve as keynotes for much of his poetry.
His first poems were published in literary magazines in Athens and Salonika. In 1939 he brought out his first collected work Orientations. WVhen the Italians invaded Greece in 1940, he joined the army as a subaltern on the Albanian front. His experience marked him strongly. The war was fought in winter in tangled and hostile mountains. The Greeks were indifferently armed and equipped, and sup,,ly was difficult. Most of the time the daily rations amounted to a loaf of bread and a handful of olives. There was exhilaration from victory, and the liberation of old, lost centres of Greek civilization, followed by the collapse when the German invasion rescued Mussolini.
These experiences are reflected in the poem he published in 1945, Heroic and Elegiac Song for the Subaltern Fallen in the Albanian Campaign. lie published little for the next 14 years, part of which le spent in Paris. Then came in 1959 his best known
and probably his best work, To Axion Esti. The title recalls a Byzantine hymn and means "It is worthy"; it is also the name given to a famous icon of the Virgin.
The Greek language is infinitely flexible and euphonious. Greek poetry has the longest continuous history of any in Europe; the whole of his heritage is available to the poet of today. In this long work in three parts there are elements that recall the classical writers, the medieval liturgy, the poems of the War of Independence and the work of the school of Seferis, Gatsos, Engonopoulos, and others whose revival of lyric poetry in the thirties was initiated by the publication in 1931 of Seferis's prophetically named The Turning Point.
Elytis is a serious as well as a sensuous poet. He has said himself: "I consider poetry a source of innocence full of revolutionary forces. It is my mission to direct these forces against a world my conscience carnot accept; precisely in order to bring that world, through continual changes, to be more in harmony with my
dreams. '
David Hunt

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
I hear that it is already beinig said that Sylvia Plath was essentially a minor poet on the grounds that her Collected Poems (Faber £1O, or £4.25 paper) reveal that she wrote a number of poems less powerful than the ones which took the literary world by the roots of its hair in the posthumous volume Ariel (1965). This reviewer begs leave to differ. Seen in *context, the verse which poured out of Plath in the last year of her life is not diminished. Its impact is still terrible and terrifying: The woman is perfected. Her dead
Body wvears the smile ofaccomplishment,
The illusion of a Greek necessity....
Those lines begin what Ted Hughes now tells us was her final poem, dated 5 February 1963. Six days after writing it, the poet put her head in a gas oven, and accomplished the death she wanted. Let me make what I am trying to say quite clear: Plath's achievement as a poet did not require her suicide; yet that suicide was inevitable. There is a price to pay for each poet,
and Plath knew the cost of her own obsessions. Look again at the lines quoted. "The illusion of a Greek necessity." Only a major poet could have got things that correct. Because this collected volume shows that Sylvia Plath had to work hard at her craft, writing a number of Parnassian poems in order to find her own voice, it should not be assumed that shie is a lesser poet than the final "perfected" poems prove lher to be. It remains only to be said that Hughes has edited and introduced Plath's poems with tenderness, tempered by exemplary reticence. Forget the legends and the gossip. Here are the facts. Facts which amount to some of the most hair-raising and heartstopping poetry written in our tinie:
Dying
Is an art, like everjthiing else. I do it exceptionally weiL I do it so it feels like hell. I do it so it feels real.
I guess you could say I've a call.
D. J. Enright must occupy some colour at the other end of the spectrum. His Collected Poems (Oxford £10) shows him to be a poet who has made an art of avoiding whatever it is that irks him into verse. They call this irony, and of course it was fashionable to be ironic in the
Fifties (when Enright began). Listen:
Only one sttbject to write about: pity.
Self-pity: the only subject to avoid. Hlow difficult to observe both conditions!
The surprising and pleasing thing is to find that Enright's self-conscious intelligence has not allowed him to turn a shrug into a grimace. His verse has improved with the years (which is more than can be said of most of the Fifties' writers), and at his best he can now write poems which are at once perfectly intelligible yet manage to imply the mysteries they refuse to explain. His faults are a certain slickness - he can be too neat and entertaining. But be only falls into this trap when he forgets his own excellent prescription for the writing of decent verse: Yozu need defeat's sour Fuel for poetny.
Its motive power Is powerlessness.
Bernard Spencer died in mysterious circumstances in 1963 - he was either struck down by a railway train, or fell frdm the door of another. The ambiguous nature of his death is somehow all of one piece with his verse. The Collected Poems, edited and with an introduction by Roger Bowen (Oxford f8.50), reveals him as a typical poet of the
Thirties and Forties, a traveller, a man finding nostalgia for some never-quite defined "home" in his sense of exile when in Palermo, Madrid, Athens, or Vienna. This is a piercingly unhappy volume, for Spencer seems always to have written well when inspired by deep depression:
Ifowu many times have you smiled a reckoning smile
Either when there was some quest on of money
Or to humour one of the dead wvho live around?
That begins a poem called "Evasions". Unfortunately, the next line reads: "Oh, but that's been going on since the world began." In other words, Spencer strikes me as a poet impelled into verse by much the same pressures as worked the oracle for Norman Cameron, but whereas Cameron (a far finer spirit) did not turn aside into ballad-like refrains which dodge the issue, there was always a certain glibness in Spencer which made it easier for him to complete a stanza, while avoiding the original impulse. All the same, this is a welcome and moving book.
Brian Patten's Love Poems (Allen & Unwin, £6.95) are not really love poems at all, unless infatuation with the possibilities of smart metaphor can be considered sufficient to persuade a woman into bed and a poet that he is
telling the truth. I was impressed by individual poems by Patten, and this book appears decorated with praise of mine to the effect that he is a poet of "great lyrical tenderness". I apologize, but I now withdraw that praise.
The lyricism is there, all right, but I was misled into thinking that the tenderness was truly applied to the object. Most of these poems are addressed to Patten with love from Patten. They are heartless.
John Heath-Stubbs's Birds Reconvened (Enitharmon Press, £3.90, or £2.55 paper) is small fry ornithology by a poet capable of greater things. But at least he concentrates upon the birds, rather that on his own ingenuity. He has this to say about the heron:
standing,
Not in his greyi stillness,
VWatching the waters for his prey - but all in motion,
As he tries to get into his snaking gullet
A flapping, wvhite-bellied, obstinate cuss of a fish.
Of course, one can't be sure that herons see it that way, But it seems likely. And I reckon John Clare might have approved the attempt to see the thing from the bird's viewpoint, and the precision of language.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Norman Nicholson was born in the small town of Millom on the west coast of Cumbria. Now 67 years old, he still lives there. If poetry begins at home then Nicholson has strong claims on the attention of any serious reader. Not that he should be considered as a "local" poet, in the sense that his work would make most appeal to his fellow Cumbrians. He writes about what he knows best - the people and the places round about him - -and over the years he has dug deeper and more directly in search of not just his own roots, but some ,common. human root which might make sense of it all. Sea to the lWest (Faber £5.95, paperback £3) reveals him at the height of his considerable .powers.
Here, as you might expect, are poems about a world of ,rock and stone, becks, walls, dunes, Scafell Pike, shadows ,and clouds over combes. Nicholson picks over and pokes at his own particular -patch with the assurance and assiduity of a twentieth -century Wordsworth. That comparison is inevitable. But it is where the two men part companV that Nicholson begins to be most interesting. He has a fine poem, for instance, called "On the Dismantling of Millom Ironworks", which begins as a kind of quarrel with his
I
predecessor for averting his gaze from "the charcoal-burning furnacelSited like a badger's set deep in Duddon woods" - in other words, for rejecting the poetic possibilities of the Industrial Revolution in the name of Nature - moves on to celebrate, with much attention to detail, the ugly but sensuous reality of this ironworks where:
my father's father,
Foremran of the back furnace, unsluiced the metal lava
To slop in fiery gutters across the foundry floor
And boil round the workmen's boots
but comes to the conclusion that now that the ironworks has been dismantled:
maybe the ghost of Wordsworth, seeing furthier than I can,
WVill stare from Duddon Bridge, along miles of sand and mud-flats
To.a peninsula bare as it used to be, and, beyond, to a river
Flowing, untainted now, to a bleak depopulated shaore.
The language is flat and unambiguous, but the poem as a whole seems inspired by a splendid uncertainty very truthfully expressed. Is that "bleak, depopulated shore" really to be preferred to the human reality and even the peculiar beauty which Nicholson found in the .ironworks of his childhood? Is he being ironic when he says that Wordsworth's ghost can see further than he can? Or acknowledging that there is a false romanticism in his own nostalgia for what, after all, was a filthy blot on the landscape? The poem troubles the reader with such questions, and is the stronger for not offering easy answers.
Nicholson is certainly no mere daffodil-lover. In lighter vein, he has a delightful poem in praise of weeds:
Even the names are a folk-song:
Fat hen, rat's tail, cat's ear, old men's baccy and Stinking Billy
Ring a prettier chime for mne than honepsuckle or jasmine,
And Soweet Cicelt' smells cleaner than Swveet W'illiam though she's barred from the garden.
Nothing is barred from Nicholson's garden. That's why I like him. And if that garden is small, what matter? The soil's rich, the roots go down deep, and the gardener has green fingers.
Dannie Abse probably cultivates a window-box in Hampstead. A practising doctor as well as a poet, he seems from his verse to be a thoroughly urban man. Way Out in the Centre (Hutchinson £5.95, paperback £2.95) is his first selection since that eyeopening "Collected Poems" four years ago, which showed Abse to be a much more various and accomplished poet than most of us had believed. The new book more than confirms that impression. Here are poems which worry away at the complexity of human relationships (husband/wife, father/son, doctorlpatient), others which deal deftly with Abse's heritage as a Jewish person who has worked out his own stance as a somewhat apprehensive humanist, and best of all a handful of splendid poems in which the poet observes the doings of the streets of London, lights going on in the suburbs at
night, the mystery of unoccupied office towers, people going about their business, scraps of overheard talk. Perhaps this sounds boring? I can only quote to show that it is not. Here is the beginning of a poem entitled "Another Street Scene" (outside the grocer's, Golders Green Road):
They quarrel, this black-bearded man and his busy, almost flying wife
she with her hands, he with proverbs.
I find that almost perfect, and irresistible as narrative. If one test of a good short poem is that it should grab the reader by the buttonhole from the first three lines, then surely Abse has mastered a difficult art. He is a story teller in verse, a poet who keeps his ears and eyes open and offers item after item which rings unmistakably true. The result could be merely clinical, the poet-ascamera. But the quiet compassion, the. sheer likeability of Abse's habitual tone makes him avoid that pitfall. I recommend in particular the poem "A note to Donald Davie in Tennessee", the last five words of which give this book its excellent title:
I too am a reluctant puritan, feel uncasy
sometimes as if I travelled without ticket.
Yet here I am in England way out in the centre.
Three for Water-Music (Carcanet, £2.95) offers Donald Davie himself, that same "reluctant puritan",
with a little sequence of poems, at once quirky and formal, in which Arethusa and Phoebus crop up in some unlikely contexts, e.g. "the England of silver/cigarette cases and/Baptist chapel on Sundays." Unsurprisingly, this gives rise to a thicket of exclamation marks. Her father's brother rapes her! A poet's lie! A boy turned to a newt! Those ejaculations begin three separate bits of verse. Wow! I say! Hang it all, Bob Browning! Has our reluctant puritan turned into the Owl of the Remove? The volume also contains a reprinting of "The Shires", that pedestrian tourist exercise in which Davie seeks to celebrate the counties of England. Having just experienced a bit of Cumberland through the eyes of Norman Nicholson, I turned with some interest to what Davie had to report. He begins:
I tend to suppose the part I know least
Of England is the north-west.
For the sake of the rhyme alone, I could wish for his sake that it had been the north-east. Never mind. He goes on to delight us with the information that he spent his honeymoon in the Lake District. And concludes:
Thnts in my memories. North-west, I know Vou least, or best?
A poet's tease! East, -west, leasf s best! Perhaps he make up his mind sometime? I recommend a dose of Norman Nicholson.
Robert Nye

Author: Chaillet, Ned
Title: Lyrics of the Hearthside
Full_text:
Lyrics of the Hearthside
Arts
George Eliot
Soho Polytechnic
The best part of the first half of Lyics of the Hearthside is that it makes way for the second half. It may have taken Joseph Mydell as much thought and research to put together the first half, but it does not show. With access to all Paul Laurence Dunbar's poems and letters, he does notinng more than make a quick survey of Dunbar's attitudes to his American life, summnarizing his reactions to the War between the States, to black life in the South and in the North - and
to read well and slightly dramatize a selection of writings that illustrate those attitudes..
Mr Mfydell is considerably more successful in the second part. He takes hold of the material with a finer relish, and connects it so that it tells something. of the man in the actual context fo his life. Where he began with simple performances of the material, no more genuinely informative than any reading might be, he touches the spirit of Dunbar after the interval.
Dunbar, born in 1872, was ,virtually the first black American poet of real international note. His lyrics .frequ.ently sang with rhythms that still escape most white writers and his influence extends now to jazz singers, such as Oscar Brown Tnr, and to Stevie Wonder: Mr Mydell links those rhythmns to his performance with stylish assurance once he stops cata-

loguing Dunbar's lif'e and gives. it a context. The context is' finally a happy one for London, revealing Dunbar's reactions to being lionized by British society while still only 25.
ThaTt context could make the show a success if London was given to supporting acts that are 'distinctly "`off-Broadway", that 'aim to find and entertain their . nattural audience for a packed limited season. London is not n?oticeably good at that, but there should certainly be an -udience that would applaud the obvious rich talents of MrMydell at the Arts Theatre.
When Verity Bargate 'was interviewed by Melvyn Bragg on television, shortly before her death, he commented on the hrnmber of women writers she had encouraged at the Soho Poly ' and. waited for her response. It was typical that she fdund' it. too obvious to be conrinented on and pushed on to the next subject.
The policy- there. las. always
becr concerned with fostering talent. wherever it was found. There are' still many traces of her influence in the- progradmme, yet Margaret Wolfit's *George Eliot. plays more like'a lengthy- response to Mr Bragg, detailing' the minute struggles of being a woman and being an 'artist.
Miss Wolfit, like' Mr Mydell, :ttempts to reveal. the life and -reveal the attist, reading from letters and reading. from' the bookcs. HIer portrait of George E;liot :does not ever' give life, to "the books in the way that Mr Mydell awakens the poems, and !her steady insistence on biog-raphical data, verbal footnotes such-as-those identifying Eliot's 'lover, .'George Henry Lewes, 'gives it thie quality of a lecture. It do'es eventually become a pleasant 'lecture, but why Richard Ehigby Day takes credit as a d*rector, I-cannot itnagine.
