Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
=FDMLI-M~
I think it was Christopher Logue who once characterized the drabness of the Engiishb Movement poets of the 1950s as being like the antics of two bald men fighting for possession of a comb. His own verse has always had Plenty of hair. Ode to the Dodo (Cape £6.95, or E4.50 paperback) selects the best of it.
He began, in the days of that Comb War, as an unfashionable dandy, a peacock strutting in para-rhymes, a poet of night and cloaks and tambourines. fie has refined the romanticism, as they say, and nowadays is more likely to take his inspiration from the Police Courts. His work is witty, well-turned, and makes its appeal instantly or not at all. To my owrn taste, he has never surpassed the excellence of the moving elegy "For My Father" which was inciuded in his first. book W'Zand and Quadrant (1953):
Spider
how can I get his most, most gentle Voice,
across the sacrament of death? Ant,
from the spire of that grassb,ade,
can y,ou see larger absences than his?
Blackbird
behind the marbloom, what is there new
beside the pearly wake of snails,
for me to put upon this paper stone?
"Ah!"Ife would say, "you should have heard me sing,
before I broke my shotilder wA istling. "
The wvhole poem does something quite rare in an elegy: it makes its subject live in his own right, and not just an occasion for grief.
Some of the early poems have been revised, not always to their betterment. Speaking from memory, the fifth line in the sixth sonnet frori the collection Devil, Mfaggot and Son (1956) has been spoiled. That line originally spokc of the poet as "A most modern ape on his bare knees", wvhile it now calls him an "instantaneous ape on hairpin knees": the revision ruins a memorable absurdity. It was made, I daresai, because Logue now finds the naivety of his first insniration disagreeable. But his -naive poems, early and late, are by far his best. There are enough of them to make this an outstanding collection.
George Fraser, who died last year after a life largely devoted to being a friend to other poets and to poetry itse3f, left a legacy of verse which has now been edited by Ian Fletcher and John Lucas as POems of G. S. Fraser (Leicester University
Press, £7.50). Bcginning with Hoome Town Elegy (1944) and ending with Conditions (1959), Fraser published quite a body of interesting work on his ow-n lifetime. But the real riches here come from the uncollected poems he wrote in the i970s, after he had retired from the London literary scene. These things -- usually conversational, often couched in the form of celebrations of poets who were his friends - break out of the Yeatsian straitjacket and employ the rhythms of common speech to good effect. Speaking of George Barker, for instance, hle manages to say something true both of that "oddly, informally grand" writer, and of him-self, the comment on lhimself being characteristically throwaway, muttered, but startling:
Men envy and fear the know-how Of the Fates they have riot had:
But I thiznk of your life with love now.
(It was 1, not you, went mad ...
The tone of this reminds me of Fraser's arresting remark in a note at the back of his late collection Essays on TwentiethCentury Poets (1977) where, criticizing his own work of 30 years before, he commented: "I wrote this as an agnostic of deeply religious sentiments. I write now as an Anglican with few religious sentiments: I need the sacraments but hate the sermons and the false goodfellowship. In 1947, 1 was better and wiser." Few contemporary poets, I suggest, have been less romantic about their own illusions.
jolhLn Wain's Poems 1949-1979 (Macmillan, £9.95) is rigorously selective, but contains enough of this writer's sharp early verse to be worth purchasing if you are not already in possession of A W^lord Carved on a Sill (1956). That hook tcok its title from some lines by !Robert Graves, and the new one begins with a longish poem entitled "Visitin- an Old Poet" which is also plainly about Graves although it does not name him. Graves is Wain's mentor and his touchstone. The most vigorous bit in the new poem celebrates the tinme when Graves was
young ant stubbom and full of sap and running over with poetry, when he was savage
sarcastic and funny, when he cut r-ough capers...
It is difficult to avoid the feeling that Wain here is writing what amounts to an elegy for his own lost sap. He has certainly never surpassed his own "rough capers", although they were not (in retrospect) especially rough, for was he not one of those original bald men fighting for tho cc,n,h) .~ _ _
Kozert iNye

Author: Mann, William
Title: Feast of fanfares and serene poetry
Full_text:
Feast of fanfares
and serene poetry.
Jubilee Gala
Coliseum
The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh went to the London Coliseum last night to attend an operatic gala commemorating the golden jubilee of the company at first known as Sadler's Wells Opera, now as English National Opera.
Brilliant fanfares from Beniamin Britten's coronation opera Gloriana, greeted the royal party on arrival. They entered the royal box to mnore fanfares, and then Britten's moving version of the National Anthem, sung in front of the front dropcurtain by the asembled opera company. After the final curtain-fall, the Queen was to be presented, on stage, with bound volumes on the history of the company and its present London home.
The gala performance itself was unusually enjoyable, as such events go, avoiding the choppy, unoperatic night of as many star singers as can be crammed, optimistically, into too little time but concentrating instead on whole scenes from four favourite operas that have long been connected with the Sadler's Wells/English National Opera.
Most interesting, perhaps was the Pub Scene, introduced by the Storm interlude from Peter Grimes. Its first performance in June 1945 was the most important the company ever gave. Gnimes is not at present in ENO repertory, but is due to return in something like the vigorous, attentive (admittedly sketetal) staging seen here, the
music spouted, hurricanefashion, under Sir Charles Mackerras's ebullient direction.
Alberto Remedios made a moment of almost screne poetry in "Now the Great Bear." Anne Collins as a lively Auntie, Norman Bailey's bluff Balstrode, the fzrmly projected Boles of Donald Pulley (welcome back), and Shelagh, Squires pent, forbidding Mrs Sedley, all promised something exceptional for the forthcoming new cast.
The third act of Puccini's La Boheme, the most sheerly exquisite, craftsmanly flawless, emotionally overwhelming, known to me in any operatic repertory, had to have a place. It offered us no snow, an inn covered in scaffolding and tarpaulin, and Mini uncloaked for a bitter winter's dawn - bad omens: but here were Josephine Barstow, an irresistible Mimi, and John Treleaven's romantic Rudolph (when they sing in English, it is mad to translate their French names into Italian).
From the Wells's marvellous Verdi repertory we had the study scene from Don Carlos, a parade of noble singing and fervent playing under Mark Elder, Linda Esther Gray, Richard Van Allan, and John Tomlinson preeminent. As finale there was a clever digest of the ball scene from Johann Strauss's Die Fledermaus, with ballet, the Champagne song, "Duidu" nicely led by Alan Opie, the prancing of Eric Shilling, the debonair playboy of Emile Belcourt, and Strauss's music dancing, for once in immaculate style, under Mackerras. You can see it all tonight on BBC television.
William Mann

Author: Wain, John
Title: Over a thousand years
Full_text:
Over a thousand years
-It was not until, to quote the first line of an excellent poem by Yeats, "My fiftieth year had come and gone" that I was offered the chance to make a really substantial selection from the whole range of English poetry. Of course I accepted at * once. I have always believed ih
the usefulness of criticism (pr'ovided, of' course, that criticism is kept in its right place, as an ancillary, activity), and: I knew how important the major 'anthologies had been in' influenci.ng taste. With thlat part of me that is a critic, I welcomed'. the opportunity to produce a book that might help people to see English poetry in itsu f splendour.
I thought back to Palgrave in the 1860s. A;n admirer of Teniyson, 'he, consulted the Laureate during the preparation of the Golden Treasury, that -phenomenally successful an.
thology. which more or less moulded English taste in poetry in his day. Those poems that came closest to the limpid, choicely cadenced sometimes rather viscous, lyricism of Tennyson were what Palgrave liked best, and they became what many English readers liked best.
Palgrave's full title was Thze Golden Treasury of English Songs and Lyrics, so that he did at least nod towards the large body of satirical, meditative, narrative and dramatic verse in English that he was leaving
aside. But his very skilful selection was so popular and had so much influence that by th2 time Quiller-Couch came to edit The Oxford Book of English Verse in 1900 he had no qualms about presenting very much the same kind of selection with a much more take-or-leave-it title: -the tradition of English verse is here.
.I- am not advancing a conspiracy, theory; both these worthy men saw themselves as offering, for the delectation and benefit of the reader, a nosegay of the kind. of poetry they themselves liked. Certainly they meant no harm. But they were rather like: theatre directors usir.V various .tricks. of lighting and grouping to get the audience to. look at one restricted part .of the stage when in fact, an enormous panoramic spectacle was in progress. Obviously the balance has -been redressed since, and poets whopn Palgrave and Quiller-Couch under-represented, such as Dryden and Blake, have been offered to the public in many a tasteful package. Yet those two anthologies, for all their faults, were welcomed by the English reading public and given an honoured position. Households that contained no other books of verse had those two on their shelves. And, while I naturally hesitate to speak for anyone else, I would guess that the core ambition of -every anthologist
since their day - every one, that is, who has attempted not a period or specialized anthology but a broad canvas - has been to produce a book that would have the centrality, and win the acceptance, that Palgrave and Quiller-Couch did, while doing more justice to the scope and variety of English poetry.
In other words, to have range, breadth, a large freedom of choice as between one idiom and another, and yet still be able to say to the reader: "This is English poetry". To cater for many tastes and many moods without ending up with a ragbag of unrelated items that give the reader, ultimately, the impression that the field is too wide to be presented within a single book.
That has been my aim in Everyman's Book of English Verse. Range, contrast, spectrum. If there is a kind of poetry that has been written successfully by an English poet and it is not in the book, then to that extent I have failed.
Of course this has meant departing from standard anthological practice. Most anthologies begin at the point where the language becomes unmistakably "modern" - effectively, the sixteenth century. I felt I could not tell the story of English poetry without including the Anglo-Saxon achievement. Of course this has. meant translation, since a
modern person cannot inderstana Anglo-Saxon without study; and where I could not find translations that cotipletely satisfied me I have had to do them myself, or commission new ones; but modernizing Anglo-Saxon does not seem to me quite the sa-me thing as translating the wvork of a French or Italian poet. This is our language, in its pre-Norman form; these are our rhythms; and certainly these are our subjects and preoccupations.
This decision gives the book a range of a thousand years (the youngest poet represented is, at a guess, some 25 years my junior) and I do not suppose I have been equally successful in representing every style and every period. But I have, for this task, one temperamental advantage. My taste in literature is conventional. (Hostile critics may substitute the word "commonplace".) If a poet has been admired by a good many generations of English readers, the chances are that I shall admire him too. I have never been influenced by the notion that to build up one poet it is necessary to undermine another. I happen to like the poetry of Milton, but if I did not, it would not occur to me to spend years, as F. R. Leavis did, trying to stop other people liking him on the grounds that this would make them less receptive to opposite qualities in, say, Shakespeare. I do not
believe one's literary taste works like that. I
Personally' I enjoy most-of the well-known things in' nglish poetry.' I like the bold;
confident stride of Dryden and the delicate lyricism of Cam' pion.- I'like the diamond-polish of Pope and the unplaned roughness of Kit Smart. I- amn moved by the creamy, Virgilian melancholy of Gray and' the sharp anguish of Hopkins.
I have also departed frnm practice in including, extracts from long poems. I admit that bleeding chunk s are not 'a pretty sight, yet it seems to xrae possible to be too. seagreen in.corruptible about this. -All readers of poetry do in fact revisit their favourite passages in long poems or speeches from plays; if this is permissible (and I am waiting for someone toaeill me that it isn't), then it ought t6 be permissible to put stich things into an anthology. I
Most of the poems in the book I have: known for many years, and they have weathered well. But of course I did some fresh reading for the occasion; and there are fifty or sixty here that were new to me. I thiuk, though, that I have learnt to recognize durability when I. se,e it. There are 544 poems, or extracts from poems, in this book; and everyone of them',J find interesting, and. expect'to go on finding interesting for the rest of my life.
John Wain

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
John Ashbery is the Salvador Dali of contemporary verse in English - by which I mean that he is a master draughtsman who has degigns on his audience to convince us that he is really a genius. Like Dali, he has no one recognizable or characteristic manner. His work is an anthology of styles. He writes poems in which nothing is certain, and meaning is consistently withheld. Some of his earlier books (I'm thinking particularly of The Tennis Court Oath, published in 1962) consist of verse of such remorseless obscurity that there was even an anecdote current that he wrote it by selecting the seventh line down on the seventh page of every seventh book in his library. If not true, then it still teils a trtith. Ashbery is mahy -voices in one man. He's a joker, a trickster, a clown. -What is. remarkable about him is that, having said this, I still have to say that -the poems in, his As' We Know (Carcanet New Press, '£4:95) have a quality of pure mesmerism.- The- long - "Litany" egpecially, written in double .columns, for two voices which we -are meant to hear or overhear simultaneously but independently, is. a stunning achievement. I cOnnot understand! it, - and after several readings :1 am' convinced that being understood is no part of Ashbery's purpose, yet it has a power' of - verbal fascination swhioh keeps drawing the reader back. - Instrutnental in - this process are of course the brief individual passages which can imrnmdiately be understood:
But poetry is making things in the
past; The past transcends and excuses
thesc Grimy arguments which fog over as You begin to contemplate them.
Poetry Has atready happened. And the
agony Of looking steadily at something isn't Really there at all, it's something you Once read about; its narrative thrust Carties it far beyond what it thought
it was All het up about; its charn, no longer A diversionary tactic, is something
Grace, in the long run, which is what
poetry is. What it comies down to is this, perhaps: that Ashbery's work intrigues because it concen-
trates a playfully profound imagination upon the whole problem of meaning and identity, and comes up with no answers, only alternative quastons in the form of verse which in a sense replaces the joys and anxieties which inspired it. He always seems deternmined to puzzle out some mo e-than-personal truth from all rhe accents and accidents of its saying, with a result that while he has no single "voice" he often rises to an unquestionable authority of tone. He will baffle you. But he will haunt you. It's worth working through the bafflement to the ghost, in my opinion. To return to my original figure: while Ashbery, like Dali, can turn out work which seems merely jewelled and meretricious, his is nevertheless a real and disturbing talent. In the corner of the most stagey Dali picture, you will often find a well-drawn boat or wristwatch. In the corner of Ashbery's most rhetorical and evasive poems, you will often find lines as memorable and truthful as any going.
Edward Thomas, at his best, consists of nothing else but such corners. In a sense he vlas helped here by the fact that he did not start writing poems until he Was 36, and by the accident of his death in the first stages of the Battle of Arras some three years later. If the writing of poetry may be compared to walking, we might say that. a. poet who begins young (and Thomas is the only major poet I can think of who did not) learns to run before he can walk, learns how to deal with the "big" moments before he can find meaning in the "small" things of maybe more profound significance, and when he is not running the young poet nmay waste his time trying to imitate other walkers or setting out deliberately to develop an original walk of his own, the deliberateness being in this case absurd. Thomas avoided such antics. Knowing, as it were, plenty about the proper disposition of his arms and legs before he came to poetry, this poet hit his stride immediately. Here is the conclusion of what the new paperback edition of The Collected Poems of Edward Thomas (Oxford, £2.95) shows to have been only the fourth poem he wrote in his life:
I have ,nistdid the key. I sniff the
spray
And think of nothing; I see and I hear nothing,
Yer seem, too, to be listening, lying in wait
For what I should, yet never can, remember:
N'o gatdet2 appears, no path, no hoer. green bush
Of Led's-love, or Old Matt, no child beside,
Neither fdther nor mothet, nor dny plainate;
Otily an avenue, dark, nameless, without enVl.
That will prevail, I think, when higher pitched voices have worn themselves out. Thomas 'wrote only 144 poems in that astonishing burst of energy which was his very brief life as a poet. Of that number, about two dozen are of the first water. He was not a war noet. His work - as Martin Seymour-Smith once pointed out - is ultimately nearer to Rilke than to Robert
Frost. Seymour-Smith defines I his subject-matter as "not nature - though he evokes nature finely - but the menacing and tormenting web of eroticism, beauty (as he felt in nature) and solipsist experience". I thitik thiS is worth repeating because it is true, and because EtIward Thomas is so often miisunderstood and underestimated because faintly prailsed for the wrong reasons. The new -xford paperback contains l'sb his private diary kept during, his last three months as a soldier.
Hahs Magnus Enzensberger's The Sinking- of the Titranic (Ctrcanet New Press, £3.95) is interesting. The poet takes wn historical event and pursues it through 33 cantos and a munber of interspersed pieces which ex-arlibe; and attack his own inotives and methods. I found the nervous self-questionirig miore moving than the narrative sections, though the latter aie certainlg impressive in their variety, moving from tihe lyric to the satirical with much ease and authority. The translation from the German has been done by Enzensberger himself.
Finally, I would like to recommend Herbert Lomas's collection entitled Public Foot. path (Anvil Prets, £3.25) for its sequence "Todmorden". about the Pennines where he was born and spent his childhood; Libby Houston's At thze Mercy (Allison & Busby, £4.95, £2.75) for its very moving title poem in memory of her husband, the artist Mal Dean, who died of cancer in 1974 at the age of 33; and Peter Porter's Engitsh Subtitles (Oxford, £3.50) for its excursions and discursions in manv forms and directions.
Robert Nye

Author: Martin, Brian
Title: Recessional
Full_text:
Recessional
Church Poems
By John Betjeman Illustrated by John Piper
(John Murray, fS.95)
"Church of England Thoughts", one of A Few Late Chrysanthemums (1954), collected now in Church Poems, contains a stanza which as well as describing Magdalen Tower's chiming bells, might just as well describe Betieman's poetry:
A Church of England sound, it
tells
Of "moderate" worship. God and
State, WVhere matins congregations go Conservative and good and slow
To elevatiors of the plate.
Church Poems are for the faithful. Some concern church architecture, furnishings, and a great deal of bell-ringing. Many are embellished by John PiDer's charming and elegant line drawings. Some dwell, in passing, on death and resurrection. Others, such as "Autumn 1964", show Betjeman as celebrant of God's creation in days before the ravages of the Other Power's Dutch Elm Disease ineradicably altered English landscape:
The yellowing elm shows yet some
g,reen,
The melTowing bells exultant
sound, Never have light and colour been
So prodigally thrown around.
And in another, amid the duckweed of Letcombe Brook. he loDks with gentle eye on "a mud gray-' trout which "hovers and darts away at my approach". Heaney's tough, military trout is totally alien:
A volley of cold blood
Ramrodding the current
Some of the poems are old: the new ones were composed while Sir John and John Piper wandered the land composing the Shell Guides. As he writes in his introduction, "Both of us were none too solemn". There is always a hint of puckishness surviving in Betieman's verse. In "Our Padre" from Continual Dew (1937), a mischievous, satirical voice is in command:
Our padre is an old sky pilot,
He's tied a reef knot round my
heart
and the chorus is about pulling "for the shore, sailor" with the padre rowing stroke. At the same time, the poem makes moral comments on human nature in general, and on the present condition of Church of England parishes in particular. As Sir John says, churches are not just "architectural style and rateable values": they are human institutions, vicars, vergers, parish mags, congregations.
He never allows his poetry to escape the real world, and. this no doubt is one important reason why he remains so popular. There is even a hint of the utter mundaneness of Pbilip faldn about his verse. In "On Leaving Wantage, 1972", bellrngers are described making for the church tower,
From rumpled beds on far-off new
estates,
Fwm houses over shops along ithe
Fum rad-hrick villas somewhat
fiurTher out.
But how much more optimistic
is all this and the sound of, Betiernn's carillons to Larkdn's "cut-price crowd" down from "the raw estates" to spend on
consumer durables. The warm spirituality of the C of E, as interpreted by Sir John, fills that awful vacancy, that empty blueness, seen through "high windows" by his heir-apparent.
"Septuagesima" more than any of the poems is a song of. praise for the Church of
England at the core of this. collection. Betjeman notes that. Septuagesima is
A somewhat unattractive time
Which hardly len-as itself to rhyme.
But still it gives the chance to me To praise our dear old C. of E.
Not only is the Church's embracing doctrine praised but the ordinary work of the parish, whether done by the cleaner of the aisles or the "Treasurer of the P.C.C.", is given its due significance.
Poets laureate have always been the prey of satirist and parodist; Colley Cibber fell victim to Pope, and Masefield too was ridiculed. Betjeman is not unscathed; but his parodists usually miss his characteristics of humanity and homeliness. Anthony Burgess's nasty satire in Earthlp Powers is wide of the mark: Dawson Wignall "not yet O.M. but tinkling with other awards" eludes his original. Joriathan Price in "Sir John Revisits Jericho" (1978) gets closest to him, -parodying his ballad style and making Sir-. John and his "St Barnabas, Oxford" the content of the poem.
Church Poems ends with what might be called, in these Erastian, economically stringent times, a C of E "recessional", "Blame the Vicar", a cautionary tale. A carping congregation will drive away the vicar and find "The living's been amalgamated". All these poems show Sir John's warm-hearted enthusiasm for the unobtrusive parish churches and a caring affection for their congregations.
Brian Martin

Author: Renshaw, Heather
Title: Subversive
Full_text:
Subversive
Strictly Private; an anthology of poetry, chosen by Roger McGough; illustrated by Graham Dean (Kestrel £4.95) Wherever did young Mr McGough go to school? And did his teachers really inflict the Golden Treasury on him "because they were paid to and because the syllabus demanded it"? Well, Academe's loss is England's gain. The effect of all those "heavy and dusty" poems was to inspire the witty disenchantment of his verses "in the glassroom" and elsewhere. Now he has brought along some friends to augment his subversive lyric voice.
To begin with it is funny and astringent. Such a change to have home-truths served up without any fancy garnish: you fit into me
like a hook into an eye a fish hook an open eye
but 173 pages of whinge and aggro convert anything in the poetry that was " strictly private " to sternly claustrophobic. All right Wes Magee, you may be a " left wing radish, raw and red as a thumped nose "; all right Adrian Mitchell, it is good to know that
" in Manchester there are a thousand puddles " hut so many " recognizably contemporary voices " grating on like this begin to make Palgrave's Treasury more golden than Mr McGough credits. I never want to hear Wordsworth on daffodils again, but after reading Adrian Henri's cut-up of the poem with a Dutch car advertisement I find that the Old Sheep's bleat has something to say after all.
Heather Renshaw

Robert Frost once actually defined poetry as "wihat gets lost in translation-" There is some truth in that, for a good poem invariably happens some-where close to the roots of any given language. The better the poem, the harder to translate or transplant it? Hearts are easier.
To say that a thing is impossible, though, is not to say that it should not be tried. The poems of Paul Celan present very great problems for the translator, especially his highly idiosyncratic final poems before his suicide in 1970. MNichael Hambutger rises brilliantly to the occasion in his selection Paul Celan: Poems (Carcanet, £7.95), a bilingual edition spanning the poet's whole career- Hamburger admits at the outset that Celan's work "confronts us wiith difficulty and paraiox" from wvhichever direction we approach it. Hermetic, desperate, precise, characterized by what Hamburger well-defines as "their peculiar leaps and bounds, their haltingness and their silences ", Celan's poems at their best transcend personal anguish and comnunicate a truth common to us all:
Black milk of daybreak we drink
3ou at 22ight
we drink pou at noon death is a
master for Genmany
we drink you at sundown and in
the morning we drink
and we drink you
death is a master from Germany
his eyes are blue.
he strikes Dou Zwi Zeaden 7ulZels
his aim is true
a man lives in the house your
golden hzair Margarete
he sets his pack on to us he grants
us a grave in the air
he plays with the serpents and
daydreams death is a master fronz Germany your golden hair Margarete your ashen hair ShuZmrnith
Celan w7as Jewish and botth his parents were murdered in a concentration camp. He came to refuse permnission for anthologists to use the poem whose final stanza I have quoted above, " Todesfuge " (" Death Fugue"), because he felt its imagery was too direct, too explicit, and because the was cut to the quick by the critical accusation that he had made something "beautiful" out of events too ferrible for wordsthe poem is of course about. Auschwitz. Celan aspired to a pure poetry, an absolute poetry, yet at the same time his work is rich and dark with religious and political self-questioning. Speaking about poetry, he once quoted this definition by MIalebranche: "Attention is the natural prayer of the souL" Hamburger refers to this and quite properly ad's that he neither knowvs nor considers it his business to know -what Celan believed. "It is this quality of attention in his poems that points to a religious sensibility.
I might add that this marvellous volumre is a real eyeopener to those who previously knewv Celan only by repute, or through one or ntwo pieces in anthologies. Here is a major poet-and since Hamburger has been prudent and selective especiallv in the area of those poems which cannot be reproduced in English because they attaclk the German language itself by punning having to do with Celan's " anomalous position as a poet born in a German-speaking enclave that had been destroyed by the Germans", because of this,. I suggest, not all the poetry ihas been lost in the translation.

His Selected Poerns 1965-1975 (Faber £3.95, paperback £1.95) is a most enjoyable book, full of immediately Miceable things, but for me it confirms the suspicion I have felt with each of his individual collections-that here is a poet of indubitable talent who has settled for writing what Gerard Manley Hopkins called "Parnassian " verse, as opposed to poetry proper, the language of inspiration. Parnassian, says Hopkins,. can be written only
by real ,poets, but it is not in' the highest sense poetry, being " sp.oken on and from the level of a poets mind, not, as in the other case, when the inspiration, w,hich is the gift of genius, raises him above himself.' Parnassian, in other w~ords, is what a poet writes when he tries to write a poem. WNell, Heaney only rarely seems to be doing anything else, to my imind, and the occasions vwhen he lets the poem speak for itself are too infrequent to justify the high praise wvhich some critics have heaped upon him.

Author: Hillier, Bevis
Title: The quest for inscape
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS
The auest for inscaDe
Selected Prose
By Gerard MIailey lHopkins
Edited by Gerald Roberts (Oxford, 9Sp)
A friend of mine at Oxford had a lowv opinion of one of the lecturers in English literature. He invented for him a spoof list of for2hcoming lectures, which included "Shakespeare the novelist" and ` George Eliot the man".
"Gerard Manley Hopkins the prose wvriter" sounds almost as absurd. For all his vaunted aim of writing verse in the rhythms of everyday speech, Hopkins remains poetic. True, he drained poetry of its stagnant poetic conventions, eliminated " o'ers " and "e'en's" and replaced the plaved-out Italianate " beauteous " wvith the Anglo-Saxon "` lovely "` He also mocked what he called- the " trioleteers " the triflers in verse. (Andreiv Lang, the chief offender, was his exact contemporary at Balliol.) But Hopkins merely substituted one kind of mannerism for another. It is gloriously effective, in poems such as The Wreck of the Deutschl and and The Windhover: but it can hardly be said to approach the colloquial. Even when he needed to command everyday speech, in his sermons to ordinarv folk, Hopkins used such passionate and improbable metaphors that his congregation, to his chagrin, burst into laughter.
One might expect his prose to be mannered, full of voluptuous imagery-an expression of the temperament to which rich vestments, ritual, incense, dinging bells and golden monstrances appealed. We find just those qualities in the prose of another nineteenth - centurv Roman Catholic poet, Francis Thompson, wvho wvrote of Shelley:
The universe is his box of tops. He dabbles his fingers in the do-ffall. He is goZd-dzislu tVith twnbling amidst the stars. He makes bright mischief 7ith the
moon. Thc meteors nuzzle their noses in hzs hand. He teases into growtling the kennellcd thunder and laughs at zhe shaking of its ficri- chlain. Hc dances in and out of the gates of heaven: its floor is lirrered with his broken jancies. He runs wild over the fields of ether. He chases the rolling world.
Hopkins never indulged in that kind of ritualistic prose. His child-like outlook was against it: and the greatest prose influence of and on his whole life was Newman's Apologia (1864), which inspired his reception into the Roman Catholic church (by Newman himself) in 1866. Like the best conjuring tricks. the Apologia achieves the maximum of mystification wvith the simplest of means, the most disarming professions of nothing-up-mysleeve. Infatuated with the message of the book, Hopkins 'was equally a convert to its pellucid style-though perhaps unwittingly, as he made severe criticisms of Newman's prose in a letter to Coventry Patmore.
How un-mandarin and unpurple-passagey his own prose is. The verv first line of this selection (fromn a letter of 1862) contains a second sentence only two words long. Some passages have a dynamic quaintness that could belong to no other author. Who else could have written (of Goethe and Burns) : " Thev spoke out the real human rakishness of their hearts and everybody recognized the really beating. though rascal, vein "? And sometimes we find in the prose the germ of a future poetic effect, as when he writes, in a Meditation on Hell: "You have seen a glassblower breathe on a flame; at once it darts out into a jet taper as a lance-head and as piercing too "-an obvious anticipation of the phrase " live and lancing like the blowpipe flame" in the poem dedicated to Robert Bridges written in 1889, the year of Hopkins's death. At the same time, it is surprising to learn (from a letter to his brother Everard) that Hopkins thought
prose, "though commonly less beautiful than verse and debarred from its sympathetic beauties, has, at least possible to it, effects more beautiful than any verse can attain ". Here speaks the defer-der of pied beauty and wildernesses, of language untrammelled by metre or rhyme.
Gerald Roberts's selection is judicious, and, set chronologically as it is, forms a kind of informal autobiography of Hopkins. Only a few passages do not seem to earn their placer. The recurririg glories are the natural descriptions, so remiriscent of Leonardo's in their obsessional detail and the quest for what Hopkins called "inscape ", the form - giving essence of things; and the literary criticisms which Hopkins svapped with Bridges, Patmore, Canon Dixon and other friends Often nervy and diffident in his dealings *vith men. Hopkins was serenelv confident not to say dogmatic-in his literary judgments. R. L. Stevenson has effects " worthy of Shakespeare ". The genius of Blackmore's and Hardy's novels is "not much inferior to what made the Elizabethan drama ". On the freethinking George Eliot (" this Evans-Eliot-- Lewis-Cross, woman ") a more stunmary judgment is passed: " overdone reputation . . . half real power, half imposition." The priest tugs at the critic's armr.
Compliments to the art director of OUP on the most perfect cover design that could have been chosen: a painting of bluebells by H. Larpent Roberts. It illustrates one of the most lyrical natural descriptions in the book. It is a pity Gerald Roberts omits the fervent Blakean lines from the Diary of Mav 1870 which begin: "I do not think I have ever seen anvthing more beautiful than the bluebell 1 have been looking at. I know the beauty of our Lord by it."
Bevis Hillier

Author: Treglown, Jeremy
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
,Poetry"
am
Selected Lyrics and Satires. of John Wilmot. Second Earl of Rochester, edited and introduced bv Ronald Duncan (Rebel Press, £3.95)
Because of his scandalous reputation, Rochester has always been good for publishers'
balance-sheets. The first collection of poems attributed to him came out within months of his death, three hundred years ago this year. It was pirated, and nearly half of its contents were actually by other poetsEdmund Ashton, Aphra Behn, Charles Buckhurst (Earl 6f Dorset), George Etherege, Charles Sedley and others.
Similar rip-offs followed, and the republication by The Rebel Press of Ronald Duncan's selection, first brought out in 1948 and completely unrevised, belongs to this tradition. It contains no new material-least of all any acknowledgement that it has been outdated. Duncan's pretentious and slapdash introduction tells us for example (and his publisher's advertisements imply) that the poems are out of print. This was true in 1948 but is far from being so now. In order of appearance since theft, and still available in paperback, and all either cheaper than, or the same price as the Duncan edition, there aPre Vivian de Sola Pinto's Muses' Library
edition, £2.75-a very useful text though missing two poems, one of which Duncan prints; David M. Vieth's edition of the Complete Poems (Yale, £3.95), a rigorous scholarly edition based on the most substantial research yet done on the texts; and John Adlard's The Debt to Pleasure (Carcanet, £1.95), an attractive, full and-for the general reader-adequately reliable selection from all Rochester's writings. And if, like Duncan, you are really more interested in "Rochesteriana" than in the works of Rochester, you can get secondhand a cheap facsimile reprint of the 1680 Poems on Several Occasions, published by the Scolar Press. Many of the poets included in it-and in Duncan's selection-as "Rochester" are now available in separate scholarly editions, particularly Etherege and Buckhurst.
Of Duncan's book the best that can be said is that a fair number of Rochester's best poems are in it, even though the last stanzas of " Love a woman ? You're an ass ", " Vulcan, contrive me such a
cup " and "Fair Chloris in a pigsty lay " are missing. But mosl readers wifI not know whether these are among the genuine items or not without consulting other books. Of the sixty or so poems included, in fact, twenty-five are almost certainly not Rochester's, and the authors of many of them are known: four by Edward Radclyffe, for example, two by Buckhurst and one each by Thomas D'Urfey Sir Carr Scroop, Charles Blount John Sheffield (Earl of Muigrave). John Freke, Edmund Ashton, and Rochester's wife Elizabeth. Ronald Duncan tells us that Rochester " is a poet in his own right". This is quite true. What this selection unwittingly demonstrates is that a fair number of his contemporaries were poets in their own right, too.
Jeremy Treglown
The tercentenary of the death of John Wilmot, Earl of Rochester will be marked by a symposium at Wadham College on September 22-23. Bookings to the Steward, Wadham College; Tel. 0865-42564.

He did a douze. . His legs arose. In curlicues.i
Perfecr, .too, Is Ambrose Bierce's-definition of -an egotist -as " A persbn of low taste, more interested in himself than in me ". But such pleasures take some findinig. When Kingsley Amis colleczed The New Oxford Book of Light Verse int.1977, he, omitted American-poets almost entirely-partly from inclina. .ti4n,. perhaps, but chiefly because this anthology by Wiliani Harmon had already been.. planned to complement his: Auden's Anglo-American territory in the original Oxford Book of Light Verse of 1938, now renrinted as a paperback (Oxford, £3.50), was being cut in two. All anthologies conduct campaigns in taste-the more personal the more campaigning -and as Amis departed radically from the populist tone of Auden so, from the start, does Harmon take issue with Amis.
The Professor of English at Chapel Hill is genial enough, but irredeemably donnish and windy, and instead of Am-is's tough, terse and wholly consistent apologia, Harmon first attempts, not too successfullv', to define ways in which American Lighit Verse is peculiarly American and then writes, of the dark, destructive side of comedy: "This Dionysian, anarchic id-spirit of misrule seems to represent the pre-so-cial and pre-logical Individual-as dear to American conservatives as to JeanJacques Rousseau-the Individual who can turn every solemn civic utterance into rude and incult parody".
For heaven's sake. None of this would matter more than the normal difference between a dissertation and a seminar did not a sense of purpose in the choice of the poems themselves prove equally elusive. There is simply too much: the vision blurs. Amis compressed more than 400 years of English poetry into 121 poets and 329 pages; Harmon, with half that number of years to work on, takes half as many poets again and 528 pages to make his choice. Inevitably,. and unnecessarily, the general level of verse is far lower than in the English collection, and some of it-restricting the representation and diminishing theimpact of talents like "Orpheus C. Kerr ", John Greenleaf Whittier, Innes Randolph, Phyllis McGinley and Ogden Nash-should not be there at all.
One problem when 'choosing the poems for an an.thology of this kind is tlat America lacks the received tradition of High Verse-no Shakespeare, Milton, Wordsworth or Pcpe-which Light Verse needs to kick against and take off. What she does possess, or so it laoks from over here. is a rich nineteenth century folk poetry, and a twentieth centurY skill in the metropolitan lyric that i;s .unrivalled. It is with its handling; of these truly Americ6n forms that The Oxford Book 4f,Ameri can Light Verse seems- both timorous and unbalartced.
The boy. sto0d,on the burning deck,
His feet were full of blisters;
The flames came up and burned his pants,
And now he wears his sister's.
Anon, chosen by Christopher Logue and illustrated by Bill Tidy.
True, we get the who:le of "Yankee Doodle Dandy" and " Meet Me in St Louis, Louis "; there is "Little Brown Jug" and a couple of coarse exchanges from the Civil War, but apart from "Clementine" and "Starving to. Death on a Government Claim ", not much from California, and still less from the railroads-after all, Bill Bailey (ivho is present) was a brakeman on the Baltimore and Ohio. I should have liked more poems of immigrant life, since those chosen are mostly Germ man, and convivially, irresistibly comic:
Size hat haar as prown ash a
pretzel, Her eyes vas himmel-plue,

It is probably true that manir lyrics for the stage. lose bones and flesh when separated from their melody-even "Anything' Goes " needs a singer'5 phrasing and thiat tiny intake of breath to loop Cole Porter's internal rhymes into the memory of the line before-but the other examples of Porter (five), Hart (five); - Hammerstein (three) and Ira Gershwsin (only two!) earn their plac&w'ithout music so well that it seerms more than a shaxtie to have only one lyric' each from Frank Loesser, Johnny Mercer (".Jubilation T. Cornpone ", hardly *typical) anid Stephen Sondlheim (" Gee, Officer l(rupke ", ditto)' and nothirig' by Kern, Berlin, Alan 'Jay Lerner; or' Richard Wilbur at all.
Perhaps Professor. Harmon would describe what I miss as Popular or Folk. Verse that is not High can ;also be Nonsense (on the whole, an un-American activity) or Comic, not to men'tion.. Silly, .and then- there are 'Ballads. Fibei- anthologies have ,beben eveh- mere fastidious than ..Oxford's -}'n keeping all these

far, avoiding Light aitbg6t1ieir. The Faber Book of Nonsense Verse (Faber .£5.95) makes little attempt to define Nonsense beyond a liberated mirth "-that does not-take itself too seriously. Building his anthology on the massive foundations of Lear and Carroll at t-heir most brilliant and disturbing Geoffrey Grigson also provides a rich and idiosyncratic choice of sometimes unfamiliar stuff by, among others, Christian Morgenstern (Grigson's translation), Daniel Kharms, Charles Cros, Robert Desnos and.George du Maurier all in French, and a huge body of work by Mr Amis's least fav-. ourite poet, Anon (e.g. "Oh, that my lungs could bleat like butter'd pease " c. 1655). Many might also be- Comic, Popular or Ligh;, , btqt that a darkingredient of ihstability thickens the brew. "Little birds are dining/Warily and well ".
It is hard to imagine either Oxford or Faber blessing an anthology of Silly Verse, but for devotees of the genre and for gigglers of all ages The Children's Book of Comic Verse (Batsford £3.95) assembles, a treasury of much silliness and joy. 1tere is a world trembling with the.temptations of outrage and disobedience, of knickers and wvigs and bad manners at table, of' murdering minors andrichly deserved fates. Author: Jarrett-Kerr,, Martin
Title: Reconciling the claims of poetry and Revelation
Full_text:
Reconciling the claims of p!oetry and Revelation
During the past eight years The Times has been running an occasional series 'of articles concemed with Literature and Religion. Martin Jarrett-Kerr, whose piece on Gerard Manley Hopkins initiated the series, has made the suggestion that the series should be given a new lease of life.
Literature and Religion-or Religion and Literature ? There is a real differerce. " Literature and Religion " suggests that the primary emphasis is on literature: but that the very study of literature " for its own sake " reveals, incidentally, certain convictions about life, its meaning and levels of valuation, death and its signals. eternity or nullity, which are usual topics of religious discourse. The danger is that these "religious" elements are seen as peripheral to the real business of writing well, and religion becomes a series of secondary options, decorative trinkets picked up in the Portobello Road. "Religion and Literature ", on the other hand, starts from the primacy of reEigious faith, ,and then seeks tell-tale t,races of itself in drama, poetry, the novel. Here the danger is that literature will be plundered, its "sacred" bits lopped off and the residue discarded.
This occasional series prefers, on the whole, the first danger. Religion, if true, has nbthing to fear-from an identity parade -competing with others in a " pluralistic " row. Indeed, the second danger is the- most serious even fromn a religious point of view. For not to take seriously literature's claim to full attention is to commit sacrilege, howvever "`religious" the intent. So we opt for "Literature and Religion ".
But is this not already to take sides in another dispute: that between the " high ", and the "low" valuation of literature? Shelley's expression of the "high " view is well-known: poets are the " unacknowledged legislators of the world ", orless well-known-the earlier statement, " Poetry redeems from decay the visitations of divinity in man". Goethe claimed that fate "has exalted the poet " above the toils, passions and rages of man, " as if he were a god ".
By contrast, we have the more modest view of the function of literature. T. S. Eliot, for instance, noting the high claims made for poetry, said "If a poem of mine entitled Ash Wednesday ever goes into, a second edition, I have thought of prefixing to it the lines of Byron in Don Juan:
I don't pretend that I quite
understand My meaning when I wrould be
very fineBut the fact is that I have
'nothing planned Except perhaps to be a moment'
merry. Even more blunt is Auden's formulation:
Art is compatible with polytheism and with Christianity, but not with philosophical materialism; science
is - compatible ivith philosophical' maTerialism and wvitli Christianuty, but not wvith polytheism. No artist or scientist, however, tan feel comfortable as a Christian; every artist who happens to be a Christian wishes he could be a polyt-ieist; every scientist in the same position vishes that he could be a philosophical materialist. And with good reason. In a polytheist society, the artists are its theologians; in a materialist society, its theologians are the scientists. To a Christian, however,' both art and science are secular activities, that is to-say, small beer
Perhaps Auden's tongue was a little in his cheek. But it looks as if a high view of religious Revelation (which Eliot and Auden had) must go with a low view of poetry; whereas a low view of Revelation (and both Goethe and Shelley rejected' the Christian view) must go with a high' view of poefry.
But'if we look wider we see
the matter is not so simple. Shakespeare had a high view of his art-for surely he speaks in the Chorus, preluding H'enry V. O for a muse of fit, 'that would
ascend
the brightest heaven of inven-
tion....
Those wvho believe Shakespeare was a Renaissance sceptic will say that this proves the above -that a high view of poetry goes with a low rating for Revelation. But wait:
Sing, heavenly Muse, that on
the secret top
Of Greb, or of Sinai, didst
inspire
That shepheard -[Moses].... Mlilton. had as high claims for poetry as Shakespeare: yet this opening of Paradise Lost identifies the Muse with the Divine Logos. And Wordswvorth echoes this in his " Prospectus " to his unwnritten epic, " The Recluse": Urania, I shall. need
Thy presence, or a greater muse
if such
Descend to earth or dwell in
highest heaven.
Thus even Wordswoith, like Milton, was able to combine a high view of the poetic calliig- with an equally high view of divine revelation.:
Of course it" wasi harder. for.
Wordswvorth than for AMilton to hold both together; and it is still harder,for their successors today. Yet ave still have those who can write, as Patrick White did:
I suppose what I am increasingly intent on trying to do in my books is to give professed unbelievers glimpses of their own unprofessed factor. . . The churches defeat their own aims . . . t'arough the banality of their approach, and bv rejecting so much that is sordid and shocking which can still be related to religious experience ... I feel t.at the. moral flaws in myself are more than anything my creative source.
And the distinguished novelist and (above all) short-story wvriter-who died tragically so young-Flannerv O'Connor has it in more specifically Christian terms. Looking at the true calling of the wiriter she says that it is concerned with "what is distinctive in man". For the real identity of man cannot be found by Gallup Polls. "It is not made from what passes, but from those qualities that endure . . . it lies very deep. In its entirety, it is knoivn only to God, but of those who look for it, none gets so close as the artist ".
Martin Jarrett-Kerr,

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Inoculation, heavenly maid. descend! English verse is rich in cxnic possibilities, not all of them as unintentional as that line singled out for quotation by Coleridge in Biographia Literaria. You will find it, together with much else in the same vein, in that matchless "anthology of bad ver'se" compiled by D. B. Wyndham Lewis and Charles LGe, The Stuffed Owl, first published ir. 1930 and now available again in an Everyman hardcover edition (Dent, Â£3.95). The secret of The Stuffed Owl is that it contains only good bad verse-that is, verse written according to the rules, innocent of faults of craftsmanship, but hilariously inept in effect. As in these lines from Wordsworth: This piteous news so much it shocked her,/She qaite forgot to send the Doctor. Or these from Mrs Browning: Our Euripedes, the human,/With his droppings of warm tears. Lewis and Lee had a killing eye for the ludicrous. Their anthology remains a classic of literary malice.
The writing of light verse, let alone deliberately comic verse, is a tricky business, as I am trying to suggest. There is onie contemporary 'who. seems ta me a master -of it, and" who gets better and better with each book. He is Gavin Ewart. and iis collection Or Where a Young Penguin Lies' Screaming (Gollancz, t3.2J paperback) shoiw's him at the height of- his s4dmirably unsolemn powers. Ewanrt is a skilled technician with' a' good rude sense of humour. considerable command of
dramatic effects, and a nice quirky interest- in off-beat subjects. I prefer him to Betjeman for two reasons: he is not so evasively trivial, and he is mucli less predictable both in what he chooses to write about and the way in which he writes it. His work is difficult to qutote fairly; his successes are. a matter of tone and cumulative effect, rather than clever stanzas or individual pay-off lines. I think this book would give entertainment to any literate reader, and make an ideal Christmas present for anyone wanting to give something indubitably modern and sophisticated but at the same time great fun to read. In short, give it to anyone who would not be seen dead within reach of the work of Pam Ayres -Thoughts of a Late-Night KInitter (Arrow Books, Â£1), Some of me poetry (Arrow Books, Â£1), Some more of me poefry (Arrow Bo6oks, Â£1),- and All Pam's Poems (Hutchinson, Â£2.95). No one wants to be too heavy-handed about this rubbish;, but it does seem' to me a pity that su;-h a talentless writer should have comhe to represent " entertainment value " in verse. Read ohe and you've read' them alL Her reputation as a reciter of her own stuff is another matter.
Not to be thought snobbish, I shall add immediately that .Ayres just strikes me as bad of her kind. So does Roger McGough, of a slightly different kind, who epoits an almost equal la&k or talent in his Summrer :witb AMonika (Whiz2ard 'Press~ / Andre Ddutsch, Â£I.95), a boook of feebly flip~ lov'e'poems which might sound' better-if we had pop music to go with them, but I adoubt it7 ;unless it' was very
loud music' Work such as McGough's -aspires to the condition of nmusak, to borrow a *phrase . from the - hovelist
.ichael. Moorcock. -McGough ought to be compared with Cole Porter.- Ira Gershwin, -John Lennon; he 'strikes mne as looking decidedly infeiior in that cornpafiy. ' ' -
Admirers of Private Eye's little laureate E. J. Thribb (17) will need only to know. that a book of his elegies is how available. It is entitled, of course, So. Farewell then . . . (Elm Tree Books, Â£2.50). The Thribb joke wears a bit' thin before 55 pages are out, but his combination of absolute banality and completely threadbare langutage has: its 'attractiveness.. The trick-7for those who do not know it-is to take some newsworthy subject and then to have Master Thribb from a South. London suburb pontificate upon it in free verse, usually beginning with .the word So followed by a full. stop. The mind of. twentiethcentury television man is laid h.are in this process. The w-ittiest (or do I mean daftest ?) lines are those which notice that a few months ago there was *actually an Irish racehorse named So: So..

Called "Farewell"

Author: Dickinson, Patric
Title: Music into silence
Full_text:
Music into silence
The Ordeal of Ivor Gurney By Michael Hurd (Oxford, Â£5.95)
This is the first biography of Ivor Gurney, composer of songs and of poetry (1890-1937). To those who know his work and have been led to believe that he went mad because of the wvar, this will make even sadder reading. Mr Hurd shows clearly that the instability was innate.
Gurney came from a poor Gloucestershire family. His voice as a choirboy (he once stood in tor a drunken soprano at the Three Choirs Festival and sang with Albani ! ) led to his being helped by various educated people who recognized his exceptional musicality; but this also led to a growing alienation from his family; so from the age of 10 he -war rootless, or at home in other people's homes.
He was self-absorbed, confident of his own powers and impervious to his teachers'
criticisms, yet as the author shows, both lovable and
itterly sincere. In 1911 he won a scholarship to the RCM. He looked like Schubert and had no regard for clothes or meals; but everyone, even Stanford who tried to teach him, had the greatest hopes-in particular Marion Scott, who also taught there. She was a " motherfigure" who saw his potential genius and also his 'hopeless incapacity for taking pains or fitting into any social pattern. Ilis eccentric behaviour was already alarming his friends, Herbert Howells, Will Harvey and John Haines, all Gloucestershire men.
Up to this point in his book Mr Hurd is an excellent chronicler, though with a tendency to conjectures: "Possibly" or "he must have ". He isn't so hlappy when it comes to the War, interspersing Gurney's letters with bits of potted comment on its military conduct. Later in the book he speaks of Gurney's poetry as having a therapeutic element But it was the war itself that Gurney hoped would help him; he already referred to himself
as "neurasthenic ". If one dare call the Western Front " in. stitutional " or " social ", for Gurney it was, and what is so dreadful is that he knew he had need of it. He was happy and "normal" among comrades, men from Gloucestershire. He wrote poetry; he even composed songs. But in his later poetry, it is always Gurney's War.
He was back in England early in 1918, lightly wounded and slightly gassed. He had begun to hear voices; and an account of a long conversation he had with Beethoven was disturbing. However he managed to take up his schol;arship again, taught now by Vaughan Williams. He was known a bit; everyone tried to help and in the years 1919-22 he worked frantically, while living a crazy vagrant existence-playing in cinemas, labouring, never anything for long. Rut still there were great hopes for him. He had published two books of poems and his settings, particularly of conteMporary poets were being noticed. But the voices grew more insistent; he aimed at suicide; felt himself actually tormented by "the wireless" and " Electricity ".
In 1922 he had to be "shut
up" and remained in Dartford asylum for 15 years, visited by the devoted Marion Scott, and others, till he died of TB, his writing degenerating into nonsense, his music into silence. It is a sombre and distressful story.
Yet it is essentlal to look at what he left as if one didn't know. He is crystallized in his best songs and poems; it is essential to see Gurney the artist, and the extravagant claims Mr Eurd makes, in his touching but naif enthusiasm, won't really help. But Gurney is abidingly worth reading and, what's more, his Poens, with a truly perceptive memoir by Edmund Blunden, are acually in print (Chato, 1973). Gerald Finzi and his wife did everything possible to foster his music, and this too is avalable.
To bring to life someone as odd as Gurney has proved beyond the author's powers-it would probably be beyond anybody's-and the best bits in the book are Gurney's letters and poems: but so they should be. ".. . no history of November keep the guy ", he wrote. It's a line that seems to sum up why he is worth remembering.
Patric Dickinson
Ivor Gurney - the a.sylum years.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
" The really hard thing, as Henry James might have said, is to make your own destiny coincide w.%ith the necessity of your art." Henry James did not quite say it. The Australian poet Peter Porter does, in the course of a survey of the state of poetrv in the last quarter century in Britain, published in the magazine Encounter (80p) which is celebrating its twentyfifth birthday. Mr Porters point is sensible. He observes that most poets are forced to fake the coincidence-"if only because they cannot bear the thought of being judged irrelevant by history." And he goes on: "But the future will not divulge its taste, and those who woo Prince Posterity most desperately,may be surprised to find him ignoring them."
One of the poets singled out for praise by Mr Porter is Geoffrey Hill, whose work he notes (in a less felicitous phrase) as being admired by " each end of the taste spece trum ". Admiration is indeed what I feel in reading the verse in Mr Hill's new collection Tenebrae (Andre Deutsch, Â£2.50). He has returned to the strict forms which characterized his earlv work, and within those forms be refines his thoughts and feelings so astringently that one would be hard put to find a slack line in the book. The twvo sonnet sequences entitled " Lachrimae ' and "An Apology for the Revival of Christian Architecture in England" are especially impressive.
The only fault I would note in Mr Hill at this stage in-his interesting progress is that he tends to use his mastery of form as an excuse for remaining tight-lipped. A good sonnet releases as much as it contains, but this poet is unw-illing to make the act of surrender wshich woulld allows him to wvrite in that way.. The result is sometimes over-polished and Parnassian, SD that the reader is more moved to admire than to be moved. All the same, the seziousness of this volume is self-evident and it stands out from the ruck of contemporarv verse as something excellently made, the wvork of a craftsman probably well alware of what he needs to do in order to become an artist.
George Barker's villa Stellar (Faber paperbacks, Â£2.S0) Provides an illuminating contrast. Mr Barlker began, nearly half a century ago, as a hit-ormiss man, a wild artist if ever there was one, a high Romantic throwing his talents down in poem after poem from the precipice of self to commit suicide on some rude and rugged pun. He has changed a good deal over the years, though without ever losing wshat wvas admirable in such daring, and anyone who thinks that they knoV (and probably dislike) him because of those early excesses ought to take a look at what he is doing now. The verse in Villa Stellar continues in much the same vein as his last book, Dialogues, remembering people and places wsith mordant affee-
tion, employing a kind of wit vhich has been rare in English poetry since the death of ByronL The particular essence of George Barker seems to me best suggested by adapting Byron's famous remark that after the publication of Childe Harold he woke up and found himself famous, because in most of Barker's later work it is as though Byron had wvoken up and found himself William Blake. The confidence of the Blakean exercise, seldom lapses into bathos now, but as a matter of taste I prefer the Byronic quips:
You ask me where I atm going ? IVeU, Pin either passing througlz Italy on my way to Hell,
or, to put the matter a bit too wittily,
passing throughl Hell on my way to ltaLZ.
Villa Stellar abounds in things as quotable and relaxed and entertaining as that. It is, to employ a useful word coined by James Joyce, jocoserious.
Jocoseriousness also characterizes the best noenis in Geoffrey Grigson's The Fiesta and Other Poems (Secker & Warburg, E3.50) especially a handful of love poems. that succeed in the difficult business of being personal without being coy or messy. Grigson is another poet wvho has written nearly all his finest work late in life-in his case, more or less since the publication of his Collected Poems f963). I do not think any critic sh'ould try to discover why this may be so, although the reasons can be clearly felt in the freer rhyrthms and authority of language in the itfore recent books. A poem here, entitled " Visit from a Biographer ", provides a clue and then quite properly instructs us to shut up vith such speculation. It is about an encounter wvhich Mr Grigson had with someone wanting to wvrite a biography of Norman Cameron, and his refusal to gossip about thatsuperb poet whose wvork has much in comrmon with his own.
I have room onlv to recomnmend two books by younger poets-Peter Ackroyd and Craig Raine. Both seem to me of the highest promise. Mr Ackrovf4s Co=nthy Life (Ferry Press, 177 Green Lane,; London, SE9, Â£1.50) is remarkable, howvever difficult most of the psems may be to understand individually, because it is unmistakably the work of a poet for whom words are the experience. He has something of the quality of early Auden or r2cent John Ashbery -an air of being wounded into speaking, while remaining cold in what he says and how he says it. That coldness. which has nothing to do wvith a lack of feeling, gives the work a,uthority. Anyone vwho cares about poeni- should seek this book out and refer immediately tv page 33, where there is a poent "about" tbe coldness I speak of. It is the final poem in the book, and I assume by this'.that MIr Ackrrovd knows exactlv what he is doing. Ir Raine is more uticertairi, but the tit!e poem in his volume The Onion, M1eihory (Oxford, Â£2.23) has a similar self-awareness. and if he cl-n go on revisiting the mood that made it then there may well be another genuine new poet on the sgene.
Robert Nye
