Author: Ratcliffe, Michael
Title: Taking it seriously
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS
Taking it seriously
The New Oxford Book of Light Versc
Chosen and edited by Kingsley Amis
(Oxford, £4.50)
The original Oxford Book of Light Yerse was edited by Auden and published in 1938. The first thing to be said about The New Oxford Book of Light Verse is that Kingsley Amis has produced a selection as unlike his predecessor's as it could possibly be and, that vhile you may well wyish to possess both, you could not agree with them equally. Auden is eccentric and full of surprises, but Amis, I believe, is more apropos.
The tsvo editors have one thing in cormnon. Both begin by taking light verse seriously: where pleasure and amusement are concerned only the best will do. Auden, however, declared that light verse was one of the vital luxuries of democratic freedom, and should speak in the contemporary language of its audience. This allowved him to include Kipling's harrowing "Danny Deever" and to omit the immortal but hardly colloquial "Jabber-wocky" in favour of things like this:
Tlhay set orn ther nollys For to kepc thzer pollys, Godc blake bollgs.
For batryng of batts.
And so on, for some nine pages and 26 stanzas of "The Tournament of Tottenham ", wvith notes at the foot of each page. Sounding in his introduction more bracingly like the original Jim Dixon than for some years, Amis will have none of this, and vith one sivinge removes from his choice all literature before Shakespeare-Skelton, for instance, for committing both unforgivable crimes, of being (a) unfunny and, if not unfunny then (b) obscure--and reduces the contributions of Anon from well over a half to less than one tenth. ("The Vicar of Bray" is a rare point of accord.) In pursuit of the true vox populi Auden included so many anonymous folk-songs and ballads that he left insufficient room for poets of provenance and name. Mr Amis restores the field of light verse to the professionals in a fastidious and patLician selection. Rude, too, of course, from time to time:
An Argentine gaucho named
Bruno
Declared, " There is one thing I
do know: A woman is fine
And a boy is divine,
But a llama is numero uno"
Auden further limited himself to poems not already in "Q's" Oxford Book of English Verse, but Amis has sensibly gone straight for what he likes best, irrespective of the poems chosen. by Helen Gardner and rPhilip Larkin for The New Oxford Book.of English Verse and The Oxforcd Bonk of.Twen-. tietit Century English Verse: at least one poem. MacNeice's, thrumming "Bagpipe Music ", is in all three. Amis omits Pope and Dryden on his own grounds that the former's unpleasantness and the latter's high tone deprive them of the requisite lightness, and from Auden's list he also removes Herrick, and demotes Edward Lear as too whimsical (or, perversely, in The Owl and the Pussycat, as too "touching"). He has also managed to round up an unusually large number of poems savaging Wordsworth, a cause near his heart.
Above all, Amis removes light verse from the uncertain claims of populist art and places it squarely where it belongs: in the century and a quarter between Byron and Betieman. (In many -ways " A Subaltern's Love-song " ise the perfect light verse.) His heroes are poets like Winthrop Mackworth Praed (1802-1839), Charles Stuart Calverley (1831-1884) and W. S. Gilbert, who is in with the grisly-grim " Yarn of the 'Nancy Bell"' and.with songs from Pinafore, Pirates (2), lolanthe (the nightmare, which Auden had, too) and Ruddigore. All three combine a brilliant technique with asperity of mind and a (reasonably) generous heart. Each has the superb confidence to stand cliches and pretensions on their bead and mock, without destroying, them.
To me the least familiar was Calverley, an invalid lawyer and Fellow of Christ's College, Cambridge, master of the precise inconsequence certain to tumble a high Victorian tea-party. into a felicity of helpless giggling: Forever! What abysms of woe
The word reveals, what frenzy,
what
Despair! For ever (printed so} Did not.
Amis chooses six Calverley poems, and all are funny. Auden chose one, and that, characteristically, a wistful, but unfunny poem about memories of Cambridge. Praed's breathtaking "Good-Night to- the Season ! " explodes through both anthologies, of course, as it is also honoured in Gardner, but Amis scores by matching it with Ted Pauker's very clever pastiche ("A Grouchy. Good Night to the Academic Year") which perfectly expresses the editor's owvn views. on the lunacy of further education in the modern,age. (Likewise the pleasures of drinking and the impossibility of foreigners are reflected in The. New Oxford Book of Light Verse.)- Pauker is much less successful with "A Trifle for Trafalgar a. parody of Chesterton's "Antichrist." ode, with Edward Heath as monosyllabic stand-in for the original F. E. Smith. Chesterton was devastatingly,angry and wrote a much funnier poem: Mr Pauker, alias Robert Conquest, is playing at scales. -
There are oddities. Americans just creep in, with Frost and Bret Harte, but there is no Ogden Nash and nothing. from Hollywood or Broadway (what about Sondheim ?). Amis believes that most performing lyrics look flat in collections like this, and the point is proved not by "Mad Dogs and Englishmen ", which is inviolate, but by his second Coward choice-" Bad Times are Just Around the Corner", which palls most horribly offstage. I think his view of light verse in the seventies is excessively bleak and that, if he could find room for Alan Bennett's Betjeman parody (" Place-Names of China"), he should, by his own demands for technique at the service of entertainment, have included somethilg -by Tony Harrison and Christopher Logue. But if there is anything more deadly than a Skelton unfunny it is an Amis unamused, and he rightly relies on his positive responses to provide a reliable and sympathetic guide. The result is a rich and relaxed collection.
Michael Ratcliffe

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: A sense of duty
Full_text:
A sense of duty
John Masefield: Selected Poems
lVith a preface by John Betjeman
(Heinemann, £f5.90)
Tohn Masefield was born 100 years ago today. The remembrance is unlikely to set a younger generation on fire. Yet, as the present Poet Laureate says in introducing this handy volume of selections from Masefield's verses, the man vrote two lyrics which will be remembered as long as the language lasts (no prize for guessing that he means " SeaFever" and "Cargoes", though he then goes on to refer to these, rather oddly, by means of their first lines and not their titles). He also wrote three narrative poems wvhich have a vigour and a freshness quite distinct from anything perpetrated by his boring contemporaries - The Everlasting Mercy (1911), Dauber (1913), and Reunard the Fox (1919). Masefield is absolutely out of fashion now. He was overvalued in his owvn lifetime. so no doubt there is justice in this reaction. But English poetry rejects some of its owvn virtues and possibilities if it quite forgets effects like these:
"After him." " Catch him."
Out him." " Scrob him."
"Wle'll give him hell." " By God, ue'll mob him."
" We'll dick- him, scrout him, flog him, fratch him."
" All right " I said. " But first you'll catch him."
That is from The Everlasting Mercy. If you compare it wvith the work of an earlier poet wvho succeeded in capturing and enacting the rhythms of colloquial. speech in his versesay, Wlilliam Barnes-then it does not look or sound particularly startling. Masefield wvas never really as revolutionary as he seemed to be, and it is true that he injected a spurious:realism into his verse by1 the u'se of somewvhat silly verbs'supposed to contain considerable masculinity-" scrob " and " fratch "-and, famously, by all that use of invective: "You. closhy put." /" You bloody liar ", and so forth. The point is that it does not
really work. Masefield should be given marks for recognizing that the gentility of his contemporaries was unacceptable. He cannot, in all fairness, be saluted for releasing them from that gentility in his oNvn poetry. He is nearer Browning than he is near Barnes. He tried to sound as though he was writing in his. shirt sleeves.
This is to criticize John Masefield by high standards, the standards that his own best work demands. There was precious little of that best, if any, after he became Poet Laureate in 1930-a fact which seems to have impressed itseli uncomfortably u;-on Betjeman, who notes that someone should have written a letter to Masefield telling him that he did not have to submit verses on topical events to this newspaper. "The Laureateship ", declares Sir John, "is nowv officially regarded not as a spur to further verse writing but as a reward, as Eric Gillett described it to me. for, work already done."
It w us Masefield's sense of duty that caused him to submit atrocious poems to The Times. Doubtless it was a sense of duty on the part of The Times that caused it to print them. As Sir John adds, with his tongue somewhere near his cheek, I should guess: "The appointment (of the Laureatesnip) is
in the gift of the Prime Minister wrho advises the Queen. Ramsay Macdonald advised the appointment of Masefield."
Perhaps we are now far enough away from Masefield's official fame to recognize his genuine minor gifts ? There are one or two other poems in this selected volume, besides the couple singled out by Betjeman, which might well live.
There is also the little niatter of Masefield's novels: among them Jim Davis (1911), Sard Harker (1924),. Odtaa (1926), and Dead Ned (1938). There is a case to be made that his best work was done in prose. Simple racy, straightforward prose. The kind of thing he was always trying to force into verse came naturally enough to him when he abandoned poetic form and let himself go with stories in the manner of Robert Louis Stevenson.
With the present Laureate, I hope that . this book gains Masefield new readers. Unlike him, apparently, I hope that those same new readers will transfer their disappointment with Masefield's verse into an interest in his prose. The first good thing to be said about that prose is that there is no crippling sense of duty in it.
Robert Nye I
An extract from a forthcoming biography of- Masefield. by Constance Babington Smith will appear in this week's Saturday Review.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Basil Bunting once described .limself: Minor poet, not conspicuously dishonest. It is a 'good description, and an honourable one, and I think it is borne out by the work in his Collected Poems (Oxford £3.75, E2.25 paperback). Overshadowed .or years by standing in the reputation of Ezra Pound, and 'repeatedly written off as a disciple ,it was the sonata-like long poem Briggflatts (1966) which compelled reassessment of this neglected English poet, now 78 vears old. What is attractive about Briggflatts is the way in which it marries personal experience and landscape with the wider world of historical allusion. But if I wvere introducing Bunting to someone who had never read a line of his, I would choose something less ambitious, some. thing precise and unforgettable, such as'
Not to thank dogwood nor the wind that sifts
petals are these words, nor for a record,
but, as notes sung and received still the air,
these are controlled by yesterdap evering, a peal after
the beZls have rested.
The current issue of the little magazine Agenda is a special Basil Bunting issue, in which there is a valuable transcript of some remarks made by the poet himself on what he was trying to do in Briggflatts. Agenda costs 90p and is available from 5 Cranbourne Court, Albert Bridge Road, London, SW1l 4PE.
Two other volumes of a life's work deserve respect, and more. Allen Tate's Collected Poems 1919-1976 (Faber, E6.95) demonstrate that he must have serious claims to be considered the leading rhetorician of his generation of American poets. If I cannot warm to his verse it may be because he sets out to chill us with a classical assurance that never lets the reader forget that this is art with a capital A. I miss the overheard note. In Bunting's terms, Tate's bells are forever resonant. but there is rarely a peal to linger in the mind after they have done their solemn job. I make an exception of one or two of the earlier poems, notably the superb lines which begin:
T1re idiot greens t1he meadow
with his eues.... Anyone who can make every word work for its keep in the way that he does is plainly a considerable poet. I wish Tate had wvritten more poems as compact, and with as unwavering a rhythm. The Complete Poems of Keith Douglas, edited by Desmond Graham (Oxford, £3.95), confirms that when Douglas wYas killed in Normandy, three days after D-day at the age of 24, we lost the
finest poet to come out of the Second World War. Direct,. using words not to decorate, his thoughts and feelings butto hammer them into the shape of sense, Douglas wrote at least. seven poems wihich ensure his, survival among the English poets. I quote the two quatrains which conclude Vergissnzeine
nicht. since there is as muchlj poetry in this pity as in anything by Wilfred Owven a war earlier:
But she would weep to see today how on his skin the swart flies
move;
the dust upon the paper epc
and the bzrst stomach like a cave. For here thze lover and killer arc
iningled whlo had on7e body and onze heart.. And deathz who had the soldier
singled cas done the lover mortal hurt.
Two volumes of posthumous pieces, Robert Lowvell's Day bv?
Day (Faber, f3.95) and John., Berryman's Henry's Fate and Other Poems (Faber Paperback,' £2.75) do not seem to me to add much to the stature of either of the poets, and the Berryman in particular seems to be something in the nature of barrel-scraping since it consists of poems wvhich he rejected when putting together his last twvo books. Still I wvould be the last to deny that Berryman's anguished and conf used outpourings can touch the heart. What one requires of poetry, though, is that it touches the heart (and the mind) in such a wvay that the reader says: These words, yes, and no other, That is a precision approached in John Montague's The Great Cloak (Dolmen Press with. Oxford, £2.75), a collection of love poems that demand and reward careful reading at their own slow, sober, pain-informed pace, and most particularly in a little volume by A. Alvarez entitled Autunn to Autumn and Selected Poems 1953-1976 (Macmillan, £3.95). The last book is a real eye-opener. Alvarez is wvidely knowvn as a reviewver, but he has written few poems and never pushed or peddled. himself as a poet. WhTbat comes. off from this most distinguished selection is a sense of authenticitv and necessity. The poems have been -wrung from the poet: almost against his wvill. I am reminded of something John Aubrey once said about Sir Walter Ralegh: "He was sometimes a poet; not often." That is true of most poets, on]y most poets publish all the stuff they write, so that time has to sort out the occasions wvhen they, were poets at the moment of writing. Alvarez, like Ralegh, seems to have mastered the art of holding his own poetic ambitions in check. He writes poems when he is a poet. Thatis not often. But it is often enough to make this a book to set beside Norman Cameron's The Winter House or Martin Seymour-Smith's Reminiscences of Norma-in other wvords, with the best of the neglected and unfashionable and utterly genuine poets of our rather nasty century.
Robert Nye
Books next week include Michael Ratcliffe on " The Goebbels Diaries", edited by Hugh Trevor-Roper. Sir WVilliam Haley on Tolstoy's letters. Philippa Toomey on historical novels.

Author: Cotterell, Laurence
Title: Bitter fruit
Full_text:
Bitter fruit
Men Who March Away
Poems of the First World War Edited by I. M. Parsons
(Chatto & Windus. Â£1.50)
Out of Battle
The Poetry of the Great War By Jon Silkin (Oxford, Â£2.50)
Jon Silkin examines the motivations and feelings of the poets by reference to a representative selection of them, while Ian Parsons gives the feel of the poetry itself, also by. representative selection. Their choices of
exemplars are remarkably simi-. lar, and more than tvo-thirds. of the authors whose poetry has been included by Mr Par. sons are also considered by Mr Silkin. Indeed, apart from its own intrinsic appeal, Men Who March Away provides the "illustrations", as it were, for Out of Battle.
In a necessarily limited yet admirably lucid introduction to the poems he has chosen and arranged, Ian Parsons refers in passing to wvhat Cyril Connolly called " the explosion of Georgian Marsh-gas." Jon Silkin enlarges on the topic of that phenomenon, tracing a continuum from Coleridge and Wordsworth (with their sometimes agonised reactions to the French Revolution and the subsequent French ImperiWlism),t
through Shelley and Byron to Hardy and the Georgians, and so to the war poets, some of them leading lights in that "Georgian" school.
Yet, with the ruthless honesty marking his whole study, Mr Silkin says at one point that "The enthusiasm for the war remains a puzzle ". Since he wrote those words the definitive biography of Julian Grenfell has appeared, giving a clue to th^ enthusiasm of upper-class young men-a cleansing of their self-assumed guilt-stains with a wallowv in mud and blood-but what of the rest? Possibly some part of the answer is summed up by Chesterton (who is not even mentioned by Mr Silkin, although it might be thought that GK's bitter comparison between the fate of the rulers and that of the fighting-men would have struck a responsive chord) when he has his working-class Briton say.
I knew 110 ill of Boneu, anud
plentv of the squire, And for to fight the Frenchizan t
did not mnzch admire, But I did bash hiis bagginets
because lie came arrayed To straighten out thte rolling road
an2 English drunkard made. Ian Parsons includes three of Chesterton's war poems, along wvith those of other writers who are surprisingly ignored completely by Jon Silkin, namely Wilfrid Gibson, Osbert Sitwell (who seems to say something special in "The Next War "), and Arthur Graeme West, wvho got into the army through the ranks despite eye weakness and died of a sniper's bullet. How could Mr Silkin not be drawn to
God ! Ihow I 7hate you, you uouing
cheerful ienz, Whose pious poetry blossoms on
your graves As soon as you are in them. ...
When all else is said, how stimulative of ever-fresh speculation is Jon Silkin's logically developed exploration, sometimes impassioned and often exciting. And how much its reasoning enhances appreciation-emotional and analytical -of the carefully selected, exceedingly evocative poems presented by Ian Parsons!
Laurence Cotterell

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Robert Nye
Little magazines are the life blood of new poetry. Auden made them rhyme with "intellectual marines". He should have known. After all, he had Geoffrey Grigson's New Verse behind him from the startand New Verse was arguably the best little magazine of the century so far. The Auden rhyme is intended to draw attention to the pioneering and exploratory qualities of a good magazine of this kind. If the little magazines do not take risks, then the big publishers can be guaranteed to take even fewer thar. 'usual. A healthy magazi.ne sceile does not create poets, of course, but it might make it a bit harder for the real ones to be ignored for ever.
Does fame nmatoz, ro the true poet ? It should not. But recognition is a different thing. There is a letter in which Gerard Manley Hopkins asserts that being known is " the air the poet breathes ". Poor Hopkins had little enough of that air in his own life, and managed; yet, even then, the process is two-way, and we could regret that Browning and Swinburne had no opportunity to be startled into a fresh awareness of their own limitations by reading, say, Tlhe Windhiover.
Of all the current crop of literary magazines, Bananas, edited by Emma Tennant, is probably doing most to ensure that the real right thing does not go unrecognized. Starting in 1975, this quarterly newspaper of lbe arts quickly established for itself the reputation of being\ a bit rude, a bit tough, and a whole lot unpredictable. Now there is an anthology of writing from it, called simply Bananas (Quartet Books, £2.50), culled from the first eight issues, and certain trends become apparent. Bananas is feminist, aggressive. and committed to unfashionable excellence.
Would any other magazine of the moment dared to have printed Martin SeymourSmith's long and briliant analysis of what is wrong with contemporary English literary life, "A Climate of Warm Indifference "? This has some of the violent accuracy of Wyndham Lewis at his best, and Bananas almost merits comparison with Lewis's own magazine, Blast, in having an identifiable force and vigour, the impress of a strong directing intelligence in its editing. It has- published outstandingly fine stories by Angela Carter, J. G- Ballard, Ruth Fainlight, and Beryl Bainbridge. Mbre to the point of this column, it is regularly packed with interesting poetry-Peter Redgrove, Jenny Joseph, Ted Hughes, Elaine Feinstein, and Jeremy Hilton all appear in the anthology, and the magazine can claim to have discovered an unusually talented newcomer in Daniel Brand, who was only seventeen when he wrote the poem included here.
Bananas 9, the winter issue, is currently available, and well uip to standard (50p. from 2 Blenheim Crescent, London, W.11). Since publications of this kind depend upon reliable subscriptions, I will mention also that a cheque or postal order for £3 made payable to
Bananas Publishing wvill provide you with a year's supply.
Aquarius, edited by Eddie Linden, is more purely a poetry magazine. It has now run to ten numbers, and the tenth, in honour of John Heath-Stubbs in the year of his sixtieth birthday, is altogther worth acquiring (Flat 3, 116 Sutherland Avenue, London. W.9. 60p). This issue, guest-edited by Sebastian Barker, has photographs of Heath-Stubbs, and an interviesw with him, and poems and prose. pieces that celebrate his life and work, the contributors including George Barker, C. H. Sisson, David Wright, Gavin Ewart and Kathleen Raine. Another very vorthwhile magazine, Agenda, edited by William Cookson, devotes its latest issue (Vol. 15. No. 4-numbers suggesting an uncommon and commendable longevity in this field, incidentally) to translations from the French. Agenda is obtainable from 5 Cranbourne Court, Albert Bridge Road, London, SW1l 4PE, and costs 75p, or f3 for an annual subscription to four issues.
There is something peculiarly satisfying about reading r.eiv wsork in littie magazine format, in that the reader is allowved to treat some of the writing as his own discovery. However, if you miss out first turn around you can ahvayz catch up on the year's best ir. Poetry Dimension Annual S (Robson, £4.25 and £2.25) the anthology in which Dannie Abse selects the stuff wvhich seems to him most lasting from the past 12 months.
After little magazines, small publishers . . . Perhaps it is not surprising, given the present shortage of money iti the country, that much of the most interesting new work is coming from tiny private presses. Giles Gordon's The Oban Poems (Sceptre Press, £l.50) is one of those short, swift, unpretentious sequences best-suited to this kind of publication anywvay. It has all the qualities of Gordon's best prose-an observant eye, a strong sense of shape and rhythm, a quiet refusal of the easy options. Sceptre Press can be reached by addressing yourself to them at Knotting, Bedfordshire, MK44 1AF, but you had better hurrv because this edition iS limited to 150 copies and I should think it must be a collector's item from the start. By and large, I prefer to ignore such items, but wlhen the writer in question is as good and collectable as Gordon, or as genuine a poet as James Reeves, then I make an exception. Reeves, nowv nearly seventy, must have a serious claim to being the most undervalued poet in thf land, buit two smrall presses have donc him proud vwith his latest publications, both signed and limited editions, both exquisitely produred and illustrated. These are The Closed Door (Gruffyground Press, Ladram, Sidcot, Winscombe, Somerset f6) and Arcadian Ballads (The Whittington Press, Manor Farm, Andoversford, nr. Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, GL54 4HP. £25). The latter has pictures by Edward Ardizzone who has also signed it. The forrder, signed by the poet and the artist Richard Shirley Smith, has poems as good as this:
r tread the ucars fromn love to
love. I think the past fro.n name to
And now is where I cene,
To find each new love different And every love thc suirne.
Reviews next week include: Paul Johnson on The Abuse of Power by James Margach; Jonathan Sumption on Janus: a Summing-Up by Arthur Koestler.

Author: Wardle, Irving
Title: Witty and agile lyrics among exotic foliage
Full_text:
Witty and agile lyrics among exotic foliage
Kingdom Come
King's Head
Irving Wardle
Stewart Parker's Belfast musical, Spokesong, dug some unexpected fun out of the British imperial slag-heap, and in this sequel Mr Parker tries to go one better and bring down two colonial birds with one stone.
To clarify that mixed metaphor, Kingdom Come takes place on a Caribbean island largely populated by Irish immigrants and concerns the festivities for the 300th anniversary of the settlement. A pageant committee assembles on the veranda of an hotel, ostensibly to plan the show, but really to hatch factional plots for an anniversary coup. Intrigue festers under the bland supervision of an old party called Pyecraft who seems to have Whitehall connexions. The black police chief is in league wvith a lady figurehead of th&e Protestant ascendancy; the black newspaper editor with a judge's daughter; the republican priest with an island girl called Teresa. By means of bombings, shootings, and mass poisoning each group hopes to wipe out the opposition.
I offer these details in the hope that they may guide intending spectators through the exotic foliage of Tony Tanner's production. It took me most of the evening to wvork tllem out. I still-cannot account for the mercenaries end strikers who are said to be lurking offstage, not to mention the founder-figure of Huge Flood who looms large in the first scene and then vanishes. It is also as much of a shock to the spectators as it is to the
chiaracters when the royal yacht appears purposefully on the horizon; up to that point, one had taken Macalla for an Irish protectorate.
A great deal of information is packed into the opening number which goes whizzing by, leaving you to work things out for yourself. Perhaps someone has taken the scissors to Mr Parker's book and snipped out Pyecraft's credentials, together wvith explanations of all the other random alliances in this sunkissed Ulster.
Suffice to say that whlen the great moment arrives, Teresa casts her Irish harp aside and reconciles the island's differences with a song in favour of the human race, which is promptly confirmed by the parade of the black nationalist as Britannia and the policeman as a leprechaun. And if you can put the story out of your head, there are other things to enjoy.
The songs mav often part company with the narrative, but they include some of the wittiest and most agile lyrics I have heard since the last Sondlreim. Shaun Davey's score excels in coupling Caribbean rhythms with the sound of the ceilidh, not to mention evocations of the old Savoy Hotel for the lady British Unionist. She is played by Sonia Graham, a ramrod Big House memsahib who abruptly comes on strong as a jazz dancer and close-harmony singer.
Her partner is Glenna Forster-Jones, radiating erotic danger in a golden boiler suit, alternating a sullenly impassive mask with a wide crocodile smile, and leading Carl Andrews into the evening's best number. Cy Grant as the police chief and Des Keogh as the priest and trigger-lhappy harpist, are other prominent contributors to this enjoyable mess.
Photograph by Donald Cooper Des Keogh and Glenna Forster-Jones.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Chair and table talk
Full_text:
Chair and table talk
Professing Poetry
Robert Nye
by John Wain
(Macmillan, Â£6.95)
"Joln," says Yevtushenko, "you are a very juicy man." John tells us that Yevtushenko said that. Page 233. They are having lunch with others-" We are on opposite sides of the table, but we signal to each other with understanding." Wain ponders the meaning of being a juicy man. " Since from his expression I see that this is a compliment, I assume he means that I am the opposite of a dry stick."
So he is. A jticy man. Illdeed, juiciness is all in this rather unusual book. John Wain, poet, novelist, critic, has since late 1973 been the Professor of Poetry at Oxford. lie occupies, as they say, a chair. And it is a cnair which has been occupied by distinguished writers before him: Auden, Graves, Day Lewis, Blunden, Fuller. Most of these writers published the lectures which they delivered from that chair,
the ex cathIedra stuff. And tlhat, of course, is what Mr Wain is doing now. Only Professing Poetry, being the work of a juicy man, does not contain merely the words delivered from the chair, but the thoughts of the chairman on the way to the chair, and the circumstances in the local pub on the way home from the chair and so on and so forth. In other words, it is a set of Oxford Professor of Poetry Lectures (fairly formal pieces on Auden, on Larkin, on Empson, on Emily Dickinson, on Edward Thomas, and on more general topics such as " Poetry and Social Criticism ") buttressed with chat about the gathering in the author's garden when the news came through that he had been elected, happy little reminiscences of the victory dance performed by his friends Philin Larkin and Peter Levi later thht niglht, extensive quotations from the wvork of younger poets he has encouraged while at Oxford and rather chummy wordpictures of them, all designed or throw n together to open a window not just on the author's mind but on his way of life.
The merit of the book is that it does provide a sort of continuum, and the reader is then free to decide whether be enjoys existing alongside it or even (if he can accept Mr Wain's blandishments) within it. A dry stick would march up to his chair and deliver his thoughts on, say, Empson and then retire. Mr Wain, all juicy, can not only range up and dowvn in Empson's work (where he has a distinguished track record, having been one of the very first to draw serious atten-
tiont to its uniqueness) but can tlhrow in provocative afterthoughts about Empson's lifestyle, muttering darTlly about his lack of a CBE, telling us that "his blunt directness is that of the Yorkshire squire (though it was his elder brother, I believe, who inherited the broad acres "). This gives Professing Poetry an unbuttoned quality wvhich is most uncommon in current literary criticism. If anything, it reminds me more of the tradition of table talk, rather than chair talk-the sort of remarks which Drummond of Hawthornden recalled being made by Ben Jonson, or which Coleridge could never 'be prevented from outpouring wvhether he had an audience or not. The snag is that Mr Wain (as the nine new poems at the back of this volume remind us) is certainly not a poet who can be mentioned in the same breath as Ben Jonson or Coleridge, and consequently his table talk is often mere chatter of little interest to anyone save his friends. But he is a generous man, and his habit of interspersing his lectures on the famous with puffs for the unknown is not necessarily a bad habit. One of these geese might really be a swan, and then a future generation will conclude that Mr Wain was a prophet as well as a professor.
Meanwhile, his book is readable, and easy-going, and decent with praise, and the lectures must certainly have inspired an undergraduate or two to assume that poetry is something one might try to write, and not just to analyse or evaluate. The professor is a professional.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Her Storms
Selected Poems 1938-1977 By Sheila Wingfield
(Do)men Press/John Calder, £7.50)
Admissions
Poems 1974-1977
By Sheila Wingfield
(Dolmen Press/ John Crmlii P<
On the Rocks -
By Seb.-stian Barker
(Martin Brian anfi (VTCi-ffa P9'i
A store of Candles By Frank Ormsby I (Oxford. £1.95
I The Dwe"ing-Place By Clive Wilmer
(Carcanet Press, £2)
Sheila Wingfield, now in her seventies, is perhaps about to be discovered again. I say "again" because her earliest work was praised by Yoats and Walter de la Mere, and then in the Forties she impressed Herbert Read and in the Fifties G. S. Fraser. Fraser is still impressed, and has provided a preface to Wingfield's Her Storms: Selected Poems 1938-1977 which contains a comprehensive selectin of tie work of a lifetime.
This book, taken together
with a volume of recent poems, Admissions: Poems 19741977 should be sufficient to bring her to general critical attention. The heartening thing is that she has done well enough without it. Here is a poet who has not spent all her spare time in a BBC studio, who is hardly represented in any of the anthologies, who has probably never given a public reading nor won a literary prizein short, a poet who has not played the dangerous game with Fame which so many twentieth century poets assume to be necessary to their careers. Indeed, Sheila Wingfield seems to me best recommended by the observation that she has never had a career, in that sense. She has simply pursued a lifelong vocation of writing poems. For this reason, and for others which no doubt strike deeper, her work has an uncommon but essential quality of necessity:
When Hsuang Tsung, great
emperor,
Giddy and ill, cffried in a litter, Saw the stars swap,
His conquests and his arguments And powers, faling into fever
with him,
Pulsed their lives awag.
Bow to his shade. To be at rest
is but a dog that sighs and settles: better
The unrelenting day.
That is a whole Wingfield
poem, not untypical in its tautness, its consonantal music, and its mnsistance upon the merits of even pain-flecked consciousness. The title of the poem is "Poisoned in Search of the Medicine of Immortality". If one of the jobs of poetry is to say hard things clearly, in words that come out of each other with such authority that alternative words seem impossible, then Sheila Wingfield can be sure of her place among the English poets.
Sebastiitn Barker can be sure of no such thing. His On the Rocks is by all reasonable reckoning a terrible book, an outpouring of sonnets-well, 14. line howls-on the subject of his wife's infidelity. Barker shouts and weeps and strikes murderous poses over the corpse of his own affections. His command of technique seems is no way adequate to the urgency of what he had to say. Why, then, is -the book worth mentiooning'? Because it finally eludes all reasonable reckoning, bemg the unmistakable real thing. Anyone bored as they should be by the timid lucubrations and evasions of so much contemporary verse will find in this book the note at least of an authentic passion:
0 my daughters, What a mother you have I Right
over tle horns of the moon
She threw my heart. Down, down,
into the dark
She let it drop. And on to the
bright Apollonian
She drove her radiant desire. And
now in the squeak
And scratch of meeting him she
holds the lover's inquest:
"Is this one dead, or t'other
one ? Which death do I like the best ? "
Having quoted this, I see that it is both less clear and rather better written than most of the rest. If Barker can baild on the feeling for language which spurs him to such things as "the squeak and scratch of meeting ", without losing any of the fury, the emotional and intellectual reality that has unbalanced this particular set of poems, then there may tell be a considerable new poet on the scene. His courage and his confidence are already commendable.
Frank Ormsby's A Store of Candles and Clive Wilmer's The Dwelling-Place are both first books. Neither is exactly -exciting, but Wilmer in particular seems deliberately to eschew ex. citement-and achieves some sober. well-crafted, sensible poetry as a result. Ormsby has a rieher sensibility, and a more various appreciation of scenes. but his verse is rougher-grained. even anecdotal, as though he were somehow determined to prove that the poet can be the fellow next door.
* Christmas is "coming, but none of the books I have mentioned (with the exception of Sheila Wingfield?§) would make much of a present for. someone ,with a general: interest in modern verse. Specifically as presents, I recfimend an edition of Wallace.. Stevens's masterpiece The Man with the Blue Guitar, which has etchings by David Hockney (Petersburg Press, £5.50); and The Penguin Book of Zen Poetry edited and translated byvjucien :Stryk and Takashi Ikemoto (Allen Lane, £3.95); and twso anthologiesthe PEN New Poems 1977-78, edited by Gavin Ewart (Hutchinson, £4.95), and the Arts Council of Great Britain's New Poetry 3, edited by Alan Brownjohn and Maureen Duffy (Arts Council, £4 and £2.25, distributed by Carcanet Press). New Poetry 3 is particularly to be encouraged because it provides evidence of bw attractively unfashionable yet interesting an anthology c,an be, when its ditors are prepared simply to select the bter poems that come their way, without soliciting established poets to provide conributions. The Arts Council advertised And received about 10,000 poems in response, from which the present selection of 200 poems has been made.
Robert Nye I

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Prussian Nights, by Alexander Solzhenitsyn
(Collins/Harvill, £3.75)
German Poetry 1910-1975, edited by Michael Hamburger (Carcanet Press, £3.50)
Selected Poems of Lawrence Durrell, edited with an introduction by Alan Ross
(Faber, f2.95 and £1.50)
In the Stopping Train and Other Poems, by Donald Davie (Carcanet Press, £2)
Implements in Their Places, by W. S. Graham (Faber, £1.95)
Solzhenitsyn composed a lon. gish narrative poem in his head while he was serving 'his sentence of forced labour under Stalin. It is based on his owvn wvar experience with the Russian army, and in particular on the coincidence that his battery followed the same line of advance into' East Prus. *sia that Samsonov's Seco)nd Army followed wvith disastrous consequences in 1914. Samsonov's defeat is the theme of Solzhenitsyn's novel August 1914. It is hard to tell, fromRobert Conquest's transldtion of the nerrative poem as Prussian Nights, whether we should regard the poem as a footnote to the novel, or vice versa.
Ideally, of course, one would like to say that each is a vital and self-sustaining work of art. Solzhenitsyn is a man of courage and intelligence, ar.d his writing has the nobility of truth told no matter what [he consequences to the teller. Uinfortunately, good novels ind good poems are not achieved merely by the exercise of truth telling, and where August 1914 seems to me a passable sol't of novel, if rather badly constructed, Prussian Nights in this translation reads like no sort of poem at all. It is, in a wvord, doggerel. The first four lines are example enough:
Open up, you alien country!
Wide open let your gates 71e tVrotwn !
For, approac7ing, see how boldly Russia's battle-line rolls on I
The publisher prints the Russian text on facing pages, and I can only hope that those able
to consult this will not find in it the bathetic and incongruous sound of a bad hymn tune which seems to hum and drone throughout the wshole translation.
Auden said once that in translating tone wvas ail. If
Conquest has correctly ren-- dered the tone of Solzhenitsyn's verse then so much the worse for Solzhenitsyn's verse. The achievement of Michael Hamburger in his compendious one-man anthology Gernan Poetry 1910.1975, is that he catches so many and such various tones-from the inwardness and sensitivity of Rilke to the freexrang'ng knockabout comedy of Gunter Grass. Once more, the publisher provides the original texts on facing pages, and the result is a remarkable anthology-a complete introduction, to German poetry in tthis cenitury. No major poet is omitted, and many attractive minor figures ate included. Amongst the latter I was pleased to see Kurt Schwitters, whose delightful "To Anna Bloom" is just the sort of poem that usually does not get included in big anthologies. (I wish, though, that Hamburger had used Schwitters's owvn English translation of this.)
Selected Poerms of Lawrence Durrell, edited with an introduction by Alan Ross, provides a timely reminder that whatever Durrell's fame as a novelist and charm as a writer of books about Mediterranean Places it is principally as a poet that we ought to consider him. Some of his poems, indeed, do seem to come from .th-e part of h,is mind that writes the popular prosethese things, while pretty, do not 'have aMy great feeling of necessity abo.ut them. But Durrell at his best is more than an observer of exotic places. Ross has done him a real service by this selection, which is almost solidly the authentic thing. I refer to three poems as examples of Durrell's range and d-epth-" To Ping-Ku, Asleep "'
which is-- beautifully te,nder, "Nemea ". which has an incantatory lyricism not far away from Rimbaud at his most magical, and "A Ballad of the Good Lord Nelson ". The last could only have been written by Durrell. It is hard, bawdy, Witty, dashing, dashed-off, and brilliant. I wish he had written two dozen things like it, to the dismay of all the academics. First stanza only:
The Good Lord Nelson had a swollen gland,
L#ttle of the scripture did he understand
Till a woman led him to the promised land
Aboard the Victory, Victory 0.
Donald Davie's In the Stopping Train and Other Poems is interesting chiefly for its title. poem, in.which' Davie finds a' chattier. and more open-ended way of talking to himself. The verses otherwise seem to me the same tired and timid mixture as before, with no discern-
ible pressure of feeling behind' them. W. S. Graham is also a great talker-to-himself and his new collection Implements in Their 'Places contains many poems in which he keeps clear-' ing his throat or approaching the possibility of saying some-. thing. Graham's finest achievie-. ment to date seems to me his long poem Thee. Nightfishing '(1955). In' 'truth, he ;seems to have one subject only' ~and that
subject, rath.er boringly, is w.rit-. ing, the 'act of literary creationA
eRobrt Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Jung once said: "It is not Goethe that creates Faust, but Faust that creates Goethe." ,W;at he meant is that there is ,a sease in which the poet is a spectator in the theatre of his o*n .imnagination.: The idea is not. -'.ne-7-it ' iis a modem 6bspre¢sion 'of Cone theory of Romanticism, " ivhich in turn derives from Greek notions of rhe poet as possessed by a daimon. Why I mention it here is because if I had to nominate on-e living English poet whose work seems to fit into this category that poet wvould be Peter Redgrove, whose FrontK Every Clzitnk of the Ark and. Otlier New Poetrns (Routlea:ge & Keg'an - Pajl £4.95) is a book vhich~ f tvould find difficult. indeed,. to 'describe in any other': terms et alll. That is Redgrove's strengrir, and his limitati6n. On *the one hand, you sense- that you are in the presence of a miinjinspired, a man thilking and fe6ilm, in images, a mun whose wiork is the natural overflow "f y.nconscious depths of creativity. On the other hand, there is'the suspicion that Redgrovc is at the mercy of his own psychology. His poems stream and sing and rage and bless. I wislh that they more often stood still. and told their truth quietly, as in the beginning lines of "The Breathing-Place ":
Your picture in each fallintg
raindrop Your hair blowing as the rain
falls Your hair in the waters as they
unfold Your hair brushling me as you
read me Does not compensate. Touch me
thtere, lhe saus, At mp root, in tilat spot, mp
sadness.
I do not think, in saying this, that I am wishing Redgrove were another kind of poct. These lines are llot uncharactelistic of him. There Is tenderness in this book, as well as energy, and wvhen the two come together he writes with a sensitivity and an openness that remind me of Rilke. What he needs, perhaps, is a Faust or a Duino angel-I mean, some over-riding theme which wvill take hold of his prodigal imagination in such a way as to give it concentration. Yet this is to criticize rather sniffily *a volume of poems which is as fertile in invention, and as rich in verbal substance, as anYthing we are likely to see this year.
lain Crichton Smith is another poet possessed by the daimon. In his case. this does not mean the outpouring of poems which are repetitive in imagery, or dark anid difficult to follow, but it does mean that he tends to wvrite uncritically. His book In the Middle (Gollancz, £2.95) contains half a. dozen superb.. things, a -good de4I' . `ele that is interesting and wvhich no one but Crichton Smith could have written, and some stuff which should never have left his wastepaper basket. Crichton Smith's facility allors him to mnistake fanicies
It Changed My Life, by Betty Friedan (GOl'ancz, £5.95). No counting the number of lives changed by Betty Friedan's first book, in 1969, The Feminine Mlstique. From being an ordinary housewife and mother. (is there such a person ?) she found that hundreds of thousands of Vomen al!l over the world felt as trapped .mid dismayed as she did. Betty Friedan kept going, throigh interviews with
for the real thing-'witness two bad poems, one about a girl reading Milten at the . cash desk in the supermarket C"Pupil's Holiday job )% and .a trite pictu -postcard-.;pieco. called "In Ireland ". SWhen Crichton Smith is in the grip of his dainton, however, his language changes for the better, and his images are never predictable, and the rhythm of the lines is at one with their sense:
TIhe owvl stands on the moor with
its ringed glasses itn the red lighlt that's painted on
the grolund. The rabbit cocks its ears on an
old mound and the ihens pick their skirts up
and go hoome. Yet even after that fresh nrSs, he goes and spoils -it with lhg moo*n casting "its eerie light" in the next stanza. He is a careless writer, but then he is so prolific that he can afford to be. At his best, he is authentic and inspilred, and he writes poems possessed by an impressive self-awvareness, and by an even more impressive awvareness of the self's linitations as a source of awareness. Again: a major con_entra-ting theme would perhaps
induce in him a poetry of: greater resonance then he -is achieving at present.
John Ashberv's Self-Portrait in a Convex MNiirror (Carcanet Press, £2.25) -is the most accomplished of the volumes I have under Treviev. Ashberv, again, is aln inspired poet, and the daimon has already achlieved in his work a remarkable individuality of tone. He lets his imagination go, but he never losers control of his language. Peter Ackroyd has described Ashbery's wor-k well: "It continually presen,ts the language of feeling wivthout enacting it ". There are times when this leaves the readcr frustrated, as though the poet were fl,i;rting wvith a deliberate avoidanlce of meaniing. Bu t t;hen meaninglessness is not hard to ach:eve, and Ashbery-even at his most opaque-succeeds in wvriting lines of unusual memorability. lt is as if he says: "Wheat this means is that I make you remember it ". And the saying works. I recomnmend Ashbery's difficult and teasing and often very beautiful and funiiy p-oetry to readers who have not yet made its acquaintance. The nearest thing I know to it in Engligh-to define its peculiar flavour-is the prose of Ronald Firbank. Li.ke Firbank, too, he is a much tougher and a rather m*ore serious wvriter than you'd think at first glance.
Books in privately printed editions are generally awful, but Harry Kemp's Poe7ns in Variety (obtainable from the author at Old Hall, High Nibthwaite, near Ulverston, Cumbria, £3) is an exception. Kemp's wrork is classic and austere. He keeps his daimon on a tight rein, and lets it out for little epigrammatic trots. 'But there is a ..rea1. pressite. of
lived experience behind the lines, and some dn.teresti.ngly complicated feelings get expressed with simplicity.
Robert Nye
Simone de Beauvoir and the Pope, anger, resentment,
divorce, involvemenit in the. complicated pollitical scene of the National Organization of women which she helped .:to found, attacked by the extreme sexual politics of the lesbian element. As seen in this book of notes, reprinted pieces, diaries and reflections, she is both a revolutionary, in tha&ta major social change has taken place, anid also a wise, far sighted and, indeed, noble soul.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Gaudete, by Ted Hughes (Faber, £ 4.50)
Collected Poems 1948-1976, by Dannie Abse (Hutchinson, £4.95 and £2.50)
The Oval Portrait, by Kathleen Raine (Hamish Hamilton, £3)
45 Mercy Street, by Anne Sexton (Secker & Warburg, £3.90)
Divine Comedies, by James Merrill (Oxford, £2.95)
Ted Hughes, narrative poem Gaudete started life as a film scenario, and I think that if Hammer Films were still in the blood business they would snap it up immediately, with Christopher (Dracula) Lee an obviQus choice for the star part. It concerns the Rev Nicholas Lumb. a priest abducted by spirits inlto another world and replaced by a changeling who (as the Argument says) "interprets the role of minister in his own way ". What this means is explained on page 113-Mr Lumb has (t new religion. IHe is starting Christianity all over again, right from the start. IHe has persuaded all the women in the parish. /Only woman can belong to it. IThey are all in it and he makes love to them all, all the tine. The broken-backed rhythm of rhe lines quoted might be justified by the fact that they are supposed to he the story, told " through sobs and tremblings ", beaten out of one of the women by her husband (Evans' first blow crushes her- lip . . .). Whether the hysteria of the rest can be justified by the misadventures that befall the Rev Lumb in a slaughterhouse in the prologue I cannot say, but I fee' sure this experience (Half a ton of guts. -Balloon out and drop on to Lumb. /He fights in the roping hot mass) cannot be claimed to have helped his nature or the versification. After our "goateved vicar" has fornicated with his female parishioners, mostly outdoors, he is shot and his body is burned in the church basement. A mysterious stranger then appears on the West Coast of Ireland, whistles up an otter, and leaves a tattered notebook full of verse for three little girls to take to their priest. These verses, touching on guilt and remorse, seem to me preferable to what has preceeded them, and observably better-written. Indeed, I would suggest that only the last 24 pages of the book deserve to be considered as poetry at all. So considered, here is a note of tenderness and regret which is new in Mr Hughes' work, and not unwelcome:
Looking Tor her form I find only a fern.
Where she should be waiting. in
the flesh
Stands a scarnore with weeping
letters.
It is a relief to turn from these nightmares to the wellcrafted and decent work in
Dannie Abse's Collected Poems 1948-1976. In a prefatory note, Dr Abse tells us that his arnbition has been to write poems which appear translucent but are in fact deceptions. "I would have a reader enter them, be deceived he could see through them like sea-water, and be puzzled when he cannot quite touch bottom." That defines my own experience of this book, and the interesting thing is perhaps that where Dr Abse seems most personal and occasional, writing out of some small piece of immediate experience, making a poem that is like a story told in verse, there his work begins to be possessed of that not-quitefathomable quality wvhich other poets have more deliberately or directly sought. I am thinking of poems like Uncle Isidore. Portrait of the Artist as a Middle-aged Man, and Peachstone:
For that night Ihis wife brought
him a peacl,
his favourite fruit, whlile the sick
light glowed, and his slack, dry mouth sucked,
sucked, sucked, with dping epes closed-perhaps
for her saketill bright as blood the peachstone
showed. The heartening thing about the book is that poems as good as this grow in frequency as Dr Abse progresses. He has learned with the years where to find the extraordinarv in the everyday, and how to celebrate it without straining his throat muscles.
The Oval Portrait belongs to a different tradition, and one that still commands respect when practised by a poet as gifted as Kathleen Raine. This is poetry as high song, mystery, occult wisdom, and if the note is sometimes thin nevertheless Miss Raine's sincerity and purity of utterance are never in doubt. At the other extreme, the poems in Anne Sexton's 45 Mercy Street impress wvith their grim if playful realism. Mrs Sexton had one subjecther own death-wish. These verses, or chants, the last she composed before her suicide in 1974, are like the nursery rhymes of the child deep in all of us, that child still afraid of the dark but longing for it also.
I recommend James Merrill's Divine Comedies for its narrative poem The Book of Ephraim, the strangest and deepest thing Mr Merrill has given us. He is a poet of the kind once called couth by the New Yorker : that is, a poet on whom you can rely for order, and form, and good sense. Here he employs his reasonable skills to explore areas of shady unreason, and the result is something like Yeats' book A Vision as it would have been if written in racy workmanlike verse by a sceptical Robert Browning who only believed a half of what the spirits hrd to tell him.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry

Robert Wells, at 30, and with a single book, The Winter's Task, seenis to mle to establish himself as one of the best young poets now writing. le writes poems that are plain and unpretentious,. poems firmly in the English tradition, poems devoid of ambiguity. or dislocation of syntax. Reading him is first of all a pleasure because you find yourself in a landscape you seem to recognize. Then it is a surprise and an instruction because that landscape is not quite as it wyas in Hardy, say, or in Edward Thomas. Something is different, the mental weather has changed, some freshness in the seeing has been matched by a newvness in thC saying, with a result that we seem to be looking at familiar fields. grown suddenly foreign and full of mystery. I will not say " niagic ", since Mr Wells is not at all a sloppy poet. If anything, I should suppose that his critical -masters are Yvor Winters, wvith his insistence that a poemn should be a memorable and intelligible statement, and T. E. liulme,
aith his wish for "accurate, precise and definite description ", and a poetry that is "dry atld sophisticated ". Life and poetty have a nice way of being more various than even the most reliable theorists allowv, however, and so we have Ir Wells, Writing two sttntas in regulat mtntte on a conventional theme, "After Haymaking", and coming up with the following:
The last bale ptoced, he stretched
* out in the hay. Its wam nth and his were one.
He watched the fields beneath the
* oweakening daW And felt his skin still burniifg
with the sun. WVhen it was dusk, he moved.
t between his skin And clothes the sweat rdn cold.
He trembled as he felt the air
begin To touch add touch for wvhat it
could not hold. No unexpected happening, no flashy images,. not a single departure from the word'order of common speech, yet in the peculiar. sensuousnesss of the vhole, enibodied in that repeated touch, the poem comies alive and is like no one else's poem. A poet who can use the word arnd to such effect that you can almost feel it (as Mr Wells does here, in his last line) is someone to be reckoned with. The book contains a dozen things as good, includitig the
impressive title poem. Here is an authentic new voice.
It must have been harder to distinguish the authenticity in the first six books by Ezra Pound, published between 1908 and 1912, because they contain so many voices, or echoes of
other people's voices. Swin-- burne, Do4wson, Browning, Whitman, not to speak of Villon and Pound's beloved ProvenBal and Italian troubadours, all seem to put in their strophes. When he came to make his own definitive selection for the " Personae " volume of 1926, Pound rejected 99 of these early poems, and when his daughter eventually persuaded him to republish some of them in 1965 he introduced that book as "a collection of stale creampuffs ". What is the point, then, of Collected Early Poems of Ezra Pound ? Well, in the first place it is a marvrellous job of editing, putting together not just the contents of all those early books but a great number of previously uncollecttd ponems from periodicals, and assembling them beautifully in a volume which is a bibliophile's delight, containing reproductions of ill the original titlepages ind copious and careful notes on every textual variation. It the second place, it is ani eloquent testament to Pound's innocence and to his sense of vocation-there ig somtething noble about these verses, even where they are most brash and grate On the nerves wvith their Wardout Stteet misconceptions of the English language- But, above all, in the thitd and most important place, this book sets "Hugh Selwyn Mauberley " and
The Cantos" in context, shotwing what Pound had to overcome, not just in the way of Victorian influences hbLt in his own termperatlent. Here is a modetn poet strutggling to be born.
Samuel Beckett's Collected Poems itt Englislh and French is the work of an unmistakable modern who wvas never qUite born as a poet until he found himself in prose. Stuch a piece as "tWhoroscope" (winner of the Nancy Cutard £10 Competition for the best poem on the subject of Time In the Sumnimer of 19301) is now unreadable exceitt as a joke. tut it is a brilliant and spiky and serious joke, full of the touches later developed into a whole game of verbal tennis in the novels. Apart from such foreshadowings, toecketts finest verses are in French, amoong them the outstanding
je voudrais que mon anour meure qtt'il p?euve Sur Ie cimetidee et les ruelles ouz je vais
pleuruht cClle qui crta m'ainzer
Foul lines as bitter and beautiful as anything he has written.
finally, two anthologies. The Oxford Book of Welsh Verse in Etzglish, chosen by Gwyn Jones, ranges from the bardic Aneirin and Taliesin to the hardly less bardic Dylan Thomas, but finds toomw for the quieter mherits of Dafydd ap Gwilym and Edward Thornas as well, Altogether, there are 238 poemes, more than half of them translated from the Welsh language, The Pengui Book of American Verse, editedt by Geoffrey Moore, statt witll Anne Bradstreet and euds with a number of versifiers Who ate miserly with punctuation and very free with anti-White tacial sentiments. Its most serious emhission is Laura Riding: arguably the most gifted and inportant American poet of the twentieth century, and completely ignored bere. Miss Riding's dislike of 'antholo, gies is well'known, but Mr Moore gives no evidence of having even asked her.. At only £1.75 for 656 paRgs the book repreaenxs value of a kind.
Robert Nye

Swift said England was never able to boast more than three poets at a time-Our chilling climate hardly bears A sprig of bays in fifty years. That is not an opinion which will do for a regular reviewer of new verse but I find myself agreeing with it in an absolute sense rather more than a reviewer should. There are never as many poets as there seem to be. For that' reason I have used this column in the past with some sceptiiism, trying to describe what our contemporaries are doing, and making a guess as' to its worth, but not crowvding each paragraph with poeticules and Poetasters. I don't intend to change the general pattern now, but this paMticular pre-Christmias round-up will include more names and more books than usual,'in an attempt to provide something of a list from which anyone can take an item or tVo wvith confidence that they will make acceptable gifts.
T-he fi*st bookt needs' no apology-except from me, for not drawing attention to it sooner. It is Padraic /Vallon's Poems (Doiman 'Press, f3).' Fallon was an unfashionable and authentic poet, who died two years ago, having waited a lifetime to publish this-hiis first ind final collection. Attempts have been made to fix him in a rural tradition, but while the imagery of these poems is often drawn from the presences of the Irish country-. side, the mind at large within them is modern and unpredictable, and their rhythms have an authority which seems to me to'come from a congruent attention to form and to the truthfulness of the thing said:
No soeet mouth but cormces to tiis, God, Attis too for all that Great
Goddess And heavenly stuff:
'Much is-man and not enough.
'He is talking about death. A
sense of ithe muchness of man being not enough, and persistent energy in tt-ying to sav what else there might be, with outLsacrificing poetry for certainty, makes this moTe than just a collectioh of fine indi-i dual 'poems. Fallodn is mythhaunted and truth-possessed, a eomplete poet and I won't be 'surprised if 1further- reading confirms ny impressionr that he was the best Irish poet since -Yeats. " '
No one yet has: had a chance to neglect 'or ignore the work in Teen English Poets (Carcanet Press, £2), for this anthology introduces people not previously published except in periodicals. The poets: are Robert Wells, Neil 'Powell, .Gareth: Reeves, Alistair Elliot, Grevel Lindop, Michael Vince; Xeith Chandler, Clive Wilmer, William Bedford, and Charles Boyle. What they ,have in common is a' lack of glamour, 'ind man interest in getting the poem "jright" however awkward the results -may sound. In the more successful poems, of.course, the craft and the truth are at one, and Robert Wells strikes mesas already outstanding it this stage, since none
of his 12 podms in this book is much below the level-Dof-that *-marriage.. Carcanet plan to publish a full-length. book by him, and by. several of the others. Meanwhile, this book allows a little hope for the future.
David Wright's To the Gods the Shades (Carcanet, £3.90) consists of new and collected poems by' a writer whose, wsork *encoqipasses an unusual variety of moods and themes. That . makes. Wright sound .facile,
however, . Which he is notalthough I must admit that his overtly romantic and rhetorical pieces leave me cold, and the YWright- I respect is the one without the singing robes. At his best he constructs a hard and clear and memorable verse, with an implication of music in the back of its mind.
Kevin .Crossley.Holland finds poems in indefinite occasions, moments of doubt and hesitation, and does not let himself *go, emotionally or intellectually, although there is both intelligence and a considerable lyrical sensitivity in the way his poems. are made. The ti^le'piece of The
Dream House (Andra Deutsch,. £L.95) is interesting-a sort of dream poem, using halfrhymes and .a refrain of ".John, John, John" which sounds as though it comes out of a nursery rhyme; only it is barer and. colder than any -nursery rhyme, for this poem is about a wake. Partly about a wakes I should say, for I think. this . "dream-house" is the place, where Crossley-Holland's talent resides, and he should visit it more often. With Patricia Beer he - has- also recently edited the second Arts Council anthology New Poetry 2 (Arts Council, £3.80 and £E2).
Waking the Dead - (Gollancz, £2.S5) -shows Alasdair Maclean still- deepening and developing the poetic concernsv which made Fromt the .Vilderness (1973) such a heartening first book: These are poems about - deathhe poet's -mother died while his first . collection was at the printers-but he protests.again that they are " also fictions "! What he means is .that he is not- in the True Confessions business, and a good thing too. This is a fine book, and in one poem, " Explaining Death ;to a Child ", Maclean transcends anythlng he has achieved so far, and has -witten something which deserves to pass.straight into the anthologies.. -
Just room left to recommend Peter Bland's Mr Maui (London Magazine Editions, £2.75), lwich contains the best of his New Zealand poems, as well as a selection of work written since his return to England; Stanley Cook's admirably plain statements in Alphabet (Harry . Chambers/Peterloo Poets,. 90p)
and Form Photograph (75p)-: ind Staff Photograph *(75p), probably the. best poems ever written about the -experience. of being a schoolteacher; Gavin Ewart's often hilirious No Fool Like an Old :Fool .(Gollarict t-2.95) -; and the -new edition of . Arthur - Wiaty's . Japaese;

Author: Lewis, Jeremy
Title: Seeing the light
Full_text:
Seeing the light
I The Little Maeazines
A Sttdy of Six Editors
Bv Ian Hamilton
(Weidenfeld & Nicolsot, £4.95) "A Milton might be living in Chicago today and be unable to find an outlet for his verse ", wrote an: indignanit Harriet Monroe 'in 1912;' and shortly afteri4ards she took steps to remedy the situation by found.. ing Poetry, one of' the subjects of this witty/ extremelyv readable but all-too-brief survey of "the milost exemplary and memorable" of this century's little magazines. Like her fellow-Chicagoan Margaret Anderson, who founded The Little Review two years later, Harriet Monroe was one of those - admirably missionary individuals without whom feiv little inagazines would stagger off the ground, .and but for wvhom literature itself would be very much the poorer; and one of those editors who may lack original talent themselves (" In 'lazy laughing Pinama-/O flutter of ribbon betwixt the seas ") but are driven by a combination of literary idealism and indignation over the exdlusiveness or timidity of established publishers 'and periodicals. As' a glance at the acknowledgements page of almost any. collection of poems or short stories will confirm, little magazines are invaluable for established writers as well as "for the untried and the experimental. The best of them are essdntially- one''man bands, reflecting the taste and the. stayihg poxiWer of the found:ing editor, 'and Ian Hamilton' reckons that even these begin to flounder or fade after a
decade or so. Yet despite modest life expectancies, equally modest circulations (T. S. Eliot's The Criterio71 averaged 400 copies an issue) and shoe-string finances, the little magazines can justifiably pride themselves on backing unknown horses and ventilating unfashionable points of view, and it is there that their enormous value lies.
As the founding editor of The New Review-and, unlike Miss Motroe, an extremely impressive poet in his own right-lan Hamilton is in the perfect posiw tion to introduce us to this colourful, feud-ridden vanguard of the literary life. His six essays on his chosen magazines -The Little Review, Poetry,4 The Criterion, Partisan Review, Geoffrey Grigson's New Verse and Cyril Connolly's Horizonare as entertaining and perceptive as might be expected. It is something of a revelation to realize what a blunt instrument the redoubtable Geoffrey Grigson wielded in New Verse, the magazine which did so much to establish Auden's reputationi (C. Day Lewis was, anathematized at one stage as "grease in the sink-pipe of letters"); and he reminds us once again of, the dubious resonances of T. S. Eliot's advocacy. of an " aristocracy of culture-". Given the rather random, discontinuous nature of the book .as a whole, one cannot help wishing that he had thrpwn his net a good deal wider, and put his editors and their magazines in a broader perspective: but-even *the most indomitable researcher might well 'decide to call it a .day ,when faced with yet a,nothir mountain of ye]lowing back-numbers (Scrutiny? Pcn.otiin New Writing? The London Merc'urp, even ?).
* /
Despite its tantalizing brevity, The Little Magazines is replete with sardonic observations and pleasing anecdotes, the best of which concern the two ladies from Chicago-possibly because they shared an amiable weakness for the banal or the frauduleiit, particularly after they had shaken off the cdrrective influence of Ezra Pound. Ever active on behalf of those he admired, Pound persuaded a slightly bemused Margaret Anderson-whose original idol was John Galsworthy-to publish Eliot, Yeats and several episodes from Ulysses (as a result of which The Little Review was several times burned by the authorities, and Miss Anderson and her' coeditor put on trial) ; after his resignation as foreign editor, The Little Review discerned genius in the unpiromising form of Baroness' Else von Freytag Loringhoven, a frenziedly inarticulate poetess with a yellowed face, blackened lips, a cancelled postage . stamp attached to her cheek and a coal-scuttle lashed on her head like a helmet. And Pound finally broke with Harriet Monroe after her growing enthusiasm for a. wholesome, allAmerican type of poetry had led her to extol such oddities as Lew Sarett, a specialist in Red Indian rhythms ("Ho 1/ Hi ! Plenty-big talk !/Ho.! Ho! Ho ! "). But for all their occasional absurdities, niagazines like these performed-and continue to perform-an invaluable function by making it possible' for future Miltons to see. the. light; .and that's what the little magaiines' are ultimately all about.
Jeremy Lewis

Sonetto"- a -ittle tune, a -sing.song sound, -a.sigh,

As far as the specifically English tradition is concerned, the position is even* more striking. One can say quite simply that-with one or two notable, and intriguing, exceptions-the entire history of English poetry from Wyatt to Auden, can be told through its sonnets. They lie there like a trail of small, glistening stepping-stones, across the whole great flood. It is for this reason that The Faber Book of Sonnets will, in my view, become a classic among anthologies,.
Once the scale of the idea is grasped, it is an obvious one-beautifully so. The selectidn by Robert Nye is almost- equally obvious and excellent; and the result is magic. Looking o'ver the . collection, one has the impression. of four great and distinctive epochs: ' the Elizabethan.Jacobean, the Romantic; the Pre-Raphaelite, and the Modernist-and this itself provides an interest-' ing critical viewspoint.. -'
Robert Nye's choice -in the tirst two "epochs!" seem,s to me impeccable. The third epoch is perhaps a fraction less sure. His main voices are Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Christina and Dante Gabriel Rossetti, together with Hopkins and Hardy. But one feels a loss of centrality, a slight willfullness of choice, Hartley Coleridge (1796-1849). .and the mad Harvard mystic Jones Very (1813-1880) are both given eight sonnets (the same as Wyatt); while Meredith's powerful and tormerfted poems from "Modern Love" (1862) find no place, and Browning and Tennyson are only granted two appearances each. this a little fustv.
But it does not rcally matter. Mr Nye's handling of the fourth epoch makes up fnr everything. This is where the " classic" quality of the anthology might seriously have faltered. but his gaelic spy-point from thie spires of the National Library at Edinburgh, serves him in good stead, and his choice is calm, penetrating, and basically just. Representative single sonnets are used to mark out the modern course with. out smartness or embarrassment-Rupert Brooke, Owen, 'Graves, MacDiarmid, Dylan Thomas, Roy Campbell, ee cummings, Lowell. Berrymnan, Larkin and so on. But just enough emphasis is given to the ivonderful sonnets of Pound (perversely and beautifully returning to GSuido Cavalcanti), Robert Frost, W.H. Auden and Patrick Kavanagh (again brave, but probably right) to suggest the strong and distinctive development of the "Modernist" fornL If there is a tendency towards Celts and Gaels and New Englarnd men, it does nothing to lessen the quality of the poetry-on the contrary; and this too is part of the story. Altogether it is an outstanding bit of editing and a very remarkable book A pity perhaps that Robert .Nve did not grant himself one sonnet, by way of envoi for the long marvellous journey ahead.
Richard Holmes

Author: Ratcliffe, Michael
Title: Exorcizing the witch of Amherst
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS
Exorcizing the witch of Amherst
The Life of Emily Dickinson
The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson
By Richard B. Sewall
(Faber, two volumes, £17.50)
Edited by Thomson H. Johnson (Faber, £3.95)
Emily Elizabeth Dickinson (1830-1886) chose to stay at home in an ambitious and Protean age, but from behind the half-open upstairs door in Amherst, Massachusetts, she too aspired to glory:
To pile like thunder to its close Then crumble grand awan
WhiZe Everything created hid This would be Poetry-
Or Love-the two coeval comeWe both and neither prove-
Experience either and consumeFor None see God and live-
'oetry and Love; GSod and fire and death: throughout her eatraordinarily unsung career -only seven of her 1,775 poems were published in her lifetime-she alchemised the essence of experience in so many lines as terse as these that we think we have her measure. So it takes a brave man at the start of a biography of 800 pages, to admit not only that his book is undefinitive, but that the whole truth about Emily Dickdnson will never be known: "She seemns almost wilfully to have seen to that", he reminds us again, on page 668:
Tlhe family, the early friends and the later, the mentors and the masters. the lovers or wvould-be lovers or fantasy lovers-each yietds its modicum of meaning. I2n our present state of knowledge, however, no more than that can be claimed for an?
of them. There is a feeling of incompleteness, of areas still to be explored, of mysteries that still beckon. The aim must be to shore up what truth we have as firmly as possible in the never-ending dialectics of readings and counter-readings. . .
I quote this passage at length because it exemplifies Richard B. Sewall's sensitivity and fair-mindedness, while summarising the range and resonance of his book. The Lile of Emily Dickinson is magnificent, the best biography I have read in the past 12 months, and the best literary biography since Richard Holmes's Shelle,y: the Pursuit two years ago: like Holmes, Sewall makes sure that the poems themselves are never fae from the heart of the narrative argunment.
Although Emily Dickinson covered her lifetracks with a coquettish thoroughness at times, the poems themselves thrust ever deeper into our 20th century earth and there are few writers in whom life and art breathed so nearly as one. By using a great scholar's gifts of patience, synthesis anid understanding to illuminate her life, Professor Sewall has amplified her literary achievement.
He is calm, but committed, believing that over the next decade, Dickinson will joiii Whitman as America's " seminal poet ", and that the implications of her life and work are inexhaustible. Time will take care of the oracle, but the inexhaustibility both Sewall's Life and the Complete Poems prove beyond doubt. Hardly a page of the Poems can be opened without the disturbance of riddle, ellipsis and paradox or the shock of plain words-chain, plank, red, song, stars, East, fly and bee-working as never before. And the letters, first collected three years after the Poems, in 1958, and quoted liberally through the Life, are scarcely less remarkable, in many cases an uninterrupted continuation of the poems.
IVe were waked bu tize ticking of the bells-the bells tick in Anzherst for a fire, to tell the firemen I sprang to thze window, and each side of the curtain saw that awful sun. The moon was shining hizgh at the time, and the birds singing like trutmpets.
Vinnie came soft as a moccasin, " Don't be afraid, Emily, it is only the fouzrth of July " (1879)
Onlv the wind saved the house. Edward Dickinson, Congregationalist and College pillar of Amherst, last of the' Connecticut Valley
"River Gods", had died of exhaustion in 1874 -Emily was devastated-and his widow was bedridden by the time of the fire. Vinnie was the younger sister, giddy once, but later the ferocious protector of Emily's total withdrawal from society and of her poems after death. Vinnie was heroic, yet it was Austin, their brilliant brother, who shared Emily's imagination most closely and with Emily's warm encouragement-she was deeply attached to both -Austin had married the ambitious Susan Gilbert in 1856. The Dickinsons lived at The Homestead; Austin and Sue settled next door, at The Evergreens, and the marriage proved bloody and bitter. When Mabel Loomis Todd arrived in Amherst with her astronomer husband in 1881, she and Austin fell passionately in love (some heartrending unpublished letters here) and " The War Between the Houses "5
smouldeiing for years, blazed into the open:
How red the fire rocks below...."
These are tche people and this is the story that Sewall tells with such subtlety in Volume One. It reads like a terrible new tale of frustration from the worlds of Chekhov and Edith Wharton; it is violent with the slumbering terrors of O'Neill. And of Emily Dickinson, for Sewall succeeds marvellously in reflecting these emotional tragedies in the mirror of Emily's intelligence and making clear once and for all that here in Amherst, in The Homestead and The Evergreens, was real world enough for the poems:
She dealt her pretty words like BladesHow glittering they shone-
And every One unbared a NerveOr wanto ned witl a Bone-
So much for Sue. Emily missed nothing.
" iMy friends are my estate ", the Queen Recluse once declared, and Volume Two, foliowing a loosely chronological pattern, shows Emily reflected in the friends and relatives with whom she corresponded, mixing poems, jokes and letters, throughout her life: first loves, dear cousins, and huge influences like judge Lord, the great preacher Charles Wadsworth and Samuel Bowiles, editor of the Sprinzgfield Republican, with whom she fell in love. The convivial Bowles was totally unsuited to her-older, manied, worldly, insensitive to her revolutionary language-but she worshipped him, and he is the most likely intended recipient of the desperate letters addressed "Master" and mercifully never sent, during a long period of breakdown around 1860.
Popular legend turned Emily Dickinson into a white witch and pert versifier, ethereally letting dowvn buns from her bedroom window to the small children of Amherst. Professor Sewall has exorcized the witch and the versifier and reconstructed an amazing sensibility which took its incandescence not just from the Bible, Shakespeare and the seventeenth century Metaphysical poets but from the Pturitan tradition of self-reliance in the hills around her and, most of all, from the hard and bitterly humorous world at the bottom of the stairs and
