Poetry
George Barker reminds me now of the priest who, asked what he did in the French Revolution, replied " I survived ". Barker goes on surviving. His kind of ruffian romanticism, briefly in favour in the 40s, has hardly been popular since. His new book Dialogues etc (Faber paperback, £1.95) has been made the Spring choice of the Poetry Book Society, which is sensible, if surprising. Sensible because Barker, at 63, continues to write lines and sometimes whole poems that impress themselves upon the memory by reason of that quality of in2evitability which his best work has always possessed. Surprising because Barker is still the Wild Man among contemporary English poets, the word-besotted punster, the perpetrator of appalling rhymes. Who else would dare link Apocalypse wvith umpteen tits in the same stanza? It is as though Byron had been set the purgatorial task of rewriting the poems and prophecies of William Blake.
The eight "dialogues" of Goag and Magog which run through the present book seem to me less interesting than the "1 etc" which surrounds them. In the dialogues there is an element of the factitious. Thev are literary ballads and jigs, and their tum-ti-tum rhythms provide the poet with an excuse for saying nothing much in a rather flashy wav:
All thut you have inside your hairy chest," he said.
is that old cuckoo clock and it ticktocks until vou're dead."
Barker has written well in ballad form, but nowadavs he does better without it. In among the "etc" are sardonic statements about the distance between love and its physical and verbal expression, some fine celebrations of Italy (where the poet recently lived for seven years), and a handful of those odd, nagging, largely imageless poems which represent Barker at his most inspired. It is as though this poet had a second voice. When the voice takes over, the bdd puns and the strutting rhythms fall awvav and he wvrites with extraordinary quietness:
How can I see them ? Part of
them is me.
Thep will not anstwer when I ask
their nanes.
Sometimes I do not knowv if they
are even here
Wlhen I perceive them. I am1 their
k;nowvledge of
Their own identity, because the
purpose
Of mtn half existence is to elicit
theirs.
They beg for love. I also beg.
For themt.
That is a wvhole poemr, and the one with which the present volume concludes. Who are "they"? The Muses, perhaps; the mysteries; unwritten poems, or inspil-ers of poems on a level wvith Rilke's angels. It is a measure of George Barker's success as a poet that it ranges from such intimations of the numinous to the bawdy bril-
liance of The True Conjession (1950). He has never surpassed the last named, in its particular line, and it may be the one vork by wihich he will be kno.wna by posterity. That is posterity s problem.
Pat-ic Dickinson's The Bearing Beast (Chatto & Windus paperback, £2.25) shcwvs that he is nowv at t,;e height of his powers, matter of an epigrammatic wvit wvhich previous volumes had adumbrated but never quite accomplished. He is a cool poet, a gentle poet, the sort that james Reeves had in mind *lhetn he celebrated one whose wvork had "no Celtic bombast ". buit wvas inspired bv an `u tn presunming Saxon grace". Tha-t Saxo;i grace brealks its owin bounds inl the final poem of the book. "A Memorv of Dylan Thom;s ' ,where Dickinson emplo-s hexameters wvithout sounding like Clough, and wvhere he comes to terms with his owxn opposite, so to speak, in the person of the poet Reeves may have had in mind. "Stillness" is more typical of Dickinson's mood and manner:
The stillness, the still-blue daes
when Sun draws seed from the mnindThe steel-blue brigh7t nights uoi
can fecl The 12eat of the szars
On your touching fingertips
it begins, going on mvsteriouslv to speak of how in that stillness come the moments when wve "feel the love/Of the lifesavers, the men and wvomen! Who know and te7/Of the deadly powers ". Dickinson inevei- presumes to speak in the voice of those powers, and it is this restraint, this awvareness of his owvn limitations. wvhich gives his verse authoritv.
Elizabeth Darvush, once championed by Yvor Winters, wYho called lier " one of the few d-stinguished po^ts of our century ", comes wvith a new champion, Donald Davie, introducing her Collected Poems (Carcanet New Press, £3.25). Mrs Daryush, born in 1887, is the daughter of Robert Bridges. I suspect that it is this factstupid as you may find the outcome-wshich has consistently put people off her -work. Bridges is an undervalued and desperately unfashionable poet. At her best, as in the sonnet in svllabic measure, entitled "Still-Life ", lhich formed the basis of Winters's case 'or her. Mrs Daryush is quite unlike her father, or anv other EngliJh poet, but admirablv true to herself and the lang-uage:
Through the open French
wtindow, the wvarm? s.tnl lights up the polished brcakfr;st-
table, laid round a bowl of crimson roses.
fcr onea service of lW'orcestcr porcelain,
arra'ed. near it a melon, peaches. figs.
small hot rolls in a napkin, fairy r ack of
mnast. buttter in ice, high silver ccffcc
and, heapedl on a sa?ver, thie
morning's post. That is surely as fine a beginning as anv sonnet makes, in English, in this century? And the sestet does not disappoint. Archaisms consciously deployed make some of these poems rather heavy going, if you try to say theni aloud, but the finest woork is as scrupulous and unaffected as the lines I have auoted.
Robert Nye

Author: Blyth, Alan
Title: Exhilarating expression of poetry
Full_text:
Exhilarating expression of poetry
BBC Singers/Poole
St John's
Smith Square
Alan Blyth
One of the choral masterpieces of the early part of the eighteenth century, Domenico Scarlatti's Stabat Mater, is still underrated and heard too infrequently. As a piece of sustained writing that joins the sound world of his polyphonic predecessors with that of a new harmonic originality, it is a work which, apa.rt from its technicaI skill, overflows with imagination and poetry in its varied yet unified setting of a familiar text. Distant keys are explored, but always in the service of expression, not effect. The
result is at once poignant and exhilarating.
The BBC Singers, using Jurgens's authoritative edition, did the work justice, relishing the chances for choral virtuosity and taking full notice of the many eloquent moments, such as the searching "Quae morebat " and the extraordinary beauty of "Sancta mater ". Where any fault crept in, it was usually of intonation, almost forgiveable in a difficult, tenpart setting. John Poole, the choir's conductor, was concerned to emphasize the contrasts of mood and style, but could sometimes have asked for quieter singing.
Scarlatti senior, Alessandro, was also admirably represented by his serene, rather archaic setting of 0 Magnum Mysterum,
as far removed as possible in the context of its time from his slightly more familiar operas. His Tu es Petrus, also given, comes nearer to the secular world. Both pieces were fervently sung.
So was one of Dallapiccola's last works, Teinpus Destruendi, Tempus Aedificante, a setting of two medieval Latin poems. Like Domenico Scarlatti, Dallapiccola knew how to use the vocal techniques of his time with discernment and confidence. The first piece was more direct, the second more mannered. Both were bold and exclamatory, also keenly fitted to their words. After that, Bach's motet, Lobet den Herrn, seemed almost like light relief for the choir, and they sang it, as befits the music, with joy.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Ever since those notorious Clark Lectures, 20 years ago, when Robert Graves laid into his contemporaries right and left, reserving a particular knockout for Ezra Pound, there has been something of a ten. dency for critics to set these two poets up as opposites. If you are a Gravesian, then you mutter that crack about Pound's Chinese ideograms being copied from the nearest tea chest for all you know. If you are a Poundling, you remind people that Graves's contribution to English letters at the time of Pound's trial was to urge publicly that Ezra should be hung. Yet critics who know better-I am thinking especially of G. S. Fraser-have found the merits of these two poets not mutually exclusive. And people wvho have known both of them-see, for instance, Ronald Duncan's volumes of autobiographyhave even put it on record that they were not unalike in personality.
The ideal Christmas present for your poetical nephew, then, to help these civil wars to cease in his troubled mind, would be Ezra Pound's Selected Poems 1908-1959 (Faber, £3.50 and £1.30) and Robert Graves's Collected Poems 1975 (Cassell, £8.50). Each book is the working record of a lifetime's devotion to poetry. Curiously, it seems to me that both men hit their peak round- about the same moment-Graves with the heart-broken lyrics of lost love which he wrote just prior to The White Goddess (1948), and Pound with that superb eighty-first canto out of the Pisan prison-cage:
Pull down thy vanity, it Is not man Made courage, or made order, or
made grace. Pull down thy vanity, 1 say pull
down Learn of the green world what
can be thy place . . . That sounds a note possibly unique in twentieth century poetry in English. It was a brief magnificence, but the diligent searcher in Pound will find others. I recommend his book in particular for anyone seriously interested in learning the craft of verse. Graves has more obvious technique, but it is used to distance his thoughts and feelings, make them somehow smaller, neater, and more bearable. In Pound you catch a man's mind moving, and the poetry is the movement. Of course, that could be awful, and sometimes it is. The worst Pound is much worse than the worst Graves.
Sydney Goodsir Smith's Collected Poems 1941-1975 (John Calder, £7.50) gathers together the life-work of a Scottish poet who died earlier this year at the age of 59. He
deserves to be better known. Smith's greatest achievement is without doubt "Under the Eildon Tree ", a series of elegies in which personal and subjective elements are subdued to the myth, of Thomas the Rhymer and his seven-year sojourn in the lands of the Queen of Elphame, and in which the mood shifts with remarkable and successful abruptness from the romantic to the self-satirical. MacDiarmid apart, I rate him the finest Scots-writing poet of the century. This book .shows, amongst other things how well he had heeded MacDiarmid's slogan, " Not BurnsDunbar !
Alan Brownjohn's A Song of Good Life (Secker & Warburg, £2.90) deliberately does without fireworks. No verbal pyrotechnics here, but good solid craftsmanship, an honest look at the complexity of human relationships. and one or two poems that nag at the memory-less .because of good lines that
stand out, as on account of the absence of lines that stand out, all being delivered to the reader in the same level tone of uncompromising seriousness. I'm not so very keen on the play, " A Love Song ", which pads out the middle, and occasionally a monotony of scene or ti r e obtrudes-it is usually late afternoon in Mr Brownjohn's world, or late September, or last thing at night, and he'll be sounding tired after a hard day's work-but there is at least one poem here, "The Ship of Death ", which is better than anything he has ever published before, and which seems to suggest a level of excellence in him still to be fully explored. Mr Brownjohn is genuinely seeking to write the kind of verse which will cast light on soriething dark in human nature. The attempt is honourable.
So are the attempts made in two slim volumes by a newcomer, Simon Curtis. These are Something for Nothing, a flimsy yellow-covered pamphlet, the first publication of an imprint from 17 Mauldeth Road, Manchester- 20, and distributed without a price, and a more accessible book, On the Abthorpe Road and other Poems (Davis-Poynter, £2.50). Mr Curtis writes a poetry which is just the other side of common speech. But this is common speech when it is sensitive and truthful:
A walk through the neighbouring
churchyard shows It is a lesson they well
demonstrate. Those cold foreigners, in their
mossy rows. One it is something to have got
quite straight.
The awkwardness of that final line is deliberate. It is a way of saying it which, I think, Edward Thomas would not have despised. Mr Curtis is a poet to keep an eve on.
Robert Nye

The editor of. this niagazine, Harry Ghambers, has high standards, 'and printed work of outstanding qtiality, while struggling all the while on an annual grant quite incommensurate with what> was required. In the past, Chanmbers was responsible for publishing in pamphlet jform the work of Stanley Cook. Cook has good poems in the final Phoenix, which also contains work by Kenneth Allott, Alan Brownjohn, Gavin Ewart, Seamus Heaney, Norman Nicholson. Pcicr Scuphiam and several others, and an interesting set of fac4imile worksheets . of -poems bv Fleur' Adcock. Tony Harrison. Michael Jlongley, Edwin Morgan, William StMfford, Andrew Waterman and some of the poets alreadv mentioned as contributors. It seems -to put it rmildly- great shame that a magazine as whollv dedicated to new poetrv as this ont should go to the wall while flashier productions flourish on big Arts Council grants.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
A Stevie Smith pIoem is immediately recognizable. Tottering on the edge of doggerel, her art was a habit of never quite falling over. Or if she did fall, she would make it look like a dive. At her best she was very simnple and very good: O lovers true
A4nd othcrs too
Wlhose lbest is on?1, better TJn:e mv advice
Slhun compromise
Forget him and forget her
She differed most from her contemporaries in her adherence to a belief in inspiration. " All the poet has to do is to listen ': she said once. "The poet is not an important fellow. There will always be another poet." But not another with quite her ear for the oddnesses of speech, the way slang can sing, or tired words from the hymnal stand up and dance. The language will miss her. The Collected Poems of Stevie Smzitl (Allen Lane, Â£8.50) puts together the contents of all her published books, including the doodles with which she liked to deco.
rate them. I could have donei without these drawings-they I misrepresent her seriousness.
There was a fierce mind under that floral hat.
Alan Ross's Open Sea (London Magazine Editions, Â£2.25 or Â£1.25) brings together his war poems, and confirms an impression that they comprise his best work. He is essentially an observer, and his experiences in destroyers on the Arctic convoy route and then in Germany in the immediate postwar period gave him plenty to observe:
Something (but what ?) could be
made of tlhis.
Two U-boat officers turning to
piss
In swastika shapes against a wall.
His verse is interesting when it does not seek to " make " anything of events, but only to report them-which he can do with honesty and an unforced sensuality.
Finally, brief recommendations for three books. Some Sweet Day (Oxford, Â£195) is a sequence of poems by a young poet, Hugo Williams, with a lyrical gift reminiscent of Hart Crane's. There is unusual intensity at work here-Williams makes his meanings clear, when his feelings are not. Sons of My Skin is Peter Redgrove's selected poems 1954-1974 (Routledge & Kegan Paul, Â£3.95 and Â£1.75), a good introduction to
a prodigal talent, well assembled and introduced by Marie Peel, although her pre. fatory essay misses the humour that transfigures Redgrove's surrealism. The Kensintgton Mass (Agenda Editions, 5 Cranbourne Court, Albert Bridge Road, London SWll 4PE, Â£1.50j is the unfinished draft of a poem on which David Jones was working at the time of his death. It is a fragment, but in its liturgical preoccupations a crucial one, and besides Jone. is a figure of sufficient import. ance to make even his uncown. pieted fvorks of interest.
Robert Nve

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
The hero of John Wain's poem Feng (Macmillan, E2.25) is the anti-hero of the original Hamlet story. Feng is the usurping.king, 11 the sick and hallucinated petson who seizes power and then has to live with it ". Mr Wain has gone back behind Shakespeare to Saxo Grammaticus for his myth. Feng is Horwvendil's brother, Amleth's uncle. He murders Horwendil in jealousy, marries his queen Gerutha, and ascends the throne. The end is predictable: Death,
costutmted as Amleth, is coming. I
hear his tread. A few more steps, he will come
thzrough the door eyes steady with hate, sword lifted
for my throat. But in that moment, poised and
framed for killing, he will pause an instant: Surprise
will flash into hlis eyes, and something behind
it: fear. IThe quotation shows the strength and the weakness of Feng. It has a moral dignity and a seriousness fitting in someone who has just published a biography of Samuel Johnson. At the same time, its diction betrays it as uninspired, and its construction, while honest, is awkward-the clumsy repetition of the word "will" only underlines the fact that what is being said is banal.
For a longish poem, this one tries to get bv on a minimum of ideas. Accept the limited nature of the attempt and the achievement, and there is pleasure to be had from Mr Wain's concentration upon a handful of images-the tower, stones in a circle, deer fighting
on snow-and his teasing out of meaning from them. In case we miss the modern application he reminds us: "Since I have lived through an age in which raving madmen have had control of great and powerful nations, the theme naturally seems to me an important one."
The theme of lain Crichton Smith's The Notebooks of IRobinson Crusoe (Gollancz, Â£2.60) is, I suppose, isolation. There are a number of verses about lonelincss in it-and as usual with this poet a scattering of good poems that certainly look lonely in the company they have to keep. Mr Crichton Smith has always been a hit-or-miss artist, and there are too many misses here - including the title sequence-for the book to be recommendable to someone who does not already know his power. What I admire about this poet in his ability to let go, while remaining in control of his craft. He is best when he stops talking to himself, or the sea, or Charlie Chaplin (he has already said enough on these subjects) and addresses his wit to some less elevated object.
Humour is not-so prevalent in modern verse that I care to let it pass without cheer. Ronald Bottrall's Poems 1955-1973 (Anvil Press, Â£2.95 and Â£1.50) is another book in which the most successful poems are relaxed and amusing, though highly intelligent. Mr Bottrall has other manners, and in par. ticular he can make clipped lyrics on the slightest of excuses in the way of subjects with perhaps more skill than any English metrist since Bridges; but it is the ramblings, confident, autobiograplhical "Talking to the Ceiling " which is the triumph here:
Mp father used to stay up late at
night Ostensibly to read theology.
Instead he roamed about the house Sampling a few novels or detective
fiction, Reading for some strange reason The last chapter first.
His night cap was a nip
Of any medicine thtat lay alound.
The direct examination of per. sonal experience also has its rewards in Growing Points (Carcanet Press, Â£2.75 and Â£1.40) which is Elizabeth Jennings' finest book of poems for many years. There is a richer variety of subject-matter and a more significant resourcefulness of rhythm to these poems than one had grown used to in Miss Jennings' work since her Collected Poemns of 1967. That last volume, indeed, is now made to look premature. No future " Collected " is going to do.without the superb "Rembrandt's Late Self-Portraits ", included here, or any of the interesting series of sonnets, from which I quote the end of " In a Garden ":
I need not have stood lonig
Mocked by the smell of a mown
lawn, and yet
I did. Sickness for Eden was so
strong.
Nostalgia for the infinite is again drawing out the best from Miss Jennings' considerable gifts. No one seriously interested in poetry should miss this book. Two others, also by female poets, which fall into the same category: Ruth Pitter's End of Drought (Barrie & Jenkins, Â£2), since it contains such truthful lines as It was all so desolating, Tragic yet loving: grievous and quite all right; and Molly Holden's The Country Over (Chatto & Windus, Â£1.50) for its poem in which a photograph of Thomas Hardy is compared with a young fox-He was not being sZy, only careful. Miss Holden is in direct line of descent from just about everyone in The Penguin Book of English Pastoral Verse, edited by John Barrell and John Bull (Allen Lane, Â£4) -although how those two splendidly named gentlemen managed to omit Edward Thomas from such a book, when he is the epitome of their tradition and much more besides, I am quiite at a loss to say.
Robert Nye

Author: Spender, Stephen
Title: The language of T S Eliot
Full_text:
THE ARTS
The language of T S Eliot
Today, more than 10 years after his death, Dliot remains a poet enormously admired. Yet his work can scarcely be felt as an influence in our time of "confessional" poets, the authenticity of whose poems is guaranteed by the immanence of their suicides, and of those poets who act out their " turned on" selves at poetry readings.
Eliot thoughit that it should not be the aim of the poet to "express !himself " in his poetry. He thought that, on the contrary, the poet in his work should extinguish his own personality within the wider objective life of the tradition, which, for Eliot, was something very close to being the communion of the dead. The living poet was regarded as a kind of outpost of the dead: to maintain living communication with the past he had to speak to the living in a poetic language which wvas as new as their concerns were new.
Yet although Eliot did not express his "I ", he revealed in his poetry the imagery and rhythms of a uniquely personal sensibility. And despite his concept of the poet as a craftsman dealing with his material like one concentrating on a task . . . " in the same sense as the making of an efficient engine or the turning of a jug or a table-leg ", there is autobiographical material in The W!aste Lad, and the last section of that poem was written almost -like automatic writing, wvhen the poet was suffering from a nervous breakdown.
Like Yeats, Eliot is a poet who incorporates oppositesantinomies-in his work. His impersonality has a uniquely personal tone; his traditionalism turns out to be a revolutionary form of modernism; his idea of the poet as a scieptific worker constructing his poems in a laboratory of his mind is consistent with such a scientist producing an extremely mysterious almost indefinable object of "language rich and strange "; and in the same poem (Four Quartets) in wvhich the poet is seen as struggling wvith words and concerned wvith " purifying the language of the tribe ", the poetic word finally merges into the divine Word-the Word made flesh.
In one of several wrvitings about Baudelaire, Eliot maintains that the poets of his owin generation had more in common with the writers of the Nineties than with the literary generation wvhich "includes Mr Bernard Shaw, and Mr Wells, and Mr Strachey". The reason he gives for drawing this distinction is that Shaw, Wells and Strachey were the "progeny of Huxley, and Tyndall, and George Eliot and Gladstone. And with this generation Baudelaire had nothing to do ".
The distinction here made is vital. It explains why certain modern artists, among them Baudelaire and Eliot, seem, in addition to their having unique creative gifts, to have been in possession of some elixir -which gives their work a quality of survival, of unchangeability amid the changes of modern history. The reason does not lie simply in Eliot's studies of the tradition, nor even in his great critical intelligence, but-as a result indeed of these-in the profound realiz. ation and execution in his poetry of the conviction that in art the subject niatter has to become completely transformed into thle texture of the medium-the language become poetry-poetry perliaps very remote from the subject out of which it originated. It is this which the artists of the nineteentlh century-obsessed wvith their subject matter-had largely forgotten, and which poets like Baudelaire, painters like Delacroix and Manet, grasped. Eliot, as a young man, went to school at the symbolist, pure poetry of Baudelaire, Mallarme and Laforgue. He never forgot that poetry is the alchemy of language.
Nevertheless, although he saw poetry as the transformation of the material into a special language governed by rules of tbhe imagination which were " autotelic ", what makes him a great poet rather than the minor symbolist writer of one of his exquisite early " Preludes ", is the conflict in his work between the poetry as poetry and the pressure upon the poetry of wvhat it is about. By the "subject " of a poem, Eliot meant the poet's philosophy, his beliefs, his actual lived experience and his personality. All these had to be transformed into the language which was so different from them, but they were nevertheless "there ", and great poetry somehow arose out of great material of life. He was himself a trained philosopher, he became religious, and -he had in hiim all the qualities of the
' man who suffers" contained within the " mind which creates ". Thus in his criticism as well as in his poetry he is all his life preoccupied witlh the question of the relationship of the poetry to its subject matter.
He is anxious to cut the umbilical cord connecting the two. And yet he knows that great poems have great subjects. In his earlier- criticism he argues that for a Shakespeare or a Dante his subject matter is simply material of life lying around, which the poet r ealized he may make into great poetry, but without any idea that in the poetry he is expressing some philosophy of life implicit in the subject. Thus, before his own religious
T. S. Eliot
conversions, he argued that for Dante the philosophy of Aquinas was only material which lie recognized was suitable for The Divine Comedy.
Howvever, after he became a Christian it became increasingly difficult for Eliot to maintain that a poet's religion, when he used it as material which he transformed into his poetry , had no connexion with the poetry. qua poetry. The fact thiat in his poetry he evidently believed in the religious views which he held as a man, outside his poetry, caused Herbert Read to comment that Eliot's poetry, after The Waste Land, had become " moralistic ". However, in Four Quarlets Eliot does not abandon the idea that the poetry is something separate from the subject matter of religious belief which it expresses. If he had done so, Four Quartets would be a didactic poem in which the poet used poetry to illustrate a religious or philosoplhical thesis.
The greatness of Four Quartets is that Eliot makes poetrv out of the quarrel between the idea of there being a subject matter transformed into language which is nothing but the poetry, and the idea of religious truth being expressed in a language which is poetry, but
wvhere the poetry does tlot matter", because religious truth is wrhat matters. It might be argued indeed that certain mystical experiences can only be expressed in language wvhich is poetry: so that in the poetry of, for example, St John of the Cross, the poetic truth of the imaginlation and the truth held to be literal fact of religion, become one.
In Four Quartets Eliot becomes a great poet, but a good deal of it is not his greatest poetry. His greatest poetry contains a concentration of quintessential transformed language, and is very close to the "pure" poetry of "Those are pearls that were his eyes" which probably provided for Eliot his ideal of what poetry should be. His prose criticism also contains passages of vivid metaphor-like thnse in Keats's letters-wvlhich strike one with the force of pure poetry. It is his concentrated language wvhich makes Eliot's work a touchstone for other poetry even when his general views about poetry and criticism may be out of fashion.
SteDhen Snender
Siephcnl Spender's study of T. S. Eliot for the Font'caia Modern Masters Series is publisized on M Tonday at 80p.

Author: Fishlock, Trevor
Title: 'Twixt poet and public
Full_text:
'Twixt poet and public
Poetry of Wales 1930-1970
Edited by R. Gerallt Jones
(Gomer Press, Llandysul, Dyfed, f4.25.)
For English readers this parade of 35 Welsh poets is an eye opener. The difficulties of translating poetry from one language to anothier are immense and notorious. But Gerallt Jones has succeeded in communicating the strength and talent of men w-hose work has had a hitherto limited audlience; as well as the flavour of an important period in the development of Welsh language expression. The 1930s were a watershed in Welsh poetry, Mr Jones remarks, and a larger body of competent verse has been published in Welsh during the past 20 years than at any time in the past 400.
The collection covers a large range, reflecting the changes in Welsh life. It provides an insight into the work of men who served their apprenticeship in the early decades of the century and the work of men now building reputations. Thus it ranges from Gwynn Jones, Williams Parry and W. J. Gruffydd, through the post romantic giants such as T. H. Parry-Williams, Saunders Lewis and Gwenallt, through Waldo Williams and Kitchener Davies, to younger men like Dafydd
Rowlands, Bryan Martin Davies and Gwyn Thomas. During the 1930s Welshmen began to reflect the growth of Welsh nationhood. The best pots, Mr Jones says, bega,n to present the common theme, the nation's plight in the face of the threat to its existence posed by the complexity of modern society. "Welsh poetry during this time regained an impetus and direction, rediscovered its Christian roots and became specifica'lly and impressively nationaaistic."
He is concerned, however, at the erosion of the modern poet's position. The Welsh poet is still a social figure of importance but there has been a deepening communication gap between poet and public. Mr Jones says there should be closer examinatlion of the part the media can play in forming a bridge betwen poet and audience and suggests that some distinguished poets should take a less Olympien view of the question of communication. The future, he says, appears uncetain and whether poetry itself can regain a wide audience remains to be seen.
In the meantime this volume performs an important service in enabling the non Welsh reader to share part of the culture of Britain rhat has not been easily accessible to him.
Trevor Fishlock

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
A Nip in the Air
Collected Poems 1929-1974
By John Betjeman
(Murray, fl.50)
By James Reeves
(Heinemnann, f4)
Two years ago, when the runners for the Laureate Stakes were called over, a well-known firm of bookmakers named Auden as odds-on favourite, witlh Betjeman at 5-1 against. In response to inquiries the same firm announced, however, that they wanted " nice friendly bets only"-something regretted by all who noticed that their know-
ledge of poetic form. was so scratchy. Poets are born, not made, and if any born poet was ever a born laureate that creature is John Betjeman, wbose talent has always been for occasional verse. If any living poet could write a passable set of stanzas on HRH The Prince of Wales dropping in to tea at Balnoral by parachute then it would be Betjenian.
The royal occasions commemorated in A Nip in the Air are less demanding. There is a " BaUal of the Investiture 1969 " (You knelt a bog, you rose a mnan./And thus your lonelier life began); there are rhyming couplets, about inland waterways (heaven/Severn) declaimed in the presence of the Queen Mother wvhen she reopened a lock of the Upper Avon; there is " 14 November, 1973 ", which refers to Princess Anne as a vhite lily and instructs her to glow oni the grotunds that she is high in the poet's heart and other hear ts. These effor ts are disappointingly pallid beside the
unofficial Betieman, best represented here by a satire on the mindless chat of executives (Essenti;ally I integrate the current export drive/And basically I'm viable from ten o'clock' till five); an angry song about county types (God save me from the Porkers); a Broyningesque exercise about a homosexual caught for procuring a minor; and a poem about Aldershot Crematorium
The oddest Item is a letter addressed to one Mary Wilson: Dear Mary,
Yes, it wuill be bliss
To go with you by train to Diss ... Can our Poet Laureate really be asking the wife of our Prime Minister to accompany him on a railway trip to Diss, Norfolk for an unspecified purposei Diss is the Latin for hell, of course, but that is no excuise. The poem fusses about whether the ronmantic pair should travel first class, for fear of reporters, or second, for socialistic reasons. It ends with a line to make the stuffed owl hoot: Dear Mary Wilson, thiis is Diss. It is all rather splendid and I await the denial from Downing Street.
James Reeves never ran in the l.aureate Stakes. He is a true poet, and true poets tend not to run in anything, except the memory:
Do you too wonder ff the finest
thzing A promising flower can do
rs but to imitate with all its art
All other flowers that ever grewv ' You looking from vour window
see the spring Each year perform its leisurely Long act of memory,
All nature gone into rememberinig. What am I to say of this? That it is "too reasonable and too truthful "-Yeats's dismissive comment on reading Reeves's fiist book, from wvhich it cozties? Yes, wvell, Yeats had a point. You can be bored bv Reeves's neatness, by his need to make his verse formally watertight. But then there is another Reeves, a Reeves who wvrites untidy, inspired angry poems that seem too well up from quite a different source. I am thinking of such things as "Greenhallows ", which as you read it becomes your onv dream; and " The Little Brother"; and the four compelling lines which make up a strange poem, "Song":
Suffer these hands, the heart's
interpretation.
Because r come to vou as one who
comes
Not at the minute's nor the mind's
dictation,
Suffer these hands, the heart's
interpretation.
I will say of this only what I would say of the second stanza of "TThoughts and Memories5" quoted above-that here surely is the authentic accent of English poetry when it gets beyond personality, or when it salts a man's tongue as plainly as in Clare or Coleridge or Hardy. I hope that his Collected Poems 1929-1974 brings James Reeves at last to the attention of the wide public. So much the worse for the wide public if it does not.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
. .~~~F
Auden has been dead a year. Confronted with his posthumous Thank You, Fog (Faber, E1.75) can one wish this Mr W. H. all happiness and his measure of eternitie ? Here are 19 poems and an antimasque. Nothing leaps from the page with those rhythms which made him such a power when he was young. Everywher e there is artful monochr ome, consciouslv unambitious irony, a setting for that light verse where his talent was at home.. 1 won't disparage a strange achievement. In the last years of his life Auden made light verse bear a weiglht of seriousness. There is a sense in which he ended up writing poems like capers cut in carpet slippers, winking, artful, domestic verse, made from an awareness of the limitations of his talent, and a moral insistence on the rules of the " game" which is poetry. The nicest poems in Thank You, Fog are a relief when seen against the poe-faced visages of some of his surviving contemporaries, still addicted to language as magic.
Take the title piece. This celebrates his return to England from America in 1972. ln skilful syllabics (seven to the line) he welcomes differences between New York smog and fog in the Wiltshire countryside at Chi-istmas, immuring him with friends in a manor-house. Birds sing (those " whose blood/is brisk enough "), but mostly he praises El landscape of bare trees condensing the weather " to definite drops ", while
Indoor specific spaces, coso, accommodatte to
retniniscence and reading, crosswvords. affinzities, fun.
I suppose this is Austin Dobson up-dated ? All the same, platitudes and all, a poem like "A 'i hanksgiving "-in which he names and thanks the poets and others who formed him, nct forgetting Hitler and Stalin whlose -vickedness "forced me to think about God "-is a not contemptible coda to a' life's vork.
Donald Davie, %hvl " has absented himself in California since 1968, has recently shown a comparable concern with Englishness. His collection Tle Shires (Routledge, E2.50) offers a poem about each of the English counties. The book strikes me as tourism, with Davie paying visits not merely to the obvious aspects of each. place but to the scenery of his own talent. Every county gets a literary accolade-although to drag in John Fowles for Dorset, when William Barnes gets no mention, seems wvorse than fashionable. The veise is slack -" Derbyshire " looks like a sonnet witth octave and sestet, but consists of rhymed
couplets; a pepper of exclamation marks tries to do the job of feeling; photographs doctored to make silhouettes on the pages where the poems are printed cannot disguise the book's triviality. Davie's nostalgia has been ill-served by an attempt to try on Betieman's old suits with none of Betjeman's panache.
Full of descriptions of places that have taken his fancy, Charles Tomlinson's TIze Way In (Oxford, £1.25) shows off a painter's eye-snow is seen as " a batter of ash and crystals ", pylons in moonlight are " frigid lattices ". Such observation is pretty, but this poet is forever trying to wring Deep Meaning from it and his verse splinters into fragments of philosophy. Someone once described Tomlinson as a glum fellow trying to learn how to play the flute. There's little joy to his perceptions. The same goes for Douglas Dunii, but then Duiin has no flautist ambitions, and his Love or Nothing (Faber, £1.25) brinigs together poems in a good, plain voice. I like " The Wlhite Poet ", which showvs there is still.stuff to be learnlt from Laforgue, and "AArs Poetica ", a fantasy about typewriters writing poems on typewriters: We are the 'Typewriter Mutses, wve
wvere bred
Ba IWV. C. Williams on Patience
Strong. .
Dunn is a witty poet, inclined to let wit shape a poem when inspiration dries up. David Black r elies more upon fancy. The Happy Cr-ow (Lines Editions: Macdonald, Edgefield Road, Midlothian, S0p) shows him digging away in his own weird mine of sin and philosophy, often discovering nothing more interesting than a few Zeen tags ; but it also has a splendid poemn (" The WaterLily ") in praise of the riches of the depths of unknowing, a handful of lyrics with an origilal pulse, and a longish poem called " Melusine " that is remarkable.
Black is Scottish. His absence from Madle in Scotland, edited iy Robert Garioch (Carcanet, £2.S0 & £1.25) is a serious omission in an anthology otherwise notable for good poems by Robin Fulton, Tom Buchan, and Paul Mills. Stewart Conh's New Poems 1973-74 (Hutchinson, £2), the annual PEN anthology, is mo-e coherenit than volumes in this series usually are.
Finally, magazines. The anniiversary issue of the Quarterly Reviewv of Literature is a paperback book (26 Haslett Avenue. Princeton, New Jersey, £2), and testimony to the catholic but perceptive editorial judgment of Professor T. Weiss and his wife over the years since 1943. Wallvaper- (11 Ascham Street, London, NWS, £1) is an avantgarde newcomer. full of sums and teasinig stories. worth getting for a set of " Modern Sonnets" by the poet Anthony Howell.
Robert Nye

Author: Alderson, Brian
Title: Leading young readers from mere verse to great poetry
Full_text:
Leading young
readers from mere verse
-to great poetry
Between the playground of children's verse and the landscape of poetry there lies a profound chasm. Everybody like the playgtound. You get nursery rhymes there like lollipops, and you get "The King's Breakfast" and "The Raggedy Man"; but not many people find their way out and across the great divide. It is said that their high expectations are lured away by siren voices chanting "To Daffodils " and are crushed under limp-bound Selections from Tennyson (with notes).
Recently some attempts have been made to provide a bridge by adopting the fairly obvious expedient of building out from the playground. Among the qualities that make children's verse so universally enjoyable are its spirited rhythm and humour, and in anthologies like Geoffrey Summerfield's Voices-whose three volumes were three good reasons why Penguin Education should never have been allowed to die -one saw a great editor leading young readers from street-songs and graffiti to some of the .greatest poetry there is.
There was precedent for Voices in two other anthologies Dawn and Dusk and Rising Early (Brockhampton Press) edited by Charles Causley, who has triumphed again in his recent Puffin Book of Magic Verse (35p). As its title implies, the book is more narrowly based than its predecessors, but Mr Causley is generous in his interpretation of "magic" -partly, one suspects, to keep a foothold in the world of children's rhymes. "The Man in the Wilderness" (who asked of me/" How many blackberries grow in thze sea ?") rubs shoulders with "La Belle Dame Sans Merci" ; a popular recitation against warts with some of Robert Her. rick's filigree " charmes ".
As poet rather than editor (his funny ballad about Colonel Fazackerly Butterworth-Toast is included in Magic Verse) Charles Causley is also a representative of the gallant band who have tried to carry children across the chasm by writing poetry that itself carries echoes of the playgrounds-an altogether more difficult commission than compiling' anthologies. One of its most notable practitioners is Ian Serraillier, a selection of whose work .spanning the last thirty years, has been published as The Robin land the Wren (issued, not very appropriately, by Kestrel
The Headless Gardener
A gardener, Tobias Baird,
sent his head to be repaired;
he thought, as nothing much was wrong, hc wouldn't be without it long.
Ten years he's weeded path and plot, a headless gardener, God wot, always hoping (hope is vain)
To see his noddle back again.
Don't pity him for his distresshe never sent up his address.
A Fritz Wegner Illustration from Tle Robin and the Wren.
Books, Â£1.75). The " childish " qualities are obvious: not just the dominance of Fritz Wegner's pictorial designs, which -sometimes command more space than the verse, but also Mr Se*raillier's liking for the poetic treatment of nursery literature. He writes a five-verse set of variations on "The North Wind doth Blow" in his title poem, f*or instance, and he neatly versifies such fables as "The Rabbit and the Fox" and "The Town Mouse and the Coluntry Mouse ".
Ian Serraillier's manner with these children's themes is however a step away
from childhood. As well as lengthening and embroidering his sources, he gives them a modern idiom-a conversational tone, which flattens out the "poetry" and prevents it froni getting'too lush or facile. (There is almost an echo of Dr Seuss in " What, swallow that muck ? " said the mouse from the town./" It would stick in my throat. It wouldn't go down.")
This roughening of the surface is a skilful way of suggesting that poetry. is. more approachable than the schoolroom allows-a technique even more evident in Michael Rosen's Mind Your Own Business (Deutsch, Â£1.25) whose contents range from Old Ben Brown "who played the ukelele with his trousers down ", through the farcical saga of "My brother got married in a wimpy bar", to a group of poems where the artist's perception is intensified by the cheerful informality of his verse.
Mr Rlosen is happy to write whole poems as conversation pieces and he has a nice ear for the way kids speak (peas for breakfast please he said/and a plateftul of peas is what he got), his uninhibited enjoymenTt of the whole operation standing in sharp contrast to the well-meaning but rather stiffjointed attempts of more famous poets to write "with young people in mind " (a phrase with more than a hint of condescension). These are the Chatto Poets for the Young, edited by Leonard Clark, a series in which four new contributors have just appeared (75p each). John Fuller's Squeaking Crust comes nearest to catching the energy of popular verse and his poem sequence for music " Fox-trot " probably comes over well in performance, but like two other volumes (D. J. Enright's Rhyme Times Rhyme and Phoebe Hesketh's A Song of Sunlight) the humour is often quirky rather than broad, and there are subtleties of allusion and phrasing which demand the response of a committed reader. of poetry. Vernon Scannell's The Apple-Raid is perhaps the most successful book of the four "for young veople "- partly because it is not so self-conscious and partly because it seems more convinced, as its author says, that he who needs no poetry or bread/is really in a devilish bad way.
Brian Alderson

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
. . . _
There are few enough authentic poets at any time to make the task of discovering and trying to define them difficult-without bothering whether they come dressed in Faber grey or Gollancz yellow, or whether their stitches are up to the standard of tailoring we expect from Oxford University Press. All the same, the activities of one contemporary publishing house have now reached such e pitch that I feel something must be said about it.
Cai canet Press began a few years ago by publishing pamphlets and first collections by *a handful of vaguely Oxfordorien:ated young men. Now, fi-oni an unlikely address (266 Councillor Ilane, Cheadle Hlulme, Cheadle, Cheshire SK8 SPN), it is pttblishing under its variouis imprints new and old work of much variety and r e- sou rcefuln ess.
Elizabeth Daryush. the daughter of Robert Bridges and virtual inventor of syllabic verse, was rediscovered by this firm. They re-publish HD, high priestess of Imagism, in heer later- manifestation as a visionary of the blitz. They issued two months ago what is already being recognized as one of the most important volumes of collected poems to appear since the war-C. H. Sisson's In tize Trojan Ditch. Criticism and translation have not been neglected by Carcanet either. And the second volume of the
book-form magazine PoetrV Nation, published twice yearly uiider their aegis, is now in the shops (£2.90 annual subscriptioIl).
The back cover of a Carcanet book reads these days with something of the authority which Faber books used to possess in Eliot's prime. Their authors are a roll-call of achievement and promise. Within this.house there is plainly an informed and enthusiastic passion for poetry, and a comnmitmettt to poetry which cares more about the dialect of the tribe than the money in the bank. Passion and commitment have not been so popular among publishers, or common in their minions, that the literary world can afford to ignore them.
Besides Poetry Nation- 2- vhich contains the best new poem for yeais from the pen of Elizabeth Jennings, and good poems by Gareth Reeves, Douglas Dunn, Daniel Weissbort, Stewvart Conn and Roger Garfitt, as well as some bInilliantly sceptical criticism, notably bv Colin Falck on Robert Lowell-five new Carcanet titles lie before me. George Kendi-ick's Bicycle Tyre in a Tall Tree (£2 and £1.25) is the most interesting-a first collection by a young poet with an educated ear and a gift of thiinking with his imagination. Kendrick tries on various suits from the British Home Stores of modernism, but his best suit is his owin offhand sen1se of humour:
I woutld say a bicycle tyre in a
tall tree has real poise, for there the birds
twill sing and all the buds break into
-- geotnetrU. What a good throto thjat was.
Humour is just what Jon Silkin lacks. The Principle of Water (Carcanet. £2.20 and £1.25) is his most extended selection for some time, and here, as before, lhis earnestly groping verses in praise of vegetables and waterwhleels doing their stuff in the north country remind me too often of Erasmus Darwin's Loves of the Plants. Silkin is like a boxer forever flexing his muscles and snarling at the air, but never hitting anything much. Perhaps a larger subject than swelf or slag-heaps would help ?
I have room only to mention the three other books as demonstratiAig Carcanet's versatility: Tyorkin & the Stovemakers (£2.50), poetry and prose by Alexander Tvardovsky, editor of Novy Mir, translated from the Russiap by Anthony Rudolf; Ten Anglo-Welsh Poets, edited by Sam Adams (£2.50 and £ 1.25), which includes work by Gwyn Williams, Glyn Jones, Roland Matlhias, Harri Webb, Leslie Norris, John Ormond, Raymond Garlick, John Tripp, Gillian Clarke, and John Pook; and Ten Irish Poets, edited by Jlames Simmons (£2.50 and £1.25), whiclh has work by its editor and George Buchanan, John Hewitt, Padraic Fiacc, Pcarse Hutchinson, Michael Hartnett, Eilean Ni Chuilleanain, Michael Foley, Frank Ormsby, and Tom Mathews: These anthologies, published with support from various Arts Councils, do well to direct attention to distinctive vitalities outside the usual province of London.
Robert Nye

Author: Null
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Iago was an honest man ;/1 have that reputatdon too.
Poems have tO do w~ith saying such thing6. Poetry is that way of saying them. C:. H. Sisson is a poet-a man impelled to find personal rhythms for some more-than-personal truth. It would be hard to speak too highly of his In the Trojan Ditch: Collected Poems & Selected Translations (Carcanet Press, Â£3.25). Sisson belongs with those who have used common speech to say things not commonly said-Edwvard Thomas, the early Eliot, Hardy, Barnes, Donne, Raleigh. . . . I reach back for names. English verse in this century has not been so thick with them that anyone who cares for it can afford to ignore Sisson.
He was born in 1914, wrote verse in adolescence, stopped at 20, started again in a troopship on the way to the war, but did not begin writing the poems by which he will be remembered until about 1950. The present book starts with his most recent verse, including "The (Jak ", which is remarkable in speaking from places where the mind prefers silence-Christ is a language in which we speak to God/And also God, so that we speak in truth. As a guideline, a reviewver might refer attention to a valediction which comes half-way through:
Catullus my friend across rtwenty centuries,
Anxious to complete vour lechery before Christ carne
since much of Sisson's journey is a* return to source and an attempt to reknit Christianity to the pagan world, or rather to explore the relationship of the flesh of paganism and the religion of the Incarnation. Do not fail tO StOp at "The Crucifix ",
"Human Relations ", "~ The Garden of Epicurus ", " A Letter to John Donne ", and "sIn a DaTk Wood ". TShese will read you. Indeed, if. you are a poet the difficulty may be in starting again once they have done so.
The poems in Philip Larkin's Hi'gh Windows (Faber, Â£1.40) remain loyal to past victories on a small patch of ground. Once more Larkin provides the modest lyrical bits (" Cut Grass ", " The Trees"); the formal essay-poems in which a subject-visiting the sea, looking at old men, disliking hospitals-is treated in metres de-
cently subdued to their occasions; and the tough stuff. The last is least interestingLarkin goes on about other (younger) chaps getting their sexual share, and more, while it seems (from "Sad Steps") that he only gets out of bed to piss and look at the moon, or gets back into bed to write poems about pissing and looking at the moon. There's something laugh. able about thzis . . . The line falls out of that particular poem and takes a cruel peek at some of the others.
If Larkin visits Dublin you can bet there'll be a funeral before the end of the first stanza. And when he raises his voice now, letting off the selfsatirical brakes to bring one of the longish pieces to a halt, the result is an alliterative whim. per-no more smashing "poetical " cliches as in " An Arundel Tomb " or that stuff about love being like an enormous yes in the poem about the jazz clarinet player in The Whitsun IVeddings; these days it's hospital visitors With wasteful, weak, propitiatory flowers....
Still, the same old Larkin (.ike Eliot, he always seems a generation older than he is) remains the same decent old Larkin. His unfurnished poetry Of furnished rooms is certainly his own.
It used to be Anthony Thwaite's as well, but now he has read St Augustine and in New Confessions (Oxford, Â£1.50) tries on that saint's skin to create "a personal book of meditation and transmutation". The dove is not our pigeon, as it says on page 37. Who is going to disagree? I prefer my Augustine straight, and my Thwaite cutting his suburban grass with Larkin's Qld mower.
RVobert Nye
Keith Douglas, 1920.1944, by Desmnond Grahamn (Oxford, S5.W0). "Where are the war poets?" readers asked during the Second World War, looking over their shoulders to Owen and Sassoon and even Brooke. Of the three most uiotableSidney Keyes, Alun Lewis and Keith Douglas-none has. even yet had the attention he deserves. Now we have a full biography of Douglas, which perhaps rather misses the point: that his poetry was the only important thing about him. His rather unremarkable life is set out in great detail, and the book is particularly welcome because of the full use 'the author makes ot the poems, and their relation to the events of that life.

Author: D.P.
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
The Puffin Book of Magic Verse, edited by Charles Causley (Puffin, 35p). Anthologies of poetry made for children have got steadily better and better during the past half-century and during the past decade Charles Causley has made two of the best of them. In his new book (splendidly. a paperback, and an inexpensive one) he has gathered goose-pimpling verse " about" warlocks and ghosts, giants and changelings, together with charms, spelils and curses.
He prints well over 150 poems, many of which one would not expect from most anthologizers, who would have been unlikely to catch. say, Edith pitwellis The youth with the red-gold hair, A. L. Rowse's Ardevora Veor, or A. E. Housman's Her strong enchantments failing. Barbara Swiderska provides chilling linedrawings and an irresistable cover design. Only the presence of the illustrations, and perhaps the careful simplicity of the excellent introduction ("All poetry is magic. It is a spell against insensitivity,. failure of imagination, ignorance, and barbarism ") convey the slightest hint that this is a book meant for young readers. AU is, in facr, as it should be. Walter de la Mare would have approved.
D.P.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
David Jones is now famous as the poet Larkin left out of the latest Oxford anthology. Since Yeats omitted Laura Riding from its predecessor, history may see these Oxford books as of interest because they managed between them to neglect two of the most important Twentieth century poets in English. Thze Sleeping Lord and Otlter Fragments (Faber, £2.95) ivill enable readers to judge the truth of the first of these suggestions. For extended analyses of Jones, I refer attention to the issue of the magazine Agenda devoted to his work (1967); as for Riding the current issue of the magazine Stand contains a useful introduction to her poems and to her subsequent rejection of poem-writing as an insufficient means of truth-telling.
Jones and Riding have this in common: a seriousness which I shall call religious. Jones is a Christian, Riding is not, but they might find common ground in a phrase Simone Weil used, of the world being " God's language to us ". It is by delight in that language, and specifically by returning to the central act of the Christian faith as an anamnesis, a re-callingi or re-presenting of an event in the past " so that it becomes here and now operative by its effects" (the words are those of Dom Gregory Dix) that Jones has made his poems. He is modest about these makings, calling The Anathemnata (1952), for example, " fragments of an attempted writing ". In effect all his verse is a meditation upon the Iiicarnation and Crucifixion. It is sacrametital. He sees man as of his nature a poet, since he is one "who makes things that are signs of something ", and in that making which is the Mass he sees made not just sign but Signature.
The poems collected in the new book are beautiful. They take speech-the speaking of soldiers stationed in Palestine "in the earlier decades of the
first century AD ", and others at the edges of the Roman Empire-and they move the mind through a supra-historical "present" in which there is no distinction between what happens now and what happened then.
I think Jones is a visionary poet, comparable with Blake, and that if you take the trouble to read him in the light of his sources-the liturgy, and Dix and Maurice de la Taille on the liturgy-you may arrive at the conclusion wvhich Anthony Thwaite offers in his Poetry Today 1960-1973 (Longman Group, for British Council, 50p), that when these fragments are gathered they will be perceived to provide " an historical Christian counterpart to what Ezra Pound failed to achieve in the Cantos ". Thwaite's pamphlet is worth getting for many judgments in which a similar soundness finds quiet vords for itself.
I Prayers
Are not the rafts on wliich we slzall
be saved.
We say no grace. We seek it in our
food.
Thus Philip Oakes, whose Married I Singular (Andre Deutsch, £1.25) could not be farther away-from Jones. Yet I wonder.... Oakes is a materialist. He writes of food and spiders and tea and bedmaking. He creates an active surface of words, through which his subjects come alive. But Jones is more of a mater. ialist, taking matter to its conclusion. Oakes would be shy of that, but he fashions authentic verse of the shyness, and I like his truth to the limitations of experience. The same goes for P. J. Kavanagh's Edward Thomas in Heaven (Chatto & Windus, £1,25). This poet mistrusts the romantic, yet is full of nostalgia:
I wear my grave-clothes and I do
not mind.
Small trills escape from small birds
suddenly:
I'm going nowhere and the
thought's my friend.
Full of michief, too. See "The Famous Poet". a satire on that aspect of Ted Hughes which stalks through woods full of feathered Fascists
Robert Nye

Author: Blyth, Alan
Title: Poetry and Prey
Full_text:
Poetry and Prey
We know Hermann Prey today as much as an opera singer as a Lieder interpreter, yet when he set out on his career he had no idea of going on the stage and intended to devote his life to song and that alone. Nowadays, as his schedule tells you, Liederabende have to take their place alongside appeara!nces at the Metropolitan, La Scala, Vienna, Salzburg and Covent Garden.
In a sense he is still truest to his first lorve because there, as he puts it, " the success of the evenings depends on vou and nobody else". His programme for his recital at the Festival Hall tonight contains quite a number of Goethe settings. How much did his choice of songs depend on the quality of the poetry ?
" When I was younger I could only sing settings of poems I admired. Now I feel that there are many songs where, even if the words don't mean so much to me, I find consolation and satisfaction in .the cut of the melody or the harmonic interest. But, naturally enough; when you get fine poetry as well as fine music, the rewards are stilil greater. Even more interesting is to contrast, as I'm going to do, two different settings of the same poem-in this case Schubert's and Loewe's of Goethe's Erlk6nig ".
Schlusnus was Prey's idol when he set out on his career in the early 1950s. "After all, he was the most admired Lieder singer of the previous generation, and I wasbound to be influenced by him. Today I think I've moved away from Schlusnus's predominantly lyrical approach to a more dramatic one, where the treatment of the texts has perhaps gained in significance for mealthough of course I hope I'm not neglecting the importance of a beautiful line."
Prey has strong views on accompanists. " I find it hard to have as my accompanist a player who has worked with one singer thle day before, me today, and yet a t!hird artist tomorrow. That's no way ta gain rapport. I'm not blaming the pianists ;because this is a fact of recitatl life and they have to earn a living, but it is not altogether satisfactory. For years, until we ihad a disagreement on interpretation, I worked happily with Brendel. Of late, I have worked quite regularly with Leonard Hokanson, who is partnering me in 7 Lfondon. I'm sure that in the I future each singer will have to jform a duo with one particular pianist. It should be a kind of I marriage."
jThe operatic side of Prey's ;career began. with the Wmppertata and Wiesoaden companies , in 1951-52, but soon he was
spotted by Gunther RKennert who tooks him on the roster at Hambhurg, where he remained until 1960. " For a lonlg time I
did small roles, or else larger ones in modern opera-good for the musical development but bad for the voice. My breakthrough came in operetta, a work by Honegger called Les Aventures du Roi Pausole. After that Rennert began to have faith in me and I got major parts. .1 suppose the decisive step on to the international kdder came in 1957 when I sang Figaro in a new production of Barbiere at Vienna, and that rwle and Wolfram have been my most successful outside the German-speaking world. I think -1 was the first German baritone to appear as Rossini's Figaro at both La Scala and the Metropolitan, and of course I made my Covent Garden debut in the part last season."
Oddly enough, in Mozart's opera it is the Count not Figaro that has up to now been his part. Although he will be the Count in next month's Scala production he hopes soon to have a chance to sing Mozart's exbarber at Munich. It touches on a. sore point in Prey's thoughts. " It's such a pity that most opera houses look for a bass or bassbaritone rather than a true baritone both for that part and for Don Giovanni. If you listen to the singers of the past in the arias from Giovanni l'ou can hear my idea of the title role, a light, elegant, rather degenerate sound. Giovanni should sound liglht and airy so that he contrasts with Leporello."
He thinks, too, that more of the Verdi roles would be in his grasp, were there a return to an older approach to that composer, and gives a graphic example from Rigoletto to prove his point. In his Hamburg days he sang Posa, and he wants to do the part again, but only in a new production of Don Carlos. He would also like to sing Falstaff soon. But I put it to him that perhaps he should be satisfied with being the best Papageno, Guglielmo and Wolfram of the day.
" Yes, of course I get satisfaction from 'doing those parts well but I would like to enlarge my repertory, specially in the Strauss field. You know I made my Salzburg debut in 1959 as that other barber in Schweigsame Frau and of course I sang Storch in the famous Munich Internezzo, which came to Edinburgh in 1965. I would like now to go on to Barak, Jochanaan .and Mandryka. Why don't they do a new Arabella for me in Munich ? Well, you write to Mr Rennert and tell him that. The only trouble witb these Strauss parts is that the orchestration is -so heavy when the baritone comes in. Just look at Mandryka's long monologue in the first act of Arabella. Strauss didn't like his male singers; thaes quite clear. But with the right conductor. * . ."
Alan Blyth

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
It is easy to miss the merits of Andrew Young. His poems are quiet. They do not show off a personality. They make no fuss about tradition. They just are. And, like all real poetry, this means that what they are is neither old nor new, but seemingly remembered even the first time we read it: It it should come to this
You cannot wake me with a kiss. Think I but sleep too late
Or once again keep a cold angry
state.
Young was not always as good as that. But his Complete Poems (Secker & Warburg, Â£4.50; paperback, Â£2.25), as arranged by Leonard Clark contains enough to make it probable that a dozen of his poems arc already table-talk among that company where Donne sits down to dine with Edward Thomas. He died two years ago at the age of 86, after a crowded but unambitious life as priest, poet, topographer and naturalist.
Following a dead master, it is fitting, if dispiriting, to turn to some live beginners. Colin Falck's Backwards into the Smoke (Carcanet Press, Â£1.75
paperback, 90p) is costive with its own integrity. Verses are squeezed out of the toothpaste tube of Self, and worlds of significance made to depend upon brief shrugs of imagery, especially when the First Person Singular addresses the Second Person Singular in what we may take to be a relatedness of sexual feeling. Yet if I cannot admire the tube I yet must concede considerable skill in the squeezing. The American- Samuel Menashe, in Fringe of Fire (Gollancz, Â£2), risks coyness and cosiness in offering flimsy imagistic frag. ments as though they were the outcomne.of L classical restraint; while I have never felt that his lines achieVe the intensity, aimed, for, some of them have a lapidary charm, not unlike LTndor:
The shrine whose shape I am Has a fringe of:ffre - Flames skirt my skin
(though' in so tiny a poem the control over the letter S ought to .be. tih.ter)*) .-.he
Elaine Feinstein's The Celebrants and Other Poems (Hutchinson, 2l; paperback, Â£1.20) and Kathleen Raine's On a Deserted
Shore (Hamish Hamilton, Â£2) try to clarify spiritual mysteries within human relationships, especially as these may be uncovered in man-woman love. These two poets have it in common that they establish a valid metaphysics out of their experiences as women.
Alan Ross's The Taj Express (London Magazine Editions, Â£2) is more enjoyable in its evocation of place than anything of his which I have read before. Nor are these merely wish-youwere-here poem-postcards, since the sense of geography is coextensive with an expression of mood. usually senrsual, giving the verse close texture with what it describes.
Just room to recommend Peter Ackroyd's London Lickpenny (Ferry Press, 60p), which is notably at the other end of the scale from Andrew Young, favouring an impenetrable surrealism jamming together lines in a flat, hallucinated style reminiscent of the early John Ashbery. None of this would be of anv import if Ackroyd did not show indelible signs of mind. This heady mixture of distinctive rhythmic vitalities is Just the sort of thing which authentically inspired poets produce in a first book, for if you. do not start out rich how can you expect anyone to believe in your later refinings?
Robert Nye
Business Books
-including Aubrey Jones on ' Incomes Policy and Capital Sharing in Europe 'by
Derek Robinson-
reviewed on page 28

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
I ._.
In 1968 there was a translation competition, adjudicated by George Steiner, in The Sunday Times. The poem set was Baudelaire's "Spleen ". Steiner was perhaps rendered splenetic himself when versions rained on him from all over the country, bearing such pseudonyms as Henry Birdsong and W. H. Laudanum, each typed in green and brown. Their author was Nicholas Moore, son of philosopher G. E. Moore, known as a poet in the Forties. when he worked with Tambimuttu on Poetry London, largely forgotten since.
Since T ambi's day, Moore has been growing flowers-he is the author of The Tall Bearded Iris, which he describes modestly as out-of-date. Steiner's challenge tore him away from horticulture and back into an orgy of verse, the results of which may be found in Spleen (Menard Press with Blacksuede Boot Press: 1 Primrose Gardens, London, NW3, 60p). This would make a nice last-minute Christmas present for anyone who shares Robert Frost's view that poetry is what gets lost in translation, or who appreciates little presses doing witty and literate things.
Moore's high spirits conceal a seriousness set forth in his preface, " On the Impossibility of Translation ", wher.* he argues that all a poet does when he translates is produce a version of himself in foreign fancy dress which may or may not suit him. The felicities and faults of his 31 parody poets (who include Nicholas Moore) are various enough to prove his case.
One of the poets parodied, HD, otherwise Hilda Dolittle, Empress of Imagism, has been resurrected with a foreword by Norman Holmes Pearson in Trilogy (Carcanet Press, Â£2.50; paperback, Â£1.25), which collects three sequences inspired by the
bombing of London. A blitz of apocalyptic imagery blurs the Hellenic style, and the most that can be said of these effusions is that they are not as bad as Edith Sitwell's " Still Falls the Rain ", with which rhetoric they deserve to be compared. HD translating bombs into angels is too much.
George Barker's In Memory of David Archer (Faber, Â£1.95) celebrates the publisher of his first book. Barker has suffered from comparisons with Dylan Thomas, and it's true that at his worst he goes on about wombs and tombs and rods and roses, while the iambic pentameters strut like traffic wardens looking for symbols to book. The new volume has much worse, but also its quota of best, and this poet when he is thinking sounds like Blake rewritten by Byron, which is to say that he is a romantic with an ear for speech. rhythms.
R. S. Thomas, poet and priest, works at the other end of the scale, as anyone can see from Selected Poems 1946-1968 (HartDavis, MacGibbon, Â£2.95). Chary of rhyme, Thomas's poems puzzle out their meaning through assonance, returning again and again to the emblematic figure of his peasant parishioner lago Prytherch. I confess to wishing that Prytherch wor ld answer Thomas back just once; he might mention, for instance, that he is fed up with being forever poeticised, however bleakly, as turning the pages of the fields. Nevertheless, if Thomas has been writing the same poem for 22 years it is a real poem. He knows his country to the bone.
So does Alasdair Maclean, whose From the Wilderness (Gollancz, Â£2; paperback, -1) has a coherence which springs from the poet using his experience as a orofter up on the hard peninsula of Ardnamurchan. Maclean writes about the seasons and peat-cutting and .tems of local history, but he is closer to John Claire than to any who have exaggerated the pleasantness of country life. He is bitter about what is happening to the Highlands-just as Clare was angry about Enclosures. But don't read this book for natronising political reasons.
Briefly, may I recommend the neo-Augustan stylishness of John Fuller's Epistles to Several Persons (Secker & Warburg, E1.75 ; paperback, Â£1), and the more complicated elegance of his dad Roy's Tiny Tears (Andrie Deutsch, Â£l 50). Both Fullers also turn up in the PEN anthology, New Poems 1972-73, edited by Douglas Dunn (Hutchinson, Â£2), which manages to be catholic yet discriminating.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Let's do it
Full_text:
Let's do it
The Faber Book .of Love Poems, edited by Geoffrey Grigson (Faber, Â£3.25)
The Penguin Book of Love Poetry; edited by Jon Stallworthy (Allen Lane, Â£3.25)
There are two views of love and poetry. The first is that what gets said between persons in that condition constitutes the one story and one story only, the single poetic theme underlying all others, and that the proper study of poetkind is therefore Woman. The other holds that a poet in love is not more likely than a plumber to write a good poem about it. Robert Graves has been a proponent of the first view. Roy Fuller recently went on record with the second.
- These two anthologies don't settle the argument, although if either appeared in a cheaper edition it might sell well to plumbers looking for verses which they could pass off as their own in order to seduce female customers. Grigson's is for your intellectual plumber, with pretensions to regret and philosophy if not syphilis. Stallworthy's gives the more urgent
note, the a Christ, if my love were in my arms,/And I in my bed again" bit. As it happens, each includes the anonymous poem from which that cry comes, and there's a degree of overlapping of other material, as you'd expect.
With moderns, Grigson has the securer taste-his Eliot is the superb " La Figlia Che Piange ", for instance, where Stallworthy's is that embarras. singly awful " Dedication to My Wife" from The Elder States. man. At the same time Stallworthy prints a feeble piece of juvenilia by Hart Crane wvhen presumably he could have chosen any of the lyrics from the same poet's mature volume, White Buildings. Grigson incluides an extravagant heap of Greek marble chippings by Landor. George Barker, Kenneth Patchen, and Robert Frost don't get a single poem into either book. Neither does that pretty good love poet Dante Alighien, but then She might have opened up areas beyond Muses or plumbing.
Robert Nye
