Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Sooner or later it occurs to every English poet to write a long poem about King Arthur, and while we can be glad that most resist the temptation we may equally be grateful thlat John Heath-Stubbs has not. Heath-Stubbs is a classic-minded but romantic-spirited writer, and his Artori7us (i nitllhaimon Press, Â£3.50) combines scholarship and inspiration in fair proportion.
Ranging through a variety of forms, this heroic poem provides pleasure by its shape alone-no inconsiderable thing in days when poets have forgot. ten Yeats's injunction that they "learn their trade ". Artorius himself stands for the poet as archetypal form-maker. His defence of Roman values aaainst barbarism has parallels with our situation: " Living as we do at the beginning of the Second Dark Age." But the epigraphs give subtler clues. Milton pitted against Tom o' Bedlam, and it is because Heath-Sttubbs hias both in him that his poem gen.c rates tension to justify its length.
Artorius as a *vhole pursues not simply Form, but " the White Stag, the unattainable " ; its various voices have the poet's quintessential gift, " I become what I sing "; a guideline
is its returning to that boast of Taliesin's, from the Mabinzogioni. where he declares that he has existed as a catechist of order from the world's beginning. In one memorable section, in Book 2, Gwion/Taliesin informs us that he has been all the poets, from Langland to Dylan Thomas. These are pleasures noticed from a first reading. This is a text to be reread.
Peter Porter in Jonah (Secker & Warburg, Â£4.75), has collaborated with the painter, Arthur Boyd, to produce a series of poetic and pictorial annotations to the Biblical story. Apollo and Dionysus, reason and imagination, have never sat comfortably together at Porter's table. He has either been too reasonable, hence dull, or too imaginative, hence incoherent. Here the mythopoeic subject gives him a focus, and the result is a confusion-cancelling seriousness which sounds inspired. Jonah's prose journal of his spell inside the whale serves to flex Porter's muscles for formal poems in praise of God's other creatures: worm, gourd, cat. The epilogue returns to celebrate order with severity, burning the Dionysian torch at Apollo's altar:
For us the Garden is set in its
clockwork glorv,
Nineveh sits by the river forever
in the story.
No-one is old and God listens on
his throne,
At the end the bone sings: 71e
hears the singing bone.
The work to which I am draw-
ing attention is not self-expression, but the expression of something more mysterious and recalcitrant than self. Few have expressed that more sensitively or witlh a stricter sense of word-rightness than Osip Mandelstam, the Russian whose caustic and lucid poems, the epitome of a wholly modern classicism, are now starting to appear in English. His Selected Poems, translated by Clarence Brown and W. S. Merwin (Oxford, Â£2.50), should be compared with another Selected Poems. translated by David McDuff (Rivers Press, Â£2.2.5; paperback, Â£1), and a booklet called Chapter 42 and The Goldfinch (Menard Press, 75p). The last-named contains a missing chapter from the memoirs of Mandelstam's widow, plus related poems, all translated by Donald Rayfield. On the subject of translation, buy the volume now handsomely made of Peter Dale's versions of The Legacy, The Testament, and Other Poems of Frangois Villon (Macmillan, Â£6). Villon is hard to translate, as Pound said, because he rhymes on the exact word. Dale does well, going for muscle, bone, and mood and letting the music take care of itself.
Nobody who has read this far with sympathy for my theme of the poet as catechist of order should miss Martin Booth's Coronis (Andium Press, Â£1.85) or the first issue of Poetry Nation (266 Councillor Lane, Cheadle Hulme, Cheshire SK8
SPN, published twice yearly, subscription Â£2.90). Booth constructs litanies of unpromisingly mucky romantic matter, but his grip of his craft, together with a dedication to the making of a sense which will reach beyond reason, give his work a fumbling power:
In this place
Christ nailed wind on the
headstones und watching it howl round tried to shake it loose.
" Noumenon ", quoted there, is an achievement for a poet still in his twenties. The "Archdeacon Broix" sequence, "Steeple Gidding ", and "Visit of the Exegete " are nearly as good, and full of possibilities for future refinings.
Poetry Nation, edited by C. B. Cox and Michael Schmidt, stands I think for grace as much as form. This book-style magazine, out for the first time today, contains poems by C. H. Sisson, Elizabeth Jennings, Donald Davie, Douglas Dunn, Roger Garfitt, Charles Tomlinson, Fleur Adcock, and others committed to poetry as the best linguistic means we have of making sense of our senses. Essays by Schmidt and Davie, Adrian Stokes on " Psychoanalysis and our Culture ", and a long interview with Edgell Rickword, make this a substantial addition to the present poetry magazine scene. Plainly there is going to be nothing trivial about Poetry Nation.
Robert Nye

Author: Jebb, Julien
Title: Poetry International
Full_text:
Poetry International
Queen Elizabeth Hall
Julien Jebb
Can it be seven vears ago that Allen Ginsberg did his celebrated double act with Ungaretti ?
The audiencc is still young, entlusiastic and very large. But the American howle; has lost some more hair fromli the top of his head, and gained some more about tile jowl and chini. Encumbered by crutches, which made access to the podiu- i difficult for him, and still accompanied by his Alystery Wheezer Box he moaned a few disjointed lines about his broken bones from a recent work. Ungar-etti was no longer with us. I fled.
This has been the most various and ambitious season of Poetry International, which can now be regarded as a miniature poetic equivaient of the Proms. Nursed through infancy by Patrick Garland, helped later by Ted Hughes and now in the capable and imaginative hands of Charles Osborne, it was a triumphant week Ginsberg or no Ginsberg. Early on there was a satirical revue mounted by Ian Hamilton and Clive James, dedicated snuffers of any false flame seen to flicker in the poetic firmament, these two television critics reallv do despise a lot of poetry, and their hatred is fashionably ferocious. There were also evenings devoted to libretto, politics and translation all held at Nash El ouse.
turiday aold Saturdayv wse retuliied to the ampler spaces of
the Queen Elizabeth Hall, and to the sight of the festival's patron Bard. W. H. Auden, who has declared that Poetry International is the most important event of its kind in the world. His reading was preceded by some new poems by Vasko Popa. the Yugoslavian of gentle, heraldic mien who, like Cavafy. seems to stand at an angle to the universe-and a slight one to the microphone. It was good to see Patrick Garland back on the platform to read the trans. lations of Popa's dense limpid allegories.
Then came the announced star. Auden, as ever, recited recent work. A hymn to the privacies afforded by English fog, which incorporated unhappily easy references to global gloom to filth and violence; but this gave way to other much finer things: marvelled revelries at the creatures who inhabit our skin
stoical wit about "a new necessity, death ". And a piece of lambent, polemical doggerel against the motor car.
The greatest impact wvas made by Peter Porter. With the exception of John Fuller (vho has not yet appeared in Poetry International, please note), he is the only younger English poet who treats art with the same awed and loving familiarity that others give exclusively to nature, themselves, or, very occasionally. God. His are concrete poems, not concrete poetry ; his verbal skill is never facile. his feelings are profound his ironies charged with passion. and his sense of the continuous. f ruitful marriage of life and art explodes into poetry.

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Lowells, Cabots and God
Robert Lowell is one of the Lowells of Boston, Mass. James Russell Lowell was his greatgrandfather's brother. Cigarsmoking Amy, empress of imagism, was his cousin. Of nearer and dearer relatives he has spoken in Life Studies (1959). Those guilt-edged ghosts are never far from his inspiration, and any of his books might bear an epigraph from Anon: I come from t)he city of Boston,
The home of thze bean and the cod, Where the Lowells speak only to
Cabots, And the Cabots speak only to God. Critical opinion about Lowell is divided. Some prefer the early rhetoric, where he usurps the function of the Cabots and prays in thumping iambics. Others go for the talkative distress of those 14-line verse-shaped units, in which he sheds skins like veils. Three years ago he published a sequence of these called Notebook. Now he has rewritten hundreds of units from it and serves them up again as History (Faber, Â£2.95) and For Lizzie and Harriet (Faber, Â£1.40). History also contains 80 new units, while The Dolphin (Faber, Â£1.75) consists entirely of fresh work. What all three books offer is a pageant of being Robert Lowell. He is the man, he suffers, he is there. His marriag,e breaks down. His daughter grows up. He chats with T. S. Eliot on a traffic island-about the problems of having famous relatives. When his feelings itch he scratches them, and the blood rhymes. It is possible to respect the open heart surgery while thinking that a necessary pressure has been dissipated in its exercise. All three books are crammed with OK names and up-to-the-minute r eferences. Perhaps every age gets the Lowell it deserves ?
Lawrence Durrell has always been a bit of a Cabot, addressing himself aristocratically to God in the guise of some Mediterranean deus loci. Vega and Other Poems (Faber, Â£1.40) sees him also resuscitating verses, in this case from the recent limited edition entitled The Red Limbo Lingo. The new poems here are sufficiently various to make a worthwhile collection, all the same, with Durrell excelling in that mood of sunburnt anti-nice-
ness which suits him like a pirate's patch:
Always at midnight when I hear the chimes,
I tell myself while pouring out a drink,
Things are less complicated than you think.
Dreams, therefore crimes, honey. . .
The three voices of poetry, as defined by Eliot, allow for God (the poet talking to himself, or nobody), and the Cabots (the poet addressing his peers), but not quite for Peter Redgrove and Penelope Shuttle. Their book The Hermaphrodite Album (Fuller d'Arch Smith, Â£2.50) sounds at first like Eliot's third voice-the poet speaking in an imaginary character to another imaginary character-but as monologue follows spell follows litany, and articulation is given to bones and stones and water and fire, you realise that this is an ambitious oracular attempt to speak in all the voices, and at once. What's more, the individual poems come unsigned, so that no one is to know who wrote what. This could lead to pointless confusion, but it doesn't, because Redgrove and Shuttle, both intensely committed to a way of thinking about the world in images-or, more truly, apprehending and recreating the process of the world in images-seem here to have broken through to a single, several-tongued, pentecostal voice which has little to do with the expression of personality. There's a lot of blood, snot, frogs, jewels, and magicking, but don't let this deflect you into suspicions of surrealism. These two poets are about something sacramental, not decorative:
Heal me, I will wash your feet
Forgive me, I am the sinful lamp
Remember me, I am still bleeding The book bears a vital motto, from Goethe: " My work is that of a composite being, which happens to be signed." Each poem in it might be likened to an altar on which gifts of images are offered. But the images have the energy of icons: they become what they represent.
Some of The Hermaphrodite Album remains obscure to me, and repeated readings do little to elucidate the dark places on an intellectual level, yet I would claim that this is a beautiful and important book. Those who look to poetry for spiritual nourishment will find food here. It may not be to their taste, but then the real thing has a way of tasting strange at first.
The magazine Modern Poetry in Translation has been an intelligent enemy of insularity ever since its beginning, 16 issues ago. -he current number, guest edited by Anthony Rudolf, is a bumper book-length job devoted to French poetry (10 Compayne Gardens, London, NWG, 50p). Rudolf's introduction presents a critical view of routes and roots available to English poetry-he directs attention to the work of David Jones and Laura Riding, on the one hand, and to French verse since Mallarme on the other. I am not sure that he has grasped the seriousness of Laura Riding's total rejection of poem-writing as an activity inimical to truth, but he certainly knows his way around the contemporary French scene, and his own translations of such as Jean Paul Guibbert, Alain Veinstein and Yves Bonnefoy are first-rate, and could illuminate contemporary English poetic practice if they obtain the currency they deserve. Also to be commended are Elaine Feinstein's and Graham Martin's versions of poems by Louis-Rene Des Forets, and Rosmarie Waldrop's translation of some difficult texts by Edmond Jabes, who is on this showing unquestionably a major writer. Perhaps Rudolf means only to refer us to Riding's importance in having taken poetry as far as it will go. If that is so, then the French word-adventure which stems from Rimbaud may well provide a parallel alternative worth considering, and this magazine gives a Michelin guide to it, with many good stops in the form of poems. But surely it hasn't escaped Rudolf's notice that Rimbaud gave up poetry also, and went to Africa, where he spoke to neither God nor Cabots, and substituted gunrunning for alchemy ?
Robert Nye

Author: Null
Title: Poetry International
Full_text:
Poetrv International
The sixth Poetry International. from June 25 to June 30, will again be divided betweeii the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Institute of Contemporary Arts. At the Queen Elizabeth Hall on June 29 and 30 poets from six countries will read their own work-preceded where necessary by English translation. Earlier that week, from June 25 to June 28, there will be two programmies nightly at the ICA, at 6.30 pm and 8.30 pm, of a more diversified nature. All 10 programmes will be directed by the Arts Council Literature Director, Charles Osborne. who has worked on the five previous festivals.
Poetry International has presented more than 50 poets from 19 countries, and this year it will have its first South African, Oswald Mtshali. Mr Mtshali lives in Johannesburg and his book of poems, Sounds of a Cowhide Drum, which ran to fivc reprints in South Africa, 'Was published in England last year. He will appear at the Queen Elizabeth Hall on June 29. Other poets at the Queen Elizabeth Hall are W. H. Auden, Basil Bunting, Richard Eberhart. Allen Ginsberg, Chester Kallman, Thomas Kinsella, Huilt MacDiarmid, Vasko Popa, and Peter Porter.
Also at the Queen Elizabeth Hall (on June 30) will be the Greek composer Mikis Theodnrakis, who now lives in Paris. He will be performing his ownI settings of Greek verse-mucb of it written by poets who have been invited over the years to appear at Poetry Interniational but who have been unable to accept.

Author: Alderson, Brian
Title: Classics for kids
Full_text:
Classics for kids
The Oxford Book of Children's Verse
Chosen and Edited with Notes by Iona and Peter Opie
(Clarendon Press, Â£2.25)
In the beginning there was coInAsel and exhortation. Manners at table and a care for one's Immortal Soul may not seem to have much in common, but to the earliest writers who directed verse at children they shared one important advantage: a devout honesty of purpose could make up for much deficiency of style (or, as T. S. Eliot said in an altogether different context: "The poetry does not matter").
Later, the options widened. In the fifteenth century the grace of a poem like "Covetousness" seems a marvellous accident. In the sixteenth century the anonymous "Unhappy Schoolboy" catches only briefly the liveliness and wry humour of his tribe, so long accustomed to having their tails peppered "with good speed". But as the child comes to figure more in men's -thoughts and sympathies, so, through Herrick and Smart, Ronksley, Marchant and the ever-present anonymous rhymsters, lightness and wit become an acceptable -ingredient. in the child's own verse.
Undoubtedly one of the most welcome features, of Iona and Peter Opie's new anthology is the view it gives of the emergence of what, in terms of craftsmanship, is one of the most delicate and difficult of .all poetic modes. They have not set out merely to assemble a lot of poems that will be enjoyed by children today-the market, happily, is well-stocked with such offerings. Nor have they sought to provide a definitive collection of all that is best (under such terms it would be harfd to justify the inclusion of, let us say, Henry Dixon's "Descrption of a Good Boy " and the omission of EDdward Lear's l)ong). Instead they have tried to chart the evolution of the poet's attitude to writing verse special-ly r for children-the object being " to make available in one place the classics of children's poetry ", while also recognizing that even if these have not always stood the test
of time they were at least "cherished in their own day ".
Few attempts have been made in the past eo construct
an anthology on quite the same. principles as this, and certainly none ias been compiled with the same care as to chronological arrangement and bibliographical annotation. In consequence it is possible to draw from the collection a fuller sense than before of the -hesitancy, the sententiousness and even the bravura that have all gone into the poet's work in finding a voice for ,t he poem that [he wants to twrite. it is fascinating, for instance, to observe the gradual appearance in -the corpus- of children's poetry of lullabies and ballads, emblems and nursery rhymes. nature poems and poerns imitative of the child's own voice, and then to watch the developrnent or decline of their form. How consistent we seem to have been in prayers and hymns, and what pleasure we have had in standing the cautionary ,tale upon its solemn, unenlightened head.
Furthermore, i.f one takes The Oxford Book of Children's Verse in context with such other books by.its compilers as The Lore and. Language of Schoolchildren or The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes, it is possible to see more. clearly how much the child's education in poetic enjoyment derives from the street songs and graffiti, the nursery rhyimes and playground chabts of npopular tradition. While the experience of generations has b.een enriched by- the incantatory iHow many miles to Babylon " or the energet,ic " My mother said ", the earnest adult composer has all too often got stuck in homilies jagainst nosepicking or unconvincing assertions that there are fairies at the bottom of the garden.
For this reason, the cursory treatment of the twentieth century and decision to exclude all living poets Awho have written for children is much to be regretted. In the interests of balance it is just possible to accept the comparatively modest representation of. ICipling and De La Marey Farjeon and Milne, but how much more could have been shown of the persistence of tradition . if Robert Graves.or James Reeves had been allowed a voice ? And what could we have learnt of experimentation, or nonsense, or even of manners, if room had been made for Ian Serraillier, and. Spike Milligan, and the retiring Professor of .Poetry at Oxford?
Brian Alderson

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry and commitment
Full_text:
Poetry and commitment
The first poli*ical poem in English is Piers Plowman. Chaucer was a feudalist, Milton defended regicide, Marvell's satires spawned the Whigs. Shelley sealed his letters with a revolutionary wafer and Blake vore a red cap in the streets at the time of the French Revolution. lIt will be seen that political commitment among poets did not start yesterday. Today, of course, we have Auden disowning his pink past on the grounds that his own poems did not save a single Jew from the gas chamber, but we also have a number of younger poets-not all of them noisy-who would say that this is no reason for not writing poems about the Jews and the concentration camps. Several of the best of these poets have been associated with the quarterly magazine Stand, begun in 1952, which now celebrates its coming of age with an anthology Poetry of the Committed Individual (Gollancz, Â£3.20 hardback, or Penguin, 35p), edited by its presiding'spirit Jon $ilkin.
There is some excellent writing in this book, not least in translation-work by Blok, Voznesensky, Brecht, all in versions by poets.' We almost expect foteign poets to be political, though, and the surprise comes when we encounter a poem as good and as English as Geoffrey Hill's " Funeral Music ", which makes an anatomy of history while fulfilling both halves of Silkin's clever title, being comniitted and individual. That Hill's subject is the Battle of Towton, 1461, and not Belsen, might have a lesson in it. Could be that it takes poetry about 500 years to translate time into meaning ? Hill's more recent-minded; poem "September Song "-bearing the epigraph. "born *19.6.32, deported 24.9.42 "-seerfts. to me less achieved, less true. It depends'upon its epigraph, needs this detail,, where C"Funeral Music" has another kind of capacity: to move the reader to tears-the. caioacity of' being history purified to the' point where it is no loniger the details that appall,'but the total act of 'meaning-' which is the,'poem itself. : , '
I wish Auden were among the contributors to The Hotue That Jack- Btilt edited by Brian Patten'and Pat Krett (Allen & Unwin, Â£2.50; paperback, 85p),
for no other reason than that all royalties from this book go to Shelter, the National Campaign for the Homeless, and that if your poems cannot save lives it might be some comfort to think of them giving roofs.
Forgive the cruder note sounded by contributors here. It seems that some were asked for poems "expressing the agony of slum life ", others drew inspiration from Shelter's own report " Condemned ", and in any case it is difficult to keep your temper when -you think of the one and a half million inhabited dwellings in this country which have been officially designated as unfit for human beings.
Besides, if there are poems here which do justice only to the passionate feelings that have unbalanced them, tlhere are. rather more which speak out against injustice and indifference in society with an effectiveness that is certainly not due to rhetoric on behalf of a political party. I am thinking especially of Edwin Morgan's Glasgow sonnets, Philip Hobsbaum's rvecalling of a violently ulrban chlildhood, and George Mackay Brown's Nativity poem which mllakes the opposite of the polit all too often made in sermons.
A new magazine which has nolw run albeit slowly to three issues and grown increasingly dedicated to the question of the moral justification of poetry is the reviewJ Ishmael, edited by Francis Boylan (60p, Librairie de la Presse, 6 Place Clemenceau, 64-Biarritz). The solutions implied by Ishmael go. deeper - than politics or humanitarianism. It seems that here at last-for the first time since Eliot's Criterion ?-is. a magazine which supposes very seriously indeed that if poets are required to " do good " then the good which they can best be required to do is pobms..
Early issues, had poems by George Barker, Xathleen Raine, Peter Levi, and C. H. Sisson, as well as *some xictra6rdinarily penetrating critical essays by the last named. The latest has nine unpublished poemg by that excellent poet Patrick Kavanagh, and a long essay on him by Boylan. Ishmel is committed to. "speech joined to spirit",; its party is poetry; join it.
Robert Nye

Author: Ratcliffe, Michael
Title: A delicate lack of rant
Full_text:
BOOKS r0 t r .. .
, _ _ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~I(
A delicate lak of r ant
The Oxford Book of Twentieth Century English Verse
Chosen by Philip Larkin
(Clarendon Press/Oxford, Â£3)
This is a very important book. It contains 584 poems by poets from Wilfrid Scawen Blunt to Brian Patten, and it has no precedent in range or scale. Like all Oxford anthologies it will carry with it something like the force of law, influencing the taste and lives of at least one generation of readers. Like all anthologies of poetry since the world began it will be vigorously strafed by other poets and anthologists wvho feel they could have done better: if the cadres of English poetry have run true to form, you won't see the sky for the shrapnel by next Sunday morning. Fear not, it is perfectly safe to buy The Oxford Book of Twventieth Century English Verse. Mr Larkin has done an incredibly difficult job well.
He keeps his cover. Not for this compiler the barricade stand of Al Alvarez and Michael Roberts, or the imperial tone of the aging Yeats ("I have stood judgment UpoIn Wilde, bringing into the light a great, or almost great, poem. . . . ") In a tiny Preface of less than a page and a half, promising "w vide rather than deep representation ". Mr Larkin drily states his business and is gone:
I found my materials fell into thlree groups; poems representirng aspects of the talents of poets jiudged either by the age or by myself to be worthy of inclusion, poems judged by me to be worthty of inclusion weithout reference to their authors, and poems judged by me to carry woith them something of
the censti,y in- wlitch tzey were wntten.
That's your lot. It is an indication of procedure rather than a confession of faith. Into Mr Larkin's first group go, aMong amaniy others, " The Waste Land" and "Little Gidding"; "The Lake of Innisfree" and "' Easter 1916"; " Sea Fever ",, "Anthem for Doomed Youth" and "Do not go- gentle -into. that good night"; Hardy's "I Channel Firing ", MacNeice's " Bagpipe Music " and De la Mare's "All that's past ":
Oh, no man knows
Throzsgh what wild centtures Roves back t1te rose
Group Two contains good single poems by poets wlho may not have produced a notable oeztvre or by writers whose ilain achievement lies elsewhere: I liked especially Herbert Palmer's splendid " Rock Pi9grim ", " The Great Moth " by Robert Gittings, tlle brillinntly ftnny " Encounter " by Edgell Rick-vord and Noiil CoNvard's " Boy Actor ". Some rather silly poems get in here, too, like Isherwood's C" On His Queerness " and Alan Ross's apostrophe to Sir Stanley Matthevs :
Hcid of a Penrgino. uwth faint flare Of the n0ostrils, as thzotuh Lippizancr-Zk
he srniffed at the nir,
F4-indintg it goodi beneath himn, h draws.
That kind of thing could give soccer a bad namue, never miind poetry.
croup Three, " poetns carrying somethiig of the centuy in wvhiich they were written '. vill, I think, prove wore trichly enjoyable in the long rxntt. As the best of his own work would lead us to ekpect, Milr Larkin shows a taste for poems about dolly birds, railwuy's nnd the conimon round of pirovin-
gial and suburban life; but here, too, is. Arthur Waley, ruefully employed in the wartime Censor's Office. J. B. S. Haldane joking about his cancer operation to encourage the others ("A rare example of the-truly public poem"), Paul Dehn's superbly long-limbed `Armistice" of 1945, and the vigorous exchange between a sceptical Alex Comfort (writing
nder the name of 'Obadiah Iornbrooke') and a majestic George Orwell on the priorities of protest and service in the Second World *War. Kingsley Amis ticking off Jesus, Adrian Mitchell on provisions for genocide, Adrian Henri jollying us along. There are very fewv Bomb poems, actually,, perhaps because Peter Porter's (" Your Attention Please ") is so frighteningly precisee
Ret?lember to press the sealing Switch when everyjone is in
The shelter. Set the radiation
Aerial, turn on the geiger barometer.
Turm Off your Television notw.
More than half the wvork in Tlze Oxford Book of Twentieth Centzury English Verse belongs -to writers borni before 1900. Poets today under the age of 50 account for only 80 of the 625 pages: these figures certainly indicate caution but, considering the astonishing profusion of 20th century talent born in the last 40 years of the 19th century shey should not surprise us nnd I don't think they can
iirly. be described, as they have been, as "reactionary ". J. C. Squire earns his place, even if Alfred Noyes does not.
Most alitlhologists stake out agnreed lines on the great central territory of Hardy, Yeats, Eliot and Audeni. Beyond that the wvidest opportunities for disagreement are exercised. Larkin adds to his centre Kip-
ling,; Lawrence-and Betieman. The latter's very funny "Diary of a Church Mouse" would be welcorie. in any collection of English verse, but he is then extravagantly over^represented by ten further poems, plus a great chunk of Sui77moned by Bells:, he occupies much mnore space than HIousman, MacDiarmid, MacNeice, Graves, Spender or Day-Lewis, and nearly as much as Yeats. I would have willingly traded three or four Beejemans for the inclusion of W. 3L Rodgers and David Jones.
It is impossible to say howv Mlr Larkin's last 80 pages will look after another 15 years; Geoffrey Grigson's own P>oetry of the Present (-1949) gave great prominence to a number of poets-Hubert Nicholson, Derek Stanford, Norman Nqicholson-who have not surfaced by so 'much as a single p,oem in Larkin; and others, like Charles Madge and Druxh-mond Allison, who have only done just that.
I hope that future editions will increase the representation of Basil Bunting (although we already have the magnificent ' Chomei at Toyama" complete), Donald Davie, and Geoffrey Hill, whilst amending that of Gunn to include at least "tCarnlal Knowledge " and "A Mirror for Poets " as Alvarez does in Thze Newo Poch-y. But if all anthologists have the duty to include certain poems they don't much like, they also have the privilege of choosing some that hardly anyonle else will. Mdr Larkcin has discharged both duty and privilege with a de'licate lack of rant, and we shall be delightedly in his debt for many years tO come.
Michael Ratcliffe

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry
Irishmen and others
I met Patrick Kavanagh just once. He told me that he had cancer. lie seemed cheerful about it, pointing out that some Irish officials had awarded him a pension when the disease was confirmed. "Like a prize each year until I die ", he said. 'The prospect of.cheating officialdom gave him a reason for living. In fact he lived on for five years. r hope the prizes didn't stop.
I have just seen the reprint of his Collected Poems (Martin, Brian & O'Keeffe, Â£1) and realized what a good poet he is. much more various than memories- of the early verse allowed for. This book runs from the. lyrical simplicities about tinkers and blackbirds which he wrote while still scraping a living from a farm in Monaghan, through the long poem about Ireland which made his reputation and brought the police to his door (The Great Hunger), to the parish of gossip about matters df life and death which constitutes the later poems.
Intuitive, epigrammatic, shrewd, Kavanagh is always the peasant, seeing how much he can get away with, returning again and again to a handful of themes perceived as underlying all creation. Here is a complete short poem which gives his authentic flavour, "Sanctity ":
To be a poet -and not know the
trade,
To be a lover and repel all women;
Twin ironies by which great saints
arie made,
The agonizing pincer-jaws of
Heaven.
Seamus Heaney and Stewart Conn are two younger poets, one Irish, one Scottish, whose work also derives from a strong sense of place. Heaney's Wintering Out (Faber, Â£1 paperback) is impressive for the accurate quality of its observation-snipe " stagger in air ", a diseased fish turits to face the current and "its whole head opened like a valve ", cocklebeds on the shore are seen as " white pocks " and porpoises cartwheel " like the flywheels of the tide, /Soapy and shining ".
If your pleasure in poetry favours the felicitous phrase then Heaney is your man; Conn, though, seems to me to have a more complicated and rewarding talent. The poems in An Ear to the Ground (Hutchinson, Â£1 paperback) draw upon Ayrshire and Highland mnemories, and evoke "the still heron on his stalk " and so forth, but this poet is after something stranger than activated descriptions and what looks like a book of people and place poems is in effect a book of love poems. The metaphors are found in urban experience too, and those familiar with the peculiar autumnal seediness of Glasgow's West End-all leaves, decaying terraces, and a river which " runs like stinking lard " -will recognize the justice of its presence here. Conn frets away at dark states of mind and the heart's unease in terms Iof landscapes .patched with shadow.
Warrior's Career (Macmillan, Â£2), Alan Brownjohn's fourth book of poems, shows him redeploying his faculties to fashion a kind of verse which can deal with what he calls "beautiful, living ordinariness ". He is a rather smarter, snappier Larkin. Television sets left on in shop windows, black cigarettes, the sadness of barstools-Brownjohn's props are impeccably upto-date, and if just occasionally there is a sense of the objects crowding out the thought there is more often an agreeable ease of manner and reference.
The same goes for George MacBeth, whose latest collection Shrapnel (Macmillan, Â£2) returns to what has always been !the most fertile of his several inspirations-that which occasions in him a style of dandified celebration of odd animals and vegetables : " To The Master of This Book, The Lord Gorilla " " The Lesser Horned Artichoke ", "The North American Whooping Carrot ", etc. MacBeth even includes a litany, a hymn, and a spell. The Lady Sycorax presides. Whether the poet is posing as Ariel or Caliban is not clear.
Prayers and other offices addressed unplayfully to God make up the substance of John Berryman's posthumous Delusionzs, Etc (Faber, Â£1.50), a book which has upset some critics, quite understandably, by reason of its Christianity.
Let m4e be clear about this. It is
plain to me Christ underwent man & treachlery . ~~~~~& socks & lashes, t72irst, exhaustifon, the bit, for my pathetic & disgusting
This is evangelical to the point of hysteria, but I can see no need to runa for the cover of literary sophistication.. The ambiguity of " socks " is even brilliant, in context: does he mean blows and/or the tokens of male humanity we suffer upon our feet ? Christ may be said to have undergone the pain of such trivia, in being made flesh, as well as. the more obvious pain of t'he scourging before the crucifi%ion. Tbheimage is oiily grotesque or bizarre if your knowledge of Christ echludes the contemporary. Donne would not have eschewed it, nor Hopkins, nor foi that ma-tter Patrick Kavanagh.
. . .~~~~~~~~
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Revisiting areas of talent already perfected
Full_text:
Poetry
*Revisiting areas of talent already oerfected
Poems 1970-1972
By. Robert Graves.
(Cassell, Â£1;90)
I love. therefore I am'
Robert Graves's formula, twicegiven, in English and Latin, at the end of a new poem called Five, might well be preferred to the usual Descartian modegty. The difference between loving arfd thinking has always exercised his mind to some tune. Once he wrote poems about. it which exercised the heart also-" Pure Death ", "The Cool ,Web ", "The Terraced Valley ". There is nothing of that quality or intensity in his latest volume of verse, Poems 1970-1972, 79 pieces which are required to add to his Collected Poems (1965) as two sections.
The shape of the love poems in the first section is much what we have come to expect of Graves-events are elegantly examined for their deposit of myth, unanswerable questions are posed, a special rhetoric stands between the poet and his experience. The poems of " contemporary comment" are slighter in content, and more obvious in their rhythms.. The book as a whole is testamentary to the manner in which Graves has perfected a formal and satisfying poetic idiom immediately recognizable as his ownand no one should underestimate his craftsmanship, the dues he owes to what he once called "a devil of verse" who prompts him how "to evade the patent clumsiness of truth ". The sadness is in how far that idiom lies from living speech. He sounded better when he stammered more, his heart in his mouth, his head less sure of what it thought it knew.
lain Crichton Smith is a hard poet to pin down with critical tacks. A habit of elusiveness seems second nature to him, not least where he is most local and rooted in his own Scottish landscape. His Hebrides lie perhaps just west of. the human heart, and the deer on his high hills are thoughts. Not that intellect Qr emotions obtrude, but married as they are in his best poems they breed images at a great rate and then he gives a sense o thinking at the nib of his pen, working on the page, writing like Forsteirs old woman in order to see what it is that he wants to say. His new book Love Poems & Elegies (Gol. lancz, Â£1.50) is very much in character, a kind of outpouring checked by craftiness. An unhappy love affair and the death of the poet's mother have provided the inspiration for these pieces, but it seems no injustice to Smith's sincerity to suggest that as shown here those events are occasions for diffusion rather than concentration.
* If Smith had not taken care to inform us of the two wounds, it would have been possible to suppose that all the blood came from one place. All the same, I recommend Love Poems and Elegies as an antidote to all those many modern collections consisting of poems about poems, poems about paintings, and poems translated from other poems. You can. taste the real in Sinith's writing.
You can feast on it (and choke too, if you don't look out) in Peter Redgrove's Dr Faust's Sea-Spirhl. Spirit (Routledge, Â£1.50; paperback, 75p). Here are poems about stones and water and sand and iroll and shadows, poems concerned with entropy and metamorphosis,
poems. so thick in the stuff of the natural world that they make even pantheism interesting-though I wish Redgrove would see the sense of Chesterton's remark that nature is our elder sister, not our mother, and use his mind a bit more to make distinctions between himself and bacon, human love and the force that drives the green fuse through the etcetera. Redgrove's self-identifying with the Protean characteristics of the shape-shifting Welsh mythological hero Taliesin gives the biggest clue to what he is about. Read the book as one long poem, and that poem as an encounter with information about the physical world presented in terms of rhythm. It is certainly exciting.
Philip Hobsbaum's. Women and Animals (Macmillan, Â£2) and R. S. Thomas's H'm (Macmillan, Â£2) will appeal, on the other hand, chiefly to those who already know these poets by better work past-published, for there is an air in both volumes of revisiting areas of talent already perfected-in Hobsbaum's case, the poem of ruthless self-accusation, in Thomas's, the poem to justify the ways of God to Job.
I suggest that Norman Nicholson's A Local Habitation (Faber, Â£1 paperback) or. Donald Davie's Collec,ted Poems 1950-70 (Routledge, Â£3.75) are better buys, the Nicholson because it shows, a good minor poet exploring his patch for the first time in depth, the Davie because it reminds us again of the elegant way he wore his neo-Augustan corset in the good old days of Brides of Reason (1955) and A Winter Talent (1957), singing the sofa and the hare and the difficulty of finding suitable accommodation for the Muse at Cambridge. Stylish manners suited Davie. Alas, he has now moved on.
Style is also the word for the work in Jorge Luis Borges' Selected Poenms 1923-67 edited by Norman Thomas di Giovanni (Allen Lane, the Penguin Press, Â£5), which prints Spanish and English on facing pages and gives us more than 100 of the poems which this master mazemaker considers his best. Borges' talent is essentially for the parable and the puzzle. He has a bibliography where his heart should be. One might be excused therefore for finding the prefaces and notes more intdresting that the verses.
Signs of Life is the first hardcover collection by a 50-year-old Huddersfield schoolteacher, Stanley Cook, whose merits I noticed when he published a pamphlet called Form Photograph last year. This comes from an unfamiliar publisher (E. J. Morten, Â£1.25, Warburton Street, Didsbury, Manchester 20). He writes a flat, unpre. tentious, uncomfortable kind of poem, usually starting in some incident of his own life, or the social history that has shaped him, and. he has the advantage of never being slick or glib, so that the words really work for their keep within the lines, and the awkwardnesses of technique match the unsentimental intensity of what he has to say.
The key poems here are the -ones on Rembrandt and Sheffield, particularly - the six stanzas on " The Cholera Monument, Sheffield," which strike me as remarkable. Cook is earnest, deliberate, and utnderivative, an unassuming poetwho vill probably never be famous;: but I think he is authentic.
Robert Nye
