Author: Ratcliffe, Michael
Title: Restoring passion, grandeur and public life in poetry
Full_text:
BOOKS
Restoring passion, grandeur and public life in poetry
The New Oxford Book of Enelish Verse
Edited by Helen Gardner
(Oxford, Â£3.25)
T. Sturge Moore is gone, with his flowers nodding gaily, scent in air. Gone, too, the Scoutish exhortations of Henr y Charles Beeching (b 1859) and William Watson's horrid little "Song": April, April,
Laugiz tlhy girlish laughter; Then, tl2e moment after, Weep thy girlish tears!
The inclusion of such poets and their work in Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch's original Oxford Book of English Verse (1901) reflects less on Q's particular judgment-though he favoured the faery-than on one basic problem facing every verse anthologist: the treatment, if anly, of contemporaries whose work is still in progress. Q's 1939 revision still contained no Eliot, and the only general survey to presemt the twentieth century fairly and squarely in
the context of its predecessors has been John Hayward's Penguin Book of English Verse (1956)-excellent, but with 450 poems in all, offering a limited selection.
Dame Helen Gardner's New Oxford Book of English Verse starts again from scratch, includes less than half of Q's choice, is twice as long as Hayward, and brings English poetry up to the last war. At which point she draws a fairly firm line, declining either to take Q's risks or to hedge bets like Palgrave: Fuller si Larkin no. She takes Hardy, Hopkins, Yeats and Eliot as the four major poets of the last hundred years and gives ample representation to each: 22 poems by Hardy, 11 by Hopkins (including " The Wreck of the Deutschland" complete); 16 by Yeats; and for Eliot six, a misleading number since it includes The Waste Land and "Little Gidding" uncut.
For the rest, MacNeice is clearly her favourite and ringingly speaks the Epilogue to the whole book, with his "Fanfare for the Makers" who preceded
him: "To make is such. Let us make." I regret Dame Helen's exclusion of Auden's marvellous " 1st September 1939 " (Hayward has it) but she retains the magical " Lullaby " and, true to MacNeice's " cloud of witnesses ", suggests the common tradition that unites their testimony with two other Auden poems"Musee des Beaux Arts ", with its reverberance of Browning, and the grand funeral ode for Yeats:
Follow, poet, follow right
To thze bottom of thze night,
With your unconstraining voice Still persuade us to rejoice.
The common tradition: to rejoice, to celebrate, to argue, to persuade. The most stimulating aspect of Dame Helen's selection is the gloriously positive view it offers of the English poetic achievement: her poets stand up and are counted. To develop and balance this view she has omitted American verse entirely -presumably Oxford will publish a large nmodern selection in due course--and she has rejected that declared preference for the lyrical which inspired all earlier anthologists.
It is not too much to say that she has revolutionized the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries entirely. The representation of Spenser and jonson is up 50 pei- cent ; of Donne, Herbert, Dryden, Blake, Byron, Tennyson and Rossetti it has doubled; there is five times more Pope than in 1901 (16 poems, or extracts from poems, as against three). Many of these changes, of course, reflect common twentieth century shifts of taste and reputation; more significant, because less immediately obvious and more personal to Dame Helen's historic theme, is the radical reordering of choice within the work of a poet whose numerical representation remains roughly the same.
L'Allegro and 11 Penseroso, for example, are replaced by three dramatic extracts from Paradise Lost Books I, IV and XII and by "On the Late Massacre in Piedmont ", Milton's far from pastoral reaction to the murder of the Waldensians in 1655, a superb piece of State poetry by which Cromwell sought to rouse the conscience
of Protestant Europe - " Avenge, 0 Lord, thy slaughtered saints. . .". Compare this with Shelley on England in 1819: " Rulers who neither see, nor feel, nor know / But leechlike to their fainting country cling ".
Dame Helen honours the forthright, the poet who speaks his mind not merely to his fellow-citizens, but to his lover and to God. There is more great love poetry and religious verse here than in any previous anthology and, perhaps because they excelled at both, Donne and Dry. den are its first heroes. Sir Arthur was a gentle knight, shied away from Donne's ravish. ing God, from the button-holing prayers and the kingly proclamations of love and marriagebed; he interrupted "Ecstasy" after five stanzas, thus reducing it to the merely pretty: none of those body-and-soul meetings for him.
Dryden he clearly thought of as a Restoration intimiste and charming versifier. In restoring to us Dryden's grandeur and passion, Damne Helen rejects that picture perhaps too thoroughly, but we do now have the withering attack on Shadwell and those on Shaftesbury and Buckingham in Absalomn and Achitophel, the generous tribute " To the Memory of Mr Oldham ", all of Alexander's Feast, and the extraordinary vision of London's mercantile millennium arising from the ashes of the Great Fire.
Pope had one poem-the short " Solitude "-in Palgrave's Golden Treasury, and it is astonishing that even Q should have ignored " A little learning is a dangerous thing" and "Know then, thyself, presume not God to scan ". But Pope was above all the poet of public life and such a man meets the needs of our own time and
Pope: a central figure
his own rather than the century in between. The whole mighty. glittering and unpleasant sequence is here. Pope's place in The Newv Oxford Book of English Verse is not merely a chronological one: he is central to it in every possible way.
The rehanging of Wordsworth, on the other hand, is a little odd: we gain, predictably, more Prelude and the poem to Toussaint l'Ouverture, but we lose most of the sequence Q called " England, 1802 " which, invoking Milton and anticipating Shelley, Eliot and Auden, might have been thought to exemplify Dame Helen's vision of the poet as prophet to perfection. Blake, Byron, Tennyson and Browning are all encouraged to fire their heavy guns again, to greater effect. And so to Arnold and Hardy and Hopkins: the poet in public, the poet in love and the poet with God.
It should be stressed that, whilst this is a personal and didactic anthology it is also by far the most balanced and most wide-ranging we have, offering superlative value to almost every taste. It is generous to poets-like Wyatt, Campion, Housman or Edward Thomaswho might not be swimming down its great central stream. Its attention to detail is a delight: it takes good care to answer Goldsmith's too-familiar Deserted Village with the magnificent Crabbe, and to counter Mordaunt's "Sound, sound the clarion, fill the fife ! " with John Scott's angry lament on the human wastefulness of eighteenth-century conscription. It is never solemn.
Let the end lie with one of the humbler witnesses: Winthrop Mackworth Praed (1802-1839). Journalist, barrister and member of Peel's first Cabinet, Praed was a vigorous versifier. Or so one sees now: Q represented him with an exceedingly wet " Fairy Song ", but Dame Helen knows what barristers and MPs are about, even versifying ones, and, with Praed's " Good-night to the Season ! ", she effects a three-page rescue which sweeps the reader off his feet.
Michaet Ratcliffe

Author: Howard, Philip
Title: The Good Poetry Guide, 1972
Full_text:
The Good Poetry
Guide, 1972
The New Oxford Book of English Verse, known prosaically to its intimates Rs ANOBEV, is published today, daughter of the classic anthology that has sold nearly 900,000 copies in two editions since 1900 and pupped a prolific and.handsome litter of other Oxford boqks of poetry of different periods and countries.
The process of selecting such an anthology has been changed radically since Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch made his choice of " the best " English verse written between 1250 and 1900, which at the time seemed durable enough to outlive m'arble, the gilded monuments of princes and the shifting taste of fashion. Three fatctors, at least, have combined to change it. First, another 50 years, exceptionally rich and r-evolutionary in poetry, have passed. Secondly and even mote significantly, the map and perspective of poetry have been entirely redrawn by Eliot, Pound and thle modern movement. Thirdly, the selecting has been done this time not by Sir Arthur but by Helen Gardner.
The Merton Professor of English Literature at Oxford has as fine an ear and as deep a learnIng and love for poetry as Sir Arthur, but she is a child~ of her generation and has her indivdual and strong tastes.
in any such collection of "the best " (the phrase has to be shrouded -in inverted commas these self-conscious days, or it seems priggish), of the fadeless flowers of English verse, about half the entries choose themselves. It simply has to include h-hall I compare thee to a summet's day ? and, regrettably some may think, Hail to thee, Blithe Spirit. The next quarter of the entries in the new anthology are not unexpected. The idiosyncrasy of the anthologist shines in the' lat quarter.
When Sir Arthur made his selection, he deliberately restricted himself to numbers " either- lyrical or epigrammatic", following in the- footprints through the dewy meadows of lyric of that other great Victorian anthology, Palgrave's Golden Treasury. This restriction entailed little Donne, less Pope, no Swift, and the representation of poets such as Dryden, Byron, Tennyscn and Browning solely by their lyrics. It meant leaving out such famous poems, characteristic of their authors' best work, as Ulysses, My Last Duchess and Dover Beach.
Sir Arthur's idiosyncrasy also allowed him sometimes to prefer "the more beautiful to the better attested reading "; and he did not scruple to excise weak or superfluous stanzas, without mentioning what he had done, " when sure that excision would improve ".
Times and tastes have changed. Dame Helen Gardner won her scholarship to St Hilda's in 1926 wvith papers on Donnp and Milton, poets usually .supposed to be antipathetic. Her, reputation as one of the most perceptive and witty of the twentieth-century scholars of English literature is largely founded on her editing of Donne and her critical writings about Eliot, whose- work she has always loved (her book includes the whole of The Waste Land and Little Gidding).
Dame Helen was invited to select and edit the book about 10 years ago. Just as this happened she was commissioned to write'several other books and to serve on the Robbins Committee on Higher Education. But in her spare time, in what she describes unpersuasively as a desultory way, she started to re.read all the poets and to make preliminary collections of, for ex-ample, 40 poems by Hardy, which would eventually have to be reduced by half
Then about two years ago she vas awoken in the black and
startled middle of the night'by a telephone call, fortunately not from The Times but from: The Guardian. The wretched, rash, intruding reporter said: ",This is very exciting news that you have been chosen to pick the New Oxford Book bf Eiiglish Verse. Is it true ? P'
Dame Helen was very angry. She .harbours a. suspicion that the call was a plot by the Clarendon Press to force her hand and accelerate her progress. In fact the call did propel heo into the finial stage of preparation of the book on a Hellenic- cruise in 1970. During this-she played a game with the literate crew of passengers and lecturers to be found on such a voyage, by asking them to name'10 poems that wvere not famous but.that they would be sorry not to see included in the Oxford. book. She was pleased to find a rneasure of agreement. Her high quest had 'also been discussed. and the, choices argued through common rooms and the drawing rooms of north Oxford for years.
In September 1971 Mrs Bridget Bertram offered her services as research-. assistant. Final choices' were made.' The complicated mechanical work of checking texts, counting. lines, tracing sources and prepaiing copy for the -press so neatly that no stanza is cut in half by a page was completed in a year; even though Dame Helen had to spend five weeks in. hospital for an operation oh her hip. The new book is the same length as "Q's" revision of 1939, but in physical shape it is longer, more elegant, less squat.
Dame Helen has a conspicuous taste for satire: She also takes the view that a chrono: logical anthology ought to show the reaction of great poets to great events. So she has made room for such series of recurrent themes as Dryden on .the Great. Fire, Eliot on firewvatchers, and MacNeice and Dylan on the Blitz. She particularly regrets that she could not find room for how well Horatius kept the bridge in the brave days of old, but it is such a long poem. Browning, oddly enough, was easy. Of all her choices she is most unhappy, she says, about Kipling. She wanted to have in Queen Elizabeth at her mirror and How far is St Helena from a little child at play ? "But how- can you leave out Recessional ? "
She would like to have included more moderns, but by the, time she had done justice to Yeats, Hardy, Hopkins and Eliot, she was pressed for space. She decided not to pick poems written after 1950 for twVo reasons: first, . she considers that the anthologist should wait until a poet's oeuvre is complete, or she may misrepresent him (" Q " fell into that hazard with Yeats) secondly, "My taste becomes uncertain as I grow older. I do not react so strongly to new material or distinguish as clearly as I did. I have a letter fronm Eliot saying that this happened to one ".
She appears. to know her diverse and beautiful selection of flowers by heart, quoting them with an affection and fire that indicate that her taste is as sure as ever.
NOBEV will inevitably' find its way by school prize-givings, Christmas presents and personal shopping into hundreds of thousands of shelves. Whether it is the only book of poetry in the case, or is surrounded by rank on rank of other poetry, it wvill be an ornament and a luminary there, a constant. source of sweetness and light and wit.'
The New Oxford Book of English Verse, -published by OUP, E3.25.
Philip Howard
RevLew 4t2 Michlael Ratcliffe, page 11 ;

Author: Alderson, Brian
Title: Reasons for few rhymes
Full_text:
Children and books
Reasons for few rhymes
Nursery rhymes past, the truffles dug from Stevenson and Walter de la Mare, where next do children go for their poetry? How often is there an effqkrtless transition between the rhymes of childhood, which come (and stay) with such complete naturalness. and the serious poetry of the adult world in those stout volumes bought by libraries and those slim editions limited to 40 copies ?
The dead hand of "education" is perhaps partly to blame for our growing up to be a nation indifferent to poetry (what, after all, can be worse than Chaucer taught for the sake of the syllabus ?). And perhaps there is a cumulative reaction at work too-for parents and teachers who dislike poetry are not best able to encourage a liking for it among their children. But another reason that has been cited from time to time is simply the dearth of books. The number of poets who have successfully modified their art for children is nothing like the number of novelists, and the children progressing from a natural enjoyment of Hilaire Belloc or Old Possum have too often had to find a way through unprepossessing "treasuries" or "collected works ", which obscure the too few exciting anthologies and single volumes that will keep their enthusiasm alive.
Like nature, though, publishers abhor a vacuum, and the past year or two has seen a marked increase in the number of books of original verse specially written for children. In the past few months this increase has -almost reached the
proportions of an avalanche-- well over a dozen new books and collections having been published-and the sheer quantity of poems raises questions as to the limits of the possible in writing verse for children.
Card Lockhart Smith, in one of the happiest vblumes of the glut, Riding to Canonzbie (Hamish Hamnilton, £1.25),, has kept close to. the experience of her audience by extending and developing the style and rhythms of the nursery rhyme so that her new words and new imaginings do not seem unfamiliar. Her book is cast as an alphabetical sequence of characters (" Ahnabel Avalon " to ' Zebediah Zidcup ") and its success is pointed up by com-, paring her easy, friendly lines with those which George Barker offers us in a like sequence of animals, Alphabetical Zoo (Faber, £1.30). Mr Barker probably has slightly older children in view than does Miss Smith, but this leads to loss rather than gain, in that he seems to--see it as an excuse for clumsy rhythms (which may have been intended to be subtle) and for jokes which are either-forced or else fired briskly over the reader's head.
The poet whose poetry is normally written in expectation of an adult readership often seems to be unsure of his voice when he turns intentionally towards children. This may be of little account with writers like Ogden Nash and David McCord. who have both had new books recently published in this country, and who make few claims, to be anything more pretentious than verbal entertainers, but a poet of the stature of Roy Fuller is altogether more demanding.
His recent collection, Seenz Grandpa Lately ? (Andrd Deutsch, 1.15), is something of a miscellany-some " poems that children might like "-cbmposed occasionally over the last few years and now brought together. Certainly none is em-
barrassing in the way that, say. George Barker's " Rhinoceros " is, but there tends' to be a gap between simplicity of intention and the sophistication of its final expression. When Roy Fuller ceases to be too directly conscious that children may be reading his verses (as in "The Dream '. "Happy Lion ", " The Courts") he. finds a balance between thought and word which paradoxically shows the young reader the possibilities of poetic statement. Elsewhere, though, except for some nice jokes, it is difficult to see the child always keeping pace with the professor.
Nowhere, however, does faith in children's response to poetry seem more optimistic than in Chatto & Windus's new series of "Poets for the Young ", edited by Leonard Clark (whose editorial policy does not seem to be sufficiently definite for it to appear anywhere but on the book-jacket). Two volumes in this series by Michael Baldwin, Hob and Othler Poemzs, and by R. S. Thomas, Yolng and Old (65p each), will certainly present 'an imaginative challenge to young readers", but it is hard to believe that the poems " have been written especially for children". Writing like thisstrong, brusque, ellipticaloffers none of the concessions that make Grandpa a slightly tentative book. At this point, the only criteria for judgment that will do are those for poetry
tolut court.-
* The new book by David McCord is Mr Bidery's Spider Garden (Harrap, £1.40) and the two by. Ogden Nash are The Aniinal Garden and The Crutise of the A ardvar-k (Andre Deutsch, 9p each). Deutsch have also just published Marko's Wedding, a collection of ballad poems by. Ian Serraillier, who is a pastmaster at jerking traditional idiom into a speech pattern that is very much his own.
Brian Alderson

Author: Milner-Gulland, Robin
Title: The chessboard conjurer in human shape
Full_text:
The chessboard conjurer in human shape
Vladimir Nabokov:
Poems and Problems
(Weidenfeld & Nicolson f2.95)
Nabokov made a precocious namo for himself in poetry long before embarking on novels, and has continued (with declining frequency) to turn to it ever since. Less extraordinary than his prose, his poetic oeuvre is none the less important and varied-perhaps too varied, since there are unevennesses of tone and taste (in the earlier work especially) which show through even in this small selection. Gradually overcoming adroit but vapid eclecticism, by the 1930s he had developed a powerful vein of "miniature myths ", lucid yet disturbingly awry visions-worthy to stand beside those of his coeval Leningrad " absurdists ". The latest (1967) and most limpid pQem in this collection is for me the finest.
The poems ate followed by 18 chess problems: included not so as to pad out a thin volume, but programmatically, as a " corollary " to the verse. It wvould be presumptuous for an amateur solver to assess their merit, but they are entertaining (and instructively annotated), wvhile one or two show the expected mailed fist in velvet glove. Yet they sit uneasily with the poems they are to complement: the twvo art-formns are manifestly different, much as Nabokov would desire their similarity, and eager as he is to solicit our attention for the task of the creator in both cases.
For the specialist this book has an extra dimension of great interest; Nabokov has courageously translated his own Russian poems into English. As a polemical theoretician of translation he has done much good in challenging the usual weak rhymed paraphrase of " poetic ' versions: but his own ideal of "iiterality " or " rigid fidelitv"
poses problems which ho does not seem willing to face. Fair enough to proclaim that, from the bundle of elements constituting a poem, only a few can be imitated, and among these prose sense has primacy; another matter to treat literary translation as if it were not irrevocably itself a literary activity.
Concealed " literary " touches are in fact ubiquitous in these versions; because they are not consistently integrated, the results are often banal or embar-assint. There are many deft tums of phrase, but these are counterbalanced by the moments when one has to consult the lucid Russian to clarify the obscurities of the English. His proclivity for inventing words (" racemosa ") or adopting extravagant locutions is a harmless, even amusing literary fad, but runs quite counter to Ihe pretensions of a basically impossible literality
Such awkwardnesses (particularlv rhythmic) in the translations make one suspect simple lack of ear for the cadences of English verse. Yet this is belied by the fluency (once or twice marred by wordiness) of the fourteen English-language poems, which makc a pleasantlv lighthearTed episode in this strange, contradictory but alvays interesting volume. These are sometimes Betjemanesque, sometimes surrealoccasionally (" An Evening of Russian Poetry ") mnemorable and moving.
Detractors of Nabokov wNill detect in this volume much archness, pedantry and self-congratulation. his supporters will relish its wvit and self-assurance. The uncommitted may well find it perplexingly inconsistent. but in its vcry unevennesses should discern a welcome human quality, softening our usual image of Nabokov the faultless and impersonal coniuror.
Robin Milner-Gulland

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Red-handed in a piece of poetry
Full_text:
Red-handed in a piece of poetry
The Lost Ones
By Samuel Beckett
(Calder & Boyars, Â£1.40)
The Lost Ones is Samuel Becketi's own translation of a text which appeared in French for the first time last year under the title Le Depeupletir. It consists of 14 paragraphs. The first 13 were written in 1966; the last, consisting of sentences observably less coherent than what has preceded them, was added in 1970. The whole may therefore be considered as a work predating those other abbreviated texts, Ping and Lessness, which Beckett has published in recent times. In content it seems rather to belong with imaginationi Dead Imagine.
" Abode where lost bodies roam each searching for its lost onc." That is the opening semence. One notes the cunning, the wordwitchery, the Irishness. All those long and short Os. Beckett seems unable to stop himself achieving ihis kind of rhetorical glamour wvhen he brings anything into English, try as he will.
There is inlernal evidence here that he does not try hard enough. The word strid tlence occurs tNvice, on page 3S and again in the penultimate sentence. I he associations are correct in that the word is used of insects. Crickets and grasshoppers are stridulous, meaning that they produce a shrill, grating sound. But the action of the verb to stridulate is defined in the OED only as stridilarion. sfridulous,zess or sbrididlency, and the third of these is observed to be both obsolete and rare. Beckett is caught redhanded in a piece of poetry. He has coined his s!rideldence because it sounds better in context than the correct usage.
The initial sentence, quoted above, is interesting also for its romanticism. There is a tension throughout the text between a mood which could be called wet and a mind which seeks assiduously to give every appearance of dryness. A place is described. It is the inside of a cylinder. In the cylinder are persons (including a white-haired woman with a child which is referred to as a ,iiie). and ladders, and niches and tunnels. There is a dearth of f'oor space. There ire vibrations. Copulations occur. T-he reader may wobble between wondering if he is being invited to contemplate limbo or the Masters and Johnston sex laboratory. However, a lack df action suggests that the latter is unlikely.
Dante is mentioned a little way into the second paragraPh. Like that poet, Beckett has laboured to find working structures for
things difficult to think '. 1 here are other resemblances, and I hazard a guess that when all these residua are put togetlher it may be seen that Beckett has been about a piece of disquisition the more metaphysical for its insistence on a symmetry of arrangements, for its mention of incidents which are nol permitted to modify a narrative of ideas, and for its rather musical method of progress. The Lost One.s is not the first Beckett text which has borne as it were the air of being a kind of conical footnote to the Comnmedia.
Robert Nye

Author: Nye, Robert
Title: Commonwealth verse: in the thick of a war of images
Full_text:
(ommonwealth verse: in the thick of a war of imqge.c
Commonwealth verse. It sounds like a spedies of influenza and often it is. The wildly hospitable Australian Poetry 1971, for instance (Angus & Robertson, Â£1.50), contains little of interest. "Hell take freak poetres; I like good verse", declares one ultra-robust contifibutor, anmous aBs are so many of his compatriots to prove that his culture is in the right place, 'but wth some few exceptions the poems included here are neither f-reakish nor good, jst sad indications that the English I anthologies of the fifties have at
last ireached Australia by sea-mail and been swallowed whole.
Judith Wright's " Hal-%way " i s one of the exce,p6ons, a poem sooted in somathing peculiarly Australian, exercising its wit on the local event to confirm more general and important possibilities;
,t saw a tadpole once in a sheet of
ice
(a freakist Joke played by my
couitry s weather). He hung at arrest, displayed as it
were in glass, an illustration of neither one thing
nor the other. The tadpoiles are busy thro,ughout the book, alas for the most part with pens instead of tails, writing vea-ses iThustrative of nothing much save the faet Ihat the English language won't quite fit the Australian landscape. Peter Porter looks high-lass in this company.
The editor of Australian Poetry, Chris Wallace-Crabbe, turns up again with a book all his oxvn, Where the Wind Came (Angus & Robertson, Â£1.50), as does another contributor, Roland Robinson, with Selected Poems (Angus & Robertson, Â£1.25). Robinson has an engaging line in flora and fauna and aboriginal myths, but the first line of the first poem
runs " I made my verses of places where I made n.:v Fires " and manufacture is indeed apparent everywhere, the poems so many fancies constructed upon observation. Wallace-Crabbe spares us at least the stockwhip and the swag (see Robinson's " Grendel " for perhaps the most inappropriate employment of these properties ever); his is a more sophisticated, various, and subtle voice.
The variety seems a bit bewildering. How many WallaceCrabbes are there ? The better poems are possessed by a single speech-rhythm, however, and among these I'd count " Evening at San Miguel" and "Signs "-a delicate tribute to Paul Klee-as wholly successful. Elsewhere his inventiveness certainly subserves a serious intent, but the effect is ventriloquial.
Turninsg from Australia to Canada, it is a pleasure to note
the devotion to poetry of FTed Cogswell, a university professor in Now Brunswick, wvho ran a little magazine single-handed in that couatry for 14 years and since 198I1 has iploughed back much of his salary into the publishing of Fiddlchead Poetry Books, completelv without subsidy or other official encouragement. I have to admit that l can't always see the merit in the verse he publishes, but the two latest books from this source are wvorth seek:ing out. These are Cogswell's own The Chains of Lillipat and More Poems by Gil Orlovitz. both obtannable direct from the publisher at the Departmen;t of English, University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, NB, Canada, the former costing 50 cents and the latter two dolLars. Cogswell writes an attractively unpretentious poetry obviously inspired by personal expe6ience.
There is nothing flushed or verbose about him, and his ambition rarely exceeds his abilities. Orlovitz, on, the other hand, takes on the world in poem after poem, and the effect is occasionally as incong-ruous as po.or John Clare in the madhouse imagining he was " Boxer Byron, made of iron " The intcrcsLing thing about Orlovitz, thoxugh, is that in the thick of a war of images you suddenly find him making straightforward statements of the most qpeaceful simplicity, as at the end of this sonnet about his mother's death:
The oxygen's turning grey, she said, my feet are down to earih. she said, and tnrning black-I can dye my shoes black, she said, and walk alongside my hearse, she laugihed. She recogniized ine from photographs.
Orlovitz needs to be read in bulk. This way, the darkest of his poems throw light on each other.
William Plomer, born in South Africa nearly seventy years ago, has never exhibited that kind of cxuberance characteristic of other South African poets such as Roy Cqmpbell and David Wright. He is a careful, even an arid, Ironist, at his finest in the social satires which he disguises as balladds. His new book Celebrations (Cape, Â£1) contains a number of fastidious exercises on public themes, and a handful of more pemonal and gentle poeTns, mostly in looser conversational rhythms, amongst which "No identity" is remarkable. Plomer's indifference to modishness is refreshing.
Plain, precise, but informed by a dispassionate decency, Celebrationis, which is the Spring choice of the Poetry Book Societ, makes an honourable postscript to Plomer's Collected Poems (1960).
Robert Nye

Author: Pitt, Valerie
Title: Christian myths map the poet's progress
Full_text:
Christian myths map the poet's progress
Literature and Religion-8 T. S. Eliot
By Valerie Pitt
There is. or was antil Mrs Eliot published the early drafts of The Wasteland (Faber, Â£5) last year, an orthadox doctrine about Eliot. He is the " invisible poet ", the ansi-romantic whose emoti,ons and personality are never allowed to intrude into this poetry. He evokes. as. in The Wasteland and The Hollowv Men. the crisis *common to all of us in the decay of Western Christendom:
Thtis is the wvay the world ends
Not with a bang but a wvhimper.
But Eliot writes onrly as spectator. He is his own Tiresias, a tired prophet compelled to endure and record even,ts in which he has no personal part. This austerity extends to his Christian writing. No one reads Eliot (or do they ?) as we read Herbert or Hopkins, as a devotional or. still less, as a confessional poet.
To youn,ger generations Eliot's Christianity beloengs to his rolc as tired prophet. It served, like the mountain to Moses, as a standing place to view-judgeand shelter from the confusions of his generation. There is something in this. Eliot did not become a Christian un,til 1927. when he was nearly 40, had already published The Wasteland and had edited The Criterion for nearly five years. He had, long before, abandoned his ancestral Unitarianism for a quiet agnosticism acd an interest in Eastern religions. He had considered but, so it is said, did not adopt the
Buddhist Way because Buddhism has no r.oots in Western culture. If this was his true reason it is very significant. For in the early 1920s Eliot was preoccupied both in his criticism aid in the editorial policy of The Criterion with the roots of Western culture, with sustairving " tradition ", the order and wisdom inherited from the past which both nourished individual talent and kept - undisciplined squads of emotion " in decent check:
Extreme High Church Anglicanism, the religion he did adopt, provided the exact religious compleme.mt of these literary concerns. It was, for historical reasons; obsessed in the 1920s and 1930a with questions of ecclesiastical author-ity and tradition: ritual, dogma, discipline, and certainly anv unruly squads of religious emotion, were all to be measured against the inheritance or fanoied iniheritance of the Christian past. Contsidering this, generations to whom " trad " is primarily a jazz term. may wvell ask if Eliot adopted Christianity at least partly hecause it was a coniservative force. one way of holding togethet the disintegrating heritage of European civilization ?
The disguised High Toryism of The Idea of a Christian Societv gives coloir to such a view, one which it is now difficult to sustain, unqualified, in the light of Mrs Eliot's edition of The Wasteland. There the "invisible poet" begins to materialize behind the tired prophet. Mrs Eliot repeats her husband's assertion that the
poem was not about decaying civilizations: it was about himself and was written in a period of prolonged personal suffering. The waste, infertile land may belong to universal myth : here it reflects Eliot's own state and indeed the unamended poem has a startling qua{ity of personal anguish. And if the poet is present, in his owvn person, in The Wasteland, why not i.n the Christian pooms !
The Four Quartets are, obviously concerned with "Time present and time past ", " both perhaps present in time future ", an.d with the way in which history finds new meaning and reality in our consciousness of the present. Even prayer, especially in Little Gidding, belongs to the tradition
You are here to kneel
Where Prayer has been valid
Having said that, however, we have to recognize that history in the Foutr Qutartets is not just any history: it is the history of a particular consciousness, Eliot's, come alive and aware in places which had art ancestral or a personal significance for him, whore he could drawv on an accumulated awareness built up through many generations:
not the life time of
one man only But of old stones whicit
cannot be deciphered. It is i.n Eliot's personal experience that the past and the present come alive in each other and are particularly vital in his con-version to Christ, in whose Incarnation history opens into eternity..And it is because of this relationship
between Christ's etermity and the moments of history, that Eliot is able to mnise the Christian story for myths of his own spiritual progress. As he was Tiresias in The Wasteland, so he is the Magus in the Journey of the Magi and Simeon in A Song for Simeon. Both the last two poems remember a long comning to the event of Christ's birth, the moment of difficult revelation which seperated the new life from thei.r own prasts. Both endure anticlimax: there is a time after as well as a time before the moment of revelation which remains unillumined by the drama of rapture or martyrdoni.
The more personal Eliot is, the more he speaks directly to ouT condition. Because he is the Magus, so are we: we transfer the universalized symbol from the poet's state to our own and read hiTn. yes, as a devotional poet. I mean as a poet who deepens understanding of our life in Christ. What is more, in spite of the anti-climax, the sense of an apparently insignificant before and after, the poetry speaks of his search in history for the meaning of life and of his experience, " fell in the blood and felt along the heart", of what he found in the Christian tradition. The event, the birth which gives meaning to the flux of things had happened. There is order, there is hope:
Let me Resign my life for this life,-
my speech for that inspoken The awakened. lips parted,
the hope. the new shins.

Author: Wood, Michael
Title: The neck of eloquence
Full_text:
Books_- -
- - C : I . I I . I
The neck of :eloquence
poetry in England seems a small -arld. Within a random selection of recent volumes, we find George Barker, author of one book, praising Jeff Nuttall on the dustJacket of another, and Alan Bold dedicating his new work to Barry Cole, who also has a new work. In a poem by Tomr Pickard we meet Nuttall again:
as I was running up
the dowtn escalator I passed Jeff Nuttall running down the utp. What this suggests is not so much a coterie as a certain poverty, a scarcity of landmarks, and this is precisely the impression the poetry makcs: It is stranded, bewildered stuff for the most part, floundering among old habits of theme and diction, and making forays into new lands only to get stuck in nornscnse or self-importance. Both Jon Silkin and Nuttall, for example, recognize the problem, make serious attempts to escape into harder, sharper visions. But then their lartuage simply congeals into harshness. odd syntax, strange uses of wnVvrn words:
Its bridnlides emerged, multiplying
densely, conzparing an opa4ue bud of wood and leaves
rnot chItzklng light through, or air; populous of
itself, impacted T*hese Lines, by Silkin, seem to me xrfeadatble, and like t1be rest of Amana Grass (Chatto/Hogarth Sp), horribly strained, trying much too hard. Nuttaill huas finer things, a lot more energy end inven,tion to start with, bbut there, is the same fall into congestion: "Blood stands acid/At a faccid VYelid . What b'igins in Ntuxta'X as a cry, a response to a creeping menace hidden all over the world becoMes just a tendency to shout (Poemzs 1962-1969, Fulcrum Press f 1.60).
Maureen Duffy, by ooatrast, murmurs nOicely. The Venuz Toazi,h (Weidenfeld and Nicolson 90p), full of echoes of Donne, Marvell, Shakespeare, touches of Dylan Thomas, is elegant, charming and all too easy to read. lt seems half unconscious Or its mlany borrowv-
ings from dead poets, and quite unconscious of any need for a poet to face the asperities of reality now and again. These are love poems, and.a modern love which flows so sweetly into such smooth language either has been betrayed by the verse or is itself a fraud.
Alan Bold manages some briighter, less literary love poems (" Talk to me now/Instruct me how/Muah my World is the world she has "), and some fluent translation's, but 4 Pint'of Bitter (Chaatto and Windus Â£1) is curiously without a centre, even without an edge, and totters between virtuosity and flatness. Auden is clearly Bold's master here, and Bold can do a lot of the things Auden can do. But this is Auden without his wit and compression, 'and I'm not sure what is left wvhen those things are gone.
The common difficul.ty in all this work, perhaps in all verse which is not simply metrical, is to qiicken language into a life not possessed by daily prose, and the most obvious solution is an arty word order or " poetic ' invention: a bed Tiepoloed with sunrise (Maureen Duffy), a pavanne of daffodils, the gavotte of the grass (Alan Bold), the spastic fandangos of love (Jeff Nuttall). But these are fake answers, evasions of the issue, mere decorations. of our drabness. and I want to turn now to some authentic solutions.
It is possible, for example, for a sensibility to pin and for potential damage to be so strong that it simply takes languiage into its service, and this is the case with Elaine Feinstein (Tiae Magic Apple Tree, lutchinson Â£1.50). She is a poet of small moments which take on meaning not because they are great events in disguise but because they mark patterns of behaviour as they seem to settle. Thus, brief joarneys matter because they launch habits of separation, they2are beginnings of an end
love donit be lonely don't let us always be leaving singly on
somne-bleak joirney wait for me. Lonel'iness here is not a fate but a decision you make yourself at
sbme half-unseen, point in your life. a bad choice.
But there . is also the reverse' route out of poetry's badlands: into a language of such wit and grace that it doesn't seem to matter what You say; away from gravity. What is attractive about poets like Tom Pickard and Tom Raworth is that they have taken Verlaine's advice (twist the neck of eloquence) not in the sense of banishing eloquence but in the sense of subduing it. Thus Pickard (Thte Order of Chauce, Fulcrum Press Â£1.40) can write "Sleep is the sacrifioe of sorrow" as the ironic titlc of a poem whose movement is of another kind:
my finigers become butterflies
stranige words travel to my balls Raworth (Lion Lion, Trigram Â£1.25, and Movinig. Cape Goliard Â£1.50) can wvrite of thle sparkling games/flickering at the end of my youth, but the lines are themselves a game. a comic mood, an impersonation of an old-style poet. The play and complexity in tbe humour of entered a strange monastery/the order of chzance (Pickard), or life is against the laws of nature (Raworth) seem to me to be worth any amount of stretched solemnities.
In this context, Penguin Modern Poets 19 (Pemguin 30p) appears as a sourcebook, tracing the read back from Raworth and Lee Harwood, a gentler, slowermoving poet in a similar vein, to John Ashbery and the socalled New York school. The road has fine scenery, leads to a world related to that of pop art, where everything, and especially the diet of the popular imagination, becomes matter for metaphor, and for wry, underplayed ver,bal music.
In his Poems of Places and People (Faber Â£1.50) George Barker seems set apart from all this, and in a sense he is, by his great distinction as a poet, his total command of a mature style. Yet in this commanid there is a limitation, a poise which shuts him off from rough subjects, and he seems much more at home on the "winter track ", as he puts it. in a "landscape of winter dreams ", brooding on the past, lost friends, emptied places, than in the sultry and ambitious climate of his " Veusberg", a sequence of poems, inchuded in the present volume, about the ruining, castrating goddess. So that Barker does belong with most Of the new English poets, trapped by his mastery as they are bound by the ioverty. Whatever his lin ants d occsional failures, George Barker expresses better than anyone now writing a distress whidh never wlhines or clings to false ooniorts, a clear sense of what we have come to call our atlienation.
Michael Wood

Title: Children's books

Lovers of poetry %vho have not travelled much in rcalms beyond the E.xeter by-pass wvill need to knowv that tiggie hobbin is an adaptabic Cornish pudding that can bc eaten first oi last according to the quantities of raisins you put in. Although children, we hope, %ill not he given to heart sickness. they may still find contentment in Mr. Causley's Figgic Hobbin IMacmillan, 21s.}--a confection of poems neither so indigestible nor so outright Cornish as the sweetmeat sounds to be. Cornish subjec-ts certainly abound (Stephen Hawker pretending to be a merrymaid ' and singing to the parishioners of Morwensto-e from a rock in the

Allthrough the book there are echoes.cither of popular rhymes. or of writers who have used the distinctive metric of popular rhynmes. Walter De La Mare in the mysterious Tell me. tell me, Sarah Jane ": or James Reeves in

At the back of it all though is Charles Causlev's own voicc. wr,. faintly elegfiac, sh.unning the easv effects that his simple verse formis could lead him into, and leaving the readers imagination to fill out the unspoken suggestions in many of his poems.
Building upon the traditional manner is a natural technique for a poet designedly writing for children (a questionable enough exercise since. unlike bedtime stories or books. about farm machiner. poetrT. if it is good. is surely just for "people "). In the poe;ri of someone like lan Serriallier, though. there is evidence of an attempt to impose upon ballads and nursery rhymes a distinctively

His two most receni books: The Ballad of St. Siimeont (Kaye & Ward, 21s.) and The Tale of Thlree Latdliubbers (Hamilton. 21s.) are t%pical of this process: awkward, occasionallv disjointed struotures, with none of the ease of Charles Causlcv's regular measures. but xwith sudden, offhand thrusts of irony or humour.
In both these books, however. the verse has been used as the hasis for a picture book-colour illustrations to the second bein.
provided bv Ra,rnmond Briggs, and to the first by Simon Stern. The result is that there is a faint discrepancy between Serraillier's slightly sophisticated manner and a format suggesting nursery simplicity. Ir matters less in The Tliree Lanidliubbers. where the narrative is brief and the gaudy, funny pictures a storv in themselves. but St. Simneon, whose complex rhythms are supported by lumpy. rather sardonic illustrations, is verv much a picture book for disenchanted adults.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Ted Hughes: a brutish metamorphosis
Full_text:
Ted Hughes: a brutish metamornho sis 1
Some 12 years ago Edwin Muir, that most gentle of Scottish poets, wrote of Ted Hughes's early poetry: "His imnages have an admirable violence." Since Hawk in tlte Rain (1957) ivas folloewed by Lutpercal (1960) and Wodwvo (1967), the violence in Hughes's' poetry has grown arm in arm with his -popular reputation into a shape of impressive and almost proverbial proportions. Crow (Faber 20s.) his latest piece. is-- even in comparison with the bloodClotted vistas of his Seneca's Oedipus (i969)-the most gory and agonized sequence to date. I do not exaggerate: -
He stands trousered in blood and log-splits
The lolling body. bifurcazes it
Top to bottom, kicks away the entrails-
Steps out of the blood-wallow.. .
Ytet this poetry has received a generally rapturous applause. A work of genius ". writes one d-istinguished critic; " a newv hero ", writes another reliable one. It may be that this praise is merited. Certainly Hughes is a poet of great linguistic power, and-speaking of post-war English poetry-of the first order of magnitude. Nevertheless, his work fills me vith doubts and unease.
Ted Hughes has always written about the animal world, and the implied animal. analogies with human violence. His -poetry is not unconnected with the wave ot popular animal behaviourism which has washed over us so disturbingly in the past decade (Lorenz. Morris. Ardrey et al.). But in Cro;v. for the first time, Hughes turns the tables and writes consistently from an animal point of view looking back in at the human world
The human world is presented as essentially a place of adult carrion, .rubble and torn sinewzs; ..while CrQW. himself is fundamen-
-taly a childish character, a Mickey Mouse figure. who is minced, crushed, beheaded, made cataleptic in one poem. only to come bouncing back, stropping his beak, in the -next. It is in the impossibility of taking this ghastly equation of existence seriously that my first doubt lies. As a wvorld view, and Hughes. does advance it as a wvorld.view (perhaps there is an odd kind of arrogance here ?)-it is either mildly frivolous or totally despairing. (I was fascinated. to hear a radio critic recently describing these same poems as "enchanting ".)
Separating out these two elements, the childish and the obsessively vi6lent, it is clear that they have run their course throughout Hughes's published works, though previously restrained by the tightest of poetic leashes. Indeed, many of the poems in Crow have direct forerunners in earlier books
In Crow there is development of a kind: the violence is both more extreme and more carefully located, while the childish vision is used more deliberately.and more grosshl. Violence is nowv overtly centred o01 human- love, sexual relations, and childbirth. In '.A Kill ", "Crow and Mama ", "A Childish Prank ". " Crow's First Lesson". 'Crow's Account of St. George ", attd "Song for a Phallus "-to name only the obvious ones-love and birth are treated in terms of butchery, slaughterhouse xvorlk, and: murderous guilt. The poemn called "A Kill "--"As he drowned in his own blood/ Dragged under by the weight of his guts/... And.smashed into the
rubbish of the ground "-is for example a description of childbirth. Even in the beautiful-penultimate poem, "HMow Water Began to -P-lay", the primtordial waterdro. plet conducting its investigations into natural processes ,reaches a typical impasse:
It' went ato tie woinb it met mzaggots and rottenness
It came weepinzg back it wanted to die
This is the third cause -for doubt.
I do not believe that the final test of a sequence of poems lies in its purely aesthetic success. One looks for qualities, difficult: to. describe, of life-enhancement, of responsibility to Riving. How Crow .answers in- this respect may be
inferred. Yet it is.not -here, but in the .brutish metamorphosis coming.
over Hughes's linguistic skill, theapparently deliberate resort to primitive hamfisted adjectives and trudging nonosyllabic phrases, that I rest my final cause for doubt. Though there are many lovely passages. especially in
"Crow and the Birds" (much quoted. elsewhere) and "Crow's Undersong " (which does not, perha'ps significantly.. -feature Crow himself)-
SiC brings petals inl their nectar fruits in their plush
She brings a cloak of feathers an animtal rainbowv
yet these are. unfortunately but unquestionably, the exceptions. T hc linguistic and aesthetic norms in Crowv are passages like those describing Lho two final postnuclear lovers--
Mzztations--at ho;ne in the ,nzclear glare.
Horrors-lhairv anrd slobbery, glossy and raw.
The questioDing of this- kind of writing, and all it implies,- is then the fourtth doubt about Ted Hughes's new work. Unlike my fellow critics, Crow fills me with little rapture :
Turning northwards, there are three new collections of. ScoMttish poetry which- .are to be highly recommended. The. Collecred Poems of Buirns Singer, edited by W. A. S. Keir (Secker & Warburg. 70s.) are the' work of a poet and biologist of. unusual .intellectual penetration . and fine nurrative gifts, exemplified in his long poem " The Trans~paaent Prisonter '
Sipgers'din fragically at Ehe age of 36 in 1964, andhis work fisaot w.idely ke wn. The writing is difficult ast first sight, comblrning the energy and grace of Dylan Thamrgsl wfith then intesse moral and personal probing of Yeatws. There are Stwo refreshing Prefaces by H.ug MacDia,Mid and W. A. S. M er,aas iways giving the
ansdeid Ce1'tic view of the largely hateful EngtEsh tradition. and the collection as a whole repays careful and sympathetic study.
The other two books are anthologies: Scottisht Poetry Fitve edited by G. Bruce, M. Lindsay, and E. Morgzan (Edin'burgh USP., 15s.) an excl}ent mails'tream colilection: and Thte Akros Anthlology of Moderm Poetry 1965-70 edited with a lively polemic Introduction ( Scottish Palefaces" versus "Scottish Redskins ") by Duncan Glenn who is one of the masters of the Scottish Little Press movement (13s. paper. 23s. hardback. from Akros Publications, 14 Parklands Avenue, PenVortham, Preston, Lancs.).
Richard Holmes

Author: Sadie, Stanley
Title: Handel's nature poetry revealed
Full_text:
Handel's nature poetry revealed
Acis and Galatea
Queen Elizabeth Hall
Stanley Sadie
Handel is not often counted among music's nature-poets. But A cis and Galaiea must surely represent the topmost peak of pastoral music- - the stylized .ature idyil at its most unclouded in Act 1. then with darker shades of tragedy in Act 11. yet still within the pastoral convention. More than that: there is humour too. " The monster Polyphemer" brings about the mortal catastrophe, but he is also very funny: we laugh and cry. both at once, and both in earnest.
If that were not enough. the work ends with Galatea's grief transfigured in one of the most sublimely beautiful songs ever written, " Heart, thou seat of soft delight". with the murmurs in sweet thirds of soft recorders and violins standing for the " crystal flood " that her beloved Acis has now become.
Ideally. there should have been at the Queen Elizabeth Hall on Wednesday a scene representing in a " Picturesque Manner, a Rural Prospect. with Rocks, Groves Fountains, and Grotto's: amongst which . . . a Chorus of Nymphs and Shepherds. the Habits and every other Decoration suited to the Subject ". But it was a pure concert performance, and the nymplhs and shepherds of the Handel Opera Society Chorus wore black evening dresses and dinner jackets. The music's range of co'our came across, however.
The Bristol Sinfonia. based on 10 violins, incauded a pair of recorders one of which twittered charmingly in spite of Galatea's admonitions in "Hush, ve pretty warbling choir ". The string playing was finelv alert in the first act (it needed to be in the overture, done at a spanking pace), and textures were beautifully airy. 1Act 11 was rather more tentative, with Charles Farncombe's rhythms seeming less strong-Acis's " Love sounds th' alarm ", for example could welcomely have been more belligerent. Happy as most of his tempi were, he might profitably have let the work move on faster towards its climax. And why so often were we gratuitously given the dreary thurmp of a pizzicato double-bass ?
For sheer professionalism, in the putting over of- words and music and their meaning, Owen Brannigan as Polypbemus stood
out. And the voice is stiU there too. Ian Partr!dg's Ais was elegantly phrased and warmly expressed, but never seductive in tone, nor ideally resolute in Act. I1. April Cantelo sung surely, as always, but coolly; the sensuousness of Galatea's music was lacking. As Damon Duncan Robertson did little more than sing the notes. there was no sense of Handelian line. The choral music was strongly and energetically sung, mostly in the familiar &A.T.B. version rather than Handel's original but impractical S.T.T.T.B. Here and there the tenors, not surprisingly. sounded strained in exposed music.
In the early evening Festival Hall recital, David Sanger gave the first performance of a new organ work by Peter R.acine Fricker, called Praeludium (because based on seventeenth-century formal and textural methods). It is nine minutes long, but its brevity does not belie the composer's programme-note remark about a large-scale work. It cleverly combines strong musical argument with a highly idiomatic treatment of the instrument.
It starts rhetorically-what instrument can *be rhetorical nowaNtys if not the organ ?-and mbves on to explore other facets of the organ's personality: there are rich. echoing chord patterns with blocks of sound juxtaposed ; there are fleeting, winding lines ranging over the whole keyboard and pedalboard: there are passages of briliant toccata-like figuration. There is a sense of pattern-weaving about the music, of abstract shapes looked at from a variety of angles. It is not as severe as much of Fricker's music; the feeling for the organ's idiom and its colour rules that out. Although breaking little new ground. it is a valuable addition to the organist's modern repertory.
Mr. Sanger aLso Played the obligatory Bach. The D minor concerto after Vivaldi struck me as rather lacking in drive and brilliance, and as somewhat unimaginatively phrased. A group of chorale preludes from the Orgelbaichlein went better. particularly the more direot. forthright ones; registration was sensitively chosen. and articulation was clear, but more feeling for the expressive shape of Bach's lines would have been welcome in. for example, Wenn wir in hochsten Nothen sein

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: A poet of royal virtue
Full_text:
A poet of royal virtue
Hugh MacOiarmid is now 78, his eyes still like coal_pits, his hair like the North Sea in Marcih He has been in many ways the King Lear of modern poetry, a stubborn figure of royal virtues and exceedingly crotchety demeanour (Who's Wlro entry "Recreations: anglophobia "), who has been out on his own in a storm (blinding Nationalism, eccentric Communism, epic conceptions of poetry's function) with nobody very much wanting to help him in. And he preferring the outside company anyway: "Ah no ! These bourgeois hopes are not our aim ". (" Third Hymn to Lenin ").
Although he is the modern Scots poet, and a major English one (whatever he may growl), his works have appeared until recently in obscure and limited Scottish editions, or obscure and expensive American ones. Not unnaturally he has gained the reputation of being unreadable. Unreadable ?-- try this littie love song (" wheesht" means hush):-
Whiteesht, witeeshi, my footish hert, For weel ye ken
I widna ha'e ye stert A uld ploys again.
It's guid to see her lie Sae snuod an' cool,
A' lust o' lovin' by-
Whee%t, wheesht, ye fule!
It comes from Hugh MacDiarmid: Selected Poems (Penguin, Ss.). The weight of this welcome collection lies in NlacDiarmid's poetry of the Thirties, the political exposition of " the Seamless Garment " and the " Hymns to Lenin ". But it is comprehensive enough to illustrate everything from his most exquisite lyrics (like the above) to his broadest didactic claims. "Our concern is humnan wholeness-the child-like spirit. Newborn every day-not, indeed. as careless of tradition. Nor of the lessons of the past: these it must needs inherit ". Scots, wherever it occurs, is carefully glossed.
MacDiarmid's greatness lies in his determination to open poetry up: to scientific and political conceptions, to social responsibility. and above all to the men and women in " the lang coffin o' the street ". His concern is kingly. and in my view, an absolute value: Are my poems spoken in the
faetories and fields, In the streets o' the toon ?
Gin they're no', then rm failin to
dac What I ocht to ha' dune.
How far has he succeeded ? Enough to have written several long poems of first importance. Enough to have passed on these issues, alive, to the next generation of Scots poets.
Penguin Modern Poets 17 (5s.) contains David Gascoyne, W. S. Graham, and Kathleen Raine. In itself, this surprising choize of three poets who until now might have been considered as Forties material, iS a shrewd editorial diagnosis of parallel developments among our youngest writers, The nervous social anger of Surrealism, the glowing, inclusive and very personal communication of Tomantic imagery. are undoubtedly with us
again. The days of dry, clipped wry, "witty ", neurotic drawingroom poetry are numbered.
Of the three, Kathleen Raine's writinrg has aged least well: dreamy isles, wafts of Sitwell, cloudybright. She nowhere speaks so clearly to the young poet as in her magnificent critical work on Blako (1968). Gascoyne still feels like a period piece; but his " Christ of Revolution and of Poetry" is instructive, and at maximan intensity he shows the exemplary " tuning" power of Surrealism:
Now tie beckoning ntictkv of
diseases purrifies the saloon,
The severed limnbs of the galaxy
wriggle like chanmbermaids,
Thze sewing-machine on the pillar
condenses the windvdill's halo. How many frequencies of the contemporary mood he has included here: Eluard, Dali, the desperate domestications of latterdav Prufrock; even. one might hazard, a touch of raffish gothic from the Folies Bergere. But it is W. S. Graham who speaks most directly, his honest regional modulations of voice, his steady assault on the knocking silence across which poetry must come, his vividly dramatic use of modern heroic roles-the explorer, the prisoner, the pilot-out of which to write. He is the most impressive, the most present.
Donald Davie looks back at the work of Pound and Olson in Six Epistles to Eva Hesse (London Magazine Editions. I Os. 6d.). These lithe, amusing verse letters consider the American poets' use of myth, hero, history, and ' trampoline " rather than linear Time. His address is friendly but critical. speaking up for the virtues of rhyme, and, uinexpectedly, the Comic Muse. Verse, not poetry
crtainly; though some beaming muse must surely claim the garland of his splendid attack on American mythography that
Makes every goddess the Great
Mother And women types of one another, and Hathor, Circe, Aphrodite
One pair of breasts within one
nightie. Two newcomers. Mjichael Schmidt is 23 and rnm a lively new Lttle P,ress with a bias towards Oxford and Intelligence: Caracanet. Look out for their pamphiets. His own Bedlam and the Oakwood (15s. or 1Os. Caracanet Press. Pin Farm, South Hinksey, Oxford;), leans towards lite.rary themes, but is brilliantly coloured by Mexican material. eagles. tombs, blue unicorns. His most characteristic role is eoet as archaeologistL digging for life among the emba'lmed, with many bizarre and interesting results. At the moment his forms are too restricted, but there is lots of imaginative life struggling out.
Finally. John Moat, who lives in Devon and wrote a sad and beautiful little first novel Hereot (1968) about a writer's attempt to live in a lonely cottage threatened by an imaginary, but powerful, Grendel. His poety in Thunder of Grass (Barrie & Jenkins, 16s.). much of it love poetry, echoes this threatened situation, though the observing eye is less acute and less humorous than in his prose. The countryside plays a graceful and unselfconscious part in traditional lyric and fairytale themes. The best undoubtedly is a poem after John Gower's story of the incestuous child-lovers, Candace and Marshall. Moat produces a magical, simplistic, re-creation.
Richard Holmes

Author: Blyth, Alan
Title: Poetry, virtuosity
Full_text:
Poetry, virtuosity
Festival Hall
RPO
Oddly enough, Tippett's first symphony, written all of 25 years ago. received what was apparently its London premierc at last night's R.P.O. concert conducted by ltawrence Foster. Extraordinary that a work so exuberantly enjoyable. so easily assimilated-.provided you are prepared to concentrate-does not figure on the programme of at least one London orchestra in every season.
Tippett was here in the full swing of his early, strongly contrapuntal- period, willing to examine an idea from ever- possible standpoint, allowing his fancy full freedom while at the same time keeping, almost miraculously, a sense of unity not only in a movement but throughout the work as a whole. He also here proved that he has an infallible ear for keeping his textures clear even when on the page the scoring may look heavy.
All this bespeaks the keenness of mind, -the sheer genius of composition, that was soon to lead him on to the delights of Tile Midsummner Marria.Rc, as London audiences will be able to confirm again for themselves when Covent Garden revives the opera next month. Even these days this sympathv must be devilish to play and conduct. Mr. Foster and the orchestra, without modifying speeds or shirking dynamic breadth. overcame practically all the technical hazards and, in the slow movement, added poetry to virtuosity.
These were just the qualities Radu Lupu brought to his playing of Beethoven's second and third concertos. Hc replaced Arrau at short notice and the elder pianist would surely have approved of the younger's combination of finesse and intellectual control. Lupu did not make the mistake of taking the B flat Concerto into the nincteenth century; more positively his playing here, one or two understand-
able smudges apart, was crisp, fresh. spontaneous. The C minor, with which he won the Leeds competition last year. was full of interpretative insight-interpretative liberties too. but they practically all seemed justified on this occasion because they emerged so naturally from Mr. Lupu's romantic heart allied to his superbly sensitive fingers.
Alan Blyth

Author: Null
Title: Poets
Full_text:
PCETI
THE PENGUIN BOOK OF SCOTTISH VERSE, imroduced and edited by Torn Scott (Penguin. lOs.).. A nationalist anthology of genius, one of the best Penguin has ever managed. The weight of the selection falls quito rightly on the great preReformation poetry, on Robert Henrysoun (the whole of his lovely " Testament of Cresseid " is here), William Dunbar (" the idiocy of caling him a 'Scottish-Chaucerian' "') Gawin Douglas, and the Balads; though Robert Fergusson (tricked into an Edinburgh Bedlam), Burns and Hugh MoDiarmid get their due. Tom Scott shepherds in the strays (Byron, Stevenson, Lang, Kathleen Raine) like a benevolent but fietcewme watchdog wary of the predatory English and their "fag-end of modern Poetry". The solemn scorn he holds for English poetry, the passion with which he looks to the Gaelic and European traditions give this collection a drive and cohesion one rarely sees in a modern anthology.
THE PENGUIN BOOK OF IRISH VERSE, introduced and edited by Brendan Kennelly (Penguin 10s). A helpful and spirited anthology chosen to illustrate the distinctive development of Irish poetry and its mythological resources. It is divided into three parts: * Gaelic translated ", " AngloIrish ", and " Yeats and After ". T;he third section, occupying over a hundred pages, gives what is really the first attempt at an overall perspective on post-war Irish work, assembling together James Simmons, Rivers Carew, Desmond O'Grady, Kennelly himself, Seamus Heaney, Michael Longley, Derek Mahon, and 23-year-old Tom McGurk. Very welcome.
LUPERCAL, by Ted Hughes (Faber 8s.). His second book, 1960, dedicated to Sylvia Plath. "Pike ". " Thrushes ", " Hawk Roosting ", etc. It is odd to think that this little volume contains what are already some of the best-known English poems of the century.
COLLECTED POEMS: BASIL BUNTING (Fulcrum 21s.). The Northumbrian poet, now 70, the courage and, tenacity of whose life, the compactness of whose work, have'been of such direct and intimate assistance in the revival of English poetry in the 1960s. Note particularly his creative use of translation, and the austere application of his famous blue pencil.
BOLTS OF MELODY: NVEW POEMS OF EMILY DICKINSON edited by Mabel Loomis Todd and Milicent Todd Binghamn (Dover 28s 6d). This was the first major edition of Emily Dickinson's work. . which appeared after long and sometimes bitter editorial struggleein 1944. no less than 58 years after her death. It contains 666 poems and eight pages of facsimile. It is still one of the best colections (though the full modern canon has nearly three times the number, and Emilv's wild and beautiful spelling, punctuation and capitalization have been made to conform to a cruel orthodoxy).

Author: Brett, Guy
Title: Hockney's poetry and wit
Full_text:
Hockney's poetry and wit
by Guy Brett,.
Whitechapel Gallery Hockney
Despite his fame and his popularity David Hockney is ar. elusive sort of artist. Blut the Whitechapel Gallery bas made every -effort to bring bim home to roost. Mark Glazebrook's catalogue lists and illustrates virtually al Hockney's Paintings since 1960 and the exhibition which opens today puts on show a large number of them, as well as all Hockncy's prints anid etchings.
Many of Hockney's recent paintings have been about California. So. much so, that one easily identifies his qualities, his whole painting style, with the vision he has given us of that place. Describing ' California " one describes a Hockney: the expensive but biscuit-thin buildings set off tastefully with shrubs, the oval or rectainle of tame swimming-pool water, the carpet-like lawn which' a sprinkler, half fountain and half maintenance.device, keeps always green. People generally make languid appearances. In "Portraii of Nick Wilder". for instance, the Los Angeles gal!eryowner soaking in his pool, appears
like a living bust surrounded by the depersonalized components of his home and comfort, which also form a collection of amusing and elegant passages of painting.
Hockney has caught the antisoptic. v~pid atmosphere of-California so well th~at people feel he must disapprovc of it. But he says he enjoys it. And this seems to me to describe exactly the sort of freedom, the kind of vassive detachment, that goes with a witty temperament. He enioys it. but he sees it clearly. Hockney is painting about artificialities, and has always enjoyed the myriad, artificialities of the technique of painting. One thing that, in an exhibition of internationai mainstream art, makes his work stand out as an oddity is his readiness to play about with art devices -nd styles whicth other artists may take very seriously. He is so detached from these devices that he can treat them as things, in some cases like pieces of furniture surrounding a figure in a painting.
But this makes one wonder all the more where Hockney's heart lies. A device he has often used is a curtain, painted as if it was hanging very near the pictureplane, often with runners painted in near the top of the canvas. He likes it partly because it is a similar
tning in substance to the canvas itseif. He manipulates the curtain cleverly enough in' many paintings as a technical d&vice for reveUling a "scene within a scene", but it is only in some human, sensual situation, for example in "Two men in a shower ", that the curtain beones a poignant influence in the vainting.
Hockney's work has no trace of rhetoric. Part, of -his poetry and Wit is to let effects emerge rather than force them, whioh often makes his work look deceptively casual. It appears in his earliest paintings based on graffiti. Where another might play up the drama of these anonymous messages, Hockney is shy and oblique: "I want to meet somebody -who is like myself" is written faintly on one. His early work, referring to his agitated student life in London- is full of clinging and dancing figures. even if the titles always keep a cool hold on events. But the toothy faces are gradually replaced by imipassive heads, sometimes based on Egyptian sculptures, appearinug among domestic things, and Hockney comes to the neat and relaxed realist paintings he is making today.
Again, their success seems to *depend on letting things emerge
and letting an emotion take bold of the artificialities. In " The -room. Tarzana ", the setting is flawlessly neat and artificial and the boy of flesh and blood lying on 'the bed becomes a focus of sensuality in a- rather similar way to the adolescent girls in Balthus's paintings. I don't think this emotion depends on a human presence.
Yet in many of his recent paintings he seems to become caught in the. blandness he enjoys. The double portrait of Christopher Isherwood and Don Bachardy has acres of mere sweetly coloured formality. Going over to the etchings and drawings you find there is a quality of continuous delight missing in many of the paintings. 1. say- "delight" because it is in Hockney's use of the medium itself, and appears in the most straightforward portrait, an extraordinary skill and knowledge. Here also you can see how important the them- is to Hockney. Setting up paintings sometimes leads him into a kind of visual perversity, but his detachment. his lack of formal commitment, Tesponds marvellously well to being whisked off to illustrate the world of Cavafy or the Grimm Brothess, where the atrnosphere or magical story can support his imaginative and furiny references.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Got to have heart
Full_text:
Got to have- heart-
Richard Holmes
It fs probably treacherous. perhaps even in bad taste, to admit it. But at the present time there is an extraordinary:.uncertainty about who exactly modern poets are. and what exactly they are meant to be doing. It ist a. moment of peculiarly English diffidence and indecision; and certain things simply canMot be said,
For example. "The Review
which may be described as the haunted medieval castle of modera English poetry, has issued forth from its grim critical portcullis three pale' and desperately thin poetry pamphlets (No. 21, parts 1, 2, and 3: 2s. each) by Colin Falck, Hugo Williams. and Alan Page. The first two display an alarmingly. identical kind of acute depression and emotional dryness. which breathes out a few low murmurs of verse. whimsical, hesitant, lipbiting to the point of comic self-pity. Mr. Falck in the night-
Alone with the night wind
I man this damp house and lie awake
Remembering your voice last summer.
Mr. Williams, the next morning-
In the'morriing the birds break up our lovemaking.
They treat us, like very young children.
They know it will end in tears.
These poets move one with a wholly altruistic passion to pat them on the shoulder and render tea and sympathy. It is not the lack of skill (the skill is there, sometime exquisitely), but the lack of heart. Such a criticis. it is only fair to point out, is an acknowledged academic heresy. with a technical namre to define it. What is inescapable nevertheless, is that Alan Page in the third pamphlet, versions k-onm the Greek, " Poems of Yannis Ritsos", simply by drawing on completely un-Eng-
lish sources of energy and feeling, corncs up with some really accomplished and beautiful poems: see particularly " First Voluptuousness ".
It is symptomatic that the New State'sman poetry critic should recently (March 6) spend several hundred words describing an "' identikit ' average English poet ". He did this presumably on the off-chance that someone answering to the description might be discovered, apprehended, and brought in for urgent questioning. In his fourth collection. A Cold Day at the Zoo (Rapp & Whiting, ZSs. and 16s.), Edwin Brock the policeman turned adman. is also assailed by waves of uncertainty witb his occupation amounting sometimes to self disgust.
But he has become expert at pulling valuables from the continuing wreckage-as he dramatizes it-of his private life. He has anger. ebullience, and-saving grace-.bursts of caustic humour. He has, on occasions, the true poet's blindingbhonesty. These qualities are summed up in a rmemorable passage:- You buy me
in a small transparent ball
almost entircly filled with water. You shake me
and a Plastic snowstorm will ensue.
The title of that poem is. justly, "A Man of the World".
The love poem is perhaps the classic and riskiest form of the search for identity and certainty. When it is pursued with such deftness and originality and laughter in a first collection like Michael Mackmin's The Play of Rainbow (Cape Goliard. 30s. and ]5s.). there is cause for real excitement and congratulation. " When all the seas gang dry, my dear" is one of the timehonoured formula; with typical gaiety and a shot of science-
fiction, Mackmin transforms it into-
when the. ise caps
shift and *e into the sea, and the ocean7'
flood across the-lofty deserts. we will not be ready.
couehed in. dynms on the seabed, our aesthetics;
whispering to seaweed instead of trees.
Mackmin, born in London 1941, fiils his poems with an unusual lushness of textures, tastes. and smolls - skin, strawberries. denim, petals, butterflies. field scents. Though the verse movement can become va.porous and slight, he is deft with new phrases. "the flut and flack of blaok wings"; and has delightfully oblique or. even surreal ways with erotic sensation
"under the dress the puzzled} knowledgeable body ". Again and again he pulls off raptures of fine, smiling, excess which establish his special poetic presence on the sctnthe breeze Or a word can raise a nipple.
intangible solidity, alpine
strawberry castle. Honesty, and gaiety: we seem *to need those especialy now in poetry; and beyond that. courage to take risks--with the clearly stated theme, or the large poem, or the totally new idea. This tirne, it took an American, Edward Dorn.
I met in Messila
TIhe Cautious Gunslinger of impeccable personal
smoothness . .
Gunslinger I and 2 (Fulcrum, 28s. and 16s.) is sometbing brilliantly new: a cowboy comicepic, conducted largely in dialogue. It is dazzling. racy, modish, provoking- hyperbolic and lyrical by turns. Some of the cast : a talking Horse, who winks at the girls and rolls huge tampico joints; lil, a gorgeous architypal saloon
Madame A singer-poet who strurns choruses on a lute which Iooks'like a giuitar: Cool Everything, who hitches across the prairie carrying a five gallon gascan of Acid (" The poet then presented I the Rose- to his nose/and sniffed the autotbeistical c,mical/Wliat subtle, richnessz l ..whbslpered/thiks:wduld turn one into an alle`ory .) And Gunslinger. himself, a Texan immortal. hunting his man on the dusty circuit between Mesilla. Las Vegas and Boston. Gunslinger is like a dispossessed Greek god who headed out West : his lightning draw (' spun there/ in that warp of relativity one seesiin the backward turning spokes of a buckboard") is mythic: he shoots words rather than bullets at the enemies of peace and precision. He is also sadly wise. as all gods are---
I have no wish to continue my debate with men.
my nmare lathers with tedium her hooves are dry
Look they are covered with the alkali
of the enormous space
between here and formertv.
Need I repeat, we have co'me
wvithout sleep from Nuevo Laredo.
iFor the gradual creation of the cowboy figure. see Dorn's
Hands Up " Totem Press, 1964 and The North Atlantic Turbine ", Fulcrum 1967).
The comic epic has alwast been used to say something serious. "This is for your sadly missing heart ", says a voice. perhaps the Gunslinger's, in the opening invocation that seems familiar. Suffice it here, that the narrator's -. I". Dorn's o%kn identity. dies off in the swelterinh_ stagecoach to Vegas: and no-one, least of all the poet, is the worse-
