Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry and the politics of pressure
Full_text:
Poetry awd the politics ofpressure)
The door knob has moved
Ricitard Holzes
THE TRUTH OF POETRY
BY MICHAEL HAMBURGER (Weidenfeld & Nicolson 55s)
The difference is, you might say, that our door handles do not turn in the night. Or if they do, it is stifl a movement of innocence, the household hound pawing to be let in, the baronia-
ghost making his Dickensian round. At the very worst, the intention is amorous. But for the Polish poet Tymoteusz Karpowicz, there is a totally different significance in that chill rattle, one that is felt by most Europeans and one that is central to Michael Hamburger's The Truth of Poetry: What horrible dream made the poet
jump out of his sleep
like a- stage from a burning forest ?
(The butterfly from his metaphor had covered him with its wings}
and the door knob that he had described.
has moved.
Here the intention is murderous. Behind, the door in the night in 20th century Europe has been the hand of military and'political terror, the threat of repression, persecution, even genocide. It is a simple fact. Your fear is metaphysical. says another' Polish poet, ".mine is small-a clerk with a briefcase ". Beside the simple fact, as in Karpowicz's poem, the European poet's traditional language shakes to pieces. The Symbolist butterfly dissolves in literary dust the Surrealist forest folds. up like a pantomime stage-prop. There remains the prosaic. anonymous fact ; there remains what Mr. Hamburger calls "the international anti-poetry" the door knob has moved.
This pressure, which 'is both social and linguistic. does not really jnake much senge in England. We know about it, but we
have not known it. In our poetry it is only reflected obliquely. In the dark violence that broods in the ditches and-ponds of Ted Hughes's early nature poems; or earlier still in the deliberately childlike horror of Auden's ballads before the War
O ifs broken the lock and splintered the door
O it's the gate where they're turning, tumning
Their boots are heavy on the floor And their eyes are burning.
But abroad it does make sense, and ".anti-poetry" is a term Mr. Hamburger can apply in different and illuminating ways to poets as distinctive as Brecht, Tadeusz Rosewicz, Andrei Vosnesenski, Hans Magnus Enzensberger, Zbigniew Herbert, or even William Carlos Williams.
Karpowi z'zs is only one poem, and of course anti-poetry is only one point at issue. But it is exemplary. The critical and imaginative, gap which Mr. Hamburger has -had to leap in this brilliant and sweeping-study of " modern poetry from Baudelaire to the 1960s " is immense. Though his book is primarily an examination of German, French and American poetry, he ranges over more than 50 important poets, among them Russian, Portuguese, Polish, Italian, Greek, and Spanish. There are very few foretunners on this scale: C. M. Bowra's Poetrv and Politics (1966) perhaps.
Hamburger has already been called "encyclopaedikc ; one would also add patient, gentle and clearheaded in exposition, lavish with translated material, amazingly free from the rural sourness deep in most English critics' bones, and quietly but subversively armed with confidence in the power of poetry to
hold a psition in modern society. He writes that "to remember the 'great rubbish dump', junk yard and cemetery bf the recent past, while doing all they can to prevent the creation of more, is one of the functions that has come to unite poets in almost every part of the world ". You see the mad glint in his eye. And are very grateful for it.
In his delicate working of the theme of " tensions " between public and private poetry, literal and absolute imagination (tensions which he finds within rather than between good poets), two crucial things emerge about his argument. First, it could not have becen made except by a critic who is also and simultaneously a fine translator and an interesting poet. The three work together and it is a good omen.
His latest collection of poems Travelling (Fulcrum, 30s.) shows how directly, though darkly, he confronts society at the same time as saying "the poem knows better than I do what it's about. what form it must take, what material it needs ". This intimate sense of masks and personae comes out excellently in the early chapters, and he
greets. the Portuguese poet l Pessoa, who wrote and indeed lived under four entirelv different names, like an old fiend.
Secondly. he is at last a man writing with a continuous sense of the political status of poetry. Not political in a crude ideological way, but in the way that makes Enzensberger's superb poem "the end of the owls " political, in the way that acknowledges the complete hum4n responsibility that the poet has in wbatever society he writes. As much as any family man, to guard the door.

Author: Harrison, Max
Title: Flashy treatment of poetry
Full_text:
Flashy treatment of poetry
By Max Harrison
On his gramnophone recordings of popular concertos Nelson Freire tends to make an unpromnising start but to improve sharply later. Perhaps the shortness of the four movements of Liszt's Piano Concerto No. I partly explains the unflattering account he gave of himself at the Festival Hall last night on that they afforded him little time to settle down.
There were several quite good Passages, such as the opnBg keyboard solo of the Quasi adagio, wAhich had some lyrical feeling, and much of the scherzo, where speed. accuracy and lightness are the most obvious requirements.
Buit in the main the concerto was dispatched purely as a display vehicle-this being underlined by a brash yet perfunctory accompaniment from the Royal Philharmonic under Rudolf Kempe.
No one could doubt Mr. Freire's ability to move about his instrument with astonishing speeoindeed. there were parts of the concerto that one had never heard played anything like so fast. Musical considerations, hoever, took a very distant back seat, ard this was shown by the uneven noteva'Lues of many passages The opening double-octave flourish was a dear instance. although there were plenty more. Liszt's poetry cannot survive this lind of flashy treatment.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Underground poets
Full_text:
Underground poets,
Not so public
(Ricliard Holmes
CHILDREN OF ALBIOiN
Poetry of the " Underground" inl Britain
EDITED BY MICHAEL HOROVI7Z (Pelngin 0Os)
On the cover of this anthology, Blake's Albion bursts out of nether darkness in fleshly apricot glories. On the dedication page, Allen Ginsberg salutes the " new-nippled generation ". In a vatic editorial Afterword (60 pages), Michael Horovitz heralds the coming of the PoetPriests and the "remaking of languages round which the new 'global tribes can settle". But among the poets--3 contemporary and not so con temporary Children of Albion-an altogether more restrained, more various, more inquiring mood proves to be emanating from the mianholes of Charing Cross Road.
Horovitz, though cloaked with bad puns and daggered with self-advertisement, makes good points. Underground poets, he says, stand for public poetry in performance, for radical political commitment, for the prophetic social visions inspired bv Blake and Ginsberg. He is borne out in part by one of the best poets here, Adrian Mitchell: and would also be borne out by Christopher Logue, Alan Bold and Alan Jackson if they werc
not inexplicably excluded from the body of the text. Bu; remembering Orpheus (or Lot's wife), Hlorovitz does not look over his shoulder.
For the most striking common factor among these " Underground" poets-who are on the wbole the kings of what one may call the Big Little Presses (Fulcrum, Trigram, Ferry, Anvil)-is a brilliantly recovered use of the tight, hardrhymed lyric stanza or Song form. It appears in Tom Pickard. Gael Turnbull, Adrian
l itchell, Herbert Lonias, John Arden and Neil Oram. In John ,McGrath it produces a simple and faultless verse like-
When up the Strand the foxes glide
And hedgehogs sniff and wildeats Yell
And golden orioles come back
To flash tbrough Barnes and Clerkenwell
When govenments and industries Lie choked by weeds in fertile rain For sure the few who stay alive
Will laugh and grow to love again.
This is certainlv Blakean. but it's the earlv Blake of ' Cbimney Sweeper" and "London". The other connion note is intinmate rather than vatic: a new intimacy of an unembarrassed, open-handed kind, often concerned with children or growing up (into the childhood of poetry) as in Patrick Waites's pungent " Blue Dog " or Ansehm Hollo's nemorable Zoo visit. "'Which animal did you like best ? ' 'That man'."

Author: Null
Title: Pooter
Full_text:
Pooter
Once, Twice, Frice, Fice, Nice, Vice and Spice: A poetry publisher must know the little magazines-mimeographs, wads or glossy marvels. In addition to the foregoing, he should take in (or have taken in, for many have short lives): Poetmeat, Nightrain, Bean Train, Wild Dog, Long Hair. Software, Fish Sheets. Fubbala,Circte, Circuit, Nomad and Stand.
Poetry publisher Stuart Montgomery finds that agents arrive too late on the scene. He keeps his ear close to the underground. and reads, or has read, Diary of an Assassin. I Like You, Poemns Fromt tlhe Floating World. Betwveen Worlds, Open Space, King Ida's Watch Chain and Poor Old Tired.Horse.
Montgomery, 29, Rhodesian, soft-voiced poet, publishes only poetry. His only catalogues are on his book-jackets; his wife Deirdre does the paperwork; he has no travellers but two parttime assistants; his warehouse is a garage in Highgate whi.-h may soon need its roofbeams raised; he was sidetracked into publishing while doing a Ph.D. tin cell surfaces at University College Hospital; he rarely costs a book accurately; he's learnt typography doing it; his debts " kick around" Â£3,000; his Fu!crum Press could be for poetry in the Seventies what Faber was in the Thirties.
He keeps his familv (two little girls) on the procceds of public readings. Fortnightly he is somewhere uttering from Circe, which took seven years to write and which he will publish this autumn for himself. He drives off with his car full of books and persuades them into t'le shops where the readings are. " I cover every major town three times a year, which is about enough."
As a poet be stays on the network. He trawls in Flame, Fort. Fux, Fire. Sphinx, Underdog, Underground, Ambit, Gambit and Matter. As a publisher he has a tolerance for the drop-ins of the permitted society. He has to have-they ring him from San Francisco to pass the time of day. Only it's night time here.
He began with Basil Bunting, in 1965. Bunting's Loquitnr was a throwaway gesture, he says. He was guilty about the size of his grant from the Medical Research Council. Richard Hamilton designed the cover and they put everything into it. Bunting's Briggflatts is his best seller, nearing 7,000. Now 3,000 is his routine first print for every book. Penguin, Montgomery says, offered Bunting Â£50 for paperback rights. " It turned out to be a bad joke." But in any case he'll do his own paperbacks, as Faber do. "The author as well as the publisher makes more out of it."
Montgomery is the cynosure of the poets who think in terms of involvement-xvith media, with audiences, with one another, with paint, with print. He mistrusts the poets who send off a bundle of manuscripts without knowing what goes on at the press. " Every poet has at some time to become his own publisher, arrange his own readings, be involved in production. Bunting brought out his own first book, Pound his first two. Creeley ran the Divers Press, William Carlos Williams paid a little printer round the comer to bring out twvo booklets, Yeats's books were done by his sister, e.e.cummings had a tame printer. Spender did Auden's first book.
" The whole concrete poetry thing came out of direct involvement. Poets have to be adaptable, infiltratc the media and find out what suits them best. Books are only one available form, and the publisher has been a bad middleman." He is not a member of the Publishers Association, but did found the Association of Little Presses. Which teeters along.
The word he wanted for his imprint when he started was the Chinese Clhung. which Ezra
Roderick Delroy
Stuart Montgomery, publisher and poet.
Pound translated as Wobbling Pivot But Fulcrum inspires more confidence commercially. How much confidence, for the Seventies ?
"Well." Pause. "We get the books out more cheaply than anybody. It was an accident I found that production with style was what was wanted, but thafs what we do. But really, we'll make it because we have a backlist." Magic word, backlist! Spoken like a member of the Publishers Association. It is 40 titles long now and he will add 18 a year. In the autumn he will bring out works by Lee Harwood, Christopher Middleton Michael Hamburger, Lorine
Niedecker. Tom Raworth, and later a Collected George Oppen. "Collecteds are always dangerous but so far it's worked."
He does this dangerous work sitting cross-legged on a sheepskin-covered bed at home. There is an office elsewhere, but there's no phone and nobody to answer it. He stays away, daunted perhaps by the piles of incoming journals: Black Mountain Review. The National Review, the Northwest Review, the Eastwest Review, the Niagara Frontier Review, the Paris Review, Choice, Voice, Link, Srim, Tiger's Eye. Poetry and Audience, Poetry (Chicago), Poetry. Et, explosively, cetera.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry,
Lyric impulse with political irony
(Richard Holmes
ANTHOLOGY OF CONTEMPORARY ROMANIAN POETRY
EDITED AND TRANSLATED BY ROY MACGREGORHIASTIE
(Peter Owen 40s)
The poetry of Romania has been received in England with the kind of scepticism usually reserved for such central European phenomenon as the sea coast of Bohemia. A single edition of Romanian folk ballads infiltrated late Victorian England under the editorship of the comic dramatist Vasile Alecsandri, and I have managed to turn up a somewhat chintzy anthology "The Bard of Dimbovitza " collected " from the lips of peasants" in 1902. There is only one Romanian library in the British Isles-at Hull, where Mr. MacGregor-Hastie lectures. Even the exemplary new Penguin Companion to European Literature (1969j observes no more than one Romanian author born in this century. Finally
there is a story about the Bntish Council taking a high-powered delegation of Romanian writers on a cultural visit to the Black and White Minstrel Show. Enough.
Romiania does have both poetry and a sea coast (Ovid was exiled there on the Black Sea, and wrote," a man dies happy here even against his will "). Since Trajan conquered Dacia in 105, arnies have stumped continuously cast and west across the plains of Wallacia and Moldavia, and the Latin base of the Romanian language has been rich-ly layered with Slavonic, Turkish, Greek, German and Magyar elements making it s.uperbly thick in metaphors and associations. The Napoleonic Wars 'brought a dominantly French and western consciousness to the metropolis, and to this day Bucharest with her boulevards and cafes, her flourishing theatres and literary
magazines, looks wistfully towards Paris. Branciusi and lonesco are of course Romanian, and so too Tristan Tzara, the originator of Dadaism in Zurich. In 1965 the new regime of Nicolae Ceausescu took over from the Stalinists, and symbolically changed the vaguely Slavic " Rumania " to the sharply Latinate " Romania ". It was also a good year for poetry, and many poets who had not published since the thirties brought out new volumes.
Closely supported by the Rumanian Writers Union, but single-handed and obviously unencouraged in England, Mr. MacGregor-Hastie has collected, translated, edited and introduced this first modern anthology in English. It covers poets born between 1880 and 1944, a sweep equivalent to the Faber Book of M lodern Verse combined with Alvarez's T he New Poetry. Although the selection is kept down to two or three poems each, and translations are never more than workmanlike, a unique and attractive quality emerges from the 57 poets included: indigenous and sparkling folklore mixed with French and German surrealism; a strong lyric impulse tempered by the terrible irony of their political experiences (the like of which, it can never be over-emphasized, are completely unknown to us on this island). Furthermore, the Romanians are certainly the most energetic
poetic translators in Europe. As their master figure Tudor Arghezi urged, all the poets have their " personal translation programmes" which reach out to France, Germany, Italy, Spain, America, Russia, and (reproachfully) England.
The most striking pieces in the whole book are from a group of five poets-Eugen Jebeleanu, Gellu Naum, Maria Banus, Magda Isanos and Nina Cassian (note the last three are women) who faced the Second World War in their twenties when the older literary figures had nearly all been herded into Tirgu Jiu, known as the poets concentration camp. One by Magda Isanos opens-
I would like to hiss this poem like
a wave breaking, to cover the black part of the
world so that everything would be white like an enormous hospital
without any dead, without any
names.... She fought and died in 1944.
I suspect that the note of desperation is not entirely irrelevant to Romania s present situation from which this anthology has gallantly struggled into the open: and our ignorance of what is excellent there does not help. Or should we go on believing with the learned Benedictine Dom Augustin Calmet that Transylvania is merely the home of the encastellated vampire (see Dissertation sutr Les Vampires el Revenants, Paris 1749) ?

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Second Poetry International
Full_text:
Second Poetry Internationalj
The whole point of poetry
Richard Holmes
"Poetry was always meant to be spoken aloud ", stated W. H. Auden as he surveyed the clamorous foliage of Green Park from the vantage point of the Arts Councirs rooftop, " but Homer could rely on his audience knowing the Proper Names: I can't." " The whole point of poetry ", gasped Robert Bly, swaying hypnotically in the limelights of the Queen Elizabeth Hall, " is in the end, as the Orientals knew, to wake up." "You see, I am both a scientist and a poet", said Dr. Miroslav Holub confidentially in a corner, "my poet friends like that; but my scientist friends do not. For them it is creating falsehoods, speaking inaccuracies. Poetry Readings in Prague ?-ah, no." "I listen to these young men", said 73-year-old Austin Clarke, majestically ablaze with white hair, emerald-green knitted waistcoat, and small black Guinness bottle, " and I think they complain a bit too much. We know
of these troubles in Ireland. Our poets have seen it all before. Still, they're learning."
We are all learning. The four evenings of the Second Poetry International almost exactly fulfilled Philip Sidney's downright definition of 1580: "to delight and teach ". A Third International is now planned for 1971. but after the multiple triumphs of last week's Festival-with poetry (and varied attitudes to poetry) trom Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Greece, Ireland, the West Indies, and America-one can only hope that it will take place next summer, and annually thereafter. The London International could become a fixture to rival Spoleto. Then perhaps even the politicians might include it in their calendars, and Ritsos and Voznesensky and Wole Soyinka could be with us again.
The first two pioneering Internationals (1967, 1969) have been co-directed by Ted Hughes and
Patrick Garland. Mr. Hughes himself made many of the contacts abroad, and the translations we heard on stage are closely linked to the fine Penguin Modern Poets series which now includes Enzensberger (Germany), Herbert (Poland), Holub (Czechoslovakia), Grass (Germany) and Popa (Yugoslavia). The Hungarian Janos Pilinszky, whose harrowing war poetry had such an impact this year (his voice deceptively gentle, his face fine-boned, fastidious), will appear in a translation by Hughes this autumn.
Patrick Garland has established an excellent style of direction. Tight reading schedules and minimal introductory fuss are combined with what looks like a deliberate and somewhat impish policy of contrasts (and even clashes) of poetry and personality on stage. Pilinszky delicately easing his collar while Robert Creeley and Robert Bly embraced in mutual Calliopian enthusiasm. W. H. Auden for ever tapping his chronometer, jangling his change,
trying to hustle off stage while Austin Clarke embarked on yet another eighteenth-century Harp Song. Indeed, each night had its quite individual piquancy and success.
Poetry emerges, in a way we easily forget in England, as a magnificently public expression of communal emotions. My fellow critics (some of whose pens I cannot forbear to note were locked so professionally in their hands as to impede the physical action of applause) tended to admire the more homely species of feeling: the urbane reactionary scorn of Auden; the sharp cocktail satisfaction of Ogden Nash rhyming the backend off the American matriarchy; the dignified metaphysicality of Derek Walcott's approach to West Indian problems. But it was in those alien moments of embarrassment. or puzzlement or even affront that the genuinely international element broke through. Bly outrageously mixing homestead haiku with Vietnam horrors; Clarke patiently relating his Gaelic inberitance to James Larkin and Liberty
Hall; Brathwaite (the other West Indian) abandoning the iambic for the calypso rhythm and actualUy singing his lyrics
Holuh fiercely celebrating Jan Palach-" where man ends/ flame begins ". The shock, the confrontation with a flavour of thought or feeling not quite to oiur exquisite English palates, was the great thing, the poetic thing, the international thing.
So, hopefully, we await next year. Mean-while there is a considerable amount of spooken poetry to be heard. I pick out especially the monthly progranmnes on. B.B.C. Third Radio " Poetry Now " and " The Living Poet"; current poetry recordings from Argo, and Stream Records; *and Jeremy Robson's Poetry and Jazz circus which tours constantly acnd has just released in its wake Poems from Poetry and Jazz in Concert (Souvenir Press, 30s.), a cheerful orange anthology of prize pieces by 24 poets with miany photographs to prove it is really happening here at lost.

Author: Smith, Janet Adam
Title: Poetry, drama, history and jeremiad
Full_text:
Poetry, drama, history and jeremiad
AN ORKNEY TAPESTRY
BY GEORGE MACKAY BROWN
Janet Adam Smith
(Gollancz 42s)
George Mackay Brown is an Orkney man and a poet. He was encouraged to write poetry by another Orkney man, Edwin Muir. under whom he studied at Newbattle Abbey. He has much of his elder's visionary powers, of the older poet's feeling-natural in islands strewn with the stones and dwellings of prehistoric man-for the movement of time, so that every present life seems to contain within it something of lives long past.
Edwin Muir, exiled at 14 to Glasgow and then a wanderer in Europe, looked back to his Orkney childhood as to a lost Eden-" The sky fitted the earth then". George Mackay Brown still lives in Orkney, and in his prose stories (collected in A Calenidar of Love and A Timne to Keep) he can turn a sharp eye on the harshness and the follies of island life: the girl who has to sell herself for drink, the progressive
minister who thinks of Christ as the good organization man, the drunken fisherman who can't see that his neglected wife is dying. But behind his unillusioned view of the present is the sense, not of a lost Eden (though if there was a Fall he would put it at the Reformation) but of what the community could be and perhaps, at moments in the past, has been. In the finest of his poems, like " The Funeral of Ally Flett ", he has celebrated such a community, bound not by sentiment but by mutual needs, concerns and pleasures in fishing-boat, harvest-field and pub. Now in Anz Orkney Tapestry he is trying to:
get back to the roots and sources of the communitv, from which it draws its continuing life, from wlich it cuts itself off at its peril.
It is a rich, uneven mixture of poetry, drama, history and jeremiad. First there is the record of one valley, Rackwick, on the island of Hoy. from the coming of the longships and the first settlers to the coming of " progress " and only one farm left. Then come portraits of three
Vikings: the warrior Sigurd killed at Clontarf, the martyr Magnus whose death brought peace to the islands, Rognvald the Crusader. He built the Cathedral of Magnus in Kirkwall, and went to Jerusalem to atone for all the " murder, piracy, rape, war, sacrilege" done by Norsemen from Greenland to the Volga; when the fleet made landfall at Nar'bonne he passed the summer making courtly love to the Countcss Ermengarde among the roses and troubadours.
Two chapters follow on Lore, which does not mean the usual guidebook snippets of quaint customs but an account of the midsummer and midwinter rituals-pagan in origin but still living in the midsummer fires and harvest reels, the singers at the door on New Year's Eve. Lastly there are pictures of two poets: an anonymous ballad singer in the hall of Earl Patrick about the time of the Reformation, and a poet not long dead, Robert Rendall. Rendall was a draper in Kirkwall who wrote dim Georgian verse-but when he
turned to the Orkney dialect produced poems direct and unsentimental as the sagas, "the most beautiful poems written by an Orkney man since the Reformation killed the songs and ballads of the people ". The book ends with a play about drunken fishermen and a heavenly visitant.
It is an odd mixture but I think it is Mr. Mackay Brown's way of making certain statements. Even in the bloodiest days, he seems to say, there was a sense of belonging together, of sharing each other's lives. Even in the most brutal days there were some, like Magnus, to give their lives for peace and some, like Rognvald, to find that love could mean courtesy and gentleness. Even in the most ignorant days the words of ballad-singer or common crofter could have a bite and edge. Even in the poorest days there could be dignity, and a sense of the mystery and richness of life, expressed in the rituals of church or harvest. Such are the forces that shaped the community. Now, looking round at people who parrot yesterday's television
opinions, call their homes Sunnybrae or Roseville instead of the stark Norse names, he begs them to remember what kind of men they truly are.
Mr. Brown is a far better poet than preacher and some of his diatribes on the present run too glibly. It would be easy to accuse him of selectivity, in his history and social observation. For instance, the eight men who manned the Hoy lifeboat last March and were drowned in the Pentland Firth must have been subjected to Mr. Brown's corrupting influences-ideas of progress, mass communications and so on-but they acted with the unsentimental courage and compassion of a Magnus. But I am sure that what matters in Mr. Brown's book is-the concern he shows for the quality of life, for the possibility of men living together in true cooperation with each other and their environment. He writes of the place he knows, a handful of northern islands with 20,000 people. But the questions he raises concern us all.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Poetry /
Dragon's tongue
| THE LILTING HOUSE
Richiard lolmes
An Anthology of A nglto-Welsh Poetry
EDI7ED BY JOHN STUART WlILLIAMS AND .M4EIC STEPHENS (Dent 36s)
The Wclsh Dragon, it is said, has a forked tongue. One tip speaks English and the other Welsh. Writing in English, but often inspired by or translating from the Welsh, the Anglo-Welsh poets stand self-consciously at the hot and delicate joint. As one poet, Anthony Conran. puts it. the actual word " Welsh " means strangers; but " Cymry " means friends, compatriots.
In this " authoritative and comprehensive " twentieth-centurv anthology, the poets emerge as passionate mediators: between vhat is seen as the corrupt imperialism of London and the slaty isolationism of Cardiff: between damp provinciality and crackling nationalism; between old chapels and new supermarkets.
The very fact that such a collection has appeared is intimately related to current political and cultural upheavals, and has literary parallels in Ireland and Scotland. Behind this book lies the Penzguin Book of Welsht Verse (all in English, 1967); and behind that, the Oxford Book of Welsh Verse (all in Welsh, 1962). And skirmishing alongside now are the lively quarterly issues of Poetry Wales-bilingual, of course.
At first you may have doubts: to call W. H. Davies or Edward Thomas (St. Paul's and Oxford) or even Dannie Abse " Anglo-
Welsh" smacks of ingenuity. But then in Idris Jones. Dylan Thomas, R. S. T homas, Ravmond Garlick. a strong Welshzness does genuinely emerge: a Welshness in attitudes to tradition and survival (" Warming our hands at the red past") : in the dignified, musical use of language: and above all in the consciousness of a Welsh Problem as their inescapable inheritance. R. S. Thomas fixes it superbly:-
Yet men sought us despite this.
Mv high chek-bones, my length
of skull
Drew them as to a rare portrait
By a dead master. I saw them
stare
From their long cars, as I passed
knee-deep
In ewes and wethers, I saw them
stand
Bv the thorn hedges, watching me
string
The far flocks on a shrill whistle.
Even the old Welsh cvngha. nedd - word-tuning - modulates the last line.
In the younger poets (thougb all here have passed their thirtieth vear to heaven) the future holds rich and un-English possibilities. In Anthony Conran, wonderfully swelling translations from the old Welsh. In John Tripp and Meic Stephens, a raw satiric use of the old bardic status in the community, as representative spokesman not teacup dilettante. In Raymond Garlick an appeal to Europe
source to which our ballads grope
context, compass-card
and hope
over the heads of London and Gomorrah. Europe, after all. was where the great Dafydd ap Gwilym turned in the 1360s, and redeemed the green invaded valleys with his lyrics.

Author: Potter, Dennis
Title: A public sort of poetry
Full_text:
A public sort of poetry
NEW NUMBERS
BY CHRISTOPHER LOGUE
Dennis Potter
(Cape 25s, paperback 12s)
Although Christopher Logue rnodestly describes himself as a ' sexy young girl living among corrupted villagers" he could scarcely by any other exercise of reason be called a purely decorative poet. Except that some of his nore aggressive poems are printed on posters which are occasionaUy used by odd householders to add trendy typographical variants to their living room cisulsion. Nfy literary agent, for example, displays one of Logue's large poster-verses (all 100 per cent of it) on his otherwise quite ordinary kitchen wall. It is stuck tp above the refrigerator, which duly shudders from time to tirne-but I feel that the piece belongs better over the gas cooker, a literary appendage to thle blue flame and fumes and slowly cooking bits of innocent animal:
High in the freezing summer air
Sixteen smiling censtables will
Spray
hlallucinating vapours on the crowd from U.S. army helicopters;
and when these dreamy moistures
bead their flesh
troubled enthusiasts will cat each other raw....
It is difficult to be entirely comfortable in such a kitchen. even if you were assured that the poster was impregnated with a chemical which kills flies. The eye struggles down the lines to take in the blind war hero, nine naked girls, the Foden Motor Works band, and a spastic who faints outside the National Gallery. Always, in Logue's scenarios, the sky is full of weeping reds and moulting birds chirrup weary obscenities at each other through the thickening carbon monoxide. An all too familiar landscape. easily assembled out of masticated newspaper cuttings.
The best of Christopher Logue's most recent poems have come down off the wall and coagulated together between the shiny, salmon pink covers of a respectable publisher: shouts and sniggers divided up by firm black lines which sprawl across the page like uprooted railings from some blighted private gardens. It is good to have some of these poems on the page; that one on the kitchen wall, too, for here it can be shut away or turned off like any other appliance.
Yet this is still overwhelmingly a public sort of poetry, owing more to megaphones than meiosis. Polemical, lavatorial, de-
liberately or even wantonly philistine and occasionally sad in a theatrical manner, these pieces need to be read aloud in a crowded room Nvhere each individual spasm of distaste or embarrassment can be subsumed by the inevitable collective guffaw, which would space out the delivery. Logue is, at the very least, often extremely funny, though bitterly and grotesquely so. He might almost be categorized as the cruelly mutated Donald McGill of poetry, full of pillarbox rhythms, lewd couplets and improbable mamillary fantasies. But each laugh is framed by a w-ince, the way we smile nowadays, frightened to let too much get through.
And New Nrumbers does not let enough through either. Instead of the sexy young girl living among corrupted villagers one senses instead a lonely, middle-aged beachcomber dwvelling in a festering metropolis, picking over newspaper headlines, advertising hoardings, restaurant asides, or vaiting for the television picture to collapse into creamy blankness. Logue has perhaps deliberately turned himself into a chronicler of the second-hand experience, the weary joke, the motorway fastness. He does not even seem to
hear the tunes vhich remind us. of other people's desires. It is a heavy price to pay, this battlescarred " commitment " which blurs all the faces and forgets the individual features. Thus, he writes more of what might be called the mere callisthenics of sex rather than the quick-ening emotions of love, which can (believe it or not) be caught in a gesture which plucks whole sentences out of the air.
But to leave it at that would be too harsh. Christopher Logue seems to be refusing to use his considerable gifts on the far side of the disgust and disintegration and psychosis which now set the parameters of almost all creativity. There is a dogged honesty about his lewdness, a desperate integrity about the jokey alienation. He will pivot upon a wellknown advertising slogan, turning it every wvhichway, lacerating each commercial syllable until you feel that only rotting offal is left on the supernarket shelves.
Go to work on an egg
bounce a cheque on an egg fail your test on an cgg
wipe your arse on an egg despair on an egg
touch yourn an n cgg
and so on, and so on, ever more ludicrous until the shell splinters in a helpless little joke.
He is fond, too, of making endless lists of things, hoarding bits and pieces, a kleptomaniac carefully hiding the deeper unease he refuses to explore. New Nuimbers must surely be the hesitant prelude to genuine development-no matter how much more horrible -or a confession of exhaustion. I prefer to think, and very inuch hope, that it is the former. Now-he has to open the egg.
Certainly, the arrogance is there to go beyond the chewved up slogans. He admits in his first line that he writes "in order to change the world ". Well, of course. But do not wait to read the evening papers, Mr. Logue.
If this book doesn't change you give it no house space; if having read it you
arc the same person you
were before picking it up, then throw it away.
The publishers would have been in tune with the irony so often expressed in these funny, troubled and lively pages if they had folded in a KEEP BRITAIN TIDY sticker. Personally, I am keeping my copy, and admitting nothing.
But it is the next one I want to sce.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry of exploration
Full_text:
Poetry of exploration)
" To love all without loss of edge "
Richard Holmes
Ile Oxford Poetry Lectures, like the Papal Encyclicals. are well-known dividers of men of good will. As Roy FuUer surveys the English field from the rampart of the spiry city, arguing for the traditional values of high tone and high skill enshrined in Richards' Practical Criticism (see 1LS 22 May), and excommunicating the insurgent experimentalists for Sentimentality-one wonders if the lines of faith are not being drawn, by both sides, too eagerly, too dogmatically. The opposition of traditional with experimental verse is a lax alternative. Surely the real question is, what can a poet be doing, as Eliot would say, now and in England.
Nathaniel Tarnms new book is called The Beautifutl Contradictions (Cape Goliard, I 5s, hardback 28s). This is how he sees the poet at work:
rhyming the fields and cities
scanning the roads apportionig the harvests
liberating the days
motor of energies guide of hands
bed of rest setting his songs to music
his music to the spheres he has time in the carth his body
he has time to spare
for the most beautiful revolution
of all. At once the largeness, the confidence is striking. Something has to be found: an alternative poetry in an altemative world. The issues
can be named: pollution of the land and the heart by the cities, unjust proportions of prosperity, narrowing of national sympathies, insularity of scholarship, emnpris. onment of work and creativity. The issues are downright and affronting: Le Corbusier having already said in the nineteen twenties / that architecture properly understood could replace revolution I but we can't even learn in England how concrete slobbers under rain ". Mr. Tarn is neither architect nor guerrilla. By " beautiful revolution ', he means not silver bullets but an encircling ot all human conditions with inagination; as one says of a stunned patient, we must bring them round. "The problem ". he writes in the first of 15 sections. "is to love all without loss of edge."
His wveapon is anthropology. Taking his cue from the wvork of Levi-Strauss, he uses myth (especially from South America) as a visionary expression and solution of social contradictions. It is solution in the primary sense of getting perspective, getting irnaginative control: the Mayan rain priests reincarnate in times of trouble. the child's story disarms the dark nursery. The vork of Brecht and Andre Breton is an inspiration; the long, flowing line-though sometimes dangerously becalmed and prosycomes from Tarn's own translations of Pablo Neruda (1966); the mythic material is intractable. but
Nathaniel Tarn
boldly used. Beyond anything, the risk is magnificent because it is the genuine alternative, a poetry of exploration.
The same forceful engagement clearly drives the young Scots poet Alan Bold. His first English cotlection, To find the New (1967) was too bitter a polemical tract for the delicate juices of the southern palate, both Marxist and MacDiarmite. Since then his verse has deepened and sweetened, drawing energy from the wvhole Scots movement as can be traced through two excellent publ4 cations ot last wvinter, the
Agenda" Scottish Issue and the anthology Scottish Poetry 3
(Edinburgh University Press). Now, in A Perpetual Molion Machtine (Chatto & Windus, 18s.! it has become poetry like this:
It darkens. How we sadden as
our planet Leaves the sun again for half A revolution. How we fear
The dark, the turning-away Wc hunger for the glare.
This way we share our world. Only this way ?
Ideal socialism and the imagery of physical sciences substitute for anthropology; but the grasp at immediate issues is the same as Tarn's.
Again the same argument: the poetry waits for us in material conditions: so explore, enlarge the territorv of concern.
Jon Stallworthy is 34, and Root anlid Branch (Chatto & Windus, 18s.) is his third collection. He has written two critical works on Yeats, and his reverence for traditional qualities, the well-turned stanza and the fiercely guarded economic emotion, is wholesome and satisfactory. Compared, however, to a not dissimiliar poet like D. J. Enrigbt (his SeleczeC Poe7us 1953-65 are ako out from C:hatto at 21s.), there is a new. expanding current which probes the human response to cars, telegrams, planes, news photography and other areas of our mechanical enclosure.
Significantly, Mr. Stallworthy is not just shoring up fragments: he has a large central poem "The Almond Tree". The subject is
intensely personal, the birth of a mongol son, but there is a quick freedom of imagery which connects sharply to the outside world, as when in the hospital corridor he is told of his son;
This was my first death.
T'hc " I " ascending on a slow last thermal breath
studied the man below
as a pilot treading air might
the buckled shell of his planeboot, glove, and helmet fccling no pain
from the snapped wires radiant
ends. He achieves this vivid cxten&ion again and again.
'ITo get a fair perspective on this explorative poetry, it is worth making a complete switch to David Harsent's first book A Violent Country (Oxford. 18s.j. I his is tight, closed, intensely private writing, fascinated by physical parts and solitary mental obsession: the ascetic, the nomad, the suicide, the nightmare dreamer. The metaphoric energy drives inward, often sexually, and imaginative insight is like pain, like neuralgia:
hier toes. her nipples,
the small bones in her hands. ache towards perfection.
until the whole acephalous column glows
The Woman is naked before her mirror. This too is a kind of exploration. But she is needed outside; and Mr. Harsent. who has undeniable power and concentration, is needed outside urgently as well.

Author: Chissell, Joan
Title: Youthful Chopin in all its poetry
Full_text:
Youthful Chopin in all its poetry
By Joan Chissell
In a recent television interview Artur Rubinstein admitted that all tile preparation in the world would not guarantee a great performance: miracles of that kind just happened -or the reverse. Certainly the gods smiled at the Brighton Festival on Saturday when .Mr. Rubinstein played Beethoven's C minor and Chopin's F minor concertos with the lIondon Symphony Orchestra under Daniel Barenboim-whose respect for the values of an older generation is rare among the young.
It would be difficult to conceive a performance of Chopin's youthful concerto revealing more of its true poetry, less of its indebtedness to the virtuoso note-spinning of Hummel and Moscheles. Mr. Barenboim again (as recently in the Festival Hall for Ashkenazy) did wonders with the much abused accompaniment; cvery note had a reason for being there, and the dialogue between orchestra and keyboard was uncommonly close. But the arch-magician was Mr. Rubinstein, who combined super-sensitive. limpid-toned response to every passing nuance with a touching simplicity of style. It was not to himself but to the 19-year-old Chopin's genius that he drew attention with so much love. There was a similar affecting simplicity in his playing of Beethoven's No. 3. not least in the Largo, marvellously eloquent without recourse to ponderously slow tempo. In the first movement Mr. Barenboim sometimes seemed in search of stronger drama. but again the performance had an invaluable quality of spontaneous creation. So did Leonore III; the offstage trumpets, and the dawning hope from answering orchestra, were uncommonly stirring.
Beethoven from the Czech Philharmonic in the second of its two concerts in the Dome on Friday had not quite the same high voltage, though by the finale of the Eroica the conductor, Vaclav Smetacek, seemed caught up in the Promethean impulse. Earlier. Mr. Smetacek's respectful sincerity, for all its precision, was not galvanic enough to guarantee precise chording or absolute punctuality in solo entries. woodwind sounded a bit too dulcet and vibrato-laden for Beethoven-the oboe also a bit flat. But in place of intensity there was a welcome mellowness in the orchestra's corpotate tone and style, particularly well suited to Dvorak, whose rarely
heard Mass in D v;as the programme's focal point of interest.
Apart from a few passing gcsturcs of formal, fugal piety. Dvorak does not aim at awe-inspiring grandeur here. The work is a tender, personal testament, full of melting lyricism and detailed imaginaiive colouring of keywords (like * Crucifixus "I and clauses. Friendly angels give car to the balmy kyrie; a contralto soloist launches the Credo like song ; t1lh,re is an evensong sunset glow in the organ introduction to the Benedictus. T-his work drew a much more personal response from Mr. Smetacek. and he had exceliently alert and pliable help from the Brighton Festival Chorus and Sussex University Choir--but they must beware of losing pitch in soft singing.
The festival diary would not be complete without rcference to Sir William Walton s presence on the West Pier as incisive conductor of his Facade with the Brighton Music Theatre Ensemble. though it was unfortunate that a badly placed microphone on Saturday night obscured so many of Alva Lidells streamlined words.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poets from America
Full_text:
Poets from America
From Mistress Bradstreet to the Boston vniind
Richard Holmes
Not much love has been lost between America and her poets. Pound in the Pisan cage. Robinson Jeffers in his stone tower facing the Pacific. Hart Crane leaping in-
to the Gulf of Mexico. And yet. it has been a truly poetic affair, odi et amo: Pulitzer prizes. Poetry Centres, Guggenheim fellowships, the honour of misquotation in a Presidential address.
Donald Hall's excellent new anthology American Poetry (Faber. I Is.) makes inspired strategic use of this uneasy relationship, knowing full well that something of the same mood exists between America and England. Our objections to Madison Avenue. Vietnam, the Chicago Democratic Convention become irrelevant, even helpful " No American writer of any value feels that he represents his country"; when he writes a poem ' he commits an un-American activity ". From Anne Bradstreet (Massachusetts. 1612-1672) to Robert Lowell Mr. Hall makes this a vividly attractive collection of wayward, alien spirits ("Whitman the bearded nurse . . . Edgar Poe the necrophiliac Southern gentleman "). Even Robert Frost.
healthy as a bag of pop corn. is really " romantic. alienated. egocentric ". stopping by dark woods.
Why not ? It is high time we applied such imaginative intelligence to other points of friction, like the American emphasis on -verse technique. In Modern Poets on Modern Poetry (Fontana. 8s. 6d.), II of the 16 poets are transatlantic. Yet poetical manifestos were once thoroughly English (Sydney, Dryden, Shelley ...); always both sign and explanation of suddenly changing conditions. The most distinctive line of theory here is about a more open, responsive verse, discussed in turn by Pound, Carlos Williams, Frost (another surprise), Cummings (bulging lower case), and most recently Charles Olson (1950). The single paragraph bv Olson on pate 278 explaining how " the type writer. due to its space precisions. can indicate exactly the breath, the pauses . . . " is the most simple and helpful explanation of fifty years concern with " the spoken measure " so far written. Do read that.
Olson's " Projective Verse" essay has proved a kind of Ten
Commandments for the Black Mountain poets (though stylistically more like a ball - game harangue than Exodus). Robert Duncan. himself now 50. is perhaps the. most distinguisbed of these. From the start his approach has been magical and aesthetic:
I make poetry as other men make war or make love or make states or revolutions ". 7he First Decade, 1940-50 (Fulcrum Press, 35s.) begins with a wonderfully rich exploration into a world of idealized power and beauty. Even his women are heraldic-" their nakedness is like a feud of brilliancies". But in the long i Venice Poem ". written shortly before discovering Olson (1948), his almost mystical concern for form and energy has reached a critical stage, lovely and yet brittle. rose, ultramarine, rising, falling.
tfhe same wave rolls and reversed unrolls. rolls and reversed-
the dropt cup reappears fron its
fragments,
springs to hanfd as if frvon now-h,re
coitnplet'
Thereafter, to the end of the book and the decade. there is a growing alarm and outgoing alertness which culminates in the fine "Song of the Border Guard",
written during the Korean War, clarion. armed-
Thle borderlines of setnse in the
morning light
are naked as a lihe of 7oetry in a
war.
-His second volume, Derivaiions. 1950-56 (Fulcrum Press, 35s.). is much more an experimental note book. including the period when he taught at Black Mountain College. You can follow him as he strips the line down to syllables; tinkers with the voice hesitating, skipping, stalling; writes himself letters on the whole process. You can now also hear him on the magnificent Stream Record L.P. Robert 1Duncan (P1206. 30s. 9d.).
John Berryman. 55, bearded, crotchety eccentric poet of marvellous elegiac wit, is from a different pole in American writing. with its more literary and traditional attractions. His " Homage to Mistress Bradstreet " (1956) was based on a passionate liaison with that seventeenth century lady from Massachusetts Bay. Nevertheless, in His Toy His Dream hlis Rest (Faber, 50s.) wbat a voice this too has become:-
I consider a song wvill be as hurmming-
bird
stiii. down-light, missile-inetal-hard,
& strarnge
as the world of anti-matter
where they are wvondering: does time
run backward-
which the poet thought was true.
Scarlalfi-suipple;
but can Henry write it ?
Sometimes, yes indeed. Henry i5 Mr. Berryman's protagonist (" not the poet, not me "), speaking or spoken to in as many cases Rs grammar will allow, reminiscent in his multifaced and sensitive furies of Nabokov's Humbert (but without that affliction). In these 308 songs which conclude the " 77 Dream Songs " (1964), Henry is turned like a radar bowl on Mr. Berryman's daily trials.and travels. and esp^cially towards growing old amid the deaths of his literary generation - Delmore Schwartz. R.P. Blackmur. Randell Jarrell, Sylvia Plath. So he becomes cast. eften with exquisite rightness, as the confessor to the Confessional Poets-
We are struck down, repear the crtroniclers,
having glowed. Henry from hearsay can vouch for most of this
Leaving the known ivorld with an
awkward kiss
he haunted back aniong his
colleagues in this verse constructed in angry play.
W. S. Merwin. a New York
poet in bis forties, is yet another contrast amid America's infinite variety. In Tlhe Lice (Hart-Davis, 25s.) his style is as bare as boards, empty of literary reference, slow in appraisal. Single lines stand like pools of meditation: " If you find you no longer believe enlarge the temple". The rhetoric of earlier work has rubbed away, perhaps because he has been constantly on the move and translating since 1949 - Portugal, France, Majorca, England, and France again. Now his similes leap silently at the throat in the manner of continental surrealism: " My words are the garment of what I shall never be/Like the tucked sleeve of a one-armed boy."
And there is still more of America to be found in our Little Presses. I pick out particularly Stephen Jonas's Exercises for tire Ear (Ferry Press, 18s.), an 80-page collection of small ravishing snatches of the Boston sound, witty, wise and immensely skilful, breezy breath from the West
Luies
we ain't sat
but ghee tars
aplenty.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Irish poets: old battles, new hopes
Full_text:
Ifish poets: old battles, new hopes
Richard nb's 'l
When Yeats died in 1939, Irish poetry did not stop. ALL the same until the late 'fifties, it was a Ian tiTne. The work was carried on almost entirely by two men: Austin Clarke and Denis Devlin, later with the magnificent support of the Dublin publisher Liam Miller and his Dolmen Press. In 1951 Clarke's pamphlet Poetry In Modern Ireland was publi&hed-a brilliant unilateral declaration, full of fight ("Wben Keats turned to mythology, he went to Lempriere's Classical dictionary; our poets went out of doors "). Seven years later an Oxford Book of Irish Verse appeared-de facto recognition, admnittance to Parnassus.
Devlin, who became a Consul In the Irish Diplomatic Service, was in the great international tradition of Joyce: he studied in Dublin, Munich and at the Sorbonne; worked in Italy, North America and Mexico; translated from Du Bcllay, Goethe, Quasiviodo, Valery, Eluard, Char . . . an endless list. He presented problems of nationality, identity and belief with a surrealism learnt direct from the French, which may well be his greatest gift to later poets like Thomas Kinsella. The Heavenly Foreignzer (Doitren 52s. 6d.) is his last work. a contemplative love poem, published nine years after his death.
Kinsella, born in 1928, is a major representative of the midcentury generation. He first made his name with translations from the Gaelic published in the fifties. and several fine ballad pieces. Among important early pieces is
" The Baggot Street Deserta ", the poet loaning from his attic window above Dublin. meditating on his art and his nation. Night li'alkler and Other poets (Dolnien. 25s), includes a reprint of his Wormwood sequence, lyric poems of domestic suffering which are haunted by dark intractable sVyIbols of sexual pain
The two trunks in their infinitesinal dance of growth
Have turnld completely about one another, their join
A slowly twisted scar. that I re ise . .
I will dream it stain.
This sequence has already had considerable influence in America, where Mr. Kinsella now lectures.
The new title poem extends the theme of the " Deserta ", but with a bitterness and terror which is overwhelming. Again, the issue is dispossession: from nation, from love, from one's own mind. The opening section recalls the moment wlien the " moron voiceless moon" was torn from the earth, as if it were the formative experience of childhood:It meant little to me then.
Though I remember playing in the
silence
When the rain of fragments dropped
in the streets afterwards
-Bone-splinters, silvery slivers of
screams.
Blood-splinters rattling, like crimson
flint..
This is a powerful and difficult work: Mr. Kinsella advancing to an intensity sometimes close to hysteria.
The pattern of his work is charactcristic in his generation of Irish poets. Exile of the spirit (the
Irish still avoe Amnt}) Whkl is ftlt

Kece, 30s.), the journey of exile utiidoelies all 33 sections. sornetimes describcd with a singing ritual clarityThe season ripe, wid
geese yearly form and nf to some mysterious field behind the north wind
and the sun's scalded eye.
Many a madman's followed suit. One year so did I.
On the way we meet a Tireslas, prophesying decline and fall over blood-red wine at a cafe table; an arial bistory of the Gallic peoples' invasion: the long tideline of the Oedipal battle; and a final image of the dying Gallic or Celtic warrior (the sculpture was dug up in Asia Minor). Despite structural confusion and patches of footsore rhetolic, this becomes after several readings a most striking piece that ends with a lovely coda of hope and renewal.
Turning to Brendan Kennelly's collection one realizes just how new and precious such hope is. In Dream of a Black Fox (Allen Figgis, 25s.) the "white irrational faces" of the young are apparently "clawed and screwed with violence ". During "A Kerry Christmas ", perhaps the best of 44 poems, Mollie Conner, shawled in black,
A to 2X generdtiotl on her back, Nooi,tished by the hni:u rosmigent
story,
Ut XiAi4ing whlat ecstatic voices mean, Stulmbkl to hac private. certain glory. Sx Is an old manl watehing dogs,
eperetlece is thte art of the PigKillcr, tlih very stars are "stark as huttgry cbLildren in our cities ".
Nothling says more for Irish poetry than it has produced mrenwhilc Richard Murphy. The Battle o' Auglhrimn (Faber, 18s.), conmtmissioned by the B.B.C., dovolops directly from Mr. Murphy's previous long sea poems, "The Last Galway Hooker" and "The Cleggan Disaster . 1Hc is now strong enough to abandon nostalgia and savagery for history and judgmcnt.
Aughrim, Horse Ridge, was fought in 1691 between Irish Catholics led by a French marquis and Protestant planters and their Dutch mercenaries. Papal plumes fell before well-deployed money, and 200 more years of colonial repression were sealed. Mr. Murphy leaps at the theme: shuffling time-sequences, characters, points of view, verse forms, he directs the story for hard maximal effects. Cut into unidentified voice among the peasant ranks-
Who cares which foreign king Governs, we'll still fork dung, No one lets us rab soil: Roman or English school Insists it is God
Who must lighten our burden
Digging someone else's garden.-
It is all done with this bold touch: a bright mosaic of incidents drawn to the moment of action, then scattered back up across the centuries. We end with French
tourists re-embarking for Orly airport.
Whioh brings us at last to the new generation, and Derek Mahon who, at 26, publishes -his first book Night Crossing (Oxford, 15s.). This work has taken him from Trinity, Dublin, to Amorica, " successively a university lecturer, Xerox operator" and back to Ireland to teach. This is a small but very varied collection, darting in unexpected directions: a studious craftsman's translation of Villon's " Testament"; persona-poems of de Quincey, Van Gogh, the Vermeer Forger; travel poems in America, and love songs.
There is a fine new freedom here, a sense of available space. Mahon has skill, wit and offhand arrogance. He deals summarily with " Dowson and Company"the Rhymers Club which included the young Yeats-using one of their own " sculpted stanzas ": " Perhaps you found that you had to queu'-For a ticket into hellDespite your sprays of laurel."
In " Glengormley " Mr. Mahon makes his farewell to the heroic landlocked age, with tender sarcasm-
Only words hurt us now. No saint
or hero,
Landing at night from the conspiring
seas,
Brings dangerous tokens to the new
era-
Their sad names linger in the
histories.
The unreconciled, in their meta-
physical pain,
Strangle on lamp-posts in the dawnv
rain....
The Irish are well beyond the Pale.

Author: Hunt, John Dixon
Title: Imperishable presences
Full_text:
Inperishable presences
THE PENGUIN BOOK OF VICTORIAN VERSE
John Dixon Hunt
EDITED WITH AN INTRODUCTION BY GEORGE MacBETH
(Penguin Ss)
THE POEMS OF TENNYSON
EDITED BY CHRISTOPHER RICKS
(Longmnans 84s)
George MacBeth's polemic introduction pleads for Victorians who are neither lapsed Romantics nor primitive modernists he is impatient for us to quit the " insipid truth to life of Whistler " and celebrate instead the " spectacular inventiveness " of Watts and Alma-Tadema. For poetry this requires us to lose those partial views that modern critical taste has contrived and that allow just a few Victorians to become honorary members of the Metaphysical School. And indeed it is rather baffling to see Cleanth Brooks sur. prised by joy at the ambiguities and intricacies of " Tears, Idle Tears", yet ignoring totally the uniquely Victorian work, The Princess, from which the lyric comes.
MacBeth argues for the Victorians largely as narrative writers. They sought, he rightly suggests, fictions in which to conceal and yet explore their inward anxieties and obsessions. So we have Meredith's expression of savage, physical frustration in The Nuptials of Attila, more direct. more effective than Modern Love. and the symbolist narrative of Idylls of thze King, though I think MacBeth fails to appreciate how difficult it was for Tennyson to maintain consistently their structure of "psychological icons " Arnold's Balder Dead, again contrasted favourably with non-fictive pieces like The Scholar Gipsy, is offered as subjective epic,
though perhaps a more striking example, that MacBeth does not mention at all, would be Morris's Sigurd the Volsung, a terribe lament for a long-lost capacity for real emotion.
Quite properly, The Penguin Book of Victorian Verse is devoted to displaying its editor's thesis and, like all good anthologies, it succeeds magnificently by this vigorous tendentiousness. Both its surprises-Sebastian Evans, Agnes Mary Robinson, Lord de Tabley-and its quirks-a penchant for dialect, and selections from Rossetti, Hardy and Tennyson that do not enforce as strongly as they might the ideas of the introduction-are all part of this volume's determined assault upon our vague defensiveness towards Victorian poetry.
If MacBeth is determined to salvage fragments of a poem or a bad oeurre in order to promote fresh notions of Victorian literature, Christopher Ricks provides all Tennyson's poetry for the first time within one cover (just-there are over 1,850 pages). Here we may trace his career from Poems By Two Brothzers, through much that he rejected after one publication (the magnificent " Hesperides ". for instance), until " The Dreamer ", the last poem he finished, in which he laments in dramatic form the conflict between his vision and the iron times and then succumbs (MacBeth's thesis, again) to a less credible, personal lvric of faith in ultimate good. Ricks provides substantial headnotes to each poem on origins, publication and a variety of criticism; footnotes offer a selection of often intriguing textual variants and parallels and allusions to other work-the appropriate passages of Lyell and Chambers, for example, with " In
Memoriam ". It is a handsome and strenuous editorial achievement. of which perhaps the best testimony is that the apparatus is itself constantly enthralling with its impressions of the poet's public. publishing, creative and private lives, from which one returns with renewed attention to the poems themselves.
Several reflections emerge from this full-scale exposure to one of the two poets without whom no sense can be made of the Victorian age (and when, incidentally, may we expect the other, Browning. in this series of Longman's Annotated English Poets ?) Much of Tennyson's imaginative energies were absorbed in a lifelong, fluctuating effort to render public the resources and tensions of his inner life. The effort is obvious not only in the early poems like " Mariana " and " Ulysses " but is maintained with magnificent confidence into later poems like " The Ancient Sage " (1883) and " Demeter and Persephone" (1889). And if Tennyson's best poetry seems to us the dramatizing of the private, wve are perhaps most easily dismnayed by his self-imposed obligation, especially during the Laureate years, to accommodate public themes to poetry; yet his technical resourcefulness makes some of these pieces the best occasional and public verse since Dryden.
Often in apparently direct contrast to his search in myth and other historical narratives for metaphors of his inwardness, there is his dedication to establishing a public typology of Victorian incident and circumstance by which to generalize his vision. The Spectator of 1850 praised his " pictures of common landscape and of daily life " without realizing, as we now car, how these very images of spiritualized commonplace convey and accommodate the forms which Tennyson most eagerly apprehended:
... imperishable presences serene
Colossal, without form, or sense, or
sound,
Dim shadows but unwaning
presences.

Author: Potter, Dennis
Title: Poets: squatting round the mat
Full_text:
Poets: squatting round the mat
Dennis Potter
THE MODERN POET: Essays reprinted from the Revieiv
EDITED BY IAN HAMILTON (Macdonald 35s)
MODERN POETRY: a personal essay
BY LOUIS MACNEICE (Oxford 38s)
Poetry has always been and always will be, in Eliot's lines, a raid on the inarticulate or an " intolerable wrestle with words and meanings." But perhaps those who too emphatically place the emphasis upon "intolerable" should have the grace to pack it in and grow roses or something. Now. too often, the wrestle has become more important than the words. with critics squatting round the tussling-mat eagerly noting down each slippery, inconclusive hold. We are inundated with poems about not writing poems. There are grunting little rhythms acknowledging that, if there is anything meaningful left to say, the poet does not know how to say it.
And so like almost any othez declining sect, or impoverished party, poetry and its attendant swarm of cotinmentators is greatly given to public declarations of intent, regeneration, manifestos and new movements. Critics not only like to cut up cadavers, thev also delude themselves into the belief that by examining the entrails they might somehow transplant a new set of innards into the whole putretying bag of driedup skin.
When A. Alvarez gathered together some moderately good modern verse about seven years ago he called it TIhe Neiv Poetrv and introduced the collection with the kind of spare-part surgery
implied in the preceding paragraph. Beyond The Gentility Principle, he said-and to say something like that you cannot afford to be anything other than aggressive. By the time the Revised Edition came round in 1966, he acknowledged that there was an inevitable gap between 'the generally rather sober verse and the inflammatory introduction ".
Alvarez himself--if onlly to judge by the poem printed at the back of The Modern Poet-is not much of a hand at writing the actual stuff. But if we started chopping up critics in this way there would be almost nothing left to fill the still multiplying acres of higher literary journalism. Better to read inflammatory prose than sober, not to say genteel, verse.
" Here is a collection of essays, lively, lucid and distinguished" begins the blurb which introduces this selection of re-published article from the Review. Lucid however, is very low down in the list of appropriate adjectives. Prose too. can turn out to be an " intolerable wrestle ", this time with words far more than with meanings.
Graham Martin, for instance, seems to approach a poem with a dictionary in his hand, which is the nearest literary equivalent I can think of to pulling the legs off a spider or-if you prefer a more romantic mode-the wings off a butterfly. His piece on Roy Fuller objects to the use of the word " lust " in one of the poems, claiming it to be "one of those unusable words, which should be forcibly retired". I might, with that similar precision which so cleverly camouflages imprecision. question the adverbs in the quoted sentence.
It was no vague nostalgia which
I breathed
Between the purple colloids of the
air.
Martin says this sounds quite pleasant till you look up the meaning of " colloid ". Among things a colloid is "a sticky gelatinous substance having the consistency of glue ". Fuller. he says, was " lucky to have been able to breathe at all ". Other, and worse examples of such word-picking followwhole colloids of obtuseness so gelatinous that it sets into something which, for me, illustrates more clearly than anything else the essential, if apparently wobbly, difference between those who create and those who can t.
But the opening essay in the book, " Dreams and Responsibilities ", is brilliant. Colin Fakck here faces full on to the permanent problems of poetry and the afflicted sensibilities of the contemporary poet. He engages with the things that matter, rather than wvith individual syllables or crossword-filling nonsense. He sees that poetry, far from just conveving the shock or desperation of living godless and almost hopeless in our modern mess, must search out meaning and vision through our experience of others. We still need a real commitment to the human world and its conflicts. Poetry must assume "its full role as the origin and continuous recreation of our morality and our understanding '.
That sounds. again, like manifesto-mongering: but Failck is precise enough in his examples and tight enough in hi5 arguments to make it seem otherwise. Even so he is a critic who accepts that "the only test of criticism in the end is whether we can give
rationality to something we already dimly feel ". The creative writer, by contrast. is surely more concerned with pulling out and articulating what we already dimly feel, ambiguities. irrationalities, contradictions and all.
Louis MacNeice began the last chapter of his 1938 book, Modern Poetry, with the ever timely observation that " writing about poetry often becomes a parlour game. The critic is more interested in producing a water-tight system of criticisms than in the objects which are his data." MacNeice's often dogmatic and propagandist book, now reissued in an attractive new edition, survives the old arguments and the withered enthusiasms of that perilous decade to read with surprising freshness, exuberance and-most stai tling of allambiguity.
Ah, but he could write worthwhile poems. That's why. The combination of these two booksand the increasing sense I have of the unalterable impertinence of weekly reviewing-finally persuades me that I too should pack it in. Not to grow roses, but to turn whatever equipment I may have towards the regenerative process concerned with "tthe origin and continuous recreation of our morality and our understanding ".
Arrogance is sometimes better than impertinence. But I refuse to look up either word in the dictionary. I am not yet Morocco bound.
Dennis Potter svill continue to vrite regularly, althoutgh no longer weekly, for The Timnes Satuirdav Review.

Author: Furbank, P. N.
Title: The doctor and the poet
Full_text:
The doctor and the poet
P. N. Furbank
THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS
(Mac(iibbon and Kee 63s)
It is a peculiarity of poetry, among all the arts, that you can not only make poems of the kind vou intend to but also make them ont of the experience of trying to and failing. William Carlos Williams has written fine poems of both kinds.
Some of his poems succeed. as he would want thean to, in grasping and rendering " thinRs ". But more often, when he succeeds. what be Is rendering is moments of baffled conviction in the face of "things "-moments when the complete beauty is there. at a hair's distance, ready to be clasped, but what the words grasp is the perfect conviction rather than the " thing " itself
That remarkable poem " A morning imagination of Russia" dramatizes what is clearly a common experience for him-a fumbling progress from " the feeling/ that there is a piece of glazed paper/between me and the paper" to the desired state when
... We have paid heavily. Bat we have gotten-touch. The eves and the cars down on it. Close.
The poem is an achieved work of art. His Autobiography (published in America as long ago as 1951, though the* publishers oddly don't mention this) is not quite that, but it has the same pattern. It funbles, things come in a bit at random; at the best it's what the theory of "Projective Verse " would call a * field ", and at the worst it's an old man rambling; and then, a number of times, excitement sets in, the prose
leaps into life, and something is said with great force and genius.
The theme which really engages WiUiams, who spent most of his life as a general practitioner in Rutherford, New Jersey, is " Medicine and Poetry ". His theory of poetry is inextricably tied up with his theory of a doctor's duty. The doctor listens. He loses himself in his patient; he becomes himi, so that when he detaches himself again it is like reawakening from sleep. And what he is listening for, and what the patients are trying to communicate, is a poem, "the poem which their lives are being lived to realize ".
It is actually there, in the life before us, every minute that we arc listening, a rarest element-not in our imaginations but there, there in fac. it is that essenoe which is hidden in the very words which are going in at our ears and from which we must recover underlying meaning as realistically as we recover metal out of ore.
A very un-Wordsworthian and un-Eliot-like view of poetry: for, in their own ways, both the Symbolist and the Romantic poet claim the right to exploit reality, transmuting it into something elsc or applying it to their own egocentric concerns (what did the Old Cumberland Beggar ever get out of Wordsworth ?). Whereas the essence of Williams's theory is respect for reality. But it is a theory which his whole life, as well as his work, gives a kind of backing to.
These passages on poetry and doctoring, and on the general artistic revolution to which he belongs (' the making of that step, to come over into the tactile qualities, the words themselves beyond the mere
thought expresed "), together with a curious, semi-successful attempt to discuss a friend's house, without metaphor, as a poem, are the heart of the book.
As for the rest, it's hit and miss. He manages to say fairly little about the Paris of Stein, Hemingway and Joyce; and not al that much about Pound, who was an intimate friend, though he beautifuly catches his swagger. For a lot of the time the style is help. less and cliche-ridden; there are various kinds of information he never troubled to learn how to *-ut into prose at all. Nor has he any objection if anecdotes turn out to ihave no point; the profoundest stories have no point.
... I never wanted to be a surgeon, Marvellous men-I take off my hat to themn. I knew one once who whenever he'd get into a malignant growth would take a hunk of it and rub it into his armpit afterward. Never knew why.
It's a ramshackle book only if you want to think of it as ramshackle, for the meaningfulness of the life it records gives it point. You sense this strongly in the final chapter, which has a very strange quality. Williams takes his grandson to revisit the scene of his magnus opus, Paterson. It is winter, and the brink of the falls at Paterson has grown a crop of ice-globes, as big as a man's head. His grandson, who all through the drive has kept looking out hopefully for dangers, is thrilled. He manages to grub up one of these "hell-cabbages ", and he and his grandfather start hurling them furiously on to the ice below. This little coda to Paterson is as fine as anything in the poem itself.

Author: Rees-mogg, William
Title: Pope and the poetry of Man
Full_text:
Pope and the poetry of Man
William Rees-Mogg
ALEXANDER POPE: The education of a genius
BY PETER QUENNELL
(Weidenfeld and Nicolson 63s)
Alexander Pope's character was as antithetical as his verses. There is hardly any statement one can make which cannot be countered by its opposite. Pope had a genius for friendship but his quarrels with those who had been his friends were as bitter as with his enemies. Pope was psychologically marked -by the crippling disease of his childhood-he was only 4ft. 6in. high-but his early years were spent in extremely happy family life. Pope had no understanding of theoretical philosophy yet the Essay on Man is the only major didactic poem on a philosophical theme in English.
This series of contradictions and the contrast, which Peter Quennell brings out, between his ambition to be a good man and his inability to manage it. makes the life of Alexander Pope a fascinating adjunct to his poetry. His life has been written many times and we have more evidence about him than about any but a very few of our major literary figures. Although he was born only 124
years after Shakespeare, the reliable knowledge we have about every aspect of his life is in total at least a hundred times as great as the evidence we have about Shakespeare. This mass of evidence is almost as bewildering as the shifts of his intrigues.
Mr. Quennell has written a life which has the feeling for character of a good novelist. His method is entirely scholarly and he has relied throughout on the latest available work on Pope's life, and particularly no doubt on the letters. The effect is to bring out the character in a living way and particularly the character while it was still forming, Pope's character as a child and as a young man.
This book, like Professor Sherburne's excellent wvork. is the life of Pope as a young man. Peter Quennell takes Pope to the age of 40 and Professor Sherburne left him rather carlier than that The three major monuments of his poetry in this period are The Rape of the Lock, the translation of Homer and The Dunciad. Mr. Quennell is at his best in dealing with The Rape of the Lock, which he obviously enjoys and finds delightful. He gives a good account of the translation of
Homer. though he is rather less successful in bringing out its poetic quality and he seems to feel affection for Thze Dunciad.
From his earliest work Pope had developed the peculiar intensity of expression which is his particular virtue. There is no English poet who can press so much meaning into each phrase while retaining such complete clarity. He is also, like Shakespeare, though his range is less wide, primarily a poet of human nature. By a peculiar aberration of critical judgment, the romantic critics thought that inanimate nature-daffodils and mountains-were poetic in a sense that human nature and human society was not.
Perhaps it was the development of the novel after the publication of Pamela in 1742 that gave authors a different and more flexible form for the portrayal of character. Yet for those who find human nature a subject of inexhaustible interest, Shakespeare and Pope are the two inexhaustible English poets. Peter Quennell has succeeded in bringing out the character of a poet whose first belief was "the proper study of mankind is man "-

Author: Null
Title: So honourably born
Full_text:
THE TIMES aturday EVIEwV
The UJnder-read Classics: Wordsworth
So honourably born
"There are several reasons why his
poetry is so little respected by the young... and one of them is that he does not
write for them." Margaret Drabble
rescues Wordsworth from the tyranny of the examination syllabus and finds that,
uneven as they are, his works show enough intelligence, insight and unease
to make them company for a lifetime.
Perhaps it is Impertinent to describe Wordsworth as underread: but under-read, misread and under-enjoyed by me he certainly was for years, and I can't help feeling that others like myself were diverted at school from a true liking by rn-considered readings of The Daffodils and totally incomprehensible passages from that profound and obscure work, The Prelude.
When I looked, years later, at the Lyrical Ballads, they appeared to me in a light of revelation: I had not expected to find anything so moving, so deeply felt, so highly intelligent, so courageous. And from this new beginning I was led to the later works, and to the whole magnificent, consciously endured curve of ascendancy and decline that marks his poetic output.
There are several reasons why his poetry is so little respected by the young who read him dutifully for the examination syllabus; and one of them is that he does not write for them. He is not a poet Nvho writes with violent or accessible optimism or despair. He writes a great deal about children and adolescents, but not for them: he writes reflectively, and from a stoic experience of maturity. Even his earliest poems are marked with resignation and endurance. Many teachers, themselves charmed by the recaptured and recreated sensations of youth in The Prelude, must have thought it a poem that would communicate easily; and Wordsworth is also suitable for teaching in that he never writes about sex, being, as Byron and Shelley pointed out, a solemn and unsexual man, " a kind of moral eunuch ".
But in a sense these very qualities disqualify him as a candidate for juvenile enthusiasm: the passions he describes are peculiarly those of maturity, and childhood in his works is always seen through adult eyes. A large section of his poems was grouped, by himself, under the title "Poems
