of the Affections n-and It b startling to note how many of these deal with parental love, often betrayed or harassed; and of all the passions this is perhaps the least sympathetic to the nonparticipant, being a notoriously one-way emotion. Even the loveliest evocations of it, the most lyrical, are inaccessible: the last two stanzas of The Affliction of Margaret, for instance, which seem now to me to be among the most touching he ever wrote, and which unite simplicity and dignity of diction with striking human insight, used to leave me quite unmoved: the last of these says (the mother is speaking of her lost son)
Beyond participation bie
My troubles, and beyond relief: If any chance to heave a sigh,
They pity me, and not my grief.
-and this is precisely the point, her troubles are beyond participation, at least to the uninitiated.
And other, less tender and conventional pieces do not even invite participation, for Wordsworth never shies away from describing the more homely and indeed, to some, ludicrous instances of affection-that of the mother for her idiot child, that of the cheerful Matron of Jedburgh for her mute and paralysed husband. And this leads to another of the reasons why his work repels so many: he is not afraid of the ridiculous, whereas there is nothing that schoolchildren more suspect and dislike. Some of his poems, such as the Idiot Boy, The Thorn, Simon Gray, and We Are Seven, arouse nothing but derision in the classroom, and beyond it.
Wordsworth did not escape criticism for these works even in his lifetime, and from his most syrnpathetic critics: a friend tried to dissuade him from including We Are Seven in the Lyrical Ballads, saying, prophetically, that it would lay him open to everlasting ridicule, but he replied mildly that it must take its chance. Coleridge, more sensitive to bathos than
Wordsworth in Westmorland: memory, perc,ption and a sense of loss.
" The Child is father of the Man " . . .
tress. His sister Dorothy nursed him back to health from the mental breakdown that this experience helped to cause, and he transferred his affections to her: too violently and dangerously, one cannot doubt, as her diaries and his Lucy poems show. Dorothy presided over the rest of his emotional life: she went with him to Calais to arrange the future of his French daughter, she stood by while he married (and it was certainly not a marriage of passion) Mary Hutchinson, and she lived with him and his wife for the rest of her life.
These facts speak to me of a damming up or diversion of natural sexual energy, which is perhaps one of the causes for the feeling of imminent loss of power lhat pervades the poetry he wrote in his mid-thirties. He aged early, physically : and Dorothy, in her fifties, fell ill and suffered for the next 30 years, which she spent confined to a wheel chair, from recurring bouts of mental illness. Wordsworth himself suffered from various psychosomatic afflictions, and one can only guess at the pent emotions that took their vengeance in that apparently peaceful household. Almost unbearably poignant to read, now, is a short poem written for Dorothy in youth, wvhich projects Wordsworth's ideal of old age:
Thy thoughts and feelings shall
not die, Nor leave thee, when grey hairs
are nigh, A melancholy slave;
Blut an old age, serene and bright, And lovely as a Lapland night Shall lead thee to the grave.
So few of Wordsworth's images of content were fully achieved: his friends and his beloved daughter Dora predeceased him, his poetic vision failed him, and he was left alone, grimly surviving, solitary and eccentric, stoically upholding the virtues of companionship and normality. It was not for nothing that he wrote at the age of 32:
We poets in our youth begin in
gladness. But thereof come in the end
despondency and madness. In fact, the whole of his middle period is marked by a sense of almost willed foreboding: he willed upon himself a living death, as he willed upon Lucy/Dorothy a poetic death. Occasionally, a gleam of his bitter awareness shows through the endeavour to survive: as when he looks at the dying celandine, " and in his spleen, he smiled that it was grey ".
Finally, I think it is this acknowledgment of the process of loss that I most admire in him: he accepts it, as he accepts mutability, dissolution, decay, vicissitude, flux, the whole ebb and flow of grace-all words drawn from his own vocabulary. His works, uneven though they are, are not merely the blossoming of one brief period: they chart and span a lifetime, they are company for a lifetime.
Wordsworth, effectively dissuaded him from making his blind Highland boy set out upon the water in a common bathtub (as he did in fact), and Wordsworth obligingly substituted a turtle shell for the bathtub: but some may feel his original adherence to the bathtub more truly decorous.
He defended the subject matter of The Idiot Boy in a long, celebrated and eloquent letter to John Wilson, which is one of his finest pieces of prose: and when Sarah Hutchinson, his sister-in-law, wrote to him that the leech gatherer in Resolution and Independence talked too much about nothing much, be rebuked her insensitivity with characteristic and daunting confidence:
You speak of his speech as tedious . . . it is in the character of the old man to tell his story in a manner which an impatient reader must necessarily feel as tedious. But Good God ! Such a figure, in such a place, a pious, self-respecting, miserably infirm Old Man telling such a tale ! My dear Sarah, it is not a matter of indifference whether you are pleased with this figure and his employment.
One cannot fail to admire the sheer strength of his moral and artistic judgments, and in his successful period at least they are powerfully united.
But perhaps tho greatest bar to an early admiration, and the most lasting inducement to it, is not bis subject matter or his indifference to ridicule but the fact that he is a poet of process, of growth, of change. His poems chart the growth of his own mind, from its earliest enthusiasms and terrors, through its social awakening, to its gradual disappointment and resignation; from the ardent revolutionary to the distributing of stamps for Westmorland, and the Laureateship.
Many images in
the water
Many of his greatest poems have an internal process and growth, a sense of motion and natural development, that are unrivalled in any other poet. He is a nature poet, indeed, but not merely the landscape poet and flower painter that the Victorians admired: he charts the unexpected but inevitable movements of the mind. and those movements, as he describes them, are never mechanical or rationally supposed: they are felt, they are real, they have the authority of experience. In the sonnet Sutrprised by Joy, the movement from momentary hope. through sickening remembrance of loss, to hopeless grief, is conveyed with such natural ease and such fidelity that the reader shares and endures 'Aith the poet the whole cycle of emotion.
On a larger scale, the whole of The Prelude (which is sub-titled Growth of a Poet's Mind) is an
exploration of change, not chronologically or clinically recounted, but relived and passionately questioned and recreated. The structure of the poem itself reflects this exploration: it is not logical or carefully planned, it flows and returns and makes detours, with the movement (to use an image which he himself constantly uses) of a river. The poem is full of developed images that describe the natural, organic processes of perception; there is one in which he compares the process of memory, of looking into past time, to " one who hangs down-bending from a boat ", who sees in the water many images...
Yet often is perplexed, and cannot
part
The shadow from the substance,
rocks and sky,
Mountains and clouds, from that
which is indeed
The region, and the things which
there abide
In their true dwelling; now is
crossed by a gleam
Of his own image, by a sunbeam
now....
and there is another, similar one in which he describes his first impressions Of London, and their slow growth, as those of a man who enters a cavern with torches, and at first is confused, then thinks he sees the roof and all the details "1 exposed and lifeless as a written book "; but who then looks again, and finds
a new quickening shall succeed, at
first
Beginning timidly, then creeping
fast
Through all which he beholds; the
senseless mass,
In its projections, wrinkles,
cavities . . .
Unites, embodying everywrhere
sonie pressure
Or image, recognized or new,
some type
Or picture of the world ...
Both these images describe beautifully the act of perceiving: the shifting layers of awareness, the ebb and flow of reality and vision.
Wordsworth is a peculiarly truthful poet: he never claims to see what he cannot see, he reports faithfully the limitations, as weLl as the dim extents of his revelations, and his total work is very far in effect from the abstractions that represent him in some anthologies. He is never afraid to expose his own ignorance: his description of his changing feelings towards the French Revolution is both an impressive historic account and an impressive piece of selfcriticism.
He has also a great gift for capturing the irrational, the casually and not causally connected images that speak to him and constitute his moments of power: Resolution and Independence is a perfect example of a poem which seems to tell a story, but which in fact, as do so many incidents in The Prelude. presents instead a fusion of internal emotions and external landscape, an illogical yet wholly significant conjunction oI passion and event. Several of his best pas-
sages are based upon moments trivial or seemingly trivial, that widen out into meaning with a kind of spreading flow: as when the Woman in Scotland says to him. "What, you are stepping Westward ? " or the man on the mountain informs him that. without noticing it, he has already crossed the Alps: both remarks at once factual and portentous. both incidents at once trivial, historic, and symbolic.
Wordsworth perhaps best deserves to be described as a nature poet because his images, incidents, and thought processes are natural: they are drawn from nature. they are not yoked by violence together, they show both the psychological insight of the great nineteenth-century novelists, and the organic wholeness of the scenery which inspired him.
The trials of
human affection
Another reason why some fail to admire Wordsworth is a charge that can be laid at his door only: it is that he wrote such a vast quantity of bad and indifferent poetry, and betrayed, in doing so, some of his own finest principles. How a man who wrote as he did of poetic diction could have ended up composing lines like "Thine is the tranquil hour, purpureal Eve" is hard to imagine. But to an addict like myself, even these lapseswith the exception, perhaps, of the sequence of sonnets in praise of capital punishment-have a certain power, because they are in a sense so much a part of the cycle that began with such energy, and because the reasons for the decay, appear to have been so human, so inevitable, and so honourably born. They are part of a whole.
There has been much speculation about the causes for Wordsworth's poetic decline, and the sad truth is that the value of his poems can be roughly assessed by a quick glance at the date: anything before 1805 is well worth attention. anything between 1805 and 1820 is worth attention, and anything after 1820 is for enthusiasts only. The causes for this falling off can of course never be known. but it seems to me that he was, in a way, trapped by his own ethic, and by his own affiliations. He had thrown in his lot with human affection, and he had to endure its trials. He suffered very greatly from the death of his brother John in 1805, as various elegies bear witness, and also from the death of two of his children in infancy: but most of all he must have suffered for his sister Dorothy, who at one time appeared to him as his salvation.
One can only speculate about Wordsworth's sexual nature: the facts are that while he was in France at the age of 21 he fell in love with a French girl, Annette Vallon, who bore him a daughter, and whom he abandoned, reluctantly, in great dis-

Author: Thwaite, Ann
Title: Asking to be read
Full_text:
Asking to be read
Few chuldren nowadays miss the chance of reading really good twentieth-century poetry at schooL If there are still some teachers around like the one David Holbrook knew, who ridiculed Lawrence's " Snake " and forbade the reading of "modern stuff", there are many more who use the new anthologies, which contain a majority of work written nearer five years ago than 45. It's usually good modern stuff, too; the days of empty poems about goblins and jolly farmers are over. Nature poems need no longer be about larches in gay green gowns and nuts ripe-brown which come tumbling down.
But what about the children's
bookshelves at home ? Tha chances are that among the alluring new picture-books and storybooks, poetry is represented by a 1928 edition of Come Hither in faded maroon, with its spine loose. Parents with guilty consciences would do well to buy a new book: D. H. Lawrence Poems selected for young people by William Cole (Macmillan 21s.). There are some odd inclusions including some poor poems, but all the right ones are there and the book asks to be read, with its scarlet jacket, strange black illustrations and well-spaced lines.
There are poems here which can mean something (quite a lot) to a child as young as eight, including "'Snake", of course, and the extraordinary "Tortoise Family Connections". Older children will begin to understand what Lawrence meant when he called thought "man in his wholeness fully attending ".
With his " hidden emotional patterns ", Lawrence has recently been called a highly dangerous model for young writers of verse. I wonder if he really is. At least in his best poems he keeps his eye solidly on the subject, despising self-importance and overstatement. Gregory Harrison, whose Posting Letters (Oxford, 15s.) is a collection of new poetry specially written for children, would be a far worse model. He himnself is at his best when he is most simple. He writes of men, come to clear the site of a Roman camp for building, " running coarse thumbs along axe blades/ and looking coldlylat the useless trees". His poem "The Snipe" ends "And I was glad/they'd pulled me from my chair to see/ this creature feeding/so fastidiously ". But mostly he is too dense, too clotted, over-loaded with clever-clever phrases.
Nonsense Is a good thin end of the wedge for offspring affecting to dislike poetry; there is no denying that it is poetry but few can persist in disliking it. William Cole, the Lawrence editor, has compiled an excellent bedside book, Oh What Nonsense (Methuen 16s.), embellished with marvellously apt line drawings by Tomi Ungerer. There are a few familiar faces here (Sir Smasham Uppe's and those of Milligan's thousand hairy savages) but most are unknown, American, and well worth getting to know. Cole has deliberately avoided including Lear and Carroll because they are so readily available.
Those who want the Carroll poems away from the prose can now buy Jabberwocky and other poems with lots of full colour by Gerald Rose (Faber 18s.).
Ann Thwaite

Author: CUMMINGS, RY E.
Title: Shift along, Catullus
Full_text:
Richard Holmes
Shift along, Catullus
COMPLETE POEMS 1913-35 atod 1936-62
RY E. E.. CUMMINGS
(MacGibbon and Kee, 2 volumes, 63s each)
The verdict of his own generation seems to be: well, hand him down C:atullus' old laurels. For the man ix-ho wrote twelve books of poetry, tWo autobiographical novels, several plays and. stories and cssays. it is a bit dusty.
Edward Estlin Cummingspoet-painter. born Cambridge. Mlassachusetts 1894: lived in Paris. New York. and New EngLand: died September. 1962-was that unforgivable thing, a Romantic. All his life he believed in himself and other individuals, rather than the sublime generalities of Marxism or Heaven or the United States or Literature: " nobody in general and someone in particular is incorrigibly and actually alive ". Pound (who believed in Literature) had his ideas tested to the breaking point in the cage
-t Pisa, when he was 55; but Cummnings was on the anvil at 23, just out of Harvard.
For five months in the winter of 1917 he endured a concentration camp at La FertW lacd where he was herded and frozen and starved by the French (for whom he had volunteered to serve in the Ambulance Corps). In a situation which Kafka or Camus would have turned into a grey nauseous, nightmare. Cummings continued to make notes and sketches, and five years later, with the help of T. E. Lawrence and RFobert Graves, he published The !5normous Room, a book of irrepressible gaiety and grip, reissued this year (MacGibbon and Kee 36s).
At La Ferte, Cummings found the beliefs that carry all his writing. He found that the lyrical subsists even to the extremities of fear and filth, and is therefore real. He found in the personalities of his fellowv inmates an unassailable fortress of value. (There are four tigures especially, described, after Bunyan as The Delectable Mountains: a gyppsy. a Polish mute, the camp fool. and the magnificent childlike Jean Le Negre. These are the first occupants of what becomes in the poetry a denfirnonde gallery of balloonmen, whores, knifeiliarpeners and tramps.
Besides being a Romantic, Cummings was all his life a
painter. This has also proved awkward. The connexion between mnodern painting and modern poetry, while familiar to Frenchmen such as Apollinaire, Breton and Aragon (whom Cummings knew and translated), is obscure in English. We tend to think back to George Herbert's wing and altar-shaped poems, and remain puzzled. But Cummings was at home in Paris. and intimate in European art. His first published paper (Harvard. 1915) was a comparison of Cubism and Futurism with modern verse technique. In his Comnplete Poems we have at last the ful range of his achievement and example, which might well be seen as analogous to Paul Klee's.
Like Klee, Cummings settled on the childlike vision as the essential one, which is the characteristic strength of
all ignorance toboggans into know and trudges up to ignorance again: but winter's not forever, even snow melts; and if Spring should spoil
the game, what then ?
as weU as such devastating notorieties as: " A politician is an arse upon/which everyone has sat except a man.". Like Klee, he discovered the value of neverending experiment / games, of inspired ceaseless tinkering with his materials. (There are 175 extant manuscript drafts of the poem ' rosetree, rosetree" in Volume 11). And like Klee, he allowed kinesis. the movement of the " active line " to shape his composition. to destroy the literal surface, to carry everything before it. Cummnings's line is always jumping about, scattering letters and punctuation marks, rushing down the page in a shower of syllables.. Brackets serve to drop the voice, or raise an eyebrow; spare words pun-up with each other; even individual letters sometimes mobilize (as here), helping the moon to get up.
mOOn Over tOwvns mOOn whisper
less creature huge grO pingness
Cummings said he used " intelligence at intuitional velocitv". Surely he has nmore to teach our concrete pocts than any computer ?
tn 7fthree Pl/avs and X Bildlet (Peter Owen, 37s. 6d.), he is working fruitfully on other frontiers. though the connexion with the poetry is direct. (In the collection "Is 5" of 1922. he had written:
"Like the burlesque comedian I am abnormally fond of that precision which creates movement ".) HiJim, the major play here, has a
good deal of the burlesque, moreof the Absurd. and the headlong swiftness, of the revue. It is in three Acts. dominated by a lover's dialogue (the artist and the women) closely, playfully and sweetly written as a dreamlike search for identity. The discussion is punctuated by the unlikely advent of three Miss Weirds-rocking chairs and knitting-and various contemporary social phenomena (1927) in light disguise: bread mobs, capitalists and drunks,
fascists and fairies and Englisb-. men on tours, Americans (" mostpeople") in Montmartre ordering "sham pain ". Frankie and Johnnie in Harlem. and others.
In the lovers' dialogue. there is a typical outburst:
Thc average "painter ", poet " '*playwright" .. is a person who cannot leap through a hoop from the back of a galloping horse, make people laugh with a clown's. mouth.. . But imagine a human being who balances three chairs on top of another., on a wire. eighty feet in the air with no net underneath, and then climbs to the top chair ...
Cummings's fantasia show his absolute modern relevance again: it is precisely the poet as performer. as acrobat. as clown (and perhaps, hopefully, as magician) which now fascinates us.
Ever since R. P. Blackmur delivered his attack on Cummings in the thirties-a sensationalist. incapable of moving beyond posies -there has been something of a conspiracy to underestimate or ignore what he actually managed. But now the books are available. a great store of experiment and joy, waiting to be drawn on. Moreover, Cummings has been a harbour of tradition, too: no other modern American poet has used rhyme and regular Iyric metres as he has done; or written so many fine sonnets (pate Bcrrvman}-a skill he learnt from Rossetti. In the last pages of his poems there is an overwhelming sense that his life and work had rung true for him:
Wild (at our first) beasts uttered
- human weords
'our second coming made stoncs
sine like birds---
but o the starhiuhed silence which
our third's
No, crabbed (though bMloved) Catullus, keep your crown: but. shift along a bit.

Author: Sadie, Stanley
Title: Thrills and poetry in The Trojans
Full_text:
Thrills and poetry in The Trojans
By Stanley Sadie
In what was probably the longest ever Prom----it started at 4.30, ended after 10.0-the B.B.C. gave us yesterday The Trojans, complete to the last note: a splendid anticipation of next year's Berlioz centenary. Not many operas can be expected to go so well in concert performance. True, spectacle and atmosphere are a vhal part of it. as with every French Vrand opera; but the static, essentially non-developing character of much of the work represents another aspect of the French classical tradition. The Albert Hall, oratorio's home, did not seem a bad place for these grand tableaux. for these noble human beings inexorably steered by forces outside themselves.
And in quite another way, too. Trhe Trojans responds to concert performance: Berlioz's marvellously subtle and fantastically varied score comes over with a clarity and sparkle one could hardly hope for from a pit.
1 he performance itseif was Masnificent. Colin Davis, of course, conducted: he drew almost uniformly superlative playing from the L.S.O.. and shaped the more
dramatic scenes to produce thrilling climaxes-in Part 2 especially. for Part 1, anyway, musically less even. was marred by small slips (though the clarinet solo for Andromache was beautifully done. by Bernard Walton). The l..S.O. Chorus. with Chelsea Opera Group members, sang finely too. particularly in the big ceremonial scenes, but sounded a bit elephantine (it is aboiit 175 strong)
There was much first-rate solo singing: among the secondary roles I was speciallv struck bv Anna Reynolds's sensitive, shapely sustained lines in Anna's music. Ryland Davies's sweetly nostalgic singing of Hvlas's lament, Delme Bryn-Jones's clear if not particularty poetic account of Choroebus's part. Amy Shuard made a strong Cassandra. though it obviously does not lie ideally for her. Dido was the accomplished and dependable Josephine Veasey--- not quite thrilling, as yet, though her duets with Anna and Aeneas were perhaps the evening's best things, vith lovely soft, poetic iinging: Aeneas was Ronald Dowd, a strong. characterful. involved performance, the words (it vas sung in English) excellently enunciated.

Author: Null
Title: Britten's haunting poetry
Full_text:
Opera/Stanley Sadie
Britten's haunting poetry
Royal Opera House: Billy Budd
By Benjamin Britten
Not many contemporary operas pull as fiercely on basic feelings as Billy Budd; it is one of the most difficult works to write about, one where the task of intellectualizing and verbalizing emotions is desperately hard.
That I should have to begin a notice of last night's Covent Garden revival with such an apologia may perhaps testify to the performance's impact. The fearful, haunting poetry of the work can not often have been more fully realized. Though the opera is not. to my mind, wellproportioned in its revised two-act version-the seamen's acclamation of " starry Vere " has diminished point, the final scene of Act I seems prolonged in the context and the hanging scene disproportionately (if mercifully) brief. Still, it emerges as one of the sharpest, most forceful portrayals of AngloSaxon attitudes: of the subduing of emotion, of the relationships between men in a closed community, of love and hate. compassion and cruelty, corruption and martyrdom.
The principal roles were taken by the same artists as in the first performances, four years ago, of the two-act version. Robeit Kerns
makes a warm, fresh Billy, all innocence and simplicity; but I wish his vords came across more clearly (an American is at a disadvantage when ears are tuned to English diction). Forbes Robinson's Claggart is masterly: not merely deep and cavernous of voice, but wi.h a kind of stillness of heart, fixity of purpose, which bear home his darkness (whether or not his soliloquy, rationally speaking, makes sense). Captain Vere was sung by Richard Lewis, particularly impressively in the framing scenes for the r eminiscing old man, slightly less so in the main action. where there was some want of both resolutioand reflectiveness; V'ere is surely a bigger character than he suggested. There were some very fine sketches of the smaller roles; I can single out only John Shaw on the upper deck, Delme Bryn-Jones down below.
Britten's score responds splendidly to Georg Solti's conducting: 1 admired not only his handling of the vivid moments or the taut ones (like the court-martial scene) but more particularly of the quieter ones-the scene after the flogging, the soft, sustained low strings behind the officers' conversation in Vere's cabin. the delicate placing of those suggestive triads when Vere goes to tell Budd his fate. Ande Anderson has rehearsed the production, to excellent effect, it is full of touches which add point and depth to the action.

Author: Null
Title: Selected Poems by W. H
Full_text:
SELECTED POEMS bv W. H. Auden (Faber 7s 6d). The poems for this "original " paperback selection are chosen by Auden himself and extend in time from Poemns 1928 to About the House (1966). It is a very lovely selection, detailed and representative,
appealing to every kind of audience that Auden's poetry has enjoyed, and marks Auden's recent preference for the shorter poems. Epigrams, lullabies, religious definitions, give way to the poetry of moral landscape and "civility '. and the volume ends appropriately with "Thanksgiving for a Habitat", a celebration of the homeliness that expresses spiritual values. In a selection extending over forty years, it might have been helpful to see the poems dated.

Author: Holmes, Richard
Title: Poetry: inside history of small conflicts
Full_text:
k Poetry: inside history of small conflicts
Behind the student's public battle, the parents' private one. Behind any door, the tight inside history of small conflicts a family has, stretching back through each generation. The struggle of a few close-knit lives with poverty, respectability, hard work, illness, love. And behind one door is the remarkable Family Albusn (London Magazine Editions, lOs. 6d.) of Brian Jones.
It opens with Aunt Emily, growing up in the backstreets of North London before the First World War. Spinsterhood is waiting for her. She is lonely, generous, a little mad:
Eldest. Little old lvolnan from
thte start ... Liked the wa(y cats padded
for food, padded off, kept
neat, Wvere ill in corners.
Mother wvorked. I fed kids, kissed, soaped them, shoved all into bed. And it
wvas horses and cats I loved.
Then the rest of the family. Grandad marooned and asthmatic in his grate-side armchair after' a lifetime on tropical seas. Uncle Fred, snarling through his last teeth at the loss of the Boer War, of the Empire, of his own dignitv. Pretty Ada--' family-treasured like the Klondyke nugget brought
home by Uncle Fred ". Bill, -her husband, who moves out to the suburbs, makes good, wears a bowtie at the boss's party. And finally the new generation,, their son David, who goes to University, breaks with his background, and remembers his wedding with laughter:
tottering and dignified, her tribe
(all well-to-do) watchzed over thze glass-rims
warily the reined and ominous exuberance of all mny lot-
pink hats exploding flowers. low-born, squat
Brian Jones writes with passionate colloquial sympathy about incidents we all recognize, the daily pressures behind living in England now. Using a series of dramatic monologues - funny, sour or lyrical-he does that most difficult thing, tell a story at direct poetic intensity. Like Aunt Emily he can feel each person as special, as " touchy as a nettle ".
Mr. Jones is still in his twenties. He works as a teacher in Canterbury, and published a striking first collection two years ago. The present book, in its openness and originality, puts him on the front line o& the new English poetry. It is writing to startle anyone, with the
jerky detailed authenticity of your own home-movie. He can make the new blaze out of the old, like the moment when Grandad grows expansive in his armchair in Islington, and suddenly begins to tell of great seabirds-
that followed clippers in the
China seas
and never budged a wing, and
of the fogs
arou(nd Newfoundland, that a
sailor could
carve with a knife, or cork in
bottles... and finally.
he tried to give what wealth he'd
gained those hints of possibility
that goad you ng blood....
The American poet Robert Bly is also concerned with blood, but blood spilt, the blood on the hands of his own country. The Light Around the Body (Rapp and Whiting, 21s.) is a public protest. It is a named attack on the imperialism of Johnson, Rusk -and more surprisingly- John F. Kennedy. It is a lament for " The Great Society ". What kind of irony is it when you see that these poems carry the American National Book Award 1968 ?
The Kitchen Poems (Cape Goliard, 13s. 6d.) of J. H. Prynne
acknowledge the impendinrg crisis, but explore it behind the scenes again, and are more probing and much more difficult. Mr. Prynne's " kitchen " is basically economics: the backroom where not only wars but all our individual jobs and hopes and fears are calculated, graphed and statistically defined. He shares the distrust of this generalizing process-affecting both our language and our thinkingwhich comes from the tradition of Pound, from the great Cantos against usury.
The English cendition is now so abstract that it soumds like an old record; the hiss and crackle suborns the music, so that the trte literal has very few names.
The search for the " true literal" ("The public is no more than the sign on the outside of the shopping bag "), deserves putting in a current context, and an Introduction could have ihelped here. Briefly: Mr. Prynne (Cambridge Lecturer, specialist in Victorian poetry and black corduroy suits) is in close contact with the Black Mountain poets.
Working in what is a new field. the "Kitohen Poems " are still struggling with their own problems of abstract language, and a
deadened verse paragraph which occasionally flares into life: " the splintered naming of wares creates targets for want like a glandular riot ". They ask for patience and attention, and hold out for the future.
Anselm Hollo has produced a marvellously cool translation of Selected Poems: Paavo Haavikko (Cape Goliard, 16s.). Haavikko is a Finn from Mr. Hollo's native Helsinki, the leading poet of the Modernists who brokle away from " Germanic syntax and nationalistic idealism " in the 1950s. In particular, the long poem " The Bowmen ", with its mixture of imagism and troll-myth and radical politics, comes across into English as if it were Mr. Hollo's own, with a haunting manner that hides fire and steel. (An Introduction gives helpful background.)
Finally, if you want to fade into the background altogether, try the Penguin Classic Poems from the Sanskrit (4s. 6d. translated by John Brough. Love, for the classical Indian poets, was physical but ceremonious; and the great season was not spring but the time of the autumnal monsoons:
Nvow in the rains the screaming peacocks dance.
Richard Ho lnes

Author: LANGFIELD, JUNE
Title: Jolly evening of poetry
Full_text:
Jolly evening of poetry
The Barrow Poets have been givin,g successful music and poetry entertainments in pubs and are now playing to a larger audience at the May Fair Theatre. They obviously missed the intirnacy of their usual setting, and the theatre took some time to warm up, but in the end their enthusiasm and charm conquered and the audience thoroughly enjoyed itself. T,his is, I gather, their chief aim. The programme is deSiberately ligh.tweight, with roistering seductions and funny verses, some good, some a little obvious. (The most serious item, three poems on loneliness, is only risked at the end.) It bears traces of being designed to compete with the evening pin-t-a poetical packet of crisps. A theatre, even a small one, can take something with 'more meat in it.
Still, it is a very enjoyable evening. The music is charming, ranging from airs by Bach and Mozart to souped-up folk tunes played on strange instruments that might have been designed for an angel by Hieronymus Bosch.
JUNE LANGFIELD

Author: Wade, David
Title: New poetry in Pinter
Full_text:
RADIO
New poetry in Pinter
By David Wade
One of the remarkable things about Harold Pinter's Lantdscape. given its world premiere on radio last night, is that in it Mr. Pinter successfully combines the tried and familiar with the new. displaying in both a complete command of his powers.
Duff and Beth sit in the kitchen of a country house. Here they have been employed, he as chauffeur and general handyman. she as cook and housekeeper. They have the house to themselves; their employer, Sykes. is no longer around-perhaps he is dead. It is evenine. and as they sit. Duff recounts to Beth the prosaic events of the day before: how he walked to the pond and took shelter from the rain, then went to a pub where some nut complained about the beer. Carefully he avoids the past earlier than yesterdav. Beth never answers him. She is in a past far beyond yesterday-reliving a day spent with a man bv a desolate b=ach. Was this man Duff ? Probably, although her vision of him is strangely at odds with the coarse, rough-spoken man who now talks to her.
That man lying in the sand, whom she recalls so lovingly, seems to represent a hope of what her life might have been, a hope in which is mingled some part of another,
finer man-it may have been Sykes -a hope at all events blasted by experience. This experience is foreshadowed in what she recalls, for in that remembered day " ... . he turned to look at me but I couldn't see his look. (Pause) I couldn't see whether he was looking at me. (Pause) Although he had turned. And appeared to be looking at me". As the play proceeds Duff, drawn by his wife's silence, also moves into the past, remembering his own failure to live up to her dreams. his resentment at it and his one shameful outburst of violence against her.
In Duff we have. as it were. a traditional Pinter character, crude and inarticulate yet creating out of this his own telling imagery. He is played with absolute mastery by Eric Porter. Beth is utterly different and here Mr. Pinter is writing in another style. The phraseology has its familiar exactitude. but it has. besides a fresh and exceptionally limpid quality. From it emerges the portrait of a woman drawn with a tenderness that reveals in the author a new poetic, even romantic strain. Peggy Ashcroft, voice delicately vulgarized, missed not one inflection of this exquisite dialogue. Both she and Mr. Porter were admirably supported by Guy Vaesen's sensitive: production which bridged long silences with distant country noises or courageously just let them be silent

Author: Bowra, C. M.
Title: Imagists and Eskimos
Full_text:
Paperbacks_
Imagists and Eskimos
PRIMITIVE SONG
By C. M. Bowra
(Weidenfeld 21s)
For all its A-pollonian Oxford elegance, this is a revolutionary book. To begin with, it is our first comprehensive Anthropology of poetry. Sir Maurice Bowra has studied the songs of the most primitive peoples now alive on the earth-the Bushmen. the Eskimos. the Pygmies, the tribes of South America and the Australian outback-and returned as near as possible to the roots of literature in human society. He discovers poetry emnerging from the ritual of the dance, through charms, prayers, and the sudden lyric outburst, into communal chants, stories, and the passionate explanations of Myth.
There is an extraordinary correspondence between primitive and modem poetic practice. The Eskimo hunter Orpingalik is recorded as saying: " Man is moved just like the icefloe out in the current-thoughts wash over himn like a flood, his breath comes in gasps, his heart throbs. Poems are thoughts sung out with the breath when people are moved by great forces . . :' This is startlingly close to the ideas of Pound. William Carlos Williams and Charles Olson on how poetry works. They agree that poetry is powerful and communal experience sung out, to be heard.
You gull, up there.
steer down towards me, come to me.
Your wings are red
up there in the coolness.
You could call that an Imagist poem. But it is by an Eskimo.
THE THEATRE OF THE ABSURD by Martin Esslin (Pelican 8s 6d). A classic of campaigning modern criticism. Starting from the rapturous reception of Godot in San Quentin prison (1957), Mr. Esslin defines his own influential catchphrase in four long essays on Beckett. Adaamov. lonesco and Genet; then spreads into an informative and international catalogue of related playwrights (Pinter, Frisoh, Grass, &c.); and settles into a solid discussion of the tradition and significance of the Absurd. This edition adds material on the Pol,ish and Czech theatres, and a retrospective chapter. Richly partisan, it remains the best introduction to the post-war European Theatre open both to excitement and disagreement.
A PERFECT STRANGER by Edward Hyams (Panther, 5s) "Adam left Eden because he suffered the disease no god has ever understood ... boredom with a beauty and a truth made for you but not by you." This is, too, the predicament of Luther Emmettrich, urbane, good-looking; but feather-bedded. His quest for kicks drives him to violence, and murder, but even then he has to contrive his own fate. Mr. Hyams's novel is flush with penetrating social comment; idlehanded Luthers are all around us (at all social levels) and the Devil continues to find work for them. A MOTHER'S KISSES by Bruce Jay Friedman (Penguin 5s). Mr. Friedman has taken the traditional American Jewish Momma, doubled her horrors, freshened her make-up, sharpened her tongue and made her good as new. Joseph, daydreaming teenage innocent, is dispatched to a summer camp, rescued from a theft charges enrolled at a Mid-West agricultural college. Momma Meg arranges everything. Joseph is grumbling, passive, clumsily aware of his sexuality; Meg is frenzied, devoted. Mr. Friedman makes the most of this unequal battle, and sketches in, quickly and accurately, a host of minor supporters at the fray. Very, very funny: the dialogue a knock-out.
BEER IN THE SNOOKER CLUB by Waguih Ghali (Penguin 4s). The club is in Cairo, the beer iImitation Bass, concocted by Ram and Font, two young Egyptian Copts. Their tradition and schooling, and a period of studying in London (Ram's is "p Perhaps the only copy of Tribune that comes into Egypt ") have left them outsiders, disenchanted with the Revolution's methods, but yearning for commitment. For Ram, the relationship with his rich famnily, makfing the best of Arab socialism, and with Edna, a rich Jewess, only increases the tensions of an intellectual defeated by two admirable, detestable, civilizations. Written with gentle, comic poignancy: a genuine original
WHAT HAPPENED AT HAZLEWOOD by Michael Innes (Penguin 4s). The Simneys are eminently the sort of farmily likely to be involved in a scandal. After the unexpected arrival of three Simneys from Australia, quarrels, smashing glass, oaths and hate in passing the marmalade break out over the matter of what happened at Dismal Swamp all those years ago. Sir George provides a first-class sensation by being found mysteriously dead in the library at midnight, with snow falling. Long lost claimants to the title, blackmail threats, an hysterical clergyman, an anthropologist, and a beautiful actress all add to the mystery.

Author: PAXTON, GEOFFREY
Title: The little insects may now join in
Full_text:
the little
insects may now loin in
VOICES: An Anthology of Poetrv and Pictutres
EDITED BY GEOFFREY SUMMERFIELD
(Penguin Educationz. Three volumes, 8s 6d each, teachers' htandbook 2s 6d)
Traditional school poetry anthologies are constructed to a pattern: there are plenty of ballads, a few limericks and comic pieces; anything up to a third is concerned with ships and the sea;
there is a hefty staple of Major Poets on the seasons, animals and people, counterbalanced by a few modernistic stanzas about pylons and arterial roads. The intention is honourable: to offer an historic tour of Eng. Lit., and to develop a child's awareness of his literary heritage.
The results in the classroom are less noble. The teacher is often bewildered by the difficulties of utilizing a selection which respects the poet rather than the child. He drowns with Sir Patrick Spens, perjures himself by playing along with the anthology's assumption that sea-faring is the only metaphor for adventure and escapism, justifies the Romantics by arguiing that, well, really, Autumn is mellow and fruitful, isn't it and in a froth of
enthusiasm points triumphantly to the contemporaneity of a poem which mentions traffic lights.
Geoffrey Summerfield, with neither hesitation nor repentance, has ignored the traditional pattern in this three-volume anthology of poetry and pictures intended for lower, mniddle and upper forms of secondary schools. His Voices are those of poets speaking in the classroom, introducing or extending the children's discussion or work. An immediate and common dialogue from classes who have looked at the books: "Please, sir, this isn't poetry ". " Why not ?" "Well-it's about people like us
And so it is. The poems look at people: in the first book directly and simply, then with more concern for reaction and context, and
in the third book, with an awareness of the shape of existernce. There are a large number of good, quite tricky, modern poems, a deal of traditional folk-verse, and some sharp translations from Czech, Japanese and AngloSaxon. There is very little of the Greats, but a confident display of those poets (Clare, Hardy, Thomas, Owen, Frost) who speak with respect and gentleness to young people.
The layout is firm and businesslike, something after the style of B.B.C. schools pamphlets; notes are restricted to the essentials of vocabulary; poets are not given dates. Physically, then, the anthology forces the child to make his own judgments and examine his own response, since all poems are
presented as equals. The numberrhyme which he has himself chanted, the hard humour of the gravestone epitaph, the unsophisticated account of the Black Country cock-fight-these are given equal prominence with final, disciplined comment from Sandburg, Lawrence, Hopkins.
Each book has about 30 pictures on the theme of the poems. Some are splendid (particularly the nineteenth-century photographs of industrial life) but there is a colour-mag modishness about some of the war illustrations. Again, layout, and juxtaposition leave verdict and extension to the child himself. And unillustrated anthologies have begun to look incomplete.
A group of sharp sixth-form
scientists started to look at Voices: within five minutes they were reading to each other some of the things they had found. A school anthology which has such an immediate appeal is doing its job properly: letting the poet speak. For the teacher who wishes to bring the poet's voice more fully into class work (and indeed the books could serve as a firm base for a whole English course) there are some modestly authoritative notes in a separate pamphlet.
A title in the first book is Depressed by a Book of Bad Poetry, I Walk toward an Unused Pasture and Invite the Insects to Join Me. Mr. Summerfield has given the pasture a purpose; his invitation to the little insects is fresh, exciting and irresistible.
GEOFFREY PAXTON

Author: HOLMES, RICHARD
Title: Poets: Campbell, Lowell, Herbert, Sexton, Barker
Full_text:
Poets: Campbell, Lowell, Herbert, Sexton, Barker
Roy Campbell fought for the Nationalists in Spain, railed against pink Utopians and birth-controllers, translated San Juan de la Cruz and not Catullus, preferred the couplet to vers libre, and was still excluded from the Faber Book of Modern Verse on bis death in 1957. In fact he was awkward.
His Selected Poetry (The Bodley Head, 30s.) shows to what purpose. It is clear that Campbell had two exceptional gifts. The range of a natural adventurer in all things (he wrote lyric, narrative. allegoric and polemical poetry. and translated from Latin, Spanish. French and Portuguese); and with this, an aboriginal directness of style, of feeling, of image. Autumn, that great English excuse for seasonal maudlin, becomes in a brief love poem:
I love to see when leaves depart, tze clear anatomy arrive,
Winter, the paragon of art,
that kills all forms of life and feeling save what is pure and will survive. Already now the clanging chains
of geese are harnessed to the
moon. . . -
He was caught in the red terror in Toledo 1936. when " life. a fly upon a rum-glass rim, was subject to the vilest drunkard's whimn". and he never forgave (or was forgiven by) " MacSpaunday ". his composite scarecrow of MacNeice, Spender, Auden. and DayLewis
and all who farmed the carnage for
good pay
though from the bayonets they kept
far away,
from Koestler down to Earnest
Hemingway.
His Georgiad (1931) and Flowering Rifle (1936) are full of hate and historical bias. as indeed are the " Dunciad " and " MacFlecknoe ", whose edge and energy they catoh continually. And since Pope, who has so celebrated the brisk unfashionable strength of the pentameter couplet:
With its ten fingers twirling thumbs
of rhyme
to seize and clamp the trailing
th'oughts that fray
and scatter like tobacco by the way, and in iambics fold them, neatly set, as nimble fingers scroll a cigarette for memory to case them in his
breast
and smoke at leisure, as it suits him
best.
Poetry, a meditative handrol1 for the sailors, cowmen, and soldiers he lived among.
And also for the contemplatives. Penguin Classics have re-issued Campbell's versions of Poems by
Roy Campbell: an awkward case.
St. John of the Cross (4s 6d). St John's ecstasy was experienced in an 8 by 8 stone cell in the sweltering summer of Toledo 1567, and Campbell has caught the terror and the passion of the place, the dark night of the soul. The short line can crab his manner, but again and again he achieves an extraordinary Psalmic balance of the explicitly erotic with the implicitly sublime. The breathless " Upon a gloomy night " is justly famous, and there are others as fine. Campbell worked with strange humility (for him), and rhymed "translate " with " assassinate ".
His versions of Baudelairestiff, almost disapproving-suffer in comparison with the agonized empathy that Robert Lowell has since deployed upon them. Lowell's Baudelaire is now collected in a coffee-table gloater's edition, The Voyage (Faber 84s), with haunted full-page illustrations by Sidney Nolan in red and black and desperate blue. Lowell is much less reliable than has been made out, but he can make a brilliantly distorted mirro, of his original, up-dating the exotic ennui of the Second Empire to the skintight neuroses of the Pax Americana:
If poison, arson, sex, narcotics,
knives
have not yet ruined us and stitched
their quick.
loud patterns on the canvas of our
lives,
it is because our souls are still too
sick....
a superb traduction of the French.
The problems of politics and translation coincide in the eighth of the Penguin Modern European Poets: Selected Poems of Zhigniew Herbert (4s 6d). Herbert is a Pole who fought the Nazis underground, and sat out Stalinism grimly behind a desk. His poetry first saw light in 1956. and is here translated by Czeslaw Milosz and the Canadian Peter Dale Scott into clean open versions. Herbort uses Greek. Shakespearian, and homemade myths with a kind of coldwater wit, startling private judgments to matters of public and political fact. He is Fortinbras who soliloquizes over the dead idealist Hamlet. His world, in spite of human horror, is solid, reasonable: "I have never observed a chair shift from one foot to the other.. . . I suspect that objects do this from pedagogical considerations, to reprove us constantly for our instability ". His cool is
classic, deliberately adopted. He remembers in the midst of public crisis
Thucydides says only
that he had seven ships it was winter
and he sailed quickly
A good collection to learn from, with signposts set at the beginning by A. Alvarez.
Penguin Modern Poets 11 (3s 6d) is dull by contrast, in spite of a cover of electric gold. D. M. Black inhabits an interior Scotland of symbolic Judges, seething with hoards of squiffy dwarves apparently escaped from an insecurely framed Tenniel illustration. Peter Redgrove is getting graver and more opaque in his domestic illuminism, although his prose fantasias show mad glints. D. M. Thomas alone is outward bound: he writes pointed Science Fiction poems, inspired by Bradbury and Arthur C. Clarke, with a great sense of the grotesque and the sharp backlash of SF plots.
Oxford Paperbacks offer another threesome: Poems by Thomas Kinsella Douglas Livingstone and Anne Sexton (7s 6d). This is a distinguished group of colonials (from Dublin, Kuala Lumpur, and Massachusetts respectively) in slightly thin selection. Mr. Kinsella has a delicate dancing stanza, and Mr. Livingstone a way in animal affairs. But Anne Sexton stands out: a passionate. troubled. American homemaker, anxious to be honest, to discover her own feelings in others: the Victorian grandmother of "Some Foreign Letters ", or the " Unknown Girl in the Maternity Ward ". She has the bitter sparkled fear of her close friend Sylvia Plath: they discussed death and drank Boston martinis together. Her style is free, gathering movement across spacious uneasy living-rooms: I hear as in a dream
the conversation of the old wives speaking of womanhood.
I remember I heard nothing myself. I vas alone. I waited like a target.
From George Barker comes The Golden Chains (Faber 18s.), 104 small lyrics each of two quatrains, by an old master of
' figure-skating in the stanza ". The sexual disillusion of the original "True Confession" (1947), and the somewhat paunchy rhetoric of later work. are here both sweetened and disciplined. Mr. Barker summons odd places of vision-Stour River, Tivoli. Victoria Terminus, the Land of Pelops-dreaming, and adjusting memories. Reading through gives that distracted melancholy pleasure of throwing stone after stone into the sea.
RICHARD HOLMES

Author: BRETT, GUY
Title: Cool state of the word
Full_text:
Cool state
of the word
CONCRETE POETRY: An International Anthology.
EDITED BY STEPHEN BANN (Alan Ross 36s).
Concrete poetry overlaps with the fields of painting and music, just as painting and music today overlap with poetry and with each other. Phonetic poems, chants, mantras, are related to music: poems where traditional literary syntax is replaced by spacesingle words in spatial relations on the page which can be taken in at a glance-are close to painting. In concrete poetry words are treated as signs, like forms in concrete painting, and this makes the poet as free to relate them as a concrete artist is to relate forms. In one of his essays on modern poetry Dom Sylvester Houedard puts this very clearly: " The word is no longer the prison of some esoteric meaning and no longer shocked by its juxtapositions."
This cool state of the word has cxisted since the early days of modern art when the autonomy of each field of art began to be broken down, especially by groups like the Dadaists. Moholy-Nagy in his ' Vision in Motion" treated music, writing and visual art together. He discerned a " lightening of material" (meaning grammar
and syntax) in poetry exactly equivalent to the lightening of material in painting and sculpture.
The presen,t anthology, which is the first widely available contains some marvellous poems. But It is about concrete poetry in a fairly strict sense. Stephen Bann, by his choice not oiily of poets but also of work by the poets seleoted, has cast the book very much in the mould of Gomringer and the Brazilian poets. These precise typographical " constellations " (Gomringer's title), geometrical blocks of wordsounds austerely evolving and mutating words; are they not one aspect only of concrete poetry ? The most formal aspect perhaps, stylistically coherent, but tending to hide the possibilities of language revealed in other works by several of these poets, as well as by other poets.
The book's production helps create this impression. It is a neat square format and an elegant printing job by the Shenval Press. But you have to consider the effect on poems which make their own space, of all being given the uniform space of a book. It must reduce the spontaneity of the packets and cards, posters, cut-ups and long strip books (as well as objects in which words are inseparable from physical sensations and sequences of actual movements) in which poets have put out their work recently.
GUY BRETT
- Typestract" 1967, by Dom Sylvester Houedarda contributor to the "Concrete Poetry" anthology-from an exhibition of his recent work at the Lisson Gallery. This diagraun-poem is perf;aps a metaphorfor the interrelation of material and immaterial things: speech is symbolised as an object and held in a box.... As with many of his poems, Houedard keeps elegantly within the limits of the typewriter keyboard.

Author: Raynor, Henry
Title: Poetry with trickery gives pleasure
Full_text:
Poetry with trickery gives pleasure
By Henry Raynor
We do no service to the arts if we leave them at the top of their mountain to consider only the highest raptures and most tortured anguishes of human experience. It seems actually to do them good to bring them down every now and again to romp in the valley.
The willingness of The Barrow Poets (Heather Black, Cicely Solith, William Bealby-Wright and Gerard Benson. with Susan Baker. their violinist, and Jim Parker. who plays the oboe and the cor anglais) to do this is one reason for their success as entertainers in pubs, on gramopbone records and last night in a well-filled Queen Elizabeth Hall.
Their poetry ranged from Dunbar to clerihews; it contained serious, moving works, parodies and ridiculous tricks with words. Their music embraced Morley, Campion, Dowvland, Bartok and, among other jests. Mr. Parker's Fantasia on a Theme by Balfe; Mr. Parker's jokes are, incidentally, 4uite good ones.
The other reason for the pleasure they give is that they choose poetry which can without inflation or distortion be projected to an audience. There is no pnvate coramunion between speaker and poet but a public delivery, nicely timed last night to the audience's speed of reaction, sometimes tastily hammed. of words moving, thoughtful, witty or simply funny.

Author: Carner, Mosco
Title: Chopin poetry captured
Full_text:
I MUSIC Z
Chopin poetry
captured
By Mosco Camner
The chief interest of last night's Promenade concert at the Albert Hall centred in the young Russian pianist, Victoria Postnikova, whc won the first prize in the Chopin Competition at Warsaw in 1965 and the second prize at last year's Leeds International Piano Competition. With such credentials in her pocket Miss Postnikova could bL sure of the enthusiastic reception which she received from the packed audience.
The concerto she chose for incr Prom debut was Chopin's in E minor, and. as her performance proved to the hilt, it was a very happy choice. For one of her age it was astonishing how completely she was inside the music, basing her interpretation on the poetic content of the concerto-so much so that its technical aspect seemed almost incidental.
True, there was a measure of emotional reserve in her playing of the appassionato phrases in the first two movements-even a certain detachment. But this seemed to matter little. For she moulded her lyrical lines with such inborn musicianship, brought to them such perfectlv controlled tone and minutely graded dynamics that one sat completely enthralled.
Needless to say, her technical command is faultless, but it was more in the feathery lightness with which she negotiated subtle florid ornaments that one admired her than in the glittery runs and double-thirds a la Hummel. And though the finale was carried off with great rhythmic verve, it lacked sufficient tonal sparkle. After the intenral Miss Postnikova regaled us with a superlative performance of three of Rachmaninov's Preludes. Op. 23.
In attendance was the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra under Sir Adrian Boult, who opened the proceedings with Mendelssohn's mildly inspired overture The Fair Melusina, and concluded them with Brahms's Second Symphony of which the conductor gave a deeply sympathetic account allowing the music spaciousness and breath.

Author: SADIE, STANLEY
Title: Poetry and colour of opera revealed
Full_text:
Poetry and colour of
opera
revealed
By
STANLEY SADIE
Since Weber was a great composer and Planchd a poor librettist, any revival of Oberon must take the music as its starting point. Cambridge University Opera Group's production, which had the first of three performances tonight, includes everything that Weber wrote except one rather inferior aria. and trims Planche's text to the barest minimum and sometimes a little beyond it, for the omission of certain scenes and the shortening of others makes some of the motivation and action even obscurer than they were to start with.
Yet this, I am sure, is basically the right way to do it. The music showed up marvellously. It is so wide in range: heroic in Huon-s " From Boyhood
trained " and Rezia's " Ocean, Thou Mighty Monster ", deeply pathetic in his prayer and her cavatina; brilliantly illustrative in the stormn scene, utterly enchanting in the mermaid's song; full of happy melody in the numbers for the secondary characters and in the choruses; and the wbole beautifully scored with a gossamer touch in the fairy music, with bright colours in the exotic scenes. It has inspired composers as unlike as Wagner and Sullivan.
And as conducted by Mr. David Atherton, with an orchestra of Cambridge students past and present (plus a little stiffening), its appeal was irresistible. The overture clearly had been rethought, and Mr. Atherton's free but firmly controlled rhythms made real. imaginative musical sense. The same
feeling for the poetic qualities of the score and of its rhythmic qualities too, informed his direction the whole evening.
Mr. Ande Anderson's production had some weak moments-especially in the scenes in Baghdad and Tunis-but he and the designer, Mr. Hugh Durrant, made the best of the theatre's facilities and gave us a certain amount of magical illusions in the transformation scenes, reinforcing it with gongs and the modern magic of electronic sound.
Among the cast. Miss Margaret Kingsley sang Rezia with strong line but hard tone; Mr. Jon Weaving, appearing at short notice and evidently hampered by a cold, made a creditable attempt at Huon. Miss Anne Howells was an accomplished Fagima, and Mr. Neil Jenkins and Miss Janet Hughes were persuasive as the fairies.

Author: Null
Title: Poets American and English
Full_text:
Poets American
and English
Louis Simpson's Selected Poems introduces to English readers an excellent American poet-and one in whose work many of the recent developments in American poetry are mirrored. The poems in this book that date from the first 10 years after the war are elegant, witty, reserved-even in the poems about the war the worst experiences are held some distance away in the memory, rather as in Mr. Simpson's description of the Aegean:
Though still the ohve glows Like silver, and the rose
Is glittering and fresh, as in their day, No witnesses remain
Of battles on the plain
And the bright oar and the oar spray.
But in a poem published three years ago Mr. Simpson said of American poetry: Whatever it is, it must have A stomach that can digest
Rubber, coal, uranium, moons, poems.
In his latest work the digestion is going well, and there are some poems of real finesse and force about America after Walt Whitman: the clash between high dreams and happiness-and their inextriable entanglement; the banks and the cheap housing u'nder the great cloud-wagons moving overhead on the Pacific shore, and the "murmur of serious life" still going on among it all.
Randall Jarrell, who died in a car accident last year, was the author of one of the wittiest of campus novels. Pictures fronm an Institution; but his last book of poems, Thle Lost World, consists mainly of rather rambling dramatic monologues. Those about his childhood are probably the least satisfying, but the sharp-eyed, yet gentle, studies of marriages have the ring of justice being done and truth being said. A quite different kind of poet is Mr. Robert Creeley, almlost held as a saint now on the more progressive campuses: in his very short poems there is no meditation, just an attempt to catch, in the breathing of a few syllables, some passing, delicate feeling:
My lady fair with soft
arms, what
can I say to
you-words, words as if all
worlds were there.
The best poems in his Poems 1950-1965 are inimitable, but many seem just to slip off the tongue and vanish.
To turn to the new volumes of English poetry, Mr. Charles Tomlinson also writes in short lines dropping down the page in a tentative, graceful way-moreover, his last poem is dedicated to " Robert and Bobbie Creeley ", and his title is American Scenes. But he uses the manner to describe things seen rather than things feltfrom a desert landscape to a half-pear. Sometimes the result is too bare of human interest, sometimes there is a rather weak philosophical twist in the conclusion, but in those poems where feeling builds up with the strokes of the picture-particularly in some poems of snow-scenes-the effect is very fine.
Seamus Heaney's Death of a Naturalist is a first volume by a young Irish poet. Descriptions are the best thing in his work so far, too, but he does them in a way quite other than Mr. Tomlinson's: his forms and rhythms are conventional, but full of apt and flashing similes: frogs like " mud grenades", a river "oil-skinned, wearing A transfer of gables and sky" a horse-ploughman's shoulders "globed like a full sail ", a dead turkey "in immodest underwear frills of feather . . . A skin bag plumped with inky putty ".
Mr. R. S. Thomas's Pieta is another group of poems on his dominant theme, the bleakness of both nature and the human spirit in the Welsh hills, and his own unreciprocated love for them. Mr. George Barker, on the other hand, has some poems in new and unfamiliar moods in his Dreams of a Sunmmer Night: "The Sisteron" is about an unexpected happiness and peace of spirit, brought to him by "eyes that are kinder far than mine". The joky casualness that mars some of the other poems in the book is quite kept out of this one. Miss Elizabeth Jennings has produced her best collection for some time in The Mind Has Mountains, with its wise and tender studies of mentalhome patients-poems as thoughtful about the psychiatrists as they are understanding about the suicides, with a measured tone that is sometimes very moving. Most of Miss Karen Gershon's poems are about even greater horror, Jewish suffering in the war, and her own complex emotions about the dead as one who escaped. Her Selected Poems is an impressive book both for the feeling and for the restmirat with which it handles its themes.
Finally, a book to take its readers far away-and yet leave them feeling strangely at home: Mr. Ulli Beier's anthology, African Poetry, where a wealth of imagination brings out the life of men and women as diverse as the bushman who prays to the moon " Take my face and give me yours ", the Ethiopian girl who thinks of her worthless lover as " a measure of water thrown on the hearth ": and the covetous Yoruba hunter who sings to the antelope
You have more brass rings round your
neck
than any woman.

Oxford University Press. 21s.

80pp. Eyre and Spottiswoode. 18s.

227pp. Calder and Boyars. 35s.

57pp. Faber. 18s.
