Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Putney To Parnassus
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
PUTNEY TO PARNASSUS
By
Oliver Edwards
How much we owe to chance benefactors, even more to those who forever remain unknown. I can stil remember the thrill of making my way through my school's book of poetry and suddenly finding among the Casabiancas, and the Excelsiors, Heart of Oak, and The Private of the Buffs, some verses including: -
Pale, beyond porch and portal,
Crowned with calm leaves, she stands Who gathers all things mortal
With cold immortal hands; Her langtuid lips are sweeter
Than love's who fears to greet her To men that mix and meet her
From many times and lands.
As I was to find out later, the whole of Swinburne's " Garden of Proserpine " was not given, just three or four stanzas. (When I did unearth the poern in full I at once got it off by heart.) But I have often wondered who it was, which master living or dead, who had decided that among all the stoicism, and the patriotism, and the heroism, that could profitably be pumped into small boys, a little beauty would do no harm.
This is the centenary year of Poems and Ballads, but the memory has not come back to me because of that. It is because 1 have been reading the new edition of Sir Ifor Evans's English Poetry in the Later Nineteenth Century. It is a remarkably comprehensive conspectus of a rich period. He includes Woolner and Allingham, Massey and David Gray, in between the chapters devoted to Rossetti and Meredith, Hardy, Bridges, Kipling, and Housman. (There are many others; this is not a catalogue.)
The pages that held me most were the 42 on Swinburne. For one thing they are as up to date and as balInced a view of Swinburne as one could hope for. Sir Ifor retires from the Provostship of University College London this year. He has been such an outstanding administrator, and collector of unknown benefactors, that one has been inclined to look forward to his release so that he could return to his studies. This new edition of his 1933 work shows that he has never abandoned them. Among all his occupations he has managed to keep up with wbat has been written since and significantly added to his subject. His notes and brief bibliographies show his critical eye has not slept.
This is particularly valuable in the case of Swinburne. During the greater part of his life and for 50 years after his death, rumour and suspicion clung to the name of Swinburne. Then in 1959 Professor Lang began publication of his definitive edition of Swinburne's Letters. He included Gosse's unpublished memoir on Swinburne. It is true, as Sir Ifor Evans says, that all Gosse revealed
had been known. The memoir could not clear Swinburne's name. It did replace hints by facts, conjecture by certainty, on all matters except one.
Professor Lang also restored Swinburne to his proper place among the great English poets. And Sir Ifor indirectly, without ever going out of his way to make the point. removes much of the odium that the Romantics attached to Watts-Dunton. He may not have been a likable man but he was a well-meaning and, where Swinburne was concerned, a devoted one. He saved Swinburne from an early end: he thus enabled the world to have some works of the poet only just below the highest, and he may even be said to have begun the eighty year process of restotring his fame.
If Swinburne had died in 1879 or 1880 we should also have been deprived of some of his best prose. I admit that his excessive enthusiasm for his favourites can become tiring, rather like being out too long in a high wind. He was nevertheless a sensitive and original critic. Whether he was writing on Hugo or Shakespeare, Whitman or Dickens, WiLkie Collins or Charles Reade. he had almost always something interesting to say.
More important, had Swinburne not been taken to live at No. 2, The Pinn, we should never have had his trilogy of Mary Queen of Scots complete. If Birnam Wood came to Dunsinane as the portent of disaster, nothing but good came out of Fotheringay at Putney. Earle Welby thought that Swinburne over-valued Mary Stuart, and placed it below Chastelard and Bothwell. At the same time Welby pointed out that it was as a writer of tragedy Swinburne went on developing to the end of his life. And without Mary Stuart the massive triptych would have remained incomplete. We should not have had the wonderfully dramatic da capo-one of the haunting moments in tragedy-of Chastelard's song.
Sir Ifor writes on the Mary Queen of Scots trilogy at length. His temperate appreciation set me reading the- plays again. It is true to say "again" of Chastelard and Mary Stuart but I cannot say with honest certainty I have read every line of Bothwell before. (I shall never do so again.) It is a monstrosity as a play. Sir Ifor calls it gargantuan and quotes an early reviewer who said it " had about as many lines as Hamlet supplemented by Paradise Lost ". The genius of Shakespeare would have ruthlesslv truncated this fantastic centre-piece. Yet not the least of the many things I owe to Sir Ifor is that he persuaded me to stay to the end.

Author: From Our Special Correspondent
Title: Poetry that cries out for music
Full_text:
THE ARTS
Poetry that
cries out for music
From Our Special Correspondent
ALDEBURGH, JUNE 17
This morning's concert took the form of a memorial tribute to Dame Edith Sitwell, divided between readings of poems and music which either the poetry or the poetess herself had inspired, some of it previously unperformed. It was a programme which rightly belonged to the Parish Church rather than the Jubilee Hall: every poem cried out, like the grass-blade in "How Many Heavens . . ." that " God is everything ! ", though Mr. William Plomer himself in his clear and mellifluous reading seemed rather too ifluenced by a pulpit style of delivery. It was a programme which also brought home just wthy so many of Dame Edith's poems, however complete in themselves, yet cry out for music: the extraordinary richness of her imagery is something that few composers will ever be able to resist.
The most ambitious of the unfamiliar works was Humphrey Searle's " The Canticle of the Rose" for solo voices and choir. This was of particular interest for the way in which, while solo voices as it were tell the story, the rest of the choir provide an atmospheric background as complete and evocative as any instrumental accompaniment. There was a magical passage for female voices inspired by the imagery of a " river flowing "; there was a daring excursion into tum-tumming hum-drum worldliness for male voices. The other new music was for the organ alone. Malcolm Williamson's two epitaphs for Edith Sitwell, though slight, made a perfect prelude and postlude for a programme such as this, with their striking contrasts of high, sustained celestial calm and stabbing lower sonorities. Lennox Berkeley's equaUy succinct " Aubade " brought urbaner, sometimes even smiling, contrast in a style at first neo-Bachian, but the argument was ultimately dissolved rather than resolved.
Of the familiar music in *the programme, Britten's own third Canticle, " Still Falls the Rain ", for tenor, horn, and piano struck home most forcibly with the economical directness of its response to poetic imagery. In Michael Tippett's "The Weeping Babe " for soprano and choir compassion releases a flow of counterpoint, beautiful, but less emotionally concentrated. There was also Malcolm Williamson's unassumingly simple " A Young Girl " for choir. Mr. Benjamin Britten, Mr. Peter Pears, Miss April Cantelo, Mr. Neil Sanders. Mr. Simon Preston, and the Purcell Singers under Mr. George Malcolm were the sensitive artists.

Author: Null
Title: The poetry of precision
Full_text:
The poetry of
precision
Our watches told us that Anton Webern's last three works, which were played in succession during last night's B.B.C. concert at the Festival Hall, had lasted a little over half an hour. Instinct contradicted fact: we seemed to have lived through as intense, as far-reaching an experience as most composers offer in an entire evening's music.
The enigma is easily explained. Webern's music is packed so tight as to make a rushhour Tube seem empty by comparison. But not often is its emotional conten.t as manifes, indeed as striking, as it %%s under Mr. Pierre Boules. The B.B.C. Symphony Orchestra seemed so utterly at ease over what notes to play, and just when and how to play them, that they could concentrate on the notes' whys and the wherefores. So the music made real sense-eacih of the variations of Op. 30 was sharply characterized, and the whole had both logic and feeling.
No less assured was the singing in the two cantatas. The B.B.C. Chorus negotiated their awkward leaps as confidently as if they were singing Bach. Mr. Barry McDaniel brought tonal warmth and truly expressive line (the intervening rests notwithstanding) to his two movements in Op. 31. and Miss Halina Lukomska, though at first hard in tone, sang wiLh considerable beauty as well as accuracy, and in " Freundselig ist das Wort "-the heart of the second cantata,-as both fleet of voice where necessary and moving in expression.
Mr. Boulez also gave us a good deal to think about in the other music he conducted. Stravinsky's Rite of Spring can never have been more clearly played; some might say, never more clinically-certainly it lacked a truly Dionysiac touch. But it was a joy to be able to hear so much of the score. Inner detail which generally is obscured by carelessly placed emphases was in evidence, so finely adjusted was the balance, so sharp the articulation. The price was paid in terms of sheer physical excitements it was, if there be such a thing. a slightly restrained orgy.
In Debussy's Nocturnes, too. Mr. Boulez offered a reading to please the mnind but not to satisfy the emotions. It was a delight to hear a performance of such lucidity. such rhythmic verve, and one which made us so aware of the poetry of precision. But the warm, satiated textures and sensuous atmospheres we remernber cannot be mere illusion; Debussy is not, surely, as cool a comnoser as Mr. Boulez would have us think.

Author: Null
Title: Gleams Of Poetry Came Through
Full_text:
GLEAMS OF POETRY
CAME THROUGH
When Brahms wrote his F minor piano sonata, Op. 5, he was an unbridled young romantic of 20 exulting in his prodigious command of the keyboard. To tackle it without a massive technique is merelv asking for trouble. and time and time a'ain at Wigmore Hall on Thursdav Mr. Guthric Luke found himself unable to cope with its vehement chordal climaxes. Needless to say his spirit was always willing, and in the simple Intermezzo-like Riickblick. where Brahms himself no longer storms high heaven, his playing was shot through with many a gleam of poetry,
Even NMendelssohn's Variatio,,s sirieuses
in D minor at the start of the programme caused Mr. Luke to labour rather too hard for his performance to sound w'holly elegant, and it was not till after the inte-vali that swimming for thc most part within his depth, he was able to relax and cnjoy the music to the full.
True. Weber's " Invitation to the Dance" was rather too lumpily accented, but Faurc's A flat Impromptu, Op. 34. and C. sharp minor Theme and Variations, Op. X73, were nimble of finger and graceftully .phrased, and Liszt's St. Francois de Paule
strode manfully over the waves by way of conclusion.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry Spoken With Feeling
Full_text:
POETRY SPOKEN WITH FEELING
Lamda Stutdio Tlheatre:
Footprints in my Words
This charming entertainment, based on the poetry of Rabindranath Tagore. and presented with music, mime, and dancing, is being performed here until Saturday and is opcn to the public.
It seems a pity that it has not received more attention. Tagore's Poetry is not widely known nowadays; and this performance, being something of a spoken -anthology, could be a persuasive introduction to his writing.
Tagore's poems were originally written in Bengali; and those who are familiar witil the original texts say that their delicate texture and depth of meaning cannot survive the process of translation. What does survive seems remarkable enough to make one regret the loss. The verse, with its light rhythms, its persuasive imagery of dew, petals. and shadows, its ironic humour and meditative intonations, is constantly delightful.
The programmc is directed by Mr. Michael Friend, and Miss Surya Kumari, who proves a consummate dancer and mime. is responsible for the choreography. Both she and Mr. Gerson da Cunha speak poetry with a touching delicacy of fecling. The music is directed by Mr. S. D. Batish.

Author: Null
Title: Revived Ballet Keeps Poetry and Fun
Full_text:
The Arts
Revived Ballet Keeps Poetry
and Fun
Royal Opera House: Cinderella
It seems incredible, watching the Royal Ballet's Cinderella, which was revived in a revised production at Covent Garden last night, that this was Frederick Ashton's first attempt at creating an evening-long ballet. Of course there have been manv changes of detail s;nce its premiere exactly 17 years ago. and this revision introduces several mnore, most notably an enchanting new solo for the Fairy Godmother, which now at last perfectly sets the mood for 4the Dances of the Seasons.
Yet basically the virtues of the work remain unchanged: the same balance of poetry and fun, the same blend of the tuaditional classic ballet and of the equally traditional English pantomime. For once (and this is Ashton's great achievement) these apparent opposites sit happily side by side, and even imperceptibly merge to form an entertainnment that is gentle and wise as well as amusing. It is also a perfect embodiment of the wishes of the composer who wanted his score to be " as danceable as possible ".
Prokofiev's music, sweet and fluent, with a curiously affecting sad undertone in the final solemn wedding raptures, was handsomely played last night by the Covent Garden Orchestra under Mr. Sergiu Comissiona's direction. The new settings by Mr. Henry Barden are strangely Frenchified but effective. adequately pretty in the transformations and rightly fanciful in the ballroom scene. Not all of Mr. David Walker's dresses are an improvement on the early designs they replace, but one must be grateful that, with their help, the fairy tale element now works better than ever before.
It was a sentimental, and therefore in this context appropriate, touch to have ,three of the original principals playing once again the roles they created 17 years ago. Ashton himself and Mr. Robert Hlelpmann clown to the top of their bent as the Ugly Sisters, and Mr. Alexander Grant's Jester is as amusing as ever if no longer so nimble. Moreover, Miss Margot Fontevn. who was prevented only by acciden't from being the first Cinderella, proved herself once - more still the best. with an irrepressible,
just slightly naughty sense of humour to season her serenity, her sparkle, and her radiance.
XIMr. David Blair made an impetuously handsome Prince, and Miss Annette Page a Fairy Godmother of irresistible charm. Mr. Keith Martin's Dancing Master is an original and apt characterization, and Miss Merle Park's brilliance as the Autumn fairy really deserves a whole notice fo itself.
Mr. Robert Helpmann and Sir Frederick Ashton as the Ugly Sisters in Cinderella at the Royal Opera House.

Author: Lucie-Smith, Edward
Title: Eighteenth-century English Painting and the Poetry of Fact
Full_text:
THINGS SEEN
Eighteenth-century
English
Painting
Poetry
of
Fact
and
the
" Conversation Piece with Lord Hervey ", by Hogarth.
By Edward Lucie-Smith
The exhibition of English pictures of the period 1730-1830. now at Agnews in aid of Enterprise Neptune, is entirely drawn from the collections in houses which belong to the National Trust. The show serves as a kind of confirmation, if not canonization, of a change in taste which has been taking place for some time now. We have more respect for English painting, and we look at it in a new way.
This change began in the broad sense with Professor Pevsner's memorable series of Reith lectures on the " Englishness of English Art ". In a narrower sense it gathered impetus from the exhibition of the work of George Stubbs which was held some years ago at the Whitechapel Gallery. We can see the results of the change in the astonishing prices which have recently been paid at auction for English pictures of high quality. William Scott costs almost as much as CanaLetto, and Brooking more than van de Velde. And it must be said that, though American collectors, and Mr. Paul Mellon in particular, have been pioneers in this field of collecting, the renewal of interest in English eighteenth-century art is not simply a revival of the old Duveen taste for fulllength portraits of pretty children and glamorously aristocratic ladies. What hold our interest today are the conversation pieces, the landscapes, the pictures of ships and shipping-all those things. in fact, which bring us closest to the real England of the eighteenth century, to the country and the people as they actually existed.
But though the change has taken place, it has not yet been supplied with a rationale. Post hoc justifications are of course suspect, and never more so than when they concern the movement of fashion in the visual arts. Yet it seems to me that there is now a real case for the critical reexamination and reevaluation of the English painting of the eighteenth century. We have never looked at it in its proper context, and this is what has led to its being neglected for so long. What I shall sav here is only a sketch-the details need filling in, and no doubt some of my generalizations will turn out to be risky ones. But I hope, at least, to supply the framework for a new discussion of the subject.
Air of the Provincial
Let me begin. then, by acknowledging that the English art of the period is usually thought of as occupying a marginal place on the European scene. Compared with French or Italian (and particularly Venetian) painting, it appears provincial and unsophisticated. English painters, we are told, had very little in the way of a native tradition behind them -in the seventeenth century, almost all the notable artists in England had been foreigners-and they were much less free than painters on the Continent to create as they pleased. Patrons had a clear idea of what they required, and what they required was the prosaic depiction of themselves, their families, their houses and their domestic animals.
This summary of the condition of English painting is no more than a halftruth. To understand why this is so, we must consider the position which was held by England and Englishmen in the politics and thought of the eighteenth century as a whole. One of the basic facts about the condition of England at the time is that it is almost the only country which was not, potentially at any rate, a breeding ground for revolution. Englishmen were content with the main
outlines of the social and political system of their country, and the advanced political theorists of the Continent (and in particular the philosophers of the Enlightenment) held up English institutions as a model to the rest of the world. English political thinkers, such as Locke, had in any case exercised an immense influence over the new doctrines which were being preached in Europe.
English painting reflects this situation in a curious way. It is an art of acceptance, not an art of escape. The Rococo fantasy wbich we now so much admire in a painter like Watteau represents a retreat from reality which is in complete contrast to what we find in an Englishman like Hogarth. The Hogarth conversation piece from Ickworth. which is now on show at Agnews, provides a good example of this. It is at least as fluently and elegantly painted as any Watteau which I can think of. Especially marvellous is the free and fluid brusbwork with which the artist has created the fruit on the table, and the basket of fruit on the ground. But Hogarth is not creating a dream world. an ideal society. lie is content to show us what is.
Influence of Stage
Of course, the picture is not completely without artifice. The grouping derives from what Hogarth saw on the stage. Everything is arranged to be more typical, more telling, more concentrated than " real life " would be. Little anecdotal touches are brought in to catch the spectator's interest-a good example can be found on the left of the picture. where the clergyman with a telescope clapped to his eye is just about to be tipped off the chair he is standing on. The picture is not, perhaps, as miraculously resolved and unified as a mature fete galante by Watteau. But Hogarth is. in a sense, undertaking a more difficult task. He is not providing a substitute; he is trying to show us the genuine thing, to explain how these particular people conducted themselves, and what their relationships were to each other. The picture has a concentration of meaning in it which is absent from contemporary conversation pieces painted in France or Italy. It is a great deal more intense than any picture by Longhi. for example.
The growing economic power of England during the eighteenth century attracted many painters from abroadin particular. many of the most distinguished Venetian painters were err-
ployed by Blritish patrons, not only Canaletto, but decorators such as Pelligrini and Arnigoni. It says something for the integrity of English painting that the influences which these painters brought with them were painlessly absorbed. It is true that a certain snobbery often led the rich Whig magnates of England (the principal source of patronage) to prefer foreigners to nativeborn artists, with the result that a pair,ter of imaginative landscapes like Richard Wilson tended to have a hard time of it. Towards the end of the century, too. the growing obsession with the idea of History Painting led to an impatience with the conditions imposed by English patrons. Artists like Reynolds and Romney undoubtedly felt that their talents had not been employed to best effect. sirnply because of the conditions in which they found themselves.
On the other hand, those specimens of History Painting which we have from the brushes of these and other artists do not encourage us to feel that we have suffered any great loss. The cult of History Painting was, in part at least, an expression of the revolt against the inferior social status of the artist which was taking place all over Europe. The theoretical issue was a cover for the more practical and pressing one.
Matchless Masterpieces
Meanwhile, in the second half of the eighteenth century, English painters were producing masterpieces which cannot be matched elsewhere. I am thinking, in particular, of the two country scenes by Stubbs, which are also included in the exhibition at Agnews. These show harvesting and haymaking. They are a strange and beautiful combination of the utterly natural and the mathematically precise. The intervals between the various figures are as calculated as they would be in a great mythological composition by Poussin. Yet the other comparison which we think of is with some of Peter Breughel the Elder's pictures of seasonal occupations. Stubbs has the same reverence for the natural. seasonal rhythm which Breughel displays, and he sharec Breughel's ability to recreate reality and to make the spectator experience it at iis highest power. What we find in Stubbss best work is the poetry of fact. It is this poetrv which touches us again and again when we look at English eighteenth-centuLry painting.

Author: Null
Title: Poems for the Good-Hearted
Full_text:
Poems for the Good-Hearted
A great deal of recent American poetry has gone back to the job of heartening the good-hearted. l wo of the many impressive volumes of American poetry lately published here show, respectively, a master and an accomplished pupil at the job. The master is the late William Carlos Williams, whose Collected Later Poems contains all his poetry written in the 1940s. In those grim years Williams wrote hundreds of slangy, slightly hectoring reminders of human decency and pleasure, as when he speaks of the refreshment to be had from
the humility of the snow that silvers everything and is
trampled anid lined with use-yet falls again.
Starlings chattering at the sun with hiorny lips ", the ' heavenly grossness" of Ford Madox Ford licking his lips after a Provenqal meal, spirited girls and whiskydrinking old ladies-these and the subjects of all his other casual-seeming sketches illuminate a continuous concern for simple human brotherhood and happiness.
The pupil in the field is Miss Denise Lcvertov, an Essex girl who went to America after the war and now manages to be both a characteristic and a very individual ligure on the American poetic scene. The earlier poems in her book Tlle Jacob's Ladder are most like Williams's. The newer ones have the same ambition to enter people's lives lightly and unobtrusively, " stirred into paper coffee cups, eaten with petals on rye in the sun ", but their glimpses of human ease and pleasure are more subtle, less jerky and joky. like her poem about an old man walking in the rain, contentedly drifting this way and that under the pull of his two dogs conflicting desires.
Theodore Roethke, who died in 1963, had a very high reputation in America, but his posthumous collection The Far Field is rather disappointing: in too many of the poems, eloquent though they are, the bardic or the courtly manner seems at odds with the violent. spontaneous impulses they are often about. The two most important volumes of American PoetrY of late are books that deal with violence in a different way. One is Ariel, by Sylvia Plath, who also died in 1963, when she was living in London. Her poems at their best combine an exact and powerful delineation of cruel or self-destructive emotion, with a brave wit or a determined hanging-on to happiness. They are noble poems. Mr. Robert Lowell's For the Uitionz Dead marks him out clearly as one of the most gifted poets writing in the English language today. It is his most
varied book yet, and its dazzlingly sharp and subtle evocations of nostalgia, hatred, grief, subdued pleasure-all these emotions often intricately worked into a single brief lyric or monologue-make the reading of it a profound participation in the modern life of the human soul-and the human body.
Recent English poetry seems rather slight by comparison. Mr. Frederick Grubb makes a good case for it in his first book of criticism, A Visionz of Reality, though he has also got objections to register in his readably cantankerous way. Of new books of verse by English poets. Mr. George MacBeth's A Doomsday Book shows the most original invention and care for craft at the same time-it instructs the reader how to play games as doom descends, and if the games seem sometimes facetious and the doom theatrical, there are a few unique and thrilling poems to which neither of those objections can be made. Mr. John Wain's rhetorical meditation on the world today, W'ildtrack, is too loosely written to hold much interest. while Mr. D. J. Enright, in Thte Old Adam, deftly satirizes the feebly liberal mind, but in a way he has done before.
Two volumes of collected poems should, however, be remarked on: that of Bernard Spencer, yet a third poet to die untimely in 1963. whose book is full of the colour and sadness of the world; and that of Mr. Robert Graves. who has unfortunately omitted some of his best early poems and included too many of a very recent. rather monotonous sequence. His previous Collected Poems, second-hand, would be a better buy.

Author: Lucie-Smith, Edward
Title: Purity and Thinness in Concrete Poetry
Full_text:
THINGS SEEN
Purity and Thinness in Concrete Poetry
By Edward Lucie-Smith
The fascination with the idea of the total aesthetic experience-an experience which fuses the ideas and sensations offered by two or more of the arts-is beginning to acquire a g6eat significance for modern writers and painters and even (I suspect) for musicians. A symptom is provided by the very wellmounted little exhibition called " Between Poetry and Painting". which is now on view at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, in Dover Street. The scope is, perhaps, narrower than the title suggests. Though the exhibition casts a backward glance at such pioneers as Kurt Schwitters and Guillaume Apollinaire, it is, in fact, a celebration of the new " concrete poetry " movement.
Concrete poetry is difficult to describe, but easy to recognize. The aim is to give words a new dynamism for the eve ----to make the poem a kind of emblem or ikon of what is being said. This has some immediately striiking results. If we choose to regard the products of the movement as belonging to literature. then it is the internationalism which strikes us. The exhibitors at the I.C.A. are French, German, Czech, and Austrian, as well as English and Scottish. The techniques they have in common seem to provide them with a kind of Esperanto. Words one doesn't in fact know signal their meaning thanks to the design in which they are set.
But it is by no means certain that concrete poetry belongs more to literature than it does to the visual arts (one practitioner says frankly that " a more accurate term for this sort of work has still to be invented "). My own inclination is to see concrete poetry as somewhat closer to painting than it is to writing. Yet perhaps this preference is an irrational one, and counts as a comment on the very different atmospheres which now seem to surround poetry and painting in England. The show has none of that characteristic defensiveness which one associates with literary experiment. Nor does it have that excessive regard for the vagaries of the writer's own personality. How can one be satisfactorily 'confessional " when one is also being "concrete " ?
Distinguished Ancestry
All the same, whether or not it inclines more to art than to literature, let me try to place the movement among the competing styles of modern painting. Its ancestry is, of course, very distinguished. It includes the Italian Futurists and Dada. In the guise that it now presents itself, however, concrete poetry seems to be the meeting ground of a number of absolutely contemporary ideas. It is, for example, a branch of abstract painting of the severe and geometrical sort. But the image creeps in at the back door, through the word which forms the unit of pattern. And often the meaning the image conveys is basically rather sentimental. If one examines the work of Ian Hamilton Finlay (the most highly regarded British practitioner) one is surprised to find that what he so often hints at is the refined and rather bloodless pastoralism of the Georgians -sbut up inside the severe patterns he makes. a lyric from The Week End Book is mewing to be let out. But, to do Nir. Hamilton Finlay justicc. he has another line of experiment which seems to me more fruitful. In his more recent wvork. he introduces the idea of sequences in time-a booklet wvhose pages you turn so that you encounter certain words in isolation, following each other in staccato rhythm. What one sees
here is something like -he revolt against the completely static image which one finds in " Op " Art.
Another topic which fascinates the concrete poets, as indeed it does many rnodern painters, is the relationship to be found between the word and the actual thing it stands for. It was an interest in this problem which seems to have inspired Apollinaire to create the "Calligrammes "-still the most beautiful and lyrical things of their kind. But this, in turn, inspires me to a brief digression-one cannot, I think. discuss the topic of concrete poetrv without remarking that, even if it sometimes seems sentimental, it also has a genuinely Iyrical strain. There is a purity and innocence about some of these typographical diagrams which can make the processes of conventional literature seem verv laboured. Why bother to pile image on image when a diagram can give you the thing itself-the very object you wanted to represent 2
Act of Redemption
But sometimes-ancl here I return to my main theme-concrete poetry is genuinely abstract. Letters become the basis for experiments in forn-a ready made vocabulary of shapes from which interesting patterns and rhythms can be built up. but whose * ready made" quality provides the artist with a kind of necessary recalcitrance, a resistance to what he wants to do. The workl of poets and typographical designers here finds a point of contact with what is being done by one or two of the most highlv regarded American painters, notably Jasper Johns. Some of John's most beautiful paintings are based upon sequences of numbers or of letters. These numbers and letters are, it is true, there so that John can "redeem" them with his beautiful brushwork. and in the severe typographical patterns favoured by some of the exhibitors at the I.C.A. one feeLs, perhaps, the want of just such an act of redemption.
It is here, I think, that one encounlers the real weakness of the whole movement, in both its visual and its verbal aspect, as it has so far shown itself to us. The purity I have mentioned is paid for by a certain thinness. Even Apollinaire's "Calligrammes" seem notably less substantial than his other work. The constant fault of whimsicality, wbich one finds in so much concrete poetrv, is perhaps one of the results of this thinness. But to pick upon this alone is not to go to the heart of the matter. The wish to provide a " total " experience of the kind I mentioned in my opening sentence was also a wish which was known at the period of the Baroque. Baroque theatre, with its elaborate stage machinery, i;s masques and pageants, was the product of just such a desire. On its less ambitious scale, and with a characteristically modern spareness, concrete poetry trics to do the same thing-to occupy ail our faculties. It is significant that the exhibition at the I.C.A. appeals to the ear as well as the eye-tbere are recordings of the poets reading their own work: either specially created "sound poems," or the verbal translation of the images we see before us.
The dividing line between being occupied and being distracted is, one discovers, v'ery narrow. I found myself delighted by the exhibition as a whole, but unable to regard many of the exhibits as independent works of art in their own right. Concrete poetry is, at the moment, a visual-verbal laboratory from which something wholly convincing has yet to emerge.

Author: Null
Title: Voice of the poets
Full_text:
Voice of the poets
BY PATRIC DICKINSON
Eliot changed his personal voice; his rhythms are neither Boston nor East Coker but rather from Atlantis. English African poetry has at the moment this quality of nowhere, of being translated from a language no one has ever conversed in.
When Samuel Butler went up-country in nineteenth-century New Zealand and visited sheep-farms he found "gentlemen " and in one remote place a Tennyson under the bed. He expected and implied class distinctions.
There is no class distinction in the African writers of English poetry: only the distinction between writing well and badly. But they begin now. Africa has no culture in the sense that Greece and India have offered to the West moral ideas and myths of enduring value. Indians if they choose to do so write in English in an entirely different milieu from Africans. A young poet such as Dom Moraes is so sure of India he can afford to write in a purely English tradition-indeed like a Rupert Brooke bereft of 1914. One would not know, a diehard would say, that he was an Indian Waring. This aspect of worldEnglish has disadvantages. Tagore chose. Moraes chooses to write in this, an alien tongue; maybe to think in it. Medieval scholars argued and often thought in the dead language of Latin.
Poetry must be living language. The West Indies-in whose small compass so many bloods and colours mix, whose history is African, European, American -the West Indies seem to me to speak NVhitsun fiery English, basic Waring. Their novelists are already well with us, Lamming or Naipaul. Their poets have about half a dozen modes of English to play with. It is enthralling to read them at it, as assured and as gay as Evan Jones, John Figuera, or Derek Walcott. Rhythmically they are difficult to read (as Robert Frost would be to an English-speaking Italian) for in this sort of world-English the basis of poetry, the rhythmic root, can too easily be unearthed.
But to use this metaphor of earth: we live on it. Over a great space of earth, English is used to communicate, one being to another. This Commonwealth exists, its lingua franca is English. Poets, whatever Shelley meant by " unacknowledged legislators ", do speak both locally and universaUy. Shakespeare came from Stratford-uponAvon: we know that. Where did his plays come from ? That we shall never know nor need to. There is this Commonwealth and everywhere there are poets in it: where do they come from ? Scholars and geographers can answer. But do they write well ? Yes, and readers from all over the world must find them and enjoy them. Time will "pardon" them, in time. But we are here now-in Eliot's words-we must read them now:
Quick now, here now, always-
ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
Help in the photographic preparation of this supplement was given by: the Australian News and Information Bureau, National Film Board of Canada, the office of the Canadian High Commissioner in London, and the Commonwealth Arts Festival Press Office.
What's become of Waring
Since he gave us all the slip?
SO BEGINS A POEM of Browning's written over 100 years ago. It is generally assumed that Waring was Alfred Domett (1811-87) and what became of him is well known. He went to New Zealand where he attained high office and went on writing rather turgid and mediocre Victorian verse. Another line of Browning's comes to mind, " I was never out of England, it's as if I saw it all ".
Let me use Waring as if he were a Commonwealth poet now, and regard his problems. Waring, the New Zealander, comes from a small country. The settlers and the Maoris now live at ease. The Maoris have learnt to speak English: the New Zealanders speak an English a great deal derived from their Scottish ancestors-purer than cockney. The problem of their poets has been and still is to write in a tongue which is their own, a rhythm of speech which reflects their own vernacular. But they do not want to be " regional ". We in this northern island " the mole between all Europe and the exile-crowded sea " smugly think of ourselves as a centre of culture. The emphasis is changing, for America is offering a second sort of English language and culture (a different speech r-hythm), but still young Waring wants to write as a New Zealander and be accepted by a London publisher and have the plaudits of the Sunday critics. I begin with New Zealand for of all the accents of English speech used in the Commonwealth it is nearest to English English. It is perhaps for this reason that young poets such as James K. Baxter and C. K. Stead are able to write as themselves in a tone of voice which is positive. Time, as Auden puts it, " pardons " a poet for " writing well ". This question of writing well seems to vex the Antipodes most-I think because their language is really only ours. The Australians are aggressively national. For example, W. J. Turner is omitted from the Penguin Anthology of Australian Verse because he made his life (and was published) in England, and the same is true of a much younger poet, Peter Porter. Yet the attitude and the rhythms of their work are Australian and are based upon the sound and rhythm of speech they grew up hearing.
The tendency, both in New Zealand and Australia, is to write lyrically about their native lands, but satirically about people here, there or anywhere. I think this springs from their being so closely bound to our one language. No New Zealander or Australian would claim that Domett or Adam Lindsay Gordon were great poets, but they adhere to the English tradition. Young Australasian Waring has read Chaucer and Skelton and Donne and Pope and (possibly) Browning and Tennyson. Far from having to justify being Antipodean young poets such as Nan McDonald or Ray Mathew seem fully alive to the world-fungus of Eng. Lit. and intent upon escaping its growing over them.
Canada being so near to a cognate language has had a far harder time. (I must omit French-Canadian poetry.) To write like a Canadian is half to overhear American speech and, it seems, still half to hear London calling rather louder than Chicago. Writing well in Canada has not come easily. Balladwriters like Banjo Patterson in Australia or Robert NV. Service in
Canada have escaped the problems of more serious poets. Canadian Waring seems only too cognisant of American University broiler-house methods of Lit. Crit. The editors of a recent anthology think Canadian poetry "can be very interesting if readers and critics, but more especially if school teachers and university professors, begin to see that poetry is the fullest and most adequate expression of our thinking and living ". This has a depressingly dead sound, or would have, if Earle Birney or Douglas Le Pan or David Wevill did not write well, " whether on the shores of Asia or in the Edgware Road ". There is half of half the problem of Commonwealth poets. For the basically English-speaking, it must matter, but not matter, where they are. It is silly of Australians to resent Turner or Porter living in England: suppose they had opted for Canada-a nation of two languages, French and English ?
In Africa the indigenous populations have been most widely subject to these two languages, NMgritude for Frenchspeaking Africans is a literary attitude which English-speaking Africans are apt to denigrate. But the problem of writing poetry is different for a Nigerian as opposed to a Canadian. He is aware of other languages and English may not be the language he was brought up to think in. The African Waring may still be writing in translation:
One wife be for one man.
I done try go church, I done go for
court
Dem all day talk about di "new cul-
ture "
Dem talk about " equality ", dem men-
tion " divorce "
Dem holler am so-tay my ear'nearly
cut;
In this satirical piece young Frank Aig-Imoukhuede is so free in English he can write pigeon, know it, and have a go at western morality in a way wholly different from young David Elworthy having a go at upper-class afternoon tea in New Zealand. African poetry it seems to me iust be (and is) fascinated by language. " A primrose by the river's brim" is part of the conventional imagery of exile to Antipodeans or Canadians. To an African, reading Wordsworth must be a mystery. African delight in language is reflected in all their poems, which are preponderantly written without rhyme. Rhyme, we know, was a vulgar innovation in the decline of Rome; and when it came in many of the, poets were writing in a literary language not really their own. African poets like Wole Soyinka or Christopher Okigbo are entrancing and entranced by language. Either they write of people or ideas. There is no yearn for the exposition of landscape to bolster nationality. Their aim is to write like . . . how would this sentence go on ? .. . Like T. S. Eliot ? He may well stand for this sort of expatriate poetry.

Author: Null
Title: Vade-Mecum
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
VADE-MECUM
By Oliver Edwards
When writing of William Watson last week I mentioned the three or four beautifully judged lines T. Earle Welby gave him in A Poputlar History of English Poetry. No sooner had the reference come into my head-seemingly unbidden, as such things do-than it also occurred to me that I should write about that little-known masterpiece. The fact that M. R. Ridley, when writing of the Manx poet Brown in his new book of essays Second Thoughts, makes exactly the same kind o( reference to the neglect of Welby's book need not, I think, deter me.
Welby's heyday was immediately after the First World War. He had been born in India, and up to the age of thirty-nine he had worked mainly there as a journalist. One Man's India, in which he gave word pictures of those years and his reflections on Indian life, is one of his two best works. A small book, it contains the distillation of a sub-continent. Posthumously published at a time (1933) when Indians were even more sensitive than they are now, it was not popular. Yet who will now say he was not right about Tagore ?
In 1920 Welby came to England and settled here for the remaining 13 years of his life. Naturally he turned to journalism for his mainstay. It was, however. of a different kind. He became a writer on The Satuirday Reviewv, and when the split occurred and Gerald Barry gave up the editorship of that paper and founded Tlze Week-end Review Welby went with him.
The fruits of that late blossoming are to be found in two volumes, Back Numbers and Second Impressions. He declared the essays to be table-talk, and repeated the point more than once to distinguish them from criticism. Yet there is plenty of good criticism in them. How refreshing it is to be told-at any rate in middle age-that while " The N uptials of Attila " is a very great poem, "it is also the furious debauch of an imagination rejoicing in barbarism". Austin Dobson. he said, was a man of genius who had been praised only for his talents. " It was a very sound artistic instinct that sent Ernest Dowson to the Latin convention in those poems which might be compared with [Thomas] Ashe's." At the same time, table-talk abounds. Where else would one learn that, contrary to the general belief, Swinburne was not a strong'swimmer ? " Where he did surpass almost every contemporary was in his ability to float hour after hour, on a rough sea."
One thing common to all these extracts is that they are about poets. Welby was equally ready to write about Trollope, Disraeli, Wilkie Collins, Froude, Gissing, Samuel Butler, Thomas Hardy, Charlotte Bronte, and Boswell. In The Dinner Knell he engaged in "table-talk by turns gastronomical, literary, political ". (The Cellar Key is beyond me, as I know nothing about
wine.) But it was poetry first, last, and always, that held primacy in Welby's mind and heart.
He wrote studies of Swinburne and Arthur Symons. He edited, with the most self-effacing discretion, the great collected Landor. He compiled an anthology, The Silver Treasttry of English Lyrics. He wrote A Popular History of English Poetry.
This last was first published by Philpot soon after Welby settled in England. It received a warm welcome but did not make the general stir it should have done. Maybe after the 1914-18 poetic debauch not many wanted a panorama of poetry from Anglo-Saxon and Provencal sources to Masefield and de la Mare. Methuen republished it in 1933, and it is in this handy form that it has been my companion ever since.
Another reason why A Popular H.story of English Poetry may not have had the acclaim it should is that those who have only glanced into it may have remained unbelieving that the triumph Welby in fact achieved was really possible. Such volumes generally fall between two extremes. Either, in order to make the work readable, the author chooses the great names only, writes glowingly about them, and leaves a feeling of inadequacy and incompleteness, or in order to get everyone in, he produces a dull catalogue.
Welby loved the minor poets as well as the major ones. Both his essays and his Silver Treastry show him at home with Barnabe Googe, Ebenezer Jones, Bartholomew Griffin. Chidiock Tichborne. as well as with Milton and Shelley. And when he came to write his Popula, History, he felt he must find a place, even to the length of quoting two stanzas, for Elizabeth Siddal.
Poet after poet, great and small, is presented, judged, placed in literary or historical perspective. Yet the book is unfailingly readable. One can pick it up, open it anywhere, with the guarantee one wiU borrow time from whatever the next engagement is.
There are a number of reasons. One is that the author is one of the greatest and most catholic lovers of true poetry who ever lived. Another, that he moved through his domain with the grace, wit, and assurance of a man who knew every inch of it. On top of these he was a writer who had a running style and could yet make his judgments, where necessary, short and memorable. Lastly he knew exactly when and what to quote. Of all literary accomplishments this is the most tricky.
The number of books that will unfailingly make readers is very few. In its own field A Popular History of English Poetry is to my mind unique. No writer could ask for a more living memorial. As long as a copy exists anywhere, it will lead someone into the realms of gold..l

Author: Null
Title: American Poetry's Casual Look
Full_text:
American
Poetry's
Casual Look
There is an American little magazine that sends out mrocking rejection slips to poets who submit verse in iambic pentameters: This entitles you to one free copy of the next book by Alfred, Lord Tennyson." That is the more pugnacious side of the main movement in American poetry recently-a movement away from elaborate 'academic" verse to poetry of a more colloquial style. Walt Whitman was the founding father of this movement, but its main hero nearer in time is William Carlos Williams, the small-town doctor-cum-poet who died last year at the age of 80.
Messrs MacGibbon and Kee have started bringing out in Great Britain all Wiiliams's work: the first two volumes are a varied collection called Pictures from Breughel, and his long poem Paterson. Paterson is an imaginary town in New Jersey which Williams created as his symbol of America, and the poem is a mosaic of lyrical and narrative fragments about the people of this town, interspersed with fascinating newspaper clippings and letters. Sometimes Paterson is itself seen as a man, the townspeople as the Population of his dreams. Open the book ahywhere and a clear Image of some facet of American life springs from it; what it seems to lack is a coherent interpretation of American life, in its drifting pages. Pict,ures from Brueghel, too, is a little too deliber.ately limited to precise, casual-toned description.
Miss Marianne Moore is another longhonoured American poet She too writes in a colloquial vein, but a rnore refincd and fanciful one. Her latest book, Thte Arctic Ox, does not contain anything so. good as the best in her Collected Poe,ns, but the urbane moral lessons she draws here from contemplating giraffes, jellyfish, chameleons and the animal of the title all have her inimitable note-she sets the arctic ox. for instance, with its "golden fleece and winning ways ". against less desirable animals:
Camels are snobbish
and sheep. unintelligent;
water buffaloes, neurastheniccven murderous.
Reindeer seem over-serious . . .
Miss Anne Sexton is at the other end of the spectrum from Miss Moore. Eveiything Of hers, good or bad, is honest and intense personal confession-how the "I"1 of the poems felt when not going to her father's funeral, or after having an abortion, Lor trying to commit suicide. There is a moving and dignified truthfulness about
poems like " The Truth the Dead Know": Gone, I say and walk from church.
refusing the stiff procession to the grave, letting the dead ride alone in the hearse.
It is June. I am tired of being brave.
But some of her other Selected Poems are too nakedly artless to convey the feelings that obviously prompted them.
The most difficult but perhaps also the most gifted of all these American poets is Mr. John Berryman. His 77 Dream Songs is a collection of short, beautifullyphrased sets of dream thoughts and sensations? not always easy to unravel but evoking an extraordinary range of feelings, with a grave modern humour flashing through them:
There sat down, once, a th;ng on Henry's
heart s6 heavy, if he had a hundred years
& more, & weeping, sleepless, in all them
Henry could not make good. time Starts again always in Henry's ears
the littlo cough somewhere, an odour,
a chime. Two more American volumes must be briefly mentioned: the rather whimsical verses, sometimes depending on almost Victorian word-play, that Mr. John Updike wrote for the hew Yorker, now collected in Telephone Poles; and some delicate sketches, in the new half-whispering voice, by Mr. Donald Hall in A Roof of Tiger Lilies. The last good translations into English of the remarkable Italian poet Bugemio Montale were some done a couple of years ago by the American poet Mr. Robert Lowell, in his Imitations, so perhaps it is also appropriate here to mention a handsomely produced new volume of Montale translations, with the originals facing them. by Mr. George Kay. To read the loose but vivid Lowell versions, Mr. Kay's carefully literal verse translations, and the originals, side by side, is very rewarding even for a reader with no more than a smattering of Italian.

Author: Null
Title: A Good Autumn Harvest of English Poetry
Full_text:
A Good Autumn Harvest
of En1qlish Poetry
Mr. Robert Graves dominates this autumnt's collection of new volumes of poetry, as he domiiated the autumn of 1962 with his previous book. Man Does, Woman Is represents perhaps an even more congenial mood than that last collection-there, the calmly arrogant image of the poet as " lion lover" haunted most of the lyrics; here, the prevailing note is of submissive gratitude to the woman-goddess:
Woman with her forests, moons. flowers. And watchful fingers:
We claim no magic comparable to hersAt best, poets; at worst, sorcerers.
Mr. Graves still has, at his own watchful fingertips, the power to suggest emotion of great purity and intensity, yet does not fail to remind us too of ironic, and comic, human frailty. The combination comes out very sharply, for instance, in a wry song called "A Phoenix Flame ", where the lover, burning with passion, asks for a nook out of the sun, for
Who could boast a careless wit,
Dkoubly roasted, heart and hide. Turning on the Sun's red spit,
Consumed inside ?
The best book by an English poet of a younger generation this autumn has undoubtedly been Mr. Donald Davie's Events and Wisdoms. There are a great variety of themes and forms in this collectionsketches of places as far apart as California and Chopin's birthplace near Warsaw, incidents from his childhood and his present life, moral reflections and moody lyricsbut a consistent delicacy of diction and an unsparing intetligence run through them all. " Low Lands " evokes beautifully the scene in low-lying country-
... slow light spilt and wheeling over
calm
Inundations, and a snake's still menace
looding with bruised sky belfry and
lonely farm-
then passes, by sure twists of the thought to such a landscape's tedium, its defencelessness-and its oddly noble dependence on others' mercy. In most of the poems there is this same quick, easy movement from sight to reflection.
Mr. Paul West also writes vividly about places-Avila, Hokkaido, Burma, a ballpark in the United States. But he lets his harsh, rich portraits yield the feeling he wants from them with much less explicit comment than Mr. Davie. The poems in The Snow Leopard ovoke a world almost bare, too, of the gentle humanism to which Mr. Davie constantly returns. Mr. West's hostile yet colourful universe seems to have sensuous and sensual pleasure to offerbut only to those who can match it in intensity, whether Japanese suicide-pilots, children, or-the inanimate heroine of one of the finest of these poems-a block of new flats at Poggio Reale, Naples:
She flaunts her confidence before all
modern eyes,
Encouraging and yet a sudden world
apart.
Some of these poems seemn slightly loose and unfinished; but they compose a striking volume.
The best poems in Mr. Edward LucieSmith's Confessions and Histories are his very thoroughly-imagined historical monologues. Particularly appealing is his " Rubens to Helene Fourment ", Rubens's thoughts as he paints the superb portrait of his wife in a dark pelisse that is now one of the glories of Vienna. Mr. LucicSmith gets into words not o'nly the painter's awareness of the dying relationship between him and Helene. but also his in-
comparable sense of her physical beauty. Oher figures successfully brought into these pages are Caravaggio, a fourth-century Grcek among the Scythians, and the Sibyl in her jar.
In Recoveries Miss Elizabeth Jennings offers some careful and sensitive reflections on relationships in hospital, and also some good poems on the relationships between partnts and children. Her concern for tidiness of vision does, however, make her work over-neat at times. Patric Dickinson, in This Cold Universe. is another poet who sometimes allows his skll with lyrical forms to lead him into too artificially balanced conclusions. though his work clearly springs from a romantic and generous spirit. Mr. Gavin Ewart's Londoners is an agreeable if utambitious book-a bit of history, a bit ol atmosphere, all in verse, about places iu London from Barnes Bridge to Harrodi Finally, the late C. S. Lewis's collected Poems do not establish him posthumously as a poet; but some of his sharper-evcu, at times, Plain grumpy-satires have a dash of satisfying force in them, while his slighl,
romantic poems will at least evoke the I man for those who admired him.

Title: The Poetry of Giselle
Full_text:
The Arts
The Poetry of
Giselle
Royal Opera House: Giselle
The success of Giselle, like all of the Romantic theatre, depends on its ability to make us suspend not so much our disbelief as our cynicism. We have to feel what Gautier called " Giselle's pretty death" and we have, moreover, to feel the poetry of a situation so alien to our age that we must, unconsciously, believe either in fairies (difficult for all but the Peter Pans among us) or, more probably, iu a man obsessed with poetic visions.
It is the sovereign virtue of Giselle as danced by the remarkable partnership of Dame Margot Fonteyn and Mr. Rudolf Nureyev, who returned to the ballet at Covent Garden last night, that they can make Giselle into a poetic experience to be shared with their audience.
In vears to come, when asked whether Dame Margot was a great Giselle, we shall probably answer " No " with some reluctance. A great dancer, and ironically enough an always improving Giselle, this has never been among her finest roles and. in spite of the inspiration of Mr. Nurcyev, one imagines that it now never will be. Mvagnificent, honest, and tender. it misses the supreme by the hair's-breadth of simplicitv. Also. perhaps, Dame Margot's dancing is not ideal for Giselle. lt lacks lightness and deliquescence. No one can have everything, and the glowing qualities that have made Dame Margot the Aurora of our age are naturally less at home in this elusive Romantic tragedy.
Mr. Nureyev is, of course, the Albrecht. His shocking choreographic interpolations (how inartistic it is to insert a virtuoso series of entrechais into the last act !), and even his acting mannerisms, were again proved to be of total unimportance in the face of his wild, Lermontov-like poetry, his fevered yet still exquisitely beautiful dancing, and his conception of Albrecht as the man of feeling surrounded by a world of sensation who finds redemption in a tragic love.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry and Athletics
Full_text:
Poetry and Athletics
The Royal Ballet's choice of programme to open the new season last night possibly looked more impressive on paper than it proved to be on the Covent Garden stage. Undeniably, it would be ditficult to envisage a more suitable ballet to open with than Balanchine's Serenade, but after this beginning the programme appeared to trail away disappointingly, and neither MacMillan's images of Love nor Massine's Mam'zelle Angot left a particularly forcible impression.
Of Serenade it is harddy possible to have enough, and the Royal Ballet dance it with just that mingling of poetry and athletics, of Chekhov and Gecohetti if you like, that halps provide the ballet with its chaaracteristic mood of triumphant elegy. It is first and last a women's baLlet, for the men are used strictly as broodingly Romantic partners, who lift high, emo e much but dance little. The women, as a consequence, have it all their own way. and Balanchine seems actually to merge them with the Tchaikovsky music, giving that music a new dimension and, indeed. a new importance.
The performance, if perhaps the slightest degree below the revival's Premiere last season. was nevertheloss masterly, with the ensemble moving like leaves in the w.nd and the principals, Miss Svetl;na Beniosova, Miss Nadia Nerina, Miss An.nette Page, Mr. David Blair and Mr Donald Mac-Leary, all danoing with that grave but unemphatic ecstasy required.
Mr. MacMillan has removed three episodes from his excursion into ShakesPeariana, Images of Love. These were perhaps among the weakest. one is grateful. Avowedly inspired by Shakespeare's views of love. the ballet adds little to the solemnly intoned quotations it is meant to illustrate. There are, naturally with Mr. MacMillan, many worthwhile passages, including a striking pas de deux for Miss Beriosova and Mr. MacLeary, but the choreography's total effect is almost as slight as the Peter Tranchell music accompanying it.
Mam'zelle Angot Massine's efficient ballet bounfe, developed from a Lecocq oporetta, has not been seen in the opera house for some years. although it was revived last summer at Drury Lane. Miss Merle Park danced with ferocious charm as the eponymous mam'zelie, and is probably the rumbustiously best interpreter the role has ever had. For the rest, despite Mr. Alexander Grant's familiarly bouncy Barber and some excellent portrayals in the smaller parts, the Performance lacked something in spirit.

Author: Null
Title: Music And Poetry
Full_text:
MUSIC AND POETRY
Art drew close to us and the fleeting of time seemed merely one of art's possible themes, when Dame Edith Evans and Mr. Robert Eddison joined last night with Miss Patricia Carroll at the Arts Theatre in the first of three performances of a programme of poetry and music devised by Mr. George Rylands
The words of Keats, Blake, Milton, Shakespeare might, as Dame Edith spoke them, have sounded arrogant in their beauty, if Miss Carroll had not provided the background of another muse, using as an introduction to the first grouD of literarn extracts Bach, to the second Janacek to the third Liszt and to the final. group Schubert. The musicians, offering an alternative to the poets, caused the impact of the poetry to be gentler. They supplied an echo not to Dame Edith's voice but to the vigour of her thought, complementing it, rounding it off.
Mr. Eddison's voice was by contrast that af reason., seeking to establish the why and wherefore of things rather than proclaim their essence. He showed he could do this both seriously in Tamburlaine, and to humorous effect, with a Victorian undergraduate's letter about the sights of Rome.

Stratford

.The Stratford-on-Avon Festival willopen, as usual, in time for Shakespeare's birthday. The Royal Shakespeare Company begins its conspectus of English history according to Shakespeare-performances eventually in sequence of the history plays from Richard 11 to Richard III-with Richard 11 on April 15 and the Henry IV plays on the following day; the later histories will be added as the season progresses; the cycle will be completed on August 12 and will run until December.
Special quatercentenary celebrations however, crowd the period between April 21 and September 6. A variety of relevant exhibitions, led by that arranged by Mr. Richard Buckle, are available; folk dancing, sometimes British and sometimes international, offers its attractions frequently. The Shakespeare films of Sir Laurence Olivier, Othello in the film versions of Orson Welles and Sergei Yutkevidh, and the Japanese interpretation of Macbeth, The Throne of Blood, together with the Bolshoi Ballet's filnM of Prokofiev's Romeo and Jtliet, are -to be seen. Local schools are taking part. with performances of Twelfth Night and Andre Obey's Noah as well as appropriately Elizabethan entertainments.
Sunday evenings between July 5 and August 20 are to be devoted to "The 1964 Festival of Poetry ", directed by Mr. Patrick Garland. A series of poems commissioned for. the festival will be heard in the first programme, and that of July 26 will be centred on the work of Mr. Roy Fuller, the "poet of the year". Other programmes of readings and music, The Tremendous Ghost and In Praise of Shakespeare, occupy April 26 and 28, while the reopenink of the Stratford-on-Avon canal by Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother on July 11 provides an opportunity for fireworks, concerts, and a performance of Henry V.
The musical events of the quatercentenary are almost a festival in them-
selves. -At the CityF of .Birmingham Symphoay Orchestra's concert on June 14 Mr. John Gardner's The Noble Heart, a work commissioned for the festival, will have its first performance, Miss Heather Harper and Mr. Michael Langdon are the soloists. with the Festival Choir. Much of the music to be heard is directly Shakespearian. PurcelIls The Fairy Queen. conducted by Mr. Anthony Lewis with Miss Jennifer Vyvyan, Miss Honor Sheppard, Mr. John Whitworth, Mr. Robert Tear. and Mr. Trevor Anthony, occupies May 16. Recitals entirely or partly of settings of Shakespeare's lyrics are to be given by Miss Harper and Mr. Richard Lewis (May 19), Miss Ann Dowdall and the Orchestra da Camera. conducted by Mr. Brian Priestman (June 12), and M. Gerard Souzay (June 16). The London Symphony Orchestra. conducted by M. Monteux. offers a programme of Shakespeare-inspired works by Tchaikovsky, Mendelssohn, Faur6, and Berlioz on May 17.
COMPOSERS OF THE PERIOD
Composers contemporary with Shakespeare provide the programmes of the B.B.C. Invitation Concert on Anril 21, and concerts by the Goldon Age Singers and the Elizabethan Consort on May 15, by the choir of King Edward VI School, Southampton, on June 13, the Birrningham University Motet Choir on July 4, King's College Choir on July 31, and the Hamish Preston Choir on August 1, as well as of organ recitals by Mr. Piet Kee on June 10 and Mr. Ralph Downes on August 5. On August 8 Mr. Julian Bream provides an evening with the English lutenist composers.
The anniversaries of C. P. E. Bach, Leo Hassler, and Gluek are celebrated by Stratford-on-Avon Choral Society on May 23 in a programme of unusual interest and enterprise, wiule Rameau's bicentenary is the occasion for a concert by L'Ensemble Alarius de BruxeUes on August 2. Other concerts are given by Mr. Menuhin and the Bath Festival Orchestra (April 26), the Amadeus Quartet (June 13), the Philip Jones Wind Ensemble (July 10), and the Royal Shakespeare Theatre Wind Band (August 9). Alil these programmes combine ShakesPearian affiliations with interesting Work of other periods and are notably unhackneyed, as is Miss Janet Baker's catholic survey of English song on September 1. Miss Marilyn Mason's organ recital on the following evening provides old English and new American music.

Title: Moonfolk and Mountainfolk In some New Poetry
Full_text:
Moonfolk and Mountainfolk
In some New Poetry
Mr. Ted Hughes's new volume of poems is an account of the creatures he has imagined living on the moon. But you don't feel he has simply imagined them; his grave, worried air, with many a head_5haking or bit of homely advice, makes them more real and gives you more shivers than any other kind of talk about them could. Sorne of t;hemn seem to have evoilved along the line of human folly, like the moon-cabbages who are either " bundles of great loose lips" or " bundles of flapping ears ", and whose " mutual ahnusements resound ". Others seem the embodiment of human dreams, like the earth-owl, which can fly through the moon's substrata with unfal,tering wing. But all live in a terror-ridden environment, where crab-grass, the burrow-wolf who swallows meteorites like marshmallows; and "the flying strangler, the silent zero " lord it over the " snail-saliva silveriness" which Mr. R. A. Brandt's drawings for the book so well convey. This is Edward Lear's universe, with a new chill in the air.
After his versions of the Russian poet Fyodor Tyutchev, Mr. Chatles Totnlinson now comes up with some free but often brilliant translations of the Spaniard Antonio Machado. He has worked, as before, in collaboration with that polyglot don, Mr. Hcnry Gifford. Machado was an Andalusian who spent some of the most important years of his life among the "impassive, sturdy" ilexes of the Castilian mountains, and who found in them a resonant symbol for the people who maintained the gravest and finest of Spanish traditions. His own best poems are like simple, evocative images etched with stone on stone. Mr. Tomlinson has conveyed this effect with his words scored at expressively varying intervals down the page; though in a few caces he overdoes it, with too much of a silent " hey presto I " holding us up before each word appears.
Mr. R. S. Thomas is trying to do for Wales something of what Machado did for Castile, He is a more self-conscious poet, torn by his intense loyalty to the men of the "high ploughland" and his sense that, especially in recent times, his fellow countrymen have too often become starved and narrow in spirit, like the farmworker
Draped over his bones like a thing To scare birds.
He is a patriot and nationalist without illusions, and some of his poems are bittcr:
Move with the times? I've done that all right: In a few years Buried a nation
None of those farms In the high hills
Have bred children.
My poems were of old men.
The death of two accomplished poets in their middle fifties was a recent tragedy. Bernard Spencer's last book, With Luck Lasting, is full of superb and joyful impressions of moments of time in Greece and Spain and England. Spencer had a quite unique gift for conveying, without comment, the physical impression of a place he
liked and all the excitement it stirred in him. A spring wind:
Spring shakes the windows; doors
whang to,:
the sky moves half in dark and half shining like knives . . . A Spanish dancer:
Back will go the head with the dark curls and the foot will stamp . . .
dry like a thirst the guitar rings.
Louis MacNeice's last volume, The Burning Perch, had more of a cloud bianging over it. Its locale is a ghost-ridden London-sonetimes, as in " October in Bloomsbury ", wanly lovely, but more often populated by the unforgiving spectres of failure. The strength of the poems is in the deftness and cool lack of self-pity with which these spectres are drawn.
Finally, a verse play, two anthologies and an encyclopedia. Mr. Lawrence Durrell disappoints rather in his play An Irish Faustus. He has set Faustus in the palace of Queen Katherine of Galway, and (as usual these days) made him win the battle when tompted -to give up white magic for black magic. His strongest enemy is not Mephistopheles at all, but the queen who is in love with her vampire husband. TIhis rather crude Gothic note is intermingled with poor mock-medieval hutnour about Martin the jolly pardoner. Mr. Durrell is also the editor of this year's P.E.N. anthology, which has its usual mixture of good Poems and interesting effortsMr. D. J. Enright's con.tdbutions strike one as the best this year. The English Association s Poems of Today gives about two poems each to 79 different poets who have been writing since 1947-a very catholic selectio5n. but with plenty of the plums in it.
The eoncise EncYclopaedia of English and American Poets and Poetry contains much interesting information, but has its oddities. Its short entries on individual poets are Written in a variety of critical styles, from' the one which introduces John Clare as a Poet " who attained a: liberated purity of sensation and style ", whatever that may mean, to the one that inforrns us that " William Empson is the oddest English poet who wrote between the two World Wars ". A number of longer articles deal with subjects abstract and historical. like " Metaphor " and " Middle English Lyrics ", where stricter editorial control over style and approach would again have made the book more satisfying. There are 96 good full-page portraits.

Title: An Experiment with Music
Full_text:
The Arts l
An Experiment
with Music
Settings of Poem
Royal Court Theatre: Festival . of Poetry
Mr. Eric Mottram's survey of the American poetic scene today (the first of last night's programmes in the current poetry festival), moved from some late verse by William Carlos Williams through poems by Mr. Robert Lowell, Miss Muriel Ruckeyser, Mr. Jonathan Williams, Mr. John Hollander and Mr. Ronald Johnson (all of whom read their own work) to poetry by other young wrliters unknown in Britain.
The programme represented a broadening of horizons from Mr. Lowell's sensitive introsptions, which draw everything he encounters into his private woild. Mr. Wlfiamrs and Mr. Johnson love external facts; Mr. Hoiander and Mr. Ken Coch (one of whose wotks Mr. Hollander read) are almost metaphysical wits. Only Mr. Williams, however, delights in technical variety or the poet's play with words and rhythms; for the most part, this was poetry of assertion through images subsequently analysed.
The second programme brought to light Mr. Patric Dickinson's experi. ment with music. Messrs. Lennox Berkeley, Humphrey Searle. tichard Arnell and Nicholas Maw each provided a setting of Robert Graves's ' C'ounting the beats ", the moving conversation in which two lovers qlietly triumph over the transcience they dread. Mr. Searle uses the poern to express typical intensities of his own. Mr. Arnell and Mr. Maw have set it with rhetorical dcmlamation, asking less acrobatic virtuosity of Mr. Gerald English, who sang each setting sendidly; some of Mr. Maw's vocal phrases .are very beautiful. Mr, Berkeley has composed quiet, intimate music with a flowing melodic line.
As the poem was not the composer's choice, the lively interest of the experiment rather outweighed its arctistic value; at any rate. two hearings were not enough to supply any feeling tlt a real fusion of poetry and music had been achieved. Mr. Berkeley's song, the closest to the mood of the poem, is still miusic expounding a test.
The experiment was followed first by each composer's account of the difficulties he had experienced in setting the intensely thoughtful poem; each agreed thlat, in spite of its easily singable diction, its rapid changes of mood had almost defied musical form; this fact, lUke their avoidance of the obvious musical imagery of heartbeats tat couont " the bleeding to death of time ", was evident from what they had written. T'hey were then asked to discuss their position as songwriters in relation to Arne's " Come Away, Death " (Why not, one wondered, to a song by Dowland, Daniel or Purcell, composers more relevant to their problem ?). Their discussion was amusing, high-spirited, clever and livelv. Naturally enough, it Produced no statement of really substantial value; the songs themselves covered all the points raised.

Title: Poetry Double Bill
Full_text:
Poetry Double
Bill
Strong Contrast
Royal Court Theatre: Festival
of Poetry
Two programmes will be presented on each of the six days of the 1963 Festival of Poetry, which the Poetry Book Society has promoted in association with the Arts Council. On the first day, yesterday, an anthology entitled "The Rebel " was followed later in the evening by " Poets and Poems ", which consisted for the most part of readings by four poets from their own work.
There was an enormous difference betiveen the two. " The Rebel ". which Mr. Patrick Garland had arranged and prodAuced on behalf of ithe Apollo Society, was, considered as a programne, a professional piece of work. Five speakers and two singers providing their own acoompanimsent. all of them men, put on the stage something that was in its way a piece of " theatre ".
They wove their way in and out between three movable screens, leaving the stage now to one man, now to a group, as though a meeting of the Jacobin Club were being held, at whicb members, istead -of making their own speeches, quoted from MWlton, D. H. Lawrence, Ned Kelly, Robert Enmext, James Joyce. and others.
Late in the evening we heard Cain saying that he did not know wihere A-bel was and asking whether he was bhis brother's keeper. Did Mr. Garland intend to remind us that every other man is ou,r brother and to suggest that the rebel's defiance of society is at bottom a protest against our forgetfuiness of that relaftionSip ? If so, this would supply his anthology with a connecting link. in the absence of wbich the rebeLs' defiance seemed to have no moral basis. As it was, the argument of Dostoevsky's Grand Inquisitor to the effect that man. though bornaa rebel, is only haff a rebel and with the other aflf of hiimself craves ,to be told what to do, went unanswered when Mr. Peter Bowles delivered ftwith much forme at -the end of the proramme.
" Poets and Poems" was not a piece of "theatre ". Miss Sarath Hamilton's pabited swreens were now used for the flinst time, but Mr. Paul Roche, Mr. Alan Brownjohh, Mr. Peter Porter and Mr. Christopher Logue merely stood there in turns and read to use rather than declaimed at us. Later, M.r. Stanley Myers played songs by Mr. Logue, which he had set to music, and Miss Jean HaTt sang them.
None of this was oratory. It sounded like something that a writer, having done all he could with it and then put'it aside. was now trying out on an audience. What beter justification could there be of our presence than ,that we were makcing up an audience such ias these poets needed for their own ends ?
The other three poets, treating us as an audience other than a theatre-audience, established a relaxed atmosphere which the* Festival's director, Mr. Patric Dickinson, probably hopes to maintain during the rest Of this week.
