Title: Poetry Aided By June Magic
Full_text:
POETRY AIDED BY
JUNE MAGIC
Open Air Theatre: Much Ado About
Nothing
Don Pedro . ..... JoHN JUSTI Don John ...... EDGAR WpxFoRD
Leonata .. ... DAVID KING Benedick ...... DENIS QULLEY Claudio ... .. BERNARD LLOYD DogberrY ..... MICHAEL BLAXEMORE Hero .. ... JILL DIXON Beatrice ... .. ANN MORRISH
Produced by DAVID WILLIAM
With the connivance of the weather, the Regent's Park auditorium last night had one of its comparatively rare opportunities of becoming one of the most delightful of theatres, adding, as extraneous noises died away, its own magic to a play that often seems to need the aid of as much enchantnent as possible.
Mr. David William's production, if it does not aim at the spectacular mannered elegance which Sir John Gielgud has taught us to associate with this work, has the merit of being consistently worked out, so that the fantastic improbabilities of laaudio and Hero go properly in counterpoint with the emotional growing up of Beatrice and Benedick. Furthermore, it is designed effectively to bring out the best in its players; it is not imposed upon them but evolves from their personalities and talents.
Thus, if we are not altogether convinced, we are kept interested, amused and happy for most of the time, watching a delightful quality of happy serenity in Miss Jill Dixon's Hero and a lively forthrightness in Mr. Bernard Lloyd's Claudio. Mr. Michael Blakemore's Dogberry has a magnificent opinion of himself, but could bear a riper fruitiness of voice. The Beatrice and Benedick of Miss Ann Morrish and Mr. Denis Quilley are sensibly interpreted and played with effective directness. Their afwitatin the early scenes is not an affectation of enormous superiority but an adolescent game which they continue just a little belatedly to enjoy; the mock calamity of Hero's disgrace forces them to grow up, and they do so effectively.

Author: Null
Title: Everything And The Kitchen Sink Between Paper Covers
Full_text:
Everything And The Kitchen Sink
Between Paper Covers
The flood continues, with an average of five or six new paperbacks published everv day. As usual, many, of these recall Swift's phrase, "sweepings from butchers' stalls, dung, guts, and blood", but when they have bobbed away or sunk a great deal of good reading remains. Substantal reinforcements have come this year from some American series which are now more readily available, no:ably the excellent Signet Classics, Collier Books, and Barron's Educational Series. There has been a welcome increase of poetry and drama, several good art books, and some useful symposia; and paperbacks have moved still more firmly into Europe, not only with translations but also with more books in the original languages, such as W. H. Allen's Collection lnternationale.
Those long-distance runners, the Penguins, are now -far from lonely, but they are still in the lead. They have launched two new series this year, Peregrines and Peacocks. The latter, designed for what are sometimes called "tween-agers ", are very wishy-washy: there seems to have been some misapprehension about what young people like to read. The Peregrines were introduced rather self-consciously as " egg-head Penguins ", of " more specialized appeal than Pelicans"; in 'what way they are more specialized is not clear, particularly as one of the latest batch, Carcopino's Daily Life in Ancient Rome. appeared in 1956 as a Pelican. Still, this is a good series. mainly of literary criticism..
Penguin have also contributed substantially to the poetry and drama collections. Their new series of Modern Poets, arranged troika fashion. has started well, and they have brought out volumes of Yevtushenko and Rimbaud. Georgian Poetry, Latin Verse at.d Ch;2lese Verse; but their anthology The New Poetry is disappointing. Routledge are reissuing some of the Muses' Library in paperback; Evergreen Books offer an absorbing collection of Lyrics of thle Middle Ages, and Collier have The Spoonl River Anthology and Swift's Poems. There is a Selected Yeats (St. Martin's Library) and a Collected Betjeman (Murray). a fine bilingual edition of S-J. Perse's Seamarks (Harper). and Thom Gunn and Ted Hughes share a Faber volume.
Drama ranges from Henry Livings, Alun Owen and John Whiting (the latest Penguin New English Dramatists) to Leo Kirschbaum's scholarly edition of Marlowe (Meridian) and the 1603 Quarto of Hamlet (Barron). In between are Williams. Wilder, Sartre, Pirandello and various Irishmen, all in Penguin. Strindberg (Ancbor) and
Cocteau (Oxford). The admirable Methuen Modern Plays continue, Hill and Wang are reprinting some of the old Mermaid series, and Barron have a good list of Theatre Classics. Criticism includes Gordon Craig's Thle Art of thle Tlheatre (Mercury) and Ma7vin Herrick's valuable Tragicomedy (Unive7sity of Illinois).
There has been a remarkable number of books on Russia. including Hans Kohn's The Mind of Modern Russia (Harper), xerdyaev's The Russian Revolution (Ann Arbor), and such useful source-books as The New Communist Manifesto (Harper) a'nd Marx on Econiomics (Pelican). There is even more on American history and Politics; pride of place must again go to Hlarper, who are bringing out an edition of the definitive Morris and Commager series The New American Nation. They are also issuing some important works of American scholarship in the Langer series Thle Rise of Modern Europe. At home, Churchill's History of the Etnglish-Speaking Peoples (Cassell) and Toynbee's A Studv of History (Oxford) add their idiosyncratic solidity to the lists. and, among more specialized studies. Alan Bullock's Hitler (Penguin) stands out.
The symposia range widely. A notable collection is Twentieth Century Views (Spectrum), writers so far covered including Camus, Eliot, Whitman and Fielding. Writers at Work (Mercury), The Permanence of Yeats (Collier), A Century of Darwvin (Mercurv), Angola: Viewvs of a Revolt (Oxford) and Continuity and Chanige in African Cultures (Phoenix) indicate the range, and there are twvo massive and useful compilations in Readings in Modernt World Civilizaation (Macmillan, N.Y.) and European Political Institutions (Van Nostrand).
Scientists cont;nue to be well catered for, particularly by Dover. Cambridge and Paperrnacs. Dover include among the,r subjects Superfluids, Canonical Matrices, Continuous Groups of Transformations and vwnhat ought surely to be a children's book-Charles Babbage and his Calculating Engines. The interested layman is admirably served by Pelicans and such studies as Sherwood Taylor's Science Past and Present (Mercury). while Dover's reprint of the 1665 edition of Robert Hooke's Micrographia is an appealing curiosity.
Among the art books should be mentioned the Fontana Unesco Series (Collins) small, cheap, and very well Produced. Larger and dearer, but also good, are Thames and Hudson's Concise Histories of Art. by Gerrnain Bazin. and Modemr Painting. by Sir Herbert Read. Rothenstein s Modern English Painters occupies two Arrow volumes. and Hauser's Social History of Art four from Routledge.
Fiction, home and foreign, can no doubt speak for itself. Joyce Carey makes a welcome return to the lists of Pensnuin and
Angel with the Infant Jesus. (From the Ursulint Convent a. Landsberg am Lech, c. 1480.) From Max H. von Freeden's Gotihic Sculpture: IThe Intinmte Carvings. (33 full page plates. Oldbourne Press. 45s.). Photographs
by F. L. Kenett.
I 'our Square, and Lowrv's Under the Volcano is an outstanding addition to the Penguin Moder
Classics. But, except for Calderbooks and Evergreens, there is still a lack of adventurousness where new writing is concerned: something like Hutchinson's New Authors imprint would be very welcome in paperbacks. Of the Lawrences, T. E. seems to have taken over from D. H., and Ponguin have just issued a well-timed Se v en Pillars of Wisdom.
There have again becn some very good travel and adventure books, such as Norman Douglas's Old Calabria (Peregrine) and L. P. Kirwan's Polar Exploration (Penguin); while for those whose mind to them a kingdom is, Karen Horney's Self Analysis (Routledge) Tnrovides an indispensable preparation for the narcissistic rigours of Meet Yourself as You Really Are (Penguin) or Eysenck's formidable K n o w Your Osvn IQ (Pelican). Those who get tired of looking at themselves can feast their eyes on Brigitte Bardot and the Lolita Syndronte (F o u r Square): Simone de Beauvoir's prose is portentous and turgid, but the pictures are delightful.

Author: Null
Title: Comedy Competes With Poetry And Music
Full_text:
COMEDY COMeETES
POETRY AND MUSIC
To have called the programme presented by the Apollo Society at the Aldwych Theatre last night " a programme of poetry and music" and to have left it at that, seemed a little unfair of Mr. Christopher Hassall who devised it The programme contained an element of prose comedy. Since Dame Edith Evans contributed to this by allowing us to hear her in Pinero, Bridie and Sheridan, it is not surprising that the third element should have been extremely strong.
It. did not, however, blend well with the 'legitimate " elements of poetry and music. The latter might, if left to themselves, have yielded a more satisfactory total impression than the three together actually made.
Between Purcell played by Miss Viola Tunnard and by Mr. Martin Penny and
Ye Meaner Beauties of the Night " spoken by Mr. Hassall, and arain between Stravinsky's " Espanola " and Dame Edith's speaking of Mr. Osden Nash's "Guests " and of Sir Osbert Sitwell's "The General's Wife refuses "' there was rapport. there was sympathy. So also was there at the end when Mr. T. S. Eliofs "The Soul of Man ", spoken by Dame Edith, was answered by Bach's Choral Prelude.
But Dame Edith as the Duchess in The Gay Lord Quex, as Lady Pitts in Daphne Laureola4 or as Mrs. Malaprop was enough to mfake any musical commenlt on these characters seem supefluous. However welcome in themselves, they had. somnewhat the effect of being usurtpers in Apollo's temple.

Author: Null
Title: Sounding the Personal Note in Modern Poetry
Full_text:
Sounding the Personal Note
in Modern Poetry
Mr. Hugh MacDiarmid is a Scots poet who does not want-and will not get-the kind of praise that Scots give to their national poet on Burns nights.
Still to thee, 0 Burns,
The punctual stomach of thy people
turns,
he writes in one fierce early poem-
A boozy haze
Enchants your lays
And Gluttony for a change
Finds Genius within accosting range. Mr. MacDiarmid has been a battler all the forty-odd years of his poetic- lifebattling aginst the reign in Scotland of ignorance and complacency and English influence, battling for the larger life and for art and. as a means to those as he sees it, for comTnunism. Or, to be a little more Precise, since the word " communism " has lost nearly all meaning by now, for Lenin's vision of the world-and, even then, for that vision put in its proper place. Lenin is firmly the hero of some of his most forceful poems, but he is called in one, with a fine painful complexity, "barbarian saviour of civilization"; in another it is Rilke who is set by Lenin's side, the basis of Mr. MacDiarmid's comparison of them being that everything that either had to do with
moved intact,
Clean, clear and exact.
In brief. the Collected Poems reveal Mr. MacDiarmid as a writer of an intelligence, breadth and nobility far greater than has usually been attributed in England to the
says of the great poets: "They reflect time, I am the very ticking."
Dame Edith Sitwell. her collected Poems behind her, offers 10 new poems in The Outcasts. They have her familiar fine mesh of music in them, but in the thoughts they express only show the broad lines of noble generalizations about life. Mr. Edmund Blunden, in A Hong Kong House. makes a larger addition to his previous Poems of Many Years: his wellknown gift for gentle and delicate comment on unnoticed beauties of nature or spirit is as strong as ever.
A group of poets all round about their forties have brought out volumes at the same time and give a good impression of the prevailing tone on the more crowded roads of English poetry at the moment. It is surprising how much they have in common-they let casual incidents in their Life push them into some brief reflection. romantic or wry or both at once, without carrying the thought farther than necessary to make a passable poem; they worry, in poems about the value of poetry; if they break into deeper thought. as like as not the echoes of Yeats's sense of the conflict between imagination and morality sound strong in them still.
But each of these four manages to achieve some personal note within the dominating convention Mr. John HeathStubbs, in The Blue-Fly in lhis Head, never drops his dandy's manner as he weaves his classical parallels to modern trivialities, or lays down his wit as careful-casually as he would a pair of gloves on the table. Mr. Robert Conquest deals more gravely and intellectually with passing ideas and impressions, in his volume Be-
Indian village study by Rune Hassner from Phot/grapity Year Book, 1963 (207 illustrations. Photography Magazine
Ltd., 35s.), Edited by Norman Hall.
tween Mars and Venus. Mr. Alan Ross tends to restrict himself to pure pictures. mainly in Africcan Negatives. of South Africa an(i the Maghreb. which he paints very steadily, with an occasional liberal-minded thrust of thought or pang of sensual nostalgia. Mr. Dannie Aose. in Poems, Golders Green is the most amiabiv boYish and at the same time the most slap-dash of the four, grumbling that pcople both in Golders Green and in Soho find him odd when he sometimes wants to scream when he is with them, or wondering whoever it is who sits reading in the Public Library; and, in another section of the book, speaking about the anti - Semitism of recent history in poems whose obvious passion cannot fail to move but which are, it must be frankly said, not especially well-written.
An exciting book of a very different kind is Inmitations. a set of free versions of some great European poems Dy the American Robert Lowell. They would not be good *:ribs to the originals. but are done with an amazing vigour of language that still keeps the originals' tone: the Baudelaires shock, just as they must have shocked France a hundred years ago. the Paster-
rebarbative nationalist and red. Here. especially, from his carly voltimes, are some of the keenest-edged and most touching love-lyrics of the century, and here too are discursive pieces and broadsides that embody a massive attempt to consider the horrors and glories of European civilization as seen through Scottish eyes, and the kind of personal and artistic life that can be lived within it now. The manv poems written in Scots should not deter the reader --there is a good glossary. and those words that are not glossed quickly reveal their meaning as they recur from one poem to another. The effort is worth it: Mr. MNacDiarmid will clearly leave his mark on ts.
Mr. Rov Fuller's Collected Poemns are also a solid achievcment. but it takes the form of a thoroutgh testimony of disenchantement. Mr. Fuller's short verses are cleanly whittled artefacts, but over the years deal mainly with one abiding melancholy in different forms: a sense of the repeated ruin of the world's hopes. and of his own incapacity to do anything at all about it. His mood is caught in what he
naks have all the modest majesty of their aiuthor. A careful analytical account of Mr. Lowell's own poetry so far is given in Mr. Hugh B. Staples's Robert Lowrell : T/he First T:eenty Years.

Author: Null
Title: Violinist of Wistful Poetry
Full_text:
Violinist of
Wistful Poetry
If it is to attract a large audience, a concert on a hot Sunday evening in July must needs present a popular prograrnme. Last night's Festival Hall concert by the Philharmonia Orchestra under Mr. Alexander Gibson conformed to this notion by including the violin concertos of Brahms and Tchaikovsky; but it was not altogether oh popular lines, for it began with Beethoven's overture Leonora No. 2, which is far less frequently heard than the later sister work, and it also contained Mozart's rarely performed Symphony No. 32 in G. AlH in all, it was a well-planned programme.
Mr. Henryk Szeryng was the soioist in the concertos. If any doubt still lingered in our minds as to bis position amrong front-rank violinists, it was completely dispelled by last night's performance. True, Mr. Szeryng's tone is on the small side and this told perhaps most in the Brahms. But it is a tone rnost refined and of the utmost suppleness, brilliant of colour and, so far as its restricted strength will allow, capable of a warm, sensuous expression.
This he combines with a technique that is not only faultless but dazzling ip the effortless ease with which he surmounted the steep hurdles in thc Tchaikovsky. Indeed it was the latter work that revealed the full measure of Mr. Szeryng's virtuoso style, with runs, arpeggios, and ra,pid staccato passages being brought off with an incredible brilliance and verve. And into the lyrical portions (particularly the Canzonerta) he infused a sentiment of gentle, wistful poetry that was admirably suited to Tchaikovsky's me.lodic vein.
Equally impeccable in all technical respects was the Brahms, but here Mr. Szeryng seemed somewhat inhibitedat any rate the first two movements demanded a more immediate approach and greater emotional warmth than he was able to demonstrate. Nor did he pay enough attention to Brahms's giocoso marking in the finale, but it was played with much brio and rhythmic address. Mr. Gibson partnered his soloist most accurately and sympathetically, piloting his players with a sure hand through the perilous reefs and shoals of the concertos.
The account Mr. Gibson gave of the overture was neatand precise, if perhaps lacking strong dramatic accents, while the symphony received a stylish and well.shaped performance.

Author: Null
Title: Eugene Onegin Revival Lacking in Poetry
Full_text:
II>-
The Arts
I
Eugene Onegin Revival
Lacking in Poetry
The revival at Sadler's Wells last night of its 1952 production of Eugene Ozegin v. as a competent and workmanlike affair. But where was the charm, the sweetnzss and. above all. the melancholy poztry of Tchaikovsky's masterpiece'? It was certainly not a production to set the Thames on fire.
The opera stands and falls by the singers of Tatiana and Onegin, but last night Ava June, who sang the heroine, hardly entered into the true snirit of the part and gave a performance that was vocally rather wooden and angular; nor did her acting show the liveliness and charm required by th.s role. The famous ' Letter " aria passed off without making any deep impact.
Much compensation for our disappointment was afforded by Peter Glossop, who was every inch a virile
and very personal Onegin, bringing to the part a suggestively dark. wellmoulded and clear tone. This singer is evidently going from strength to strength.
W:lliam McAlpine sang Lensky with lyrical feeling and great flexibility of phrase, especially in his second-act monologue, but the volume of his voice seemed rather small on this occasion, while Maureen Guy made Olga still more significant than this role is. . Of the supporting cast, Harold Blackburn was a very acceptable Gremin, and Anna Pollak as Madame Larina and Olwen Price as the Nurse filled in the picture capably.
Wanvick Braithwajte held stage and pit well together, but the playing he secured from his orchestra frequently suffered from anaemia.

Author: Null
Title: Candour, Clarity and Compassion in Modern Verse
Full_text:
Candour, Clarity and Compassion
in Modern Verse
Three or four years ago there was much talk in the literary papers of the new " Movement " in English poetry-a fresh wave of poets all dedicated to candour and clarity and economy of language in their verse. Now three of the poets given pride of place in the group by the literary journalists have just published new collections. They give a vivid picture of where the " Movement" is moving.
Many readers must be familiar with Mr. Kingsley Amis's comic self-torturing selfappraisals-to be found in his witty verse as well as his novels. Mr. Thom Gunn is an Amis with the thumbscrews turned a dozen timos tighter. But, whereas MT. Amis laughs and runs away from his ghastly views of himself, Mr. Gunn stands and looks firm at his colder and harsher portraits. And in the gazing he reconciles himself. in his way, to their harshness Sheer existence, in fact, whatever its quality, can gratify Mr. Gunn-when it is clearly apprehended he feels in it an unfailing intensity. Various poems in MY Sad Captains present fearful but awed portraits of old lechers and young, and vivid moments of delighted insight into the almost empty wonder of teddy-boys' minds. looters', and snails'. A superb poem, " A Man of the City ", ends:
By the recurrent lights I see
Endless potentiality.
The crowded, broken, and unfinished I
I would not have the risk diminished. Yet he always, it would seem, sees what the risk is. This kind of candour. leaving one with the ice that burns in one's hands. is the finest and hardest of all, and these look like some of the most important poems to have been written since the end of the war.
MT. John Wain's candour is of a different kind. He is, perhaps, too worried ever to be a very good poet. Mr. Gunn has a liberal lucidity of vision: Mr. Wain, going farther in one way but nothing like so far in another, 'has a liberal concern. He is concerned, often movingly, with nuclear weapons, the state of poetry, America, murderers. and his own character. But his anxious language is often more rhetorical or sociological than poetic, even though the very neat stanzas he employed in the early days of the " Movement " have given way here to more varied sets of rhythms. Weep Before God stops at the halfway mark in the purposes of poetry: it shakes up and leaves one shaken up. But it does that Job very well.
Miss Elizabeth Jennings wrote some of the best English personal poems of the last decade, Donne-like but delicate. Her darting. searching mind is still at work in Song for a Birth or a Death, but so agitatedly now that she tells us, paradoxically, less than she used to. She aims at
being complex without, one feels, being really open. There are some rather impre&s&ive poems here about being in love with a man under vows, but it is impossible to tell if he is monk or priest, or simply a married man. This is not vulgar inquisitiveness-one has no personal curiosity about Miss Jennings, one simply wants to know properly what state of mind she is in fact writing about. Oddly, her manner of writing remains cool and collected in spite of th^ese disturbed questionings -one tinks of struggling cocooned victimns helplessly stirring a neat web.
To pass to names much longer familiar, Mr. Louis MacNeice offers us in Solstices a new collection of those diary-poems at which he is so good. For sheer ease, knowingness, and ready magic a little poem called "Nature Notes" beats all these three younger poets. But Mr. MacNeie, even in his poems about his fears, is relaxed and comfortable in a way none of the younger ones is.
The Selected Poems of the American poet Mr. Conrad Aiken take us back to the sp.rit of 40 years ago. These massive works of introspective symbolism, packed at the same time with Wordsworthian intuitions and Keatsian sensuousness, are a sort of hinterland to the poetry of Mr. T. S. Eliot and Mr. Ezra Pound. One may read them for their wonderful richness; in addition, with their manifold allegiances, they throw a light all round on European and English and American poetry of the twentieth century.
Other latter-day words: in New Poems 1960 Mr. Witter Bynner, an American now in his eighties, offers us some strangely disconcerting and touching Chinese-like images; in Later Poems Mr. Austin Clarke, writing from within the Roman Catholic cburch, brings together many years of pungent satire on obscurantism in Eire. and the Collected Poems of Mr. Ralph Hodgson, 90 this year, remind us of that true feeling of his for nature and romance already loved by readers in the pre-Eliot days.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry and Pace Achieved
Full_text:
Poetry and Pace
Achieved
Ford's Challenge
Well Met
Vasques (Mr. John Woodvine) and, right, the leader of the Banditti (Mr. Patrick Crean) watch as Putana (Miss Patience Collier) is taken into hiding during the
action of 'Tis Pity She's a Whore at the Mermaid Theatre last night.
Mermaid Tbeatre: 'Tis Pity She's a
Whore
Since the dramati-t's attitude to his own lurid material is still a matter for debate among scholars, Ford's seething amalgam of incest, violence, and protracted kllling is a challenge to directors. Mr. David Thompson justifiably stages it with the sensationalism of an X certificate film, yet keeps the steely narrative in sight througb all the hysteria. What is more, there are passages in which the poetry comes through to impose its controlling shape. Mr. John Carruthers's set, on two levels of restrained strapwork outline, and his costumes, richly manageable, allow for a fast pace.
The play can be taken as a cynical distortion of Romeo and Jlliet, its lovers now brother and sister, the nurse a courtesan. At the Mermaid, Miss Patience Collier's amoral servant suits the pattern exactly. So does Miss Zena Walker's Annabella, whose capitulation is as convincing as the sly, knowing flirtatiousness which follows it almost at once. The initial surrender carries an authority which saves her from becoming despicable, even when she flutters her eyelashes at Soranzo, the suitor chosen as dupe to conceal her crnme. This, we are given to understand, would in normal circumstances have been her choice. For a moment or two, she senses it, before destiny moves her on.
Meanwhile, subsidiary characters realisticaDly die from sword and poison, no symptom spared. It is to foreshadow the final butchery to which the incest and the vengeance for it will lead. Miss Barbara Barnett, an uninhibited plotter alternating between fury and intrigue, gives the most chilling of these warnings. After her death scene last night the silence was complete. The action continues in another key and is ready for a tragic dimension not quite achieved.
By this time the lovers and Soranzo, insolently played by Mr. David Sumner, should be isolated in a balance of conflict until Ford's intention to discredit Soranzo takes effecL If the lovers fail here to unite in a tragic defiance, the fault lies in Mr. Edward de Souza's Giovanni, who lacks the personality to be an adequate partner in crime of Miss Walker. A troubled gravity, casualty fluent and rhetorical where the verse demands a slow, terrible drumbeat, makes Giovanni seem more like the victim of a brawl than the anti-hero who has willed his own destruction. Mr. de Souza acquits himself well in the last of several athletic fights but his director unkindly leaves Giovanni's corpse too far downstage for any actor to conceal his breathing.
In compensation for this weakening of the crisis, the production offers new insight into Vasques, the servant who appoints himself a tutor of revenge. Mr. John Woodvine asserts himself from the outset as a surly ruffian in command of every situation, and his brief talk with Miss Collier is seen to be the action's decisive twist. lago achieved little more.

Author: Null
Title: A Duty To Perform
Full_text:
A DUTY TO PERFORM
PLEASURE IN READING
By G. S. Fraser
I am a lecturer in English literature in a provincial university and used to be a professional reviewer of new books, especially books of poetry and about poetry. It is very hard for me to know when I am reading for pleasure and when reading is work. I treat all books in a sinisterly professional way.
Even when I intend to read a novel merely for pleasure I find myself looking at the first sentence, and then at the last sentence. I read about twelve pages in the middle, to get the general tone and texture, and then leaf back and forwards to fill in the gaps. This is the quickest and most efficient way of arriving at a rough general estimate of the book's merits. If the estimate is really favourable I read it again, from beginning to end, at a much more leisurely pace. Similarly with a new volume of poems or critical essays I skim over the pages or the Paragraphs with a lacklustre eye until I come upon some piece of prose or verse on which I really bark my shins; then I start reading, backwards and forwards from that centre, slowly and appreciatively.
But even when I am reading in this more ruminative way, am I really reading for pleasure? If I have a pen or pencil handy, I cannot stop myself from sidelining cogent paragraphs or underlining striking lines of verse. I put a lively volume of criticism down on a table, and walk up and down my work-room, arguing with it. Struck with a new poem, what I am first noticing is rhythm, cadence, turn of phrase; I murmur lines and phrases aloud to myself, and if somebody looks over my shoulder and asks, ".What is this poem about ?1" I have to shake myself awake, and skim over the poem with a cold prose eye, before I can give a cogent answer.
In all the reading of a professional reader like myself there is, of course, a special egotistic pleasure, the pleasure of exercising a skill. One comes to know certain poems, certain passages of prose, as a conductor knows a score, and one does not so much read them as perform them to oneself. Or one expounds them to others. Scholars who have worked very hard for years on the sources and symbols of very difficult poets, like Blake and Yeats, have told me that after a certain stage any natural and spontaneous delight in the obvious, surface splendour of the work of these poets left thern ; they felt that they could never look at a poem by Blake or Yeats again, merely to enjoy it. I am no scholar. But it is true that going over a difficult poem by Donne or Hopkins, say, with an intelligent student is much less like pointing out to a companion the glories of a sunset than like teaching a clever child how to take to bits and put together again a mechanical toy. The life, the flesh-and-blood glow, has to be taken for
granted; what lends itself to exposition is syntax, logic, argument, the articulation of a skeleton. The great Lord Hartington, not a literary man, in his later years casually picked up, one day, a copy of Paradise Lost, and slowly read a page or two: " How fine that is ", he said, " I had forgotten how fine it was ! " The tutor or lecturer may occasionally murnur, " How fine that is ! " to remind his class that he is a human being. But that is not what he is paid for doing. And similarly the first-year student of English literature who wants to express his excitement about poetry in the manner, say, of Lamb or Pater will soon get his knuckles rapped. What we want from him is the rigour of the game, eye on the object, argument, point, relevance.
The pleasure of reading for a teacher or critic of literature is, in essence, a professional pleasure. He is never really away from the shop. But I have some tastes in reading which are eccentric, whimsical, and perhaps childish. The books that I read most nearly purely for pleasure are, I suppose, the books that I read in bed for half an hour before going to sleep. For years my favourite bedside book was a cheap two-volume edition of Lord Morley's Life of Gladstone. This is not a biographical masterpiece; somebody has said that of the three chief passions of Gladstone's life, religion, finance, and Ireland, Morley properly understood only the third; and his style has been described as looking like marble from a distance but, closer, like blancmange. At the period, however, of the Suez crisis and of Hungary I found something inexpressibly soothing in diving, as one dives under the blankets, into the solid comfort and sedateness of the Victorian age, into Gladstone's voluminous rhetoric and agile and troubled conscience as these fastened themselves on problems which, serious enough in their time, seem to us now happily anchored in a secure age.
I have read again and again, also, before going to sleep a chapter or two of that very lively but certainly not profound or subtle or consistently characterized Irish comic romance, Charles Lever's Harry Lorrequer. Another Irish book I like is an old volume, in small print, of Curran's speeches, their rhetoric an inextricable compound of the tawdry and the sublime; and yet another, by an author as funny and brutal as Smollett but not so coarse, is Sir John Barrington's memoirs. But the professional reader, even when half asleep, is still sleepily on duty; Curran and Barrington have helped me to understand Yeats; Morley, for that matter, gives me a grand, dense feeling of the world in which Tennyson and Arnold moved. The professional reader is nevei not on duty; but he is never, if he is a good professional, without pleasure either.

Author: West, Rebecca
Title: Round Trip
Full_text:
ROUND TRIP
PLEASURE IN READING
By Rebecca West
Sometimes one's reading, when it strays from the course determined by one's current work, describes a circle. If the book is important enough to send one out on the tour of questioning among other books it is often able to answer the questions they ask in their turn. I have just come back after some weeks of such travelling to the pleasant places where I began.
In Thie Oipltic Voice, a study of the relationship between poetry and science by the English scholar Elizabeth Sewell, I have been fascinated by the exposition of what the poets and philosophers of our culture felt that the ancient world -was telling them about themselves when it invented the myth of Orpheus. That sent me back to Tue Metamorphoses, for none of them quoted a speech there ascribed to Orpheus which has always struck me as marvellous even for that marvellous work.
When Orpheus goes down into the underworld and begs Pluto and Persephone to give him back his bride Eurydice, he says: " I have tried to bear her loss, and I will not deny that I have really made an effort to get over it. But Love defeated that." Then the verse becomes hesitant, as if he doubts whether anything real to men kept its reality in this place of shadows. "Love ", he explains "is a god whom we human beings know very well. But I am not sure if you know him here. But I rather think ", he goes on, " you must. After all, if there is any truth in that old story of an abduction-" and suddenly his hesitancy leaves him. He comforts the gods with a firm statement to the gods: Vos quoquie iunxit Amnor. Love joined you also.
Orpheus shows himself both modest and proud. He assumes that the gods do not share all human emotions, because they are superior beings. But he claims an absolute value for love, which must be conceded by gods and men alike, who by that concession achieve a splendid equality.
I went on reading Ovid for some time, but presently I found myself haunted by the suspicion that somewhere in our literature another great man had shown a mortal addressing much the same sort of inquiry to an immortal, with less happy results. And I was right. It occurs in the eighth book of Paradise Lost, where the angel Raphael is coming to the end of a visit so lengthy that it began in the fifth book ; and the conversation, which started magnificently with an exposition of the celestial wars, has turned to general matters and has deteriorated.
Adam asks some quite intelligent questions about astronomy and Raphael discourages the scientific spirit (" Think only what concerns thee and thy being ") with a severity unimpressive because he is evidently not sure of the answers. (" But whether these things be, or whether not. . . . ") Next Adam seeks advice regarding the relationship between the sexes, and when Raphael replies, in a style which unfortunately recalls the style of Polonius, he seems much more sure of his ground than when he was talking about astronomy.
Perhaps for that reason, Adam then inquires:
Bear with me then, if lawful what I ask; Love not the heavenly spirits, and how
their Love Express they, by looks only, or do they
mix Irradiance, vir.ual or immediate touch? It is in essence the same question that Orpheus asked Pluto and Persephone,
but surely he asks it with better spiritual manners, and Raphael's reply sets Adam no good example.
To whom the Angel with a smile that
glow'd Celestial, rosy red, Love's proper hue, Answer'd, Let it suffice thee that thou
know'st Us happy, and without Love no
happiness, Whatever pure thou in the body
enjoy'st (And pure thou wort created) we enjoy In eminence . . .
But after a more refined fashion. It is strange that Ovid makes Orpheus speak as a Christian might who knelt before an altar to pray that a purely human affection might be preserved, while Milton makes Adam and his angelic visitant converse with a materialism much more comprehensible in a pagan world where religion and folk-lore were inextricably entangled.
Well, the great sometimes fall below their greatness; and I turned to a book which robs that reflection of any melancholy, Claudel's AMemoires Imnprovises, perhaps the silliest work any man of talent has ever produced, but not unlikable. My favourite passage is his denunciation of the contemporary American woman for her coldness and luxury, from which he kindly exempts the wives of the trappers who so bravely accompany their husbands on their journeys into the interior. But I had forgotten his shocking remark that the first two hundred pages of Dostoevsky's The Idiot is a masterpiece of composition which recalls the masterpieces of Beethoven. Not just one; all of them.
Though authors tend to write gassily about music, musicians often make good hard-headed authors. 1 turned to one of them at this moment, to that fiery and isolated spirit, Mr. Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji, the gifted composer and pianist and critic; for he contributed to the volume issued as a memorial to the great Russian Medtner a turbulent essay containing a number of good things including a denunciation of " difficult music " in which it is possible for a performer to make a mistake " without anyone being a penmy the wiser ". Medtner's music, he points out, was extremely elaborate, but if at any performance there had been a blunder, it would have been recognized at once by every instructed listener, as an interference with the composer's design. In fact, intricacy is not the same as difficulty. If the governing intention and the craftmanship be strong enough, elaboration comes as smoothly to the mind as simplicity.
At that back I went to Miss Sewell, who prints at the end of her book 13 " working poems" which she wrote at the same time. They are intricate and crystalline. Back I went to Paradise Lost, al! but the passages when Raphael stayed too long. Back I went to The Metamorphoses, which I opened this time at the page where Iris is arousing Somnus as he lies among the stored dreams of mankind. The idea of the awakening of the god of sleep from his sleep has its complications. Ovid deals with them in four words: Excussit tandem sibi se. He shook himself free of himself. I have been reading Milton and Ovid every night since then, now one and now the other. Very pleasant it is, but I get less and less sure (in spite of their reputations) which is the Christian and which the pagan.

Author: FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
Title: Poetry In The Theatre: An Innovation By Barrault
Full_text:
POETRY IN THE THEATRE: AN
INNOVATION BY BARRAULT
FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
PARIS, APRIL 10
It is only since he was appointed director of the Od6on-Theatre de France that M. Jean-Louis Barrault has been able to demonstrate in practical terms his ideas concerning the role of the theatre in modern life. M. Barrault believes that the theatre should be used as a centre for all the arts, and within the past two years he has organized exhibitions of paintings, lectures. concerts. and pantomime programmes at the Odeon.
Guerre el Poesie, the latest addition to his repertory, is a monza.ge of poems with music and film projections, and can therefore be considered as the logical extension of his theories into the domain of poetry. It is not, of course. the first time that M. Barrault has presented a programme of verse. His series of extracts from the works of Shakespeare. Sartre. and Claudel linked by a text and commentar:es have met with some success botb in France and abroad. But Gu,erre el Pofsie. which has been devised by M. Henri Pichette, is considerablY more than the spectacle poOiquegenerally characterized by a complete lack of theatrical impact-tfiat is commonly mounted in France.
M. Pichette's programme is intended to be the first of a series devoted to various universal themes; the series will continue in the autumn with a programme entitled Amoureuse Poesie. He has assembled in the present one an anthology of epic, lyrical and satirical verse, with a few prose extracts for good measure, on the theme of war, and he has built up a coherent programme which becomes almost a poetic drama by the judicious use of music, lighting changes, and film and still projections. A simple abstract decor based on geometrical forms by M. James Pichette is used as the setting, and the poems are presented without introduction by actors in their ordinary dress.
It is a far cry from the romantic views of the medieval warrior poet to the reasoned horror of the contemporary pacifist, yet M. Pichet:e's cunning use of photography and the frequent insertion of songs and music seemed to make this transition smooth and somehow inevitable. An unusual aspect of the programme, which no doubt played its part in the general cohesion, was the omission of any reference to the authors except in the programme, where they are listed in chronological order from the thirteenth-century Bertran de Born to those still living.

Author: Null
Title: Laughter Without Poetry
Full_text:
LAUGHTER WlTHOUT
POETRY
A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S
DREAM
Mr. Michael Langham's productidn of A Midsummer Night's Dream, wvhich was received with vociferous applause at the Old Vic last night, has a good deal to recommend it. Mr. Langhamn has approached the play with a comic inventiveness that is really fresh although, at times, he seems inclined to show his author how funny the play can be if a gifted producer is given a free hand.
Some of Mr. Langham's inventions are only gimmicks-the play opens with a hymeneal chant and pseudo-dervish dance before the entry of a manacled Hippolyta -but the imbroglio of the four lovers is freshly and cleverly handled. One cannot help thinking of the production in terms of its producer than its actors.
Though. in one sense, the funnier the play is the better is the effect it makes, funniness is not its total content. Mr. Langham sees it as an essentially realist play in which imaginative lyrical bubbles are burst and an unlyrical truth manifested. Mr. Campbell, when Bottom is translated, has a splendid braying guffaw, and this is released to salute the end of Titania's numarks about the flowers V'lamenting an enforced chastity ".
Mr. Humphry's Theseus is abruptly businesslike with his poetry, and the lovers are encouraged to eloquence only whilst they are spell-bound. Even Oberon seems to think of the bank "where on the wild thyme grows" in terms of a comfortable hotel near Charing Cross, and only allows us to feel the delight of his poetry when assuring Puck that they are spirits of another sort. Mr. McCowen moves splendidly and looks like a supernatural royalty, but he seems to be unconscious of the ecstasy that is his essence.
This ecstasy, which never denies laughter. should touch everyone in the play before the curtain falls; we noticed it in Miss Leigh-Hunt's realization of victory, Demetrius being hers, and in Bottom's awakenlng: elsewhere, it was missing. Mr. Courtenay's masculine, mischievous Puck is pleasant, Miss Dench is volatile and attractive; Mr. Stride and Mr. Meacham are equally lively. The mechanicals have an odd assortment of accents.

Author: Cloyne, George
Title: Dead Beat
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
DEAD BEAT
By George Cloyne
I have been sent an anthology. This, I should add, is not a rare occurrence. I am sent anthologies of Imagist Poetry, of Apocalyptic Poetry, of poetry ranging from Dada to the Movement. This time it is The New American Poetry, 19451960. And I have read it.
When I say " read ", I speak a little less than the truth. For a certain proportion of the book is not strictly readable. The writers who contribute to it -and they include those of the Beat Generation, of the San Francisco Renaissance, the Black Mountain Group, and the New York Poets-are not particularly well-known in this country, with the exception of Mr. Jack Kerouac, Mr. Allen Ginsberg, and Mr. Lawrence Ferlinghetti. They have this in common: that their poems are commonly written for recitation rather than reading. Boomed out to a jazz accompaniment, they might seem better than on the cold page. A listener could at least take refuge in the jazz. But what interests me is that the volume contains a set of "Statements on Poetics ". It ought, therefore, to be possible to discover exactly what this new poetry is trying to do.
Ever since Mr. Eliot made the critics appear ridiculous more than 40 years ago by edging his way, like a rockclimber, towards the summit, without being noticed by observers in the plain, very few commentators have shown much courage when it came to assessing new kinds of literature. They have been afraid of the unfamiliar, afraid of the young, afraid of their own impercipience. Thumbing my way, in gingerly progress, through poems which mark the mind no more profoundly than a fly marks the window-pane (and often in much the same fashion), I have decided to accept the role of fogy which is thrust upon me. Longing to respond, longing to feel at home in a world of bearded bards in boxcars travelling widdershins through the subconscious, I have been studying in particular the pronouncemerits of Mr. Charles Olson, who seems to be the theoretician of what he calls Projective Verse. "Form ", I learn, "is never more than an extension of content." Every poem has to find its own appropriate energy, it has to move fast from one perception to another. It may seem, therefore, that Mr, Olson has been reading the preface to Lyrical Ballads, a supposition made the more probable by the fact that his further rules are paraphrased from Coleridge into an awkward version of Basic
Jargon. But the point he is making is only related to what used to be called free verse when Laforgue wrote it, and later turned, with surrealist help, into the poetry of free association. It can be witty and charming-there are poems of both kinds in this anthology; it can even (as in Mr. Ginsberg's celebrated " Howl ") generate a certain animal grandeur. What it cannot do is to achieve its aim, to oreate a permaneni and immediate poetry. For the poet reduces himself to an intermediate status somewhere between a vocal chord and an Aeolian harp. By "getting rid of the lyrical interference of the individual as ego" (the phrase is Mr. Olson's), the poet is likely to get rid of his poetry as well. At the best, he scales down his poem to a miniature, even though its verbiage drags over several pages.
What we have reached, then, is a regression to the cult of the " amusing ". This lethal word has been applied, during the past 30 years, to one art after another. From ballet to interior decoration, from the Parisian music of 1920 to objets 1routves, clever people in search of high fashion have turned amusing. Often they conceal their purpose under a plausible disguise: fashion, after all, is at its most "amusing" when it is deeply serious. But what they produce bears the same relation to the central themes of each art as the hobble-skirt or M. Darius Milhaud's choice of a seedsman's catalogue as libretto for a choral work.
It is easy to be amused, in this sense. by the new American poetry-which, incidentally, leaves out of account most American poetry that is new in the true sense of the word. But it will be a sad thing if the greater part of what may loosely be called Beat poetry is taken for anything other than what it is: a brittle echo from the Boulevards of many years ago. It avoids the bloodless decorum which inhibits much of our own new poetry. It calls a spade some very curious names indeed, and perhaps imparts a momentary thrill to the innocent thereby. But the total result on the reader is an emotion which is less Beat than dead tired. The effective reaction against formal sweetness in poetry took place nearly half a century ago, and no fresh show of indignation can disguise that fact. What poetry needs today, on both sides of the Atlantic, is less preoccupation with form as an extension of content, and greater preoccupation with memorable form as a clothing for memorable content.

Author: FROM OUR MUSIC CRITIC
Title: If Music and Sweet Poetry Agree...
Full_text:
The Arts
If Music and Sweet Poetry
Agree . . .
FROM OUR MUSIC CRITIC
That art is one, that all the arts are the same kind of phenomenon, is axiomatic with artists, philosophers and plain men. A Society of Aesthetics'has recently been formed in London to focus discussion on the special character of what used to be known as the Sublime and Beautiful. An international conference is sbortly to be held in Athens to pursue further such fundamental questions as whether art needs be beautiful and whether natural beauty is the same sort of thing as the beautiful in art. Sir Herbert Read touched on a few Of such topics in an inaugural address L.iven to the British Society of Aesthetics early this month and allowed that some tnodern art was not beautifil but' was -what ? vital ? true ? significant ? Philosophers have debated such questions from Plato onwards but have tended to regard them as secondary to logic and ethics, though Aristotle, excellent fellow, wrote a Poetics as well as an Ethics and a Politics. With English philosophy in its present state of abniegation of systems aesthetics has as a matter of fact come in for a good deal more attention than heretofore-otherwise surely no one would have thought of founding a society to focus it
NO SUCH THING AS ART
At one fairly recent symposium devoted to the philosophy of art at Downside a speaker from Oxford came out bluntly with the view that art was not one, that there was no such thing as Art but only arts. Shocking as such a -view is, one begins to flirt with it at the practical level. Try to organize a festival of the arts and you can have a gorgeous time putting in all the things you like best and inviting the world to join you in'enjoying them. Realizing that the unity of your festival is only the unity of your individual taste without any sort of universal validity you decide to concentrate on a period and so achieve unity of time. But then you find the arts do not move in parallel: music is centuries out with painting and literary developments correspond with neither, though Curt Sachs wrote an unconvincing book to show that the Zeitgeist controls them all, and modernism at the moment shows a geater degree of similarity than usual in that all the arts tend to unintelligibility, i.e.. to be based on an aesthetic of construction rather than of communication. And supposing you got your arts lined up by unity of time and spirit they would jump apart according to divisions of language and nationality.
Yet at the practical level promoters of festivals are arranging their programmes to cover wider and wider fields of artistic experience. King's Lynn, though a small festival, has an enormous spread: ballet and jazz rub shoulders with song recitals and chamber music; the sense of hearing is complemented by the sense of taste, though wine and cheese do not add up to fine art; drama is in attendance with painting and the visitor can ask himself at the end of a week whether he thinks his varied experiences have been fundamentally the same in kind. He may say yes to that but still be in doubt about the comtnon element, unless it be the exercise of sensibiliRy.
The question is posed more acutely still by the activities of the Apollo Society. Someone had a good idea that on the analogy of the song recital poetry could be declaimed, and as songs and piano solos have been partners for a century and a half,
the piano should bo invited to break up too long stretches of the spoken word. Surely it would be easy to intersperse congruent morceaux among lyric poems, ballades perhaps among ballads and, improbably, a few curiosities of piano literature among parodies. Mr. John Betieman had dug out a wonderful old Victorian galop, " Oui vive " for piano duet, which was played on Tuesday in a programme of poetry and music that gave great pleasure but absolutely defied aesthetic justification-its unity, we all suspected, was simply Mr. BetIernan's highly idiosyncratic taste. This echo from a hundred hunt-balls was funny in itself-after all the Victorians were fullblooded and high spirited people and they would dance to it with wild hilarity; it was funny as a period piece; and it was musically ludicrous, so that it set the mood for a group of parodies. But no more at this recital than at other meetings of the Apollo Society was it apparent on what principles, if any, piano music can be chosen to match lyric poems.
Music and poetry can come to terms in song, for, with some surrender of sovereignty by both arts, a new work of art combining the expressive powers of both can be created, the poem having to do the conceptual part of the business, the music the evocative, but each serving the other, the poem as starting Point, the music as ultimate issue. But Schumann's piano pieces will not really go with English Poems, even if the moods and the dates are the same, for they are too Gennan and too lushly romantic; nor will Debussy who is too French-or would he pair off with Dante Gabriel Rosetti ?
ENJOYABLE VARIETY
What in fact makes such mixed recitals and such festivals enjoyable is their variety. The festivals have something for everybody. If, as in a place like Bath, the eighteenth century stares you in the face, you can make your programme congruous therewith and so provide an extra shock of pleasure at the recognition of the congruity-it was so with Handel at Hollkham Hall the other afternoon. But the Apollo Society's recitals always leave behind among their pleasure a disturbing feeling that there is something a bit wrong with the mixture. It is not that more music is required: not at all, music is a good servant-witness its service to the church, the theatre and the dance-hall-and is quite ready to take second place and provide relief. The problem is congruitywhat will go with what ? Let the process of trial and error go on by all means, but let the aestheticians turn their attention to it and see if they can discover underlying Principles of choice in mixing the arts. Here is something for the agenda of the Athens conference.

Author: Cloyne, George
Title: The Poet's Task
Full_text:
THE POET'S TASK
TALKING OF BOOKS
By George Cloyne
Mr. Donald Hall, in a recent nuum ber of Tile New York Times Book Review, has some salutary things to say about the state of poetry in England today. His main contention amounts to this: that "the best poetry of the modern world has involved sophistication, cosmopolitanism, and deliberate ambition ". He then sadly comments that " the best young writers of England have resigned from this nmodern world ". This is because they have, in his view, taken refuge in regionalism, in the kind of committed attitude wihich sets a hatred of social pretence above considerations of technique and devotion, and because they cultivate a domestic modesty (hostile to any but minor poetry.
It was time for this to be said. Mr. Hall is not merely dismissive. He concedes our part of natural honesty, a taste for critical argurment, and the gift of observation. But these are attributes which lead towards some deolicate object carved out of a walnut-shell, rather than to the permanence of granite. It remains that the imagination today is curiously hostile to any manifestation which enlarges its scope. It prefers to dance, like an angel, on the point of a pin.
Not only so, but it resents the spirit of enterprise in others. I suppose that when the course of poetry in the last generation is finally mapped and indexed, the names most -likely to recur are these of Mr. Pound and Mr. Eliot, flaanked by such contempoararies as Dame Edith Sitwell, and followed by the decade of Mr. Auden and Mr. Spender. A little later comes Dylan Thomas, and after that a lullX in which talents appear, flicker like marsh-lights, and one by one turn to other avocations.
This is an unfair judgmen,t-just as Mr. Hall's dismissal of the Georgian poets is unfair. There are excellent poets now writing-Mr. George Barker is an obvious examnple in one generation, and Mr. Ted Hughes in another-who a-re by no means to be dismissed as vwill-ofthe-wisps. But fame writes her poge with an uncertain finger. This writer or that is accepted as the leader of a period, while to a third a label is pinned which has no connexion with his intention.
The sum of the matter is that critical standards alter every 20 years or so, -with the effect that most of the elder writers Whom Ihave named are set, by general opinion. in a sunset glow. They may be acclaimed or reviled, but I am not sure they are much read. And this, not because they are out of touch with the main-stream of poetry, not because they are difficult, but because they are all vaulting poets with some inaccessible target before their eyes, whereas the younger writers who have made a name for themselves sinee 1939 are generally scornful of targets, unless they are solely political or social.
If whrat remains is a very buttoned-up sort of poetry the fault is partly with readers rather than writers. For some years now it has been an axiom that readers are very easily tired. Having grappled with the complexities of Ulysses and The Waste Land they are (or so the argument runs) exhausted. All they ask is a slow return to the mellifluous evocations or stanzas of the nineteenth century. Indeed, Mr. Hall's point of departure is a young woman in Essex, Who, when she learnt that he was a poet, had nothing better to say than " Uh .. . what sort ? The straightforward kind ? "
We are always being told that poetry has at last become simÂ¶ple once more, as though simplicity were automatically a virtue. But the truth is that readers are more discriminating than they are supposed to be. It is not simplicity they look for but merit. The only readers who restrict their pleasure to simple poetry are those who have no genuine interest in the subject at all. They are like visitors to France who cannot be bothered with a suce, and com,plain because they do not get their tea. They may respect habit, but they are not concerned with principles.
The world, nevertheless, is Xull of readers who care intensely about poetry. They seek in it not an opiate but a stimulus. It nmight be thought, therefore, that the poets would answer better to their vast new audience; that they would feel a burden of responsibility in the fact that poetry has stretched its frontiers to include anybody capable of thought and feeling. Somehow. however, they have lagged behind. If they are conscious of a political commitment they are likely to put it in the forefront of their verse. If they have no commitment they will take refuge in charm, or wit, or erudition. That is why I am glad Mr. Hall has spoken his mind. For neither charm. nor wit, nor erudition suffices without the extra gift of having something to say.
The poverty of communication in poetry seems to go in direct ratio to the amount of it available. When, as in the age of Dryden, any civilized gentleman might also be a poet, there was a completo identificatioa of the poet with the Zeitgeist. He wrote what his period required of him, and in the necessary manner. Nowadays, poets are obsessed by their own independence. Now, the poet first assumes a bardic mantle and then wears it like a beaoh-towel. I am sure Mr. Donald Hall is right in condemning the mediocre notion of the function of poetry entertained by some of our good younger poets. Only when they link their verse to the core, rather than the surface, of contemporary life wil their readers turn to them for the authority which they have inherited from Coleridge and Matthew Arnold.

Author: Cloyne, George
Title: Who's Who?
Full_text:
ITALKING OF BOOKS
WHO'S WHO?
By George Cloyne
At the turn of the year poetry reaches a wider public than at any other time, if only because we are more conscious then of the legacy from which much of our lyric poetry springs: the carols whose simplicity enfolds some of the most magical stanzas in English. Christrmas, far more than the other ecclesiastical seasons of the year, is intimnately associated with poetry, and an extremely intelligent book of essays by an Australian poet, Mr. James McAuley, may e:~plain why.
The book is called The E id of Modernity,and its contention is that something has gone badly wrong with the arts since they lost their spontaneous and easy contact with metaphysicssince they became almost as a matter of course self-regarding. Mr. McAuley's argument is exemplified in many contexts, but one in particular has held 'ry attention: he notices that under strong inspiration the mind tends to " lay hold on the ancient symbols by which men once understood who thzey are." This, he suggests, leads to a tug of war between the fashionable attitude of the moment and the spontaneous tendencies of the heart; and he concludes that from this struggle comes much of the obscurity which has made modem readers fight shy of poetry.
I have been trying to assess the value of this in the field where it is most clearly applicable: that of religious poetry. It is noticeable that, of early poems, such as " Quia amore langueo " or " Of a rose, a lovely rose," nearly aU are anonymous. These exquisite lines speak with the voice of the whole human race: they are as universal to the society which made them as the paintings in a Book of Hours or the stone ribs of a cathedral. There is no reason why any single artificer should claim them for his own, and yet to show the extraordinary variety which can be put into this disembodied verse no more is needed than a glance through the opening pages of Dame Edith Sitwell's recent Atlantic Book of British and Amnerican Poetry.
The change came slowly, as religious poetry moved away from a Virgilian innocence towards the personal dilemmas of the Reformation. No doubt it is easy to exaggerate that innocence. Just as Florentine art preserves the balance and the colour of the Renaissance so beautifully that we forget the violence and the tyrannies of that cruellest of cities, so what remains to us of the Middle Ages is all peace, all order (unless it is aU anathema); we do not look far below
the surface. But by the end of the skiteenth century a startling change had occurred in religious poetry. With the greatest of all our religious poets, Donne, we find ourselves suddenly hand in hand. His moments of vision and of torment might flash up from the world of to-day, but for one thing: in Mr. McAuley's phrase, "he understood who he was" -an understanding shared by Herrick and George Herbert, by Vaughan, Traherne, and Milton.
After the coming of the eighteenth century, to understand who one wasin the McAuley sense of keeping a proportion between man and infinitybecame very much more difficult. It was soon involved, if not with madness outright, at least with paranoia. Neither of Blake nor Smart, not even of Coleridge, could it be said that they were at ase within the framework of their intellect. The innocence of the Middle Ages had gone for ever, and the shifting certainties of Progress had not yet taken their place. Where the old religious poetry had been serene, or, later, activist in an attempt to regain serenity, the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries treated their religion as moths treat the lamp: wings fluttered against the burning possibility of a certainty until they scorched in the flame.
And since then religious poetry has never been at ease. Either it is doggedly pietistic, or rhapsodical after a fitful fashion, or tied up in the knots of a hard-won technique. Even those who have transcended these limitationsHopkins, say, or Dame Edith herself -have been 'unable to move with equal tact among religious and secular themes. The simplicity which marks the very best religious poetry has been obscured by an obnubilation of sheer skill. Indeed, of all living religious poets I can only think of Dame Edith who offers her subject the supreme courtesy of not changing her tone when she turns from purely secular poetry to the mood of " Still Fals the Rain."
We are a long way by now from the early carols, and so conscious of our own striving egos that we can never expect to touch utter natural simplicity again. A story is told of Lord Berners, to whom a woman friend of some social consequence was complaining that she had had difficulty in getting a table in a nightclub. " But of course," she said, " when I told them who I was it was all right." "And who were you?" asked Lord Berners. It is a question of general applicability.

Author: Null
Title: Masefield's New Epic: The Story of Ossian
Full_text:
Masefield's New Epic: The
Story of Ossian
At the age of 81 Dr. John Masefield, the Poet Laureate. has made a revolutionary gesture in the cause of spoken poetry by presenting a new large-scale work to the public in the form of a gramophone record.
"The Story of Ossian," an epic poem based on the body of Irish legend surrounding Finn MacCoul and his son Ossian, has been recorded by the author under the auspices of the Academy of American Poets and is released in this country by Argo (RG 178, price Â£1 19s. 9d.). The work lasts over an hour, and it is doubtful whether any other living English poet (with the possible exception of Mr. Andrew Young) could have renounced print on such a heroic scale. The long poem is not a favourite exercise of modem poets, and those who do attempt it tend to avoid putting their stamina to the test of continuous narrative. It is precisely Dr. Masefield's mastery of clear-cut energetic narrative that enables him to command unbroken aural attention.
SYMPHONIC AFFINITIES
The poem is in three parts: it begins and ends as a boldly delivered tale, framing a central passage of unearthly lyricism. This spacious design has obvious symphonic affinities. and the vigorous realism of the first section is organically related to the rarefied atmosphere of the second. The legends on which the poem is based, besides giving the poet an opPOrtUnity to exercise his gfts as a stor-teller and to re-invoke the romantic landscape that recurs constantly in his past writings, also furnish a hero whom the author can use as his own spokesman.
Finn, an old warrior-king, has set his heart on marrying the daughter of Cormac, a neighbouring chieftain. He dispatches his two sons to woo for him: on tbe way they are met by Niamh. a radiant creature who warns them that the marriage may end in disaster. but promises Ossian that if it does he will escape with her from the earth. The marriage does lead to internecine carnage, and Finn's supporters at the end of their tether are met again by Niamb who places Ossian on horseback and leads him up to the sky. There he lives in a state of timeless ecstasy passing through cities " built in beauty's praise by deathless beings:' and contemplating all the variety of nature.
Then he returns to earth and finds that he has been away three centuries, and that he has become "an old, bent, broken thing . . . a worn-out coin, too battered to be spent." The Poignancy of this return is softened at the end when Niamh, too, comes back to earth to release him from his body.
VAGUE ROMANTIC VALUES
This account, though it conveys nothing of the poem's expressive qualities, does emphasize its main flaw-the vagueness of its romantic values. Ossian's sojourn in the eternal regions is intended as a vision of ineffable harmony between man and nature. Perhaps such a vision can be approached only in veiled emotive language; but Dr. Masefield fails to evoke it even in that way. His cities with their speaking weathercocks, his remorseless reiterations of the word "beauty," his rapid and exotic changes of scenery, are directly reminiscent of The Box of Delights. In that otherwise delightful children's book Dr. Masefield so saturated the reader in marvels that one dreaded the moment at which little Kay would reopen the magic box and embark on yet another conducted tour of the land of fancy.
In "The Story of Ossian" it is plain that the romantic vision is not intended as a delusion, for the hero is reunited with it at the end. But this resolution is a hollow formality compared with the stark desolate poetry Ossian speaks as an old man, "lost, unreal, evil, dim," inconsolably grieving for the dreams that wasted away his youth.
POET'S SENSITIVE READING On the page "The StorY of Ossian " would probably look monotonous: it is written in regular iambs, the ABAB rhyme scheme periodically contracting into couplets to secure emphasis. But there is great flexibility in the handling of this simple pattern, and the author's reading follows its nuances with absolute sensitivity. The voice is fastidious, firm and musical, its dynamics may be narrow, but its expressive range is vast.
As a companion disc Argo have issued two readings by Mr. E. M. Forster (RG 153). On this record Mr. Forster, in a dry youthful voice, can be heard reading his story "The Road from Colonus " and his essay "What I believe." Introducing the second piece. Mr. Forster states that since it was written during the war some of his opinions may have been modified: but he has allowed the text to stand. "I don't believe an author has any right to tamper with his text."

Author: Null
Title: Matthew Green
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
MATTHEW GREEN
by Olver Edwards
When Dr. Johnson has said of a poet's solitary claim to fame that the work is not poetry that should be the end of hirn. Yet just as the Doctor himself found it useful to quote to Boswell on a later occasion two lines from this same poem in order to reinforce a point, so through over two hundred years the name of Matthew Green, its author, has held on, cropping up here and there in each generation, tenaciously refusing to be forgotten.
For one thing, browsers in Tlhe Dictionary of National Biographly-that " best record of a nation's past that any civilization has produced," as Professor G. M. Trevelyan has rightly called itwill from time to time come across the entry on Green and at once know they are in the presence of a real person. Under 300 words in length, it is one of those tiny masterpieces which Leslie Stephen could do so admirably, and which get to the heart of his subject much more successfully than do his longer essays. He tells us that Matthew Green (1696-1737) held a place in the custom-house. Bureaucracy was then very much as it is now, for officialdom decreed an economy measure that the allowance for supplying the customhouse cats with milk must be withdrawn. Green, says Stephen, petitioned the authorities in their name-and won.
The details of his other story about Green may not be strictly accurate but the gist is the same in the differing versions. Stephen records that "When a waterman insulted him as he was bathing by calling out Quaker, and a friend asked how his sect could be detected when he had no clothes, he immediately replied, 'By my swimming against the stream.'" An earlier version of the episode has it that it was one Sylvanus Bevan who was impertinently addressed by the waterman, and that it was upon his meeting Green, and expressing surprise to him, that Green delivered himself of the epigram. Either way the wit was his. What importance there is in the discrepancy lies in the fact that while Green came from a family of dissenters, there is no evidence that he was a Quaker. His poetry discounts the idea.
That poetry consists of only some five or six works and, in effect, like "Shipwreck Falconer," Green is the author of only one poem that matters. The Spleen. An Epistle Inscribed to his particular FRIEND Mr. C. J. was written in the last years of Green's short life, and the first edition "Printed and sold by A. Dodd, without Temple-Bar and at all the Pamphlet Shops in Town " was published posthumously. Mr. Dodd was obviously a loving craftsman and in justice to his memory let it be recorded the poem was printed handsomely. They knew the value of large type, good black ink, and the proper placing of the text upon the page, in 1737.
There is another person to whom tribute is due and that is Mr. C. J. He was Cuthbert Jackson, one of those friends for whose entertainment Green,
a most assiduous minor official, used to produce in his leisure hours jertx d'esprit in prose and verse. When Jackson first received the epistle " it was quite short." Knowing a good thing when he saw one he persuaded Green to fill it out. Even then, however, there was no idea of publication. That was left to Glover, another of Green's friends. Between them, Jackson and Glover made sure the custom-house man should have his tiny niche in the great hall of British poets.
In spite of Dr. Johnson it is deserved. Green still has his admirers. One friend to whom I mentioned his name the other day, at once began to recite
Laugh and be well. Monkeys have been Extreme good doctors for the Spleen; And kitten, if the humour hit, Has harlequin'd away the fit.
We can, moreover, in this matter set up one good Tory against another. George Saintsbury described The Spleen as " one of the liveliest poems of a century which has produced many lively poems." Saintsbury also said it was "a little Philistine and decidedly hedonist." There are times, indeed, when it rcminds us of Omar Khayyam.
Me never did ambition seize,
Strange fever, most inflam'd by ease ! The active lunacy of pride,
That courts jilt Fortune for a bride ... Reforming schemes are none of mine: To mend the world's a vast design: Like theirs, who tug in little boat, To pull to them the ship afloat Happy the man, who, innocent
Grieves not at ills he can't prevent.
Green himself is said to have suffered from the spleen. If that were so, most successfully did he overcome it. It has been pointed out that his poem is really a poetical paraphrase of Dr. Cheyne's treatise on " Low Spirits," a chapter in " The English Malady," published in 1733. But Green's experience and fancy took the cures much wider. Hunting, and bowls, music, the theatre-there are few solaces to which he caninot turn. And his final dream of content is one of those simple rusticities which strike a note in everyone.
Two hundred pounds, half-yearly paid, Annuity securely made,
A farm some twenty miles from town, Small, tight, salubrious, and my own. Two maids that never saw the town, A serving man not quite a clown, A boy to help to tread the mow,
And drive, while t'other holds the
plough. May heaven (it's all I wish for) send One genial room to treat a friend,
Where decent cup-board, little plate, Display benevolence, not state.
And may my humble dwelling stand Upon some chosen spot of land: A pond before full to the brim,
Where cows may cool and geese may swim; Behind a green, like velvet neat, Soft to the eye and to the feet;
Where odorous plants, in evening fair,
Breathe all around ambrosial air . . .
And so it goes on, deceptively easy except to those poets who have tried to do it. "Never did a man of genius" one admirer wrote of Green over a hundred years ago, " leave fainter marks of his footsteps upon life." None the less his work falls on the ear and his character upon the mind pleasantly, even in these vastly different days.

Author: FROM A CORRESPONDENT
Title: Anthologies of Verse
Full_text:
THE GRAMOPHONE
Anthologies
of Verse
Dame Edith SitwelL
FROM A CORRESPONDENT
JUPITER RECORDINGS LTD. is a
new company which has been founded for the particular purpose of recording English poetry. So far it has issued two discs-the first part of an anthology of twentieth-century poetry (JUR OOAI, price 39s.), and the first part of a junior anthology of English verse (JUR OOBI, price 29s.).
The first disc bristles with battered old favourites such as W. H. DavieÂ§'s "Leisure" and Fleckeer's "Old Ships," and conveys the innocuous impression of a set of writers given mainly to whimsicality and bucolic rufnination.
The readers are Miss Jill Balcon, Mr. John Glen, Mr. Christopher Hassall, Mr. Carleton Hobbs, Mr. C. Day Lewis, and Mr. Stephen Murray. This list is misleading if it suggests variety. for the recording is overwhelmingly the work of its director, Mr. V. C. Clinton-Baddeley. Wbereas Miss Balcon and Mr. Day Lewis, for instance, are allowed one brief poem each, Mr. Clinton-Baddeley reads 17. His reading inclines towards excessive resonance which overloads some of the slighter lyrics and falls short of the bardic weight demanded by poems such as Hardy's "An Ancient to Ancients" and Yeats's "The Second Coming." The most satisfying readings'on the disc are of poems written in a relaxed conversational idiom.
Virtuoso Reading
At the end, like a baroque firework, Dame Edith Sitwell soars extravagantly aloft. Her performance, of three of her own poems, is that of a virtuoso attacking the most hair-raisingly difficult and musically worthless of concert studies. Meaning is ignored, words being treated entirely for their value as sound and for their place within intricate rhythnic schemes: and while the heady voluptuousness of "Most Lovely Shade" and the compressed ironies of two pieces from " Facade " do emerge, they remain severely detached from the flowing cantabile and staccato brilliance of the voice.
The junior anthology, less ambitious though it is, seems a more satisfactory undertaking. Unlike the twentieth century anthology it has a distinct audience in mind. and is well designed to awaken a taste for verse. Lyrics stay well within the boundaries of childhood experience, ballads and narrative poems predominate, and, with the exception of a mawkish piece by Ralph Hodgson. there are no duds.
