Author: Null
Title: Figures In A Landscape
Full_text:
FIGURES IN A LANDSCAPE
OSBERT SrrwELL: On the Continent.
It is 40 years, he tells us, since Sir Osbert Sitwell planned a trilogy which is now completed by On the Continent. The previous volumes, England Reclaimed and Wrack- at Tidesend, successfully evoked a pastoral and a sea-side mood respectively, by means of a set of portraits in free verse. The present collection deals with expatriates"inquilines," Sir Osbert calls them-and thus a very private wing has been added to the National Portrait Gallery, consisting entirely of pen-sketches of non-notabilities in the period immediately before the First World War.
Sir Osbert has always excelled in the art of the written portrait, and there is a salutary exercise for those who may complain that the form of verse he has chosen is too loose in structure and rhythm: they can try to do half so well themselves. The whole series of poems is, in fact, very carefully composed. If the first volume reflected, with due poetic permutations, the world which revolved round Sir Osbert's Derbyshire home, and the second that of his father's other house at Scarborough, On the Continent must be linked to the Tuscan castle of which he has already written in prose. Thus the trilogy makes a poetic commentary on the early sections of his autobiography; the personages it commemorates are put forwvard with the fantasy and charm of statues in a rocaille setting and, for those old enough to remember the social historY of Florence a generation and more ago, there will be the additional amusement of catching a hint, here and there of the living eccentrics who once peopled that extravagant colony of inquilines.
The poems themselves are full of admirable touches, " Her square face like an unfinished game of noughts and crosses,"
her loaf of white hair" "a dry and abstract wig." Sir Osbert: it will be seen, is generally astringent about the human subjects of his poems, reserving his considerable tenderness and skill of sympathetic evocation for landscape, or-if humans must intrude-for very simple folk The themes of the book are bound together
1O9pp. Macmillan. 12s. 6d.
in a brilliant Grand Finale, and what now remains is to publish the trlogy in a single volutme.

Author: Null
Title: Descend, Ye Nine! Descend And Sing
Full_text:
DESCEND, YE NINE! DESCEND
AND SING
Nine volumes, of which six are first collections. Nine volumes which are far from exhausting the list of poetry published during the past few weeks. It can be said, therefore, that although poets are commonly, and rightly,, said to labour under general discouragement in a materialist world, they have remained obstinately articulate. Furthermore, all nine of these volumes are interesting, and some much more. than that. Where they fail is almost always at the same point. There is a constant tendency in modem poetry for the poem to turn into a thumbnail essay in verse. No poetic experience is communicated, yet some superstructure of verse has been added to what is essentially a prose train of thought. The result is as far as possible from the theory of poetry put forward explictly by Mallarme and Valery and adopted more or less tacitly by most of the successful poets writing in English during the past 40 years. And often it is extremely difficult to read.
Warning may be given by a title. Southey at Grasmere," " On reading Epictetus," *' Thoughts in a Lady Chapel "; such themes-invented at random-recur in book after book, indicating that a sequence of ideas has been set in motion, cultivated ideas. novel even, and certainly " literary " in the extreme. Yet communication is at the wrong level. Everything is packed into the poem except poetry.
There are, of course, exceptions to this generalizat:on; but it is noticeable that most of the poets here named approach poetry in a somewhat wry and diminished frame of mind. Much the most accomplished is Mr. Roy Fuller, who uses a dark skill on the intricacies of the world around him. Yet for the sudden true-sounding note of poetry it may be wiser to turn to the much more uneven book of Mr. Brian G:les-a poet hitherto only known from occasional appearances in periodicals, yet capable of an authority which deserves immediate acclaim. Two other first collections in this list must also be picked out: that of Mr. Quentin Stevenson, a true and moving poet at present weighed down with a certain amount of cumbersome equipment, but paring his learned art, at times. to a moving simplicity; and a little book by Mr. Dom Moraes, a writer not yet 20, whose start is a strikingly auspicious one.
Mr. Ted Hughes is already known on both sides of the Atlantic, and his book is the choice of the Poetry Book Society. It is marked by brilliance and variety, and in these qualities it matches Mr. Donald Davie's A Winter Talent. In both, however, the impression left behind is of a highly articulate writer casting his thought into a mould of verse without noticing that much of it is only an alembicated form of prose. By comparison, the greatei simplicity of Mr. Anthony Cronin and Mi. Twbwaite gain. They content themselves with lucid, agreeable statements in verse. well turned and kept deliberately low in tone. And last there is Mr. Christopher Hassall, who remains an entirely pleasurable poet. He can be witty, or sentimental. or evocative as he pleases; he is also an admirable technician. If there is a slight feeling of disappointment hanging over The Red Leaf it is because Mr. Hassall has not been more ambitious. He only does what he can do well and easily, and
he contents himself with too relaxed a verse structure whenever he uses a long line.
In fine, then, the poets have plenty to offer, and even when they set a wall of other people's books between themselves and real life their responses are never slack. It remains for most of them, however, to reconsider the important distinction between writing poetry and translating short sequences of prose thought into verse.

Author: Null
Title: Modern Poets In Search Of A Public
Full_text:
MODERN POETS IN SEARCH
OF A PUBLIC
There are many objections to be made to the poetry of any age, but usually they can be reduced to two main categories: the absence of authority, and the absence of an individual voice. A number of poets have lately given opportunity to test this generalization, and it must be confessed that all too often they induce a degree of weariness in the reader. Their pages are beautifully set; their stanzas are shapely and the movements of their fancy brisk. But somehow the poem itself turns too often into something like the object which falls from a Christmas cracker-at first sight inexplicable, then quite amusing, and finally dropped on the table without another thought.
There are exceptions, however. Those who remember The Winter House of over 20 years ago will certainly be delighted by the Collected Poems of Norman Cameron, to which Mr. Robert Graves has added an exemplary introduction. The merits of these poems can be indicated by quoting in full the shortest of them:
Forgive me, Sire, for cheating your intent, That 1, who should command a regiment, Do amble amniably here, 0 God,
One of the neat ones in your awkward
squad. Cameron assessed himself as a part-time poet, but this volume makes it clear that, within his fastidious range, he was one who will not be forgotten. Clear, decisive, idiosyncratic without being self-consciously odd, his poems are not among those easily laid aside. Nor are the best of Mr. George Barker's; and among those best must be accounted the autobiographical True Confession, one of the few really impressive long poems of our time. Mr. Barker is very uneven, but his collection covering 25 years shows at its best an incandescencewhich can warm as well as dazzle.
The other poets listed below fall into groups: There are those who continue an expected path like Mr. Day Lewis and Mr. MacNeice-the one mainly elegiac, the other lit by an uneasy brilliance w-hich
seems on the verge of breaking into something new without ever quite doing so. There are the poets of the future, Mr. Bus Singer and Mr. Thom Gunn, whose newness of vision has still to be tested by time. There are two voices from America, Mr. Wilbur and Mr. Eberhart-both worth hearing, though both are rather too prolix. And there are three outriders: Mr. Kirkup, who has put together a rather unsatisfying mixture of the very good and the very disappointing; Mr. MacCaig, who adds to his range a deeper insight than in Riding Lights, and shows himself among the best of contemporary Scottish poets; and Mr. Mackintosh, who once again shows that he is among the few modem writers of light verse who can be named in the same breath as the acknowledged masters.
All of these deserve something better than a mere mention. It would be easy to expatiate on Mr. Singer's really striking use of extended forms-he is a poet who needs .space-on Mr. Kirkup's unexpected and delightful visions-" The Convenience " is an example-on Mr. Wilbur's airy accomp lishment or Mr. Gunn's more sombre
licities. All in all, in fact,thishasbeen a good season for poetry.

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Peacock As A Poet
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
PEACOCK AS
A POET
By Oliver Edwards
Mention Thomas Love Peacock as a poet and the likelihood is that at once souieone will pipe up with
The mountain sheep are sweeter But the valley sheep are fatter
But that, it may be -objected, is a song. Peacock himself declared it to be " The War Song of Dinas Vawr.' While no one would wish to challenge Peacock as a writer of songs, above all of drinking songs, is not poetry another matter ?
I would like to leave that issue on one side for the moment. We can get along without settling it because we can, I think, get along-for the purpose of the argument-almost without the songs; certainly without the drinking songs. This may surprise readers who know Peacock only in his novels, and for whom such rollicking affairs as " A heeltap ! a heeltap ! I never could bear it ! " " If I drink water while this doth last" and the glorious "Hail to the hieadlong! ", falling naturally into the general fantastication of the plot and setting, have over-shadowed the beauties of the quieter lyrics. The emphasis was strengthened some years ago by a pleasant little volume, Drinking Songs from Peacock's Novels. Here wvas obviously a festive, jovial, jingling old gentleman, a bit of a genius in his queer way. But a poet ? Or else, at the other extreme, people may have come across an equally slender volume, Rhododaphne. That, they may have felt, settled Peacock's poetical pretensions once for all.
The fact is that " Poems " and " Poems and Plays" fill two volumes out of the 10 in the Halliford edition of Peacock's works. Much handier is the book of Peacock's poetry Brimley Johnson compiled for Routledge's " Muses' Library " 50 years ago. The odd copy is still to be found in the second-hand shops and I commend it to anyone who comes across it there. Brimley Johnson was one of the Honest Dobbins of the book world. He had taste and judgment; he was careful and conscientious. In this companionable, pocketable - for those who have the right kind of bookmen's pockets-volume of over 400 pages, his work must have given pleasure here and there through two generations.
Sheer bulk cannot, of course, make a poet. Nor does one need to accompany Saintsbury all the way in the opposite direction when he chants:
The laughing Queen that caught the world's great hands
and proclaims that, because of that one wonderful line and despite " volumes of triviality and vulgarity and sentimental gush," Leigh Hunt was indubitably a poet. Peacock has no need of either of these props. He has no "jewelled phrases five words long." And, with one exception, his long poems can be left to the devoted. One has to have a real affection for Peacock to find enchantment in " Palmyra," " Rhododaphne," or "Fiolfar, King of Norway."
- Peacock wrote poetry from boyhood on. By twenty-one he had produced a respectable amount of apprentice work. But it was two or three years later, some time after 1808, that he struck an assured note in "Remember Me."
And what are life's enchanting dreams, That melt like morning mists away ?
And what are Fancy's golden beams, That glow with transitory day ?
While adverse stars my steps impel,
To climes remote, my love, from thee, Will that dear breast with pity swell And wilt thou still remember me ?
There are eight verses, and I wish I could recite them all.
It may be objected that even this is precious near a song. Listen, then, to " The Grave of Love," which Earle Welby found so " inexplicably beautiful."
I dug, beneath the cypress shade,
What well might seem an eHin's graye And every pledge in earth I laid,e That erst thy false affection gave.
I pressed them down the sod beneath; I placed one mossy stone above;
And twined the rose's fading wreath Around the sepulchre of love.
Frail as thy love, the flowers were dead 'Ere yet the evening sun was set;
But years shall see the cypress spread, Irnmutable as my regret.
Or read that lovely lament, "Long night succeeds thy little day," which Peacock wrote on the death of his threeyear-old child, Margaret. Or pick up Gryll Grange-pick it up in any caseturn to chapter XV and find " Youth and Age."
I played with you 'mid cowslips blowing When I was six and you were-four;
When garlands weaving, flower-bells
throwing, Were pleasures soon to please no more. Through groves and meads, o'er grass
and heather, With little playmates, to and fro,
We wandered hand in hand together But that was sixty years ago.
If you do not read on, then I have failed to make my case.
The Devil's advocate never suffering unemployment, there may still be objections that these are small cargo for immortality. I would not agree but, as the lawyers say, even if I did, I would claim that many of the songs in the novels are poetry. (If songs are not poetry what becomes of Robert Burns ?) Were this not enough I would summon up the one exception among the longer poems. " The Genius of the Thames " is, to me, one of the best things that majestic stream has inspired. Starting with the description of an autumn night on its banks, Peacock tells the story of its long history, takes the reader down its course, and then, hearing music at Richmond, reflects on those once great empires through which the Euphrates and the Tiber flowed.
Time, the foe of man's dominion,
Wheels around in ceaseless flight, Scattering from his hoary pinion Shades of everlasting night.
Still, beneath his frown appalling, Man and all his works decay:
Still, before him, swiftly-falling,
Kings and kingdoms pass away.
Cannot the hand of patriot zeal,
The heart that seeks the public weal,
The comprehensive mind
Retard awhile the stormns of fate,
That, swift or slow, or soon or late, Shall hurl to ruin every state.
And leave no trace behind ?
The first time I heard those lines was in the school chapel when, instead of the usual sermon, the closing verses of " The Genius of the Thames" were read to us. I was at an impressionable age and they moved me deeply. But I do not think it is merely recollected emotion that convinces me Peacock was a poet.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry Of To-Day And To-Morrow
Full_text:
POETRY OF TO-DAY AND TO-MORROW
DAME EDITH SrIWELL ON
A LIVING ART
In a talk on poetry given in London yesterday Dame Edith Sitwell had sorme kind words to say for a few young poets writing to-day and some sharp ones -for
the host of inferior versifiers." Nor did critics of poetry escape her rebukes.
Dame Edith Sitwell, who was delivering the Hermon Ould memorial lecture organized by the English centre of International P.E.N., said that one of the troubles with a great many younger poets was that " they have not the faintest idea how to use consonants, with the result that their verse sounds numb, flat, and dead." Grandeur could not be obtained without a skilful use of consonantal systems.
Lack of technique was another failure of many poets of to-day. " They write in lifeless quatrains, or else produce attempts at geometrical designs so easy to manage that any schoolboy could do so, and which have the cramped dimensions of prefabricated houses." Such methods. Dame Edith Sitwell suggested, had replaced the "flabby, so-called free verse which was previously fashionable among incompetent versifiers." This was actually bad prose cut into uneven lengths with blunt scissors.
FREE VERSE DIFFICULTIES
The lecture was rich in quotations to sharpen the argument, and at this point Dame Edith Sitwell quoted:-
For time is up, you have upset the table. Time is up, your red trousers are burntTime is up, the- wireless is smashed. Oh, helpless now, I see This-is reality.
"Well," grimly remarked the lecturer, "if that is reality that is just too bad ! In fact, free verse was appallingly difficult to manage. She asked her audience to listen to the " melodic beauty " of a master of the medium: -
Such are the clouds
They float with white coolness and sunny
shade
Sometimes preening their flightless
feathers.
Float, proud swans, on the calm lake And wave your clipped wings in the-azure
air-.- -
Gather new coolness for to-morrow's beat And sleep through the soft night with
folded wing.
A further danger inherent in much verse by younger writers was due to their misunderstanding of the uses of concentration, or " the condensing of essence." - Yeats had this power. The passion of his poems was compressed into verse as strict as mathematics. To achieve it, it was necessary in the first place to bave something to concentrate on, and when there were neither ideas of any consequencc nor Passion, "all you get is a form of stingincss."
As an example of critical ineptitude, Dame Edith Sitwell took a passage from English Poetry, by Mr. F. W. Bateson, who wrote that poetry was " no more useful, strictly speaking, than any other human activity," and that " to make delight the basis of poetry is as wrongheaded as to make happiness, the basis of virtue." If that writer had his way.- Dame Edith Sitwell declared. Keats, to mention only one great poet, would be of no worth. She went on to define' the maniy. uses of poetry. " It is the deification of reality. It should make all our days holy to us. The poet should speak to all men, for a moment, of that other life of theirs that they have smothered and -forgotten."
FEAR OF VIGOUR
After a reference to the need for live rhythms supported by live words-"-the fierce animal line that conveys vigour and fire "-Dame Edith Sitwell paid tribute to the late Mr. Roy Campbell, -" whose every line conveyed that vigour and fire." Many critics of our time had a mousey fear of vigour, and of splendour; They regarded these as " bad taste. like wearing a diamond necklace on a golf course." Roy Campbell would never be admired by critics suffering from that timidity.
Dame Edith Sitwell also praised the Powerful qualities of Dylan Thomas, who. she said. ' strips from words their old, used, dulled sleepiness, and gives them a refreshed and awakened meaning; a new percussion." Earlier, testifying to her eagerness to discover new talent, she reminded the audience that --It was L. and- not the people who helped him to his deatb. who first wrote of. and Praised. Dylan Thomas.-
In conclusion, she quoted with approval a tew young poets writing to-day, including Jon Silkin, Charles Causley, Burns Singer. Geoffrey Hill, and Quentin Stevenson. It had been her duty to- point out "certain misfortunes in the present age of poetry in England," but these writers, she said, filled her with hope for the- future.

Author: FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
Title: Oxford University Poetry Society
Full_text:
OXFORD UNIVERSITY
POETRY SOCIETY
" KING OEDIPUS "
BY SOPHOCLES
TRANSLATION BY C. A. TRYPANIS
FROM OUR SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
OXFORD, FEB. 20
The contemporary stage has known much experiment in the translation of Greek tragedy, ranging from Professor Gilbert Murray's lyric apostrophesburnished but complex for Sophocles's stark grace-to an American Jason who, if memory does not painfully deceive, was referred to (without perspicacity) as "a decent sort of chap."
Professor Trypanis's new translation steers a moderate course between the two extremes: his verse moves in the clean rhythm of the sculptor's chisel, rarely jarring if without that spurt of imagination in which words seem to spring like flowers, miraculously, out of barren rock. But the real test of a translation is its effect on the stage, and in the performance by the Oxford University Poetry Society at the Taylor Institution to-night the play and dialogue retained their dramatic shape.
For Oedipus above all is a drama, both of character and structure, and if Agamemnon is the first murder play, here in Sophocles we have the first drama of detection, as superbly dove-tailed in its way as Ibsen's The Wild Duck, and with Oedipus as its classical Gregers Werle driving to destruction through his inability to let sleeping dogs lie. The disaster foreordained by destiny is precipitated by his own character, and this gives him the stature of a tragic hero, as volcanic in his pride as Lear, he is a man who must rip out the truth from the womb of time, and let the lava of his suspicion and impatience lose him the temperamental balance that might have kept him bis friends and given him royalty in defeat. Not for nothing Creon rcfers to "self-torture," a "sullen, angry mnercy," and flings the rebuke: "To throw a friend away is throwing your life away."
Yet if his passion can be wilful, ungenerous and unjust, it also has integrity, he is a king who can rule his subjects if not always himself, and this full authority Mr. David Webster at Oxford could not yet command-not. for instance, as Mr. Lindsay Evans as Creon commanded it at the end, although his rich voice could compass the gradations of rage and fear and he kept a grin on the character throughout. He was well supported by Miss Beryl Eeman's mature grief and dignity as Jocasta, and Mr. P. Billingsly as the Messenger told his final tale of woe with immense delicacy of expression.
Professor Trypanis produced the Play with a classical simplicity always mellow to the eye but the slow formality of the speech and movements of the Chorus gave a strictlY ritualistic impression which is rather alien to Sophocles, and muted the play's crescendo of conflict and revelation.

Author: Null
Title: Apollo Society's Busy Time
Full_text:
APOLLO -SOCIETYS
BUSY TIME
RECITALS SOLD OUT
The Apollo Society.is enjoying a busy season just now, dispensing verse and music in a way that refreshes habitual readers and stimulates that great body of poetry lovers who somehow nev.er get around to opening a poetry book.
The latest series of six recitais' three before and three after Christmas, in the Recital Room of the Festival Hall, continues; except that the demand for tickets for February 3 proved so great that Dame Peggy Ashcroft, Professor C. Day Lewis, and Mr. Albert Ferber were able to fill the hall again on Sunday night.
The two readers were well contrasted: Dame Peggy Ashcroft nourishes her technique with an instinctive lyrical iipulse that is a joy to hear, whereas Professor Day Lewis's-by comparison-dry voice (the adJective is used apropos wine, not dust)
savours each word, while his poet's mind makes clear to us the form as well as ihe metrical ingenuity of what he is reading. The programme on Sunday was skilfully constructed. For instance, the invocation to wind and rain from Kathleen Raine's " Northumbrian Sequence " introduced Debussy's " Ce qu' a vu le vent d'ouest," which set the mood for Shelley's "Ode to the West Wind," which led into Debussy's " L'Isle Joyeuse." After an interval came Professor Day Lewis's own " Moods of Love," and this, itself a sonnet sequence, formed something of a modem counterpart to Shelley's ode.
The series in the Recital Room continues on March 3, when Miss Flora Robson, Mr. John Laurie, and Miss Joan Davies are the artists, and on March 31, when Miss Margaretta Scott, Mr. Michael Hordern, and Mr. Julian Bream will perforrn. The society, however, does not confine its activities to one place. On March 10 Mr. Stephen Spender will be "At home" for a Sunday evening programme at the Royal Court Theatre. In the first half of the programme he will introduce a selection from his own PoetrV.

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: How To Enjoy
Full_text:
ITALKING OF BOOKS
HOW
TO ENJOY
By
Oliver Edwards
Apart from Old Possuem's Book of Practical Cats, I am no fan of Mr. T. S. Eliot. I do not understand much of what he has written; I am not attracted by the rest. But earlier this year Mr. Eliot went to the University of Minnesota and there delivered a lecture on " The Frontiers of Criticism," which is the most. exciting and interesting thing of its kind I have read since A. E. Housman's TEe Name and Nature of Poetry.
Mr. Eliot, somewhat bewildered to find himself "from time to time .. . regarded as one of the ancestors of modem criticism," set out in his lecture to show that " there are limits, exceeding which in one direction literary criticism ceases to be literary, and exceeding which in another it ceases to be criticism." His paper is easy to read and easy to understand. (Incidentally, he justifies the average reader of some of his work by confessing that, having re-read his own thirty-three-year-old essay The Function of Criticism, he found himself wondering what al the fuss was about.) But at Minnesota Mr. Eliot was not making a fuss. He was expounding a few simple, but modernly overlaid, truths. Leaving on one side such seductive pleasures as the idea that if Coleridge were alive to-day he would take a lively interest in the social sciences (I would give much to have a Coleridge essay on, say, Professor Barbara Wootton's Testament for Social Science; here would be clarity nobly obscured indeed), one quickly gets down to Mr. Eliot's main theme. It is to analyse the critic's most useful purpose. The nature of such writing involves him in discussing the nature of reading.
Each generation, Mr. Eliot asserts, must provide its own literary criticism; and each generation " looking at the masterpieces of the past in a different perspective, is affected in its attitude by a greater number of influences than those which bore upon the generation previous." Added to this, we now have a situation in which, with "serious literary joumalism . . . an inadequate as well as precarious means of support for aU but a very few," many of the critics are teachers, and many teachers are critics. This means that " the critic to-day may have a somewhat different contact with the world, and be writing for a somewhat different audience from that of his predecessors." No one can deny this. To me it seems we have not gained. The pedantries and aridity of much modem literary criticism are surely due to the fact that it is written by specialists for specialists. " A good deal of contemporary criticism," says Mr. Eliot, " originating at that point at which criticism merges into scholarship, and at which scholarship merges into criticism, may be characterized as the criticism of explanation by origins." This leads him to two books " with which everyone should be acquainted "-John Livingston Lowes's Tite Road to Xanadu and James Joyce's Finnegans Wake.
It also leads him to the reflection that the one thing they have in common is that we can say of each of them: " One book like this is enough."
Mr. Eliot thinks that the best of his own literary criticism has been that on poets and poetic dramatists who have influenced him. But, he says, this kind of " workshop criticism " has one obvious limitation. " What has no relation to the poet's own work, or what is antipathetic to him, is outside of his competence." Also such a critic's judgment " may be unsound outside of his own art." Again " the question of how far information about the poet helps us to understand the poetry is not so simple as one might think." A different answer may well have to be given not only for each poet but also for each reader. Mr. Eliot takes as example Wordsworth, and the various biographical guesses about Dorothy, Annette Vallon, and Wordsworth's marriage. For himself, he confesses, " I feel no need for any light upon the Lucy poems beyond the radiance shed by the poems themselves."
Understanding a poet and understanding a poem, he asserts, are two different things.
I am even prepared to suggest that there is, in all great poetry, something which must remain unaccountable however complete might be our knowledge of the poet. When the poem has been made, something new has happened, something that cannot be wholly explained by anything that went before.
Revising a former definition he made of the function of literary criticism he now simplifies it to be to "promote the understanding and enjoyment of literature." Understanding and enjoyment, he stresses, are not separate activities. " To understand a poem comes to the same thing as to enjoy it for the right reasons." Praising the worthwhile is more important than condemning the second-rate. Eventually he is led to this summing-up:
We can therefore ask, about any writing which is offered to us as literary criticism, is it aimed towards understanding and enjoyment ? If it is not, it may stiU be a legitimate and useful activity ; but it is to be judged as a contribution to psychology, or sociology, or logic, or pedagogy, or some other pursuit-and is to be judged by specialists, not by men of letters. We must not identify biography with criticism: biography is ordinarily useful in providing explanation which may open the way to further understanding; but it may also, in directing our attention on the poet, lead us away from the poetry. We must not confuse knowledge-factual information -about a poet's period, the conditions of the society in which he lived, the ideas current in his time implicit in his writing, the state of the language in his periodwith understanding his poetry. Such knowledge, as I have said, may be a necessary preparation for understanding ihe poetry; furthermore, it has a value of its own, as history; but for the appreciation of the poetry, it can only lead us to the door; we must find our own way in.
So much do I agree with all this; so thoroughly have I been stimulated by the lecture that I feel I must have been reading Mr. Eliot with a blind eye in the past. I am going to try him all over again.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry Recital
Full_text:
POETRY RECITAL
THE APOLLO SOCIETY
Miss Margaret Rutherford, Mr. Christopher Hassall, and Mr. Osian Ellis joined last night in a recital of poetry and music for the harp which was given in memory of Walter De La Mare. A large audience filled the Recital Room of the Royal Festival Hall and strove, with qualified success, to maintain that degree of absolute silence exacted by occasions of this kind.
Poems by De La Mare occupied only the first half of the programme. It was the inferior half. The choice of music was apt (in particular a superbly evocative Impromptu by Rotissel), and groups of poems discriminately selected. But most of them were killed in the act of declamation- the inner voice cannot with such facility be translated into public utterance. The only poem that escaped diminution was "Three Jolly Farmers." a piece with strong rhythm and narrative line.
Mr. Hassall read sensitively, if without any marked distinction. It was Miss Rutherford who made the evening memorable, for her reputation has been made in caricatLring occasions of this kind. Her gestures are familiar-the imperious toss of the head, the jaw gamely squared. Last night these were seriously applied, though we have come to know them as the stock in trade of the outraged games .mistress and the lady trapped at the frontier with excess baggage. It was tempting to take every rustle of Miss Rutherford's dress for a joke, and to imagine that her reading (which was intelligently considered) would at any moment be rudely interrupted by a gang of mutinous fourth fotrmers.
Miss Rutherford came into her own in the second half of the programme by reading Virginia Graham's "Panic." This episode of office life concerns a letter whose loss drives a secretary to the brink of suicide. Miss Rutherford's development of this farcical crescendo established her once again as a performer who, on her own grotnd, is unrivalled.

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Gold Medal
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
GOLD
MEDAL
By Oliver Edwards
This is being written-to use a phrase first attributed to Charles Lamb, a fact which should delight our subject-con amore. It is appreciation, not criticism. No doubt both time and learning could do it much better, and so one day someone will do it. But the news that the Queen's gold medal for poetry has been given to Edmund Blunden is so splendid that I cannot withhold a short note of pleasure. I have not consulted thoroughly the now fairly long line of his works. Those I have by me are only the Poems up to 1940, Undertones of War, T7te Bonadventure, The Mind's Eye and Votive Tablets. I shall therefore say nothing of his later work, or his devotion to Charles Lamb, Shelley, Keats, Vaughan, and Clare. It is no matter. I have cargo enough.
The first things that strike one about this little collection are its diversity and its quality. Nature and war poems; war book, travel book, literary and other essays-each is first class in its kind. Each, too, has stayed the course; When recently I quoted a list of 1914-18 books I had compiled in the 1930s, more remonstrances were made about the omission of Undertones of War than of any other work. The men who knew remember. There is the honesty of the opening sentence: "I was not anxious to go." There are such things as this:-
Daytime was play in the Islands [a part of the front near Festubert] that summer; night was a perpetual tangle. If one went forward patrolling, it was almost inevitable that one would soon creep round some hole or suspect heap or stretch of wired posts, and then, suddenly one no longer knew which was the German line, which our own. Puzzling dazzling lights flew up, fell in the grass beside and flared like bonfires; one heard movements, saw figures, conjectured distances, and all in that state of dilemma. Willow trees seemed moving men. Compasses responded to old iron and failed us. At last by luck or sorm stroke of recognition one found oneself; but there was danger of not doing so; and the battalion which relieved us sent a patrol out, only to lose it. that way. The patrol came against wire, and bombed with all its skill; the men behind the wire fired their Lewis gun withno less determination; and, when the killed and wounded amounted to a dozen or more it was found that the patrol and the defenders were of the same battalion. I knew the officer who led that patrol; he was by temperament s,uited for a quiet country parsonage, and would usually have mislaid his spectacles. Or this from the poem "Third Ypres" which he included in the same volume.
The hour is come; come, move to the reliefl Dizzy wc pass the mule-strewn track where
once The ploughman whistled as he loosed his
team; And where he turned home-hungry on the
road, The leaning pollardmarksus hun grerturming We crawl to save the remnant who have torn Back from the tentacled wire, those whom no
shell Has charred into black carcasses-Relief !
They grate their teeth until we take their room And through the churn of moonless night and
mud
And flaming burst and sour gas we are
huddled Into the ditches where they bawl sense awake, And in a frenzy that none could reason calm, (Whimpering some, and calling on tht dead) They turn away: as in a dream they find
Strength in their feet tobear back that strange Their body.
Blunden once complained of the "slight injustice - done to him by the assumption that because The Shepherd won the Hawthornden Prize he must be a rustic poet. We must avoid the other injustice of giving the impression he is predominantly a First-war writer, although-as he himself pointed out ill the collected volume of his poems upto 1930 -war became part of his experience so young as to "mould and colour the poetry almost throughout this book." He also reflected 10 years later that " those who saw that tremendous time will know that it does not easily give up its hold." But he has many other strains. Poems such as " The Covert " and " The Barn" take us into the heart of old England; and the last verse of "The May Day Garland" shows how beguilingly he wages his war with our old enemy.
And for these courteous children. And Love that's ever a child
The May should never fade to-night Could Time but be beguiled,
Could Time but see the beauty of These singing honied hours,
And lie in the sun adream while we Hid up his scythe in flowers!
With most poets, perhaps, there is too great a readiness on their readers' part to believe they are speaking in person when really they are singing in character. Blunden has warned us that many of his pieces were written " not as elements of an autobiography but in the spirit of projection and daydream." Yet here and in many other poems I amn sure we have the man.
We have him, too, in The Bonadventure, which is one of the truest pieces of reporting that has come from a tramp steamer. Then there are the essays. These reveal more by implication, however. Votive Tablets contains his best work; The Mind's Eye, ranging through Flanders, Japan, England, and literature, displays his many-sidedness better. Some of his essays have been written for special occasions, a centenary, a new book coming out, a cause to be supported. But it is the choice of these things that can tell us much. Edmund Blunden has rarely written on a subject that did not engage his interest. It is sometirnes said that he has not fulfilled his earliest promise, that the flow of creative work has not been kept up. If this is so-and I do not know what he has unpublished-it may be because he has of late years been fully occupied in being a good citizen of the world of letters.

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Off The Gold Standard?
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
OFF TIE GOLD STANDARD ?
By
Oliver Edwards
Tell me the poetry a man can recite and I will make a fair guess at his age group. For the sponges we are in youth soak up two kinds of verse: that of the established canon which appeals to us, and whatever in contemporary writing fires our imagination. To be precise, it is most likely to be poetry just passing out of being contemporary. The very young do not get on to the newest thing, but to the newest that seems on the way to becoming established. So it is that many men (and women) in what I still like to think of as vigorous middle age have an abashed predilection for quoting Flecker.
This first came home to me in a romantic fashion. Being held up in Honolulu during the war, waiting for some corner of a bomb-bay into which we could be stowed, a fellow victim and myself arranged to meet at midnight on the terrace of the Moana Hotel. There, under the great banyan tree, at our feet the surf gently rolling up Waikiki Beach (a triumph of advertisement over Nature, if ever there was one), we took it turn and turn about to recite poems to each other till our repertory was exhausted. And when we finally went to bed about 3 a.m. I suddenly reaiized what a standby Flecker had been to me. In fact I seemed to know more of his work by heart than that of any other poet.
How many bells, I wonder, do 'Saadabad," " Riouperoux," ' The Old Ships," " Yasmin," " The War Song of the Saracens," and " The Golden Journey to Samarkand " ring with the young to-day ? Flecker has not been well served by the anthologists. The Oxford Book of Modern Verse has only three of his poems; the Albatross Book of Living Verse one; the Faber Book of Modern Verse none. Robert Lynd put two of Flecker's best pieces into his collection, but then one could always be sure of Lynd. Richard Church's Poems of Our Time 190042, one of the most representative and most intelligently arranged of all modern anthologies, has " The Old Ships." And yet Martin Secker's noble edition of the collected Poems runs to well over a hundred items with very little juvenilia. We are a long way away from the days when it could be confidently proclaimed that Flecker's work "l ike some masterpiece of Greek sculpture ... will be found to epitomise its period "; that he would " be read and admired centuries after those who were his contemporaries have passed away "i; and that " in the years to come generations of poetry-lovers wil1 be eager to know what kind of man he was."
Was this all far-fetched ? Might I just as well throw away my long-hoarded first edition of The Old Ships (complete with mermaid removed from the later covers)? Or is Flecker merely in the
usual trough ? (Forty years after death is a long time to stay in it.) Clearly if he is going to journey through the generations and the centuries, some of his cargo will have to go overboard. Looking at them again Jately I found The King of Alsander, Flecker's only novel, better than I had remembered it; the Collected Prose not so good. Neither, I think, has any chance of survival. And as a letter-writer Flecker was ordinary. We are left then with Hassan, Doin Juan, and wvhatever we choose to keep from the poems.
The two plays have rather played Box and Cox with each other. For many years Flecker was known almost solely as the author of Hassan. Don Juan was just another play he had written. But slowly it has, in estimation, crept up to its more famous fellow and, in some people's view, even passed it. The fact is that Hassan needs to be superbly well done (which also means extravagantly mounted) not to seem tinsel. Don Juan, as George Bernard Shaw was the first to see-and as a television Performance some time ago reminded us-exists in its own right. Don Juan; Frarnlingham, the Conservative Prime Minister; his two daughters; and the soothsaying Owen Jones are all flesh and blood in a way Haroun, Rafi, Pervaneh, and even Hassan himself are not. Don Juan, moreover, has for the past 20 years had an altnost topical relevance. Flecker knew nothing of modem dictatorships or of the hydrogen bomb, but the poet in him seized the deep anguish of the moral dilemma in choosing between peace and war.
For, no matter in what form Flecker was writing, he was always purely and simply a poet. For that reason I myself think Hassat will prove the more enduring play of the two. The golden road to Samarkand may have got a little oily of late, and in poetry as in so many other things we have temporarily gone off the gold standard. But both plays will come back to the stage from time to time as new producers with imagination and courage and the love of the running line arise. And on many shelves and in many hearts they will long find a place. So will such poems as "Tenebris Interlucentem," " To a Poet a Thousand Years Hence," -The Old Ships," " Riouperoux," " StilLness," " Pavlova in London," " In Phaeacia," " Santorin," " Brumana," " The Old Warship Ablaze," and " Saadabad." Their harmonies and melodies may seem uncomnfortably pleasant to the ear in this cacophonic age. But Flecker spoke truly when he said in the preface to The Golden Journey to Samarkand that he had written " with the single intention of creating beauty." He fulfilled his intention. Surely that is something which will last ?

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Hymns As Poetry
Full_text:
TALKING OF BOOKS
I
HYMNS
AS POETRY
By Oliver Edwards
It has long struck me as strange that the anthologists of English poetry have shown so very little appreciation of the literary merits of many of the English hymns. The Golden Treasury contains not one, and The Oxford Book of English Verse but a very few. Those which Q admitted were an early sixteenthcentury example, Henry Vaughan's " My Soul there is a Country," and Addison's " The Spacious Firmament on High." One might have thought that, after so nobly, with that last poem, ushering in the great era of English hymn-writing-let us call it that from Addison to Newmanthe anthologist would have been emboldened to give some other examples. But no. There is not another hymn (in the generally accepted sense of the word) in his selection of what was finest among the shorter English poems.
Can it be that the English have so much the habit of keeping their various types of thought and feeling in separate compartments of their minds that they cannot think of hymns as literature ? Or is it a form of Puritanism which refuses to see aesthetic qualities in an essentially religious exercise of words? If this latter be true the Puritanism is one not shared by our neighbours the Welsh, for when the late W. J. Gruffydd in 1931 compiled his Welsh anthology he drew more numerously upon William Williams Pantycelyn, the greatest of the Welsh eighteenth-century hymn-writers, than upon any other poet except Ceiriogand one of the latter's contributions, even, was a hymn. Yet the best English hymn-writers were by any unbiased standards poets of very notable rank.
The hymn, as a literary form, has one special claim upon the esteem of anyone who has been a professional writer. In the hymn the writer must express himself With sincerity of feeling, vividness of phrase, and eloquence, within a comparatively limited choice of metres, and within a range of subject-matter and thought dictated to him by the tenets of his faith. There ale, let it be admitted, a vast number of hymns in which this searching test has been too much for the poet's skill. And there are a good many cases, too, in which words and tune form so much a single unit in the mind that it is hardly possible to disentangle the strictly literary element. I remember that the singing in school chapel of " I praised the earth in beauty seen," with the moving final lines of its first stanza, "And earth and ocean seemed to say, Our beauties are but for a day," brought to the adolescent mind a sudden sharp realization of this world's transitory nature-a lasting emotional and aesthetic (though not I think religious) experience. Yet how much of that effect was due to Heber's words, and how much to the noble air by John Hullah to which we sang them, I cannot now attempt to determine.
For all that, however, there are Many hymns about whose merits as poetry there can be no doubt at all-especially among those of the eighteenth century.
There was a precision, combined sometimes with orotundity, in the poetic diction of that time which served the hymn-writer admirably, and which he could use with complete sincerity-as could be instanced again and again from Charles Wesley, and perhaps above all from Isaac Watts. How can any anthology of English poetry be adequate which does not contain the poem that has probably moved more English people more deeply than any other? "Our God, our help in ages past" (which is how Watts began his poem) is full of the most vivid and exquisitely phrased images. And in Watts, too, are some of those overwhelming anthropomorphic visions which were characteristic of his century:-
My God, who mak'st the sun to know
His proper hour to rise,
And to give light to all below,
Dost send him round the skies.
There is, implicit in that stanza, a vivid way of seeing things which one finds again, half a century or more later, in the most beautifully worded of Cowper's hymns:-
God moves in a mysterious way,
His wonders to perform:
He plants His footsteps in the sea,
And rides upon the storm.
Try mentally to materialize those two stanzas, and is the result not something very close in kind to the visions which William Blake expressed in watercolour ?
Nor are these isolated, or especially rare, instances. The eighteenth century supplies many other hymns which may be read with aesthetic enjoyment; and in one of these, Toplady's " Rock of Ages," there is an impassioned mystic self-abasement, almost a self-torture, very different from the common placid standard of religious feeling anid expression in England:-
Nothing in my hand I bring; Simply to Thy Cross I cling;
Naked, come to Thee for dress;
Helpless, look to Thee for Grace; Foul, I to the fountain fly;
Wash me, Saviour! or I die.
How can the anthologist - unless blinded by some irrelevant consideration -have failed to appreciate the qualities of such poetry ? It is too much to believe him so inhuman that he can have read, without trembling on the verge of tears, H. F. Lyte's sonorous, melancholy, and yet uplifting valediction:
Swift to its close ebbs out life's little day; Earth's joys grow dim, its glories pass away; Change and decay in all around I see;
0 thou who changest not, abide with me.
Rather one imagines that some stubborn, half- unconscious resistance, based on the feeling that poetry ought, at least in itssimplerforms, to beabletomake its effects without calling in aid all the spiritual suggestion which lies within the religious and devotional themej that it should bea "pure" art, has as a rule inhibited him from giving way to his own instinctive feeling. If so, it is time that he should recant, perhaps taking the very words of his recantation from another great and beautiful hymn:
"Pride ruled my will: remember not
p-ast years."

Author: Edwards, Oliver
Title: Translated Lyrics
Full_text:
ITALKING OF BOOKS
TRANSLATED LYRICS
By Oliver Edwards
How is one to iudge of the merits of lyric poetry written in a language with which one is not, or only imperfectly, familiar ? That is a question by which many devoted readers have been bothered-some of them to the point -of forswearing the reading of all translated verse, since, they would say, poetry is untranstatable. To them, one of the first pleasures of learning a new language comes when, with grammar 'cook and dictionary in hand, they succeed in construing a few short and simple lyrics. Then, to their eyes, appears a new, subtly national vision of the beauty of the world, differing refteshingly front that of the poets of any other-literature, even though dealing with the same elementary materials.
That sense is perhaps but an illusion; for how is one to tell how those same lyrics appear in the eyes of readers to whom the language is the mother tongue ? Does Verlaine's 11 pleure dans mnon coeur sound and mean-or-perhaps better imply -the same to English as to French readers ? The question is unanswerable. Yet the thrill of first peering into the poetry of another tongue remains one of the joys of reading-and what is more, often rouses in the reader a longing to transpose this newly descried loveliness into his own tongue, partly, no doubt, for the edification of his monoglot compatriots, but much more for his own satisfaction-to; show: himself that be can (or possibly, if he is quite honest with himself, that he cannot) do it.
This itch to translate is very widely spread. Dr. Johnson was rendering Horace into English verse in his schooldays, and his last English poem, writter in November, 1784, was a version of Diffugere Nives:
The snow dissolv'd no more is seen,
The fields, and woods, behold are green-
the same ode which A. E. Housman rendeied very beautifully into the idiom of his own day, later by almost a century and a half. Yet, in so far as each translator abandoned Horace's metre, and substituted one from his own national tradition, it is certain that neither version can fali on English ears just as the Latin did on Roman.
it may be that the happiest results come when the translator does not tie himself too closely to the original. This freedom he sometimes takes avowedly, as when Cowley described his Anacreontiques as " translated paraphrastically," or sometimes leaves to the reader's perception, as when William Johnson expanded six lines of Callimachus into the eight famous lines which are among the comparatively few lyric translations that have their own standing as English poems. In that small class, too, may perhaps be put that sonnet of Yeats which, nevertheless, though it starts with a miraculous echoing of Ronsard, soon slips away into the Celtic mnists.
Undoubtedly, however, the most notable example of a translation which is an English poem in its own right is FitzGerald's Rubaiyat, a piece which is additionally curious in that it itself has been translated into other languages, once, at least, with remarkable success. I have lately been trying to make some acquaintance with Welsh poetry, and have been able to recover something of that same thrill of discovery that I knew when, in youth, I first dipped into French verse. One Welsh poem I have come across is Sir John Morris-Jones's translation from FitzGerald, and with this I tried the experiment of reading aloud a particular stanza to two English friends who know no Welsh. It was correctly guessed, in one case straight away, in the other at a second hearing, by both friends as ' A book of verses "-and so on. Evidently, therefore, the translator had caught the metre and sound of -the English very closely-though whether FitzGerald did the same for the Persian is another matter.
As for the reverse process-Welsh poetry to English-a craft which Sir Idris Bell has practised with distinction-there is obviously much Welsh verse that is untranslatable, if translation is to keep the metre and sound as well as the sense of the original. Yet there are some pieces which are perhaps possible to attempt-and being no less subject to the itch of translation, and no less hopeful, than some of my betters, I have tried my hand at a few of them, for example, one of the Hen Benillion, or old traditional verses
While yet the salt is in the sea
And in the wood the green birch tree, And still the crow feeds by the shore, My dearest dear, I'll corne no more.
And while the gable-end is white
And on the dove are feathers bright, And oxen tread the meadow track
My dearest dear, I'll not come back.
In sense (ipart from some liberty with the crow, who, in the original, -tends his nest, and won't rhyme in English) that seems to me fairly near the mark, and the metre will perhaps pass. But does it mean to the English heart what the original does to the Welsh ? Ah, there indeed is the rub; but at least it is fun to make the attempt.

Author: Null
Title: Contemporary Poet
Full_text:
Recent Books
CONTEMPORARY POET
_9b
RHETORIC AND VISION
GEORGB BARxER: A Vision of Beasts and
Gods. Faber and Faber. 9s. 6d.
Mr. George Barker's new volume, which is the second choice of the recently founded Poetry Book Society, marks a definite stage forward in the development of this gifted and uneven poet.
There has never been any doubt about Mr. Barker's vigour and dash, but fastidious critics have sometimes found his language gaudy and even flashy, and the emotional attitudes struck in many of his poems morbid and strained. It has been easier, also, to indicate his talent. by reference to isolated lines and stanzas, to a generally diffused energy, than by pointing to any poem which has been certainly a success as a whole. Mr. Barker's most serious faults, inflation and pretentiousness, are not absent from A Vision of Beasts and Gods, but the book contains a number of poems-notable among them "Letter to a Young Poet," " Channel Crossing." ".The Dying and Heroic Captives of Italy," " Love Letter," " Epitaph for Many Young Men " in which Mr. Barker displays both a new confidence in the organization of a poem round a general theme and a new sensitivity towards some of the quieter modulations of lanzuage.
The two longest poems in Mr. Barker's book, " Goodman Jacksin and the Angel " and the sequence " Justice at Midnight,' are less satisfactory, though for contrasting reasons. The first of these poems, a dialogue between personifications of man's carnal and spiritual natures, is an eloquent but slightly diluted versification of theoloRical commonplaces. " Justice at Midnight," a meditation on God's justice and mercy from the desperate, but not quite despairing, sinner's point of view, is more personal in its appeal, but more obscure in its symbolism. An aspiring melancholy, a cry for light from the darkness, for water from the dust, is the general mood of these poems. It is a mood whose dignity compensates for a certain inherent monotony in its scope. There is still a certain "staginess " in Mr. Barker's rhetoric-sometimes we cannot help feeling that he is using his words to whip up his feelings-but on the whole his manner in A Vision of Beasrs and Gods has a more sensitive unity than in any of his previous volumes.

Author: Null
Title: Two Successful Poets
Full_text:
TWO SUCCESSFUL POETS
IN SEARCH OF SIMPLICITY
VERNON WATKINS: The Death Bell.
Faber and Faber. 10s. 6d.
NORMAN NIciOLSON: The Pot Geranium.
Faber and Faber. 9s. 6d.
Under the auspices of the Arts Council the Poetry Book Society has come into being, in order that once a quarter a volume may be selected for its members. The first volume thus to be chosen is Mr. Vernon Watkins's, and in addition a recommendation has been extended to Mr. Nicholson's The Pot Geranium.
Thus the society comes into action with a flourish; for Mr. Watkins is already known as one of the few contemporary poets who can handle extended forms with success, and Mr. Nicholson's elegance has been widely recognized. Since, therefore, in both cases the poet is too skilled to be accused of an uncertain aim, the occasion is a good one for trying to assess the justice of their reputaltions.
Mr. Watkins is a Welshman, and in his earlier volumes, The Ballad of the Marl Lwyd and The Lamp and the Veil, he cultivated a richness of utterance which ran parallel to Dylan Thomas. He has now pared his exuberance to a much greater economy of phrase, and at the same time adopted a stricter metrical framework, both in the ballads which comprise one part of his book and in the lyric poems which make up the rest. His poetry is thus more accessible than formerly. It exemplifies a very general tendency to break away from the gnomic or the ambiguous modes which were fashionable before the war, in search of a fresh simplicity, and there is no reason why even those who are chary of modem poetry should miss the pleasures which are scattered through these pages.
The same might be said of Mr. Nicholson. He cannot be catalogued simply as a country poet of exceptional grace and, where it is appropriate, keen wit. His poems are always lively expressions of a temperament, and they will appeal to anyone with an ardent visual sense and an ear for music. Neither poet, perhaps, is at full stretch in these volumes, but both offer ample justification for the existence of the Poetry Book Society.

Author: By Our Art Critic
Title: A Vein Of True Poetry
Full_text:
A VEIN OF TRUE POETRY
MR. AUGUSTUS JOHN'S EXHIBITION
AT BURLINGTON HOUSE
By Our Art Critic
For some years the work of Mr. Augustus John has not stirred up much excitement among artists or critics. He has continued to be watched with unabated interest by the public and by Fleet Street as the President of Bohemia; collectors have continued to acquire, and to send up the prices of, his early drawings and the paintings which they considerit is surprising that they should, on the whole, be so seldom mistaken-to be of the right period and to represent the right subjects. But it is only necessary to compare the influence that Sickert has continued to exert on British painting to see that unlike him Mr. John is not one of those fortunate artists who need fear
nothing from the movements of fashion I and taste.
The exhibition which opens to-day ini the Diploma Gallery at Burlington House makes this neglect seem outrageous, but at the same time explains it. Apart from a small group of his earliest paintings, it divides easily into three parts. There is a dazzling display of his drawings, which occupies the greater part of two rooms. There is a compact group of 36 of the small panels he executed between 1910 and 1914, and with these goes an admirable choice in another room of portraits done for pleasure at the same period and also the single example of his large compositions of many figures, the ' Lyric Fantasy," painted during these fruitful years. Then there is the work of the professional portrait painter, mainly from 1918 onwards, but with some earlier portraits such as the well-known painting of the Lord Mavor of Liverpool; with the portraits go other examples of his later work, still-life and landscape subjects which in the later years may be considered the portrait painter's relaxation. As an appendix there are seven works of sculpture, an art which Mr. John has practised only in the past year. No works from the Tate are included.
A GREAT DRAUGHTSMAN
The effect of the drawings, when seen in such abundance, is overwhelming. They do more than explain why Mr. John's contemporaries were convinced that here at last was a great modern artist in England; they suggest even now that a genius of that order had really appeared. Perhaps it is as well to be a little suspicious of Professor Brown's and Professor Tonks's standards of draughtsmanship, since they were capable of deciding that an artist whose work was not realistic in a particular way was simply unable to draw. But their standards were, after all, based on an acute appreciation of certain old masters and the work of MIr. John is in itself a proof of this. He could, as this exhibiticn shows, turn out a drawing with an almost supernatural resemblance to any one of some half-a-dozen old masters, not merely a pastiche of Rembrandt, Tiepolo, or Watteau, but a work done directly from the life in their manner. And this strange faculty is evidence of how well Mr. John had learned his art in the best of all schools, that of the museums; they illustrate what devotion to great art accompanied his virtuosity.
Unfortunately the Slade did not then teach its pupils how to paint in oils, even though Steer might, on occasion. do what Mr. John himself considered his most beautiful, because his least inhibited, painting on the canvas of a pupil. The earliest pictures in this exhibition are talented enough, but from the first it is clear, and particularly in the portrait.
' Merikli," of 1902, that the young artist had had no real grounding in the specific task of the painter in oils, the business of completing a picture without
spoiling the quality of paint. And even if the Slade had shown the way to a solution of this problem, what kind of painting then existed, in which such equipment as Mvlr. John had could have found full and satisfactory employment ? His power of draughtsmanship would have fitted him to work in Raphael's studio, but in 1900 there was no way in which it could be used directly and with conviction.
As it happens, the example of a very minor artist turned Mr. John into a painter. Round about 1910 he conducted, with Innes, a private and insular postimpressionist revolution. The figures that he could have drawn in the round with such power were now flattened to bare silhouettes; the detail that he could have included in a drawing without in any way impairing the breadth of the design was now ruthlessly left out. But the coiour is radiant and clear, and the paint, which has aged very beautifully on almost all the small panels of this time, is laid with a sweet and sensitive touch.
CELTIC SENTIMENT
At the same time Mr. John now found expression for the vein of true poetry that runs through the best of his work. In part the sentiment of these pictures is Celtic, otherworldly, and ideal, but never for a moment did he paint in a Celtic twilight. To these blue distances and golden suns Mr. John transferred, not some wraith of the literary imagination, but quite simply and in literal fact his family and friends. And as it was said that no one who had not lived before 1789 could know " les douceurs de la vie," so these pictures seem inspired by the happiness of life before the First World War, the now unimaginable happiness of a young painter who could have a very successful exhibition, make perhaps £50, and with it take his family to the seaside in the South of France.
Mr. John has made a creed of independence and perhaps it was natural that he should be more readily influenced by a small artist than by another great man. But just as his draughtsmanship needed for its full employment a tradition like that of the Renaissance, so when he became a modern painter his art needed the only kind of tradition that exists to-day, the influence of one or two great artists and the climate of fiercely critical opinion that such a man can create in his immediate neighbourhood.
STUDY OF CHARACTER
And this was all the more necessary because Mr. John chose to practise an art which nowadays is guided by fewer and lower standards than any other kind of painting; his interest in character and the gift for catching a likeness which shows itself even in his most decorative compositions almost inevitably made him a portrait painter, but the result was that he now had nobody except himself to say whether anything was properly painted or no. And quite clearly Mr. John is not a good critic; the unevenness of his later work is really startling, and this even in the simplest technical matters, like the introduction of a sudden patch of flat and inexpressive paint into a firmly modelled head. He remains a force and a power and every now and then there is a picture, a landscape or a portrait, of one of his sons, in which all has gone brilliantly well. But though it is impossible not to see that here is a great man, this is too great a man, one sometimes feels, to practise the painters' slow and nine-tenths mechanical art.

Author: Null
Title: Mr. Eliot's Three Voices
Full_text:
MR. ELIOrS THREE
VOICES
UNDERSTANDING TIE
POET
MR. T. S. ELIoT yesterday urged an audience of about 2,500 at the National Book League's annual lecture, in the Central Hall, Westminster, to bear with the apparent obscurity of some poets and to try to understand their language. His lecture was entitled "The Three Voices of Poetry." These three voices were, Mr. Eliot explained, the voice of the poet talking to himself-or to nobody; second, the voice of the poet addressing an audience; and, third, the voice of the poet when he attempted to create a dramatic character speaking in verse.
Some poems bad indeed been written for one person, but, said Mr. Eliot, a good love poem, though it might be addressed to one person, is always meant to be overheard by other people. - Surely," he added, "the proper language of love-that is, of communication to the beloved and to no one else-is prose."
Mr. Eliot then traced the distinction of the three voices in his own mind, as a writer of poetry. In writing The Rock, he had come to realize that verse to be spoken by a choir should be different from that to be spoken by one person, and that the more the voices who had to speak it the simpler it must be. The choruses of The Rock were examples of the second voice. In them he spoke for himself. In Murder in the Cathedral, however, the choruses had to be consistent with the character of the Women of Canterbury: but the drama was still fought out in one person through whom the author could speak. There was no real " third voice."
In a verse play; the author must not identify himself with any one character, and give him all the good lines. He must sympathize with all his characters, but give them only such poetry as was plausibly attributable to them. The dramatic monologue was an example of the second voice, even in a play. But Brown:ng's poetry had a dramatic element in it which was more nearly akin to the third voice. " Is there, perhaps," asked Mr. Eliot, "another voice of the dramatic poet whose dramatic gifts are best exercised outside the theatre ?"
CLARITY AND OBSCURlTY
Turning back to the first voice, Mr. Eliot said that there was a kind of poetry in which the poet did not know what he had to say until he had said iL "He is oppressed by a burden which he must bring to birth in order to obtain relief." Mr. Eliot did not believe that the relation of a poem of this class to its origns could be more clearly traced than that. The poet must above aU be concemed to achieve clarity for himself. "The most bungling form of obscurity," said Mr. Eliot, " is that of the poet who has not been able to express himself to himself; the shoddiest form is found when the poet is trying to persuade himself that he has something to say when he has not."
Even if a poet had written a poem primarily without thought of an audience, he would also want to know what it had to say to others. "If you complain that a poet is obscure and apparently ignoring you," Mr. Eliot said, " . . . remember that what he may have been trying to do was to put something into words which could not be said in any other way, and therefore in a language which may be worth the trouble of leaming. If you complain that a poet is rhetorical and that he addresses you as if you were a public meeting, try to listen for the moments when he is not speaking to you but merely allowing himself to be overheard: he may be a Dryden, a Pope, or a Byron. And if you have to listen to a verse play, take it first at its face value, as entertainment, for each character speaking for himself with whatever degree of reality his author has been able to endow him."

Author: Null
Title: Fifty Years Of Poetry
Full_text:
FIF-TY YEARS OF POETRY
A NEW ANTHOLOGY
The Faber. Book of Twentieth Century
Verse. An Anthology of Verse in Britain, 1900-1950. Editors: John Heath-Stubbs and David Wright Faber and Faber. 12s. 6d.
In compiling this anthology the editors were faced by the difficulty that Michael Roberts's Faber Book of Modern Verse stood formidably as " the standard anthology in its field "-the phrase is worth quoting because it is the claim made for it by the publisher. In what field, then, could a new anthology stand, covering much the same period of time and many of the same poets as its predecessor ? Upon what principles has it been compiled ? Mr. Heath-Stubbs in his introduction suggests that what he rather obscurely calls "the antithesis of style" in twentieth-century poetry " is really the contrast of Innocence and Experience, the
one dominated by the image of a Garden, the other by a City." The anthology seems based upon this conception: thus Mr. Heath-Stubbs discovers a " pastoral mood" in the poetry of Hardy and A. E. Housman, and finds " the image of Innocence" in the "mature work" of Miss Sitwell, Mr. Eliot and Mr. Dylan Thomas.
PERSONAL PREDILECTIONS
This seems a strange approach to a halfcentury which has been marked by a change in the language of poetry as great as that which took place during the Romantic revolution. What- it arnounts to in practice is simply an expression of that "' personal predilection " to which all editors must confess, untouched by any social or historical principle but generally attached to a mild romanticism of mood and language. One admirable feature of The Faber Book of Modern Verse was that Michael Roberts managed to include work by almost every poet. of recognized importance at the time he made his choice: and where anthologists depart from this practice, as the compilers of the present book quite markedly do, it is not enough to say that their reading has been full and conscientious and that " any glaring omissions will. .. probably be intentional." There are poems here by Hardy, Housman, Yeats, Mr. Auden, Mr. Eliot, and others which would merit inclusion in any anthology of the half-century's poetry; but there is much work also which, when the wide field to be covered is borne in mind, reveals standards of judgment that can only be called eccentric.

Author: FROM A CORRESPONDENT
Title: Public Readings Of Poetry
Full_text:
PUBLIC READINGS OF
POETRY
QUESTION OF COPYRIGHT
FROM A CORRESPONDENT
The Arts Council bas only recently interested itself in the cause of poetry and the small sum which it is now putting by-just under Â£1,000-is helping, in a modest way, to encourage the appreciation of verse through the spoken word. The grants go to local poetry and literary societies (some of them very small) that organize public verse readings by professior.al readers and, where possible, by the authors themselves. Many of these societies, especially in the midlands and the north, are descended from the Philosophical Societies that were in vogue in the early days of Queen Victoria.
The idea of promoting the cause of poetry in this matter sprang originally from the prize poem competition held in connexfon withi the Festival of Britain. More than 2,000 entries received for this competition were published in a Penguin volume, 28,000 copies of which were bought by the public. The Arts Council then set up its own poetry panel, and though it was unsuccessful in obtaining an increase in its annual Treasury grant for this purpose, it was able to find nearly Â£1,000 within the limits of its existing resources. When copyright poetry is included the authors are entitLed to a fee, but many societies do not apparently realize that a reading constitutes, in effect, a public performance. More pertinently, many of the poets themselves do not seem to be aware of the fact that they may claim fees for the public reading of their works. To remedy this the Art5 Council's poetry panel has been trying to find a simple and effective means of assessing fees and collecting themn without discouraging those interested in the promotion of the readings. The Copyright Committee of the Board of Trade IS now working out a report on the questioin of copyright as a whole, which will embrace recorded poetry. But whatevef changes may be proposed the council hopes that they Will no prejudice the position of the poet, nor bamper the use of copyright poetry by those seeking to make it better known.

Author: Null
Title: Contemporary Poet
Full_text:
CONTEMPORARY POET
Louis MACNEICE: Ten Burnt Offerings.
Faber and Faber. 1Os. 6d.
Mr. Louis MacNeice, of the generation that held the poetic limelight during the thirties. is these days by far the most prodigal of his talent. Mr. Auden operates gravely, obscurely, and sometimes beautifully from America, it is true; but Mr. T. S. Eliot seems to meditate more on the structure of drama than on the writing of poetry as a natural way of expression. At any rate, the shorter poem no longer seems to interest him. Mr. C. Day Lewis, in the habit of a professor of poetry, devotes most time to disquisitions on technique and to ambitious translation. Mr. Spender writes autobiographical prose, criticism, rapporrage, and vows to keep his poems on ice.
Mr. MacNeice alone seems to think instinctively in poetic terms and Ten Burnt Offerings. the product of a year with the British Council in Greece, is evidence of vitality and genuine experiment. Mr. MacNeice has always used the social life going on around him, the common shared details as well as private situations. as raw material for his poetry, and as a result any book of his has great imn-mediacy. He is, if such a thing may be said, the right kind of contemporary poet: scholarly, historically and socially aware, with a fresh, idiomatic use of language, an eye for his environment.
Although the 10 long poems of this new book are uneven, they have all these qualities. Only the attractive lyrical poet, the observer with a sardonic but exciting eye, has an affected alter ego, a parlour-room wisecracker who juggles with rhetoric, religion, philosophy, and metaphysics as though they were oranges. The technical sleight of hand can often be admired, but less often its intentions. Luckily three or four poems, inspired by India or Greece or by characters from classic legend, come through unscathed. Then it is possible to observe a distinguished poet working through a period commonly considered devoid of poetic impetus.
