Title: New Theatre
Full_text:
Entertainments
NEW THEATRE
IE-COCKTAIL PARTY"
" THE -~COCKTAIL PARTY-"
.By T. S. ELIOT
It has been an exhilarating night for the few who have always clung to the belief that poetry remains the natural as it is the traditional language of the English stage. They have seen actors who were speaking yerse to a modern theme put an audience on easy terms with a play built deliberately on a popular model, an event to send them away glowing with positively sinful pride in their loyalty to a cause which has so often during the past century flickered into life only to flicker out again.
It may flicker out yet again. What encourages the hope that it wil not is that this time the poet-dramatist has driven straight at the capital difficulty of verse drama. Mr. Eliot has picked a form which prose realism has worked to the point of exhaustion; and into it he has breathed new life.
The importance to the theatre of The Cocktail Party is the practical proof its affords that verse can give refreshing precision to the light, easy, amusing exchanges of fashionable drawing room comedy, and that the new idiom of which it makes actors free has also in its power to give a haunting intensity of its own to the rather frightening moral implications which it discovers beneath the surface of the comedy. At the Edinburgh Festival, in New York, and now in London, too, as would happily appear from last ni$ht's response, audiences have found themseIves at home with this verse. It has stirred, amused, challenged their imagination: it has, in short, entertained. The medium of their entertainment is verse which while keeping closely in touch with the development of their own speech, is yet able to rise, by almost imperceptible transition, to passages of grave and high beauty. It is not the beauty of verbal splendour but of verbal power, designed to serve the ends of a dramatic action which at the proper moments it iiluiinates and transtigures. From this poetry the anthologies will gain nothing; the poet is single-mindedly a dramatist and it is strictly dramatic poetry.
The action deals with problems of personal dissatisfaction which are the current coin of West End comedy, and they take shape from the sprightly extravagances of cocktail party chatter. There are losses, but there are also gains, in this recast production, but Mr. E. Martin Browne has taken care that the essential values of the play should be preserved. It has less comic verve, but more force than the Edinburgh production now in New York.
Mr. Rex Harrison gives the psychiatrist a less cryptic, a more professional, air than Mr. Gunness, with the result that the ' guardians "
-on one plane of 'reality accomplished worldings, on another symbolizing jointly the silent moral self with which the wilful superticial self must sooner or later reckon-are made more readily acceptable. Julia's desolating trivialities are theatrically less amusingly, but more plausibly'pointed by Miss Gladys Boot, and Mr. Robin Bailey, the third guardian, is also less amusing and more plausible.
But Miss Margaret Leighton takes full advantage of the opportunities Celia gives her. Celia is the social butterfly who has the courage (arising from despair) to face her own truth. Miss Leighton and Mr. Harrison are both equal to the demands of the scene which is without a rival in modern poetic drama, that in which Celia chooses the hard, the terrifying way. Mr. Ian Hunter makes a humorous and *a human figure of the husband who is incapa'ble of loving (is he, by the way, so rare a specimen as romantic drama assumes ?), and Miss Alison Leggatt does not spare the wife who is incapable of loving.
It is a structural weakness of the drama that by the end of what is really the second act the main crises have been virtually resolved. The long final scene with only the fate of those who made the choices to describe is in danger of being no more than an epilogue to the play. Mr. Eliot meets the danger by defining and intensifying the connexion between the world of life and the other world where, in Shelley's phrase, " do inhabit the shadows of all forms that think and live tiU death unite them and they part no more." He also administers some well-calculated shocks to the sensibility by the psychiatrist's full acceptance of the enviable fate of those whom a strong sense of vocation has led to martyrdom.
These measures successfuUy renew and sustain the threatened tension, and the final impression is that the various choices and their implications have found something near to complete theatrical fulfilment. Paradoxically, the play, by its very completeness, takes on complexity. From this nch complexity we may draw many different meanings, each " according to his capacity."

Title: English Poetry
Full_text:
ENGLISH POETRY
LOAN EXHIBIMTON IN
LONDON
The loan exhibition of editions of English poetry got together by Mr. John Hayward for tfie National Book League was opened at 7, Albemarie Street yesterday by Mr. John Masefield.
It is certainly the most complete collection of first and early editions of the English poets, from Chaucer to the.present day, that has ever been shown in public; the only comparison is with the exhibitions of. the Grolier Club in New York, but these displayed only the works of single poets or single periods. With the books are shown some most interesting portraits, including the fine portrait of Dryden by Kneller, the " Deanery I. portrait of Donne, Severn's drawing of Keats, Richardson's Matthew Prior, and Watts's Tennyson.
The exhibUtion is designed to satisfy the strictest requirements of the bibliographer and bibliophile, and the catalogue, compiled by Mr. Hayward, is extremely detailed and should be of the greatest! value to students; much of its information is also of interest to the general reader. - At the same time the public is invited to indulge its appetite for historical ironies by observing the rare volumes in which poems now universaUy known made their first shy and often unsuccessful appearance; it seems almost incredible that many of the books should be in such perfect preservation.
The exhibition begihs with Lord FitzWilliam's copy of Caxton's " Canterbury Tales," the only copy still in private hands in England and in wonderful condition. In the rich collection of incunabula and other very early works may be seen a great curiosity, Walter Smyth's " Wydow Edyth," a unique copy of the first edition of a work hitherto known only to the most erudite. The Elizabethan age and the seventeenth century are represented by the finest specimens of the major and ninor poets, and the eighteenth and nineteenth century collections contain many volumes of the highest rarity, including the juventha of the most eminent poets. Among the modern volumes is a copy, lent by the King, of Mr. Masefield's " Reynard the Fox," which the Poet Laureate illustrated himself and presented to King George V.

EXHIBITION OF FIRST

An exhibition of English poetry, consisting of first and early editions of the English poets from Chaucer to the present day, has been organized by the National Book League and will open at 7, Albemarle Street on Thursday, April 10, at 3 p.m.
Almost every book in the collection has been chosen because it was, to those who originally bought it or read it, the first sign that a new poet had appeared. It will be the most comprehensive collection of rare of especially interesting books o( English poetry ynt show n in public; 10 of the books are believed to be the only existing copies, and of a number of others only about half-a-dozen copies remain. The books have been chosen and procured for the exhibition by Mr. John Hayward, who has also compiled a detailed and comprehensive catalogue. The books have. all been obtained from private collections in this country and from college libraries in Oxford, Cambridge, and London. Although many rare books have gone to America in recent years there remain enough books in private hands in Great Britain to make an exhibition of this kind possible, though original editions of English poetry are now hard to find; even a number of very recent works have become extremely rare. Most of the EnAlish poets are represented by a single volune, but two or more are allowed to the major poets.

Title: English Poetry Of Many Ages
Full_text:
ENGLISH POETRY OF
MANY AGES
THE QUEEN AND PRINCESSES!
AT RECITAL
The Queen, Princess Elizabeth, and Princess Margaret were present at a recital of poetry in the Wigmore Hall yesterday. The recital, over which the Poet Laureate presided, was arranged by the Society of Authors and given by a company of poets and actors.
It was in all ways a memorable afternoon. There was a sense of exultation, as well there might be: for in two hours one heard sounded most of the great voices of English poetryMarlowe declaiming, Shakespeare romantically young, Donne and Marvell dealing confidently with earthly love, the quiet tones of Henry Vaughan. Those who spoke this poetry of the past were well chosen, Their instruments were as various aS those who played upon them, ,whether it was Milton borrowing the trumpet tones of Miss Flora Robson for his indignation, or Dryden bequeathing to the tongues of Dame Edith Evans and Mr. Gielgud a vision of youthful love and youthful sorrow, or Burns at his simplest and most moving on the lips of Mr. John Laurie.
It the second part of the programme, which was devoted to contemporary work, declined in splendour, it was more the fault of the poets than the poetry. Mr. C. Day Lewis, Mr. Louis MacNeice, and Mr. Thomas came off znuch better in reading their own work than Mr. Walter de la Mare Mr. T. S. Eliot, and Nliss Edith Sitwell. Wilfred Owen's " Anthem for Doomed Youth " wes' left to' Miss Flora Robson, who read it just about as well as it was written, and Mr. Valentine Dyall spoke poems by Alun Lewis and Sidncy Keyes with an imagination and power those youngAmen would have thanked him for.
The afternoon ended with a pretty cornpliment by the Poet Laureate to the Queen, who made "all Britain's birds to sing."

Title: Music And Poetry
Full_text:
MUSIC AND POETRY
REC1TALS AT QUEEN MARY
HALL
Verse speaking has recently been coming into increasing favour. It " goes with " music of a certain kind very well indeed, and a recital in which the two arts show their neighbourliness is capable of giving pleasure and mental refreshment. A series of lunch-hour recitals arranged by Miss Anne Baker has been running at Queen Mary Hall on Thursdays for some time; yesterday Miss Baker appeared herself with Mr. Myers Foggin.
The word " diseuse " in English usage has come to mean not a speaker but a singer with insufficient voice to sing anything more than quasi-dramatic ballads and sketches. Miss Baker is both more and less than a diseuse, *in that she does not attempt to sing but is an accomplished speaker. Her selection of pieces which she recited between Mr. Foggin's groups of piano solos was apt and varied: it contained prose as well as verse, humour as well as lyrics, and character studies presented with just the right degree of suggestiveness. Mr. Foggin chose pieces to match, nothing too long, but all acceptable things like Falla's "Ritual Fire Dance " and chorale preludes of Bach. Both performers knew how to present these small things significantly and gracefully.

Title: The Poetry Of Landscape
Full_text:
_Entertainments |
THE POETRY OF
LANDSCAPE
INTERPRETATION IN TWO
STYLES
At the comprehensive exhibition of 54 new paintings and drawings by Miss Ethel Walker, at the Lefevre Galleries, IA, King Street, St. James's, Shelley's remark that to go to him for a fact was like going to a
gin shop for a leg of mutton is recalled.l This is not to say that Miss Walker's work is alcoholic or that she flouts the facts of nature, but only that she works by distillation rather than by carving. From whatever she finds in nature she distils the essence in its values of tone and colour, and her work is to be judged and enjoyed accordingly and not as an exercise for the teeth.
In the case of a less experienced artist a smaller exhibition than this might have been advisable, but Miss Walker has reached a stage in her career when everything she does is to be accepted with gratitude for what it gives-and a wise tolerance of what it does not. More truly than of any other contemporary artist can it be said that her defects are the defects of her qualities. If there be a general and characteristic defect in her work it is that she is inclined to neglect that machinery of the picture which is a consideration preliminary to painting. For lack of that machinery the large painting of the nude, " The Bather," looks rather helpless. On the other hand " Models Resting " shows that, when it comes to her at once, Miss Walker can make a completely satisfactory composition of large-scale figures. It is possible that if the shadows about the legs of the farther figure had been a little lighter in tone the implied space in depth between the two figures would have been more consistent with their difference in scale, but otherwise the composition is as logical as it is pleasing. A special word is due to Miss Walker's treatment of the nude in general. She excels everybody in the kind of sublimation which excludes the animal but preserves the human being, and not the least attractive thing about " Models Resting " is the effect of a human as well as a pictorial relationship between them.
With a few landscapes, of which "The White Village" is a delightful example, the exhibition consists of portraits, nudes, flower paintings, and marines, but whatever the subject there is the same presentation of essence rather than facts. As may be seen in " M. Lucien Pissarro, Resting," and " Tom Moossom, Fisherman," Miss Walker can paint men, but it is questionable if her qualities are not most fully expressed in her portraits of young women. " Nicolette " is an exquisite example. Among the flower paintings " Contrejour " and " Flowerpiece " may be picked out, and among the marines " Seapiece, an August Morning " and "April Storm." Miss Walker is a poet with the brush. She may supply matter for the argumentative-like the Scotsman reading " Paradise Lost "-but in matters of taste, feeling, and colour she never lets you down.
At the same galleries there is an exhibition of 26 pieces of sculpture by Miss Dorothy Charol. By far the best things among them are the small bronze, "Horror," which shows interesting contrary movement, and the two terra-cottas, " Supplication " and " Dream," which have a Tanagra quality. Miss Charol's efforts at stylization do not inspire enthusiasm.
MR. JOHN NASH
Mr. John Nash is to be congratulated on his present exhibition of 35 new watercolours at the Goupil Gallery, 3-5, Burlington Gardens, which gives a more complete impression of his talent than we have had before, His work has always shown great sensibility and a poetical appreciation of landscape for its own sake, irrespective of human association, but hitherto it has been a little lacking in the qualities that distinguish the work of his brother, -Mr. Paul Nash. In these water-colours he adds to his poetry a more intellectual grasp:of both landscape structure and the form of the picture. It is not a-case of imiitation but of clarifying his own aims, with the result of sharpening, if anything, the temperamental differences between the two artists. It is evident, for example, that though he gives sufficient indications of depth, as in "Corner of a Field, Wiston," Mr. John Nash js not acutely interested in threedimensional composition but rather in the surface pattern of the picture, in which he shows a fertile invention, with unexpected rhythms. He is particularly happy with the clean spaces of snow and sand dunes, as in " Snow," " Winter," " The Frozen Pond, Meadle," and" Sand Dune, Matterhorn"; otherwise preference -geherally goes to the water-colours in which the landscape is seen through a screen of trees, such as " Wood on the Beach, Penmaen," " In the New Forest," and " Woods by the Shore, Gowver."

Title: Poetry And Politics
Full_text:
POETRY AND POLITICS AN AMERICAN WRITER'S PROGRESS
AN AMERICAN TESTAMENT: A Narrative
of Rebels and Romantics. By JOSEPH FREEMAN. Gollancz. 16s.
" If I have ventured to recount certain personal experiences," declares Mr. Freeman, " it has been on the assumption that they might be of interest to those who want to know how an American writer, starting from one set of social, moral, and literary values, may arrive at another; how he may develop from romanticism to reality." In fact, his book is all personal experience, nearly 600 pages of straight autobiography, and since the only " reality" he now recognizes is that acknowledged in modern Moscow his narrative is in essence the story of his slow but surc discovery of and confirmation in Marxism.
Its appeal, though, is broader than that might suggest, for he is concerned to show the whole background of living which shaped his development, and he writes with a ready and able pen, whether describing his Ukrainian childhood (too shortly), the New York slums where his boyhood and youth were passed, his student development as Socialist and poet, his years of journalism which included a working visit to Europe, his wide range of acquaintanceship among American radicals and bohemians, and his visits to Russia and to Germany, where, in 1927, his story for the time being ends. The names of Randolph Bourne, Charles A. Beard, Isadora Duncan, Max Eastman, Floyd Dell, Upton Sinclair, Norman Thomas, Michael Gold, Scott Nearing. Mavakovsky, Eisenstein, Trotsky, and Stalin will help to plot the book's broad range and interest.
It is as it stands the record of the progress and resolution of the conflict in one man's mind between poetry and politics, and if one finds the final integration forced it is not because one is personally unable to accept it but because the writing itself grows less living, more prone to special pleading. In truth, one feels. the poet has less joined hands with the politician than regrettably agreed to submit himself to the other's orders.

Author: Null
Title: Words For Music
Full_text:
Entertainments
W WORDS FOR MUSIC
THE LYRICS OF HENRY
NEWBOLT
It is symptomatic of the habit of segregating the arts that a long obituary notice of Henry Newbolt contained no reference to his songs as such. " I did not know he was a musician," someone may say, and the answer is that he was not. But he was one of the few poets of the present day who could write poems which come to life when they are sung. Not all lyric poems have that quality. Some of the finest in the English language tempt the musical composer only to defeat him and his colleague, the singer. They read like songs and the literary critic expatiates
on their musical charm, but the moment the composer begins his search for the right tune he discovers that they have no need of one. The rhythm is too irregular, the imagery too rich, the thought too condensed. The poem is so complete in itself that it will not bear the musician's touch, however delicately applied. He may coax it into becoming a song by an artistry too subtle for the comprehension of the generality of singers. or it may lure him to the use of technical artifices which defeat their own end. The result is artificiality. This accounts for the fact that most of the great songs of the world, from Purcell to Brahms, have been settings of words which a fastidious taste condemns as at best second-rate poetry, while the unfastidious public clings to the false doctrine that
So long as the tune has a r iglht good swving, It doesn't much matter what words you sing.
It was Stanford who discovered that Newbolt's verse had in it the makings of fine song. The verse mattered: it had character and purpose and a charm of its own, but it was not filled too full. It offered a stimulating suggestion to the musician and lent wings to his melodv. When the Songs of the Sea" were prodttced at a Lceds Festival 34 years ago the apostles of musical advance wrote them down as cheap and obvious because Stanford had caught the essentials of the poems and the first essential was a simplehearted sentiment. The lyric in each case yielded up the right tune to the composer easilv enough, at least so it seemed to the listener. One cannot read " Drake's Drum " and " The Old Superb " now without hearing Stanford's music. Words and music so belong to one another that one is almost persuaded that the poet wrote his verses with Stanford's tunes running in his head. These poems seemed to offer the composer an easy success. But let the rash critic who thinks that try what he can do with one of the sea ballads which Stanford did not set. He will soon find what need they had of the composer's genius, that anyone less sensitive to the implications of words than Stanford will inevitably overstress the obvious sentiment and turn the song into a bald banalitv.
If these particular songs are not as popular as they were in the first 20 years of their life, that is because the present generation has grown afraid of the rattle of Drake's Drum for reasons which have nothing to do with the artistic merits of the songs themselves. But there are others both in this set and in its later companion " Songs of the Fleet" which strike deeper. " Homeward Bound" and " Farewell," to name one from each set, are songs the poems of which would live by themselves, but they are greatly enriched by the music which thev inspired. Such a line as
Soft as old sorrow, bright as old renown
needs music, and just such music as the composer found, fornits fulfilment.
Many of Newbolt's songs were written in the hope that they would find muisic. which distinguishes them from those lyrics written to make a music of their own. A few were written with the definite purpose of providing a text for the musician. That is always a purpose dangerous to the poet, but Newbolt could surmount the danger. He did so very largely in the libretto of the opera The Travelling Coinipanion, which he wrote at' Stanford's request, for whatever is unsatisfactory in that work is due to inexperience of what is necessary to the construction of a stage play, not to any weakness in the lyrical portions. The unsullied freshness of the girls' chorus "All in a morning glory," and the Princess's song in the second act, show Newbolt at his best, and those numbers brought Stanford up'to his best.
The poem called "The Wandercr" in the collected volume is also a song written to order,, though no one who reads it for the first time there would guess that it was. Many years ago a composer, not Stanford this time but Walford Davies, and Newbolt's own particular singer, Harry Plunket Greene, were planning a song cycle together and trying to do it without the collaboration of a living poet. The English poets from Shakespeare to Robert Browning were drawn on, for the thing was to be not so much a cycle as a suite, contrasted songs linked by. a certain sequence of thought. But a hitch came where something in the nature of a light and buoyant scherzo was needed,for.which no words were forthcoming. Most of the poems were chosen and the music composed, but when the series was tried over in private the need for the scherzo was felt by all who heard them. Then Greene said, " I wonder if Newbolt could write something," and the result was "To youth there comes a whisper out of the West." It is a perfect little song in two four-line stanzas, each of which is shaped for melody with a climax in the last line. When the song cycle was produced in public it was the most successful of the series, which suggests that song is liable to contradict the proverb that two is company and three none. When the poet, the composer, and the singer are good company song flourishes. Newbolt's spark of poetic genius glowed most brightly in company with the musicians.

THE POETRY OF HEINE
Thic story of Hcinrich Heine, told on Saturclay ni-ht by Count Alfred Hcssenstcin and illustiatcd by Schumann's music, might have piovided a golden opportunity for introducing new listeners to the charm of German Lieder. Instead Cotnt Hcsscnstcin addressed himself to those whlo alrcady knew Heine's poems and Schtimann's music, and no song.or poem was quotcd in its cntirety nor a full translation ofTered when hc quoted the originals. Even those listencrs who havc loved the Dichrterliebe as long as they can remember, must have felt a pang of disappointmcnt at this curtailing of the songs, and it seems doubtful if those who did not know German got any really clear idea of them. This was a pity, as Count Hiessenstcin has a talent for invoking the spirit of charm and pathos of the romantic movement.

The lovely song about Cologne Cathedral and Lochner's Dombild was however quoted too carly in the broadcast, as though it werc merely a description of the Rhine, instead of a marvellous transcription into music of the sight of the great Cathedral reflected in the river. Author: Null
Title: Modern Verse
Full_text:
MODERN VERSE -
MR. YEATS'S ANTHOLOGY
THE OXFORD BOOK OF MODERN VERSE,
1892-1935. Chosen by W. B. YEATS. Oxford: Clarendon Press. London: Milford. 8s. 6d.
By a happy inspiration the Oxford Press. has chosen whom many would choose as the greatest liying poet for the editor of the volume which brings down to the present day the series of Oxford Books of Verse.
Mr. Yeats contributes not only some of the finest poems included in the book, but also an introduction which is a brilliant and penetrating essay on English poetry during the last half century. He is magisterial in his justification of the principles on which his selection has been made. He rejects, for instance, a large body of "War" poems on the ground that " passive suffering is not a theme for poetry," and justifies his ruthless abridgment of the "Ballad of Reading GaolU' with the words "my work gave me that privilege." In that case, the poem as he prints it is his vindication; but he is less happy in his treatment of Pater's famous Mlona Lisa passage, which, presented as a piece of vers libre, seems jerky in its rhythm, in spite of a textual alteration evidently intended to accommodate it to its new form. The device was necessary, however, if the passage was to be included in this anthology, and Mr. Yeats was evidently resolved by placing it in the forefront of the book to acclaim Pater as in some sense the inaugurator of modern poetry, in the comprehensive sense in which the phrase is used in the title of this volume.
It may surprise some readers to find in a book with this title poems by Dowson and Wilde, Henley and Wilfrid Scawen Blunt, as well as poems by Mr. Eliot, Miss Sitwell, and Mr. Dav Lewis; but Mr. Yeats rightly claims that " even a longlived man has the right to call his own contemporaries modern "; and the period which the book embraces-from "The Hound of Heaven " till after " The Waste Land "-falls within the lifetime of men now living. Moreover, the revolution which inaugurated the period-the liberation of poetry by writers of Mr. Yeats's generation from the "impurities" of politics and morality-was as important as any of the changes which have transformed poetry so bewilderingly during the last quarter of a century.
Mr. Yeats writes with penetrating insight of the different influences at work in poetry during the period he discusses, and with remarkable sympathy of some of its latest developments. Those who would cavil at his principles of selection, or at the high arguments with which he justifies them, may reflect that any ordinary man can be mechanical, and that greatness, even whgre it is wilful, is given us to learn from, not to teach.

Title: King George's Reign In Verse And Music
Full_text:
Entertainments
KING GEORGE'S REIGN IN VERSE AND MUSIC TRIBUTE OF THE. B.B.C.
Last night the B.B.C. paid in English verse and English music a tribute to the life and memory of King George V. At the first thoughi it did not seem possible that a'concrete idea of what King George was to his country and his people could be constructed out of ternis in poetry and music that have no specific reference to him, but such is the wealth of English poetry and the inspiration, infrequent, perhaps, but so audible when it is there, in English music that at the end of the hour it seemed almost as though the poets and musicians, the dead and the living, had collaborated with each other in full consciousness to give shape and expression to the character of King George and the eventful history of his reign.
Four Sovereigns of England stood out before King George, announced the prologue; Alfred, for whom spoke Mr. G. K. Chesterton in his " Ballad of the White Horse " ; Henry V and Elizabeth, who had Shakespeare as their interpreter; and Victoria, with Tennyson as her Laureate. The broadcast followed on without any break for a specific commentary. King %George's love of the sea and the growing idea of Empire wore represented by extracts from the works of that- great Englishman who died such a little time before his King, Rudyard Kipling, and the approach to the Great War found its echo in 'the symbolism of music and the equally majestic music of the Bible. The broadcast reached its greatest height in the minutes it attempted to convey something of the feeling, not only for the cause for which the country was fighting, but for the land, the land of hedgerows and little fields and quiet hills which the English volunteer army left for other and alien shores. A poem by the present Poet Laureate which he wrote in August, 1914, a poem in which he found a precise and perfect expression' for his love of the Berkshire Downs, was followed by one by Wilfrid Owen, perhaps the greatest of all the poets slain in the War. Rupert Brooke might well have found his way into the noble band of those who spoke for England and their King, for the work he did in the early davs of the War mirrored with a crystal intensity the mood of passionate idealism in which the'young, untried manhood of the country went to battle.
The end of the War, the trials and anxieties of the transition period, and the steady mounting of the love of the people and the prestige of the Crown until the glorious triumph of the Silver Jubilee was reached, was expressed last night in the words of Mr. Siegfried Sassoon's " Everybody Burst Out Singing," which, although it was written for another occasion, caught the exultant gaiety of the time. The passage from Ecclesiastes, " Remember now thv Creator in the days of thy youth," and a number of lines from Wordsworth's " The Happy Warrior" brought the broadcast towards its close, which was finally reached with a verse from Kipling which by implication commemorated the Queen, as some verses from the Psalms had done earlier, and with some lines by Mr. R. Ellis Roberts, .who was .responsible for the arrangement of the broadcast, which ended with the words, "This man wvas England."
The music of Elgar, Gibbons, Sullivan, Vaughan Williams, Parry, and Purcell gave the right background to this story of the Throne of England and of the life of one of its most beloved Sovereigns, but it was the spoken word of the poets which gave it at once its majesty and its intimacy. The thunder of the Biblical cadences and the musings of Thomas Hardy as he walked his Wessex lanesKing George moved in the spirit of both and both had helped to make his England. The verse was eloquently, but not too eloquently, spoken by Mr. Felix Aylmer, Mr. Laidman Browne, Mr. Robert Farquharson, Miss Lilian Harrison, Mr. Ralph Richardson. Mr. Robert Speaight, and Mr. Ion Swinley.

Author: Null
Title: East Anglia In Verse
Full_text:
Books of the Week
Continued from page 6
EAST ANGLLI IN
VERSE
BALLADS, SONGS, AND
RHYMES
BALLADS, SONGS, AND RHYMES OF EAST
ANGLIA. Arranged with Notes by A. S. HARVEY. (Norwich: Jarrold. London: Simpkin, Marshall. 5s.)
Among the many pleasant and useful forms which local patriotism may take is the collection of poetry and verse connected with a particular part of England. Mr. Harvey's East Anglian anthology is compiled upon the principle of giving, where possible, entire poems, or at least fairly long extracts; and his collection is arranged under three heads: Early Ballads; Songs and Rhymes of the Peasantry; and Modern Ballads.
The folk-songs which he records include versions of such well-known things as " The Sprig of Thyme," " TwentyEighteen," " The Thresherman and the Squire," and "The Tree in the Valley " (here called " The Immutable Tree "). But much the most remarkable of them is the strangely beautiful old ballad that begins:-
My father was the first good man
Who tied me to a stake;
My mother was the first good woman
Who did the fire make.
My brother was the next good man Who did the fire fetch;
My sister was the next good woman
Who lighted it with a match.
They blew the fire, they kindled the fire,
Till it did reach my knee;
0 mother, mother, quench the fire-
The smoke will smother me !
East Anglia has been peculiarly lucky in being the setting for many of our best ballad stories. There was the Battle of Maldon, in 991, which furnishes the gallant tale of Brihtnoth's defence against the Danes, and of his death at their hands. There are the ballads associated with the shrine of the Virgin at Walsingham. There is the immortally touching legend of " The Babes in the Wood," whose father,
A gentleman of good account,
In Norfolk dwelt of late
Who did in honour far surmount
Most men of his cstate.
As for the pieces of known authorship, they, too, include many celebrated narrative verses. Was not Boadicea, " bleeding from the Roman rods," as Cowper sang, Queen of most of what is now East Anglia ? It was in a Norfolk town, too, that the Yorkshire murderer, Eugene Aram, was arrested, as Tom Hood so dramatically wrote: -
That very night, while gentle sleep,
The urchin's eyelids kissed,
Two stern-faced men set out from Lynn
Through the cold and heavy mist; And Eugene Aram walked between,
With gyves upon his wrist.
These poems Mr. Harvey quotes in full, and he gives also two gently pleasing ballads by the almost forgotten peasant poet of the early nineteenth century, Robert Bloomfield. Nor have legends of the Eastern Counties failed to find modern poets and versifiers, represented here, to tell them once again.

Title: New Books At The Week-End
Full_text:
NEW BOOKS AT THE
WEEK-END
" THE TIMES LITERARY
SUPPLEMENT"
The newest books irt their variety from tiction to biography, history, politics, and belles lettres are surveyed in the current issue of The Times Literary Supplement, which in its new and enlarged form is now published at the week:end-to enable readers during their leisure to keep abreast of literary affairs.
Two books on eighteenth-century nature poetry provide the theme, in the leading article, of an original examination of the poetic diction of the English "Augustan Age." The writer, while not defending the age from the assaults of the later romanticists, insists on the necessity of that much criticized diction to embody the poets' conception of man's control of nature. If the use of " Augustan " phrases is properly understood, the argument runs, the effectiveness of the poetry made out of them may be seen for what it was.
The new novels reviewed include Miss Mary Ellen Chase's " Silas Crockett " and an English translation of " The House of Cosinsky," by Peter Mendelssohn. The intellectual evolution of M. Romain Rolland is discussed in a criticism of his " I Will Not Rest," in which the French author makes a selection from his writings to illustrate his political progress from detachment
above the battle " to advocacy of Communism. Other books reviewed include " The Governments of the British Empire," by Professor Keith; Mr. F. J. Harvey Darton's study of village life, " English Fabric " Mr. J. W. Linn's biography of Jane'Addams; ' The Strange Life Story-of Willy Clarkson,".by H. J. Greenwall; " Catalogue of Books Printed in the Fifteenth Century Now in the British Museum "; " The Chbster Beatty Biblical Papyri " and". A ThirdCentury. Papyrus Codex of the Epistles of Paul " - " A Book of Battles." by George Philip Baker; and a translation, with some extensions, of H. H. Ploss's work on " Woman."
Among the attractive feajtures of the Literary Supplement in its new form are the illustrations which accompany some of the articles. The currcnt number is available to-day from all town and country booksellers and newsagents, price 3d.

Title: Missing The Poetry In Shakespeare
Full_text:
MISSING THE POETRY IN
SHAKESPEARE
A HINT TO ACTORS
Mr. GUY BOAS, in a lecturc on -A fundamental defect in professional productions of Shakespeare " to mcmbers of the Elizabethan Literary Society at King's Collegc, Strand, last night, said that Shakespeare's plays were grcat poctry, the most beautiful poetry that had so far hccn written. In Shakespeare's poetry the human heart inl all its moods found perfect expression, and that was the verse which the Shakespearian actor or actress had not only to speak, but to feel and understand and interpret.
B.ut there were players, many of them highly distinguished, who did not even try to speak Shakespeare's verse as poetry, but who, suffering from an obsession that they must be intellectual or realistic, muttered their lines as if they were twentieth-century prose.
The quality in Shakespeare which no English audience could stand up against, provided that it was properly administered, was the mesmerizing spell of the poetry.
Among professors of English and the English staffs of universities and schools there were many Shakespearian scholars who, though they lacked theatrical technique, possessed just that Doetic sensibility which was required. If Mr. Basil Dean or Mr. Bridges Adams, before producing a Shakespeare play, werc able to invite Sir Artiltir Quiller-Couch or Professor Dovcr Wilson to read the play over withi the cast for two or threc days beforc rehearsing began, with a view to communicating the thrill and magic and ring of the poetry, what a transtigtired pzrfornnancc they wotild get.

Author: Null
Title: Mr. De LA Mare On Poetry And Prose
Full_text:
MR. DE LA MARE ON POETRY
- AND PROSE
The postponed Warton Lecture by Mr. Walter -de la Mare on ' Poetry in Prose " was given yesterday at the British Academy. The PRESIDENT (Dr. J. W. Mackail) was in (ihe chair. Mr. DE LA MARE said that many familiar definitions of poetry apply almost equally well to an imaginative prose, and technical devices invariably associated with verse are habitually present in good prose. Even metre, the only specific technical distinction-apart from recurrent rhyme-between prose and verse is frequently perceptible in gobd prose, though it becomes a defect as soon as it is apparent, or when it is obviously unintentional. The modern tendeniy to restrict the ideal of prose to what may be roughly described as the prosaic-the logical, plain, and severe-may be a definite handicap to young imaginative and original writers of our own day who are aware of it and who yet are unable to express themselves freely and fully in verse.

Author: Wallis, J. P. R.
Title: A Literature In The Making
Full_text:
A LITERATURE IN
THE MAKING
ENGLISH AND AFRIKAANS
INFLUENCE OF NEW ENVIRONMIENT2
By Professor J. P. R. Wallis
M OST discussions of Anglo-South
African poetry start from Mr. A 4 Rudyard Kipling's obiter dictum which'. the sometime President of Magdalene caught up into his chapter in the concluding volume of the Cambridge History of Literature. The laureate of Imperialism, when asked ,what South African poetry there was besides his own, replied: " As to South African verse, it's a case of there's Pringle and there's Pringle, and after that one must hunt the local papers, There is also, of course, F. W. Reitz's Afrikaanse Gedigte, songs and parodies 'in the Taal, which are very characteristic." It is matter for regret that Sir Herbert Warren, who had done much lecturing upon the literature of the Dominioris, allowed this judgment to influence hinm so far as to limit his " autoschediastic " survey to Thomas Fringle all but exclusively. For the opinion upon which he justified himself in his own eyes is no more true than that Mr. Kipling is a South African poet.
The insurmountable obstacle in the way of those who would discourse of South African literature is that as yet it does not exist. There is a Union, but it has not unity in any. intimate spiritual sense of the word. It still speaks with two voices, and neither carn claim to express the whole. But nothing is here for tears or perturbation. But the furnaces and anvils of Los, as Blake would have said, in the fashioning of the generations of men, condense an age into a hammer-stroke, and know nothing of our fume and fret for" results." So the dispassionate observer, privileged spectator of a fascinating phase of evolution, sees in the rivalries of the twin tendencies, tP e English and the Afrikaans, not an antagonism but a composition of forces, whereof the resultant is neither one nor the other, but a diagonal into which both are merged equably. Therefore, in dealing here chiefly of .English developments in South African literature there is no hint that it is greater or less than its compeer, still less any vain essay to prophesy that in the end this or this will emerge supreme.
IN EARLY TIMES
To, revert then, to the early chapter of the story, which need not take us farther back than the middle decades of the last ccntury, 'so recent it is. Much has been made of the criticism that colonial literaturec.is. mainly derivative. This is, and, of c6urse, must be, a consideration that makes it all the more interesting. Literature'is no plant that thli,ves in new soil. It requires rich depths, age-long accumulations-of association and tradition, native and inalienable. When, therefore, it is s'6t in another hemisphere, under another sun, and in an entirely novel environment, it presents fascinating problems in what may be called literary ecology. To those who come from the riches of the opulent
North what South Africa offers may seerrflike poverty itself. But to look closer is to see and appreciate processes that are not only interesting in themselves but that by contrast throw into fresh relief factors in the aesthetic life of the Old World which are too little regarded. There are compensations, too, in being permitted to study a literature in the making.
In the early times, that chronologically are so incredibly near, the modest civilization of the Cape Peninsula (which was all that counted then) was a simple and isolated thing, with its remoteness accentuated by the tardiness of communications. And, reading the signs, one gathers that' the sense of strangeness, almostjpf exile, was stronger than that of intimacy evenrin acommunity numerically small and inevitably thrown into close contact. When, therefore, the desire for self-expression' asserted itself, it was natural that the spirit, overleaping the sundering leagues, should return to the familiar modes. This, indeed, is true of later singers, nor is their work the- less South African therefor.
Unfortunately no one has yet undertaken to tell 'in anything like detail the literary history gf these early years. The late-Professor John' Clark, of Capetown University, had the work in hand, but it was left unfinished at his death. The material, too, is not easily come by. Many of the slim volumes; often the products of local and homely presses, have dropped out of sight, and the search through contemporary newspapers and magazines is laborious and not often rewarded by finds of notable worth. Still it ought to be done, a work of love for some devout South African. Part of the interest will ie in the recovery of picturesque life-histories. There is, to cite a minor example, the case of Stafford Cruickshanks, "late of the Grenadier -Guards," as he declares on his first title-page. One of a numerous and hard-pressed Irish family, he narrowly' escapedremigration to America as a child, had little schooling of the formal kind, escaped from the drudgery of unpromising occupations'. by enlisting, served in the China wars, and then came to the Cape, where he seems to have spent most of his time in the Grahamstown district. He was an ardent missioner in the cause Qf temperance, and his zeal therein informs much of his, verse. For all his poetic ambition-he put out four cantos of rhymed couplets on " Predestination "- he is at his best little more than facile, and shows' most effectively in light tale or topical satire.
HENRY FOOT
There is more of culture and " taste "- the - outmoded word best denotes the quafity-in " makers " like Henry Martyn Foot, a Nonconformist parson who left Devon in search of health, and towards the end held the chair of English Litera-
ture and Philosophy in the South African College. As in his successors, John Noble and John Clark, a shrewd wit and masculine good sense brace his style, and if it can scarcely be said to soar, it does at least march briskly. Or there was Mrs. M. E. Barber, born Bowker, by descent and by marriage connected with two families who have left their marks on local history. She
had An earnest and'tuneful gift, and may be taken as one of the earliest of a long
line of women writers whose work graces if it does not exalt South Africa's poetic achievement.
The editorial rule that living writers may not appear in the Cambridge History excluded many veterans, like Dr. Kolbe, from Sir Herbert Warren's survey. Coleridge, who heightened eulogy in praising Pringle, might, in a more candid mood, have been led to speak of these poets as being "like little potatoes-no great tlhings." But that will not quite do. They have their virtues-sincerity, thoughtfulness, and the senise of poetic values. Dr. Kolbe, for instance, is a singer of delicate fancy, light and flexible, and of a pleasant urbanity. The general reader can catch something of the savour of him and his fellows in E. H. Crouch's " Treasury of South African Poetry and Verse " and in the later " Centenary Book of South African Verse" by F. Carey Slater.
These little anthologies illustrate the broad differences between the early and what may be called the middle periods in South African verse. A concise statement
O:)n.W tss Pauli-nesaiuh's delicate talent had, as she herself tells, tobe coaxed into utterance by Arnold Bennett's fostering interest, but the result; her tiny sheaf of exquisite vignettes, justified him and her. Too many others, less sensitive, have overworked the elegiac mood, confounding it with the lugubrious, which South African life and character are not. In striking contrast stands the work of Mrs. Sarah Gertrude Millin. Alike in her novels, her discursivewritings, and in her notable study of Rhodes,her spare,tight-lipped style will concede nothing to easy and refracting sentiment. With her the bare dispassionate statement, judicially aloof, has to make its own way; the naked arrow-shaft, lightly
barbed and tightly feathered, best exemplifies her manner, which at times almost diverges into a mannerism. But if it is a weakness it is a good onie.
There is one vein that might be. explored to greater advantage than it has been. Mrs. Margaret Alston's "An Old Cape Homestead " illustrates the kind and its charm. There is much, overmuch, talk of South Africa's spell, but in general it stops there. The loving intimacy that gave England " The Compleat Angler" or
The Natural History of Selborne" or "Fallodon Papers," has given little token of its existence among South Africans, yet few peoples enjoy a heritage of richer promise in this kind. It is still much the same with her wonderful past. Only the politically minded have tapped it, and not for the highest purposes. The records of the first travellers, traders, hunters, and adventurers are brimful of every variety of interest, lying on the surface, ready to hand. But daily some precious portion drops away, with the passing of some old inhabitant, and few regard it. Fortunately there are signs of awakening conscience in this connexion, notably in the emergence into public recognition of the lifework of Dr. John G. Gubbins,-embodied in his rich collection, of Africana now housed in the University of Johannesburg.
DUTCH INLUENCE.-A farm at Schoongezikt, at one time owned by John X. Merrimaii. It is typical of those buil by the early Dutch settlers. The pictuire was taken during the visit of the Duke of Kent, then 'Prince George.
xhight niatc6f them ftrhspectevdY-wtfi"-tie early Victorian and the, primitive Edwardian modes. The latter works more in local colour of the primary sort, somewhat after the impressionist manner. The striking characteristics of the landscape, 4the novel accessories of life and the sounding names of things and places, as well as the piquant snatches of Afrikaans or of native speech help to adorn or to trick out verse, and there is temptation, not always withstood, to develop them into easy mannerisms. But the finer spirits are untouched, and their work is the richer. There is, to note one instance, Kingsley Fairbridge. The story of his brief, life, which has been published,
CAPETOWN.-A view looking up St; George's Street, at the far, end of which can be seen the Anglican Cathedral, the first English church in South Africa. St. Geor,ge's Street was known in 'the early days as Berg Street.
reveals the heroic reserves in the national character at its best, and his little sheaf of poetry, South African to the core, has a close concentration and " drive."
The older strands persist, a background to the new variegation of pattern. Sometimes the shuttle carries threads of alienseeming twist, yet they belong and are congruent. Charles Murray-" Hamewith " Murray-came from Aberdeen, bringing; his rugged northern dialect with him and the lilt of the northern tunes. Yet he is as South African in the fullest sense as any of " the sons of the soil." The country and his part in it set him singing "The Whistle " and " The Back o' Beyont" no less than " Hamewith."
Later English South African verse is as old-fashioned and as " modem " as English verse anywhere else the world over. It can match the newest vagaries, and parody them too, as Mr. John Ross, ol Kimberley, has done. Some day perhaps this retiring maker of -pleasant verses may be persuaded to admit the world at large to the enjoyment of what has hitherto been reserved to his friends.
Looking back over the course of this story one finds it easier to understand the work of Roy Campbell. It would seem as if he saw, or thought he saw, thatpoetry in the Union had fallen into a
bad rut of style aL. that a kind of spiritual in-breeding was most perniciously debilitating it,. What should have been a spirited adventure was sinking into a spinsterly hobby. Wherefore, after minor sallies, he plunged heels over head into a boisterous sea of verse and buffeted his way amazingly over or through the tumble and swirl of it in pursuit of his monstrous Behemoth of a theme. Now and- again it looks as if ne momentarily loses way, or comes near to foundering in the enormous turmoil. Buit it was a dashing enterprise, one of the most daring the country has Icnown. It stirred comment, not always of the wisest, and he retorted with his succession of satires in the Churchill vein. He castigates with gusto, wielding the lash with the same headlong dash that had gone to the chasing of the Terrapin. It is a pity that bot youth cared so little whether he flicked the offender or the inoffensive. Latterly he has turned aside to chase or bait other game, contenting his pen with exercises of slighter compass and quieter style, as in his "Flowering Reeds" and his " Broken Record," with its memorable glimpses of his early days in 'Natal and its attractive picture of his father.
Tnere is nothing to tell of the drama in a country where the commercial theatre is a monopoly and the repertory movement. a tentative affair. But in prose a wider reputation has been won. There are the famous names, with a goodly following of modestly respectable minors 'in the work-a-day modes. Olive Schreiner is already'a classic, with the world's implication of an over-readiness to take her fame and worth on trust. Sir Percy Fitzpatrick's memories and sketches are chiefly historical, but his "Jock of the Bushveld" holds its peculiar place unrivalled. No less memorable for swift incisiveness of narration and the generous spirit informing them are Colonel Deneys Reitz's " Commando " and its sequel, " Trekking

Author: Null
Title: Speech And Song
Full_text:
Entertainments
SPEECH AND SONG
THE POET'S LIVING
VOICE
Poets have recently shown an increasing anxiety lest their art should become a dead language, written and read but never spoken. M^r. Laurence Binyon's valuable article contributed to The Times Educationzal Suipplement of December 1 declares their anxiety and describes the means now taken to encourage the appreciation of poetry through " presentation of the poem in the living voice." Such presentation he maintains
can communicate a pleasure such as many who know poetry only on the printed page would never have expected. And if poetry is not enjoyed what is the use of learning it or teaching it ?
Every musician must sympathize with Mr. Binyon's argument and may take comfort from it for the comparatively backward condition of education in the " sight reading" of music. We are, perhaps, fortunate in the fact that few of us can read the score of the Ninth Symphony as easily as we read a speech from Shakespeare, and consequently our pleasure in it is dependent for the most part on our hearing of it. We are still a long way from having to defend music from becoming a dead language. The day may come when scores of the Beethoven Symphonies will be given as school prizes or issued by newspapers at special subscription rates to their readers on filling up a coupon. In that day musicians will have to take action similar to that which the Poet Laureate, Mr. Binyon, and the English Verse-Speaking Association are taking now. Meantime, all except a few overeducated specialists know that if they want to enjoy music they must play it or sing it, go to concerts, or at least buy a wireless set or a gramophone; they know at any rate that thev cannot get their enjoyment by reading in a book. Because of this music remains the art in widest popular cultivation.
The poets are taking example from the musicians and are attempting to organize the teaching of speech on lines similar to the teaching of song and instrumenl. Mr. Binyon alludes to " choral speaking " as " a recent development rich in possibilities." Just as there are many who cannot sing a song but can join in a chorus, so,
teachers in schools have discovered that many boys and girls are too shy to attempt a solo recitation, but when they have the support of cornpanions and are trained to speak as a team they lose their shyness and by degrees they gain the confidence to speak alone.
" Choral speaking, however, is not merely a tool in the hands of the educationist; it is claimed as an art to be cultivated for its own sake and capable of giving pleasure to the listener like choral music. Mr. Binyon testifies that certain performances of it heard at Oxford this year and last " carried the audience away and created an impression of quite unforgettable beauty." None will question the testimonv of so high an authority.
But classes of choral speech have been introduced into many of the- Competitive Musical Festivals throughout the country, and it may be questioned whether that is the most appropriate place for them. For the beauty of choral speech is a poetic beautv, not a musical one, and its technique of expression must depend on the avoidance of the characteristics of musical expression. The wisdom of hitching the poetic wagon to the musical star may be doubted. It can scarcely be possible to judge the quality of choral speech as a musician judges the singing of a part-song. Music is made out of strictly regulated pitch intervals and time values. The judge of the nartsong can say whether the choir sings the right notes in tune with a pure tone and with good balance betveen the parts. He can test the singers' accuracy in reproducing written time values and other factors of expression clearly indicated in the score. Over and above these he will keep a margin of marks for his approval of such matters of taste as are suggested by the terms "Interpretation" and " General Impression." But choral speech, *f it is to have any poetic beauty, must keep at arm's length all the technical processes of music. A ' sing-song voice," that is the approximation to the tones and rhythms of music, is the worst condemnation of the speaker. One has only to listen to a congregation saying the General Confession together in church to.realize how corporate speech tends to. become levelled to a monotone. The teacher of verse-speaking classes must, one imagines, expend a good deal of time in eradicating the monotone, preventing the voices from rising and falling together by strict intervals, and counteracting the tendency to let the metre of the verse take charge of the ensemble as time values control a musical ensenzble.
No doubt the skilled teacher understands how to cultivate this anti-musical technique, so essential to the beauty of spoken verse or prose, but the musician seems to be the last person likely to be a fit judge of an art so diametrically opposed in principle to his own. At an informal hearing lately one musician remarked that the male and female voices of a speech choir spoke a whole poem through in consecutive sevenths. His ear instinctively translated the natural pitches of their voices into musical relationships. Though the criticism was correct in itself it did not really touch the case, for the important thing is that speech should be at a pitch natural to each voice and not at an artificial or agreed one. If two voices naturally speak at the interval of a seventh the discord between them may mean everything to music and nothing to poetry.
Choral speech then must determine its own criteria, whatever these may be, must develop along its own lines, and above all avoid being treated as a kind of inferior or semi-articulate music. Let poets judge its progress. Musicians can watch sympathetically but cannot do much to help
in giving back the living voice to poetry save through the time-honoured process in which the two wed their " divine sounds and mixed power employ."

Title: The Poetry And Art Of William Morris
Full_text:
THE POETRY AND ART OF
WILLIAM MORRIS
LYCEUM CLUB TRIBUTE
The Poetry Circle of the Lyceuni Club held a dinner last night at 9, Chesterfield Gardens in honour of the poetry and art of William Morris. Miss May Morris, a daughter of William Morris, attended. Miss Sibyl Bristowe president of the Poetry Circle, presided.
Miss MORRIS said that she hoped her father would not go down to posterity as a decorative poet. Often he sacrificed whole passages of good verse in order to improve his work. He was a serious verseman who fouhd metre eminently suited to his purpose. He was a very shy man, though he lived a ttue artist's life.
Mr. SrURGE MOORE said that the fatct that so much of Rossetti's work had been saved was due to Morris. Morris's social and political ideas were proving sounder than was long supposed and were to-day receiving endorsement from the new economists.
Responding to the toast of the guests, pro-
posed by the CHAIRMAN, Mr. RICHARD CHURCH
said he had bcen shown letters by an old lady living at Parsons Green which were written by Morris as a schoolboy to her father, who had been a servant in the Morris family at Woodford. Title: English Verse-Speaking Association
Full_text:
ENGLISH VERSE-SPEAKING
ASSOCIATION
FESTIVAL AT OXFORD
Ine tngltsti Verse-Speaking Association, which was formed three years ago to cultivate the intelligent appreciation of poetry, will again include in this year's festival at Oxford a series of versespeaking competitions.
Mr. Laurence Binyon, Mr. Gordon Bottomley, and Mr. Richard Church will be among the judges, and the classes will include the speaking of lyric, narrative, dramatic, and light verse, choral speaking, and Bible reading. The poets represented at the festival will be Thomas Nashe, Samuel Daniel, Shakespeare, Milton, Dryden, Pope, John Clare, Browning, Swinburne, and Francis Thompson.
While not aiming at a rigid standardization of any one variety of fine speech, or at interference with such things as the vowel idiosyncrasie3s of regional speech, the English Verse-Speaking Association has as one of its objects the evolution of a standard of practice in right speaking that shiall command the assent of all teachers and practitioners. The speaking of verse has, of course important connexions with the theatre; but it is hoped that the forthcoming festival will show clearly that these do not consist in making verse theatrical, but, rather, in bringing the atmosphere of poetry into drama.
The festival will be held in the Taylor Institu. tion, Oxford, from July 25 to July 27. Entries for the verse-speaking competitions will close on June 16.

Author: FROM OUR MUSIC CRITIC
Title: Music Fructified By Poetry
Full_text:
MUSIC FRUCTIFIED
BY POETRY
WAGNERIAN TRADITION AT
AlMSTERDAM
FROM OUR MUSIC CRITIC
AMSTERDAM, JUNE 14
Halewvijnl, a symphonic drama in nine scenes, with music by Willem Pijper, was produced last night by the Wagner Society of Amsterdam in the Mlunicipal Theatre. and conducted by M. Pierre Monteux. The production supplied the dramatic element in the Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music. The music is to some extent, though not solely, of that type which the International Society fosters; the drama and the relation between it and the music is wholly suited to the ideals of a Wagner Society. It is founded on a national folk legend which nay be read as an allegory. Halewiin is a wizard whose song enthrals all womankind. The king's daughter meets with him in the forest and, though warned that to follow him means death, nothing will deter her.
Her maidens dress her regally for the adventure, and she goes forth alone. H-alewijn offers her the choice of a halter or a sword. She chooses the latter and artfully persuades him to leave it, a little carelessly, it seems, within her reach. While the King's daughter loves the artist, she is without illusions about the man, and, seizing the sword, she pursues him to his lair, to return triumphantly bearing aloft the head of Halewijn. You may slay the man, but not the song, Halewijn's mother declares; and so, though the King's daughter returned to-the castle just as the family were' giving her up for lost, and indeed deposited the head of Halewijn in the very centre of the family dinner-table, a vision of the wizard himself appeared above the King's seat, singing the immortal song which obliterates courts and crowns. Moreover, the song which the composer has put into -the mouth of Halewijn is no triumph of contemporary art; it is a tune, plain and good, and perhaps that carries the moral for the International Society to ponder over.
Those of us who are still good Wagnerians, that is, old-fashioned and romantic minded, could enjoy Halewijn frankly and without misgiving. Here is music fructified by poetry, or perhaps poetry fructified by music. Anyhow, the two belong to one another, and Pijper's orchestra is discreet, hinting at tragedy in eloquent interludes between the scenes, welling up round the more lyrical utterances of Halewijn himself, delivered in the rich baritone of Mr. Sydney de Vries, and receding to a mere thread of sound while the King's daughter intones rather than sings her contribution to the dialogue. Miss Lisbet Sanders-Herzberg presented both in voice and manner the pcrfect picture of clearsighted maidenhood.
Specially attractive was the distant musical accompaniment to the robing scene. The imaginative stage pictures, the rich costumes, and the ungarnished fashion of the dialogue set into the symphonic texture, all tended to recall the collaboration of Debussy and Maeterlirick in Pelleas, though the score itself, of which M. Monteux and the Utrecht orchestra gave an extraordinarily sympathetic reading, bears no direct trace of Debussy's ipersonal characteristics. Possibly it may be suggested 'that the story, which enibraces the qualities of the Pied Piper of Hamelin, Bluebeard,,and-Judith, with-the head of Holofernes in something of the atmosphere of "The Immortal Hour," calls for a more robust musical style than that of Willem Pijper's choice. As a contemporary the composer is a little afraid of romanticism, but still he is subject to its spell. And this may be the interpretation of the parable. Contemporary music awaits a king's daughter who is not afraid.

Title: Lamb And His Friends
Full_text:
-Books of the Day
LAMB AND HIS
FRIENDS
. .
MR. BLUNDEN'S STUDY
;HARLEs LAMB AkND HIS CONTEMPOR4RIES
By EDLMuND BLUNDEN. (Cambridge University Press. 7s. 6d: net.)
*Mr. Blunden has somewhere defined: criticism as* "at its finest a secondary poetry." If the suggestion is'soun'd,he wrote, "then Lamb is probably -the chiefof critics." Lamb was an .ess'aist -first, and Mr. Blunden is first a poet. It is im-' material. Both have brought to their interpretation of others.at once the intuition and the music of poetry-qualities: possessed by Hazlitt (for all his indiscipline)'and in our own day by Mrs. Woolf, -but by too few among professed critics. We can only wonder that Edmund Blunden has not written of Charles Lamb before; - wonder, and be grateful that, to adapt a phrase of Elia's, the two points are now miraculously co-united.
Illustration is well-nigh impossible. We can but compare Lamb's verbal explications of Titian and Raphael, even of Hogarth, with Mr. Blunden's brief impressions of the. Essays in a passage beginiiing:-
From them, as though from a scrics of novels -and. it is hard that Lamb did not for once act on Wordsworth's advice-a number of spirits or figuresbhaeve found their way into the hearts of. ,the English and Anmerican reading worlds.. Elia himself-not Lamb precisely, but dressed very much like Lamb in black, with "' immaterial legs " tidily gaitered-is not allowed to die; he stOOps along past every file of London schoolchildren, fearing to be taken for a governor," and is in every old college library, smiling at the erudition of this queer race....
(This is the Lamb of whom Mr. Blunden has " formed a notion that he begins to be neglected.") And Lamb's recovery from .the paralysis that Mary's madness and his mother's death induced isso explained:-
Presently a deeper perception of the crisis grew in him, who had in childhood been more ready than most to shape himself to and beyond his restraints and privations. He saw the future in the light of the excellence of his sister, and thec happiness of his bzeing enabled to minister to tisat cxccliencc Thus rising from his desolalion, Lamb gently resumed some measure of his
p6 ast vanities.b --
It is then suggested-and the claim is a large one-that only this tragedy prevented his " ripening into a masterly and continued accomplishment of verse, and ranking in authority,of performance with Coleridge and Wordsworth."
But if Mr. Blunden, like Elia, dedicates no inconsiderable portion of his time to other people's thoughts, he does not nmerely, here at any rate, dream away his life in others' speculations. We read him because weare sure he will illumine much in Elia the essayist that we have missed. There is learning also in these seven short chapters. If Mr. Lucas has left little of biographical fact to be recorded, Mr. Blunden, approaching from another quarter, has turned over and over the books Lamb read, the books his friends wrote, and other less promising things in .books' clothing. Joseph Paice, of Bread Street Hill, merchant-Lamb's first employer-is revealed, " his memory stored with poetic treasures of the Elizabethan era "; Lockhart (who thought " Elia" good, but "John Woodvil" better) approving the "Speci-
mens ; Coleridge and his friend together annotating the margins of Basil Montagu; and Lamb himself, for.on'ce out of temper, rebuffing an importunate Godwin. Mr. Blunden' is perhaps too allusive, too little precise. We suspect that behind the smooth succession of his apt phrases lies a mass of sources unexplored before-marginal . notes, letters, magazines, forgotten memoirs. But' in'Athe' critical passages-and "the biographical element is mainly confined to the needs of. a critical., theme "-this allusiveness, which shows a. mind impreg-nated with the Elian, makes for charm and sw~ifthess of style. If one- of Lamb's '2'minor arts" was expertness in quotation, misquotation, and parodic recollecti6ih, one of Mr. Blunden's rmajor virtues .Js' that he-can merge himself with his subject, 'and yet forfeit nothing of his individuality. Lamb has been fortunate in his interpreters;, we'picture him, on that unknown and silent shore, varying one of 'his own tributes-" This noble benefitgratitude' 'forbids me to. conceal their names-I owe to the kindness.of the most munificent firm in the world-the house of Cornwall, Ainger, Lucas and Blunden. Esto.perpetua !"

Author: Null
Title: The Exeter Book
Full_text:
Books of the Week
THE EXETER BOOK
N:EW LIGHT ON THE
MANUSCRIPT
TiE FXETER BOOK OF OLD ENGLISH
POETRY. With Introductory Chapters by R. W. CHAMBERS, MAX FiRSTER, and ROBIN FLOWER. (For the Dean and Chapter of Exeter Cathedral: Lund, Humphries and Co. 8 guineas.)
The Exeter Book is justly described by Professor Chambers in the introduction to this splendid facsimile as " one of the most oessential documents of that remarkable civilization of pre-Conquest England, the true importaance of which in European history we are only slowly beginninig to realize." The vernacular poetry in which the life of Europe in the Dark Ages was depicted seems to have been written down but seldom, and when written to have survived still more scantily.
England has the unique distinction of having produced four great codices, in Which some portion of this body of poetry is saved. It is only a tiny fragment out of a lost world of song, but it helps to give a mearung to many centuries which would otherwise be, in large measure, dumb to us.
Of these four codices, one in the Cotton collection at the British Museum contains the long epic of " Beowulf." Another, in the Bodleian, gives, us among much else the poems of Caedmon. A third, in the Chapter Library of the Cathedral of Vcrcelli, in Piedmont, gathers both poems and prose homilies.
THE REPRODUCTION
All of these codices had already been published in facsimile for the detailed study of scholars, when the Dean and Chapter of Exeter undertook two years ago the pious enterprise of reproducing for the first time the largest, the most varied, and the oldest of the four collections, containing some 30 poems, of which only two short passages overlap with verse preserved elsewhere. The task is now accomplished, and the collotype pages of the Exeter Book in the hands of their 250 subscribers give a,, clear a text as can be seen in the original, while the removal of the vellum strips securing the scarred leaves at the end of the book has revealed letters, surviving on the edge of gaps, which the editors both reproduce and print. Two of the leading Anglo-Saxon scholars, Professor Chambers, of University College, London, and Professor Max Forster, preface the text with historical and descriptive studies of the manuscript. while Dr. Robin Flower, of the British Museum, has produced some new palaeographical evidence for the dating and circumstances of the compilation.
As we now have it, the Exeter Book begins in the midst of the first of three great sections of Cynewulf's " Christ." It preserves for us the same poet's " Juliana," and such eariier masterpieces. not yet assigned, as " Widsith" (The Traveller's Song), and "Deor" (The Bard's Lament), in which traditions reaching back to the fourth century survive the changes of language, and the legendary figures of Weland Smith and Wade of the Haelsingas emerge among characters dimly known to history. It gives us in "The Ruin " an Anglo-Saxon's visior of a Roman city, perhaps Bath, as il looked in decay; it gives us such elegies as " The Wanderer " and " The Seafarer" and the dignified, heroic narrative ol "Guthlac," together with much else, such as the fragments of an allegoric bestiary. and a collection-of Riddles. Grateful as we may be for what we have, the editors emphasize the possibility that there may have been manv more poems in the original manuscript. When Bishop Leofric gave it to the Cathedral of Exeter, some time before 1072, it was described as " one large English book on various subjects composed in verse." Now it occupies only 123 folios of large and upright script, though an extra eight folios bound with the text give us an Anglo-Saxon list of Bishop Leofric's donations, a Latin abstract of this, and various unrelated legal documents.
BISHOP LEOFRIC
This preliminary matter is the subject of a detailed and valuable study by Professor Forster, while Professox Chambers tells us what is known of Leofric's life. The Bishop was apparently not English by birth, and certainly not English bv education, having his upbringing in " Lotharingia," a term stretching from modem Lorraine to the Netherlands, After serving as Chaplain and Chancelloi to Edward the Confessor, he was appointed in 1046 to the combined sees of Devon and Cornwall, then held al Crediton, but obtained a charter from the King in 1050 to transfer his seat to the Church of St. Peter, Exeter, where there was more security against pirates. Leofric survived into the reign of the Conqueror, and died at Exeter in February, 1071-72. The list of his benefactions (which survives in two Old English and one Middle English copy) includes some 66 manuscripts. Of these the Exeter Book itself has remained at its place of deposit since the death of Leofric. except for twe journeys to the British Museum, once in 1831, when a most useful transcript was made by Robert Chambers and checked by Sir Frederic Nladden, and again in the past two years, in order that it might be photographed for the present publication, repaired, and rebound. Among its companion manuscripts in Leofric's donation nine can be identified in the Bodleian, three in the British Museum, and four in the University or College Libraries at Cambridge. There is also a Lambeth Manuscript of Bede on the Apocalypse (Lambeth MS. 149), which appears to have come from Exeter. This is used by Dr. Flower as first-class evidence for the possible origins of the Exeter Book itself.
Considering the script of the latter and comparing it generally with West Country manuscripts, such as the Salisbury Psalter, he dates it " well within the second half of the Tenth Century . . - probably between 970 and 990, and rather early than late in that period." With the Lambeth Bede he shows a detailed resemblance of hand first pointed out to
nim by Mr. Kenneth Sisam. Now this Lambeth manuscript contains not only the name of Leofric, but an inscription in an eleventh-century hand, stating that in 1018 "this volume also" was given to a monastery of St. Mary the Virgin, at a place now not to be deciphered, by a certain Aethelwvrduis Diix. Dr. Flower proceeds from this to make the tempting conjecture that it was the Exeter Book which was presented to this religious house by A ethtelwardus Dux with the Bede, and that Leofric brought thence the two together to Exmr. He points out that
there was in l01 an Aethelweard 1 Ealdorman of a district including Dorset, Somerset, and Devon, who- witnessed a charter of Crediton about that very year. Moreover this Aethelweard had married the granddaughter of a more famous namesake, who was his predecessor as Ealdorman of this district--Aethelweard the chronicler and patron of Aelfric. This Aethelweard the elder, a kinsman of King Alfred and an inspirer in the tenth century'of the revival of English prose, would be no unlikely patron for a collection of English-verse also. It is not difficult then to follow Dr. Flower's hypothesis (he would not claim it as more than this) that the book was compiled in a West Country monastery for Aethelweard the elder early in the period 970-990, and given in 1018 by his namesake and kinsman to Crediton or some other local house, whence Leofric removed it to his new episcopal seat.
Dr. Flower shows that, though serious study was not devoted to the Exeter Book until. Humfrev Wanley and George Hickes examined it in the early eighteenth century, two of the sixteenth-century pioneers of Old English studies had seen it-John Joscelyn, who took several notes from it, and Laurence Nowell, whose hand can be recognized in several glosses written into the manuscript itself. One further new point discussed'by the editors deserves comment. This is the existence in the margins of six pages of apparently unique decorations incised with a stylus bare of ink or colour. Among them are a rosette, a crossed D, an angel's head with wings, a woman's figure, a veiled hand, and a man on horseback. These very curious ornaments, probably done in the late eleventh century, have been reproduced most successfully in the facsimile.
