Title: Moorish Songs
Full_text:
Books of the Week|
MOORISH SONGS.'
t&NKNOWN TRANSLATIONS BY
- THOMAS PERCY
4N;CIENT SONGS, CHIEFLY O;N MOORISHi
SUBJECTS. Translated by THomAs PERCY. (Oxford University Press. London: Milford.' 42s. net.).
Bishop Percy is now chiefly remembered for" his "Reliques of Ancient English Poetry." But this, though his. magnuim .opust; was only one of many literary. activities. A scholar with several languages at his command and with all the antiquarian enthusiasm of his age, he published a translation (via Portuguese) of a Chinese novel and some Chinese poems, -more than one volume of translations from Icelandic, and " A New Translation Iof the S.ong of Solomoi.!' His own ballad, "'The Hermit of Warkworth," ran into -several editions in a few years, some of his verses appeared in Dodsley's " Collec*tion of Poems," and when, later in life, -he gave up the study of songs and ballads as perhaps incompatible with the duties of Bishop of Dromore, he published an essay on the origins of the English stage and the historical plays of Shakespeare.
So much is generally:known, together with the bare fact.of:his friendship with IBowle, editor of " Don Quixote." It has -remained- for a recent gift from Percy's $reat-granddaughter to the Bodleian to prove, not only that Percy himself at one time projected a first critical edition of Cervantes' satire, but that in 1775 a volume of his own translations of Moorish songs actually reached the stage of proof, though it was never proceeded with. In the beautifully printed volume published in a limited edition Mr. John Johnson has completed at the Oxford University Press what was begun 158 years ago by "'S. Leacroft, at the Globe, Charing Cross." Percy 'had procured -designs for an engraved title-page and frontispiece, and these are reproduced from the original copperplates, together with three drawings for woodcuts by
Henry Swinburne. The text consists of the l four translations with originals which survive in proof, a fifth translation (of " Rio Verde, Rio Verde ") which appeared in the " Reliques," and two other renderings which, as the editor states, " are so free as not to. invite compariso'n with the originals." In a scholarly preface Mr. 'Nichol Smith discusses Percy's interest in Spanish literature (printing two newly discovered draft letters about the " Don Quixote " project) and attributes to him ,the position of pioneer in more fields than that of the study of ancient English ballads.- - -
The translations make pleasant reading, though they bear the mark of the eighteenth century clearly stamped on them. Percy was confronted with the difficulties of every translator of verse; but he was not blind to them and obviated many of them with a considerable measure of success. To' avoid the ., affected stiffness" of a literal rendering he found himself constrained, as he confesses, to adopt in places " a more simple epithet, though less poeticalt or expressive." Too often, indeed, with the licence of his period, he departs some distance from his models, and introduces phrases *and*ideas-foreigxi to-their-spirit. *But if
*%ve say of Percy that he fails, for all hisl artifices-or because of them-to recapture the rugged and sonorous grandeur of the Spani,sh, this is no more than we must say 'of Southey, Larckhart, and of Longfellow.

Author: Null
Title: Books To Come
Full_text:
BOOKS TO COME
One of the legacies left by Lauro de Bosis, the young Italian poet and airman who flew to his death in the autumn of 1931, when he scattered anti-Fascist leaflets over the streets of Rome and was not again heard of, is being issued by Humphrey Milford immediately in " The Golden Book of Italian Poetry." This is an anthology covering the whole range of Italian verse down to contemporary writers. It was compiled and edited by Lauro de Bosis, who, besides being a distinguished poet himself and the son of one of the best-known lyrical poets of the last generation, lectured on literature at Harvard University and translated many modern English works into Italian, including a three-volume abbreviated edition of Sir James Frazer's " Golden Bough."
The Cambridge University Press announces a new history of Italy's struggle for nationality and independence, written by Mr. G. F. H. Berkeley as the result of a life study of the subject. Spending most of his winters in Italy the author has been in touch not only with State archives and libraries but also with those who could keep him abreast of the constantly increasing supplies of information. His book, entitled " Italy in the Making, 18151846," is expected next month. The longer process of Italy's development through the centuries, with her contribution to the sum of world culture, is traced in another forthcoming work, entitled " An Outline of Italian Civilization." This has been written by Dr. Decio Pettoello, and will be published by Cassell early in the New Year.
The visit to London in 1641-42 of John Amos Comenius, the educational reformer, marked a memorable stage in the evolution in this country of the scheme for a great institution for scientific research, a movement which led some 20 years later to the foundation of the Royal Society. The details and significance of that visit are recorded in a work entitled "Comenius in England," by Mr. R. F. Young, which the Oxford University Press hopes to have ready in December. Contemporary documents are included by the author showing that England was " in the main stream of Western European civilization, and, indeed, was leading the advance on the very eve of the Great Rebellion," as well as illustrating the interest taken by Comenius in educational work among the Indians of New England and Virginia.
* Although the late Philip Wicksteed was most widely known as a Dante scholar, his more enduring work may perhaps be found in the science of economics. A new edition will shortly be published by Routledge, in two volumes, of his "Common Sense of Political Economy," which marked the culmination of his devoted labours in this branch of knowledge. The book has been out of print for years and copies are at a premium. The new edition will contain an introduction by Professor Lionel Robbins.

Author: FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT
Title: Scott's Poetry
Full_text:
SCOTT'S POETRY
INFLUENCE OF LIDDESDALE
FROM OUR CORRESPQNDEMN
HELWICK, SEPT. 11
MAJOR ELLIOT, MI.P., Financial Secretary to the Treasury, speaking at the Scott centenary celebration at Hawick, in Roxburghshire, yesterday, said that in Hawick they would remember the guest of Branxholme and the ride. of Liddesdale. Here was the soil that bred him, here rang still the tales which were told him and which he told the world again. He was the very breath of Scotland that came from the moors, sometimes as a gift and someTanes as a song. What he got from the borderers was the strength to be serious. Lord David Cecil had truly said that it was by his power of tragedy that Scott must have his place. It was in Liddesdale that he learnt tragedy.
In 1792, when he was but 21, he crossed into Liddesdale for sevehi years. He took that road again. From this was born the minstrelsy of the Scottish Border and from this was born the poet, the man wvho looked into his own hills and saw through them to the other side of good and evil.

Author: Null
Title: Goethe
Full_text:
Books of the Day
GOETHE
LIFE AND POETRY
TK'E LIFE AND WVTORK OF GOETHE. By
J. G. ROBERTSON. (Routledge, 12s. 6d. Iiet.)
GOETErE AS REVEALED IN HIS POETRY.
By BARKER FAIRLEY. (Dent, 8s. 6d. net.)
GoETnE: A CENTuRy AimTR. By F. W.
FELKIN. (Oxford University Press, 3s. 6d. net.)
GOETHE'S AUTOBIOGRAPHY. Translated
by R. 0. MooN. (Alston Rivers, 10s. net.)
All these books are designed, by their timely appearance together, to help us to celebrate the Goethe centenary with understanding. Dr. R. 0. Moon's translation of Dichtung und IVahrrheit reads fluently and comfortably, and it is now, some time since the last English version appeared. Professor Robertson's is an extension for the occasion of a work already well known; he may be said to be most concerned with giving us aii upto-date biography and literary history. Professor Barker Fairley, of Toronto, is almost entirely occupied with an analysis of Goethe as a poet: his is a thoroughly original contribution and shows an uncommon insight into the wvorkings of the Goethean mind. Mr. Felkin's two concise chapters, w hich may be described as mixed, suggest a philosophical clue to the heart of the mystery.
For mystery there still is for English readers about much that relates to Goethe; Professor Fairley, indeed, finds that a " distressing vaguieness " has gatlhered round his name; and in any case his genius wvas so large and manysided that it is easy to put the wrong emplhasis on this or that element in it. He is pre-eminently an author wlhose meaning is illustrated by his life: hence there will alvays have to be lives of him, and a full-dress life is bound to be copious. Taste, too, changes and affects our judgment of him. Gone is the generation to which Carlyle gave the injunction, " Close tlhy Bvron; open thy Goethe." The Byron hardly needs closing now, while as for parts of Goethe, such as IVerther and the Wahlverwandtschlaften, it is admittedly an acquired taste that is needed. Even Faust is pronounced by many to be in one sense or another a magnificent failure; Goethe either attempted the impossible, or lhe made an imnpossible drama out of it. But all English readers can admire Part I.; and to Goethe's lyrics they are prepared to yield the palm instantly. They can see that, like Slhakespeare, he is full of immortal quotations: like the Scriptures, full of proverbial 'wisdom. Of his wvisdom, indeed, a mere look at his countenance would assure them; 'Mr. Felkin, wvho recalls an appropriate passage, hints that Goethe may possibly have had abnormal optical powers; and in another sense Professor Fairley says the same, for in the Platonic cave, -as he puts it, Goethe by some dispensation seems to sit sideways and to see both the wall and the objects whiclh file past it. For the appreciation of this uncanny wisdom a good biography is essential, so much seems to rest in Goethe himself rather than in his country or in his times, for he can hardly bo said to be the great child of a great age as Shakespeare was. There are those who have been surprised, even pained, at the thought that so mighty a force should have been harnessed so long to a petty concern like the little State of which Weimar was the capital ; if so, it becomes all the more important to understand exactly what Weimar was and what Goethe did there. Professor Robertson appears to regret Weimar, as a cramping influence ; Professor Fairlev, on the other hand, holds that it was Goethe's poetic salvation.
When the complicated relations between the biography and the works have been set forth, as they are by Professor Robertson, and when something of the Goethean debt to Spinoza is acknowledged, as it is by Mr. Felkin, the present age, which sees in Goethe a poet more than anything else, ought to find Professor Fairley most stimulating. How is the yoTi-riKl pav-rEa to be accounted for ? Our guide is an enthusiast of uncommon insight. He begins by reminding us that it was as a worshipper of Shakespeare that Goethe made his literary debut; then folloved a succession of influences, many of them, as everybody knows, female, while others again were literary. None, however, dominated him ; he had
too strong an instinct for Entsagung and Beschriinkung; he absorbed as much as his nature needed and no more. He was essentially a lyrical poet ; lyric is the prevailing note of the Urfaust, wvhich Professor Fairley compares, as few do, with its contemporary Werther ; he was not cut out for long composition iike a Virgil or a Milton, and yet, such was its attraction for him, he had to spend some 60 years over Faust, so elaborating and enlarging the original fable until it became another Divine Comedy. Nor, " fragments of a general confession" as his poems in one sense are, was there ever quite such an unselfconscious writer: " he is innately objective " ; he sought for objectivity all his life; an audience has no existence for him " the most nonchalant of authors, writing his verses as a matter of course, when he is impelled to m.rite them, and remaining unperplexed when the impulse deserts him." A firm belief in Goethe's inspiration whenever he wrote leads Professor Fairley to some admirable explanations of episodes, such as the W\'alpurgisnacht. in Faust, often misunderstood by commentators, and to a full appreciation, often less forthcoming than merited, of the astonishingly rich v,ariety of metres used by Goethe, though Goethe troubled himself no more about nietrical theory than he thought about thinking. Goethe's poetic mind was, he insists, " marvellously true to its kindred points-true to the self wvhich speaks and to the nature which prompts," and the scale of his being was fortunately large enough to let that fidelity have full play.

Title: The Romantic Poets
Full_text:
THE ROMANTIC POETS.
TilE OXFoRD BOOK OF REGENiCY VERSE,
1798-1837. Chosen by H. S. MIxftout. (bxford: Clarendon Press.> London: Milford. Ss. 6d. niet.) 1.
Betweeni the oclose of the "Oxford Book of Eighteenth-Century Verse" and the opening of the-" Oxford Book of Victorian -Verse " lies a period to which, as Mr. 'Milford explains.; it is hard to affix a satisfac' tory title,'but which eomprehends so great a production of illustrious poetry that it demands an'anthology at least as extensive as the others. Within this period the whole work of Shelley, Keats, and Byron (merely to name tho greatest) was accomplished, and, since the lives of these light-givers began and ended i n the times 'of George IV., we may aecept for praotical purposes the term of Me. Milford, now giving uS his "Oxford' Book of Regency Verse.".
When one considers that the dovelopment of Wordsworth alone requires over one hundred of, lr. Milford's pages, and that the notable poetio art of the Regency era was as much embodied in long' and well-marshalled compositions as in brief "decisive actions" of lyric and ode, the main weight of our anthologist's task is recogiiized. But there is a secondary iiecessity and problem. In the splendour, the rapidity and variety of the most eminent Regency poets, the delicate jierfections of many poets "of less note s, have been lost to view. Particularly was this true from the very beginning in the case of some beautiful but sequestered singers -as Hood, Darley, Clare-who flourished at a time when most progressive appreciators had eyes only for Shelley andEeats and the extension of their honour. Previous instances of Mr. Milford's e'cemplary bookmanship and fineness of response to
rhatever is admirable would have warranted us in anticipating that his Regency anthology solved aflike the problem of port-raying without curtailment the most powerful genius of that time, and the question of recalling attention to less powerful but perfectly expressed person. alities with their glimpses of the "august abodes."'
The result is in accord with such anticipations; Mr. Milford's selection will delight the general reader and encoutage the particular inquirer. The scope of the book does not disdain those passages of poetic humanity which a mistaken austerity of criticism often leaves out of the picture-familiar verse, wit and satire, in vvhich the Regency poets were almost as remarkable as in pure romance and intellectual beauty. No political incident or public 'quarrel passed in those days without a set of-ballads and pasquinades, and the clmax of those dexterous and certainly lyrical comments on this nether world was Byron. Inspiration from 'the topics of the news was never realized more fully'by poets of every degree. Mr. Milfbrd's inclusions on this ground are a salutary proof of the solid meanings of the romantic movement and the free hand which poets have'in finding themes. But we do not wish to make this point the head of our gratitude to 'the antholog-ist -
He has assembled a series of great and coherent 'poetry, 'the ethereal, the philosophical, the'pictorial, the musical, the iro ical; he has 'shown equally the triumph of C6leridge with the' kingship of Scott, the sustained -glory of Shelley with the impulsive.mystbay-of Darley, the rich depths of Keats with the clear current of 'Southey, the gay vivacity of Peacock with the intimate playfulness of Lamb. In his regard for the scholar-on whom the' general reader depends-he provides 'in structive references to the texts aind sburces of' his transcripts, and cannot but. give a- valuable direction to' those who, charmed with 'h first generous offerigs, long tog? farther in this noble region.

Author: Null
Title: Book of the Day
Full_text:
Book- of the: :Day-.
THE CLDMON MS.
._
BRITISH ACADEMY COMMEMORATION.
THE CA :DMON 1MNU]spRiPT op. ANGLO-
SAxo2N BIIBLICAL POETRY, Junius XI in the Bodleian Library. With Introduction by Sin IsRAEL GoLNcz. Published for the British Academy. (Oxford University Press. London: Milford. Â£10 lOs. net:)'
In this stately folio, which commemorates the twenty-fifth anniversary of the incorporation of the British Academy, Sir Israel Gollanez sees a long-cherished desire of his fufilled. He is to be cordially congratulated on this, and on the form which he and the. Oxford Press have given to it.. We have here a full and permanent record of one of -the most important monuments *of early. English literature and pictorial art.
The Junius manuscript was written about. the year 1000, very probably at Winchester. Very probably, again, it passed into the possession of Christ Church, Canterbury; a "-Genesis in English with pictures" figures in the fourteenth century catalogue ..of the Priory library. In post-Dissolution times we first hear of it as in the possession of Sir Simonids d'Ewes, and then of Archbishop Ussher, who gave it to Francis Junius, who, dying in 1677, bequeathed it to the Bodleian.. It contains four Anglo-Saxon poems, which are known respectively as "Genesis," "Exodus,". "Daniel," and "Christ and Satan." The first three are paraphrases of Biblestory,ofvarying merit, the fourth tells of the Fall of the Angels, the Harrowing of Hell, the Doom, and the Temptation of Christ. The first poem is moreover illustrated with nearly fifty outline drawings, and there was evidently an intention to adorn the " Exodus " andl " Daniel " in like manner, for many pages and half-pages in them are left blank. The last poem, *hich is by a somewhat later scribe, was not meant to be illustrated.
Great and varied as is the interest of all the poems in the book-and there are no- other copies of them-the greatest interest attaches to the " Genesis." Junius, who printed the whole contents of the volume in 1655, believed that everything in it was the work of Caedmon, the inspired herdsman-poet of- the seventh century whose story is so beautifully told by Bede. But criticism, which began very shortly after the publication of the text, disposed of Caedmon's claim to have written the last three poems, and threw grave doubts upon his - authorship of the " Genesis." It became a question whether there was in the world any fragment of his work other than the nine lines which some nameless benefactor had written -on the margin of the venerable Cambridge manuscript of Bede's " Ecclesiastical History," to which some would add the verses carved on the Ruthwell Cross. What is Sir Israers verdict on this most important questiont He reminds his readers that it has been demonstrated that in the " Genesis " there is a long interpolation from another poem on the same subject. This is an AngloSaxon version of part of an Old Saxon (German). Genesis-poem ;- in it are eontained those remarkable passages about Satan which, it has been thought, were known to. Milton. The interpolation is known as " Genesis B," and the remainder of the text as " Genesis A." And we are glad to read that of " Genesis -A" Sir Israel-believes that Caedmon may very well be the author; though, as has long been recognized, the dialect of- the poem has been altered from Northumbrian to West Saxon.
Interesting again it is to find Sir Israel appro,ving the, fancy that the poem
' Exodus" may be, if not by the great Aldhelm of Sherborne, "then by one of his school, and certainly by a kindred spirit," and to learn that ".Exodus" was most probably known to the author of " Beowulf." But we must not follow him through the whole of his fascinating review of the literary contents of.the mannseript. Only this remark may be permitted: that we. doubt if the theology of the last of the poems, " Christ and Satan," is. in realitv. as unorthodox as he thinks it.
Something must be said about the pictures. They are not of the very finest style, but they are very spirited, and many of them-particularly those of the story of Satan and the Fall-are unique, for they illustrate a unique text. It seems to us probable that upon those which are concerned with the Bible story light would be thrown by the Greek pictured Octateuchs. The proposition may seem curious; yet it is provable that a German nun in the twelfth century copied Byzantine pictures by the score: we refer to Herrade of Landsperg and her book the " Hortus Deiciarum." The Cssdmon manuscript offers a curious example. Sir Israel Gollanez' acutely points out the occurrence of the symbol. of Aries, the Zodiacal Sign, in a picture of Enoch. He would find, if he looked at the Greek Octateuchs, that their practice is to represent Enoch accompanied by the Signs of the Zodiac, or pictures of the months, which he was the first to make known to man. The only other pictured Bible of AngloSaxon make which we possess is the Heptateuch Claudius B. iv in the Cotton library, which belonged to St. Augustine's, Canterbury. It has well over 400 pictures; it has some resemblances to the Junius manusclipt, and, irn our opinion, it well merits investigation from the point of view of a possible Eastern origin. Sir Israel makes one specially ingenious suggestion when he deals with an elaborate decorative design which fills a blank space on page 225 of the manuscript. According to him it is a design for the ornamentation of the binding of the book. That it suits such a purpose well is clear; the Oxford Press have adapted it on the cover of the volume before us. It is for experts in the craft to tell us whether or not the theory will hold.
We have not noticed more than a fraction of the matters of interest-textual, artistic, literary-which fall to -be treated by Sir 'Israel in his introduction. The sourcei of the " Daniel," its relation to the poem in the Exeter book called " Azarias," the question of the names of the wives of Noah and his sons, of the sources of the " Christ and Satan"; on all these and many' other curious points much is said which can hardly fail to interest, and it is well said. -In one particular Sir Israel has failed to make his meaning perfectly clear. He has of necessity to deal fully with the question of the structure of the manuscript and the possible loss of leaves. We wish that besides explaining his view in words he had furnished us with sectional diagrams of the gatherings. or quires of the manuscript. These would have shown us, more clearl than words can do, what is the aetual *condition, 'and what he " hypothecates " (vve quote his word, but feel sure that'his use'of it is un'wonted). It may seem pedantic-for him and for us to dwell long on so technical a point as the make-up of a' book; but it must be remembered that we are here concerned with the unique copy of a difficult text, and that many theories about the integrity of that text stand or fall by the 'correct answer to the question " Are there leaves nilasinlg. here ? In 'conclusion. 'we con.gratulate-Sir Israel once more upon s lont!desired; a-welcome, and a splendid pubhi'cation..

Author: Null
Title: Mr. Hardy's Poems
Full_text:
MR. HARDY'S POEMS. I
A SEVENTH VOLUME. I
HUMAN SHOWS, FABt PHANTASIES, SONGS
AND TREFLES. By THOMAS HARDY.
(Macmillan. 7s. 6d. net.)
To-day Mr. Thomas Hardy publishes his seventh volume of lyric poetry. The poems in it number one hundred and fiftytwo; and the appended dates, or some such note as " From an old draft," show that they include poems recently written and- poems written, or sketched out, years ago. Mr. Hardy is wise in not leaving to other hands th6 task of going through the still ungarnered poetic harvest of a lifetime, but giving his own final touch to whatever he deems worthy of preservation. The title of thle volume tels that it contains poems diverse in aim and in kind. There are stories in it ; there are httle songs; there are poems of what appear to be personal memories and emotions; there are studies of the aspects of nature, and there are philosophical reflections on the riddle of life. The collection shows once more how inevitably a poet Mr. Hardy is;
Any little old song
Will do for me, says one poem; and
I only need the -homeliest
Of beaztatirrings.
That is partially true. Almost, you would say, anything seen, heard, or felt turns to poetry in his mind'; but the homely is not his only field. And when he chooses the homely, he gives it, no less than the august and the profound, the stamp of his own mind in the poetic utterance which he has invented and which is his only.
Many of the poems in the new book, especially, perhaps, the majority of those which sing of the inevitability of death, will fall into their place in the bulk of Mr. HIardy's poetry. A few stand out, and wvill demand inclusion in any further selection that he or andther may make. Among these are the little group of poems about
ainter, which seem rather to make than merely to show winter. Another is this profound little eight-line flash of psychological insight:-
The tragedy of that moment
Was deeper than the sea, Wben I came in that moment
And heard you speak to me
What I could not help seeing
Covered Ife as a blot;
Yes, that which.I was seeing.
And knew that you were not!
We should choose also the poem about the jackdaws in the church-tower who heard the bells for the first time in their lives when the peal was rung at the Armistice:-
"I t means some snare
For our feet or wings; But I'11 be ware
Of such baleful thingsp!
And forth he flew from his louvred niche To take up life in a damp dark ditch,
So mortal motives are misread, And false designs attributed,
In upper spheres of straws and sticks, Or lower, of pens and politics.
While Mr. Hardy's mind keeps its bent towards the past (as both the personal regrets and the stories of old days in this volume show), there is evidence here also of his vigorous intellectual curiosity. Some of the philosophical poems take in relativity; and find in it, at least for poetical purposes, new ground for that kind of hope which was not wholly ruled out of The Dyn*8ts.
