Title: Heroic Age Of Poetry
Full_text:
HEROIC AGE OF POETRY.
THE LOST BOOKS OF ENGLISH
LITERATURE.
A paper was read to the Bibliographical Society yesterday, at 20, Hanover-square, by PRoESsoRs R. WV. Cwnio3ms, on "The Losi Books of English Literature." The lecture] pointed out how even students of the Latin and Greek classics (although their imagination was stimulated from time to time by the discovery, or the claim to the discovery, oi lost'works) often failed to allow sufficiently for the vast' gaps in our records.
With regard to English literature before the time of Chaucer, Professor Cliambers said that the proportion of loss had been beyond comparison heavier than in the case of the classics. Two great bodies of heroic poetry had flourished' in England, and the first had been almost lost, the second entirely. The first flourished in the centuries immnediately after the Anglo-Saxon settlement in Britain and dealt with traditions.which had grown up around the figures of the great "Barbarian " leaders at the time of the break-up of the Roman Empire: men like Attila, Theodoric the Great,' or Alboin. The second nourished in late Anglo-Saxon and in Norman tumes, and its heroes were Anglo-Saxon and Anglo-Danish Kings and leaders, such as Edgar or Hereward the Wake. If these lays iad been preserved it was safe to say that ,hey would have proved to be of greater nterest than those homilies and lives of 3aints which bulked so largely in medieval iterature.
The lecture was illustrated by lantern slides if inscriptions, carvings, drawings, and fragnenitary leaves recording traces of the lost iterature.

Author: Null
Title: The Profession Of Poetry
Full_text:
THE PROFESSION OF
POETRY.
'PROFESSOR GARROD ON
MODERN TENDENCIES.
The recently-elected Professoi of Poetry at Oxford, Mr. H. W. GnARROD, Fellow of Merton College, gave his inaugural lecture at the Examination SchooLs yesterday. Mr. (Garrod, who had chosen for his subject "' The Profession of Poetry," began with a brief but sympathetic reference to the death of his predecessor, Professor W. P. Ker, " a man who hated the waste of wvords," " a man full of poetry," who died " young at seventy." Mr. Garrod said that amid as our present difficulties he thought that there was no happier augury than the vitality of poetry and of the 8tudy of poetry. Turning to the modern school of poets, he noted that most of their verse was lyrical, its language pla., and its conception of the character of the poet different. " The race of long-haired poets," he observed, "'is-dead."-
lTe did not pretend to be in fuU sympathy with the modern school ; he had a sneaking affection for " poetic diction," a belief that one of the purposes of poetry was pleasure, and that " very little affords permanent pleasure which has not some hold in ethics." He would venture to suggest that some modern poets had not fully realized how difficult the business of poetry had become. Already one part of poetry, sonfg, which was the union of speech and music, was dead; to-day /a song wanted two men's work, and one of them did it badly. We had dropped from the unity of words, music, and dance to mere verse, and we were askiug now whether even verse was necessary. loetry must have its pains ; it was ai particular manner of expressing life, and its glory was in proportion to the greatness of its strife. There was a danger that the bizarre elements of modern civilization might gain on poetry and rob it of its essentials. Tho problem of converting the complexity of our material civilization into poetry was less easy than a good deal of modern practice seemed to imply.
I Aristotle bad taught us that it was the
function of poctry to elimnmate the unessential; the poet was the man with an eye for metaphor, who perceived similarities which escaped common men, and lie had also the touch of " mania." For the poet was essentially mysterious and " bardic," and the guarantee of hxis veracity was himself.
TfE Ro0AnTc REVIVAL.
Professor Garrod turned in conclosion to the poets of the Romantic Revival and showed how Wordsworth, Coleridge, gend Shelley were each of them not only poet but " that abject thing, a professor of poetrv." They had their theories of poetry and conformed to them in their practice. The foundation of their theory was a bold sensationalism; the function of the poet was to preserve " a more lively sensibility." Poetry described things as they appeared to the senses ; its descriptions were at once less real and more true than those arrived at by the aid of reason alone; its effects were supernatural, because natural. It redeemed us out ot life into ourselves; out of all that seemed not to matter into a world, vital, organic, pulsating.

Author: (BY OUR DRAMATIC CRITIC.)
Title: Satire
Full_text:
I SATIRE.--
HANDICAPPED FOR
DRAMA.
| MR. MAUG HAM'S COMEDY.
(By Outt DflNEAMTIC CnITaC.)
In the current Literary Supplement there are some suggestive remarks on satire as a literary "kind." I apologize for the intrusion, but catnot help avowing that the writer, in controverting the common saying, " Satire is not poetry," does I it, in my judgment, too muchi honour. The
saying is absurd on the face of it, almost as absurd as the counter-assertion which the writer offers in answer to it, "Satire is poetry." For literary kinds are not classifications of art, but merely for convenience vwe talk, for convenience, of satiricajl or didactic or epic or dramatic poetry, but these divisions have' no tsthetic meaning ; thcre is only poetry. To say that satire "is." or "is not " poetry is. like saying that a duodecimo volume, bound in half-morocco, top edge gilt, is or is not poetry. Poetry may happen over any subject, as it miay be bound up in any volume. Flat ubi tcult. It may owe its origin as well to indignation as to love, to the bitter taste as to the sweetness of life ; but these origins aro not poetry, which is pure expirssion and nothing else.
.Nevertheless, there is a soul. of goodness in things evil and an element of truth in many an error. With a little good will you can read a certain sense into " Satire is not poetry " which will rescue it from its plight of sheer nonsenso. The sense, namely, that satire is not a favourable motif for poetry. For the satirist is the slave of his theme, and though slaves may be poets they would stand a better ehance as free men. Satire is a parasitic' thing, a " functiofi," as the mathematicians say, of its subject ; it must stick fast to that or it will cease to be satire; it must maintain communication with its base, or it will be "in the air," chimaera bombinane in vacuo. "Who would not sigh if Atticus were he ? "- but. if there had been no Addison, and Atticus were a mere Aunt Sally of Pope's imagination, nobody would sigh. Yet the quality, the poetry, of Pope's verse would be unaffected by the question whether Atticus were or were not a real person. For artl has its own life, follows its own laws, and refuses to be conditioned by subject. When the subject galls it, it simply throws its cap over the mills and goes its own way. That is why poetry is seldom pure satire, why it exhibits more often only a. "satirical veins" running through a richer material, the material of pure poetry. The Supplement writer is, of course, fully aware of this, as is shown by his remarks on the Elizabethan dramatists.. "No one can deny that satire is a frequent and often valuable ingredient in the dramatists. . . . Some of the vitality of Elizabethan drama, its direct contact with life, comes from this- satirical vein. Jonson and Marston are full of it; most of the others possess it in varying degrees. Even Shakespeare has a great satirist in him." Observe that no claim is put forward for drama as all satire ; satire is only an "ingredient" among others, a " vein." It is quite true that this ingredient, this vein, is of real value for its vitality, its. direct contact with life'; my point is that this direct contact can be only intermittent. Maintained steadily throughout, it would be fatal to drama. For drama must have its own life, cannot be rigidly shaped by that real life which is its'subject, must give free play to the dramatist's imagination.
I think we have a striking example nf this truth in Mr. Maugharn's new comedy, ,Qur Betters. But, someone objects, we have been talking about poetry, and what has poetry to do with a drama in prose ? The answer is, everything. The poetry we have been talking about is only a short name for all, imaginative literature, whether in verse or in prose. Let us call it by a better, because less confusing, short name ; let us call it art, and proceed. Mr. Maugham's play starts as a satire, and it illustrates the difficulty, indeed the virtual impossibility, already spoken of, experienced by the dramatist in maintaining that direct contact with life required from the satirist. The persons satirized are a particular set of American girls, the rich girls who buy titles in the European marriage-market. The dramatist proposes to exhibit not so much the turpitude-for he is a comic writer-as the frivolity and snobbishness of these loveless bargains. And the frivolity and snobbishness constitute the atmosphere of his play. EHad he kept to mere frivolity and snobbishness, we should have had more effective, because more accurate, satire, and certainly less disquieting drama. But probably we should have had the feeling of being sent empty away; we should have enjoyed Mr. Maugham's wit and cynicism, but missed what we all want in the theatre -a poignant dramatic interest. That Mr. Maugham will give us at all costs, and so finds himself driven by dramatic exigencies into turpitude of characters and incidents, after all. AWay, then, goes the direct contact with life of the satirist! For who will pretend that his Lady George is typical? Typical, may be, in her shrewd brains, her sheer "push," her success in ",getting there"; typical, too, in the vulgarity and materialism of her idealsall fair subjects for satire-but in principles and conduct a callous, shameless monster rather than a real woman, to say nothing of a real American woman. She lets herself and her establishment. be "run " by a rich elderly lover, and abandons herself, not from passion, but from mere caprice or just to spite a woman rival, to that rival's young lover. When discovered, she nevar turns a hair ;: just brazens it out, and artfully secures not only a reconciliation with her elderly lover, but also with the outraged woman rival. A most potent character, to be,sure,
in drama ; but as a piece of satire, remotei from all contact with life, incredible. So~ wvith the woman rival. She exists merelyas a contrast in turpitude with the other; perhaps turpitude is too grave a word for this caricature of the grande amoureuse, who haggles over the price of the motor-car with which she bribes her young lover, and who, on discovering his infidelity, promptly marries him for safety's sake. The satire, in a word, has either retired in favour of drama or degenerated into burlesque. Our fair American cousins may safely remain undisturbed by Mr. Maugham's satire, and may say of it what Lamb said of Coleridge's metaphysics, " it is only his fun."

Author: Null
Title: Mr. Stebbing's Versions
Full_text:
MR. STEBBING'S VERSIONS.
GnEEic AND LAT= ANTHoLOGY: GR:
MASTERPIECSS. LATw MAnsTsUEcEs. GR=e EPIGaAmS AND SAP1'Ho. Three Vols. By WirI2Aur STEBBING. Fisher Unwin. lOs; 6d. each.
Not only out of loyalty to Mr. Stebbing, who was Delane's right-hand man on this journal, but also on their own merits; do we welcome the three volumes of verse translations from Greek and Latin poetry which he has just issued. They are not altogether new, for the Latin and the Greek " Masterpieces " appeared not long ago, though they are here aigmented with selections from writers whom he did not at first attempt ; but the volume of Greek epigramis appears for the first time. They have occupied, he tells us, his leisure for the last ten years ; and were they to be considered merely as the achievements of a nohageriarian they would be remarkable. But they have received, as we happen to know,* due admiration on the only grounds that can be satisfying to one who essays such a task-.
I Mr. Stebbing does not strictly translate; he thinks the thoughts of these poets into his ovwn, and 'while sometimes the version (the result of his turning a passage over in his mind) corresponds closely enough with the original, it is often considerably expanded. This process goes perhaps to its greatest length in his treatment of Sappho, where, it should be noted, he does not neglect to handle the latest pieces recovered by arch20ology. His method has its attractions. For one thing there are plenty of close translations extant; and, for another, Mr. Stebbing's 'mind moves naturally on classical -lines, and if he thinks more into a passage than a translator would, his thoughts are not alien to
it. His stylc is ripe and vigorous, and his versification, if it has its peculiarities in
the way in which he treats the stress~accent of English verse, cannot be said to be any'thing but his own. It is impossible here to indicate all that his volumes contain, but some of the finest specimens of Greek and Latin poetry are represented. IDy no means negligible are the shoe, prefatory appreciations of the different authors. Here Mr. Stebbing always sys something just and stimulating, and he is not a slave to convention. IFor instanee, while perceiving why Pindar must have commanded thc approval of his- compatriots and contemporaries, be is still a little perplexed by the " unqualified, modern literary appreciation" of him. That, is candid, and classical scholars are not always so honest vwhen they recommend the literary qualities of the subjects of their professional studies.

Author: Null
Title: Mrs. Meynell's Last Poems
Full_text:
MRS. MEYNELL'S LAST
POEMS.
THE LAST PoE3ms oF ALacs MEucELL.
(Burns, Oates, and Washbourne. 3s. 6d. net.)
This volume bears out Mr. Chesterton's recent saying that " the point about [Alice Meynell's] poetry, as compared with most modern poetry, was this: that she never wrote a line, or even a word, without putting brains into it; or, in the most exact sense, meaning what she said." Her spare sincerity, her disciplined reticence, is one reason why the book is so slender. Poems on such themes as " Intimations of Mortality," " Time's Reversals," "In Honour of America," " The Laws of Verse," "To the Mother of Christ the Son of Alan" might have swollen to quadruple their size if Mrs. Meynell had been willing (as she never was) to raise the sluices of rhetoric a single inch. Some difficulties due to compression would also have been avoided; but this poet is worth the toil of discovering her Eecrets, and she can be simple enough when simplicity suffices. Take, for instance, these four lines "in time of war," headed by Richard Hooker's words, "Lord, I owe Thee a Death ".
Man pays that debt with new munificence,
Not piecemeal now, not slowly, by the old: Not grudgingly, by the effaced thin pence,
But greatly and in gold.
Besides the grave march of verse loaded with ample thought there are in this collection snatches of the author's lighter, most delicate music, which we hear, for instance, in the tiny ode to Thetis
In ber bright title poets dare
What the wild eye of fancy seem Similitude-the clear, the fair
Light mystery of images.
Round the blue sea I love the best
The argent foam played, slender, fleet; I saw-past Wordsworth and the rest-_
Her naturaL Greek, and silver feet
In two pieces, "The Laws of Verse" and "The English Metres," fMis. Meynell professes her faith that the measures of traditional prosody are not fetters but pinions of fancy. She values, indeed, the relative freedom of our English metres, " tethered, uncaptured, rules obeyed ' at ease"' ; but the poet's liberty must acknowledge its bounds, and it is to the ideal of law simply that she dedicates some of the finest lines in the book.-
Dear laws, come to my breastl
Take all my frame, and make your close arms
meet
Around me; and so ruled, sO wamed, so
pressed,
I breathe, aware; I feel my wild heart beat.
Dear laws, be wings to mel
The feather merely floats. 0, be it beard
Through weight of life-the skylark's
gravity-
That I am not a feateer, but a bird.

Author: Null
Title: Modern Poets
Full_text:
MODERN POETS.-
A NEW ANTHOLOGY.
A MISCELLANY OF POETRY, 1920-1922.
Edited by WLLIAM KEAtN SEYMOUR.
(John G. Wilson. 6s. net.)
When an editor prints two of his own poems in the anthology he has chosen from others, he puts a sword into the hands of the critic. " By this evidence shall you be. judged," the critic might say, "not only of your poetry but of your poetical sense." The critic might be wrong, but surely he would be human.
It happens, however, that one of Mr. Seymour's two poems, "Cesar Remembers," is among the best in the volume. The sword must be rendered to him, hilt f6remost, with all honour ; and if we could but quote the whole poem, most readersno doubt very wrongly, but surely very humanly-might be content to take on trust the remaining sixty poets of such a poet's choice.
C*sar, that proud man,
Sat in his tent,
Weary with victory,
With striving spent. WVhere the grey Chilterns
Coiled and slept
That hard-lipped Emperor
Vigil kept.
But Casar cared not
For dyke or wall, Faint and remote
Came the bugles' call; Soft in the shadows
He saw, and heard, A Roman garden,
A Roman bird.
The verse is hard and hammered, like that of " Emaux et Camees," and the effect as immediate and sure. Some of the other poets are inclined to be vague. On a first reading we are not quite certain what they mean, and when we do discover it is painfully apparent that they do not mean very much. A touch of the concrete would make them different and better writers, and help modern poetry on its journey from promise to performance.
But Mr. Aldous Huxley, in "Theatre of Varieties," leaves nothing to be filled in by his reader's imagination. He is ironic-Mr. Huxley never forgbts to be that-in describing his entirely mundane scene, where
Circle on circle the hanging gardens descend, Slope from the upper darkness, each flower
face
Open, turned to the light and laughter and
life
Of the bright stage.
And much play is made with the " bill," its conventionalized names and hyperbolic allurements for "Saturday night in Camden Town." The picture is brilliant in detail, from the " worldrenowned Van Hogen Mogen" on the stage to the " stretched gargoyles " in the audience, hanging on the conjurer's patter. We all know " Dobbs and Debs," and the terrible infant with its questions.
Another picture from life is Mr. Edmund Blunden's " Country Sale." But how different the subject, how much simpler. the outlook !
The strife of tongues even tries the auctioneer, Who, by the dealer smirking to his leer, A jumped-up jerky cockerel on his box,
Runs all his rigs, cracks all his jokes and
mocks ;
"MadAfn, now never weary of well-doing,"
The heavy faces gleam to hear him crowing. And swift the old home's fading.
It is like a page from 'Hardy, but we may be sure has 'een independently observed. Mr. Blunden can paint nature as well as man-nature in all her freshness:-
Primroses, howv we hailed their peeping,
Under the black-barked woodides creeping.
Mr. Richard Aldington's Muse is more sophisticated. She has kept her memory of the Greeks, and perhaps, less consciously, of Matthew Arnold. She recalls the song of the nightingale through many associations-but recalls it as vividly as Mr. Blunden the primrose.
There are several noble pieces here of Mrs. Meynell's last work, and they serve not only to put a final stamp of distinction on the book, but to suggest, more strongly than might have been expected, how strong was her influence on some of the younger poets. Quite a large proportion of the verses might be traced, in theme or craft, or both, to the indirect inspiration of her spiritual precision.

Author: Null
Title: Georgian Poets
Full_text:
GEORGIAN POETS.
I A NEW ANTHOLOGY.
GEORGLIN PoETRY: 1920-1922. (The
Poetry Book Shop. 6s. net.)
Mr. Marsh, in a short preface to this fifth volume of Georgian poetry, replies good-humouredly to- the critics who have begun to question the wisdom of continuing these selections. Into that question we cannot profitably enter here. The increasing prevalence of anthologies of modern verse, very similar in detail and character, is a phenomenon in which poetry and economies are nicely entangled. It is for the poets to agree to them, if and as long as they will or it Pays them. It is for the critic to judge them irrespective of names and formulas.
A collection which includes Mr. de la Mare, Mr. Davies, Mr. Blunden, Mr. Armstrong, Mr. Freernan, Mr. Gibson; and Mr. Graves, all at their latest and best, and M1r. Abercrombie and Mr. Lawrence at their second best, is bound to be both a choice and convenient volume for those who do not read these poets at first hand. Three poems from Mr. Monro's " Real Property " (in our opinion his highest achievement), Mr. Nichols's " Night Rhapsody " (from " Amelia "), a generous choice from Miss Sackville-West's " Orchard and Vineyard," and a new and admirable one from Mr. Brett Young's poems, do not lessen its appeaL. In addition we have five poets of at present slender repute, Mi. Hughes, Mr. Herr, Mr. Pellow, Mr. Prewett, and Mir. Quennell, to stimulate our curiosity, if not to reward it: urcrost,ifnttorwr
There remain Mr. Drinkwater, Mr. Squire, and Mr. Shanks, in whom, as it seems to us, the virtues and vices of Georgian poetry are satisfactorily enthroned and popularized. For although Mr. Marsh may justly deny that an " insipid sameness is the chief characteristic" of this anthology, yet that "lack of inspiration and comparative finish " which he fancies hostile critics imputing to his choice is a very constant rea}ity. Of such a charge certain of these poets are wholly innocent. Yet even so fine and accomplished a one as Mr. Freeman is not entirely guiltless.
TECHNIQUE AND PASSION.
So many of these poets, we are driven to ieel, are sensitive, tolerant, and talented. They could turn out agreeably finished verses to order on any concrete subject from a dog to a door-handle. They observe the small details of Nature with a
rindly curiosity and report of her with a dainty daring. They lavish whimsies and faintly provocative emotions upon situations Tn themnselves often :commonplace, but for the heightenled speech- of passion, of imagination touching the heart of things overmasteringly, we look almost in vain.. Mr. Freeman comes near to it in such a line as " Now, now I am but thought kissing your thonght," but so often an accomplished technique serves only a lethargy of soul, and the necessity imposed through deficient power upon these poets of keeping us awake by crafty verbal surprises soon fails of its purpose. We weary of smiling our momentary approval of a- trick, and when the coquetry of conceits assumes the mask of mnocence, as in Mr. Kerr's
I lingered at a gate and talked A little with a lonely lamb,
our smile broadens into laughter.
As with a building covered with nicely trimmed ivy or crowded carving, we often thirst. in reading this book for something bare and stark and strong. Mr. Lawrence once could. give us it, but here he relapses into a whimsical soliloquy over a "golden snake," and is diffuse. Mr. Abercrombie, who has the giant in him, gives us a poem often fine in rhythm and in phrase (" My spirit drank my flashing senses in," for example), but in his protracted struggle after passion and imagination he wants ares serenity. Many others fail lamentably to reconcile subtlety with sincerity-the problem above all to be solved by the modern poet.
We have purposely stressed what we consider the grave weakness of many poems here collected-their talented triviality. The beanty and insight of the others is only more evident by comparison-; and it it good that such poems as Miss Sadeville-West's " Evening " and Mr. Brett Young's " Quails ' should now speak to a wider public.

Author: Null
Title: Georgian Poets
Full_text:
GEORGIAN POETS.
I * _
M1ODERN REALTSM AND
MORALITY.
AGE OF ""PROSE AND
TZING-BOOM."
(By Maurice Hewlett.)
Mlr. Williams-EDlis in her book " An Anatomy of Poetry " (Blaokwell) does not, as she professes, anatomize poetry: that would puzzle her, as it has puzzled many a poet and many a philosopher. ]Rather, she makes a bold incision in Our corpus poeticum, and would have us believe that her klife follows a natural line of cleavage.
She believes that " Georgian" poetry, by which she really means post-belum poetry, severed by act of hers, has really been organically severed all the timeonly we did not know it. Having de. monstrated that to her own satisfaction, she then deals with her separated mass, poet by poet-one of them, by the way, being Mr. Sturge Moore: qua diabe a114ait-il faire dans cete gaItre ?
Now, though I am here to be convinced, I should say at once that Ms Williams. Ellis has not convinced me. She has left rme rooted in my old belief that her line of cleavage is not one of nature's but of critics' cleaving. I think still that there is but one differentiation of poetry to be made, which is-, and alwayswilt be, between good poetry and bad poetry. 6he may call that academic, and I dare say that she wvill. I call it common sense.
A more serious argument concerns both matter and manner. Mrs. Williams. Ellis says that " Georgian " poems
are the cspression of an attitude of mind which iS. strongly contrasted with that of the Victoriar,s. These modern writers were
brouRht up in an atmosphere In which the validity of certain truths and the adzirableness of certain virtues were assumed to be Felf-evident. -. . . They lived to aee these virtues, embodied in tho Prussian citizen, produce the late war. Some of them are now inaimed or blind. They thus learned pretty forcibly the horrors of a taken-for-granted morality.
A CocxNny Ruy=.
86 much for ethics; now for s3sthetics:-
They had further been brought up to a belief in the efficacy of certain literary doctrines. For instance, the suitability of certain poetic forms to the freatment of certain subjects . . . the *b;olute fatality to the success of a poem of the presence of certain poetic solecisms (rhymes like "morn" and *da?wn," for example). They lived to sce theso taken-for-granted formult produce-absolutely nothing. . . . If moral right and wrong had been obscured by for'nule, was it not possible that so had testhetic right and wrong?
The answer is that it was not possible. No lapse of years, no incursion of war, will make: "omorn" and "~dawn"-snything but a cockney rhyme. No weariness of strife, nor post-bellum laxitv, can turn "Thou shalt not" into "By all means." Poets were simple, sensuous and passionate long before the late war, and the poets of to-day are not the first to knock chips off' the Tables of Stone, if indeed thoy are doing it. Wea do well or ill, as they write well or ill. But the canons o.f morality and of art are much older than Queen Victoria; and this much is true of the two codes in conjunction, that if you write disgusting poetry, it will, to that extent, be bad poetry.
Well, then, we extend the argument. Milton set out to justify the ways of God to man. But "'Tennyson was even surer about the facts of morality than he was about the facts of poetry "- was he though t-" because, we should now say, he was a Bood poet and an amateur moralist." Does it make you surer of a thing to be an amateur of it ? But never mind.
The difference, says Mrs. WilliamsEllis, between the likes of Tennyson and the poet of to-day is that this one
regards the facts of moralUty . . . not as tbinp to -be defended or attacked, but as things 'to be ascertained. Hence . . a great deal, of the alleged impropriety and nbsorption in questions of sex Of the modern poet. Hncne also much of the renlism of such writers as ltr. Masefeld and Mr. Lascelles Abererombie.
ThE PsEuDo.Swrms.
1Really, I don't know that our poets are more absorbed in sex than they'used to be; and when I remember Swift, I don't kuow that I can say 'that they deal. wit1 it mnore lealistically.' There are more pseudo-Swifts about than is healthy. I cannot deny an. apparent cult, of the violent, the ugly, the crude, and the unrestrained-forth from which, 1 affirm, good poetry will never come. WVe are not 'given many examples of modern realism, as Mrs. M illiams-Ellis camls it: a rather sticky one frolD Mvlr. Gordon Bottomley and one very absurd from Mr. D. Lawrence. This is what she calls "verbal Puritanism" in the latter poet:-
And if I never see her again ? I think, if they told me so,
I could convulse the heavens with mvhborror I think I could alter the frame of things in
my agony.
I think I could break the system with my
heart
I think, in my convulsion, the skies would
break.
I, myself, think that in his convulsion he says the same thing five times. It is not the laws of Sinai or Parnassus that he breaks there, but the law of good sense and the law of sincerity. WZrhat are you to do with a man who talks like that, except toll bim. not 'to be a -go0se t Mrs. Williams-Ellis doesn't think. him at 'all' a gbooe. On the contrarv, her comment is that " Poetrv has conie back to 'what is sometbing like a Words. worthian care and meticulousness in the matter of language." The adjective Eeems to me unfortunate.
After all that, Mrs. Williams-Ellis drops her cleavage and comes up to my own. WThen she says of Feste's song in TzefItA Night that it is Georgian in effect, she intends a compliment to Shakespeare. It fails, though, because she does not produce any Georgian lyric in the least comparable' with it. I do not say that she cannot-but it will take lher "all her 'time." Feste's song is unpremeditated art. I have said something of it and its companions in this p]e~e, and need not repeat it. They were the product of a lyrical age, just
s sprely so as the Border Bsallads were.
Whatever " Georgian" poetry may be,
it is not unpremeditated; nor is ours a lyrical age. It is an age of prose, an age of. Tzing-boom ! As for our harps, ue have hanged them up-somewhere. When poets, as our author says, are "6aaertaining" questions of morality, they are not engaged in lyrical exercises. Lyric poetry must come from the hears or it wrill not fit the lyre.

Author: (By John Middleton Murry.)
Title: Pencillings
Full_text:
Books of the Day.
PENCILLINGS.
ON BAD POETRY.
STEPHEN PHILLIPS AND
THE SOCIALISTS.
(By John Middleton Murry.)
MIr. Clutton-Broek's recent reference to the case of Stephen Phillips brought two things to my mind. One was an idle disCUslon of badness in poetry which had ended in the safe and sound conclusion that the worst, like the finest, effects were wrung out of blank verse (Who was it, by the way, who, when asked for a definition of blank verse, defined it as the cornparative of "'damn ba-l "?) There began the usual rivalry- in producing bad lines of blank verse for the general derision. " A Mr. lWilkinson, a clergyman," was, of course, exhibited. That is not a very bad line, really. It is hopelessly prosaic, no doubt, but badness in poetry is a positive quality; it is not the absence of something that ought to be there, but the presence of something that ought not to be. Bad poetry is not so much prosaic as hyperpoetical. The lines we remembered were, liko Wordsworth's, neutral rather than bad, and we were dissatisfied with them. Suddenly a silent member of the company said that ther worst line of blank verse he had ever read was:-
The mystic sweetness of a garden wet.-
It was, he said, by Stephen Phillips. The competition was ended.
* * * *
It might be worth while to analyse the positive badness of that iine. Even " the mystic sweetness of a wet garden," for all the forcing of accent, would be better. But it would be hopelessly bad. " Mystic sweetneass" is 9 impossible phrase; we mnight even go so tar as to say that ".mystic" is an impossible epithet in poetry at all times. At the best it is a cheap conjuring trick. In Stephen Phillips's line it is only a would-be impressive synonym for "mysterious " or " strange." " The strange sweetness of a wet garden " might pass muster in prose: changed into that blank verse it is made emptilly pompous by " mystic," and the rhythm is murdered by the inversion, " a garden wet." But the explanation explains nothing. There is an enormity in that line which cannot be analysed into its elements: there is, in fact, a " mystic badness" about it.
The other association suggested by the name of Stephen Phillips is kinder to his memory. It is an incident which, it seems to me, has a signiflcance of its own. One Sunday morning in the early autumn two years ago I was walking in Hampstead, and I passed a group of people arguing in the open road in front of Jack Straw's Castle. Instinctively I slowed down to listen. As usual, they were arguing for and against Socialism. Thinking that nothing would come of it, I had begun to move away when my ear was caught by the name of Stophen Phillips. Instantly I was curious. What eould his name be doing in that argument? I pushed my way forward and saw that a fat man of about sixty was the dominant personality. lie had puffy red cheeks and small twink. ing grey eyes, which continually swerved away from a hot-tempered and rather dirty young man in spectacles with whom hoe was arguing, and roamed benevolently over thi company. With a podgy hand ho fingered a thick gold watch-chain; and he wore . an old. yellow straw hat. He looked like a genial and none too prosperous pablican' Aid I naturally concluded that he was arguing against Socialism.
But not at all. It was he who had mentioned- Stephen Phillips, for lie mcntioned him again. He had relapsed into a far-away look and a patient smile while he stood listening to the fiery young man, vho was obviously an extremist. lIe looked like one, and besides he violently denounced Mr. J. H. Thomas. for " ratting." WVhen he had done, the fat man said: " I don't know anything about that. What I do know is that there was a man called Stephen Phillips. He was one of the finest poets in our time, and. wve let him die in the gutter." He-said it quietly, without emphasis. Nobody seemed to care. The sense of the meeting seemed to be that poets were queer fishes anyhow. and you couldn't afford to' worry about what happened to them.
* * *: *
The fat man was a dittle disgusted. "Perhaps you've never heard of Stephen Phillips? " he said to us all. * There was no answer. "Well,": he sighed, " he was a fine poet, he was, and he finished up by having to cadge for a shilling for a drink. We let him die." Ile paused. "I don't know anything about this young gentleman's ideas," he wqnt on. " I'm oldfashioned," he said with a charming smile. " I've worked hard, and I've read a few books, and I don't want my books or my little house taken away. But I do say there's something b- wrong with a country that lets a poet like Stephen Phillips die in the gutter. That's the kind of thing that makes me a Socialist." He spoke so quietly that every one was impressed and silent, except the young man with the spectacles. ..
"Have you read Karl Marx's 'Capital' ? " he asked the' fat man truculently.
"As much as I could, I. have, young man. A red-covered book.. I got, it gt home."
"Well 7" said the young man very meaningly.
" Well," said the fat man, smiling,. ".I don't like it 'alf so much as 'John Ball's Dream."'
* * * *
I do not know whether the fat man's account of Stephen Phillips's end is true, though he spoke as one who had known him in his latter days, and perhaps had given him the shillings. But it seems to me that Stephen Phillips's memory gains rather than loses by. the story. It is no small thing for a poet to have been regarded with such kindly reverence b;v an honest man, and to have become for him the symbol of genius and the misfortunes of genius. That achievement shoulfl weigh heavily in the scales against the bad line4 he perpetrated. For me, at any rate,, his, memory is indissolubly united -with that of his generous champion. For him' I have a peculiar affection. Perhaps he was ineffectual: perhaps it is the mark of the Socialist dreamer to prefer "The Dream of John .Ball " to " Das Kapital ": but the quality of the preference .Is I somehow pleasant. And at any rate he was one of those unselfish souls to whom .
'the miseries of the world
Are misery and will not let them rest. They are the silt of tie eatth.

Author: HOBBINOL.
Title: Colin Clout's Corner
Full_text:
COLIN CLOUT'S
CORNER.
"OUR NATIVE AUSTRALIA."
GLEANINGS- rioM AUSTRALASIAN VERSE..
(1) LovE POEMs.: (2) NATUItu POEMS.
Gatliered by MARY E. WILKINSON.
(Mclbourne: Whitcombe and Tombs, 4s. 6d. each.)
One volume of these " Gleanings" has already been published: " Poems of Manhood." The design of the sezies will be appreciated, one hopes, on grounds of patriotism, poetry, and friendship. The anthologist apparently has relied chiefly on contemporaries, but the absence of biographical details makes it hard to say: and although those tliree earlier poets Harpur, Gordon, and Kendall appear, they appear for a brief space only.
For these three the English reader here and there has long had a kindness. There was a forest spirit about that giant backwoodsman, Charles Harpur, which swvept with grand power through his best poetry. His genius rejoiced in the storms that massed their fierce omens, broke in darlkness and left after them " a quiet mind" upon his hills. He is not well realized in the love sonnet to which he is confined .in the present anthologies. Of kindred inspiration and still more striking eloquence was Harpur's friend Kendall. whose two poems in the " Naturc " volume d6 not reveal his nearly fcrocious vigour, as
rattles over riven rocks The thiunder harshi aniid dry,
And blustering gum and brooling box
Are threshing at the sky I
Then Gordon, master of rhythms since pirated by poetical cheapjacks, florid at times but daring always, beat out his own path; wi'ielding, indeed, his long lines as a stock-rider might his wrhip. And in company with these it is not unreasonable to set Alfred Domett, whose thirty years in New Zealand inspired the sinigular and voluble poem " Ranolf and Amohia," with such pictures as that of the Fountain Terraces:-
Such fairy work as frost alone Were equal to, could it o'erlay
With tender crust of crystals fairFine spikes so delicately piled-
Not wintry trees, leaf-stripped and bare, But summer's vegetation, rich and wild.
Of the many poets chosen by the compiler, nione reveals so definite an individuality as those now mentioned; but there is no lack of distinguished pieces, both of love and of nature. Facile lyrics abound in Australia-indeed, they do everywheie-but, on the whole, a radiant directness of deeper impulse characterizes these songs from the South. Mr. Souter, for instance, wrvites in homely words and rhythm:
The rime was on the barley-grass as we
passed the homestead rails;
A Darling Jackass piped us in, with hlis trills
and turnis and scales;
And youth and nlcalth and carelessness sat
on the saddle bow-
And Mary lived at Irlsh Lords, on the road
to Ivatnhloe.
But with a suddenncss pworthy of the elder ballad he closes on "that stern word, Nevermore." Nessun maggior dolore; true for all time, and ever a tantalizing mood for the best poets' expression. There are several other poems here which call for remnark: they leave that sweet wish in the mind (in the words of one of them)
to glide tlrough busy life Like some small brook alone,
That vinds its way 'mid grassy knolls,
Its music all Its own.
I HIO3BINOL.

Author: Null
Title: Colin Clout's Corner
Full_text:
COLIN CLOUT'S
CORNER.
POETRY OF THE DAY.
THiE REALISTIc REVOLT IN MoDE:RN
POETBY. By A. M. CLAnRK (Oxford: Blackwell. 2s. 6d.)
Professor Clark is "bewildered in our poetic Babel," but he has girded himself, gone hither and thither resolutely listening, and now he tells us what he heard. There were sounds, he records, of a violent reaction to refined art. They break down all the carved work thereof with axes and hammers. "It is a quest for the .pimitive " : " The age- of humanism is gone." This was the belief borne in upon him by the publicities of noise achieved lby much free verse, where once 'the. deliscate and stately music of Arnold aiid Heredia charmed the ear. Nor is it free verse only which displeasedAhiasense; the 'writers of traditional.verse are faulty- and slatternly, dodgiig rhymes with base ingenuity, wrenching language, coptorting rhythm.
But he is not a pessimist, or at. any rate not a confirmed pessimist. If he was, he could never have persuaded himself to read and to appraise the quantity of poetry, verse and worse to which his pages refer. If he was, he would have taken pains to choose specimens of " worse " in all its glory far more disgusting to "A Constant Reader" and "Laudator" than those he gives. His are mild to the first one which I have at at hand:-
by god i want above fourteenth
fith's deep purring biceps, the mystic
screech
of Broadway, the trivial stink of rich frail firm asinine life
(i pant for what's below. . . . &c.
And, indeed, he hardly seems confident of the extent to which the " Whitmaniacs," as he calls them, are representative of modern poetry. His statement " This revolt is in many ways more apparent than real," though countered by another, "In all the arts, poetry included, we are misled by new artistic aims, definite only in revolt," is to be observed in this connexion. Or again, one finds him on one page distressed 'at "our poets, too conscious of themselves to be completely sincere ; on another saying, "What we have to be thankful for above all is the abundant sincerity of our poets."
The truth is, I believe, what Professor Clark has been at moments inclined to think-the revolt is nothing very terrible. Much of the vers libre which forms the official organ of the renegadosc is scarcely more than vers de aoietAe ; the Person- of Quality would no longer revel in feminine rhyme but in the most sordid, the most ferocious, the most shapeless outcry (warranted harmless). " London Lyrics" should no longer run
This is Mabel's window-pane;
These are Mabel's roses... ibut
Stop, driver ! Bump I The identical I The very place !
The magnolias recount the assignation pianissimo, and so on, freely. But such things do not affect the few beautiful poems that have been written in novel
forms, nor the relation of those achieve-' ments to the body of contemporary verse. They are one phase of the inevitable " period " of our verse, a small rare flower ; meanwhile, among the countless attempts, in traditional form, that happen every year, not a few additions are made to the English treasury of poetry. The younger poets are men for the most part well versed in the best of their forerunners and jealous for their fame ; at worst, as Professor Clark in one. of his kindlier moments says, they are only " trying to establish a compromise between the Whitmanists and the old loyalists."
HOBBINOL.

Author: Null
Title: Mr. Hardy's New Volume
Full_text:
MR. BIARDY'S, NEW
I - VOLUME.
LATE AND EARLY
LYRICS.
A DUALITY OF SELVES.
LATE LYRics AND EARLiER WITH xM&Y
OTHER VEBsEs. By THomAs HARDY. (Macmillan. 7s. 6d.)
One of the poems in this book begins:In a heavy time. I dogged myself
along a louring way,
Ti my leading self to my following self
Said: "VWhydo you hang on.me
So harassingly?"
The leading self is one who feels and dreams ;. the following self is a matterof-fact fellow who dislikes illusion and distrusts feeling. In word and movement, and subject and sense, this poem, "1He follows himself," is right Hardy, and, up to a point, it is shrewd self-criticism. There are always the two Hardys : one acutely sensitive to joy and pain, both his own and others', and one ever shrinking back from feeling into cold thought, because joy: is brief and chancy, and pain is sure. There always have been the two selves * for in " A Young Man's Exhortation," a poem of 1857 now first printed, we see them at loggerheads, with the leading self bearing it off in the end.
If I have seen one thing
It is the passing preciousness of dreams;
That aspects are within us ; and who seems
Most kingly is the King.
Both selves are poets, and so readily and wholly poets that the tiniest incident, or even a day with no incident in it, can open in one or other of them the reserves of being and the passion for singing. When the two work together, then comes Thomas Hardy's finest poetry. One secret of the greatness of " The Dynasts " is that in it the leeIding self could tell his huge passionate story in harmony with the following self's logic, and the following self found his logic lit to splendour by the passion of the leading self. Often the duality gives us that sort of amcabman poem well known to students of Hardy. Here is the first verse of a new one
-When friendly summer calls again, Calls again
Her little flfers to these hills,
We'll go-we two-to that arched fane of leafage where they prime their bills Before they start to flood the plain
With quavers, minims. shakes, and trills.
"-We'll go," I sing; but who shall say What may not chance before that day I
And sometimes the following self has things nearly all his own way.
But the outstanding and delightful impression which a first study of this new volume leaves is the power of the leading self. The first poem in the book contrasts good weather with bad. And, if the poet shuns the w et and the cold, he thoroughly enjoys the experience of shunning it and the power in his craft vhich can turn the experience to beauty. A stronger instance is.easy to find. In " Penance," a pale, thin man sits playing on an old harpsichord, to which he would not listen when a dead woman had played
it:-
I do to-day
What I would not then ; and the chill old keys,
Like a skull's brown teeth Loose in their sheath,
Freeze my touch; yes, freez.
For all its grimness, that is not the work of the following self, the denier: it is the work of the leading self, the affirmer, with his sensitiveness, his biting imagination, his intensity. of experience and of utterance. Every now and then in this new book -there comes a touch of that crabbedness which shows that this poet works not through sound to sense but through sense to sound, and does 'not always push right through to his end. Making for beauty first of all by exact adaptation of words to thQught.and feeling, he is more, perhaps, than most poets at the mercy of his own leads of vitality; for should his feeling or his vision flag, he cannot cover up the droop with decoration. And to watch hima working in this way is to see how very great are his vitality, his apprehension, his intensity; how much of positive delight in experience there is in him, for all his regrets, his fond loyalties to the past, his tenderness towards all sufferers, trees, birds, men, women. From this new book we- learn once more that he can sing as purely as a boy ("First or Last" is one of. the sweetest little songs that he has ever macde), and tell strange and tragical tales; can. achieve, by his own method of precision, sudden suggestions of immeasurable greatness, or flashes of description so vivid that they all but make one jump, and can weave his own music, like no one else's, now involved and recurrent, and now as clear and sweet as a quick stream, using words that no one else has dared to use in poetry, and rhythms that no one else has lit upon-all by means of the force of his apprehension and imagination and the power in him that must turn to poetry whatever he thinks or feels.
There is an." Apology " prefixed to these poems. The following self wrote a good deal of it; and only the following self would have bothered to reply to the nonsense whereby people have tried to make Hardy out the versifier of a borrowed pessimism. But the following self gets in a neat little bit or two.

Author: (By Edmund Blunden.)
Title: Landscape In Verse
Full_text:
BMooks of the Day.
LANDSCAPE IN
VERSE.
18TH CENTURY
POETS.
I (By Edmund Blunden.)
There have been of late signs and rumours enough of a new-critical enjoyment of eighteenth-century poetry. The attention of book-collectors,. bibliographers, and anthologists appears, perhaps through the evident overcrowding in the earlier fields, to be tuming to that one; and for the mere luxury and love o0 (to say the least) a pleasing poetical content in the delightful dress of the eighteenth-century quartos, no excuse is ehneeded.
Whether the research that is now in full cry will succeed in adding unto us poets Iand poems of startling appeal, overlooked lir the swarm of contemporary publicists t or by the vagaries of taste, is too hazardous a question even for a 'wide solution. This may be said, that it will increase the pleasures of reading that are available without the' help of special collections.
The chances are that the poetical status of the times of Pope and Prior, Thomson and Gray, will not be. sen|sationally revised; but equally we have Ithe prospect of happy modest flights of fancy, social and amicable trifles turned with the neatness that is a little lower than genius, and pastorals not the less alluring because Celia treats Strephon with considerable coolness on an English upland, and there are footnotes explaining that the solan-goose is " An aquatic bird, on.'.the eggs of which the inhabitants of St. Kilda, another of the Hebrides, chiefly subsist."
RURAL VIGNETTES.
One characteristic, a lovable characteristic, of the eighteenth century, familiar to those who find their recreation; if not their spiritual refreshment, in the treasurehouses decreed by Robert Dodsley' in Pall Mall, or Geo. Pearch after him, will for various reasons puzzle the anthologist precisely how to represent it. It is the habit, amounting to a peaceful passion, of doting on landscape, and of painting it in words. The effect is that of water-colour, for the most part.
The anthologist's difficulty will lie in the facts that the verse which I speak of in itself is not so various, since it deals principallY witb quiet rural scenery in the one way; and that it often occurs, like a prospect between rows of houses, in the midst of a lengthy and ephemeral poem, a bright interim. Those evergreen pieces, Matthew Green's " The Spleen " and John Dyer's " Grongar Hill," can scarcely be denied their 2place, and they indeed record, mn unp?retentious and yet almost perfect colouring, the English scene at large. The brown fallowvs still keep their Sabbath, as thev did for the Or,lske, ,-lr,+. 9+;n X
the clover, pea and bean Vie in variety of green. Dyer's hilltop still gazes
Where the evening gilds the tide-
How clse end sinall the hedges liet
What streaks of meadowvs cross the eye!
But the full contemporary sway of a kindred enchantment will be difficult to convey in a selection'based on poetic intensity. t b
Even thonigh the writers preserved in Dodsley and other repositories were what they have been admitted to be, imitative, and settled in some humble smallholding at the foot of the poetic mountain, there was a skill and there remains a sweet means of contentment in their easygoing verses. The pleasure that they had I genuinely felt is pleasure still, an innocent brightness. The eighteenth-century mind, that had no illusions of its being associAted with the etemals, found life agreeable; wished to say so; took, therefore, such a topic as "The Valetudinarian" or "Wisdom," and, remembering Milton, said so in verse.
FORGOTTEN SINGERS..
The result was probably an exordium banishing the antipodes of the matter"Hence, Disease and pining Pain," or "Hence, simpering Folly, hence," and then, after the just allowance of unwvanted personifications, the invitation, " But come, thou Goddess boon and young." Till, presently, the ai.thor has arrived at his especial rural scene,-
The bleating flocks; the lowing kine;
The smoking- cots, and pointed spires, The setting sun's reflecting flres; Woods dark waving in the dale;-
Rays which gleam; and clouds which sail; Shades and lights by turns contending; Gradual colours softly blending...
Thus, Dr. Marriott, who published one volume of poems. One may readily find a rval admirer from Dodsley's six volumes or Pearch's four; "- Esq." (Dr. Marriott's name itself is nowadavs scarcely more enlightening), is certainly no less of a lover and rather more of an observer. Who would not acknowledge the plain, the delicate truth of some lines in his poem " Vacation " (which informs us indirectly by its " Aroint thee " at the outset that - Esq. was a law stur dent) ?:
Soon as ev'ning clouds have shea
Their wat'ry stote on earth's soft bed, And through their flowing mantles thin Clear azure spots of sky are seen,
I quit some oak's close-cover'd bow'r To taste the boon of new-fallIn show'r To pace the corn-field's grassy edge,
Close by a fresh-blown sweet-bri'r hedge; 'While at every green leaf's end Pearly drops of rain depend,
And an fmrtlby iragrance round
Rises from the moisten'd ground. Sudden a sun-beam darting out
Brightens the landskip all about,
With yellow light the grove o'erspreads, And tips with gold the haycock's heads: Then as mine eye is eastward led, Some fair castle rears its head,
Whose beight the country round com-
mands,
Well-known mark to distant lands,
There the windows glowing bright Blaze from afar with ruddy- light
Borrow'd from clouds of scarlet dye, Just as the sun hath left the sky.
In the present state of poetry, the rural theme is frequent, but we do not often meet with the eighteenth-century's landscape-drawing there. Perhaps it would not be too much in the laudator spirit to say that we are not so appreciative of the lie of the land, the order of tilth and tithebarn, pond and sheepwalk, the embattled wood and the emhosomed*lodge-house, as was that age. The eighteenth century was its own best critic, and in its own best octosyllables laughed its foible to the blush, its ha-has, its Chinese temples, its dumpy statuary, its waters winding
Tn angles. curves end zig-zag lines, From Halfpenny's exact designs.

Author: Null
Title: Disaffection
Full_text:
Books of the Day.
DISAFFECTION.
FORM AND PHOBIA.
(By A. Clutton-Brock.)
Thlo Victorians, especially the Victorian poets, were guilty of an offence that now seems unpardoniable: they wore their hearts on their sleeves. Their poetry was all poetry of the affections, and disgust Played but a small part in it. For them it was a virtue, as wvell as a delight, to like things ; and they were never ashamed, they were evenl proud of simple feelings aroused by such objects and events as have aroused them all tlhrough the ages.
Sianburne in his youth seemed a dangerous rebel; Meredith, always and especially in his verse, was held to be perverse and difficult; but both of them, really, wore their hearts on their sleeves, like Tennyson and Browning. " Love in a Valley," for instance, is one long surrender to the tender passion, that same old tender passion to whiclh the Song of Songs surrendered itself. Swinburne cursed, at times, iu a simple primitive way, but he preferred to bless ; and evei' his cursing was a -kind of negative llessing; you could see what he loved in what he hated and the music was always the same. As for Tennyson-well, he was utterly naked and unashamed in the expression of his affections ; and so was Browning. Both of them rush to beautiful and pleasant subjects with an eagerness that now seems indecent. They are never anxious to face the hideous facts of life ; they prefer the other kind.
No one can deny that they had their artistic defects. It seems to us now that they had a habit of saying more than they felt and that this habit got into the ,very sound of their verse. Their cadences were obvious, and sometimes they remind us of the throaty tenor or the languishing violin-
That even the weariest river
NVinds somewhere safe to sea.
How very weary that sounids; and how plainly you can hear the singer sliding down to an expected close in-
0, for the touch of a vanished hand And the sound of a voice that is still.
We cannot understand now how anyone could write anything so obvious as that, both in sound and in sense; and Browning, in "The Lost Leader," is no less obvious. There, too, you can hear the voice rising in manly indignation; and falling more in sorrow than in anger; there is not a young poet writing now who would give himself away so simply. Certainly their poetry is all terribly tuny, as Wagnerianis used to say of Mozart a generation ago; and they would abandon themselves to their tunes like Venetian Gondoliers in moonlight.
PoErTuy or DISLI,D.
Now it all seems so far off that people psychologize about it; they explain how the Victorians disguised the workings of the sexual instinct in themselves, but they are not aware that one can also psychologize about the poetry of to-day, much of wbich seems to express nothing but a series of phobias. It is an interesting question both aDsthetic and psychological, whether it is possible to write poetry only about what you dislike; and the attempt is now being made by many young poets. Repression betrays itself in their form no less than in their content. Not only do they refuse to write about anything which has been the subject of poetry in the past, but their very refusal sounds also in their verse, or in that avoidance of verse which is called vers libre. The name is not a good one; for there is nothing free about most of it. Freedom is positive; but, in purpose and in form, much vers libre is negative; it is an avoidance of every rhythm and cadence, in which former poets have expressed positive feelings. You can see the writer incessantly flinching away from the obvious, rejecting the tunes and the emotions that offer themselves, like a jaded Sultan in his seraglio; and this gesture of rejection, repeated with growing impatience, is all that he has to offer in the way of poetry. The result is pathologically rather than artistically interesting.
Meanwhile the expression of positive feelings is left to the vulgar. The task that was once worthy of Mozart and Keats is now performed in music-halls and draw:ng-room ballads. The artist smiles enig-
natically at it all; but about what? fter all these phobias and refusals and repressions, what positive thing remains. Behind their dislikes what do they like ? That, finally, is what we wish to know of a poet or any kind of artist; and he must not incessantly take cover in irohy about the absurd affections of other people. Sooner or later he must come out into the open and express his own affections to us. Already we grow tired of this poetry, and all this art, that is merely disaffected. There is nothing intrinsically interesting in dead cats and cigarette ends, nor shall we wish to hear about them for ever, merely because the Victorians gave us a little too much of lovers and moonlight. The danger ahead, in fact, is a too violent reaction; and I expect the next generation of poets to outdo the Victorians in sentimentality and simplicity. Someone will discover that Haynes Bayley was a great poet, and " She wore a vTeath of roses " will be the pattern for the most advanced verse. Those who turn too violently from sweets to unsavouries will rush back to yet sweeter sweets to get the taste out of their mouths.

Author: Null
Title: Books Of The Day
Full_text:
BOOKS OF THE DAY.
-L
ENGLAND I'N POETRY.
Here perhaps is a "gift-book" that many have been looking for at this season. It has several qualities to recommend it; it is neither new nor old; it ought to be as acceptable to the general as to the highly critical; it is well printed, and, above all, it is cheap. We have only one misgiving about it, though the misgiving vanishes when we have explored its pages; but at first sight the title, POEms oF HoXE AND OvausEAs: Compiled by Charles Williams and V. H. Collins (Clarendon Press, 3s. net), may put too hasty bookbuyers off the scent. But it accurately describes the contents, for most of the poems in this anthology are about England and the rest are about English lands overseas.
Let not those who insist on saying Britain for England grow indignant; for the greater includes the less, and the English language holds all together. Although Coleridge wrote " 0 dear Britain, 0 my mother isle," he is in the minority, and of our latest poets few, except Mr. Doughty, have chosen to stray from the patriotic tradition sanctified, if not begun, by Shakespeare, and continued, through a long succession, down to the days of Noyes, De la Mare, Flecker, Brooke, and Cripps. By quoting some of the living names we wish to indicate at once that besides the old there is plenty of new or recent poetry in this volume ; and it is the judicious and yet liberal inclusion of writers whose copyright has yet years to run that gives half the charm to this collection. The other day a modern versewriter made an attack on the compilers of anthologies, not for what they omit, but for what they desire to insert: he argued that to obtain a place in an anthology does a contemporary writer more harm than good, because the public is thereby led to think that he has written nothing else worth reading. But to those who cannot be expected to buy volume after volume as they come out and yet wish to know something of the better products of the modern English muse, an anthology like this is of real service. It is supplemented, but not dominated, by the classics ; im fact, nobody here dominates or overshadows anybody else ; from Chaucer to the latest of them all meet sub specie sodalitatis.
So taking the established great on trust, thankful that they are there, and that, all told, they are in the majority, and not repining if certain favourites are missing, we may judge this collection rather by the living writers to whom the two editors gave a place. The first thing to rejoice over is the inclusion of several pieces frequently quoted, but not always easy to find; for instance, Newbolt's "Clifton Chapel," Q.'s " Alma Mater," Bowen's "Forty Years On," Davidson's "Runnable Stag," Belloc's " South I Country," and Cripps's " Essex." Happily
there are no war poems, and perhaps only one or two which show the influence of the war; nor is the Imperialist note pro| nounced, but when it is sounded it is
heard not materially, but spiritually, as in -Sir A. Conan Doyle's " Frontier Line," which for all its deliberate imitation, is a decided improvement on its German prototype. The next thing to be glad of is the high standard which the editors have demanded of their contemporaries: they are believers in form, and show preference for the memorable. Naturally there are some inequalities, but on the whole a distinct family resemblance is maintained, and much the same features can be traced among the older representatives of the family.
And what are these family characteristics ? Among them, no doubt, are love of country, national pride, loyalty to hearth and home, and delight in natural beauty; but these qualities do not by themselves altogether set the tone. We must add at least cheerfulness, good humour, and an occasional propensity towards individual oddity. The effect that these excerpts make on the mind is akin jto that made by Edward Thomas's i anthology, though that was mostly prose; England is, on the whole, a cheerful place, and despite a modern wistfulness, absent 'from the older writers, and suggesting history learnt and responsibility realized, the English are yet a cheerful people, even when absence from home tinges their thoughts with sadness. They do not take their sorrows too seriously; at any rate, there is no moping or frenzy in these pages; much more often does the sense of humour lie a close neighbour to melancholy. The editors, we should say, are in broad agreement with Thomas's reading of the English character; and consequently we find more than one specimen of his poetry here, and well does it deserve to be handed down. So, for all its strangenesses, does Mr. Doughty's " Muse of Britain " merit publication, apart from its original context. But selection becomes too invidious. A word must be added about the arrangement of the extracts ; they fall into five sections:-In praise of England, Merry England, the English Land, Places, and Overseas. The last section contains little work by actual oversea authors; but that little is often on our lips and quoted in our newspapers.
