Author: JALOUX., M. EDMOND
Title: Literature
Full_text:
LITERATURE.
RECENT WORK IN
FRANCE.
POETRY AND ROMANCE.
By M. EDMOND JALOtX.
If we ex2amine the state of French literature as a whole since the armistice we see that it reveals characteristics which are not very different from those of politics. I mean that the opposing tendencies which are to be remarked are; on the one hand,- a definite -wish to return to classicism and the spilit of tradition, and, on the other, a desire to upset& everything and re-create everything anew, even sy,rntax and almost language-briefly, an Extreme Right and an Extreme Left.
It seems to me that in England the latter is more familiar than the former. I have read, from tiime to time, more than one article which praised the tendencies of the advanced' school, with a v1isible -contempt. for the rest. For t,wenty years- there has been- an inclnation to regard every literary and artistic I*Work simply from the point of view of its novelty, and to consider that its essential quality consists in saving what
as not yet- been said. One should be on -one's guard against such a point of view as against a regular disease of the spirit, otherwise one quickly arrives at incoherence and foolishness. It is especiaUy necessary to remember that the characteristic quality of the French minid is its balance, tiat is, the gift which it possesses of arriving at a mean between actions violently contradictory. In the present case, it vill certainlv succeed in giving a classic life to literary elements of the most turbulent and disturbing lkind. If it were not for the revolutionaries, our writers enamoured of classicism would soon arrive at vain repetitions and sterility;, if it were not for the classicists, the innovators would founder in disorder and madness.
These remarks apply more particularly to poetry, which is verv clearly marked by a traditional group and an anarchist group. The other day there appeared a verv well-compiled anthology entitled the Pleiade. It was selected bv one of our best poets, Joachim Gasquet, author of the Chants Secuiaires and the Hymnes, who died quite recentlv, in May, 1921. It include§ Joachim Ga-cauet himself, the Comtesse de Noailles, gXwier de Magallox. Charles Deren-nes, Pierre Canco, Femand ?Iazade, and Pauil Val6rv.
With the exception of the last. named, these poets seek to give a cla-sic form to emotions which, whatever they may sav. are almost all Romantic in inspiration. In every case one finds happy images, a very special sense of music and ly,rical sincerity, coupled with much emphasis. often exaggerated. To these names must be added those of Abel Bonnard, Jean Louis Vaudover, Paul Souchon, Emile Henriot, Lucien Fabre, Robert Vallery-Radr,t, Andr6 Th6rive, Eus6be de Br6monen d'Ars, Albert Erlande, Fernand Gregh, Maurice Levaillant, and manv others. If they have one feature in cominon-and ihey have, beeause thev belong to the same!generation-it is that their romantic imagination is tempered bv discretion and a taste which the poets of- 1830 liever knew; they also show traces of an old love of the symbolic poets-a certain feeling for the inner life, for the tliings of the soul, for the inborn analogies which ex5st between the outer world and ourselves. On the other hand, they have completely forgotten that there has been a French Parnassus, neither picturesque nor rich of rhyme, nor glittering, but even, -often enough, showing a Idnd of poverty in poetic craftsmanship and technical resources-
SYMBouLsrs As-i UNANUMISTS.
If we now 'turn to an entirely opposite school, we find a complete reviv-al of symbolism--at least, such as was manifested by it-s originators, Uallarmn6 and ArthuLr Rimbaud. Rimbaud especiaUy raised up a whole group after his likeness, which sought like himn to create a world entirely of the brain, without common me-asure witlh our own, a world strange, absolute, and impenetrable. To the influence of Rimbaud came to be added that of MNarinetti and of Guillaume Apollinaire and of the psycho-analysis of Vienna and Zuirich, lwhence spring those pieces withoaut logical coherence, composed of single words, of sl- and half imperceptible analogies, of unexpected tr'cks, mingled w^ith true and just impressions,- with delightfuil banter, the -whole snatched, as it were, with great difficulty from the subconscious life of the brain.
The names of Mlanx Jacob, Andr6 Salmon, Blaise Cendrars, Louis Aragon, Andre Breton, Philippe Soupault, Pierre Reverdy. Jacques Rigauit. Pali Morand, are inseparably associated with these attempts-names to which must be added those of Jean Cocteau, George Gabory, and Radiguet, who, starting from the same source, seem now to wish to return to it through the style of the quatrains of Mallarln6 to I know not what delicate and nalve art of images d'Epinal in literature.
FinaUv we must not forget either the lUnanmi.sts,whoFe rude and inembroidered poetry seeks to interpret the social and general movements of humanity, Jules Romnains, Diuhamel, Luc DIirtaini. Jomve, Arcos, Vildrac, or that little band of fantastic poets who, inspired- by Jotulet who died in 1920, mingle with their light imagination -the irony, the grace, t.he unexpecte.d, of the old poets of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, Francis Carco, Jean Pellerin, Ren6 Bizet, Tristan Dereme,- Philippe Chabaneix. AU these poets have published collections since the arnistice and may therefore be judged bv their work.
But I must linger a moment over the most importarnt - of them. Les Forces Etcrnelles, by the Comtesse de Noailles. It is a vXehement and grandiose work, containing two elements 'which are generally irreconcilable andi which are here united by the genius of the poet- on the one hand, a natural lyricism, easy, abundant, admirable ill eloqluence, though an eloquence sometimes too obvious
ann too rhetorical i on the other , a painful s eeeking after human and poetic trutth, lines admnirable and Profound, which sink into the very dePths of the fsoul, One of the highest and purest of
the lyric flounts which have fed humanith . This enormouis book swings between these
two poles--sometimes it is influenced by that kindl of laaw of enumeration
which makes so many? poe ms end with a imaeime adding-up of theme,s s sometimes it nchie s;es those pieces, poignant, sincere, restrained and sober in e xpression, which to) s sa nothing of their picturesque
exterior, result in the finest lyric analyses whiwh it is possible to conceive. Perhaps in this book Mine. do IN'oaailles's music is less rich, less sippless le, haisonioous than in ththe earlier works, but on the other hand, the intellectual and sentiffemntal expression is more intense and true.
31-M. Paul Valry, too, is unrivalle d. It is no doubt realized : ttat this great pbc p belongs to t hhe - gneration of -the
<NEWPAGE>
post-symbolists, to that of the writers who, like Pierre Loilys, Andr6 Gide and Camille Mauclair, came immediately after the Regniers, the Barres, the Paul Adams, the Vi6l6-Griffins. At the age of 25, Paul Valery was celebrated in a
roup of young nmen; then for a long time he kept silence. But, in 1917 he published a new poem, La Jeune Parque, which had considerable success. To-day, Paul Valery holds a privileged place; the reviews struggle for his poems, of which a slim collection appeared recently. It is certain that if Paul Val6ry -is adniired to. this extent, he is in some sort recasting, French poetry. Two essential things distinguish him from other poets-first, the very matter of his verse, which seeks to borrow from the voice itself its ductility, its inflexions, its sweet. variety; then the moral element of which. his verse is nmade, which is in no way accidental or human (in the sense in which a piece of news is human), but intellectual, .abstract and full of allusions to those continuous phenomena which formn the very life of thought. These are the two great original qualities of Paul Val6ry; if space permitted, I would gladly have set them forth more fully.
Turning now to romnance, we find genres less marked than in poetry. Let us pass by for the moment the great writers, who have published since 1919 works as fine as those which came before that date, and to whom we shall refer later. There remain among the young writersthat is to say, the novelists of from 25 to 40-two very definite movements. The one is composed of analysts, writers on the inner life, some of whom study feelings, others ideas and irnages; it must be said that, from this point of view, the present generation will leave clear traces upon the intellectual history of our time. The other consists of writers of adventure, visibly influenced by the great English writers from Daniel Defoe to Stevenson. The whole of the intellectual youth of France belongs to one or the other, and sometimes seeks to unite the two currents.
The analytic novel, in its new form, is chiefly represented by the names of Marcel Proust, Jean Giraudoux, Val6ry Larbaud, Jean Schlumberger, Francis de Miomandre, Paul Morand, Gilbert de Voisins, Jean Louis Vaudoyer, Ernile Henriot, Andr6 Th6rive, Pierre de Barneville, myself and others.
Marcel Proust is clearly one of the most eminent men of the time; he has had the courage to make an entirely fresh study of the human being and not to admit that it possesses any moral movement which is not, in his view, verified by experience-whence his bold* ness and the importanee of what he has
to tell us. It may be said henceforth that there was a psychology before Proust and that there will be one after him.
The case of Jean Giraudoux is very different. He is in the first place a fantasist, but a fantasist who rests upon truth. Imagine an analyst who. does not wish to analyse or demonstrate anything at all, but who makes us perceive all that passes in the soul of his heroes by a play of images, sometimes witty, sometimes lyrical, sometimes ironical. He has points of contact at the same time wvith La Fontaine, with Heine, and with Meredith.
Less recent than the foregoing, Val6ry Larbaud has an extraordinarily just feeling for truth, and with an art acid, sharp, troubled, and a delicate and singular intelligence, he handles moral problems which until his time remained almost impenetrable. The life of the adolescent, of quite young girls, acquires under his pen peculiar freshness and intensity. It may be added that the scene of Valery Larbaud's last novel, Beaute, men beau Souci . . . is London, of which it contains admirable pictures, especially of Chelsea. I have more particularly mentioned three men who seem to me the best, but I refer you equally to all those whose names I have given. I think that this group of writers is going to add something to the tradition of our psychological novel.
TAT s or ADvEX,RuEx.
It has been wTrongly thought by the critics that the popularity of the book of adventure is to be ascribed in France to the war. I do not say that the war has n6t contributed to it, but it must not be forgotten that in 1912 the Nouvelle Revue Fnaneaise published an important essay by M. Jacques Riviere on what, in his view, a French book of adventure ought to be, and that shortly afterwards Alain-Fournier wrote his Grand-1M16aulnes, which may be regarded as a masterpiece of its kind, and Andr6 Gide his Caves du V'atican.
It may be said, besides, that the book of adventure, hardly arrived on the scene, is already inx course of profound modification-or of miscarriage; in this case adventure turns quicldy into melodrama. Nevertheless, several good authors have already distinguished theniselves in this line. We may mentioa Pierre Benoit, wvith Kanigsia,rck and L'Atlantide; Louis Chadourne,- with Le Maitre du ANavire ; Pierre 3Iac-Orlan, with Le Chant de l'Uquipage and A bord de l'Etoile Matutine; Maurice Larrouy, with Rafail Gatouna; Francis Carco, with L'Equipe; Reae Bizet, with L'Aventure aux Guitares; and others. But which of these writers, except perhaps Benoit and Mac-Orlan, will still be writing books of adventure in ten years' time ? On the other hand, I am quite sure that at the same date neither Marcel Proust nxor Giraudoux, Larbaud nor Miomandre, will have modified his usual manner!
We have also, further, among the young writers, story-tellers, who continue more directly the tradition of their immediate -forbears and niAny of whom possess the greatest talent; such are the powerful realists, more or less tinged with philosophy or idealism, Gaston Ch6rau, J6rome and Jean Tharaudc, Emile Baumann, Henri Duvernois, Marcel Boulenger, Binet-Valmer, Pierre Ville-
tard, and others. It may be added that Louis Hemon, who died recently and who belonged to this group, left a fine study of French Canada in Maria Chappe de Laine.
NEW WORKS BY OLD MASTEBS.
Finally, we must not forget that our well-known novelists have published since the armistice works which count among their best-as if the end of the war had given them all a fresh impulse of energy and power. Thus Prime Jeunesse is one of the finest novels of Pierre Loti, and Le Petit Pierre one of the most perfect works of Anatole France. Paul Bourget has written a magnificent novel in Un Drame dans le 1Monde, and in Le J'usticier and Anomalies books which will remain masterpieces of this kind so characteristically French.
Henri de R6gnier has taken us back in La Pecheresse to the seventeenth century which he knows so well. In Tant pis pour o Gerard'd'Houville gives himself up to the deliciousi fancies of a keen and always poetic imagination. Among others, Abef Hermant has written La Journee brave, a dramatic and poignant picture of the years before the war; Andr6 Gide has given us his admirable Symphonie Pastorale; Louis Bertrand an historic picture in L'Infante; J. H. Rosny art extraordtinary prehistoric tale inx Le~ Fain Giant'; Henri Lavedan a sort of popular epic poem, 1rNne Oldie and
Gaudias; Reae Boylesve a moving portrait of a woman, Elise; Marcel Pr6vost a dramatic story, La nuit finira; and Henri Bordeaux his two studies on the moral consequences of the war, La Reurrection de la Chair and La Chair et l'Esprit.
One may see from this rapid examination the imnportance and vitelity of French literature since the war. We have endeavoured to distinguish from the current flood of production the great laws which direct it and the. currents which are -to be felt in it. Those which we have set forth are certain, but are they last-
g ? Literary fashions change ever more qtuckly. will the movements which wo have indicated survive longer than their predecessors.? The future alone can tell.
TRANSLATIONS IN FRANCE.
The chiefnovels of Thoma3 Hardy have been known in France for 20 yeurs--t all events, Jude the Obacure and Tees of the D'Urberrilles. Other works of Hardy's, less important, have appeared in translation; one only is missing, The Mayor of Casterbridge, which will be published in October among the collection of the Nouvelle Revue Fran$aise. The Nouvelle Revue Franiaise has also undertaken a complete translation of George Meredith-no light task! The Shating of Sle gpat has appeared recently, Beaucha mp's Career and T'he Egoiwt will be out this autumn. The same firm has also undertaken -the translation of the chief works of Henry James, of which the first volume is ready for publication; of Samuel Butler, admirably translated by one of our best young writers, Valery Larbaud; of Joseph Conrad, whose Typhoon has appeared in a perfect translation by Andr6 Gide; and the plays of W. B. Yeats.
Rudyard Kipling was long ago published by the Mercure de France; I believe that the Jungle Book is almost as popular in France as in English-speaking countries. The Sirene, which has already published the plays of Synge, is about to issue John Galsworthy's The Man of Property and James Joyce's Portrait of the Artist in his Youth.
Three publishing houses simultaneously (the Nouvelle Revue Fran.aise, the Edition Francaise Illustr6e, and the Sirene) have issued during the last two years the principal works of R. L. Stevenson, who is extremely popular in France.

Author: Null
Title: Poets And Humanity
Full_text:
POETS AND HUMANITY.
DEFECTS OF THE ROMANTIC SCHOOL.
Professor Grierson delivered yesterday beforethe British Academy the Warton Lecture on English Poetry, and took as his subject “ Byron, Arnold, and Swinburne.”
The Lecturer recalled the controversy which had been excited in the eighties of last century by Matthew Arnold’s claim that Wordsworth and Byron were the greatest English poets of the V.'th century. To this Swinburne had replied with the utmost reverence, speaking with respect of Wordsworth, but emptying upon Byron’s head the frothing vials of his shrill and exuberant vituperation, and championing against both the more purely imaginative and musical poetry of Coleridge and Shelley. This attitude towards Byron was explicable if one recalled the exotic spirit and exquisite technique of tho poetry of the “ sweet new ’• school ot Rossetti and Swinburne, their wonderful reconstructions of old moods and old modes. The style ot I) yr on must be judged on its own merits. His accents were those of the orator and the talker, and for his purposes these were the most effective. Swinburne judged him by standards that were not entirely applicable. He was as generous a fighter in tho cause of humanity as Shelley and more practical and intelligible. For Byron there was no escape from the conflict in his soul by way of any romantic dream of a return to nature. The only escape lay in heroic action and self-control, the summons which took him to die in Greece.
The question raised between Arnold and Swinburne was primarily that between poetry as an art, existing for its own sake, and poetry as a reflection and criticism of life. But it also raised the whole question of the, poetry of the Semantic Period. That poetry had been fed on dreams of nature, of the golden age, of the ages of faith, of progress, to an extent that was not true of the great poetry of other epochs—Greek tragedy, Shakespeare, aud the Elizabethans. These had found in human nature as it was, and was always likely to be. tho material for tragedy and comedy and poetry, or if they wrote of ideals it was as an incentive to the individual in the perennial war of good and evil. We had, lost touch with that side of romantic poetry with Milton’s theology. Poetry must come back to earth, and learn with Thomas Hardy that its great theme was humanity regarded with a sense of pity and a sense of humour. It was because Byron was not a romantic at all, as was said by way of reproval, but a poet as full of humanity as that other misanthrope Swift, that his poetry, despite its limitations, had still a touch of magnetism.

Author: Null
Title: Songs And Theories
Full_text:
SONGS -A ND THEORIES.
ACCESSORY MUSIC.
EARLY RECITALS.
Ideas about songs and singing have found an unusually prominent place in the recitals of this week. Mr. Douglas Marshall led the way pn Monday, when, in a programme which he gave at the Æolian Hall, he included a manifesto about the interpretation of poetry through music., This was put forward as the theory on which Mr. Alec Robertson had composed a set of five songs, which were given a central place in the programme.
Mr. Douglas Marshall sang the songs ; he also wrote the manifesto, and arranged that Mme. Adey Brunel should recite each poem before the song was sung. The song, the interpretation, and the theory were trli submitted to the judgment of the audience with a frankness which deserves the response of sympathetic attention. The theory, lilte most theories of art, seemed to us a half-truth. It laid stress on an idea which has been recurring to literary-minded musicians constantly for the last 300 years at least—namely, that the art of adding rnusfe to poetry still requires some justification, which is found in the plea that the music interprets the poetry. But it is when we come to consider how music interprets poetry, or anything else for that matter, that the difficulties begin. If we understood this theory aright, and Mr. Alec Robertson’s practical exposition of it in the songS before us, the answer was that it is to be done by making music conform, as far as possible, to all the dimensions of poetry. Mr. Marshall says, “A changed accent, an over-prolonged syllable to give time for a musical effect, or a volumetric error for the sake of vocal effect, are all unjustifiable.” That answer has been .responsible for most of the wrong tracks which' song writing has taken, because it ignores the fact that music can only be anything when it follows its own laws and fulfils its own dimensions. “ Just note and accent ” are valuable accessories of interpretation, but the great song is the one which throws a wholly riew light on the poem by refashioning it in a musical- design: The more the poetry insists on its own design the less it is likely to provide a suitable opportunity for music. Hence it comes ' that' the majority ot the greatest songs of the world have been made with inferior poetry.
Mr. Alec Robertson and Mr. Marshall, too, are very conscientious in "following every verbal suggestion, and the former ha's been particularly successful in the conversation betwee.1 a nymph and a goblin, called “ Overheard on a Salt Marsh.” Comparing the sung version of the poem with Mmex Brunei’s spoken one, one realized that the two were doing just the same thing through the two mediums of the singing voice and the splitting voice, but one questioned whether the interpretation of the singing voice deserved to be called " soxig" more than that of the speaking voice. Every honest singer knows that the song is more than words plus notes, and Mr. Marshall proved his knowledge of it in singing “Bocca ridenti” with evident dqlight in its purely musical qualities. His tone and wo cal control seem to have improved lately. He found so much to express through them that he denied his own theory in “Land of Heart’s Desire.” one of a selection from " Songs of the Hebrides.’* Indeed, it was so loaded with long-dqiwn vocal effect that one was tempted-to search for " volumetric errors” instead of listening to a simple folksong. It should be mentioned that Mr. Aubyn Raymarfy perfect accompaniment added much to the success of this recital.
Music by Chart.
Miss Ursula Greville’s attempt to combine song with ideas on ths following ; night was less stimulating, because she reduced the song to & minimum, and left the ideas to someone else. Mr. Leigh Henry was her spokesman, and, armed with an elaborate chart of song composers, which reminded one drearily of a plan for telephonic communication in trench warfare, he proceeded to a disquisition on the history of song from primitive chant to Stravinsky. After -20 minutes ot thia sort of thing, to give one verse each'of such songs as " Sally in our alley ” and “ It was a lover arid bis lass,” to proceed then to further disquisition is"-to make rather large demands on the patience of an ’Audience which has come to hear music. Mr. Leigh Henry’s warning against treating music as a literary accessory deserves to he borne in mind in considering the MarshallRobertson theory. In this instance, ’however, music became an accessory to Mr. Leigh Henry, which is worse, and Miss Ursula Greville’s pretty voice and finished style deserved better.
The plan of Mr. Gerald Cooper’s programme at the Mortimer Hall on Wednesday showed him also to be a
singer with ideas. Bach, Mozart, and the Elizabethan song-books foiled- .the first part x>t the - scheme; five poems by W. B. Yeats, set by Philip Heseltine for voice, flute, English horn, -and string quartet, and Bernard van Dieren^ " Schon Rohtraut,” for voice and string quartet,represented ^the moderns. With a new Rhapsody for mezzo-soprano (Miss Dorothy Helmrich) and instruments, by Arthur Bliss, and a Mozart quartet for flute and strings (Koechel, 285), this promised an evening full of interesting variety, but the singing did not fulfil the promise. One feels certain that Mr, Cooper, with his evident taste and perception, could do more to get over the disabilities of a small voice. At present his whole manner is too cramped and restrained to convey anv definite idea of what the music means to him.
On the same evening Miss Ilma Marx gave a recital at the Æolian Hall. Her programme was planned on thoroughly conventional- lines, and placing it beside the experiments we have here described, one realizes that such a programme has its advantages. The singer can concentrate on her performance. Her singing of " Deh vieni " was well polished and musical, it a little inelastic in rhythm. Her voice was not commanding enough to give thorough satisfaction in " Ritorna vincitor" (Aioa), but it was a capable performance. . . .
There were some elements of good singing in Miss Iseult Morice's recital at the Wigmore Hall on Wednesday, if we may make the assumption that she felt very nervous ; for the voice trembled so much that it was sometimes hard to tell what the note was, and it seemed impossible for her to hold any note through to the end unchanged. The words were pronounced unaffectedly, just as we speak them, but not quite clearly enough to enable us to put down the programme and listen. • The phrasing was particularly sane and intelligible, and the idea of the song as a whole was made clear.
“ RectTal Concerts.”
Mr. Sterling Mackinlay did not convince us, by the first of a series of " recital concerts,” as he calls them, winch took place at the Wigmore Hall on Monday night, that he is going to add greatly to the musical amenities of the town. He has not set himself a sufficiently high standard of performance, while the selection of music to be performed does not indicate a character clearly enough defined. Is
there really room lor a programme, for instance, composed for the most part of operatic arias, and per-
-_--—✓ - . 4 of operatic anas, ana formed by young artists of obvious inexperience ? XTwvada Alhriwi tvlin Xvaa THotinev a flpcf
iwmeu uj juuug Muow «
Mme. Sylvienne d Albert, who was malmig a. first appearance, was handicapped by the difficulties of “ Connais-tu le pays ’ from Mignon, and her con----- . 1 assured manner only made her vocal deficiencies stand out the more. She has a soprano voice of excellent quality, but her method is poor
and her singing generally hard and uneven. Miss Dorothie Squire, a mezzo-soprano—-another naturally
voiinais-i fldent and
good voice—also showed lack of thoroughness in training, for she was. inclined to force the tone and get out of tune, while the actual production was “ woqjly.” Mr. Vincent Ryan has a resonant baritone voice and a rough-and-ready style of delivery which made his performance of the Prologue to Paaliaeci heavy and unconvincing.
The New Russian Ckoib, under Mr. Saminsky. heard at the Wigmore Hall on Tuesday, would probably have sounded better without the piano ; but one cannot be sure, since both sopranos and tenors force their notes out ot tune, and what at least held together might have fallen apart. They sang songs of moderate difficulty with accurate time, but without much unanimity of phrasing ; one called “ The Noisy Rain " had rather more character than others^ We were glad to hear Miss Lilias Macldnnon and Mme. Zoia Rosowsky again, about whose playing and singing there is no question.
Mr. Laukasce Turner, accompanied by Mr. O'Connor Morris, played at the Wigmore' Hall on Thursday last week Lalo’s Symphonic Espagnole, the Chaconne, and some smaller pieces. He has, at his best, a remarkably good intonation, though there were some equally remarkable lapses. The Chaconne was taken too fast ; it is long, it is true, and even a good player, such as he is, may be forgiven for fearing that his audience may get impatient. But the “ length " of music has nothing to do with the clock. Brahms’s Hungarian Dance No. 7 showed a sense of rhythm, but a Rondo of Mozart’s was again too fast The best music we heard, as performance merely, was Cyril Scott's Sonnet No. 2.
Mr. Godfrey Ludlow, who played the next night at the same place with the same accompanist is not very firm in his intonation and has a limited technique, but there Is a good deal of music in his bow. Leken's- Sonata in E major has need of it; there are long melodic passages that ask for all that a player can put into them, and on the whole received it Moffat's " Le Paon ” is certainly a find, and would make -many a modest fiddler happy who could extract the music from its grave meanderings ; the same can hardly be said of an Adagio " bizarria " by (we are not told Much) Bach. After that came the turn of the pianist, who showed patience from the first note to thelast - of Mr. Dunhill's Sonata in F.

Author: Null
Title: Books Of The Week
Full_text:
BOOKS OF THE WEEK
THREE FAMOUS BLUECOAT BOYS.
Mr. 8. E. Winbolt has compiled the “ Christ’8 Hospital Anthology ” of “ The Poetry and Prose of Coleridge, Lamb, and Leigh Hunt ” (Bryce, 12s. 6d.n.), as an act of piety after “ a school fife of 11 years at Christ’s Hospital, four years of close connexion with the school as an exhibitioner at Oxford, and 28 years as a master both in London and at Horsham.” By putting together these extracts and prefacing them with an account of the lives of the writers woven into a single story, he hopes both to remedy the neglect of these illustrious Bluecoats which he has observed among Christ’s Hospital boys, and to show the general public how closely the lives of the three were “ interdependent and coloured by early school associations." He would have been more likely, we think, to stir young imaginations and fix in his readers’ minds “ the general literary and political tendencies of the time ” if he had chosen a less arid system of chronicling. Indeed, such sentences as “ Next year (1809)—that of Corunna, Wagram, Talavera, and Wellington’s retreat to Torres Vedras, and of the birth of Tennyson—was not to improve much the position of Coleridge,” or “ While Peel was carrying Catholic Emancipation in Ireland to a triumphant issue, Lamb, living with the Westwoods at Enfield Chase, was returning more particularly to poetry as a solace,” are not arid merely, but bewildering. They make a fine art of irrelevance.
Coleridge, Lamb, and Leigh Hunt were not strictly school contemporaries. The first two came to Christ’s Hospital in 1782 ; the third did not enter there till ten years later. It is said that
in the charming bronze group shown here, which is one of the school prizes, the third head bent over the book with Lamb’s and Coleridge’s is not Leigh Hunt’s, but belongs to T. F. Middleton., a creature of quite another mould. “ M. is said to bear his mitre high in India,” Lamb noted when his schoolfellow became
Bishop of Calcutta. Middleton is to be seen to-day in St. Paul's in all the pomp of marble wig and lawn. He stands blessing two nude and tiny Indians, male and female, and by the unlearned is frequently mistaken for the Almighty creating Adam and Eve. Decidedly Middleton is no fourth for our triumvirate.
“It is probably difficult for anyone but an old Christ’s Hospital boy,” says Mr. Winbolt, “ to realize the very great extent to which these three men bore the strong stamp of Christ’s Hospital all their lives.” It would be less difficult if he had not himself hidden the
key by omitting from his anthology Lamb’s “ Recollections of Christ’s Hospital. Coming as a rule from a family “ liberal though reduced,” says Lamb, the Blue of that day had a character of his own, a blend of “ pride ” and “ restraining modesty,” which was “ as far removed from the abject qualities of a common charity boy as it is from the disgusting forwardness of a lad brought up at some other of the public schools.” He was a gentleman, and, therefore, clearly marked off from the “ charitable grinders ” and other uniformed schoolboys with whom he brushed shoulders in the City streets; but he was a poor gentleman, and therefore could not ape the strut of the sons of the ruling class. What differentiates the legends of the Christ’s Hospitallers from those of other great schools is a certain graceful lucklessness in their heroes, a kind of whimsical gallantry in misfortune. Are these notes not easily to be marked in the after-lives of Coleridge and Elia and Leigh
Hunt I
A NURSE OF ROMANTICISM.
Let us take an illustration or two. Leigh Hunt tells us in his “ Autobiography ” that the ogre Boyer once knocked out one of his teeth with the back of a Homer. The sight of the blood alarmed the pedagogue, but, adds " Skimpole,” charmingly, “ it was a loose tooth, and I told him so.” “ I did not know it was forewarned, sir,” pleads the hero of another legend, caught in an outrage on the master’s desk too gross to have been provided against by the lawgiver, and even Boyer is vanquished. Vanquished, too, was the town-damsel whom Elia’s friend Allen pinched in waggishness, and who, “turning tigress-like round, was converted by his “ angel look ” and changed her terrible halfformed word to “ Bless thy handsome face ! ” Did Allen, we wonder, look at all like the shyly deprecating “ Grecian ” who appears in a reproduction of an old print here, wearing (rare sight I) the “ little cap no bigger than a crumpet ” on the side of his head ? If so, we understand why the town-damsel melted. To bathe in forbidden waters is commonplace, but to be lectured from the bank, as Leigh Hunt and his fellows were, by her Serene Highness the Margravine of Anspach, majestic in hat and feathers and trailing riding-skirt, could only befall boys who should have been wearing blue coats. No royal favours for them, you perceive, but at least no common hangman’s rope. They are spoiled by no genie but the spirit of Romance.
To return to the “ Recollections." They contain a passage more significant than any we have yet quoted.
The Christ’s Hospital boy is a religious character. His school is eminently a religious foundation ; it has its peculiar prayers, its services at set times, its graces, hymns, and anthems, following each other in an almost monastic closeness of succession.. This religious character in him is not always untouched by superstition. . . . Hence the peculiar avidity with which such books as the Arabian Nights Entertainments, and others of a still wilder cast, are, or at least were in my time, sought for by the boys.
Religion, superstition, • and the Arabian Nights ! Here are the Ancient Mariner, and Kubla Khan, and Abou Ben Adhem, and the essay on “ Witches and Other Night Fears.” Here, too, the metaphysical dreams and ecclesiastical musings of Coleridge’s declining age. In the revolt of early manhood he may sketch his “ Pantisocrasy "—a Utopia in the style of Rousseau for “ twelve gentlemen of good education and liberal principles” and twelve ladies to match—but he will end as the compeer of Chateaubriand and the Schlegels. He will indoctrinate England with transcendental Idealism, and carelessly sow the seeds of the Church revival. He will pass away not dreaming of what he has done, and Arnold and Newman will battle for his relics.

Author: Null
Title: The Puppets
Full_text:
THE PUPPETS.
THE DYNASTS” AND SHAKESPEARE.
POETRY AND SUGGESTION.
The other day, at the corner of a Bloomsbury square, I found my path blocked by a little crowd of children who were watching a puppet show of an unusual kind. The usual kind, of course, is Punch and Judy, which has become a degenerate thing, with its puppets grasped in the operator’s hand; these puppets were wired, in the grand manner of the art, and had a horse and cart, no less, for their transport. The show, though lamentably poor in itself -—the puppets merely danced solemnly round and round without any attempt at dramatic action—was rich in suggestion. Do we not all keep a warm corner of our hearts for the puppets, if only for their venerable antiquity and their choice literary associations ? Why, in the grave pages of tho Literary Supplement learned archæologists have lately been corresponding . about the Elizabethan “ motions,” and in the very last number Sir William Ridgeway traced tho puppets back to the Syracuse of Xenophon’s day and told us how that author in his “ Symposium ” makes a famous Syracusan puppet player say that he esteems fools above other men because they are those who go to seo his puppets (vtvp-arraara). My own recollections connect Xenophon with parasangs rather than puppets, but I am glad to be made aware of this honourable pedigree, though I strongly resent the Syracusan’s remark about the amateurs of puppets. I share the taste of Partridge, who ” loved a puppetshow of all tho pastimes upon earth,” and I sympathize with the showman in “ Torn Jones ” who could tolerate all religions save that of the Presbyterians, “because they were enemies to puppet-shows.” And sol lingered with the children at the corner of the Bloomsbury square.
Puppets, some one has said, have tliis advantage over actors : they are made for what they do, their nature conforms exactly to their destiny. I have seen them hi Italy performing romantic drama with a dash and a panache that no English actor hi my recollection (save, perhaps, the late Mr. Lewis Waller) could rival. Actors, being men as well as actors, and therefore condemned to eSort in acting, if only tho eSort of keeping down their consciousness of their real, total self, cannot attain to this clear-cut definiteness and purity of performance. But the wire-puller must be a true artist, his finger-tips responsive to every emotional thrill of the character and every1 nuance of the drama ; indeed, the ideal wirepuller is the poet himself, expressing himself through the motions of his puppets and declaiming his own words for them.
It was with this thought in my mind that I ventured, when Mr. Hardy first published The Dynasts, to suggest that the perfect performance of that work would be as a puppetshow, with Mr. Hardy reading out his own
blank verse. I pointed out the suggestive reference to puppets in the text. One of the Spirits describes the human protagonists as “ mere marionettes,” and elsewhere you read:— Forgetting the Prime Mover of the gear As puppet-watchers him who moves the strings.
Further, at the very core of Mr. Hardy’s drama is the idea that these Napoleons and Pitts and Nelsons are puppets of the Immanent Will. If ever there was a case for raising a puppet-show to the highest literary dignity, tliis was one. •
But it was all in vain. Either Mr. Hardy
was too modest to declaim liis own verse in public, or else the actors pushed in, as they will-wherever they can, and laid hands on as much of his work as they could manage. And so wo had Mr. Granville Barker's version early in the war and only the other day the performance ut Oxford and I have nothing to say against either, save that they were, and could only be, extracts', episodes, fragments, instead of the great epic-drama in its panoramic entirety. A puppet-show could embrace the whole, and one voice declaiming tho poem would to be sure not give the necessary unity of impression— that singleness must bo first of all in the work itself—but would incidentally emphasize it.
The puppet presentation would, however, do much more than tins, It would clarify, simplify, attenuate the medium through which tho poem reaches tho audience. The poet and his public would be in close contact. It is,' of course, for many minds, especially for those peculiarly susceptible to poetry, a perpetual grievance against the actors that these living, bustling, solid people get between them and the poet and substitute fact, realism, flesh-and-blood for what these minds prefer to embody only in their imagination. There is the notorious instance of Charles Lamb, with his objection to seeing Shakespeare’s tragedies acted. He complained that the gay and witty Richard HL was inevitably materialized and vulgarized by the actor. Lamb, as we all know, was capricious, and indeed made a virtue of caprice, but what do you say to so serious and weighty a critic as Professor Raleigh ? Talking about the Shakespearian boy-actors of women, he commits himself to this:—“ It may lie doubted whether Shakespeare has not suffered more than he has gained by the genius of later-day actresses, who bring into the plays a realism and a robust emotion which sometimes obscure the sheer poetic value of the author’s conception. The boys were no doubt very highly trained, and amenable to instruction; so that the parts of Rosalind and Desdemona may well have been rendered with a clarity and simplicity .which served as a transparent medium for the author’s wit and pathos. Poetry, like religion, is outraged when it is made a platform for the exhibition of their own talent and passions by those who are its ministers. With the disappearance of the boy-players tho poetic drama died in England, and it has had no second life."
A little " steep,” is it not ? Logically it is an objection to all acting of poetic drama. Boy-players of girls are only a half-way house. The transparent medium, for tho author’s wit and pathos would bo still more transparent if it were merely the medium of the printed page. . Now this much is certain. Shakespeare conceived his plays, whatever poetry or wit or pathos he put into them, in terms of men and women (not boy-women). Tho ideal performance of Sliakespeare would be by tho men and women who grew in Shakespeare’s imagination. But they, unfortunately, do not exist in flesh and blood, but only in that imagination, and, to bring them on. the stage, you have to employ ready-made men and women, who at tho very best can only be rough approximations to the imaginary figures. In this sense it is not a paradox but a simple commonplace to say that no one has ever seen Shakespeare’s Hamlet on tho stage, or ever will see. And.the greater the “ genius ” of the actor, the more potent his jjersonality—though he will be tho darling of the majority, thirsting for realism, the immediate sense of life—the more will he get between the poet and imaginative students like Lamb and Professor Raleigh, who want their poetry inviolate.
Tliis seems like a digression, but is really to my purpose. Flesh-and-blood actors we shall always have with'us; they will take good care of that themselves. But for the imaginative souls who are for compromise, who are for halfway houses and look back fondly to the boyplayers, I would say: Why not try the Œts ? These also present a “ transparent m ” for the author’s expression. And, further, tho purely “ lyrical" passages in which Shakespeare abounds and wliich seem so odd in-the realism of the human actors (e.g., the Queen’s description of Ophelia’s death) would gain immensely by being recited by the poet (or wire-puller). A puppet-show Hamlet nught be an exquisite experiment in that highest art
whose secret is suggestion.
A B. W.
Mr. Frederick Coblcy, who" died at Ilkley, in his 70th year, was founder and for 21 years managing editor of tho Wharfcdalc and Airedale Observer. Latterly he had been devoting himself to local historical research.

Author: Null
Title: Lyrics And Jingles In Paint
Full_text:
LYRICS AND JINGLES IN PAINT
AN ARTISTS TWO PHASES.
The exhibition of paintings by Mr. Duncan Grant at the Gallery of Messrs. Paterson and Carfax, 5, Old Bond-street, leaves us puzzled and a little depressed by a wilfulness, perhaps unconscious, which seems to hamper his great talent. No cne can look at his Room with a View without seeing that he is a born painter, one whose very paint makes beauty, when ho chooses. It is the same with the flower piece next to it. These are bosh what we may call lyrical pictures, beauty conjured out of the paint, as the lyric poet conjures it out of words; colour unforced and almost undesigned. Everything is unexpected but right; and it all seems to be effortless. ■ Perhaps it is; perhaps the weakness of Mr. Grant is to mistrust himself when he is not effortless. Anyhow, this spontaneous beauty turns in other pictures into a kind of automatism. Take, for instance^ the nude, Venus and Adonis. Here the head of Venus is charmingly conceived and executed against the cloudy background, but in the body Mr. Grant gives us a series of billowy curves, each of which seems t o involve the other with a mechanical rather than inspired inevitability. The body is a mere pretext for these curves, as if a poet had started a poem with a few lines of sense and' then had let the words run off with him into ahey-diddle-diddle jifigle,
. This jingle-painting really gives up the problem of art, the problem of maintaining a counterpoint between words and sense or design and reality. Here and in another nude the counterpoint is gone, and we have a design of mere echoes, like rhyme for rhyme’s sake in verse. And so it is with the still life, the Wash-hand stand, where are the same billowing curves imposed on the objects rather than drawn out of them. It will be said that Mr. Grant gives us a pure design; but, just as the most beautiful music is always found in words that express sense unforced, so, it seems to us, Mr. Grant’s best designs come where he draws them out of nature, as in the two pictures we mentioned first, and the fine portrait of a Lady, and several delicate landscapes. It may be that the hey-diddle-diddle kind of picture is a useful exercise as a first sketch for a work in which the billowing should be mitigated and the echoes softened until they seemed but a natural emphasis. As it is, Mr. Grant seems to have a real, and an automatic or mechanical, spontaneity without any intermediate phase. We should, like to see him deliver himself up utterly for a while to the passion for nature ; we believe his devotion would be rewarded.
Major Darsie Japp, in a number of small pictures in the Twenty-One Gallery, Durham House-street, Adelphi, shows himself an interesting landscape painter as we might expect from his large picture in the War Pictures exhibition, where he has solved the difficulty
of combining large figures with landscape very cleverly. He has great variety of. method ; indeed he seems to see landscape eimply and as a whole and then to paint it as directly'as. possible. Thus his colour is unforced and convincing in pictures such as the Undercliff and the Hedge at Tremedda. In the portrait called Aragonese he practises the fashionable emphasis by slight distortion; but he is more successful with his Breton Boy, which looks like a direct transcript from life, with an emphasis firm but nowhere forced. It is an admirable little painting. •

Author: Null
Title: Poetry And Commonplace
Full_text:
POETRY AND
COMMONPLACE.
.MR. JOHN BAILEY’S WARTON LECTURE.
; i
Mr. John Bailey, at the invitation of the Council of the British Academy, delivered this year’s “ Warton Lecture on English Poetry ” at a meeting of the Academy held yesterday at the rooms of the Royal Society. He took as his subject “ Poetry and Commonplace.” Dr. J. W. Mackail presided.
Poetry, said. Mr. Bailey, might at first sight seem to have no relation to commonplace. But the word commonplace meant a truth of general application: and, if most often used now of truths which were merely trite, it also included those great truths of universal application which were of inexhaustible life. Of these poetry could not have too much. It had no greater business than to be for ever rediscovering their meaning, till in its hands platitudes came to life again as aphorisms. The great poets were at least as much occupied in giving new life to old things as in discovering new. How little many of them, Virgil, Dante, Shakespeare, Moliere, cared about inventing new matter for their poetry I Men more commonly required to be reminded, as Johnson said, than to be informed. We were vaguely aware that death was certain or spring delightful: but when Shakespeare retold these things dull knowledge took on a throbbing energy of sudden life.
No poet illustrated this better than Wordsworth, who took common life, plain people, and universal emotions and gave them freshness and. power. What was it which to-day had most meaning for us in Hebrew poetry ? the eternal freshness of such ancient commonplaces as God is our hope and strength. What did we love most in Horace ? Again the beauty with which he had recreated the hoariest commonplaces of life and morals. The same thing might be illustrated from Homer, Pindar, and the Greek tragedians. And the other side of its truth was seen in contemporary poetry which, with all its energy and interestingness, was apt to lack universality and timelessness. So again it might be seen in George Meredith, who did what he could to kill his poetry by the restless ingenuity of his intellect-, which seemed to scorn to share the common thoughts of men. Contrast Gray, who, by the opposite method, had given us the best loved and most quoted poem, in the language. These instances, the Psalms, Horace, Gray, all illustrated the truth that, even if originality be the greatest of the gifts of genius, it could not do its work if it neglected to lay its vivifying hand on the common things of life, the universal thoughts and feelings of men.

Title: Oversea Poetry
Full_text:
OVERSEA POETRY.
SIR HERBERT WARREN ON THE NOTE OF EMPIRE.
!
At a meeting ot tho Itoyal Colonial Institute, yesterday, Sir Charles Lucas to the chair, Sui IlEliBEirr Wahhbn read a paper on Overseas Poetry.
It was not altogether easy. Sir Herbert Warren explained, to decide by what standard to judge the now, fresh, young growths of the Empire. Their own standards were not quite ours; universities,
academics, schools, coteries, conservatoires, a leisured and literary class, were abundant in Europe, but were only beginning to abound in the Dominions, But the Dominions, each and all, were great, poetic countries, with magnificent and varied scenery, though much of it still lacked association: splendid races in the nmkitig, though not yet fully made. Their poetry had passed the earliest stages; under the influence ok Imperialism it had common charac(eristics, the restlessness, the fever, tho cleverness ot modern cities along with the freedom of the wide open spaces. It was still largely an open-air poetry, the poetry of men of action and movement-, tinged with tho British love and spirit of sport, to-day deeply dyed with the spirit of war. It showed three main notes, love of tho new home, love ot the old home, and love of the Empire which included both.
He would begin with Canada, whoso poetry had undoubtedly a colour and character of its own. It might be found in the “ Oxford Book of Canadian Poetry,” edited in 1313 by one who was yesterday a leading living Canadian poet, bub was no longer so— Wilfred. Campbell, certainly a poet of Empire, whose
England, England, England, Girdled by ocean and skies. And the power of a world and tho heart of a race, And a hope that never dies.
was a fine poem of Empire. Other Canadian poets were Bliss Carman, with a poet’s love of the sea; his two cousins, Charles G. D. Roberts and Theodore Roberts, Archibald Lampman and Duncan C. Scott. Canada too had her French poetry; lx>uis Frechette, the most conspicuous, was the heir of .Franco and* of Victor Hugo, as Bliss Carman was the heir ot England ’ and ok Tennyson. A delicious blond of both was the work of William H. Drummond.who did not forget the forests and the lakes, tho habitant and the voyageur, half French, half English, and could also strike, and strike
well, the Imperial note. A little poem which gave the feeling ok Canada and the Canadian background
was “ The Whitethroat,” by Mr. Theodore Hand :—
Shy bird ok tho silver arrows of song, That cleave our Northern air so clear, Thy notes prolong—prolongI listen, I hear:
“ I—love—dear—Canada, ’Canada! Canada! ” There were also tho Senior Chaplain to the Canadian Forces, Canon F. G. Scott, ok Quebec, who camo over with the first Canadian Force in 1914, and had boon at the front over since: Mr. Robert Service, author of the 11 Rhymes of a Red Cross Man ” ; and an attractive French name—Lieutenant A. S. Bourinot.
Australia.
Australian poetry had a history of about a century. Adam Lindsay Gordon’s poetry and philosophy had given a ply to Australian literature which still persisted. Ok the younger generation, George Essex Evans, a Welshman, who went out to Queensland in 1881, seemed the most real and comprehensive Australian poet of his generation. He sang
Not as tho songs of other lands
* Her song shall bo
Where dim her purple shore-line stands, Above tho sea.
Her song is silence : unto her
Its mystery clings;
Silence is tho interpreter
OI deeper things;
O for sonorous Voice and strong To change that silence into song, To give that melody release, Which sleeps in the deep heart of peace With folded wings.
Then there was the most characteristic and up-to-date and realistic Australian poem, “ The Songs of a Sentimental Bloke,” by C. J. Dennis, 1015, whose work was real poetry, a charming old story told in a new way. New Zealand poetry, too, promised well. Was not Now Zealand there-? Ask Mr. Harris, whose “ New Zealand's Lament" moved him well nigh to tears.
South Africa hud a Kipling in Cullen Gouldsbury, who died at Tanga in August, 1916:—•
How broad thy love, how big thy reverence!
Mjreh hast thou given us ere thy going hence, Now take what wo may give and leave tho rest— Take earth of ours thy world-wide Church hath blest:
Sleep, body, by our sea, beneath our stars 1 Go, soul, to peace in honour from our wars!
So sang of him another very different South African poet, the Bev. Arthur Shearlcy Cripps, who was as it Livingstone were fused with Kebto in a. strange dual personality, and writing ot Kipling and Bhodcs.
The lecturer mentioned many others. The Empire, so vast,various,splcndid.could not kail to have its poets. We could see its promise and potentialities through the eyes of t he ” oversea singers.” Thero was another overseas poetry also, which was always ours, doubly, trebly ours to-day—tho poetry ok the United States. America had her poets to-day, older and younger. One of these, Alan Seeger, had loved, life and “ honour more ” :—
But I've a rendezvous with Death, And I to my pledged word am true ;
I shall not fail that rendezvous.
He had not failed it. Young America would not fail it. Nor would older .America. Read tho " Red Flower?1 issued in the last few days by Dr. Henry Van Dyke—that faithful, linn, yet fervent minister and minstrel.

Title: The Book Fortnight
Full_text:
THE BOOK FORTNIGHT.
HUMANITIES IN WAR TIME.
POETRY AND FICTION.
Last Tuesday wo dealt with history, memoirs, politics, war, and in general with subjects, other than technical, the study of which should “ help us all to play a worthy part in tho campaign for higher national efficiency.” Knowledge, we have been told, is power ; and the publishers, who have joined together to promote their “ book fortnight " with the aim of increasing bookbuvers from a few hundred thousand to a number something nearer the 45 millions of our population, are helping to increase power by spreading knowledge. But knowledge is not all ; power is not all.
At this moment we have before our eyes the spectacle of immense power and hoarded knowledge doing their best to wreck the world. Human progress, human happiness depend upon something else than knowledge leading to power and power crashing into self-assertion. We may plainly see, indeed, how knowledge and power can betray each other, unless they are tempered, sweetened, and guided by other forces. And for a nation which is prepared to spend its all in the defence of another ideal than that it is not merely advisable, it is a plain duty to prosecute the studies that foster the ideal of amenity, good will, justice—in a word, humanity. The connexion between humanity and “ the humanities'” is more than verbal. The fullness of life comes not only through tho literature of knowledge and the power that knowledge gives. It is an equal duty, an equal wisdom to-cultivate, deepen, and enrich our lives and aims by tho literature of imagination, of beauty, ot spiritual enlargement, and exaltation.
National Home-Reading Union.
The lists issued by tho publishers who have joined in tho “ book fortnight "and the announcements of other publishers make a useful guide to the best of current literature. The choice of a good bookseller, moreover, who understands and appreciates the wares in which he deals, is a necessary provision for the would-be reader ; while those who are humble enough to consider themselves more or loss beginners in tho good habit or reading (and many who are not beginners as well) may be counselled to avail themselves of the National Home-Reading Union. This energetic and knowledgablo body has lately begun to issue a scries of pamphlets (Is. net each) which arc valuable not only for the introductiqns they offer to the study of this or that author or subject, but for the classified bibliographies in each pamphlet. To Mr. J. W. Mackail’s “ William Morris ” and Mr. F. W. Moorman’s “ Shakespeare ” there have recently been added an excellent essay on “ Style and Composition” by Professor Hastings Crossley, and a fascinating introduction to tho study of British folk-songs and folk-lore by Sir Laurence and Lady Gomme.
Some Wab Books.
_ We arc concerned to-day principally with the literature of imagination ; but before inspecting the season’s books of poetry, of belles-lettres, and of fiction, we may glance at one or two important volumes belonging either to the literature ok knowledge or coming somewhere between the two. A notable war-book is Mr. Philip F. E. Schuler’s “ Australia in Arms ” (F. Unwin, 12s. fid. net), which, with the help of admirable illustrations, plans, tables, and so forth, puts on record in worthy style the training of the Australian troops, their doings in Egypt and on the Suez Canal, and their heroic achievements and sufferings in Gallipoli. The war, again, has filled many people with a desire to know more about our great and mysterious Ally, Russia; and a glimpse at tho greatness and infinite variety of Russia may be obtained from Miss M. A. Czaplicka’s remarkable travel book, “My Siberian Year” (Mills and Boon, IDs. 6d.). To Russian fiction wo shall come later ; but a sidelight on the country which Miss Czaplicka describes may be obtained from one or two of the stories in the second series of “ Talcs by Polish Authors ” recently translated by Else C. M. Bcneeke and Marie Busch (Blackwell, 5s. net).
The great questions of nationalism and internationalism, which are now occupying many thoughtful minds, may be studied to better advantage than ever before in three of this season’s books. In “ Europe Unbound,” by Lisle March Phillipps (Duckworth, 6s. net), and “ Nationalism and Internationalism : The Culmination of Modern History," by Ramsay Muir (Constable, 4s. 6d. net), two very able writers consider the great conflict of ideals which now divides Europe, trace the historical development of tho conceptions of law and justice, of the existence of national States, and the recognition of a unity of Europe, and show how they are brought to a test by the war. In “ Tho Monroe Doctrine : An Interpretation ” (Duckworth, 10s. 6d. net) Dr. Albert Bushnell Hart “ offers the only comprehensive account of the Monroe Doctrine in all its phases—that is to say, of the whole attitude of America to the world outside,” and deduces the conclusion ’ that tho United States, having already sacrificed its isolation, must be prepared to take an active part in tho conflicts of the future. And before we pass on to the study of' literature, one other important book must be mentioned : Mr. E. S. Russell’s “ Form and Functions : A Contribution to the History of Animal Morphology ” (Murray, 10s. 6d. net), a searching and fascinating inquiry into evolution, heredity, life itself.
“ Belles-Lettres ” and Criticism.
In tercentenary year it is natural to look first of all at the Shakespearian literature of the season. “ The Book of Homage to Shakespeare,"’ put forth by Dr. Israel Gollancz under the auspices of the Tercentenary Committee (Oxford University Press, 21s. net) is perhaps a luxury, though many of tho contributions, English and foreign, are so valuable as to demand republication in a cheaper form. “ Shakespeare’s England ” (Oxford University Press, 25s. net) is a book all but indispensable to readers of Shakespeare, so various and accurate is the information that it contains upon the life and manners of his age. Other studies of Shakespeare have been many. Some arc general ; some arc devoted to special points, like Sir E. Maunde Thompson’s " Shakespeare’s Handwriting ” (Oxford University Press, 7s. 6d. net), and Sir Archibald Gcikio's “ The Birds of Shakespeare " (MacLchoso, 3s. 6d. net) ; but one that perhaps deserves special attention is “ Tho English Drama in the Age of Shakespeare ” (Sidgwiek and Jackson, 18s. net), a translation of part of the monumental history of the modern drama by Professor W. Creizcnacli, of Cracow, whose special achievement it is to treat the Elizabethan drama not as a matter of pure literature, but in its relation to the politics, social history, religion, and other forces of its age. Lighter entertainment may be found in the Studio’s special number, “ Shakespeare in Pictures ” (5s. net), which sets before us the history of Shakespeare illustration.
Of other literary criticism there has been no small quantity published, among the most important volumes being a reprint: “ Poetry and the Renascence of Wonder ” (Jenkins, 5s. net), by Theodore Watts-Dunton, tho eminent Victorian critic, whose “ Life-Liters,” by Thomas Hake and A. Compton-Rickctt, has also been published recently (Jack ). The opinions of that strange and interesting creature Lafcadio Hearn have been issued under the title of “ Interpretations of Literature ” (Heinemann, 30s. net). Mr. William Watson, the poet, has published a “ plea for the older ways " in writing—not wholly unnecessary, no doubt, in these days of daring and sometimes brutal literary experiment—under the
title of “ Pencraft ” (Lane, 3a 6d. net) • and among a large number of other critical works we may mention Messrs. Nisbet’s little series of “ Writers of the Day ” (Is. 3d. each net), in which Kipling, Hardy, Bennett, Shaw, and other eminent authors arc, briefly characterized. It is natural, perhaps, that in times like these, which stir all minds to" thought, expression should be found through the medium of the essay ; and English literature’s proud heritage in the essay has been suggested recently by the republication, under able editorship, pi Henry Fielding’s once famous “ Covent Garden Journal ” (Oxford University Press, 21s. net).
That tho art of essay-writing is not lost is proved by several recent publications : Sir. W. Warde Fowler’s remarkable “ Essays in Brief for War-Time ” (Blackwell, 2s. 6d. not) ; Mr. R. W. Mackcnna’s “ The Adventure of Death ’’ (Murray, 3s.- Cd. net) ; Mr. Galsworthy’s “ A Sheaf ” (Heinemann, 5s. net) ; and Mr. E. V. Lucas’s charming mixture of grave and gay, “Cloud and Silver” (Methuen, 5s. net) ; while another recent issue of essays inspired by the war is M. Maeterlinck’s “ The Wrack of the Storm,’" translated by M. A. Teixeira do Mattos (Methuen, 5s. net). With these, too, may Bo associated the anthology of prose and verso made by the Poet Laureate (Longmans, 5s. net)—distinctly a book to uplift and console in times of stress ; while Mr. A. Macphail’s very interesting anthology, “ Tho Book of Sorrow ” (Oxford University Press, 6s. net), has its obvious bearing on the present times.
To belles-lettres, again, rather than to biography, belongs Mr. W. B. Yeats’s exquisite little volume of “Reveries over Childhood and Youth " (Macmillan, 6s. net). To the study of Eastern thought and art, as remote from our own, yet as necessary to Britons, especially among Europeans, an interesting addition is Dr. Ananda K. Coomaraswamy’s “ Buddha and the Gospel of Buddhism,” with its fine illustrations (Harrap, 15s. net). Of Portugal we may learn much from the anthology “ Portugal,” with English versions by G. Young (Oxford University Press, 7s. 6d. net). For reference there are our faithful friends, Chambers’s “ Cyclopædia of English Literature ” (31s. 6d. net), and “ Chambers’s Encyclopædia ” (£5 net, 10 vols.) ; and along one of the byways of tho study of literature wo are pleasantly taken by Mr. W. Longman’s “ Tokens of the Eighteenth Century connected with Booksellers and Bookmakers ” (Longmans, 6s. net).
Poetry.
Tho war has brought into being an immense amount of poetry. Many a young man who never guessed that ho was a poot has been stirred by his experiences at the front to expression in verse; and while volumes of this character are too many to enumerate, a good bookseller could recommend the best, and some day, no doubt, a publisher will issue an anthology of them. Meanwhile, the reprinting of the poetry of the past has been carried on if pot more widely, certainly not less so than in time of peace.
A volume of marked if special interest is Dr. Milton Perceval's Poetical Ballads illustrating the Administration of Sir Robert Walpole ” (Oxford University Press, 8s. Cd. net); and tho famous “ Ben Gaultier Bal'ads ” have been issued in a new illustrated edition (Blackwood, 5s. net).
Among the poets of our own day, readers may note tho collected poems of James Elroy Flecker (Seeker, 7s. Cd. net), the brilliant singer who died recently; a collected edition of the poems of Mr. Alfred Noyes (Blackwood, 10s. net); and the addition to the Golden Treasury of a volume of selections from the poetry of Mr. Thomas Hardy (Macmillan, 2s. 6dL), who, great as a prose-writer, is held by some to be even greater as a poet. New poems have been published by Mr. Masefield (“ Sonnets and Poems,” published by tho author, 3s. 6d. not); Mr. W. B. Yeats (“ Responsibilities,” Macmillan. 6s. net); Mr. Maurice Hewlett, who in " The Song of the Plow ” (Heinemann, 6s. net) sings “ the song of English history as it might have appeared to Hodge himself ” ; Miss Evelyn Underhill, who in “ Theophanies ” (Dent, 3s. 6d.) has revealed anew the mysticism that is tho spring and substance of her poetic genius ; Mr. William Watson, whose “ Retrogression ” (Lane, 3s. - 6d. net) contains, as it has been said, “ verse for the mind, not the soul ” ; Mr. A. 8. Cripps, in “ Pilgrim’s Joy ” (Blackwell, 2s. 6d. net); and Mr. John Oxenham, who has followed up his last year’s “ All’s Well” with a similarly hearty and widely appealing volume, “The King’s Highway” (Methuen, Is. not).
Miss Irene Rutherford McLeod has issued a new and striking book of poems, “ Swords for Life ” (Chatto, 2s. 6d. net); and “ Lustra of Ezra Pound ” (Mathews, 5s. net), and Mr. D. H. Lawrence’s “ Amores ” (Duckworth, 5s. net) will give readers a glimpse into some of the tendencies of modem poetry. Finally, wo may note a new volume of prose translations from his own Bengali poems by Sir Rabindranath Tagore, whose " Fruit-Gathering’’ (Macmillan, 4s. Cd. net) is a worthy successor to his much-treasured “ Gitanjali.”
Fiction.
A notable feature of the year’s publishing is the number of translations from the Russian. Their merit is very various, and at present it is impossible to form anything like a satisfactory “ library ” of them; but they are all worth the attention of readers. Mrs. Constance Garnett has begun a translation of the tales of Tchekov, of which two volumes out of eight have already appeared (Chatto, 2s. net each). To tho English versions of Kuprin has been added “A Slav Soul, and other stories” (Constable, 5s. net); Korolenko is introduced to us by “ Tho Murmuring Forest ” (Duckworth, Gs.); Sologub’s “ Little Domon ” has been followed byon almost equally remarkable book, “ The Created Legend ” (Seeker, 5s. not); Andregev's “ The Little Angel ” is to be had for a shilling (Hodder and Stoughton); and while Mr. J. M. Murry has published an interesting study of Dostoievsky, a novel by his daughter, L. Dostoieffsko, “ The Emigrant ” (Constable, 5s. net), has thrown light on the position of educated women in Russia.
As for our English fiction, it is so well advertised and the libraries are so alive to its quality and kind that there is little need to be particular in these columns. Among the many novels dealing with various aspects of the war, to “ Mr. Birtling Secs it Through,” which we mentioned last week, there might be added Mrs. Hamilton’s “ Dead Yesterday ” (Duckworth, Gs.), Miss Rose Macaulay’s “ Non-Combatants and Others ” (Hodder and Stoughton, 5s. net), and Mr. Hugh do SiSlincourt’s “ A Soldier of Life ” (Constable, 5s. net); besides innumerable tales of adventure and active service, at the head of which como tho stories of Ian Hay, of Boyd Cable, and Sapper.
Our most eminent novelists have not been barren. A glance at the lists shows Mr. Arnold Bennett’s “ The Lion’s Shore ” (Cassell, Gs.); Mr. Maurice Howlett’s " Love and Lucy ” (Macmillan, 5s.- net); Mr. W. W. Jacobs’s “ The Castaways ” (Hodder and Stoughton, 5s, net); Mr. Temple Thurston’s “ Tho FiveBarred Gato ” (Hodder and Stoughton, 5s. net); Mr. "W. J, Locke’s “ The Wonderful Year ” (Lane, 6s.); Mrs. Belloc Lowndes’s “ Lilia ” (Hutchinson, Gs.); and Mr. Algernon Blackwood’s “ The Wave ” (Macmillan, 5s. net). Lucas Malet has put out two books, one her own, “ Damaris ” (Hutchinson, Gs.), tho other, “ The Tutor’s Story,” begun by her father, Charles Kingsley, and finished by herself (Smith, Elder, 6s. not); and Mr. Cunninghame Graham has issued what he declares, alas I to be his lust volume, “ Brought Forward " (Duckworth, 6s.).
Not to bo passed over by any lover of good fiction are the “ Collected Tales ” of Mr. Barry Pain, of which one volume has been published (Seeker, 5s. net). The strange and brilliant work of tho American author, O. Henry, is being issued in a number of volumes (Nash, 3s. Cd. each); and a hearty laugh may bo had out of a new humorist, Sir. Herbert Jenkins, tho author of “ Bindlo ” (Jenkins, 5s. net). For the rest (and they are many), the advice of librarians and booksellers and the publishers’ announcements should bo sufficient guide to readers who regard novela as something more than a more pastime.

Author: Null
Title: Poetry Of Empire
Full_text:
POETRY OF EMPIRE.
CANADIAN AND AUSTRALIAN VERSE.
•
'
'
Sir Herbert Warren, Professor of Poetry, delivered at Oxford on Saturday the second of two lectures on the Poetry of the Empire, dealing with the writers of Canada and Australia.
The Professor proposed only to deal with what might be called the “ Imperial ” poetry oi the two countries. But this he would interpret in a wide sense. He recommended two books, the “ Oxford
Book of Canadian Verse,” selected by Mr. Wilfred Campbell, and the “Golden Treasury of Australian Verse,” edited by Mr. Bertram Stevens. In certain broad features tile poetry of Canada and Australia resembled each other. In both the early poetry was largely immigrant; in the latter halt of the century the native poetry had steadily aud strikingly increased. But Canada was of the north, Australia essentially southern ; the Red Indian was more romantic and picturesque than the “ black fellow." Canada contained a large French province and element, and had also a huge neighbour, whose influence could not but affect her profoundly. Australia was more homogeneous and more isolated. The Imperial life of both lands might be said to have begun with poets born about 1860.
The1 Canadian Spirit.
Mr. Wilfred Campbell was certainly a poet ok Empire; witness his “England,” beginning:—
“England, England, England, girdled by ocean and skies.
And the power of a world and the heart ok a race, And a hope that never dies."
Contemporary with him was C. G. Douglas Roberts. His “ Canada ” was a striking poem. Another poet, Theodore Roberts, struck what was more the note to-day in “ The Reckoning," in which, speaking of England as “ the little island in the foggy sea," he warned the world that “They who would reckon with England, must reckon with England’s sons.” Another Canadian, Bliss Carman, gave, in his “ Low Tide on Grand Pre,” very sympathetically, the feeling of Canadian scenery which had appealed so strongly to Longfellow, and could be found also in Archibald Lanipman, and in Theodore Rand’s poem on the Whitethroat, with its refrain;—
“I — love — dear — Canada, Canada, Canada."
To feel the country too wo must look at her French poetry. Louis Frechette was the heir ok France and of Victor Hugo, as Bliss Carman was the heir of England and Tennyson. But there was yet another vein of verse, represented by William H. Drummond, ok Scotch family, but born in Ireland, who had gone to Canada as a boy and lived in the back-woods. Though he became a Professor of Medical Jurisprudence, he never forgot the forests and lakes, the habitant and the voyageur, half French, half English. “ Little Lac Grenier ” or “ Johnnie Courteau ” was poetry of the Empire.
A very representative poet of Canada was Canon Frederick George Scott, of Quebec, now serving as a chaplain at the front, from which he had sent striking poems. His “ Hymn of Empire,” made famous by being quoted by Mr. Chamberlain during the South African War, true and great Imperial poetry, and echoing Tennyson’s denunciation of the “ craven fear of being great,” struck the note of Canada’s strength, and also of her high and noble aims. His recent poems from the front, “ On the Rue do Bois," printed in The Times, and “ Requiescant," and “ O Canada, my country and my love 1 ” carried still further the same ideals.
The Thbbe Notes of Empire.
There were three notes ok the Empire as found in Canadian poetry: Love of the new homo, Canada. Love ok the old home, England. Love and loyalty to the vast whole which united both, and linked the past and the present to the future, the Empire itself. Ik they crossed.the Pacific they would find these same three notes floating out to meet them over the southern waves. Australia was no less full, perhaps even more full, of poetry. There, too, it had begun a century ago. In Australia poetry had gone hand in hand will, public life and journalism. A characteristic pioneer was Sir Henry Parkes, and another was Adam Lindsay Gordon.
But the real poetry ok the Empire naturally belonged more to younger men. One ok the most conspicuous was a Welshman, George Essex Evans, author, ot the “Secret Key.” In “An Australian Symphony ” he had suggested what Australian poetry might be. The same opportunity had been found by an Irishman, Mr. John Sandes. Yet another Imperial poet was Mr. Douglas Sladen. A still younger poet, Mr. Archibald Strong, had brought the earliest and latest ideals of Empire together in “ Sonnets of file Empire,” one of winch, “ Australia to England.” had appeared in The Times. New Zealand was excellently represented by Mr. William Peinbcr Reeves. Australia too, like Canada, had her spiritual poets, such as the devoted Bishop of Carpentaria. Dr. Gilbert White, whose hymn “ Australia ” had been quoted with much effect at St. Paul’s by the Archbishop of Canterbury.
Time forbade him to include India in his survey of the Empire, and particularly such poems as “ The Trumpet" of Rabindranath Tagore.
We were living in a tremendous time. “ On us the ends ok the earth had come.” “ World-might or going under” was our socmen’s motto. “Worldright or going under ” our own. These sorrows, these ' struggles, these sacrifices, this anguish and agony were the birth-throes of the Empire.

Author: Null
Title: The Old Testament And Arabian Poetry
Full_text:
THE OLD TESTAMENT AND ARABIAN POETRY.
SOME INTERESTING COMPARISONS.
' ■
Sir Charles Lyall read a paper to the Royal Asiatic Society yesterday- on " The Relation of the Old Arabian Poetry to the Hebrew Literature of the Old Testament.” Sir Mortimer Durand was in the chair, and the lecture room of the society was crowded.
Snt Charles pointed out that Hebrew poetry and Arabic poetry were in outward form very different* Though the languages of these two great historic branches of the Semitic stock were nearly akin, there were great divergences between them. Arabic prosody, he said, bore a very close resemblance to that of the Greeks, whereas Hebrew verse might rather be compared, to the rough Saturnian rhythms of the early Latin poets, or the chants of our northern forefathers, recently imitated by the Poet Laureate in his Christmas ode in I Tic. Times. Turning from form to substance, they found & most close and extrao rdinary resemblance between the old poetry of Israel and the compositions of Northern and Central Arabia in the classical period, and the great gap of 12 or 13 centuries seemed to vanish entirely.
It was only in the first great period of the history of Israel, ending soon after the establishment of the monarchical system, that close resemblance between the literature of Israel and that of Arabia could be expected, because only during that time were the conditions of the two people similar. It was remarkable how few were the fragments of Hebrew poetic composition which had survived to us from it. Many poems of the period quoted in prose literature had perished, and its two outstanding monuments were the Song of Deborah and the Lament of David on the death of Saul and Jonathan. Both of these poems were strongly and markedly Arabian in feeling, in texture, and in expression, with the exception of the. theophany with which the first of them opened. The Arabs of classical times and their descendants, the Bedvtin of our present day, were one of the races least touched by the solemnities of religious awe. Sir Charles proceeded to compare the Song of Deborah with an Arabic poem celebrating a great battle in the sixth century, in which the tribe of Amir ib n Sa-sa-ah routed a great combination which the neighbouring tribes of Central Arabia brought against it. Similarly he compared David’s Lament with a dirge by Duraid, son of AS'Simmah, on his brother Abdallah. He based on these parallelisms the theory that when these ancient poems of Israel were composed the contemporary Arabs of the east and south were making verse of the same kind. There was no reason to Sose that the civilisation of the Israelites in the »r of the two historic periods was superior to that of their cousins, the sons of Midian, Ishmael and
Edom. Apart from the mission of Israel as founder ok a world-religion and his unique capacity for the reception and development of religious ideas there was little difference between him and his neighbours. But in the three or four centuries ending in the return from captivity there was very great religious advance. The Book of Job belonged to the time of the second Isaiah. The writer went outside the limits of Israel and plaited the scene of his colloquies in Arabia. This unplied that in his time it was believed that wise men capable of carrying on such discussions could be found, there. The reasonable conclusion was that there were then poets in Arabia who dealt with just the same subjects as their successors nearly 1,000 years later, and handled them in approximately the same way. Arabic poetic art in the time of tribal Israel as well as in the later literary period, probably covered much the same subjects as it did at the beginning of the Islamic age. The sole reason why none of these compositions of ancient times were now extant probably was that they were not committed to writing, but perished with the human memories in which they were preserved.
