Author: Null
Title: Poetry And The Cinematograph
Full_text:
POETRY AND THE CINEMATOGRAPH.
The Poetry Society, in its efforts to encourage a love of poetry in all classes, is apparently quite willing to utilize any legitimate means, and it will be interesting to see whether anything practical comes of the demonstration of “ speaking pictures ” which was given before its members yesterday by the Clarendon Film Company.
There have been efforts in the past to adapt wellknown poems for cinematograph purposes—a version of “ Maud ’’ was produced three years ago. But on such occasions the spoken word was omitted, and from tho point of view of encouraging a love of poetry the value of the film was little. Now, however, by a clever process of elaborate synchronization between the moving picture and the living voice the Clarendon Film Company have made a decided advance on past productions. We are not quite sure that the Poetry Society will agree with the company as to what constitutes the sort of poetry which it is desired to spread among the poeple. The only picture which dealt with a poem of any real pretension yesterday was that based on Tennyson’s “ The Gardener’s Daughter," and this, strangely enough, was the one poem which was not recited. It is obvious, of course, that many of the better known poems are quite unsuitable for the purpose, and that the subject must be carefully chosen, but it was somewhat surprising to see that every picture presented yesterday touched on death in some aspect. From the point of view of synchronization, however, the films left nothing to bo desired.

Author: Null
Title: The Poetry Recital Society
Full_text:
THE POETRY RECITAL SOCIETY.
' Lord Coleridge presided yesterday at the annual dinner of the Poetry Recital Society at the Hoiborn Restaurant.
Mr. Galloway Kyle (secretary) stated that letters expressing regret at inability to be present had been received from Lord Crewe, who was obliged to be at a political meeting at Winchester, the American Ambassador, the Duke of Argyll, Mr. E. W. Longfellow, Lord Edmund Talbot, Miss Isabel Swinburne, Mr. G. Locker Lampson, Mr. and Mrs. Humphry Ward, Sir L. Alma Tadema, Lord Avebury,
Sir George Reid, Lord Lytton, and others.
The Chairman proposed the toast of “The Immortal Memories of the British Poets," which was drunk In solemn silence. He said that he regretted that Lord Crewe, the son of a poet, was unable to be present that night to take the ohair. In his absence, and at somewhat short notice, he had contented to fill his place. It was, he thought, a happy idea which occurred to the authorities of that society to bid them assemble that night in pious memory of the great poets from whom they claimed descent or kinship. He did not know whether the Heralds’ College had investigated all their pedigrees. (Laughter.) He was not sure whether they were there to testify to the ’soundness of tho hereditary principle or the reverse. (Cheers and laughter.) It might be that they were all of them poets, either actual or potential. (Cheers and laughter.) This was said to be a material age, but it was pure sentiment which had brought them together. While the nation was proud of its deeds rather than of its words, still they must claim to surpass all other nations as a nation of great poets. (Cheers.) Truly wonderful had been the output of their poetry from Chaucer right down to the present day. He could not even conjecture an explanation of the wealth, the continuity, and the variety of their poetic thought. It might Ue in the Inspiration that they had received from their struggles for liberty and order. It might lie in the flexibility and the music of their mother tongue. It might lie in something which defied analysis—the indefinable inspiration which seemed to breathe upon their
Mie Duke of Norfolk, replying to the toast, said that the gathering that night was a proof of the grasp that poetry bad upon this country.
The Rev. C. W. Wordsworth, Mr. E. H. Coleridge, and the Rev. J. H. Shakespeare also spoke.
The commemoration ode, written by Mr. Irving Taylor," was recited by Miss Elsie Fogerty. Mr. AiJbSd East proposed, the toast of “ The Poetry Recital Society? ’ to which Sir Robert Edgcumbb and Mr- Solomon J. Solomon replied. Other --beeches followed, and Sin Alfred Lyall proposed the health of the chairman. A number of poems were recited during the evening.

Author: Null
Title: Notes On Books
Full_text:
NOTES ON BOOKS.
Mr. Herbert Trench’s Poe
The author of Deirdre Wed and Other Poems (Methuen) has produced a little volume which bears on almost every page the stamp of genuine poetry- His inspiration is Celtic, like that of a whole young school now much in favour, but his endowment is much more solid, and his muse much more free from affectation, than is the case with most of tho Irish poets and poetesses of the day. In outline “ Deirdre Wed ” is a very old story, tho story of a tyrant's bride who falls in lovo with ono of tho victims of his injustice and escapes with him, after many adventures, into safety ; but it is told with such a mysterious charm of language, imagery, and music that wo can quite understand tho enthusiasm with which it is beginning to bo spoken of by tho lovers of poetry. Whether it is likely to be popular is quite another question; probably tho treatment will ho found too remote from common speech, and tho atmosphere too rarefied. Somo of tho “ other poems " aro fine, end not wanting in simplicity, and tho concluding pago of “ Claviers at Night " is like a great picture by Mr. Watts.
Other Verse.
We welcome tho new edition of tho Archbishop of Armagh’s poems, under tho title of The Finding of the Book and Other Poems (Hodder and Stoughton) ; a volume, as tho author says,11 scarcely so much another edition as another book." Tho Archbishop's lyre has many notes, religious, ethical, fanciful, descriptive, and patriotic ; it is alwuysmolodious, always pleasant to hear. Nor is thoro any falling off in the section described as “ recently written " ; witness tho poem first published in our own columns, “ Is War tho Only Thing that has no Good in it ? "
Sir Lewis Morris lias issued a new volume (already in a second edition) under tho name of Harvest? Tide (Kegan Paul), tho date of his title-pago reminding him “ that he is no longer a writer of the 19th century alone." His merits and his limitations have long been familiar, and both are conspicuous in the new book. Thoro is a curious poom called “ Apologia," in which he indicates
pretty plainly which of his brother versifiers it is that he does not admire; there is another in which, by talking of tho man “who sees life whole and secs it one," ho shows how boldly ho can borrow from Matthew Arnold ; while four lines further down, by bidding us “ put off alike tho tiger and the apo," ho shows us how Tennyson can bo assimilated with advantage. Still, it is bettor to echo the phrases of great minds in writing about things of good report than to evolve an eccentric style for tho purpose of rhapsodizing over impropriety. Sir Lewis Morris has always been " on the side of tho angels " in that respect. Tho popularity 1 his poems havo enjoyed is largely duo to this. ; They appeal to tho good instincts of ordinary people ; they arc easily understood ; aud the ideas which lio at their roots are never so original as to bo startling or to set in motion "bewildering trains of thought. They ate read with pleasure by thousands who would never exert their minds sufficiently to road the groat poets, and probably they do good to thousands. Certainly, they cannot do them any harm.
Mr. VV. B. Yeats, a much-admired poet of tho neo-Celtic school, has published a thin new volume, ample in its margins, under tho title of The Shadowy Waters (Hodder and Stoughton). It seems to us that this wants just the qualities which “ Deirdre Wed " possesses in abundance. Shadowiness, of which Mr. Yeats has enough and to spare, is not sufficient for poetry. Tho poet must havo something to say. On the other hand, Mr. F. E. Monoy-Coutts, in his tiny volume The Mystery of Godliness (John Lane), has a great deal to say, having to treat, in some two hundred stanzas, tho mystery, not of godliness only, but of tho universe. That the theologians, or even tho ordinary educated reader, will always agree with Mr. Money-Coutts is not to lie expected; but it is a satisfaction to find in these days a poem with some good hard thinking in it, especially when the thought is simply expressed in tho familiar four-lined stanza. With this little book we may mention a new English version, commendable from many points of view, of the lyric utterances of a great man, Mr. ’J. M. Morrison’s translation of tho Poems
of Leopardi (Gay aud Bird). Sad as they arc, Done can deny that tho canti of the greatest of modern Italian poets are abundantly well worth reading. Mr. Morrison’s seems to be a good and scholarly version.
Tho writer of Heartsease : A Cycle or Sono (David Nutt) might well havo called hor dainty volume “ An Englishwoman’s Levo Poems." They would compare favourably with the muchadvertised " Love Letters." Hero is no violent striving after effect, but a charmingly sincere gift of emotion wedded to melodious verso. Tho metres aro varied with a good deal of technical skill, and this variety dispels anything like tho monotony which sometimes attends cycles of poems inspired by a single passion. The range of expression is not wide, but, within tho limits sho has set herself, the author of " Heartsease " lias produced verso of grace and distinction that lifts tho little book well out of tho common ruck.
Four volumes in a lighter key aro Mr. Anthony C. Deane’s New Rhymes for Old (Lane), tho new edition of Horace in Homespun, by the writer who calls himself “Hugh Haliburton" (Blackwood), Burns rrom Heaven, by Hamish Hendry (Richards), and Miss Fowler's Love’s Argument and other Poems. Tho last shows tho pen of a facile and versatile writer ; “ Hugh Haliburton,” whoso book is already well known in tho north, is a genial humourist, applying Hoiatian standards—in Scotch verse—to the minor problems of modern life ; Mr. Hendry, though his volume is unequal, writes clover Scots; and Mr. Deane, as a parodist, is sometimes almost as good as Mr. Owen Seaman.
History.
Professor Lanciani's small volume, The Destruction of Ancient Rome; a Sketch of the History of the Monuments (Macmillan) is printed in America, and may lie tho substance of lectures delivered in that country. Anyhow it ismore summary and popular than the author’s former volumes, and it is written more exclusively from one point of view, being an attempt to answer tho question. How did tho glorious buildings of ancient Romd and tho Campagna fall into minor disappear, and who is responsible for tho destruction of tho works of art that abounded there within the memory ot history ? The interest of such a discussion is obvious, and no man could conduct it better than Signor Lanciani. It is a miserable story that ho tells, and one reads it with an uninterrupted feeling of depression. His main point is that, although tho various sieges of Romo by Alaric, Genseric, and others did immense harm to certain buildings, tho barbarians have far less to answer for than the Romans themselves, headed by Popes, cardinals, and great nobles, who through many centuries deliberately used tho ancient buildings as quarries out of which to build the new. The jiuthor, who gives chanter and verse for. his
H a
. ' 1 ; i : : • i i :
accusations, has told, a story full ot tragic
interest.
Ml*. W. 6. Hazlitt some forty years ago published a history of Venice in four volumes, and this ho has now rewritten and issued in two stout octavos, under the title ot The VENETIAN REPUBLIC ; its Rise, its Growth, and its Fall (A. and C. Black). Some former books of the author have not prepossessed us in his favour, but in tho volumes before us he has produced a: serious work, and appears to have given considerable study to the masses of new material which havo been made accessible since I860. The researches of the late Mr. Rawdon Brown, and such publications as tho 30 or 40 volumes of tho diaries of Marino Sanuto (1496-1533)—to mention but two sources out of many—have entirely transformed the task which the modern historian of Venice must set himself. Of tills Mr. Hazlitt has been conscious, and, though probably it would bo easy to criticize his volumes in detail, they form tho most comprehensive history of Venice as yet accessible to English readers.
A separate and very romantic episode of Venetian history is delightfully told in tho quarto volume Frangipani’s Ring, by the distinguished German writer and critic Henry Thotlo ; tho English translation by “ J. F. O. L." is published
by Mr. Macqueen. Nine years ago, while he was working in St. Mark’s Library, some peasants brought to Herr Thodo an old inscribed gold ring which they had found in making some excavations in the Pordenoue region; and by a series of happy guesses, wonderfully confirmed by contemporary documents in the library, especially tho voluminous diaries of Marino Sanuto, tho fortunate new owner identified his ring with one that had been lost in tho year 1513 by that deadly enemy of Venice, Count Christoph Frangipani, commander of the Imperial forces that were then invading tho northern territories ot the Republic. Tho discovery led him to investigate the life of the Count, the story of his marriage with the sister of the celebrated Cardinal Matthew Lang, his capture by the Venetians, his long imprisonment, his wife’s romantic devotion, and his death ; and the result is a charming book, full of new matter and unpublished letters, the whole forming a most vivid page of the history of Venice and her neighbours in the great days of her glory.
Lord Edmond Fitzmaurice has republished in book form, embellished with a couple of portraits and a map, two articles from t he Edinburgh Review on Chaiu.es, Duke of Brunswick (Longmans). If ho is ambitious of an historical reputation, ho had bettor have left them anonymous. Like most articles in the two great quarterlies, they exhibit a wide range of knowledge in relation to tho subject. The author has read many memoirs, &c., besides ordinary histories, and ho has some grasp of tho period he is dealing with. Like most periodical literature, these articles contain crude opinions and judgments running into extremes, because epigram is for such compositions almost necessary, and space is wanting to tone down exaggerated outlines of action or character. The shadow of Macaulay is perhaps still over tho Edinburgh Review. Lord Edmond Fitzmaurice’s work reminds one of Macaulay’s famous essays, both in its merits and in its defects. There is no direct imitation of stylo; but there is the same effective sketching of the general aspect of things and the same skill in relieving graver delineations by personal touches. Unfortunately, also, there is tho
same, or greater, lack ot accuracy in illustration, tho same ignoring, for the sake o£ rhetorical effect, oE qualifications and limitations such as an historian should in honesty introduce. Tho writer ok an ephemeral article may perhaps bo forgiven for not verify ing his incidental references. An author who publishes an historical work under his own name can hardly be excused for leaving them incorrect. As a brief sketch of a man who played a great part in his time, and might have played a greater had ho been mado of sterner stuff, this little book is interesting, but it is not a permanent contribution to history.
Mr. I1'. M. Hueffer’s The Cinque Ports : a Historical and Dsscrutive Becord (Blackwood) is an attractive volume, well illustrated by Mr. William Hyde, on tho history of one of the most interesting regions of England. Mr. Hueffer indeed makes no claim to bo considered an authoritative historian ; he presents himself, almost too avowedly, as tho literary man; but he knows how to make good use of what has been already discovered ;.nd written, and his historical narrative is not amiss. Mr. Hyde, who had already proved tho poetical qualities of his art in his illustrations to Mr. Meredith’s poems, has contributed some really charming drawings, especially those of Bomney Marsh and of tho salt-flats near Bye.
Miscellanea.
A capital selection of Cartoons by Sir John Tenniel has been issued in a half-crown volume (Punch office, Bouverie-street). There is no necessity to tell what qualities of drawing, what humour, aud what apposite illustration of events are to be found in the great cartoonist’s work; it is too well-known to need recommendation. When Buskin said of him that ho had raised tho art of caricature to a
higher plane, he only said what every one who has studied the cartoons must have felt vaguely
tiidicd havo felt vaguely, oven though thoy could not express in words I what they felt. All tho pictures in this volume
have a double value—artistic and historical. Tho latter will increase as time goes on, and, if our children and grandchildren admire the drawing less highly than we do, they will only proclaim themselves poorer than their parents in taste and appreciation.
The Jew in London, by C. Russell and H. 8. Lewis (Fisher Unwin).-—A careful investigation, mado for tho Toynbee Trustees, of tho statistics and conditions of Jewish life in East London. A book of great interest, written without bias of any kind, and accompanied by a really wonderful statistical map of East London, showing tho proportions of Jewish and Gentile population over a largo area.
Readings in the Paradiso of Dante (Macmillan).—These two volumes complete Mr. Warran Vernon’s elaborate aud line-by-line study of tho Divine Comedy ; a book which has already established its position as an indispensable help to tho English student of Dante. There is a brightlywritten introduction by tho Bishop of Ripon.
Domesticities, by E. V. Lucas (Smith, Elder, and Co.) ; “ a little book of household impressions," lightly-touched essays on meals, clothes, walks, the books to read, and many other matters of daily concern. Tho anther's genial humour has already mado him a general favourite with readers, and this bright little book will confirm his position. ___________

Title: Poetry
Full_text:
Brief Notes.
Poetry.
L
The pressure on our space makes it Impossible for us to review at length any large proportion of the multitude of books which pour from the press in the last three months of the year. The following short notes, however, may be of service ,to intending readers :—
Mr.Laurence Binyon’s Odes (The Unicorn Press).—A thin volume of highly-accomplished verse, somewhat in the manner of Mr. Bridges ; the subjects chiefly from classical or medieval
story. The best is perhaps “ The Death of
nest 18 Tristram*.’^ which, if it does not disnlace Matthew
. :
rnosovey poemrom our affections, at least gives a new and beautiful reading to an immortal story of passion.
The Professor, and other Poems, by A. C. Benson (Lane).—Scholarly and sincere, the first part showing a genuine lyrical gift. The longest poem, a blank verse monologue put into the mouth of the poet Gray, is an interesting piece of psychological analysis.
Titania, and other Poems, by A. 8. Cripps (E. Mathews).—A small volume by one of the group of poets who came out of Oxford a few years ago. The songs are charming, and sonnets like “ Perdita ” and “ On the Graves of a War ” have a pathetic note that is not common in the verse of to-day.
The Wild Knight, and other Poems, by Gilbert Chesterton (Grant Richar ds).—Clever .generally pessimistic, and sometimes, as in “The Wild Knight,” verging on the grotesque.
The Prayer of St. Scholastica, and other Poems, by Lady Lindsay (Kegan Paul.—Graceful and sincerely felt, but striking no new note of feeling or melody.
Gisli Suksson, a Drama and Poems by the late Helen Barmby (Constable).—These are “poems of the old Norse days,” and Professor York
Powell, an expert and enthusiast for everything Icelandic, writes a highly laudatory preface to them. Miss Barmby died too soon, and the little book is primarily a memorial of what its editor calls “ the busy, curious brain, and the brave, gentle heart ’ ’ of one who might have done great things had time been allowed her.
The Handy Man, and Other Verse, by Harold Begbie (Grant Richards).—War poems and songs by a clever admirer, not to say imitator, of Mr. Rudyard Kipling.
Poems ; Chiefly Sacred, by Dr. Chadwick, Bishop of Deny (Hodder and Stoughton).—Tho Bishop of Derry writes in the vein of his distinguished \ predecessor ; his poems are for the most part happily free from the commonplace from which clerical poets seem to find it so difficult to escape.
Three small volumes of translations in verse deserve notice:—
An Echo of Greek Songs, Englished by W. H. D. Rouse (Dent), is a dainty little collection of epigrams from the anthology in which the writer acknowledges an occasional debt of Mr. Mackall.
Songs of Modern Greece, by G. F. Abbott (Cambridge University Press), is more important, being perhaps the best existing collection of modern Greek songs with literal English translations and good notes. The .book is indispensable to all intelligent travellers in Greece.
Songs from the Book of Jaffir (Macmillan) is an anonymous collection of clever verse and prose, professing to be adapted from the Persian. Bindra, the jester, who contributes
half the sdngs, ought to take his place in the train of Omar Khayyam.
The following are noteworthy, among col¬
lections and new editions :—
The Oxford Book of English Verse, 1250 to 1900 (Clarendon Press).—A volume of 1,000 pages, yet convenient to handle, because of the excellence of the Clarendon Press paper. The editor is Mr. Quiller-Couch, who has “ set his heart on choosing the best.” Strange to say he only gives three pages out of his thousand to Chaucer, while Bishop King has five, Thomas Campion seven, and Mr. Meredith fourteen. But in the making of anthologies, quot homines, tot sentential.
The Treasury of Irish Poetry in the English Tongue, edited by Stopford A. Brooke and T. W. Rolleston (Smith, Elder, and Co.).—This is an authoritative and almost final collection such as we might expect from the hand of two skilled critics and Nationalist Irishmen. The book is edited by Sir Charles Gavan Duffy, and among the editors of sections we find the name of Mr. John O’Leary. This is appropriate enough in a book of which a large part is passionately anti-English ; but it is only fair to say that the book contains also poems by Mr. Aubrey de Vere, Mr. Lecky, and other believers in
the Union. Politics apart, there is no question that the collection contains a large amount of genuine and delightful poetry. We are only somewhat surprised that some of the noble and intensely Irish verse of Miss Emily Lawless is not among it.
The Early Poems of Alfred Tennyson (Methuen),by John Churton Collins.—Mr. Collins edits Tennyson as he would edit a Greek classic, giving the various readings and necessary notes in explanation. This and the introduction show a wealth of Tennysonian learning to which no other critic could pretend. Charmingly printed and bound, and well illustrated by Mr. W. E. F. Britten.

Author: Null
Title: The Poetry And Letters Of T. E. Brown
Full_text:
The Poetry and Letters of T. E. Brown.
The author of “ Fo’c’sle Yarns ” was quite un-; mistakably a man of rare parts and gifts, though; his repute among his friends was evidently much higher, and no doubt deservedly much higher, than his public reputation. If tire estimate formed and recorded by his friends of his personality and genius is not exaggerated, he must have belonged by birthright to the immortals; but he never entered on
his inheritance. EEis life was uneventful; it is his character and qualities that interest. He was the son of a scholarly clergyman in the Isle of Man, and was educated at King William’s College. Nominated by Dean Gaisford to a servitorship at Christ Church, he there gained a brilliant double first, and, not being deemed eligible as a servitor to a studentship at Christ Church, he stood for and obtained a Fellowship at Oriel. But, apart
. . from his brilliant undergraduate career, he made no mark at Oxford. He married early and accepted the headmastership of the Crypt School at Gloucester. Thence he went to Clifton College as a colleague of the present Bishop of Hereford, and at Clifton the greater portion of his active life was spent. In his later years he spent much of his time in his native island, to which he was passionately attached, deeply loving its people, its scenery, its legends, its dialects, and its wild, seafaring life.
There is not much in. a life so devoid of incident to arrest the attention and engage the interest of those who did not know him- We must look for the real Brown, or for so much of him as can be known to those who never saw him in the flesh, in what his friends have to tell us of him and in what he tells us of himself in his letters to them. He was a great letter writer, and gave his friends of his best; and the two volumes of his letters which have been edited by one of his friends, Mr. Sidney T. Irwin, with a charming " Introductory Memoir ” (Constable) will be appreciated by all lovers of good
literature. Still, even in his letters, which are
undoubtedly of high quality, we do not see all that his friends evidently saw in him. We do not recognize in them the man of whom the Bishop of Hereford writes :—
To compare Brown with the average run of even the
^b°T^LaU
onrS 7k SVtiS
familiar northern scenes; but we miss the pent-up forces, the volcanic outbursts, the tropic glow, and all the surprisingly manifold and tender and sweet-scented outpourings of soil and sunshine, so spontaneous, so inexhaustibly rich, and with the great heat of fire burning
and palpitating all the time.
Such an appreciation surely points to a much larger and richer nature than shows I itself in these letters. They are good letters, I as we have said, spontaneous, sympathetic, I varied, kindly, humorous, and full of a fine sense of literature. They are also sui generis. Ig were neither fair nor criti-1 eally just to compare them favourably or un- I favourably with the famous letters of more famous men. They must be judged on their own merits; I and so judged they will be rated high. But they will not be rated with the highest. There must have been some subtle bond of spiritual and intellectual sympathy between Mr. Brown and his friends which made the latter see more in his words and thoughts than the world at large is ever likely to find. Much is said by his friends
of his wide literary knowledge, his large literary
sympathies, his exquisite critical faculty. We are ready to take all this for granted, but we do not find quite so much of it as we should expect in I the letters .We hardly know whether his extreme, not to say extravagant, admiration for the work of his fellow-islander, Mr. Hall Caine, is to I be set to the credit of his critical faculty, or of his island patriotism, but as criticism it is perhaps a little out of the centre. He is happier in an apoph-1 thegm like the following :—“ There are nice Rabelaisians, and there are nasty Rabelais-1
ians, but the latter are not Rabelaisians.” But, on the whole, the letters will I be judged and. appreciated, not for their I literary or critical merits, but as the intimate, I albeit imperfect, record of a temperament and I personality which displayed to all who knew the writer some of the rarest attributes of genius, If the genius is not so , conspicuous to the stranger as it was to the friend, there is no more I to be said. But manifestly the personality was I rare and the temperament engaging. |
In a volume published by Messrs. Macmillan wo have Mr. Brown's collected verses. Most of them are stories of rural and seafaring existence among the Manx, and couched in the local dialect, partly Celtic survival (biddiuzg—" cream I ready for churning ”), partly commonplace (ger tatt “ get out,” or glioses “ghosts ”). Addressing the problematical future poet of the island, Mr. Brown said :
• -
Thenative a^nt'pie.mcholed
With Cockney balderdash. Old Manx is waning.
Again—
With Keltic force, with Keltic fire,
With Keltic tears let every string be burning. No doubt this was Mr. Brown's poetic ideal. I He is “ soaked in local dialect,” but very little of it is 11 old Manx ” ; which we humbly ] take to be a dialect of Gaelic. " Hould this hoss,’ for instance, may be old Manx, but may more probably be regarded, as a blend, of IrishEnglish and of American. Potatoes ætepriddhas, which has a Gaelic look ; sthrooghing, for _ stroking, resembles the Irish brogue. 11 These I dialee’s is terrible,” says one of Mr. Brown’s heroes, and a note adds, " people toiZl talk in I dialects.” They will, and will write in them too,and 1 the Manx dialect appears, on the whole,to resemble English in an Irish mouth, with a few Gaelic words, and possibly, though. we have not observed it, a dash of Scandinavian. "While this I is the form of speech, Mr, Brown’s matter and manners are somewhat akin to those of the usual English literary writers in dialect; the vein of sentiment is even rather Scotch (though. I not so much so as that of Ian Maclaren), Mr. Brown, being of Scotch Border descent. The narrators of his very long versified narratives are Manxmen, usually, and have large excellent hearts, and often employ picturesque ex-1 pressions. In “ Mary Quayle ” we have a very old motif—that of “ Adam Bede.” The sweet-
heart of the Manx wooer has a child to an under-1
graduate. The wooer induces him to promise to come to marry her, but the young Oxford man I
is drowned., the day before he sets out, while playing a salmon. He was found, dead, but clinging to his rod. “ like the good, one that he I was,” to quote Bon Gaultier. How a river full of Crags and precipices appeared in a land of I “ meadows like long lakes of grass,” the geologist may inquire, but perhaps the stream had cut a I kind Of canon, as in the Cumberland Eden. At all events, the idea of the tale is rather well worn (except the part about the salmon, though Lap. nlwAOi-lv n nnan non in finhiAnl n<n/4 -Al, n. 1
that has already appeared in fiction), and the
merit lies in the descriptions of Manx character and landscape.
The fault of Mr. Brown is copiousness. He has not a curiosa felicitas, but almost an incuriosa facilitas. The poems occupy 736' pages of close type. We have enormous abundance of verse like this :—
No, no !
Only to go,
To flow,
To fling my spray in the sunny glow,
To splash. To dash, Heels over head with a crazy crash,
Again,
Did you put it in the papers?
No, no ! What capers !
No, no!
Splendid though !
“ What capers,” indeed ! “ Sir,” said
Johnson," a man might write such stuff for ever if he would abandon his mind to it.” Endless screeds
Dr.
of such irregular fluency become extremely tedious. The poem of “ Old John,” though lengthy, has form and biographical interest; and there is a pretty piece of rural vers de societe, styled “ An Oxford Idyll.” The passion for nature is, throughout, sincere, and among the lyrics is a charming piece, “ I bended unto me.” Probably Mr. Brown would have had more readers
is a discreet editor had selected- his hest ahd
Tmeses! pieces, with the choice of his tales os rural -sentiment and sorrows in the Manx dialect, though many of these would have been quite as welcome in prose as in a. scamper of runaway rhymes. Mr. Brown, in short, wish many poetical qualities, was not -a poet ; his verse is far too facile, and far too formless ; it is not distilled like drops of-amber/but pours down like the rain from rocky heights, an a turbid, hurrying spate of uncouth words. The narrators, to be sure, are naturally garrulous men, and to make them extremely prolix may be dramatically correct. But it results in a volume of 736 mortal pages ; very few of them marked by distinction. This is the more strange as Mr. Brown was intimately familiar with classical literature. As occasionally happens, he chose models and a style utterly unlike what he most admired in literature. It is as if Tennyson had given us many hundreds of pages in the manner of the " Lincolnshire Farmer,” which would have been most “ tolerable and not to be endured.”

Title: Poerty And Criticism
Full_text:
Poetry and Criticism.
Mr. Edmond Holmes, the author of a little volume of poems which made a decided mark, has
----- ’
published an essay on a question often asked and as often unsatisfactorily answered, What is Poetry ? (Lane). If, as he himself is the first to admit, his replies to this question are only partial, if they will seem inadequate to some ok his
. . , . , ,- . , . ,., „
readers, we must at least give bun credit for an. attempt to reach back to first principles in a day when most critics are content to beat the air, and to throw out persona] judgments without sayabatis the code b7^htheyare bound,
”-01n®a bos the first requisite of one who
would write philosophically upon poetry ; he has a clear understanding of the main problems that have to be met. His little book is the develop-
following:—
Poetry is tho expression of deep and strong feeling.
"
es tomengoe fe*t- Deep and strong feeling is generated by contact w a’ and implies perception of, hiilden reality ; in other words, poetic feeling has clear insight for its counterP:irt‘ .. S18.t is often taken to generate emotion, just 8,s emotion i* often taken to generate insight.
And again,if these indicate what the poet is in himself, another set of principles may be discovered, if we examine how he should communicate himself to others; that is, expression also has its 1 _» „ _
Principles , and the second part of the essay develops the truth that in poetry feeling finds its own voice, and in doing so wakens responsive feelings in other hearts.” So Stated the discussion may g^em a Uttle cold and academical, but Mr. .7 L 7> 7 , . . •
Holmes writes both clearly and agreeably, has a ready command of illustration, and, though he is dealing with truths that sound elementary, he has a true instinct for the avoidance of the commonplace. The tittle book may be ranked with Mr.
Raleigh s essay On Style, published a year or two ago, and will not be less valued than that as a scholarly attempt to find a solution of questions which many people ask nowadays, without nansinn- for an answer
Pa®i>mglor an answer. , . . .
On the other hand, Mr. Arthur Symons in his volume The Symbolist Moe
tube (Heinemann) takes for investigation only a
very special phase of very modern poetry—the poetry represented by a group of French writers whom he is inclined to regard as the spiritual progeny of Gerard de Nerval. Few attempts to ° •. ... , . . ,. . . y
elassiky literary tendencies are satisfactory ; few felines are equally applicable to all the people they are meant to denote ; and one might easily protest against grouping under one title men so different as De Nerval and Maeterlinck. How>* <-, ,, , . , . .__
eY®rl Symons attaches to his term a meaning whicu makes it fairly applicable to all his poets.
He describes Symbolism as— An attempt to spiritualize literature, to evade the old. bondage of rhetoric, the old bondage of exteriority, Description is banished when beautiful things may be evoked magically ; the regular beat of verse is broken in order that word* may fly upon subtler wings. . . . A* we brush aside the accidents of daily life in which
men and wemea imagine that they are alone touching
human reality, we come closer to humanity, to every-
thing in humanity that may have begun before toe
world, and may outlast it.
The average educated, man, the average man of tetters will probably reply that “that way commonly mean by “ the accidents of daily life I includes the general sum of human experience, the normal emotions, affections, joys, sorrows ; the things with which Homer dealt, and Sophocles and WoTdsworth ; while what these writers would | , .., . . J # ,, , , ,
I substitute for them are for the most part inchI vidual fancies, often morbid fancies, of vheir own. which cannot be thoroughly tasted cxceoti
by morbid minds. Still poets like Verlaine,
MaJlarmd, and the rest have attained to a certain importance, durable or not, and a book which gives a trustworthy account of them,written with Mr. Symons’s ability, is sure of a welcome.
The writer has simultaneously published a volume of verse of his own, Images of Good and Evil (Heinemann), and this naturally partakes of the qualities which he admires in other poets. In prose he aims at being, so to speak, the successor
of Walter Pater ; in verse he “ throws back ” in part to the Symbolist French writers, and in part to the early-middle period of Mr. Swinburne. "Wo confess that we should like the poetry better if “ dreams ”—the word and the thing—pervaded, the pages less, and if there were not quite such a banishing of the large emotions of life. Quito the best of the poems are those written in Spain, whether or not they have anything Spanish in them ; the two called “ At Tarragona”and “ At Toledo ” have a genuine mystic note, and that called “ Spain,” addressed to a Spanish dancer who lightly sings of the ruin of her country, touches reality in a very different way from many of the poems which aim at a more obscure truth, and do not always hit it.
With Mr. Symons’s volume we naturally group that called Decorations (Smithers), the posthumous publication of the unfortunate Ernest Dowson, in whose memory Mr. Symons writes some interesting pages in the current Fortnightly Review. Dowson died the other day, aged 32, worn out with drink and ill-success ; a pathetic figure from every point of view, who became tragic in his end. He was a genuine poet ; in reading his work and the story of his life one can but repeat the futile wish that fate and his temperament had been kinder to him, and that he might have had a better chance of making his gifts prevail.
The fire is out, and spent the dregs thereof. (This is the end of every song man sings 1) Tho golden wine is drmik ; tho dregs remain. Bitter as wormwood, and as salt as pain ;
And health aud hope have gone the way of love Into the drear oblivion of lost things.
So sang poor Dowson towards the end of his life, and we now know that he spoke from experience. His ghost may have the feeble satisfaction of knowing that now that he is dead his thin and not too wholesome muse will be cherished by the little band of English readers who value all poetry that is sincere and musical, whether the message which the poet has to give be sweet or bitter.
Professor J. K. Ingram, of Dublin, the author of Sonnets and Other Poems (A. and C. Black), is perhaps not a poet, but he is a man who has felt deeply, and writes with clearness and force. It is interesting to find him avowing and reprinting the famous rebel song, “ Who fears to speak of Ninety-Eight ?” which he wrote some fifty years ago, though in the preface he is careful to say that he “ now no longer sympathizes with those who preach sedition in our own day, when all the circumstances are radically altered.” The professor is a thoroughgoing Positivist, and he makes the religion of humanity and the fame of “ the Master ” (Auguste Comte) the subject of a good deal of harmonious verse. We can read it with interest, but are no more convinced by it than by the admiring sonnet “ To the President of the Transvaal ”—for Mr. Ingram is what is known as a pro-Boer. By far the best of the poems are those which describe with much sincerity and pathos the writer’s own sorrow in the death of his wife.
Another volume ot Irish verse, which has the genuine note of poetry, is Miss “ Moira O’Neill’s ” Songs oe the Glens of Antrim
(Blackwood), a little volume of CO pages which deserves a permanent place in any collection of Irish poetry. It is not generally known that in the midst of the non-Gel tie county of J Antrim are some “ glens ” inhabited by Irish as thoroughbred as though they come from Mayo, |
and the writer, who describes herself as “ a
glenswoman,” catches up the poetry of these people and throws it into verse, now light, now pathetic, of a really charming kind.
We have already briefly noticed the adaptations of Lucretius which Mr. W. H. Malloek lately published in the Anglo-Saxon Review. These
experiments in the metre of FitzGerald’s “ Omar
Khayyam ” have now been reprinted in a small volume under the title Lucretius on Life and , Death (A. and C. Black), and in their per-! manent form the verses will be read with ‘
interest. Translations they are not; they are a much-expanded paraphrase of some of the most' striking and most genuinely poetical passages of the great Epicurean poet. Mr. Malloek, who has '< written so much in praise of the Roman Catholic ’ position, does not shrink from presenting the " extreme, and, as he would say, the only philosophical alternative. This has never been put so forcibly in English verse as it is in these powerful stanzas.
Amid reprints we have to notice the volume containing the Complete Poems of Mathilde Blind (Unwin), which is edited by Mr. Arthur Symons, with an interesting memoir by Dr. Richard Garnett; and the volume called First and Last Poems, by Arabella Shore (Grant Richards). In the latter case it is only a portion of the poems that are reprinted ; some of them
'iave no^ bGen published before. Mathilde Blind c^eyer rather vehemen.-writer, who
might perhaps have been a poet had she ever
attained a complete mastery of English ; but, as was natural in one of purely German birth
who lived for the most part among Germans in her youth, she never learnt to use our speech with perfect freedom. Nor was she always alive to the difference between rhetoric and poetry. She grasped the Darwinian hypothesis, in its application to human life, with fair success, and her poem on “ The Ascent of Man ” is a vigorous presentation of it. But it is singularly rhetorical in form, though probably the writer, with her strong sense of the manifold injustices that hang on the skirts of progress, wrote it in all sincerit.

Author: Null
Title: Short Notices
Full_text:
Shout Notic
Mr. Murray’s new edition of Bykon has now reached the third volume of the poetry, which includes, with many minor poems,“ The Corsair ” and other Eastern tales, “The Hebrew Melodies," “ The Siege of Corinth,” &c. Mr. Ernest Coleridge, the editor, has noted with the greatest care all variations of the text, and has added illustrative notes in sufficient abundance. This
volume, in fact, like those which have preceded it both in prose and verse, seems to show that no future edition of Byron need over be attempted. Commentators will have nothing to do but to quarry in tho materials which Mr. Coleridge and Mr. Murray have provided for them. This is nob the moment to discuss tho impression made upon a modern reader who turns to these poems either for the first time or, as will be the case with
most of us, after an interval of many years ; enough to say that they present a curious mixture of tho hopelessly antiquated and of the permanent. Perhaps never again, certainly not in our time, will the world take pleasure in anything so rhetorical, so obvious, so elementary as, for example, “ The Corsair," which, as wo are here reminded, was devoured with passionate eagerness by the public when it appeared, in the beginning of 1814. “ I sold on tho day of publication—a thing perfectly unprecedented—10,000 copies,” wrote "Murray to tho author ; and all
—,—, - the world went mad about Conrad aud Medora
<NEWPAGE>
and Gulnare. A few splendid passages, a few immortal couplets remain to give us pleasure
now ; the rest scarcely counts in. comparison with “ Childe Harold ” and “ Don Juan,” the poems ■which reveal the real Byron. It may be added that the volume contains the several small poems which show what a wretched creature that real Byron sometimes proved to be. “ The Sketch,” here printed in “ Poems of the Separation,” was not too severely described by "Wordsworth as “theBillingsgate of Bedlam,” and. was denounced in The Times when the verses were first published as “ low malignity and miserable doggerel.” But it need hardly be said that a volume which contains such verses as “ She walks in beauty ” and “ "When we two parted,” and a hundred other well-remembered things, is not to be condemned "because "* The Sketch ” is ignoble and “ The Corsair ” not much more than a declamatory exercise.
In I Believe (Religious Tract Society) the Bishop of Calcutta, Dr. Welldon, endeavours to set forward the nature and reasonableness of the Christian creed “ in such language as the young could easily understand.” If by “ the young ’ he means sixth form boys or other young persons old enough to be exercised by spiritual difficulties among whom, intellectually, may be classed the intelligent artisans,the book is well adapted for its purpose. But its author by no means confines himself to tho ‘1 very simple words ’ ’ which in his preface he states that he has found it necessary to make use of in teaching Christian doctrine to the young. Such sentences as this, “ The first, question of religion is clearly this—How did the Universe—i.e., the sum total of phenomena—come into being?” or, “Tho realization of God’s Universal Presence is a powerful incentive to virtuous and godly living ” demand more than a child’s intelligence; and the fact that Dr AVelldon cannot reduce his exposition of the creed to simpler terms shows the weakness of the contention, sometimes put forward,that abstract dogmatic theology can be taught to much purpose to very young children. As Dr. "Welldon truly says, the technical terms of theology “ have no meaning for them, and simply pass over their heads.” For older boys or intelligent working men this commonsense, manly statement of the truths of the Christian creed as worthy of belief—understanding by belief not a claim to certain knowledge, but assent to reasonable probabilities—may be
commended as helpful.
Religious disputes, as we know to our cost, turn largely upon things unessential, and the first requisite for a rightly-balanced view is to distinguish, in doctrine and practice, between what is really essential and what is impressive perhaps, but of subordinate importance. This Canon F. J. Holland, of Canterbury, essays to do in a modest little volume entitled Essentials in Religion (Arnold), of which we can at least say 0 si sic omnes ecclesiastici I It comprises six sermons delivered in Canterbury Cathedral, under the headings Essentials and Non-Essentials ; Essentials in the Divine Faith, the Divine Law, the Divine Sacraments, Church Organization, and Church Ritual. In the first, which is introductory, Canon Holland illustrates the distinction from St. Stephen’s speech at Jerusalem, which sets forth God’s covenant with his people as essential, but the Temple and the Law as nonessential now that their purpose was fulfilled. In the next three the doctrines of the Apostles’ Creed, the rule of the Ten Commandments understood in the spirit and not in the letter only, “Regeneration,” or the new birth in Baptism, and the memorial sacrifice and Holy Communion in the Eucharist, are laid down as essentials. In the last two sermons the preacher does what many disputants on Church questions are unwilling to do. He goes back to the New Testament, and finding how little is there said about either organization or ritual, he concludes, as most impartial minds do, thai
Church organization and Church ritual, however important and helpful, are not essential to the true idea of the “ Holy Catholic Church.” The term ” Church,” as he truly points out, is confusedly used sometimes in its lower sense of ecclesiastical order, sometimes in the higher and truer sense of spiritual union in the Body of Christ ; and he effectively illustrates the difference by the “ dismal alteration of sublime descriptions of God’s Church” in Holy Scripture, if for the word “ Church ” be substituted “ecclesiastical organization, ’ ’ On the question of incense he has some sound and practical remarks ; and his attitude towards this and similar questions is thus summed up—“Be ritual what it may, no ritual is absolutely essential ; and be ritual however gorgeous, all ritual will tend to become more and more simple unto its final extinction in the perfected Church.” We can only repeat, O si sic omnes!
An interesting study of the representative system in Japan has been published in Brussels
in the shape of an exhaustive essay, SystiIme Repr^sentatif au Japon (Lamertin, Bruxelles), prepared for the Brussels Free University by M. Hisatsuna Furuya, Doctor of Political Science. The first chapter deals with the causes and methods which secured so rapid and successful a transformation of Japanese institutions under
the pressure of Western ideas. The second and third chapters set forth in detail the composition j of the Japanese Diet and its procedure, and the 1
fourth and last chapter is devoted to a critical I examination of the working of the representative system as now established and of the further reforms which in the author’s opinion are still requisite for its final development. Political students will certainly feel grateful to M. Furuya for having furnished them with so useful a handbook on a most interesting subject of modern constitutional history.

In. her Letters FROM Fast Africa (Univerities Mission to Central Africa), Miss
Gertrude Ward gives a charming picture, simple, unstudied, and yet full of graceful and graphic touches, of the daily Use of a nurse in an upcountry mission station in tropical Africa. “ The letters (with three exceptions) were written in all simplicity to relations and friends for private perusal, without the least idea of publication ;
but they well deserve and should certainly attract a wider circle of readers among “ that laree public which cares increasingly for things African. Things African at this moment suggest other ideas than those which are associated with the . kindly agencies of missionary work and Christian benevolence. But there is an Africa in which love and peace and. devotion are doing I good work apart from strife, and of this Africa I and its charm for brave and, gentle souls Miss I Ward’a letters speak very movingly.

Mr. Frederic Harrison’s volume, called Tennyson, Ruskin, Mm, and other Literary Esti mates, is in some sense a sequel to his volume on “Early "Victorian Literature,” published five years ago. That, however, kept itself almost exclusively to the novelists and historians, and the reader found himself taking up a volume on
literature from which poetry and philosophy were expressly excluded. Here on the other hand, we have, as far as the bulk of the essays are concerned, a series of " estimates of some of the leading influences on the thought of our time,” together with a few articles of a more retrospective kind, especially two very: excellent ones on the new memoirs and letters of Gibbon. It is hard to say anything fresh about those “ leading influences ” ; has
not everything been said a hundred times over about Tennyson and his poetry, Mill and his Individualist philosophy, and (just now especially) about Ruskin, the critic and the social reformer ? Perhaps it has, but yet Mr. Harrison’s essays on these subjects, as on others, are worth reading, for nobody denies either the width of his cultivation or the independence—so far as Positivism allows him to be independent—of his mind. In the essays on Tennyson and Ruskin we find him breaking what is for him new ground in his very elaborate criticism of their workmanship as writers of verse and prose. On Ruskin’s prose he is very good indeed ; on Tennyson’s verse he carries nis criticism to fantastic lengths. And in judging the matter of Tennyson’s poetry he is certainly not more convincing. Mr. Harrison condemns the poet for his halfbeliefs, his " honest doubt,” and his disposition to “ faintly trust the larger hope ” ; and yet when he comes upon something that Tennyson really did believe in, the something which its enemies call Imperialism and its friends the world-mission of England, he promptly denounces him as a Jingo and a journalist. "What is this but to condemn the poet because he and bis critic do not believe in the same things ? Ae to the other essays, we cannot but keel the critic overrates the late J. A. Symonds ; but his essays on Freeman and Frowde, and on the Gibbon autobiographies, are
excellent, while that on J. 8. Mill is based upon
excellent, while that J. b. Mill is based personal kn9\ti£difo.jandj2ti_tilOJ.lyid mem9KSLQL^
time when Mill’s influence among young liberal thinkers was something to which no parallel exists at the present day. As to Matthew Arnold, Mr. Harrison, as might be expected, praises his poetry, his literary criticism, and his generosity ot mind, while he waves aside Arnold’s philosophy and his attitude towards the Bible. Here, again, one has to remember that Mr. Harrison is a convinced Comtisb, and a Comtist who has old scores toaoff.

Mr. Alfred Austin has returned to the kind of composition which he made so popular in " The Garden that I Love," and in a volume of prose narrative interspersed with lyrics has pictured the winter and spring spent by a little English group on the Riviera, and in a villa near Florence. That country is so delightful in itself and in its wvealth of association, that even a much less practised pen thhan Air. Austin's could make such a book attractive. Any one with an eye for the country and the people, and with somo knowledge of history, could produce a pleasant volume about them ; a skillel writer vith a genuine love for fiowers,blue skies, and cont adini, and some knowledge of art, was certain to write what would command the interest of many readers. WVhat we have said only concerns Mr. Austin's prose, biit tho songs and short soliloquies in verse which he puts into the mouth of " the poet " are quite as important. " The poet," let it be said, is one of the four characters of the story, the others being Veronica-clever housewife, good botanist, and competernt historian-Lamia, the fascinating young girl for whose pleasure the wholo tour seema to have been devised, and the ' I " of the book, who professes to wvrite theaccountofit. To say that there is any system in the book would not be true. It is not a story, nor an essay, nor a guide-book, nor a poem, but it has something of all four. The conversations lack dramatic truth, and any one who tries to read them aloud will see that they do not really represent talk. Here are two examples:-
Suddenly other persiana were pushed back, sand Veronica joined us.
'What are you all doing9 "
Do you remember," anwered Lamia, " the vifo of Cosimo, Pater Patrin, asking him, when advanced in years, why be so often sate with closed eyes, and his answering that he did so in order tu accustom tiem to what thev must soon always be doing' I nm opening mine thus early, feeling that, in such a world as this, I shall never be able to close them again.
That is not how charming young women talk, whether in Italy or elsewhere ; and in like manner we may demur to the followving:-
" Some of these are very successful," I ventured to observe.
" Not," said Veronica, " if in the notion of success be included that of succession. Congratulated to-day, wvvl they not be consigned to oblivion to-morrow, when right taste has resumed its authority, or when some one yet more extravagant creates an impression, equally sudden and equally transitory, of a somewhat similar character i' "
But the passages of description are excellent, especially such a one as this, suggested by the first appearance of the fireflies
" A firefly ! A firefly ! "
It was Veronica, invariably the most observant of us, whoso voice called to us to welcome tho fairy visitor, whose arrival is as deli"htful aud mnmcintous au event in Italy as the wving of The first snallow, the call of the first cuckoo, or the note of the first nightingale in England. WVe were all on the alert in a moment, calling in return
" V'here ? UL'here ? "
It was a single, solitary firefly, for one may say of fireflies as of primroses:-
First you come by ones and ones, Lastly in battalions,
and it moved and twinkled in the deepening twilight, among the olive trees, a miniature and terrestrial plant, haviDg no fixed orbit. I need seareely say that this was some days before Pasqua delle Rose. though WVhitsuntide happened to be an early one, and the following night we saw three, and the night after seven. 'Then-for May can be capricious in Tuscany as elsewhere-the weather was not propitious for them. But by the time the moon was nearly at full they were plenteous as stars in the MIilky Way, and while they fltted sand glistened among the darkening leaves the nightingales rejoiced and enlivened each other with the song that an ancient story and inherited association have transformed for us into a strrin of imaginary sadaess. Life offers no more enchanting combination of sensations than fall to one's lot on a warm Italian night in Mlay, when moonlight, fireflies, and nightingales weavo their concerted charm; and night after night we repaired to the same antique marble seat, where we liked to think Lorenzo and his associates had often sat, in front of the same dark silent cypresses, and drank in the same sweet, grave, harmonious delights.
Good,too,are some of the historical reminiscences, touched with the lightness of hand wvhich -Mr. Austin sometimes forgets in his conversations. And many of tho lyrics have great charm , note especially the dialogue betwveen the Mountains and the Sea, and the " Good Night" Which well deserves quotation:-
Good-night ' Now dwindle wan and low The embers of the afterglow,
And slowly over leaf and lawn
Is twilight's dewy curtain drawn.
The slouching vixen leaves her lair,
And, prowling, sniffs the tell-tale air. The frogs croak louder in the dyke, And all the trees seem dark alike: The bee is drowsing in tBe comb,
The sharded beetle hath gone home
Good-night !
Good-night ! The hawk is in his nest, And the last rook hath dropped to rest. There is no bum, no chirp, no bleat, No rustle in the meadow-sweet.
'Thc woodbine, somewhere out of sight, Sweetens the loneliness of night.
The Sister Stars, that once were seven,
Ilourn for their missing mate in Heasen. The poppy's fair frail lpetals close, The lily yet more languid grows,
And dewy-dreamy droops the rose
Good-night !
'We notice, hownver, some mannerisms that appear to be growing upon the writer, especially a trick of turning substantives into adjectives or participles, as where in the former of these two poems the mountains are described as "nimbused by sunlight."

Mr. E. V. Lucas, who modestly calls himself the " editor " of this little volume, has met wvith a piece of good fortune suclh as seldom falls to the lot of a literary man. In 18(94 there were discovered "two masses of correspondence relating to the family of Charles Lloyd (17I8-1828), the Quaker philanthropist and barker of Birmingham." Among these papers woro found lotters from S. T. C oleridge, Wordswortli, Southey, and many of their iriends, and, above all, more than 20 new letters of Charles Lamb, " some of them worthy to rank with his best." This mass of correspondence was put into the hands of Mr. Lucas, w'ho has had the pleasant task of building Up, upon that foundation, what he rightly calls the " story of a notable family." All students of Coleridge and his circle know something about Charles Lloyd the younger, who went for a time as pupil or " paying guest " to Coleridge in Somersetshire, and sonme of whose poems were incorporated with those of Coleridce himself in one of the volumes published by Cottle at Bristol. The recently issued letters of Coleridge and Mr. Dykes Campbell's Life have thrown much light upon this incident, but little has till now been known of Charles Lloyd's family. EHis father,the Birmingham Quaker,was a remarkable man ; his principal function in life, perhaps we may say, was to found Lloyd's Bank, but, as Mr. Lucas ingeniously points out, he had "a mental vigour and variousness " which, though of course in a very minor degree, almost anticip ated Mr. Gladstone. He was "concerned in Iargo schemes of benevolence," ho was an authlsonity upon finance, he was intensely religious, and he devoted his leisuro to translatinp7 Homer and Hiorace. Of all this,
and especially of the last phase of the elder Lloyd's history, a full account is given by Mr. Lucas, some of whose chapters contain specimens of the translation of the Iiad into the heroic couplet, with the shrewd criticisms of Lamb and the pompous approbation of the Swan of Liehfield, Anna Seward. But neither here nor in the aecountsgiven of Charles Lloyd the younger does the main interest of the volume consist. W'hat gives it a real claimto attention is the story oftheafriendship between Charles Lamb and youn'Robert Lloyd, Charles's brother, who, oppressea by the stifling atmosphere of his home, and being inclined to the new ideas of Godwin and his circle, ".eloped " from Birmingham (without a companion, bien entendu) and took refuge with Charles Lamb in London. This was in January, 1799, but we have three letters dated during the preceding autuimn which show that Lamb had rapidly taken the position of adviser and elder friend to the impulsive, serious-minded ,op..One,of these as Mr. Lucas remarks, 'is how_
Charles Lamb in a new and beautiful character," the charaoter of an adviser and moderator, for it is nothing less than a letter of good counsel sugeesting to Robert a way out of his spiritual difficulties. The letters of Lamb already published, delightful as they are, contain nothing precisely in this tone, so that it is worth while to quote the conclusion of this letter to Robert Lloyd, premising that the substance of the whole is to urge the lad to depend for happiness rather upon his own character than upon his circumstances or even his friends:-
I do not wish to deter you from ma'king a friend, a true friend, nDd such a friendship, where the artieS are not blind to each other's faults, is very us and valuable. I perceive a tendency in you to this error, Robert. I know you ba've chosen to take up an high opinion of my moral v,orth, but I say it before God, and I do not lie, you are mistak-en ia me. I could not bear to lay open all my failings to you, for the sentiment of saiamu would be too pungent. Let this be as an example to you Robert friends fall off, friends mistalke us, they change, t3cy grow unlike us, they go away, they die ; but God is everlasting and incapable of change, and to Him we may look with cheerful, tnpresumptuous hope, while we discharge the duties of life in situations more nutowardly than yours. You complain of the impossibility of improving yourself, but be assured that the opportunity of improvement lies more in the mind than the situation. Humble yourself before God, cast out the sellish principle, wait in patience, do good in every way you can to all sorts of people, never be easy to neglect a duty, tho' a small one, praise G-od for al, end see His hand in all things, and He wrill in timue raise yoa up many frierds-or be Himself instead an unchanging friend. God bless you.
C. LAMB.
Tho breach between Robert Llopl and his family was soon healed ; w-ork was found for Robert at Birmingham, and for some years afterwards an intermittent correspondence was kept up between him and his friend in London. 3Ir. Lucasblames Robert, with some reason, for maldng this correspondence so scanty, and indeed it is difficult to understand how a young man who had only to write to Lamb to bo sure of extractin' from him a marvellous bit of criticism or playful picture of life should havo been so chary in thei use of his opportunities. But some letters he did extract, and to our good fortune they have now been disinterred, after lying lost for almost a century. It is hard to choose among theso vhether we should quote the eulogy of Isank; Walton, or the passage in praise of London as against the country, or the little rhapsody about Jeremy Taylor, or the letter to Robert congratulating him upon his marriage. All areas perfect as they can hc. Perhaps the followving, " a piece of the tnle Elia," gives the most characteristic picture of Lamb:
Dear llobert,-I shall expect yon to bring mo X brimful acconnt of the pleasure which Walton has given you, when you come to town, It must square with your mind. The delightful innocence and healthfulness of the angler's mind will hava flown upon yours like a zephyr. Don't yon already feel your spirit filled with the scenes ?-the banks of iivers, the cowslip beds, the pastoral scenes, the neat alehouses, and hostesses and =ilkmaids, as far exceeding Virgil and Pope as the " Holy Living " is beyond Thomas aKempis. Are not the eating and drinkiing joys painted to 1he life ? Do they not inspire you with an immortal hunger? Are not you ambitious of being made on angler ? What edition have you got ? Is it 11awkins's, with plates of Pisentor, &e. ? That sell3 very dear. I have onlv been able to purchasethe hast edition without the old piates wvhich pleased my childhood: the plates being worn out, end the old edition diflicult land expensive to procure. 'The " Complete Angler " is the only treatise written in dialogues that is worth a halfpenny. IlIany elegant dialogues have been written (such as Bishop Berkeley's I I Minute Philosopher "), but in all of them the interlocutors are merely abstract arguments personify'd; not living dramatic characters, as in Walton, shere everythiag is alive the fishes are absoluc.ly charactered; and birds and animals are as interesting as men aud wvomen.
I perfectly understand the nature of vour solitariness r.t Biram, and wish I could divide myself, " like a bribed haunch," between London and it. But courage
you will soon be emancipated, and (it may be) have a frequenit power of visiting this great place. Let them talk of lakes and mountains and ronmantic dales-all that fantastic stuff give me a ramble by nighbt, in the winter nights in T onden-the lamps lit, the pavements of the motley Strand crowded with to and fro passengers, the shops all brilliant, and stuffed with obliging customers anud obliged tradesmen-give me the old boe1Astvils of London, a walk in the bight piazzas of Covent Garden. I defy a man to be doll in such places-perfc-t 1ahemetan paradises upon earth ! } hav lent ou.t my heart with usury to such scenes from my childhood up, end have cried with fulness of joy at the multitldinous recenes of life in the crowded streets of ever dear London,
Of course, these letters of Lamb are the gems of Mr. Lucas's volume, but all the rest has considerable interest for students of the Coleridgean circle, and tlhough it is hard in these days to admire the elder Lloyd's Bomer, or to tak-e much interest in the illustrious Anna Seward,Mr. Lucas has dealt wvith these good people discreetly and could scarcely have dispensed wvith them.

Trn; LMriEr.3nAN CLERGOY ASD nr SrLrrEmsTix oF RxaicIOx, by Hcnry Gee (Clarendon Press), is a very thorough piece of w ork. turning the microscope upon a special point of ecclesiastical history-viz., the treatment of the cleroy in the first siS years of Elizabeth's reign. The reaction under Queen Mary, accompuanied by a large number of deprivations, bad considerably altered thb acrsenaeZ of the clergy; and when Elizabetl came to the Throne in 1558 she found a large number of tho "secular " clergy-according to Camden, 9,400, a figaure probablby exaggeratod -attached to the esistinp stat,e of the Chlurch. Convocation and the IJmsversitses at once set themselves in opposition to the expected legislation of Elizabeth's first Parliament. The Acts of Supremacy and Uniformity, which formed the legislative basis of the settlement of religion until the second Parliament of 1563, were stoutly opposed by the Bishops, wvho afterwvards with one exceptioni were deprived for refusing to take an oath admitting the supremacy. A Royal visitation of both provinces to administer the oath to the clergy was followed by a permanent ecclesiastical commission sitting at intervals from Noveinber,1559,toJuly,1562; Nrhlti,underincreased fears arising from the religious wars in France and the proceedings of Mary Queen of Scots, a fresh commiission -with increased powers was issued, followved in 1563 by moro severo penal lavws. ldr. C-te shlows, from a careful examination of contemporary documents, that during the period covered by his inquiries (1558-1564) tho penal laws were leniently administered, and that the total number of clergy deprived of parochial or University preferments for nonconformity in those six years cannot have much exceeded two hundred. The estimates of modern Anglican Church historians, ranging from 189 to 400, depend ultimately upon .9trype and Camden, both of whom, Ir. Gee shows, were dependent upon a list given by Nicolas Sanders, a deprived Oxford Professor, in his book, "De Visibili M:onarchia,"published at Louvain inlfl. This list, however, can be shown to be inaccurate, and the calculations made from it must be abandoned. Mir. Gee has done his work well and thoroughly, with illustrative documents in support of his main conclusions that enable the reader to judge of their soundness.

It consists chiefly of quotations from Ottley's " Life of Andrewes," Dean Church's " Mlasters in Theolo"y," and the memoir in the " Library of Anglo-?atholic Theology "; hut it is well put together, and gives the reader, wvithout much trouble to himself, a fair idea of Bishop A ndrewes's character, and of the relations between Church and State at the end of the 16th and beginning of the 17th centuries. Dr. Edwvin A. Abbott's researches into the accounts of the death and miracles of ST. Tno3xas OF CA rusu.uY (Black) were,he tolls usiincidentaI to the preparation of a critical commentary on the Four Gospels the object being " to consider other instances of documents relating the same fact in different language, as the Gospels relate in different language the acts and -words of Christ." Tho rdpepyovohas grown under his hands into two goodly volumes, containing, first, an exhaustive comparison of eleven Latin narratives of
m m(fiveby eye-witnesses and six by anonymous v Ers) ,witha poem inNormanFrench by one Gairnierin1l1;o,undtbeSaga.a laterproduction,anda comperiso,n of thewbhole wiith themodern acconnts of Stanley and Tennyson; secondly, an account of the miracles of St. Thomas as descrixed by Benedict and William of Canterbury, those common to botlh writers being arranged in parallel columns. From these investigations Dr. Abbott deduces canons of historical criticism which be considers applicable to the study of " synoptic " documents in general, and the Cospels in particular. The parallels which he points out between the Becket documents and the Gospels are in many respects striking; and with his general conclusions upon the prinuiples to be observed in ascertaining historical trath from -various and sometimes coilicting lines of evidence we may agree. But he hardly takes oufficient accountof the difference, as literature, betweenthe Gospelnarrativesandthe medievalmonkishchronicles that record the beliefs of a yet more credulous age. The -ccretions of legend orthefalsificationso7 error, though not excluded, are surely much less probable in the case of literary histories compiled (as the p reface to St. Luke's Gospel showfs) in a more or less historical spirit than in chronicles SUC11 as those which Dr. Abbott examines wvith such discriminating patience. With this reserve, ve accept his inquiries as having some bearing upon :New Testament criticism, and as in themselves a scholarlike attempt to sifIt -rains of vheat from a heap of chaff. But even with the qualification thLat St. Thomas's miracles were chiefly due to strong emotional excitement in persons affected by them, we shoulld hardly go as far as Dr. Abbott in accepting them as historical. In this, his book is a mi-xture of credulity and scepticism.

Containing, as the book does, brief essays on literary subjects, chosen by themselves, by such -writers as Mr. Goldwin Smith, Mr. Leslie Steplhen, M11r. B3irrell, MIr. Andrer' Lan- Mr. Austin Dobson, Mr. Herbert Panl, Tord Crewe, M1r. Edmund Gosse, `Vemon Lee," and "JohnOliverHobbes," it is natural that there should be much in it that is fresh, personal, and interesting. Sometimes we have a definite addition to knowledge, as where Lord Creve gives us a more eoact account than has ever been printed of the famous or nc.torious leaf of the album at the inn att Tlontanvert, whereon Sbelley, travelling in company with Mary Godlwin and Claire Clairmont, proclaims, in doubtful Greek, his atheism. The leaf itself came into Lord Houghton's possession, and is inserted, with all its very curious entries and erasures, in a copy of Shelley's " Revolt of Islam," in Lord Crewe's library. Mdore often the writers discuss questions in which they feel a special interest, or on which they possess special information. liaturally enough, M1r. Austin Dobson takes us througth a novel written almost a century aro hrb one E:. 13arrett, mentioned by hiiss Ansten, hut probably now unknown to everybody but the writer; Mr. Herbert Paul tries very successfullyto revive our admiration for Person, trae critic and true wit; and Mr. Leslie Stephen, triting on "perishable books," points out hows desirable it wvould be that nine out of ten books now produced should be printed on such paper as would automatically ensiire their rapid extinction.
The latest of Mr. Grant Allen's historical guides, which deals witlh VmuicE (Grant Richards), has the mnerits and the faults of the others. That is to say, its root-idea is good and original, wvhile the execution is unequal, being hi places excellent and in others leaving much to be desired. As we remarked in noticing the earlier volumes, it is a great thing for the ignorant but fairly intelligent visitor (male or female) to be takcen in hand on his arrival at a city rich in history, like Venice or Florence, by a guide for whom history is a living thing, and wvho instinctively views individual objects-a palace, a piazza, a church-in its relation to the life of the place as a whole. This Mir. Grant Allen does, and the general resut of his teaching must be to stimulate the. traveller who walks or floats through Venice ;ith this guide-book in his hand. For instance, none of the accepted guidebooks brings out wvith any clearness the relation of certain great churches in Venice, and of a whole class of pictures, to the plague epidemics vwhich often swept through the city ; MIr. Allen devotes a chapter to this subject, to the churches of the Salute, San Rlocco, San Giobbe, and San Sebastiano, and to tle numberless pictures of the two grent plague saints-St. Sebastian and St. Roch. In the Esme w.ay ho treats the Friars' churches together and explains many of the differences betwieen them, and muany of the features of the wsorks of art whichl they contain, by simple historical reasons. At the same time some of Mr. Allen's history, and a good deal of his art criticism, area little hasty; and vwe cannot understand v;hy he dissuades the traveller from visiting the Madonna del Orto, wrhich contains two of the most wonderful Tintorets in the world, and the 3Museo Correr, where there are various first-rate pictures and an extraordinary collection of 18th-century costumes.
M1r. W. J. Stillman's en-a ing account of his squirrels BrmY AND HA' fXS aiurray) has reached a second edition, and has an extra chapter added on the successors of these pretty little household pets. The bool;et, whic wil delight all lovers of animals, is sold for the benofit of the " Violet Home," founded by Miss Hyacinthe Cavendish B3entinch to assist poor children in need of surgical treatment. MIr. Stillman's intense sympathy with birds and beasts is shown also in the tw o fairy tales contained in L1m BsaruA (Richards). Prettily fanciful in substance and simply told, they should serve to keep many a nursery party interested at the twilight hour, when " Please tell me a story " is an urgent and not-to-be-slighted petition.
