We remarked, in reviewing the first volume of the new edition of Byron a month ago, that it is under the charge of two editors and is being brought out in two parallel series, Mr. Ernest Coleridge taking in hand the poetry and Mr. R. E. Prothero the prose. It is the first volume of the latter which now makes its appearance; the I.snr- AND JoUr-NALs, extending from 1798, when the lad was ten years old, down to 1811. It will be remembered that this is not tho first important new edition of Byron which has recently been projected and begun. 'More than a year ago another publisher, Mr. Heinemann, began to issue an edition, directed by Mr. W. E. Henley, and the first volume of this, which is all that has at present appeared, contained letters down to 1813, with a series of learned and elaborate biographical notes. Unfortunately this edition was not and cannot be complete. for it was not issued by arrangement with Mr. Murray, the successor of Byron's original publisher, who stil retains certain copyrights,and who,inaddition,possesses many unpublishedByron manuscripts. Nor had Lord Lovelace, Byron's grandson, been a consenting party to the Ifenley edition, so that nobody was surprised wheni, about the time of the publication of that volume, it was announced that the new unauthorized issue would be promptlv met by an autborized one, put out by the old house with all their available strength of new raterial. In reeard to the first volumae of the poems, we have 2ad, of course, no opportunity of comparing it with Mbr. Elenley's work, but it is different with the prose. The volume before as, in fact, comes in1tO direct competition wvith the volumo issued by Mr. HIeinemaun in 1897. The new editor expresses his regret that the work could not have been done by Mr. Henley, to whose abilities he pays a cordial tribute ; but as the fates have decided otherwise there was nothing left for him but to proceed. His first volume, down to August 22, 1811, " prints 168 letters, or an addition of 107 to Moore, 90 to Halleck, and SO to Mr. Henley." We have gone through the list, and find that these 80 consist mainly of family letters (to the poet's half-sister especially), to John Hanson, his lawyer, and other persons very close to him, while one long and interesting letter to Mr. Murray is given, though it was written ia 1820, and is, therefore, a little out of its place. It will remain to be seen wvhether the modern world. which has so ianch to read, will interest itself in these slight records of the boyhood and growth of a great man. Certainlv the editor is right in saying tba.t the letters " give the truest portrait of the man," and that " they possess at their best, in their ease, freshness, and racy vigour, a very high literary value." The first and third qualities will appear more fully in the later letters, as we see by comparing the ease and fluency of the 1820 letter (abourt the character of his deceased friend, C. S. Mlatthews) .with the stiffness of the early writings. It is scarcely necessary to say that the picture of Byron's home in his boyhood is not by any means attractive. His father, who died when the boy was three years old, -was
a gambler, a spendthrift, a profliate scamp ": his mother, though she bore her 'ard lot with fortitude, and w-as " in her own vay a devoted mother," was of an ungovernable temper and her son found her impossible. Such a home training was a fit preface to Byron's own matrimonial career: but to that, of course, we are not introduced in this first volume.

This narrative of Mr. Aubyn Trevor-lBattyes journey across Arctic Russia is ajaequel to his wellknown 'Icebound on Kolguev.' )V hen, on leaving Kolguev, Mr. Trevor-Battye was landed on the inhospitable shores of the Kolokolgova Gulf, he desired to make his way home as rapidly as possible. The autumn was just beginning, and at that particular season travelling in that region is almost entirely suspended for reasonsvwhich the author sets forth as follows:-
There are five seasons in the year in Northern Russia -our four, and a fifth, Rasputnya by name. Ilsaputnya means literaly *l the parting of the Wvays," ard is used for a period between autumn and winter. Travelling by one of the high northern trails is easy enough in summer when the ground is drv and firm, is delightful in winter when the sleighs glide over the snow. sad ,over the ice of lake or river; but in Rasputnya it is not easv, it is very difficult, and no one dreams of moving then. It is freezing one day and thawiag the -next, the ice-charged rivers are dangerous for boats, and all the land is morass and swamp. Daring the _whole of October the Government postal service is stopped, labour contracts are off, and the keepers of the stages are entirely freed from their usual obligation to supply the traveller with horses or slcigbs. This explains why. when an inqmry es to mv whereabouts was made from England, the inevitable answer -came that no news could arrive IItill the swamps were irozen up." Certainly no Russian could imagine any peraonrashenough to tr and travel then. But an Eugliishmn is proverbially obstinate; and meantime through these swamps I was pushing on inch by inch by vanous shifts and devices. It is of these that the story tils.
In other words, the interest of Mfr. Trevor*Battye's narrative rests, as he acknowledges him-elf, " on Pasputnya, and on Rasputnya alone." It rests, however, on a sufBciently finn foundation. It is not likely that the narrative of Mr. Trevor-Battye's experiences will tempt other travellers to follow in his tracks; a journey tduring the seasou of Rasputnya across the "; tundras " and through the forests of Northern Russia will never be undertaken by chcice, and can seldom be undertaken through necessity, as it was in Mr. Trevor-Battye's case-for he was pledged to his companion to be back in England lbvCristmas, and determined to fulfil his pledge, vihich he did. Such - journey may therefore be regarded as quite exceptional and almost unique, and on that account alone it is rell worthy of permanent record. Though Mfr. Trevor-Battye tells his story with a light heart and unflagging spirit, it is an unbrolken vecord of hardship, difficulty, exposure, privation, discomfort, and incessant peril, from the time he left the Kolokolgova Gulf until he finally reached A&rchangel-and even there, as the following story shows, his periis were not at an end:
My friend MIr. Wilten (the only other Englishman in Arehaagel), who had ebarge of a sw-mill on an island at some distance from the shore, had asked me to dine with him, saying that the ico was safe enough if I kept to a certain track, which any guida could, point out to me, or 1 could follow for myself, as it was marked by heaps of noaw. But that evening it began to snow agam, and the night was exceedingly dark. I took a droski down to the water's edge, but the man would come no further, as the ice would not bear a horse and sleigh. There was not a soul about, so I was obliged to make the crossing by myself. I could see the lights of Wilton's island tinkg far away, as I committed myself, not without some misgivings, to the chances of this passage. The ice was usually tirm enough, but sometimes it seemed to bend, and it creaked in an omious was, and when I was half-wary across I began to wishi 1 hd not started. It 'was so dark that I could not see the heaps of snow, only every now and then I stumbled against one. Very lowly I crept along, expecting every moment to be dropped into a water hole and delivered to the sturgeon of the Dvina. Meantime Wilton was uncorking iis liquors in his wa=m diningroom, blissfully umeonscious of his expected guest's position. Eventnualy, when I was about two-thirds ,over, I saw a light moving on the shore of the island, and hollosed out to ask if I was right. " No." c mme back L voice in Russian, " you are off the track altogether; mind, there's water there ! Now come straight to this light ! " Doing as I was bid, I arrived safely. But my cautious progress had turned a ten .gainutes' crosing into one of nearly half an hour.
This story is characteristic, for the chief dangers ,and difficulties encountered by Mr. Trevor-Battye 'were those involved in the frequent passage of ionly partidly frozen rivers, and he seems to have d many narrow escapes and to have extricated :himself from many an almost desperate situation by sheer pluck and resource. The narrative of this dreary journey is monotonous in the .sense that the same difficulties constantly recurred and were as constantly surmounted; 'but, though the story is simply and moderately told, it bears abundant testimony to the fortitude, endurance, and cheery stoicism of the tri-vellers who traversed these desolate and forbidding wastes, as well as to the gocd temper and goaul will of those who helped them on their way. 'The book is dedicated by special permission to the present Tsar, and concludes with a warm -expression of admiration for his character.

This book is in some respects disappointing.
lt is written by contribnTora of _practical exs.
perience as teachera or examiners, and, apperig as it does at a tine when secondary education is " in the air," it might be expected to throw light upon some, at least, of the problems connected vith a national system of secondary education, upon. which the country and Parliament must one day form an opinion. The essays are certainly well written, and the opinions expressed by the writers are eminently sensible. But it is a book for professional teachers rather than the general public. It is more concerned with technical details than with comprehensive principles-with the work of a sixth form, the arrangement of school lessons, the different systems of teaching appropriate today and boarding schools, the place of mathematics, science, or modem history in a school curriculum, the preparation for University scholarships or matriculation, and the likematters of great practical interest to those engaged in the work of education, but not equally interesting to others. Its field, too, is very much limited to the larger public schools in their relation to the Universities, and those who are familiar with public school and 'University work will, we suspect, find its conclusions somewhat obvious.
With this preliminary caution not to expect too much, we can recommend the book to those interested in practical education. The HigTh Master of Manchester Grammar School speaks with authority on the difliculties of day s^hool teaching; and, with regard to the superiority of the linguistic training in German as compared with English secondary schools, he points out, very truly, that the real difference lies in the conditions under which they work. There is in England " no leaving certificate, as in Germany, required by all good firms of their clerks; there is no compulsory military service of which such a certificate will lessen the length. Boys leave school when their parents think that it is time for them to be getting to work, and not because they have reached any definite stage in their education." Mr. Lowrv, an Eton master, writes on the " Tutorial System " atpublic schools ; and the Rev. H. M. Burge, in one of the best papers in thevolume, on "Some Problems connected with the teaching of Sixth Forms." Though only a college tutor at Oxford, Mr. Burge seems to have grasped somo of the principles that make a good headmaster. He demurs, wo think justly, to the modern notion that a headmaster should do little or no teaching, but devote himself to ' organization," thereby sacrificing what Arnold considered his golden opportumities,in which really great teachers have alwavs left their most permnanent mark.I Those who were pupils of Dean Bradley in the sixth form at Marlborough will bear us out. We are glad to see that Mr. Burge has also a good word for repetition and retranslation, now for the most part crowded out from an over-varied curriculum. The teaching of mathematics, science, modemu languages, and history receives appropriate and symnpathetic treatment from different essayists; and the London UYniversity matriculation examination and that for Oxford and Cambridge " Higher Certificates " are explained by the chairman of the Incorporated Association of Headmasters and one of the secretaries of the Universities' School Examination Board. Finally, another Eton master writes on " Public School Athletics," and even he is constrained to admit that something is wrong in the present state of things. Schoolmasters, in fact, have encou-aged athletic sports, partly as useful for disciplinary purposes, partly as an opportunity for friendly intercourse with their boys, till the cultus of athletics has outgrown control, and threatens to absorb not only the time, but all the thoughts and interests of boys, whose general conviction, we are told, is " that athletics are the one thing in the worldworth caring about." Those who still think that boys aro sent to school in order to learn may well ask in respect to this athletic craze, Quoncque tandem ?
The latest addition to the " Parnassus Library " of GreeklandLatintexts is AESSY LUvS (Macmillan), edited by Professor Lewris Campbell, who contributes an introduction, with a limited number of critical and explanatory notes. Like other volumes of this series, the book is tastefuUy bound, and would be an attractive addition to any library even were its contents of less.valne than tbey are. Professor Campbell gives us a judiciously selected text,vwith but few experiments at emendation, and his notes are scholarly and helpful. The Greek type employed-an imitation of the
uncial ' character of early IMSS.-is a little puzzling at first sight; but it is very neat, and may possibly be more serviceable for a critical edition of the text, in which MSS. must be considered and discussed.

Wo have met the name of Mr. H. C. Macdowall now and then in the magazines, but, so far as -we know, H1 my or Gursi A-,D OTrER PoRaTRArs (Macmillan) is his first book. It is a book of much interest and real promise. The author has chosen a period and a group of subjects which must always retain their attraction for the modern world, and which,strange to say, have beensearcely tonchedbyE;nglishwritersof any historical pretensions,those wars of religion to vhich Michelet devoted two brilliant volumesO years ago. Since that date the researches of French scholars bave thrown new light upon the events and the actors in them; and besides, there is always room for studies mainly biographical, however vivid may be the general pictures of a period that have been painted by historians. Mr. Maacdowall's two principal essays deal with Henry of Guise, the leader of the League, and with Agrippa d'Aubigne, poet, historian, soldier, and Protestant clhampion, the friend of Henri of Navarre and-such is the irony of history-the grandfather of MIme. de Maintenon. A shorter and slighter essay deals with Catherine of Navarre, the sister of Henri DT., one of the martyrs of the religious quarrels of the time. But this essay is of altogether minor interest, only valuable as showing how a high-placed personage may be systematically made miserable for reasons of State. The essay on Henry of Guise, which covers 170 pages, is an admirable piece of historical work, in which the author has made singularly clear to us tho complex system of political and religious intrigue which surrounded the last of the Valois kings and marked the rise of their great rivals, the house of Lorraine. Three principles were at work in France-the principle of uncompromising Catholicism, headed by the Guises; the principle of royalty, -which centred in Catherine de Medici and her three short-lived sons, each of whom in succession wore the crown; and the principle of religous liberty, represented by the Huguenot gentry of the south and west of France, and their two great chiefs the noble Coligny and the time-serving but immensely dexterous and, in the battlefield, heroic Henri of Navarre. The historian cannot, of course, treat these independently; a picture of the Duke of Guise must have the other two elements as a background. This is the case with the work of _r. Macdowall, and in fact the chief fault we have to find with his essay is that the personal impression which it leaves upon the reader's mind tends to be lost among the, multitEde of facts relating to the time in general. We should have liked, for example, a clearer explanation of Guise's popularity with the people of Paris, and it might have been well to attempt a precise summnary of his character, which at present we
are leit to gather from a mass of incidents.
Again, that mysterious personage Henry m., with his youth of immense promise, his period of demoralization after his residence in Poland, and his strange renewal of strength in his nnal strn,u,glewithGuise,reqmiresmoro explanationtbna the historianoffers. Stillboththisessayandthaton Agrippa d'Aubignd, especially perhaps theolatter, since the subject admits of more concentration,
are of real interest. Mr. Macdowall has steeped himself in the contemporary chronicles and
memoirs; he writes withont prejudices and leaves
hisreader to draw his own moral conclusions;
and, in a word, he shows himself qualified to do more thorough work in French history than many Englishmen have recently been able or willing to undertake.

There was no potentate in the early years of the 18th century who provided more material for
gossip and amused scandal-moncering in the Jourts of Europe than Frederi k William the
First of Prussia. " For," as Carlyle says, " he was lik-e no other King that then existed or had ever been discovered. . . . . Ho would have ibeen stmun e anvwhere - but amon=the daDner.
I Royal gentlemen of the 15th century, wh t wasto I be done with such an Orson of a King ?" Most of
the stories tord about him are concerned with his | passion for tall soldiers,and it is principally of such
storiesthat Mr. J. B. Hutchinsons RoiwNcx OF A REGIUMNT is made up. Stingy as be was, the King was ready to spend almost any sums to keep up the standard of h.eight in his regiment of Giant Grenadiers, and the surest road to his favour wias to supply him with recruits. " He who sends me tall soldiers can do with me whatever ho likes," he used to say; and, though they ridiculed him, his fellow-sovereigns were quick to take advantagre of his foible. He was far from relying entirely upon presents of men, however. Just3asthe Sultans of old had agents in all parts of their dominions to keep their harems supplied with beauties, so Frederick William had man-hunters all over Europe, usingr every artifice of cajolerv and force to gret their mnster huge soldiers. Tney stuck at nothing in pursUit of their prey. One party went so far as to enter a church during service and would have marched off with all the tallest worshipprs if a quick-witted priest ready with a suitable text-' Cast out the unclean thing from among you "-had not roused the congregation to effectual resistance. "MlIy brother the sergeant " (as George IL called him) was often involved by the acts of his emissaries in difficulties with his neighbours, but he cared little so long as he secured his prey. He had his pet giants well looked after in a tyrannical way,but they had a hard time of it, and his caprices (as, for instance, when he thought a regiment seemed out of sorts and ordered every man to bs bled on the spot !) led to many unsuccessful attempts at mutiny. Blat the King was not the man to let disaffection flourish unchecked, andhis " MeansofGraco,"-hisdaughter Wilhelmina's name for the regiment in reference to her father's pa:tiality towards those who increased its numbers-were only disbanded when they had played the part carefully designed for them by the King himself in his funeral ceremonies. Mr. Hutchinson has compiled an entertaining volume,though he does scant justice to Frederick William's character. He presents exclusively its eccentric and scandalous sides. Carlyle (whose name does not, by the -way, appear in Mr. Hutchinson's list of authorities) may have rated the King's volcanic talents too high, but it is a pity that we have not in the
'"omance of a Begiment'" some suggestion that he was more than a half-mad drill-sergeant vwith no interest beyond his barrack gates.
A GrzEA Cnucrw SocraTy (S.P.C.K.).
This is an interesting, and withal mcdest, chronicle of a great and successful work. Few, perhaps, of those wvho passthe Christian Knowedge Society's premises in Northumberlandavenxue, breaking the line of monster hotels with its windows full of attractive books and pictures and maps, and recognize it for a great centre of religious publications, have realized how truly and for ow aong the S.P.C.K. has acted up to its name and principles bv " promoting Christian knowledge." This record of its history, Two 1UiDrDED YEARS, 16'J-1898, will well repay perusal. It was founded at the end of the 17th century, at a time of considerable intellectual upheaval followina upon the Reformation. The inhilosophical speculations of Hobbes, subverting natural distinctions between right and wrong, had led to the assertion of a natural basis for ethics, which in its turn suggested to Lord Herbert of Cherbury, Tindal, and other Deists the possibility of a natural foundation for religion; and this again stimulated inquiry in the field of natural philosophy. Newton, Locke, Descartes had sounded various depths of knowledge. In religion, the period of the Commonwealth had produced a flood of antagonistic sects, in opposition to all of whicch Quakerism sought another standard of faith than the Bible in the supposed light of the Holy Spirit. Religion and morals were alike at a low ebb when, in the comparative lull of =uroncan politics that followed the Peace of Ryswick in 1.697, the S.P.C.K. was founded by a veer, two lawyerS, a country gentleman. and a clergyman (Dr. Bray). The first schemne, entitled " A General Plan of the Constitution of a Protestant Congregation or Society for Propagating Christian Knowledge," eontained also the germ of the " S.P.G.," which, in fact, was an offshoot of the S.P.C.K. The two chief branches of work contemplated were in the" plantations " or colonies abroad and in parishes at home-in each case by the provision of libraries of saitable literature. Great efforts, as we see from the minutes, were made in the society's early days to combat Quakerism and free thought. And besides its interest in the plantations, the societv appears to have devoted attention to sailors in the Fleet and P'rotestant communities on the Continent, and to the education of the poor in the principles of religion.
This last, indeed, seems to have been one of its original objects; and at a meeting in 1699 a circular letter was addressed to " clergy correspondents " in which, lon" before education was regarded as a matter of public importance, the lines of a system of national education on a religious basis were clearly laid down. Schools were founded by private subscriptions and the proceeds of sermons or lectures and were known as " Charity Schools," at which the cost of " cloathing a Poor Boy " is given in 1706 at 19s. 9Md., in 1710 at 15s. id.; and that of " cloathing a Poor Girl " at los. 7d. in 170l, and 12s. lOd. in 1710. The annual service of charity schools, at which about 4,500 children were gathered under the dome of St. Paul's, was held for nearly 100 years (1782-1877) and was, as the compilers of this record point out, one of the earliest ways in which the cathedral was utilized for a large congregation. It is curious now to read that, after the death of Queen Anne, the charity schools were distrusted for their supposed Jacobite tendencies, apparently with some reason, as the society's records mention the need of choosing " a master well affected to his Majestv and Government; " and in 1716 the Archbishop of Canterbury thought fit to advise that any catechisms " that meddle with political or party principles " should be thrown aside as 4" pernicious to the original Design of those pious Nurseries." Partisanship, however, was steadilv discouraged by the S. P. C. K., whose guidance of the beginnings of national education was both wise and cautious; and the records in this volume might be studied with advantage by the hotter heads on either side of modern educational controversies. At each subsequent stage in the development of education the society seems to have risen to the occasion and enlarged its operations. The foundation of the National Society in 18l relieved the S.P.C.B. from the direct care of schools, but it did groat service to the cause of religious education by timlely grants to Church schools in 1870; and it is largelv due to its munificence towards t;he Churchtrajnig colleges that those institutions still hold the field in the training of our elementary school teachers. Of the societv's work
asaseat ublishin house, in the dissemination ofcheap high-t dliterature at home and abroad, and in translation of the Bible and other Christian literature into many strange tongues, the volume gives ful details, and we commnend to all who are interested in such work this record of a great purpose nobly conceived and faithfully carried out. It must be a very pre-
judiced mind that vould see in the "promotion of Christian knowledge," according to the theory and practice of this society, anything but a benefit to mnkind.
SymrA AND EGYT (Methuen).
Professor Flinders Petrie's new book SymUA A-ND EGYPT FROM THE TimL EL A-sAa-rA LzrraRs (Methuen) will doubtless receive full notice from Egyptologists, for it is an important exposition of the results of one of the most memorable of the writer's discoveries. We, however, must be content with directing general attention to this marvellous record, which throws light upon a multitude of the intimate details of the pub li and private life of Egypt and Syria in the 14th century B.C.-that is to say, at a time not very distant from the
Eebrew invasion of Palestine. Mr. Potrie reminds his readers of the discovery of this mass of cuneiform correspondence at Tell El Amarna. A few years ago the natives, whl-e plundering about the ruins, and carrying off Akhenaten's bricks for their modern houses, lit upon this record chamber containing many hnndreds of tablets. Negleted by official experts, they were finally carried in sacks to Luxor for sale, but
"were largely ground to pieces on the way. What has been preserved therefore is but a wreck of what might have been had any ,nerson-eanal to tha occasion_mlaced his hand
upon them." What were saved were bought for the British and Berlin Museums and for various private collectors, and these have been lately edited by a German savant, Hugo Winckler. Mr. Petrie goes over the ground again and gives a suminary, and in many cases a transcript, of the letters, with ample geographical and cbronological appendices. The addition to our knowledge made by these letters is nothing short of amazing, even when it is compared with the m.nv other discoveries of a like nature which have been made in Egypt durinz the last sixteen years. We find in it an elaborate correspondenee between the Egyptian officers in and about Syria and the King: accounts of insurrections, invasions, andvarious other political events going on exactly as they went on 800 years later, in ersian times; accounts of tribute and of presents of jewelry, gold, and slaves; and, what perhaps is the most remarkable of all, an absolute identity of names in many cases between the Syria of 1370 B.c. and the Syria of whatwe commonly call historical times, and even of to-day. Beirut, for example, was even at that day a flourishing city; so, too, was Jerusalem; and we have constant references to the invasions of the Khatti or Hittites, and of the Amurri or Amorites. One very curious point is suggested, though perhaps not quite established, oy Ilr. Flinders Petrie. Every reader of the New Testament has been puzzled by the reference in the Epistle to the Hebrews to Melchisedec, King of Jerusalem, " without father, without mother, without genealogy." Mr. Petrie ingeniously suggests that this means that Melchisedee was an elective chief and not an hereditary Prince, and he confirms this by pointing out, from these letters, that " Abdkhiba of Jerusalem repeatedly used the formula ' neither my father nor my mother appointed me in this place, the strong arn of the King established me over my father's territory." We must leave it to soholars like Canon Driver to say whether Mr. Petrie's tempting hypothesis is tenable.

The work of cataloguing the inexhaustible treasures of the British Museum proceeds apace, and we have to welcome the first volume of an important new section of it-TnE CATALOGa: or D.uAwnws ByY urrisir AnsTsr, and of ArtistB of Foreign Origin wrorking in Great Briiain (published by the Trustees). This has been done with great care by Mr. Laurence Binyon-another instance, by the way, that a poet may be a very useful public official. From Air. Sidney Colvin's prefac we learn that the catalogue is to be completed in five or six volumes, all of reasonable size; out from the accident of the Museum's possessing a very large number of drawings by artists who come under the early letters of the alphabet, this volume onlv takes us down to the end of the letter "'C." Naturally, a collection like that of the Museum, which is enriched from time to time by miscellaneous bequests or by the chances of the auction room, cannot be formed with any very scientific rercrd to proportion, and the number of an artist's drawings hich it may contain is no guide to his artistic importance. Thus it happens that the list of works by William Alexander covers 12 pages, and that those by Samuel James Ainsley are almost as numerous; whereas there is only one drawing by the charming artist Samuel Austin,one bv Alfred Clint, two by J. J. Chalon, and five by Sir A. W. Callcott. William Alexander was the first Keeper of the Prints in the Museum (1808), which accounts for tho Museumn possessing the original drawings that be made as artist to Lord Macartney's Embassy to China. The very large collection of the topographical London drawings by J. W. Archer were purchased from the gentlemau vho had commissioned them, and although they may not be of much artistic importance, they are of great historical value. Again the immense collection of Geortre Cruikshank's sketches, the mere 'list of 'Viich covers some 80 pages, was bequeathed bv the artist's executors. Posterity might have been content vith a small selection from these, but, on the other hand, we could spare nothing from the late 31r. John Henderson's splendid bequest of drawings by David Cox, which includes a number of the most beautiful of that great artist's works. Among recent artists who, without claiming a place in the first rank-, yet eminently deserve to be represented in the national collection, are such men as Randolph Caldecott and Edmund Calvert: in their works the MIuseum is very rich. Considerable historical interest, again, attaches to the large collection of drawings by MIary Beale, the pupil or imitator of Lely; by her and bv her son Oharles theMuseum possesses nearly 200 sketches, of which many are recognizable as contemporary portraits. Another -roup whichthrows light upon the history of art in lingland is the lar-e collection of the drawings, mostly portraits,%by Edward and Robert Byng, assistants of Sir Godfrev Kr,eller, " for whom they painted drapery, and rhose unfinished pictures they completed at his death." They are instances of that very common phenomenon in art history, the disappearance of a pupil's namne behind that of his master; undoubtedly one or other of them really painted many of the emisting works that we attribute to Kneller. On points of this kind Mr. Binvon's catalogue throws great light. and he therefore deserves the cordial thank ef all students of the English School.

Mr. Charles F. Lummis is a frequent contributer to American magazines of papers dealing with the life and character of the Spanish and other Old World races of the North American Continent. In " The Land of Poco Tiempo," which we noticed some few years ago,he dealt with iNew Mexico and its strange peoplie mainly from a descriptive and picturesque point of view. In his worlk on MhIco OF To-DAY (Harper and Brothers)-largely founded on papers which have appeared in Harper's Ma.zinc-his object is more directly historical and political. He describes " The Awakening of a Nation " with great vigour, but in a rather sophisticated style. The work is, he acknowledges, a less " definitive picture of Mexico to-day "than ho had at one time desired to make it. But leisure and opportunity have failed him, and these pages are, in consequence, " submitted, not as a description of hIexico, but as a finger-board along the path to comprehension. If hurried, they are not hasty; if generic, they do not lack the ancestryof detail; if friendly, it is not by ignorance ; and if they may help one, American to more neighbourly feeling for a nation we have every reason not to despise and not to dislike, my recompense will be ample for all the work [ would like to have done." The extract may serve to give readers a foretaste of Mr. Luiamir's very peculiar and not very attractive style. We should better have appreciated his book if he could write plainly, simply, and straightforwardly. But in spite of a mannerism which often irritates and rarely charms 31r. Lummis contrives to draw a picture of Mexico which is full of interest and actuality. It contains a vivid portrait of Porfirio Diaz, the President, who has wrought such wonders in the regeneration of Mexico, and a stirring sketch of the strange adventurous career of one whom ho sems to regard as the Bismarck of the New World. Certainly the contrast which Mr. Lummis draws between the Mexico in which Juarez died andc the Mexico of to-
day is a very emphatic testimony to the patriotism and statesmanship of Porfirio Diaz.

(Hodder and Stoughton), is a brief biography of a genial and active worker in many good causes, whose kindly deeds and gracious qualities were well known, not only in her native place and among her own people, but in many parts of the country. The doubt was natural, but the reticence and simplicity of Miss Orme's method may well have removed it. She draws an engaging, but not too intisate, picture of a sterling character and of a well-spent life, vrorthy alike inits domestic felicity and in its public activity to serve as an example to others.

Lrrwsirv STxTssnur AnD Ora=s, by :Norman Hapgood (Dnckworth) is a group of essays by a Europeanized American whc has the cleverness of his race, the tricks of his culture, and the self-assertion of his year He patronizes and criticizes from the same lofty standpoint Lord Rosebery, Mr. lMorley, and Mr. Balfour, finding that the first " has the virtues of the cultivated few and lacks the abilities that alone can reach the many," that the "whole spirit " of the second " seems thin and quarrelsome," and that the style of the third is " awkward, jerky, inaccurate, and inelegant." Tan Fimst PEmosorHn:ss OF Gny cm (Regan Paul and Co.) is an edition and translation of the fragments of pre-Socratic philosophy (Thales, Anandmenes, 1arerlitus, Zeno, Pythagoras, Empedocles, and others) preserved in quotations or allusions by later writers. These early thinkers held an important place in the history of Greek thought, and much has been written about their systems; but the original material for their study is after all but scanty, consisting of fragments preserved by later writers, such as Aristotle, Theophrasus, Plutarch, the Stoics, aud the neo-Platonic philosophers There is also the evidence of the Greek " doxographists," or students of early thought, who describedin their own language the opinions of earlier writers ; butthis is obvioisly of less valuce tan even such fragments of their actual writings as are here collected. Mr. A. Fairbanks, the edtor and translator, who we observe dates from Yale University, seems to have done his work well, and his book should prove useful for students of Greek philosophy.
No sportsman's library shoula be without some specimens at any rate of the work of Charles .James Apperley, who as " lhimrod " introduced a new style into sporting literature. Threequarters of a century ago Apperley, a country gentleman who found that his devotion to hunting was cost;ing him more than he could afford. hit upon the idea of making some money by a book on his favourite sport. A friend advised him to write articles instead, and the Mag-azine he vwrte for doubled its circulation in twvo years.
N imrod "quickly becameknownandappreciated "in every quarter of the globe," to quote a contemporary publisher's advertisement; and his work was eagerly sought for. He was even asked to contribute to the grave Quartcrlyt Reviewr, from which are taken the three papers on THE CHASP, THE RoAD, AND THLn Tua. (Arnold), now reprinted with a pleasant introduction by Sir Herbert Yaxwell. The new edition has been well cared for by printer and binder, and, with the original illustrations by AJken as well as a few new ones. it mnakes a volume seemly to loolk upon and full of entertainmnent within.

VERLSE NEW AND OLD.
Besides the volume wilich we have already reviewed, some other poetical productions of the wveek claim notice, though mest of these are reprints. Mrs. Tynan Hinkson, already favourably'known to readers of poetry, has produced a little volume which she calls MIRACLE PLAYS
Oun LOnD'S CO?NG AND CHIDHOOD (John Lane) ; a group of versions of the early chapters of the Gospel, with a number of legendary additions, told in verse of an almosttoo conscious simplicity. The story of the Flight into Egypt, and of the healing of the leprous babe who afterwards grows into the penitent thief, is told with considerable charm. Mir. Patten Wilson's illustrations are prettily dosigned, bat might have been better drawn.- SON1NnTS AND SONGS, by May Bateman (Elkin Mathews), appear to have been written more or less under the inspiration of the " Sonnets from the Portuguese." It is refreshing to find in these days verse so passionate and at the same toime so little physiological.-TIIn SEA-KING'S DAUGE}ITER (G. Napier and Co., t3irmingham) claims attention as much for the outward form as for the matter. It is described on the title-page (which, by the way, comes at the end like a colo-
phon) as " by Amay Mark, deeorated by designs byBernard Sleigh, engraved by the designer and by L. A. Talbot ; printed at the press of the Bir-
idgham Guild of Elandicraft "; a sufficient indication that it is as much a work of ornament as a work of poetry. Tho decorations and the printing are certainly interesting, and the verse, when one contrives to decipher it, is rather pretty aud inelodious. It is not likely, however, to mako the reader forget "the Forsaken Merman."DRIFT, bv Beocles Wilson (Gay and Bird) appears to be the work of a Canadian autborof unimpeachable Datriotism,. proud of "the 'Motherland ",
and of the noble heritag. of Canada. The verso is moderately good.-Among the reprints we have to notice the first two volumes of the " People's Edition " of Tennyson (Macmillan), apparently issued in emulation of the " Temple Shakespeare. " These tiny quartos, issued at one shilling eauh in decorated cloth bindinig, ought to be extremely popular. The first of them, which is entitled " Juvenilia," contains a good many sonnets and songs which the author at one time suppressed, though, of course, they have long ago been rediscovered and several times reprinted.-A much more ambitious reprint is that of Shakespeare's nuStMirtE NIGHT's DanAn, with illustrations by Robert AnniAg Bell, and an introduction, in the form of a letter to a child, by Israel Gollanez (J. M. Dent and Co.). Mr. Anning Bell is a born designer, and in this book whether he draws the fairies, or Bottom and his company, or the decorated borders for his illustrations, the result is equally charming. Tho last few years have seen very many productions of the kind, but none more successful.-A reprint that has a real bibliographical as well as poetical interest is that which Mfr. A ndrew Lang has made of a curious poem called the DEATH-eAKE, written by Thomas T. Stoddart in the year 1830 (John Lane). The title page," The Death-Wake or Lunacy; a Necromaunt in Three Chimeras," would have delighted the new sect of the Romanticists in France, but in sober England and in soberer Scotland it must have caused, if anything, a throb of amazed horror rather than of pleasure. Mr. Lang's short introduction tells all that seems to be known of the author of this strange poem, who, after plunging at 20 years of age into the deepest waters of romanficism, became for the rest of his life an ordinary citizen and an enthusiastic a-ngler, only venturing again into verse as a writer of occasional anglng songs. The story of the Death-Wake is that of a mad monk, Julio, who loves a dead nun Agathe: a story, as nfr. Lang remarks, which won for the author the praise of7EdgarPoe, and which, to a certain extent, anticipates Theophile Gauthier and Thomas Beddoes. More important than the story is the execution; for Stoddart writes the tensyllabled couplet with extraordinary melodiousness and with a very individual note, " no more the rhymed heroic verse of ' Endymion ' than it is that of Mr. Pope or of Mr. William Morris." To our ear, indeed, it is a good deal like the verse of " Endvmion, " and it contains many an image, ,many a line, and many a cadence that Keats would net have disowned. Collectors of literary curiosities will be grateful to 3fr. Lang for his gift of a book which was well worth reprinting.-A small volume of Thoreau's PoEms orS NATcas, selected and edited by H. S. Salt and F. 13. Sauborn (John Lane), is also welcome,though the poetry of the New England transcendentalist and recluse will never rank so high as the prose records of his impressions of external nature. Thoreau was half a poeb, but only half; he had the feeling, the thought, in a high degree,ibut only a small measure of the gift of metrical expression. Still, out of all he wrote in verse there is enough good lyrical and meditative poetry to fill a small volume, so that the editor's task has not been in rain.-Dr. Islay Muirhead's translations fromn Lucretius, which he publishes under tho title of* Erioun-nAN SCIzNCn: AND POETRY, appear in a revised edition (John Bale and Sons). The introductory essay seems to us better than the translations, which, tlhough flowing and fairly correct, are somewhat long and want vividness.

Not nmany of our young poets belong of set purpose to that school which,under many names, has been for some years past enjoying a kind of success of curiosity in Paris-the suhool which dlepends primarily for its effect upon neologism and contortion of phrase. Ial. Verlaine and ,Iallarmd, to name two poets who have doubtless been long since outstripped by many disciples, would seem to consider that simplicity and poetry are incompatible, and that a verse or a poem is valuable in proportion to the amount of meaning that can be packed into it, provide(d al ways that to unfold the meaning demands a tremendous effort. We have hagd the same thing in Eingland in the days of Donne and Cowley, and it had a great nomentary success, bat not even our present-day curiosity about the past has ever been able to bring back Donne and Cowley into fame. lt is not,then,likely that any real success will attend the efforts of Mc. Francis Thompson, a writer of a very real talent of a certain kind, to convert the lovers of English poetry to a love of strange involutions of words, similes that have a conccit for their foundation, and verbal forms that ask to be recommended by their novelty. What shall we say, for example, when the poet shows us the air full of the misty forms of the Hours, and tells us how they-
Curd to the tincture which the opal bath,
Like rainbows thawing in a moonbeam bath ?
In Donne or (Urashaw we might find such an image highly characteristic, but we should hardly admire it and we should certainly not think it worth transplanting. Again, these Hours are prodigiously varied in their movements-
Some with languors of waved arms, Fluctuous oared their fiexile sway Some were borne half resupine On the aerial byalinec
and, when a pretty child appeared against the sunset, immediately the sun
Sublimed the illuminous and volute redundance Of locks that floated round her face.
On every page we have such terms as " terrene," " gracile," " constellate," " deliquious," " agarics," and once the poet is positively not afraid to say that the night fires
Make every wave upon the harbour bars
A beaten yoll: of stara.
nind yet there can be no doubt that Mr. Francis Thompson is a poet, though not quite the poet which a singularly uncritical series of " Press opinions upon his last book would have us believe. These SIsTERsSo Gs,writtenin praise of two little sisters,contain a number of lovely and most musical lines, and some passages-such as the seventh section of the first poem-wvhich Spenser would not have disowned. No one, again, could acetse Mr. Thompson of wantillg that first and best eo,uipment of the poet,the power andthe habit of thought ; but if his thought is clear to himself it must be owned that he often fails to make it clear to his reader;

ments of Roman oratory.1" Dr. Peterson prefixes an adequate introduction, in which he explains and discusses the whole grimy story of how '& a mother appeared at the bar of a Court of justice to prosecute the son of har bosom on a charge of having first by foul means procured the ruin and convicbion of her guiltless husband, and afterwards taking his life by poison. BOOKS OF THE WEEK.
A HISTOIty oF ENGLISH POETRY (MaCmillan).
Xr. Courthope has undertaken a task of monuMental proportions-a task whiel Pope conceived, from which Gray, who ht one time thought of undertaking it, was deterred by its magnitude, and tj' the fact that Warton was employed on a similar undertaking, and of which Warton himself only executed a classic fragment. Mfr. Courthope's high literary relputation, the nature of his previous studies, and the masterly execution of this the first portion of his task all attest his rare qualifications for the great work he has undertaken. The present volume deals with "1 The Middle Ages * Influence of the toman Empire-The Encyelopadic Education of the Church-The Feudal System." We are promised a second volume in the course of next year,which will deal with the poetry of the sixteenth century, showing the influence of the Court and the Universities on the art. Two further volumes will be devoted to the poetryof the seventeenth century, one of which will trace the culmination and decline of the poetical drama under the Stuarts, the other the decay of the medieval tradition and the growth of the classical influence in English verse composition from the reign of James I. up to 1688. A final volume or volumes will show the development of English poetry between that date and the Reform Bill of 1832. Mlr. Coutthope's method, as expounded in his Preface and in his Introductory chapters, and as eXhibited in the general execution of his work, appears to us to be singularly well conceived. " By English poetry," ho says in his opening paragraph, " I mean metrical compositions, written in our language from the period at which it becomes fairly inte.ligible to readers of the present day. By the Art of Elnglish Poetry I mean all characteristic writing of a metrical kind that can be classified under any of the recognized forms of compositionepic, dramatic, lyrical, or didactic. Aad by the History of the Art of English Poetry I maean, not simply an appreciation of the raotives by which each individual poet seems to have been consciously inspired, but also an inquiry into more general causes which have unconsciously directed imagination in this country into the various channels of metrical composition." This prognant conception of the meaning and scope of his work gives unity and sustained interest to Mr. Courthope's treatment of his subject. It enables him to discern and appreciato the value of those less interesting of our earlier writers whom Taine summarily dismissed as " those good people who speak without having anything to say. You may find them," adds Taine, " in Warton." So yo a may, but Wartoti, says Mr. Courthope, by simply collecting archaic materials without attempting to group and classify them, created a kind of distaste for the historic study of our early literature. Mr. Courthope himself sets about his task in a spirit at once more catholic and more historical. Acknowledging a breach of continuity, which some critics have failed to recognize, between the poetry produced in England before the Norman Conquest and the poetry of Chaucer, he nevertheless declines to recognize the latter as the unadulterated and unaftiliated product of a vague influence called the " Renaissance."
From Chaucer downwards we may distinctly observe in English poetry the confluence of three great streams of thought, whieh blend in a single channel without any of them ever quite losing its separate life and identity. Of these the farst,and perhap the most powerful,is the genius of Race, th stream of Igglo-Saxon language, character, and cn=tt, modified by the influence of Scandinavian imagination, as awell as by all the impulses and ideas derived from the Latin nations through the Norman Conquest. The second is the tradition of education systematized by the Latin Church; many traces of which stiU survive in the courses of our Universities and public schools. 'The third is the tradition of GrwcoRomzan culture, carried through the barbarous ages in ainy slender ducts and channels, vvhich, mingling the spirit of the ancient world with the infant civilization f Europe,i prepared the way for the great revival of aFtt and letters con monly known as the Renaissance.
This thesis is worked out at length in the present volumne with rare insight and scholarly erudition, and in particular the tracing out of the slender but never-exhausted stream of (Ordeco-Roman cilture through the ages com'ionly called dark is a masterly piece of work, ias original as it iB sound and imstructive.

Title: LATIN POETRY (Macmillan)
Full_text:
LATn PoETry (Ma=lln).
The character and purpose of these brilliant Suggestive Lectures, delivered on the Percy Turnbull Memorial Foundation in the Johns Bopkins University of Baltimore, by the Regius Professor of Greek in the University of Dublin, may best be indicated in the Professor's own words, taken from the opening paragraphs of his introductory lecture as originally delivered:-
In the first of the lectures I take a very rapid sarvey of Latin poetry as a whole, never pausing to consider at all closely any particuilar poet, except in the case of one or two literary personages whose minuence on the course of Latin poetry seems to have been generally underrated, and to whom I shall not have an opportunity to recur in subsequent lectures. . . . The next lecture, too, dealing with the early Latin poetry, must still be of a somewlhat general cast. After that we shall be able to confine our attention mainly to individual ts, or to corn, or contrasted pairs of
Doe pai~~~oery ofth poets, until the consideration of the Poetry of the
Decline again makes it necessary to abandon the microscope for the field-glass, and to accommodate our vision to a wider prospect. . . I must aim at putting before you what I think most interesting in counoxion with Latin poetry, sometimes describing how certain masterpieces (fortof course, we shall be brought to consider some masterpieces) have affected myself. * . . I shall not attemp to give a life of each poet who may be under consider tion, except iu so far as the incidents of his career have lefi a distict impress on his work. . . . I shall have to *sk not what were the works of each poet, but what was his work ; how he looked out on the world, and what was the world on which he looked ; whether he had a messa to society, and how far lte succeeded in delivering it.
I shl be by no means an unvarying eulogist of Latin poetry. Indeed, in the case of some of the poets Ifear I shall run the risk of being caUed a harsh and unsympathetic critic. I shall have to put before yon many things which have often been said before. I have2 however, endeavonred as much as possible to avoid tracks that are too well beaten, and to dwell in preference on points of vies which may seem to have been comparatively neglected.
To attempt, it may be said, to say anything at the atme time true and new on such a thome as Virgil or Horace really seems out of the question. But it is a characteristic of philological and historical inquiry that the same subject admits of being viewed from very diverse points, and this is peculiarly true in dealing with poetry. Each actor, each musician, has a different way of rendering Shakespearo or Beethoven, and there is no final interpretation of the work of a great artist. Literature can do no more than give as the opinions and sentiments of particular persons , at particular times. To estimate-even to understand-these opinions aud sentiments we must know something of the times and circumstances in which they were expressed. It will be requisite, therefore, now and then, to invade the domain of history and bio raphy, and thus diversify our more purely literary studies.
This attractive programme is not less attractively carried ouat and no student of Latin literature wil fail to recognize the ripe scholarship, the sound critical faculty, the skilful literary presentation, and the suggestive originali;y of view.* so frequently displayed by Professor Tyrrell. We confess to a little surprise thlat the Professor should have thought it necessary to give English renderings-sometimes his own, sometimes those of other translators-of the illustrative passages quoted by him. This is rather a slur upon the scholarship of his audience and must surely be superfluous in any case; because a lecture on Latm poetry delivered to an audience unabquainted with Latin can hardly be rendered much more attractive or even more intelligible to such an audience by a translation of such passages as the lecturer finds occasion to quote ; the point of view and the general treatnentof the subject mnustremain asunntelligibleas before. And this must especially bethe case with a writer who,like Professor Tyrrell,is soimbuedwith the spirit of Latin literature that he could not if he would treat it ab extra, and must necessarily appeal to corresponding sympathies in his audience. We cannot here follow Professor Tyrrell's survey of Latin poetry in detail, but we may direct special attention to his strikin& appreciation of early Latin poetry, to his loity estimate of Catullus, to his courageous apology for the poetry of Cicero, and to his ingenious presentation of the thesis that Horace was neither sincere nor original as a poet, but that, like all the poets of his time, he "' conceived it to be the function of his art either to reproduce in Latin the masterpieces of Greek literature or to adapt to the taste of his own age the old poets of his own land." Thus we are told that "the bore whom Horace met on the Sacred Way .
had no objective existence for Horace at all, but was only aLuoi1ian bore ich1auff;" that "it seems highly probable that the celebrated account of the journey to Brundusium-though no doubt the journey was actually made by FHorace in the company of MBecenas-is not a genuine record of adventures which they actually met, but rather a polished version of a piece in which Lucilius gave a versHfied account of a journey from Rome to Capua and thence to the itraits of Messina," and so forth. It would be eqjuaily pleasant to follow Professor Tyrrell in his admirable appreciations of Lucretius, Virgil, and Juvenal, not to mention other poets only less supreme than these ; but we must say that he seems to usto be a little hard on Persius. While doing full justice to the fine ethical fervour of Persius he is irritated, as all critics must be, to some extent, by the contortions and eccentricities of his style. The Professor says of him that he II seems to have laboured under a failing rife in our own literature at present, and to have been physically incapable of saying a plain thing in a plain way."i That is true, and Persius is for that reason often the most exasperating of Latin writers. But we can, and ought to forgive much to the writer of the'line
Virtutem videant, intabescantqcle reliEta,
and perhaps Professor Tyrrell hardly forgives enouzh.

I EAms.lS LyRic.*
The selection of these English lyrics is the justification of (r. Watson's preface, whichmight otherwise lay itself open to the charge of canrying eulogy to excess. Mr. Watson has, in our opinion, vindicated the soundness of his judgment and his literary discrimination by the specimens he has selected. In one way we are inclined to go farther than he does, for we prefer Mr. Austin's simpler vein to his more amibitious efforts. At homne or on foreign soil, on the earth, in the heavens, or in intermediate spheres he is always a poet; but he never sings so sweetly or so melodiously as in England. Mr. Austin, we are told with truth, ignores Nature-that is to say, the idol or fetish of formal and metaphysical poets. On the other hand, he is in the closest communion with the buoyant nature that is weeping or smiling in our surroundings through the changing seasons. " That, says Mr. Watson, "is why I consider him in the truest and best sense a Nature-poet." In fact, Mr. Austin has been setting an example, with the just balance of sense and sound which " future generations will loos for in their poems." We can only hope that the example will be generally imitated, and that future generations will not be disappointed. For all through these lyrics we have a harmonious blending of pleasing melancholy with genial mirth, and they are rich in those shades of realistic description which remind us of " The Queen of the Mflay" and "ILocksley Hall."
Take the brightness of "I A Birthday," which appropriately opens the volume. The poet revels in the sights and sounds of the present,regardless cr unconscious of what the future may have in store
The earliest sound that greeted me
aVas the ousel's ringing tone
The earliest sight, lambs frisking free
Bound barked oaks newly thrown.
Then comes in "' Primroses " and " A Defence of English Spring," a fre7sh breath of the English spring-time with which he preladed his Italian " Human Tragedy." Even with poetical licence it is no easy task to defend satisfactorily MEarch winds and cold April showers. At least, Mr. Austin makes the best of things, and almost persuades us that we ought to enjoy the weather of both months. There is no denying the force or the charm of his painting when he invokes the memory to the aid of his muse -
Nowfrowns the sky, the air bites blealk, -
The young boughs rock, the old boughs creak, And fast before the following gale
Come slanting drops, then slashing hail.
WVe heartily agree with him when he revels in the delights of the field flowers and the fragrant bloom in the old-fashioned gardens -
The blue bells with the grasses mingle But soon their azure will be scrolled Upon the primrose cloth of gold. Yes, there are early lady-smocks
The children crumple in their frocks.

Title: Walter Savage Landor.*
Full_text:
VIAMMJ MA-laB LA2WM0R.
In these two charming volumes, the one containing a life of Landor and the other selection3 from his prose and verse, Mr. Colvin has, it seems to us, done a service to the cause of what is best and highest in literaturo, such as a modern critic has not often the happy chance of accomplishing. Recent years, indeed, hnve been frtuitful in admirable judgments on poets and poetry, delivered often by brother craftsmuen, wel qualified both by native gifts and acqtured ski,]l to pronounce on poetical work. But the umuerous volumes of selections or of biography, in which we have all taken pleasure, have, with a few exceptions, handled themes long sinca familiar to popular interest and admiration. The interest of each book has depended not so much upon the subject matter, which was well known and accessible in manv other shapes, but upon the contact between it and the critical mind at work upon it. We have had Mr. S.vinburne on many poets, old and new ; Mr. Matthew Arnold on Byron and Wordsworth; 3Mr. Symonds on Shelley. As far as the poets themselves went, the world would probably have gone on reading them whether the critics had delivered themselves or not. The attraction of criticism and selections has lain first and foremost in the relations between judged and judge,in the effect produced by the well-known and often-discussed work of another generation upon the finest minds of our own. To Mr. Colvin's volumes, however, belongs the charm not only of fine literary relation, the true charm of criticism, but of a auasi novelty of aubject besides. Reverend and faudiliar as tne name of Walter Savage Landor has been all through to an dlite literary few, it is a mere commonplace to say that to the general reading public he has always been and still is practically unknown. In the first place, his works, either buried in a number of rare volumes, or gathered into a large and bulky collection, have been difficult of access; in the second, his inequalities, his obscurities, his moer length, to name nothing else, have stood persistently in the way of popularity. Even on his own generation, occupied with many of the same thoughts and ideas which moved him, he had little effect,and howmuch farther off from him stands the world of to-dlay than the worldof Shalleyand Keats. Lander, who was well aware of his ineffestiveness as far as his contemporaries were concerned, had, in revenge for it, a boundless confidence in the future. "Ishaldinelate, hesaid,superbly, "butthe dining room will be well lighted, the guests few and select." Or, again, " The worms must have eaten us before we rightly kinow what we are. It is only when we are skeletons that we are boxed and ticketed and prized and shown. Be it so; I sha1lnot be tired of waiting." There are some who, like Mr. Leslie Stephen, doubt whether this trust of Landor's was really well-founded. And, indeed, had his work been left in the shape in which it was originally put forth, it would probably havs fallen more and more out ot reading so slender is the connecting link between farge portions of it and th edominant sympathies of to-day. From such a fate, howvever, it has been in our opinion, saved by Air. Caolvin's skilf
and adequate selections. His little volume, containing as it does all that is most perfect in LJander's prose or verse, can hardly fail to spread the knowledge of this great, though perverse, artist far bayond the limits it has hitherto reached. M1r. Colvin has, as it were, recovered and caged for us one of the austorest and most remote, but at the same time; within his own range, one of the most exquisite of singers. Brought so close to our eyes and ears as he now is, it will be hard indeed if the world does not listen to him and delight in him more than it has listened vet.
MIr. Colvin's biography of Landor is, of course, largely based upon the Life by Forster, but tho later writer has been fortunate in havina been allowed access to some valuable unpublishea materials,mostly iu the possession of Mr. Browning and Mr. Augustus Hare, and has, besides, had the help of whatever monographs on or reminiscences of Landor have appeared since Forster's day. To the biographical use of them he has brought a much more highly trained literary faculty than Landor's first biographer, with al his fidelty and affection, could dispose of, and the result is that we have not only a lively and interestingsketch of Lanior's life, but connected with it and surrounding it an excellent series of critical judgments upon Landor's works, in which all that the impartial friend can have to to say of it has been probably finally stunmed up. There aro many things, indeed, that TIr. Leslie Stephen says, in his remarks on Landor contained in the "Hours in a Library," which Mr. Colvin does not say; but then Mr. Stephen writes, not as a friend, but as one who has been too much irritated by Landor's eccentricities to appreciate his qualities as keenly as he feels his defects. This is not the spirit which any one can fairly expect from a biographer, nor would he be properlyfittedfor his task if be had it. At the same time Mfr. Colvin is very far from blinking Landor's real faults, moral or literary. Both in the biography and in the preface to the
' Selections " he carefully defines what be believes to be his chief defects as a writer-his lack of argumentative power and of the sense of sequence, and the absence in him of true literary tact, so far at anyrate as his relations to his reader are concerned; while iu the IAfe he brigs into clear view the wild,ungovernable temper which left its mark upon every stage of Landor's careerandwas always hurryiAg him from one scrape into anothar. The crises in his life were,in fact,all so many quarrels. He left Rugby because of an act of insubordination for which he entirely declined to offer the smallest amends; he was sent down from college because of some mad attack upon a fellow undergraduate's rooms for which he would make no apology; a quarrel with his fatber sent him to live by himself in London, Wales, and elsewhere; and when he married he quarrelled, not indeed altogether without reason, with his wife, at first temporarily, and then after nearly 80 years of married life hopelessly. The breach cost him his chilEren, whom he loved dearly, and his Italian home, but be was incorrigible by experionce. A worse quarrel than any, and attended by the most miserable consequences, drove him out of England again at the age of 83, and beforo he died he had even contrived to fall foul for a time
or J31x. Iforster, the most untiring and the most devoted of friends. NIever were quarrels worse managed or less profitable to the man who made them. In defiance of Polonius, Landor would rush into a fray without a thought of consequences, but being iu it he bore it so that his opponent hal far more reason to laugh at him than to beware of him. After a wrangle with a country attorney, he would SUppOS3 that everything had been gained when he had belaboured his enemy in some brilliant Latin verses; and when he had thrashed another brother of the law for insulting him, the only course his practical wisdom suggested to him was to escape the trial, a line of action involving a flight abroad and the consequent handing over to trustees of his Welsh property, Llanthony Abbey. Yet, in spite of all these strange ungovernable outbursts, Landor's most noticeable qualities. perhaps, through life, paradoxical as it may sound, were courtesy, sympathy, and generosity. His rage worked itself off in fits of laughter, scarcely less formidable to the byLstander; he could always forget his grievance in his beloved Latin verses; dogs, children, and young girls could win from him almost any service and to those few friends whom he loved best, and with whom he had no opportunity of quarrelling, he was one of the most loveable and noble-hearted of men. Throughout life he was an ardent politician; but in spite of muchthat isshrewd and weighty in his various political writings, his politics really were little less wild than his temper. The t,vo ends of his political creed were perpetually tugging him different ways. On the one hand he hated kings and priests with a fierceness which is by no means without its touch of comedy for the bystanders. As a young man it was impossible for him to enter the Army, for no regiment would admit such a republican firebrand as he was generally believed to be. In his earliest poem, " Gebir " (1798), the hero is described as meeting George III. in the nether regions, " a wretch with eyebrows white and slanting brow," and the triumphs of the French Republic over empires and thrones are revealed to a supposed ancestor of the French nation, as fraught with " glory that shall strike the crystal stars." As life went on his Jacobin fervour never deserted him, as it deserted Wordsworth' and Southey. Re grew, indeed, to
