hate the Irench as the betrayers of iSberty ; but for the cause of peoples versus kings his enthusiasm never wavered,and in his old age we find him witing passionately to Emerson to defend tyrannicide, or hanging rapturously on the news of Garibaldi's successes. Never was he more sincere and never was he more eloquent than wheu he was glorifying Liberty as he understood it. Hle makes Scipio say of the last desperate defence of Carthage *
"$ Calacnity moves mc; heroism moves me more.
that Asdru al should have found equals, his wife none, my mind, my very limbs are unsteady with admiration. 0 Liberty ! what art thou to the valiant and brave when thou art thus to the weak and timid ! dearer than life, stronger than death, higher than purest love. Never w ill I call upon thee where thy name can be prefaned and never shall my soul acknowvledge a more exsAted power than thee."
These are fine words, and Laudorspoke them from his heart. iBut democrat as he was towards kings or cardinals, for the practical machinery of democratic governments he hai scarcely any sympathy at all. He had a truly Carlylese belief ingreat men as against " the vulgar," cared nothingfor the franchise questions with nhich histim3was full, and actually prided himself on never having exercised a vote or entered a political meeting. In the cause of the poor at home or the oppressed abroad, his pen was always ready. He saw clearly the great ends of liberty and public virtue; but his grasp of the means by which they might be attained was little less than childish. When Carlyle called him a mere rebel, Landor protested indignantly that in his eyes Venice was the pattern State, and that he despised Republicanism of the American type. To point the modern inquirer to Venice as a model is, as Mr. Leslie Stephen pertinentlyremarks,"simply to say that you have nothing but contempt for all rolities. It is as if a lad should be asked whether he preferred to join a cavalry or an infantryregiment, and should reply that he would only serve under Leonidas !
Of Landor's literary friendships Mr.Colvin draws an interesting and, on the whole, a very attractive picture. His devotion to Southey is well known. As Byron put it-
". . . that deep-mouthed Bceotian, Savage landor, "Has taken for a swan rogue Southey's gander."
Landor's admiration, indeed, must be admitted to have had a touch of absurdity in it, when we find him classing Shelley as the third poet of the age, the firsb boing Soutbey, and the second Wordsworth. But on the whole his relation to Southey ranks as ono of the few golden threads in Landor's ragged and rudely-woven life. The affection between them never failed from the moment when Southey first made eager acquaintance with the unknown author of " Gebir " till the lips of the elder friend closed for ever upon tho murmured name of the younger. His friendship witb Wordsworth was much less intimate, end had its times of eclipse. Wordsworth's narrow and prejudiced literary taste disgusted Landor, whose reading was immense, and who was never at any time of his life afflicted withthat blindness towards the gifts of others which made Wordsworth somet,imes a disappointing companion. X reported saying of Wordsworth's, that he would not give fhve shillings for all the poetry of Southey, sent Landor rus~hing wildly into print for the defence of his friend. Wordswrorth, however, took the matter calmly, as was his way, and in time the gust blew over. Landor never ceased to regard the King of the Lakists as a great poet, plaguied indeed, by an occasional demon of triviality and dulness, and both in Latin and English, while his feelings of respect for him were at their height, he paid him some generous tributes. Shelley and Landor never met. They were once in Pisa together, but Landor, fired by what he had heard of Shelley's behaviour towards his first wife, refused to call upon him. Later on he regretted the harsh judgment which had kept them apart, went out of his way to place on record his regret for his own loss, and his final high estimate of Shelley's character and gifts. That he should have ranked him as a poet below Southey, while calling him " incomparably the most elegant, graeoful, and harmonious of the prose-writers," only shows that Landor's critical instinct was surest within the domain where he himself excelled. Tcwards Bvron, the arch-romanticist, Landor, the arch-classic of his time, seems to have had a sort of natural antipathy. In one of the " Imaginary Conversations," Southey's friend revenged him for the " Vision of Judgment " by a sketch of Byron under the guise of Mr. George Nelly, Lord Rochester's illegitimate son :_
*Whenevar he wrote a bad poem he supported his sinking fame by some signal act of prohigacy-an elegy by a seduction, an heroic by an adultery, a txagedy by a divorce. On the remark of a learned moan that irregularity is no indication of genius, he began to lose ground rapidly, when on a sudden he cried out at the Haymarket, * There is no God.' It was then surmised more generally and more gravely that there nvas something in him, and he stood upon his legs almost to the last. 'Say what you will,' once whispered a friend of mine, there are things in him strong as poison and original as sin.' "
But with regard to Byron, too, Landor had his regrets when regrets availed nothing; Byron's death in the cause of Gree-e touched and changed the whole current of his feeling, and in the second edition of the dialogue quoted above, Landor added to it a pathetic note expressing his softened mood.-
" if, before the dialogue was printed be had performed those services to Greece which will renaer his name illustrious to eternity, those by which he merited sulch funereal honours, as, in the parsimony of praise, knowing its value In republics, she hardly would have decreed to tho most deserving of her heroes-never would I, from whatever provocation, have writtenasyllable against him. Oh I
iatIsould have clasped his hand before he died only to makie him more enamoured of his ow 'virtues, ,ndI to keep him with them always."
For his younger contemporaries-for Mr.Browniug, with whose massive and profound genius the author of " Count Julian ' felt a close and natural affinity, for Mr. Tennyson, and for Mr. Swinburne, whose visit to him shortly before his death at Florence was one of the Iast pleasures of his life, Landor was the most genial of friends and critics. "IIis talkc" says Mr. Colvin, " was not only incomparably rich and full,it was delivered with such a courtly charm of manner and address, each a rotundity, mellowness, and old-world grace of utterance, as were irresistible." The mero range of his literary and political memories made him such company as fewv men have the chance of being. In 1864, it was like listening to a voico from another world to hear Lander talk familiarly of Fox and Pitt, of the persons and events of the French Revolution, or of his childish recollections of the AmericanWar of Independence. This longspan of life MLr. Colvin divides into three distinct periods of literary activity, of 26, 16, and again 26 years respectively, the first marked by "Gebir," " Count Julian, "and someof bi-sbestLatinverse; the second by all his finest work, such as the " Imaginary Conversations," "Periclesand Aspasia," the "Examination of Shakespeare," and the "Pentameron"; and the third by a mass of miscellaneous productions, mostly poetical. Landor himself considered his poetry more amateuring compared with his prose, and the estimate is no doubt on the whole perfectly just. After making every allowance for his lack of argumentative power, for his obscurity, for his Latinisms, and for the intermittent character of his dramatic sense,which will bo at its keenest in one page and desert him in the next, Landor's prose, if it continues to be read at all, must always rank with the bestin the English language; whereas his poetry, with the exception of a few pieces of first-rate quality, so few they might almost be counted on the fingers of one hand, is, as a whole, nowhere near the first rank. But how beautiful are these rare exceptions. One knows not who else could have written them. "Rose Aylmer," with its haunting melody; " Artemidora, "with its chastened tenderness; the exquisite flowerpassage in the " Foesalan Idyll," the famous shell simile, and two or three more-these surely, if nothing else, must keep Landor's poetical memory green so long as poetry is loved. For examples of his prose Mr. Colvin has naturally drawn almost entirely from the "Imaginary Conversations," giving one or two of what he calls the dramatic conversations in full, and gathering detached aphorisms and sentences from the reflective and expository group. On the whole, the examples are well chosen, though sometimes the shorter extracts are too much cut down to be quite inteligible, and there are one or two dialogues which hardly justify their distinction from the mass of their fellows, especially the weak and characterless dialogue between Essex and Spenser, and the poor one between Fra Lippo Lippi and the Pope.
In the preface to the "3elections" Mr.Colvin has tried to satisfy his own mind and his readers' as to the causes of Landor's sca.nty popularity, and the definitions he gives, in the course of his investigations, of the classical and romantio temaxers are just and subtle. That. Landor was
a classio stranded in a romantic ago; that he cultivated the art of bare strength in expression, while others were ransacking heaven and earth to find adornment for the many-coloured garment of their muse, that he deliberately denied himself means of poetical expression which every other modern poet has squandered-hero lies the common explanation of his want of success, and no one could put them better or more freshly than Mr. Colvin. But the causo really goes deeper. Modern romanticism, with its boundless curiosity, its determination to feal all, to represent all, is but one aspect of the scicntific spirit which has been the great birth of our timne. From it, as a French critic justly says, " has been born the critical spirit af our learned and complicated nineteenth century." The medinvalists of Scott's day, strange as it may sound, were " the pioneers of an age of exegesis and of documents." .Phey were really the iiuxleys and Darwins of literature, for they were the leaders of literary experiment. And becaulse their work was in harmony with the great current of the time,it has been fruitfuland effective. Bunt Landor throughout his life was absolutely untouched by the scientific temper. In no one department was his knowledge of the type which the modern world respects ; and in poetry, instead of throwing himself boldly on to the great stream of speculation and ecperimentwhichfloated o many of hs contemporaries into the harbour of enduring suc^ess, he preferred to practise tours de force in a corner of still water, out of the common course, aud where the world generally found itself too busy to look in upon him. B:a7t, at rhe same time, if he was radically out of sympathy with his age, his facultv of literary expression, within the limits he chose for himself, was unrivalled. For all those who look upon writing itself as a fine art, Mr. Colvin has done a true service by this pair of well-plannad and wellexecuted volumes.

Title: Adam Of St. Victor.*
Full_text:
ADAM Op Sr. V.CTOB.* I,
The reprint in three handy volumes of 1. Gautier's excellent edition of Adam of St. Victor's sequences will be welcomed by studonts of the Latin poetry of the middlo ages. Up to a recent date the farne of Adam, one of the most prolifio monkish poetst rested upon, a comparatively slender basis Off tho. 106 sequences published in the present work, only 37 wore given to tho world with the autbor's name b) Clichtovous in his "Elucidatorium Ecclesiasticum2,which passed through sev3ral editions from 1515 to 1556; others appeared anonymously iu various collections, but the bulk remained for centuries buried in the library of the Abbey of St. Victor. In the poot's time that abbey stood in tho auburbs of Paris, but was afterwards included within the walls of the growin city. During the French RIvolution,itsharel
the fate of other monastic institutions Its members wero dispersed and its precious manuscripts-Adam's sequences among the number= removed to the National Library in the Louvr, where 1..Gautier.discovered them many yearslater. The author's life i8 all but a perfect blank, whidh even the unwearying research of the French scholar has not beon able to fill up. All that is known of Adam is that he entered the monastery of St. Victor about 1130 as a young man, and was still alive in 1172, M. Gautier fixing the 'date of his death conjeoturally about 1192, At St. Victor he wrote his numerous poems for the great festivals of the Christian year and for the days of the saints and martyrs wilose sacred deeds and miraculous powers are recorded in his verse. As to bis nationality various ocinions ar 4ntnrter;nA Tl'hA
manuscripts call him 4" Brito," wbich may indicate a nativo either of Brittany or England. French writers would naturally be inclined to claim the poet as their countryman,and Archbishop Trencha great adniirer of Adam-concedes the point; without sufficient reason, we think. For "' tho fact," cited by him, '" that France was the main seat of Latin poetry in the 12th century, aud that all the most f mons composers in this kind were Frenohmen," proves absolutely nothiug, seing that many of the monks of St. Victor were notoriously foreigners, who would naturally adopt the style of poetry practised there. On the other an intrinsic proof of Adam's English birth might be discovered in his extreme fondness for alliteration, a device all but unknown in the Romance langu9ges,while it wvas the very backbotie of the metrical principle in Anglo-Saxon poetry, long before rhyme was thought of. We do not attach much force to this argument, but in a question where all is doubtful, it may appear worth mentioning as a piece of collateral evidence.
In discussing the merits of bis original, Mr. Wrangham's critical judgment is obviously impaired by the predilection whch biographers generally, and very natorally, have for their heroes. He speaks of Adam of Ss. Victor as " perhaps the noblnst mediseral classio we pcsoss, ' and looks upon the mnonstrous statement of Dr. Neale that the monkish versilier is " to my mind the greatest Latin poet, not only of medoieval, but of all a es," as " an almost pardonable exaggeration.' He even thinks it necessary to quote the equally absurd phras3 of another writer, accordiig to which Adam is the " Schiller of the MIiddle Ages." A more meaningless parallelism has never been invented. -There is in the naediaval poetnot a trace of Sobiller's dramatic pathos, or of his force and grandeur of diction. Adam is, in the first instance, a ouphuist, addicted to all manner of verbal and metrical artificialities and not adverse to a downright pun. " Sub securi stat securus," ho says of one martyr, and is anxious to derive the name of his favourite saint Agnes from the " agius Dei." These mannerisms are, of course, not peculiar to him alone. Medaimval poets areveryfond of turning etymological affinities to religious account, and it is probable that the Virgin Mary owes the attribute " maris stella " quito as mu.h to an accidental similarity of name as to the fact that iri the mythology of the Roman Church she superseded the ideal of antigue womanhood, the sea-born goddess Aphrodite. Bat Adam of St. Victor goes far beyond his compeers in his passion for verbal qufbbles and subtleties of vers3, and it is, perhaps, owing to this circumstance that even in his own age he distinctly occupied theposition of a literary poet. There is nothing mn his work of the intense pathos or the human feeling which, in spite of the learned idiom, appealed to the hearts of the people in such sutblime efforts as the "l Iies iri," the Ambrosian hymn 4' To Deum laudamus," or Jacopone's '"Stabat Mater." The tendemess of that sweetest of lullabies-
"Dorrii fti, dormi ! mater
" Cantat unigensto,"
and the triumphant confidence of that l:ean of the Christian faith, Venantius Fortunatus "Vexilla regis prodeunt," are aliko unknown to himn Neithler has he passed through the terrors of the valley of the shadow of death which inspired the grand " antiphona de morte " " Media vita, in morto swnus, ' written, it is said, by Notker after he had seen workmen who were building a bridge suspended over a terrible precipice. The strength of Adam of St. Victor lies elsewhere, He is a scl%olarlI poet, a competent cr. ftsman who wields his tools with skill, is fastidious in the choice of his epithets, and tells a story neatly and succinctly. His legend of St. Agnes, the sainted maiden who at the age of 13 prefers martyrdom to we:lth and luxury and love, is an excellent specimen of narrative poetry as practised in the middlo ages. His proficiency as a story-teller as well as tie variety of his motres, which has been a sore trial to Mr. XYrangham's skill as a translator, Adam to some extent derived from a source little suspected by his reverend critics. It was during his lifetime that the trouweres of Northern France founded a national epic upon the legends of the Arthurian and Carlovingian cycles, while at the same time the lyrical poets of the South developed a system of metrical art unrivaled for subtlety and variety by Dante himself. From that system Adam seems to have takeu more than one valuable suggestion, and there are in his poems distinct traces, for instan2e, of the grammatical, or, as it is technically caUed, the " dictional " rhyme and other subtleties familiar to the student of that vast compendium of metrical lore, the Leis d'amors.
Into further techni^al details, interesting as they would be to the stude ut, we cannot for obvious reasons enter hore. It is enough to say, that as a connecting link between sacred and profane poetry in the middle ages the sequences of Adam of St. Victor gain all importance not hitherto roalized by any writer on the subject. It is but fair to add that Mr. Wrangham's translation has beon executed with care and skill, the metres of the original having been strictly adhered to. The faithful randering of one of Adam's elaborate stanzas from a poem on the Nativity may be quoted by wvay of specimen
"He Ellsha's true successor,
"Goa-man, counted a tramsgressor, NI
To the Shunamite, to bless her, "Hath reatored her son again. "As a giant runs He ioying,
"Who, His shoulder's strength employing, "Bears lais sheep, Death's law destroying 'Back to primal joys oi men."
" The Liturgical Poetry of Adam of St.Victor, from the text of Gautier. " With translations in the original metres and short explanatory notes. By Digby S. Vrangbarm. London; Regan Paul, Trench, and Co.

Title: The Works Of Alexander Pope,*
Full_text:
| THE WORKS O ALBXANDER POPS,* I~~~~~~~~~~OE .I.
Tho literary history of England for noarly a century3ndahalf contres round threo personalities,each in hiS day tho focus of all that was said or written, that was either wise or witty. He who knows minutolY tho livos of Dryden, of Pope, andof Dr. Johnson, with their sayinga and doings, their friendships, and their enmities, ksiows intimately the courso of English letters, and poetry, from tho Restoration to tho FronchRevolution. This is not because any one of the three men has any claim to be considered either the greatest intellect or tho noblest mind of his age. All the three had cotemporaries moro illustrious, and more considerable, either in literary genius, or in reaeh of philosophical idea. Dryden was cotemporary with Newton and with Locke; Popo has no protensions to the genius of Bolingbroke, or tho force of Swift, or the philosophy of Butler; Johnson cannot compare in regard of the highest and most prized mental qualities with Hume, or Adam Smith, with Burke or GSibbon. But whatever their inferiority in the more splendid gifts of intellect, each of these threo mon-Dryden, Pope, and johnson-is a representative man of his age. Each gathered round himself, either attracting or repelling, the circulating atoms of thought, feeling, passion, and preoudice, vwhich were floating in the social atmosphere of his time. In a greater dogree, and in a more poculiar mannor is this true of Pope. Mr. Matthew Arnold has lately pronounced against the " historic estimate " in the study of poetry. There are no doubt pooms which may be taken wholly apart from their socular surroundin s, and viewed absolutely, as works of art. ltr. Arnold's doctrine, howevor, wil uot cover the case of Pope anv more than that of Dante. Tho pootry of Pope is the mirror of his age, and the most completo representation which wo have of social life in the early years of Georgo II. It may be doubted, indeed, if we know any period so well and so distinctly as we do this. For hero we know not merely the facts, but tho sontiments and passions, the hates and fears, which attach to and animate the filats. And this insight is gained chiefly through Pope-his poems not his letters-chiefly from his own verses, but partly also from the illustration wbich has been gathered round his verses by generation aftor generation of scholiasts. To feel the importance of Pope's poetry as the mirror of his age, we havo only to reflect what an eclipse would come over the London of 1720-40, if Pope's poems, with the commentaries adhering to them, should be suddenly obliterated. The memoirs of LordaHervey, the letters of Horace Walpole, and in a subordinate degree, those of Lady Mary Wortley Montague, are each of them precious cotemporary records. But all the three taken together could not replace for us the illumination shed upon every object which fell waithin its ken, by the verse of Pope in his satires and epistles, and moral essays.
It is these pieces which form the contepts of the volumo of Pope's works, the third volume of the poetry, and the first under Mr. Courthope's editorship, now given to the public. Theso pieces are vithout question the most valuable of all that Pope has left us. In his own day, and for a generation after it, the " Essay on Manu " was regarded as Pope's capital work. But in spito of occasional brilliant passa es in the essay, various causes have combined to sholve that poem for us in our day. It is not merely that optimism is out of fashion, and that the moral pendulum has swung in the opposite directien but that even granting tho truth of Pope's thesis-viz., that whatever is, is right-wo have becomo too consoious of his feebleness, and incompotence, to handlo that or any philosophical pioblem. Popo's versifiled rendering of Shaftesbury and Bolingbroke had a triumphant success in his day, owing to the striking illustrations, pithy sayings, and the brilliant passages, with which Pope's skill could dress out an argument. We live in an age of " Essays," and know, only too well, what a show an extemporizing philosopher, whose stucdies have been limited to magazines, can make, with his hastily got-up information. Pope, in the "Essay on Man," was just like one of tho prophets of our own day. Eithor conversing with Bolingbroke, or dipping into Shaftesbury's charactoristics, his quick perception seized the general drift of that philosophic theory, whichflfoated loosely in the air of London, and he prosenteo it to tho reader with a literary finish acquired by 25 years study of the art of polish. Tho applause of his cotemporaries rewarded him for his labour, and disguised from himself the fact, which is patont to us, that his selection of a philosphical subject was a mistako.
But though amid tho chorus of applause which grected the "Essay on Man " it was impossible for its author to know how worthless itsphilosophy would soon seem, that instinct which guides goniuis soon detormined bim in the right direction. The occasion of his trying his hand on the "Imitations of Horace," might be, as he told Sponce accidental
" When I had a fever one winter in towvn, that confned me to ry room for fivo or six days, Lord ]Bolingbroke, who came to see me happened to take up a Horace that lay on the tablo, ana on turning it over dropped on the frst satiro of the second book. IIe observed how woU that would suit my case if I were to imitato it in English. After he was gone I read it over, translated it in a morning or two, and sent it to press."
This casual suggestion of Bolingbroke mado in 1732 could do no more than reinforce the sense, which might long before have been coming to Pope, of tho true direction in which his strength lay-that, namely, of personalities, and living portraiture. Discerning friends had seen this long before. As early as 1722, Atterbury, who had seen the famous lines upon Addison, wrote to Pope, " Since you now know in what direction your strength lies, I hopo you will not suffer that talent to bo unemployed." Though the first of tho " Imitations of Horace" did not appear till 1733, yet during the interval Pope was composing trenchant satire, in bitc and couplets, which wero afterwards piecod together to form whabt is now called the " Prologue to the Satires.1' It is no paradox to say that his ': Imitations of Horace " aro tho imost original of his works, as they are to us, by reason of their contents, the most valuable. These " Imitations," eight in number, make, with the "Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot" and tho two " Epilogues," a body of verso the most sparkling, lively, and poignant that our own or any modern language has to show. They aro not throughout -no poetry is or can be-of equal vigour. A superior critic can point to many a feeble line, to somo even bad lines, to defective grammar, and strained parallels; but, in spite of blemishes, the canvas, as a whole, is animated by a glow of life, and light, and reality such as we may seek for in vain in othor pictures of tho manners of contemporaries. An uneqnaleod master of expression, he
has preserved the Iife of the past for us in a state of suspended animation. "Popo," as Mr. Ruskinhassaid, "is the most perfect representative we have since Chaucer of the true English mind."
Mr. Ruskin's hint of the resemblance between Pope and Chaucer suggests to us at tho same time tho difference botween tho two poots. And the comparison, whether by way of Vw ness or unlikeness, is equaUy helpful towards tho understauding of Pope. Both the " Canterbury Tales " and Pope's 4 Satires " are a presentment of tho living soIeity by which oach poot found himself surrounded. But in Chaucer, as in Molibre, the portraiture is generic. He draws for us classes of men, not individual lin;onesses. In Pope, on tho other hand, everything is personal and individual. Whenever Pope attompts to generalize, whether it be truth or character,he immediately falls below himself. As tho theodicy of tho " Essay on Man," tbhe attempt to "v indicate tho ways of God," seems to us now puerilo, so the moralizing of the " Moral Essays ' reads trito and common-laleo. His reflections and his maxims are now consignad to the copy-book. But as tho feeblo philosophizing of tho " l say on Man " was and is redeemed by tho brilliant colouring of the illustrations and tho sparkle of the epigram whieh enforced it, so in tho "M Ioral Essayse and " Satires" we regard the platitudes of bis moral theory morely as tho mortar and cement which hold togother the miseollaneous characters of living men and women in someosort of whole. When Popoetells us to search the ruling passion, for " thoro alone the wild are constant,andthe cunning known," wo nover think of following tho direction,or of taking thoewords for anything more than the obligatory preamblo to the piquant character of the Dukoe of Wharton which this maxim, so poromptorily announced, intro:luces. It is just here teat the critical finger can point out the proeise limit of Pope's power. He could not rise from thoepar-
* "Tho Worlis of Alexander Pope." loew edition, 'with ,introduetion and notes by tho Rev. Whitwotth Elwsn and WYillism Jwn CouKhoDx VOL IIL Munoz. lSSL
ticular to tho ge0 eral. Be was always endeavouring to do so, nnd always with one result-a fall into the occah of platitude. His imagination could not, as Chaucer's did, create porso)nage after personage, each embodying a type, and at the samo time endowed with tho porsonal identity of
nman or woman whom Weo have or might have known. Pope's portraits are real, not because they aTe the embodimente of a vivid imagination , but because they are tho lino observation of a lynx-oyed observer of the fasults and foibles of
polwhom he actually kmnov. Tlius, theo value of his "Essays" and "Satnires"to unsis thoir storical value. Other essayists and versiliers may have given us the manners of the time. Pope'sversi goes benoath the mere manners, and expresses thE passions, feelings, thonghts, and motives of ar atistocracy which, after a period of fierce religiow war, htd come into quiet possossion of undisputed authority in all that concerned social life, morals, taste, and breeding. The fuirious Parliamentary battles of the timo, and the beat vith which Walpole was assailed, should not cisguise from us the fact that tho great religious struggle of tho preceding century had (for a time) died down, and given place to a mere dynastic division of Whig and Tory. The Government was actually in the hands of the Whigs ; it was resisted and reviled by the Tory and Jacobite Opposition. But, regarded from a distance, -inimsters and their antagonists together formed a homogeneous aristocracy, having in common the ideas, sentiments, and qualities which constituted the civilized England of tbh Hanoverian age. In Pope'e "Satires "we find a bright re'flection of these men and their way6:-
"E e shows us the rise of woman as a controlling power in secicty and politics- the extension among the niobilty of an Italian taste in paintinz andl architecture the hatred felt by the Catholics for tthe moneyed middle class, whvich was the backbone of the Revolution, the mnainstay of Whiggery, and tho bulwark of Protestantism. in his satires, too, *ve seo a mirror of the feelings of the Parliamentary Opposition directed by Bolingbroke and Pulteney; of their rancour apsinst walpole's foreign and domestic policy; ot the relations between tho Uourt and the arty of the Prince of WVales; of the popular dislike of the oanoverian dynasty and of Low Churh principles Besides, we have suggestive glimpses of the pnterior of society at a time when St. James's was the extreme West. end of London, and old Burlington-houso was but just built. The ' British youth ' appear at their diversions at White's Chocolate-house, llocly-in-tho-Hole, or Fig's Academy. Complaints aro heard trom polite society of the degradation of tho stagc in consequence of the public passion for spectacles. I'be penniless ' man of rhyme walks forth ' froma the Mint, and tho dealiogs of tho illodged bard of Drury-lane with his aristecrati: or commercial patrans are exposed in the full light of pitiless ridicule. As wo read the society of the past rises hefore the imagination in its dramatic reality. The age in many respects may have had the defects of its poet, but, like huim, it was not without generous qualities ; it is, at least, fuU of human and historical interest, whether it be regarded as the period when the British Empire first began to rise, or as the aristocratic stage of English society, in which the realities of charactcr displayed themselves with a frankness wanting in our own democratic tines, when the individual is apt to disguise his natural imputses in deference to publio opinion."
It 1o0uows Irom this that such poetry as that of Pope stands much iu need of a commentator. So lifelike, indeed, aro his pictures that they never fail to impress even readers who are wvithout any knowvledge; but our appreciation and enjoymont of Popo rises in proportion as our independent acquaintance with history and biography is anlarged. It is the first business of an editor of Popo to explain the allusions, to fill up the blanks, to ferret out tho now obscure facts, and to explain the poet's personal reoations to the various objects of his love or his censure. In all satiro, from tho very nature of tho case, thero is an obscurity of personal allusiou ; but' this becomes almost desperate in Pope, owing to the tortuous ways of the man, who at once wanted to bo understood and feared to be. He would havo beeu sorry that it should not have been supposed that Timon meant tho Duke of Ohandos but ho did not reaUy mean him; he quite intonded somebody else, as he could say both to tho Duke and to himsolf with the honesty of that completest self-deception which at last overtakes the habitually disingenuous mind. Even while the ink of his satire was wet, it required the accompaniment of a running commentary. Swift writes to Pope in 1728:-
|" The notes (to 'The Dunciad') Icould wish to be large in what rolates to tbo persous concerned, for I havo observed that 20 miles from London nobody understands hints, initial letters, or town facts and passages. 1 insist you must have yoer asterisks fllcd up with the real names."
If a contemporary, an intimate friend of the author, and living in the same circle of acquaintance, as Swift was, found much that he did not understand, how much more must a reador a century and a half later require the helping hand of an annotator.
And somo measure of such holp has not been wanting from the very first. Popo put footnotes to his pooms himself ; but his notes, so far from being explanatory, aro ofton only designed for mnystification. Heo seeks to guard bimself by voil. ing the aim of the tex-t, where it is at all direct, under ironical p raise in the note. But Pope enjoyed the sinwlar distinction of living to see at least one of his works furnished 'with a regular commentary aftor the mannor of n classic. In our day we have societies formod for the study and illustration of the works of living writers ; but in tho history of literaturo the instances are extremely few in which a living poet has attracted a commentator to his sido. OnO such instance is found in Selden's notes to Drayton's " Polyolbion," perhaps the most learned commentary on any book in the English language. The object of Warburton's commonton the "Essay onMhan" was notexplanation, but Apology. The natural theology of the " Essay on Mau " was neither better nor worse reasoned that were any of the thoistio treatises of the day. But it bad naturally attracted more attention and roused the zeal of the professional answerers moro than they. A heavy Swiss professor, Jean Pierre Crousaz, had levelled a ponderoas volume, which had been immediately translated into English, against the " Essay. " Pope was in dire alarm. It was not that he cared for the imputation of free-thinking, which attached to many of his best friends, and e3pecialy his," guide," Bolingbrok-e; but what Popo above all dreaded was unpopularity, from whatover cause. He was in this respect the opposito of Thoophilo Gautior, who took a mischievous pleasure in running countor to the public and tho fashion and affecting to address himself to the feIw. Pope, indeed, is constantly talking as if he wero a Gautiar. When Pope protends that his only ambition is to
"Maintain a poet's dignity and eC3e,
And seo what friends and rcAi what books I please; "To sleep witbout a poem in my head,
"2Nor know if Denais bo alivo or dead."
we ail know this is only the author's mockmodesty, and that Pope is playing with us his little innocent farceo of hido-and-seok. In any one else such affectation would be allowed to pass with a smilo at its transparency. But tho editors and critics of Popo seem to be all men of such exceptionally fine morality tbat they cannot over. look such a want of uprightncss,and Pope is always on these occasions branded as a hsrdened liar. His pretonceo of not caring for public opinion really conceals the most acute sensitiveness to the son populi, and when tho storm of orthodox reprobation set in against the " Essay on Man " Pope mIust have be 7un to think in what shape he could retract or disavow the Deism imputed to that poem.
In this his hour of need a champion camo forward from the ranks of his enemies, though Pope did not know the savago things Warburton had been in tho habit of saying of him, such as that tho II Essay" was collectod ftom the " worst passages of the worst authors," and that its doctrines vere "rank atheism." This was whilo Warburton consorted with literary hacks of the lower stratum -Concainen, Thcobald, and other " Dunces." But Warburton was bent upon rising, and in this Crousaz businoss ho saw his opportunity. Ho suddenly transferred his advocacy to Pope's side. Tho "Ei:ssay on Man " at onceo ceased to be made up of "the worst passages from the worst authors," and heavy monaces wero uttered, Bishop Law tolls us, against any one who should prosume to insinuato that Popo borrowed anythig from any man whatsoever, instoad of " rank atheism " the poem now breathed pity and sound pbilosophy in every line. Tho articles in which 'Warburton set out his amonded views originally appaed in a monthly publication callod the fWor of the Leaned. Tho substanco of thom was, at Pope's request, formed into a commontary and printed in tho nextandallsubsequenteditions of tho "Essay." Worso than this, Warburtonl earned from Pope's gratitude the honour and profit of boing left Pope's literary executor.and thus entitled to write notes on all tbo rest of Pope's worlk. Of the dis. honourablo uso ho made of this trust Mr.Courthope gives somo strildng i-iiances. One of the worst is his depriving Martha Blount of the honour in. tonded for horby the woet of beinz the "itdy"-
<NEWPAGE>
to whom was addressed the epistle on the " Oha_ racters of Women." Warburton, who at one time saw a good deal of Pope, mioht have done much towards tha proper business -of an editor. When the meaning was obscure he could always have sought its explanation at the fountain-head. He has told us some-very few-facts about Pope which we should not otherwise have known. But his discharge of the duty of general editor of the works was marked by uuscrupulous disregard of the interests of the dead author and a design to make the edition subservient to his own promotion in tho Church. When Pope made his will he expected Warburton to be as eager to upbold his poetical credit with the public as he7ad been when he championed the " 1assay on Alan." But the Warburton of 1751 was a different man from the Warburton of 20 years before. Then he had been a struggling and obscure author; he was now on the way to the highest dignities of the Church. Instead of defending his author's position and attaching himself to his cause, he inserted at intervals at the foot of thepage, dpropos of nothing, an unmeaning panegyric. 'The personal allusions he endeavoured to slur over by assuming an air of arrogant superiority. There is a passage in Pope's " Satires and Epistles," 4, 85, which has been the cruxc of all the commentators and is still unexplained:-
I Ris wealtl bra,e Timon gloriously confounds; A-sked for a groat, he gives a hundred pounds, "Or if three ladies like s luckless play,
*Takes the whole house upon the poet's day."
Who is Timon? Who the "three ladies "? And whose play?? Warburton's note is characteristic of the man and .of the edition:-
"1 The common reader, I am sensible, will bo always mnore soUcitous.about the uanaes of these three ladies, the unlucky play, and every other trifling circuinstace that attended this piece or gallantry, than for the explanation of our author's sense or the illustration of his poetry. Bub hsd it beea M1r. Pope's purpose to indulge so impertinent a curiosity be had sougbt elsewhere for a commentator on his writings."
In a hypocritical " advertisement " prefixed to his edition, Warburton pomnpously informs the reader that by his advice and suggestion Pope finally altered his poetry so as to adapt it to promote " the ends of virtue and religion." AVarburton was suspected by Croker of having tampered with tho text of the " Satires." The more carefui investigations of Mr. Elwin have disproved this suspicion. But no credit redounds to Warburton for his fidelity to the poet's own text ; for he was bound by the terms of Pope's will, tnder penalty of forfeiture of his legacy, to print what Pope leftwithout alteration.
Warburton was so established in his legal and testamentary rights as proprietor of Pope that it has not been possible from 1761 to the present flay to have Pope without having him thus strangled by his Old Man of the Sea. Dr. Aitkin long since complained that " it is scarce possible in many places to enter into the poet's real meaning without laying aside the Commentary." Every one complained,but no one dared the innovation of discardina Warburton. Even Mr. Elwin, in the present edttiou, feared the charge of incompletenes*, and reprinted the whole of Warburton's Commentary on the " Essay," though removing it from the foot of the naze to an annendix.
Of the editors wioi succeeded Warburton our spaceforbidsustogive an account. Each contributed something--Roscoe the least, Warton the most. Joseph WVarton had a cultivated classical taste and a scholar's knowledge at least of the Latin poets. Warton had besides the advantage of being ablo to consult living _persons who had known Pope, 3specially Lord Batburst and Dr. Spence. Scattered about in Warton's notes are many precious original memoranda or anecdotes. We have said that Roscoe contributed the least of all Pope's editors to the elucidation of his author. It would be probably safe to say that he contributed nothing. Roscoe's reading lay in the Italian writers of the Renaissance ; oE tbe 18th century he knew nothing. Mr. Adolphus Ward says, " Roscoe has shown that Bufo was not meant for Lord Halifax. " No allusion in aUl "Pope's Satires " is of more assured interpretation than the Bufo of the "Prologue of the Satires." Roscoe'sdenialthat Lord Halifax wvas intended is a testiniginstance of hisqualifications as an interpreterofPope.The public and the booksellers,however, f oundthat style of e
ing good enough. Two editions of Roscoe's Pope have been placed upon the market at a bigh price.
Editors of English classics are now tried by a higher standardthin that which was usual 5Oyears ago. The present Elwin-Courthope edition is a very different work from the old style of " trade " edition hastily got up to order. Mr. Elwin bad made it 'lifficult to find a successor for himself, such had been the exhaustive patience with which he had worked his way tbrough the overwhelminmass of detail wbich had gathered round Popo ana all his works. But Mr. Courthope has not shrunk from repeating the process of laborious research which is necessary before any single affirmation can safely be made as to what Pope did, meant, or intended. And in the tone aaopted towards the author the present editor approaches more nearly to judicial impartiality than did his predecessor. Mr. Elwinlay on Pope's scent something like the huntsman's terrier following the hunted fox through the windings of his last refuge in the sarth. In Mr. Courthope's introduction to the present volume tbhere is muoh less of the public prosecutor, with a full recognition of the duty of in editor to explain. And if Pope's editors are inevitably driven to approach their work in the spirit of literary detectives it is owing to Pope's own mystifications and underground proceedings. Perhaps, indeed, the time has hardly yet arrived for the definitive edition of Pope's poems. When the tortuous labyrinth of intrigue in which his various publications are enveloped has once for all been fully unraveUled, there will bo no need for each successive editor to essay his skiU in disentangling the maze of error. The whole subject, indeed, may well be banished from the scholar's edition of Pope as unprofitable and not properly belonging to literature. It may even be made a question if critical estimates ought to find place in a perfect edition of any poet. There are some excellent remarks in Mr. Courthope's introduction on Pope's stvle, but thrown as they are into a controversial form, being an answer to Mr. Leslie Stephen, they may, perhaps, be thought more appropriate to a reviewv or an independnt essay than to an edition.
The proper business of an editor of Pope-tbat of explaining dificulties and recalling vwhat is known of forgotten personages -is performed by Mr. Courthope with exemplary diligence. It is slways a matter of doubt whether explanatory notes should be foot notes or should be placed together at the end of the text. There can be n doubt whatever as to the rule that when it has been decided to place the notes at the foot of the page condensation and brevity should be studied as much as possible. This cannot be attained on the variorum plan adopted in the present volume, the plan, that is, on which the notes of previous editors are introduced in their own words. When a vaiiorum commentary becomes itself entertainingreading, and many of them are such, it becomes a substantive work and should be kept apart froni the original text. The footnote annotator should keep hinself and his apparatus out of sight and allow the reader's interest to settle exclusively on the text.
Mr. Courthope says that of the obscurities of personal allusion in Pope much must now be regarded as beyond the reach of explanation and much must remain mere conjecture. We may justly congratulate him upon having left so little unexplained. In. the couplet:-

aope is certainly referring to some piece of Rab-. bimcal lore which he had seen in some book, but no one has yet been able to produce the passage:-

Ans Bug now bas and Dorimant would have."
Mr. Courthope has now placed it beyond a doubt that the first pseudonym here stands for the Duke of Kent. But the same evidence seems to confirm Bennet's conjecture that the liue:-

in ".pilogue IL," 238, should be filledup wvith the oames Kent and Grafton rather than with those of George and Frederick as prooosed by Lord -Marchmont. Ne are still unable fo discover the motive of the line:-

the ehye is alluded to, pe=l;aps the7 complaint fur whi PopeconsultedCheselden;'Ontho line

the editor usefully reminds us that Soho is here not used for the square which was still fasbionable, but for Wardour-street,wbich was originally called Old Soho, and had already begun to acquire a connexion with old curiosities. But is Air. Court. hope's London topography eoually good when he asserts, in page 411, that the houre of the Prince of Wales was in Lincoln's-ini-fields? Much of the merit of the " Imitations of Horace " depends upon the adaptations of the English ciroumstances to th;ose of Augustan Rome. If the Horatian original is not printed by the side of the English it should. always be kept in. viewv. Mr. Courthopo has for a moment left it out of sight in writing his note on the line: -
ChYoi coantry, chief, in arms abroad defend"

The author of "The Songs of Twvo Worlds nIas completed his cycle of the " Epic of Ilades " by the addition of two new books, the titles of which-Tartarus and Olympus-express their subjects.. Eis present volumes continue the promise of his earlier work, and advance it, somewbat further towarts fulfilment. In one seanse the idca of his Epic is not only ambitious, but audacious, for: it necessarily awakens reminiscences of Dante. In another, however, it shows a just appreciation ef'his special power of anssimilating poetical fancies and wveaving' them into graceful forms, for it supplies him with congenial themes, which he casts cleverly into miodern shapes and turusinto practical and profitable teachings. Che charactcr of the eioem may be said to be a Christisnized PaganiMn. The deities of his Olympus are refined and idealized ; even Aphroditd disavows the grossness of the senlsual worsbip that *vas paid her. Herd is the Goddess of Duty, Ar.temis embodies the spirit of knowledge and wisdom, while Zeus is the great primal cause and power, the all-pervading soul of the world, but dimly comnprehensible to human perceptions. The author searches forhiddei meniningsin the creations (f ite old mythology and ingeniously shows them susceptible of unsuspected interpretatious. Not unfrequently he is charmingly pathetic, as in his Helen and his Psycho ; hs I)eianeira and his Eurydice ; and the powers of love, of song, and of beauty are his prevailing themes. In a Fiebruary ,dream, on the eve of the translation to iades-

T'he spirits are waiting, as we shall wait, the beatific end ;" they are touched by melancholy mSiiories. cheered. by unforgotten joys ; and by the light of reflection, as in a new inspiration, they read the bitter lessons ol their lives, wihich are sweetened by the hopes of a bappier immortality. Appropriat.ly enough, the first meeting of thu poet in that world of spectres is with the shade of SEarsyas, to vvbom death has brought consolation, if not oblivion. The victim ot the wratliful rivalry of the Sun God cau almost rejoice in the rash challenge whicb pronmaturely qu,nched his joyous ambitions. It is better to have tailed gluriously than to be contented with mere ignoble succ-ss, and only to have listened to the godlike song of the victor and executioner soothed the pangs of a terrible deatu. Not that - the New Writer cloihes the penalty paid by M7 arsyss in the rLalistic horrors that were revelled in by clasRdcal Lxicographer and mudiatval artists. The loser is not flayed with cold-bloodLd deliberation, and all that 'is io be distin6tuished beneath his loosened robe is "the scar of cruel stripes, t-o hastily concealed." Although the English have a far greater atake in the East than any other nttion, yet, strange to say, wve have hitherto done less towards elucidating and investigating Oriental literature than almost any other nation in Etrope. But if ve consider that the wvorks of the master minds of a people are the best and most infallible guides to the light understanding of their-feesling and sentiments, we cannot fail to regret this auDineness. Fortunately, the reproach is at last being gradually removed, and although the Government is stiU indifferent in the matter, private enterprise is supplying the deficiency, nnd popular translations of the Indian and Persiani classics are appearing with a frequency that argues a greater and more intelligent interest in the subject. One of the most important of these works is that just issued by 3Iessrs. Triibner, tho dfivn or collected poenms of Hdfiz :Shfrdz, translated into English verse by Herman Bicknell.
The name of Hdfiz, the national poet of Persia, is familiar enough, no doubt, to most people, but to any one except an Oriental scholar it suggests little more than a vague idea of Bulbuls, roses, and Eastern love tales. The recognized interpreter of Oriental poetry to the English reader is Moore, and lovers of " Lalla Rookh " will easily recognize in the name of the Persian bard that of Hafed, the hero of " The Fire Worshippers." Yet this very name shows boiv superficisl was Moore's acquaintance wvith Eastern tlhings, and how very imperfect his rendering of Eastern poetry must be. Hafiz is a title given in Muslim countries to any learned theologian who has committed the wvhl,ole of the Koran to memory, and, therefore, is the very last name that should have been chosen for an Arab-hating, anti-Moslem, <;uebre chief. In the present case it is the nwm de plume of 6hems ed din Mohammed of tihfrlz, one of the most eminent of the mystical poets which Persia has produced. His works consist of about 700 poems, chiefly of those called ghazals, or odes, short pieces with the same rhyme to every alternate verse throughout. Of thie style and subject-matter of these poems we shall speak presently.
In L{ermany much has been done for the wvorks of lHlfiz. A magnificent critical edition of tile text has been issued and edited by Brockhaus ; and metrical translations by Von Hammer, by Itosenzweig,of Vienna, and by Nesselman, of Berlin, have also appeared. England, however, has done little, if anything, towards making known these really remarkable lays, and beyond a few forgotten nietrical versions in old nunibers of the Asiatic Aiiaccllany, and an able article in a recent number of MacmiUain's Magazine, HRfi7 has never found an exponent in this country. Tho translation of the poems of Hldfiz, by Hermani Bicknell, which has just appeared, is therefore the more welcome as it really fills up a serious gap in literature. Mr. Bicknell's career was a strange and adventurous one. As a military surgeon in India, he first made his acquaintaneo with the East, and he subseauently visited Java, China,Cashmere, 'l'ibet, Egypt; Syria, and Arabia, and even performed the pilgrimage to Mecca. Unlik-e his great predecessor in this exploit, Captain Burton, he tvent wvithout disguise of person or nationality; but his biographer, in telling us this, says nothing abont the Moslem rites and observances which he must have followed to qualify for the journey, for as a Kafir it is clear that he would not have been permitted to enter the Holy City. Mr. Bicknell was a man of decidedly eccentric habits, but his eccentrieities led him to do some useful things, this translation of H4tiz among the number.
How thoroughly the late Mr. Bicknell studied his author and prepared himself for the wvork of translating may be gathered from the fact that he went toTersia and resided for some time at Shirdz vith the sole object of making himself acquainted with the scenes amid wbich HIafiz wrote. 'The beautiful designs of Mr. Haerbert, B.A., which are included in the volume enable the reader to realize these surroundingrs for himself. ere we have the
afizfyah, a district of :;hira.z, in which many of the spots mentioned in the odes lie, and a scene in whichi Persian revellers are carousing to music and singing. In these two pictures which are executed in chromo-lithography, the peculiar brightness aud clearness of the Eastern atmosphere is admirably rendered. The volume also contains a good coloured lithograph of Bdtiz's tomb and some equisite little woodcut vignettes by other hands. This is, unfortunately, a posthutnous work, as the translator did not live to complete his labours, but died while the first sheets were in the Press. It was his original intention to publish the whole of the poems of 1II1fiZ; but, as we aro told in the proface,he ultimately " determined to select only front those poems which ho considered the best, and undoubtedly genuine." The selection is no doubt a good one,-any selection from Hafiz, even at random, would be good,-but we cannot help thinking that it is owing rather to tne progress already made by the translator when he resolved to publish than to the reasons adduced. There is, at least, one poem of more than doubtful authenticity, the wellknowvn tdza ba tfdza woo ba now, and some of the best odes, and occasionally even the best part of an ode, are omitted. To reproduce the single rhyme that occurs in every alternate hemi-stich of each ode is obviously impossible, and the resemblance to the Persian is therefore never complete. This being the case, we think it would have been much better to select English metres with corresponding movements ; the result would certainly have been more pleasing to an Einglish ear. The fact is that the metres in any language are not artificial or arbitrary forms; they grow naturally out of the accentuation of individdial words in the language, certain groups of which, of definite length, become more pleasing than others. Now, since in English the voice is invariably depressed at the end of a sentence, while in Persiai it is slightly elevated and prolonged, there is au initial difficulty in the way of representing one metre by the other. To put a foreign metre servilely into Englislh words is like translating literally into a foreiga language and following the syntactical arrangement of the original. The key to the interpretation of Hafiz's songs is to be founid in a combination of Materialism and Suflism-that strange system of metaphysical philosophy and theosophy which.has.sprung up from the endeavour to reconcile two such diametrically opposite cults as the Pantheism of the Aryan races and the severe -Monotheism of their Senmitic conquerors. The Eastern poet aims at leading his readers to the contemplation of spiritual things by appealing to their emotions. The delights of earthy beauty and the pleasures of the sense are e=thuiastically described by him, but behind this veil of allegory there really does often lurk a spirit of devotion to the Deity, a yearning after perfection, and a longing after eternal love. They claim to be in so intimate a communion with tho Deity, through devotion and the cultivation of their higher and nobler feelings, that they can afford to rise superior to the petty details of dogma and superstition.

M.r. Arnold's " Indian Song of Songs " is a mort unpretending but scarcely less remarkable book. It is a translation from the Sansscrit idyll, the Gita Gov!%ida of Jayadeva, in which the superiority of heavenly and intellectual beauty to the attractions of earthly loveliness and sensual pleasures is treated under tlo allegory of a love tale. Krishna, an incarnation of Vishniu, is found at the opening of the poem lavishin'g his affections upon some beautiful sheepherdesses to tlhe neglect of Radba, the personification of intellectual and moral beauty. At last tbe chlrms of the legitimate nmistress, depicted in very glowving colours by the author of the original, succeed in makinz an inpression on Krishna's Aieart, and he is ultimately won back to rectitude and happiness. The poem is rendered into very musical English verse, and, although rather a paraphrase than a strictly literal translation, it evinces a thorough kuorledge of the language of the original. The metre is varied for each different section of the work, and a pleasing variety is thuis obtained. The sentiment of tho poem is tender and noble. Here, for instance, is a verse which, changing only the proper name of the being invoked, would not be out of place in Christian bymn-book:-

The volume, a handy little octave, contains also some minor original poenks, founded on Oriental legends, which display, as might be expected from their author, considerable power both of conception and execution. " The Rajpoot's Wife," a Hindoo story suggestie of the history of Judith and Holofernes, is a very striking production, both in the metre and the mode of working out the plot. So, too, is " The Rajah's Ride," which re;ountslhow a chiettain of Sindh, after languishing for along time in captivity with bis Moslem foes, was made to ride an intractable holse in the hopes that he woulld be disuraced and killed. Instead, however, of meeting with such a fate, he lea s tho wall of the fort, outrides his pursuers, and pays a visit to his faithful wife. Arrived lhome however, he scornss to comnmit so mean an act as horse-stealing, and lieedless of the consequences rides back to Lahore and delivers up the steed to his Maflometian captor, who generously gives hinm his freedom and a magnificent present besides. It would have been better for Mr. Arnold's re. putation for Oriental scholarship had the last poem in the book been oimitted, or, at least, had he not yielded to ]his evident penchant for introducing snatches of verse in the original language. The story on which the verses are based is founid as an exercise in a well-knowu elementary Aratbic grammar, and tells how the Caliph Mohtasiini, whil. raising his glass to his lips, was informied that a certain Arab lady was takeni captive by a Ureek lord. On hearing this, MIohtnsim ordered out.a band of lheroes, mounted on 300,000 piebald steeds, rescued the lady, slew the barbarian, and then, and not till then, quenched his tllirst from the vessel whlich he had before raised to his lips and set down untasted. One or twvo sentences of Arabic whwich are given in the course of thle poem aro miserably misquoted, whether by the author's fault or that of his printer we knowv not. On the whole, however, the work is a very pleasinig one, and may be cordially recommended to any one who wishes to make himself acquainited with the sentiments and legendary lore of our Indian fcUowsubjects.

Title: Recent Poetry

RECEVT POETRY.
II.
'_he third series of " Songs of Two Worlds," by "A New Vriter" (Henrv S. King and Co., London. 1875), is not unworthy of its predecessors. It presents the same command of metre and diction, the same contrasts of mood, the same grace and sweetness, perhaps the same strength and weaeness, ns the volumes which have already met with so favourable a reception. WYe confess the title is still a puzzle to us. Perhaps it wvas meant by its author to be an enigma with more than one solution, and, as Ave have no taste for that kind of guessing, we prefer to let it go unsolved. "A NeL\w Writer " owves some of the popularity his poems have achieved to the way in wvhich they harmonize wFith some passing mood of contemporary thought. The perplexities and strivings of modern thought and the bewildering contrasts of muodern life are the chief theuies of " A New Writer." Subjective poetry, to borrow the useful phrase of a criticism now almost obsolete, is, perhaps, the most difficult poetry of all to treat wvith supreme success, and the poetry of " Songs of Two Worlds " is intensely subjective. Nevertheless, though it needs a master hand to handle such themes with perfect success so as to bring light to the world from the smoke and heat of the struggle, it behoves us to do justice to the " New Writer's " merits in the line of work he has chosen for bimself. He has ample command of musical and vigorous diction, and of varied and skilful rhythm. It is true that in " Evensong," the most considerable poem in the present volume, the line of demarcation between philosophic and poetic diction is not very clearly observed, and the thought is not completely fused in the poetry. Thus, such a line as " How atom with atom at first fortuitously combined " is an ingenious and praiseworthy attempt to fit philosophy to metre, but it reminds one rather of the drearyspeculations ef Lucretius than his magnificent bursts of poetry. The poem, howvover, as a whole, Is vivid and suggestive, if not entirely satisfying. But to take a comrmon and familiar object and show forth its ideal side with graceful skill and delicate imagination, to see the poetry and the pathos of daily life is the special powver which " A New Writer " possesses, and this he enjoys to a degree wvhicb poets of greater range might envy. In a former volume a poem called " The Organ Boy " struck this note with considerable force and power. It is, perhaps, still the best example of " A New
Vriter's" special and intrinsic poetic faculty. In the " Org,an Boy " the contrast between Italian
ivilization, ancient and modern, andthat of England iS finely wrought. Somethling of the same note is struck again in the " Street Children" of the present volume, but we fear it shares the proverbial fate of repetitions. Many of "A New WYriter's" siighter poems are reaUy songs, and could they find a sympathetic composer would afford a welcome relief to the vapid monotony of ordinary drawing-room music. It is ditlicult to see why amidst the inexhaustible wealth of English verse so much trash should be thought good enough for musical treatment and tolerated both in pu'Dlic and private. On the whole it cannot be denied that "A New WVriter" has won a definite position among contemporary JEnglish poets. If we cannot as yet place him in the front rank, yet he has written enough to showv that he has powers which may some dav make good his claim to it. At present, it is true, his themes lack variety, and his treatment independence,but lie is always thoughtful as well as graceful, and frequently vivid.
*" it and Humour," by the late genial editor of IPunch (Bradbury, Agnew, and Co., London, 1875), is a collection of verses which have from tiue eto time appeared in that periodical. "It shouldbe borne in mind," says Mr. Shirley Brooks's son in a brief preface, " how these poems were written. There was no time for choosing of epithets, for weighing of phrases, for polishing of liiies; there was no time to wait for favourable seasons and conditions, they had to bo written from week to week in whatever bodily pain or mental grief their author might chance to be. Many of the epigrams in this volume which seem the most higghly polished were written off impromptu,and even of the longer poems -to give an example of the rapidity wvith wvhich they were produced-' The lRime of the Ancient Alderman' was begun and finished in an hour." It is inevitable in a volume of verse composed in such a manner that there should be much which has but an ephemeral interest. But the volume wvill serve pleasantly to beguile an idle hour, and it will hereafter be of real value to the student of conteinporary manners and politics. Unfortunately, there is nothing which so quickly loses its interest as occasional verse of a humorous cast. The secret of its success lies in its hitting the mood of the passing moment, and its essence is so volatile that it evaporates in a few days. It is no slight testimony to the vigour and versatility of Shirley Brooks's peculiar talent that so much that he wrote retains a permanent interest, and will bear reading again whenthe special occasion which called it forth is forgotten. It is impossible to characterize briefly the contents of a volume so varied, or to single out special parts for commendation where so much deserves it, but the writer seems to us especially felicitous in parodies and brief epigrams. " The Baby in the House " must lhave hit Mr. Coventry Patmore very hard. " Gladstone Unmasked " is so clever a parody of " the Spanish Cloister " that Mr. Browning himself must be almost inclined to forgive it. Mr. Tennyson has more reason to complain. "H ome they brought her hipdog dead " is amusing enough, but the exquisite song it mimics is scarcely a fit subject for such a travesty. The volume contains several sets of verses of a more serious type. It often fell to Shirley Brobks's lot to have to write the " In MIemoriam " verses in which Punch from time to time records the nation's mourning for distinguished men, and he acquitted }iumself of the difficult task with unfailing grace and feeling. It cannot be denied that there is much in this entertaining volume vhich reads rather flat, and though the editor boasts of the wealth of his material, -we are not sure that ho would not have exercised a sound discretion in rejecting a good deal of wlhat he has retained. Flat champagne is not an exhilarat-
ing oeverage, anr wlen Jokes are stale, they need more than ephemeral wit to carry them ofi Still, c.onsidering the circumstances of hurry and pressure under wvhich many of these poeins were produced the reader will probably be disposed to judge the least attractive of them as leniently as possible. Versatility, promptitude, abundant wit, an unfailing command of varied metre, a fertility and aptitude of allusion, and unflagging good-humour are qualities rarely found in suclh profusion as that exhibited byShirley Brooks. Mlany of his poems are as amusing now as when they were first penned, and this is much to say of jeux d'eaprit which were all prompted by a passing occasion; even if some of them haye lost their flavour, they were probably quite as highly appreciated on their furst appearance. It is only just to add that, though his satire is often keen and his wit sharp, he is always generous, and the volume does not contain a single bitter or ill-natured sarcasm.
The " Poetical Worka of SydneyDobell" (Smith, Elder, and Co., London, 1875), have been published in a collected form, with an Introductory Notice and Memoir by Professor Nichol, of Glasgow. They cannot be strictly reckoned among recent poetry, for Sydney Dobell died a year ago, in his 51st year, and, as his biographer tells us, " his literary labours may be said to have well nigh closed with his 30th." But this is the first collected edition of his poems that has appeared, and in their present form they make a fresh appeal to a new generation of readers. What the result of that appeal may be it is very difficult to say. There can be no doubt that the author of " The Roman " was a poet, and a poet of very high quality. Had he fulfilled in later years the promise he exhibited in his first poem, there is no living poet whom he might not have rivalled. In " The Roman " there is vigour, originality, melody, dramatio force, tenderness, and political fervour enough to make the reputation of half-a-dozen minor poets. It has its faults, it is truo; it is immature in conception perhaps, and somewhat monotonous in structure, and the blank verse is disfigured byS the tuo frequent use of the eleven-syllable line ; but it is undoubtedly a work of power and genius, and alone would vindicate Sydney Dobell's claim to a recognized place among Enalish poets. Of "Balder" it is more difficult to speal- decidedly; it may be as Professor Nichol declares, a poem for poets, but it is undoubtedly a tax on the patienco of ordinary mortals. We may be permitted- to rejoice that it was never completed on the scale which the author projected. Its structure bears the same relation to an ordinary drama that a Dutch laudscape, without figures, where the monotony of swindmills is only brokeni by the mhonotoug of poplar avenues,
hoar:to tinarv acener.-It is an in terminable monot
logue varied only by "pauses" and "interludes of music " (left, no doubt, respectively to the discre.ion and imagilatiOn of the reader), and not very mUelOdious SOllgs. It contains noble passages anud splendid hoists of poetry it is true ; but thes3 are bot enough to make a great poem. Perhaps the best criticism on it iz that *written by the autlior himself :-" Poetry, by w.hatsoever other qualities it be distinguished, has this common characteristic -that it will live. AWhether, therefore, this work be poetry or not, I think its assailant may equally claim our condolence. On the one hand lie assaults it to no detriment but his own ; ou the other, I liave imposed on him the labour of killing wvhat, if it can die, should never have been born." Perhaps it is not unfair to add that whein a ccrpse is found, thepresumptiun is equally strong-infavour of suicide as in that ut mnurder. " Balder" was not very successful at its first appearance, though the author of " The lRoman" was a man whose 'aterary reputation was sufficient to sec-rre him a swecis d'estiine at least. If it could not live when it wvas first published we fear its vitality is not likely to be increased by age. There is truth and force in Professor 2Nichol's judgment of his friend's poem. " Every part of a consummate 'work of art ought, like the hand or foot of a finished org-anism, to bear evidence of its purpose. Did the ' Inferno' stand by itself it would still have a terrible unity. Mr. Dobell's tragedy is not only incomplete, but confusedly chaotic." We fear th-at the admiration and even adulation of his' friends to which Professor Nichol's memoir bears abundant witness, may have been injurious to the developmient of Sydney Dobell's genius. He was educated at home, and pursued his mature studies under no better gsudance than Iis own. He lived apart from the great world, and tho singular charm of his personal character seems to have disarmed the wholesome criticism of those who surrounded him. Hence he never learnt to correct Iiis faults, and gave the rein to a wayward, and, perhaps, somevhat morbid genius. Balder" contains the materials of a great poem no doubt, and "The Roman" very nearly is one. But the uncorrected faults of the earlier poem are reproduced and multiplied in the later. The theme of " Balder" is less interesting and its treatment is more prolix and monotouous. Thehalf of it is certainly greater than the wvhole, and a tenth of it would be more likely to live than either. The poems entitled " Sonnets on the War," and " Enoland in Time of War," are just what might have been expected from the author of " Balder" and " The Roman." They contain much that is attractive, much that is indifferent, and not a little that is positively repulsive. If their better strains provoke an unfavourabie comparison with the poet who wvrote "M Milton, thou shouldst be living at this hour," the parallel is still more to the disadvantage of Sydney Dobell in their wreakest. parts. It is a pity Sydney Dobell's friends were not ashamed to reprint " The Orphan's Song," "W Vind," "Farewell," and others, which do not seem to us to rise above the level of doggrel. Mr. Dobell's latter years were saddened by failing health, and his public literary efforts ceased when he was little over 30. It is possible that his early poetical impulse wvas quenched in suffering, and that he had not the patience to undertake the task of revising his poems, and rejecting those which a mnaturer taste must have condemned. WVe cannot but think that the editors of the present volume would have been -wise had they su pressed some of these poems; at least, they would have raised a more enduring monument to their friend's memory. Some poets live in selections when the bulk of their worlks has passed into oblivion. There is mucll of Sydney 3obell's work that deserves to live in this way, but there is not a little that his greatest admirers might -well wish to be forgatten. It is difficult to believe that the same man was the author of the best and the worst poems which these two volumes contain. They are a striking proof that real genius is not inconsistent with the most childish and wvaywvard taste.
