It must affect us like music or wvine, but it must certainly have wvisdom, like an instinct, directing it from vithin. Every excellent poetic work has a physiognomy of its own, an organic character of its o-n, the possession or non-possession of which the world will sooner or later sympathetically determine." This is a bold appeal to the judgment of the world, and we are not quite sure that the verdict will satisfy the appellant. There are many names transmitted to posterity, says a witty French critic, which never reach their address, and it is just possible that posterity may have very little to say about M1r.
Scotts - -oems." -ixternal and adventitious merits, to use his own test, they, no doubt, have in abundance. They are rhythmical, varied, picturesque, vivid, but -we cannot find in them much of the stuff of which immortal poems are made. As for " wisdom," we are not quite sure that we understand what Mlr. Scott means by it. We look for such a quality in a didactic poem, but it has not much place in a ballad or a descriptive piece. WVe certainly look in vain for it, in its ordinary sense, in such a poem as " Tuie Duke's Funeral ;" in this poem, wshich stramngely enough comes underthe heading " Studies from Nature," and in the sonnet " On certain Critics at the beginningof tho Century," there is, in our judgment, neither wisdom nor dignity. Mr. Scott is more successful in Lis " Ballads " than in the rest of his work ; his more serious and, so to speak, personal poems leave the reader cold and unumoved, but the B.3allads are vigorous and musical. Mlr. Scott felt early the influence of that revived medi.evalism, wfhich, like tbe earlier Romanticism in France, took so strong a hold of our leading poets and artists a quarter of a century ago. The Ballads are a product of this influence; if they bear the marks of arevivalin a sliaht lack-of spontaneity and simplicity, they are skilful imitations, though even here Mr.
bcott's eltorts nave been surpassed by the more finished performance of his friendl, M!r. D. G. Rossetti. Ve could wish Air. Scott had been more sparina in tha use of obscure and irrelevant burdens in some of his poems of this character. They serve, no doubt, to exhibit the poet's sldll, but wre doubt if the reader is not gonerally tempted to skip them and to get at the drift of the poem undisturbed by such troublesome interruptions. In Mr. Rossetti's " Sister Helen " the burden is so wrought into tahe texture of the poem that it enhances its weird force, and gives it unity and purpose. But Mr. Scott's burdens are too often grotesque acnd unmeaning, or, at least, their meauing is so far-fetched and obscure that they mar instead of aiding the effect of the poems in which they occur. I'oets addicted to ballads with burdens should bear in mind the immortal parody of C. S. C.-" Butter and eggs and a pound of cheese ;" the memory of this homely line has spoilt the fortunes of imany a pretentious ballad. We cannot call 2r. Scott's first-rate poems, but the reader will find in this vol-ume much melodious verse, muchgraceful description,some line reflective sonnets, and little of positive failure. The attractiveness of the volume is considerably enhanced by the illustrations. I1r. Scott's Jkijll as an artist is well known, and that of Mr. Tadema needs no commendation from us. The three etchin's of "Love Originating Art" "An Old Chest,'? and "Pygmalion " are quite chirming. Mr. Scott tells us that MIr. Tadema's illustrations are his first efforts with the etching point, and he favours us wivith his own opinion as to their success. We hesitate to differ from a critic whose judgment is so much respected, but we seem to de'ect in Mr. Tadema's drawings some traces of his unfamiliarity with his instrument. " The Great Sphinx " is very fine, but " Fair Rosamond " is stiff and somewhat ungainly, the background of " Eric aud tne Waterwitch" is sbapeless and confused, while parts of " Lady Janet" are grotesque and almost hideous. Nevertheless, the illustrations, as a whole, are so far above the level of ordinary works of the ldnid as to belongtoadifferentcategory.lVhatever opinion may be formed of Mr. Scott's merits as a poet, his gifts as an artist, and those of his friend,will render his volume acceptable.
" The Ship in the Desert" is the title of a new poem of the Far West, by Ir.Joaquin Miller (London, Chapman and Hall, 1875). The author is well and favourably known to the public Irom his earlier works " Songs of the Sierras" and " Songs of the Sun Lands." America has produced several poets and a good deal of verse, but with the exception, perhaps,of Walt Whitman, none of its native singers bear a more genuine impress of its soil and life than lMr. 3,Miller. %Vhitnman is the noet of democracy
andl the future, 1.r. lVliler of pioneers and thprairies. The " Ship in the Desert" is a series of transcripts of the sueeiery and life of the Westein deserts, strung together on a sli_ht and rather ubscure story. lt is evident froim the preface that Mr.I Miller does not set much store by tbe narrative part of hiis litest wvork. * Thle world," he says, "w will have its way, anid, like a spoilerl child, demands a tale." His ow-n taste is for " sceines and descriptions of a inigity land of mystery andl wild and savage graudeur" as lie fnds ther on the banks of the hidgher Nlissouri,-the Rockv Mountains, and the plhaiis of Upper California, the weird and desert craule of the Aztec race. Btnt a poemn canl scarcelv be made up wholly of descriptions, and AIr Miller has shown in his former works that he can fit his descriptions of the scenery he loves wvith appropriate motives of human feeling and passion. Perhaps the pictures of the scenery he dascribes are enhanced bv the dfeampv and unsolved mystery of the tale he tells ; but we agree vith lhim that it is but a " slight thread of fiction," and though not inappropriate it mi?ht have been wrought out nmore fully and developed to greater purpose. However this may be, 1r. MIiller's descriptions are fresh, vigorous, poetic ; they bear the stamp of personal and loving observation; as we have said, they are genuine prod nets of a gennune American minse. 'The following brilliant picture from the preface, vwhich will remind many readers of Walt Whitman by its concentration and directness, is alumost a summary of the poem
The frail and baffeted rafts on the river, the women and children huddled together, the shouts of a thousand men as they swam vith the bellowing cattle; the cows in the stormy stream, eddying, whirling, spinning about, calling to their young, tkeir bright lhorns shining in the sun. . . . The wild men waitinO on the other side, painted savages leaning silent on their bows, despising our weakness, opening a way, letting us pass on to the unknown distances, where they said the sun and moon lav dowrn together and brought forth the star,. . . . The long and wvinding lanes of waggons, the graves by the wryside, and women'weeping together as they passed on. Then hills, then plaiLns,palched lands hlke Syria, dust, and ashes, and alkali, cool streams with vwoods, camps by night, great wood fires in circles, tents in the contre, like C:esar's battle camps, painted men that passed hke shadows, Showers of arrows, the wild beasts howling from the hll.t
'These are sonme of the scenes wlhich MInr Miller describes with considerable force and poetic insight. I3is feeling for the Wlrestern world is genuine and intense; and there is, perhaps, no finer passage in the volume than that wherein he commeemorates the forgotten labours and
"The still endurance of the rude, unpolished sons of
solitucde."
The pioneers of Western civilization. His versification is flowing and graceful, though occasionaLy disfigured by a too uncouth colloquialism.
" ' She sleeps uncommon sound,' he said,"
is a specimen of the rare freaks of imperfect taste in an otherwise very striking poem.
F'rom the Far West to the Far East the transition is easy, and the joiuney from the Pacific seaboard to the shores of China is a common one. It is not often that China furnishes a theme to an English poet, but in ." Yu-Pe-Ya's Lute" (London, Macmillan, 1874), MIrs. Augusta Webster has sought her inspiration from this uncommon source. The tale is founaed on a Chinese legend, translated under the title of " Le Luth Brse," by BE Pavie. The story is very slight, and loses much of its delicate charm when reduced to simple prose. YuPe-Ya is a high-born and wealthy noble, and a consumunate master of the mystery of music and the lute. In his travels he meets with a peasant, TseKy, whose musical skill is revealed by the mystic sympathy of the lute. Yu-Pe-Ya at first scorns his lowvly craft-fellow, but soon discovers that his command of the instruiment and its lore is not inferior to his own. Thereupon a friendship springs up between the two, and Yu-Pe-Ya invites Tse-ky to accompany him to the great city ; the latter refuses, as his aged parents are supported by his labour, and the new friends part, Yu-Pe-Ya promising to come back shortly and seek out his brother in song. After a year he returns, and as the summons of lds lute brings no response from Tse-Ky, he sets out to seek his dwelling. On his way he meets an old man, Lao-Pay, who turns out t, be Tse-Ky's father, and from him he learns that Tse-Ky is dead. LaoPay conducts him to Tse-Ky's grave, over which Yu-Pe-Ya breaks his theasured lute, and then he returns sorrowfally to the city, having taken upon himself, as a pledge of his brotherhood for Tse-Ey, the burden of supporting his lost friend's parents. Such is an outline of the story told with skill and delicacy bv Mrs. 'Webster. Ve hate here an Oriental theme, and the motives it deals wvith seem s;trange enough to WVestern ideas, but -IMrs. WVebster has managed to invest it with a tender interest. So attempt is made to makce it an accurate transcript of Chinese sentiment or life, nor to deck it vwith what is commonly called local colouring. This is, perhaps, wise. Chineselife and manners are so unfamiliar to our literature thiat to transplant them without modification is the -work rather of science than of poetrv. But Doetry is -well eDtitled to take a striking theme from any source, and treat it according to its own fancy. This is -what Mrs. Vebster has avowedly done. " Yu-Pe-Ya's Lute " is slight, but it is graceful and attractive. The versification is very smooth and sweet, and several of the songs-especially " WVaiting, waiting "-are beautifuL Taken for vhat it is, a simple treatment of an exotic theme, with no claim to be called a great or original poem, " Yu-Pe-Ya's Lute " achieves a success which is denied to many more pretentious efforts. It is a quaint and pleasing trifle, all the more attractive that it afibrds at least a glimpse into a life and literature which to maost English readers is as strange as that of another
planet. __ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

AIIr Camueron has, accordingly, determined that these illustrations of Tennyson should appear in a separate volume in their untouched state, and in this determination she has been strengthened by the desire of the poet himself as wel as of many artists. It has been Nlrs. Cameron's ambition in illustrating Tennyson to catch as far as possible the ideal character of the subjects, and, as Milton says of mUusic, so to treat tho pnet's noble conceptions that her art too might he "married to immortal verse." This principle of illustration may be well exemplified in the case of Artiur himself, theflos cyguin, " the blameless King." How difficult such artictic treatment of a great subject is, and, at the same time,how severe Mrs. Cameron's judgment has been on her own attempts, is proved by the fact that befora satisfactory photographs of these 12 plates were pioduced no few,er than 200 plates Mwere taken. Such fastidiotis perseverance brings indeed its owln rev;ard in the consciousness that nothing has been left undone to make these illustrations perfect. May their success encourage others to enter on the same field wvith something of the same genius and spirit; in that case we nmay hope to see poetry illustrated vwith nmore reality and life than are to be found in the meagre attempts hitherto produced.
Turning- now to the plates tbem selves, the frontispieca of the volane is a lively representation of Tenny:on himself, which gives the character of tbo poet in all his serious thoughtfulness, "full of noble things." Next comes a scene from "Gareth and Lynette," where in a care-

In rendering this scene T4rs. Cameron-us, indeedi, it is but fair to say she has been all throuah the volume-has been most fortunate in her models. Nothing can exceed the beauty of the slumbering knight, nor tho tender grace of the maiden whho leans over him and touches him gently with her hand. :No. 2 is a well-known scene from "Geraint and ,Enid," whe.e she arrays herself in "a faded silk, a faded mantle, and a faded veil," at her husband's bidding. We know nothing in photographic manipulation that surpasses the skill and grace with wvhich the white tints are produced in this plate, a feat which, we may observe, is repeated in No. 6, "Lancelot and Elaine," perhaps the finest plate in the volume, as well as in No. 9, where we see the guilty Queen, and how she-

No. ( is a scene from the same Idyll, where Vivien has had her will and heard the charm, and Merlin lies as dead in tho hollow oak , " lost to life and use and name and fame." In this case we may mention that the hollow oak in which Merlin is represented us sunk to sleep is one which stands in the grounds of the Poet himself at Farringford, near Freshwater, in the Tile of Wight, near which place Mr Cameron heraelf resides. The pure, passionless faces of the spirituial lovers are rendered with a sober grace, wbich is a fitting preparation for Nos. 10 and 11, both taken from " Guinevere," the first when, as we have already said,shemoved about her paLace proad and pale, thinking herself slighted by Lancelot; the second where, whon Lancelot still lingered in spite of the Queen's warning-

This photograph, which represents the passionate greeting of the guilty pair just before their detection by Arthur, many will think the fineBt in the book. It probably is tle finest in grouping and composition; but for ourselves wev adhero to oiur old love and admire Elaine the most. Full_text:
MRI. AATMAZEW ARNOLD'S NBW POEMS.+
A critic does not often vwrite poetry. But Mr. 3Iatthewr Axrnold was a poet before ho was a critic. Iai his criticisnms-whether this be to their praise or blaae-he is still something of a poet, and in his poetrY he is aiuch of a critic. Thero was a time *hen he sang for singing's sake; and the melodv of tome of those strainus is still pleasant to tlle ear. But his "Shepherd's Holyday" has, he laments been lost many a year; and if ever he wvrites now it 2slr-nifestly because he has something to tell.
z!Ldtama on Empedocles,-the bard,the orator,the Dl1aster of the great sophist, Gorgias, the philo60pher who vvaudered over the earth subduing naature, whether by science or by magic, the patriot who expelled tyrants, and might have been himself a king, now worshipped as a god, now an exile,and the story of his mysterious end on Etna, comnmences this long-defefred volume. it is all attempt to showv that Thought mayprove a taskmaster as cruel as Sense. Empedocles, compelledto fly the debasing society of mankdin on pain of absence fromI himself, had.sought refuge with Apollo inhis moonlit peaks and caverns. But the votary of the God, " youthful but scornful," and " intolerably severe," finds that he has escaped the slavery of sense only to have wandered far from his own soul, to have become-
" Thought's slave and dead to every natural joy-
. . . . a living man no more,
" Nothing but a devouring flame of thought, " But a naked, eterually restless mind."
He will not return and seek shelter from himself in the companionship of men,whom he denounees as a people of children, who asked of him, the inspired sage, not wisdom, btt "sDells to mutter," and listen gladly to the sophist brood which overlays the last spark of man's consciousness with words. And his pitiless solitde nmaddens him. Bandied between the two he longs for rest, to be resolved into hsis "well-tried friends and ministers," the elements, fiom which he came. But on the brink of death he pauses, terrified by his own reasoning, that, when death comes, the mind, the thought, if we have suffered them to be the master part of us, will, since they, unlike the body, can have no parent element to return to, forbid the material parts from returning to their several elements -to earth, wvater, fire, air:-
But we shall still be in them (miad and thought), and
they in us,
"And we sball be the strangers of the world,
"And4hey will bo our lords as they arc now; ":And keep us prisoners of our consciousness, "And never let us clasp and feel the All
"'Bat through their fornis, anud modes, andstifling veils. " And we shaU be unsatisfied as now,
"And we shall feel the agony of thirst,
" The ineffaolo longing for the life of life
"Baffled for ever; and stiu thought and mind
"Will hurrv us with them on their homeless march."1
For such he believes to be the doom of those who have not reverenced the harmony of their nature, but have let one part play thle tyrant over the soul, and so, becoming isolated from the general universe, have fallen away
'nlto some bondage of the flesh or mind,
" Some sloughl of sense, or some fantastic maze
" Fored by the im erious lonely thinking power ;" who have, in short, Teen disloyal to their
"i Oew only true deep-buried selves,
' Being one wvith which we are one with the whole world." We confess to rather grudging the prominence and space assigned by the author to this very undramatic drama. Yet the conception of Empedocles is fine, though not sufficiently beaten out; and there is a ringing sweetness in the contrast of the sombre complainings of the old !self-doomed prophet on the charred, blackened, melancholy waste above, with the joy9us music, far down in the greon and dewy glades, of the boy Callicles, "the sweetest harp-player in Catana," who has followed him through the night to chann away with his lyre the gloom which, 'with a poet's subtle intuition, he appreciates more truly than the master's wisest disciples, but fancies might be soothed away, like his own, by the mere spectacle of " the lovely mountainpaths"
"What mortal could be sick or sorry here 1"
The two several utterances, seer's and harper's, in their rise and fall, seem to melt together into a dialogue; and the Tennysonian grace of the minstrel's tale of Cadmus and Harmonia in their Illyrian glen, or Typho writhing under Etna, and letting the seastream wander through his hair, compensates for the twenty-three preceding pages, through which Empedocles has been " accompanying himrself in a soleman manner on his harp," the merit of which, whatever else it may be, Mr. Arnold will acknowledge is hardly the merit of poetrv.
The poem was printed some years ao, though soon withdrawn from circulation; and its real date is legible everywhere. Yet Mr. Arnold is justified in now issuing it as a " new " poem, by the very distinct unity of philosophical conception traceable between it and its later-born companions. There is, indeed, a sort of undesigned conthiuity running through all the poems in the volume, which gives them a- common interest independent of their different degrees of individual poetical merit. Everywhere we find marked the same impatience of isolation, ifi respect whether of physical or social existence, or of idceas. The fear of the Sicilian that, in the several e.lements of his being,he may be debarred after this life friom reunion with universal nature, takes the form, in the later poems, of a cravinig to be emancipated,at least in dying, from the local eddies of humani life, to be confronted alone with Nature, with
"The world which was era I was born,
"The wvorld which lasts wheon I am dead. "Which never was the friend of one,
"Nor pronmised love it could n ot give, "But lit for all its generous sunu
" And lived itself, and made us live"and so at last
" To feel the universe my home."
The horror of Empedocles at being doomed to dwvell, " far from my own soul," in a web of ideas spun by the inteUect, reappears later under the reiterated complaint that we Englishmen travel otir round of labour,
"And never once possess our soul "Before we die.
The feeling of the need of living the life of the " soul," that is of living in tlle whole and not only in part of our being,as it was the clue to the self-reproaches of the votary of Apollo for havina wasted his life in disputing with folly, so it is the motive of the poet's lament for his friend Arthur Clough, the mnonody on wvhom, under the pastoral name of Tliyrsis, is, perhaps, the most charming poem in the avolumwe, that
" his piping took a troubled sound
" Of storms that rage outside our happy grouud; " He could not wait their passing."
And there is the samne apology for all his taunts against the present for its absorption in the present, forits blind hopes and blind despairs. The soulr he teaches, is alone worth living, or fighting, or dying for. It isi the Palladium of human life.
" Set where the upper streams of Simois flow
"Was the Palladium, high 'mid rock and wood; "And Rector was in Ilium, far below,
"Aud fought, and saw it uot, but there it stood.
"It stood; and sun and moonshine rain'd their light "On the pure columns of its glcn-built hall.
"Backward and forward roll'd the waves of fi7ht
"RoundTroy; but while this stood, Troy could not falL "So, in its lovely moonlight, lives the soul.
"Mountains surround it, and sweet virgin air"Cold plashing, past it, crystal waters roll; "We visit it by nioments, ah! too rare.
"Men will renew the battle in the lain
"To-morrow; red with blood will Xianthus be; Hector and Ajax will be there again, "Helen will come upon the wall to see.
"Then we shall rust in shade, or shine in strife,
"And fluctuate 'thixt blind hopes and blind despairs, And fancy that we put forth aU our life,
"Asid never kuow how with the soul it fares.
"Still doth the soul, from its lone fastness high. Upon our life a rujin effluence send -
"And when it fails, fight as we will we die, And while it lasts we cannot vwhollv end."
13ut, although thus a common ground for what may be considered the two divisions of the volume, is supplied by the idea, underlying both, of the harmaony of Nature in all its phases, and of man's duty to be loyal to his own " deep-buried self, the soul,"
as the only meansof vindicatig his place in the general system, another positive element is imported n3 ~the later portion.viz., a demand for sympathy,- not only with the universe, but specially
with our fellowY man, a refusal to bel
"Alone elate " While the world lies forlorn "
a looking forward to a possible future flood which shall sweep men free from a dead doctrine, nnd, still more, the dawning of a sense of obligation
" That end to help men gain:
" Ono mnighty wave of thought and joy i"Lifting mankind amain."
The negative side, however, is more strongly developed in the sentiment even of the later poems than the positive; even if much of what we have treated as positive may not itself from one poinit of
view be considered to be negative. Hardly a single poem except " Calais Sands," and a Bonnet or two,
but has its cry against what is accepted. Mfen are told to battle, but against what is, ratlier than for what ought to be; and, even so, in the hope not to win victoryliving but dead, Mr. Arnold's Psalm of Life is a requiem:-
" Creep into thv narrow bed,
"Creep, and let tiOmore be said !
'Vain thy onset! all stands fast;
Thou thyself must break at last. "Let the long contention cease !
"Geese are swans, and swans are geese.
Let them have it how they will! "Thou art tired ; best be still !
"They out-talk'd thee, hiss'd thee, tore thee. "Bettermen fared thus before tlee; "Fired their ringing shot and pass'd;
Hotly charged-and broke at last.
" hageonce more, then, and be dumb i
'Let tevnictors, when they come, 'I "When the forts of folly fall, "Bind thy body by tke waIl,
This, itself no jubilant ode of triumph, is sung over the champions of truth; for otlier combatants, triumphant in their own way, in the battle of life, a dirge of admirable dreariness is- suggested by the text, " What is it to grow old ?"-
It is-last stage of all.-
"When we are frozen up within, and quite "'The phautom of ourselves
To hear the world applana the hollow ghost "Which blamed the living man."
England, more than all other nations, seems to Mr. Arnold, as we all know, to have lost the keynote of the scale of her destiny; and, lettin-
"Slow die out of her life
"Glory, and genius, and joy":The wearyTitan ! with deaf
Ears and labor-dimm'd eyes, " Regarding neither to right, " or left, goes passively by.
Staggering on to her goal."
But so, too, the whole world about us is to him a chaos, which--
'?ath reaUy neitber joy, nor love, nor light,
Nor certitude, nor peace, nor help for pain; "And we are here as on a darkling plain,
Swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight, Where ignorant armies clash by night."
With tolerance, which is not eclecticism (but which, if poets were not privileged, and he were on his trial before a tribunal of the orthodox for the heresies of this volume, would hardly serve him), he holds, indeed, that to believe in som religion, however credulously, is better than to believe in none; for, among religions,-
" Which has not taught weak wills how much they can ? "Which has not fall'n on the dry heart like rain? Which has not cried to sunk, self-weary man, "Thon must be born again?"
But, speaking in the name of Obermann, he cries that the religion of the world at largel is a collection of dry bones-that a storm has split up the old beliefs, on fragments of which men go tossing about the open ocean, unconscious that they are severed from the shore, and thatChirist is dead again.
"While we belioved, on earth he went, "And open stood his grave.
"Men call'd from chamber, church, acd tent, "And Christ was by to save.
"Now he is dead. Far hence he lie
'In the lorn Syrian town,
And on his grave, with shining eyes, "The Syrian stars look down.")
Mr. Arnold reverences the living past 'le reverences even the faith in the dead past, by whose tomb its votaries watch and look for an awakening. He has not their hope; but he lingers by their side in sympathy with their grief. To the austere teachers of his youth, who ask-
"What dost thou in this living tomb?" J He answers-
"Not as their friend or child I speak!
F "But as, On some far northern stranld, T
" Thinking of his own gods, a Greek

But Mr. Arnold is a poet, and not the less so that he criticizes Homer and theorizes on his countrymen's lamentable deficiency in Geist. It is nearly a hundred and thirty years since Gray made the samo autumnal journey. The almost savage solemnity of nature, the nine trees hanging from the crags, tho thunder of the torrent, the clouds, impressed hint witlh more awe than the younger poet could spare from the human spectacle, from the contemplation of these
" Last of the peoplo who believe."
But, on the other hand, the poet of the eighteenth century, if he saw Spirits and Death in the ravine below, remarlced no terrors, or mystery, or gloom within the Carthusians' "solemn seats of holy pain" above, but only " extreme neatness," and "C wonderful decency, with nothing of finery."
Mr. Arnold's verse is aLways melodious,except by caprice, as in the strangely jarring close of "-eine's Grave," and in a few heedless rhymes. He can be, however rarely, carelessly graceful, as in "Calais Sands." He achieves didactic stateliness, as in the "Palladium." The "Epilogue to Lessing's Laocoon" and "Obermann Once Morc" showY -what powers of expression are at his command. He has a choice of Dead Mlarches, but rather sombre, like Beethoven, than triumphant, like Handel; and he absolutely revels in elegies,-from the dainty melancholy oE " Thyrsis," where the personality of the dead friend is nearlyhidden in the roses heapedover his memory, to the noble simplicity of "Rugby Chapel," whiclh is rather a funeral sermon by a son over a father than an elegy, and the bitter-sweetness, the quality in which Mr. Arnold most delights, of " Heine's Grave." Whether he have the gift of depicting the movement of life (according to him the peculiar province of poetry among the arts), by wvhich, in the "E]pilogzue to Lessing's Laocoon," he appears to signify a sympathetic intuition and power of representation of the shifting currents and groupings of life, cannot well be tested by a volume concerned almost exclusively with the poet's own moods. But so far as the movement of the inner individual beingand moods comes within the definition of the attribute, it is visible in " Heine's Grave," which is, indeed, too dramatic in essence to be worth quoting in fragments.
We have enumerated what apDear to us the chief poetical merits of the book. - In considering its shortcomings we feel for the first time conscious of a regret that Mr. Arnold is its author, and thus forbidden, lwO fear, by les convenances, to analyze and pass judgment on his own work, as no one certainly could moro subtly, or would more impartially. For ourselves we are contented to note something of apparent effort, a want of spontaneity and naturalness, but, especially, a want of terseness. This want of terseness and compression is the most serious charge, except the one great charge of intellectual fastidiousness, to which this volume lays Mr. Arnold open as a poet. He touches, and retouches, not an expression, like Gray, but a thought, till all its pleasant angles get wern away. He never seems able to pursuade himself that his readers can be trusted to draw a moral or complete an antithesis, or, even with both premisses given, deduce a conclusion for themselves. And yet even this troublesome tendency would appear hardly to be somethinginseparable from Mr. Arnold's genius. It undoubtedly blunts the edge of many noble thoughts in " Obermann Once More," and is the one fault of the poem on the Chartreuse. But in a sonnet he can be musical, yet brief and self-contained. "Immortality," or "The Good Shepherd with the Kid," would bear us out; but we quote in preference "A A Picture at Newstead," as exhibiting in addition the power of telling a story, as well as suggesting its lesson, which is Mr. Arnold's specialty as a sonnetteer:-
" What made my heart, at Newstead, fullest swell ?
'Twas not the thought of Byron, of his cry, ":Stormily sweet, his Titan agony;
"It was the sight of that Lord Arundel
"'Who struck, in heat, the child he loved so well, "And the child's reason flickered, anrd did die. "Painted (he will'd it) in the gallery
" They hang; the picture doth tho story tell.
" Behold the stern, mail'd father, staff in haud l " The little fair-hair'd son, with vacant gaze,
"Where no more lights of sense or knoxvledge are ! "Methinks the woe which made that father stand,
' Baring his dumb remorse to future davs.
"Was woo than Byron's woe more tragic far."
There is one other very conspicuous characteristic, we do not say defect, of the volume. We hardly, indeed, know whether to rank it amongr its merits or its defects that it is impregnated with allUsions, literary and historical. There may, it is true, be danger of temptation to malke extravagant draughlts on the associations clustering about great names and famous memories, wvhen a poet seems gifted with power by the spell of a line, or a word, -" Achilles pondering in his tent," " The wizard Merliniin his forest grave," " The walls whereByron came"-to conjure up aUlforl ' &Arthu,re, and Childe Hai-old, anld " the tale of Troy divine," to follow in bis train. But Mr. Arnold's allusions are always so much to the purpose, tinting, but not obscuring, his own conceptions, that the audience to whom chiefly he speaks, and whose intelligence is flattered by the constant appeals to it, will not have the heart to complain that the atmosphere of the volume appears absolutely to rustle witlh the wings of invisible spirits from all the four corners of literature.
Our catalogue of MIr. Arnold's defects appears soon closed; and it may be supposed that we anticipate wide popularity for a volume displaying such gifts as thoso to which we have directed attention. We dare anticipate no such thing. He has melody, grace, and power of expression. Within his own limits, and for his own class, he even has
"Charm, the glory wbtich makes "Song of the poet divine."
It remains to be seen whether these qualities will tempt the public, outside Mr. Arnold's public, to brave Mr. Arnold's intellectual morgue, or whether
popular curiosity, if not sympathy, can be roused to watch the development of an intellectual type more purely academical than perhaps English poetry has ever yet been made to reflect.

Mr. Frederick Locker, who now follows in the wake of the Laureate and of Mr. Browning, has a
genuine poetical gift, but he belongs to a peculiar class. In him is maintained the succession of that line of poets, from Suckling to Praed and Thackeray, whose effusions may perhaps best be described as masked poetry. The true feeling of the poet is masked with laughter. It is the poetry of men who belong to society; who have a keen sympathy with the lightsome tone and airy jesting of fashion ; who are not disturbed by the flippancies of smaU talk, but, on the contrary, can see the gracefulness of which it is capable; and who, nevertheless, amid all this froth of society, feel that there are depths in our nature which even in the gaiety of drawing-rooms cannot be forgotten. Theirs is the poetry of bitter sweet-of sentiment that breaks into humour, and of solemn thought that lest it should be too solemn plunges into lauginter. It is, in an especial sense, the verse of society. When society ceases to be simplo it becomes scepticaL Nor are we utterly to condemn this sceptical temper as a sign of corruption. It is assumeed in selfdefence, and becomes a necessity of rapid conversation. NVhen society is refined it begins to dread the exhibition of strong feeling, no matter whether real or simulated. If real, it disturbs the level of conversation and of manners, if simulated so much the worse. In such an atmosphere emotion takes refuge in jest, and passion hides itself in scepticism of passion. We are not going to wear our hearts upon our sleeves; rather thau that, we shall pretend to have no heart at all; and if, perchance, a bit of it should peep out, we shall hide it again as quicldy as possible, and laugh at the exposure as a good joke. If a lady in a baUroom finds that her back hair has escaped from the ligaments with which it is wonderfully and fearfully held together, the best she can do is to laugh; we may laugh at ourselves also when we give way to feeling and pass it off as a momentary weakness. In the poets who represent this social mood there is a delicious piquancy, and the way they play at bo-peep with their feelings makes them a class by themselves.
In this class M1r. Frederick Locker holds a good rank. He writes gracefully, andamidthe mockeries with which like the rest of his kind he amuses Us he shows just so much of his deeper nature as wiU establish between us a genuine sympathy, while we are stimulated and tantalized by the sauciness with1which when we are in full expectation of seeing emotion rise to its height he breaks into a smile, and seems to say that he was only jesting. This was the sort of temperament to which Mr. Thackeray had a strong leaning. He showed it in his own writing, andl he showed it in his appreciation of Mc. It is eight years since the first edition of London Lyrics was published, and we can trace a continual progress in the author's style since then; but he has much yet to do before his poems ciiu be accepted as finished works. And we insist upon this point because in the particular kind of poetry which Mr. Locker has attempted as most congenial to his tastes styl'e counts for much more than in any other kind. In other forms of poetry the fulness of the heart may excuse some roughness rof expression. In this the thing to be expressed is, so to speak, a jumble, a confusion of laughter and tears, sentiment mangled by scepticism. It is the business of the poet to make this mutilated sentiment endurable, therefore to smooth over the sense of mutilation by the finish of style, to reconcile the contradiction of passion and scoffing by the utmost delicacy of treatment that avoids alike roughness on the one hand ana commonplace on the other. The deadliest sin of all in such a style is commonplace. Title: Praed's Poems.*
Full_text:
PRABRDS POEMS.*
There is a species of poetry which was more in vogue in ante-Reform Bill times than it is at tho present day-a poetry which bears somewhat the same relation to the sablime genius of Shakespeare or Milton, that Clodion, orFiammingo, or even the Dresden China shepherds and ahepherdeses of the last century do to the sculpture of Praxiteles or Michael Angelo. Smoothly written ters de aociitf,
where a boudoir decorum is always preserved, I where sentiment never surges into passion, and humour never expands into boisterous merrimentexquisitely rounded and polished,-such was tho kind of poetry by whichWinthrop MIaekworth Praed won his reputation. In his peculiar walk he has never been surpassed, but his walk has ceased to be popular. Perhaps this is partly owing to the fact that the taste of the present day is opposed to delicate sentinentalism, and that this sort of verse, except in the hands of a master of the art, such as was the subject of our notice, is apt to degenerate into the pretty inanity which, except in a very few songs-such, for instance, as " I'd be a butterfly'characterizes the writings of the lateThomas Haynes Bayley.
Winthrop Mackworth Praed was the youngest son of Winthrop Mackworth Praed, seijeant-at.law, and for many years chairman of the Audit Board. He was born in London on the 26th of July, 1802. His mother died when he was about seven years old, but her place was well supplied by the care of an elder sister, and at eight years of age he was placed at Langley Broom School, near Colubrook, and after remaining there for four years was sent to Eton. At Eton his progress was rapid. From an early age he had shown a very remarkable poetic faculty, and his first efforts in English and Latin verse exhibit marked indications of the wit and fancy which were so conspicuous in his later writings. Some. of these pieces are to be found in the volumes beforeus, and they are interesting, inasmuch as they throw light on the formation of the author's mind.
In the year 1820 Praed set on foot the Apis Mat sa, and soon afterwards the tEonian. It is noon his contributions to the latter periodical that the brilliancy of Praed's early reputation was
founded, and is still maintained.|
PraedXi health was delicate, and his amusements were principally of an intellectual character. He was fond of chess, could beat all the boys of his own' age, and it in remembered that he was selected by a schoolfellow much older than himself-the celebrated Dr. Plsey, as an antagonist worthy of his skill. He stone in school theatricals, was exceedingly expert at the game of fives, and afterwards became an excellent tennis player. He was fond of whist, and spoke with effect at the debating society, and while still a schoolboy took a leading part in founding the Boys' Library.
Much was expected of Praed when he went to Cambridge in 1821. His scholarship was pre-eminently of the Etonian cast, and the following critical remarks by a friend of the poet are so much to the point that they ar given in his own words:-
"The character of Praedsratin and Greekerse Is peon.- lar. It is the exact translation, for the most part, of the same style and diction which he wielded with hardly greater ease in his native language. The same parkling antithesis, the same minute elaboration of fancy, whether employed in depicting natural or mental objects, and the mas aver present undercurrent of melaneholy are fonnd in both. Of a certain kind of Greek, adapted to the curious production caUed at Cambridge a Sapphic ode, and of a certain degree of Latin soholsrhip, competent toexprem alltheide3s necessarytohis verse, but not to sondthe depths, or exhaust the capacities of the language. he was master. His epigrams are, perhaps the most scholarlike of his productions in clasic verse - but it may be said of them all, what cannot be maid of many such exercises, that they were Greek and Latin poetry.'
The long list of Praed's academic honours proves that he worked hard at College. But he was no mere University bookworm. He was a constant speaker at the Union, where he was contemporary with Lord Macaulay; he cultivated generat literature, and mixed largely with his fellow atudents.
In the'autumnn of 1822 he became conneoted with. Mr. Charles Knight's Quarterly Magazine, and was soon its animating and directing spirit. Among the contributors were the Rev. John Moultrie, the Rev. Derwent Coleridge, (the author of the Memoir, excellent as far as it goes, from which these details are extracted), Lord Macaulay, Mr. Sidney Walker, and Mr. Nelson Coleridge.
The Quarterly Magazzne did not live long, and in 1826 a new periodical entitled the Brazcs Head was commenced by the same writers; however, notwithstanding the talent that Praed brought to its support, it failed to attract public attention, and it was abandoned after it had reached the third number. One of Praed'a most characteristic pieces " The Chaunt of the Brazen Head," first appeared in this miscellany. We extract a few lines which are very felicitous. The poem contains many light touches of fancy and feeling.

The year 1825 found Praed once more atEton, as private tutor to Lord Ernest Bruce and it was during his second residence there tiat he commenced the series of poetical contributions to the magazines, &c., of the day, which form a considerable portion of the volumes before us.
He was called to the bar in May, 1829. He went tha Norfolk Circuit, and was rising, rapidly into practice, when, in 1830, he was returned to Parliament for the borough of St. Germain's, and again for the same place in 1831. In 1832, after the passing of the Reform Bill, he unsuccessfully contested the boroulch of St. Ives, and to this period, we believe, may be attributed many of his exccellent political squibs. Of this most difficult species of composition he is said to have been a consummate master. Hlispoliticalwritingsare not included in the present volumes, but Mr. Coleridge holds out the hope that they may hereafter be reproduced in a collected form.
In 1834 he was returned for Yarmouth, and about this time he was successfully employed by the Duke of Wellington to defend him in the columns of the Morning Post agyainst the attacks of some of the Liberal papers.
Under the Ministry of Sir Robert Peel, in 1834 and 1835, Praed held the office of Secretary to the Board of Control, and, during the latter years of his life, that of Deputy High Steward of the University of Cambridge.
In the sumimer of 1835, while his hopes of public advancement were yet high, he was most happily married to Helen, daughter of Mr. George Bogle. Little remains to be told. His health began to fail
in 1838, giving serious anxiety to his friends, and though the vigour of his mind and the interest which he continued to take in public affairs still supported him, he grew rapidly worse, and expired in his own house in Chester-square on the 15th of July, 1839. Three editions of Praeds' Poems have been published inAmerica They are all, necessarily, very imperfect, but still they reflect great credit on their respective editors, and, indeed, on the American people who demanded them. The first edition was published in 1852. It is very incomplete, for it contains only some 50 pieces, and those not all by Praed. Yet, curiously enough, 'nearly all Praeds best poems are to be found in it; and this is satisfactory, as showing that the best poetry remains in the memory, and( is not easily allowed to sink into oblivion. It is significaint that when only a portion of a poem is gven in the American edlition it is always thebet

they do not appear in the present volumes, are fome lively couplets entitled " Chivalry at a Discount." We select one stanza as a fair sample of the whole, and should feel much obliged to the editor of this edition if he coiild inform us who wrote them, supposing Praed did not do so:-

There are several poems in the American edition which we believe were written by a Mr. Fitzgerald, such, for instance, as "gHobblodehoys " 4 A Letter from Miss Mortimer" "I Good Night 'J " A Chapter of Ifs," &c. They are by no means tad verses, but besides being more or less imitations they lack the vigour and refinement of the master, and every now and then the cloven foot peeps out. But they contain some pretty lines, and there is a quatrain in " Good night," which is very picturesque, and will dwell in the memory.
And I, while my cab in a shower " Is waiting, the last at the door,

There are some exoellent verses in the Gem for the year 1831, called "M Mars Disarmed," which should also have been included.
As we have already remarked, we do not think that Praed's longer poems are as successful as his shorter pieces; but they are aU full of admirable touches. He hadva keen perception of surrounding influences, as well as powers of minute observation, and he added to these a bright and abundant fancy. He had also a wonderful gift of verse, and this, with his fertility of expression, was almost a snare to him. He is occasionally too diffuse to satisfy the rigid critic.
Mr. Coleridge's memoir states taat after Praed's death he was spoken of by Lord Russell as a rising statesman, but we are inclined to think that, if he had lived, his chief reputation would stiU have been that of a poet. His gifts were such as might, in some measure, have disqualified him from shining in the sterner and more earnest career of politics, though certainly the possession of the same sort of ability did not prevent Canning from taking a first rank as a statesman.
It is possible that these volumes have appeared at rather an unfortunate time. Mr. Tennyson is justly considered the first poet of the day, and the tendencr of the-lesser poets is to imitate hin. He is admired by the publicevenforhis mannerisms; and It is not, therefore, likely that Praed, who is opposed to him in nearly every respect, will at once attain the positionto which he is entitled. Some day a reaction will set in, and another fashion wiiU be in the ascendant. Then Praed, with Iiis idiomatic terseness and pith_4is distinctness of thought and accuracy of expression, will, perhaps, be as unduly elevated as he may now be depressed; but both he and Mr. Tennyson, in their respective a:Ls, winl always be looked up to as genuine poets, and that of no mean order.

Author: Null
Title: Professor Aytoun on Poetry and Dramatic Literature
Full_text:
PROEBS5OR AYTOUZV on POETRY and
DRAMA TIC LiTERA TURE.
Our eloquent and impassioned visitor from the far north has come and gone. He has found no churlish welcome in these soutnern parts. Fashion and beauty have hung upon his syllables, and an auidience, almost too delicate and refined to appreciate the Caledonian fare that has been set before them, have at least expressed their heartiest approval of the unexpected dish to which they have been treated. The Scottish minstrel has nothing to complain of. He may return to his native heather, seize his harp, summon his clansmen, and sing to them of the victory won over Saxon earls and blue-eyed maidens, descended from chiefs who once did battle with the Bruce. For ourselves, we acknowledge the grace of the genius that gave us for our delight the Lays of the Scottislh Cavaliers., We were of the firas to welcome the manly strains, and are-not disposed now to withdraw our spontaneous praise. But Mr. Aytoun is not only a successful poet, but also a learned professor. In the morning, when he is at home, he writes inspiriting verses for the world at large. In the afternoon he quietly descends from Pegasus-a very Shetland in his build and strength of limb-puts on his spectacles, and gravely lectures to the ingenuous youth of Edinburgh upon Rhetoric and Belles Latres. What if he has come among us, leaving half of his intelligent self in the Scottih capital, and that the very half which he was bound in common honesty to bring along with him? We have diligently attended the interesting and clever readings of Mr. Aytoun, and we must own that not on one occasion have we been fortunate enough to meet with the professor. The Scotch poet day after day has taken forcible possession of our ears, but the instructor, for all we know to the contrary, has been fast asleep in his Edinblurgh chair, taking needful refreshment after the laborious duties of the University session.
Mr. Aytoun has a poetic theory. He expounds it; but his exposition is delivered, enforced, and illustrated, not with the calm judgment and well balanced independence of a teacher, but with the impetuous and daring partiality of a devoted partisan,; and hence, though there is undoubted truth in his utterance, it is so mixed with unquestinnable error that we are but performing a necessary duty in briefly calling attention to the mistake which all Mr. Aytoum's hearers are likely to commit, if, upon the faith of the distinguished lecturer, they resolve benceforwardto look-upon-the broad field of literature from the only point of view at which he allows them to regard it. The substance of Mr. Aytoun's position is simply this :--Poetry is not poetry unless it be addressed to the ear; and even then it does notfulfil itsmission unlessthe ear be that of the common people. This is the definition. The national songster completes the syllogism by a very summary proces3. The Scotch ballads are addressed to the ear of the common people; therefore. the Scotch ballads constitute the only genuirie poetry in the British isles. If this be not the view of the latest of the Scoteb minstrels, we are puzzled to ascertain what other different view he laboured to impress upon the minds of his listeners.
The manner in which throughout the lectures this theory was illustrated was as 2ijef as the theory itself. Whenever Air. Aytoun thought it necessary to recite a ballad, he took care to select one of the noblest and most stirrino in the lan-guage, and to declaim it with all the emphasis and fervour at his command. Whenever he deemed it expedient to rehearse poetical compositions of any other sort, he generally exhumed the most worthless, and sent them forth with the shabbiest recommendation his voice could give them. Not, indeed, that he told
ou outright and in so many words that the verses were wretched and unworthy your regard. Not he! The professor is too far north for that. On the contrary, he professed vast esteem for the writers of the poems in question, and introduced them into that fashionable assembly at Willis' Rooms as dear friends whom he had long known, and whose acquaintance he should be sorry to dispense with. We have a dstinct recollection of the affectionate manner with which, for example, he presented to their Ladyships a most intimate and esteemed acquaintance who flourished in the Elizabethan period, and whose greatest fault was that he had imitated too closely the fancifuil style of Spensera poet, himself, much too fanciful for the upholder ef the paramount claims of the Scottish minstrelsy. No wonder the ladies tittered when they saw the gentleman. His hat was over his eyes, his nankeen trowsers did not reach to his half-boots, his coat sleeves were hanging over his hands down to his knees, and his toes were turned in. " This, ladies and gentlemen," said the courageous professor, " is my valuedfriend, the Spenserian poet. Respect him for my sake, and cutivate his society." Not a smile was on the professor's countenance, though his tongue was in his cheek. Well, we cannot say-we have never seen a duke in the uniform of Dusty Bob; but his Grace could hardly look more ridiculous in the costume than British poets appeared when dragged to light, from time to time at Wil is' Rooms, by their obliging friend, the Professor of Rhetoric and Belles Letres in the University of Edinburgh.
"I do not try to do what I could not," exclaimed Professor Aytoun, with much manliness, during one of his earlier lectures; " I do not seel; to hide mly Scotch accent from you. Take me as I am." Let it be so, and we shall love the man; for we all love
ationality, true genius, high courage, noble sentiments, audgraceful utterance. Certainly we caunot consent to take our late accomplished visitor for what he is not. It -was pardonable-it was moreit was heroic in the Scotch professor to deliver his lectures on poetry and dramatic literature before an EIdinbuirgh audience, and to treat half the illustrious names known to English literature with comparative contempt, wvhile he was placing Scott upon apedestal just lower than that of Shakspeare, but higher far than those of Chaucer, Milton, Spenser. AVe will add that it was a daring if not a desperate act to repeat, without the alteration of a line, in the broad streets of London, doctrines originally intended for a select and sympathizing audience, less solicitous for the fame of dead English poets than for the glorification of their own beloved and classic land. BIut heroism and coiuage are one thing, and true criticism is another. The former Professor Aytoun has exhibited in abundance; the latter we take leave to say we have yet to receive at his hands. His lectures are not lectures upon poetry and dramatic literature, but upon the excellence of ballad poetry, interspersed with occasional remarks, just and unjust, upon the English writers. It is ctirious to observe that, in the course of these lectures upon English poetry, Paradise Lost was scarcely referred to, even by name; Chaucer was introduced -with au apology; Pope with condemnation; Ben JonsonNithpity; Beau montandFEletcher with an accusation that they never wrote a line with a love for their art, Moore with a rebuke for his Eaqtern stories; and all the dramatists, from Massinger down to Congreve and Farauhar, with indiguation and contempt. The Scotchmen alone have no blots -upon their pages. Scott will endure as long as true poetry is understood; Campbell is faultless; and they who wrote the ancient ballads are of course immortaL This is the gist of the six lectures just delivered in London; but we warn the
brilliant auditory to beware how they take the Iinstruction home without further counsel and advice. This Edinburgh laddie hath a fascinating style; but I he wrote the Bon Gautier ballads as well as the Scottish lays, and is as sharp at satire as he is sweet in song.
One word as to his theory. There can be little doubt that the professor utters a broad and general truth, when he asserts that poetry should. be written as if it were meant mainlv for the ear and heart, and not for the eye and intellect of the listener. The music of a poem is as essential to its acceptance as perfume to the flower. The first poetry was recited bythe poetto his audience, and this origin should never be lost siglt of as characteristic of the art; a *true poet will frame his verse under the consciousness that it is to be pronounced with passionate emphasis in ears that are constrained to hear by the melody and power of the music. Sympathy between the poet and his readers is maintained only by a_ vivid progress of passion, and can be protracted only to the degree that the former imagines that others are lingering on his lay. But is there no music in the organ tones of Milton, in the exquisite strain of ;3penser, in the happy and exuberant verse o Tlhomas Mfoore? I:Es there no passion but the vehement and turbulent? The passion of the poet isa-strongpossessing affection, alivewith pleasure aUd pain, and specifically, Moved by the theme or occason. Will the professor of Belles Lfres insistthat,in order to exhibit this affection,itis absolutely necessary for the poet to be in a passion himsnelf, and to lay about im liEke a fighting man in
the battle of the Harlaw? There is passion and music enough ii Coleridge's Gen2eieve, but the passion is deep, penetrating, subdued, and thrilling; and the flow of the melody that lingers upon the drchaimed ear long after- the verse stops is as the murmur of waters in the mountain brook-a sound giving life, form, and beauty to pervading silence,
-We admit-the efficacy of passion in rousing, quicken.- ing. strengthening, aud even illuminating the intellectual functions; but let not Mr. Aytoun attempt to persuade us that we shall look in vain for such passion in the works of those iUustrious English poets who have so largely helped to build up tha intellectual glory of our common country; but that i; is the property-sole, entire, and indisputable_ of the Scottish ballad writers.
It is also true enough that poetical compositions should be addressed, as Mr. Aytoun insists, to thee ears of the people; but *hat does he understand when he speaks of " tae people ?" Mr. Cobden clamours sometimes for the rights of the people, but -when we closely inquire into :the meaning of his words we find that his clients conLstitute only a very limited section of the community at large. Thet
Scoteh professor falls into the sam.e mistake. Het talks of the ear of the people when he simply meau the popular ear, and he never in his life gave expression to a greater error than when he declarecl fromI his desk, that all poetry ceases to be worthy of its name the instant it ceases to recommend itself to, the. uncultivated imaaination. When Mr. Aytoua criticised the poems of Wordsworth, he justly condemned the puerilities of that great poet, and took occasion to observe that there are subjects too meau for the art. of the poet to deal with. May there not be subjects, images, and thoughts too loftv for the vulgar to comprehend ?- Is the lowest unlolding of mind competent to judge the highest ? Carry the proposition, to its furthest limit, and to what conclusiondowe arrive? If the popular ear be the -arbiter and judge of the poet's faculty, not only must the poet's wvo:k, as a -rhole, find popular favour, but every thought, word, and tone must be brought down anld meted to the popular standard -an oppressive subjugationof art, against which the voiceof civilizationunequivocally criesout. Theoffice of all art is to extend and raise the intellectual vision; the function of the poet, especially, is to exalt his listeners while they are taking hiis strains into their hearts. In the world, he spiritualizes men as religion spiritualizes them out of it. Therefore, in fact, ,poetry exerts a constant antagonism to the merely popular mind; but the conflict is sublime, for victory gained on the one side is productive of nothing but advantage and self-respect on the other.
If the whole of Mr. Aytoun's lectures are carefully read-and we hope he will publish them, for the advantage of those who did not hear them delivered-it w,ill be found that the style of reasoning indicated above pervades aU these compositions. Truth is spoken, but not truth enough; full justice is done to the species of poetry vhich it is the delight of the lecturer himself to cultivate, but sufflcient justice is not rendered to the poetic styles wvith which his genius has no established relations. :E[e is more Scottish than British-more national in his tastes than universal in his sympathies. He has a poet's soul, but he is swayed by the prejadices of a. class. If he were a Jacobite or a Covenanter, he would die for his Sovereign or his faith. Let us not wonder that he is unscrulpulous in his defence of his poetic prejudices and prepossessions. Earnestness is not too common a virtue now-a-days. In politics and in poetry the professor is passionate to a fault-but the fault is amiable, and criticism involuntarily applauds even while it deliberately condemns.

Title: Poems, by the Hon. Julian Fane.*
Full_text:
J- £, tk_ 2n;yJUlrAN FANE.*
WI' aflirme the other day, that poetry is iot extinct i lEngland. We might have said the same thin 6f stage-coach travelling. The eye and soulI of the traveller are still occasionally roused, as if from a dreatn, by the visible presence of a Jehu, not wholy givenup to tin-and-water and despair,
fdo amiar box, respectable, wholesome-looking, solemn as the last man, and pursuing'his vocation as steadily as in the days of yore when the spirit of the age was innocent of all design against him. Poetry is still among us,' but 'the precious flower is scarce. Steam, electric telegraphs. ggantic victories over time and space, and over the physical impediments of naturemighty poetic achievements themselves !-have rendered usimpatient of purilities and content with no versification but the highest, and of that commodity the supply is smaul. Here and there you have a glimmering of genius, always welcome and potent in its operations, but the general atmosphere is dark. If versHiers -would know the temper of the people in this regard, let them take their wares to the publishers of London, and ask the dealers the intrinsic value of the stuff. We will not afflict the amiable vendors by anticipating the reply. Yet have we not ceased to appreciate sterling metal. It would be a contradiction, indeed, if an age that will be remembered hereafter for its sublime discoveries and huge practical developments should be open to the reproach of insensibility to beauty in its piirest forms. If publishers shrink wit]h affright from mediocrity, they still doff the cap to excellence. Another Thomas Moore would be a welcome visitor in Patlenoster-row, and a second Byronif he be %pong uB-has a second John Murray ready-made to his hands. The writings of Wordsworth at this hour act upon the springs of thinking in all minds competent to reason and to learn, and a worthy successor of the poet of Rydal Mount would not lack the substantial rewards secured by the author of The Excursion in virtue of his poetic labours. Because we have no stomach for gooseberry wine, let it not be said that we are insensible to the flavour of nectar.
Tennyson has no ground of complaint against the age he lives in and adorns. His fame is brought home to him in the unmistakeable and pleasant form of abundant coin of the realm. Yet Tennyson has affectations of thought, feeling, and expression unworthy his genius and fatal to his influence. Sir Edward Bulwer Lytton writes long poems, and in his prefaces tells us exactly what poetry should be. We turn to the poems ,themselves, and discover what poetry is not. Browning, who has his admirers, must laugh in his sleeve at the credulity of man, while he audaciously presumes upon its existence. The author of Festus pours upon the world a flood of murky water upon which float gems that dazzle by their brilliancy and astonish by their value. We hold it a miracle that Mr. Bailey, who flings occasionally, but only too rarely, at our feet stars that merit a lIace in the sky for ever, has patience and blood sufficiently cold to indite hundreds of pages of the foggiest metre that ever distressed the prosaic mind and touched with unaffected sorrow the soul of the true lover of poetry. This writer, however, stands at the head of a class which is, we fear, daily increasing, and from whose conspiracy against common sense the worst consequences may be dreaded. Few modem versifiers, indeed, give proof of the requisite poetic susceptibility revealed at times in the otherwise dreary poem of Festus; but nearly all of them show the same daring and prevailing contempt of sobriety and truth. Because an express-train travels at the rate of sixty miles an hour, Pegasus is surely not required to fly a thousand miles a minute. If the former has annihilated our notions of space, we do not ask the latter to kick out of our brains all ideas founded upon reason. The 'Lshion of throwing dust in the eyes of those whose brains are deemed impenetrable to sober verse can never answer in the long run. It may blind and confound the weak, but the strong it will simply excite to merriment and scorn.
Mr. Fane is not to be charged with such extravagancies; and, although his verses by no means indicate powers of the highest kind, there is so much unquestionable evidence of poetic feeling in many of his compositions, and he evinces so commendable a disposition to write sensibly and truthfully upon the topics he has selected for poetic illustration, that we hold it right to give encouragement to an effort made for once in the right direction. His little volume is full of promise; the fountain of song is fresh within him, and we are convinced that care and culture only are required to give vigour and high purpose to the current. If we miss in Mr. Fane's verses the luxuriant imagery of Keats, we are not offended by the wildness and exuberance which in that gifted man degenerated into grotesque extravagance, and in the tribe of his imitators assume the character of utter nonsense. Thought is the basis of Mr. Fane's poetry, and the language in which it is poured forth is natural at all times, and occasionally strikes with a singular power of melody on the ear. We recommend the youthful author-for young his writings indicate him-to eschew publication for a while, and to submit to that self-discipline without which excellence is rarely achieved, and underwhose control genius is best able to stamp its character on the general mind. There is such a fault as spoiling a good crop by a too eager desire to reap the harvest. Mr. Fane may avoid the evil by abstinence and industry. Let him instruct his muse, and render it familiar with the triumphs of England's great masters of verse; he may keep himself aloof from the danger of servile imitation by looking upon external nature and into his own spirit with the poetic eye with which he is endowed, and which constitutes his safest guarantee for independence and originality.
Scanty is the number of our genuine poets, and we would willingly rescue one for the coming generation, which threatens to be barren of the commodity.
* Poems, by the Hon. Julian Fane. London: Pickeriag, 1852.

TENNYSON.*

Stand forth, Alfred Tennyson. Rise from thy sofa; lay aside thy cigar; come and give an account of thy misdoings againstthe majestyof poetry. Dost thou plead guilty to three volumes of musioal mysticism of which thou art indicted; or,dost thoucry "not guilty," set up a justification, and throw thyself upon the country ? Well, be it so. Thou shalt be tried by thy peers.
It must have been a marvellously green and fertile age, when it could be affirmed, " Quot homines tot sententie." Ever since then the ratio between men and opinions has been altering, population expanding, eriginal thought decreasing, until in this more than iron age five ideas wiU serve on a moderate computation for SOO men. As one consequence of this position, our first glance at a book is like our first look at a child to see whom it is most like-whence is to be traced each separate feature of its face-whence derived its port, its power, and its expression. We knew a youthful enthusiast who believed that no combination ef character could exist that was not already described by Shakepere; and therefore his first act, after being introdaced to a stranger, was to reach from his shelf those mighty volumes and hunt them through, as a botanist does his Flora to identify a new found wild flower. We do not therefore say-
"Had'st thou a father; had'st thou a mother?"
For that part of a book's physiology is too well known to need the question, but we proceed at once to its genealogy.
Tennyson does not write at all like Milton.- Agreed. His is not the style of Pope.-Conceded at once; yet he must have had progenitors, and he has already offspring. There is even a Tennysonian school, and Browning and Mies Barrett have sat at his lecture. " What say you," asks one, " to Shelley, filtered into Keats, and racked off into Tennyson2." Why, we answer, if any reader thinks to find, in the last-mentioned, a " Family Shelley," or a "KEeats for the use of Schools," they wilt be disappointed; although now andl then lineament and look do discover that both those poets have been in the family tree of Tennyson's verse.
There is one mark about Tennyson and his followers by which they distinguish themselves from the last generation of worshippers at the Castalian fount-they look forwards, not back. Like Mrs. MIalaprop, all their reminiscences are to the future. Tennyson chooses to float on and with the age. He wishes to move with the mass of his fellow-beings, whithersoever their habits and their modes of thinking may be migrating. He docs not care to fight backward through the onward crowd, or groan for the good old days. Be finds the present good, and the future likely to be better. If he is saddened, it is with such a thought as this:
"Wll tfiirty seasons render plain
" Those lonely lights that still remain, " Just breaking orer land and main 2"
He sees the glowworm begin to " pale her ineffectual fire," and his sympathies are with those who will hail the fullness of a new intellectual day. Nor in this does he utter dove-like mournings, hut he healthily girds up his loins, and adds his voice to the voice of the multitude-only, being a poet, and they but men, he strives to mingle music with the general cry.
Other oharacteristics of Tennyson are his suggestiveness; his sensuous appeal to the mind through euphonous metres and rhythm; his prodigality of images and pictures. In this latter partioular his resemblance to Shelley is easily traced. In the poetry of both, like sunlight and olouds quick drifting over aR April landscape, field and homestead, grove fountain and silver watercourse, are touched by light and left. The clay is seized for an image,- and, while half formed from the plastic mass, the model is thrown down to make way for another conception. It is the wayward hand of the minstrel upon his harp, when, wrapt from men, his thick-coming fancies fleet before his sight, almost too rapidly to "leave the whispering of a name behind.' Coleridge was king of this kind. In Kutbz Kh7an his mellifluous voice is indistinctly heard striving to express the evanescent images of an opium-dream. It is pure peetry, abstractedfrom the reasoning mind. But we cannot deny or conceal the fault in Tennyson, or Shelley either, that imperfection waits on this lavish production of ideas; nor the more objectionable vice of purposed obscurity. Here, too, Coleridge must be joined with the other malefactors while CriWabel, in sphynx-like beauty, stands accusing him for ever. Poetry may be highly suggestive and far removed from all that is matter-offact, yet not involved with dislocations of grammar or vagaries of diction. "Nor," says Sir Egerton Brydges, " is affected drea-miness and mysterious intelligibility the strain of the real muse. Inspiration speaks clearly, and is the oracle of truth."t In reading Tennyson, one is constantly startledbyhalf-formed images; hybrids, begotten by fancy upon modem facts and material objects. These produce in the reader's mind correspondent i!npressions, imperfect, ineffable, inarticulate murmurs from the legion within to the wizard's muttered incantation without. How canthe image onthewatersbe clear when the object they reflect is broken and obscure ?
If we were the embodiment of the Etching Club, we would illustrate Tlw Two Voices throughout, verse after verse. It is Tennyson's best poem; and, however great may be its native or affected indistinctness, he supports himself long on the wing, and comes homo well and truly to his ultimate destination. His course is not, indeed, straight and unwavering like the bee's at evening to her hive, but rather like the kingfisher's wayward and exstatic flights; yet the bird knows his nest, and is true to his flowery-margined stream. The poem is composed in rhyming triplets ; not the terza rinea of Dante, which Shelley has adopted in Prince Athanase, and other pieces, without much effect. It paints the obstinate battle in man's heaxt between the good and evil principles. In the hour of natural depression, at the ebb of the spirits' tide, despair approaches his victim-not novw, indeed, as the "blatant beast," roaring, rending, and treading all under foot; but, sitting like Iago at the Moor's ear, he pours in the poison of specious reasoning and pretended commiseration. Ievertheless, the tempter's first question.-
"Thou art so full of misery,
" Were it not better not to be ?"
is aver bold, and awakens an immediate answer. The reply of the bettervoice leads to a more exposed point of attack. The whole universe is to be weighed against the atom man. The innumerable orders of life are arrayed, and against them is confronted one individual of one species. The infinite past andcfuture are, as it were, by an awful paradox, to measure the duration of mortal man, that flower of the field, that cloud of the early morning. The asswers of the better voice are fainter, and choked with sobs. Still it fights on, though driven from post to post, as each pillar of philosophy to which the warrior clings gives way under the pressure of the conflict. And when the impressiveness of nature weighs upon our spirit-when we have spent a day over the microscope, and have discovered life within life, and all that we touch to be but a ptenum of vitality-then, at night's approach, changed instruments, and directed our telescope to the heavens, gazing, past the stars, on the nebulous light of other systems-when we feel ourselves standing a mere point between two infinities-then what answer can be given to the appalled soul, save the dogmatic answer of unquestioning faith; what rest is there for the spirit of man, but with child-like trust to lay his head on the pillow of infinite love and close his eyes in hope? At one moment the soul militant seizes on the Pythagorean scheme, but its invalidity is at once apparent, because it is obliged to use the opposite argument to Wordsworth's, which aflirms that
"Not in entire forgetfulness,
"And not in utter naledness,
"But trailing clouds of glory do we come ;"
and to allow that oblivion attends the "slipping through from state to state," so that all personality or identity vanishes. Even here the same yearning for the advancement of our race breaks out,-
"Were this not well, to bide mine hour,
" Though watching from a ruin'd tower, "How grows the ay of human power?"
Finally, when the reasoning of the head well nigh succumbs to the suicidal arguments of despondency, the battle is turned by the reasoning of the heart. While intellect grew faint, and could scarce make any longer a show of resistance, there remained an instinct in the bosom uncrushed and unsubdued. It was the love of life and the life of love that, like the prisoner's little flower, pressed uDward into sight between the stones of his cell, orthe spire of mos3 that saved Mungo Park from yielding himself up to death on the desert sands. The sight of human affection, calm, pure, and sunny, the interchabged love of a child and its parents, as they walked to-

t AiAtobiography.
wards the house of God oa t,he S,bba'h morn of early spring,
earvprn., - made unity so swee,b
" My frozen heart began to beat,
"Remembering its ancient heat ;"
and influence after influence rolled its waves to his breast until the better voide triumphed, and the healthy tone proper to a man ancd a Ohristian returned.
In Lockstey Hall the full energy of the poet of advancement iB in play. In the deep wounds of the affections, to escape the preEent he throws himEelf upon the future. He gives up all the past, when he flings threats andi bitter taunts at his shallow-hearted love, and prophesies her mental recession to the lowerlevelof her preferred saitor. As the troubled torrent ef a mountain stream the verse rashes on, and the flowers of fancy mingle confusedly with indignation and scorn the pang of the present and the wild prospect of co 1 g ages.
There is xeal poetry in (Enone, and sweet wild music in the La4 of Shalkot, albeit that the name of the latter calls to mind recollections of beefsteaks, rather piquant than odorous. Tennyson adds colour to form in his classical groups. In (Euona he clothes our own feelings with the garments of Greece. His manner is not to dig up dismembered ruins and set up the cold skeleton in our every-day.haunts, but to lead us by the hand suddenly into the genial and glowing climate of Ionia, where shading the eyes with our curved [palm we see through the ruddy day
"Beautiful Paris, evil.hearted Paris
"Leading a jet-blackgoat white-horn'd, white-hooved, comine
" up from reedy Simois aU alone."
When we read the Lady of Shakaet. we hear a voice beside us chanting in low tones a fitful melody. It is pure, sensuous poetry. We forbear to ask too closely what hidden meanings divell in ita misty dreaminess. We would not for the world break"our toy to discover its concealed music.
The two volumes of poems have been before the public for several years. Taken as a whole they were rather the first fruits of a new mind, the presage of a future, than that on which our author was to ibuild his reputation. It was better to askc, certainly, "Why does not Tennyson publish more6 " than "Why has he published so much ?" There was a tacit expectation among many that he would give to the world a poem worthy to follow those lyrical and detached pieces in which many beauties and much vigour were mixed with and abated by many faults and affectations. There has been time for his mind to mature itself, and his style to be pruned and chastened; time for the plan of a greatpoemto be oarefully digested and elaborated. Bat, alas! that expectation is not fulfilled in the appearance of T& Princess. The faults remain unchanged, the affected singularities of style are more numerous than before. Pity that where feeling and fancy and the poetic temperament are so strongly manifested, an author's care for his fame should be too slight to use those gifts with discaretion-to set his jewels in consistent workmanship. Must we come to the conclusion that we have seen the extent of his power, or are we to hope still for nobler efforts ? The first pages of Thk Ptincess really seem introduced tD deter readers from going farther in the book; yet, having crossed the rabicon of a dozen pages, mach beauty and vigour is to be found scattered throughout a plan very fantastic, and impaired by a style often unintelligible. The fourth and seventh cantos are the best portions of the Medley.
It is our hearty wish that Tennyson may be even new working at his forge to produce a great and permanent work. To disuse his talent is a crima in the possessor of it, and a wrong to the community.
